column2: A public reception is to be tendered to Bartholdi and to the workingmen's allegation of France in Tammany Hall at 8 P.M. next Monday.

Although there was no stake event on the card at Sheepshead Bay yesterday the racing was high class and the contests spirited. The fourth race, a handicap sweepstakes at one mile, furnished one of the prettiest finishes of the meeting. There were but five starters, and of them Ramapo, and that unreliable jade Reckon, of the Louisiana Lottery Stable, were the two most fancied in the betting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The House Committee on Ways and Means heard tariff talks to-day by representatives of several industries. N.A. Gilbert of Shelby, Ohio, speaking for a company that makes tubes for bicycles, asked for free raw material. His concern uses steel billets made in Sweden only. He said it was impossible to get such steel billets as he needed in this country.

The Vigilant, at Mr. C. Oliver Iselin's request, was remeasured by Mr. John Hyslop, and, instead of being 86.34 feet on the water line, according to the last measurement, she is 86.12. This makes a considerable difference in her racing length, which now is 96.80 feet. If she had sailed under this measurement in Thursday's race she would have allowed the Colonia only 14 seconds time over the thirty-mile course, instead of 20 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The famous old war ship Hartford, now lying at San Francisco, is to be entirely rebuilt. Secretary Herbert has authorized the use of $456,244 for this purpose. This afternoon the Secretary approved recommendations of the Board of Construction that the amount named, previously placed at his disposal by Congress, be expended in reconstructing the old ship, and orders directing that work begin at once were immediately sent to San Francisco.

The following curious side light upon missionary enterprise is supplied to me from the Punjab: "I notice in your paper a reference to the cost of converting Jews. It reminds me of the cost of converting the heathen in these parts. The missionaries at Kangra have been at work since 1846, and have converted in that time one adult.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Thomas James of Chicago was almost instantly killed in a runaway accident at Montclair this morning. In the same accident Mrs. Florence West was very seriously injured and her ten-year-old daughter Marjorie, slightly hurt.

Some of our contemporaries take exception to the cup defenders upon the ground that they are "racing machines." Of course they are racing machines, and everything else is sacrificed to speed. But it is no more an objection to a racing yacht that she is a racing machine than it is an objection to a thoroughbred horse that he is a racing machine.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Yale athletic Captains feel very sore just at present at the way three of the most promising athletes who were to enter Yale this Fall have been decoyed away. For two years Charles Millard, Francis Murphy, and William Donovan of Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., have been regarded as billed for Yale as soon as they finished their preparatory course.

Dun's Review to-morrow will say: "Improvement has extended from the banks to the mills. The condition of great Industries has distinctly mended, though still seriously depressed. More important by far than stay rise in stocks is the fact that more works have resumed during the past week than have stopped operation, so that the producing force of the country, after months of constant decline, has begun to increase.
On the 1st of September, commenting on the manner in which a receiver was appointed for the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, we remarked:

Mrs. Margaret Anderson, a young woman who lives at 35 cottage Place, went yesterday to Jefferson Market Police Court with a heavy black veil over her face. When she stood before Justice Koch she lifted the veil and disclosed two ugly slashes, one on each cheek. They had been inflicted by ber worthless husband and will disfigure her for life.

A peculiar phase of this season of cup defenders has been the course followed by Gen. Paine. The General formerly owned his boats, but it transpires that since his declaration of 1889 about the laws of nature he has taken great pains to have his creations stand in the name of "my son John."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A meeting of the Committee on the Election of President and Vice President and Representatives in Congress has been called for to-morrow by Chairman Fitch. A number of bills were introduced last Wednesday and referred to this committee, providing for the repeal of the Federal election laws.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- O.B. Coddington, a farmer living three miles east of the village of Guilford, is under arrest on a charge of attempting to kidnap the ten-year-old son of A.R. Brown and hold him for ransom.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- The market opened heavy, but was firm the remainder of the day. Toward the close it became buoyant and closed strong. Atchison gained 1 3/8 and New-York and NewEngland 2. The copper stocks were a feature, being active and strong. Dominion Coal was also strong and sold up to 16.

On application of Lawyers Friend and House the United States Circuit Court of the Southern District of New-York has issued a writ of habeas corpus and certiorari in behalf of John Gilmore, formerly an inmate of the Elmira Reformatory and now a prisoner in the Tombs. The writ is addressed to Warden Fallon, as well as to the managers of the reformatory, and is returnable Sept. 20.
GLOUCESTER, N.J., Sept. 8 -- While training this morning at the race track Jockey Houben's horse stopped suddenly, throwing him off. He was instantly killed. He was seventeen years old.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 8. -- The rear guard of the Grand Army veterans is departing to-night; the decorations are beginning to come down, and by to-morrow the national encampment of 1893 will be but a memory.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- When F.J. Kaldenberg Co., the pipe manufacturers, made an assignment of their business in New-York, William P. Fiero was appointed referee to report as to the advisability of allowing a voluntary liquidation of the affairs of the company.

The question of the criminal liability of the officers and Directors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, in the light of the startling disclosures in The New-York Times, was discussed yesterday with interest by the depositors of that institution.
Francis J. Palmer, a civil engineer and in ventor, committed suicide some time on Thursday by inhaling gas in a room at Smith McNell's Hotel, 199 Washington Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Bureau of Statistics. Treasury Department, in the monthly statement for July last, just issued, makes a long and technical explanation of the changes in amounts made necessary by the adoption of the rule in computing the values of imports and exports of merchandise to take into consideration the depreciation of money in the countries where the imports originated.

The Coney Island Jockey Club took yesterday the last of the necessary steps to tree itself of entangling alliances with the now practically defunot Board of Control. At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the club the following preamble and resolution, that are self-explanatory, were adopted:

That was a splendid tribute to Surrogate RASTUS S. RANSOM which we published yesterday morning. Leaders of the bar and men prominent in public office and in all the activities of the city, citizens whom every New-Yorker knows and whose opinions command wide respect, united in words of praise and admiration for the Surrogate and in expressing the belief that he should by all means be renominated.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Asa Lemlein of the wholesale tobacco and clear firm of A. Lemlein Co., 2,327 Third Avenue, New-York, was arrested this morning on a charge of larceny, preferred by Max Lourin of this city.

NOANK, Conn., Sept 8 -- The crew of the steamer Annie L. Wilcox report that while fishing in Long Island Sound Wednesday they saw a school of fish and put off in their boats to set their seine. They had two-thirds of the seine out, they say, when the steamer Vestor of Greenport came along and Capt. Littlefield with his boats tried to claim the fish.
Money on call loaned at from 3 @ 3 1/2 cent The last loan was made at 3 cent.7

RYDE, Isle of Wight, Sept. 8 -- The third race between the Britannia and the Navahoe for the International Gold Cup was to have been sailed to-day over a fifty-mile course. When the start was to be made the Navahoe was beyond the line. She was called back, and in turning split her mainsail. The race was then abandoned. It will probably be sailed to-morrow.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The House of Lords this evening rejected the Home Rule bill by a vote of 419 to 41.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The President has appointed ex-Congressman Albert S. Willis of Kentucky to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to the Hawaiian Islands, and Allis Mills of Virginia to be Consul General at Honolulu.

The management of the United Press announces in the following circular that it has decided to sever all its relations with the Associated Press, but that it will be glad to furnish all Associated Press papers with its news service:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 8 -- The Hon. C.H. Tupper, who was yesterday knighted in recognition of his services in connection with the Bering Sea arbitration, said to-day that the British side in the arbitration had to fight hard to secure permission of pelagic sealing, and that they did well to get the regulations they did.

The large Church of the Paulist Fathers at Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue was filled to overflowing yesterday morning during the ordination of three former deacons of the Paulist community and ceremony of making a former Dublin barrister a sub-deacon.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept 8. -- Dairyman William Barrett of Maspeth, who shot and killed ten-year-old John Egan at Blissville Monday afternoon, was this afternoon held without bail for the Grand Jury, the Coroner's jury having found Barrett was responsible for the boy's death.

In order to intensify the rivalry at the World's Fair sports to be held in Chicago, The New-York Times has offered a handsome medal, to be given to the athlete making the best individual performance. It is one of the prettiest medals ever manufactured by Robert Stoll, and the competitor who is lucky enough to win it will have a token that he can point to with pride.

Ernest Fownes, the celebrated English professional coachman, was recently in New-York to investigate the field for an establishment so frequent in large foreign cities, where a skilled driver who loves to handle a "four " and cannot afford to keep up an establishment can secure a proper outfit. His idea is to keep on hand at all times a number of firstclass teams for four-in-hand or tandem driving.

Prof. Sargent of the Harvard Gymnasium sore that the bicycle stoop is a menace to health. It should be added that the front stoop on these chill evenings -- but young people do net take colds easily. -- Chicago Tribune.

-- The consecration of Bishop Lawrence, successor of Bishop Phillips Brooks of Massachusetts, is to take place at Trinity Church. Boston, on Thnrsday, Oct 5. The Right Rev. Dr. John Williams of Connecticut, the presiding Bishop, will be the consecrator, assisted by other Bishops, of whom there are about seventy-five.

Returning confidence in business circles now waits only upon the final action of the Senate in repealing the silver purchasing act. The panicky feeling which brought so much trouble and loss to the business interests of the country within the past two month has apparently worn itself out, and there is promise of a reawakening of commercial activity as soon as the silver question is definitely settled.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Mrs. Lizzie Halliday, the woman charged with the murder of her Husband and the MaQuillan women, was brought to the Sullivan County Jail to-day at 3 o'clock by Constable Scott, who has had her in charge since the arrest. The trip to Monticello from Burlingham was made across the country in a wagon, a distance of twenty-five miles.

Renewed appeal in behalf of the suffering inhabitants of the sea islands is made by George L. Dale, J.J. Dale, and D.C. Wilson. Gifts of clothing and other useful articles should be sent, securely boxed, to the Ocean Steamship Company, foot of Canal Street, marked J.J. Dale Co., Beaufort, S.C. Merchants sending goods are asked to send to J.J. Dale Co., care of S. Gukenheimer Sons, Savannah. Ga.

METZ, Sept. 8. -- To-day's military operations consisted in a great battle along the line of the stream of the French Nied. The grand event of the day was a brilliant charge led by the Emperor, under the command of Gen. Count you Haeseler, down a steep slope from Coligny and up the opposite hill toward Mont against the Bavarian division.

Frank Ellison, under indictment for assault in the first degree, second offense, for having made a brutal assault upon Broker William H. Henriques on June 5, was taken to the Court of General Sessions yesterday that a day might be fixed for the trial.

-- Only one game of the championship series of the Metropolitan District Cricket League will be played in this vicinity to-day, the Staten Island Cricket Club meeting the Patersons at Livingston for their return match. The St. George's second eleven are scheduled to play a league game with the Brooklyn second at Prospect Park, but they have forfeited the match, and instead will play a mixed eleven against the Brooklyns.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 8 -- The State Fair at Waverly closed to-day. President Gaddis estimates the total attendance during the week at 75,000 persons. The average rate of admission was 30 cents. The receipts from admissions were $23,000. From various other sources the managers received $14,000. The expenses of the fair, including money spent in prizes and cash awards, will be in the neighborhood of $28,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Early in the session to-day there was a fair trade in wheat, but after the first half hour the market was quiet. No very important changes occurred, although the market ruled steadier. The opening was about 1 8c higher than yesterday's closing, and during the session advanced 3 8c or so more, fluctuating within a 5 8c range, and closed about 3 8@1 8c higher than yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The race for the Doncaster Cup to-day was won by Lord Cardegan's Prisoner. Col. North's Simonian was second, and Mr. Jersey's Lady Roseberry third. The cup is of 600 sovereigns, added to a sweepstakes of 100 sovereigns each.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 8 -- The three St. Clair County Judges who have just returned to the custody of the Federal court here may raise a new point in the celebrated bond case. It is said that they will all tender their resignations and that Gov. Stone will accept them. In that event it is believed Judge Philips will refuse to liberate them.

WATERVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The hop season in Central New-York, as far as the picking and harvesting are concerned, is drawing to a close. The yield this year is unusually large and fine in quality. If the opening prices for the new hops were higher the growers would be better satisfied.

CHICAGO, Sept 8. -- Richard M. Hooley, the veteran theatrical manager, died here to-day. He was one of Chicago's earliest theatrical managers, and his career threads the history of local management. His birthplace was Ballina, in County Mayo, Ireland, where he was born April 13, 1822. He was carefully educated in the schools of Manchester, England, his father being a prosperous merchant.

The Cunarder Campania, which, sailed from this port last Saturday, has, according to a cable dispatch, succeeded in cutting 2 hours and 47 minutes from her own eastward record of 5 days 17 hours and 42 minutes. She cleared the Sandy Hook bar at 12:14 P.M. Sept. 2 and reached Queenstown at 8:06 yesterday morning.

-- The St. Louis Browns and the Brooklyns will meet at eastern Park this afternoon. Before and after the game there will be bicycle races under the auspices of the National Cycling Association. Wheeler, Schotfield, Berlo, Dorntge, Hutchin, Rich, and other last men will compete. Rich is going to ride a new machine that weighs only sixteen pounds.

The Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs will hold a big race meet on Saturday next at Waverly, N.J. The association is made up of deligates from various wheeling clubs to this city and vicinity. There are twenty-five clubs represented at present.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept 8. -- There was a rather startling robbery on the Grand Trunk express train last night between Detroit and Suspension Bridge. The robbers were not of the mask-and-revolver variety of highwaymen, but were sleek, sly fellows who purloined many valuable articles while the passengers were asleep in their berths.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The steadily-increasing attendance of visitors to the fair, and the prospect that the present average will be sustained until the end, has given the stockholders reason to expect that some of their money will come back to them.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I note that recent remarks of mine regarding relief funds for the unemployed have been severely criticised and the position of the Charity Organization Society quite misunderstood, and I beg your leave to correct and explain.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- In relation to the Baum and Sherpinski cases. Superintendent S.C. Wrightington of the Massachusetts Board of Lunacy and Charity has written as follows to Superintendent Blake of the New-York Department of Charities and Correction:

They have seen a sea serpent in the Upper Ottawa. Mrs. John Lahey, the wife of a respected farmer who lives near the head of Allumette Island and about a mile from the Calbute Locks, is authority for the following story. It is customary for the farmers' wives living near the river to go down to the shore to do their washing.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Panic has seized on the mine owners of Yorkshire. The striking miners have broken away from all control. They are pillaging find burning in all directions, and the authorities seem helpless.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Financially the Grand Circuit meeting at Point Breeze course was a decided failure, and the Philadelphia Driving Association is in a quandary to know the proper time to draw the great stars of the turf to its city. In 1898 the association led off in the meetings, and failed to draw the best horses on account of a late season and the horses not being fully prepared.

In the now-celebrated suit of Dr. Jaeger's Sanitary Woolen System Company against Le Boutillier Brothers, respecting the right to use the term "Jaeger" in connection with the manufacture and sale of a certain line of goods, the Jaeger Company has, by no means, been worsted, as the first reports of Judge Gildersleeve's decision might seem to have indicated.

GARRISONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- All day everything has been quiet about the country home of the late ex-Secretary of State Hamilton Fish. During the morning hours a few of the neighbors called at the house to take a look at the face of the dead statesman. Among the callers later in the day were the venerable Mr. Osborn, Col. Arden, and Samuel Sloan.
At a special meeting of the State Society of the Cincinnati held yesterday afternoon at Delmonico's, the following minute offered by Secretary Schuyler was adopted:

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- All the large rubber boot and shoe factories will start up on Monday, Sept. 11, after the usual Summer vacation. They are crowded with orders, which will necessitate their running for the rest of the season to their full capacity. This will give employment to about 20,000 hands.

WASHINGTON, Sept 8 -- Secretary Gresham decided, this morning not to wait longer for official notification that a rebelion had broken out in Brazil, and he accordingly sent a cable message to Minister Thompson, who is supposed to have reached Rio de Janeiro by this time, instructing him to concur in a general diplomatic remonstrance against the burdensome interference with the foreign commerce of Brazil through the suspension of telegraphic communication.

Brutal beating and inhuman lack of care is the treatment which Dr. George H. Elliott of 228 West Eleventh Street says an idiotic child less than five years old received in the children's ward on Randall's Island during a month's detention there.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Sept. 8 -- P.M. Another sharp advance was the feature of Stock Exchange trading to-day. It crime after noon, and the strength continuing to the close left shares generally at the best prices of the day. At the opening the market was weak, and there was a rush to sell.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- The advance in the Traction stocks continued from the opening to the close. Metropolitan sold up to 96's and Philadelphia to 86. Large amounts of Baltimore Traction are changing hands at 19, and New-Jersey Consolidated Traction 5s took a sharp break of 10 points, selling at 70, as against 80 on Wednesday.

Lillian Russell Has finally determined to knock off the remnant of the matrimonial chain which still binds her to "Teddy" Solomon. For seven years she has been practically free from all allegiance to him, having separated from him in September, 1886, but in the eyes of the law she is still his wife, and for reasons of her own Miss Russell now wants to be rid of even this relationship.

Business was brisk in the City Hall and most of the municipal departments yesterday. The Mayor's return from his vacation has set things booming. The city officials have shaken off Summer lethargy and settled down to business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Faulkner compromise broached to-day in the Senate, which proposes the coinage of silver dollars at the rate of $3,000,000 a month until the aggregate coinage shall be $800,000,000, is not a part of the Administration programme in the Senate, and it will not at all disturb the supporters of unconditional repeal.
Ex-Congressman Henry G. Burleigh of Whitehall, Washington County, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, and as usual he had something to say about Republican State politics.

-- The Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey will hold a ten-mile road race for the championship of the association over the Elizabeth-Cranford course this afternoon at 4 P.M. The teams will consist of four men each, and the following clubs will be represented: Elizabeth Wheelmen, Elizabeth Athletic Club Cyclers, Atalanta Wheelmen, and Hudson County Wheelmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The final meeting of the Pan-American Medical Congress was held this morning. The various recommendations by the several sections were generally adopted by the Executive Committee. The most important exception was as to the one advising a temporary suspension of immigration from European countries in which cholera is now prevalent.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 8 -- It is a battle between giants now. No sooner bad the details of the Mesaba Range consolidation between the Duluth and New-York interests been telegraphed over the country than the leading officials of the Minnesota Iron Company hied themselves hither. They are to arrive in Duuth to-morrow and proceed by special train direct to the mines at Tower over the Duluth and Iron Range Road.

Since the attack upon the New-York banks, which was made in the United States Senate by Paffer of Kansas and his New-York ally, David B. Hill, a number of important financial institutions in the West have passed resolutions of approval of the judicious and patriotic course pursued by our banks.

CHICAGO, Sept 9. -- Death took away two prominent theatrical men this week. Thursday Anson Temple, lessee and manager of the Schiller Theatre, was killed in a railroad wreck near this city, and Friday Richard M. Hooley, proprietor of Hooley's Theatre, died after a short illness. Nothing has yet been decided about the disposition of the theatres they had charge of.

More perfect weather for aquatic sports could not be desired than that which favored the Union Boat Club for its fourteenth annual regatta on the Harlem River yesterday. At 2 o'clock, when the first race was called, the tide was just on the turn, and from that time the boats had the advantage of the young flood.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 9. -- Henry C. Payne, who suddenly became ill on a St. Paul Railroad train while on his way home from Chicago Thursday afternoon, will be out in a day or two.

Anais Segalas. The death is announced in Paris of Anais Segalas, poet, novelist, playwright, and celebrated in the jonrnal for which Willis and Poe wrote as the dramatic and literary reviewer of The Paris Corsaire in its best years.

The members of the New-York Cycle Dealers' Association celebrated their recent organization by a race meet at title Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon, which was the most novel cycling event of the season. The programme included races for firemen, letter carriers, policemen, militiamen, actors, and for the dealers themselves.
President E.T. Jeffery's report of The operations of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad for the year ended June 30 last has just been issued in complete form, It is dated Aug. 26. Mr. Jeffery says:

I notice that the sash or girdle called a "cummerbund," derived from the Persian "kamarband," or "loin band," has become immensely popular in England, the waistcoat being discarded in order to display this picturesque belt. The proper hue for a cummerbund is crimson, but I have seen, some very pretty samples of the article at Brighton vended at the certainly not afflictive price of five and sixpence.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept 9. -- Capt. Frank A. Hinkey and Manager E.O. Holler of the Tale football eleven were in town this morning making final preparetions for the formal opening of the Yale football season at Travers Island next Monday morning. Both were busy during their entire stay with, a host of arrangements and left the city this noon for New-York, where they will receive the candidates for the team as they report for practice to-morrow.

On Thursday, as a drove of bullocks numbering about 140 were being driven from the Canadian shed to the Woodside lairage, at Birkenhead, a singular accident happened. On the river side of the Alfred Dock there is a narrow undulating bridge, recently placed there by the Mersey Docks and Harbor Board for the purpose of conveniently transferring cattle to the lairages.

-- Among the ladies who participated in the reunion of the Woman's Relief Corps at the gathering of the Grand Army of the Republic in Indianapolis last week was a delegation of five from Salem, Mass., who styled themselves "Salem Witches." They wore a white satin badge bearing gold lettering and the figure of a witch in red, riding a broom.

Two Chinese immigrants were landed from the steamer Saratoga of the Ward Line yesterday in defiance of the authority of the Collector of this port. Their names are Ge Ah Tek and Yung Ki, and they arrived here from Havana last Monday. They pretended that they were students, but Chinese Inspector Seharf did not believe their statements and detained them on board the steamer.
The following letter describing the work of the cyclone in the South has been received by George L. Dale from William C. Thomas, with J.J. Dale Co.:

These are the days when at the various country resorts an air of change and restlessness Is evident. The touch of frost in the morning and evening air, the opening of the city schools now close at hand, and, more than these, the renewed vigor which the long Summer outing has developed, make the loiterer think of the city home and city work, and plan for an early "departure.

The new French cruiser Sachet was launched at Toulon, France, Aug. 10. The Suchet has a displacement of 3,429 tons. Her principal dimensions are: Length, 311 feet 8 Inches; beam, 40 feet, and mean draught, 17 feet 6 Inches. She is provided with engines designed to develop 9,000 horse power on forced draught.

Viewing a yacht race from the decks of an excursion steamer is ordinarily about as unsatisfactory as most of the eights which excuraionista go out to see and don't. Bat it was different with those members of the New-York Yacht Club who east their fortunes on board their specially-chartered steamer Taurus yesterday. The magnificent distances which excursionists usually have to complain of were dispensed with, and all details of the race.

The sales of real estate at auction announced for the present week are all in legal proceedings and will be held in the Trinity Building Salesroom. Next week will begin the regular sales of property voluntarily put on the market. Details of all sales are subjoined:

-- The Rev. Evan Rees of Cardiff, South Wales, won the prize offered for the best poem at the assembly of Welsh singers in Chicago on Thursday. The great event of the day was the "chairing of the bard," a historic ceremony inherited from the ancient Cambrians, which, it is said, had never previously been performed outside of Great Britain.

SAUGATUCK, Conn., Sept. 9. -- Dr. Keyes of New-York, father-in-law or Vice Commodore P. G. Sanford of the Atlantic Yacht Club, whose Summer home is here, is an expert fisherman. Every Summer he has done good work with hook and line, out his piscatorial achievements in that way are of slight value compared with what he has accomplished with a seine.

Dr. Joseph Senner, Commissioner, and Col. Herman Stump, Superintendent, of Immigration, returned yesterday from Canada. They had been conferring with the Canadian authorities regarding the immigrants, many of them undesirable, who are coming into this country after having been landed, in Canadian seaports. The conference was held In Quebec, and there were present Deputy Minister of the Interior Alexander McKim Burgess. Dr. Senner, Col. Stump, and the representatives of the railroad and steamship lines.

The Society of the Cincinnati, of which Hamilton Fish had been President General since 1854, has issued general orders officially announcing his death, and requesting members to wear the usual badge of mourning.

It is unfortunate that musical composers are for some strange reason not deemed as worthy of the attentions of the Atlantic cable as small-fry politicians or ladies who forget their domestic obligations. About the middle of last month there died in Milan, after a brief illness, a composer whose untimely end was a distinct loss to Italian music.

The Staten Island Cricket Club expected to have an easy victory over the Paterson team yesterday at Liviningston, but the visitors from New-Jersey surprised everybody by the Bland they made, and the match finally ended in a draw.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- A cable message has been received at the State Department from Mr. Thomas L. Thompson, United States Minister to Brazil, stating that there is danger of the bombardment of Bio by the revolutionary fleet, and in view of that fact martial law has been declared.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Public dissatisfaction with recent acts of the Street and Water Commissioners culminated to-day in legal proceedings before Judge Lippencott. Two writs of certiorari were asked for. Allan L. McDermott, Clerk of the Chancery Court, asked the court to review the proceedings in record to asphalt pavement.

The recent economical performance of the United States cruiser Philadelphia in the passage from Rio de Janeiro to Callao, 5,000 miles, on one coal supply is attributed in well-posted naval circles to the peculiar excellence of design of the Philadelphia's engines. The designs of the Baltimore and Philadelphia emanated originally from British sources.

The rejection of Mr. Gladstone's Home Rule bill by the House of Lords, while it created little surprise in this city because of the well-known hostility of the Peers to all measures of reform in the interests of the people, was the general topic of conversation yesterday among Irish-Americans.

Rapid-transit schemes constitute a fruitful source of Wall-Street gossip. No less than a dozen syndicates -- each with many millions of capital -- have been organized within the past two or three years for the purpose of giving this city an adequate system of rapid transit. In no case have these syndicates been able to stand the test of investigation.

There is no longer room for doubt that a revival of industrial activity has set in and that the process of restoration of trade and commerce is well under way. The week under review has brought a succession of favorable developments, and they hare resulted in considerable accession to the growing feeling of confidence in the future which has developed since the House passed the silver repeal messure a fortnight ago.

The controversy at Havana Ranch, which has caused the dispatch of troops thither from Fort Ringgold, involves a curious question of jurisdiction. The 3,000 sheep owned by a citizen of Texas and seized by the Mexican customs officers were on land whose exact status is a matter of dispute.

Copyrighted, 1893, by The New-York Times. LONDON, Sept. 9. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent] -- Gilbert and Sullivan began this week directing rehearsals of their new comic opera at the Savoy. Interest in this event, which gives a welcome new lease of life to a phase of human enjoyment which had seemed dead and buried, has been much damped, however, by the superior opera bouffe attractions at Westminster.

Until the vigilant, Jubilee, Pilgrim, sad Colonia meet on even terms in a good steady breeze of wind, the America's Cup Committee of the New-York Yacht Club Will have nothing upon which to boas the choice of a cup defender except mere theory, or foots which are calculated to influence the committee to ignore the Valkyrie's well known heavy weather qualities.

Residents along Greene and Gates Avenues and Madison and Rutledge Streets, Brooklyn, were startled yesterday by reading in a morning newspaper that the Brooklyn City Railroad Company had decided to steal a march on the property owners by forcing the construction of trolley lines along those residential streets in spite of the opposition of the Aldermen and the protests of the residents.

The recollections of the theatrical week are all agreeable. The three new plays -- for "Fanny," already defunct, does not count -- are all worth remembering, and of one of them, Mr. Thomas's "In Mizzoura," the remembrance is particularly enjoyable, for there are many things in this play one appreciates more highly as they come to mind afterward than he does under the direct influence of the performance.

It was Vigilant weather yesterday, and eventually it turned out to be the Vigtlant'a race. Vigilant weather is light airs and smooth aras. This does not mean that the Tobin bronze boat does not like a stiff blow with a tumbling sea, she having proved in the first trial race that she can do well in a good rousing topmast breeze, and with the waves twisting and twirling every way.

In Helen Watterson's thoughtful and conservative paper in the current Forum on "Women's Excitement Over Woman,' " she says some words that should he heeded by many of the so-called progressive women of the day; and is there, by the way, a more ironical or pathetic phrase than this, which is so common that it writes Itself -- " the progressive woman " ?
After a close and interesting came the Brooklyns won from the St. Louis Browns at Eastern Park yesterday. The hitting on both sides was weak, but the errors of the visitors were the more damaging.

Harry Wheeler did not take part in the National Cycling Association races at Eastern Part yesterday, and in consequence the lesser lights carried off the prizes. There were 5,500 persons present. In the open mile race Carl Hess defeated Brolo, Rich, Sohofield, Price, and other speedy men. The wiry German was in good form, and could have won the race in much faster time if pushed.

We have been of the opinion from the beginning of our recent business troubles that they could not fairly be described as commercial or industrial chiefly, but almost wholly as financial. Their essential characteristic was a contraction of credit, due in the first instance to apprehension as to the maintenance of gold payments by the United States.

Among the interesting factors which go to make the increase of speed in the latest yachts is ability to lie close to the wind. A vessel beating to windward has to cover a great deal of ground in her diagonal course. It is obvious that this distance will be materially increased by inability to lie close to the wind and maintain her speed, or, in nautical parlance, to "point high."

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The season of field sports on Woodlawn Oval under the auspices of the Saratoga Athletic Club was concluded this afternoon. The weather was fine. The sports were witnessed by about 500 persons. The starter and judge of walking was James Robinson, who is also the official handicapper of the club. Mr. Cummings of the Acorn Athletic Club was the referee.

The new United States boarding steamer Hudson, built by the Revenue Marine Service for duty at the port of New-York, is believed to be the best engined craft of her type in New-York Harbor. Her engines were designed by Commodore George W. Melville, Chief or the Burean of Steam Engineering of the Navy Department. They are duplicates or the engines of the new naval practice cruiser Bancroft.
R.H MACY SIXTH AV., 13TH TO 14TH ST. Millinery. (SECOND FLOOR, MAIN BUILDING.) BEAUTIFUL EFFECTS IN TRIMMED NOVOWN MANUFACTURE. GRAND ASSORTMENT OF ADVANCE FALL FASHIONS IN HATS, BONNETS, AND TOQUES.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The President sent to the Senate to-day the following nominations:

LENOX, Mass., Sept 9. -- This has been really the first social week of the Autumn season. There have been a score of dinners, many luncheons, small and large dancing parties, a baseball frame by the young people, a dance and candy pull at Mahkeenac Lake, and other entertainments which the younger sat heartily enjoy.

The latest collision between foreign missionaries and the Chinese populace may serve as a typical example of these regretable incidents. Two inexperienced men, beginning to learn the Chinese language, find themselves planted in a hostile district, acquire land and erect buildings in a style notoriously offensive to the native people, and, it is fair to assume, do other things in keeping therewith.

"Men do not put new wine into old bottles," said Mr. C.F. Cross to a representative of The Westminster Gazette, "nor do they put good pianofortes into bad cases. But they write and print their best things on rubbish. By a curious coincidence I have to-day been examining the paper of some books in the Patent Office Library three centuries old.

TOMKINS COVE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- A handsome new sidewheel steamboat of the New-York and Monmouth Steamboat Company was launched at Rodermond's shipyard here this morning. Miss Mamic E. Dick, daughter of G.H. Dick of New-York City, the President of the company, broke a bottle of champagne over the bow and christened the boat Little Silver, in honor of one of her stopping places on the Shrewsbury River.

The agents of the Cunard Line and the officers of the newest of ocean greybounds were highly jubilant yesterday over the remarkable and record-breaking achievement of the steamship Lucania upon her maiden voyage. Her corrected time for the westward passage is 5 days 15 hours and 37 minutes, which is 1 hour and 13 minutes within the fastest record, now held by the Paris.

There has always been more or less curiosity expressed as to why so many wealthy young men, and those with wealth in view, joined the National Guard. Few there are who really Join it because they want the manual training which it brings, or who are in love with the attendant hardships, at which the most enthusiastic are wont frequently to declaim in language more forcible, than elegant.

The World's Fair awards have sounded the death knell of medals for objects of the fine arts. Not because in the knell there was neither the golden nor the silvery note; not because France, Belgium, and Norway withdrew their exhibits from competition, in disgust at the absence of medals of silver and gold, but because the giving of medals is recognized as a farce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Although dark and threatening clouds enveloped the city, thousands of people lined the banks and in gayly-bedecked craft crossed the Potomao to-day to witness the annual Potomac River Regatta. While the rain did not fall, the weather was quite chilly, and, although a brisk breeze swept across the course, the water was smooth, and it did not in any way interfere with the oarsmen.

The new United States revenue steamer Windom is now on the slips of the Iowa Iron Works, Dubuque, Iowa. Special interest attaches to the construction of the Windom as tending to demonstrate the ability of Western establishments on the Mississippi River to engage in Government work.

About 100 of Boston's musical people gathered in the library of the Harvard Musical Society, in West Cedar Street, that City, on Friday noon, to hold a meeting in memory of the late John S. Dwight. The Transcript says it was not at all like a funeral, but more like the gathering of friends to bid their old comrade godspeed on his long journey into new lands.

Bennett's Casino, the largest music hall in Brooklyn, was destroyed by a fire which was discovered at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, involving a loss of $100,000. Four persons were injured, and five women, employed in the place, had to be carried down on ladders by the firemen.

When Cashier Vail of Brooklyn returned from his Saratoga outing, and came face to face with President Keeney, it was generally felt by the depositors in the Commercial Bank that something ought to happen. People familiar with public affairs in Brooklyn, are, it is true, rather apt to look up a sensitiveness as one of the lost faculties there.

CHICAGO, sept. 9. -- Only a moderate amount of business was transacted in wheat to-day, and the feeling developed was rather strong. The principal feature was the strength to the low grades. The opening on December was about 1/4 c higher than yesterday's closing, advanced, 1/8 c more and then receded 3/8 c, rallied 3/8 a 3/4 c receded 3/8 c, held steady and the closing was about 1/2 c higher than yesterday.

The National Academy of Design will open its classes in better shape this year, for it has imported a new collection of casts and has secured additional room outside of the Academy building. The classes open on Oct. 2, and continue until May 12. Edgar M. Ward will have charge of the classes, and the School Committee is composed of George W. Maynard, John Rogers, and Edwin H. Blashfield.
The weekly bank statement, issued to-day, shows on increase in reserve at $4,533,900. The banks are now $2,966,375 above legal requirements.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Mme. Flavia Van Den Hende save another delightful violoncello recital at one of the cottages Monday morning, assisted by Mr. Griffith. The entertainment was under the patronage of Mrs. T. Gordon Hunt, Mrs. Thomas C. Kerr, Mrs. M.B. Craig, Mrs. J.H. Shults, Jr., Mrs. T. Willis James, Mrs. James Moir, Mrs. L.C. Field, Mme. Fabbricotti, Miss Krabs, and Mrs. Harry Kingsley.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 9. -- The Jury In the Westinghouse conspiracy case disagreed, and the defendants, Morris W. Mead, William J. Clark, and Milton H. Hamilton, will have another trial.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Clearings to-day were $10,896,025. Money easy at 7. P cent. New-York exchange quiet at 60c premium. Sterling exchange slow and dull, with a narrow market. Posted rates, 60 days, 483 1/2; demand, 487.

The performance of the United States monitor Nantucket off Cape Hatteras in the hurricane of Sunday, Aug. 27, has in the opinion of experts, brought out important stability features which have all along been claimed by the advocates of the monitor type of craft. It is contended that had the Nantucket been perfectly tight about the decks she would Have been a safer craft in the hurricane than even the stanch corvette Kearsavge.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- To the southwest of the inhabited part of Albany and less than two minutes' walk from Washington Park stand the tasteful new buildings of the Dudley Observatory. The observatory fronts on Lake Avenue, from which the ground rises in a gentle slope toward the buildings, which are situated about eighty yards back from the street.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept 9. -- Thera is considerable speculation at present as to what will become of the parochial school in connection with the Catholic Churah of Our Lady of Grace. Last Sunday the Rev. Patrick Corrigan, pastor of the church, announced that the school would not be opened immediately, and in the meantime he was willing the children in the parish should attend the public schools, if their parents so desired.

The Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company ran fewer trains than usual during last month. It means, nevertheless, to curtail its train service still more. The midsummer schedule, which went into effect Aug. 1. reduced the number of trains on the west side roads by ten. Although the officials will make no statement on the subject, it is a well-known fact that several trains were takes off earlier in the season.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 9. -- Lient. Commander C.H. West, United States Navy, acting as assistant to the Lighthouse Inspector at this district, will take command of the lighthouse tender Cactus upon his arrival here from New-York to-morrow, and locate the buoys marking the course in Long Island Sound over which the new Government cruiser Castine will be tested.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- The market has teen strong again for the Traction stoots, Metropolitan rising to 93 3/4 Philadelphia was steady at 86. It is rumored that the Metropolitan Company is likely to begin paying dividends again in January. Baltimore Traction advanced to 19 1/2 and People's to 14 1/2 Reading securities were all buoyant, specially the stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Considerable was said to-day before the House Ways and Means Committee concerning the duty on flax. A.B. Turner of Paterson, N.J., representing the Barbour Brothers' Flax-Spinning Company, said that, though he would prefer the tariff to be undisturbed, reasonable revisions would effect quite a reduction from existing rates.

New-York's well-paid and well-fed Giants finished their series of home games yesterday in a blaze of glory, so to speak. After losing twice to the Cincinnati Reds, they arose in their might and evened up matters by thrashing the players from the Porkopolis twice in one afternoon, a feat the fear Glants were not guilty of before this season.

HELENA, Mon., Sept. 9. -- In the brief Period that Montana has been dignified by Stehood its political affairs have caused little agitation in the ranks of both the great political parties and in the United States Senate. The Fall election of 1890 suited in the sauabble over "Precinct and the organization of two Legislatures, and the election of two sets of "United States Senators.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 9 -- The Cassell Publishing Company of New-York, which was recently forced to suspend, owing to the defalcation of a trusted employe, has been reorganized. The company filed articles of incorporation to-day with the County Clerk.

ELIZABETH, Sept. 9. -- The ten-mile team race of the associated cycling clubs of New-Jersey took place this afternoon over the Elizabeth-Cranford course in the presence of nearly 2,000 spectators. Four clubs entered teams of four men each. The competing clubs ware the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark, the Hudson County Wheelmen, the Elizabeth Wheelmen, and the Elizabeth Athletic Club Cyclers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- While the harness racing at Washington Park to-day was full of interest to the 6,000 spectators, it did not meet the expectations of horsemen in point of quality. The 2:20 trotting race, in which a fast contest had been looked forward to, with Brignoll Wilkes, 2:14 1/2, and Ellard 2:12 3/4, as the contending horses, turned out to be a commonplace race between Answer and Katie Earl.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- This time two years ago the bank rate was 2 1/2 per cent., and the bank held exactly the same stock of gold, as now and the same amount of reserve. Foreign exchanges were then more unfavorable. Yet at present a 5-per cent. rate is maintained when it neither controls discounts nor influences gold movements in the slightest degree.

The Harlem Cricket Club took a very weak combination up to Morris Park yeaterday for a match with the home team, and suffered a vary had defeat by 132 runs. They were handicapped by four absentees, and their batting proved weak and the bowling indifferent.

The benefit tendered to "Jack" Dempsey, the exmiddleweight champion pugilist last west was a big success. Gus Tuthill, who managed the show, yesterday handed Dempsey $2,469.57, which was the not receipts. The box-office receipts amounted to $2,877 and the subscriptions to $803, while the expenses were $1,212.43. The financial statement is as follows:

Having appealed in vain to the depositors to take the burden off their shoulders and reopen for them, largely at their own risk and expense, the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, and, realizing the near approach of the sitting of the September Grand Jury, the Directors of that mismanaged institution yesterday appealed to the shareholders for relief.
An esteemed Republican corrrespondent addresses us the following letter of inquiry:

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9. -- A reign of terror has prevailed over this picturesque village since the middle of June. In many circles only one topic of conversation is heard -- the "burglar." After dark the town has resolved itself into an armed band of resistance. Men who never knew fear lose one-half of their sleep sitting at their windows with shotgun or revolver in hand, watching for the return of the "man."

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- Every theatre in town is open. At the Columbia, John J. McNally's new farce, "A Country Sport," with Peter F. Dalley as star, is the attraction, but; although the merit of the work and the quality of the acting have proved to be rather above that shown in McNally'a "A Straight Tip," the attendance thus far has not been very large. It will run for another week, at least.

The Frenchwoman, unlike her English sister, has, as a rule, a very good business education. In the common schools she is taught household bookkeeping, and is given lessons in purchasing and useful expenditure. As a wife she is expected generally to help her husband in his business, and sometimes she manages it entirely for him.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The gay season at this resort is over, but the September season, which has its votaries as faithful as any that make it almost a matter of religion to spend August at Saratoga, is well inaugurated. All the arrivals come now from one way -- the north -- but they are sufficient to fill any town, except this abnormally elastic one that stows away 30,000 persons without winking.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Col. Elliot, ex-member of Congress from Beaufort, S.C., reached Washington yesterday, was soon in conference with the Supervising Surgeon General of the Marine Hospital Service, and told a story of the condition of affairs in that part of the country that promptly secured the aid of that department and the co-operation of the President of the United States.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 9. -- The Kill-von-Ku'g Yacht Club sailed a regatta over a fifteen-mile course for the Houseman Cups this afternoon. The course was from the Bobbin's Reef Light to Buoy 12 off Norton's Point, Coney Island.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept 9. -- The United States Battlefield Commissioners announce that they find themselves confronted with the fact that a land syndicate, composed largely of non-residents of Gettysburg, have taken options upon the historic and most interesting parts of the battlefield, which, it is understood, the Government desires to preserve.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Thirteen yaohte, in size from a cabin sleep to a fifteen-foot catboat, raced here this afternoon for valuable sliver prizes given by the Shrewsbury Yacht Club. The race was under the direction of the club, and was the second and probably the last race of the season.
BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- The market opened strong, Atohison Being the feature and up 5/8 Dominion Coal Was strong, selling Tip to 18. The market closed firm, with alight concessions from highest.

A return issued by the Admiralty yesterday, on the motion of Lord George Hamilton, gives the number of " seagoing war ships in commission, in reserve, and building, and the naval expenditure, revenue, tonnage or mercantile marine, and value of seaborne commerce of various countries for the year 1893."

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept 9. -- Alderman Halloran and Major Kennedy had a tussle last night after the adjournment of the Common Council in which the Mayor proved his ability to take care of himself. Alderman Halloran was aggrieved because he fancied the Mayor snubbed him in ruling out a resolution and would not recognize him when he took the floor.

The story Of Mr. McLeod's Boston and Maine speculations was concluded in The Times yesterday. The present management Came into pOWer as a protest against these very transactions and was expected to repudiate them, to contest any liability on their account to the bitter end, and to secure restitution to the company of the securities which had been unwarrantably removed from its treasury.

STRASSBURG, Sept. 9. -- Emperor William passed to-day in this city. There were no manoeuvres, but the Fifteenth Army Corps marehed in review before him. The weather was fine and an enormous crowd gathered here from the surrounding country to see the parade. After the review the municipal authorities entertained the Emperor at luncheon in an immense tent erected for the occasion on the Broglie Platz.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- A head-on collision between the night White Mountain flier and a freight train on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad occurred at 7 o'clock this morning two miles north of Norwood. Both trains were running at full speed when the engineers saw their danger and reversed. The engines were badly smashed, and two persons were slightly injured.

Charcot generally asked neuropaths, who came to him for advice, whether they drank, took intoxicating drugs, smoked in excess, or had mad forbears. Only three persons in his long experience confessed on some of these points -- unless first under the influence of the will. The neuropath, he found, thought himself or herself faultless Men, he also found, were subject to hysteria.

QUEENS, L.I., Sept. 9. -- The rifle shooting competition between teams of twelve sharpshooters selected from the Seventh and Twenty-third Regiments of the National Guard of this state and the crack team of marksmen from the Thirteenth Regiment of the Pennsylvania State National Guard was shot off on the Creedmoor range to-day. The result is that our doughty rifleman of the Seventh and Twenty-third had to submit to defeat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Representative Geary of California, author of the law of 1892 providing for the deportation, of unregistered Chinese in the United States, is satisfied that the provisions of the law will be enforced by the Administration. Yesterday and to-day he had interviews with President Cleveland and Secretary Carlisle upon the subject, and later said:
SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 9 -- The Seattle Clearing House Association passed the following preamble and resolutions at Ha meeting yesterday:

The careless observer of passing events in local politics is probably of the opinion that the dominant factor in the politics of this city at the present time -- Tammany Hall -- is lying upon its oars in full confidence that it can elect its city and county ticket this year with the greatest ease and that no work or worry is called for.

The interest of M. Leopold Mabilleau's work does not lie in its subject, which now is trite, but in his method, which is a practical application of the most advanced theories of literary criticism in France. An element in its charm is the unaffected simplicity with which the book appears, being neither prefaced by defensive arguments nor aided by the authority of a great name. M. Mabilleau had no celebrity.

There is no one so cynically independent of honorable partisan obligation as your "boss." It is now semi-officially announced that Mr. McLAUGHLIN expects to elect Mr. BOODY -- if he concludes to renominate him -- solely by the aid of Mr. JACOB WORTH, who now holds in the Republican organization of Brooklyn a position analogous to that of Mr. McLAUGHLIN in the Democratic organization.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 9. -- The steamship Worrimoo arrived yesterday evening from Honolulu and brought advices up to Aug. 31.
BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- The election of the Rev. A. C.A. Hall as Bishop of Vermont is a matter of great interest to Episcopalians everywhere, but particularly in this city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- One hundred fears ago, on Sept. 18, 1793, the cornerstone of the Capitol of the United States was laid by George Washington, with all the ceremony that could be observed at the time, when Washington was scarcely more than a hamlet. Just named, but when its future greatness was indicated upon a map prepared by that skillful but irascible engineer Major Plerre L'Enfant.

Emma Goldman, the Anarchist, is now in custody in this city. She was brought from Philadelphia last evening by Detective Sergeants Jacob and Heidelberx. The young woman was recently indicted by the Grand Jury for making inflammatory and seditious harangues and inciting to riot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- An order has been issued by Secretary Herbert reducing the term for which a man can retain his name on the registration Hat as eligible for work in navy yards from two to one year. The effect of it will be to wipe off the list gradually the names of all those who have been certified as desirable men under the last Administration for employment.

Cornichon, a young laborer, has been arrested for having pushed his master, a man named Rougier, off a scaffolding and caused thereby the latter's death. The tragedy happened at Levallois, a suburb of Paris. Rougier, who was a mason, was at work on the second story of a house in course of construction and Cornichon was assisting him.

H.H. Potter, President of tie Board pf Commisioners of Charities and Correction, was asked yesterday about the statement made by Mrs. Jacob Roborson of 105 Bedford Street, that her idiot boy Arthur had neon ill treated and starved at the asylum on Randall's Island, had been kept dirty and had heen tied down with rope that out into his flesh, and kept in the burning sun.

FALL RIVER, Sept. 9. -- Since that fateful June day, the longest of the year and perhaps the longest in the life of Lizzie Borden, when twelve of her countrymen declared she was "not guilty" of murder, as charged in the indictment, many changes have been going on in her affairs, and for the first time in many years she has found herself a woman of freedom.

What promises to be the grandest fistic struggle which has ever occurred in this country between midget monarohs of the ring will be the meeting of George Dixon and Solly Smith, which will Take place at the Coney Island Athletic Club on the night of Monday, Sept. 25. The battle will be for a purse of $10,000 and the featherweight championship of the world.

The bank statement of yesterday was even more encouraging than had been expected. There was an increase in the reserve of $4,533,900, showing an average surplus above the legal requirement of $2,966,375, or, in round numbers, of $3,000,000. This compares favorably with the statements of other years at this season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- An innocent looking little bill introduced by Mr. Morgan in the Senate this morning brings to the surface the fact that the World's Fair Columbian silver half dollars, issued in aid of the fair, are rapidily drifting back into the Treasury.

The New-Jersey Athletic Club eleven played, at Central Park yesterday, when they gained a victory over the New-Yorks by an Innings and 11 runs. Runs were scarce on both sides. Tyers and A. Gunn bowling in great style for the New-Jersey men. Edward Skyne's 21 was the best effort of the day. The totals were: New-Jersey Athletic Club. 72; New-York. 22 and 39.

Of course, the rejection by the House of Lords of the Home Rule bill was expected, but it is not likely that, even by the bestinformed Englishmen, it was expected that the rejection would be made by so overwhelming a majority. Certainly the majority was far greater than a political survey of the House of Lords would lead anybody to suppose.

The new wraps show some ideas likely to make trouble for the women who bought expensive coats last Winter and hoped to fall back upon them for a second season. Capes may be altered easily; scarcely any alteration is necessary, in fact. Coats, however, are changed radically. The close-fitting skirts of last year's coats are out of date entirely.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- There has been a marked diminution to-day in the talk about a compromise in connection with repeal. When the Faulkner proposition was first made public, the silver men permitted the fact to become known that they would be willing to accept it. They ware under the impression that the Administration would agree to Mr. Faulkner's plan, and that they would secure a much greater concession than they had expected.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, Sept. 9 -- P.M. Stock Exchange prices scored another advance to-day, and although there was a Blight weakening just before the close the end of the week found the market well above the level of last Saturday. At the opening there was a series of sharp gains, London buying materially assisting in sending prices up a few pegs.

Yesterday was a busy day on th Fifth Avenue Club courts, Fifth Avenue and O e Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street. The poi t system was again adopted as the method of scoring and the usual close matches resulted. E. Cobb, with a handicap of 36 points, and F.C. Leubuscher, with the same handicap, had a close struggle, cobb finally winning by a single point 48 -- 47.

The animation of success has made Niblo's a notable feature of lower Broadway every night during the past week. Thanks to the popularity of the German dwarfs, this old theatre, whose slumbers have of late years been oftener disturbed than broken, la thoroughly awake, and amusement seekers have been surprised to find that its distance from their ordinary haunts is by no means "Impossible."

Calling hard names, we are well aware, will not have the slightest effect on the Senators who are now by the use of dilatory tactics opposing and putting off the passage of the Wilson Repeal bill. Their hides, we know, are thicker than the hide of ALTGELD. They acknowledge no responsibility to public opinion.

The leading ship, Inconstant, advanced, towed by what proved to be the J.B. Say, whose duty was to drag her through the mud in case she ran aground. As the strangers drew nearer three blank discharges were tired from the Chula Chom Klao Fort, where Commodore de Richelieu, assisted by Capt. von Holck, was in command, to warn them off, but, as no notice was taken, a shot was fired across the Inconstant's bows.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The Rev. Louis Albert Banks, Prohibitionist candidate for Governor, has been one of the most conspicuous of local pastors. He is known throughout New-England almost as well as here.

M. Charles Fere, a well-known authority at Paris on nervous and mental diseases, and who gives particular attention to them, as they manifest themselves in infancy, says they are frightfully on the increase in France. The Paris correspondent of The Weekly Dispatch writes: "This he thinks due to the increase of beer drinking, absin the drinking, and bars.

I sincerely hope that the next general election will result in an overwhelming majority for home rule. But it is obvious that, as sensible men, we must contemplate the possibility of the reverse happening. To take for granted that what we wish must occur is only worthy of fools. What, then, ought to be done? "We ought to declare at once for home rule all round, and go to the election with this cry.

The management of the Aquarium at Westminster has the laudable ambition to secure novelties, but that ambition has overreached itself in engaging the "invulnerable fakir," Hadj Soliman ben Aissa. This young man's performance is entirely unsuited for a public exhibition, however interesting it may be to scientists.

Every one in Flatbush, L.I., knows Patrick MoKenna. Mr. MoKenna is rich, big, and burly. The scales give his avoirdupois as 275 pounds. . When he is weighed in the estimation of some people, however, the figure is something less.

The nineteenth and most successful regatta of the Varuna Boat Club was held yesterday afternoon over the Bay Ridge course. As early as noon groups of bronzed oarsmen, with their wives, sisters, and sweethearts, came trooping down to the clubhouse on the Bay Ridge shore, and by 2 o'clock, the time at which the first event was scheduled to start, the capacity of the cozy little boathouse was taxed to its utmost.

-- Stuart Robson is in town making preparations for his revival of the "Comedy of Errors" Sept. 18. The new scenery has been painted by Voegtlin and shows the Odeum of Ephesus, exterior of the house of Antipholus, changing to a garden; the ports and docks of Ephesus, and the rock-cut church of the early Christians.

Henry Guy Carleton's romantic drama, "The Lion's Mouth," will be presented at the Star Theatre to-morrow night for the first time in this city, with Frederick Warde as Rinaldo, a role he "created" two years ago. Louis James will have an equally strong character in Fra Angelo.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Representatives of knit-goods manufacturers to the number of eighty, doing business at Philmont, Hudson, Waterford, Cohoes, Little Falls, Amsterdam, Fort Plain, Fonda, Herkimer, Schenectady, Stillwater, and Catskill in this State, and at Bennington, Vt., met here in secret session to-day at the Delavan House.

Most of the real estate brokers and operators who have been out of town for the Summer began to put in an appearance during the past week, and the remainder will doubtless be on hand and ready for business by to-morrow. Inquiries are made almost daily for property by persons who are supposed to be ready and willing to buy and some negotiations are reported by nearly all the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Cleveland's second daughter was born at noon to-day in the White House. Not until 2 o'clock, however, was the announcement made to the public. At that hour Private Secretary Thurber, who had not been previously informed of the event, was told by Mr. Cleveland that he might impart the news.

Ex-State Senator Thomas J. Creamer made the following statement yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times in reference to the proceedings recently instituted by him to recover $100.000 from the Fithian family, which he claims is due to the heirs of the late Richard B. Connolly:

As a sequel to another book, Mr. Grant's present volume shares to some extent the familiar fate of sequels. It it not always the second book that is the inferior of the two; indeed, we can conceive of a second being the better; but rather the fact that freshness and originality of idea do not so much impress us in a sequel as they do in a first work.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 10. -- Mrs. James Reid of Brooklyn, who has a Summer cottage here, was awakened about midnight yesterday by the attempts of some one to pry open her front door. Mrs. Reid pluckily armed herself with a revolver and went down stairs to receive the intruder, but the burglar was frightened away by one of the servants lighting a lamp.

The picnic ran of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs yesterday was a great success, and the attendance, over 300, was greater than the committee expected. The New-York and Brooklyn clubs met at the rendezvous at the Battery early in the morning and took the 9 A.M. boat to Staten Island. At St. George they were met by the NewJersey clubs, which had come by way of the Bergen Point Ferry.

Without a home, deserted by her husband, with a three-months-old baby and three little boys to care for, Mrs. Marianne Rild went to the Harlem Police Court yesterday and told to Justice Feitner a pitiful story of suffering. Daring the recital of her troubles she sobbed bitterly, while her three little children clung to her skirts frightened and trembling.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10. -- During the week the Trenton Battle Monument Association will complete the details for the dedicatory exercises. The Battle Monument, on the site of the historical battle of Trenton, will be dedicated Oct. 19.

Jacob Felsenstein of 227 East Fiftieth Street rode down town Saturday night on a Third Avenue elevated train. He intended to get off at Canal Street, but he was so absorbed in a newspaper that he did not reach the car platform until the guard had closed the gate. The guard refused to let him off, and Mr. Felsenstein rode to the Chatham Square station.
The Executive Committee of the Irish National League of America has issued the following manifesto in regard to the Home Rule bill and its rejection by the House of Lords.

A case of fatal poisoning by toadstools was brought to the notice of Deputy Coroner O'Hare yesterday. On the 5th inst. Frank Cattano, thirty-six years old, of 378 Willis Avenue, went to West Farms with James Olivera to pick mushrooms. They found a dozen, and Cattano's wife cooked them for supper. She and her child, the men, Olivera's wife, and her two children ate of the stew.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- For the first time in weeks the lobby of the Arlington was to-night the gathering place of a number of prominent New-Yorkers.

Information has been received in United States ordnance circles of additional experiments in Germany with Kenka-Hebler tabular projectiles. In The New-York Times of Sept. 5 the ballistic data were given as obtained from the perfected "heavy" and "light" tubular bullets fired from the German service rifle of model 1888. The data have now been obtained for these bullets fired from the 5 mm. Hebler rifle.

The four cup defenders will soil over a thirtymile windward or leeward course outside Sandy. Hook again to-day for the benefit of the America's Cup Committee. The gentlemen forming that committee will carefully watch the performance of each boat and endeavor to decide which is the best all-round boat.

-- The annual, club road races of the Lafayette Wheelmen were Held over the Elizabeth-Railway coarse last week. They were well contested and were witnessed by a large number of members and friends of the club. The one-mile scratch was won by J.T. Beam, with W. Miller second and V.D. John third. The 100-yard dash was won by E.A. Van Nest, with J. Gano second and P. Rogers third.

So much has been done in astronomy during the last six years that this third edition of Miss Agnes M. Clerke's book was necessary. It notes the progress made since the publication of the second, and thus furnishes much that is new. The growth of the book is visible in many directions. The index is much more copious the chronological table has been extended and there are new and valuable tables of data.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 10. -- Jan Parylack of this city has been trying to sell his infant daughter. Parylack, with his wife and child, came to this country from Austria several months ago. Not finding the prosperity they expected, they are anxious to return to their native land.

The quantity of wheat (including flour in terms of wheat) exported last week was 4,902,000 bushels. There has been very little variation in the weekly exports for three weeks past. The magnitude of this outward movement can be seen most clearly when the quantity exported for the first ten weeks of the current fiscal and crop year is compared with the exports for the corresponding weeks of the last three years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Few Congressional debates in recent years have been so rich in statistical data as the silver debate now in progress, and the many comparative financial tables used contain valuable information on the subject. These tables, largely, have been prepared by Acting Director of the Mint R.E. Preston, and, judging from the demand for them, are receiving world-wide attention.

WASHINGTON, Sept 10. -- Commissioner of Navigation E.C. O'Brien has submitted to Secretary Carlisle a carefully-prepared and exhaustive report making certain recommendations to provide for the better protection of life and property in the navigable waters of the United States and on the North Atlantic Ocean.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- All the great religions of the world will be represented in the Parliament of Religions which opens its sessions to-morrow and continues for seventeen days. Its object is to bring together the world's creeds in an assembly, "in which the common aims and common grounds of union may be set forth and the marvelous religious progress of the nineteenth century be reviewed."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The September cotton report of the Department of Agriculture shows a decline from the August condition of the crop of fully 7 points, being 73.4 this month, as against 80.4 last month. This is the lowest September condition since 1881, which stood at 70. The condition Sept. 1, 1892, was 76.8. For the same month in the years 1891 and 1890 it was 82.7 and 85.6 respectively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The general Impression that the skeleton of Guiteau. President Garfield's assassin, is on exhibition in the Medical Museum, which has been in existence ever since his death, is dissipated by the statement of Deputy Warden Russ of the District Jail, published to-day. In it ho says:

Madison Square Garden was yesterday converted into a military camp, being ocoupied by the English Military Tournament Company, who will give their first performance this evening. The flooring has been removed and replaced with earth, to admit of the various military evolutions that will form the chief features of the exhibition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- While there is a good deal of gossip respecting the action of the Senate this week, those best acquainted with the situation look for nothing sensational. There are enough speeches in sight to consume the entire week.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept 9 -- The easier feeling in the local money market which was noted last week has shown a further moderate development in the pant six days. While the minimum rate to regular customers remains unchanged at 7 cent., there is some inquiry for outside loans, and the offerings on brokers' lists show a distinct decline in the rates that borrowers ore willing to pay.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- The season of rifle practice at the New-Jersey camp ground at Sea Girt ended on Saturday. Gen. W. Bird Spencer, who has been in charge of the State's rifle range, and is Inspector General of Rifle Practice, in reviewing the work of the season, said:
Hungry men hereafter will be regarded with suspicion by Capt. A.L.C. Boive, who commands one of the Consolidated Gas Company's scows, which is now moored at the foot of West Forty-fifth Street.

Hugh McLaughlin, "boss" of the "machine" Democracy of Kings County, has learned from his agents in the Eastern District of Brooklyn that if he nominates his friend Daniel Ryan for Sheriff next month, German-American Democrats will knife his candidate at the polls on election day.

The Trades Union Conference for the Relief of the Unemployed held another session yesterday at the International Labor Lyceum, 257 East Tenth Street. The committee appointed to consider the advisability of holding a labor demonstration recommended that a mass meeting of all working men, organized and unorganized, be called to take place in Union Square on the evening of Sept. 29 to explain to the public the true condition of affairs among the working classes.

-- In his reminiscences, which are being published posthumously in the "New-England Magazine," Mr. B.P. Shillaber describes the accidental beginning of the Mrs. Partington "sayings," and refers to the number of imitators who quickly appeared and who almost universally misrepresented the character of the amiable old dame.

The foreign exchange market has been quiet. Posted rates for sterling ware $4.83 for sixtyday bills and $4.86 3/4 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.82 1/4@$4.82 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.85 3/4 for demand, $4.86 3/4 for cables, and $4.81 1/2 for commercial.

On La Gascogne, which arrived in port yesterday, were fifty-two French artisans who are on their way to the World's Fair. They come at the expense or the French Government, by which they were selected from among the different trades to visit the fair and inspect American methods and improved machinery which are used in the same trades in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- A joint resolution introduced recently by Representative Covert of New-York brings to public attention again the claim at Maximo Mora, a citizen of New-York, against the Government of Spain, which haa probably been the subject of more diplomatic correspondence than any similar matter in recent years.
LONDON, Sept. 10. -- The Brazilian Legation has communicated to the press an official telegram from Rio Janeiro, dated Sept. 9, which says:

TRENTON, N.J., Sept 10. -- Irene House, who murdered one husband and has seven others living, was yesterday committed to the Trenton Insane Asylum. She has become insane on the subject of marriage. She was at one time rich and good-looking, but spent her fortune on her numerous husbands.

When the Assembly districts or this city were reapportioned last year, the Fifteenth District was left with its old numerical designation, but with what was thought to be a reduced Democratic plurality. Ten of the election districts at its southern end were out off and annexed to the then doubtful Thirteenth Assembly District to aid in making that a certain Democratic district.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept 10. -- The fight to Virginia this year will be a triangular one, in which the Democrats, Populists, and Prohibitionists will take part. Each of these parties has nominated a full ticket and opened headquarters here for the prosecution of the campaign, which opens in full blast to-morrow.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Sept 10. -- This has been a strange Sunday to the 20,000 people gathered on the border of the Cherokee Strip here and there along the line. Religious services were held, but the gamblers and horse traders had the biggest crowd.

The British cruiser Magicienne, which was one of the British review squadron during the Columbus celebration, has been rocommissioned at Portsmouth, England, for further duty on the North American and West Indian station. The new commander of the Magicienne is Capt. A.C. Clarke. This officer had command of the British war ship Espiegle during the Chilean war.

SILVER HILL, Ark., Sept. 10. -- T. W. Whitley, with the elder members of his family, attended church some distance from home last night, leaving flve of his children, ranging in age from five to thirteen years, in care of the house.
