After the services were over he returned, to find the house burned to the ground and the five children cremated in the ruins.

PENN YAN, N. Y., Sept. 10. -- The struggle between the two Democratic factions in Yates County culminated yesterday. One of them has been led by Deputy Collector Calvin J. Huson. while M. A. Leary has directed the other. The result was a victory for the men in sympathy with the Cleveland Administration, who have also captured a majority of the uncontested towns of the county and will most probably control the county convention.
The money market was easier than in the previous week. Call loans were made at 2@6 cent.

METZ, Sept. 10. -- In replying to the address of the Burgomaster of Strasburg on the Broglie Platz yesterday the Emperor, after expressing regret for the shortness of his sojourn in the beautiful city, said:

The designs of the two new British cruisers Powerful and Terrible have been given out in brief by the British Admiralty. These two ships are designed to be the largest cruisers in the world, and the intentions of the British authorities concerning them have been watched closely by naval experts ever since the first announcement was made of their prospective building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- With the departure of the Newark in two weeks for the South Atlantic station there will be a general cessation, of activity at the navy yards incident to getting ships ready for foreign service. The sailing of the Baltimore leaves the Newark the only vessel fitting out for a new station.

WEIGHTS OF COINS. -- "G.W.": Can yon tell an old admirer of your excellent paper how many times in the history of the United States the weights of the silver and the gold coins have been changed, and under what circumstances the changes took place.
KISSINGEN, Sept. 10. -- Prince Bismarck's condition has caused the greatest anxiety for some time. His son William and several family friends have lately been summoned to his bedside.

TRENTON, Sept. 10. -- Senator McPherson is the target for the anxious Democrats who are seeking Federal offices and who do not think he is exerting himself in behalf of his constituency. He is attached by these men, who, not understanding the situation, think all he has to do is to command and heads will be cut off and berths without limit will be made soft and easy.

Mary Monahan of 446 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, having a grievance against Matthew Coogan, her landlord, bid an axe under her apron and visited his house. Patrolman Converse found Mary trying to enter Mr. Coogan's house and questioned her. She said she was seeking revenue and intended to "smash the windows and doors." She was arrested, and appeared before Justice Feltner, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 10. -- The police of this city seem to have stirred up a largesized and thickly-populated hornets' nest when, they broke up a Salvation Army meeting last Sunday night and arrested fourteen members of the army.

-- The first good, roads convention ever held in California, or, indeed on the Pacific coast, met in Sacramento last Thursday to see what could be done to improve the roads of the State. The movement is advocated by the wheelmen, who want better roads for bicycle riding, and by the Sacramento County Humane Society, which is actuated by consideration for draught animals and for live food animals transported over the country roads.

A large crowd of local chess players witnessed the third game of the chess match between E. Lasker and A. Ettlinger at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. The spectators were treated to a Ruy Lopez, defended by Lasker with Kt-KB3. White played rather weakly at the opening and lost a pawn, while Lasker conducted the came in sound and very cautious fashion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Attorneys for the Chinese Legation in Washington, having heard reports that additional Instructions for the enforcement of the Geary law were being prepared at the Treasury Department, made inquiries there regarding them. Subsequently one of the attorneys said they had been informed that no orders on the subject had been given other than those promulgated at the time the Exclusion act was declared to be constitutional by the supreme Court.

-- It is reported that the new Wilkesbarre and Eastern Hailroad has fallen into the bands of the New- York and Susquehanna, and that work will be pushed more rapidly on the Willlamsport branch. The latter will run from Wilkesbarre to Harvey's Lake and Williamsport and will give to the Wilkesbarre and Eastern connections for Brio, Cleveland, and Chicago.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- The Rev. Dr. William Lawrence, Dean of the Episcopal Theological School, Cambridge, is to be ordained and consecrated, Oct. 5, in Trinity Church, as the successor of the lamented Bishop Brooks.

-- Color has a strong effect upon the mind and the imagination, remarks Mr. Wedworth Wadsworth, in Brooklyn Life, and nowhere has this been more carefully studied than in the interior of our churches. The science of color may be said to have had its birth in the Church, and there also to have reached its perfection.
Among the passengers that arrived here yesterday on La Gascogne were Robert M. McLane, ex-Minister to France, and Dr. J. T. Kennedy of this city. Mr. McLane is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

The Rev. Dr. Talmage yesterday preached his first sermon at the Brooklyn Tabernacle, after the Summer vacation. The rest which the doctor took during the hot weather showed its beneficial effect in his, improved appearance. Constant worry over the load of debt which, last Spring, threatened to swamp the Tabernacle, had told perceptibly on the doctor, and he stood in need of the Summer's vacation.

The revolt of a portion of the Brazilian Navy against the Government of President PEIXOTO makes still another call upon our fleet for the protection of American interests and property. It happens that for a long time our only vessel regularly on the South Atlantic station has been the small wooden craft Yantic, of 900 tons displacement, carrying a pair of nine-inch smooth-bores, an eight-inch muzzle-loading rifle, and a sixty-pounder breech-loader.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 9 -- Local stock and financial affairs were vastly improved in the last week. The larger banks have gained in deposits sufficiently to justify them in making loans, and rates are unchanged. The best gains on the stock list were in Citizens' Traction to 60 bid, Dnquesne on sales to 25, and Manchester to 38 3/4.

Pilgrims returning from Mecca have carried cholera to Constantinople and Algeria. To prevent the introduction of cholera into Europe from Mecca there is scarcely any sanitary barrier except that which has been set up by the powers near the Suez Canal through the agency of the Egyptian Sanitary Council.
The Buffalo Courier, the leading Democratic paper of Western New-York, says in its issue of Saturday, Sept 9:

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Shortly before the smash-up on the Long Island Railroad at Berlin Austin Corbin offered to give the officers of the Queens County Agricultural Society $5,000 to be used in increasing the premiums at the Fall fair to be held here the latter part of this month. Mr. Corbin's offer was considered generous, and the society's officers at once set about making plans for an advantageous distribution of the money.

Many professional American soldiers, recognizing the danger of foreign wars and our complete unpreparedness for such wars with great powers, have devoted themselves to devising plans by which as large a part of the population as possible may be made ready to bear arms in case of need. The latest of these is Capt. ZALINSKI, whose essay on the subject of "Army Organization," submitted in competition last year, has lately been published.
WEST POINT, Sept 10 -- The first football game of the season was played here yesterday. The teams were selected from the material which practiced daily during the past week.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- It seems long years now since the burning of the Opera Comique, and even without the all-absorbing Siamese question, there would be little cause for deep interest in the matter -- until perchance the lounging Parisian began to see the building grow. Then his Boulevard Instinct would hint frequent visitations and ardent discussion.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, Sept. 11 -- P.M. Once more the stock market scored a decided advance to-day. The opening was weak, with a general tendency toward lower prices, but there soon came a rally and a development of strength which continued throughout the day.

Among the days set apart for the celebrations of particular communities at the World's Fair there ought to be one for the City of New-York. That is understood to be the opinion, of the Mayor, and there is a considerable force in it. New-York State has had its day, but the Empire State covers act only a great expanse of territory, but a great diversity of interests and industries.

After having traveled several thousand miles in an effort to escape service on board a man-of-war, two deserters from the United States cruiser Chicago were captured yesterday morning just as liberty seemed within their reach.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- If the police authorities were anywhere in the neighborhood of the old Bergen Reformed Church this evening they must have concluded they had siven the Salvation Army a boom. The old church was organized in 1660, and it is doubtful if any such congregation was ever before gathered within its walls.

Francis Henry Weeks, robber of women and children, embezzler of trust funds, and thief who stole everything he could lay his hands on before taking cowardly refuge in flight from, this country, at last feels the hand of the law upon his collar and is likely soon to be brought back by a policeman to receive the punishment for his singularly despicable crimes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Among the fourth class Postmasters appointed to-day were the following:

PRAGUE, Sept. 11 -- The Young Czechs have become utterly reckless in their anti-German agitation. For three days they nave threatened riots. Their leaders nave made so many intemperate and menacing speeches that yesterday farther Young Czechs meetings were prohibited.
Emily Arnould the nineteen-year-old daughter of a wealthy candy manufacturer, attempted suicide yesterday afternoon by taking carbolic acid.
No public sales of real estate were held yesterday. For to-day ten foreclosure sales are scheduled, all to take place in the Trinity Building salesroom at 111 Broadway. The list follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- The market opened quiet and a shade lower than Saturday's closing, but soon became active and strong, closing at slight concessions from the highest. No Clearing House certificates were taken out or canceled to-day. Total amount outstanding, $11,435,000. At the Clearing Souse this morning very little trading was done in money.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Capt. Thomas F. Chadwick's yacht Gem sailed a walk-over to-day for the challenge pennant of the North Shrewsbury River. The distance was ten miles and the race was half to windward. The time was 1:17.

BOSTON, Sept 11 -- E.E. Rice produced "Venus," the new comic musical piece by C.A. Byrne and Louis Harrison at the Park Theatre to-night. The piece was beautifully mounted and generally well performed, after the fashion of Mr. Rice's "Surprise Party," as his troupe is called, and similar organizations. Wherefore its reception was cordial.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 -- By a single run the Brooklyns won a game here to-day from the Browns. This is the fourth successive victory gained by the Brooklyns over the local club, and naturally President Von Der Ahe is in an unhappy frame of mind.

The Vigilant will defend the America's Cup. She had hardly crossed the finish line at the third trial race yesterday when the Cup Committee, consisting of James D. Smith, Latham A. Fish, A. Cass Canfield, J. Frederick Tams, and Philip Schuyler, who had watched all three races from the May, the flagship of the New-York Yacht Club, decided that she had proved the worthiest of the quartet to race the Valkyrie.

Roswell Miller, President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, says in his annual report, just issued, that the floating indebtedness of that company, consisting of bills payable, is $3,240,000, against which there is in the treasury of the company and due from Trustees $8,824,000 of bonds which may be sold.

MONTICELLO, Sept. 11 -- The chief interest in the case of Mrs. Halliday now centres in the question as to whether or not it is insanity that is responsible for the atrocious homicides of which she is undoubtedly guilty. Sheriff Beecher of Sullivan County, who is now her custodian, declares emphatically that the woman is no more insane than he himself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The time of the House Ways and Means Committee to-day was taken up by representatives of the iron and steel industry of the country. Joseph Wharton of Philadelphia, Vice President of the American Iron and Steel Association, said that the McKinley tariff suited him perfectly, and that he hoped no change would be made in it.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-second District, held here to-day, was a sort of love feast, in which the delegates from Oswego and St. Lawrence Counties vied with each other in saying and doing pleasant things for Joseph Mullin of this city. George Z. Erwin of St. Lawrence was not a candidate, but his name came before the convention through the Committee on Resolutions.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 11 -- The campaign that commenced this year in Virginia is one of the most important known in that State since the war.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- In the House of Commons to-night James Henry Daiziel, (Liberal,) member for Kirkcaldy, moved a reduction of the vote for the salary of the Duke or Cambridge as commander in chief of the army.

Many curious features appear in the record, of the career of Francis H. Weeks, who began his business life as a lawyer in 1868, and ran away from the officers of the law early last May. As a lawyer he won himself reputation and good income, bat his talents lay always in the way of doing unusual things and engineering large enterprises.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- There is a more promising programme for the second week of the Northwestern Trotting Horse Breeders' Association, though the sport to-day was not particularly good. The pleasant weather brought about 3,500 people to Washington Park. They saw a long card that occupied all the available daylight, and in the progress of which several favorites were defeated.
The official report as to the number of immigrants arriving in August has not been published, but the report for July shows the following comparative statement with respect to the countries named:

NASSAU, N.P., Sept. 5 -- The American bark E.W. Stetson, which was towed into port three days ago leaking and in bad condition generally, experienced the severe cyclone of Aug. 25-27, after having passed through two storms previously. During the hurricane three men were washed away and lost while the deck cargo was being thrown overboard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Another dispatch from the United States Minister to Brazil, Mr. Thompson, was received at the State Department to-day, but it contained nothing not known to the department except that commerce and business were suspended as a result of the declaration of martial law.

The Vigilant will defend the cup. If there remained any doubt as to her supremacy among the four cup defenders it must have been removed by the result of yesterday's race. That contest settled the question which the trial races were arranged to solve, and the decision of the committee will meet with the approval of the yachting public.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Arrangements are nearly completed for a team rifie match between representative New-Jersey military men and a team of the District of Columbia National Guardsmen some time in October on the Columbian Range in Washington. The members of the winning team will receive handsome badges, to be paid for by the losing side.
Six new cases of poisoning by fungi, supposed to be edible mushrooms, were reported to the health authorities yesterday.

Anarchist Emma Goldman, with a red pompon flaring in her hat and with an assumption of the air of a martyr that was ridiculous except to the members of the great army of the unwashed, in which she shines, was arraigned yesterday before Judge Fitzgerald, in the Court of General Sessions, to plead to the indictments which have been found against her.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 11 -- The certainty of the repeal of the Sherman act has enabled the banks here to get all the money they need, and the cotton crop, which is rapidly coming in, is being moved without difficulty. The price has advanced to 8 cents with an upward tendency and the farmers are much encouraged.

THE DYING NEWPORT SEASON -- The Newport season is slowly dying, but things there are not so insufferably dull as has been reported. There were several dinner parties during the week. On Monday H.D. Robbins gave a dinner for twelve guests at the Logerot on the Cliffs. The table decorations were of lotus flowers and water lilies. Mrs. William Post also gave a dinner on Monday to sixteen guests at her villa on Bellevue Avenue.

France's picked delegation of trades masters, who have come over to visit the Word's Fair and at the same time to study America's leading industries, promptly inaugurated their work yesterday morning by proceeding in a body to Tiffany's immense jewelry establishment in Union Square.

Some time since Capt. Creeden constituted an Italian patrolman, Thomas Butler, a special officer and detailed him to watch, the movements of certain of his countrymen. He went among them in citizen's clothes, and, having succeeded in his mission, was sent back to do post duty.

Justin McCarthy, leader of the Irish Home Rulers m the British Parliament, has cabled the, following message and appeal to Dr. Thomas Addis Emmet, President of the Irish National Federation of America:

William Greve, a Brooklyn real estate dealer, believes Mrs. Frank Halliday, the Sullivan County murderess, whom he knows, had an accomplice. Mr. Greve has just returned from his Summer home near Burlington, Sullivan County. He was active in discovering the recent murders committed by the Halliday woman.

Nearly all the delegates from this city to the convention of Boards of Trade and commercial bodies to be held in Washington to-day started for that city yesterday. The trains that carried them also had as passengers delegates from commercial bodies in New-England and the interior part of this State.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Anna Friedman, who was employed in the family of Milton M. Smith of 7O4 Columbus Avenue, New-York, was arrested to-day. It is alleged that while the family was absent from home on Saturday she drugged a child left in her charge and nearly caused its death. It is also charged that the girl stole articles worth $1,000.

Marie Wainwright began last evening at the Columbia Theatre, which is in Brooklyn, and not nearly so difficult to find, as that fact is often thought to imply, an engagement that is to last a week. Much may he done in a week. Miss Wainwright proposes to do "Frou-Frou," the intensely emotional drama; "Camille," the "heart story" of Alexandra Dumas, and "The Social Swim," a play adapted from Sardou's "Maison Neuve."

An old shellbark sat on the end of a pier running out from South Street into the East River yesterday morning. He was feeling a line as it ran over his forefinger into the water, trying to catch fish. He seemed to be having bad luck, and the longer he sat there the more impatient he grew.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Sept. 11 -- This was "Divver Day." The entire male population of the Second Assembly District of New-York, with a sprinkling from other districts, came here to do honor to the occasion and enjoy themselves at the same time. The club left its headquarter s in Madison Street early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- David A. Wells, the veteran tariff reformer, has submitted a lengthy report to Secretary Carlisle, in answer to his request for an "opinion as to the expediency, from a strictly revenue point of view, of maintaining or changing the present internal revenue taxes on distilled spirits, malt liquors, and tobacco."

So successful have the half-rate excursions from New-York to Chicago been that the general passenger agents of the trunk lines have agreed unanimously to extend the period for such excursions from the 16th of the present month to Oct. 23. After the 16th, however, six trains instead of eight will be ran each week -- two on Mondays, two on Wednesdays, and two on Saturdays.
The following statement is made in regard to the fast steam yacht Felseen and its late mishap by Capt. Peter Crowley, master, and Henry Stanwood, pilot, at that Vessel:

"There is absolutely no truth in the printed reports that there has been a disruption among the members of the Vaudeville Club over the payment of dues," said Preble Tucker yesterday afternoon to a reporter for The New-York Times.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 -- Ward and his segregation of talent from the metropolis were the same old Giants here to-day. They have teen playing a strong came at home, but when they cot here they were easy prey for the local players. It was the same old story -- at home the Giants are invincible, but on the road they are about up to the speed of the Washingtons.

Yesterday afternoon the Orange Athletic Club continued its Fall lawn tennis tournament on the club courts, Grove Station. The competitors are all handicapped, and some very close matches are expected. T. Sidney Kingman is winning right along, and yesterday he defeated Robert Slimmer in straight sets, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, Kingsman is ranked at scratch, while Slimmer played from hall fifteen.

It has been many years since the people of this city have bad an opportunity of gazing upon the manoeuvres of English troops, and it is not surprising that the Madison Square Garden should be crowded, to overflowing last evening at the prospect of seeing "Tommy Atkins " in all the glories of his martial life. The entertainment provided was unique and original.

GARRISONS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- In a peaceful spot, under waving trees, on the banks of the broad river, where he had passed so many Summers, the body of Hamilton Fish was buried to-day in a grave beside those of his wife and oldest daughter. St. Philip's Church is built on the first of the series of hills which roll up from the Hudson.

There was really very little reason why any one who loves yachting for its own sake should have spoiled their day's outing by getting seasick. But that is precisely what a great number of those who went down to the sea in pleasure craft did. The iron steamboat Taurus, which bore the flag of the New-York Yacht Club, had about 100 clubmen, with their wives, daughters, and sweethearts on board.

The Senate has before it a resolution for inquiring into the expediency of constructing a line of interior waterways along the Atlantic coast between the Gulf of Mexico and Massachusetts Bay. The present is scarcely an auspicious moment for an undertaking whose ultimate cost would be reckoned, we should suppose, in hundreds of millions.

The Valkyrie left the other side nineteen days ago and has not been sighted since she sailed. It was thought by yachtsmen that she would make the trip in eighteen days, as the Navahoe sailed across on the eastward voyage in seventeen days, and it was thought that the Valkyrle would do as well, though the weather has been against her. The Navahoe on her voyage was spoken a number of times.
WASHINGTON, Sept 11 -- Yang Yu, the new Chinese Minister, had a very satisfactory interview with Secretary Gresham to-day on the matter of enforcing the Chinese exclusion law.

The Treasury Department has received no information, official or otherwise, in confirmation of the report that the Canadian Government has refused to ratify the agreement as to the inspection of immigrants which was signed by Superintendent STUMP, the agents of the steamship lines, the Canadian railroad companies, and, conditionally, by the Canadian Deputy Minister of the Interior.
The headquarters of the Republican State Committee were opened yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Parlor J has been engaged for this purpose.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Fire broke out in the lumber yard at Pullman at 11:15 o'clock tonight and got beyond the control of the local Fire Department. A strong wind was blowing and the names were carried in the direction of the immense shops where the Pullman cars are built.

Receiver Dykman of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, yesterday, through J.C. Bergen, his law partner, applied to Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, for an order on the Attorney General to show cause why the receiver should not pay over to their owners certain notes, , left with the bank just before the failure.
Mr. Nathan Straus's racehorse Reginald, which was not sold with his other horses on Saturday last, will be put up at auction with the Messrs. Keene's horses at Gravesend on Friday, Sept. 15.

A big white cutter, with a topmast towering away up in the sky, was towed up the East River and through Hell Gate yesterday morning. All the way up she attracted considerable attention. Men on tugboats cheered her, passengers on ferryboats and big excursion steamers waved their hats to her, and even those on the piers and docks gave her a shout as she went by.

Many teachers in the public schools of Brooklyn suffered through the collapse of the Commercial Bank. They had received checks in payment for their June work. Like many others, they had confidence in the stability of the Commercial Bank. They were in no immediate need of money, and held the check, s until suddenly they realized that their month's pay was swallowed up in the general collapse.

There was quite a stir in the District Attorney's office yesterday owing to the request made by the authorities at Washington for all the papers in the case of the absconding embezzler, Francis H. Weeks, whose arrest and prosecution will doubtless result from his discovery some weeks ago by a correspondent of The New-York: Times in Costa Rica.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A.C.C. Astwood, the colored man who has been named for Consul to Calais, and whose confirmation is objected to by some one who has brought his objections to the notice of the State Department, says that his detractors are negro Republicans, and the same ones who objected to him when he was once before nominated, at that time by a Republican President.

World' a Fair excursion trains comprised the topic that chiefly occupied the attention of the General Passenger Agents of the Eastern trunk lines at their meeting yesterday. There was unanimous agreement that the hall-rate trains were a success, and a resolution was adopted authorizing Commissioner Farmer to assign dates for ten trains each week instead or six, as now provided for, from the 16th of this month to about the 23d of next month.
Money on call loaned at 3@4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

The Ways and Means Committee is listening patiently to the assertion, repeated day after day, that the foreigner pays the tariff duties. How philanthropic the foreign manufacturer must be For example, if these persons who appear before the committee are right, the generous foreigner in 1892 paid $3,589,469 in duties on cigars the entire value of which, as shown by the Treasury reports, was only $2,769,011.

A fire at 60 Pearl Street early yesterday morning furnished a first-class fireworks display. The fire broke out shortly after 8 o'clock on the top floor of the building, which was stored with Tarnish owned by Minnett Co. The flames soon reached the lower floors.
COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Sept. 12 -- The Comanche Club of the Third Assembly District, New-York, took possession of Donnelly's Boulevard Park here to-day, it being their second annual outing.

The little room behind the back stairs of the Fifth Avenue Hotel is open again, and the Republican State Committee has started in business once more at the old stand. Chief Clerk Reuben L. Fox came down from Albany Monday, and Typewriter Crozler appeared on the scene yesterday. Chairman Charles W. Hackett was around for a while on Monday, minus the whiskers which glorified him in former campaigns, but he has not been seen since.

Plans for the reorganization of the Cordage Company were discussed yesterday after it was known that a certificate of incorporation of L. Waterbury Co., Limited, had been filed in the County Clerk's office in Jersey City. James M. Waterbury, Chauncey Marshall, and Charles N. King were named as incorporators of the new company, which is to begin business with a capital of $2,400,000.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, Sept. 12 -- P.M. Lower prices prevailed on the Stock Exchange to-day, and there was less activity in the trading, the total transactions being a little above 216,000 shares. At the opening there were a few advances scored, but generally the list was heavy, prices weakening, and the market being inactive until noon, when a slight rally took place.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Sept 12 -- A big brown mongrel dog, owned by Jacob Heeb, attacked his two-year-old granddaughter, Annie Howard' yesterday and badly lacerated the right side of the child's face and neck.
Wheat was fairly active and made an advance of 1 1/2@1 5/8 c on shorts covering, a bullish West, and a better financial outlook.

The proposition to cancel the obligation of the Treasury to redeem the fractional silver coin seems to us one that can only be justified by an extreme emergency in the Treasury, and then only as an avowedly temporary measure. We can hardly see that the present conditions warrant any such measure.

The public schools in some districts of the east side are far from being able to accommodate the children who apply for admission. This is especially true in parts of the Nineteenth and Twelfth Wards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Unless the United States Senate is entirely deaf to the demands of the country. It can hardly fail to be influenced by the action of the convention of business man which assembled here to-day to demand the repeal of the Saerman act.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept 12 -- Chief Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court has delivered a judicial opinion which involves a son of the late Bradford R. Wood of Albany. Mr. Wood was at one time a leading politician of NewYork State, and for efficient political services was appointed Minister to Denmark by President Lincoln, serving from 1861 to 1865.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 12 -- Cleveland had another hot battle this afternoon. New-York batted the ball for more hits than the Clevelands, but not until after chances had been offered to retire the side. One run was scored on what ordinarily would have been an easy put out, but the ball bounced over McGarr's head instead of into his hands. Attendance, 2,000. Score:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 12 -- Traction stocks advanced at the opening, Metropolitan to 102 and Philadelphia to 92 1/2. Later in the day there was a decline of 4 cent. in each, followed by a fractional advance at the close. The recent heaviness of Lehigh Valley stock was explained to-day by the passing of the dividend. The stook broke 4 points, to 30, on the news, and failed to rally.

The brightening business situation was reflected yesterday in the markets for grain, provisions, and staples rather than in railroad securities. Wheat has advanced about 3 cents per bushel in the last two days. The advance is due to a natural boom, consequent on conditions that were expected to operate in the market as soon as signs should appear or an equilibrium in trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Very little hope remains to the Western men visiting in Washington of the defeat of the repeal bill. Such everlasting talkers as Stewart may insist that they will die talking before they frill stop, but that does not seem to deceive nor depress the men who are watching the light from a distance.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- District Attorney Sherman Hoar concluded his argument this forenoon in the case against ex-President Potter of the Maverick Bank. He declared that President Potter knew about the irregularities going on in the bank, and that ex-Cashier Work, who is also under indictment, was an accomplice. It is absolutely essential, he said, that persons who have the care of trust funds and misuse them must feel the clutching hand of the law.
Exchanging property has been one of the marked features in the real estate field for some time past. It is not altogether distasteful to the broker, because it means a commission each Way.

Lasker played the fourth game in his match against Ettlinger at the Manhattan Chess Club on Monday evening. The latter played a double fianchetto, in which Lasker had a chance of distinguishing himself in wonderful style. Ettlinger resigned after twenty-eight moves. Appended is the full score of this really brilliant game:

WASHINGTON, Sept 12 -- Preparations are being made on an elaborate scale for the celebration of the centenary of the laying of the cornerstone of the United States Capitol on Sept. 18. The ceremonies will have a national importance because of the participation of the three branches of the Government.

Early Autumn days bring crowds of shoppers into the up-town streets, and among the varied attractions of the shop windows none la greater than the display offered by H. O'Nelll Co. at Twentieth Street and Sixth Avenue. Dress fabrics are shown in great variety, but the firm has made special efforts this year in its millinery and clock departments.
Our public-men very rarely become masters of the art of bamboozling the reporters. District Attorney NICOLL did a neat job in that line yesterday.

The Jefferson Heights Tennis Club tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Nostrand and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn. The tournament is remarkable for the number of ladies entered, there being just sixteen trying for he prize. Six have been defeated, leaving ten still in the hunt. Miss H. Brooks, who is considered to be the best of the lot, has yet to play her first match.

CHICAGO, Sept 12 -- An open letter has been Bent to Theodore Thomas, at Fair Haven, Mass., signed by a number of the leading citizens of this city deprecating the attacks which were made on him while he was engaged as Musical Director of the World's Fair.

Below are the entries for the championship races to be held in Chicago under the auspices of the Amateur Athletic Union on Saturday next. The athlete making the best individual record will be presented with the handsome prize offered by The New-York Times:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 12 -- The Rev. Dr. Briggs of New-York, who was recently suspended by the Presbyterian General Assembly at Washington, passed through this city yesterday en route to Chicago. Dr. Briggs called upon Bishop Vincent of this diocese at the Episcopal Church rooms and was closeted with him for some time.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 12 -- The September term or the Hudson County courts began this morning. Judge Lippincott's charge to the Grand Jury was largely or a special character. A large audience had gathered, owing to a rumor that Judge Lippincott would have something to say in relation to sins of omission on the part of the last Grand Jury.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Train robbers stopped the Atlantic express train on the Lake Shore Road at Kessler, Ind., about midnight last night, shot the engineer, James Knapp, wounding him severely; broke into the express car, blew open the United Stutes Express Company's safe, and took its contents, consisting of four packages.
Edwin Perkins, son of Hosea B. Perkins, committed suicide at an early hour yesterday morning in front of his father's house at King's Bridge Road and One Hundred and Seventy-ninth Street.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 12 -- The five banks of Vicksburg which some weeks ago adopted the system of certified checks and reduced cash, payments to depositors to $50 daily, met last evening and unanimously voted to remove all restrictions, thus snoring their confidence in the present improved conditions.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 12 -- A large crowd of society people attended the invitation tournament of the Lenox Club this morning. Only doubles were played and two matches finished to-day. The tournament will be finished in the morning. Hobart and Talmadge were defeated two sets out of three by Fowler and Kauhn, and some of the best tennis seen in Lenox for years took place.

A morning paper stated yesterday that Immigration Commissioner Banner bad received information that Martha Huer, the Vienna soubrette and confidence woman who was sent back to Hamburg on the steamer Normannia on Aug. 17, had again entered the United States by way of Canada and was expected in this city yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Entries closed yesterday for the cycling events of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs which will be held at Waverly next Saturday.

CHIOAGO, Sept. 12 -- There wan a good trade in wheat to-day and the feeling developed, while somewhat unse tiled, was yet very firm. There was a decidedly strong undertone to the market. The opening was about 1/4@3/8c lower than yesterday's closing figures, became strong, and, after some fluctuations, advanced to a point 2 1/4c over the lowest point, and the closing was about 1 3/4c higher than the last prices of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The dog-in-the-manger policy continues to be adhered to in the Senate, much to the annoyance of the repeal men, and it is likely that it will be adhered to until some coarse shall be decided upon by the majority that shall put a stop to the idle filibustering in the body that is so weighted with dignity and comity that it hesitates to consider a closure proposition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Benor Zeballos, in the course of his address he made while presenting to-day to the President his credentials as the new Argentine Minister, said:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept 12 -- The cruiser Columbia returned to the yard of her builders this afternoon with the record-breaking figures of "21 3-10" flying from her mast, and was cheered as she passed up the river.

Harry Miner, the founder of that branch of industry known as the "green goods" business, or, in plainer words, the confidence game, died at Bensonhurst, L.I., yesterday afternoon, penniless. At the time of his death he was a police officer at a salary of $60 a month.

The unexpected refusal of the Canadian Government to ratify the agreement made by the Canadian railroad and steamship companies with the Superintendent of Immigration in this country, and ratified by our Government, will probably make it necessary for the Federal authorities to enforce the laws with all permissible severity at those points on the boundary where immigrants have been accustomed to enter the United States.

There was a merry time before Judge McAdam of the Superior Court yesterday, thanks to Alexander C. Lassen, the famous fighting Director of the New-York Concert Company, which ran the Casino. Mr. Lassen fought the fight of his life to prevent Lederer Canary from getting the theatre, hut he came off vanquished, after a battle royal that lasted several hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- In the absence of definite official advices as to the Brazilian situation the State Department and Navy Department are acting on press reports concerning the troublous times in Rio.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 12 -- A special slection was held here to-day to decide whether a city charter should be procured. The struggle was bitter, many men leaving their offices to take part in the contest.

Supervisor at Large George Kinkel of Kings County yesterday appointed Adolph Simis, Jr. a Charities Commissioner to serve the unexpired term of the late Francis Nolan, and Charles J. Henry to succeed Commissioner George H. Murphy, whose term will expire Dec. 31. Commissioner Simis will succeed himself on Jan. 1.

The question of the utmost practical importance in the reform of the tariff has been felt by all careful observers to be the question of preserving for the Treasury all needed revenue until the new tariff rates should have had time to work out their results. The extreme protectionists who secured control of the Republican Party in 1888 fully intended to make all changes in the tariff as nearly impossible as they could.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Schedule K of the tariff law -- wool and manufactures of wool -- was the subject of the hearing before the Ways and Means Committee to-day.

BUFFALO, Sept 12 -- An ideal day greeted the delegates and visitors to the eightieth conclave of the Grand Commandery Knights Templars of New-York State. Shortly before 9 o'clock the various commanderies began to move from their respective hotels to the Irogouis, the headquarters of the Grand Commandery, and at 9:30 escorted the latter body to the Masonic Temple, where the conclave began its sessions.

THE EDEY-OTIS WEDDING -- Chief among the social incidents to-morrow will be the marriage of Miss Suaan Birdsall Otis to Frederick Edey. Miss Otis is the daughter of ex-Senator James Otis, whose broad shoulders and jolly face bring back memories of fins times long since gone to politicians of both parties. Fred Edey needs no introduction to society people at any of the leading centres in this country or abroad.
Sanitary experts were detailed yesterday to search for poisonous fungi, but none were found.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Official and semi-official statements as to the enforcement or noninforcement of the Geary Chinese exclusion law continue to conflict in many material points.

O.D. Ashley, who was yesterday reflected President of the Wabash Railroad at the annual meeting in St. Louis, has issued an address to the stockholders concerning the business of the road last year. He speaks of the recent disturbance in the financial and business affairs of the country as follows:

The Kings County Republican County Committee last evening ratitied the action or the Excoutive Committee in naming the dates for the various primaries and district conventions which were fixed last week.

A commission, consisting of Dr. Paul Alien and Lawyer Charles H. Daniels, sat with a Sheriffs jury yesterday afternoon in one of the Supreme Court's chambers in the County Court House to pass upon the disputed sanity of David J. Solomon, at present an inmate of Bloomingdale Asylum.

Mrs. Charlotte L. Polo, a colored woman and a Cuban, living at 304 Adams Street, Brooklyn, 'told a startling story yesterday. If true, the story is ones of the most remarkable in the history of the City of Churches.

The new Municipal Building Commission met in the Mayor's office at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon, listened to the protest of County Clerk Henry D. Purroy against the site selected because it does not provide for the removal of the Tweed Court House, and then made arrangements for an inspection of the plans which have been submitted on the basis of the ground plan favored by all the Commissioners except Mr. Purroy.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 12 -- Frauds of a startling character have been discovered by Pension Examiners Cutler and Sidman here in Baltimore. The Government has been robbed for years by forgeries and other crimes, which have come to light through the present system of delivering pension checks at the Post Office.

PANAMA, Sept. 6 -- The new Governor of Panama, Senor Don Ricardo Arango, was inaugurated last Friday. During the ceremonies at the palace a part of the marble pavement of one of the balconies overhanging the street gave way, precipitating several persons to the cobblestone pavement thirty feet below.

The stockholders of the suspended Madison Square Bank met at the Hoffman House Monday evening and discussed the proposed assessment to make good the impaired capital. Mr. Edward Lauterbach said yesterday that all the stockholders but one were present at the meeting and expressed themselves as willing to be assessed.

The depositors of the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn determined last night to appear against the State Superintendent of Banking, Charles M. Preston, before the Governor and ask for his removal from office.

George W. Beals, T.F. Scanlon, and W.P. Wightman, the Football Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union, have issued the following circular: "The committee having football in charge recommends to the associations ot the Amateur Athletic Union that they should institute a football championship, open only to teams residing within their territory, and whose schedule shall be decided by Nov. 10.

VIENNA, Sept. 13 -- The political situation here became so threatening recently, owing to the troubles growing out of the Czech anti-German agitation in Bohemia, that the Imperial Government, with the sanction of Emperor Francis Joseph, to-day issued a decree ordering the suspension of Articles XII, and XIII, of the constitutional law concerning the rights of the citizens of Prague, the capital of Bohemia.

PERSONALS.-- Mrs. Bottome, the founder and President of the American Circle of King's Daughters, has returned from Newport, where she spoke before several large gatherings of the society. Richard Peters is in town, having come on from Newport. Miss Fannie Jones has been the guest of Mrs. Samuel Coleman at Newport. Mrs. Henry S. Hoyt and Miss Hoyt are in town.

At a meeting of the Board of Education yesterday President Sanger read a communication from the Mayor, announcing the appointment, made some time ago, of James S. Coleman, as Commissioner of Common Schools, in place of William Lummis, resigned.

LEAMINGTON, Ontario, Sept 13 -- The passenger and freight steamer Byron Trerice was burned to the water's edge at 2 o'clock this morning. Three lives were lost and two persons were so badly burned that they may not recover.
Money on call loaned at 3 @ 4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 13 -- The first indication of a revival in the plate-glass industry since the closing of the factories last Spring is shown in the partial resumption of the Charleroi Plate-Glass Works, by which 40 pots have been fired, giving employment to 400 of the 800 workmen. The work furnished will be equally divided among all of the employes as nearly as possible.

COLLEGE POINT, L.L. Sept. 13 -- Witzel's Point View Grove was populated to-day by the Central Democratic Club, the Tammany organization of the Twentieth Assembly District, New-York. The club left its headquarters, at Third Avenue and Sixty-first Street, early in the morning. At its head marched the leader of the district, Thomas J. Dunn. Michael T. O'Briea was Marshal, and bad as aides Cornelius Flynn and Edward Fitzsimmons.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The Executive Committee of the State Citizens' Anti-Race-Track League held a special conference here yesterday afternoon, in the First Presbyterian Church lecture room, to discuss the plans for an aggressive Fall campaign. Tne Rev. Dr. Kempshall, Dean McNulty of Paterson, Major Pangborn of Jersey City, and a number of other prominent crusaders from various parts of the State attended.

The passing of the Lehigh Valley dividend on Tuesday was evidence from an unexpected quarter of the accuracy of all that Mr. Rice has said in his statement to the security holders of the Reading Company concerning the iniquity of the compact through which Reading has been and is operated in the interest of its rivals.

CLEVELAND, Ohio,Sept. 13 -- It was hard work for Cleveland to win from the New-Yorks this afternoon, and yet the game should have been easy, for the Clevelands played much better ball than the visiting team. Petty did not pitch a very good game, and Wilson was weak behind the bat. Attendance, 2,100. Score:

With regard to the new blanket mortgage for $89,000,000, which it is proposed to put on the property of the Southern Pacific Railroad, Mr. Collis P. Huntington, President of the company, said yesterday:
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- A dispatch from Rio Janeiro says that the attack of the rebel fleet on the forts began at 9 o'clock.

Secretary Sullivan of the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday telegraphed from Chicago that all the principal athletes who are to take part in the World's Fair championships were on hand and getting into condition for the test on Saturday. He thinks that the meeting will eclipse anything ever before attempted in this or any other country.

It is to be supposed that everybody understands and accepts the excuses that Mr. ANDREWS has been making for his failure really to clean the streets. There is not enough money left from the year's appropriation, and to exceed the appropriation would be to violate the law. Of course this is not Mr. ANDREWS'S fault.

Mr. Joe Price brought to this office yesterday a relic of the early days of this valley. It is an old-fashioned gun of the style of musket made in 1849. It bears on the lock plate the words "Harper's Ferry, 1849," and also the spread eagle engraved upon it. If this ancient weapon could speak no doubt it would relate many thrilling stories of pioneer days.

A feeling of confidence and hopefulness is spreading steadily throughout all branches of business industry. Its more rapid spread is checked only by the dilatory action of the Senate in settling the silver question.

The New-York Times has received from a person signing "Gratitude" $5, of which $1 is to be put in each of five envelopes, which the giver also incloses, and sent to five sufferers by the recent storms on the southeastern coast.

Much building is now in progress in the district at and above Bleecker Street and near the line of Broadway. Fire-proof modarn business adifices are rapidly supplanting the dwellings and the earlier buildings devoted to trade. Among those projected and under way, some of them nearing completion, are the following:

-- The Kings County Tennis Club expects to make a good snowing at the coming Staten Island tournament. Miss Moore and Miss Helwig will probably enter under the Kings County colors, ana though neither can, hope to down Miss Cahill, they may be counted on for first-class tennis. For the inter-club championship of Kings County, Miss Moore defeated Miss Helwig, the former holder, after a colose match, which gives to Miss Moore the honors.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 13 -- The Queens County Grand Jury, in session here, commenced this afternoon an investigation of the collision on the Long Island Railroad at Berlin on Aug. 26, in which sixteen persons were killed, and many others injured.

We have received from several quarters expressions of hearty approval of our suggestion that arrangements be made for having a "Manhattan Day" at the World's Fair. The various States have their consecrated days, and there are peculiar reasons "why New-York City should appoint a day when it will specially, and more numerously and completely than usual, be represented at the fair.

Nicholas Fish, the eldest son of the late Hamilton Fish, and the present head of the family called upon Mayor Gilroy yesterday to express his own and the family's appreciation of the tributes paid by the municipal authorities to the memory of his father.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- With the prospects of a new trotting record at Washington Park this afternoon a monster crowd, the largest that has ever been at the track except on Derby Day, went to see what Nancy Hanks could do. The famous mare was at het best, but the careless way in which the course had been prepared, along with the showers ot yesterday, proved too much of a handicap for the queen.

The Produce Exchange markets were in- . fluenced by the weakness at the West, together with a general desire to realize by longs, and wheat made a loss of 1/4 @ 7/8 c, while corn fell 5/8 @ 10 bushel, with a fairly active business.

The committee of the Standard Oil Company which was appointed to resolve that trust into its original parts made a report yesterday to certificate holders. It showed that the committee had succeeded in the last year in retiring about 62 per cent. of the trust certificates. The volume of trust certificates represented a par value of $97,250,000, which the committee reported to be worth at a conservative estimate $125,000,000.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The yacht race between the Prince of Wales's Britannia and Mr. Royal Phelpa Carroll's Navahoe, which was started yesterday on a course extending from the Needles to the breakwater at Cherbourg, France, round the breakwater and back to the Needles, a distance of about 120 miles, ended in an as yet indefinite manner.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- The traction stocks were lower at the opening and declined slightly during the day, closing without any rally. New-York has taken, no part in the advance in Metropolitan, and the buying power of Philadelphia is as yet limited. United Gas declined 3 cent on fairly heavy transactions. Pennsylvania was again heavily sold to-day by London, the stock being taken for investment account.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- The market opened quiet and fairly strong. The copper stocks were the features, Boston and Montana making a small gain. Union Pacific and General Electric were weak on the death of F.L. Ames, who is said to have been heavily interested in these securities. The market closed strong at about the highest.
The story that a handsome young wife was held in pawn for 30 rubles on Ellis Island was circulated yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13 -- The first day of the Springfield Bicycle Club's tournament was marked by brilliant racing, a perfect day, and a track as fine as it could be made by carelul-working. Close to 10,000 spectators tilled the grand stand and over flowed around the track fence three deep. Unbounded enthusiasm prevailed throughout the day, reaching its climax when the international race was won.

Of course, the performances of the Navahoe on the other side have been of popular interest on this side, mainly as indications of the result of the coming struggle between the Valkyrie and the Vigilant for the America's Cup. The fact that the Vigilant and the Navahoe were built at the same time and in the same yard has led to the conclusion that one of them cannot be very much better than the other.
Fifty men were seated in the red plush armchairs which line two walls or standing in groups of three and four on the red carpet of a rectangular drawing room at the Broadway Central Hotel.

Julius Lipman, a lawyer with an office at 130 Fulton Street, had a number of callers yesterday who were not clients. Several scores of Italian laborers went down to the Fulton Building yesterday to collect of him money which they claimed was due them for wages. Mr. Lipman convinced a few of his callers that he knew nothing of them or their wages and then he became tired and left the task to the Janitor.

Ex-Chief Justice Richard L. Larremore, who, as a Judge, had been on the bench in New-York for twenty-one years, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 146 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street.

George F. Whitehead, Chief Treasury Agent at the Custom House until last year, and Col. Henry Story, Treasury Inspector, who were rebuked in a report to Secretary Carlisle by the Fairchild Commission now investigating customs methods at this port, sent a written statement yesterday to Washington defending themselves.

The financial situation continued to show improvement yesterday. There were receipts of gold by New-York banks from San Francisco amounting to $137,788. The steamship Yucatan, from Havana, brought $1,170,000 in Mexican silver dollars and Spanish money, consigned to New-York houses. A good part of it came in transit to Paris and London.

Frederick L. Ames, the wealthiest man in Massachusetts, Vice President of the Old Colony Railroad, and also of the Fall River Steamboat Line, was found dead in his stateroom on the Pilgrim, which arrived here from Fall River yesterday morning. Death was caused by apoplexy.

Three wheelmen from the cycling section of the St. George Athletic Club had a very unpleasant experience recently. They were Capt. F.W. Rubien. Lieut. F.H. Myers, and W.G. Rubien, and they were spending their vacation at a farmhouse near Burmingham. They started one day to ride to Burlingham and had none but 300 or 400 yards when they met a farmer driving a heavy wagon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Representative Dates of Alabama to-day introduced a bill to annex the Territory or Utah to the State of Nevada.

A little before noon yesterday a little old man, with a snow-white beard, and a form bent with years, yet showing, withal, much dignity, stepped aboard the revenue steamer Hudson at the Battery Barge Office and sent to the commanding officer his card.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- To those who are impatient of the Senate's delay to pass the Silver-Purchase Repeal bill, the ineffectual effort of Mr. Voorhees to-day to secure an agreement to vote at the end of ten more days of debate may look discouraging. To those here, who have known the difficulties from the first, it was not a surprise that Mr. Dubois should object to any agreement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- As was expected by the Ways and Means Committee when the tariff hearings were announced, the time of the committee has been principally consumed in listening to the requests of manufacturers that they be not divorced from partnership with the Government, which they have found profitable, and under which it seems they have been constantly reducing prices.

The consignees of the Atlas Line steamship Alvo, which has been long overdue at Haitian ports, telegraphed to this port yesterday that they had given her up and believed that she was lost in the great hurricane of Aug. 20. Whether she foundered or has been cast away on some of the many banks and shoais of the Eastern Bahamas is a matter of conjecture.

LIGONIER, Ind., Sept. 13 -- The Lake Shora de- tectives from Elkhart and Toledo, who have been scouring this part of the State for a clue to the express robbers, have about given up the chase. C.C. Needham and another detective from Elkhart have come in from the southern and central parts of the country, and they say there is absolutely no clue.

Bishop Ash of Irasburg, Vt., has taken probably the longest carriage ride of any man in America. Sixteen years ago he left his little Vermont home and drove to Minnesota and thence to Oregon and the Pacific coast. Seven years ago Mr. Ash decided to visit Irasburg once more. He crossed the continent In a covered wagon drawn by Indian ponies, stopping to see the World's Fair.

The wisdom that lurks in the bright brains of the members of the Professional Woman's League might put to blush all the philosophers of this nineteenth century. Miss Clara Thropp yesterday treated the subject of "How to Live." Miss Thropp is a little creature with the blondest of blond heads and the biggest of big theories.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The circular issued yesterday by the National Liberal Federation is virtually an important Ministerial manifesto. The federation has sent to every federated association in the United Kingdom a copy of the manifesto. It says in part:
LONG ISLAND CITY Sept. 13 -- The trolley scored its first death here this afternoon, the victim being Jennie McDermott, the three-yearold daughter of James McDermott of 116 Seventh Street.

It was said yesterday that two detectives had been assigned by District Attorney Nicoll to go to Costa Rica to make an effort to secure the arrest of the absconding embezzler, Francis H. Weeks. It is expected that the papers will be ready so that the detectives can start nest Saturday.

Gov. McKINLEY has opened his campaign in Ohio with a long and elaborate speech devoted entirely to national politics. "There was some surprise," says the Tribuns reporter, "that he made no mention of State affairs." But it is not surprising. So far as we can gather from the papers of Ohio, of both parties, Gov. McKINLEY may well believe of his administration of State affairs, "the less said the better."

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 13 -- The Street gossiped about Mr. Ames's wealth as it always does when a multi-millionaire dies. Everybody felt at perfect liberty to make an estimate, more especially as no one had any responsibility for his guess. The estimates ranged from $25,000,000 to $50,000,000.

NEW-YORK. WEDNESDAY, Sept. 13 -- P.M. There was less activity in the stock market to-day, but on the whole prices were well maintained, with a feeling of greater strength at the close than had been evidenced earlier in the trading. Soon after the opening there was a little yielding to influences seeking lower prices, bat after a slight rally and a second decline the market took on the strength it displayed at the last.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 13 -- Francis Henry Weeks, the embezzler, who is wanted in New-York, has not been arrested. He is under surveillance, however, and Consul Harrison R. Williams, acting under instructions from the State Department in Washingtan, is making every effort to prevent Weeks fleeing from the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A conference was held to-night at Secretary Carlisle's residence regarding the policy of the Government toward the Chinese as enuncisted in the Everett Chinese Exclusion act introduced in the House the other day. There were present Secretaries Carlisle and Gresham, Attorney General Olney, Assistant Secretary Hamlin, and Mr. Geary.

The funeral of the Rev. Edward Corcoran, late pastor of St. Joseph's Church, Brooklyn, was held yesterday morning in the edifice in which he preached for twenty years. The church was crowded with friends and members of his congregation. Vicar General McNamara conducted the services, assisted by Fathers Killahy, Fitzgerald, Vitta, and McGlnn.

The question of the color line in the League of American Wheelman is likely to make a great deal of trouble in the meeting of the national assembly of that organization next February. The Kentucky Division will bring up the question, and will probably be firmly supported by all the other Southern divisions. A scheme it already under way to organize a Southern league in case of unfavorable action on the color-line amendment.

Arthur T. Kenney of the University of Pennsylvania, who won the swimming championships at Chicago on Wednesday, was last year's champion and has a long record of swimming races to his credit. He won tho 100-yard dash in 1:12 1-5, beating T.M. Carey of the Cathedral Athletic Club and George Whittaker, Milwaukee Bowing and Swimming Association.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club, which is an organization of leading professional and business men of the highest standing, and to whom the Democracy does not mean a mere pseudonym for office grabbing, met last night at the Real Estate Exchange, 189 Montague Street.
Mrs. Selena MeMurray charges her husband with having put her out of the way in a lunatic asylum in order that he might live with another woman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Secretary Carlisle has written a letter to Sir John Thompson, the Canadian Premier, calling attention to the hardships, annoyances, and expense that will results from the failure of the two countries to arrive at some agreement as to immigrants landingin Canada destined for the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- There was less doing in wheat to-day and only a moderate business was transacted. The opening was fractionally higher than the closing figures of yeaterday, advanced about 3/8c, then became weak, and alter numerous fluctuations declined 1 1/8c, reacted slightly, and closed about 5/8c lower than yesterday. The speculative offerings were fair and operators were not much inclined to buy, as a further decline was generaily looked for.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept 14 -- The Rev. Patrick Corrigan, pastor of St Mary's Church, who some time ago not only defied, but attacked, Bishop Wiggar, will, though the medium of a New-York newspaper, make to-morrow another sortie on his foe, more poinied and more bitter than any he has yet made.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Secretary Gresham has received the following cable from Minister Thompson at Rio:
Suicide, following an attempt to murder a pretty girl, ended, a romance in humble life in L. Garfunkel's ice cream parlor, 315 Broome Street, last night.

Mme. Albani has explained that temporary taciturnity is the secret of her wonderfully preserved voice. That is to say, that before singing a heavy role at night she hardly speaks a word all day and remains as much as possible alone. Then Mme. Albani wisely makes it a rule never to sing to her friends.

WASHINGTON, Sept 14 -- Surgeon Guiteras, the yellow fever expert at Brunswick, Ga., late this evening telegraphed Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service that another case of yellow fever was discovered to-day near where the Cox child had the disease. This makes the fourth case recently reported and seven since the disease first appeared.

Nobody who has read it is likely to have forgotten our London correspondent's description of the House of Lords as it turned out in unprecedented force to express the disgust of "the landed interest" with the conduct of the ferocious and revolutionary GLADSTONE. Most readers are likely to have reflected that whatever is to be said in favor of the House of Lords in the abstract must be said strictly in the abstract.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 14 -- The market has been dull and drooping, with Metropolitan Traction particularly inclined to be weak. The recent advance of 33 cent. has tempted buyers to realize. Philadelphia and Baltimore Traction shares were steady at fractional declines. United Gas Improvement was weak and declined 1 1/2 cent.
The Irying Place Theatre is again to be the home of German opera, and, in an entirely new dress, will be ready for the public Sept. 30, under the management of Heinrich Conried.

Another failure in the bicycle trade was recorded yesterday when the George R. Bidwell Cycle Company went into the hands of Theron G. Strong as receiver. This concern has for several years been among the best-known in the city. It was among the pioneers in the foundation of bicycle schools, and did a large retail business, handling all the best-known makes of bicycles at the establishment at 306 to 310 West Fifty-fourth Street.

It was Mrs. Rebecca Marco, wife of Julius Marco, a hatter, of 311 Wallabout Street, Brooklyn, who died Wednesday afternoon from the effects, it is believed of poisoned coffee. Five other members of the family were made seriously ill by drinking the coffee. Coroner Creamer and the police of the Sixteenth Precinct are investigating the case.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 -- The market opened firm. Mining stocks were quite active. Union Pacific was weak, selling down 1 1/4. The market closed irregular.

Dr. Salvadore de Mendoi ca, the Brazilian Minister, arrived in town yesterday from the Adirondaeka. He went to the Brunswick Hotel, and gave orders that no cards should be sent to him. His presence in the house was denied by the hotel attaches. He want out during the afternoon and again in the evening. He left at midnight for Washington, accompanied by his son and daughter.

Play for second place in the Orange Athletic Club tennis tournament wag started yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Grove Street. All those defeated by Alexander Mann, the first-prize man, were entitled to compete. This left the second prize open to H. Lee. (fifteen,) T. Sidney Kingman, (scratch,) and C.R. Reynolds, (scratch.) One match was played yesterday, Lee defeating Kingman in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept 14 -- All the evidence in the court-martial cases against Cadets Conrod, Bash, and Seeley, charged with taking "undue advantage of their permits while at Chicago," is now in. Cadet Seeley is to be tried on another charge -- that of committing a breach of parole while under arrest. Young Seeley's father came on from New-York yesterday, and to-day Cadet Seeley forwarded his resignation to the War Department at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept 14 -- If it was not for the game of "bluff" in which the silver Senators are now engaged these gentlemen would find time hanging heavily on their hands. The game is sufficiently fascinating to keep their minds employed and it operates to make some believe that repeal is really further away now than it has been at any time since the war of words began.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept 14 -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day made public their findings in the matter of the collision of a Manhattan Beach train and a Rockaway Beach train on the Montauk Division of the Long Island Railroad at Berlin, Aug. 26, which resulted in the death of fifteen passengers and one employe and the injury of sixteen other passengers.

The untimely and disastrous collapse of a publication which bears the very promising title of "The Eagle and Brooklyn" is a morsel which was discussed yesterday with much relish in clubs and other public places in the City of Churches. Another somewhat similar enterprise, based on like principles and attended by a like catastrophe, is recalied by the assignment of George R. Cornwall, the publisher of the latter volume.

Most of our perfumes come from flowers or are made in imitation of the scents of flowers, so attar of roses, by a common consent, ranks at the head of the list of perfumes. Other preparations from roses, too, hold a high place and have long been esteemed. Rosewater is historic. When Saladin entered Jerusalem in the twelfth century, he had the walls of the Mosque of Omar washed with it.

-- John Swope of Philadelphia, who has begun a suit against Henry Villard, Edwin H. Abbot Charles L. Colby and Colgate Hoyt. charging them with "conspiracy and fraud" as Northern Pacific Directors, is a banker and investor. His New-York lawyer, William F. Randel, says that in this suit he has the backing of $75,000 of Northern Pacific stock and about $1,000,000 of the bonds.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept 14 -- One of the Judges of the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia, R.L. Weatherbe, is suing the Dominion Coal Company, of which he is a shareholder, for breach or contract and fraud. H.M. Whitney of Boston is the promoter and President of the company. In his statement of claim Judge Weatherbe demands specific performance of an alleged contract to purchase from the plaintiff certain coal areas.

Peals of hearty laughter repcatedly punctunted the otherwise solemn inquest into the saniry of David J. Solomon yesterday afternoon. As on Tuesday, the commission and the Sheriff's jury sat in one of the Supreme Court's rooms.

The Democratic Club of Brooklyn appointed a committee last Spring to examine and report on the condition of the public affairs of that city and on the responsibility for it. It consisted of Messrs. A. AUGUSTUS HEALY, GEORGE FOSTER PEABODY, DANIEL MOYNAHAN, and EVERETT GREENE.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept 14 -- State Superintendent of Banks Preston said to-night that he was making a careful investigation into the wrong statement of the "overdraft" item made in the June report to his department of the Brooklyn Commercial Bank, which made a difference of $11,000.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 14 -- Francis Henry Weeks, the New-York absconder, is to-night under guard in the Municipal Palace.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 14 -- The 2:13 pace decided at Mystic to-day averaged faster than any previous harness race in New-England. Bayard Wilkes, a locally-bred side-wheeler, with it great reputation, was backed at even figures against a strong field, and when he won the first heat with seeming case in faster time than his record, the talent fell over each other in their anxiety to lay 5 to 1 on the rapid-gaited Alcaatara (1) pacer.
Money on call loaned at 3@4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept 14 -- Secretary of the Interior Hoke Smith received, this morning a dispatch from Arkansas City, Kan., representing the distressed, condition of the home seekers who await the opening of the Cherokee Strip. It reached the Interior Department at 9 o'clock, and at 11 the Secretary wired a reply that ought to hare given all the relief asked for which it was in his power to extend.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The State Department has not yet heard of the arrest of Weeks, but there is every confidence expressed by the department officials in the good offices of the Cbata Rican authorities to assist the United States in securing possession of the fugitive from justice.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- The bankers of Chicago gave a dinner this evening, at which Controller Eckels was the guest of honor.
-- A semi annual dividend ot 1 cent. on the stock of the Keokuk and Western Railroad has been declared, payable Oct. 10 at the office of Cuyler, Morgan * Co., 44 Pine Street, New-York.

The performance of the American coastwise steamer El Cid in making the passage from New-Orleans to New-York in 4 days 2 hours and 15 minutes was regarded by shipping men here yesterday as little short of phenomenal.

Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., spent most of his time at the Hoffman House yesterday, and will return to Washington this afternoon. There was a rumor daring the day that Senator Murphy, Judge Isaac H. Maynard, and Richard Croker had been in conference.

The first large fashionable wedding of the season took place at noon yesterday at Bellport, L.I., when Miss Sarah Birdsall Otis, daughter of ex-Senator James Otis, became the wife of Frederick Edoy of this city. The ceramony was performed at the Otis home, Near-the-Bay, by the Rev. Dr. William R. Huntingten, rector of Grace Church, this city.

The courts at Tarrytown, N.Y., are just now occupied with the competitors in the open tennis tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Club. The events are men's singles and men's doubles. The matches have been limited to the singles thus far. W.O. Ludlow of the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club, and R.P. Davis of West Point played rather the beat contest up to date, Ludlow winning after the loss of the opening set.

The McBride Brothers of Philadelphia, owners of the steam launch Yankee Doodle, have issued a challenge to race their boat against Mr. Norman L. Munro's yacht, the Norwood, and the Vamoose over a five-mile course on the Hudson River for a sweepstakes of $5,000 each. They wanted the Felseen in, but the accident to that boat last Saturday puts her out of the way for the present.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Sept. 14 -- P.M. The stock market was dull and irregular to-day, with an occasional half-hearted spurt of activity in one or two securities, but at no time with anything approaching general liveliness. From the opening until the news of the declaration of the St. Paul regular dividend in the afternoon there was an especial lack of activity.

The New-York Normal College resumed its sessions yesterday with 600 new pupils and nearly 400 of the old ones. When all those whose names are registered on the college books have returned to their work President Thomas Hunter, L.L. D., will have under his charge over 1,800 young women who are anxious to receive diplomas as teachers.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14 -- The second day of the wheelmen's visit to this place opened under gloomy-looking skies, and many anxious eyes watched the gathering clouds, hoping that the rain would delay until alter the afternoon's sport at Hampden Park was at an end. An hour before the time announced for the start of the races the crowd began to stream toward the gates, taking chances an the weather.

DR. PHILEMON HOMMELL, visiting physician of the Jersey City Hospital, died at his home, 571 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, yesterday morning from hemorrhage of the lungs. He was born in Obernal, Alsace, in July, 1836. He was graduated from the College of Physicians in Paris, but adopted the profession of his lather, who was a noted chemist of his day.

Among those who addressed the Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday were certain manufacturers of plate glass, who asked that the existing rates of duty on plate glass should not be disturbed. These rates are very high. For example, the duty on polished plate glass in sizes larger than two feet by five, is 124 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The adoption by the army of a new magazine rifle, to displace the rifles with which it has been armed for years, is to be followed by the selection of a new arm for the navy.

NEWARK, Ohio, Sept. 14 -- The Democratic campaign in Ohio was opened hero to-day with a large attendance. The Grand Marshal of the day was Judge S.M. Hunter, late candidate for Supreme Judge. The Hon. William Veach, eged eighty, and an honored veteran of Democracy, was President of the meeting.

The United States Dredging Scow No. 5 was on fire shortly after 12:30 A.M. yesterday and about $2,000 damage was done before the flames were put out by the crews of the tugs Charles Runyon and John T. Pratt.

Reading security holders have, no doubt, read with surprise the facts regarding the refusal of the Heading Company to furnish coal to its old and well-established customers in New-York Harhor, whereby the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company (the Jersey Central) was enabled to secure new trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A hot partisan contest has developed in the House over the bill to repeal certain sections of the revised statutes touching Federal elections. It was not unexpected, although the shape that the opposition would assume had not been intimated.
The Home Bank, at Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street, has been robbed of $16,185 in bonds by its cashier, Howard L. Bain.

Mayor Boody, Hugh McLaughlin, and Corporation Counsel Jenks were closeted in the Mayor's office, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Neither of the interested parties would divulge the secrets of the conference, but that it had reference to the approaching Mayoralty nomination and campaign is deemed certain.
LANSINGBURG, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The Lion Factory of the United Shirt and Collar Company and the AEtna Hosiery Mill will start up in full next Monday.

CHATHAM, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The Democratic District Convention for the election of delegates to the State Convention and the transacting of other business was held here this afternoon. C.S. Rogers of Hudson was chosen Chairman. After the matter of a contesting delegation from the town of Germantown was harmoniously disposed of the following delegates were named to the State Convention: C. D. Haines. J.H. Melone of Hudson, Jasper A. Hicks of Gallatin.

In the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday, Mr. James S. McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co. sold, under foreclosure, 206, 208, and 212 West Sixty-ninth Street, south side, between Amsterdam and West End Avenues. The buildings are five-story stone-front flats, with lots each 31.3 by 100.5. The purchaser was Francis M. Breese, at $30,850, $31,050, and $31,150, respectively.

Rio de Janeiro has long been one of the great seaports of South America. Its harbor is famous as being among the finest in the world. It contains over fifty square miles of anchor-age ground, and the entrance is about a mile across. The harbor has always been extolled for its great natural beauty, and many descriptions of its charms have been written by travelers.

District Attorney Nicoll announced yesterday that the absconding embezzler, Francis H.
