Weeks, who was discovered in Costa Rica about the middle of August by the correspondent of The New-York Times, is now under arrest, and that there would be no difficulty in effecting his extradition for the purpose of bringing him to this city to be prosecuted under five indictments found against him by the Grand Jury for the embezzlement of $520,660.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The Regatta Committee of the Royal Yacht Squadron, with which Mr. Carroll filed his protest to-day after considering the subject at much length, finally awarded the victory to the Navahoe.

Cash is rapidly accumulating in the city banks. All opinions agree that the weekly statement of the banks to be issued to-morrow will be exceptionally favorable. Many quarterly dividends which have been declared, or will be declared in the next few days, will release large amounts of money.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 -- The yacht Jubilee, with Gen. Paine on board, dropped anchor off Lawley's dock about noon to-day. Gen. Paine reached his office about 2 o'clock, and consented to talk while he opened his mail.

ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 14 -- The tidings received to-day that the Secretary of the Interior had authorized an increase of the clerical force in the registration booths to any extent that might be necessary was greeted with joy by the hosts of weary homeseekers.
Dr. Henry B. Millard, the eminent medical authority and one of the foremost physicians in this city, died in Paris, France, yesterday, of typhoid fever.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- The tendency of yesterday's market was followed by further declines to-day. Metropolitan Traction gold down to 92 1/2 and Philadelphia to 81 1/4 on light transactions, with a small recovery at the close in both. Baltimore Traction was steady at 16. Electric Hights made a further advance to 12. United Gas Improvement made a further decline to 56 3/4.

Detectives Riley and Von Gerichten sailed yesterday by the steamship Alvino for Port Limon, Costa Rica, on their way to San Jose to take the embezzler Francis H. Weeks into custody and brine him back to this city.

Bradstreet's to-morrow will say: "The starting up of idle manufacturing industries has not been as conspicuous this weak as last, and in most instances has been with reduced forces and on part time. The stimulated demand for staples at prominent cities in the Ohio and Mississippi River Valleys remains the feature of the business week.

CALUMET, Mich, Sept. 15 -- The passenger train on the Mineral Range Railroad coming to Calumet was stopped by four highwaymen at Boston, about half way between Calumet and Hancock, at 9:30 o'clock this morning. The engineer and fireman were covered with revolvers by two of the robbers, while the other two ordered the express messenger to put the contents of his safe in a bag.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- There is a ghost in Washington that will not down. It is the skeleton of Charles Guiteau, which mops and mows and gibbers in several different places.

The death is announced in Paris of Jules Franceschi, the sculptor of "Le Revell," "La Foi," "Andromede," "La Mort du Commandant Baroche an Bourget," and other famous statues of France. He was born at Bar-sur-Aube in 1825. His parents were Italian. His teacher was Rude. He won his first medals at the Salons of 1848 and 1849, and was appointed a Knight of the Legion of Honor in 1874.

David J. Solomon, manufacturer of neckties, had to undergo a severe ordeal yesterday afternoon in the County Court House as be heard four medical specialists testify under oath that be was suffering from the first stage of general parcesis, a disease rarely curable even in its premonitory stage.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- The market opened quiet and about the same as last night's closing. Mexican Central 4s were strong, owing, it is believed, to London demand. The mariet closed quiet and steady.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Acting Mint Director Preston this morning confirmed the statement that an examination of the vaults in the Philadelphia Mint had disclosed a shortage of more than 5,000 ounces in gold bullion, valued at $134,000.

A rather good-looking young man, with pleasant manner and courteous mien, became cashier of the Lotos Club about June 12 last His name was Henry E. Malway. He came from the Vaudeville Club. Prior to his employment at the Vaudeville he had been employed at the Union League Club as an accountant.
CARROLLTON Ala., Sept. 15 -- A masked mob broke open the Jail here last night and shot to deals Paul Hill, Polk Archer, Will Archer, and Emma Fair, charged with burning J.E. Woods gin and mill.

ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 15 -- Everything that has life along the border of the Cherokoe Outlet is moving to-day. Final preparations for the big race are being made, and starters are scrambling for a chance to make their entries.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Chiefly through an utter disregard of the rules, there was another postponement of the sensational race for the purse of $15,000 at Washington Park to-day. Four heats were finished yesterday, divided-between Alixand Hulda, and instead, of calling the free-for-all trotters early this afternoon, two other classes were started before it was resumed.

Senator Thomas Cunningham, who was elected this year to represant the old Ninth Senatorial District in place of the late Senator Edward. F. Hagan, has returned from the mountains improved in health. He has returned with his mind fully made up not to run again for Senator, but to retire from politics so far as office holding is concerned.

Edward M. Shepard is again seriously devoting his pen to showing up the weaknesses of Mayor Boody. Yesterday he published another open letter to the Mayor, and before he subscribes himself "always and very truly yours," he says among other things:

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 15 -- The speed trial of the new gunboat Castine was a signal triumph for her builders. Her sister boat, the Machias, made a record speed trial of 15.17 knots, (corrected, 15.464.) The Castine made 16.42 knots, and the corrected time will be made known to-morrow. Fifteen and a quarter knots would represent a bonus of $55,000 to her builders.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Sept. 15 -- P.M. Lower prices ruled in the Stock Exchange to-day. Business was light, transactions hardly exceeding, 148,000 shares. Not only in the volume of the trading, but also in its general movements, to-day's market closely resembled that of yesterday, except that at times there were spurts of greater activity than was shown at any time on Thursday.

At the meeting of the Board of Street Opening and Improvement yesterday it was decided that the city and property owners benefited should share equally the expense of the widening of Elm Street. The work is estimated to cost $2,900,000. Mayor Gilroy suggested that the city should share the expense, as the whole city would, be benefited by the improvement.

The report of Mr. ANDREWS, the Commissioner of Street Cleaning, confirms the hopes of improvement in the condition of the streets that were raised by his appointment. He was known as a man of intelligence, character, and energy, and these are the qualities that are primarily needed in his place.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The Democratic County Convention to-day named T.F. Conway, James Averill, and J.P. Cuuniugham delegates to the State Convention. A resolution indorsing the National Administration was unanimously adopted, and a resolution indorsing the State administration and condemning the machine was also carried with a whirl, despite the foot that Gov. Flower's name was not mentioned, and a request to insert voted down.

Although it is reported that Angnstin Daly contemplates erecting a large and expensive theatre on Fifth Avenue, nothing definite has been done in the matter. It is admitted that Mr. Daly has received overtures from capitalists who would use the prestige of his name for such an enterprise, but it is stated positively that no definite action has been taken.
Normon L. Munro sends the following open letter to The New-York Times: To Expert Engineers, to the Herreshoffs, to Mr. William R. Heart of California, and to a Doubting Public:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The summonses sent out yesterday to members of the House to call them back to their places did not roach them in time to bring a working majority of Democrats to the House to-day, and the result was that the effort of Mr. Tucker (Dem., Va.,) to secure the order for consideration of the Federal Elections bill did not prevail.

CONEY, ISLAND, Sept. 15 -- There was a very interesting and remarkable test to-day on the short section of electric railroad here, where the system of underground conduits for electric propulsion invented by Granville T. Woods, the colored electrician of Brooklyn and Cincinnati, is being experimented with. The system consists of a conduit, in which are placed at regular intervals hermetically-sealed and watertight boxes, from which project contact points at each aide of the slot.

Mr. Harris has at length found time to draft what his friends choose to call a reply to the charges made against hts management of the Reading Company. He puts all he has to say in a few short paragraphs, and this so-called defense is published in The Daily Philadelphia Stockholder, from which The Times reproduces it in full.

In a report submitted to Mayor Gilroy yesterday Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews states what in his judgment, is necessary for the equipment of his department in order that it may effectively do the work which it is expected to do.

CHICAGO, Sept 15 -- Notice was given to-day by the Southern Pacific Road of its intention to make a redaction of $15 in one way and round trip first-class passenger rates from Southern California points to the Missouri River via El Paso and Fort Worth. These rates will become effective Monday next. They will not apply from San Francisco or through the Ogden Gateway.

If the proposition of Senator FAULKNER of Virginia were offered after the passage of the Wilson Repeal bill, when it could be carefully and thoroughly discussed without delaying the one piece of legislation for which the whole country is waiting, it would he remarkable from the point of view of the silver men.

Nineteen horses of James K. and Foxhall P. Keene were sold at auction at Gravesend yesterday by a representative of Tattersalls. It is the intention of the Messrs, Keene to have none but the best class of horses in their stable, and a weeding-out sale like the one yesterday will be held annually.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union of Kings County held a meeting last evening in the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn, and adopted an address to the people of that city urging them to throw off ring rule and elect men to office this Fall who will administer the affairs of the city honestly and without regard to partisan advantage.

The Home Bank is not the only loser through the embezzling operations of Howard L. Bain, its trusted cashier. It was learned yesterday that Cashier Bain took from the bank safe $5,500, in gilt-edged securities, belonging to Director George Ketcham.

The five-story building at 143 Duane Street, owned by the Colgate estate, was almost destroyed by fire yesterday morning. It was the second large fire in the building within ten hours. The H.B. Claflin Company's Warehouse N. at 68 Thomas Street, which contains many thousand dollars' worth of stock, was threatened.

Mrs. Ernest Hart, patroness of the Donegal Castle in the Irish Village at the World's Fair, has been a guest at the Victoria Hotel for several days. She visited Washington last week and told the House Committee on Ways and Means why the tariff should be taken off woolen stuffs, Knitted goods, linens, and laces, and explained how the work in these Industries had been carried on under toe auspices of toe Donegal Industrial Fund.

On and after Oct. 2 the Central Trust company will distribute its certificates of equitable interest in the certificates of indebtedness of the People's Gas Light and Coke Company of Chicago, issued for the payment of a dividend of 1 1/2 per cent. Books close Sept. 21 and reopen Oct. 3.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Powell Smith Co.'s cigar factory, which has boon run with a greatly reduced force nearly all Summer, will pat on the full force of over 800 hands next week. The Fall business promises to be brisk, and many large orders have already boon received. Most of the employed are girls.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- Messrs. C.A. Haviland, J.M. Lyle, Richard Drant, Samuel Peden, L. Wauke, and David T. Lynch, a committee representing the depositors of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, waited on Attorney General Rosendale this afternoon to urge that an associate receiver be appointed.

MARSHFIELD, Wis., Sept. 15 -- This city is in a panic on account of forest fires. Many families in the surrounding districts have been burned out and children are reported missing. The Fire Department was out till late at night fightlng fires inside the limits. Farmers from the surrounding country came in wagonloads for refuge in the city, many having been burned out completely.
Money on call loaned at 3 @ 4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick Z. Rooker of Albany arrived in this city on the White Star steamer Britannic yesterday morning, bearing important dispatches from Pope Leo XIII. to his representative in the United States, Mgr. Francis Satolli, D.D.

The Valkyrie did not reach this port yesterday. Last night she ended her twenty-third day since she sailed from Southampton, when she was last seen. Seafaring men say that the yacht is now due, but they will not be surprised if she does not make her appearance for several days yet. The chances of the first cup race being sailed on the 28th are getting slimmer every day the challenging yacht is out.
William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn returned from Europe on the Britannic yesterday, and his coming was entirely unexpected, not only by his political friends, bat even by his business partners.
The United States cruiser Baltimore, it is announced by her officers, will sail to-day from this port for the China station to relieve the flagship Lancaster.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept 15 -- The attendance at the State Fair was rather light to-day owing to threatening weather, bat to-morrow promises to be a record day. Gov. Flower and some militia will be here, and in the morning there will be a special programme for women. Mrs. Ella A. Boole, A.M., of Long Island, an official of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, and Mrs. Mary A. Bagg will deliver addresses.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- There was nothing doing in the markets to-day. Louisville and St. Paul opened 50 cents under parities. Trades in other Americans were featureless.

In his addresses to the voters of Ohio Gov. McKINLEY asks them to believe that the tariff duties are paid by the foreign manufacturers whose goods are imported into this country. The absurdity of this doctrine can be shown in many ways. For example, the duties on certain classes of imported goods are more than 100 per cent.; that is to say, the duties paid exceed the entire value of the goods.

Mr. Hudson here has ceased for the time being to make records of South American travel. While on the River Plate or journeying over the Patagonian plains we have found him a most interesting and original guide and philosopher as well as friend. That Patagonian book of his contained more things worth reading than any book of travel we had for a long time read.

MADISON, Conn., Sept 16 -- Madison had a god, lost it, found it this week, and is happy again. The god is a roughly-hewn, corpulent stone image, dark with age and exposure, which, there is little doubt, was fashioned by the powerful red man, who probably worshipped it.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 -- There are two changes in the Faculty in Trinity College this year. Prof. Ferguson has gone to Europe for a year's study, and his chair as instructor in history and political science will be taken by Greenough White, a graduate of Harvard University and a son of J. Gardiner White, Trinity, '54.

The Winter crepons will seem to many women the most attractive of the infinite variety of new dress fabrics offered. They are so light and soft, and will shed the dust so thoroughly from their wiry surface, that they would be extremely desirable, even without the peculiarity which makes them specially notable, that of beauty of coloring.

Minnie Meyer, a seventy-three-year-old thief, was releasnd from the Kings County Penitentiary yesterday attar having served a six mouths' sentence. As she walked out of the prison she found Detective Price of the Central Office squad and Constable Warsinger or Linden, N.J., waiting for her, she being wanted in Linden for several larcenies.

Jefferson Davis was once a Lieutenant in the Sixth United States Infantry. In 1832 the first regiment of United States dragoons was organized. Mr. Davis was always a fine horseman, and preferred the mounted service, so he was transferred from the infantry to the cavalry. He was soon made Adjutant of the regiment, and there served nutil he left the army.

The plot of the new comic opera "Peterkin," which has just been brought out at the Royalty Theatre in London, is laid in a Kentish village near the coast early in the present century, during the expected invasion of Napoleon, and centres around the ludicrous personage who bears the title role.

The performance of the Casting on her trial trip will in all probability not be estimated at its true value by the general publie. In fact, the general public has a very hazy idea in regard to the speed of our war ships. This haziness comes from the industriously-circulated misinformation about the speed capacity of certain steamboats with which we are all familiar.

NAZARETH, Penn., Sept. 16 -- The Moravian Historical Society holds its annual vesper in the Ephrata House here next Tuesday, and every one interested is cordially welcomed. Besides holding a regular old-fashioned Moravian vesper, several interesting papers will be read. The valuable historical museum in the Whitfield House is thrown open to strangers.
CITY OF MEXICO, Sept 16 -- Congress began its Autumn session this evening, and the proceeding are likely to be important and interesting.
LOWELL, Mass., Sept 16 -- On Monday next the Lawrence Company's mills in this city will resume on fall time. They have been running three days a week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The market for wheat to-day was stronger, with some activity, although the abort session had the effect of restricting trade to some extent. The opening was 1/4 @ 3/4 higher, and prices were advanced 3/4 c more, then eased off and declined 3/4 c, held steady, and the closing was about 7/6 c higher for December and 3 /4 c higher for May than the closing figures of yesterday.

The English military tournament, now entering upon the second week of its run at Madison Square Garden, has been one of the best patronized exhibitions given in the Garden since last year's horse show. "Tommy Atkins" is seen at his best in the tournament, for only the cream of the English soldiery was selected to make the trip to this country to exhibit at the World's Fair.

Late foreign advices give additional data concerning the recent performance of the Krnka-Hebler tubular projectiles. Former performances of the Krnka-Hebler projectiles have been cited in the columns of The NewYork Times. Prof. Hebler now gives tables of ballistic data of the 11 millimetre German rifle, pattern 1871, and of the 7.9 millimetre rifle, pattern 1888.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 16 -- News has been received here of the death in St. Paul, Minn., of Luther Foster, and the news recalls a tragedy that was a famous one in this section. Arthur and Luther Foster were twin brothers, and both attended Phillips Academy in Andever. They were working their way through the academy and intended to complete a collegiate course.

We do not conceal from ourselves the unpleasant truth that the repeal bill in the Senate is in a bad situation and that the situation is not growing better. Congress met on the 7th of August, the Wilson bill passed the House on the 28th of August, and was at once sent to the Senate. Meanwhile debate had already begun in the Senate on Aug. 22.

B.F. Keith's Union Square Theatre will be opened to-morrow at noon as a "continuous-performance" house. Mr. Keith and Manager Albee, who has supervised the elaborate reconstruction of the theatre during the past three months, promise an agreeable surprise for those who visit the theatre.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The race for the Cape May Cup between the American yacht Navahoe and the British cutter Britannia ended this afternoon.

-- The fighting lawyer of Maine lives at Lewistown and is appropriately named Bunker. At the Ellsworth Fair he distinguished himself by wrestling with and throwing a nine-hundred-pound bull. The next day he cleared a seven-foot fence at a bound, stopped a runaway horse with one hand, and rescued two ladies from danger.

Reading security holders have been so much mystified by the astounding figures and estimates put forth by the management from time to time that a little more information as to that subject may prove instructive. It will simply go further to prove the designs of the present management to use the road for their own purposes and to "work" the figures into that line irrespective of what they may actually be.

The writing of verse is excellent practice for a young person who proposes to earn a living, and incidentally to gain undying fame, with his pen. It increases his facility and enlarges his vocabulary. As a general thing, the better the verse the better the prose of a writer. But it does not follow that the verse ought to be published, or spoken, in public.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Gov. Flower stood for half an hour without cover of any kind in a pouring rain this afternoon at the State fair and reviewed 1,500 militiamen from various parts of the State.

The Christian Brothers will open their new college near Dobbs Ferry this week. Two years ago they bought an estate beside the home of David Dudley Field, with the intention of transferring there the institution which stands on the Western Boulevard and which has long been too small for their needs.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- An accident occurred to-day on the Great Western Railway. The scene of the accident was in a tunnel near Bath, twelve miles southeast of Bristol. An express train from Bristol to London was running at a high rate of speed through the tunnel, when one of the coaches was through some unknown cause thrown from the track, dragging the coaches behind it off the rails.

-- An offset to the Imperial Institute of London, with its attendant boom of colonial products, has been devised in Paris as a means to encourage the colonies of France. The idea has taken a more artistic, less practical, turn than the English movement. At the Palais de l'Industrie, where the old Salon reigns in Summer, galleries have been prepared to show the fine art of the Moslems.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Another down-town theatre, the Schiller, ended an all-Summer's engagement with to-night's performance Belasco and Fyles's military drama, "The Girl I Left Behind Me," completed a sixteen weeks' run, the last ten weeks of which have been played to packed houses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The torpedo boats which are being built at the New-York and Norfolk Navy Yards for the battle ships Maine and Texas are soon to be ready for their trials, and as they are the first of the kind attempted in his country much interest is attached to their performance by the department.
ARKANSAS CITY, Ark., Sept. 16 -- At 12 o'clock to-day the bars that have so long inclosed 6,000,000 acres of public land were let down and over 100,000 men and women joined in the mad rush for land.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Treasury Department has made public the facts in relation to the reported loss of gold bullion from the Mint at Philadelphia, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Bernhard Weinberger of 225 East Tenth Street, the east side banker, whose offices la Essex, Grand, and Houston Streets, New York, were lately closed, attempted suicide last evening by inhaling gas. He came here two days ago and registered at the Mount Vernon Hotel as Fred Klein of Brooklyn, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept 16 -- The disclosures in the recent Atlanta scandal have brought about more stringent regulations for the government of officers who are charged with inspecting water-tight compartments, and hereafter the department will see that they are implicitly obeyed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Sherman act was a compromise that had no element of permanence. The urgency is great, and it should be repealed at once. But let us consider how to supply its place by a system that will make permanent provision for the financial requirements of American inter-State and foreign commerce.

Military business is beginning to look up. During the week many of the National Guard armories presented scenes of activity not equaled before in months. The coming season promises to be an unusually busy one, in which the guardsmen will have plenty of hard work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Rio is in danger of another bombardment by the revolutionary fleet, according to a dispatch received by Secretary Gresham from Minister Thompson. The dispatch is dated yesterday at Petropolis, four miles below Rio, and reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The officials of the Navy Department are disposed to treat lightly the statement of the three sailors reported in The New-York Times that bad treatment at the hands of the ensigns and younger officers on board the flagship Chicago in English waters caused them to desert and return home by the first steamer.

Mr. Charles T. Dazey is the author of a new play and the discoverer of a new type of soubrette. His play is called "In Old Kentucky." Mr. Dazey is a Kentuckian and a Harvard, graduate, and has dabbled in play writing before with some success. In the dim past he furnished Maggie Mitchell and the ever-youthful Katie Putnam with vehicles in which they could disport themselves.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 16 -- To-day being the seventieth anniversary of Central America's independence -- "the throwing off of the Spanish yoke" is the phrase almost invariably used here -- President Jose J. Rodriguez of Costa Rica signalizes the occasion by issuing a decreto national re-establishing the personal guarantee of habeas corpus and extending amnesty to political exiles.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 16 -- It has been a Bay and festive week in Lenox. The cottagers have had entertainments morning, afternoon, and evening, including tennis tournament, dinners, and large balls. There Beams to be no end to the number and variety. It may be said that the season is at its height, but its continuance depends very much on the weather.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- The seventh annual report on manufacturing statistics in Massachusetts has just appeared. In 1891 the total capital invested in 4,473 establishments engaged in 75 classified industries was $431,691,711; in 1892 it was $445,405,459, making an increase of 3.18 per cent. The increase in valuation of the stock used in 1892 over that of the previous year was 4.52 per cent. while the increase of goods made was 5.37 per cent.

There were more excitement and noise in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday than ever before in the history of the place. Julia McIntyre, a young and good-looking Irish woman, was the cause of the disturbance, and sue acted like a maniac.

After a rise in the leading stocks of from ten to twenty points, the market has halted and begun to recede. Independent of other considerations, a rise as large as that would in itself justify expectations of a reaction, simply because the people who brought it about would want to turn such a goodly show of paper profits into cash.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- It has seemed this week as though Boston was going to the theatre as it never did before. Business has simply been great at half the houses and poor at none. But the week has been more than ordinarily prolific with novelties. Of these was the first production anywhere of Rice's "Venus," at the Park on Monday night.

The list of sales of real estate at auction for the present week includes mainly property to be cold by order of court in foreclosure proceedings. Two of Tuesday's sales, those of Messrs. Smyth Ryan, and one on Saturday, that of Mr. James L. Wells, are the exceptions. All sales scheduled will take place in the Trinity Building Salesroom at 111 Broadway unless otherwise stated.

An advance of about 3 cents a bushel in the price of wheat last week did not diminish the quantity exported. Indeed, the shipments were larger by 450,000 bushels than those of the preceding week, and the total for the eleven weeks of the new fiscal year is more than 54,000,000 bushels. We publish below the exact figures, with those for the corresponding weeks of the last three years:
The weekly bank statement, issued to-day, allows an increase in reserve of $7,635,325. The banks are now $10,601,700 above legal requirements.

By a vote of 7 to 2 the Board of Officers of the Methodist Episcopal Church of Windsor Terrace, Flatbush, L.I., has disbanded the Sunday school and deposed four teachers from their duties in it. The entire church is in a state of disruption in consequence.

-- A new feature of the vaudeville programme at Koster Bial's this week will be the first appearance in America of Miss Harriett Vernon, who enjoys the distinction of being "the handsomest woman on the London vaudeville stage," and who is said to occupy the same position there that Lillian Russell does in comic opera in this country.

Among the passengers for Europe on the Steamship La Gascogne yesterday were Capt. Victor McConcas of the Santa Maria, Col. Agapeef, Signor Feillet, Governor of St. Pierre; Dr. R.W. Kent, the Rev. H.C. Meyer, Count Pappenheim, and Henry Van Schalck.

The petition of the parishioners of Epiphany Church to Mgr. Satolli, the Papal Delegate, for the return of their old pastor, the Rev. Dr. Burtsell, has come to nothing. Dr. Burtsell will remain in Rondout for the present.

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Everything but good weather favored the race meet here this afternoon of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. The races were spirited, the finishes close, the field large, and the spectators were in a very enthusiastic mood. Sanger, Taylor, Banker, Dirnberger, and Johnson all entered in different races, but only Johnson put in an appearance.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 16 -- Almost helpless, but by no means hopeless, this beautiful city of the West is to-day trying to rise above a calamity which has made it unique among cities. A year ago Milwaukee was in the full tide of prosperity. Its bank vaults were overflowing and every kind of business was returning many fold the investments made.

The bank statement given out yesterday was favorable beyond expectation. The increase of $7,635,325 in the reserve, raising the surplus to the very respectable figure of $10,610,700 above the 25 per cent. required by law is a long stop toward the realization of the conditions which THE TIMES some months ago pointed out would prevail after the disappearance of the panic feeling.

STUTTGART, Sept. 16 -- A banquet was given in the palace last night by King William of Wurtemberg in honor of Emperor William, who had been present during the day at the manoeuvres of the Thirteenth Army Corps. In responding to a toast offered him by the King, the Emperor referred to the Wurtemberg Corps (the Thirteenth) as the flower of all the German Army.

Last week among real estate men was mainly one of preparation. Inquiries for Belling and Tenting, especially the latter, were quite numerous very nearly all over the city. Renting is progressing fairly well, and collectors of rent in moat instances report no unusual difficulties or delays in their collections. As a result, rates are quite stiff, and there is no disposition on the part of landlords or agents to make concessions.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 16 -- Some weeks ago the business affairs of Keene Brothers, large shoe manufacturers of Lynn, went into the hands of assignees. The executive head of the firm, William G.S. Keene, was found drowned at Nahant, and the finances of the concern were in such a state that this action was necessary. The assignees repotted at a meeting of creditors to-day.

From London comes the tale that "David Balfour," there published under the name of "Catriona," for which we confess a fondness, is "the book of the year." That is well, but not enough, for the book or the picture "of the year" is not necessarily the best book or picture produced in the year. It is merely the one most talked about.

The leading question among clubmen during the past week has been about the future of the Vaudeville Club. Members of the club have been reticent in speaking of the ill feeling caused by the increase in the dues. Several members of the club said they did not want to talk of the matter, but one member went so far as to say that he believed "the Vaudeville Club had no future."

It has been given, out by those who are admitted to an acquaintance with Mayor Boody's variable intentions that his first impulse in the matter of the report made to the Brooklyn Democratic Club by its committee of inquiry into the conduct of city affairs was to pay no attention whatever to it. But his advisers took occasion to impress upon him that he could not afford even to feign indifference.

A woman, lately returned from Brazil, tells of the curious nomenclature of the streets of Para. They are biblical or commemorative of some event in the Brazilian history. It seemed to her quite irreverent to be told that a desirable locality was "at the corner of St. John the Baptist and St. John the Evangelist Streets."

-- As Baltimore and Ohio Freight Train No. 71 was coming down the heavy grade yesterday near Foley, a small station west of Cumberland, Md., on the Pittsburg Division of the Baltimore and Ohio. it broke in two. The front of the train was stopped too soon by the engineer, the rear section crashing into it, throwing nine oars down an embankment. No one was injured.

-- A Sagadahoc historian has been hunting up the records in order to ascertain the correct spelling of the same of a famous Brunswick resort. The name is generally supposed to be "Mare," meaning "Sea," Point, and in the records of the General Court of Massachusetts in the act of incorporation of Brunswick this is the spelling; but in the Brunswick town records in the copy of the act of incorporation the name is Mair.

The new up-town dry goods store of Wechsler McNulty, at Fulton Street and Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was opened last evening to a few friends for inspection. The movement of Mr. Wechsler and Col. McNulty in establishing a retail store of large proportions so far from the shopping centre is an innovation on their part that has created much envy among the large retail dry goods dealers of Brooklyn.

A number of invited guests went to the parklike expanse called Kenslco Cemetery yesterday to see the new reception tomb just completed, and incidentally to see what great progress had been made in laying out the green lawns and swelling slopes to which the broad pasture lands have been transformed.

HARTFORD, Sept. 16 -- When the Nutmeg voter approaches the polls at the "little (town) elections" in October, he may fancy that it is a slice of the American flag, or a patch Off "Brother Jonathan's" starry trousers, instead of an ordinary ballot that the State of Connecticut has provided for him to vote.

Four boys, the oldest fifteen, found $2,000 in gold, silver, and bills in Lexington Avenue, near Eighty-fifth Street, last Monday night. Three of the boys, accompanied, by worried and tearful mothers, appeared in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning.

The "return of the natives," as a glib young woman happily styled the crowds of travelers flocking cityward, is an interesting study. Humanity en masse is always interesting, but never more so than when in a state of transition as well. In a boat or train the same types are gathered -- locomotion on water gets together no different species than such as slip along homeward on wheels.

A very worthy gathering of songs is this little volume of Charles G.D. Roberts. The first half of the book is made up of sonnets, which celebrate the humbler features of every-day life in the country. The author's success in seizing upon the picturesque aspects of familiar and even commonplace scenes and touching them with the high light of a loving and gentle fancy demonstrates his fitness to hold a poet's pen.

Tracks and porters have been busy during the last few days carrying enormous quantities of men's and boy's clothing into the spacious ground floor of the new cable house at Broadway and Houston Street, which will be opaned next Thursday by William Vogel Son for the sale of every thing required in a masculine wardrobe.

The New-Jersey Athletic Club would have suffered a defeat in their league championship game at Bergen Point yesterday but for the intervention of time. The Brooklyns batted up in fine style against them, and would certainly have gained a victory, as the New-Jerseys required 45 runs to save them from defeat and had only two wickets to fall.

COLBY, Wis., Sept. 16 -- This city had a serious time with fire since Thursday noon, the wind blowing a gale and driving forest fires at a fearful rate up to the city limits. By hard work the town has been saved, and is now practically out of danger. There are many reports of losses to farmers in this vicinity, and full reports will snow bad results.

NEW-YORK. SATURDAY, Sept. 16 -- P.M. There was very little doing on the Stock Exchange to-day, and such trading as there was was entirely professional. The total transactions were only 68,800 shares, of which nearly one-quarter was in one stock -- Sugar -- in which the business reached 16,715 shares.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- The State Firemen's Association will hold its convention at Lambertville, Sept. 27, and action will be taken toward so amending the laws regulating the Relief Fund Association that the accumulating funds can be used in the interest of small cities and towns. The law now requires that the funds shall only be used to assist firemen who acquired their disability in actual service.

The Department of Assistance Publique in the government of the City of Paris has, for cases of extreme poverty, an annual budget amounting to 50,000,000f. Parliament, the General Council of the Seine, and the Municipal Council of Paris make every year additional appropriations for the same purpose.

Justice Bartlett, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday denied the application of David E. Gibbs for a writ of certiorai against the Excise Board directing a review of the action of the board refusing to grant a license for Gibbs's saloon, 320 Myrtle Avenue, opposite Washington Park.

MILLBROOK, Duchess Connty, N.Y., Sept 16. -- It was a happy inspiration that induced Mr. and Mrs. H.J. Davison, Jr., or New-York to build tbelr beautiful Halcyon Hall in this land of fertile valleys and towering hills, carpeted with luxuriant green. It is a country specially favored by nature, with a clear, sweet atmosphere, brimful of tonic qualities, and superbly picturesque scenery as far-reaching as it is varied.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- When the sun beats fiercely upon the Capitol and the temperature in the two houses of Congress is high, thoughtless persons having in mind the appropriation made last year for improving the sanitary condition of the Capitol are apt to denounce the work as imperfect and make all sorts of assertions about the alleged unhealthiness of the building.

Four schooners raced for the silver cap given by the Larchmont Yacht Club yesterday. They furnished a grand contest. The cup is worth $500, and the trophy was won by Mr. J.E. Brooks's schooner Lasca. They started in a fair sailing breeze, but later on a squall struck the yachts, and they had all the wind they wanted.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 16 -- Capt. James L. Burriss, owner and commander of the dredgeboat Eclipse, met a terrible death on Bayou Lafourche yesterday afternoon. On the boat is a largo number of cogwheels governing the dredge. To increase the friction, Capt. Burriss entered the box to throw resin on the machinery.

Fall fabrics and Fall gowns are attracting throngs of buyers to the great store of Stern Brothers on West Twenty-third Street, one of the very liveliest business places in the city. On the counters are displayed goods calculated in material and variety to attract fair Fall shoppers, and in the suit, cloak, and other departments are displays of charming gowns and wraps.

WESTCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Old. St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Parish, in the pretty suburban township of Westchester, Westchester County, will have completed the second, century of its existence next Thursday. With perhaps, a single exception. St. Peter's is believed to be the most ancient pariah of its denomination in the land.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- The main topic of conversation here this week has been the court-martial and resignation of Cadet Seeley. The trials of Cadets Conrad and Bash attracted little attention, as the general feeling, especially in Conrad's case, was that they would be acquitted. Cadet Conrad is very popular, and it was his first offense.
Howard L. Bain, the defaulting cashier of the Home Bank, at Eighth Avenne and Forty-second Street, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday and held for trial in $10,000 bail.
"The Rainmaker of Syria," comic opera by Sydney Rosenfeld and Rudolph Aronson, will be produced in Buffalo to-morrow night. It will be brought to the Casino, in this city. Sept. 25.

The tug Talisman, one of the best-known towboats in the harbor, was cut is two by the oil-tank steamship Delaware yesterday morning in the Gedney Channel Capt. Charles Winnett, the master and owner of the tug, had an arm broken, and the fireman, Fred Freeman, was drowned. The tug sank immediately after the collision, and the crew was rescued with some difficulty.

Copyrighted. 1802, l>y The New. York Tlmna. LONDON, Sept 16 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Even if nothing immediate comes of it, the Autumn of 1893 will be long remembered for the culmination of this strange modern practice of turning whole districts of Europe into dramatic arenas wherein to rehearse vast and impressive imitations of actual war.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Sebastian B. Smith, pastor of St. Joseph's Church, this city, yesterday notified his assistant, the Rev. Henry Murphy, that his services were no longer required in the parish. The latter, having no knowledge or the cause of the pastor's action, left here to-day for Newark to consult Bishop Wigger.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 16 -- The new fourth class of the Naval Academy, now on board the Santee, has eighty-eight members, and under the strict, regular, and incessant drills the class begins already to have a military bearing. Thirty-four members were admitted in the May and fifty-four in the September examinations.

NORTH EASTON, Mass., Sept. 16 -- The funeral of Frederick Lothrop Ames took place to-day. At 12 o'clock the immediate friends of the family gathered at the Ames residence, where prayer was offered by the Rev. William L. Chaffin, pastor of Unity Church, of which deceased was an attendant.

The return of the Summer wanderer brings back really only a portion of the city's residents. There are many who linger for the Autumn spectacle, many more who would if possible, and not a few who, finding only one absence possible, deliberately make the choice of the later season, and, summering in town, turn their backs upon the wilderness of brick and mortar for a month from the middle of September.

Lawyer Van Vechten appeared before Judge Cullen in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, and moved for a change of venue in the case of ex-Mayor Patrick J. Gleason of Long Island City, charged with defrauding the city. Gleason wants his case transferred from Queens to Kings County.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 16 -- James P. Cooke, A.H. Gay, H.L. Laws, John Foos, W.P. Miles, S.L. Knapp, John Dymond, and Dr. W.C. Stubbs left this afternoon for Washington, where they will be joined by ex-Gov. H.C. Warmoth, State Senator Henry McCall, and B.A. Oxnard. They will appear on the 19th inst. before the Ways and Means Committee as representatives of the Louisiana Sugar Planters' Association in defense of Louisiana's most important product.

On board the French steamship La Touraine, which arrived yesterday, was the labor delegation of the City of Paris to the World's Fair in Chicago. There are thirty-four members in the delegation, and their duties are somewhat more extensive than the duties of the French National Labor delegates who arrived last week, for they will study also the political tendencies of the labor organizations in this country.

No doubt the future historian of American literature will be forced to undertake the task of classifying the dialects which fell sore upon the land near the end of the nineteenth century. Perhaps he will find that there 13 Some defense to be offered for their existence; he may even indite a chapter called "The Necessity of Dialect.''

The Twentieth Street Police Station was called upon last night to accommodate eight bicycle riders, for some time past Capt. Schultz has received complaints with regard to bicycle riders who run at random in different parts of his precinct. Last evening at roll call he instructed his policemen to keep a sharp lookout for riders who violate the law, and eight were arrested.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- No disposition was made of The New-York Times Medal by the judges of the games held at the World's Fair by the Amateur Athletic Union. It was no fault of theirs, however, but simply because two athletes tied their score, so that the Judges could not affirm that either had the best individual performance.

The business arrangements between Mrs. Cyrus W. Field and W.H. Curtis, the milliner, at 210 Fifth Avenue, have caused more of a sensation among milliners in the fashionable shopping district than among Mrs. Field's friends and relatives in polite society. The house of W.H. Curtis is now the envy of all the millinery shops along Fifth Avenue, both great and small.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Several members of the Vestry of St Paul's Episcopal Church are trying to force the Rev. Charles S. Witherspoon, rector of the pariah, to resign. Their desire to get rid of the minister is due, they claim, to his having collected money in the name of the church and failed to make an accounting to the vestry.

Edward Jakobowski, composer of "Erminie," arrived here yesterday on the American Line steamer New-York, and is at the Hotel Vendome. He will remain here four weeks, and must be in London Oct. 20 to superintend arrangements for the presentation in the Carl Theater, Vienna, Nov. 20, of his new opera, "The Diamond Queen."

THE COMING SEASON -- The coming season of New-York society promises to open earlier than the Fall season of 1892. Less money has been spent on the art of killing time this year than for years past for obvious reasons. A year ago private steam yachts piled, about through European waters and the New-York millionaires aboard stopped at every fashionable settlement and dispensed their generosity.

BUFFALO, Sept 10 -- Eighteen Sheehan delegates, one of whom is the Lieutenant Governor himself, were elected to the Saratoga Convention by the Assembly District Conventions in Erie County to-day. Before leaving for New-York on Thursday, Mr. Sheehan had prepared the list of those he desired to go hence to Saratoga, and to-day's conventions ratified his choice without incident.
Now to Thee, gracious Lord of the Seasons, be honor and glory and praise, That again in the Joy of the harvest our jubilant anthem we raise.

WASHINGTON, Sept 16 -- The programme of the repeal leaders in' the Senate baa thus far developed no flaws. The points agreed upon by Mr. German and Mr. Yoorhees have been carried without difficulty. This is well understood by men who are conducting the opposition fight. They would line to bring about a different condition of things, but have been unable to do so.

-- John H. Chapin of Brooklyn is coming to the front as a tennis player. In the Clinton Club, of which he is a member, he is ranked at the top. In the recent club tournament the handicap pers decided to place him at scratch, but he carried off the honors just the same. His first opponent was Myles B. Neidhardt, to whom he gave the generous handicap of half thirty.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- To build and operate the World's Fair up to Aug. 31, 1893, cost $24,532,369. At this date the liabilities in excess of the assets were $371,845, according to the report of Auditor Ackerman, although the exposition owed at that time $1,455,215. This does not include the bonded indebtedness nor the implied obligations to the stockholders.

Mrs. Annie Moores, the only woman President of a national bank, has rather had her greatness thrust upon her. The banking institution known as the First National Bank at Mount Pleasant, Texas, of which she is the presiding officer, was originally a private banking house, and obedient to the wish of her father and brother, who controlled it, she familiarized herself with all the details of its workings.

A thousand persons went to Madison Square Garden last night to hear a military band concert by the veterans of the British Army, who have been holding a military tournament there during the week. The programme was varied and interesting. Miss Theresa Vaughn sang two songs, both or which were encored. Corp. R.P. Moore of the First Royal Dragoons, a soldier over 6 feet in height, sang two army songs.

The authoritative statement made by Mr. ISAAC L. RICE in relation to the Reading Railroad Company and published in full in THE TIMES of Sept. 6, coupled with the disclosures that, have since appeared, have emphasized the necessity for a thorough investigation and complete rehabilitation.

Regarded merely as an exhibit of the actual condition of the New-York banks, the statement issued on Saturday is full of encouraging features. The increase of $3,185,900 in deposits is an extremely good symptom. The money withdrawn for one reason or another during the past three months is coming back to the banks.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 17 -- Rains about Merrill, Marshfield, and Stevens Point to-day have greatly quenched the forest fires in the region where they have thus far been most disastrous, but dispatches from Ashland to-night say the fires in the extreme northern part of the State have assumed must threatening proportions.

The dispatch from San Jose, Costa Rica, in The New-York Times yesterday, pointing out the way in which Embezzler Francis Henry Weeks might possibly slip through the fingers of the New-York detectives unless they were fully informed on the subject of international law, was read with interest at Police Headquarters in this city.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Cholera is epidemic in the Department of the Finistere, which borders the English Channel. At Damaret, a town of 1,200 inhabitants, near Brest, there are thirty cases. Acute cases have been reported also from Jaon, Pleyben, Triboul, and Douarnenez.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Somerset has recently been considered one of the pivotal counties of New-Jersey. On that account each campaign attracts attention to the county. In a few weeks the nominating conventions will be held and candidates for Senator and Assemblyman will be placed in nomination.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 17 -- New-Haven people are on the qui vive for the return of the favorites. Next Thursday they are due -- the straggling candidates for the Yale football eleven. With the preliminary work at Travels Island disposed of, the local public look forward to a brilliant athletic season in which "the queen of college sports," as Yale men call football, will predominate.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Before leaving Stuttgart on Saturday evening Emperor William tad a long conference with Chancellor von Caprivi. The subject is said to have been the projected assimilation of Alsace-Lorraine with the rest of the empire. The Frankfort Gazette says that the Emperor's purpose is no longer limited to the mere abolition of exceptional laws.

The steamer New-York, which arrived Friday, had among its passengers "Dick" Howell, the ex-champion professional bicycle rider of England, and Alfred Robb, the present champion. In a letter to President Powers of the National Cycling Association Howell says:

The money market continued easy for call loans, which were made at 3 @ 4 cent. Time money was in fair supply. Tie ruling rate was 6 cent. for the best collateral, while with poorer security a small commission was charged.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur T. Pierson, who may fill the pulpit of the London Tabernacle, preached in the Reformed Church of Brooklyn Heights last evening. Dr. Pierson has been much discussed recently as the probable successor of Dr. Spurgeon. Shortly after Dr. Spurgeon's death, Dr. Pierson, who hails from Philadelphia, was invited to preach in the London Tabernacle, and he remained there for a year under a temporary call.

-- In Munich recently the Socialists hit upon a novel device for punishing the proprietor of a beer cellar who had refused to let his rooms for a meeting of the Socialists' club. For the Sunday after his refusal he had arranged a concert, at which he expected his takings to be considerable. But the Socialists mustered early and in large numbers.

We do not wish to alarm the business men of the country about the situation of the repeal bill in the Senate, but we feel it to be our duty to arouse them. It will not do to go to sleep under a delusive sense of security. The country spoke out to the House last month and its command was obeyed.

Dr. William T. White of 130 East Thirtieth Street died yesterday at heart disease. He had lived in the Thirtieth Street house for twenty-seven years, and was well Known as a general practitioner. He was born sixty-four years ago at Richmond, Me., and was graduated from the New-York Medical College in 1855 after a preliminary course at the Bowdoln College Medical School.
ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Orange enjoys the novel distinction of having a large force of workingmen whose wages have been reduced at their own suggestion.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept 17 -- A couple, who gave their names as Frederick Maller and May Hilliard, were married by Justice Rusen of Hoboken Friday. The bride said she lived in Syracuse, N.Y., and that her parents were wealthy.

DUBLIN, Sept. 17 -- More than 12,000 persons attended the amnesty meeting in Limerick to-day. William Redmond, Parnelite member of Parliament, and Pierce Mahony made addresses in favor of the release of Irish, political prisoners. The meeting passed resolutions censuring Home Secretary Asquith because he opposed the liberation of these prisoners and denouncing the Liberal Party for having abandoned its promises to do them justice.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 17 -- There is no longer any doubt that yellow fever is epidemic in Brunswick. Eleven new cases were found to-day and in different parts of the city. The situation is desperate. The City Treasury is depleted and the Government apparently unable to help. There is no State Board of Health and no State funds available.

The Twenty-eighth Assembly District is an interesting field for political speculation as to the future. It reaches away up from One Hundred and Twentieth Street, west of Seventh Avenue, to Spuyten Duyvil Creek, and is very nearly six miles in length.

GUENS, Sept. 17 -- In the last twenty-four hours the population of this little town has been doubled by the arrival of thousands eager to see the manoeuvres of the Austro-Hungarian Army. Every train entering the town since daybreak has brought its load of Princes, Generals, Cabinet officers, or high provincial authorities.

WASHINGTON, Sept 17 -- Collector Kilbreth is in the city to-night on his way to Chicago, with Gen. Agnus, and he has met many friends at the Arlington. He has made some inquiries about the probability of his early confirmation and is under the impression that it will be disposed of in a few days, there being no opposition to it that has been manifested.

Mrs. Margaret McGee, sixty-two years old, and her daughter, Sarah McGee, thirty years old, were nearly suffocated in a fire in their rooms on the third floor of the five-story brick building at 64 Madison Street at 12:20 this morning.
Croquet has its periods of activity and depression. Just at present it is showing an upward tendency.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Sept 17 -- The corner stone of a new Methodist Protestant church was laid at Inwood this afternoon. The Rev. George R. Brown of Montgomery, Ala., who is to be pastor of the new church, officiated, assisted by the Rev. L.R. Dyott of the Hill Street Methodist Protestant Church, Newark, N.J.

Mr. Hope writes the political romance, and his New-Lindsley may be New-Zealand. At once a vigorous style and a nice sense of proportion attract the reader. The man who is half a hero is Mr. Medland. He represents the labor candidate in one of per Majesty's colonies, and he is the type of the democrat in its highest conception.
Pilot Boat No. 4, the David Carll of the Jersey fleet, which was probably the best-known pilot boat in this vicinity, is a wreck.
ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 17 -- George E. McLean of this village married his cousin, Miss Nettie Frith of Brooklyn, July 12. The ceremony was performed in Brooklyn by the Rev. A.J. Wright.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept 17 -- What may prove a fatal duel took place early last night in Carolina, three miles from this city, between Eates Wethersbee and Henry Carley of Langley, S. C., in which Carley was shot and, it is thought, wounded so seriously that he will not recover.

Clothilde Douar, a pretty school teacher, aged twenty-one, who was arrested Saturday evening for riding a bicycle on Eighth Avenue, near Thirty-seventh Street, without a light, which is a violation of a city ordinance, was discharged with a warning by Justice Koch, in Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning.

-- The Hon. George S. Boutwell of Massachusetts, one of the few surviving members of Gen. Grant's Cabinet, will surrender his residence in Boston next month in order to go to Washington to act as counsel for the Chilean Government in certain important cases to be brought before the commission especially appointed to consider them.

The much-discussed "White Elephant" store of Vogel Brothers, Broadway and Thirty-first Street, will be opened for business next Saturday. The fact that the palatial new building occupies a site so long memorable in New-York has made it an object of interest since work upon it was begun.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 17 -- There was a triple lynching near this city last night, but it was conducted so quietly that the horrible affair was not known until this morning. The victims of the vengeance of the mob were three negro brothers named Julian, and the offense for which they were punished in so summary a manner was the shielding of a fourth brother.
A life of Gen. Polk with the title "Leonidas Polk, Bishop and General," by William M. Polk, M.D., will be published in two volumes this Fall by Longmans, Green Co.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Knisely's record for the best time over ten miles of American road was chipped by one second to-day at the annual road race of the Columbia Wheelmen. William Bainbridge was the man who did it, and his time was 27 minutes 54 seconds. The performance is the more notable as the record breaker had never won a race before or taken active part in an event of any importance.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Hugh J. Lee, who accompanied the Peary Arctic expedition, has written to a friend at Meriden, Conn., from "Falcon Harbor." His letter, which was received a day or two ago, was dated Aug. 18.

DUBUQUE, Sept. 17 -- The investiture of Archbishop Hennessey of Dubuque occurred to-day in St. Raphael's Cathedral before an immense congregation. Not one-tenth of those who desired to witness the ceremonies could find room. The crowd gathered about the doors of the cathedral was so dense that when the procession, headed by Cardinal Gibbons and Mgr. Satolll, was formed it made its way through the crowd with difficulty up to the portals of the sanctuary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- This city aroused itself slowly to interest in the centennial celebration of the laying of the cornerstone of the Capitol, but now that the event is at hand and is to be encouraged by the granting of a holiday in the departments, there seems to be great probability that, with good weather, it will be an event worth seeing and remembering.

Several persons representing the sugar planters of Louisiana will appear before the Ways and Means Committee this week. Our dispatches indicate that while they will ask that their bounty shall not be withdrawn they do not hope to save it. Believing that the bounty must go, they will urge the committee to restore the old duty of about 2 cents a pound on raw sugar.

The Young Ladies' Charitable Society, which admits within its sacred meeting place and to its fold of sisterhood none but unmarried ladies, met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Lexington Assembly Rooms in East Fifty-eighth Street to elect officers for the ensuing term.
The French labor delegates from the Municipal Council of Paris yesterday visited the various labor organizations in this city.

The historic corvette Kearsarge reached this port yesterday from Southport, N.C. The Kearsarge proceeded direct to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where she will be put in readiness for a Winter's cruise among the West Indies. Sue is commanded by Commander A.S. Crowinshield.

We hope that the opposition of the Canadian Government to the agreement made by the Canadian steamship and railroad companies and ratified by the Government at Washington concerning the inspection of immigrants arriving at Canadian ports on their way to this country can be overcome by the arguments of the Treasury Department or by some reasonable compromise.

Occasionally, it is the expected which happens. An illustration of this has just been afforded by the fact that nobody has been taken by surprise though Mr. William Wilde, equally distinguished as the brother of the great original AEsthete and the husband of Mrs. Frank Leslie, has been dropped from membership by the Lotos Club for having long, continuously, and contumaciously failed to pay his dues and other things.

For the first time since the latter part of May, when he was obliged to go to a hospital for a dangerous operation, the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton yesterday occupied his pulpit in the West Presbyterian Church, in West Forty-second Street. The present condition of the country was the subject of his discourse.

Michael Marion, thirty-five years old, of Park Avenue and Spencor Street, and Thomas Somers, twenty-eight years old, of 70 Middleton Street, Brooklyn, were crossing the Wallabout Canal near Washington Avenue, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, when Marion fell into the Canal. Somers leaped in to rescue his friend, and struck a body just below the surface of the water.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- The football season at Union began to-day, although college does not open until the 21st. The men will practice steadily on the campus until the games in October. The team will loan several good men. Capt. Allen, full back and mainstay of the team, was graduated last June, and will not return. Lavery, right guard; Kenny, centre, and Yanney, right end, will also not return.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- The market opened quiet and slightly lower from Saturday's closing. Very little change was made during the day in prices, the market being very dull. Atchison lost 3/4. Dominion Coal was active around 17 1/2. The market closed dull.

There is no little debate in Brooklyn just now over the first outcropping of the dispute, still young, but already vigorous and keen, between Daniel Ryan of the Eighth Ward and John Delmar. This, by the way, promises to become one of the most vital and energetic schisms possible in the "regular machine."

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept 18 -- The Acting Commissioner of Internal Bevenue, G.W. Wilson, has advised the Collector's office in this city that the pay checks which were issued by Hartford manufacturing establishments in August for the payment of employes must be subjected to the 10 per cent, tax imposed upon the circulation of State banks.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The Roth Goldschmidt Corset Manufactory, employing 650 hands, to-day increased its running time to four days a week and will probably resume full time by Oct. 1. The factory had been running but one and two days a week.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 18 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef in fair demand. Extra India mess firm at 78s 9d; prime mess firm at 70s. Fork in fair demand. Hams in poor demand. Bacon in fair demand; Cumberland cut, about 28 to 30 1b, firm at 58s; shoulders, about 12 to 18 1b, steady at 36s. Cheese in poor demand. Tallow in poor demand. Spirits of turpentine in poor demand.

The fact that the New-York Times Medal for the best individual performance at the World's Fair sports of the Amateur Athletic Union was not awarded proved a disappointment to the many athletes that were present at Chicago when the contests were held. W.C. Stage of Cleveland, the sprinter, and F.C. Puffer of the New-Jersey Athletic Club each won two events and tied with 10 points each.

R.H. Macy Co., Fourteenth Street and Sixth Avenue, had an unusually interesting Fall opening yesterday. The several departments of their large establishment were in gala array, and the exhibition of new foreign and domestic novelties was viewed by a large throng, eager to ascertain the trend of the coming season's fashion.
The sales scheduled for to-day in the salesroom, at 111 Broadway are as follows:

It is a great pity that the question of the extension of the time for registration of Chinese under the Geary law cannot be referred to a direct vote of the property holders of California, which is the State most extensively and immediately interested. We have no doubt as to what the decision would be-about the only opponents of extension would come from those who would prefer the total repeal of the law.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- The State machine has declared war against the anti-machine Democrats who have been legally elected delegates to the State Convention, and orders have been leaned that contesting delegations to represent the machine shall be sent from the Counties of Clinton and Essex. In view of many recent statements, the first information concerning this policy of the machine was discredited in this section of the State.

William F. Roberts, a member of the well-known Rhinelander family and a cousin of Chauncey Floyd-Jones, a young, powerfully-built, and at one time handsome man, who has spent two fortunes and still has another, occupies a cell in the Yorkville Prison -- a terrible example of the destroying power of liquor, which has made of him a physical and mental wreck, whose only desire is for more of the drink which has been his ruin.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, Sept. 18 -- P.M. On the score of inactivity, the stock market to-day surpassed even the dull times at the close of last week. At no time in the course of the day was there pronounced activity, and for two or three hours stagnation ruled on the Exchange.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 18 -- Secretary Hoke Smith came to Atlanta yesterday ostensibly to see his family, but in reality to settle the Postmastership fight, and, unless all signs fail, he did settle it. The fight was a three-cornered one between J.M. Couper, backed, by Senator Gordon; Dr. Ames Fox, backed by Senator Colquitt and Congressman Livingstone, and Anton Kontz, who has strong local backing.

-- J.W. Linneman ot the Press Cycling Club of Buffalo, the holder of the world's record for the 100-mile road race, has announced his intention of confining himself to track work next year. He is of the opinion that the prizes offered for road, racing are not adequate to the hard work required of the rider, and will start in only one of them -- the Martin road race -- next season.

-- The following inscription has been placed upon the sarcophagus which rests over the remains of Simon Cameron in the cemetery at Harrisburg, Penn.: "Simon Cameron, Printer, Editor, Adjutant General of Pennsylvania, elected for four terms; Senator of the United States, Secretary of War, Minister to Russia.

Applications were granted by Superintendent Brady of the Building Department last week for the erection of seventeen new buildings at an estimated cost of $635,000, and alterations to thirty-five buildings an expenditure of $76,000.

It is probable that if the local physicians at Brunswick had assisted the Federal health authorities there would not now be a beginning of an epidemic of yellow fever at that place. The work of the Marine Hospital Bureau last month was well done. Immediately after the first appearance of the disease thousands of people left the city.

Trade between New-York and the South is reviving. Inquiry yesterday among the General Agents of the coastwise steamship lines showed a strong feeling of encouragement over the way in which the Southern traffic has picked up within a few weeks. Predictions were freely made that the amount of the year's trade with the South would come almost if not quite up to the usual aggregate.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- A dispatch received from Rio Janeiro this evening by the Brazilian Legation here says that the insurgent fleet resumed the bombardment of the city to-day at noon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 18 -- Narragansett Park, four miles from this city, opened its gates to the suities to-day. No betting is allowed at this track; the meeting, given in connection with the annual Rhode Island State Fair, is entirely for the encouragement of the breeders and owners of harness racers in their efforts to improve the breed of horses.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 18 -- The statement printed in The New-York Times this morning that the employes of the Suburban Traction Company had suggested a reduction in their own wages was a popular topic of conversation to-day.

Ex-Assemblyman Thomas F. Farrell was yesterday unanimously elected clerk to the Kings County Board of Supervisors, to serve the un-expired term of the late Edward B. Cadley. The term will expire May 31, 1894. The salary is $5,000.

William Wirt Henry, grandson of Patrick Henry, is one of the most promising members of the Richmond bar. He is a high type of the advocate, particularly in appellate practice. Mr. Henry has also served with distinction in the Virginia Legislature. He was a member of the House for two terms and a member of the Senate for one term.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Serious complications are threatened within the Western Passenger Association on account of the east-bound passenger rate war in California. The Southern Pacific put in its fifteen-dollar reductions to-day. The Santa Fe will follow suit to-morrow. Both the Rio Grande Western and the Denver and Rio Grande are association roads.

The Union Square Theatre, rebuilt and renovated, decorated with stained glass, ivory-white paint, and resplendent gilding, furnished anew with parlors and retiring rooms, hung with new curtains of silk and plush, was opened yesterday by B.F. Keith of Boston, who has come to New-York to give a fair trial to his Boston plan of "continuous performances," from noon till 10 o'clock at night, of operetta and variety.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- A fair business was transacted in wheat, and an easier feeling prevailed. The opening was 3/8 @ 3/4 c lower, and the market quickly sold off 1/8 c more for December, then advanced 5/8 c, again weakened, and prices declined 1/2 @ 5/8 c, fluctuated somewhat, and the closing was about 3/8 @ 1/2 c lower for December and 1/4 c lower for May than the closing figures of Saturday.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- The Pope has sent a letter to Mgr. Satolli, the Papal Legate to the United States, in which his Holiness treats of American religious questions. Among other things referred to in the letter, his Holiness gives expression to the satisfaction he feels at the union of the American clergy that has been completed through the efforts of Mgr. Satolli.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- There was a hearing to-day before the State Railroad Commission on the application of the New-York, New-England Northern Railroad Company for permission to construct its proposed road from Leggett's Point on the Harlem River in New-York City to Brewster, there to connect with the New-York and New-England Railroad.

Mrs. Ida Brown, thirty-five years old, who gave her address at the Elizabeth Street Police Station as 45 Monroe Street, and who told Capt. Devery of the Eldridge Street Station that she lived at 45 Howard Street, was found Sunday morning locked in the Crocker Chair Company's building, Canal and Mott Streets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- With something of the impressiveness with which Presidents are inaugurated, with procession, many decorations, appropriate speeches, and the adjunct of music that is missing from inaugural ceremonies, the anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone of the Capitol was to-day celebrated.

Money on call loaned at 3 cent. Little was doing in time money. The supply continued fair. The nominal rate was 6 cent. Mercantile paper was in some demand by out-of-town buyers, with rates quoted firm at 7 1/2 cent. and upward.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Freight traffic on the roads, both east and west of Chicago, is picking up considerably. East-bound shipments from Chicago last week amounted to 52,493 tons against 52,236 tons for the previous week and 63,751 tons for the corresponding week last year. Lake shipments for the week amounted to 123,891 tons against 85,248 tons for the previous week.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 18 -- To-nignt practically all the men who had anything to do with the robbery of the Mineral Range Express last Friday of $70,000 were in jail or under espionage, and up to date $14,000 of their booty has been recovered.

Joseph Fleischman's new flower store in the Hoffman House will be open to the public to-day. There was a private view to the favored few last night. Mr. Fleischman has jumped from a flower stand on Fourteenth Street to a business of over $100,000 a year in less than two years by furnishing flowers at low prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- There were crowds of people down town, but at noon it seemed at the Capitol as if half the people in town had determined to find places on the plaza in front of the big building or at some point in the building itself, or upon the platform in front of it, from which all that was to take place could be seen and much that was said be heard.

Mardo, a clever juggler, added considerably to the interest of "The Black Crook" at the Academy last night. He makes up very much like Fielding, who was with the company last year, but the new-comer is much more accomplished.

The Rev. Madison C. Peters, pastor of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, Boulevard and Sixty-eighth Street, made a violent attack yesterday on the Charity Organization Society, with which are connected such well-known citizens as ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild, Oswald Ottendorfer, Robert C. Cornell, Nicholas Fish, Arthur M. Dodge, R. Duncan Harris, Rutherford Stuyvesant, and Francis H. Leggett.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- In lump figures $19,000,000 went into the construction of the World's Fair buildings and the preparation of the grounds for the exposition. The point that now interests the stockholders, and incidentally the whole city and country, is how much can be realized from that $19,000,000 worth of time and material.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A new star and a new play furnished entertainment to many Washingtonians at Albaugh's to-night. The "star" is Katherine Clemons, and the play "A Lady of Venice."

-- During medieval times a woman who had nothing when she was married escaped responsibility for her debts. Women were then often married in a single garment to relieve themselves of indebtedness. A young and noble German lady of the sixteeth, century, to make assurance doubly sure, had the marriage ceremony performed while she was standing in a closet, entirely divested of clothing.

While intoxicated yesterday afternoon, Patrick Shea, who lives somewhere in Hester Street, drove off from Hester and Baxter Streets with a watering cart which John Bottini of 102 Perry Street had left to go into a restaurant.

GUENS, Hungary, Sept 18 -- This place to-day is crowded with royal personages, military officers, soldiers, and people from all parts of Austria-Hungary, who have assembled either to take part in or to witness the great army manoeuvres now in progress in the vicinity of the town. Emperor Francis Joseph last night gave a court banquet in honor of Emperor William, the King of Saxony, and other royal personages who are present.

Mr. Henry Guy Carleton has a "sagittary" in Venice in his play called "The Lion's Mouth." Some astonishment has been expressed about this, because the only "sagittary" in Venice that was previously known was that in "Othello," which has puzzled the editors of Shakespeare for 200 years. Mr. Carleton writes to The New-York Times:

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 18 -- The convention which will meet in this city to-morrow to nominate Democratic candidates for Supreme Judge and State Treasurer promises to be as tame and spiritless a gathering as the recent Republican Convention, judging from present indications.

Mr. Hoyt's farcical, melodramatic, pictorial piece called "A Temperance Town" has been "on the road" nearly three years waiting for a chance to come to New-York. It was kept away by the enormous, unexpected, and unaccountable success of "A Trip to Chinatown" at the Madison Square Theatre.

Next to David J. Solomon Himself, whose alleged insanity is now being investigated by a commission and a Sheriff's jury, the person most deeply interested in the proceedings is Miss Clara Perry Thomas, from whom he was reft on the day preceding that set for their marriage.
The Valkyrie has been sighted and by tonight will probably be at anchor in the upper bay after her long voyage across the ocean.
The September Grand Jury for Kings County was sworn in yesterday by Judge Moore, in the Court of Sessions, Brooklyn. As soon as they had organized, the members adjourned. The jurors are:

Miss Harriet Vernon of London, England, was revealed last night to the patrons of Koster Bial's. Whoever chooses can put something of emphasis on the word "revealed," even to the extent of inclining its elements into far-meaning italics. It is not at all necessary to do so, nor would it be altogether fair, Miss Vernon being a spectacle eminently pleasing to the eye.

Bernhard Weinberger, the east side banker find broker who attempted suicide in a hotel in Washington Friday night, and who left that city on Sunday in company with his brother-in-law, Mr. Nickelberg, presumably for NewYork, was not seen yesterday by any of his many creditors, although it is generally believed that he is in hiding somewhere in town.
