William Cartwright and George Theis, each eleven years old, were yesterday held in the Jefferson Market Police Court on charges of burglary. Both of the lads live in West Sixty-sixth Street, William at 225 and George at 215, and Capt. Price says that both have been arrested frequently within the past six months on the same charge.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The first ballot ever cast in this State by a woman, in either a school or municipal election, was deposited here this morning at the annual school election. Under the State law passed last Winter women are made eligible to vote at school elections, and New-Haven was the first city to avail itself of the privilege.

The Infanta Eulalie, who won the esteem of New-Yorkers, whether of high or lowly station, during her recent visit to this city, has again been brought before the public as the unconscious medium for a unique advertising scheme. The outcome of the scheme was a perfect cyclone of ill feeling, hot words, and almost a law suit.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 18 -- Several negroes were seen yesterday in the neighborhood of Camp Parapet, armed with repeating rifles. They made threats that they were going to avenge the lynching of their three comrades Saturday. This menace being communicated to the leading men of the parish, they sent out couriers, and soon gathered a small army.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- One fresh case of cholera and 1 death were reported here yesterday. In Palermo there were 15 fresh cases and 9 deaths in the twenty-four hours ending at midnight. In Leghorn 5 fresh cases and 2 deaths were reported yesterday.

HARTFORD, Sept. 18 -- Rhea produced at Proctor's Opera House to-night a three-act spectacular play, by Adrien Barbusse, with incidental music by Oscar Comettant, called "The Queen of Sheba." The scene passes in Solomon's Temple, in his palace, and in the sepulchre of Hiram of Tyre, and the time is the year 990 B.C.

On the wall immediately overhanging the registering dealt in the office of the Hotel New Netherland, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, is a painting of more than ordinary merit and historic interest. It is an oil painting on canvas by the well-known artist, Franklin Tuttle of this city, and represents the purchase of Manhattan Island from the Indians in the year 1626 by the Dutch.

-- William Townley of 483 1/2 Mulberry Street, New-York, was arrested in Hoboken yesterday for falsely impersonating another William Townley, who lives at Port Morris, N.J. Both men were employed on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad as brakemen. Aug. 29 the New-York Townley left the company's employ collecting his wages.

C. Augustus Haviland, one of the leaders in the organization of depositors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, returned yesterday from Saratoga County, where he searched the records to find out to what extent the bank was protected against Paul C. Grening's overdrafts by mortgages on Grening's Kensington Hotel, in Saratoga.

MRS. WALTER HUNNEWELL'S DEATH -- The death of Mrs. Waller Hnnnewell of 261 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, on Friday last, will take much of the joy out of the announced engagement of Miss Isabella Hunnewell to Herbert M. Harriman of this city, brother of Mrs. W.R. Travers and of Mrs. L. M. Rutherfurd. Mrs. Walter Hunnewell was the daughter of the late J. Willard Peel of Salem, Mass.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 18 -- The pilot boat David Carll was discovered ashore just before daylight yesterday morning by the patrol from the Point Lookout Station. The patrol endeavored to get a signal from the crew. Failing to receive an answer, he walked west to meet the patrol from the Long Beach Station.
The ante-mortem statement of George P. Dilworth, the mulatto now in Bellevne Hospital with a fractured skull, is contradicted by his stepson, John T. Winston, and by his wife.

The list from which Grand Jurors to serve in the Courts of General Sessions and Oyer and Terminer for the year beginning Oct. 1 can be drawn was filed in the office of the County Clerk yesterday by the board specially charged with arranging the list and of which Recorder Smyth is Chairman.

Assistant District Attorney Lindsay said yesterday that the following dispatch had been received by Mr. Nicoll from Secretary Gresham in reference to the manifesto issued by President Rodriguez of Costa Rica, which was published in The New-York Times Sunday, establishing the personal guarantee of habeas corpus and extending amnesty to political exiles, while at the same time reserving the right to extradite the absconding embezzler Weeks:

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma Territory, Sept. 18 -- A courier just in from the Pawnee Reservation states that a terrific prairie fire is raging there and hundreds of settlers have been compelled to abandon wagons, tents, and outfits and flee for their lives on their horses.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The Dutch steamer P. Caland, Capt. De Boer, from Rotterdam Sept. 9 for New-York, was spoken Sept. 17 in latitude 50 north, longitude 24 west. She was then proceeding for Plymouth, having in tow the Dutch steamer Maasdam, Capt. Potjor, which sailed from Rotterdam Sept. 6 for New-York.

The Rev. Samuel B. Halliday, the venerable pastor of the Beecher Memorial Church in Brooklyn, and for many years the assistant of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher in Plymouth Chnroh, was stricken with apoplexy yesterday afternoon, in the parlors of Plymouth Church, while conversing with Mrs. Beecher.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 19 -- Every one was looking for The New-York Times yesterday. The public had learned that a history of the recent financial wrecks in Milwaukee was to appear in The New-York Times, and every one wanted to see it. People were at the news stands and book stores an hour before The New-York Times reached the city, and scores of advance orders were received.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 19 -- Brunswick reports 1 new case of yellow fever to-day and 1 death, Johnson M. Taylor. There are 10 suspected cases being watched. People are getting out of the city as fast as they can. Two banks have moved to St. Simon's Island. The infection is spreading slowly. There is great need of assistance, as all business is stopped.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- The equalization table of 1893 was adopted to-day by the State Board of Equalization, as presented by the State Board of Assessors -- W.H. Wood, John A. Mason, and H.D. Brewster. Of the State officers who constitute the board there were present the Speaker of Assembly William Sulzer, State Engineer Martin Schenck, Attorney General Rosendale, and Secretary of State Rice.

Every one yesterday was looking for the cutter Valkyrie. At every point where the outter was likely to be reported inquiries were made all day long. Yachtsmen were not the only ones who were anxious. Hundreds of persons who never take any interest in yachting seemed to be anxious about Lord Dunraven's challenger for the America's Cup.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- As the result of the second night's play in the international billiard match, between Frank Ives and John Roberts, Jr., the American again finished, first, closely followed by the Englishman, who played, a magnificent up-hill game. By careful nurses, Ives rolled together clusters of 110, 187, 134, and 140, and quit.

In Justice Neu's court in Brooklyn yesterday suit was brought against The Brooklyn Eagle to recover $93. The plaintiffs are Cornelius R. Colyer Sons, livery stable keepers of Love Lane and College Place. Their claim is for the hire of a horse and wagon for thirty-one days at $3 a day.

The leaders of the Protestant denominations of New-York are strongly opposed to the plan which has been proposed by Dr. Michael Walsh, editor of The Sunday Democrat and The Sunday Herald, for obtaining State aid for Roman Catholic parochial schools.

Besides retiring the $1,000,000 of certificates yesterday, of which notice was given Monday, the Loan Committee of the Clearing House Association has withdrawn $400,000 additional certificates, reducing the amount of certificates outstanding to $32,405,000. The ability of the hanks to make a wholesale retirement of certificates was demonstrated yesterday, when all but 6 per cent, of the Clearing House balances were paid in cash.

F.F. Deering, a Brooklyn letter carrier, was dismissed yesterday from the service, by Postmaster Sullivas, for intoxication and neglect of duty. Deering entered a restaurant on Washington Street Saturday evening with a bag of undelivered mail and ordered supper. When it was brought he was sleeping.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Miss Katherine Germaine's connection with the "Rainmaker of Syria" company began and ended last night. Miss Sophia Holt appeared to-night as Hatstepu, King of Egypt, in Rosenfeld and Aronson's new comic opera. This part was taken by Miss Germaine last night.

Sir Alexander Tilloch Galt, K.G. C.M.G., formerly a prominent figure in Dominion public affairs, died yesterday in Montreal of general debility, at the age of seventy-six. He was a son of John Galt, the author, and was born in Chelsea, England. He went with his father to Canada while quite young, and at the age of sixteen he became a clerk in the service of the British America Land Company, in the eastern townships.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Harvard's wisdom in employing a salaried graduate athletic manager under whom all the teams are placed, and into whose hands all the money is turned, has been already proved. The work of Mr. Herbert H. White, who occupies this new office, begins officially with the opening of the football season, but he has been hard at it throughout the Summer mapping out his campaign.
John W. Gosse, a colored porter who lives at 43 West Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday morning shot Mrs. Minnie Painter, a colored seamstress who lives in the same flat, because she would not marry him.

Through freight rates from Eastern seaboard points to points west of Chicago are in a very precarious condition. They are being cut in several directions. It is alleged that no sooner did the Soo Line restore grain and flour rates east-bound than it began cutting commodity rates west-bound. All merchandise sent over that route is now being carried at least 5 cents per 100 pounds below the tariff rates.

WILLIAM'S BRIDGE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The campaign of Assemblyman A.H. Morris for the Senatorial nomination received a check to-day. The ambitious son of the Morris Park race-track magnate wishes to succeed State Senator McClelland. Young Mr. Morris has been working with that object in view for some time.

The publication of the letter of Oliver Sumner Teall to the Directors of the Vaudeville Club has called forth the following reply from Secretary Preble Tucker in behalf of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors:

Many of the better known real estate speculators were present in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday at noon when the gang sounded for business. There was some curiosity to see how the first voluntary sale for the season was to pan out. During the past six or seven weeks foreclosure sales have been the only ones.

Our neighbor, the Tribune, has devised a Congressional policy for its party. It advises the Republicans in Congress not to allow the passage of the Silver Purchase Repeal bill until the Democrats have abandoned their projected national election law reforms. These are its words:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- The market has been dull, with prices unchanged. All pressure to sell appears to be over. Electric Traction rights took a sharp break, selling at 8 1/2 against 12 1/2 yesterday. Pennsylvania was steady. Lehigh Valley rose 2 cent. on very small transactions. The buying of this stock is almost wholly by small investors, and there appears to be no speculative interest in it.

We have been made aware by the debates in Congress that no very clear idea prevails at the national capital concerning the nature and functions of the Clearing House certificates issued in this city. The following letter from Mr. WHARTON BARKER of Philadelphia makes it apparent that in places nearer home than Washington there is still some misconception:

The Jefferson Heights Club continued its Fall tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Nostrand and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn. The events were men's singles, women's singles, and mixed doubles. The women's singles are advanced to the semi-final round, with Miss Jewitt, Miss Johnson, Miss H. Brooks, and Miss Wickes as the four rival players.

NEWTON, N.C., Sept. 19 -- For some time the revenue officers have been searching for a moonlight distillery near this town, but without success. On every public day almost every man that came in from the country had a jug of newly-made corn liquor. For miles up and down on this side of the Catawba River diligent search had been made.
Money on call loaned at 2 1/2 @3 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 19 -- That appearances are sometimes deceptive was demonstrated to-day at the Pennsylvania Democratic Convention. Late last night everything seemed to indicate that for tameness the gathering would put to shame the Republican gathering which nominated Pell and Jackson.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept., 19 -- F.H. Weeks has at last consented to make a statement. He realizes that he will have to return to New-York, and seeks to justify in a measure his rascality before he has to face his victims.

To-day is the twenty-third anniversary of the occupation of Rome by Victor Emanuel, and the United Italian Societies will celebrate it by a parade and other festivities, yet no flags will be displayed upon the City Hall.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- The feeling developed in wheat to-day was weaker, a fair business being transacted. The opening was 1/8 @1/4 c lower than the closing figures of yesterday, ruled easy, and prices declined 5/8 @3/4 c further for December and 7/8 c for May, held steady, and the closing was 1/2 @5/8 c lower for December and 5/8 c lower for May. The news was generally bearish.

WASHINGTON, Sept 19 -- Having put up for several days with a Republican determination to dominate the majority of the House, the Democratic Representatives to-day met in cauous and resolved to redeem the temporary loss of prestige which they have suffered through, the inexcusable absence of their associates.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The markets continue dull and generally weak.

The New-York and Brooklyn baseball teams have decided to play a series of games, after the close of the League season, for the metropolitan baseball championship. The first game will be played at Eastern Park on Oct. 5. Davis, who joins the All-American team at the end of the season, will not play with the Giants.
Toward the end of the afternoon yesterday a short, thick-set man, with a short, stiff beard, hopped to his feet in the front pew of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church and cried:

Being forewarned that the lightning was about to strike him, Mr. Hornblower yesterday absented himself from his office at 45 William Street. He was reluctant to face the flood of congratulations that he know would pour in upon him as soon as his nomination should be announced in the press.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 19 -- Henry S. Coohran, the embezzler of thirty gold bars from the Philadelphia Mint, was again arraigned before United States Commissioner Bell this afternoon. Ex-Assistant United States District Attorney James M. Beck has been engaged as counsel for the defendant, and owing to his absence the bearing was continued until 11 A.M. Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Ind., Sept 19 -- Sir murders were committed in one family at the house of Denson Wratten, in Harrison Township, Davies County, early this morning. Mr. Wratten was ill with typhoid fever. A neighbor called to inquire after his health. He found the whole family butchered.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, Sept. 19 -- P.M. The stock market was dull again to-day, and until the last hour trading languished. Even toward the close, when something approaching activity developed, the liveliness was confined to three or four stocks. There was, however, a firmer feeling, and the list generally at the close was at its best for the day.

THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, consists of TWELVE PAGES. Among other features, it contains -- OUR CENTURY-OLD CAPITOL -- Grand celebration in Washington of the laying of its cornerstone.

PERSONALS -- William Gammell expects to sail soon for Europe. Mrs. John Lowrey has been the guest of Mrs. William A. Duer at Newport. Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Thayer are now at Chicago. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hitohcook, Jr., who have been spending the Summer at Pride's Crossing, Mass., have moved their household to their farm at Westbury, L.I., the Meadow Brook.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- It is evident, after a most careful analysis, that the position of the United States at the World's Fair lacks in some particulars, while it excels in others. It is in manufactures that better opportunities are found for comparison between the various nations, even if the subject chosen gives an advantage to other countries than the United States by reason of their longer experience and age.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 19 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef in fair demand. Pork and hams in poor demand. Bacon in good demand; long clear middles, about 45 lb, firm at 55a 6d. Cheese in moderate demand; American finest colored firm at 48s. Tallow in poor demand. Spirits of turpentine in poor demand; firm at 21s 9d. Cottonseed oil, Liverpool refined, firm at 22s 6d Resin in moderate demand; common, steady at 3s 6d.

The principal source of income of the Reading Railroad must always be from the production and transportation of its coal. It is not rare for people who have but a general knowledge of the property, and who read superficially the statements of the Coal and Iron Company showing its inability to meet its own charges, to conclude that Reading would do well if it could give its coal property away.

Judge Fitzsimons of the City Court yesterday issued an order for the arrest of Z. Reed Brockway, Superintendent of the Elmira Reformatory, on a charge of having assaulted Christian Rhodes while he was an inmate of the Reformatory. The application for the order of arrest was made by William Crosman, 206 Broadway, who is the guardian of Rhodes, who claims $2,000 damages from the Superintendent for assault and battery.

Mascot's breakdown does not appear to be half so bad as was reported. The famous pacing stallion's few weeks' rest seems to have put him all right on his feet, as when tried he does not show any lameness. He was worked a very slow mile recently and experienced no trouble, yet as a precautionary measure he may not start again this year.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Be good enough to accept, with a thousand thanks, my acknowledgment of the hospitality of your columns. It is not often, alas! that a foreign taker of notes can avail himself of such a dignified and influential jounalistic vehicle as The New-York Times.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 -- The Mount Vernon Cotton Mills have resumed operations and there is rejoicing in Woodberry. The mills shut down two weeks ago for repairs to the machinery. It was stated at the company's offices that the outlook for trade was good and that there were sufficient orders ahead to keep the looms buzzing for some time.

Judge Robert S. Hefflin of Alabama, who served in the Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Congresses, boasts that his expenses during the thirteen months of his two terms were not over $30 a month, and that he returned to his home with $9,600 out of his two years' salary and has been living in affluence ever since.

Secretary Sullivan of the Amateur Athletic Union, "Willie" Day, the champion five-mile runner; Michael Sweeny, the champion high jumper; E.C. Puffer, the champion hurdler, and other winners of the World's Fair athletic games are home from the scene of their triumphs. Mr. Sullivan says that the games were first-class, and but for unfavorable weather several track records would have been broken.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 19 -- Secretary of State Osborn will be tried in the District Court for libel to-morrow. Cy Leland, National Republican Committeeman for Kansas, is the prosecuting witness. Osborn charges Leland with stealing a large amount of coal from the State Penitentiary mine and selling it to farmers.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 19 -- Whether the Northern Pacific Railroad Company will continue to operate the Wisconsin Central between St. Paul and Chicago is still an undecided question. Yesterday the receivers of the Northern Pacific Company recommended, in answer to the petition of the Wisconsin Central suit for the cancellation of the lease filed in the United States court, that the Wisconsin Central be returned to its owners.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 19 -- A choleraic epidemic is spreading rapidly in Dampremy and Marchiennes au Pont, small towns in the province of Hainaut. Since Monday there have been 31 cases and 8 deaths.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- From this time forward there will be no favors shown in the contest for repeal in the Senate. The repeal leaders have been assured that their opponents will do their utmost to defeat the bill now under consideration, and to-morrow Mr. Voorheen will make the motion for lengthened sessions, which is accepted as a declaration that the fight will be to a finish.

It is the distinction of the President's oratory that he commonly contrives to impart significance and "actuality" to topics that seem to have none of these elements of interest. There have been a good many speeches made about the Capitol of the United States. Some of them, notably that of DANIEL WEBSTER in 1851, nave gone into the school books as suitable for youthful declamation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Nine persons were killed and twenty injured last night by a fearful rearend collision between two sections of the Big Four train known as No. 45, near the village of Manteno, a few miles north of Kankakee, on the line of the Illinois Central Railway.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Private advices from Washington indicate that the fight among the candidates for the vacancy in the Adjutant General's Department, caused by the retirement of Chauncey McKeever, is waxing hotter every day, and that, up to date, it is the Gettysburg of peace struggles for coveted position.

The receivers of the Reading Railroad have issued a statement which, if the headlines which precede it in the Philadelphia papers are correct, is a reply to the charge made against them by Mr. Isaac L. Rice in his various published statements. There is no other evidence that it is a reply to any one of the various grave charges made by Mr. Rice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Speaker William Sulzer, Register John Reilly, Police Justice Divver, and State Senator Clarence E. Bloodgood were prominent figures in the Arlington lobby this evening. The three gentlemen first named arrived from New-York this evening. Senator Bloodgood came this morning.

The North German Lloyd Steamship Company of Bremen has published an Interesting pamphlet containing an instructive resume of the operations or the company. The Lloyd is now building twelve new steamers, the largest number that has ever been contracted for at one time by a single company.

The Democratic organization of this State, popularly known as the "machine," had an unusual opportunity this year if it had seen fit to use its advantage with moderation. The antagonism which it aroused last year had subsided as the result of the sweeping national victory to which it contributed and which was so satisfactory to those who had opposed its dosigns and its methods.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Counsel for Alfred Sully of New-York and John Lornie of London this afternoon filed a petition in the United States Circuit Court asking that they may be allowed to intervene as plaintiffs in the suit of Thomas G. Platt against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company and others.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 20 -- The American Protective Association, a secret society, has been active in Kansas politics during the last two campaigns. This association, nominally anti-Catholic, is a Republican society, working under password, grip, and signal, and is especially active in its work against all foreign-born citizens.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- Thirty-five hundred people witnessed the opening to-day of the Fall Tournament and International Base Meet on the Park Cycle Track, under the management of the Maryland Bicycle Club. Zimmerman was not present, owing to railroad detention. Meintjes was also absent, and from a similar cause. They telegraphed they would be in the races to-morrow.

Edward N. Meyer, who, while ill and unconscious, is alleged to have been pitched down the steep stairway of the station at Third Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street Tuesday evening by employes of the elevated railroad, was reported to be in a somewhat improved condition last evening.

Count Eugeno do Mitklewioz, his memorable Chinese concessions, and the late Col. Eillott F. Shepard were factors in an examination held before Justice Connelly yesterday forenoon at the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 20 -- The Johnson and Dunbar gingham mills, which have been closed six weeks on account of the dull market, will start Monday morning on at least half time. The mills employ 440 persons.

The schools of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the season of 1893-4 will open Oct. 2 and continue for eight months, to Saturday, May 25. The classes of instruc- tion comprise drawing, painting, sculpture, architecture, and the industrial arts.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- The market has bean stagnant and the day has been one of the dullest of the year. Metropolitan Traction advanced 1 point, to 94, on limited transactions. With the slightest encouragement given by New-York this stock would be readily advanced by the traders. Philadelphia Traction was neglected at 82 1/8 , and Baltimore Traction was in slightly better demand at 18 1/4 .

The account of an interview with F.H. WEEKS, published yesterday in a special dispatch to THE TIMES from Costa Rica, indicates that WEEKS, though without any distinct information, suspects that there may be some persons in New-York who view his conduct in an unfavorable light.

It is announced in our Washington dispatches that Mr. VOORHEES has determined to ask the Senate each day to add an hour to its session. He began yesterday, and, if he carries out his plan, the Senate will sit till abont 9 P.M. on Saturday. This is described as "applying the screws gently rather than with force."

Bishop John P. Newman of Omaha is a guest at the Murray Hill Hotel. He will go to Madison, N.J., to-day to lay the cornerstone of the Drew Theological Seminary. On Sunday he will go to Wilmington, Del., to dedicate a church.

The procession of the United Italian Societies to celebrate the twenty-third anniversary of the occupation of Rome by Victor Emmanuel and the Italian troops aid not pass the City Hall yesterday. Became Mayor Gilroy refused to allow the Italian flag to be hoisted on the City Hall the societies declined to be reviewed and changed the route of the procession.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 20 -- A bill will soon be presented in Congress imposing an internal revenue tax on cotton goods manufactured in this country. The Government regards the present heavy premium on foreign exchange as affording unlooked-for protection to cotton manufacturers. It is not improbable that duties on all the commoner sorts of cotton goods will be low ered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- For about two weeks an inquiry has been in prepress by three marine officers concerning the truth of charges against Capt. Mitchell of the Revenue Marine Service ship Crawford, which is attached to this station. The accusations against him include drunkenness and immoral practices on board his vessel, the complaint being made by one of his subordinates.

The great store of H.C.F. Koch Co. in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues, is, par excellence, the emporium of the far uptown district, and consequently the announcement of its Fall opening is attracting thousands of buyers and seekers after the styles of the season.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept 20 -- Senator Maurice Bogers of Camden County, who is a candidate for renominatlon, but who la opposed by Republicans friendly to the candidacy of Fred Rex, has published a letter in which he charges that W.J. Thompson offered him $75,000 for three Republican votes in favor of the race-track bills passed by the last Legislature.
President John King of the Erie Railway received the following lettar a day or two ago:

The attention lately given to the subject of clearing derelict hulks away from the paths of transatlantic travel and traffic promises good results. As Mr. CHURCHMAN, the President of the National Board of Steam Navigation, urged at the recent meeting of that body, the work is eminently one for national and international authorities to undertake.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 20 -- The Wisconsin forest fres have seriously affected navigation on Lakes Michigan and Superior. Perhaps nothing shows so graphically the immense damage these fires are working as the foot that such clouds of smoke hang over two of the great lakes an to have caused a number at miner accidents and to have been worse at numerous points than any fogs eperienced for years.

A notable sale effected yesterday was that of the building and lot 697 Fifth Avenue, east side, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets. The property is immediately opposite the St. Luke's Hospital grounds, and this is the first sale in the neighborhood any significance since the hospital purchase. The lot 697 Fifth Avenue has on it a four-story highstoop brownstone dwelling, built by the late George A. Osgood and occupied by him as a residence.

-- The annual stockholders' meeting of the Connecticut River Railroad Company was held in Springfield, Mass., yesterday. The following Board of Directors was chosen: John Mulligan, Springfield; Oscar Edwards, Northampton; N.W. Whiting, Holyoke: J.H. Albin, Concord. N.H.; J.H. Williams. Bellows Falls, Vt.; G.H. Ball, Boston; P.C. Cheney, Manchester; S.M. Railrords, Newport, N.H.; J.W. Stovene, Greenfield; E.P. Kendrick, Springfield.

Another day gone and still no Valkyrie. The same anxious crowd gathered yesterday at all points where news of the missing yacht was likely to be received. Those down town thronged to the Maritime Exchange and to the Ship News Office at the Battery and inquired if the yacht had been sighted at any point, but every one was doomed to disappointment.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The Democratic Convention for the Twenty-first Senatorial District was held here this afternoon. It was called to order by Judge Glbson of this county, who was made Permanent Chairman. Franklin Fishier and Frederick R. Spencer were chosen Secretaries.

By special request Mrs. Ida Jeffreys Goodfriend yesterday addressed the members of the Professional Woman's League upon "Why we should cultivate a good taste, tact, and common sense in our social and business relations." She said:

Eleven new cases of smallpox were reported yesterday, two of the patients being physicians -- Dr. Charles Norris of the Roosevelt Hospital and Sanitary Inspector Thomas L. Richards of the Health Department. The source of the contagion in the case of the physicians was James McGowan of 429 West Fifty-second Street, who went to the Vanderbilt clinic on the 4th inst.

NEW-YORK. WEDNESDAY, Sept. 20 -- P.M. The stock market was duller than ever to-day, and trading was entirely professional. The total business reached only 128,535 shares. Nearly half of it was in Sugar, Chicago Gas, and St. Paul Whisky, Rock Island, and Atchison were the only other stocks in which the transactions exceeded 6,000 shares.

GUENS, Hungary, Sept. 20 -- The mimio warfare between the imperial army of the north and the army of the south continued to-day. The Vienna Corps having joined the army of the north, the latter to-day defeated the army of the south between Stob and Grosswarasdorf. The engagement, however, was utterly unreal. The army of the north traversed a valley, in which, in actual warfare, it would have been decimated by an enemy.

The Staten Island ladies' open tennis tournament began yesterday afternoon on the courts of the Staten Island Cricket Club, Livingstone, S.I. As far as could be judged from the first day of play the meeting promises to rival the championship tournament at Philadelphia, where Miss Terry won the championship of the United States vice Miss Cahill, defeated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Ways and Means Committee cave the last or the bearings to-day to those who had suggestions to make as to the composition of the new tariff bill. Now the majority of the committee will devote themselves carefully to the work of preparing the measure Intended to carry out the Administration idea of revising the tariff.

Charles Mitchell, the English pugilist, arrived yesterday on the steamship Teutonic. With him came "Jack" McAuliffe, lightweight champion of America, and "Harry" Darrin, the English sprinter. The latter is to be Mitchell's trainer in case the match with Champion Corbett is made binding.
DRESDEN, Ontario, Sept. 20 -- The Dresden Canning and Pickling Company's factory was turned this morning. The fire was caused by an explosion of gasoline. Loss, $25,000; insurance $10,000.

Morris Ely, a recent addition to the Brooklyn Tennis Club, seems to have carried all before him thus far. He certainly deceived the handicappers as to his playing strength, for they ranked him at half fifteen. With this handicap he easily defeated B. Jeffares, who has in past tournaments taken first place. Jeffares was ranked as owing.

--At Lone Island City, yesterday, Frederick Weissman was convicted of burglary in the first degree and John Miller of burglary in the second degree. John Kelly pleaded guilty. Walter Mitchell and Ferdinand Weissman, members of the same gang, will be placed on trial to-day.

The trot for the three-hundred-dollar purse in the 2:25 class and the trial against the track record by E.T. Bedford's geldine Gillette brought out a large attendance at the matinee of the Parkway Driving Club at King's Highway, L.I., yesterday afternoon. Not only were trotting men on edge to see the race against the record, bat so were some of the officials at the running tracks.

There was a crowd at the Atlas Line offices, 24 State Street, early yesterday morning, to ask for news of the missing steamship Alvo. The fact that Juan Ribon, a merchant of Jersey City, who lives at the Westminster Hotel, had received a cable dispatch conveying a ray of hope as to the safety of the passengers and crew caused the crowd to collect.

The Presidents of the Eastern trunk lines met in this city yesterday and disposed of two subjects relating to excursion fares to and from Chicago. The proposition of the Pennsylvania Railroad to make a general round-trip rate of $15 for the day-each excursion trains was voted down by a large majority.

The present accommodation for public-school children was made the subject of Inquiry and debate at the meeting of the Board or Education yesterday. Superintendent Jasper made a report to the board in which he said that on Sept. 13 there were 45,240 seats in the city's schools which were not occupied. Of that number 15,194 were accounted for by pupils having been excused for the day, leaving more than 30,000 seats awaiting applicants.

Mrs. Anne E. Farley, wife of ex-Sheriff Charles B. Farley of Brooklyn, was stricken with paralysis yesterday afternoon in the Grand Central Station, this city. Mr. and Mrs. Farley were on their way to Yonkers, and Mr. Farley was standing by The ticket window, when his wife fell unconscious beside him. Ambulance Surgeon Donnelly of Bellevue Hospital responded to a call and said Mrs. Farley had suffered a stroke of paralysis.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept 20 -- The monument erected in Calvary Cemetery to the memory of John J. O'Brlen, late Republican leader in the old Eighth Aasembly District, New-York City, was unvelled at 2 o'clock this afternoon in the presence of 500 spectators. Members of the association which bears the dead leader's name arrived at the cemetery in 100 coaches, and grouped around the shaft, which was covered by an American flag.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 -- The sulkies had a great day at Narragansett Park, some 20,000 persons coming from all parts of the state to see the races. The track dried out fairly well, but by tomorrow it will be very fast. The 2:23 trot was the feature of the day's sport, Prinsonian, brilliantly handled by Percy snow, a young son of the breeder and owner of the colt, winning from a strong field.

The Irving Club tennis tournament is well advanced up to the closing rounds. The tournament is a handicap affair, with men's singles as the event of interest. Thus far C.W. House, (half-fifteen,) F. M. Pendreigh, (scratch,) and George Morgan, (fifteen,) seem to have the best of it, each having a clear record of victories.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- This has been a day or surprises in the Senate. The expected has not happened.

GOLF AT NEWPORT -- Roger Winthrop and H.O. Havemeyer are the proud winners of the Havemeyer Golf Cup. They won the tournament by default, however, C.C. Baldwin, Jr., and Victor Sorchan failing to appear. Messrs. Sorohan and Baldwin beat C.A. Amory and Lloyd Warren. Messrs. Winthrop and Havemeyer in turn beat Whitney Warren and William R. Travers, and also Lorillard Spencer and Henry B. Taylor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- That well-known steeplechase horse Futurity, owned by Alderman Nolan of Albany, N.Y., died here yesterday. He was on his way from the East to San Francisco, and, taken sick on the road, was unshipped here for treatment, but too late. Futurity was a horse of good class, seven years old, by Ventilator-Carrie Mo.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- A dispatch received to-day by a mercantile firm in this city states that Admiral Mello, commanding the rebel Brazilian fleet, has sent an ultimatum to the authorities in Rio Janeiro declaring that, unless the city surrenders at once, he will renew the bombardment relentlessly and with all the strength at his command.

The will of the late Hamilton Fish, who died Sept.7 at Garrisons, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday for probate. The instrument is dated June 8, 1892. No valuation of the estate has been made and no estimate of its extent could be obtained yesterday from Charles A. Peabody, counsel for the family, who offered the will for probate.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Gov. Flower has turned over to Superintendent Preston of the State Banking Department the charges against the latter by the committee of depositors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn. The Superintendent says he will have his answer ready in a day or two.

It is generally believed by those who have the best means of knowing that in the conference to which the "Boss" of Brooklyn devoted the tranquil hours of last Sunday afternoon he and his "trusted lieutenants" reached the conclusion that Mayor BOODY should be renominated. If this decision was really made, it involves the assumption that Mr. BOODY can be reelected.
The second delegation of French workingmen, which arrived Saturday, went to Chicago last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 20 -- A terrible accident has happened to the Montgomery," was the startling report that spread rapidly around Annapolis this afternoon about 5 o'clock. A little later the great white hulk of the Montgomery lay at anchor off the Santee's wharf with a diminutive tug alongside of her gangway.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- The market opened dull and continued so until shortly before the close, when it became quite active and higher. No notable changes were made from yesterday, but the close was genrally firm.

As a result of the information contained in a cable dispatch from Costa Rica, published in The New-York Times yesterday, that Francis H. Weeks, when he fled from this city, had taken passage under the name of Watson on a steamship plying between New-York and the West Indies, a reporter made inquiries yesterday regarding the name of the vessel.

Tae Hebrew Anarchists who for several years have celebrated the great Jewish fast of Yom Kippur --- Day of Atonement -- by balls and other entertainments instead of fasting, repentance, and prayer for forgiveness, repeated the celebration yesterday.

Rear Admiral John H. Upshur left the Clarendon for Ridgefield, Conn., yesterday with his son-in-law and daughter, Lieut. and Mrs. James Russell Selfridge. Lieut. Selfridge is the son of Rear Admiral Selfridge, who, at the age of ninety-two, is the oldest living Admiral in the country. The Lieutenant and his wife have been abroad for five years.

ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 20 -- Robert Smith, a negro, to-day assaulted and nearly killed Mrs. Henry Bishop, wife of a well-to-do farmer of Botetout County. Mrs. Bishop was at the market with a load of produce and Smith bought a box of grapes. He asked her to go with him to get the money, and, taking her to a house near by, looked the door and bound her.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The proportions which each county must pay into the State Treasury under the tax levy of this year to raise moneys for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, 1893, have been computed in the State Controller's office as follows:

Upon very high authority in Tammany Hall it was stated yesterday with the utmost positiveness that nothing has as yet been decided by the leaders of the organization upon the proposed judicial nominations in this city this Fall, or upon any other of the local nominations.

The feeling which the Democrats, especially those of the Southern States, have in regard to the election, law is not an unnatural one, though we think that it is somewhat misdirected. The administration of the law in their part of the country has often been not only arbitrary and offensive, but directly or indirectly corrupt.

Director Franklin W. Hooper of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences has addressed a circular letter to the President and members of the Teachers' Association of Brooklyn, generously tendering to its members admission to full associate membership at reduced rates.

Herman Rausch has filed with the Rapid Transit Commissioners a plan, with map, for a rapid-transit system, upon which he expects to submit an argument at the next meeting. He proposes to utilize the tracks running out from the Grand Central Station and to build a union station at Mott Haven large enough to accommodate all travel of the various lines leading into the city.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Curiosity to see Henry Arthur Jones's first adventure on the exacting lofty plane of blank verse drew quite an exceptional house to the first night of "The Tempter" at the Haymarket. Hardly the height of the season could have got more Parliamentary and social notabilities together.

DEADWOOD, S.D., Sept. 20 -- At 5:30 this afternoon the forest fire which has been burning in this vicinity forten days reached Lead City. The Homestake saw mills and lumber yard were the first to go. This made a hot fire, and the flames, aided by the prevailing strong wind, are now making havoc among the frame buildings of the town.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- The Republican State Committee held an important meeting to-day, which was attended by fourteen members and Gen. W.J. Sewell. The committee decided that it would be well to maintain a vigorous organization throughout the State and to open headquarters in the City of Newark about ten days hence.

WARWICK, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Gov. Flower to-day spoke to the farmers of Orange County at their fair. He said the Legislature did a great thing for the farmers last Spring in creating a Department of Agriculture. He said:

PRINCETOM, N.J., Sept 20 -- The academlo year of Princeton University began this afternoon with an address by the President in Marcuand Chapel. Yesterday and to-day the usual September examinations for entering and conditioned students have been held. The exercises of the several classes will be entered upon Thursday morning.

The Kings County Wheelmen will give an international race meeting at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, on Saturday, Sept 30. The programme will include an international event at five miles for safeties. A one-mile novice, safety; one-mile safety, handicap: two-mile safety, handicap; one-half-mile safety, scratch, all open events, and a one-mile safety, 2:40 class, will also be decided.

The Commissioners of Appraisal for the new Harlem River Speedway met yesterday in the office of the Corporation Counsel to begin their work. The city was represented by Assistant Corporation Counsel Hawke and Junior Assistant O'Nell. Clark Bell appeared on behalf of himself and other property owners.

Interest was excited in revenue marine circles bore yesterday over the receipt of Treasury Department orders directing that the United States revenue cutters Grant and Perry be at once fitted out to proceed to Puget Sound and assist in suppressing opium smuggling.

The practical effect of the McCreary amendments to the Geary law would be simply to allow Chinese laborers in this country another chance to register and obtain certificates of their right to remain. It would not modify the law in principle or purpose in the least. The law originally gave the Chinese one year in which to register and obtain certificates.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 21. -- By an explosion of gas in the Lance Colliery, No. 11, of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company at Plymouth this afternoon five men were instantly killed and five others seriously injured.

WESTCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- For a bicentenarian, old St. Peter's Parish has been frisky as a lambkin on its own green hills to-day. Cloudless skies and clear cracing air heightened everybody's enjoyment of the celebration by the historic parish of its two hundredth birthday, which had the dual character of an imposing religious ceremonial and a brilliant social function.

Writing to The New-York Times as a critic of the work of the Charity Organization Society, a woman charges that, while the society is now caring well for poor and destitute men, and while it intends to better care for them in the building it is to erect on West Twenty-eighth Street, it pays no attention to the poverty and sufferings of women.

There was a wedding at Bolton, N.Y., a few days ago, of interest to New-Yorkers, but concerning the particulars or which little has been heard. The bride was Miss Bessie Whitman and John P. Benson was the bridegroom. The wedding, which took place in the Church of the Holy Sacrament at Bolton, on the shore of Lake George, was the third in the family of Alfred Whitman of this city within a year.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 21. -- The Maryland Bicycle Club closed its Fall tournament to-day in the presence of 3,000 persons. The sport was better than yesterday. Zimmerman, while practicing, fell, and the mishap prevented him from entering into the contests. O.S. Brandt of New-York made the fastest mile of the meet, his time being 2:16 1-5.

LYONS, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The Republican District Convention to elect delegates from Wayne County to the Senatorial Convention, which will be held in Geneva next Thursday, was held in this village to-day. Senator Charles T. Saxton of Clyde desires to represent the district again, and had a hard fight in to-day's convention to secure the delegates.

KENT, Ohio, Sept. 21. -- The Baltimore and Ohio fast passenger train, No. 6, west-bound on the Pittsburg and Western, came through Ravenna at a terrific speed at 1 o'clock this morning. The train consisted of nine vestibule sleeping cars. On the siding stood Freight No. 86, which had failed to "get into the clear."

The funeral of Miss Annie Blanche Calvert Bennett, oldest daughter of Sidney A. Bennett, who died Tuesday, will be held at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon from the residence of her relative, Henry M. Calvert, 138 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, which she made her home.

It was supposed that the Republican County Committee would open the local campaign on its side or the fence last night with a great blowing of trumpets and a great hurrah at the first Republican County Committee meeting bold since June. But it did nothing of the sort. The meeting of that committee in Grand Opera House Hall last night was sombre, staid, and even solemn.
There was an extraordinary spectacle in Police Justice Haagerty's court in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The "gradual tightening of the screws" by Mr. Voorhees, the leader of the repeal movement in the Senate, resulted to-day in the lengthening of the session about fifty minutes. It was 7:10 o'clock when the Senators vacated the chamber. Repeated attempts had previously been made to bring about an adjournment, but Mr. Voorhees had succeeded in defeating them.
The depositors' organization of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn will meet at Haviland Hall, Greene and Classon Avenues, that city, to decide what steps to take to protect their interests.

Jacob Schoenenberger and Chastine Meese, carpenters, quarreled in the shop of E.H. Fuller at 154 Prince Street yesterday afternoon, and as a result Shoenenberger died at St Vincent's Hospital at 9 o'clock last night.

WELDON, N.C., Sept. 21. -- There has been for the past week a terrible freshet along the Roanoke River. The rise was greater than has been known for fifteen years. The lands on both sides have been submerged for several days, and the corn crop on these bottom lands has been ruined.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- Henry S. Cochran, the gold bullion embezzler, was again arraigned before United States Commissioner Bell this morning. The prisoner's counsel, ex-Assistant District Attorney James M. Beck, waived a hearing, and Cochran was held in $17,500 bail for appearance at the United States District Court on Nov. 20.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The feeling in wheat to-day was unsettled. After a weak opening, at a decline of 1/8@1/4c, a farther reaction took place, December selling down 3/8@3/4c; the market then became stronger and advanced 7/8@1c, easing off a fraction, and closing with a net loss of 1-16c for December from yesterday. The early weakness and decline were attributed to lower cables, some reporting a decline or Id at Liverpool.

The sales of real estate at auction yesterday were devoid of general interest. Mr. Henry W. Donald of R.V. Harnett Co. sold under foreclosure, for $21,580, the five-story brick flat 165 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, 25 by 99.11, to Babette Guggenheimer.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The State Fair, which has just closed, has been the most disastrous in the history of the society. Bad weather set in on the opening day and continued to the finish, and on no day was the attendance sufficient to pay expenses. Those who had paid for the various privileges are heavy losers.

The formal opening of the new clothing store of William Vogel Son, at Broadway and Houston Street, took place yesterday, under the most auspicious conditions. The 25,000 feet of floor space was thronged with a large crowd of eager well-wishers, sight-seers, and customers, who inspected the stock of the immense establishment with very evident pleasure.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- The Spanish steamer Palentino, from Matanzas, to-day brought three men of the British schooner Windermere, which sailed from Key West on Sept. 4 for Mobile to load for Port of Spain, Trinidad. The Windermere was capsized in a heavy squall on Sept. 7 when 180 miles off Mobile.

MEXICO, Sept. 21. -- Several influential journals belonging to the Liberal Party are giving cordial support to the new policy of Finance Minister Limantour, whose bill levying a tax on the domestic production of cotton goods has passed first reading in the lower house of Congress.

The Brooklyn Croquet Club finished its tournament games yesterday with the Union Croquet club of this city, and by winning every one of the three games played now holds the championship of the two clues in tight croquet.

WASHINGTON, Sept 21. -- The board of inquiry investigating the charges against Capt. Mitchell of the Revenue Marine steamer Crawford, went down the Potomae to-day to visit the Crawford, in command of the accused. All of the witnesses available here had been questioned, and it was decided to hear the testimony of several persons concerning allegations against Mitchell affecting his behavior during the naval rendezvous.

-- A.P. Hinton of Oklahoma is a "boomer.'' So is S.S. Slowson, likewise of Oklahoma. They were bosom friends, and one day Hinton traded Slowson a revolver for a watch. When the Cherokee Strip excitement began they boomed along amicably for a while, but finally quarreled over a jumped claim or something.

Among the evidences of the revival of business in this city is the imposing new clothing and furnishing-goods establishment of Messrs. Clarence L. Gans Co., at 279 Broadway, which will be formally opened to-morrow morning. Mr. Gans, the head of the firm, although a young man, has been brought up in the business, his father being the oldest clothing merchant of Philadelphia.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Miss Irene W. Coit of Norwich can no longer say that she is the only young woman who has taken the examinations at Yale University and been notified by the Faculty that, except for reasons of sex, she is in every way fitted to enter the institution.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- In his exposition of the India budget in the House of commons to-day, George Russell, Parliamentary Secretary of the Indian Office, estimated the gross revenues of the Indian Government for the next financial year at 90,000,000 tens of rupees and the expenditures at 90,600,000 tens of rupees.
LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Dullness continues in the stock market. Americans are weak under the lead of Louisville, which continues to be pressed for sale.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Yesterday's defeat did not make Mr. Reid resentful to-day; quite the contrary. He was extremely good natured in his way, but his way just at this time is to perpetually insist upon being "vindicated." Seeing an opportunity to direct attention to this inclination this morning, he fell into it, and his talk about some of yesterday's performances was like comedy.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Sept. 21 -- P.M. At no time to-day was the stock market active. From opening to close dullness ruled, and when a little activity developed only a few stocks were affected. The total transactions on the Stock Exchange fell below 115,000 shares. In short, the day was the dullest the market has seen in months.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- The market opened dull and continued very narrow all day. Atchison displayed much strength. Boston and Maine lost 2 points and Bay State Gas 1/2. The market closed quiet, but with a firm tone.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- A lively row occurred in the Police Court this afternoon. James Enker, twenty-two years old, of Brooklyn, was arraigned before Justice Noble, charged with breach of promise by Maggie Bucy, twenty years old, of Blissville. Lawyer Thomas Kadlen defended Enker and Counselor Matthew Smith represented Miss Duey.

Pim, Forwood Co., the agents for the missing steamship Alvo, have heard nothing from the ship at all, nor have they received an answer to the cable messages which they sent on Wednesday to Colon, Savanills, and Mompox. These messages were sent on account of the mysterious message which was received by Seflor Ribon several days ago.

NOTES FROM BOLTON, LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The Sagamore, which was destroyed by fire last June, is fast rising from its ashes and will be rebuilt on the same lines, the principal change made being that the laundry will now be detached from the main building. It is gratifying to know that the mischief done to the fine trees about the hotel was not as great as had been feared.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- As an outgrowth of the Religious Parliament of the fair the Brotherhood of Christian Unity was to-day organized. At the head of the roll presented for signatures wan the single statement:

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Sept. 21. -- Staten Island taxpayers are interested in the assessment rolls which have just been completed by the Richmond County Board of Assessors. The valuation of property throughout the county has been largely increased. What this increase is in the aggregate cannot be learned.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 21. -- Francis Henry Weeks, who is under guard in the Municipal Palace in this city awaiting the arrival of the New-York detectives Von. Gerichten and Reilly, sent again to-day for the correspondent of The New-York Times and said that he had decided to make another statement in regard to his flight and his affairs.

The Fall opening of the millinery department of Bloomingdale Brothers at their store. Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets and Third Avenue, took place yesterday, and the handsome, well-lighted, and well-stocked showrooms were crowded with fair admirers of the great and tasteful variety in feminine headwear.
Money on call leaned at 2 1/2@3 P cent. The last loan was made at 2 1/2 P cent.

The case of the citizen arrested in Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn, on Sunday for a "violation of an ordinance," of which an account will be found in our columns this morning, is an extremely interesting one. As is conclusively shown by the proceedings before the Police Magistrate yesterday, there was not the slightest ground for the arrest.

Brokers had an hour's amusement yesterday at the Stock Exchange over a poker debt. The loser sent to the winner as collateral ten shares of Richmond Terminal stock, whereupon the creditor broker returned word that unless the $30 due was paid in cash he would close out the collateral under the rules of the Exchange.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Led by ex-Sheriff Robert E. Davis, as Marshal, 1,000 members of the Robert E. Davis Association, Democratic, of Jersey City, disembarked from the steamer Myndert Starin, at College Point, to-day. They marched to Donnelly's Boulevard Park, where the association held its annual games and outing.

Police Justice Watson of the Ewen Street Court, Williamsburg, yesterday instituted a new style of divorce. Lawrence and Teresa Harlen asked him to decide their matrimonial difficulties. Lawrence had been arrested for non-support.

The struggle for the nomination for Assembly in the aggressive Second Assembly District promises to become one of the picturesque fights in local politics this year. The Second has ever had a reputation for furnishing redhot struggles for the local offices. It was the battle ground year after year between Patrick Divver and Thomas P. Walsh, and incidentally gave world-wide fame to Timothy D. Sullivan and the late Jeremiah Hartigan.

GUENS, Hungary, Sept. 21. -- The army manceuvers that had been in progress here and in the country hereabout closed to-day, and the palm of victory was awarded to the Army of the North. In yesterday's manceuvres the northern army assumed the offensive on a range of low-lying hills between Frauerhaid and Grosswartesdorf.

District Attorney Nicoll said yesterday that the Grand Jury was investigating the methods of doing business in the Coroners' office, but had not completed its examination of witnesses. He thought it probable that the jurors would report to-day, and it is understood they will bring in a presentment charging the Coroners with neglect of duty.

Lawyer Joseph M. Deuel made a motion yesterday before Judge Lacombe, in the United States District Court, for an order to compel Postmaster Dayton to restore to Chief Federal Supervisor of Elections John I. Davenport possession of the rooms in the Federal Building from which he was evicted some weeks ago by direction of the Secretary of the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The President sent to the Senate to-day the following nominations:

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 21. -- Fred Campbell, junior member of the firm of Boyd, Ryrie Campbell, wholesale stationers and paper dealers of this city, killed himself this evening. A few days ago the books of the firm, which does an extensive business in Canada and the United States, were seized by a special officer of the Canadian Customs Department.

The Staten Island ladies tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the courts of the Staten Island Cricket Club. Livingstone, S.I. Some lively matches were witnessed la the singles, doubles, and mixed doubles. The Kings County representatives are well to the front in all three events. They will probably have a contestant in each of the final rounds.

John F. Pidcock, commission merchant and dealer in sheep, lambs, and calves at the Central Stock Yards in Jersey City, yesterday instituted proceedings in the United States Circuit Court against Dennis Harrington, Aaron Levy, James Scanlon, Michael Scanlon, Patrick Scanlon, John Shea, Abraham Vandebeck, David Shannon, Michael J. Murphy, Joseph Adler, John J. Harrington, and Dennis Harrington, Jr., wholesale butchers, on a charge of conspiracy to boycott him in his business.

Charles Mitchell, the pugilist, had a conference last night with Police Justice Newton, the manager of the Conor lsland Athletic Club, in regard to the proposed fight between Mitchell and Corbett Newton said that Corbett was wanted to light before the Coney Island Athletic Club for a parse of $40,000. Mitchell said that thus far he had been ignored in all dealings and he proposed to have some say.
ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Sept. 21. -- A tombstone which has stood nearly two years over a grave in Green Grove Cemetery, near Keyport, was sold by a constable Tuesday to satisfy a claim for debt.

One of the clever manipulators of cards, who has made victims of lovers of draw poker all over the country from the Pacific to the Atlantic Ocean, and with his partner has raked in many thousands of dollars, was exposed at a quiet little game of draw which was played in a private parlor of the Hotel Waldorf Wednesday evening.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- To-day was the day set apart for the inspection of the Elmira Reformatory by the press of New-York State. The scheme of inspection was originated by the members of the Elmira press. Twenty representatives from papers in New-York, Brooklyn. Buffalo, Rochester, Albany, and other cities arrived in the city in the morning and were received by the city editors of local papers.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 21. -- Arlon, who is to start against the record here next week, trotted a hall mile at the track to-day in 1:01 1/4, a 2:02 1/2 gait, being driven by John Dickerson.

ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 21. -- Robert Smith, the negro who assaulted Mrs. Henry Bishop yesterday, and in the riot over whom a number of citizens were shot, was hanged by the mob shortly before 5 o'clock this morning. While J. Alien Watts, Judge Woods, and others were addressing the crowd, Sergt Griffin, with two officers, took the negro from the jail and spirited him out of town.

Sensational developments are expected in regard to the suicide, Sunday, of Robert Hanna, President of the Board of Trustees of the Beecher Memorial Church in Brooklyn. Last evening a committee appointed to investigate the matter held a secret meeting in the church, Herkimer Street and Rockaway Avenue, but the members refused to say what occurred at the meeting.
From the Boston Journal, Sept. 20. The New-York Tribune, in an editorial article to which it gives special prominence, says:

A notable gathering of churchmen took place yesterday in West Eighty-fourth Street, between Eighth and Columbus Avenues, where the foundation walls have been laid for the new Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Matthew. Many members of the various Protestant Episcopal churches assembled with the clergy and the congregation of St. Matthew's Church to assist in the ceremonies of laying the cornerstone of the new church.

The controversy which has been going on between Oliver Sumner Teall and the Directors of the Vaudeville Club had fresh interest added to it yesterday. Mr. Teall wrote another open letter to the Executive Committee, replying to the one published in The New-York Times which they addressed to him on Sept. 19.

CHARLES BUTTRICK, eighty years old, a retired Fulton Market produce dealer, died yesterday morning at his home in Monticello, N.Y. Mr. Buttrick was a descendant of one of the early settlers of Massachusetts. His grandfather was Major Buttrick, one of the minute men who defended the bridge at Concord at the Battle of Lexington. Mr. Buttrick was born at Pepperell, Mass., in 1813.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 21. -- The finishing department of Oliver Brothers' South Tenth Street mill resumed work to-day. The announcement of the resumption caused a great crowd of foreigners and old employes to assemble about the gates, and a detachment of police was ordered on duty.

Mayor Boody's long-threatened application to have expunged from the court records the minutes of the June Grand Jury relating to his connection with the trolley franchise grabs, upon which the Grand Jury founded its famous presentment against him, was made yesterday before Judge Moore in the Kings County Court of Sessions.

CENTRALIA, Ill., Sept. 21. -- An attempt was made to rob the New-Orleans limited train on the Illinois Central Road shortly after 11 o'clock last night. Just outside this city, and in the battle which followed between the three robbers and the train hands, one of the robbers was mortally wounded and three of the train crew were badly hurt.
LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Private dispatches received here to-day from Rio Janeiro state that the situation there is unchanged.

The foul and rubbish-covered plaza site at the Brooklyn end of the bridge, with its piles of refuse, its crumbling ruins, its dead animals and rotting clothes, and its pools of malodorous, muddy water, has not offended Mayor David A. Boody's delicate senses of sight and smell.

"I have never shirked hard work." said Police Capt. Schmittberger yesterday afternoon in the West Forty-seventh Street Station to a reporter for The New-York Times, "but I am not hankering for another such experience as my men and myself had this morning, when three dangerous fires occurred in different parts of the precinct within a couple of hours.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Public opinion in the South on the financial situation has been grossly misrepresented by some of those who might be supposed to represent this section in Congress and by others who presume to speak for it through the columns of Southern newspapers or by correspondence with papers in the other parts of the country.

Bradstreet's to -morrow will say: "Aside from the increased activity in general trade at Atlanta, Savannah, Dallas, St. Louis, Omaha, Kansas City, Milwaukee, and Minneapolis, no improvement in demand for stapies is reported in contrast with last week. Higher prices for cotton seem to have stimulated shipments in Georgia, but elsewhere receipts at primary markets are alow.

-- Emil Levy, the pianist, has just had the experience of being saved from drowning by a woman, Miss Mallie Beck, the contralto. He is little, and she is big and muscular and swims like a duck. They were out in a rowboat, which upset, and Levy found the distance to shore too much for him. Miss Beck towed him out, rolled him on the beach, and poured brandy down his throat.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- A private telegram sent from Rio de Janeiro this morning, which reached London at noon, says the Government troops still hold possession of the city.

Miss Georgians F. Putnam, the colored teacher of Public School No. 83 in Brooklyn, has been suspended by the local school committee for incompetency. This, at least, is the charge made against her, although she holds a certificate from Superintendent Maxwell guaranteeing her fitness to teach.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It would appear that "W.C.C.," in his letter to The New-York Times has overlooked the engagement between the Wasp and Frolic, fought Oct. 18, 1812, in latitude 37 north, longitude 65 west. Roosevelt's "The Naval War of 1812" says of this fight: "There was a very heavy sea running, which caused the vessels to pitch and roll heavily.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- For the second time this Summer the World's Fair festivities came near being marred by a dreadful calamity. To-day a balloon ascension had almost a fatal termination. It being State Commissioners day special preparations were made by the World's Fair Directors to attract crowds to that part of the grounds. One of the amusements arranged for was a balloon ascension by an old and experienced aeronaut, Prof. King of Philadelphia.

No real progress was made in the Senate yesterday, unless the lapse of one day may be regarded as progress. Mr. PLAIT'S proposition to change the rules so as to permit the majority to secure action was talked about. It received somewhat cynical treatment from Mr. WOLCOTT, who invited the friends of repeal to bring it to a vote, apparently confident that a majority could not be had for it.

Lawrence Cunningham, ayoung negro coachman for Philip Gombrecht, a wealthy retired merchant living at 123 West Sixty-second Street, was held in the Yorkville Police court yesterday for trial on a charge of larceny. Cun ningham had been Mr. Gombrecht's trusted servant for several years.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- M. Emile Zola, the distinguished French novelist, who is visiting this city, delivered an address at a meeting to-day of the Institute of Journalists held at the Mansion House, the official residence of the Lord Mayor of London. The subject of his address was "Anonymity in Journalism."

The Grand Jury yesterday continued the investigation of the Coroners' office. Coroner Shea and Stenographer Strassner were examined in regard to the delay in furnishing papers to the District Attorney's office. The examination of witnesses will be resumed on Monday, and it is expected that a presentment will be made censuring the lax methods of conducting the business of the office.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read with interest your editorial of this morning on "Clearing House Certificates." There is, of course, no objection to one bank making a loan to another bank. If these Clearing House certificates were simply ordinary promissory notes secured by a deposit of gold bills receivable as collateral security taken by a creditor bank from a debtor bank, there would be no proper objection.
"The verdict of the jury is that David J. Solomon is perfectly sane."

There is grave dissatisfaction in the NewYork Symphony Orchestra. Notwithstanding Mr. Morris Reno's assertions, less than twothirds of the orchestra who played with Mr. Damrosch last year have been re-engaged for the coming season. The reason for this is unknown to any or the discharged members.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- The suite of Patrick Coleman of Hoboken against the Monmouth Park Association was tried to-day before Justice of the Peace David H. Wyckoff. The plaintiff did not appear, but was represented by Lawyer James Steen of Eatontown. The track officials also failed to show up, but their interests were looked after by Counse for Frederick Parker of Freehold.

The Directors of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company and of the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company yesterday announced a reduction of 10 per cent. in the wages of more than half their employes, to take effect Oct. 1. It created excitement, and not only the men affected by the cut, but those who are exempt from the order, threaten to retaliate by striking and tying up every elevated railroad line in the city.

KINGSBURY, Ind., Sept. 22 -- Eleven bodies resting on improvised slabs or on tables under the roof of the modest Masonic Hall of this village, and a score of injured registered as inmates of the City Hospital at Peru, seventy miles distant, tell the story of the latest railroad horror, of which this village was the scene at daylight this morning.

The October number of Harper's is a number for all the people. Its interest is continuous, and its topics are surprisingly varied. It thoroughly sustains the best traditions of the magazine, and these, all in all, are the most striking in American periodical literature. Mr. Davis's paper on undergraduate life at Oxford should be read by every man now in college or who ever was in college.

VIENNA, Sept. 22 -- Emperor Francis Joseph has issued an order in which he declares that he is entirely satisfied with the way the army manoeuvres near Guens, Hungary, which were concluded yesterday, were carried out. His Majesty praises the efficiency of the regular troops and the landwehr, and especially expresses gratification at the good discipline shown by the soldiers and their manifest appreciation of the object of the manoeuvres.

W.C. Conant, who is the editor of The Sanitary Era, has taken exception to the opinions expressed by Dr. John R. Paxton in his sermon of last Sunday, which was printed in The New-York Times last Monday.

Tammany's Committee on Organization met last night at the Wigwam and gave another reminder that a local campaign is slowly getting under way. Hundreds of Wigwam celebrities crowded the hall of the Committee on Organization, which is in the basement and is altogether too small for its purposes. Nearly all the leaders were there, and Henry D. Purroy presided.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Every friend of the obelisk in Central Park must cordially assent to the timely caution expressed in your editorial of Sept. 17 lest anything be done during the process of restoration with the mere purpose of decoration. The only safe action is to replace the former gliding so far as certainly known; that is, the glided cap and the gliding of the hieroglyphs.

The organized depositors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn met last night at Haviland Hall, in that city, and unanimously empowered the Committee of Five to proceed either civilly or criminally against the Directors of the institution.

Assistant District Attorney Shorter of Kings County was asked yesterday if he knew there was to be an international prize fight at the Coney Island Athletic Club between Charles Mitchell, champion of England, and James Corbett, alleged "champion pugilist of the world," and in the absence of District Attorney Ridgway what he would do about it.

Irving Bogart, the ten-year-old son of Peter Bogart of Flatbnsh, was almost instantly killed by a trolley car last evening. The child ran into Flatbush Avenue to board a horse car in tow of a trolley car. He was driven off and jumped in front of Trolley Car No. 1,223. He was knocked down, and the wheels passed over his body, disemboweling him.

It is a bad case of father-in-law instead of motther-in-law with Charles E. Converse, if his statements are to be believed. Mr. Converse is employed in a confidential capacity in thr Gallatin National Bank. His father-in-law, John A. Sohults, was at one time a prominent figure in the woolen trade of this city.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 22 -- Within sixty days Archbishop Kain will be Administrator of the Diocese of St. Louis by appointment from Rome, and Archbishop Kenrick will be suitably provided for.

Mrs. W. Clarence Greene, the wife of a painter living at 2,178 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, has confessed that she is the woman with whom Robert Hanna, the Trustee of the Beecher Memorial Church, who committed suicide Sunday, was in love. Last evening, at the request of herself and her husband, her name was dropped from the roll of church membership.
Money on call loaned at 2@3 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

Mary Muller, one of the principal witnesses against Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer. the wholesale poisoner, secretly departed last Wednesday from the boarding house in Brooklyn where she had been placed by District Attorney Nicoll to await Meyer's trial. Late Wednesday night Mr. Nicoll was informed that she had started for Chicago.

NEW-YORK FRIDAY, Sept. 22 -- P.M. So far as volume of business was concerned, there was little that was noteworthy in to-day's stock market. Total sales barely exceed 142,000 shares, and except for a few specialitis, dullness was the rule from the opening to the close.

The new Brazilian cruiser Benjamin Constant, which has sailed from Toulon for Rio de Janeiro to join, it is thought, the forces of Admiral Mello, is one of the most effective armed cruisers of her size afloat.

A reporter for The New-York Times called on District Attorney Nicoll yesterday to ascertain what he thought of the attempt made by the absconding embezzler Weeks to exculpate himself in the statement given to The New-York Times's correspondent at San Jose.
He Democratic Assembly District Conventions were hold in Brooklyn last evening. The following delegates to the Democratic State Convention were elected:

CHICAGO, Sept 22. -- This was the fifth night of the international match at English billiards between Join Roberts, Jr., and Frank Ives in Central Music Hall, and Ives won, but Roberts reached 1,275 points. It was a most exciting game. The contest will end to-morrow night.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 22 -- Ex-Mayor Gleason has another political fight on his hands. His party is opposing him because he will not consent to the nomination of Stephen J. Kavanagh for Police Justice and James Robinson for member of Assembly. Kavanagh was elected. Justice four years ago on the Gleason ticket, and Robinson to the Assembly last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- At the invitation of members of the Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures, Representative McCreary of Kentucky to-day appeared before the committee and advocated the favorable consideration of his bill providing for the appointment of a joint Congressional and Commercial Monetary Commission.

The Grand Central Real Estate Exchange was formally organized yesterday by the election of the following officers: President -- Philip A. Smyth; Vice President -- John S. Mapes; Secretary -- Allan G. Macdonnell; Treasurer -- Joseph J. Glesson; Counsel -- Thomas Gilleran. The intention is to begin business as soon as practicable in the rooms on East Forty-first Street.

"Do you want to see a curiosity?" asked William H. McDonough, Mayor Gilroy's confidential clerk, as a reporter for The New-York Times entered Mr. McDonough's office, an anteroom of the Mayor's office, yesterday afternoon.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept 22. -- Twelve desperate lawbreakers were sentenced this atternoon in the Court of Sessions byt County Judge Garretson. They included two gangs of burglars and three Jail raiders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Our pensioners number nearly 1,000,000. The number has increased nearly 100,000 in a year. If the increase of the next year is but two-thirds of that of the last, the total number of pensioners will largely exceed 1,000,000. That is the promise of the Commissioner of Pensions, according to his annual report, just issued.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Sept 22. -- After two months of idleness, the rolling mill of the Valentine Iron Company has again been put in operation. The mill will be run as long as the company can sell its iron.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- These were 280,000 ounces of sliver offered for sale to the Treasury Department at prices ranging from $0.74 to $0.74 50 an ounce, of which 30,000 ounces were purchased at $0.74 an ounce, and the same price offered to the remainder. The purchases thus far this month aggregated 1,510,000 ounces.
