PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- The market has been stagnant to-day. In traction stocks Metropolitan was steady at 94 and Philadelphia was weaker and offered at 81 3/4. The work on the trolley lines is progressing favorably, and the Tasker Street line was opened yesterday. Baltimore is quiet, and there appears to be considerable United Gas wanted around 57.

The Valkyrie arrived safely in port yesterday morning. She had a hard time crossing the Atlantic, but reached this harbor safe and sound, and during a most tempestuous gale proved herself a stanch and able craft and a fit champion to sail for the blue ribbon of the yachting world, the America's Cup. Now she is riding idly at anchor off the Atlantic Yacht Club House at Bay Ridge.

The City of Brooklyn and the County of Kings, to which Brooklyn furnishes almost the whole of the population, have gained a very undesirable reputation within the last few years. For one thing, Kings County has come to be regarded as the secure refuge of that peculiar form of brutal lawlessness known as prize fighting.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Sept. 22. -- The scene of the recent prairie fire on the Pawnee Reservation is horrible to look upon. Scattered all over the prairie are partly-burned wagons, wrecked camp outfits, charred remains of household goods, and here and there the body of a horse. For miles and miles, as far as the eye can reach, is a black and desolate waste.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- The market opened dull, and, outside of New-England and the copper stocks, was featureless. Boston and Montana Mining made a gain of 3/4. Atchison displayed its usual strength. The market closed dull.

Those who are in the conspiracy with the present management of the Reading Company to destroy and dismember the system in the interest of rival coal corporations attempt to give their schemes plausibility by laying stress on what they allege to be a fact -- that Reading properties, as they exist, are of poor account anyway.
Mrs. Fanny Fitch, widow of Edward Fitch and the mother of Congressman Ashbel P. Fitch of this city, died at Rye, N.Y., on Thursday of pneumonia.

According to a statement issued by the Pension Bureau at Washington, the Board of Revision is disposing of about 1,600 per week of the cases in which payment has been suspended and will complete its work of revising those cases by Oct. 10. The result will be the retention of about 75 per cent. of those whose cases have been reexamined, though in some instances the ratings will be changed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- It was to be expected that the silver Senators, who realize how powerised they would be to defeat repeal if the rules of the Senate were designed to facilitate the transaction of business, would hasten to attack the closure amendment to the rules submitted by Mr. Platt (Rep., Conn.,) yesterday.

The result will be the retention of about 75 per cent. of those whose cases have been reexamined, though in some instances the ratings will be changed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- It was to be expected that the silver Senators, who realize how powerised they would be to defeat repeal if the rules of the Senate were designed to facilitate the transaction of business, would hasten to attack the closure amendment to the rules submitted by Mr. Platt (Rep., Conn.,) yesterday.

The steamship Prinz Willem I., which arrived here yesterday from Port au Prince, Haiti, brought the information that the Haitian war ship Alexandre Petion had foundered near Cape Tiberon and all on board except one sailor had perished. Among those lost were a number of diplomats who were going to San Domingo to negotiate a treaty between that country and Haiti.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- There was a fair trade in wheat to-day, principally for local account. Prices ruled lower. The opening was about 1 8c below yesterday, becoming weak, and with come fluctuations prices declined 5 8@3 4c for December and 1 2c for,May, then recovered moat of the decline, but again eased off, the close being 1 2c lower for December and 1 2c for May.

Senator MORGAN has joined the filibusters against the Silver Purchase Repeal bill. He is not so good a Democrat as we thought him. In fact, he cannot be reckoned a Democrat at all, since he now stands opposed to the majority of his party in the Senate, in the House, and in the Nation, as well as to the Democratic Administration.
State Organizer John H. Jewell of the Republican State League has resigned. The following letters explain the resignation:

Lawless east side Hebrew Anarchists had a small slot last night The base of operations was at East Broadway and Pike Street. Three young men Insisted, on pitching cobblestones from the door of 11 Pike Street, where Frele Arbeitor Stimme is published. One or the stones hit a passer-by, who had to be taken to a neighboring drug store to have his head dressed.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Notwithstanding desperate efforts by the State Machine men, under the leadership or Robert F. Owens, Superintendent of Section 3 of the Erie Canal, the Montgomery County Democratic Convention at Fonda to-morrow will send a delegation friendly to the national Administration to the State Convention at Saratoga.

Two more matches have been finished in the Jefferson Heights Tennis Club tournament. Miss Jewitt winning from Miss Johnson and H.S. Mitchell defeating R.J. Mullins. The Jewitt-Johnson match required three sets to decide it. Miss Jewitt winning easily in the last set. The score was 6-3, 5-7, 6-2. In the men's singles Mitchell defeated Mullins two love sets, 6-0, 6-0.

We leave the victims of Mr. F.H. WEEKS to deal with the specifications of his second statement, published in yesterday's TIMES, and to defend themselves, if they can, against his charges of ingratitude. It must be owned that the charges are a little surprising. WEEKS says that their money is not in his possession.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Emma L. Deshong of North Vineland, N.J., has brought suit in the Hudson County Circuit Court against the Merchants' Insurance Company of Newark to recover $1,000 insurance on furniture burned in 1889. Mrs. Deshong was employed as housekeeper for John L. Mason, the fruit Jar inventor, whose wife was ill.

The annual Fall regatta of the New-York Canoe Club yesterday afternoon eave the spectators any amount of fan. The races were held over the club coarse at Bensonhurst, and although the wind died out toward the close of the afternoon and left most of the Bailing canoes with napping canvas, the sport was enjoyable, and the events exciting.

There had never been a beginning, at least that we could remember. Since we had known ourselves Ruth and I had known and loved each other. Together we had played on the sands when we were so little that each one was a care to the other. Together we had toddled, hand in hand, to the primary school, and sauntered arm in arm to the Foundation.
NEWPORT, K.I., Sept. 23. -- The comparative test of English and American torpedo nets, in which the Navy Department is groatty interested, will probably take place in this harbor early next week.

There are two different tribunals at Rome to which is intrusted the judgment of books, pamphlets, articles, and other writings referred to them as liable to a charge of endangering faith and morals. One of these is the Congregation of the Holy Office, or Inquisition, and the other is the Congregation of the Index.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- After being roundly abused, principally by Senators who have a selfish interest in perpetuating the present unbusinesslike rules of the Senate, the Platt amendment calling for cloture upon the demand of a majority has been referred to the Senate Committee on Rules. Mr. Platt has given notice that he will present some arguments to the committee in favor of the amendment which he was unable to advance in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23. -- United States Commissioner of Navigation E.C. O'Brien has just submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury an exhaustive report making certain recommendations to provide for the better protection of life and property at sea and along the coast of the United States and in the North Atlantic Ocean.

Major H. Capel L. Holden of the Royal Artillery, British Army, sailed on the New-York Wednesday for Southampton alter completing a short tour of inspection of various United States gun establishments.

The Methodists of Ridgewood, just inside of the city line of Brooklyn, are about to begin the erection of a handsome new church. Plans and designs arranged by the architects. Weary Kramer of Alcron, Ohio, and New-York City, have recently been approved by the Building Committee, and work will begin in a few days.

SOUTHAMPTON, Sept. 23. -- The Hamburg-American Line steamer Augusta Victoria, Capt. Barends, from Hamburg Sept. 21 for New-York, was upon arrival here ordered to delay her sailing for forty-eight hours. The cause of her detention was that the Hamburg-American Company has, in view of the cholera in the vicinity of Hamburg, decided to make Southampton the port of departure for their express steamers instead of Hamburg.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 23. -- The most successful bicycle meet, both from a financial and a racing standpoint, that has ever been held in Philadelphia was the international tournament on the Tioga track this afternoon. It was under the auspices of the Associated Cycling Clubs, and the attendance is estimated at 8,000.

The Stock Exchange theoretically holds itself aloof from the Consolidated Exchange and all its members, but yesterday the dissolution of the Consolidated Exchange firm of Harris Co. broke prices on Chicago Gas, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Sugar, and St. Paul stocks which were carried by this firm for a long account. P.M. Harris and B.G. Sanford were the members of the firm.

New-York has not been kind to one member of Nat Goodwin's company, and his part in "In Mizzoura" has been played by understudy ever since the piece was produced here. "Spot," the little Spitz dog, which originally appeared in Chicago, has been under the weather ever since his arrival here, and, singularly enough, the words and "business" of the play in which he figures exactly describes the misfortunes which have overtaken him.

At the central entrance of the Refuge Home we were received by an Austrian priest and conducted into a spacious apartment with whitewashed walls and marble floor, the coolness of which was most refreshing, as the afternoon happened to be exceptionally hot.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept 23. -- The report that the Rev. Dr. Briggs of New-York might occupy the Cumberland Presbyterian Church here was incorrect. The church belongs to the Rev. John Miller of the Princeton Presbytery, who says that before the church shall be occupied by a Briggsits he will occupy the pulpit himself.

Roanoke, Va., is a thriving city of more than 16,000 inhabitants. It has grown to its present size and prosperity from the shambling little out-of-the-way hamlet of Big Lick, with less than 500 people, in the last fifteen or twenty years. Its favorable location and the natural resources that surrounded it brought it into communication with the rest of the world by railroad, and a "boom" was created.

Here is a man who robs widows and children of over $1,000,000, and every attempt to punish him is frustrated by the sensational press, which notifies his friends of every move against him." * * *
To the Editor of The New-York Times: In view of the number of cases recently reported of poisoning by the use of various fungi as food, a few words on the subject may not be amiss.

An old French sea Captain who has made a lifelong study of matters pertaining to collisions at sea, rules of the road, fog signals, , has devised a clever scheme for avoiding accidents in thick or foggy weather. While the general ideas have been advanced before, the particular system here employed is thought to have considerable merit.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept 23. -- Vassar College opened Friday evening with the chapel service. It is impossible yet to tell the number of students that will be enrolled. It is the opinion of college officials that the present financial troubles will not make a noticeable difference in the attendance.

LONDON, Sept 23. -- A dispatch sent this morning from Rio Janeiro has been received by the Exchange Telegraph Company. The message states that the Senate was in session at the time of the filing of the dispatch, and that negotiations for peace were proceeding between the Government and Admiral Mello, the commander of the rebel naval forces.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Edward Cavanaugh, an inspector for the Westinghouse Electric Company in the Art Gallery at Jackson Park, is confined in the Woodlawn Police station on a charge of robbery. The alleged robbery took place yesterday morning in the dark passageway between the main Fine Arts Building and the West Annex. Mrs. William M, Pennell of Brunswick, Mo., was the victim.

Brazil has not had a very happy time in the last half dozen years. Some of the smaller South American nations occasionally have outbreaks which are dignified with the title "revolution," but Brazil certainly had a political revolution, not wholly without bloodshed. In 1889, and now she seems to be in the throes of another.

OWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Democrats of Tioga County held their convention here to-day. Only two Administration Democrats were elected to seats in the convention. The Hill men by fraud carried every election district in the county without exception.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- A moderate business was transacted in wheat to-day, and the feeling developed was rather weak. The opening was quite firm, and prices were 14@35C higher than the closing last night. After a low moments or steadiness prices de clined steadily to the close, which was about 34C be low final figures of yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The week just closed has been one of exceptional dullness on 'Change, and prices have failed to show marked declines only because no securities were pressed for sale, except Louisville and, to-day, Erie issues, on rumors of defaults on bonds and an assessment on shares.

John Williams, a colored man, who was shot through the left lung by Grahams Moore at Kirkwood two weeks ago, yesterday submitted to a heroic operation at the City Hospital in the removal of half of the seventh rib, says The St. Louis Globe Democrat of Monday. The operation was conducted under remarkable circumstances, as the patient was not placed under the influence of an anesthetic, and remained perfectly conscious throughout the ordeal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- The final game in the six-night match between Frank C. Ives of Chicago and John Roberts, Jr., of London was played in Central Music Hall to-night before 2,000 spectators, the American being declared the winner of the game and the week's contest amid much enthusiasm.

The following statement has been prepared by the counsel of the Jaeger Company concerning the decision of Judge Gildersleeve in the suit of the Jaeger Company against Le Bontillier Brothers of Fourteenth Street, and a request is made that The Times print it in its entirety, thus removing any impressions that have been created to the detriment of the Jaeger Company.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We women fail to see that our position and assertion regarding the need of a labor home for homeless and destitute women is in any way altered by the statements of Mr. Hebberd, Superintendent of the Charity Organization Society, in The New-York Times on Friday last. What is more, we speak from a basis of facts, though we are said to be criticising without information.

NEW-YORK SATURDAY, Sept. 23 -- P.M. The stock market was dull again to-day, nactivity being the rule from opening to close. The excellent showing made by the bank statement failed to have any marked effect, and at the last the list was weak. Total sales fell below 82,000 shares, and even in the specialties, which nave received the lion's share of attention lately, there was very little doing.

It isn't every woman that can make a home breakfast table inviting, and we all know it. Most houses are left from 6 until 8 in the morning to the servants, who exercise their own taste, so far as the table is concerned, not always with success.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The business men who have interests in Brazil, especially the coffee merchants of Baltimore, are criticising the Navy Department for what they believe to be tardiness in sending ships to Rio. The impression has gone oat that the Charleston had left Montevideo and was by this time at Rio.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 23. -- About 500 spectators witnessed the races at the tournament of the Mercury Wheel Club on the half-mile track of the Flushing Driving Club this afternoon. The principal races o the day were the one mile handicap and the one mile race for the championship of Long Island. Mr. John Lewis Childs of Floral Park donated a diamond medal for first prize in this event.

Parents amuse themselves with the phonetic disabilities of their offspring, and often take no pains to seek for a remedy in cases where children come to years far beyond babyhood without mastering the mechanism of speech. This is probably especially usual when the parents, one or both, have been themselves neglected, because imperfect enunciation is then regarded as consecrated to the new god Heredity, and is treated with respect not unmingled with admiration.

I heard Teller repeat that mournful tale of the downfall of his cherished white metal, while Stevenson sat complacently in his chair. I counted ten sleeping Senators in the chamber and two who were wide awake.

The big shop of Ehrich Brothers, at Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, is crowded early and late with buyers of dress goods during these early Autumn days, and the assortment shown in all departments seems to cover the widest range of demand. In silks, particularly, the firm says: "We can match any sample."

It is regarded as a foregone conclusion that the United States Navy Department, in view of the recent action of the British Admiralty, will adopt boiler ferrules for the new ships of the navy. At present none of the new United States war vessels, so far as can be ascertained, is provided with ferrules.

The Metropolitan Association games on the New-Jersey Athletic Club grounds on Oct. 7 promise to be very interesting. Chairman Sullivan has received a communication from the Tourists Cycling Club of Paterson, N.J., to the effect that E.L. Stone, England's famous pole-vaulting champion, and a man who at one time held the phenomenal record of 11 feet 7 inches, is now in this, country and that he proposes to compete at the coming games.

The United States flagship San Francisco proceeded to the Brooklyn Navy Yard Wednesday to dock. The San Francisco has been placed in the Simpson wooden dry dock. When overhauled she will be made ready for a Winter's cruise in the West Indies.

The official trial of the new cruiser Columbia is expected to take place within three weeks. The coming event is regarded as the most important one in the history of trial trips of the navy. The Columbia is under contract to attain a maximum speed of 22 knots per hour, and to show herself able to maintain at sea a speed of 21 knots an hour.

LENOX, Mass., Sept 23. -- The bright September days so attract the cottagers that some who thought of going away have determined to remain a while longer. There has been a slight frost, so that the leaves have begun to turn. The east mountain side, beyond the Housatonic River, has already put on its robes of purple, scarlet, and gold.

The congregation of the old Sixth Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, in Brooklyn, of which the Rev. W.W. Clark is pastor, will in a few days begin the erection of a handsome new church, parsonage, and Sunday school hall. The group of buildings were designed by Weary Kramer, architects of Akron, Ohio, and this city.

The physical beauty of women should last until they are past fifty. Nor does beauty reach its zenith under the age of thirty-five or forty. Helen of Troy comes upon the stage at the age of forty. Aspasia was thirty-six when married to Pericles, and she was a brilliant figure thirty years thereafter.

For police purposes Ireland is divided into thirty-six counties and ridings. Dublin has a police force of its own, while in Belfast and Cork a fixed force of the Royal Irish Constabulary is maintained. Each county is divided into districts numbering from two to twelve, and each district into sub-districts varying from three to sometimes as many as thirty, when temporary huts and special protection posts are reckoned.

It has been known by the police of the West Thirtieth Street Station for some time that a man had been selling tickets on the races. He explained that, as it was impossible to run a poolroom, he and others had determined the betting public must not be left out in the cold. Therefore, bets were registered in hallways, in corners, or under lamp posts.

The members of the Teutonic Athletic Club an organization composed of the members of the crew of the White Star steamer of that name, had its last day's otuing of the season yesterday afternoon. The steamer George Star was chartered and conveyed the members and their friends to Oak Point, where the race took place.

John B. Clements of the Christy Fire Clay Company has secured an option on 6,000 acres of coal land in the Ouachita River district in Arkansas, which may go far toward solving the smoke question. It is what is known as smokeless coal. It can be burned on the floor in a parlor without giving off any smoke.

Ordinary histories of the United States, after briefly relating the vain but somewhat dramatic attempt of the French Minister "Citizen Genet," as he was called, to involve this country in the complications and troubles that made European politics so remarkable at the close at the last century, dismiss him after his recall by the French Government at the request of President Washington without a word as to his subsequent career.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- The market opened dull and was featureless during the short session, closing at slight concessions from the opening. Clearing House exchanges to-day were $13,785,070, as against $13,831,324 for the same day of last year; balances to-day, $2,006,833, against $1,598,235 on corresponding day of last year.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $6,956,649, of which $1,640,050 was in dry goods and the rest in general merchandise. Imports of specie were $1,332,434. Exports of specie were $795,525.

The canoeist is Mr. Thomas M. Porter of the Mersey Canoe Club belonging to Liverpool. He rose at 5 o'clock on Tuesday morning and, finding the breeze, although fresh, was fair, and there was only a small popple in Folkestone Bay, he determined to start for the French coast. In the hurry to get ready he was unable to wait for a breakfast to be prepared, and started without one.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 23. -- Three purse races, one of which resulted in the only split-heat contest of the week ended the long meeting at Narraganett Park. Fortnna, a daughter of Fashion Farm's old stallion Jay Gould, surprised the knowing ones by stopping away from a good field in three rapid heats, the second one ten seconds faster than her record before the race.
Some words said recently by Dr. Yorke Davis in The Gentleman's Magazine have a distinct value to mothers.

Count de Langler Villars and Marquis Jullhem do Pothvav of Paris are guests at the Cambridge Hote. They arrived on Friday from Haiti, to which country Count de Villars is Minister. He is visiting the United States to regain his health and, incidentally, to see the World's Fair.

An Interesting decision, defining the rights of the United States under the New-York State inheritance laws, has been handed down by Surrogate Fitzgerald in regard to the estate of Gen. George W. Cullom, who died Feb. 28, 1892, leaving an estate valued at about $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23. -- Admiral Erben's flagship Chicago will probably be ordered home late in the Fall, if the New-York is ready for foreign service, to undergo extensive repairs to her boilers and machinery. Surprise was expressed when she was sent to the Mediterranean. Last December a board reported the boilers unsafe.

A postulant fetched me and led me through a labyrinth of passages to the church. Although the building was almost in darkness, I could see that it was in the pointed style, and that it was marked by a cold elegance befitting its special purpose. The nave was divided near the middle by a Gothic screen of wood artistically carved, although the ornamental motive had been kept in subjection.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Hill machine, it is said, will form a new County Democratic Committee next week, call primaries and conventions, and send a full contesting delegation from Albany County to the State Convention.

Six weeks ago telegraphic announcement was made that a United States war ship had been attacked and disabled by the sealing steamer Alexander, and the world next morning was talking about the extraordinary event.

In the first rush of Autumn novelties there is a natural desire to see everything at once, and women go home from a shopping excursion with a sense of hopeless bewilderment, convinced that selections from such limitless variety will be impossible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The large speed premiums which nave been earned this year by contractors for naval ships have led the Navy Department to formulate new rules for the guidance of inspection boards in the trials of the three new ships which are to be held this month.
One of the most curious accidents in the history of the North River water front happened to the big Fall River steamboat Pilgrim last evening as she was about to leave her slip at Pier 28.

Mr. Woodbury Kane, Mr. Ralph N. Eilis, and Mr. Herman Duryea, who went to England with Mr. Royal Phelps Carroll and the cutter Navahoe, returned on the steamship Paris yesterday. They came away before the race for the Cape May Cap, in order to be present at the cap races here.

The name of Judge Isaac H. Maynard was hissed at the meeting of the Tammany General Committee of the Twenty-first Assembly District, held Thursday night. After the hissing there were cries of "Shame!" "Shame!" It was a disputed question whether these cries were due to the mention of Mr. Maynard's name or to the fact that there had been hissing.

One has a kind of contempt for the collector who has no specialty, and buys without discrimination, and even without inspection. Mr. Heber, the brother of the Bishop, was a purchaser of this class. "A book is a book," he said, and he bought all that came in his way by cartloads and shiploads and in whole libraries, on which, in some cases, he never cast his eyes.

J. W. Schofield, the champion bicycle rider of England, and Harry Wheeler, the crack professional rider of this country, will take part in a match race shortly for $1,000 a side. They will probably ride on Manhattan Field on Oct. 7 at the races of the National Cycling Association. The contest will be beat three out of five races: one mile, scratch.

The worms know well that rapid heaving of the soil which betokens the approach of a mole to their innocent burrows, and the moment they feel it rush wildly to the surface, prepared rather to face the worst that lark or blackbird may bring upon them than to await the onslaught of their most ruthless and bloodthirsty enemy.

It is stated in army circles that there is a growing opinion that the new small-calibre rifle for the army will not be a favorite with sharpshooters. Generally speaking, there appears to be little foundation for this belief other than the knowledge that in most European services where small-calibre rifles are in use no attempt is made to provide the new arm with finely-graduated sights.

ST. JOHN'S, N. F., Sept. 23. -- A case of barratry developed near here yesterday. The schooner Tiger, Goodwin, master, of and for Yarmouth N. S., went ashore at Trepassey last week under suspicious circumstances. It was thought the vessel was lost designedly, as there were no provisions or cargo aboard. No attempt was made to got her off.

The Fulton Street prayer meeting, an institution familiar to all down-town business men, celebrated its thirty-sixth anniversary yesterday noon. After thirty-six years of service, interrupted by scarcely a day's absence, its founder, the Rev. J. C. Lauphier, retired from his charge. The services yesterday were conducted by C, F. Cutler. Addresses were made by the Rev. Mr. Huggins, Poet Horner, C. C. Crittenton, and the old leader.

A singular story in connection with the French elections has just been made public. The hero of it is a revolutionist named Chauviere, who has become a candidate for the Grentele district. Baring a meeting of the electors he was charged with Having shot a fireman in the course of an emeuto at La Villette on Aug. 14, 1870, for which two other revolutionists were condemned to death.

Joseph Gordon, the builder, who once represented the old Eighteenth Assembly District in the Assembly, is now being talked of in the new Twenty-third Assembly District for the lower house, to succeed William B. Ellison, Mr. Gordon, however, prefers to devote his time to his business, and he said yesterday that he was not a candidate and did not want the place.
PERU, Ind., Sept. 23. -- The passengers wounded in the Wabash accident at Kingsbury were brought to the company's hospital at this place.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 23. -- Robert A. Ammon, a New-York lawyer, who lives on Grymes Hill in the most fashionable quarter of Staten Island, is again in trouble with his servants. He has been sued for wages by servant girls, and some time ago was fined $50 for an assault upon a young woman.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 23. -- The china dinner service owned by Gov. Saltonstall of Connecticut in 1708 is likely to become a subject of great interest in the State, especially with collectors. Within a few months three pieces of this set have come to light, and there is hope of discovering other specimens.

George W. Senk, Jr., three and a half years old, the son of Patrolman George W. Senk of the West One Hundredth Street Police Station, was run over and killed yesterday afternoon by one of the heavy wagons of the Manhattan Ice Company. The policeman lives at 38 West Ninety-eighth Street, and his son was playing with some other lads in front of 48 West Ninety-eighth Street.

Three men were arrested in Sixth Avenue last night for insulting young women. They gave their names and addresses as follows: Glen B. Harris, forty-eight years old, of 2,135 Seventh Avenue, Secretary of the Pneumatic Tool Company of 67 Hudson Street; James N. Towle, thirty-two years old, of the Metropolitan Hotel, and George H. Williams, fifty-seven years old, of the Adams House, Little Twelfth Street, both salesmen for the same concern.

Detectives from the Mercer Street Police Station saw a crowd of negroes engaged last night in angry talk at Bleecker and Thompson Streets, and on inquiry they learned that Henry Wootson had been accusing Thomas Jordan of having shot a man at Shady Side, N.J., yesterday morning. Jordan was arrested.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23. -- Once in a while, and that not very frequently, the Bureau of Education gets out a book. The publications of the bureau are not usually attractive, for the reason that they seem to have been long before anticipated, the bureau being many weeks behind the rest of the Government in that respect.

It is a general tendency of the American people in the management of their public affairs to get rid of talk. The boast of a recent leader of the House of Representatives that it was, thank Heaven, not a deliberative assembly is not authenticated, but it was not wide of the truth, nor was the change attributed to his policy so great as some of his opponents wished us at the time to believe.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 23. -- Gov. Flower has been so busy of late with agricultural matters that he had not noticed that an international prize fight was being arranged between Corbett and Mitchell.

The extraordinary complacency of Mayor Bodily of Brooklyn under the scathing criticisms to which his weak and vacillating administration of municipal affairs in the interest of the "Ring" has subjected him by even the leading citizens of his own party is a spectacle on which his friends gaze with no email degree of astonishment and Irritation.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Two Democratic County Conventions were held here to-day. From the outset the fight between the two factions has had Kilkenny characteristics. The Hill forces have been under the direction of Deputy Controller Huson and Chief Civil Service Reform Examiner Thomas Carmody.

"I am taking what has been called a postal census of New-York City," said Postmaster Dayton yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times, "because I think the statistics will furnish an irresistible argument to Congress in behalf of the increased appropriation and improved facilities needed here.

George Dixen, the present featherweight champion pugilist, and "Sally" Smith, the aspirant for those honors, will meet before the Coney Island Athletic Club to-morrow eight. Dixon's record is well known, as he has figured as a fighter for about eight years, whipping the champions of England, Australia, and America.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Democratic Convention for Tompkins County was held in this city to-day, and for the first time in the history of the county the people have had an illustration of Hill politics.

The Norwood took a spin down the bay yesterday. Capt. Dand of the Stranger was at the wheel. While oft Swinburne Island the steamboat Sandy Hook came along. The Norwood was going like a streak toward New-York, She wheeled around and came up on the port side of the Sandy Hook. In fifteen minutes' time the Norwood was rally two miles and a half ahead of the Saudy Hook.

As to the healthfulness of going without shoes and stockings, there can, says The London Hospital, be no question. Some of the healthiest children of the world are to be found in the Scottish Highlands, where shoes are seldom worn at an earlier age than twelve or thirteen. The negro and coolie laborers, who work bare footed, are usually in robust health.

YONKERS, N, Y., Sept. 23. -- The Democrats of the First Assembly District of Westchester County held, a convention this afternoon in Hibernian Hall for the purpose of electing three delegates to the Democratic State Convention, five delegates to the Senatorial Convention, and one delegate to the Judiciary Convention.

The large and handsome new retail men's clothing establishment of Clarence L. Gans Co., at 279 Broadway, was opened to the public yesterday. Hundreds of people, friends, well-wishers, and customers called to give their congratulations, inspect the stylish and thoroughly first-class stockTand to make purchases.

Charles Bardery, a rigger working for Reter Connolly of Pittsbnrg, fell 135 feet from the top of the temporary iron chimney at the power house of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, foot of Division Avenue, yesterday, and was killed. His skull was crushed, and nearly every bone in his body broken.

Williams College, in Massachusetts, and Cornell University, in New-York, are to celebrate very soon, the first the centenary and the second the quarter-centenary of their foundation. These institutions stand as excellent types of two phases of higher education in the United States-the denominational college and the unsectarian university. Strictly speaking, however, Williams cannot now said to be denominational, though it is generally so classed.

Florence O'Driscoll, a whip of the Irish Parliamentary Party, one of the youngest and yet one of the brightest and most distinguished of the anti-Parnellites, arrived in this city yesterday on the Cunard Line steamship Campania.

CORNING, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The wholesale forging of checks on the First National Bank of this city by a mythical firm under the name of A.J. Haines Co. continues. Three more checks were presented to-day, one from Dunkirk, one from Fort Wayne, Ind., and the third from Decatur, Ind. This makes five received during the past week, the other two being from Fredonia and Fort Wayne, Ind., respectively.

The real estate Said during the past week has shown some evidences of activity, but they have not been very marked. A few sales of residences have been effected and some transfers of flat property have been made, usually by exchange. Regarding the latter, there is an opinion quite generally entertained that "swaps" are an indication or a poor condition of the market.

According to appointment, Charley Mitchell met Justice Newton, the matchmaker at the Coney Island Athletic Club, in the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon and signed the articles of agreement for the contest with Champion Corbett. The only thing that Mitchell objected to was the signature of William A. Brady, the manager of Corbett. To-day Matchmaker Newton will go to Asbury Park to get Corbett's signature.

For many years the rumor of a manificent diamond, said to be in the possession of a tribe dwelling in a far-away region vaguely indicated by the expression "up country," had tickled the ears of adventers. Many had gone in search of it; none had come within measurable distance of obtaining it.

Perhaps the finest looking man who stepped ashore from the Campania yesterday was the Bight Honorable the Lord Mayor of Dublin, James Shanks. He was accompanied by the Lady Mayoress, Town Councillor Mayne, Mrs. Mayne, and George Barrington, an eminent merchant of Dublin.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- During the past fortnight the Yale Faculty have been carefully revising the figures received relating to the size of the incoming freshman class, which will arrive Tuesday to begin the university course. Figures of the number taking the examinations in various parts of the world have been revised and modified as later information suggests.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- The two days' cricket match between the Philadelphia and New-York elevens ended this afternoon in a victory for the local team by an inning and 36 runs. Philadelphia scored 267 runs in its one inning yesterday. The New York team then followed and continued at the bat up to the close of the frame to-day. Their scores were: Fires inning, 121; second inning, 110; total, 231.

The Arion Society of New-York has bought the monument in honor of Heinrich Heine, the German lyrical poet, which was designed for Duseldorf, the poet's birthplace. The design is a fountain which refers to the story of the Lorelei of the Rhine embodied by Heine in immortal verse.

BUCKSFOOT POND, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Bucksfoot Pond is a crescent-shaped sheet of water in the Adirondacks, wooded on every side, yielding numerous trout in the Spring and a few even as late as the 15th of August. Deer are very abundant and very shy. It was here that a party of us, young, hot-blooded, and, perhaps, a bit foolish, decided to camp.
Seven new cases of smallpox were posted on the bulletin board at the division of contagious diseases yesterday.

M. Pettier has put a frog shower on record as having happened within his own experience. He speaks of seeing the frogs fall on the roofs of the houses and rebound thence on to the pavement below. A mud shower occurred along the Union Pacific Railway at Onaga on the 4th of April, 1892.

Justice of the Peace Richard V. B. Newton of Kings County was a busy man yesterday, for he was engaged in the congenial task of arranging for an international prize fight between the notorious pugilists James J. Gorbett and Charles Mitchell.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Mrs. Louis D. Gallison, Historian General of the Daughters of the Revolution, gave a unique luncheon and reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 120 Oakwood Avenue, to a number of the officers and members of the society. The house was prettily decorated in buff and blue, the colors of the society, and on the tables and mantels were arranged vases of goldenrod, violets, and roses.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- 1793 ! The artistic world is stifling in the hothouse heat of overculture. Watteau has passed away, Boucher also, and the rococo grace of the Pompadour years has worked and labored into the pastoral, overwrought simplicity of the Trianon. Like some rare orchid Greuze rises; pure, akin to a Greek cameo; like the perfect Queen of tropical beauty, his faces shine radiantly forth.

OCEAN GROVE, Sept. 23. -- The Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association recently decided to tear down the present auditorium and erect a more modern structure. The new auditorium will cost $50,000 and will seat 10,000 persons. It will be completed before the next Summer religious season rolls around.

That there are in this city many kind hearts and many people who perform unpretentious deeds of charity is well shown toythe result of the simple story of George L. Covert, told in The New-York Times yesterday. Since the narrative of his struggle to help support a mother and two little sisters by selling papers at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Eighth Avenue, The NewYork Times has received for him $153.

Although this volume sees the light in New-York after having been printed and bound in Boston, and although we may assume that it was written in its auther's Toronto home, the readers for whom Prof. Smith intends it are not Americans, but Englishmen. He offers some apology for the point of view from which he has written, but trusts to the liberality of Americans to make the necessary allowances.
"Good souls, no!" exclaimed the freckle-faced girl. "I ain't one of them artists' models. I'm a figure.

LONDON, Sept 23. -- The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Herr Julius Bodnar, Councilor of the Hungarian Ministry of Commerce, bids fair to be soon cleared up. In fact, it is known now that he was not drowned, as the police had concluded, but that there is a woman in the case, and that Herr Bodnar is with her somewhere on the Continent.

The new Methodist Episcopal Church now approaching completion at Fourth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street in Brooklyn is a handsome structure, and speaks well for the congregation which has had the courage to erect it in what is comparatively a new neighborhood, and now only sparsely settled.

This new volume of essays by Henry James is made up altogether of collected papers that had previously done good service in periodicals, the charming and graphic record of impressions of London originally appeared in The Century, where it was accompanied by Some remarkable drawings by Mr. Pennell, for the absence of which from the book Mr. James apologizes in the preface.

We took occasion to remark, when Mayor BOODY published his long letter to Mr. SHEPARD, that his representation of his own office as like that of a Presidential Elector was an admission of the full force of everything that Mr. SHEPARD, in his Forum article, had alleged, and that everything else in his letter, though there was much that was illogical and disingenuous, was of no importance compared to this amazing proposition.

John E. Burrill, a prominent corporation, lawyer of this city and the senior member of the firm of Burrill, Zabriskle Burrill, 21 Broad Street, died at his country house in Lenox, Mass., yesterday morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Democrats of Niagara County held their convention at Lockport this afternoon. There were 77 delegates in the convention, and of these 45 were Hill men. S. Wright McCullom brought a contesting delegation from the Second (Lockport) Ward, and his cause was championed in the convention by E.J. Taylor, backed by 32 delegates.

GOSSIP AND INCIDENTS LAST WEEK. -- An old beau, whose genial face bite been framed by the Union Club windows for years, and who has attended every racial function of importance since the war, said lest week: "I have not seen things so slow in a generation. Fact is, nobody boo any definite plans, and I hardly know where to find many of my friends. The truth is, everybody has been economizing."

Lord Dunraven arrived in port less than twenty-four hours after his yacht, the Valkyrie. The Campania came up to Quarantine at 4 o'clock, but it was not until 6:30 o'clock that Dr. Jenkins and his staff of assistants boarded the steamer. Mr. H. Maitland Kersey, who has acted as Lord Dunraven's representative in this country, followed Dr. Jenkins on the steamer, and at once greeted the Earl, who was early on deck.

Joy reigned yesterday in the Thomas family their house at 237 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street. David J. Solomon, who had been declared sane by the jury on Friday evening, was released yesterday from Bloomingdale Insane Asylum, and went immediately to rejoin his intended wife, Miss Clara Perry Thomas, from whom he had been torn by his brothers on the eve of his intended marriage.

BRANDON, Miss., Sept. 23. -- The White Cappers in Eastern Mississippi and Western Alabama have posted notices on the doors of every gin house that if a bale of cotton is ginned before the price shall have reached 10 cents the ginners will do so at the peril of having their property burned.
Four "green-goods" men and a large quantity or circulars were captured about 5 o'clock yesterday morning by Policeman Phillips of the East Fifty-first Street Police Station.

The romantic swing of "The Heavenly Twins," although the present volume was written before that work, brought Sarah Grand first Into immediate notice. Sarah Grand is certainly a most unconventional person, and daring to a degree. She does not write what has been called the skimmilk romance.
Gen. Wesley Merritt, commander of the Department of Dakota, United States Army, is a guest at the Gilsey House. He is in town on personal business.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The home rule, or Cleveland, Democrats of Buffalo and Erie County to-day announced their programme. When it was seen that they did not contest the Sheehan caucuses, held to nominate delegates to the conventions which will send delegates to the State Convention, it was thought that they had abandoned the idea of making an open contest and would be content with voting against the Sheehan candidates.

In the interest of honesty and to aid in restoring confidence in American railway securities, shattered by the extraordinary immunity peculiar to the managers of railways in this country, who to further private ends seemed to be licensed to destroy the properties intrusted to their care, The Times yesterday demonstrated the great intrinsic value of the Reading properties and the causes which led to the company's troubles.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- In speaking with an old alkali manufacturer the other day who sold his works to the United Alkali Company in 1890, the subject of the manufacture of alkali and bleaching powder at Saltville, Va., came up. This enterprise is under the direction of Neil Mathieson, Esq., who formerly had charge of the chemical works of Mathieson Co. at Widnes, in Lancashire.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: I wish to thank you for your editorial in this morning's Times on the manifesto of the so-called Irish National League of America on the Home Rule hill. Tour analysis is correct in a measure. The men who concocted and issued that manifesto are antagonistic to Ireland and everytning that men or Irish blood hold dear, both in relation to Ireland and their American citizenship.

We have four contributors to this dainty volume -- F. Hopkinson Smith, T.R. Sullivan, John A'.Becket, and Grace Ellery Channing. Mr. Smith in a delightful way gives his experiences in ambulant studios. He has tried tartanas in Spain, volantes in Cuba, canalboats, maybe, in Holland, and mules in Mexico.

--The Fisheries Building at the exposition has ten aquaria, having a capacity of 7,000 to $7,000 gallons of water each. In the centre of the eastern polygonal building is a rotunda 60 feet in diameter, in the middle of which is a basin or pool 26 feet wide, from which rises a mass of rocks covered with moss and lichens.

Courtes, the player of Pierrot, Sr., in "L'Enfant Prodigue" at Daly's, does not pretend to be a pantomimist, or a Pierrot of the lineage of Deburau. On the contrary, he is an anti-pantomimlst, a comedian without words, the first of his style, and there are not enough quodlibets in Marsellies, where audiences are instructed from infancy in the mystic art of pantomimicry, to satirize the work which Courtes is doing.

Curious things are sometimes developed by double reflections in the presence of plenty of glass to keep up the reflection. This is what a woman saw a few days ago as she sat in her car in the Grand Central Station waiting for the train to pull out:

BOSTON, Sept 23. -- The biggest telescope in the world is now approaching completion at Cambridge. It is at the factory of Alvan Clark Sons, and it is there that the lenses for the great telescope presented by Mr. Yerkes to the University of Chicago are being manufactured. The greater part of the work on the lenses is already completed.

Dr. S.J. Cassimati, one of the leaders in the neo-Hellenic movement and a celebrated scientist of Greece, is at the Broadway Central Hotel, where American scientific men and artists who knew him, at the School of Athens have paid their respects to him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The yearly salary of a Senator or Representative in Congress is $5,000. He receives, in addition, a sum representing the cost of railroad fare from his home to he capital, "by the nearest railroad route," and is credited with $125 for stationery, most of which sum he takes in cash.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 23. -- An Italian murder which occurred two nights ago attracted very little attention at the time, but it has since developed into one of the most important crimes that has taken place here for years. There are half a dozen Italian societies in the city, and they had all been invited to send delegates to a meeting for the purpose of arranging to celebrate Columbus Day in October.

The outcome of the Religious Congress at Chicago is an organization which has for its object, to use BACON'S words, "the glory of the Creator and the relief of man's estate." No man can well decline to promote the former purpose without avowing himself an atheist, nor the latter without confessing himself to be something less than human.

The last game in the championship series of the Metropolitan District Cricket League took place at Bergen Point yesterday, when the New-Jercey Ath letic Club won their title of champions of New-York by defeating the Newark Cricket Club. They had a very easy victory, too, winning by 113 runs after declaring their inning closed for four wickets.

The detailed report of the Board of Directors of the New-York Central Railroad has just been issued. An abstract of the report was printed in The Times several weeks ago. Following is an interesting comparative analysis of earnings and expenses for the year:

BUFFALO, Sept. 23. -- After a week of quarreling, bullyragging, scheming, and all sorts of trouble, the "Rainmaker of Syria" Company left Buffalo this evening. It came with Katherine Germaine as prima donna, Sophie Holtz an her understudy, and Harry Davenport as principal comedian. It goes back to the metropolis with all three of these people out of the cast.
BOSTON, Sept 23. -- Paquerette's first appearance here, in "The Black Crook," at the Boston Theatre, has been the only novelty of this week, but, of course, her antics are an old story in New-York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The report of the Utah Commission received to-day by the Secretary of the Interior indicates that the affairs over which it has jurisdiction are in a satisfactory condition. The report reviews the history of reform in Utah and gives in outline the various steps first taken by Congress and then by the Mormons themselves to make polygamy odious.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The week has been one of unusual activity and excitement here. Saturday night the cadet hop was held in Grant Hall, and Tuesday night the officers' hop came off at the same place. The latter was a notable social event and the moat successful ever given by the members of the mess.

The Central Park courts were in fair shape yesterday afternoon for the opening matches in the Central Park championship tennis tournament. E. P. Fiacher holds the title at present, and he will be called upon to detend it against the winner of the present tourney.

All music lovers remember the personal appearance of Eugen d'Albert, the famous pianist, sometimes called the Jaeger-flannel pianist, because everything he wore, even his neckties and his touch, was made of that goods. No one ever saw a homelier man than d'Albert, and no one would have supposed him capable of winning the affections of one of the most accomplished and certainly the most attractive of female pianists.

A traveler's tale of British phlegm is told in the following terms: A Frenchman was seated in a smoking carriage and had for his companion a "milord Anglais." Enter a British miss -- of course with a plaid and protruding teeth and a Skye terrier. She sat opposite the milord. He politely informed her that she had by mistake got into a smoking carriage.

-- It is rumored in Mississippi, says The Memphis Commercial, that the friends of Congressman John Allen are doing their best to induce him to enter the Guberna- torial race. Private John is a campaigner from up where the creek forks the first time, and if he enters the fight there will be a mighty rustling among the other candidates.

All crafts depend upon knowledge and acquired skill -- knowledge of the material to be handled, acquired skill in the handling of the material. Pioneers of mountaineering had first to learn what mountains actually are like, the details of their structure, and the forces in action upon them. Rock structure, which has one meaning for a geologist, has others for a mountaineer.
A young woman writing from England tells of a delightful trip taken with a Field Naturalist Club, to whose annual June excursion she gained access through friends.

Among the offices held by the Prince of Wales is that of Honorary Admiral of the Fleet, to which he was advanced in 1887. There are only two of these offices, the second being bestowed upon the Emperor of Germany in 1889.

The Chinese Minister, Yang Yu, and his retinue are beginning to feel very much at home in their new quarters, at the head of Fourteenth Street, and that they thoroughly enjoy the novelty of their now position is evidenced by the lively interest they manifest in everything and everybody.

Mr. Hibbard is modern, recent, "in touch with his times," altogether of the present, and the amused and generally good-humored observer of "people now on earth," as Eugene Field of Chicago, Ill., phrases it. This modernity is in Mr. Hibbard's thought, in his vocabulary, in his style, in his choice of subjects.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 24 -- Five hundred Democrats of the Michael Hart Association of the First Assembly District, New-York, disembarked from the steamer Black Bird at Witzel's Point View Island, College Point, to-day, to enjoy their fourth annual clambake. They were marshaled by their President, Daniel J. Sullivan.
BARCELONA, Sept. 24 -- An Anarchist tried to kill Captain General Martinez de Campos yesterday with a bomb.

BUFFALO, Sept. 24 -- The Prohibitionists of Wyoming County held a convention at Warsaw yesterday, with James H. Evans of Gainesville as Chairman and V.R. Hungerford of Castile and P.H. Wolcott of Wethersfield as Secretaries. Twenty-six delegates were present, representing eight towns, six of them being women. The following nominations were made: For Member of Assembly.

Dr. Elliott Coues, who has earned high reputation as a naturalist, and as a member of the United States Geological Survey has won merited distinction, was the best man who could have been found for the new editing of this memorable work, dealing with the expedition which had for its mission nothing short of the discovery of the land lying between the Mississippi and the Pacific Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Representative Patterson of Tennessee has introduced in the House a bill to amend the inter-State commerce law. The measure is similar to the one prepared by the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce of the last Congress and passed by the House.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 23 -- The last west has witnessed a further relaxation in the situation or the local money market, and, while 7 cent. remains the minimum rate of discount, there are plenty of funds to meet all wants, and there is, further, a growing disposition to consider purchases of paper in the outside market, but the rates at which the choicest names are now offered have dropped 3 or 4 cent.

The French theatrical company, which is to make a tour of the United States under the management of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, arrived yesterday on La Bourgogne from Havre. All the members of the company were well and in the best of spirits. With the exception of M. Coquelin, they started for Chicago in the afternoon.

The placing and displacing of a sign caused a serious row in Fiatbush Friday night. The belligerents were Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Farrell, who keep a road house on the Ocean Boulevard, and Mra. Andrew Erzinger, her son Fritz, and her daughter Gertrude.

The American Jewish Historical Society has shown good judgment in the selection of its officers, having for/President the Hon. Oscar S. Straus, for Vice Presidents Dr. Charles Gross, Prof. John B. McMasters. and the Hon. Simon W. Rosendale, and for Corresponding Secretary Dr. Cyrus Adler of the Smithsonian Institution.

This morning Judge RICHARD NEWTON, manager of the Coney Island prize-fight club, expects to receive the articles for the prize fight between MITCHELL and CORBETT, with the latter's signature. They will be brought to this city by a certain Mr. WILLIAM DELANEY en route to Coney Island to "handle" one of the professional prize fighters who will violate the law of the State at that place this evening.

The Rev. Dr. Talmage wants to see a grand international jubilee inaugurated in this section to celebrate the dawn of the twentieth century of Christ. In the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday the doctor elucidated his idea in an interesting sermon preached before a large congregation.

Among the hardest fighters of all the hard-fighting Confederate Generals in the civil war was Gen. D.H. Hill. But he had the gentle heart of a chivalrous soldier, as is shown by an anecdote told to the writer by Major I.W. Ratchford, a distinguished officer, who was Gen. Hill's Adjutant General.

Dr. Thomas B. Enders, of 163 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, who is six feet tall in his stockings, had an exciting experience yesterday morning with a burglar six feet two inches in height.

DEEP-SEA FISHING BY YACHT OWNERS. -- It has always been considered quite essential that a thoroughgoing man in society should be a disciple of Izaak Walton, and ex-Minister Robert B. Roosevelt, known to his friends as "Fisherman Bob," and a number of other gentlemen have established large fish preserves, where they can enjoy the sport of catching game fish.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 23 -- The Wesleyan eleven tills Fall will average lighter in weight than it has for several years. At the same time, it seems certain that in some of the positions where weight is lost there Will be a corresponding accession in grit and agility. The question which bothers Capt. Gordon is whether quickness can hold its own against superior weight, especially on the line.

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date last year. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Monmouth County is a great political battlefield just now. H.S. Little, who now lives in Freehold, still has control of an element in Monmouth County politics, and helps his friend. Senator Blodgett, hatch up schemes. "Staff," as he is called, is on top, having elected his nephew State Senator.

Peace now spreads her white wings over that part of this city which is designated on the political map of the town as the Twelfth Assembly District And it is a part of the town that, in the matter of local politics, has been a seat of unrelenting war, rather than an abode of peace. In the past it was a district full of political stones.

To the Editor of the of the New York: The valuable work that has been done by the United States Revenue Cutter Service of recent years in the saving of life and property along: our coasts has happened to fall under my notice, and, as a consequence, I have taken an especial interest in matters pertaining to the service.

-- The refusal of Judge Alfred C. Coxe of the United States District Court to take the Republican nomination for the Court of Appeals bench leads the Democratic Utica, Observer to say that the Judge has no use for the honor, and that even if elected the election would not be a promotion. He is a Federal Judge now.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 24 -- One of the local banks yesterday received from a man in Oklahoma a draft on New-York for $30,000, with a statement that he proposed opening a financial institution on Oct. 1, and asking that $5,000 in gold be sent him for temporary use.

The proposed international prize fight between the notorious pugilists Charles Mitchell and James J. Corbett, which has been arranged by Justice of the Peace Richard V.B. Newton of Kings County to take place at Coney Island in December, has aroused the most intense feelings of indignation in Brooklyn.

The death is announced in Paris of Eugene Hatin, historian of French journalism and of the French provinces. He was eighty-four, and he was the most active among the organizers of the anniversary celebration of Theophraste Renaudot's foundation of The Gazette de Prance. He was born at Auxerre, and the local college has his name in the roll of its most brilliant pupils.

To the Editor of the New York Times: In the report of The New-York Times's correspondent regarding the terrific hurricane of Aug. 27, no mention is made of the islands between Beaufors and Charleston, upon some of which, near the creeks and rivers, the destruction to property and loss of life were equally great.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst's trip to Europe has evidently not lightened the gloomy view he takes of things in thik unfortunate asction of the world. In his initial sermon, after the summer vacation, at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday, he informed a large congregation that they lived among depraved neighbors, and that he intended to go ahead on the old lines to make wicked people better.

ASBURY PARK, Sept 24 -- The training quarters of Champion James J. Corbett at Loch Arbor were crowded with well-known sporting men and local celebrities to-day. Judge Richard Newton, the President of the Coney Island Athletic Club, arrived from New-York just before noon. He brought with him the articles of agreement for the coming fistic contest, bearing the signature of " Charley" Mitchell.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- When Paris takes a f it takes it badly; the thing easily become an infectious malady. The bicycle is the present craze. Young, old, thin, lean, Long, lank, stout, very stout, pretty, and ugly -- every woman must, does, or will mount the iron horse. The growing passion will be a permanent one, thanks to the enterprise of sport lovers.

The original Solomon, with all his wives, was never more happy than was David J. Solomon yesterday with the one plucky woman who had taken him from Bloomingdale Asylum on Saturday, despite the protests of his relatives.

WE HAVE LOIE STILL WITH Us. -- Lole Fuller, with her serpantine dance, was to have sailed for Paris this week, but American money has tempted her to postpone her departure for another seven days. She will exhibit her wonderful dances all this week, in connection with "Jane " at the Standard, and "Panjandrum" at the Broadway.

The members of Troop A, the crack cavalry organization of our National Guard, are looking forward to the time when they will be comfortably housed in their new armory. It is to be erected upon the portion of the block on Madison Avenue, between Ninety-fourth and Ninety-fifth Streets, that is not occupied by the Eighth Regiment Armory.

The Valencia Boat Club of Hoboken was organized on Oct. 6, 1874, as a social club, bat was reorganized as a boat club within a short time afterward, and has since baen one of the leading clubs on the Hudson River. Its first officers were: President -- H. Witte; Vice President -- A. Hanger; Secretary and Treasurer -- A. Southal.

The large hall in the Jaeger Building at Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street was crowded yesterday with members of United Council, Legion of Honor, and visitors from almost every Council in New-York, and many from Brooklyn, Staton Island, and New-Jersey, During the summer months the Council has no sessions, as most of the members ore theatrical and newspaper people, who need a Summer's vacation.

PEINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23 -- Since Thursday regular practice of the candidates for the football team have been held at the 'Varsity grounds each afternoon at 12:30. Capt. Trenchard has been detained by the sickness or his father, but Wheeler, '95, and ex-Capt. King have boon giving the men light practice in running, kicking, passing, and tailing on the ball.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- The arrival of Count Herbert Bismarck and Count Rantzau, his brother-in-law, in Kissingen yesterday, is not expected to help much in bringing the Emperor and Prince Bismarck together. Many hope, however, that stronger influences will prevail and that the reconciliation will soon bo accomplished.

NEW-YORK MONDAY, Sept. 25 -- A.M. The stock market was dull throughout the week, with a general tendency toward wer prices. The great controlling influence was the uncertainty following the lure of the Senate to make satisfactory gress toward a repeal of the silver-purchase law.

Dr. Walter Vought of 12 West Tenth Street, who was in charge of the Quarantine Station at Fire Island during the cholera scare last year, died at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in the New-York Hospital of typhoid fever, which disease he contracted while attending a little child about ten days ago.

At a meeting held last Monday afternoon in the Hall of the Board of Education, the Building Committee of the Board of Education authorized the construction of a new grammar school in the Twenty-second Ward, at the corner of Eighty-second Street and West End Avenue. At the same time the plans drawn by Superintendent of Buildings C.B.J. Snyder were adopted.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Five holes in the line of the Yale football eleven have gaped widely since the team was reunited hero last Thursday. At last the Tale machine is at work, however, and the process of grinding out a new combination of football men has commenced. Quantity there is in abundance, but quality for the task of evolving a championship eleven is lacking.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept 24 -- A squad of local policemen rudely interrupted the missionary services at the Zion Methodist Episcopal Church to-night, and pat the speaker of the evening, a converted Zulu chief, under arrest.

The Rev. John Rippere, pastor of the De Kalb Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, preached a vigorous sermon last evening on the lax administration of the excise laws in Brooklyn. Incidentally he scored Mayor Boody for surrendering his principles at the dictation of a ring.

EDUCATIONAL -- "A.C.R.": (1) Is there any institution in Brooklyn, New-York, or Jersey City in whicn I may study at night for the degree og D.D. (2) How is the sherman silver law driving gold out of the country ? (3) Why can we not have a ratio between gold and silver? (4) Will any silver be purchased, to be used as currency, by the Government, after the Sherman law is repealed?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- With the usual foundation of prize pumpkins, fattest hogs, neat cattle, and strong oxen; with tests of horses in all classes; with a great collection of shell games. plate games, and those other little pastimes found at a county fair, but with all the glory shed by patrons and patronesses from the ranks at the Pour Hundred, the Westchester County Fair will begin Its annual business Tuesday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 24 -- There is now little doubt that the properties of the railroad syndicate that failed here last Spring, with the Union Loan and Trust Company's crash, will be reorganized by their creditors. The creditors have decided to take up the matter, and will pay $400,000 of overdue interest in New-York this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -- Football interest at the University of Pennsylvania is centred at present in Cape May. where about thirty men are practicing dally in the hope of making the team. Pennsylvania Starts out this season heavily handicapped. Harry Thayer, the well-known full-back; Capt. Schoff, who played end and Adams last year's centre rush. have left college, and they have decided positively not to return.

William J. Gaynor, the Brooklyn lawyer, who, the "machine" Democrats of Brooklyn fear, will be nominated for Mayor on a citizens' ticket, is at his country home, Bellport, L.I. He has been questioned by a Brooklyn reporter concerning his alleged desire to secure a Mayoralty nomination, and in his answer said:

The Valkyrie was a great attraction for the yachtsmen yesterday, and all day there was a crowd at the Atlantic Clubhouse dock to see the English racer that is to try to take back the America's Cap. The opinions expressed by visitors on Saturday were simply corroborated yesterday. That she Is a powerful-looking craft and worthy of respect, was admitted by all.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- When Secretary Gresham returns to Washington it is probable that lull and reliable information regarding the revolution, la Brazil will be given to the public. Minister Mendonea, who returned to Washington several days ago, intends to have a conference with the Secretary immediately on bio arrival.

-- A camel has twice the carrying power of an ox. With an ordinary load of 400 pounds he can travel twelve or fourteen days without water, going forty miles a day. They are fit to work at five years old, but their strength begins to decline at twentyfive, although they usually live to forty. The Tartars have herds of these animals, often 1,000 belonging to one family.

The church-going people of Williamsbridge, in the upper portion of New-York City, have long complained of inadequate church accommodations. This is about to be remedied by the erection of a large and handsome new church by the Methodist Episcopal congregation of that place.

The annual report of Commissioner LOCHREN shows that in another year the number of pensioners is likely to exceed a round million. It is the boast of this country that the people are not burdened with the support of a standing army, but here is a body of men more or less dependent upon the Government for support which exceeds in number and in annual cost any effective standing army in Europe.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 -- There is considerable excitement in the village of Milford over the finding of a complete suit of woman's clothing in a meadow near the water's edge. George Hunt, while walking through the meadow, found them. There was a black sailor hat, a blue waist and skirt, and underclothing.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The purpose of the machine leaders in calling the State Convention at Saratoga after the season has ended and all the big hotels closed is gradually becoming understood throughout the State, particularly among Democrats who will so as contesting delegates.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 24 -- The Long Island Railroad station here was broken into by thieves early this morning. The money drawer was broken open and emptied of $2, being all it contained.

It was learned in well-informed circles Saturday that the Treasury Department, proposes to establish a United States Revenue Marine cadet course. It was given out in this connection that the cadet practice vessel Chase would probably be placed in commission in the course of three weeks. The Chase is a bark-rigged sailing vessel.

This week in business follows one of extreme dullness and depression, caused by the natural spread of uncertainty as to the action of the Senate on the repeal bill. We are much mistaken if the course of affairs will not be about the same for the next week and another Monday find us under the influence of the same disquieting doubts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- statistics compiled from official data show that from January to September this year 560 State and private banks in the United States failed, and that 72 have resumed business. In the same time 155 national banks failed, 70 of which have resumed. The following table gives the number of failures of State and private banks since Jan. 1, 1893.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $7,008,250. The banks now hold $17,609,950 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $735,200, an increase in specie of $5,205,500, an increase in legal tenders or $3,471,100, an increase in deposits of $6,673,400, and an increase in circulation of $886,700.

A riot in which, fatalities were probably prevented by the timely appearance of a squad of police, occurred yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn between a gang of Irish and a gang of Italian laborers. The fight occurred at the corner of Hudson Avenue and Nassau Street. A number on both gangs were injured by shovels, sticks, and stones, which were liberally used during the melee.

A sensational story was published yesterday to the effect that J.H. Haverly, the Chicago theatrical manager, was a paretic and that he was confined in a Western asylum for the insane. Patrick Sheedy, the well-known sporting man, was said to have given this information to a party of friends on Broadway Saturday evening.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Although Livingston County is so strongly Republican that not more than one Democrat in a decade seta an office, there is as lively a lot of Democrats within its borders as can be found in any county of the State. The contest this year is between the machine and the Cleveland factions, and thus far the Cleveland Democrats have by far the best of it.
The Rev. C.H. Tyndall tamed about the Roanoke lynching tragedy last night to the congregation at the Broome Street Tabernaole.

Father Dent, the Brooklyn priest whose case in the courts has attracted attention daring the past Bummer, is in more trouble if the story Patrick McNamara tells is true. McNamara, who says he is twenty-seven years old, called at the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, and inquired in vain for the priest's address.

Senator STEWART made a fool of himself yesterday, and that is an encouraging sign. For the most part, the silver obstructionists have played their game well. They have been cool, self-possessed, and incessantly voluble. Senator STEWART, however, is plainly angry, and is for that reason obviously in great danger of being outwitted and overcome.

LIVERPOOL, Sept 25 -- Beef in fair demand, Pork in moderate demand. Hams in fair demand, Bacon in fair demand; Cumberland cut, about 28 to 30 ib, firm at 51s; long clear middles, about 45 firm at 6d; long and short clear middles, about 55 ts, firm at 53s 6d. Cheese in poor demand; American finest white firm at 47s. Tallow -- The demand is Improving; prime city firm at 26s 6d.

The doctrine was laid down in the last national platform of the Republican Party that duties for protection on imported articles should equal the difference between the cost of labor in producing the articles abroad and the cost of the same labor here. That looks like a fair measure of any real protection to labor, though there are other considerations which may make it quite unnecessary.

The cashier and bookkeeper for the firm of Rienhard Seidenburg Co., cotton brokers at 75 Cotton Exchange, have been arrested on charges of robbing their employers. The cashier is John F. Collins and the bookkeeper is Ernest Jennings Greene. Collins is twenty-four years old and has been living in good style at Scotch Plains, N. J., with his wife and child.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 25. -- Lester Pasco, the oldest resident voter in this city, will be ninety-three years old on Thursday of this week, and the event will be celebrated by the aged citizen's friends and relatives. Mr. Pasco retired from business forty years ago. He has one daughter, Mrs. E.A. Stevens, living in Nebraska, and Edward Lindsley of Cleveland, Ohio, is his stepson.

Secretary Sullivan of the Amateur Athletic Union says that the Metropolitan championships to be decided on the grounds of the New-Jersey Athletic Club on Saturday week will eclipse anything over seen in this vicinity. The entries are coming in very fast, and from present appearances, will number several hundred.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- It was not expected that there would be any interesting developments in the proceedings of the Senate to-day. According to the programme agreed to last week, the session was to begin at 11 o'clock and continue until 6. This plan was partly adhered to, the adjournment being reached twenty minutes before the time scheduled.

ASBURY PARK, Sept. 25. -- There is a lot of trouble brewing for the Monmouth Democracy, and unless the leaders of the several factions kiss and make up before election day the Republicans may be able to walk off with the rich political plums now almost ready to be picked.
ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 25. -- The Citizens' Committee of Thirteen has issued the following address to Mayor Trout:

VIENNA, Sept 25. -- The arrest Saturday of fourteen Anarchists here and the capture yesterday of sixty-eight members of a secret society at Bruenn, the capital of Moravia, has revealed the existence of a widespread Anarchist plot. To-day seven more members of the gang were taken into custody, and the proof against all the persons arrested is said to be overwhelming.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 25. -- The effects of increased business are felt in this part of the State in the starting up of mills that have been running on half time and with only half the usual number of hands employed. In many cases to all the old hands who have remained in the city has been given work.
It takes more than gloomy skies and a sulking sun to daunt the adherents of Senator John F. Ahoarn in the Fourth Assembly District.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 24. -- Lewis Baker, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Costa Rica, Salvador, and Nicaragua, is getting ready to facilitate the return of Francis H. Weeks to New-York.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The seventh annual meeting of the New-England Trotting Horse Breeders Association made a poor start at Mystic Park to-day. Rain was falling when the horses were called at 1 o'clock, and the trade was very soon muddy and slow, but as there is a lung programme of stakes to get through this week, the day's card was worked off.

Much interest was shown yesterday in the results of the sale of Twenty-third Ward lots belonging to the Vyse estate, which was continued on Saturday on the grounds until night-fall put an end to the proceedings.
