The tabulated results given out yesterday showed that 105 of the 138 lots which were to be offered were sold.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The city is filling up with strangers who have come to attend the fifty-second annual fair of the Dutchess County Agricultural Society which will begin to-morrow.

* * * That Brooklyn, the City of Churches, should tolerato anywhere in its vicinity such a loudly-heraldel and brutal affair seems almost incredible, and yet the fight is announced to come off within ten miles of its limits, Realizing the disgrace which threatens their community, the ministors and other law-abiding citizens of Kings Connty, N. Y., have ralsed their voices in vigorous protest none too soon.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept 25. -- The inter-State Fair, which draws exhibitors and patrons from the States of New-Jersey, New-York, Pennsylvania, and Delaware, opened to-day, 10,000 persons viewing the twenty miles or exhibits.
The following is translated from La Gaceta of San Jose, Costa Rica. It is the proclamation under which Weeks is held in San Jose:

Some of the Western banks have cause for gratitude to New-York through the promptness of Henry W. Cannon, President of the Chase National Bank, in defeating a scheme to enrich swindlers by the use of the name of his bank. The news which reached here yesterday showed that the game was tried in Kansas City and St. Joseph, Mo., with other places, no doubt, yet to be reported.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, Sept 25 -- P.M. There was an increase in activity in Stock Exchange trading to-day, the total transactions exceeding 220,000 shares, but such liveliness as resulted was regularly in stocks which showed a loss for the day. The whole list was weak, and at the close the market was near its lowest prices.
Kings County's Democratic Campaign Committee for 1893 has been announced. A glance at the names on the list shows it to be a close corporation or office holders and chronic office seekers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The second trial of Patrick Smith, one of the men indicted for participating in the election frauds here last Fall, will begin to-morrow. Smith was tried two months ago, and the jury at the end of a long session, at which many ballots were cast, stood nine to three in his favor, and found itself unable to arrive any nearer to a unanimous opinion.

Three of the most desperate members of the "Slaughterhouse gang" were prisoners in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, having been caught under peculiar circumstances. They were Peter Gallagher, twenty-two years old, of 225 West Sixty-first Street; John McGovern, twenty years old, of 225 West Sixty-fourth Street, and Nicholas Lawrence, twenty-two years old, of 528 West Sixty-ninth Street.
BOSTON, Sept 25. -- The market opened, quiet and without special feature, it became more active shortly alter noon and weak, closing heavy at about the lowest prices of the day.
Frank Ellison, appearing as fresh as if he had just come out of a Turkish bath, made his bow yesterday before Recorder Smyth, in Part III. of the Court of General Sessions.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 25. -- The train-robbing industry received a decided setback this morning. Two men dead and four in jail is the result of a plan which miscarried because there were traitors in the camp. The robbers expected to make a rich haul of money, as the regular express usually carries from $50,000 to $100,000 out of St. Joseph.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Standing room was at a premium at the Coney Island Athletic Club last night and the promoters of that institution for the promotion of muscular development reaped a harvest. It was the largest money crowd that ever assembled in the vast building, and it is estimated that the club officials cleared at least $10,000 on the fight.

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- Regarding the international prize fight arranged between Mitehell and Corbett, to take place at Coney Island, Gov. Flower said to-day that he believed the Sheriff and District Attorney of Kings County would do their duty.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 25. -- The announcement recently made that Archbishop Kenrick of this diocese had been retired and that Archbishop Kain had been appointed administrator created a sensation among the clergy and laity of the country. Many doubted the statement. Notwithstanding these denials it can be stated positively that such appointment has been made.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept 25, -- The continuation of the hearing in the mutter of the application at the New-York, New-Ensland and Northern Railroad for permission to construct its line was on before the Railroad Commissioners this afternoon. An adjournment had boon taken from last week in order that some of those opposed to the building of the line might examine maps presented by the company.

It was shown in the article published on Sunday that the coal output of the Reading Company increased from 6,279,000 tons in 1887 to 7,574,000 tons in 1891. This increase is even more remarkable when the figures for each year in the period are examined. They were as follows: In 1887, 6,279,852; in 1888, 6,138,942; in 1889, 6,057,101; in 1890, 6,781,305, and in 1891, 7,574,301.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- These are mighty busy days for Lieut, Gov. Sheehan, and he is doing an enormous amount of traveling. He is making a personal canvass of the Assembly and Senatorial districts of Western New-York and picking his men for nomination.

It is evident that the managers of the Democratic "machine" in this State are planning for a complete control of the convention which is to meet at Saratoga within ten days, with the settled purpose, among other things, of nominating Judge MAYNARD for election to the bench of the Court of Appeals.
Spirits of turpentine quiet and easy at 27 3/4 @ 28 1/4 c. Resins dull at $1.07 1/2 @ $1.12 1/2 for common to good strained.

The Monmouth Park Race Track Association yesterday presented their answer to the temporary injunction restraining them from excluding C. Tracy Bronson, a reporter for The New-York Times, from the race track at Monmouth Park. The case came up before Vice-Chancellor Pitney in Chancery, Chambers, Jersey City, who also listened to an argument as to whether the temporary restraining order should be continued.

The banks retired $465,000 of Clearing House certificates yesterday and notice was given of the withdrawal of $650,000 more today. Balances against the Sub-Treasury, amounting to $821,000, were paid into the Clearing House in gold. The French steamer landed $150,000 in gold, which went to a banking house for transfer to Havana.
If Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy had anything to do with affairs in Kings County, thuggish brutality, whether contemplated or actual, would find a stern, prompt, and inflexible opponent.

Mr. HAMLIN GARLAND, who is, we believe, the author of a number of very impressive sketches of prairie life, which they represent as extremely dismal, has just contributed to the Forum a paper on "The Literary Emancipation of the West." This paper recalls the memorable observation of Mr. CHARLES DUDLEY WARNER on the controversy whether the literary sceptre had passed from Boston to New-York.
William D. Page of Page Taft, lawyers, died in his private office at 45 William Street yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- The local market has been active, with a big drop in Traction stocks. Philadelphia Traction opened 2 points down from Saturday's closing, and made a further break of 5 cent to 71, with a recovery at the close of 1 cent. At 72 the stock is selling at 44 cent, premium, and, as it pays but 6 cent. It is thought by many to be high compared with similiar stocks.

-- The youthful appearance of Mr. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, has frequently caused him annoyance on his travels. At a Milwaukee hotel recently he was mistaken for a messenger boy, and on other occasions people have expressed disappointment when he appeared, because they thought there must be some mistake.

The London Times of Sept. 14 printed the following account of the race for the Brenton's Reef Cup between Royal Phelps Carroll's Navahoe and the Prince of Wales'a Britannia, which was won by the Navahoe, over a course of 120 miles. The distance was covered in 10 hours 37 minutes and 35 seconds.

Lord Dunraven received a visit early yesterday morning from ex-Commodore James D. Smith, who is Chairman of the committee appointed by the New-York Yacht Club to make all arrangements in connection with the international race. It was 9:30 o'clock in the morning when Mr. Smith called at the Waldorf.

The foreign exchange market was strong and sterling rates advanced 1/210. Posted rates were $4.86 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 $4.89 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.85 1/4 @ $4.85 1/3 for sixty-day bills, $4.87 3/4 for demand, $4.88@$4.88 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.84 1/4 for commercial.

The L. C. Wise Company, the boot and shoe commission firm at 396 Broadway, suspended yesterday, having been unable to raise money to meet notes amounting to $10,000. The notes were protested and could not be extended.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Tompkins County Republican Convention, held to-day, nominated Ed-ward C. Stewart for member of the Assembly, Charles Ingersoll for Treasurer, and Charles S.S. Seaman for Sheriff, also Frank E. Tibbetts for member of the Constitutional Convention.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25. -- The case of Borneo Moskego, the Zulu Prince arrested while making a missionary address at the Zion Methodist Episcopal Church last night, was investigated to-day. Agent Preston of the Associated Charities took the case in hand this morning and examined Borneo's diary, which was captured in the melee last night.

In default of $5,000 bail, Lawyer Charles E. Burke was held yesterday by Justice Connelly, in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of grand larceny, preferred by Arthur L. Tomes. Mr. Burke's bail was raised from $3,000 to $5,000 at the close of the first day's examination, last Wednesday.

The play last night at the Star Theatre, where Frederick Warde and Louis James are filling an engagement, but scarcely filling the pockets of Theodore Moss, was Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar." It is a tolerably familiar play, and has been performed badly in New-York more frequantly, perhaps, than any other tragedy of Shakespeare.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- There was a considerable falling Off last week in freight shipments east from Chicago by both the all-rail and lake and rail routes. All-rail shipments aggregated 48,300 tons, against 52,493 tons for the previous week, and 63,001 tons for the corresponding week last year. Lake shipments fell away from 123,891 tons for the week ending Sept. 16, to 112,839 tons last week.
It is now practically settled that there will be a New-York City Day at the World's Fair, as originally suggested in The New-York Times, and that the date will be Saturday, Oct. 21.

News reached here from Milwaukee yesterday that Judge Jenkins, in the United States Circuit Court, had rendered a decision that would enable the Northern Pacific receivers to surrender the lease of the Wisconsin Central Railroad and discontinue the management of that unprofitable property. It has thus far caused a loss of more than $1,000,000 to the Northern Pacific Company.

CASEY, Ill., Sept. 25. -- A horrible cutting affray and murder occurred last night at a country dance at a farmhouse seven miles northwest of here. George McMechan received fatal wounds from a dirk in the hands of Charles Carpenter, from which he died in two minutes, and another man, named Berry of Janesville, and two others whose names could not be learned, probably received fatal wounds.

The "machine" Brooklyn Democracy has evidently decided to enter the Fall campaign handicapped by the opprobrium and denunciation attached to the forthcoming international prize fight between James Corbett and Charles Mitchell, pugilists.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Bubear was beaten by five lengths in the sculling match to-day with Sullivan, the New-Zealander. Bubear's style lacked dash and strength, Sullivan getting the lead and holding it.

Many east-side Anarchists met last evening at Golden Rule Hall, 125 Rivington Street, to complete the organization of an "Independent Political Association," with the avowed object of lighting the Socialists.

The first break in yesterday morning's mist revealed the outlines of three foreign war ships off the New-York bar. A little later they crept in past Sandy Hook, and by 1 o'clock in the afternoon they had anchored in the North River above Twenty-third Street. The only American war ship in the North River is the monitor Miantonomoh.

The votaries of "variety" are no feeble folk to be made afraid by weather or any other of life's minor vicissitudes, so last evening, though a storm threatened and rain for a while fulfilled the menace, enough people went to the Imperial Music Hall to give an occupant to almost all of the many seats in the house and leave enough over to make a presentable fringe along the wall in the real.

LONDON, Sept 25. -- The season is rapidly approaching when the demand for coal reaches its largest volume, and as the demand increases, coal merchants advance their prices, for, owing to the strike of the coal miners, the supply is not equal to the demand. On Saturday prices were advanced 2s. per ton, and to-day a further advance of 2s. was made.

Self-praise is undoubtedly Chicago's strong point, and of late New-York has gotten in the habit of unquestioningly acquiescing in all the good things her Western sister says about herself. For the most part, too, the evil and unpleasant things she says about New-York are allowed to pass without protest or much notice here.

The necktie manufacturing firm of D.J. Solomon Co., 547 Broadway, will probably be dissolved soon, as neither David J. Solomon, who was locked up for over a month in Bloomingdale, nor his brother, Henry, who had him locked up, is desirous of continuing the business as partners. The first steps toward dissolution of partnership were taken yesterday by Henry.

An earnest request has been sent out by President J. Newton Fiero of the New-York State Bar Association, urging members of that organization to give their personal attention to the selection of delegates to both Senatorial district and State Conventions, to attend the coming Constitutional Convention.

The affairs of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn were yesterday brought before Judge Bartlett in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on an application by Receiver Dykman for instructions concerning a check tendered him by George Malcom in part payment of his note for $10,000. Mr. Malcom is one of the Directors who four years ago gave their notes for $10,000 each to assist in making up a deficiency of the bank's treasury.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- This was nominally the opening day of the annual fair of the Westchester County Agricultural and Horticultural Society, which begins in earnest to-morrow. To-day has been devoted to receiving exhibits, of every variety, for the edification of the multitude which it is expected will begin to wend its way hither to-morrow.

The women of Brooklyn flocked in hundreds yesterday to the big new dry goods store of the Liebmann Brothers' Company, on Upper Fulton Street, to see the wonderful variety of fine fashions, in the latest fabrics, displayed on every floor. The special attraction was the firm's Fall "opening" in Paris, London, and American millinery.

David J. Solomon, contrary to the expectation of his employes, did not visit his place of business, 547 Broadway, yesterday. Speaking at his house in West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, of his reason for staying at home, he said, in his peculiar jerky way:

Prize fighters, like all other classes of men, have their ups and downs in this world. Only a few weeks ago Mr. "Solly" Smith, the California featherweight, gained a victory over Mr. "Johnny" Griffin, the auburn-haired youth from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, in a little seance at Roby, Ind.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Sept. 26. -- The members of the Hugh A. Thompson Association of the Tenth Ward, Brooklyn, 200 strong, who held their annual outing at Freygang's Bay View Park to-day, had an unpleasant experience. They came on the steamer Hazel Kirk. As they were landing at the College Point dock two of the party fell overboard and were nearly drowned.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 26 -- The Reading Railroad receivers met to-day and spent an hour or more in going over the affairs of the company. A formal statement announcing the decision of the company with regard to the various obligations maturing on Oct. 1 was expected, but the announcement was made after the meeting that nothing had been done.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Republican Convention for the Thirty-second Senatorlal District was held at Clean to-day. There was not the shadow of a contest. Frank W. Higgins of Clean was nominated for Senator by acclamation.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26. -- The managers of the annual music festival have an eye to dramatic effect. They opened the first concert of the week to-night by the performance of Weber's Jubel overture, the audience rising at its close to join with the chorus la singing two verses of "My Country, 'Tis of Thee."
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The markets to-day were dull and weak. The declines were temporarily checked in some American shares by shorts covering, but closing prices were the lowest.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- The market opened very weak, with a pressure to sell. Philadelphia Traction stock opened at 70. a decline of 2 points from the previous night's closing. There was a further decline to 651/2, with a quick rally of 6 points. The closing was steady at about 70. A meeting was held by the company to-day, and it is understood that there will be an allotment of 40 cent at par, $50.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- The Democrats of Illinois, encouraged by the success of their ticket last year and inflated over the prospect of being in the majority in the next General Assembly, are already engaged in a vindictive fight over the Senatorship.

The United States cruiser San Francisco, flying the flag of Rear Admiral A.E.K. Benham, left the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday and steamed to an anchorage in the North River off Forty-second Street. The big war ship steamed past the French squadron lying in the Hudson, and fired a Rear Admiral's salute in honor of the French flag officer, Lamomaix, in reply to a salute from that officer.

HAMBURG, Sept. 26. -- The awful mortality caused by cholera in this city and its suburbs last year did not have the effect of teaching the poorer classes the benefit of having everything in a good sanitary condition, and the efforts of the authorities to fight the disease this year have not met with the support of the classes referred to.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept 26. -- The Bankers' Association of Buffalo has sent a letter to Senators Hill and Murphy, inclosing resolutions adopted at a recent meeting of business men in Washington, and requesting that they do all in their power to secure the immediate repeal of the Sherman Silver act. The letter says:

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Lewis Carll and Obadiah Ward, arrested by Albert M. Darling last night for robbing the station Saturday night, have confesed their guilt. Carll seems to have been the principal. He is an old offender.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 26. -- This pretty Long Island village to-day pat aside the lethargy incident to a suburban existence, and, in holiday attire, welcomed 5,000 persons to the fifty-second annual exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society. The weather was not what a well-regulated county fair expects. The sky was overcast, threstening clouds hung low, and a brisk, cutting wind blew across the fair grounds, making overcoats and wraps a necessity for comfort.

PRAGUE, Sept 26. -- Since the state of siege was proclaimed in this city in consequence of the violent Czech agitation against the Germans, which finally resolved itself into an anti-dynastic demonstration, seventy arrests have been made. The restrictions placed upon the people by military law are rigorously enforced, and they have apparently succeeded in restoring order.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- President Charles F. Choate caused a sensation at a meeting of the Old Colony stockholders at the United States Hotel to-day by the announcement that since the printing and distribution of the annual report a discrepancy had been discovered in the accounts of the Treasurer, John W. Washburn.

Not the least important matter to be determined by the election of the present year in this State is the choice of the men who are to make a revision of the Constitution. The convention to be held for that purpose next May is to consist of 175 delegates, of whom 15 are to be elected from the State at large and 5 from each of the 32 Senate districts.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- The market opened lower, aud during the day was active and lower. Atchison was the feature, and maintained its usual strength compared with other stocks. Toward the close them was a rally, and the market closed with a firmer tone.

The hearing on Mayor Boody's motion to expunge the published minutes of the June Grand Jury from the records, was to have been held yesterday by Judge Moore in the Kings County Court of Sessions, but at the request of Counselor Soley, representing Gen. Tracy, it was adjourned to Thursday, Oct. 5.

PANAMA, Sept 26. -- A message received late to-night from San Jose, Costa Rice, says that Minister Baker has arrived there. Mr. Baker is to take active steps to hurry the departure of Francis H. Weeks.
CARMEL, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Putnam County Democratic Convention was held here to-day, and delegates were chosen for the State, Senatorial, and Judiciary, Conventions.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- A dispatch from Kissingen says that Prince Bismarck's illness is dangerous. His family does not approve of the suggestion that has been made that Emperor William visit him at Kissingen, as they fear that the slightest increase of excitement might prove fatal.

WASHINGTON, Sept 26. -- That the rules of the Senate are the most serious bar to the passage of the repeal bill is made plainer every day to those who witness the ridiculous performances on the floor of the chamber. It is becoming a serious question with some whether there is any limit beyond which a Senator of the Stewart sort dare not venture, the floor once in his possession.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 26. -- Though some new records are expected at the meeting of the Western Southern Circuit which began here to-day, the sport started off quietly. The track is in splendid condition, with several of the grades improved by leveling, bat the wetting it got earlier in the week has left it rather slow for the present. The weather, too, is chilly, so that there were no trials against time this afternoon.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- The cordiality with which the Czar has received the Count of Paris and the Duke of Orleans in Copenhagen is regarded here with distrust. Several newspapers say that, by his unusual attentions to the two arch-royalists, the Czar is publicly slighting the Republicans, who are preparing to honor the Russian Navy.

Delia Keegan's suit against Russell Sage for $100,000 damages, for alleged breach of promise, was again before Judge Pryor of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday. Miss Keegan's lawyer made a motion to strike out, as scandalous, certain sections of Russell Sage's answer reflecting on the character of the plaintiff.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday denied the petition of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad, represented by Trenor L. Park, asking that the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad receivers be Instructed to pay all rentals and other obligations alleged to be due the complainants.

After a hard day's sifting process, four more jurors were secured yesterday to aid in the trial of Frank Ellison for assaulting W.H. Henriques. Seven talesmen satisfactory to both sides had been accepted Monday, so that only one more juror remains to be chosen to-day to fill the box. But it is doubtful if this Will see the end of the struggle to obtain unbiased men.

Dawn was just beginning to peep over Long Island yesterday when the last of a carload of Texas steers was pried out of the tenacious mud of Bushwick Creek, at Kent Avenue and North Fourteenth Street, Williamsburg.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 26. -- At the Century Cycle Club races at Homewood Park to-day George A. Banker of the Pittsburg Athletic Club won live races and A.A. Zimmerman of the New-York Athletic Club two. The track was slow. Zimmerman won the one-third mile open in 0:55 1.5 and the five-mile international in 15:08, beating John S. Johnson.

When the Allan Line steamship State of Nebraska, from Glasgow, reached port yesterday morning, she had aboard two passengers who did not board the steamship at Glasgow. They were picked up in an open boat in latitude 45 degrees 58 minutes, longitude 51 degrees, after being afloat for five days without food or water.
The steamer Roland, which arrived here yesterday, is the first of the new freight and steerage line established by the North German Lloyd Steamship Company to run between this port and Bremen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The debate upon the Federal Elections Repeal bill, which began to-day, was not as exciting as was expected. Mr. Tucker of Virginia, who, in Mr. Fitch's absence, is in charge of the measure, delivered a carefully-prepared and well-considered speech upon the question, devoting himself principally to the constitutional points involved, although he took occasion to make some reference to John I. Davenport and his methods.

The West Side Tennis Club continued its Fall tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Eighty-ninth Street, near Central Park. The events were mixed doubles, men's doubles, and ladies' singles. The women's singles was completed, Miss K. C. Millett winning first place from Miss Mary G. Millett after a hard fight. The match was one of the best ever witnessed on the West Side courts, the playing being at times of a very high order.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, Sept. 26 -- P.M. The stock market was more active today, total transactions exceeding 292,000 shares. The opening was weak, and until the afternoon the general trend of prices was downward. Then came a rally which caused sharp advances, the strength continuing till the close. Most of the stocks at the last were near their highest point for the day.

Mr. Cameron's attitude on the silver question, which, from a public point of view, has been mysterious all along, is now wholly incomprehensible. What he does represent there is no telling, but certainly he misrepresents this State. -- Philadelphia North American, (Rep.)

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- The largest and most enthusiastic political mass meeting held in this city in many years convened at Memorial Hall to-night. The large auditorium and galleries were packed, and hundreds were turned away unable to secure even standing room.

-- There are two ostriches on the Midway Plaisance, named, respectively, Benjamin Harrisonl and David B. Hill. The reason is, says The Memphis Commercial, that, like an ostrich, David B.H. will take anything he can get, and Benjamin Harrison imagines his motives are hid when he sticks his head in the sand.
Nine-year-old Thomas Long started from his home at 1,431 Amsterdam Avenue yesterday afternoon with his brother James and several other boys to play football.

One of Prof. BARNARD'S photographs, taken at the Lick Observatory, is made by Sir ROBERT BALL, the text of a clear and fascinating description in the Fort-nightly Review of the wanderings of the north pole. It is, of course, the celestial pole of which the photograph was taken, and not the terrestrial pole.

The arrest of two several sets of Anarchists in Spain and in Austria indicates that the "Social Revolution" is making progress in those countries. In Austria, the most heterogeneous of nations, excepting our own, the Anarchistic demonstrations seem to have some significance properly political, and to be connected with the restlessness of the Bohemians under Austrian rule.

ANDERSON, Ind, Sept. 26. -- The American Wire Nails Mills resumed operations yesterday with 600 men on a non-union basis. All but three of the old Amalgamated Association men signed the scale and went to work.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- The advance guard of the great Democratic army of invasion have pitched their tents in Boston, and already the camp fires are blazing brightly. Smiling faces are pictured in the glowing flames; buoyant and enthusiastic committeemen and district chiefs are arranging the preliminaries for the grand display of force to be made to-morrow.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26 -- The press of the State has demanded of the authorities of this county that they take cognizance of the admission made by Senator Maurice Rogers, that William J. Thompson of the Gloucester race track had offered him $75,000 for three votes for the race-track bills, then pending in the Legislature.

Only two sales at inaction were had yesterday out of the half dozen advertised. All were in foreclosure proceedings and there was a notable absence of anything like activity. In the two sales which were had the purchasers were interested parties to the proceedings.

Dr. Wyatt Johnston, a prominent physician of Montreal, paid a visit to the Coroners' office in this city yesterday. The doctor has been commissioned by the Canadian Government to visit the chief cities in the United States and examine into the system of Coroners and the manner of dealing with cases of sudden and unnatural deaths, homicides, , in which a medical as well as a judicial investigation is necessary.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept 26. -- The eighth annual fair of the Society of Agriculture and Horticulture of Westchester County opened, to-day. It will continue until Saturday evening. For several years this fair has been under the patronage of the people of fashion of Westchester County, and they have made it the greatest event in the year for these living on the east side of the Hudson River valley.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Sept 26. -- The General Assembly of the Democratic Societies of Pennsylvania was called to order at 10 o'clock this morning by the President, Chauncey F. Black, who delivered an admirable address. Among other things he said:

ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 26. -- The rich residents of Islip and Oakdale are wrought up over the numerous burglaries. Many have hired private watchmen and detectives to protect their homes from the marauders. There are more than a dozen detectives in Islip and half that number in Oakdale. At the latter place W.K. Vanderbilt has three detectives guarding his Summer residence.

An elderly man, slightly built, strolled into the New-York Yacht Clubhouse at 67 Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon. His mustache and hair were tinged with gray and his face was well bronzed through exposure to the weather. As he entered the clubhouse he glanced at the pictures of famous yachts that hang on the walls.

The Lyceum Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, was crowded last evening by the friends of the Rev. Dr. McGlynn, to tender to him a reception to celebrate his fifty-sixth birthday. Most of those present were parishioners of St. Stephen's Church. They were enthusiastic in their welcome to their former pastor.

That the criticisms published in The New-Tork Times from the pen of the keen-eyed French journalist M. Raymond de l'Bpee have commanded unusual attention is proved by newspaper comment as well as by the numerous letters of approval and commendation daily received by The New-York Times.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 28. -- News has just reached here that a northbound passenger train on the Louisville Nashville Railroad has been ditched between Scranton, Miss., and Bellefontaine.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 27. -- There was gloom at the fair grounds early this morning. The absence of sunshine had a depressing effect upon the spirits of the fair managers. A big increase in attendance is always looked for on the second day. The exhibits are in position by that time, and the hurry and rush of the opening day is over.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Superintendent Preston of the State Banking Department has made his reply to the charges filed with Gov. Flower by depositors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn. Mr. Preston's answer. In the form of an affidavit, is as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27. -- Harvard University does not open until to-morrow, but the football men have already been practicing for a full week on Jarvis Field. For some years the interest of the undergraduates in the game has steadily grown, and this year the Thanksgiving game with the University of Pennsylvania will draw even more attention to this branch of athletics.

Because of a critical but very respectful article on his "Washington Receiving Lafayette," published in this journal on Sunday, M. BARTHOLDI has expressed himself in violent terms to reporters of several New-York papers. M. BARTHOLDI may rest assured that no prejudice inspired the criticism, the gist of which was simply that the group did not represent his best powers.

Nathaniel Catlin, father of Gen. Isaac S. Catlin of Brooklyn and father-in-law of ex-Secretary of the Navy Tracy, died Tuesday evening at the home of his daughter, Mrs, Maria Olmstead, near Owego, N. Y. He was born in Deckertown, N.J., ninety-nine years ago, his father being Nathaniel Catlin, formerly of Hartford, Conn., a distinguished soldier of the Revolution, who married Miss Decker, daughter of the founder of Deckertown.

The statement published in The New-York Times of recent date regarding an alleged attempt of English conspirators to swindle the Mutual Life Insurance Company of this city has received confirmation at the hands of the company's officers. They are doing all in their power to bring the offenders to justice.

Funeral services were held in St. Leo's Church, in East Twenty-eighth Street, yesterday morning, for Donna Maria Amelia de Menezes Drummond Furtado de Mendonaca, eldest daughter of the Brazilian Minister to the United States, Dr. Saivadore de Mendonca. Donna Mendonca died in Wilton, Conn., on Monday, of heart failure.

Only members of the Professional Woman's League and friends in sympathy were supposed to be present at 29 West Thirtieth Street yesterday afternoon when Mrs. E. L. Fernandez gave a little talk upon "Our League; Its Aim and Object." Consequently every member who could possibly arrange it was present, and Mr. A.M. Palmer's private office on the first floor was opened and filled to its utmost capacity.

The United States corvette Kearsarge sailed yesterday under orders to cruise and destroy derelicts along the Atlantic coast. Guncotton torpedoes will be used in the destructive work. After cruising to find derelicts, the Kearsarge will proceed to the West Indies.

"Business is booming, and we have been making great preparations for the Fall season that is already well under war," yesterday remarked J.F. Slattery, the manager of the firm of B.M. Cowperthwait Co., dealers in furniture and upholstery at 193 Park Row.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Sept. 27. -- The members of the Fifth Assembly District organization, New-York City, led by Alderman Edward A. Elsman, with Arthur Reilly, Albert Deiter, William H. Daley, and William Hoffer as aides, and members of the X X Bowling Club, with guests and friends, all numbering more than 600 men, arrived on the steamer Black Bird at Witzel's Point View Island, College Point, this morning, for their annual outing and games.

CHICAGO, Sept 27. -- Two crazed Chinamen ra amuck in a crowd at Wilson and Jefferson Streets last evening and wounded five men, one of them mortally. The Chinamen, John Sam and King Ling, are looked up at the Maxwell Street Station. The wounded are:

The Valkyrie is ready for her maiden sail under racing canvas in these waters. Some time this morning her anchor win be weighed, her sails set, and, with Lord Dunraven, Mr. Kerr, Mr. G.L. Watson, Mr. T. Ratsey, Capt. Cranfield, and Navigator Harvey on board, she will sail flown the lower bay, and those on board will examine her carefully in order to find out, as far as possible, where the rig can be improved.

In the Fifth Avenue Club courts. Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, the local club tournament is well advanced toward completion. The tournament is to be finished by Oct. 1 whether all the matches have been played or not. The same "forty-eight up" system of matches has been maintained throughout, with each point counting on the final total of each competitor.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 27.-- The Constitution will to-morrow print a letter from President Cleveland to Gov. Northen, in which the President states his position on the financial question at some length. The letter is in reply to one written by Gov. Northen on the 15th inst.

Miss Josephine F. Gardner, twenty-eight years old, of 176 Wyckoff Street, Brooklyn, who was employed as forewoman in charge of the chocolate department at E.C. Rich Co.'s confectionery establishment, 160 Franklin Street, this city, was accidentally struck yesterday by the elevator in the place and instantly killed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Gov. Thornton of New-Mexico, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior, says that no act of Congress for many years has effected so important an advance toward the permanent prosperity and well-being of that Territory as that creating the Court of Private Land Claims.

The mass meeting of colored citizens tomorrow night in the Bridge Street American Methodist Episcopal Church of Brooklyn is likely to terminate in a bitter fight. The meeting has been called by Miss Putnam's friends to protest against the action of the School Committee of Public School No. 83, which recently suspended her as head of a department in that school.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 27. -- The Harris Academy of Music was thronged with Democrats at noon to-day when the State Convention was called to order. Senators German and Gibson, Congressmen Compton, Rusk, and Talbot, Collector of Internal Revenue Murray Vandiver, and other leaders had been in conference the greater part of the night on the platform.
BOSTON, Sept. 27. -- Writting of George La Watson, the designer of the Thistle and the Valkyrie, the Scotch yachting correspondent of the Globe says:

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- In musical circles there has been considerable stir this week. The restraining order entered by Judge Seaman was dismissed in the Circuit Court by Judge Grosscup, and immediately thereafter John Boyd Thacher posted the awards in the Manufactures Building before any other legal steps stopping him could be taken.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Gov. Flower received an ovation from the citizens of Canandaigua to-day. He arrived here at 9 o'clock this morning. After an informal reception at the Canandaigua House, he was taken for a trip on Canandaigua Lake. After the return, dinner was served, and the Governor, escortd by the firemen of the city, went to the fair grounds, where the fifty-fourth annual fair of the Ontario Agricultural Society was being held.

With few exceptions the various Tammany Assembly District organizations have chosen their delegates to the Democratic State Convention, to be held at Saratoga Oct. 5, Several of the districts named their men last night.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Democrats of Genesee County who are friends and supporters of President Cleveland are sorely puzzled over the delay in calling the County Convention and the caucuses. The Hill men control the county organization, and so far there has been no intimation from them that they know that there is to be a Democratic State Convention this year.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Mr. Gladstone to-day brought his visit to Mr. George Armitstead, at Blackcraig Castle, near Blairgowrie, Scotland, to a close and proceeded to Edinburgh. The Prime Minister, accompanied by his wife and son, Mr. Armittstead, and Sir Algernon West, left Blackcraig Castle at noon.
The Hon. William C. Whitney has sent the following letter to the editor of The World:

CHICAGO, Sept 27. -- Cassius Belden, an insane carriage painter, entered the south gallery of the Board of Trade about noon to-day, and, drawing a revolver, deliberately fired twice toward the ceiling, and three times into the crowded pits of the floor below and the opposite gallery. A panic immediately ensued among the traders, every one seeking safety in flight or concealing himself behind bulletin boards and other objects on the floor.

While the Senate sits helpless day after day under the benumbing flow of Senator STEWART'S outrageous gabble, the danger to the business interests of the country grows. What that danger is is shown by two facts -- the steady advance of exchange on London to the gold-exporting point and the unabated difficulty experienced by business men in securing time loans.
LONDON, Sept. 27. -- There was more business on Change to-day and prices had an advancing tendency.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, Sept. 27 -- P.M. The volume of Stock Exchange business decreased again to-day, and on the whole the market was dull and irregular, the trading in some respects following the lines of one or two of the inactive days last week.

READING, Penn., Sept 27. -- The State League of Republican Clubs met here to-day. Nearly 200 clubs were represented, 50 of them from Philadelphia alone. Henry A. Muhlenberg delivered the address of welcome. President Robinson also made a speech, in which he howled calamity, and suggested that the people arise as one man and drive the Democrats out of power.

Mayor Gilroy, after consultation with Gen. Horace Porter, yesterday announced the committee which is to arrange for Manhattan Day at the World's Fair. It has 227 members. A very large proportion of the Columbus Committee of One Hundred is upon the list.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 27. -- There has been complaint of sickness among the children attending the public school at this place, and at a recent meeting of the voters of the district a committee was appointed to examine into the sanitary condition of the building.

Speaking of the Reading receivership in a statement published by him on June 28, Mr. Rice said that the Reading "was thrown off the apparent road to prosperity with the appalling suddenness of a collision, and plunged into bankruptcy without a moment's warning when the dividend goal seemed in sight."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27. -- To-morrow Yale begins its one hundredth and ninety-fourth year most auspiciously. The exceptional material prosperity which the university has enjoyed during the last few years has been gradual and imremittent, though there are no present indications that it has reached its height, despite the unprecedented endowments of the year just passed.

-- There is a curious quarrel among the Faculty of the Chicago College of Physicians, and Dr. Leonard St. John has petitioned the Circuit Court to restrain Dr. S. B. Buckmaster from longer holding the chair of physiology, on the ground that he does not own and refuses to purchase twenty shares of the capital stock of the college, which the charter provides the Professor of Physiology shall hold.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The Victoria China Works of Altrohlau, near Carlsbad, Bohemia, owned by Lazarus Bosenfeld, represented in New-York at 60 and 62 Murray Street, and in Chicago at 66 Lake Street, by Lazarus, Rosenfeld Lehmann, have been awarded the highest honors by the jury of awards in the conferring of medals and diplomas for china and Bohemian glass.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The scarcity of coal, due to the miners' strike, has led to a further rise of is per ton on the London Coal Exchange. The demand is strong, but business is trifling, inasmuch as virtually no stocks are offering. Holders of inland coal refuse to sell, preferring to wait a further advance, which many believe is certain to come by Friday next.
HAMBURG, Sept 27. -- The authorities here have been notified of six new cases of cholera that occurred during the twenty-four hours ended at noon to-day.

Burglars invaded the jewelry store of Benjamin F. Spink, at 359 Sixth Avenue, on Monday night, or early on Tuesday morning, and carried off jewelry and silverware valued at between $2,000 and $2,500. The burglary was one of the boldest that has been committed in this city in many years, and the manner in which it was accomplished shows that the burglars were clever professionals.

BOSTON, Sept. 27. -- The Democratic campaign was opened in this city to-day under auspices bright and promising. More than 2,000 delegates packed themselves into Music Hall before 11 o'clock. Every seat on the floor and in the balcony was occupied, and a fringe of delegates and spectators stood around the walls listening to the speeches and watching the proceedings.

In the progressive State of Massachusetts the Democratic Party is thoroughly united and is evidently full of confidence. The convention which met in Boston yesterday consisted of almost 2,300 delegates, and yet it completed its work in less than two hours and a half, nominating a complete State ticket, adopting a platform, and listening to several ringing speeches.
Frank Ellison, defendant, and William H. Henriques, complainant, were face to face yesterday, the one in the prisoner's seat, the other in the witness chair.

Theodore H. Davies, guardian of the Princess Kalaulani and well known as an opponent of the Hawaiian annexationists, is a guest at the Brevoort House. He arrived last week on the Campania, but left at once for Boston. He returned to this city yesterday. He will leave to-day for Washington, and expects to sail for Hawaii Oct. 19. He intends to call on Secretary Gresham at the capital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Brooklyn has not yet taken the new navy yard land which Congress some time ago allowed that municipality to purchase. Within the period required Mayor Boody gave notice that the city would take the land, but there was no intimation when the money would be forthcoming.

The big armored cruiser New-York is expected at this port soon. She is now in Hampton Roads. She proceeded recently from Philadelphia under orders to go to the Norfolk Navy Yard. Capt. John W. Philip, her commander, on arriving in Hampton Roads, reported to the Secretary of the Navy that he did not deem the depth of water from Hampton Roads to Norfolk sufficient for the New-York.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The chief event of the second day of the Worcester music festival was a grand performance this evening for the first time in Worcester of Saint-Saens's Biblical opera, "Samson and Delilah." The choruses were magnificently given, the soloists, particularly Mme. Carl Alves, who had the leading soprano role, acquitted themselves admirably.

Howard L. Bain, ex-cashier of the Homo Bank, in West Forty-second Street, under indictment for larceny, changed his plea yesterday of not guilty to guilty before Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions. He was remanded to the Tombs until Friday. Bain appropriated twenty Wabash bonds belonging to the bank, worth about $16,000.

Champion Zimmerman will make his appearance Saturday at the games of the New-York Athletic Club to be held at Traver's Island. His last public appearance this year will be at the championship games of the Metropolitan Association to be held Saturday, Oct. 7. Champion Zimmerman will represent the New-York Athletic Club on that occasion, and it will be the last chance his many admirers will have to see him perform in this vicinity.

There are at least six prominent Kings County officials who profess to be undisturbed by the action of The New-York Times and the rapid growth of hostile public feeling with regard to the impending international prize fight at Coney Island. These sis stolid and indifferent officers of the law are:

The Annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York began its session yesterday in Holy Trinity Church, in East Forty-second Street Before entering upon the business session, the delegates, clerical and lay, took part in a celebration of the holy communion. This service began at 10 o'clock.

The foreign exchange market was firm and higher. Posted rates for sterling were $4.86 for sixty-day bills and $4.88 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.85 for sixty-day bills, $4.87 for demand, $4.88 for cable transfers, and $4.83 1/4 for commercial.

THERE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 27. -- Milder weather and a faster track enabled the circuit cracks to put in some merry miles here this afternoon. The proramme began with an accident and a runaway in be first heat of the 2:17 trot, left unfinished from Tuesday. N.T.H. was the cause of the trouble, as his sulky collided with Chiquerita in the third quarter.

Charles H. Groves and John Clark, Republican leaders in the Seventeenth Ward, Brooklyn, were arraigned before Justice Watson, in the Ewen Street Police Court yesterday morning, for fighting in the street.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Democrats of the towns comprising the Third Assembly District of Westchester County held a convention at Yorktown Heights today to elect three delegates to the Democratic State Convention, also delegates to the Senatorial and Judiciary Conventions.

NEWARK, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Wayne County Democratic Convention was held here yesterday. The County Committee, in which the State machine men have the majority, shut out all of the Administration delegates from all but five towns, giving the Cleveland men five and the Hill men ten and the control of the convention.

WHITE PLAINS Sept. 27. -- There were 3,000 persons in attendance to-day at the Westchester County Fair, near White Plains. No doubt this number of visitors would have been doubled or trebled if it had not been for the cold and threatening weather. There was a sprinkle of rain during the forenoon, and it was nearly evening before a patch or blue sky was visible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The compromise silver measure prepared by Senator Jones of Arkansas was to-day introduced in the Senate by its author. It provides that there shall be a commission, composed of three Senators, to be selected by the Senate; three Representatives, to be selected by the Speaker of the House, and three persons to be selected by the President, subject to confirmation by the Senate.

Senator "DON" CAMERON owns no obgation to his party in Pennsylvania or in the Nation. He owns none to the people of the United States. He may be guided by a sense of gratitude to personal or political friends, as he is believed to be by some observers in Washington, but those who know him best do not accord much strength to this sentiment or to any sentiment.

The shoppers who crowded the store of Lord Taylor, Broadway and Twentieth Street, yesterday must have been more than ordinarily pleased with what they saw. It was Fall opening day, and such a collection of fabrics and all the articles for woman's use and wear had not been seen in the store before. The various departments seemed to vie with each other in showing off their best points.

BELLEVUE, Mich., Sept 27. -- On the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railroad here at 2 o'clock this morning Express Train No. 5, west bound, which was late, was run into by the Erie Express, also treat bound, demolishing a specia car attached to Train No. 5.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 27. -- Minister Lewis Baker arrived here at noon to-day. A decision as to whether Weeks will be surrendered will soon be reached. President Rodriguez has merely been awaiting the presence of Minister Baker and the arrival of the documents which the New-York detectives have in their possession before taking the final step in the surrender of the fugitive.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Benjamin Harrison of Indiana received to-day a popular welcome which will rank next to that given President Cleveland and the Infanta of Spain in the history of the Columbian Exposition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Robert E. Preston, appointed to-day to be Director of the Mint, has been connected with the Bureau of the Mint since it was organized. Entering it under Director Linderman in 1873, he was continued under all the succeeding Administrations, and has become thoroughly familiar with its operations and is a very trustworthy and businesslike officer.

The work of getting an anti-Tammany ticket in the field in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards for Commissioner of Street Improvements and for Assemblymen in the Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Assembly Districts was started last night in Schnorer Hall, at One Hundred and Sixtythird Street and Third Avenue, when the Citizens' Local Improvement Party was reorganized.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The manager of the London and Brazilian Bank has received a cable dispatch from Rio Janeiro, stating that one of the banks staff in that city was killed during the late bombardment by the rebel war ships.
BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- The market opened quiet and at about last night's closing, New-York and New-England was the feature. Toward the close the market became buoyant and closed strong.

The publication yesterday morning of President Cleveland's letter to Gov. Northen of Georgia started the day hopefully in the down-town exchanges. Prices of securities took an upward turn from the earliest transactions, and while the day was not specially busy at the exchanges, there was apparent on every side a buoyancy of feeling which the markets of late have entirely lacked.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 28. -- The rush or visitors on the first and second days or the Fall exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society was nothing compared with the attendance today. It seemed that all the roads in Queens County must lead to the fair grounds from the way the carriages poured through the gates. It was an incessant stream, starting early in the day and never ending until late this afternoon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- A reporter for The New-York Times had a conclusive interview with Gov. Roswell P. Flower to-day at the State Asylum for the Insane, just outsido this city. The Governor, who is here to visit the Dutchess County Fair, had decided to inspect the asylum officially this morning, and, on the reporter's arrival, bad just finished his breakfast.

WASHINGTON, Sept 28. -- There does not seem to be any reason why the nomination of Robert E. Preston to be Director of the Mint should arouse any intense opposition, but there are anonymous suggestions that the silver men will oppose his confirmation, on the ground that he has unlawfully refused to carry out the silver-purchase law.

From the Herald's Financial Article of Sept. 28. Reading contributed to the general decline by dropping 2 1-2 per cent, on the near approach of Oct. 1, which marks the expiration of the ninety days after default on the general mortgage bonds within which foreclosure proceedings could not be instituted.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 28. -- The through passenger train of the Louisville and Nashville Railway was wrecked at 10 o'clock last night at Gulfport, Miss., a point ninety miles east of New-Orleans. The switch had been broken open, and the train left the main track and dashed into an empty freight car on the siding.

Action toward securing additional school accommodation was taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. The Controller was authorized to issue $539,248 in schoolhouse bonds. The money is to be used, in part, as follows:

The significant letter of Mr. CLEVELAND has already had two important results. It has cheered the business men of the country and inspired them with new hope, and it has persuaded some of the "doubtful" Senators that it is no longer prudent to permit the silver men openly to boast of their co-operation.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Sept. 28. -- The Park Hill Gingham Mills will start up Monday morning, Oct. 2. Reductions in the schedule of wases will be made varying from 5 to 15 per cent. In future all wages will be figured per hour instead of per day or per week.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept 28. -- Nancy Hanks proved a most profitable card for the managers of the driving park here to-day, as she drew the largest crowd that has been at the track. Her trial was a disappointment, as she fell short of the time made over the course just one year ago by two and a quarter'seoonda.

Benjamin F. Dolaro, a son of the late Selina Dolaro, the comic opera singer, was a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with James Stillwell, alias Sullivan, a Boston man well known to the police of several cities. The two men were charged with robbery, and were remanded for trial to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- This morning shortly before 10 o'clock a white man about twenty-eight years of age in some unexplained way found his way into the lower regions of the White House, and, meeting the colored cook, said to her: "I want ta see father."

The Attorney General will to-day apply to the Supreme Court in Brooklyn to have W. N. Dykman made the permanent receiver of the wrecked Commercial Bank. Mr. Dykman was the personal counsel of President Seth L. Keeney at the time the bank shut its doors. The depositors will ask the Supreme Court to appoint an associate receiver to protect their interests.

QUEEN-S, L.I., Sept. 28. -- The annual State and brigade rifle matches of the First and Second Brigades of the National Guard of the Stats or NewYork were shot off on the Creedmoor range yesterday. Right teams of twelve men each from the Seventh, Eighth, Twelfth, Thirteenth, Twenty-second. Twenty-third, Seventy-first and Sixty-ninth Regiments competed for State badges.

Andrew J. Seymour, the Western mindreader, arrived in this city yesterday with his son and daughter, and registered at the Hoffman House. He intends to place his children in school in the East. Then he will do one of two things: Take a trip to Europe or bury himself. It depends somewhat upon the weather.

Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court yesterday granted an order authorizing the consolidation of the Bloomingdale Methodist Episcopal Church, West Forty-third Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, and St. John's Methodist Episcopal Church, Fifty-third Street, between Broadway and Ninth Avenue.

Bishop C.C. Penick, formerly Missionary Bishop to Liberia, and since then in charge of mission work among the colored people of the United States, addressed the Diocesan Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church at its morning session yesterday at Holy Trinity Church. He spoke earnestly of the work the Church might do among the colored people.

The intolerable delay of the Senate in dealing with a pressing public question and the power of obstruction displayed by an intractable minority have given new zest to the old discussion of methods for making that body more amenable to the popular will. Some go so far as to maintain that it ought to be abolished altogether, but that is wholly impracticable.

The opening exercises of the Union Theological Seminary were held yesterday. Prof. Arthur C. McGiffert was installed as the Washburn Professor of Church flistory, taking the place formerly held by the Rev. Dr. Philip Schaff.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Last night William F. Sheehan was compelled to show his hand in the redistricting matter, which the Aldermen and the Councilmen have been quarreling about for two months, and he showed it by forcing his henchmen in the Council to break pledges they had made.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Some of the "foreign" writers on the Parliamentary situation in Washington give color to reports that would not for a moment be entertained by any one familiar with the rules of the Senate or the House. The Philadelphia Ledger correspondent in New-York has heard a report that has naturally not reached the Washington correspondent of that paper.

Although it severely criticises the appointment of Mr. VAN ALEN as Ambassador to Italy, the Evening Post denounces as " disgraceful" the personal attacks made in certain newspapers on the appointee, of whom it says : " He is a gentleman and a man of more accomplishments and greater fitness for the place than, we venture to say, any of his predecesaors since Mr. MARSH."

FONDA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The Montgomery Republican Convention to name delegates to the State Convention and delegates to the Senatorial Convention was held here to-day. De Witt C. Cox of St. Johnsville was made Chairman, and James McDariamid of Canajoharie and F.E. Willoughby of Amsterdam, Secretaries.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday appointed Samuel M. Jarvis of Kansas City, Mo., and Roland R. Conklin of this city receivers for the Jarvis-Conklin Mortgage Trust Company, which is a Missouri corporation, with its main office at 40 Wall Street. The complainants in the action were Benjamin M. Fowler of Poughkeepsie and J.G. Zachry of this city.

James .J. Martin, President of the Police Board; Superintendent Byrnes, President Charles G. Wilson of the Health Board, Dr. Cyrus Edson, and Police Justices Smith and Voorhees were before the Grand Jury yesterday in reference to the investigation being made of the workings of the Coroners' office.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 28. -- Three hundred dollars' worth of clothing, stolen from the Grand Central Station in New-York, as found in New-Britain this afternoon by Detective Reilly of New-Haven. It belonged to a lot of godds, valued at $2,500, which was stolen from the Grand Central. N.E. Mag, a New-Britain merchant, had the goods in his possession.

Mr. GLADSTONE'S address to the Midlothian Liberal Committee can scarcely be called a "keynote." It would have been if he had dissolved Parliament and taken an appeal to the country after the rejection of the Home Rule bill by the House of Lords. But this he has not done and does not mean to do.

Charles Simonis, five and a half years old,of 526 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, was run over and instantly killed yesterday morning at Seventh Avenue, near Fifth Street, by Trolley Car No, 412 ol the Seventh Avenue line.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Sept. 28 -- P.M. Stock Exchange prices advanced to-day, and new strength was put into the market by the news from Washington, the President's letter to Gov. Northen aud various reports which reached Wall Street as to the prospects for forcing the Senate to an early vote on the repeal of the silver purchase law being sufficient to lessen in some degree the uncertainty of the situation.

The criticisms of M. Raymond de l'Epee on the methods of transportation by the Manhattan Elevated Railroad published in The New-York Times last Monday morning appear to have attracted not a little attention, and are meeting with much approval.

At Travers Island to-morrow afternoon the NewYork Athletic Club will give its flfty-first athletic games. Besides the games there will be club lawntennis contests, swimming races, ana clay-pigeon shooting. It will also be ladies' day. Special trains will leave the One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street station of the Third Avenue Elevated Road for Pelham Manor at 12:30, 1:10, 1:30, and2:16 P.M.

The Valkyrie sailed from off the Atlantic Yacht Clubhouse as far as Sandy Hook yesterday in light, variable winds. She went out evidently in order that It might be seen how her sails set, and for her owner and designer to make note of any alterations that were necessary. No attempt was made to show how fast she could sail.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 28. -- All the roads in Westchester County led to-day to the fair grounds, near White Plains. With a blue sky and a warm and welcome sun, all the expectations of the managers of the exhibition were realized, and there was a throng of 12,000 persons within the grounds by the time the bell was rung for the first race.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The weather man gave the Inter-State Fair Association a fine day, and "big Thursday" was full of enthusiasm. The fair was well attended by everybody, including the politicians. The crowd of statesmen was not as large as usual, but it was large enough.

The first meeting of the Regular Democratic Association of Flatbush last evening became badly tangled up in the intricacies of local politics, injected into the discussion a great quantity of personal spite, and then became so pugnaciously unparliamentary that it took three stern and uncompromising glances from a squad of policemen to get things back into a semblance of order.

The National Society of Electro-Therapeutics held the first three sessions of its first annual meeting at the Berkeley Lyceum, in West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday. The sessions were held during the morning, afternoon, and evening, and were attended by prominent electro-therapeutists from this and neighboring cities.

The exposures in the columns of The NewYork Times of official corruption and scandals In connection with the city government of Brooklyn have borne fruit. The call for reputable citizens of both political parties to get together and organize a movement to place an independent candidate for the Mayoralty in the field this Fall has been heard, and there is at last a bright prospect for the overthrow of the McLaughlin ring.

The selling of residences, especially on the west side, is proceeding slowly, but each day shows some transactions. Money to loan on bond and mortgage is also becoming easier, although institutions are not supplying it. The ruling rate is now 5 per cent. instead of 6, although transactions at the latter rate are still often made.
Seth Low, President of Columbia College and ex-Mayor of Brooklyn, was Interviewed In that city yesterday on the political situation, and said:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- There was merry war at the Niagara County Republican Convention held at Lockport yesterday. Richard Crowley, who had been in retirement since John M. Wlley, the present Consul at Bordeaux, beat him for Congress a few years ago, emerged from his seclusion and completely defeated the Low-Merritt ring.

There has been some talk of utilizing the turf circle at Sheepahead Bay us a trotting track. The cost of making a first-class trottine track would be rory small, and tha Coney Island Jookoy Club is reported to be giving serious thought to the idea.

Another ocean record was lowered yesterday when the Hamburg-American steamship Fuerst Bismarck passed the Needles on her trip to Southampton. The Fuerst Bismarck left this port Thursday afternoon, Sept 21, and crossed the bar at 3:44 P. M. She passed the Needles at 7:68 yesterday morning, making the voyage in 6 days 10 hours and 65 minutes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- There were 18,000 people at the Dutchess County Fair to-day, it being Governor's Day. Gov. Flower came on the grounds in the four-inhand tallyho coach of Reginald Rives, who is President of the fair, and was accompanied by Secretary of State Frank Rice, State Railroad Commissioner Beardsley, J. W. Hinkley, Major Hinkley, and others.

PERSONALS. -- W. Harold Brown, Frank K. Pendleton, Mr. and Mrs. W.F. Burden, Miss Caroline De Forest, Miss de Barrill, Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock, and Center Hitchcock are in town. Miss Emeline Dore has closed Pinard cottage No. 3 for the season. Next Summer she will have the same cottage. Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hunt closed their cottage at Newport on Wednesday and came into town.

The clergymen of Brooklyn, without distinction of creed, and the law-abiding and order-loving citizens of that municipality, are looking with increased anxiety to The New-York Times to prevent Pugilists James Corbett and Charles Mitchell from engaging in an international prize fight at Coney Island.

NEW-HAVEN. Conn., Sept. 28 -- A promising candidate for the Yale eleven was disabled this afternoon. Alexander Brown, who wag playing tackle on the "Varsity side, went down in a scrimmage and sustained a severe wrench of two ribs. It was feared at flrst that they were broken, but an examination this evening shows only a bad sprain. He will not play lor three weeks.

LONDON, Sept 28. -- The striking coal miners in Warwickshire balloted yesterday on a proposal to resume work at a 5 per cent, reduction in their wages now and a further reduction in January. The feeling among the men will be known when it is stated that out of the 3,000 men who voted on the proposal only 2 cast their ballots in its favor.

Gen. Henry C. Young made a motion before Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court, yesterday for leave to file an answer in the suit brought against him by Mrs. Caroline M. Collins, his sister, for $20,000 damages for defamation or character.
Mrs. Leila Olyve Neame, "the woman in the case," came on the scene yesterday in the Ellison-Henriques drama before Recorder Smytn.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- The market has been steady all day. Philadelphia Traction opened at 65, with a subsequent rally to 67. The Stock is held down by the new issue of 56,000 shares. There is considerable disappointment that it was not allotted at a higher figure. Metropolitan Traction was strong all day and closed at 87 bid.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 28. -- The steamer Mariposa arrived here this morning from Sydney, bringing the following Honolulu advices: The United States cruiser Philadelphia has arrived and Admiral Skerrett has transferred his flag to her from the Boston. The latter will sail for San Francisco about the 27th.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Fears for the safety of the cruiser New-York should she attempt to proceed from her present position near Norfolk to the Norfolk Navy Yard caused Secretary Herbert to decide this afternoon to order the vessel to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where the repairs and fittings intended to be done at Norfolk will take place.
Sliver bullion certificates for 35,000 ounces sold at 74 1/2c.

WASHINGTON, Sept 28. -- The letter written by Mr. Cleveland to Gov. Northen of Georgia, stating his position on the financial question, furnished the members of the Senate with an interesting topic to-day. There was nothing in the proceedings worthy of note, so that the letter attracted more attention than it would had it appeared when the Senate was interested in a sensational performance such as that of yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The magnificent steam yacht Nourmahal, belonging to John. Jacob Astor, lies beached on the east side of the Hudson River, near Van Rensselaer's Point, just north of the New-Hamburg Railroad tunnel. Shortly before 10 o'clock last night she was on her way up the river off what is known as the Dans Kammer, and a little west of the middle of the river.

Mr. CLEVELAND has once more shown, himself the best representative and, therefore, the beat leader of the Democratic Party. His letter to Gov. NORTHEN states the actual situation with singular simplicity and clearness, and states with equal clearness and simplicity the only possible policy for the Administration or for Congress.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28. -- This was the great day of the musle festival, and the hall was fairly packed as both concerts. Women predominated in the afternoon and there was a gorgeous display of millinery. In the evening the feminine half of the ehorus appeared in white gowns and the women in the audience were in festal attire.

David Groesbeck, who was Daniel Drew's broker and at times his adviser in financial operations, died yesterday at 180 West Fifty-ninth Street. He was seventy years old. From 1850 until 1867 Mr. Groesbeck led many important stock movements, and, with a large fortune, he retired from business. He could not keep away from Wall Street, however, and engaged again in his former business.

Manhattan Day at the World's Fair should be made memorable by a great attendance of the citizens of New-York. Thousands of our people have already made the trip to Chicago. Many other thousands who want to go and intend to go have not yet used the day of their going, or perhaps have not quite brought their courage to the sticking point about starting at all.
Under the yellow light of a score of blazing gaslights the fifth day of the Ellison trial came to an end last night with the defendant in the chair.

The inquest which, the Grand Jury of this county has been holding upon the Coroner system has resulted in a presentment to the Court of General Sessions exposing the abuses that have grown up in the Coroners' office and recommending that the present system be wholly abolished. Tho Grand Jury expresses the belief that the long-standing maladministration of the Coroners' office is "a cause of embarrassment to the interests of public justice."

WAGONER, Indian Territory, Sept. 29. -- "Bill" Dalton, Frank Cheney, and "Bill" Doolan, the noted train robbers, are now camped near here. They have been making nightly visits to this town, returning to camp after spending a few hours among their old friends.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- It is asserted by the repeal leaders that the fate of the repeal bill will be decided some time between Oct. 9 and 13. It would be decided sooner but for circumstances over which the leaders have no control. Next week a number of Senators who favor repeal will be obliged to absent themselves from the Senate for a number of days.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 131@134, North Chicago at 210, Lake Street Elevated at 23 1/2, Diamond Mutch at 117. Money. 7 p cent Bank clearings, $12,533,591. New-York exchange, 80c premium.

The most interesting of real estate transactions yesterday was the sale of the Pierre Lorillard mansion at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, to Mr. Charles E. Runk of Frederick Beck Co. The mansion has long been known as one of the most elegant in the city, and attached to it is one of the finest of private ballrooms.

"The New-York Times is the only metropolitan daily that has given a prize for the Metropolitan championships of the Amateur Athletic Union," said Secretary James E. Sullivan yesterday. "Talk about patrons of pure sport, we have very few in this country. In England everybody of prominence is anxious to give a medal or some trophy to be competed for by amateurs, but in America it's different.

The brokers in the wheat pit at the Produce Exchange were busy shouting quotations at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a man appeared in the gallery almost over their heads, whose movements attracted notice. Some of the brokers who saw him quickly lost interest in the transactions on the floor and began getting behind tables, pillars, and boxes, and placing substantial obstructions between themselves and possible danger.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted at 74 1/4 @75c. Bar silver in London was quoted at 34 1/8d ounce. The New-York price for bars was 74c. Mexican silver dollars were quoted at 58 3/4c.

John Roberts, the famous English billiard player, will engage in a match with Frank Ives for $1,000 and gate receipts next week, 10,000 points to be played. The match will be commenced on Monday afternoon at 3 'o'clock at the Lenox Lyceum, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, and will be continued afternoons and evenings until Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- A spice of international interest has been injected into the situation of affairs in Brazil through two incidents that may lead to complications.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- Harness racing has seldom been conducted under worse conditions than at Mystic Park to-day. A nipping nor' easter reduced the temperature to about 40, and rain fell most of the time.

WASHINGTON, Sept 29. -- Mr. Cleveland has at last put an end to much of the anxiety which has prevailed among Western New-York Democrats since March 4 by naming the men who are to occupy three of the most important positions in that region. To-day he decided to make these appointments:

The Valkyrie was out sailing again yesterday, and in the good breeze that was blowing all day long she showed up to much better advantage than she did on Thursday. The wind blew strongly from the north-northwest and the upper bay was covered with white caps. At times the wind blew twenty miles an hour, and a better chance to test the sails and see how they fitted could not have been had.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Republican County Convention which convened here to-day was largely attended, every town in the county having a full representation. The convention was called to order by Burr Mattice, Chairman of the County Committee, and L.E. Bowe of Otego was made Chairman.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The market relapsed into dullness again to-day, and Americans fell away from the opening, under the lead of Louisville and Nashville, on a report that 50,000 new shares would be shortly issued. The closing was at the lowest figure in most cases, but Louisville and Nashville recovered half a point in the last few minutes on short coverings.

"It is useless to deny that the recent financial strain and the obstructive tactics of the silver men in the Senate have severely hurt the trade in the finer grades of men's custom-made garments," said Mr. Morley, a member of the firm of George A. Castor Co., yesterday, in their store in the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- The weather was cold and cheerless here to-day when the big Australian cricket match which has lone been looked forward to was commenced on the grounds of the Belmont Cricket Club at Elwood. About 3,500 persons attended the same, but as the play did not start until the afternoon hardly more people were looked for.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 29. -- But for an unexpected countermanding telegram, Samuel J. Macdonald, Assistant City Counsel, would nave started for Cincinnati to-morrow afternoon to be married on Oct. 3 to Miss Anna Harper, a young woman of that city. The telegram was received this morning and reads as follows:

Since THE TIMES began casting its searchlight over the quagmire of Brooklyn official and political life a good many persons have acquired new and desirable information about the affairs of that city. Information is the proper basis of opinion, and opinion of action. Our neighbor the Sun has information, and opinions about Brooklyn, and now advises action.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- There was very little trading early in wheat, and the market was dull. Fluctuations were within a range of 3/8c. Shortly before the close, however, more activity was shown, and prices advanced about 1c, the market closing 1/2c higher for May and 1/2c higher for December. There was not a great deal of outside business, although NewYork was credited with selling considerable wheat early.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- The action of the Grand Jury yesterday in indicting F.W. Smith, the convicted Cronin jury briber, now under sentence, and Otto Jirsa, for arson was followed up to-day by the return of indictments for conspiracy to defraud insurance companies against D. Brown, O. C. Churchill, Paul Lonemeyer, Robert McKnight, G.W. McKee, David Rosenblath, Charles Kinsman, Henry Schenck, and Insurance Adjusters A.S. Peck and Clarence H. Rowe.

Commissioner Andrews of the Street-Cleaning Department yesterday submitted to the Board of Apportionment his estimate of the amount of money needed to conduct his department in 1894. The gross amount asked for by the Commissioner is $3,138,931.21.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Sept. 29. -- The Weather Bureau signalman at Gay Head reported having sighted a large steam yacht ashore on the west end of Cuttyhunk Island this afternoon, apparently bilged.
