A strong northerly wind was blowing, causing a rough sea. The steam tug Eisie went to the rescue, but returned without finding any trace of the distressed craft.
Spirits of turpentine dull and steady at 27 1@28c. Resina are firm, but quite, at $1.15 for Common to good strained.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railway Company in their annual report to the Secretary of the Interior say that from a recent personal examination made by one of the Directors they are enabled to repeat with emphasis the statement of their predecessors last year as to the excellent physical condition of the system, both as to the main line and its important branches.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The final game of the inter-class series for the championship of the college in baseball was played this afternoon, between the seniors and juniors, the latter winning by the score, of 7 to 4. Each team had won two games, and much interest was manifested in the deciding contest. Six of the Varsity men nlayed with the juniors, while but four played with the seniors.

The intense feeling against the highhanded Brooklyn ring gains strength every day. Strong in their first move of opposition, the lovers of decency and probity in government find, everywhere they turn, new sympathizers and new supporters. So great is becoming the popular outcry against the unholy alliances of the ringsters that the foundations of their structure of political infamy are showing the premonitory symptoms of a rapid fall.

One of the things that go furthest to discredit the administration of justice with the plain people is the remarkable latitude that is given by Judges to lawyers. They are allowed with impunity not only to waste the time of courts that are maintained at the public expense, but also to commit substantial offenses.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- A wintry wind blew over the Westchester hills to-day, scattering cold rain wherever it went, and keeping the expected crowd away from the fair. There were only about 2,000 persons in attendance.

The leaders of the Democratic Party in the various States have so far seen the absolute necessity of protecting themselves. from the odium attaching to delay in pass-- ing the repeal bill in the Senate. In Pennsylvania and in Massachusetts they have given a clear and strong indorsement to the policy of the Administration.
A roar like the rattle of musketry, accompanied by a pounding of gongs, awoke the echoes in Mott Street just as dawn began to break yesterday.

In the article published in The Times yesterday attention was called to the doom awaiting Reading in the event of the success of the plan of rehabilitation, which was so determinedly pushed by the receivers in their own interest. The jeopardy in which Reading's general business, and in particular. Its coal business, would have been placed was detailed at some length.

The clergymen of Brooklyn are in a state of unmixed indignation over the indifference to their protests against the impending international prize light shown by District Attorney Ridgway and his followers. So quickly have they accepted Mr. Ridgway's challenge to the forces of law and order that every mail brings to The New-York Times letters from clergymen enthusiastically commending its course.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 29. -- Between 1,200 and 1,500 silver miners have resumed work this week in the Colorado mines which closed with the big slump in the price of silver last Jnne. This makes a total of not less than 3,500 miners who have gone back to work during the last ten days, and scores of other mining properties are expected to reopen soon.

CRYSTAL FALLS, Mich., Sept. 20. -- With a terrific rush the water of the Michigamme River broke through a bed weakened by mining into the Mansfield Mine, six miles from here, between 9 and 10 o'clock last night, drowning twenty-eight men who were at work directly under the cave-in.

With Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions yesterday the September Grand Jury filed its presentment respecting the Coroners' office, based upon the investigation which had been in progress for a number of days. The presentment, which was read by Foreman Emanuel Bloomingdale, concluded, with the following recommendations:

Champion Lightweight Pugilist "Jack" McAuliffe was given a testimonial in the Claremont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night. The show was poorly advertised and the house was only half filled. The bout that attracted the most attention was the set to between Charley Mitchell and "Jim" Hall.
The Dock Board's big plans for the improvement of the North, East, and Harlem River water fronts were taken, up by the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday for a public hearing.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The entries for the ten-mile road race of the Atalanta Wheelmen, to be held at 4 o'clock to-morrow afternoon on the Elizabeth-Springfield course, arc as follows:

T. Thomas Fortune, the colored editor of Brooklyn, narrowly escaped personal violence at a meeting of friends of Miss Georgiana Putnam, the colored school teacher, in the Fleet Street African Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, last evening.

Primaries were held in this city last night by the Republicans in the various Assembly districts for the election of delegates to the Republican State Convention to be held at Syracuse Oct. 6, and to the various local and Senatorial and Assembly conventions.

SAUK CENTRE, Minn., Sept. 29. -- A.H. Pettit, Alderman of the First Ward, President of the Bryant Library Association, and also President of the Sauk Centre Building and Loan Association, left four weeks ago, ostensibly for the World's Fair, but the developments of the past forty-eight hours indicate that he has no intention of returning, as there is an apparent shortage of many thousands of dollars in his accounts.

QUEENS, L.I., Sept. 29. -- The rifle match for the Governor's Trophy was shot off at Creedmoor to-day, resulting in a victory for Private John Corrie of Company B, Twelfth Regiment, who made a score of 87 out of a possible 100 on four ranges.

It is a very old saying, for which we are indebted to a poet called CAMPBELL, that "distance lends enchantment to the view." Perhaps the manner in "which the expectant public mind viewed the Valkyrie when she was 3,000 undulating, seasick miles away from us, did not exactly come under the head of enchantment, but none the less it was a condition largely duo to distance.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 29. -- The Morewood tin-plate works will close permanently on Saturday. Some of the hands will go back to Wales, and the others will go West, where tin-plate works are in operation.

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- The one subject that is agitating the minds of the Democratic Party of this county is, not whether Judge Maynard is to be nominated, for that question is assumed to be settled, but whether he will be elected, which is already one of grave uncertainty.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept 29. -- In sharp contrast to the fierce factional light of the Republicans in their nominating convention yesterday were the three Democratic Assembly District Conventions which were held here to-day. Delegates were chosen to represent the districts in the State Convention without opposition, the names being satisfactory in every case to State Commiteeman W.B. Kirk, who aspires to be put on the ticket for State Treasurer.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- In Washington Park this afternoon the King memorial fountain was unveiled with literary and musical exercises. Gen. Horace Porter of New-York, delivered the oration and William D. Morange of Albany an original poem.

What seems to have been a scheme of systematic and cold-blooded perjury was brought to light in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning when four prisoners were arraigned on a charge of conspiracy and perjury. The prisoners were Mrs. Annie Baumann of 14 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, Max Kestenbaum of 63 Columbia Street, Ernest Wilhelm Sachs of Brownsville, L.I., and Samuel Diamond of 292 East Houston Street.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Exchange Telegraph Company to-day received a dispatch stating that the City of Desterro, the capital of the Island of Santa Catharina, surrendered to-day to the detachment of the rebel Brazil fleet sent to operate against the place.
The Nourmahal, John Jacob Astor'a yacht, arrived safely off the foot of West Thirty-fourth Street, where she dropped her anchor, about 7 o'clock last evening.

Tammany's big General Committee met last night in the Fourteenth Street Wigwam for the first time since Spring. There was a large attendance of the prominent members of the organization, but, with the exception of the speech made by Nelson Smith, the Chairman of the committee, only routine business was transacted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Jacob Schoenhof and J. Rockwell Fay were appointed Assistant Appraisers of the New-York Custom House by Secretary Carlisle to-day. Mr. Schoenhof is well known to readers of The New-York Times. In Mr. Cleveland's first Administration Mr. Schoenhof visited many of the foreign Consulates, and gained an accurate knowledge of the tariff question.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Sept. 29 -- P.M. The stock market scored another advance to-day, the list developing much strength in the afternoon, chiefly on reports from Washington that the Senate would reach a vote on the repeal of the silver-purchase law in a few days.

Charles W. Denike, formerly the owner of the Brighton Beach Hotel, at Fort Moultrie, Sullivan's Island, South Carolina, has begun an action against Henry P. Degraaf, President of the Bowery Bank, Canal Street and Bowery, who was until recently the head of the firm of Degraaf Taylor, furniture dealers, 47 West Fourteenth Street.

It will be no surprise to learn that the total number of business embarrassments during the past nine months, says Brad-street's, aggregate 11,174, or 51 per cent. more than in a like portion of 1892, when the total was only 7,378, and 26 per cent. more than in the corresponding period of 1891, the heaviest previous nine months' total of mercantile embarrassments, 8,866.

An unexpected tempest sprang up in the Ellison case yesterday. Assistant District Attorney Wollman gave out the information that three of toe jurors before whom Ellison is on trial for assaulting Broker Henriques had on the previous night, after adjournment of court, spent a considerable time in the company of the lawyers of the defendant at the cafe or the Cosmopolitan Hotel, drinking and conversing.

The Bethlehem Iron Works has in view, it is announced, the establishing of an efficient armop-proving ground near its present establishment. Already ground has been, broken for proving purposes, and there are in position one eight-inch, one ten-inch, and one twelve-inch breech-loading rifles. Two of the three guns are owned by the War Department.

It really is remarkable that the fancy for black and white should, after so many days, still have such hold. Introduced as a midsummer idea, the combination has prevailed during the opening weeks of the Autumn, and gives promise of being continued well into the Winter.

The vigorous way in which the clergy of Brooklyn are repelling the declaration of Mr. Ridgway's friends that the District Attorney" owes them nothing" is illustrated by the announcements of those who will preach to-day on the subject of the international prize fight, and, incidentally, of official "non-interference."

The prize list for the ninth annual exhibition of the National Horse Show Association, to be held in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 13 to 18, inclusive has been prepared, and is being sent out to probable exhibitors.

There is much speculation in Brooklyn concerning the committee of one hundred constituted to try and unite on a candidate for Mayor all elements opposed to misrule and corrupt government in the city. It sprang into being so suddenly that no one was able to account for it.

When the careful housekeeper returns to her home after the Summer absence her first interest is in the wholesomeness of her domain; she looks to the plumbing, has pipes and traps overhauled, the cellar aired, cleaned, and whitewashed, rooms swept and renovated, curtains hung, carpets renewed, the Fall and early Winter wardrobes of the family put in order; all this and more before she looks to the condition of her napery shelves.

The uppermost, feeling or one who glances through a volume by Agnes Repplier is amazement at the astonishing amount of her literary information, the vast sum of her reading. It is not that she has read everything, without discrimination. The idea comes to one, under her influence, that she has been particularly discriminating, and, since her childhood at least, has read through no book that she did not like.

The Sailing Committee of the Royal Yacht Squadron held a special meeting Sept. 14, for the purpose of dealing with Mr. Carroll's protest against the decision awarding the race for the Brenton Reef Cup to the Britannia by 2 1-2 seconds. After hearing the owner of the Navahoe and the officers of both yachts, the committee reversed the decision and declared the Navahoe the winner of the cup.

La Fontaine's father had a place in the forestry department at Chateau Thierry, a town on the Marne, about fifty or sixty miles from Paris. He seems to have done two important things for his son besides his part in bringing him into the world. When La Fontaine was about twenty-six he handed over his place to him and presented him with a girl of fifteen for his wife.

The archeologist classes the cliff dweller as higher in culture than the cave dweller. The latter was content to exist in abodes that had already been scooped out for him, while the cliff dweller would not expose himself to storm drifts, and so walled in the crevices. Hence we see the earliest germ of architectural construction.
The weekly bank statement, issued to-day, shows an increase in reserve of $6,510,550. The banks are now $24,120.500 above legal requirements.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30 -- The Pittsburgs wound up the most profitable season in the history of baseball in tills city in a creditable manner to-day by defeating the Giants. Delegations from near-by towns, headed by brass bands, were in attendance to make the wind-up a gala one.
New-York, by reason of her contribution and historical connections, is much interested in the erection of the Battle Monument in the City of Trenton, which is to be formally dedicated on Oct. 19.

War on the lithograph as a medium of theatrical advertising is about to be begun in Philadelphia. Nixon and Zimmerman, who control three of the leading theatres in that city -- the Chestnut Street Opera House and Theatre and the Broad Street Theatre -- are the first movers in the work, and other managers are falling into line behind them.

Among the passengers on the steamship Campania, whom sailed yesterday for Liverpool, were Mrs. Helen W. Atkins, J.E. Findley, O.L. Mayer, James O'Leary, H.H. Herts, F. Ainsworth, Nathan Clark, and Dr. Norman Milligan.

NEWPORT, Sept. 30 -- The Government has awarded the contract for the building of the marine barracks at the naval training station, and yesterday ground was broken for this work. Since the removal of the old New-Hampshire two years ago the Marine Guard attached to the station has camped out, Winter as well as Summer.

This, the final volume of the Putnam edition of Washington's writings, has been long in making its appearance,owing to the delay involved in preparing on index to the entire set of fourteen volumes. The delay may also have been due to the time required for the preparation of matter additional to the writings, such as the account of the death and the sketch of the Washington family.

The discussion among the Sinking Fund Commissioners which ended in the abandonment for the present of the proposal to hand over the water front of Riverside Park for improvement by the Dock Department ought not to end without the adoption of a permanent policy with respect to this water front and suck other parts of our water front as are subject to like conditions.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- The character of the local ticket named by each party in this usually Republican county always has considerable influence upon the vote for the State ticket, and it is generally conceded about town that the Democrats put up an exceptionally strong list of candidates, while the Republicans nominated a ticket that disgusted a large section of the party and will not have the united support of the Republicans.

The correspondent of a London weekly who has been visiting Rosa Bonheur at her villa in Thomery, near Fontainebleau, describes her as an old woman, small, sunburnt, and wrinkled as a peasant. Her thick gray hair is cropped short, and if she does not always wear trousers the blouse is her constant garb.

An improved range, or really a double range, has an equal number of griddles for cooking by gas or by coal, or by both at the same time. Both sides of the range are provided with water-backs, so that the lack of hot water for the bathroom, so long the great fault of gas stoves, is done away with.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- The adjourned conference between the receivers of the Reading Rairoad Company and representatives of the New-York bondholders' committees was held in the Directors' room at the Fourth Street offices to-day, the session continuing from 10 o'clock in the morning until after 3 o'clock in the afternoon.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept 30 -- Another victim of the trolley cars was added to the list in Jersey City to-night. The incident almost caused a riot among the crowd that gathered after the accident.

The members of the Veteran Firemen's Association of California who are making a tour of the Eastern States will reach New-York to-day. They will arrive, here at 1:55 P.M. and will remain in the city five days.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Sept. 30 -- The Lutheran Synod to-day made its final disposition of the Diver case. W.H. Diver of Newport, the third oldest minister in this synod, and who has been Synod Treasurer for toe past ten years, was charged with embezzling the synod's funds. After an exhaustive trial before an investigating committee and a further hearing, he was found guilty of the charge, and this morning was deposed from the ministry.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- Twenty-five thousand feet of spruce lumber has been ordered to be shipped from the sawmill of Edward Ware, at Winslow, Me., to Grover Cleveland, Bourne, Mass. This would seem to indicate that the President intends to enlarge Gray Gables, or to build a new structure of some kind on his estate.

The candidates for the Central Park tennis championship met yesterday afternoon on the lower courts of Central Park. The events were men's singles, men's doubles, and consolation men's singles. The singles were advanced to the final round John F. Hobart of the New-York Tennis Club and Oviedo M. Boatwick of the Lenox Tennis Club being the two left undefeated.
" Come at 6," said a woman recently, an author who has spent much time abroad, to a friend, "and try a French 'salade poetique' with me. I learned to make it on the other side."

A prodigious serpent has been terrifying residents near Scranton, Iowa, this Summer, is stated by a paper of that State. Whether it was a sea monster that had worked up the Mississippi or the Summer resort sea serpent attracted by the World's Fair has not been definitely settled.

From this time on the auction, sales at the various salesrooms will be the specially interesting item to all whose taste turns toward the horse. W.D. Grand has entries of sales that promise great success at the American Horse Exchange. Mr. Grand has always enjoyed the highest respect of his neighbors in Toronto, Canada, and by his methods of business in this city has made many warm friends.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- There is trouble ahead for the Monmouth County Democrats. Senator Henry S. Terhune is a candidate for re-election, and his nomination by the Democratic Convention is cornceded. Terhune voted for the race-track bills last year, and that vote will be the stumbling block in his path at the November election.

Dr. Michael Walsh, editor of The Sunday Democrat and Catholic Herald of this city, received a letter a few days ago from the Rev. Dr. Hector Papl. Secretary of the Apostolic Delegation in Washington, which was written at the instance of Mgr. Satolli, referring to a communication published by Dr. Walsh in a morning newspaper on Aug. 23 last.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Electricity has made it impossible for a mob to make much headway in this city. If a riot is bred by the disregard of law among the unruly classes, it dies "a-bornin'" because the Police Department has the means of mobilizing its forces within a few minutes in any part of the city in such numbers as to cope successfully with any riotous crowd.

It was the growing importance of the leather trade down in the "Swamp" that called into being, in 1853. the Shoe and Leather Bank of New-York. It was first organized under the old State laws and did dusiness at William and John Streets. Its first President was the successful leather manufacturer Loring Andrews.

The fifty-two provincial delegates of the French workingmen to the World's Fair sailed for Havre by the French line steamer La Bourgogne yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- A large crowd assembled at the Triton Boat Home, on the Passaic River yesterday afternoon to witness the nineteenth annual regatta of the club and were treated to a fine exhibition of aquatic skill. The boathouse was tastefully decorated with flags and bunting, and the costumes of the many ladies present added to the beauty of the scene.

The month that begins to-day brings with it the promises of rich Autumnal tints, the splendors of forest foliage, and of gardens radiant with the brilliant tones of chrysanthemums and dahlias, and an atmosphere permeated with tonic for enfeebled lungs. While we may have cause to complain of our belated and transitory Spring, our Autumn generally denotes the perfection of weather.

For those who intend to witness the yacht races, a very pleasant and convenient route will be to take the stanch and commodious iron steamer City of Lawrence which is to leave each day at 9 A.M. from Norwich Line Dock, Pier 40 North River.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 18 -- At the request of Francis H. Weeks the correspondent of The New-York Times called upon him to-day. He was found comfortably provided for in a suite of rooms adjoining the Governor's parlor in the Municipal Palace. During the progress of the interview President Rodniguez was watching from a balcony the weekly drill of his soldiers.

At the first Autumn convening of the Boston Congregational Club on Monday night last, a new departure was taken in inviting women to be present; they have never before been at any regular meeting. And they were not only present, but very much in evidence, as most of the speakers of the evening were women.

Real estate men were of opinion during the past week that things were beginning to look brighter. The money market for loans, while not by any means what it should be, was much better than it had been for two months past. Considerable amounts were to be had at 5 per cent. Two such transactions were for $100,000 and $50,000 respectively.
SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The people of this State who believe in morality and in law and order have rood for reflection in some of the nominations to be made this Fall.

The new play upon which Edward Harrigan has been at work for the last two years has been in rehearsal for some time, and the date of its production at Harrigan's has now been fixed for Monday evening, Oct. 9. It is called "The Woollen Stocking," which is the name of a Pennsylvania coal mine, the stock of which plays an important part in the plot.

HART, Mtch., Sept. 30 -- The Rev. H.D. Webster, who is charged with gross immorality and who has been on trial before a board of Baptist ministers here, has been found guilty and suspended from the ministry.
A bride tells of a difficult moment of her recent wedding trip. A few days of it were spent with an uncle of hers, very deaf and very pious.

So is the tale of the cockroach that crawled from an Oil receptacle into a gas jet, where it took fire, and, falling, spread the flames.

More than ordinary interest attached, in the minds of real estate men, to the auction sale of lots at Van Nest, Westchester, which was held on the grounds by Mr. James L. Wells. The sale was one ordered by the Supreme Court, and was, therefore, absolute, differing in this respect from voluntary offerings.
If there is one thing that hurts the tender feelings of those who meddle with things Indian more than another it is to be reminded that what we represent in India is "the stick."

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 30 -- The Boston editor of Whittier's correspondence has been provided with copies of the poet's letters, which are owned in this city, that will throw an interesting light on the views held by the New-England Quaker sixty years ago. These letters were written to Mrs. L. H. Sigourney, and are now in the possession of the Connecticut State Librarian, Charles J. Hoadley.

The charitable and benevolent organizations of this city have united in a statment deprecating indiscriminate relief to the poor and the unemployed, or those who represent themselves to be such, and asking support for the regularly organized agencies which have the means for inquiring into the merits of all cases and distributing relief with due regard for merit and actual need.

Carre -- quite the most active, ambitious manager among the successful men -- that I need only draw a strong black line of repetition below each flattering word.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 30 -- The field of players who will come together at the intercollegiate tennis championships at New-Haven on Tuesday contains all the Eastern experts, except the Hall brothers, Miller, and Hobart. Every leading university of the country, except possibly Princeton, enters the lists with strong championship hopes. Harvard counts on a sure acquisition of the championship cup.

Baltimore is to celebrate, beginning Wednesday, Oct. 18, the silver jubilee of Cardinal Gibbons's elevation to the Bishopric. The exercises will run over Wednesday and Thursday, and will be marked by pomp and enthusiasm which will make the anniversary a historical one in the annals of the Catholic Church, in this country.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The war is on again, and the Republican factions of this Congressional district are at it, hammer and tongs, all this in the face of the claim made by ex-Peacemaker Jewell that the hatchet had been buried by the Onondaga braves, and that all things were to be lovely.

ORANGE, Sept. 30 -- The East Orange Cyclers celebrated their third birthday two months ago and are in a healthy condition both as regards finances and enthusiasm. At the clubhouse, one of the coziest little places imaginable, the members make their rendezvous in Summer, and in Winter gather before the open fires and recount the past season's adventures.

The indirect election system that prevails in Prussia, with class representation, has always tended in the direction of popular indifference toward the elections.

A special meeting of the New-York Mathematical Society was held yesterday afternoon in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, in honor of the presence in New-York of Prof. Felix Klein of Gottingen University. Prof. Klein is one of the most distinguished mathematicians in the world, and his lectures have attracted more students of mathematics from this country than those of any other professor in Germany.

It is not always, of course, that the ruling of these officials is recognized with a smile; still, it is final, however trying and secretly resented.

The pleasant building belonging to the Pratt Institute, and next door to the Inwood Apartment on Vanderbilt Avenue, has been converted into furnished dormitories and into studios. Although, these are open to any of the pupils, the bunding will likely become a centre for the students from the department of art. The luncheon room opened last Monday, and is offering this year most attractive and nutritious menus, based upon New-England kitchen recipes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Clouds of yellow dust rolling away from the fair grounds in every direction at sunset to-night betokened the close of the eighth annual exhibition of the Society of Agriculture and Horticulture of Westchester County.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The Broome County Democratic Convention was held here this afternoon, and in every respect was harmonious. A faction headed by Charles Davis, J. Stuart Wells, and J. C. Truman, who have been making a fight against George F. O'Neil, candidate for Postmaster, endeavored to defeat him in the primaries, but were not able to do it.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 30 -- There is more in the talk of "Bob" Fitzsimmons about the Corbett and Mitchell fight taking place in New-Orleans, after all, than appears on the surface, although the plan he outlined is preliminary, if not premature.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Although politicians have talked with Roman firmness about continuing the battle of the parties in the country resolutely and at once, and making the whole recess vibrate with their oratory, nothing has come of it.

A lovely woman on a stately four-cornered horse has decorated for more years than her complexion would suggest the curtain of the Irving Place Theatre. She has, meanwhile, seen many "opening nights," not a few of them successful, and many audiences big enough to fill every seat in the house, but it is doubtful if she ever had more reason for cheerfulness than she had last evening.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, Sept. 30 -- P.M. The stock market was strong at the opening to-day and in a few stocks, notably Chicago. Burlington and Quincy and Chicago Gas, there was a speedy advance. Burlington, which opened at 82 5 8, was run up to 83 3 4, and Chicago Gas, which began the day at 57 1 2, touched 58 5 8.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 30 -- The Orange Athletic football team played its first game of the season on the Orange Oval this afternoon with the Stevens Institute eleven, and after a well-contested game of two twenty-minute halves, left the field as victors with the score 12 to 0. The Orange team's make-up is slightly different from last year and outweighed the Hoboken men considerably.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Rochester (N.Y.) division of the naval militia does not receive unqualified praise from the three officers of the San Francisco who constituted a board to inspect the volunteer sailers on board that ship during the Summer cruise. The board was composed of Lieut, Commander Heald and Liouts. Fiske and Hunt, Of the Rochester division the report says:

If any one has doubted that the Eighth Regiment is in a thoroughly demoralized condition he should have been at Creedmoor last Thursday to see the team sent down to compete in the State and brigade matches. The representation, directly under the eye of the Adjutant General, made a laughable and pitiful show as compared with the trained marksmen of the other competing organizations.

A smooth-faced young man on a pneumatic safety, passing ail the fast trotters and pacers on the driveway, may be seen down the Coney Island road to-day. On his face will be a broad, expansive smile, and underneath his tight-fitting riding coat The New-York Times Medal, given yesterday for the novice race at the meet of the Kings County Wheelmen in Eastern Park, will be found.

"What shall we do, Uncle ? " asked Alan as he wandered restlessly around the room. Alan had been left alone with his Uncle for the evening, and the latter was trying to find out wherein lay the greatness of a novel which its publishers had vigorously asserted was great.

William M. Ivins, who has spent the Summer in London in behalf of clients, was asked recently by a reporter for The New-York Times to describe the situation of the London money market as he found it, and its relation to the New-York market under existing circumstances. In reply to a number of questions Mr. Ivins said:

The Valkyrie was out again yesterday sailing on the bay, and made by far the best showing since she has been in these waters. This was not so much in the way of speed as in the set of her sails and the beautiful way she was handled. Capt. Cranfield tried her on every point of the wind, and in every way the yacht traveled very fast.

The week closed at all the down-town Ex-changes yesterday with better reeling than has prevailed since business was running along sinoothly six months or more ago. Not only among those who deal in stocks, but among dealers in grain and other staples, there is evidence of strong faith that the obnoxious clause of the silver law will shortly be repealed, and that business conditions will there upon be restored to a normal basis.

Our Vienna correspondent tells us or the life of the Crown Prince Rudolf's little daughter, Archduchess Elizabeth, who is just ten years old. She finished her holidays with a small tour through the Alps, and is now busy at her lessons again. She is staying at Laxenburg, where for her leisure hours she has a pretty garden all her own, and a little cottage, the key of which she carries in her pocket.

-- The Misses Elizabeth, Agnes, and Gretta Kelly have recently returned from an extended trip to Europe. During their absence they visited the principal points of interest in England and the Continent. Their friends, the Misses M. and Jose Leckle of Pollockshields, Glasgow, Scotland, came back with them, and will remain in this country during the Winter as their guests.

From The Philadelphia Times. "Talk of snakes," said the drummer from Boston, as the crowd received the cheerful information that the train was an hour late, and settled down to pass the time as best it might, "I spent a night once surrounded by not dozens of them, but hundreds. Real snakes, too; none of those produced by good spirits, either.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: You will please publish my letter giving a true statement of the suffering of the people here since the cyclone of Aug. 27, which swept away houses, drowned thirty-four negroes, and destroyed the corn, cotton, pea, and sweet potato crops almost in toto. for the ocean tossed its waves over the whole island except the very high spots.

Many wise minds have been pondering lately about the causes that have led to the present predominance on the theatrical stage of farce and "variety." I think there is one cause, and a very potent one, too, that has been generally overlooked, and we have had striking manifestations of that quite recently.

The only member of the Board of Coroners at the office yesterday was its President, Coroner Louis W. Schultze. He did not seem to be much disturbed by the presentment of the Grand Jury in relation to the delays and irregularities in the method of doing business in the office.

Mrs. Mackay's parties in London are said to be choice as any in Mayfair. Speaking of a recent one to meet the Duke of Edinburgh "after dinner," a London paper calls it a "very select function, indeed. Mr. Bayard, the new American Minister, who was present, is a brilliant conversationist, and seems to like his location over here sufficiently well.

On a recent warm Sunday night a cable car started up from the Battery loop with the usual Sunday load of tired parents, cross, sleepy children, and young persons whose good time was sure to last so long as they were together.

The legal mills, which have been attempting for a month to sift a little wheat from the chaff of the sadly-entangled affairs of the Commercial Bank, shook the hopper again yesterday, but the machinery was clogged, and those depositors who were anxious for the appointment of an associate receiver were disappointed.
The death in London is announced of Albert Moore, the celebrated English artist, whose opposition to the academy was such a noticeable feature of his career.

Horace McVlcker has returned to his old love, says The Chicago Tribune. He has quit peach farming in Southwest Missouri, and is now back in the theatrical business. Horace tells to his most intimate friends a wild, weird reason for leaving Horticultural pursuits. Here is what he says:

BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- Three plays new to Boston have been given here this week. One was at the Columbia Theatre -- "Glenda-Lough," in which J.K. Murray and Clara Lane have the leading parts and do well. The piece is very handsomely staged. It has drawn large audiences and will run a fortnight more.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- But a small amount of business was transacted on 'Change today, but Americans advanced rapidly, and other markets were firm in sympathy. Cables from New-York reporting the fall of sterling exchange, the improved chances of an early passage of the repeal bill by the Senate, and the favorable figures of Illinois Central's annual report started a rise which was assisted more by the cessation of sales than by buying orders.

About seven weeks hence a strange and moving spectacle will be witnessed in this town. It will be strange, although it is seen every year, and it will be moving because that is its nature. This spectacle will consist of a struggle. The strugglers will be twenty-two miserable human wrecks.

In submitting to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment his estimate of the requirements of the Street-Cleaning Department for next year, Commissioner ANDREWS asks for the gross sum of $3,138,931.21, of which something over $415,000 is for permanent investment in new "stock and plant," leaving the cost of street cleaning for the year about $2,723,000.

It was in his twenty-fifth year that Raphael came to the city of the Popes, Michelangelo being already in high favor there. For the remaining years of his life he paces the same streets with that grim artist, who was so great a contrast with himself, and for the first time his attitude toward a gift different from his own is not that of a scholar, but that of a rival.
DEDHAM, Mass., Sept 80 -- The Merchants' Woolen Mill at East Dedham, which has been idle for the past three months, will run three days a week, beginning Oct. 9. on a 10 per cent, reduction of wages.
Mayor Boody is deeply wounded by the many adverse criticisms made by citizens on his management of Brooklyn's finances. To a reporter for The New-York Times he said a few days ago:

"I have myself witnessed the deliberate suicide of a rattlesnake," says Prof. Holden of Lick University, in a magazine article recently, " and think that a brief account of it may be worth recording. In the Summer of 1888 Prof. Keeler saw a large rattlesnake (with seven rattles) crawl under the foundation of the dome of the six-inch equatorial.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 30 -- It is estimated that not less than 3,00 women have registered in this State to vote for school officers at the annual town elections on Monday. Ninety per cent, of this number belong to the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and Equal Rights Club.

Oscar Blodgett was an opulent builder of Aberdeen. His fortune had expanded, the more he had contracted, and by his works he was known and approved. When in his old age he retired from business people said that he was going to enjoy his money, and he thought so untill he found how miserable he had straightway become.

-- It is not now as easy to get married in Utah as it used to be once upon a time. At least a young man who applied for a marriage license out there the other day was refused the much-desired document after he had admitted that he was only eighteen years old and had neither parents nor a legal guardian to indorse and approve his application.

We give on another page of THE TIMES a chart showing the course of the reserves of the Associated Banks in this city for periods covering the four financial disturbances of the past twenty years. We think that any one who will even glance at it must be struck by the remarkable parallelism of the lines representing the reserve in all cases after the extreme limit of depression had been passed.

Mr. Ford's second volume of the Putnam edition of Jefferson carries the writings practically through the Revolution. It thus includes the Declaration of Independence as its most important document. Aside from this item, the volume is not strikingly interesting, and perhaps the deepest impression made by it is one of that lack of continental distinction which was so marked in the career of Jefferson during the war.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- The unveiling of the King Fountain, recently, adds another work of art to the many fine adornments which Albany possesses. The other most prominent works are Scultpor Erastus D. Palmer's famous marble "Angel at the Sepulchre," in the Rural Cemetery, and Sculptor Charles Calverley's bronze statue of "Robert Burns " in Washington Park.

The "rifle-trenching tool" of M. de Layen, which was recently tried at the Armory House Parade Ground, Finsbury, and is expected" in one sense to revolutionize the warfare of the future," consists essentially of an arrangement by which a spade or such like tool can be fixed to the butt of a rifle without preventing the weapon from being ready for use either with shot or bayonet.

Translation of the Roman poets is for the most part a congenial task to a contemporaneous man of letters. In addition to the fact that classical education brings us moderns into close sympathy with Latin ideas and expression, it is also undeniably true that the great majority of our poets are like theirs, men of the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- That the air is fall of talk about compromise does not argue that a compromise is in sight, or, indeed, is likely to be adopted. The silver men would consider themselves culpably negligent if they failed to keep a number of compromise stories constantly on the move.
Lieut. William Henn of England spent the day yesterday at Larchmont. Before leaving the Victoria Hotel in the morning he was seen by a reporter for The New-York Times.
The national team championship at inanimate targets will be contested at Watson's Park, Chicago, on Saturday, Oct. 7, the last day of the World's Fair tournament at Burnside.

Preparations are being made for the early departure of the two United States revenue cutters Grant and Perry for the waters of Puget Sound. The Grant is stationed at this port with a cruising ground which extends from Montauk Point to the Delaware Breakwater. The Perry is stationed on Lake Erie.

The fashionable Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Bartholomew, at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, which is the worshipping place of many of the wealthiest families in the city, has been newly and beautifully decorated and several of its appointments have been put into better arrangement.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 30 -- The cottagers have had a large number of entertainments this week, but those that have taken place have not been so fully attended as they would have been had it not been for the death of John E. Burrill. Mr. Burrill's death was unexpected, and there were many invitations out for dinner parties which it was practically impossible to recall, and, therefore, the entertainments took place.

For over a year past there has been a great lack of accommodation for school children in the upper east side. Little has been done to relieve that pressure, yet with in the next few weeks a large and commodious school building will be completed at the corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, which will throw open its doors and take in over 2,000 of the children who now have no school accommodations.

Should the District Attorney and Sheriff of Kings County fail before election to make impossible the great Coney Island prize fight announced for December, or to punish those responsible for the seventeen prize fights that have taken place there since Jan. 1, the chances of a damaging and possibly fatal blow to the machine in Brooklyn would be considerably greater.

The present work comes from across the Atlantic and no author's name is given. In the preface the writer, lamenting "the pressure of a systematized theology" and the "dogmatic teaching" of the present day among all Christian Churches, avows his determination to be in no wise influenced by "dogmatic interpretations" or "hostile criticisms."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct 1. -- This evening, for the first time in the history of West Point, there was a regimental parade. The distinguishing feature of the parade from others was that the corps of cadets formed in two battalions of four companies each, and the officers, seven in number, were mounted. The commanding officer was Col. Mills. The Majors of the First and Second Battalions were Lieuts, Richardson and Dunning.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 1. -- The crumbling condition of the Western Associated Press is constantly becoming more and more apparent. Last Friday Washington Hesing resigned his position as a Director in the organization, and he has since withdrawn his newspaper, The Illinois Staats-Zeitung, from the Associated Press and put it into the United Press.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 1. -- Citizens of Norwalk take exception to the statement recently published that Horace T. Cook, who was renominated for County Treasurer for the sixteenth consecutive term, after having served forty-five years, had had "the longest tenure of office in the history of the United States."

It was a very striking picture of British opinion with regard to American credit that Mr. WILLIAM M. IVNS gave in THE TIMES yesterday morning. British opinion of the operation of the Sherman law is the same, plainly, as intelligent American opinion, and is imporant chiefly because it controls the investment of large amounts of money of which we have need.

Copyrighted, 1893, by the United Press. BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- Emperor William's deer-stalking expedition in Sweden has been his only genuine holiday for many weeks. From his arrival at Gothenburg, on Thursday, until he boarded the Hohenzollern again at Karlskrona, on Saturday, no official dispatches were sent or received by him.

To-day the Artist-Artisan Institute on West Twenty-third Street begins its sixth, year of usefulness under the powerful impulse of Mr. John Ward Stimson, aided by a corpse of instructors who will catch from him, If they need inoculation, that fiery enthusiasm for nationality in art which is the mainspring of the school.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Instruction in bayonet exercise, fencing, and military gymnastics will begin Monday for the fourth class, under Swordmaster Koehler's supervision, in the new gymnasium. The "plebe" will also receive his first lessons in bareback riding. The horses employed are wooden ones, but the boys get some bad falls occasionally from miscalculating the Jumping distance.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The Citizens' League movement is showing signs of activity in Camden, Union, Essex, Hudson, Passaic, and Monmouth Counties. These are notably race-track counties. The officers of the State League indicated the cause at issue in the manifesto they published, but the county organizations have enlarged on its scope.

Justice Richard V.B. Newton, official prize-fight contractor of Coney Island, has received a polite and pointed letter from the Rev. Dr. Wellesley W. Bowdish, pastor of the Embury Methodist Episcopal Church, Herkimer Street and Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn. The letter was mailed Sept. 27, but the learned judge of fistic prowess has not as yet found time to answer it.

Christopher Cannon, who some years ago was an Inspector of Distilleries for the Dublin (Ireland) Excise Department, was arrested on Park Row Saturday night for drunkenness and disorderly conduct. Yesterday Justice Meade, in the Tombs Police Court, sent him to the Island for-six months.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 1. -- Minister Lewis Baker, who has been actively concerned in arranging the preliminary steps looking to the extradition of Francis Henry Weeks, was granted an audience late yesterday afternoon with the Minister of War. Mr. Baker was closeted with the Costa Rican official for over two hours.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The appointment of George O. Vanderbilt to be the Postmaster of Princeton has created a genuine surprise in Democratic circles of New-Jersey. He came into the Post Office fight late, and being a member of Princeton alumni, he was supported by many of the Faculty. His appointment brings him again actively into New-Jersey politics.
The Hamburg-American Line steamer Augusta Victoria arrived in New-York yesterday. She reached her dock at Hoboken at 6 P.M. She brought over 267 cabin and 84 steerage passengers.

-- A young and eligible man journeyed from Springfield, Ohio, to Gov. Flower's native village of Theresa, in Jefferson County, this State, a little while ago, under engagement to marry two days later a young woman upon whom he had lavished the wealth of his affections and many costly presents. Upon arriving, however, he was informed by her that she had learned to love another, and she declared the engagement off.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church at Bergen and McAdoo Avenues celebrated its silver jubilee to-day with appropriate services. At the same time the Rev. Gustave Burkhardt, the pastor, celebrated the twentieth anniversary of his pastorate. The Rev. Philip Krug of Newark, by whom he was installed, conducted the services.
"Brooklyn's Municipal Affairs" was the subject discussed last evening by the Rev. William T. Beale, pastor of the Pennsylvania Avenue Congregational Church, East New-York.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 1. -- The original Thirteen Club of Brooklyn held its thirteenth annual outing at Witzel's Point View Island to-day. It came on the steamer Victor. The breakfast consisted of thirteen courses, and there were thirteen members at each table. They had a schedule of thirteen athletic events, after which they had their dinner and started for home.

The committee appointed by Mayor GILROY to make arrangements for Manhattan Day at the World's Fair and to prepare a programme of ceremonies meets at the City Hall at noon to-day. The Mayor has already received assurances of co-operation from a large number of the gentlemen appointed. The suggestion of a special day for New-York City at the fair has awakened an unexpected interest.

For the last time the congregation of the Scotch Presbyterian Church assembled yesterday morning in the old edifice in Four-teenth Street, near Sixth Avenue. Last evening services were held for the first time in the Sunday School Hall, the only completed part of the new building, which win occupy the entire block on Central Park West, between Ninety-fifth and Ninety-sixth Streets.

The Albion Tennis Club concluded its Fall handicap tournament Saturday on its grounds. President Street, near Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn. Beebe (owe tuirty) defeated J.G. Rollins (owe half fifteen) for final honors. 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 13 -- 11. Beobo is an addition to the Altiora Club, while Rollins is an oldtimer. The new comer was heavily handicapped, but his careu, steady game brought him out ahead.
The divorced wife of Edward Parker Deacon, who now signs herself "Mrs. F. Baldwin, Paris," arrived in New-York yesterday morning on the French liner La Bretagne.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 30. -- Local banks made some further gains in deposits this week and collateral loans were made more readily than for many weeks, but there is still a good deal of room for improvement on this score. In stocks there are few changes aside from recoveries from small breaks scored about the middle of the week.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The Treasurer announces that over 460 students are now enrolled at Vassar College, and more are expected. Regular class work is now begun.

The J.B. Lippincott Company has in preparation an entirely new edition, from new type, of Thiers's "Consulate and Empire," translated from the French by D. Forbes Campbell. It will comprise twelve octavo volumes, and will contain thirty-six steel plates. A limited edition only will be issued, and the first volume is now ready.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1. -- The oyster season opens with excellent prospects for a good yield and a probability of the highest prices oysters have ever known in this country. The severity of the weather last Winter kept the oystermen from the grounds in the Chesapeake for more than a month, and, as a result, this year's crop will be largely increased.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- The football season was inaugurated at Harvard yesterday afternoon, and Harvard won from Dartmouth by a score of 10 to 0. In the first half of the game the ball was in Harvard's territory three-quarters of the time, and only by a piece of luck did Harvard escape having a touch-down scored against her in the first game of the season.
The Rev. Benjamin Jowett, Master of Balliol College since 1870, Vice Chancellor of Oxford University, died yesterday. There were sixty years of life at Balliol represented in his personality.

With impressive ceremonies the forty-first anniversary services were held in St. Ann's Church, in West Eighteenth Street, yesterday morning. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Edward H. Krans, preached, his sermon being on "What Shall We Do with Our Down-Town Churches?"

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $6,510,350. The banks now bold $24,120,500 more than the legal requirements. The chances in the averages show an increase in loans of $348,800, an increase in specie of $2,123,800, an increase in legal tenders of $6,145,000, an increase in deposits of $7,033,400, and an increase in circulation of $785,300.
The Rev. J. Russell Taber, pastor of the Church of Good Tidings at Quincy Street and Stuyvesant Avenue, preached last night on "Physical Culture and Physical Abuse."

Palatial Stables at Newport. -- The most costly stables in America, and, with few exceptions, in the world, are situated at Newport. Oliver Hazzard Perry Belmont has just finished on the short street known as Lakeview Avenue, near Bellevue Avenue, a house for his horses and carriages which, in its completed state, has made short work of $100,000.

Readers of The New-York Times were afforded the exclusive information yesterday that Detectives Reilly and Von Gerichten, sent to Costa Rica to bring Francis H. Weeks back to this city, had reached their destination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The Montgomery will be the next trip to be taken on a trial trip. The board will report at New-London in Tuesday and the cruiser will proceed to Long island Sound under her own steam. After the Montgomery the vessel to be tried will be the Marblehead, built at South Boston, and now at New-York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Photography will hereafter play an interesting part in the reproduction of plans in the Naval Bureau of Steam. Engineering. Chief Engineer Harrie Webster has suggested that the tracings made from original drawings hereafter be photographed on a small scale, and that from these blue prints be made on sensitized linen.

GENOA, Oct. 1. -- The steamship Remo, which sailed from this port for Rio de Janeiro and Santos, Brazil, on Aug. 15, with 1,433 emigrants, has arrived at Santa Cruz de Teneriffe, in the Canaries, on her return voyage. Cholera broke out aboard her during the outward voyage, and the health officers at the Brazilian ports refused to let her passengers be landed.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 1. -- The Amateur Athletic Association championship games took place on the Rosedale grounds yesterday in the presence of 2,000 people. The weather was fine, but very chilly. Following is summary: ...

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Weeks left their home together and embarked on the steamer Panama of the Compania Transatlantica under the name of Watson. As already told in The New-York Times, they had some difficulty with their trunks, which arrived only at the last moment.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Yale tradition makes a gala day of the first Saturday after the annual opening of college, and this year proved no exception to the rule. Football, baseball, and rowing candidates were marshaled by their Captains and spent the afternoon in hard practice. Football occupies the lion's share of attention now.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- Less than the usual amount of stir characterized the opening of Yale this year. Notwithstanding the fact that the largest class ever making its entrance was being ushered upon the campus, the work of opening was taken up quietly and without friction. Only five of the eight departments of the university have, however, as yet resumed work.

The Rev. Robert Collyer, pastor of the Church of the Messiah, Thirty-fourth Street and Part Avenue, preached an anniversary sermon to his congregation yesterday. On Sept. 24 the venerable rector completed fourteen years of service with the church, but the celebration of the anniversary was postponed one week because he had been detained by illness in Chicago.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 1. -- Two hundred citizens of Austin nave petitioned Gov. Hogg touching on the bankrupt condition at the Texas Treasury. They request him to accept the sugar bounty which has accumulated at Washington to Texas's credit, and which he emphatically refused last Spring, and demand that the three Railroad Commissioners he refused their salaries, come what will.

The Manhattan Tennis Association of this city held a tournament Saturday afternoon on the Hamilton Club grounds, Hamilton Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-third Street. The object of the meeting was to select players to represent the association in the coming contests with the Interclub League of Kings County. The clubs in the Manhattan Association are the Lenox, New-York, Ariel, Fifth Avenue, and Hamilton.

The forty-fifth anniversary of the Church of the Transfiguration, better known as "The Little Church Around the Corner," in Twenty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue, was appropriately celebrated yesterday. The day also closed forty-five years of indefatigable labor in the parish for the Rev. Dr. George Houghton, the venerable rector.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Secretary Herbert has issued an order mentioning the names of Capt. L.A. Beardslee and other officers and men stationed at the Port Royal (S.C.) naval station for devotion to duty during the storm of Aug. 27 and 28. The Secretary says in this order:
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Edwin Bailey, chief of the Patchogue Fire Department, and Robert A. Bartlett, boniface and horse fancier, had a fight last night in the barroom of the Bartlett House.

The foreign exchange market was very strong early in the week, but eased off at the close. Posted rates for sterling on Saturday were $4.85 @$4.86 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 @$4.88 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.83 3/4 @$4.84 1/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 @ $4.86 1/4 for demand, $4.87 for cable transfers, and $4.83 1/2 for commercial.

NEW BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 1. -- The Richmond County Hunt hold its first meet of the season yesterday, and had a brisk ran of five miles along the trail of the aniseseed bag. The meet was fixed to take place at the junction of the Richmond and Fingerboard Boads, but the hunters assembled at the kennels, and followed the pack to the point where the hounds were cast off.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Another perplexing case is bothering Secretary Herbert. It is that of an engineer officer, and like the Johnson case in the fine and the Stevenson case in the Pay Corps, it may block promotion.

The Rev. Albert F. Newton of the Rochester Avenue Congregational Church came out in a vigorous protest during the morning services against the proposed international prize fight. In a strong prelude to his regular sermon he said:

When the city was reapportioned last year, the lower portion of the old Seventeenth District was turned into the new Seventeenth, and the upper portion, with part of the old Nineteenth, was turned into the new Eighteenth District. The adherents of ex-Police Justice Murray had always been strong in the lower part of the old Seventeenth, and the adherents of Senator George W. Plunkitt had always been powerful in the upper part.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 1. -- Gov. Tillman some time ago appointed State Treasurer W.T.C. Bates delegate to the St. Louis Bimetallic Convention, and it was thought that Mr. Bates, like other Alliance reformers in South Carolina, favored free coinage of silver.

Fifty members of the Veteran Firemen's Association of California, who are making the tour of the Eastern States, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon from Philadelphia. They wore the handsome uniform of the association, and were accompanied by their President, ex-Senator J.H. Mahoney, and the officers of the organization.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct 1. -- A letter from Justin McCarthy has been received by Thomas J. Gargan, Chairman, and Daniel P. Sullivan, Secretary of the Massachusetts State Committee of the Irish National Federation, in response to the congratulatory letter recently forwarded to the Chairman of the Irish Parliamentary Party. Mr. McCarthy writes as follows:

Senator MORGAN has fallen into grave errors and misconceptions, which it is our duty to correct. In the course of his speech on Friday he denounced the news-papers of New-York City as a "licentious and hireling press, scarcely able to string together enough viperous epithets to signify their contempt of Senators.

The Rev. J.F. Carson, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Tompkins and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, made in his sermon last night a scathing denunciation of those officials who have personally concerned themselves in arranging for the proposed international prize fight.
BUFFALO, Oct. 1. -- Little interest was shown in the Erie County Republican Assembly Convention Saturday. These delegates were chosen to the State Convention:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The October term of the Supreme Court of the United States will begin a week from to-morrow. The court will open the term with a docket that in itself demonstrates the advantages of the new Court of Appeals. While the docket for the October term in 1892 at the opening contained 1,183 cases, there are but 1,025 awaiting.

MEDINA, Oct. 1. -- In the Orleans County Democratic Convention Saturday and the primaries the day before there were close fights between the machine and anti-machine factions. In the primaries the majorities ran from only one to five. The machine controlled the convention, having a vote of 37 to the opposition's 21.

According to one of "Boss" McLaughlin's most trusted lieutenants, Mayor Boody is to be complimented by a renomination. This gentleman is authority for the statement that nothing stands in the way of Mr. Boody's triumph, except perhaps Mr. Boody's declination of the honor. This trusted lieutenant of the "boss" said to a somewhat skeptical friend yesterday:

The Rev. Dr. E. Horner Wellman, rector of the Church of the Atonement, Seventeenth Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, took his text from First Corinthians, xv., 30: "If after the manner of men I have fought with beasts at Ephesus, what advantageth me ?"

The widespread movement in the army for the repeal of the new statute forbidding the re-enlistment of any private soldier who has served ten years makes it almost certain that this obnoxious law will soon be stricken from the books. The petitions for its removal now contain about 8,000 names of officers and men.

The Times a few days ago took occasion to explain what the Reading voting trust, under the Welsh plan, really meant. It likened it to the case of a merchant being asked to place his business in the hands of a clerk for seven years, without any right on his part to interfere with it in any way during the period.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The first pruning in the ranks of football aspirants for places on the University of Pennsylvania eleven was made upon the return of the squad from Cape May last "Wednesday. Twenty-five men have been put at the training table, and that number will probably continue until the end of the season. The coaches are considerably worried over the filling of John Adams's place at centre.

Superintendent Brady of the Building Department last week approved plans for the construction of twenty-three new buildings, the cost of which is estimated at $68,000. Plans for alterations to thirty various structures, at a cost of $39,000, were also filed.

Railroad men in the East and in the West continue to talk hopefully of the prospects of a good Fall and Winter business. All that they fear is the effect of a further delay in the Senate to act on the silver question.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during September of $834,793.78. The interest bearing debt increased $150, the non-interest-bearing debt increased $487,136.50, and the cash in the Treasury decreased $408,277.28.
With a round of cheers which sounded like the loud echoes of the Seth Low campaign, the Committee of One Hundred came permanently into existence last night at the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn.

From The Philadelphia Times, Sept. 29. Those papers that have created a purely fictitious scandal out of the nomination of Mr. Van Alen as Ambassador to Italy are unwilling to abandon the fight they are making against him notwithstanding what the grounds upon which it is ostensibly based have been shown to be entirely of their own creation.

Congressman James J. Belden of Syracuse was a guest at the Windsor Hotel yesterday. He would not discuss his recent victory over ex-Senator Hiscock. He claimed that the flght in his district was only of local importance.

CINCINNATI, Ohio. Oct. 2. -- Following the announcement in last night's dispatches of the withdrawal from the Associated Press, to become full members of the United Press, of The Illinois Staats-Zeitung, the leading German newspaper of the West, and The Memphis Seimitar, comes the news that The Minneapolis Times, the most enterprising and successful daily of that city, has taken the same action.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Argentines were strong to-day. Other foreign bonds were firm. English rails were steady, Americans very weak. The markets were dull in all departments.

Frank Ellison, who was charged with having on the night of June 5 assaulted Broker W.H. Henriques in Thirty-ninth Street, near Park Avenue, was at midnight found guilty of assault in the second degree, second offense. He had been tried on two counts -- for assault in the first degree and for assault in the second degree, second offense.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- There has been a quiet demand for Reading securities to-day on the belief that the meetings now going on between Reading bondholders' committees and the receivers were likely to bring about an improvement to the company's affairs. The Reading improvement mortgage coupons were paid to-day, although when last April's coupons matured on these bonds they were bought by Drexel Co., and were not paid by the company.

MALONE, Oct. 2. -- The Franklin County Democratic Convention here resulted in a riot and two separate and distinct conventions. The fight was bet-ween the Administration and the machine men. The former had a clear majority, but the latter were in possession of the Chairman and Secretary of the County Committee, and with "paper" delegates made up a roll favorable to the machine.

Lord Dunraven, who paid a visit to Boston on Saturday, arrived at the Waldorf yesterday afternoon, and in the evening was entertained at dinner at Delmonico's by ex-Commodore James D. Smith. The dinner was served in the banquet rooms, Nos. 3 and 4, on the Twenty-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue corner of the building.

And Other Stories. By Frank H. Stockton, 12me, cloth, $1.26. In this new volume there are six of the author's inimitable tales in addition to the tills story "Aaaph." "My Terminal Moraine." "The Philosophy of Relative Existences." "The Knife that Killed Po Hancy." "The Christmas Shadraoh," and "The Rev. Ezekiel Crump."

To the admirer of the artistic in furniture there is no better place to make a selection than the large establishment of the Geo. C. Flint Company, 104 to 108 West Fourteenth Street. A visitor might spend hours there and find plenty to approve and admire. The stock is complete, and in design, finish, and general beauty it cannot be excelled. All live floors are filled with gems of the furniture maker's art.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The amount of business trade sacted in wheat to-day was only moderate, the range of prices lower, but the feeling on the whole was rather steady. The opening was about 18@14 lower declined 14c more, then recovered, prices advancing 12c, declined 12c for December, and only 14c for May, advanced some, held steadier, and the closing for December was unchanged from Saturday, while May was 14c higher.
In the case of the popular revolt against the impending international prize fight in Brooklyn one important feature is to be noted, for which no precedent has ever occurred.

The Autumn meeting of the New-York Presbytery was held yesterday la the Sooteh Presbyterian Church, in Fourteenth Street This is the last meeting to be held in this old building. It was called to order at 10:30 o'clock by Moderator William R. Harshaw and opened with prayer.

The Fall shopping days have come, and Simpson, Crawford Simpson's opening yesterday at their mammoth establishment, 307 Sixth Avenue, proved a potent magnet to fashionable shoppers in search of the latest and best in the season's novelties. The display is a surpassingly fine one, and no better idea can be obtained of what is the best and most correct thing to wear than by inspecting their large and varied line of goods.

KISSINGEN, Oct. 2. -- As is usual in the case of aged convalescents. It is hard to determine from one day to another what Prince Bismarck's condition will be. It Is certain that his last illness has left permanent marks upon him, and it is doubtful if he will ever recover his usual health and strength.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Postmaster General Bissell has been engaged for some time in an effort to save the Government from the extravagance of that "model" business man and Postmaster General, Mr. John Wanamaker.

Sir CHARLES DILKE contributes to the current number of the North American Review an interesting article upon the question, "Can Europe Afford Her Armies?" Sir CHARLES'S knowledge of Continental politics in general, and of the political aspects of Continental armies in particular, is beyond that of any other unofficial Englishman.

The first meeting of the Fall season of Sorosis was held at Sherry's yesterday. Mrs. Jennie de la M. Lozier, President of the society, was in the chair. About eighty-five members were present. No business was transacted.

Mrs. Cyrus W. Field, Jr., is at present the busiest woman in this city. To-morrow Mrs. Field, in partnership with W.H. Curtis of 210 Fifth Avenue, will make her formal debut before the shopping public as a dealer in fashionable millinery. For a week past Mrs. Field has been working courageously in getting out the announcement cards of the opening, while Mr. Curtis has been superintending the enlargement of the store.

The nomination of candidates for delegates to the Constitutional Convention ought in every case to be determined for the fitness of the person selected for the work to be done, and with the least possible reference to partisanship. There is no proper place for party politics in the revision of the organic law of the State.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 2. -- A southeast gale broke here this morning about 4 o'clock, and the wind has been increasing in velocity ever since. The wind has blown the water in from the Gulf until the river has reached Royal Street, which is four blocks from the river and at an elevation of about fifteen feet from mean river height.

Wheat declined 33@ 12c on increased supplies, easier cables, and full contract deliveries, but rallied 18@14 c on the small India shipments and a decrease on passage, with the close firm at partly 14 c loss for the day.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- Mr. Sheehan held his caucuses to-night for his Assembly and other conventions, and, with a few exceptions, had things all his own way. The conventions will be held with practically no Cleveland men in them, and every man whom the boss has slated for nomination will be nominated.

Mrs. Edward Parker Deacon, who was a conspicuous figure in a tragedy of international interest at Cannes, France, in February, 1892, when her husband shot Emile Abeille dead in her apartments, declined to see reporters yesterday or to disclose the purpose of her return to the United States.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, Oct. 2 -- P.M. The activity developed last week on the stock market failed to be repeated, and from the opening to the close business on the Exchange was dull. Two or three specialties exhibited some strength, but generally prices were lower. The close was very dull and heavy. Trading was entirely professional.

OAKDALE, L.I., Oct. 2. -- Three masked burglars made a bold attempt to rob the club house of the South Side Sportsman's Club here at 3 o'clock, yesterday morning. The vigilance of the watchman, William Maxwell, defeated their plans. The watchman heard a noise in the billiard room on the main floor.
A murder was committed yesterday afternoon in Yorkville, the motive of which, although as yet not clearly defined, seems to have been the old one of jealousy.
The Vigilant was launched from Hawkins's yard at City Island yesterday morning, and the Valkyrie was put in Handren Robbins's dry dock in the Brie Basin yesterday afternoon.

The Times has purposely abstained from comments on the several conferences held in Philadelphia, during the past ten days between the Reading receivers and certain interests represented by gentlemen who, until this occasion, have not appeared as prominent characters in the Reading comedy -- or tragedy, as it has proved to many people.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 2. -- The Republicans of the Second Assembly District of Westchester County held their District Convention here to-day and elected as delegates to the State Convention Dr. E.F. Brush, D. O. Williams, John H. Clapp, F.W. Sherman, and William Archer. The delegates to the Senatorial Convention are: James Hopkins, William L. Ward, E.B. Long, Thomas R. Hodge, and J.B. See.

Nearly 1,800 students had their names inscribed on the roll of Columbia College when that venerable seat of learning yesterday began its one hundred and fortieth class year. The chapel was not spacious enough to give them standing room when President Seth Low delivered his address.

Charles W. Watson, F.O. Mason, and George McAveny. Jr., in behalf of the Committee on Civil Service Examinations of the State Civil Service Reform Association, have written a letter to Gov. Flower in regard to certain alleged violations of the States civil service law.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 2. -- Ex-Gov. Warmoth brought news to-night of the storm's work on the lower coast. It was the worst experience Louisiana has had since 1811. The wind blew 120 miles an hour, devastating the fields, blowing the fruit off the orange trees, damaging the sugar houses, and demolishing a number of homes.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 2. -- The United States Stamped Envelope Works in this city, which have been running seven hours a day daring the past two months, resumed the ten-hour schedule to-day, and will hereafter run on full time, averaging a product of 1,000.000 envelopes a day.

The Tammany Committee of Thirty, or Executive Committee, met yesterday afternoon in the Wigwam and made the final arrangements for the trip to the Democratic State Convention, to be held in Saratoga Thursday. Tammany's delegation, including the 90 delegates and 90 alternates and interested spectators, will number 480.
Money on call loaned at 2@4 cent. The last loans were made at 3 cent.

Frank C. Ives of Chicago, the smooth-faced billiard champion of the world, and John Roberts, the English expert, began a tournament in the Lenox Lyceum, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, last night; for $500 aside. They will play every afternoon and evening this week until one of the players has scored 10,000 points.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- Bishop Ryan of the Buffalo Roman Catholic diocese will, on Nov. 8, celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of his episcopate. Cardinal Gibbons and Papal Legate Satolli will be present at the ceremonies, and the latter will celebrate pontifical high mass on the occasion.

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn met last evening and heard the report of its committee, appointed Jan. 23 to investigate the abuses in the government of Brooklyn and Kings County, and to confer with other bodies of citizens as to the means for a remedy for these abuses.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- Some one has been talking with Elliot T. Ransom of Ransom- ville. He has changed his mind again, and has announced that he will accept the nomination for the Assembly given him at Lockport last week. First he said he would, accept. Then he said he would not. Then he said he would.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- The forthcoming Democratic State Convention at Saratoga will be notable for its large number of contests. Twelve contesting delegations are already elected, and several more are likely to be chosen. In some instances the anti-machine or Administration men controlled the County Convention, as in Albany, Chautauqua, Essex, Orange, Schenectady, and Yates, and the machine, or so-called Hill forces, bolted and elected their own delegates.

One of the most noted of real estate exchanges was completed yesterday by Mr. William E. Booth, the broker. The contracting parties were Mr. John Pettit, who is well known as the owner of the Bennett Building and other property near by, including a twelve-story building now in course of erection on Fulton Street, and Mr. Henry J. Newton.

COWES, Oct. 2. -- The American yacht Navahoe, with its owner, Mr. Royal Phelps Carroll, and his wife on board, sailed from this port to-day on her return to the United States. The yacht took her departure at 4:80 o'clock this afternoon. It is not Mr. Carroll's intention to proceed directly to New-York. The Navahoe will first go to Madeira and will afterward make a cruise in the West Indies.

The formal opening of C.C. Shayne's new establishment, 124 and 126 West Forty-second Street, will take place to-day. The handsome new building, which is to be the home of the largest and best wholesale and retail fur house in the country, is conveniently located just west of Sixth Avenue. The building is four stories high, and has a frontage of 50 feet and a depth of 100 feet.

The big committee appointed by Mayor Gilroy to arrange for Manhattan Day at the World's Fair, Oct. 21, met in the Governor's Room in the City Hall yesterday. It promised well for the success of the celebration, as no more representative meeting has been held in the City Hall in several years.

BATH, Oct. 2. -- There was a split in the Democratic Convention for the Second Assembly District of Steuben County, which convened in Baldwin Hall, Addison, at 1 o'clock to-day. All of the towns were represented, and sixty-four delegates responded to the roll call. The Hill faction was led by State Committeeman J.B. Day and Charles A. Dolson, and the other by G.N. Orcutt and D.E. Morville Page.
