PORTCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- William P. Abendroth, the stove manufacturer, and his wife celebrated their golden wedding here to-night. Their handsome house, on Echo Hill, was brilliantly decorated for the occasion with Autumnal leaves, golden rod, and yellow flowers of many varieties.

Rounding the picturesque curves of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad between the stations at One Hundred and Fourth and One Hundred and Sixteenth Streets, the belated west side up-town passenger cannot fail to notice the brilliant band of electric lights which crowns an entire block on the east of the Lenox Avenue Boulevard, three blocks north of Central Park.

Dr. Thomas L. Richards, the young physician who contracted smallpox at the Vanderbilt Clinic, died at 11:30 o'clock Sunday night, in the Riverside Hospital, on North Brother Island. Dr. Richards was only twenty-nine years old. He lived at 820 West Eleventh Street.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Vice Chancellor Bird rendered a decision to-day which, if applied, would empty the lunatic asylums in the State. It may give the managers of the asylums trouble.

QUEBEC, Oct. 3. -- Lord and Lady Aberdeen met the steamship Parisian on her arrival from Liverpool, and welcomed the hundreds of European immigrants who arrived by her, carefully inspecting all quarantine and other arrangements, and overseeing the reception and comfort of the new arrivals.

Russell Sage's avowed friendliness toward A. A. McLeod's scheme to make the NewYork and New-England Railroad a through line between New-York and Boston by building a connecting road from the Poughkeepsie Bridge to this city invests that undeveloped project with a financial interest which Mr. McLeod's well-known ambition and energy would not alone arouse.

Apparently stung and shamed by the pungent comments of M. Raymond de 1'Epee in The New-Tork Times, the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company has nerved itself to provide something in the shape of improved accommodations for the traveling public.

RAHWAY, N.J, Oct. 8. -- What may prove a deathblow was dealt the Linden Blood, Horse Association last night at the meeting of the Linden Township Committee. By a vote ot 4 to 3 the committee moved to reconsider the vote of Aug. 15, when the tract was licensed. This rote for reconsideration means that there will probably tie no racing on the track this Fall unless carried on contrary to law.

NEW-YORK. TUESDAY, Oct. 3 -- P.M. The stock market was so dull to-day that it seemed at tunes to be in a state of partial paralysis. Prices held generally firm, however, and at the close as much strength was exhibited as at any other time in the course of the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The President has decided to dismiss from the army Capt. Edward L. Bailey of the Fourth Infantry. Capt. Bailey was tried some months ago on charges involving intoxication and consequent misconduct. The court found him guilty and sentenced him to dismisal from the service.

The Board of Coroners met yesterday afternoon in executive session, on a call issued by Coroner Schultze, for the purpose of taking action on the presentment found against the board by the September Grand Jury. Coroner Messemer was the only member absent.
The Governor's staff, Governor's Foot Guard, and Guy Troop of Hartford, Conn., arrived at the Grand Central Railroad Station at 4:30 yesterday afternoon, on their way to the World's Fair.

HIGHLANDS OF THE NAVESINK, N. J., Oct. 3. -- Miss Ellen. Teresa McAnerney, daughter of John B. McAnerney, President of the Seventh National Bank of New-York City, was married this morning to Vincent Hyacinth Lamarche in the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help. The marriage ceremony was conducted by Archbishop Corrigan of New-York, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Roche of this place.

Betting has commenced on the Mitchell and Corbett fight. James Dubois of St. Louis last night per $650 against @1,000, Pat Hennessy taking the Corbett end. It is expected Corbett will be the reigning favorite at $100 to $70Tom Allen of St. Louis has offered to bet $2,000 on Mitchell against $1,000, and his old backer also wants to place as much money at that price.
Although Frank Elllson's trial ended Monday night, its sensational features have not apparently been exhausted.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Attorney General Albert E. Pillsbury issued a letter to-dar in which he announced that he was no longer a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor. In his letter he said:

GENESEO, Oct. 3. -- Two delegatons will go to Saratoga from Livingston County. The contestants are the representatives of the anti-machine Democrats of he county who would no lie down under the outrageous usurpaons of the machine men.
The third round of the international chess tournament was successfully brought to a conclusion at the Manhattan Chats Club last evening. The games resulted as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau states that over the Western portions of the, Carolinas, Southern Virginia, the Lower Ohio Valley, and generally to the westward of the Mississippi the rainfall of the week has been excessive, and the Western and Northwestern States, over which severe drought has prevailed for several weeks, have received abundant rains, which were greatly needed.

Scarcely 309 persons witnessed the billiard contest in the Lenox Lyceum yesterday afternoon and last night, in spite of the fact that the match was of an international character, bringing together young Ives, the conqueror of Slosson and Schaefer, and the champion of America, and John Roberts, the English champion.

W.W. Hurt, who was exposed by Editor John A. Cockerill as a card swindler and who caused Col. Cockerill's arrest for criminal libel, has fled from the city. He should have appeared in the Tombs Police Court at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but when the Clerk called his name his lawyer, Theodore B. Steele, said that Hurt had run away.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 3. -- The Presbytery of Nassau, which comprises twenty-six churches on Long Island, between Brooklyn and Islip, ended its Fall session this afternoon. The session was held in the Babylon Presbyterian Church, and began Monday morning. The Rev. S. T. Carter of Huntington was elected Moderator.

Bicyclist Howell writes to The New-York Times AS follows: To the Editor of The New-York Times: SIR: Kindly allow me to contradict a rumor that is going the rounds of cycle circuits that I have been refused a license by the Cash-Prize League oil account of erooked riding. Such is not the case. The union has not made any charge against me that I am aware of.

Louis James, the actor, has determined to fight the divorce sought by Marie Wainwright Heretofore no defense has been entered to Miss Wainwright's suit, which was tried in open court before Judge Gildersleeve Monday, and it was generally supposed she would, be granted a decree without opposition on the testimony which she and her witnesses gave before Judge Gildersleeve.

William Mulranen, twenty-eight years old, an oiler employed in the Manhattan Electric Light Works, at Eightieth Street and Avenue B, was killed in the dynamo room of the building at 2:30 o'clock, yesterday morning by an electric shock received while he was oiling the journals of one of the dynamos.

Mr. TILDEN understood perfectly that elections were won by votes, and that sound public opinion ought not to be and could not safely be defied. The Democratic Party has need now of a leader who holds and acts on this belief. One such man it has produced, and the people have placed him at the head of the Government.

The article in yesterday's Times stating so fully the relation of the committees to the receivers caused much comment in financial circles. The close conferences which have recently been held between the receivers and some of the members of the committees, and the harmonious relations which now evidently exist are regarded as a remarkable vindication of Mr. Rice's course in severing his connection With those committees.
For some time the Post Office Inspectors in this city have been receiving complaints from the South and West against a firm advertising as the Eastern Piano Company or 3, 5, 7, and 9 Beekman Street.

PELHAMVILLE, Oct. 8. -- Miss Kate McGallard, the nineteen-year-old daughter of George McGallard, was engaged six months ago to McDonald Cross, a master machinist in the lumber yard of Wilson Adams, Mount Vernon. The wedding was announced for some weeks, ago, but was postponed, because of the illness of the bride, until yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- E.M. Knox, the well-known hat manufacturer of New-York and Brooklyn, returned Saturday to New-York from a visit to the World's Fair with something more than pleasurable memories of his ten days' stay here.

The case of Miss Georgiana F. Putnam, the colored public-school teacher of Brooklyn, was quietly disposed of yesterday in the Board of Education. Secretary Brown read the resolutions adopted by the mass meeting in the Fleet Street African Methodist Episcopal Church Friday night.

Mrs. Catharine Fitzgerald, wife of John J. Fitzgerald, an examiner in the Corporation Counsel's office, and a relative of Inspector McLaughlin of this city, was arraigned yesterday morning in the Harlem Police Court for shooting and killing Mrs. Carrie Pearsall, wife of Policeman John W. Pearsall of the Eighty-eighth Street Police Station, at her home, 515 East Eighty-sixth Street, Monday afternoon.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 3. -- The storm of yesterday was the most destructive for twenty years. No loss of life has been reported, but on every street uprooted trees, broken fences, and roofless buildings testify to the storm's force.

Without fuss or public announcement of any sort, ex-Court Chaplain Adolf stocker of Berlin arrived in this city yeserday morning from Chicago via Boston. He was received by a committee consisting of Pastors C.F. Moldenke. A. Richter, G. C.F. Haas, and W. Berkemeier, who escorted him to the Buckingham Hotel, opposite the Roman Catholic Cathedral at Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- The weather to-day has been calm, and it has been made a day of reckoning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Sydney Rosenfeld's new play, "Fritz in Prosperity," is at the Chestnut Street Theatre this week. It is the most ambitious effort yet made by Mr. J.K. Emmet, and gives a chance to him to show his ability in a "straight character part." His supporting company is unusually good, and the star has by no means all of the strong situations.
MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 3. -- The damage done by yesterday's storm will reach into the millions. The steamer Crescent City was wrecked.

Francis Wilson's revival of "Erminie" at the Broadway Theatre will delight the town. It is simply delightful, and it reflects the greatest possible credit on the judgment of the always popular comedian. It is something over seven years ago that New-Yorkers made their first acquaintance with this agreeable operetta.

On their face the reports of the officers who inspected the work of the naval militia in the Summer just past are extremely discouraging. The Boston brigade, which possesses a monitor and goes to sea in it every Sunday, has shown the results of this excellent practice, and consequently gets the most praise.
Money on call loaned at 2@3 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

Prof. Hermann Ludwig Ferdinand Helmholtz, the distinguished German scientist, and Mrs. Helmholtz were given a large reception last evening in the Law Library of Columbia College by President Seth Low and Mrs. Low. There they met over 500 representative NewYorkers in professional, business, and social circles.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 3. -- It is the general belief in Government circles that the stay here of Francis H. Weeks is rapidly drawing to a close.

MADRID, Oct. 3. -- Further trouble has broken out between the Moors and the Spanish garrison at Melilla, a town on the northern coast of Morocco. The Spanish authorities recently decided to add to the strength of their fortifications at Melilla, the state of the country and the acts of the natives, in their opinion, warranting such a course.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- The market opened, dull and closed generally dull and about steady. Honey at the Clearing House loaned at 4 and 3 P cent.; new money 3 P cent. New-York funds sold at 17c and 15c discount for cash.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Duncan McBain, a bookkeeper for the Standard Radiator Company of this city, was beaten into insensibility on Heacock Street shortly after 4 o'clock this afternoon, and was robbed of a satchel containing over $1,700.

Excitement about the cup races is almost at fever best among the many thousands of people who desire to go out to sea to see the contest, Many of the steamers are booking places very rapidly, and the question of limit of the number of passengers is important. The Philadelphia and Cape May steamboat Republic, which will leave promptly from the Stonington Line pier.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- The first official announcement of World's Fair diplomas on pianos and organs was made this morning. W.W. Kimball Company of this city received from the Judges the highest honors on all three classes of musical instruments which it makes, namely, the Kimball pianos, the Kimball reed organs, and the Kimball portable pipe organs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Samuel J. Tilden, Jr., of New-Lebanon, N.Y., spent some time at the Post Office Department to-day. There are several Post Offices in his county which he would like to have filled with Postmasters to his liking.

At a meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners held in Mayor Gilroy's office Sept. 29 a plan for the improvement of the water-front of New-York City, between Charles and Twentythird Streets, was submitted by the Dock Department for the approval of the board. All the Commissioners present, with the exception of Controller Myers, voted in favor of the plan, but the Controller claimed that his negative vote defeated it.

The Board of Aldermen, at its meeting yesterday, took up the reports made by the Committee on Lands, Places, and Public Parks upon the application of the Park Department for permission to spend $135,000 for decorating and furnishing the new wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art without advertising for bids.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Commodore John G. Walker looms up as a candidate for the chiefship of the Bureau of Navigation in the Navy Department, becoming a rival of Commodore R. D. Evans. The detail is the most prominent in the navy, since the officer selected for the place is the Secretary's confidential adviser.

SARATOGA, Oct. 3. -- Saratoga is almost deserted to-night. All the big hotels are closed, and of the big politicians of the State only Mayor Gilroy, Corporation Counsel Clark, and County Clerk Purroy are here. Mr. Purroy is quartered at the Warden; the Mayor and Corporation Counsel are at the Adelphi, which will be the general headquarters of the Democracy.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Great ease in money helped to give a better tone to the markets to-day and brought in more business. Under the lead of consols advances were pretty general.
Spirits of turpentine more active and firmer. Sales, 250 bbls at 28@28 1/2c. Reging firm but quiet at $1.15@$1.20 for common to good strained.

Popular favor does not betray any feverish, desire to ally itself with the movement for reviving the Local Improvement Party in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards. When, the residents above the Harlem River obtained a street improvement bureau for their own territory and elected Loafs J. Heintz Commissioner their main object was attained.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- A moderate business was tran s acted in wheat to-day and the fluctuations were still within the narrow limits that Have marked the trade tor some time past. The opening was weaker and about 1/8@1/4c lower than the close of yesterday. The market then advanced 3/8c, but again eased off, prices declining 5/8c, then held steadier, and the closing was 3/8c lower than yesterday.

The body of Prof. Richard Anthony Proctor, astronomer and scientist, Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society of Great Britain, was yesterday laid in its final resting place in Greenwood Cemetery under the monument set up in his honor by George W. Childs of Philadelphia.

There was a great outcry among the members of the "Rainmaker of Syria" company at the Casino when they learned early last evening that there was no money for salaries. Several of them had a very heated argument with Manager H.W. Roseborn in Business Manager Charles Barton's office.

Sunday's bracing weather apparently enlivened fishes and fishermen, for both appeared in numbers greater than usual. Everywhere returns were reported as more satisfactory. Striped bass were caught in limited number along the docks of the North and East Rivers, but better luck rewarded the anglers who were in boats. At Hell Gate, Robbins Reef, and Glifford's, Staten Island, sport was fairly good.

The Central Park players continued their tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the lower courts of Central Park. The Consolation matches were the centre of interest. The matches are well advanced through the first round.
Another accident occurred last night at the Madison Square Garden during the exercises of the British military tournament.

NEW-HAVEN, Cenn., Oct. 8. -- The intercollegiate tennis tournament was begun hero yesterday on the courts of the New-Haven Club on on Whitney Avenue. Ten colleges were represented, with twenty contestants in all, among whom are Malcolm Chace of Brown, Gosline of Harvard, Duncan Candler of Columbia, Howland, Foote, and Terry of Yale; Budlong and the McCormick Brothers of Princeton.

A political movement has been started on Staten Island for the purpose of defeating the faction beaded by Nicholas Muller. It is proposed at the next election to nominate an independent Democratic ticket. Although the movement is of recent origin, several hundred voters have signified their intention of supporting it.

BALTIMORE, Mc., Oct. 3. -- Pimilee had a large crowd at the opening day of its Fall harness meeting. The track was last and the weather perfect for the sport. The track race records at both gaits fell during the afternoon. The New-York stallion. Belini, knocked 3 1/4 seconds from the 2:16 1/2 made by Nellie Mason last Fall, and the champion pacer. Mascot, chipped a fraction from the mark he set last Spring.

The conviction of ELLISON for his assault upon Mr. HENRIQUES was a foregone conclusion. No other verdict could have been reached that was compatible with public justice, or even with public decency. A big, powerful animal with brutal and barbarous instincts which he has never succeeded in controlling, nor ever tried to control, is a dangerous person to be left at large.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Plaza Hotel and its adjoining barn and stables were destroyed by fire this evening. The flames were first discovered in the barn of John H. Westcott and the fire was probably of incendiary origin. The Plaza Hotel was a large three-story frame building. It had been sold last week by Charles Schlesinger of New-York City to Charles Hendricks of Mount Vernon, N.Y., who took possession this morning.

This morning The New-York Daily Times consists of TWELVE PAGES. Every newsdealer is bound to deliver the paper in its complete form, and any failure to do so should be reported at the Publication Office.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 3. -- 3:45 P. M. -- Beef in poor demand: extra India mess nominal; prime men nominal. Pork in moderate demand. Hams in poor demand. Bacon in poor demand; Cumberland out, about 28 to 30 in, easy at 61s; long clear middles, about 45 in, steady at 66s; long and short clear middles, about 55 in, steady at 54s. Cheese in fair demand; American finest while and colored firm at 50s.

JAMESTOWN, Oct. 3. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention held here to-day placed in nomination Urban Prescott of Machias for Senator and nominated Obed Edson, Hiram Smith, Charles S. Cary, Elvin Reynolds, and William Cranson for Constitutional Delegates. Mr. Prescott is also the nominee of the Populists for Senator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The friends of the Administration here are expecting that the convention that is to meet in Saratoga on Thursday will include among its resolutions one approving the Administration of Mr. Cleveland. The assumption is that this will be accorded cheerfully, and that it will mean the indorsement of all the acts of the Administration, and generally all the policies that have been indicated by Executive acts.

It is now an assured fact that the United States Navy is to have a submarine boat. An appropriation having been made by the last Congress for the building of such a boat, many inventors submitted plans in accordance with the requirements of the circular of the Navy Department.

The Parkway Driving Club will give a trotting matinee to-day at the track at Gravesend. The races will be 2:46 class for members' horses to road wagons, 2:35 class to harness, open to all, and 2:29 Glass to harness. The admission to clubhouse and grounds is $1. The tract is easily reached by electric cars from Prospect Park, Brooklyn, or by Culver's Coney island Railroad.

ELMIRA, Oct. 3. -- The Republican Convention for Chemung County was held at Horseheads this afternoon. The calling of the convention to order was delayed two hours. No person could be found who was willing to accept the nomination for Member of Assembly. Finally J. Sloat Fassett put in an appearance, and urged several to accept.

The nine sales at auction announced for yes- terday at 111 Broadway had the effect of bringing to the place a large number of real-estate men. There were few bidders among the number, and the prices obtained were of little significance.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- The big Riverside steel plant at Benwood, West Va., opposite here, employing 1,000 hands, started this morning after a three months' shutdown. Reductions of from 15 to 30 per cent. were made. Hungarians and Italians who participated in the riots there two weeks ago were discharged and Americans given their places.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 3. -- The Suffolk County Democratic Convention met here this afternoon. The proceedings were thoroughly harmonious. It was the opinion among those present that the party would make a great showing in the county next month. The men placed in nomination will receive the united support of their party.

The "debate" in the Senate yesterday was supplied by two Southern. Democrats, Mr. BUTLER of South Carolina and Mr. BLACKBURN of Kentucky. Both opposed the repeal bill Both, however, almost begged for a compromise. Neither of them represents the business men of his State, nor the true-interests of all the people of the country.

William Stebbins, water tender on the steamer Yucatan of the Ward Line was arrested yesterday and arraigned before Commissioner Shields on the charge of having caused the death of John Ahlers of Hoboken, a fireman aboard the boat. It is alleged that Stebbins kicked Ahlers when he was too Ill to work and hastened his death.
A wanton and dastardly murder was committed at Princeton, N.J., in several New-York newspapers yesterday.

The steamship Alene of the Atlas Line yesterday brought to this port the boat of the Alvo that was picked up by the steamship Jason on her voyage to Montego Bay. Capt. Seiders of the Alene took the lifeboat on board at Kingston, where it was left by the Jason.

The Australian cricketers made their New-York appearance yesterday on the grounds of the States Island Cricket Club at Livingston. Everything Tended to make the game anything but an enjoyable exhibition of the great scientific pastime. The light, a most important factor for the batsman who wishes to play a long inning, was of the worst description for cricket, being dark and murky, while a thick haze pervaded the ground all through the game.
The Board of Education held its final Fall meeting yesterday afternoon. Nineteen Commissioners were present, President Sanger presiding.

The White Star steamship Majestic passed Fire Island about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and spurted to reach the Quarantine Station before sundown. Fog and drizzle, however, deterred her from attempting to cross the bar, and she anchored outside Sandy Hook for the night.
At the international chess tournament yesterday the game between Albin and Taubenhaus was given up as a draw.

Whether the races for the America's Cup, which begin to-day, will be close and exciting remains to be seen, but there can be no doubt they will be the fastest, conditions favoring, that have ever been sailed for that celebrated trophy. Long strides in yacht building and yacht sailing have been made since the cup was won.

There was no hitch in the production, of "The Rainmaker of Syria" at the Casino last night. An audience which comfortably filled the house was present, and the performance was carried on as merrily as if every member of the company had received a three weeks advance of salary.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Oct. 4 -- P.M. The market to-day showed a slight increase in activity over yesterday, which was one of the dullest days of the year. Trading, however, was entirely professional and was limited to a few of tite highly speculative stock.

-- Gov. William E. Russell of Massachusetts, though still a young man, has a record of not less than 500 political speeches, most of them, of course, having been delivered in the Bay State. He has spoken in all the New-England States, and in this State, Illinois, Maryland, Virginia, and Louisiana.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Secretary Carlisle today sent to the Speaker of the House of Representatives the following letter explanatory of his silver-purchase policy:

SYRACUSE, Oct. 4. -- Thomas C. Platt's annual Fall circus will open its doors at the Alhambra in this city Friday noon. Mr. Platt calls it the Republican State Convention. While he is not able to advertise any specially new attractions this year, he can call attention to the absence of some of the old-time performers.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 4. -- The storm swept across Liberty County in a path about 200 yards wide. Its course was such that no villages were struck fully by it. At Flemington the top of Mrs. Georgia Cassel's house was blown off. The path of the tor-

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 113, North Chicago at 209, Lake Street Elevated at 21@ 20, Diamond Match at 116, Alley Elevated at 43. Money, 7 cent. Bank clearning, $14,909,501. New-York exchange, 70c premium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- That the tide is again setting strongly toward unconditional repeal in the Senate is acknowledged tonight. Men who feared only a day or two ago that the silver Senators had their opponents "on the run" have changed their minds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The report of Capts. Henriques, Moore, and Congdon upon the inquiry into the charges against Capt. John C. Mitchell, of the revenue cutter Crawford, has been submitted by the board to the Chief of the Revenue Marine Bureau, Capt. Shepherd, who transmitted it to Assistant Secretary Hamlin, by whom it was turned over to Secretary Carlisle for his consideration.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- A representative or The Christian Commonwealth had an interview to-day with Rustem Pasha, the Turkish Ambassador. The representative asked why The Christian Herald had been excluded from Turkey. Rustem Pasha warmly replied:

Among the passengers on the outgoing steamships yesterday for Europe were: On the Berlin, for Southampton -- The Rev. J.E. Abbott, Dr. J. Bertillon, R.E.N. Dodge, H.L. Ferguson, United States Navy; Naval Constructor F. B. Zahu, United States Navy; Miss Mary C. Patten, Miss F.M. Hoare, and Miss C.M. Kennedy.

It is evident from the statements thus far published of railroad earnings in September that the business of land transportation in this country is improving at a fairly good rate. The increase in earnings over August is certainly encouraging. This increase is not confined to the gross earnings, but it applies significantly to the net earnings in the cases of nearly every road.

SARATOGA, Oct. 4. -- Prominent among those here is J.K. Hamilton Willcox, who is supposed to be on a still hunt for anything in the way of a political honor that may be lacking an owner. If he should decline election as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention, the fact must not be attributed to any lack of interest on his part, but to his somewhat delicate state of health.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 4. -- The day of the opening of the new athletic field of Dartmouth College was not all that could be asked for as regards weather, but enthusiasm was not lacking. The well-equipped grand stand was crowded when Prof. C.F. Emerson arose and, with a few introductory remarks, called upon Isaac F. Paul to present the athletic field in behalf of the alumni to the college.

Cabman Daniel Irving was hailed in front of the Hotel Brunswick last night by a tall, well-dressed man, whose unsteady gait attracted the attention of pedestrians, and engaged to drive to the East Thirty-fourth Street Ferry. When the cab reached Fourth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street Irving heard a crashing of glass, and, turning around, saw the feet of his passenger sticking through one of the windows.

The report of the operations of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad for the last fiscal year, which was submitted at the annual meeting of stockholders held in Louisville yesterday, made a very satisfactory showing. The gross earnings were $22,403,639 and the operating expenses $14,382,642. The net earnings therefore were $8,020,996, an increase over the previous year of $577,397.
SARATOGA, Oct. 4. -- The Democratic State Convention, which will meet in this village to-morrow, will place in nomination the foregoing ticket.
There is a chance that one of the best customers of the Reading Road may be driven out of the business on account of Reading discriminating against it in favor of the Lehigh Valley.

Two special trains, each composed of seven Wagner, coaches, with a baggage car attached, left the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon for Saratoga with the Tammany Hall delegation to the Democratic State Convention. The first train pulled out at 1:30 o'clock, and the second followed ten minutes later. It was planned to have as few stops as possible.

The Republican gains in the Connecticut town elections seem to have been chiefly cine to the prominence given to the license and no-license question. The popular vote on the liquor traffic, where a local-option system prevails, seems to be subject to continual action and reaction. There was a gain in Democratic County Commissioners last year, and they increased the number of licenses granted in license towns.

Incapable of comprehending how Chief John Y. MoKane could be a Sunday school Superintendent and at the earns time an officer of the law who permits "scientific contests" between prize fighters at Coney Island, provided he "gets his rent." the pastor of the South Third Street Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, writes the following letter:

A week from Saturday next Prof. Albert S. Bickmore will resume his series of lectures to the teachers of the City and State of New-York, which are given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction. As has been the custom since the inauguration of the series, they will be delivered in the lecture hall of the American Museum of Natural History.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4. -- The steamship Oceanic arrived this morning from Hongkong and Yokohoma via Honolulu with the following advices from Honolulu under date of Sept. 26: The reception tendered the officers and men of the United States steamship Boston took place last night, and was one of the largest festive occasions known in local History.

Private transactions in real estate are beginning to come to the fore. The largest reported yesterday was the sale, through Mr. George R. Read, to the trustees of Mr. William Aster's estate, of the northwest corner of Broome and Elm Streets. The vendor is Mr. John T. Williams, and the consideration is stated at about $500,000.
Ten youthful criminals were arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday and two in the Jefferson Market Police Court.

Army News. LEAVES OF ABSENCE. -- Capt. William Auman. Thirteenth Infantry, two months from Oct. 20. Lieut. R.G. Paxton. Tenth Cavalry, one month and nineteen days, with permission to apply for one mouth's extension. Capt. R.D. Read, Jr., Tenth Cavalry, one month's extension. Capt. R.L. Hoxie, Corps of Engineers, one month's extension.

John Bull and Uncle Sam will engage in a contest to-day. All differences between the two cousins will be put on one side, and the contest will be of the most friendly character. The participants will take their toy boats on the big pond outside Sandy Hook, and sail a race to see who shall have the famous America's Cup, the trophy emblematic of the yachting championship of the world.

EXETER, K.H., Oct. 4. -- The Harvard eleven defeated the Phillips Exeter team to-day, 54 to 0. Two thirty-minute halves were played on a damp field. The game was Harvard's from the beginning and was characterized by the fine work of Stevenson at right end and several long rashes by Corbett.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 4. -- Managers of banks here agree that the long-looked-for revival in business has arrived. A harvest of great abundance is assured. Interior merchants are paying city wholesalers for stock purchased during the past year, and are ordering fresh supplies, and city merchants have begun to remit funds to Europe in payment of indebtedness.

Police Commissioner McClave spent yesterday forenoon in trying to determine who was responsible for the can of beer which Inspector Williams found in the sitting room of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police (Station on the evening of Sept. 21.
Money on call loaned at 2 1/2 cent. The last loans were made at 2 1/2 cent.

Grand Isle, about sixty miles from New-Orleans, was the prettiest island of the Gulf of Mexico. It had groves of oak and orange, fields of wild camomile, and lanes of fragrant oleander. Mme. Willoz, a Creole, whose slaves had gone with her lands and her wealth, and whose relatives had died in the war, rediscovered Grand Isle twenty-five years ago.

It will be interesting to see what the Democratic Convention which meets to-day will have to say on the one national question of the hour, the repeal of the purchase clause of the act of 1890. The interest will attach not so much to any light the declaration of the convention will throw on the sentiment of the party in the State.

The first meeting between the champions of the Manhattan Association of this city and the Interclub Association of Kings County will take place on the grounds of the Kings County Tennis Club, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, on Saturday. Events on that day will be women's singles and men's doubles.

Mrs. William T. Bull, who was Marie Nevins Blaine, fell while alighting from her carriage yesterday afternoon in Forty-second Street, near the Grand Central Station. The horses had become unmanageable, and she was trying to get out of the carriage to follow her son, James G. Blaine, third, who had jumped out and run into a store.

Association Hall, in East Twenty-third Street, was again crowded last evening with friends and admirers of ex-Court Chaplain Dr. Adolf Stoecker, who had come to hear him for the last time before his return to Berlin. He was received with as much enthusiasm as on Tuesday evening, and the same close attention was given to his discourse.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The practice came to-day between the second eleven and the regular team at West Point showed that Saturday's play with the volunteers had disclosed their weak points. Capt. Carson has fully recovered from his sprained ankle, and Stont was also in splendid form. Ames is stilll on slot report, but it is thought that he will be in good shape for the game with Lafayette Saturday.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 4. -- The Democracy of Nebraska is loyal to President Cleveland and indorses his official acts. This much was shown in the preliminary skirmish in the Democratic State Convention, which met to-day to place in nomination a candidate for Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and two Regents of the State university, and incidentally to consider the silver question.

From Harper's Weekly. The appointment of Mr. J.J. Van Alen as Ambassador to Italy has been received with a good deal of adverse, even Indignant, criticism. If the principal charge were true not only would the indignation be justified, but the Senate ought to refuse its sanction to the corrupt bargain by rejecting the nomination.

The sixtieth report of the business of the Boston and Maine Railroad has been issued in pamphlet form and will be submitted to the stockholders at the annual meeting to be held in Lawrence, Mass., next Wednesday. It covers a period of nine months ended June 30, the fiscal year having been changed at the last annual meeting to end at that date.

The bold insult offered to the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn by Hugh McLanghlin, the leader of the machine Democracy of Kings County, and his open avowal of his friendliness toward the proposed international prize tight between the bruisers Mitchell and Corbett, have stirred up a wonderful feeling of resentment and indignation among all classes of citizens of that misgoverned community.

The coming "scientific contest" in the arena of the Coney Island Athletic Club having been declared by its promoters to be only a contest for points, and not a prize fight, a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday called on William Edwards, the detective of the Hoffman House, and asked his opinion upon the matter.

Although the dark clouds that hovered over the track in the morning promised an abundance of rain, the attendance at the weekly matinee of the Parkway Driving Club yesterday afternoon was fully up to the average. There were three events to be decided. The track was in poor condition.

Another circular to Northern Pacific stockholders made its appearance yesterday. It came from C.D. Barney Co. of Philadelphia, and sharply criticised the present management of the company. It favored co-operation with the Belmont committee of this city in an effort to elect a new Board of Directors at the approaching election.

A wedding was celebrated yesterday morning in the Church of the Redeemer, at Eighty-second street and Park Avenue, that was of more than ordinary interest, even to persons not immediately concerned with it, in that it signal ized the rapid growth of the elaborate ritualism favored by the Anglican Church, among a certain division of the Protestant Episcopalians in this city.

BARCELONA, Oct. 4. -- Pallas, the Anarchist and would-be assassin of Gen. Martinez de Campos, will be shot either tomorrow or Friday. The condemned man continues to maintain his perfectly composed bearing, which has shown no change since his arrest save when he bade a last farewell to his little children, when he broke down and cried bitterly as he kissed and fondled them.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 4. -- Hourly reports reach here of additional disasters resulting from the storm. Frem Baldwin County, which skirts the eastern shore of Mobile Bay from Blakely to Mullet Point, a distance of forty miles, and the shores of Bon Secour Bay to Fort Morgan, a distance of twenty miles, come reports of great destruction to property, but thus far there have been no lives reported lost.
Emma Goldman, Anarchist, faced a jury yesterday in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions.

BATAVIA, Oct. 4. -- The machine men did not put in an appearance at the Genesee County Democratic Convention held here to-day, and the friends of Maxwell had things all their own way. Robert S. Fargo and Clarence Higgins of Batavia and Christian Strobel of Le Roy were elected delegates to the State Convention.

Collis P. Huntington's attention was called yesterday to a dispatch from San Francisco which said that in the inventory of the Leland Stanford estate the executrix, Mrs. Stanford, alleges that she can find out nothing about the estate's Southern Pacific holdings or collaterals. The dispatch also intimated that there was a probability of a big lawsuit.
Government bonds were 1/4 lower for registered 4s. There was one sale of 1,000 coupon 4s at 111. The following were the closing quotations.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 4. -- The trial of the cruiser Montgomery is indefinitely postponed. She went on the rocks at Black Ledge approaching the harbor at midnight Tuesday, and the injuries then received will compel her to be hauled out and recaulked and a thorough examination made before a further trial trip can he had.

SARATOGA, Oct. 4. -- The town was lamentably dull all day, and the landlord of the Adelphi, the Tammany headquarters, who had but recently recovered from a fit of sickness, wore an overcoat and shivered in the sun. Disappointment was written on every feature of his pale face, and he seemed to be saying to himself:

The five-mile race at the metropolitan championship meeting on Saturday next promises to be the event of the season, as those two well-known distance runners. W.D. Day and T.P. Conneff, will meet again. Last year these two fliers met in this vicinty three times. On Decoration Day, 1892, at the New-Jersey Athletic Club games, Conneff defeated Day.
Dr. George W. Nash, who has arrived here from Hamburg, where he acted as the representative of Dr. Jenkins, has written a letter to the United Press, in which he says:

The Executive Committee of the committee appointed by Mayor Gilroy to make arrangements for Manhattan Day at the World's Fair met yesterday at noon in the Governor's Room at the City Hall. Gen. Horace Porter presided, and, in the absence of E.V. Skinner, James W. Tappin acted as Secretary.

-- Residents of the town of Scituate, Mass., show with pride the very well in which hung the old oaken bucket that inspired Samuel Woodworth's famous poem. Some of them even contend that the self-same iron-bound, moss-covered bucket still hangs there, in spite of the lapse of nearly a hundred years.
MONTEVIDEO, Oct. 4. -- The Brazilian turret ship Bahia sailed north yesterday. It is reported that, she is going to join the rebel fleet under command of Admiral Bello.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 4. -- As tending to show the sentiment in Mississippi on the financial legislation, now before Congress, the following from George R. Dennison, a member of the present State Senate, representing a purely agricultural district, is interesting. He is a stanch Alliance man, and also a Democrat.

In speaking to a reporter of THE TIMES some days ago of the movement to reform the municipal administration of Brooklyn, President SETH LOW of Columbia College, who was once a "reform Mayor" of that city, said: "The City of Brooklyn to-day has, in my judgment, the "best charter in the country from this point of view, among others, that the administration of the city is completely within the reach of the citizens.

MADRID, Oct. 4. -- The Government decided to-night to dispatch to Melilla at once 3,000 troops and another gunboat. All officers and men absent from the Andalusian Army on leave of absence have been ordered to return to their regiments forth-with. A detachment of troops bound for Melilla was accorded an ovation by the populace on departing from this city to-day.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The markets to-day were dull, but steady. Argentines continued to advance.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 4. -- There is no longer doubt that the islands, Grand Isle and Cheniere Comanade, have shared the fate of Lost Island and that the tragedy of 1856 has been exceeded in its fatalities by the hurricane of October 1. The number of lives lost is estimated at between 1,200 and 1,500.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Prices for wheat to-day were lower, and the amount of business transacted was not very large. The opening was 35@12c lower for December and 14c lower for May. After considerable fluctuation, the price declined 58@34 further, ruled steady, and at the close December was 1c lower and May 78o lower than the final figures of yesterday.

Last evening the Rutgers Riverside Church was the scene of the wedding of Miss Jennie Oakes, daughter of Mrs. George Oakes of 338 West Seventy-second Street, to George Wilmot Swain, President of the Endicott Democratic Club. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Booth. Harry W. Martin was the best man and E. Rice, J. Faye, W. Young, and B. Miller were the ushers.
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The Telegraph's Berlin correspondent says that Prince Bismarck has suffered a stroke of paralysis, and that he is in an apathetic condition.

Drifting, only drifting. That, in brief, is the story of the first day's attempt at a yacht race between Valkyrie, the black visitor from England, and Vigilant, the supporter and defender of America's yachting supremacy.
PASSED ASSISTANT SURGEON H.N.T. HARRIS is detached from the Vermont and ordered to the San Francisco.

It is evident that the main reliance of the Democratic leaders in their unchangeable determination to nominate Judge MAYNARD has been the weakness of the Republican Party in this State. They have known that MAYNARD was not the choice even of a majority of their own party, and that his nomination could only be made by the strenuous coercion of "machine" methods.

The drifting match for the America's Cup yesterday began with a contemptuous expression of wonder why English yachts will persist in coming over here to be sent home with respectful regrets. It ended with an almost keen eagerness to see what the Vigilant has got to say about it.
Call leans were made at 2@2 1/2 cent. The last loan was made at 2 V cent.

Over in Brooklyn, there are lawyers who say they see no impropriety in the behavior of Counselors Brooke and O'Sullivan, who sat in a barroom drinking whisky with three members of the jury who were to decide upon the merits of the Ellison case, in which case Mr. Brooke and Mr. O'Sullivan were of counsel for Ellison, then on trial and since convicted of aggravated assault.
To-day will probably decide whether Emma Goldman is to wear convict's garb.

The application of Justice CHARLES DEAN LONG of the Michigan Supreme Court to the United States District Court for a mandamus to compel the Commissioner of Pensions to resume and continue the payment to him of a pension of $72 per month will bring before the Federal courts a notorious example of the scandalous abuse of the pension laws by those two worthies, DUDLEY and TANNER.

It is unfortunate that the first attempt at a race between the Vigilant and the Valkyrie for the America's Cup should have been brought to a lame and impotent conclusion by one of the two chief drawbacks to the sport of yachting. These two drawbacks are too little wind and too much.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Oct. 5 -- P.M. The stock market was extremely dull today, for the yacht race was sufficiently alluring to draw many spectators from among the traders. In their absence from their usual haunts business languished, and, although there were spurts of activity in a few stocks, most of the list was almost entirely neglected and fluctuated within a vary narrow range.

Arthur J. Heaney, one of the Brooklyn Aldermen indicted in connection with the Columbian celebration expenditures in that city, has been discoursing in a significant and sinister tone to a reporter concerning local nominations in Brooklyn this month.

The Australians brought the second game of their American tour to a conclusion yesterday on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club, at Livingston, and time alone saved the home team from defeat. The Australians, however, declared that the New-Yorkers surprised them by their exhibition in the field, and they gave the home bowlers the credit of being superior to those encountered in Philadelphia.

There is a very old saying in several languages that before you take a bull by the horns it is well to remember that the horns belong to the bull. We are reminded of this maxim, which seems the outgrowth of a world-wide sense of prudence, by the recent declaration of independence issued by Mr. MORGAN of Alabama from his place in the Senate.
Spirits turpentine quiet and steady at 28 1/2@29c. Resins dull but steady at $1.15@1.17 1/2 for com mon to good strained.

The new branch of the New-York Post Office, which faces on Depew Place, opposite the Grand Central Station, was opened yesterday morning at 1 o'clock, as was resorted in The New-York Times. It occupies about two-thirds of the ground-floor space of the Industrial Building.

The first opportunity that yachtsmen had of seeing the Vigilant and Valkyrie under sail together naturally gave rise to comparisons. Some yachtsmen find it impossible to admire the " pig anout," but few will deny that the Valkyrie's is the more piggish of the two. Of one thing there cannot be any controversy, the Vigilant is all around the more shapely yacht of the two.
BARCELONA, Oct. 5. -- Great military precautions have been taken around the Fortress of Montjuich, in which Pallas, the condemned Anarchist, is confined. No stranger is allowed to approach the walls.

It was announced yesterday that the business building 57 Liberty Street, 25.1 by 140 feet, had been sold. The property is on the same block as the lot purchased of the city last week; by the Lawyers' Title Insurance Company. This latter purchase has given rise to some comparisons among real estate men as to the value of realty in the immediate vicinity.

Horace Plunkett, member of Parliament for South Dublin, is a guest at the Brunswick Hotel. He arrived on the Majestic and is bound for the World's Fair. He is interested in Lady Aberdeen's Irish village. Mr. Plunkett is a Liberal-Unionist member of Parliament, and not in sympathy with Gladstone's efforts for home rule.

"While the French people are becoming more and more interested in the American trotting noise," said A. B. Randle of Paris, Ky., at the Hoffman House, "they are not in the least willing to sacrifice either conformation or bottom to speed." Mr. Randie has just returned from France, where he went last Summer to study the foreign market for our national horse.
The Chamber of Commerce yesterday declared its position upon the Silver Purchase act repeal proceedings, at Washington in the following resolutions, reported by the Executive Committee:

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 5. -- The racing at Pimlico was carried on to-day under disadvantageous conditions. The track got such a wetting on Wednes day that it was heavy and from three to four sec ends slow. John Turner won the 2:35 trot with Daylight, a Palo Alto-bred stallion that he has had in slow classes for two years. He was a rank outsider in the betting.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The wedding of Miss Anna Holmes Banks, youngest daughter of Col. Henry Ward Banks of Englewood, to George McConnel of Knutsford, Cheshire, England, took place this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church. The officiating clergymen were the Rev. James Eells, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Henry Schlosser of Aurora, N.Y.

Dr. H.T. Hanks read a memorial address upon the late Dr. Charles Carroll Lee, President of the County Medical Society, at the first meeting of the Academy of Medicine, held last evening at 17 West Forty-third Street. The services of Dr. Lee to the profession in general, his great interest in the academy, and his many pernonal qualities were pointed out by Dr. Hanks.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Schooner Carrie W. Babson, which sailed from here May 29 on a fishing trip to Labrador, Hudson's Bay, and Greenland, arrived this evening with a cargo of hallbut, salmon, and trout. Owing to the heavy ice met with in Davis Straits, she was unable to explore the northernmost fishing grounds of Labrador.

The Belgian steamship Wordsworth, which reached this city yesterday from Brazil, brought full accounts of the revolt now in progress in that country. The Wordsworth sailed from Rio de Janeiro Sept. 12. Hostilities had been in progress for six days.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Byrd McGalliard, the nineteen-year-old daughter of George McGalliard, a rich contractor of Pelhamville, who was to have been married Monday to Isaac McD. Croff, a widower, who lives in this city, and who failed to appear, has been married at last. Croff returned to Pelhamville last night, and at 7:30 the Rev. C.W. Bolton was called to the McGalliard residence, where he tied the nuptial knot.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 5. -- The first definite news from the Golf coast of Mississippi reached here this morning, all the wires having been wrecked in the storm. The financial loss along the entire coast will foot up not less than $1,000,000, and at least 100 lives were lost.

SARATOGA, Oct. 5. -- The session of the Democratic State Convention was brief today. The temporary organization was speedily effected. Senator Murphy was warmly welcomed by the delegates as he walked down the aisle and mount ed the stage to call the scattering to order.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Twentieth District, including the Counties of Herkimer, Montogmery, Saratoga, and to-day. Through a mistake in the calls some of the delegates met at the Commercial Hotel and some at the lower Town Hall.
Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Kendal arrived yesterday on the Majestic. They were accompanied by Manager Riddel and were met at the wharf by Daniel Frohman, who will direct their theatrical tour in this country.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 5. -- For the first time since the circuit meeting began here on Monday there was a profitable patronage, the card being quite the most attractive one of the week. It contained six classes, besides some specials, and an early start was made to dispose of the long programme. The four-year-olds came first, as their race had begun yesterday.

When the Cunard Line's mammoth steamship Campania reached this port Aug. 26, one of her saloon passengers, Mrs. B.R. Fiske of Boston, Mass., reported to the police that a leather bag, containing $4,000 worth of diamonds and a letter of credit for u20,000, had been stolen from her stateroom.

Vincent R. Schenck, formerly Secretary of the American Steam Boiler Insurance Company, and William K. Lothrop, President of the company, denied yesterday the report that a large amount of the funds of the company was not accounted for.

-- Mr. John Hooker has resigned the postion of Reporter of the Supreme Court of Connecticut, which he has held for thirty-six years. During that time he has served under the administration of seven different Chief Justices and fifteen Associate Judges. Isabella Beecher Hooker, sister of Henry Ward Beecher, is Mr. Hooker's wife.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Secretary Morton has been a proud man to-day, for his State is the first one to be heard from out of which a Cabinet officer was selected since the Presidential election.

Two young desperadoes in Flatbush quarreled yesterday over the outcome of a name of pool and one shot the other, blowing half his head off. The murderer claimed the shooting was accidental, but was looked up on a charge of homicide.

Matilda Murray, spinster of thirty-two, wants $20,000 damages from William Stamm for a iacerated heart. Miss Murray's story of wce was told at length in The New-York Times. when she began her suit for breach of promise of marriage.

The fourth and perhaps, the most interesting round of the international chess tournament was played at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. Lasker added the fourth consecutive win to his clean score by defeating Schmidt, thus maintaining the lead.

Mrs. Sarah J. Edwards of 212 West Thirtysecond Street, a member of the " Midnight Band of Mercy," whose mission is to give to homeless cats painless death, was arrested late Wednesday night and compelled to occupy a cell in the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station until yesterday morning, because a well-meaning but misguided citizen detected her committing an act of mercy to a stray and starv -ing animal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Rev. John T. James, who got himself into notoriety by smashing liquor exhibits at the World's Fair, was brought up in the Washington Police Court this morning, charged with throwing a brick through a three-hundred-dollar plate glass window and destroying about $150 of stock in the wholesale and retail liquor establishment of Charles Kraemer, on Seventh Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- People passing Main and Lafayette Streets at 8 o'clock this morning saw a well-dressed man strike and Knock down a stylishly-dressed woman. The man was swearing at her. The was screaming at the top of her voice for help, and several brawny workingmen stepped in and separated the couple. Assistant Superintendent of Police Cusack saw the big crowd and sent both man and woman to No. 3 Police Station.

None of the excursion steamers carried a crowd that more thoroughly enjoyed themselves, in spite of the disappointment attending the actual racing, than the steamer Gay Head, chartered by the Atlantic Yacht Club. The members of this influential and wealthy Brooklyn organization turned out in full force and rig, with a large contingent of their own sisters, cousins, and wives, swelled by the sisters, cousins, and wives of others not members of the club.

Superintendent Byrnes met with a painful accident Wednesday night, and is in consequence confined to his house. The Superintendent left his office at Police Headquarters Wednesday afternoon and went directly to his home, 17 West Fiftyeighth Street. In going to his room he made a misstep on the bottom step of the staircase. He fell forward and struck the left side of his lace violently against the sharp edge of the newel-post.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Charges made by citizens of Oklahoma City of alleged misconduct on the part of Capt. Daniel F. Stiles, United States Army, (retired,) in connection with the opening up of Oklahoma to settlement, had their effect to-day in the issue of an order by the Secretary of War for the court-martial of Capt. Stiles.
Charley Mitchell said last evening that there was not the shadow of a doubt that his battle with Jim Corbett would take place in the Coney Island Club arena on the date set.

It was 7:55 P.M. when the Valkyrie reached her anchorage in the basin off the Atlantic Yacht Club Station. Her arrival had been watched for anxiously by a score or more of the members of the club, and as soon as her sharp lines could be made out in the dark a steam launch was sent out and Lord Dunraven, Lord Wolverton, Designer Watson, and Sailmaker Ratsey were taken ashore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The reports of the naval officers on the State naval militia organizations have stirred up the officers of the reserves by having criticised in some particulars the capacity for work of the militiamen. It is to such portions of these reports that officers of the reserve take exception.

The cornerstone of the new West End Synagogue of the Congregation Shaaray Tefila, in Eighty-second Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, was laid yesterday afternoon in the presence of many of the members of the congregation. The platform was decorated with American flags.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- The feeling in wheat to-day was unsettled. The market was quiet during the greater part of the session, with spa ms of activity. The opening was about 1/8@1/4c lower than yesterday's closing, but some strength was soon shown, and prices advanced 1/2@5/8c. After holding steady for a while a weak feeling developed, prices declined 7/8@ 1c, and the close was 5/8@3/4c lower for December and 1/3@5/8c lower for May than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- President Cleveland's advice that an unconditional repeal of the Sherman silver purchase power be passed would be carried out, if a vote were to be taken to-morrow by not less than 10 majority. This is known to the opposition, and it is the explanation of their stubborn and disgraceful fillbustering which they persist in calling deliberation.

"The Rainmaker of Syria" was played last evening at the Casino, although Manager Roseborn did not appear to pay the principals of his company. Business Manager Charles Barton said that he had received a letter from Mr. Roseborn during the day telling him to send all the creditors to the office of his lawyer, Joseph C. Rosenbaum, at 280 Broadway, and that they would be paid.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Treasury Department yesterday purchased 40,000 ounces of silver at its counter-offer of 73.60 an ounces. The amount purchased thus far this month is 300,000 ounces.

The sailing of the yachts was viewed from a social standpoint on board the steamer St. Johns, which had been chartered for the occasion by the New-York Yacht Club. As the New-York Yacht Club is like one great family, the crowd aboard the St. Johns was one thoroughly congenial. Everybody knew everybody else.

USE HORSFORD'S ACID PHOSPHATE. Dr. J.C. STROUND, Moorostown, N.J., says: "I have used it for a, number of years in my praotios, and find it very useful in dyspepeia and nervousness." cers away on their journey. A cloud of yellowish canvas broke out on the Vigilant; another of white on the Valkyrie followed an instant later. The race was under way.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 5. -- The unexpected opposition to the nomination of E.T. Bartlett of New-York for Judge of the Court of Appeals at the Platt circus, otherwise known as the Republican State Convention, to be held here to-morrow, was the feature of the night here. Despite the fight being made against him by a number of the New-York City delegates, this evening his friends feel certain of his nomination.

To show just what a twenty-hour service by rail between New-York and Chicago means. General Passenger Agent George H. Daniels of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company arranged on Wednesday morning for a flying trip from Chicago to this city by Miss Bess Mitchell, the famous traveler, to witness the yacht race yesterday.

From Frank Leslie's Weekly, Oct. 5. Some of the best detective work of modern times has been done by newspapers. The latest service of this kind has been rendered by The New-York Times in the case of Francis H. Weeks, a lawyer of this city, who stole $1,250,000 of trust funds and fled to Costa Rica.

SARATOGA, Oct. 5. -- The convention was called to meet at noon in the new Village Hall, just finished, which coat the corporaion $100,000. The building is constructed of brick, and is of modern architectural design, being in strong contrast with the massive old-style hotels in the immediate vicinity.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 5. -- At the meeting of the freeholders this afternoon Mr. Ellis offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the Finance Committee, be authorized to borrow $72,000 on temporary loan bonds. He said it was an outrage that municipalities which paid their taxes promptly should be compelled to pay Interest on account of municipalities that shirked their responsibilities.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5. -- The Big Four has made a rate on grain and flour from East St. Louis to Liverpool in connection with its new steamship line from Newport News of 26.8 cents per 100 pounds. The regular rate from East St. Louis to the seaboard is 26 cents, so that the Newport News steamers are destined to play an important part in East-bound rates in the future.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Father Ignatius, the Episcopal monk, who made a tour of the United States some three years ago, set the Church Congress at Birmingham in an uproar to-day by denouncing publicly the Rev. Charles Gore, author of " Lux Mundi."

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- In Trinity Church today, in the presence of the highest dignitaries of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this country and of a vast multitude, the Rev. William Lawrence, D. D., was consecrated seventh Bishop of Massachusetts.

-- In a confidential moment a writer in The Boston Transcript reveals to his readers his experience with regard to two melodies, which are destitute to him of marked associations and which he does not regard as more beautiful than a good many other melodies. One of them, a song, he has heard sung but once, he says, as a sons, and that was in a foreign language.

Joseph Chamberlain, M.P., the famous leader of the Liberal-Uniouists in the House of Commons, accompanied by Mrs. Chamberlain, who is the daughter of ex-secretary of War Endicott, and his two sons, Austen and Neville, who arrived Wednesday on the steamer Majestic of the White Star Line, landed yesterday, the Majestic having passed the night outside the bar.

The blot of MAYNARD'S name upon it should not prejudice the Democrats of New-York against the ticket put forth by the Saratoga Convention, yesterday, nor work injury in repute or in votes to the candidates for State offices who have been yoked with a tainted and unworthy associate.

Assignee R.W.G. Welling called together the creditors of Francis H. Weeks yesterday morning at the office of Gould Wilkie, 2 Wall Street, and submitted to them a statement showing the condition of Mr. Weeks's assets, and the probabilities in regard to the net results of the defaulter's operations. Mr. Welling's statement in August fixed liabilities at $1,300,000 and assets at $54,000.

Controller Myers, who is Treasurer of the committee appointed by Mayor Gilroy to make arrangements for Manhattan Day at the World's Fair, on Oct. 21, has issued the following appeal for funds to defray the expense of the celebration:
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Americans were extremely dull to-day; other markets irregular. Louisville was weak on poor traffic reports for the fourth week of September.

Edward Hayes has sold his half interest in the Standard Trotting Horse Company to Morris J. Jones. The sale includes Alix, 2:07 3/4; Pactolus, 2:12 3/4; Redwald, 2:23 1/2; the brood mares, and all the young stock.

Cord Meyer, Jr. Cord Meyer, Jr., of Newtown, Queens County, nominated for Secretary of State to succeed Frank Rice, is thirty-nine years old. He has served two years as Secretary for the Democratic State Committee, and during the last Presidential campaign he was appointed on the Advisory Committee of the Executive Committee of the State.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Oct. 6 -- P.M. Delaware, Lackawanna and Western furnished the feature of the stock market to-day. Not much was doing in it before noon, but between that hour and 2 o'clock a neat twist was worked on the shorts, and the price was run up 10 points from the opening figures -- 147. In the two hours the trading in the stock amounted to over 9,000 shares.

The experiment made by the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church of abandoning the powrent system for the envelope or free-church plan has proved a distinct failure. The church property is to be sold, and its pastor, the Rev. Dr. Thompson, will probably accept a call to another church.

Stephen Little, the expert railroad accountant, who was employed to make an examination of the affairs of the Philadelphia and Reading corporations in the interest of the bondholders, has almost finished, so far as the books and accounts of the railroad company are concerned. He will proceed at once to look into the condition of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal Company.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 6. -- Chauncey M. Depew was the star of the afternoon performance. It was he who got the lion's share of the cheering. When he came in, accompanied by his son, the enthusiasm was great and Mr. Depew looked very happy.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the erection of the following new buildings were filed:

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The Merchants' Bank of this city closed its doors this morning. A Deputy Bank Superintendent is in charge. It is thought that the assets will cover all liabilities, and there is no evidence of any crookedness. The suspension has caused intense excitement. The bank has done a large business, and was believed to be perfectly solvent.

The twenty-second dinner of the American Dramatists' Club was given at the Holland House last night. The invitations were in the name of David Belasco, who was the host of the night, and the dinner was tendered to the President of the association. Bronson Howard, on the occasion of his departure for Europe.

A scheme has been devised by the officers of the Sherman Bank, at 874 Broadway, to absorb the assets of the Madison Square Bank, to asume such of its liabilities as are considered good, to make advances to depositors of the Madison Square Bank, taking their pass books as security, and to merge whatever business may still properly belong to that bank in the business held by the Sherman Bank.

While saving his brother's life yesterday morning, six-year-old John Timony of 23 Rush Street, Williamsburg, was killed by a trolley car. John and his eight-year-old brother Frank were playing with a small cart. They were on the trolley car tracks.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Complete and gratifying success resulted to-day, at the Sandy Hook proving grounds, from the test of eight-inch and ten-inch armor piercing projectiles on armor plates respectively nine inches and eleven and one-quarter ft:inches thick. Five shots were fired, four of which were for tests of work contracted for by the Government, and the fifth to test a projectile made, as an experiment, by the contractors.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Wheat opened unchanged for December and 1/4c higher for May, advancing 1/4c, then declining to the opening price, became stronger and advanced 7/8c for December and 5/8@3/4c for May, again declined 7/8c and 3/4c respectively held steady, and the closing was about 5/8c higher each for December and May than the closing prices of yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 6. -- Manager Platt had a tight rope tautly stretched between two stout poles this morning in the Alhambra, where his show was to exhibit. He had arranged to have E.T. Bartlett of New-York walk across it and perform to-day for the amusement of those who had tickets of admission to the show.

William Thomas Lawrence, over whose body funeral services were held last Wednesday in the venerable St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, was the worthy representative of a family conspicuous in this State since Colonial times. He was the son of Senator Lawrence, Minister to Sweden in the time of Madison, and the grandson of Major Jonathan Lawrence, who rendered patriotic service is the war for independence.

There is every indication that the Valkyrie and Vigilant will be thoroughly tested at windward work to-day. The weather bureau prophesies that there will be plenty of wind to-day, perhaps too much, varying from southeast to southwest. While this is just what the yachtsmen want, the indications also say that there will be rain.

Bradstreet's to-morrow will say: "Slightly more cheerful reports from leading Southern trade centres, largely due to a freer movement of cotton and the advance in price of that staple, coupled with more numerous advices of improved trade distribution at Western and Northwestern centres, constitute the principal points of interest in telegrams to Bradstreet's this week.

Isaac Horton Maynard, nominated to succeed himself as Judge of the Court of Appeals, was born at Bovina, Delaware County, April 9, 1838. He is of Scotch and English descent. He has lived throughout his life at the place of his birth and the neighboring town of Stamford. In 1862, after having been graduated at Amherst College, he read law at Delhi, in his native county.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- The final rounds in the singles and doubles of the intercollegiate tennis tournament to-day resulted in giving the championship to the Brown University. Yale was the only other college to reach the final round, and although both Howland and Foote hotly contested every point for their college, Chace and Budlong won after a close struggle. In the singles Malcolm Chace defeated Foote by a score of 6-3, 6-2, 6-3.
Call loans were made at 2@2 1/2 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.
Silver bullion certificates for 10,000 ounces sold at 74, and certificates for 25,000 ounces sold at 73 7/8. The closing quotation was 73 1/2@ 74 1/4.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 6. -- The Platt circus is over. He has pulled down his tent, and carried his harvest away snugly tucked in his trousers pocket. The above list of candidates nominated to-day by his Republican State Convention is his own chosing to a man.

SARATOGA, Oct. 6. -- From the fact that several committees had reports to make up at 9 o'clock this morning the Democratic State Convention was unable to begin work at 10 o'clock, the hour named in the resolution of the opening day. Indeed, it was past 10 o'clock when the first delgates arrived at the hall.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Buffalo Courier (Dem.) comments on the nomination of Judge Maynard as follows:

The Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria, the heir presumptive of the throne of Austria, arrived in this city yesterday. He will sail to-day on La Bretagne. He would like to stay here longer, but he is called home by a message from the Crown, and consequently he is bound to obey it.

The invitation matinee of "In Mizzoura," which Nat C. Goodwin gave for the benefit of "professionals" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre yesterday afternoon, proved one of the most enjoyable entertainments of the kind ever presented in this city. No tickets were sold, all the seats in the house being apportioned to actors and actresses.

SARATOGA, Oct. 6. -- The Democratic Convention, which has been in session in this village for two days, finished its work and has gone home. It nominated the ticket printed above, which was published in The New-York Times two days ago.

Members of the Belmont-Ives committee of Northern Pacific security holders are confident that they will be able to vote a majority of the stock at the approaching annual election. Mr. Ives said yesterday that proxies were coming in very rapidly.

A case interesting to liquor dealers is set down for argument to-day in the Superior Court, General Term. It is an appeal from a decision of the Special Term affecting the ownership of a United States internal revenue license and a local storekeeper's license for the sale of spirituous and malt liquors.
It is still to be determined whether Emma Goldman is to act the Anarchist in or out of prison.

When the case of Mrs. Sarah J. Edwards, the member of the "Midnight Band of Mercy" who was arrested Wednesday night for chloroforming a cat, shall come up in the Harlem Police Court this morning, Mrs. Edwards will be found ready to fight for her right to put an end to the existence of homeless felines.

At the Manhattan Field this afternoon the New-York Cycling Association will give a series of races in which the experts will compete for cash prizes. The races will be for the benefit of the Trades and Labor Unions of the city, the first one being called at 3 o'clock. The entries for the several event, with the handicaps assigned, are as follows:

SYRACUSE, Oct. 6. -- The Alhambra, in which to-day's performance took place, rests adjacent to the shores of the Erie Canal. It is an ex-skating rink, and is the building in which the anti-snapper or May convention was held last year.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Cornell University began the celebration of her twenty-fifth anniversary to-day. All day the alumni have been coming to the city, each train bringing a delegation. At 10 o'clock this morning a meeting of the Trustees of the university was held.

The steamship Lucania, the latest addition to the Cunard Line, arrived last night, making by 59 minutes the fastest westward voyage ever accomplished by a transatlantic vessel. The Paris, which has held the record since October, 1892, when she reduced the time of the passage to 5 days 14 hours and 24 minutes, must now surrender her hard-earned laurels to the Lucania, which completed the voyage in 5 days 13 hours and 25 minutes.

In the face of the fact that from the pulpits of churches all over Brooklyn are pouring forth most indignant protests against the proposed international prize fight between James J. Corbett and Charles Mitchell, in the ring of the Coney Island Athletic Club, the club still brazenly defies public sentiment.

Joseph Turner, a colored waiter of 751 Seventh Avenue, called yesterday at Police Headquarters and reported that his three-year-old son Willie had been enticed away from his home by a colored woman. Little Willie is a pretty child, but bow-legged. He was playing in front of his home Tuesday afternoon when a colored woman, tall and stout, wearing a red wrapper and a black jockey cap, lured him away.

The Glenham Hotel property, at 153 and 155 Fifth Avenue, which was transferred from the Cutting estate to H.O. Havemeyer on Aug. 10, has been disposed of by the latter. The price is not stated, but it is under $250,000. When transferred to Mr. Havemeyer it was put down at the latter figure and some Connecticut property was given in addition.

The independent political organization of Brooklyn, the Committee of One Hundred, held its second meeting in Conservatory Hall, Bedford Avenue and Fulton Street, last night, President James McKean in the chair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Now that the time is near for the final test of strength between the repeal and anti-repeal forces of the Senate, the opponents of repeal, mindful of the success which has attended their efforts at "bluffing," have resumed their old tactics, and are making wild assertions designed to bring about a further postponement of the dreaded day.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 6 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef, pork, and hams in poor demand. Bacon in moderate demand; long clear middles, about 45 to, steady at 55s 6d; long and short clear middles, about 55 to, steady at 53s 6d; Cheese in moderate demand. Tallow in moderate demand; prime city firm at 27s 6d. Spirits of turpentine in moderate demand. Resin in fair demand.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Oct. 6. -- The residents of this village are divided on the question of changing its name. Lively work is going on for and against the proposed change. A number of persons have Summer homes here. A suggestion, made during the season, that the village deserved a better name has grown into a movement to change Hicksville into Waldorf, after William Waldorf Astor.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 6. -- Gov. Altgeld is engaged in building an unenviable reputation as the friend of jailbirds. No Governor of Illinois has ever used the pardoning power so lavishly. Up to this data Gov. Altgeld has opened the prison doors to ninety-five convicts. This has been done in less than seven months.

KISSINGEN, Oct. 6 -- Prince Bismarck drove out with Dr. Schweninger this afternoon. He looked somewhat stronger and responded to several salutations from pedestrians along the road. In the streets of the town he was cheered by all whom he passed.

Do the people of this State propose to elect a criminal to the Court of Appeals Bench? Popular suffrage has sometimes raised base persons to high places, but it has rarely done itself so ill a turn as that. It would be a hideous travesty of free institutions. The bad rulers of history who have appointed corrupt Judges have done so because they wished justice to be perverted for their self-interest.

John Roberts, the English champion billiard player, is over 1,000 points ahead in his game with Frank Ives, and the chances are that the young Western expert will have a defeat scored against him.
