In rail play, nursing, open table work, manoeuvring for position, and other points, he is far superior to the Briton, but the latter excels in making hazards and steady play, and on that account is in the lead.

Plans for the construction of the speedway as far north as High Bridge were adopted at the meeting of the Park Board yesterday. These plans had been agreed on at a meeting Sept. 13 at High Bridge, at which Mr. Dana, Chairman of the Committee on Speedway, was not present. Mr. Dana explained yesterday that he had not understood any decided action was to be taken, so the subject was reopened.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Gen. Kirchbach, a Prussian Army officer, especially well known in the Brandenburg military district, tried this morning to kill Dr. Harich, sub-editor of The Berlin Tageblatt, and is now under arrest.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The preparations for the dedication of the sixty-thousand-dollar shaft, to commemorate the battle of Trenton, are nearly completed. The indications are that it will be the greatest day ever known in New-Jersey. The distinguished visitors and troops will probably number 12,000, and the other visitors from 40,000 to 50,000.

The yachts left Bay Ridge in tow under bare poles before 8 o'clock. The White Star tug L. Pulver had the Valkyrie, while the Commander, with Mr. Iselin's colors flying from the bow flagstaff and on both sides of the pilot house, towed the Vigilant. They went through the Narrows and down the lower bay about a mile apart, the Vigflant in the lead.

The country of this people extends in Thibet, from that point southward as far as a high range of mountains running from east to west, and is watered by the Yellow River. It is treeless and very hilly; but the pasturage is fairly good in the valleys and on the lower slopes of the mountains, which, even in September, show a clearly-marked snow line.

The musical season of 1893-4 will fairly begin, to-morrow evening. The opening feature will be the appearance of Mr. Gustav Hinrichs's Philadelphia company in "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "I Pagliacci." Mr. Hinrichs is an earnest and industrious provider of public amusement in musical form and his productions, while not of the first order, are interesting and as good as can be given at "popular" prices.

News of a disquieting nature concerning the American missionaries and teachers in Marsovan, Turkey, the seat of Anatolia College, has just been received by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Daniels, District Secretary of the American Board of Foreign Missions. The Institution is maintained by the American board for the education of the Turkish youth.

Democratic primaries for the election of delegates to the County, City, Senatorial and Aldermanic Conventions were held in all the wards in Brooklyn yesterday. They resulted in the election of the following delegates:

Under the policy of having separate receivers appointed for each of the branch lines of the Northern Pacific Railroad, more than fifty receivers will soon have a hand in administering the affairs of that extensive system. There are about twenty-five branch roads, and they represent a bonded issue of about $29,000,000.
The thirty-three delegates of the Paris workingmen returned to Havre by the French Line steamer La Bretague yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- If you enter the Horticultural Building by the south side you will at once find yourself in the department of viticulture. Here the thousands and tens of thousands of visitors every day at the World's Fair see the greatest display of the products of the vine ever made in this country.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- While speculative business outside of African mines has been at a standstill, there has been a steady investment demand for first and even second rate securities, and returns of clearings on the Stock Exchange settling days during the last three months show an increased volume over last year.
From Chicago comes a delightful little tale of Greek meeting Greek.

The case of Mrs. Catherine Fitzgerald, who shot and killed the wife of Policeman Pearsall on Monday afternoon at Mrs. Pearsall's house, 515 East Eighty-sixth Street, came up yesterday morning in the Harlem Police Court. Mrs. Fitzgerald appeared in court led by her husband, who held up her elbow-with his hand. Mrs. Fitzgerald was dressed in black, and a heavy crape veil covered her hat and completely concealed her face from view.

Most positive and conclusive evidence is herewith presented by The New-York Times to show that the so-called "scientific contest for points" arranged to take place between Charles Mitchell and James J. Corbett in the ring of the Coney Island Athletic Club is meant to be a prize fight.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 7. -- It has been discovered that the law directing the Commissioners of Dorchester County to contribute $75,000 to the building of the railroad to Fishing Bay is inoperative, and the fact will probably defeat the enterprise. The act was passed more than twenty years ago, and in the codification of the laws of the State it was omitted.

I have on numberless occasions observed the common pit viper of Southern South America, which is of a sluggish disposition, lying in the sun on a bed of sand or dry grass, coiled or extended at full length. Invariably, on approaching a snake of this kind, I have seen the tongue exserted; that nimble, glistening organ was the first and, for some time, the only sign of life or wakefulness in the motionless creature.

Hotly-contested races, close and exciting finishes, and good, all-round sport characterized the games for the Metropolitan championships of the Amateur Athletic Union on the grounds of the New-Jersey Athletic Club yesterday afternoon. The field, while small, brought together nearly all the first-class athletes of this vicinity.

Mr. Harris, in the selection of a title for this work, (which is one of true icthyological importance has shown good judgment "The Fishes of North America that Are Caught on Hook and Line" is more comprehensive than the usual one, "Game Fish." The exact definition of "game fish" never was made exactly clear.

MADRID, Oct. 7. -- The Moors have reappeared before Melilla. During the night they cut entrenchments along the crests of three hills at some distance from the fort, but on Spanish territory. They have a strong position, which can be taken only by a charge across a stretch of open country. As they are well armed, the Spaniards will hardly be able to storm the position before receiving large reinforcements.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Society events have not been as numerous this week as they were last, because so many of the cottagers went to New-York to attend the yacht races. Driving is one of the special enjoyments now. Just at this time the foliage is at its brightest and best.

The tallest office building in the world, besides being the heaviest in proportion to the area of ground covered, is now in course of erection at 64, 66 and 68 Broadway for the Manhattan Life Insurance Company.

Alexander Russell Webb, who returned to his native land several months ago to spread the light of Islam in America, having embraced the Mohammedan faith after a long residence in Asia, furthered his purpose last night by opening to the public the lecture room at the Moslem headquarters, 458 West Twentieth Street.

An expert accountant has been employed by the committee representing the depositors of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn to go over the bank's books and secure all the information possible to be had about the Grening and Hassell notes, on which they obtained $300,000. Horace Graves, counsel for the depositors, yesterday made the following statement in regard to the matter:

At the bicycle races at Manhattan Field yesterday J.W. Sohofield, J.E. Starbuck, and Charles Price had a collision in the two-mile handicap, Starbuck had his head badly cut and is suffering from shock. Schofield and Price escaped with slight bruises.

Although the sons of famous men are apt to be disappointing, the daughters seem not infrequently to seize the mantle of the paternal genius. Miss Mildred Howells is a most skillful story-teller and a clever illustrator, and Miss Clare Clemens, daughter of Mark Twain, though only twenty years old, has written a play which is highly spoken of.

Men who have a strong attachment to party are wont to overlook much in the methods employed by "practical politicians" which does not meet with their approval. They are often compelled to choose of two evils that which seems to them to be the less, and they do not feel called upon to sacrifice important interests to punish derelictions which they desire to rebuke and which they would have been glad to prevent.

Sanford Parker, a boy living at 2 Bartlett Street, Williamsburg, left home Friday morning to get money wherewith to buy food for his ill and starving mother. Being unable to earn money or borrow it, he stole part of the motor brake from a trolley car, hoping to sell it. He was detected and arrested by Policeman Schnepf of the Sixth Precinct.

The Executive Committee of the Cleveland League Central Club, a colored Democratic organization, met last evening at 115 West Twenty-seventh Street to make arrangements for a public meeting to indorse the candidates nominated at Saratoga. The meeting will be held during the latter part of the week.

When on Friday afternoon there was started on its travels the old, old story of a proposition from Secretary CARLISLE for a "compromise" no one of any sense attached the slightest importance to it. When it was found that Senator SHERMAN, in an interview with a reporter of an Ohio paper, had advanced the same proposition, then it was plain why the old, old story had been given this particular form.

When the drifting match of Thursday last came to a close and the Valkyrie was intercepted short of the finish to be informed that it was "no race," everybody afloat was curious to know what the Vigilant had to say about it.

In an essay on English life, an observant Frenchman, who had spent many years in England, made the statement that one of the presents which every English mother makes her daughter on her marriage is a reliable pair of scales, for every housewife weighs all her provisions, including meats and poultry, as soon as they are delivered.
"I say," said an Englishman, squinting through his monocle, to a youth in tweed aboard the St. John's, as the Vigilant crossed the finishing line, "did you ever see a finer race than that?"

Probably no portion of the Old Testament has come down to us in so corrupt a condition as the Book of Job. Parts of it are jumbled together for all the world as if they had been writter on small scraps of paper, which, the wind having blown them asunder, were joined again together at haphazard.

A report of the receipts and expenditures of the Press Club Fair, which was held in the Grand Central Palace for five weeks -- from May 1 last to the end of the first week in June -- had just been made to the Building Committee of the club. The total receipts were $75,371.55. The expenditures were as follows:

Columbia College opened for work on Monday last. About 1,800 students are registered, which shows an increase of 300 men over last year's roll. This increase is felt in all departments, especially in the School or Mines and in the College of Physicians and Surgeons.

Mrs. Sarah J. Edwards, the member of the "Midnight Band of Mercy" who was arrested Wednesday night for chloroforming stray cats, appeared before Justice Welde, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning, to show what authority she had for so doing. When the case was called, it was found that Mrs. Edwards had not been able to collect the witnesses who were to testify in her behalf.

Writing to Mr. Moffat, the Assistant Commissioner at Palapye, in June last year, he says:

It voices the sentiments of the three Jurors, Tucker, Castagnetta, and De Medici, regarding their meeting with Mr. Brooke and Dr. O'Sullivan in the Cosmopolitan Cafe:
BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 -- The campaign in Maryland this year will he short, peaceful, and certain. The Democrats are united, and the Republicans are disorganized, and the result is already acknowledged.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $5,978,461, of which $1,158,250 was in dry goods and the rest in general merchandise. Imports of specie were $57,422. Exports of specie were $521,276.

I have in my possession a detailed account of the temper of parties in England, drawn up in the year 1585, three years before the Armada came. The writer was a distinguished Jesuit. The account itself was prepared for the use of the Pope and Philip, with a special view to the reception which an invading force would meet with, and it goes into great detail.

Mrs. Eliza Jones Priddy, wife of Prof. James Priddy, Principal of Brooklyn Public School No. 33, on Heyward Street, has instituted proceedings against her husband for divorce on the grounds of cruel and inhuman treatment. The initial step was taken yesterday in the Supreme Court by her counsel, William Van Wyck, who made a motion for counsel fee and alimony.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Notice has been formally served by Senator Voorhees that the final struggle for repeal will begin in the Senate next Wednesday evening. In pursuance of the considerate course he adopted at the beginning of the debate, Mr. Voorhees secured the floor when the repeal bill was reported to-day and made this announcement:

Alexander Major is most worthy of recognition as the man who, facing all dangers and obstacles, originated, as Gen. Cody writes it, a line of freight wagons, a mail route from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and the Pony Express. There is a, warm friendship existing between Gen. Cody and the author of these memoirs, because, in 1855, when a mere boy, Cody was given a place in Major's line of freighters.

More than 4,000 persons saw the football match between the Yale and Crescent teams at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. At 3 o'clock Cart Hinkey and his party of long-haired players appeared on the field, to be followed a few minutes later by the red-stockinged Crescents. Capt. Hinkey did not play in the first half of the game, Cochran taking his position at left end.

On last Sunday at the Church of the Atonement, Seventeenth Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, at the time of the introduction of vested women into the already-vested choir of men and boys, the rector the Rev. E. Homer Wellman, preached a sermon appropriate to the occasion, in which he showed that the introduction of especially clothed women into the praise service of the Church is not an innovation, but a simple return to ancient customs.

The moire Persian lamb finds especial favor this season because of the revived approval of moire silk. A black satin coat has a collarette of moire Persian, with shoulder pieces of jet-spangled net. Bands of Persian lamb, edged with jet gimp, are on cloth capes.

BUFFALO, Oct. 7 -- Two of the bestknown and highly-respected Democrats in Buffalo make no secret of their feelings in regard to the nomination of Maynard. Franklin D. Locke makes a statement as follows: "I think Maynard's nomination is a direct affront upon all decent citizens in the State.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Athletes and athletics have in this city the finest homo ever provided for them in any place in the world. In fact, the clubhouse of the Chicago Athletic Club rivals, if it does not excel, in its architecture and interior decoration the most famous structures anywhere devoted to club purposes of whatever kind.

From The London Daily News. Under the existing monetary convention, the quantity of foreign money circulating in France is very great, as all travelers in that country are aware. In order to arrive at some notion as to the proportion of foreign coins to native coins, the French Govment has undertaken a sort of numismatic census.

The New-Yorks "Chicagoed" the Brooklyns for the first time this season in a one-sided game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the first game in the series to decide the metropolitan championship, and if the Giants continue to play as they did yesterday, they will win the series without the least trouble.

Why should Mr. Gladstone hesitate longer to give the Laureateship? If he intends to give it at all; if he believes that such a distinction is right, he may offer it to Paul Leicester Warren and be assured that he has bestowed it on a poet.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 7 -- The tariff campaign in this State has thus far been largely a one-sided affair. Gov. McKinley, with his usual application and persistency, has been speaking every day, and, if reports are to be relied upon, has had a fair attendance at his meetings, while Mr. Neal has made few speeches and has held but one big meeting since his opening at Newark on Sept. 14.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- While Prince Bismarck absorbs popular interest, which never tires of the minutest detail regarding him, official and diplomatic attention has been directed to the critical financial condition of Italy, and the probable effect of this condition on her relations to the Triple Alliance.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- There is reason for genuine disappointment in "Utopia, (Limited.)" It has funny things in it, and without doubt much charming if not specially notable music, but it is not what has been looked for from the reunion of Gilbert and Sullivan. The final curtain fell upon a particularly inept ending, almost in silence, until the audience remembered themselves and cheered in a perfunctory way.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 7 -- With the telegraph wires singing more regularly, the full extent of the disaster in this section of the country is becoming known. Every message brings additions to the number of vessels wrecked and lives lost. An arriving schooner at Biloxi reports that many bodies are floating on the shore at Cat Island, Ship Island, and Chandeleur Island.
Wheat declined 1/4c, with the easier West. Cut trading was very light and wholly on local account.

"The people of Venezuela," said Juan de Villian of La Guira, Venezuela, who has just returned from the World's Fair, "are just beginning to appreciate the advantages and profit from having perfect breeds of horses, sheep, and cattle. Our horses are most of them small and nearly all saddle horses, especially the very fine ones, from Peru and Chill, where they are inbred with the Arabian stallions.

Sir William Fraser's investigations concerning the scene of that "sound of revelry by night" in Belgium's capital, which Byron made famous by his poetic chronicle of it, has led him to undertake an extended series of reminiscences, and all within a few years. Besides his "Words on Wellington," he has printed "Disraeli and His Day," and the present "Hic et Ubique," and he gives us promise of several other volumes.

Philip Schuyler, who is prominent in the yachting world and who is very much interested in the Vigilant-Valkyrie contest, was a passenger by the American Line steamship New-York, which yesterday arrived from Southampton. Immediately after landing he set about finding a way by which he could witness the race.

To Senator John T. Morgan, Washington, D.C.: Esteemed Sir: It affords me unalloyed pleasure to inform you that at Friday night's regular meeting of the Jack Cade Club of New-York City you were unanimously elected an Honorary Member (with the privilege of life membership on receipt of $5 in gold, silver, legal-tender paper, or postage stamps from you to cover cost and mail charges of a handsome illuminated certificate.)

There will be more new plays at the theatres in this single week than New-Yorkers often see in a month, and some of them promise to become interesting topics. But only one of them has yet become a topic, and that is Mr. Pinero's powerful play of contemporary English life, called "The Second Mrs. Tanqueray," which has been a "play of the year" in London.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Presidential family moved from the White House to-day to Woodley, Mr. Cleveland's suburban residence. Mrs. Cleveland and her babies and Mrs. Perrine, her mother, will remain at Woodley for several weeks, in order that Mrs. Cleveland may fully regain her strength for the Winter season's social duties.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Frank J. Lytle is a grape grower of Portland, and for the last five years has shipped more or less of Chautauqua product to Bradford, Limestone, Olean, and other near-by oil county towns. This year daring the grape harvest one of the many pretty girls employed by him in his vineyards placed a note in one of the baskets she had prepared for shipment, which read as follows:

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 -- The white Republicans of the South are making an energetic effort to separate themselves from their colored brothers, but the work is not proceeding as well as it was expected to proceed. This is especially true of the movement in the City of Baltimore.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The investigation into the affairs of the Elmira Reformatory was continued this morning by the special committee of the State Board of Charities. F.F. Babcock was present to assist John H. Stanchfield as counsel for the Board of Managers.

Low prices are the rule in every department of the horse and carriage trade, and the present conditions are the most exceptional ever experienced by the trade in this city. When the House of Representatives took such vigorous action on the Sliver bill, showing that the sentiment of the conntry is overwhelmingly against it, the business men naturally concluded that the bill would be at once repealed, and business had a "boom."

ALTON BAY, N.H., Oct. 7. -- Samuel E. Goodwin of New-York was shot and instantly killed by the accidental discharge of a gun in a boat in which he and a companion were fishing this afternoon near his Summer residence at Gilmanton, N.H. He is a native or Gilmanton, but is well Know in New-York as a wealthy contractor and builder.

From The Boston Journal, Oct. 5. The breach of promise case of Mrs. Anna D. Van Houten vs. Asa P. Morse was given to the jury Wednesday afternoon, and that body three hours later reported a finding for the plaintiff in $40,000. A new trial will be asked for by the defendan.

If one should read the stories of Thomas Nelson Page for their plots, they would be found gently exciting; if for their style, they would appear quaintly humorous or sagely pathetic; but if for their reflection of phases of human life, they would seem to be ideal. Abbey might draw their heroines in the gowns of Goldsmith's characters.

While the good people of Brooklyn have been asleep and dreaming of an existence in which there is no "machine" and where no "regulars" break the law and fight and steal, the ruling powers have not been idle. On the contrary, they have been even busier than usual. Thanks to their vigorous industry, a vast politico-geographical change has been inaugurated within the bailiwick of his Honor Mayor Boody.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- District Attorney Ridgway of Brooklyn arrived in Washington to-day and registered at the Arlington. To a correspondent of The New-York Times Mr. Ridgway asserted that his sudden flight from Saratoga to Washington had no political significance whatever -- he was here simply on business with the Department of Justice in which the public was not interested.
The annual meeting of the Peabody Education Fund was concluded at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. All the Trustees were present except Messrs. Evarts, Fuller, and Morgan.

It seems to the memory not more than a few years since Mr. Glider's first, volume revealed to the public the wholesome range of his poetic sympathies and the fine qualities of his lines. That remembered volume, "The New Day," has since been succeeded by three others, not including the present. They are "The Celestial Passion," "Lyrics," and "Two Worlds."

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Oct. 7 -- P.M. The stock market was again dull, but firm. It opened quiet and steady and without special feature, and in the case of most of the securities traded in fluctuations were within narrow limits. The strength was pretty well maintained to the close. The total transactions were only 55,619 shares.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Prince Bismarck left Kissingen on a special train at 11:40 o'clock this morning. He drove with his wife in an open carriage to the station. The streets through which he passed were crowded, in many places almost to the carriage wheels. Thousands of excursionists went to Kissingen last night or earl ythis morning to bid the Prince good-bye.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Politics in this city have been complicated by a demand formulated at a German meeting last night for the nomination of a German for Sheriff. A number of prominent Germans made speeches in support of the proposition. The names of Max Salinger and John A. Tangemann were presented.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- There is much in the annual reports of Secretary Herbert's bureau chiefs of public interest. They will form the basis of the year's departmental report. The year's work in ordnance has been interesting, without startling developments. Armor has reached its best state, apparently, and the experiments of the last twelve months have shown that the earlier demonstrations were sustained.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- We were well repaid last night for the rather long and tedious journey cross the S ine to the Odeon Theatre. Not that the new play is anything the ordinary dilution of Georges Ohnetism, but a surprise and a genuine artistic treat awaited us at the top of the grand staircase.

The air was full, on a day I well remember, of all the oppressively abounding plant and insect life of the tropic underwood. Suddenly, beneath a mighty tree, where there was space for tolerably free movement, Pauli, my "colored" huntsman, takes out his knife, and, bending down, crops a long, straight stalk.

The man who said there wasn't going to be any Fall trade evidently had not walked through the store of Hilton. Hughes Co. A store that covers a city block can hold a multitude of shoppers, but even the broad aisles of this famous old store are none too spacious to give comfortable room to the crowds which fill them every day.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The Young Men's Christian Association room was crowded last night. The Rahway Anti-Race-Track League has been active for two weeks mustering its forces for action. Eloquent speeches were made and many who have been wavering came out boldly as anti-race-track men.

At Daly's Theatre, Sol Smith Russell will begin a season, of 100 performances tomorrow night, during which he will present some of his most successful plays, and possibly one new one. He will open with "Peaceful Valley," by Edward E. Kidder. In this play, the scenes of which are laid in the mountains of New-Hampshire, Mr. Russell appears as Hosea Howe, a quaint type of character peculiar to rural New-England.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- The second day's play in the return match between the Australian cricketers and Philadelphia was witnessed here to-day by an enormous crowd. There were 6,000 people present before luncheon, and as many more came in the afternoon. The game was made the occasion for a gathering of Philadelphia's most fashionable population, whose drags lined the field, while every available space in the grand stand was taken up early in the game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Secretary Gresham has appointed Thomas Dennis of Illinois, a veteran of the Mexican War, who lost both arms on board the United States ship Princeton, in the Mediterranean, by the premature discharge of a gun, to a Messenger's position in the State Department.

The North German Lloyd steamer La Salle, which sailed from New-York yesterday, carried Dr. William J. Morton, the neurological specialist of this city, who treated Gen. Grant, James G. Blaine, ex-President Garfield, and others equally prominent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The week which is approaching like the one just closing, will be rich in dramatic offerings of the highest quality. Anticipations of the first production in Chicago of Tennyson's "Becket" by Mr. Irving and Miss Terry will not be realized immediately, as the great popularity of "The Merchant of Venice" has induced the management to continue the bill another week.

The "Rainmaker of Syria," who shoots his bombs into the flies of the Casino at every performance, was almost drowned out last night by a deluge of creditors. For a long time it was a question whether he would have an opportunity to let loose his regular evening show.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Last week it seemed as if the story then to be told of the disaster of famine that was desolating whole broad counties of industrial England was as bad as anything possibly could be in the existing state of civilization.

The steamship Petersburg of the Russian volunteer fleet had a unique experience near Minicoy, in the South Indian Ocean. A sharp shock was felt by all on board and she stopped as though gripped in a vise. The sea was found to be colored with the lifeblood of two huge whales, which lay floating in their last agony.

The bank statement of yesterday shows an increase in every item, that in the surpus eing $4,508,225. The most noteorthy ncrease is in deposits. $9,215,500, bringing them for the first in a long time above the loans. The increase of nearly $7,000,000 in cash would have made a considerably larger surplus reserve had not the deposits advanced in so marked a manner.

The conservatism of the Southern people -- one of those five causes which have been suggested by Mr. Page for the neglect of literature in the South -- was shown prominently in the classical character of Southern oratory, but it was still more noticeable in the literature of Louisiana before Cable began to write.

Mme. Darmesteter is well known to novel readers as A. Mary F. Robinson. As a poet she may be said to have her fame yet to make, for, although she is not a novice in the art of verse making, she has appealed to that wider audience which continually hungers and thirsts to find out whether the man married the woman or whether, being married, one of them did not wickedly love a third person.

From The London Daily Telegraph. When a man calmly carries about with him six cartridges of dynamite and ten detonators, it is not surprising that he should cause a scare in a hospital and be regarded as a pre-eminently dangerous member of society by sick nurses and male attendants.

Jabez Knowles, commonly called "Old Knowles," had been Head Librarian of the Aberdeen Free Institute for many years. Indeed, the old inhabitant would have hesitated before asserting that he had ever drawn books without Jabez's assistance. So long had he held the post and so retired and methodical his life, that the members, without realizing it, never thought of him as distinct from the library.

There were disappointments about the first race of the the Valkyrie and the Vigilant for the America's Cup. The "dead beat and dead run," that all yachtsmen consider as the most crucial and therefore the most desirable test of a sailing yacht's speed, are not to be had by the mere volition of regatta committees.
J.R. Watson, manager of the London and Brazilian Bank (Limited) at 71 Wall Street, this city, received the following cable dispatch yesterday from Rio de Janeiro, dated Oct. 7:

A man who is constantly reading ought, of course, to be able to spell the words which he is repeatedly seeing on the page before him. Yet, as we know, it often happens that great readers are exceedingly bad spellers. Why is this? We believe it is because the bad speller sees and reads each word as a whole, as a grammalogue, or thought symbol, that is, and not as so many letters.

The week just past has shown an improvement in the matter of dealings in real estate, although matters are not yet in a satisfactory condition. Monetary conditions have changed a little for the better, but not enough to encourage either active trading or investment. The staple of sales, to borrow an expression from another business field, is still mainly confined to residences.

Hawtrey Thwaites in The Westminster Gazette. Another interesting discovery, though it does not exactly come under the head of sportsmen's adventures, may interest you. It has always been a great puzzle to naturalists where the Ceylon butterflies go at a certain time of year. You see them flying over your house and garden in thousands and tens of thousands, in one direction, toward the north.

It has been finally decided that the opera season will open on Nov. 27, with Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette," instead of his "Philemon et Baucis," as at first announced. Jean de Reszke will make his re-appearance as Romeo upon this occasion. Upon the second evening "Cavalleria Rusticana," followed by "Philemon et Baucis," will be given.

The third Congress of Aeronauts at Chicago cannot be said to mark the solution of the problem of navigating the air, but it must have done good in disabusing a host of inventors who have plunged into the making of flying machines without a clear understanding of what has been done before them and what is being studied elsewhere to-day.

G.N. Groom is a well-known man in Lavaca, Sebastian County, Ark. He has several peculiarities, but one which has fastened upon him the name of crank is best told in the following letter, which he has written for publication:

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 7 -- The condition of parties, in California, has been materially affected, for the present at least, by the Geary Chinese law and the complications attending its enforcement. As the feeling prevailing here on this subject does not seem to be very well understood in the East, it may be worth while to devote a little space to an explanation of it.

About 9 A.M. the banks of the river near the place where the shoals of fish have gathered are crowded with thousands of horses and sledges, so that it becomes difficult to reach the river. Fishermen go down to the ice and stand on it in endless lines on both banks of the river, anxiously waiting for the signal -- a cannon shot.

In Paris, the Tailors' Syndicate is preparing a new edition of their Black Book, which was originally published seventeen years ago. The Black Book contains the names and descriptions of those persons who do not pay for their clothing. Once a man is inscribed in it, he is unable to obtain clothing at any establishment unless he is prepared to pay cash before delivery.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The King Memorial Fountain in Washington Park, which was unveiled Sept. 29, has been visited by thousands of persons during the week. There have been many criticisms, some of which have not been favourable, as a matter of course. Some of the critics say that the fountain is not artistic and never will be, because it is impossible to combine rough ashlars and bronze figures in one harmonious whole.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- "The World's Fair is being used to further one of the darkest conspiracies ever conceived against the Indian race."

From The London Daily Telegraph. Wolkringer, a man formerly in business in Paris as a Jeweler, gave himself up to the police yesterday under the following circumstances. In March last he went to England and thence to America, carrying with him about u14,000 worth of jewels with which he had been intrusted by persons desirous of selling them to the trade or to private purchasers.

Gossip In and Out of Town. -- Several times the people standing high within the pale of fashionable society have remarked, "Will there be a reconciliation between the Deacons?" With one exception the answer was, "I do not know." A gentleman who has been spending the entire season at Newport said: "I do not think Mr. and Mrs. Deacon will ever be reconciled, no matter how much Mrs. Charles H. Baldwin may wish it.

Mrs. Lispenard Stewart, who was stricken with paralysis Thursday at her Summer residence in Newport, died there early yesterday morning. Her sons, Lispenard and William R. Stewart, and daughter, Mrs. Frank S. Witherbce of this city, were at the bedside when she died, having been summoned in haste from this city.
The weekly bank statement, issued to-day, shows an increase in reserve of $4,508,225. The banks are now $28,628,725 above legal requirements.

The labor demonstration in Union Square last evening under the auspices of the Labor Conference of Trades Unions for the Relief of Unemployed Workmen was not as large as was expected. The police thought the scene of the storming of Walhalla Hall might be repeated, for they were massed in Broadway above Eighteenth Street and in other streets in the vicinity, ready to pounce down upon any Anarchists who might try to capture the meeting.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Miss Edith Aurelia Fisher, daughter of the late Samuel S. Fisher of Cincinnati, and John Christopher Schwab of New-Haven, son of the late Gustav Schwab of New-York, were married yesterday in Center Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Newman Smyth.

Though little apt to do what is supposed to be a traveler's duty in visiting certain obvious places of interest, I one day hunted for the English cemetery in which Fielding lies buried, and found it at last just at the back of a little open park or garden where children were playing. On going in I found myself alone, save for a gardener, who was cutting down some rank grass with a scythe.

From The London Daily News. A correspondent at Launceston, Tasmania, sends us a disheartening account of the protectionist craze in that colony. "By a kind of McKinley tariff," he writes, "the people here have carefully themselves off from the rest of the world, and imagine they are protecting native industry.
The author of "The Book of the East" has set at naught many literary commonplaces, but not the one which lends to the physical envelope of the poet the figure of his majestic creations.

From The London Globe. The question, Who are the Basques? -- that mysterious people who give their name to the Bay of Biscay -- is always cropping up, and Prof. von der Gabelentz has recently endeavored to show that the Basque language belongs to the African Berber family of speech -- for example, the Kabyle and Tuareg.

While the depression through which the industry has passed has nearly ruined everybody connected with it, it has not been an unmixed evil, for it has taught us much which it was very necessary for us to learn. To it may be ascribed the care and cleanliness and the improved methods which now prevail in all the best cellars.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The market was very quiet today and an easier feeling prevailed. The opening was 1/8@1/4c lower than yesterday's close, recovered slightly, the market then nuctuated within a range of 3/8c, and closed about 1/4@3/8c lower for December and 3/8c lower for May. The news was of an unusual character and of a bearish tendency. Export clearances from both coasts were 300,000 bushels smaller than the previous week.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: The within letter to Senator Gorman was called forth by your appeal to the business community, and may be of interest

A woman inventor has constructed a table which will wait upon itself. The table is round, and the stationary space for plates, , is about 10 inches wide. Within this circle is a revolving disk an inch or two higher than the stationary part. On this the food is placed, and a simple turn will being the desired article within reach -- Kate Field's Washington.

Clumsy old Sandy Hook Lightship was once again a lodestar yesterday. To reach and nod good-morning to her there went down to the waters of the Atlantic Ocean hundreds of craft of all possible types, most of them visitors that had called on Thursday last and paid their respects, and then drifted down seaward for fifteen miles.

If general business were no better than business on the Stock Exchange at this time, it would be just as well to shut up shop. There is next to nothing doing. Part of the dullness of the past week may perhaps be set down to the interest in the yacht race; and then again, if there had been no race, probably the stagnation would have been the same.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Cornell University was continued to-day, when Chauncey M. Depew delivered an oration at Armory Hall before the officers of the college, the Faculty, alumni, and students. All the trains since yesterday morning had brought visitors to the celebration, and the attendance at today's various functions was as large as could be accommodated.
Nearly all of the auction sales of real estate announced for the present week are in foreclosure proceedings. In the appended list all sales will take place at 111 Broadway unless otherwise stated:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- "A nice piece of cold lamb for Senator German, and be quick about it."

The American Guaranty Association, which is said to be composed of John S. Forgotson, George Forgotson, and Etta Forgotson, and which loans money on personal property, has been made the defendant in a suit brought by Miss Emily Berdell of 65 West Thirty-sixth Street to recover $5,000 worth of furniture, which, it is claimed, was unlawfully seized by the Forgotsons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- To every child that has seen enough of the theatre to come to know the traditional Pantaloon at sight, the bewhiskered old gentleman who is always in a rage and always shaking his weather-beaten beard at Clown and Columbine, and constantly receiving the largest share of the pats from Harlequin's paddle, the appearance of the rather stupid and vicious old fellow provokes immediate laughter and excites no sympathy whatever.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 8. -- Capt Julien Le Fort, the leading man among the survivors of the Chieniere Comande, came up to town yesterday after spending six days in relief work on the island. He places the number of the saved at 300, while the population of the island and bayous immediately connected with it was slightly more than 1,500.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Dr. Everard Kempshall, "the tall and towering doctor," as he is called in Elizabeth, is at the head of the Citizens' League, which is taking such an active part in New-Jersey politics. He had just finished swinging the dumb-bells, at the Elizabeth Athletic Club, when the correspondent of The New-York Times asked him concerning the work of the Citizens' League, of which he is the President.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- The thorough canvass undergone by the freshman class of the University of Pennsylvania this week has been productive of good results in the way of available football material. Unfortunately, however, the new men are suited for positions which the regular squad is fully able to take care of. Work as Captain Mackey would, but one single, solitary new candidate for centre rush has been discovered.

DUBLIN, Oct. 8. -- Memorial services in honor of Charles Stewart Parnell, who died two years ago last Friday, were held here to-day. Thousands came in excursion trains from all parts of the country. The procession started at 1:30 P.M. for Glasnevin Cemetery, where Parnell was buried. The column was so long that it required seventy minutes to pass a given point.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 8. -- The Trustees of Greenfield Cemetery, in this town, have a complicated case on their hands, growing out of a dispute over the ownership of a burial plot in the cemetery.

Dr. Talmage yesterday fell into line with the other clergymen of Brooklyn who have protested against the proposed Corbett-Mitchell prize fight. In his morning ser- mon on "Pompeil and Its Lessons?,'' he said:

PITTSBURG, Oct. 7 -- Money is easier, and a better feeling prevails in business circles. The local stock market is very dull, and closes for the week heavy, as the public is buying very few stocks. It prefers to wait until the silver question is settled.

BUFFALO, Oct. 8. -- Alderman John White has represented the First Ward in the Board of Aldermen for nineteen years. This year he is again a candidate, and there is a determined effort making to defeat him. Republicans and Democrats alike vote for White, and Republicans and Democrats are leagued together in the movement against him.

District Attorney RIDGWAY of Kings County is reported to have said, during a recent visit to Washington, that he heard more about the international prize fight at Coney Island in a day than he heard in a week in Brooklyn. This is a compliment to the society to which Mr. RIDGWAY gains access in Washington at the expense of that which he frequents at home.

The congregation of Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, Washington Square East, bade farewell to its old place of worship yesterday morning. The church is to be sold, and, as has been told in The New-York Times, the congregation has united with the Washington Square Church, in Fourth Street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- Yale men are beginning their annual Fall speculation on the answer to the question, "How long will it be before an opposing team scores against Yale?" Two years of football have been played since the riddle was last solved, and during those two seasons two blue-clad elevens have arisen who wore champions' laurels when the last same had been played.

Gov. Flower and Mayor Boody have an- swered the appeal made to them by the Methodist preachers of Brooklyn and Long Island to use every effort in their power to prevent the proposed international prize fight at the Coney Island Athletic Club between Charles Mitchell and James J. Corbett.
Justice Welde tried to play the part of Solomon in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, but a frisky black-and-tan pup wouldn't let him.

The first edition of Goldwin Smith's book on the United States (the latest praise of which, from an able journal, is printed in The Saturday Review) was exhausted within a fortnight of publication, and the Messrs. Macmillan have a new one ready.

The Rev. J.O. Wilson, D.D., pastor of the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, at Willoughby and Clermont Avenues, Brooklyn, made a scathing denunciation of all Kings County officials who have concerned themselves in arranging for the proposed prize fight. The church was crowded, and throughout his entire sermon he was listened to with the closest atten- tion.

Wallace, Weismann, and others have given a new impulse to the subject of heredity, and now Maria Louise Pool makes it the main topic in a novel. When in poetry or romance, as did Keats with his "Lamia," or Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes with his "Elsie Venner," traits other than human are introduced, the mystery attached to the heroines deepens.

BUFFALO, Oct. 8. -- The Democrats of Orleans County held their adjourned county convention on Saturday and nominated the following ticket: For member of Assembly -- Harry O. Jones, Holly; County Treasurer -- George S. Hutchinson, Gaines; Superintendent of Poor -- Horace E. Hobbs, Carlton; School Commissioner -- Mrs. Hannah L. McChesney, Albion; Justice of Sessions -- John Millard, Clarendon; Coroner -- Dr. Clark, Kendall.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8. -- Almon B. Thomson, cashier of the Provident Savings Bank of this city, on July 13, 1886, after embezzling $63,000, for which he was to account the following day, robbed the safe of $13,000 and fled to Canada. Until last Friday he was as thoroughly lost to the public as though in his grave.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Last week the Controller of the Currency called for a statement of the banks. The Chicago bank statements showed a remarkable increase in the amounts of deposits and reserves over the last statement, which was made July 12.

The death at Andelys is announced in Paris of Adolphe Sellenick, former leader of the Garde Republicaine and the composer of four comic operas which have had a period of celebrity. He was born at Strasburg in 1820. He was a pupil of Hoerter in harmony. He was a soldier in the French campaign in Italy in 1859 and in the war against Germany in 1870.

The New-England novel, pure and simple, is attractive in two ways, either for dry, comic manner or for strong dramatic effect, and as often as not from the admixture of these two elements. "Brothers and Strangers" has the salient qualities of neither comedy nor tragedy, and yet it is not commonplace.
The Hamburg-American Line steamship Russia, which sailed from Hamburg Sept. 24, reached this port yesterday, with her passenger list depleted by five deaths which occurred during the voyage.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 8 -- "Wanted -- A Moral Cyclone," was the subject of the Rev. John L. Scudder's prelude to his sermon at the Congregational Tabernacle this evening. Notices were read in all the churches of the city to-day, requesting the election of three delegates from each congregation to the Moral Reform Society Convention in the Second Presbyterian Church Tuesday evening.

WEST POINT, Oct. 8 -- The October exercises, which consist of light and field battery drills, instructions in the school of the cannoneer, school of the driver, mortar, siege, and seacoast batteries, commenced last Monday. The preliminary exercises are of an elementary character and prepare the cadet for the more practical lessons which come later in the month.
There were no transactions in silver bullion certificates on Saturday. The quotation was 73 1/2c bid, 74c asked.

Interest at Columbia is centred mainly in the tennis tournament which is now being played on the Columbia Oval at William's Bridge. The first two rounds in singles and the first round in doubles have been played. Very good work was done in singles by Swords, and in doubles by Beach and Lewis. W.C. Larned, who won the intercollegiate championship last year, is coming from Cornell to enter '95 Mines.

The Normal College of the City of New-York opened with the largest attendance known in its history, having on the register 1,944 students, giving an attendance of 1,875. About one-third of the students are pursuing the classical course, while the remaining two-thirds are in the normal course. There are only two courses at the college.

Sticks, knives, clubs, glasses, and pistols figured in a row between two policemen and four citizens in Miller's saloon, Flatbush, Saturday night. When the row was over, John Stapleton was unconscious, with a fractured skull, and Policeman Clark's teeth had been knocked down his throat.

The lift bridge of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad over the Harlem River at Fourth Avenue was opened to travel early yesterday morning. This bridge is about 250 feet west of the old drawbridge, which is now to be replaced by a new four-track drawbridge.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 8. -- The Norwich Shook and Lumber Company's steam mill at Norwich, Vt., was burned early this morning. The building was 200 feet long, and had just been completed. It was equipped with new machinery of the highest grade, all of which and considerable manufactured stock were lost. The tire was undoubtedly of incendiary origin.

ITHACA, Oct. 3. -- The quarter-centennial celebration of Cornell University was continued to-day. Sage Chapel not having sufficient seating capacity, service was held in the more spacious gymnasium. The main hall was filled with alumni and invited guests. The decorations were chiefly red and white, the university colors, though flags were displayed, both of the United States and of several States, and ferns, palms, and other potted plants were provided in profusion from the conservatory.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 8. -- Princeton defeated Lehigh's crippled eleven by a score of 12 to 0 here yesterday. Princeton scored her points in the first half, neither side scoring in the second. When the Lohigh team appeared on the field it could easily be seen that the men were in a crippled condition. Ordway, the Captain and half back of the eleven, was missing.

With the ninth volume Mr. William Aldis Wright finishes his new edition of the Cambridge Shakespeare, (Macmillan Co.,) one of the best of all the critical editions for the purposes of most students; in fact, the best, with the exception of our own new "variorium" -- Mr. Furness's "monumental volumes," as Mr. Wright calls them.
There was a large congregation at the Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church last night to hear the pastor, the Rev. Mr. Byrnes, preach on "The Brooklyn Ring and the Proposed International Prize Fight."

The Bethesda, or, as it is bettor known, the People's Church, a branch of the Central Congregational Church of Brooklyn, at Ralph Avenue and Chauncey Street, was crowded to the doors last night with an audience eager to hear the Rev. Charles Herald, the pastor, discourse upon, "Which Wins?"

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8. -- On the basis of the developments during the last week, the adherents of Princeton have many reasons to feel encouraged at her prospects in football during the coming series. Two years ago Princeton lacked material to make a successful career; last year the supply of material was more ample, but it was too green to be brought to maturity by the training of one Fall.

The Republicans of Iowa nominated for Governor FRANK D. JACKSON, and at the beginning of the campaign now in progress he undertook to excite the partisan activity of sympathizing voters and the prejudice of veteran soldiers by the customary Republican rant about pensions and the pension policy of the present Administration.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your editorial in this morning's issue regarding Maynard meets my views to a dot. I have been determined all along as to my vote in case Maynard should be nominated. I am a Democrat to my backbone, and I know of nothing more un-Democratic than the methods employed to nominate that man.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 -- Yale has fairly entered upon her one hundred and ninety-fourth year. The last department of the university opened last Thursday, and now the machinery of the entire institution is in motion. The art and medical departments opened during the week. In the former about 35 students will take exclusively art courses this year, but over 200 will work in the department from other branches of the university.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Harvard College began Sept. 28 the two hundred and fifty-eighth year of its history. So far as can be ascertained, there has been a growth in all departments of the university, especially in the graduate school of the college and in the Lawrence Scientific School, but until the preliminary directory of students is issued next week it will be impossible correctly to state the facts and figures regarding the increase.
The sixtieth anniversary of the dedication of St. Nicholas Church, at 125 Second Street, was celebrated yesterday.

BUFFALO, Oct. 8. -- The Fourth Assembly District of Erie County is the only Republican one in the city. When Mr. Sheehan redistricted the city, a year or so ago, he bunched all the Republican wards together, and thus got rid of a lot of work during campaigns.

It must be gratifying to Gen. Cesnola and the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and other delvers into antiquarian research that the love for their specialty has at length penetrated into the profane precincts of Wall Street, hitherto devoted only to the practical everyday affairs of the world, and too little given to the ennobling influences of historical studies.
The money market showed little change in the course of the week. Call loans were made at 2@4 cent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- The Herald to-day prints the following:

The Rev. John Coleman Adams, pastor of All Souls' Universalist Church, South Ninth Street, Brooklyn, preached a sermon yes- terday morning in which he strongly ar- raigned Brooklyn's political ring and warmly praised The New-York Times, both for its exposures of "machine" methods and for its crusade against the impending international prize fight.

The mechanical course of the college was founded four years ago, and from its very commencement more students chose this practical course in preference to either the courses of science or classics. This is the first time there has been a senior class in the mechanical course. The class this year has crowded the workshop far beyond its capacity, so that it will necessitate the building of an extension in the near future.
Richard Cooper, colored, was charged in Jefferson Market yesterday with having brutally treated Willle Mitchell, a colored boy, four years old.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 7. -- The preparations for the centennial celebration at Williams are now completed. Nearly all of the buildings will be decorated, but principally West College, the library, the gymnasium, and Morgan and Hopkins Halls. More than fifty extra street lamps have been placed about the town, and Chinese lanterns will be hung in the trees on Monday and Tuesday evenings.

The Rev. Dr. Edwin Homer Wellman of the Church of the Atonement, Fifth Ave- nue and Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, last night poured hot shot into the prize fight- ers and their sponsors, the officials of Kings County. The doctor pointed to the object lesson furnished by The New-York Times in the printed list of fatal prize fights which was recently published, and appealed to his listeners to aid in the fight against such shameful spectacles.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8 -- The work on the interior of Alexander Hall has been advancing steadily during the Summer vacation, and the entire structure will probably be ready for occupancy by the present senior class at the time of their graduation. The exterior of the building is completed, while in the interior six men are engaged on the mosaic finishing in connection with the rostrum.

No nomination for a State office in recent years has been more generally commended in this city than that made by the Demo- crats at Saratoga when they placed Cord Meyer, Jr., upon their ticket as candidate for Secretary or State. Although not yet forty years old, Mr. Meyer has been well known both in business and politics for fifteen years.

Closure, or (French) cloture, is a term used in legislative parlance, and means a system of rules designed, with a due re- gard for preservation of freedom of debate and of the rights both of majorities and minorities, to provide for the closing of de- bate in deliberative assemblies.

BELLWOOD, Penn., Oct. 8. -- Quite a lively fight is on between the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and this little borough. The borough has been laying a water-pipe line into the town and through the streets, and the work is about complete, with the exception of making the connecting link under the tracks of the railroad.

The frequency with which speed trials of our new war vessels are nowadays held suggests that the steel fleet available for service is becoming rapidly reinforced. If a naval review like last April's were to come off next year the American contingent for it would be surprisingly increased in numbers and power.
MADRID, Oct. 8. -- The cable to Melilla has been repaired and dispatches of the most serious import have been arriving here since 10:30 o'clock this morning.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- The coming session of the Reichstag promises to test the firmness of Caprivi's position more than did the last one. One strong influence against the Government is the opposition to Dr. Miquel's scheme for the taxation of tobacco and wines. This may be enough to upset the whole project of financial reform.
Five cents is not much; yesterday's Times, which anybody could buy for that amount, most decidedly was, and in a score of ways.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The United States Geological Survey has been doing some important work in New-York State this Summer. The thirteen parties which were sent from Washington are still in the field, but will soon close out their work.

HAMBURG, Oct. 8. -- Prince Bismarck's special train reached Friedrichsruhe at 11:07 o'clock last night, a few minutes behind the scheduled time. Bismarck had hardly felt the fatigue of the journey, and, as he stepped on the platform, was apparently in better spirits than at any previous time since the beginning of his illness.

Nothing could show more clearly how the financial position in the United States is dom- inated by the silver question than the improve- ment in the tone of business and in the price of securities which followed immediately upon the publication of President Cleveland's letter to Gov. Northen. There is practically nothing in the letter which the President has not said more than once before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The United States Geological Survey has been doing some important work in New-York State this Summer. The thirteen parties which were sent from Washington are still in the field, but will soon close out their work.

HAMBURG, Oct. 8. -- Prince Bismarck's special train reached Friedrichsruhe at 11:07 o'clock last night, a few minutes behind the scheduled time. Bismarck had hardly felt the fatigue of the journey, and, as he stepped on the platform, was apparently in better spirits than at any previous time since the beginning of his illness.

CORNING, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The arrest of Charles T. Andrews, editor of The Seneca County Courier, Clinton M. Stahl of The Waterloo Observer, and Thomas P. Hanse of The Farmers' Village Reunion, has caused intense excitement in Seneca County.

The Rev. Nathan Hubbell, D.D., of the Wesley Methodist Episcopal Church Eastern Parkway and Berriman Street, in the Twenty-sixth Ward of Brooklyn, delivered yesterday morning a most scorching dis- course denunciatory of the public officials who have laid their plans for Charles Mitchell and James J. Corbett to engage in the alleged "scientific contest" for the pugilistic championship of the world and a purse of $40,000 at Coney Island in December.

We commend to the Senators at Washington a careful reading of an article reciting the history of closure which they will find on the first page of THE TIMES this morning. No parliamentary utterance could be more straightforward, business-like, and sensible than the brief statement with which the Speaker of the House of Commons prefaced his patting of the main question on the morning of Feb. 3, 1881.
POTTSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 8. -- The Philadelphia Bridge Works, which have been idle, will start up to-morrow on double turn, contracts having been received to keep them busy for some time.

This morning The New-York Daily Times consists of TEN PAGES. Every newsdealer is bound to deliver the paper in its complete form, and any failure to do so should be reported at the Publication Office.

Sir Richard Webster, the eminent English barrister, Chairman of the British Commissioners to the World's Fair, is stopping at the Windsor Hotel. He is on his way home from Chicago and will sail next Wednesday.

FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 8. -- The trouble in the Presbyterian Church, which started through a sermon on "The Tongue" preached by the pastor, the Rev. John Hutchinson, has resulted in the latter's resignation. The pastor, in his letter to the church Trustees, says he believes his departure will prove a means of advancing the cause of religion in the village.

It cannot be said that the men who controlled the action of the Saratoga Convention defied the respectable sentiment of the State or misrepresented the will of the Democratic Party except in the single matter of forcing the nomination of MAYNARD for Judge of the Court of Appeals. Apart from that act the spirit of concession and conciliation was displayed and an effort was made toward harmonizing the party in the State.

It was difficult to decide whether the heat or the enthusiasm was the more noticeable at Harrigan's Theatre last evening. As neither affected the other the problem may as well be left unsolved. This will have two good effects -- the avoidance of a tiresome treatise on ventilation and the giving of more attention to "The Woollen Stocking," which is, after all, the subject of these lines.
Frank Ellison has been sentenced. He is to serve in Sing Sing at hard labor for five years, with the usual commutation for good behavior.

A season of grand opera in Italian was opened at the Garden Theatre last night. The director and musical conductor of this season is Gustave Hinrichs, an earnest, industrious, and energetic musician, who has made a good reputation by catering to the taste of the public in other cities. It may be said at the outset that the performance last evening was uncommonly good for one offered at low prices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Seven hundred thousand persons, said to be the greatest crowd ever congregated, visited the World's Fair to-day, breaking the greatest one-day record at Paris by many thousand, surpassing the "big day" figures of any other exposition ever held, and establishing a mark which it is safe to predict the present generation will never see attained again.
The work of arranging the city's financial budget for 1894 was taken up yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.
Sol Smith Russell appeared in Edward E. Kidder's play, "Peaceful Valley," at Daly's Theatre last night.

The New-York Churchman's Association had a meeting and luncheon at Clark's, in Twenty-third Street, yesterday afternoon. The principal event of the meeting was the reading of a paper by Bishop Potter, entitled "Intellectual Culture as a Source of Power in the Ministry."

The Democratic Second Judicial District Convention will be held at noon to-day, in the Kings County Court House, to nominate a candidate to succeed Judge Barnard. Thomas E. Pearsall, City Judge Van Wyck, and Corporation Counsel Jenks are aspirants for the nomination. Mr. Pearsall says his services as Chairman of the Democratic General Committee entitle him to the nomination.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 9. -- Three thousand more miners have struck in Charieroi. Troops are patrolling the whole strike district, in order to protect property.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- That the United States is to have Francis H. Weeks, the New-York defaulter, given into its custody was the news contained in a cable message received by the Secretary of State to-day from Mr. Baker, the United States Minister to Costa Rica, but whether this information is based on a formal promise from the Costa Rican Government, State Department officials will not admit.

The Coney Island Athletic Club officials are still defiantly claiming that the proposed international battle between Charles Mitchell and James J. Corbett is not to be a prize fight, but merely "a scientific boxing contest for points." Ignoring the sentiment of the clergymen and all other decent citizens of Brooklyn, these men are going ahead with their arrangements for the fight.

The "Big Four" organization in the Republican Party is officially dissolved. The firm name no more consists of Platt, Miller, Depew, and Hiscock. An intimation to this effect was made public last week at Syracuse, when the Republicans held their State Convention and when the picture and the boots of Frank Hiscock, ex-United States Senator, were turned to the wall.

Last Saturday evening Paul Latzke, a reporter for The New-York Times, went to the Casino to learn whether Messrs. Roseborn, Rosenfeld, and Rosenbaum, the flowery trio who bloom in the box office of that unlucky temple or the drama, had accumulated the necessary funds to pay their musicians, pay their rent, and make such further payments as should be necessary preliminary to opening the doors of their theatre this week.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 9. -- Mr. Jackson has proposed to withdraw from the head of Iowa's Republican ticket. He informed certain Republicans who called upon him here yesterday that he had told the State Committee the whole story of his disbarment and announced his willingness to retire if the committee desired him to do so or believed his candidacy would lead to defeat or his withdrawal would save the ticket.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- With the present year the outlook for a prosperous football season is unusually gloomy. Early last Spring it was known that but few of the old players would return, and from time to time even this number has been diminished till by the 1st of September only Young. White, and Curtis of last year's team had returned.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 9. -- Charles Swinson, seventeen years old, a rider employed on the nursery stock farm of August Belmont, at North Babylon, was shot and instantly killed by Dennis Sullivan, a fellowrider, at noon to-day. Sullivan protests the shooting was accidental. He says they were in their bedroom and were cleaning their revolvers.

At the last meeting of the Department of Public Parks plans were adopted for the construction of the new speedway, to be built along the banks of the Harlem River, as far north as High Bridge. Commissioner Dana protested against the plans, because they provide for but one sidewalk along the speedway, and that upon the inside, away from the river bank.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Daily News, referring to the second race for the America's Cup, says:

It is a gratifying thing that, after a failure and a race that was inconclusive by reason of the lightness and the fickleness of the breeze, the second nominal and the first real race for the America's Cup should have been sailed under conditions that made it an entirely conclusive test, so far as it went; and it went very far.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In The London Spectator of Sept. 9 there is a communication addressed to the editor with the title "Anti-Semitism." "Y" writes that he has received "a remarkable quotation" from the Talmud. This last is so exceedingly strange that I shall be much indebted to any one of your readers who understands Hebrew and can consult the original who will verify it and describe the context.

"You are going to see a yacht race today," said the knowing chaps as The Times's tug poked her nose through the Narrows. That was at 8:45 A.M. There was a brisk wind from west southwest, and the glass was falling. It was a bright morning with a touch of rawness in the air and a light haze on the horizon.
The only sale of real estate at auction announced for yesterday, that of 324 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, by James L. Wells, was adjourned for a week.
CINCINNATI, Ohio. Oct. 9. -- Alarming reports concerning their missionaries in Persia have come to the Presbyterians here.

Ferdinand Ward, who nine years ago achieved meteoric and unenviable distinction, as a "young Napoleon of finance," when he wrecked the banking firm of Grant Ward, announces that he is compiling a book to vindicate himself and leave an untarnished record to posterity.

The World's Congress Auxiliary of the World's Columbian Exposition has arranged for an international congress of persons interested in fisheries and fish, culture, to convene in Chicago Oct. 16 and continue five days. The deliberations of this congress will cover a wide range of subjects relating to fisheries, fishery laws and kindred subjects.

"Beimath," (Fome) a drama in four acts by Hermann Sudermann, was produced last evening at the Irving Place Theatre before a good house. The heroine of the plot, which is laid in a German provincial town, is Magda, the daughter of Col. Schwartze, a retired officer and strict home disciplinarian. She leaves home because she cannot get along with her stepmother, and will not marry Pastor Heffterdingk, her father's choice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Under all the discussion that has been heard around the halls of the Senate to-day, while the repeal bill was before that excessively deliberate body, there were more suggestions for compromise. The silver men, as the opportunity for repeal approaches are more delighted than ever with suggestions and they are less composed as they consider the chances for repeal.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Oct. 9 -- P.M. The stock market was stronger to-day, and at the opening the general tendency was decidedly toward better prices. Before noon there was somewhat of a lull, and in the afternoon Louisville and Nashville was weak, declining to 46 1/4 and closing at 46 3/4, or 2 3/4 points below the last quotation on Saturday.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 9. -- There was a gathering of former Republicans at Donnell's Boulevard Hotel and Park to-day. The Logan Club of the Third Assembly District, New-York, was on its ninth annual outing. The members ran races, played football and baseball, jumped, swam, sang, and danced until 6 o'clock, when they sat down to dinner and listened to speeches.
Emma Goldman, Anarchist, has been found guilty of violating the laws which she so thoroughly despises.

G.L. Watson, who designed the Valkyrie, and who had, during yesterday's race, a prolonged view of the stern of the Morgan-Iselin centreboarder, from the deck of his own creation, was seen after the contest was over. He was asked what he thought about it. The reply was brief, and to the point.

In spite of repeated disappointments, the friends of the project to transfer the Revenue Cutter Service from the Treasury to the Navy Department have renewed their efforts at the present session of Congress, and hope for success. They believe that a combined recommendation on the subject from Secretary CARLISLE and Secretary HERBERT would carry much weight with Congress.

When the Vigilant, at 2:50 yesterday afternoon tore across the imaginary line between the flagship May and the Sandy Hook Lightship and added one more to the ong list of American triumphs the scene was one which can never be forgotten by those who saw it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The controversy over the turrets for ships of war is not yet settled, although it has been so quietly carried on that many have supposed the matter was being allowed to rest. The old question was whether the Bureau of Construction or the Bureau of Ordnance should design and build the turrets of battle ships.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- Monday, Oct. 16, will be the one hundred and sixteenth anniversary of the burning of Kingston, the then capital of the State of New-York, by the British under Major Gen. John Vaughan. The Wiltwyck Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, has prepared a programme for the suitable observance of the day, which will close with commemorative public exercises at the State Armory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Barring the spluttering rhetorical fireworks indulged in by Mr. Dolliver, Mr. Boutelle, and Mr. Payne, Republicans of the unquenchable sort, who never get along quite happily unless they can have a bloody shirt in their minds' eye to inspire them, the debate on the Federal Elections bill in the House closed to-day very tranquilly.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 9. -- The St. Paul News, which to-day became a member of the United Press, and began to receive the full leased-wire report, says editorially:

The local campaign began to boom along yesterday. Almost all of the local conventions, with the exception of the Tammany City and County Convention, will be held this week. The Democrats generally seem to believe that there is no doubt but that the State ticket will be elected. When asked as to its prospects last night, Richard Croker said:

The unusual competition did not materially affect the success of the beginning of Richard Mansfield's engagement at Herrmann's Theatre last night. The house was crowded by a fashionable and appreciative audience, and Mr. Mansfield's exquisite embodiment of the late Georgian "glass of fashion and mold of form" was found to have all its old vitality, humor, and grace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The opening day of the October term of the Supreme Court of the United States attracted an unusually large and notable attendance of counsel and visitors. The Senatorial contingent within the bar included Lindsay of Kentucky, Davis of Minnesota, Hawley of Connecticut, and Palmer of Illinois.

At the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union, held last evening in the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, the members of the organization and the teachers in their charge were urged to do all in their power to stop the projected international prize fight. Secretary Henry E. Drake read his annual report, in which he said:

HARRISON, Ark., Oct. 9. -- The Boone County (Ark.) Fair opened here to-day. Gov. William Fishback entertained an audience of 5,000 people this afternoon with the first speech of the campaign. The Governor is a candidate for United States Senator, and advocated a change in the Constitution, making Senators elective by direct vote of the people.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The Prince of Wales opened to-day the new gallery of fine arts in the South London Library. The purpose of those interested in the gallery has been to afford the laboring classes an opportunity to see the works of the best old and modern masters.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- The market opened to-day with more life on hopes of something favorable from Washington. Money loaned at 3@2 1/2 cent., mostly at 2 1/2 cent., Boston at present being the centre of cheapest money in the country. Banks are buying paper at 6 cent. Circulation in the last month has increased $21,377,247.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Representative Dockery, Chairman of the joint Congressional commission to inquire into the status of the laws organizing the executive departments, , has submitted a report.

The committees representing the various political organizations of Brooklyn met last night at the instance of a conference committee of ten, appointed by the Committee of One Hundred, with a view of uniting upon an independent candidate for Mayor. The committee adopted a resolution to support the candidate nominated by the Republican Party, provided he be a man worthy the support of intelligent voters.

RECENT ENGAGEMENTS. -- An interesting engagement announcement just made was that of Miss Elizabeth Elkins to Edward E. Bruner of this city. Miss Elkins is the daughter of Stephen B. Elkins, ex-Secretary of War. Mr. Bruner is a broker in this city, living in West Fifty-eighth Street. Miss Elkins is at present at her home, in West Virginia. No date has been set for the wedding, but it will doubtless take place early in November.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- W.I. Buchanan, Chief of the Department of Agriculture, and W. E. Curtis, late Director of the Bureau of American Republics, have organized the Pan-American Company, to give a permanent Latin-American commercial exhibit in New-York City. Interested with them are William Harper, late general manager of the Australasian Publishing Company, and a number of New-York capitalists.

The guests of the New-York Yacht Club were not surprises when the Vigilant won the race. Wish them the outcome was a foregone conclusion, and they showed little enthusiasm when the Vigilant passed between the May and the Sandy Hook Lightship twelve minutes ahead of the English contestant for the America's Cup.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The market has been quiet and steady in tone. Philadelphia Traction rights made a sharp advance to 14 1/2 and the stock sold at 67 1/2, ex-rights. An attack made on the property by a newspaper had no effect. It is semi-officially stated that Metropolitan Traction will begin dividends by Jan. 1, and that the earnings from the cable line are sufficient to pay 4 cent. on the total stock.

CONEY ISLAND, Oct. 9. -- In a building owned by Chief of Police John Y. McKane, in the county in which Sheriff John Courtney is sworn to enforce the law, and with the undisguised sanction of Justice of the Peace R.V.B. Newton, the law of the State of New-York was violated to-night under the auspices of the Coney Island Athletic Club.
