Some facts have recently come to light in Connecticut which indicate that lobbyists in that State no longer look to corporations and individuals exclusively for profitable employment, but procure a considerable part of their incomes from town governments and are even able to number city Boards of Education among their clients.

Lest any one should cherish a lingering idea that the accounts printed in The New-York Times of the brutal character of the prize fights before the Coney Island Athletic Club and the outrageous defiance of law by them have been in any degree overdrawn or highly colored, the detailed report, by rounds, of the lights last night sent out by the United Press is given in full herewith.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 9. -- At a large and representative meeting of business men held here to-day resolutions were adopted expressing the belief that the alarming condition of the country arises from the operation of the Sherman Silver act. The resolutions adopted were:

Two hundred Methodist clergymen met in the Methodist Missionary, Southey's Building, Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street, yesterday morning, aud appointed a committee to investigate the charge that Kings County officials are not only countenancing but actively interested in the proposed international prize fight.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The Mayors of the larger towns in the district affected by the coal strike met in Sheffield to-day to consider means of settling the dispute between the miners and the mine owners. The Mayor of Sheffield, who presided, suggested that delegates of the masters and of the workingmen confer and try to arrive at a settlement before the Mayors' proposition should be announced.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The Australians have had their revenge, and the second game between the famous Antipodeans and Gentlemen of Philadelphia has gone to the visitors by 6 wickets. The result of the match, of course was a foregone conclusion on Staurday night, but the Australians strained every nerve to-day to gain the victory without the loss of a wicket, while the Philadelphians strove just as hard to lower one.
ELMIRA, Oct. 9. -- At the fourth day's session of the Reformatory Investigating Committee witnesses for the prosecution were heard.

Bloomingdale Brothers' great store, Fifty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, was crowded yesterday from an early hour in the day until late in the evening on the occasion of their first Fall opening. The stock of goods offered for sale in all the departments was more, varied and attractive than on any previous year, and the 2,300 clerks employed by the firm were kept busy during the entire day.
Wheat was rather unsettled, and closed at a loss of 1/4c, as influenced, by lower cables and weaker West, with a light trade as awaiting the Government report.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 10. -- A meeting of merchants, manufacturers, and business men of this city and county was held at the City Hall last evening to consider the action of the United States Senate in regard to the reveal of the Sherman bill. Speeches in favor or the repeal were made by Frank O. Cole, John A. Walker, Joseph A. Dean, and Dr. Leonard J. Gordon.

Disgusted and incensed by the apathy on one side, of prominent Kings County officials, and on the other by the openly-expressed sympathy with prize fighting and lawbreaking avowed by the Sheriff and the Police Justices of the city and county, the civilized citizens of Brooklyn have resolved to be heard by the highest functionary of the State -- its Governor.

The question of the part-treatment of the new speedway is one of considerable importance. The same topographical conditions that by securing this river shore from commercial uses make it a good place for a speedway make it also a very available place for a public promenade. As soon as it is opened to the drivers of horses it is sure to be frequented by the pedestrian public.

Judging by the rate at which Clearing House certificates have lately been retired, there will be none outstanding by the end of the month. Yesterday's retirements amounted to $1,680,000, leaving $15,020,000 outstanding, and notice was given of the retirement of $1,800,000 to-day. The maximum amount at any time out was $38,280,000 on Aug. 29.

"The Corncracker," a new dramatic piece that combines farce, burlesque, and melodrama, was produced at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night. The author is Joseph Arthur, who made "The Still Alarm" and "Blue Jeans." The new piece is in four acts, and the scene in three of these is laid in Indiana on the line that separates the Hoosiers from the Corncrackers of Kentucky.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The October returns to the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture make the general condition of corn 75.1, against 76.7 for last month and 79.8 for October, 1892. This falling off in condition is the result of the continued drought which has prevailed since June and was not broken in the corn belt until the latter end of September.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Brig. Gen. Joseph C. Breckinridge, Inspector General of the United States Army, has made a report to the Secretary of War indicating a condition of affairs prevailing in regard to our coast defenses which is officially characterized as "disgraceful." It is shown that almost the entire Southern coast on the Atlantic seaboard is absolutely unprotected and at the mercy of a foreign foe.

Ernest Hart, editor of The British Medical Journal, talked to the Section in Public Health of the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street, last evening about "Quarantine: Its Mischiefs, Merits, and Mistakes." For half a century he has devoted much of his time to the study of the subject, and judging from his remarks there is little that can be said in praise of the system, which he claims is not effective.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10. -- The Judicial Convention of the First Circuit to-day nominated by acclamation Henry Page of Somerset County for Chief Judge and Henry Lloyd of Dorchester County for Associate Judge. This result came of a compromise effected after 5,782 ballots had been taken.
An exhibition of the Robins life guard and safety fender for electric and cable street cars was given yesterday on the Fifth Avenue street railway near Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.
What at first looked like a murder, but which, on investigation, appeared to be an accident, caused much commotion in and about Mulberry Bend yesterday.

Levi Samuels was yesterday appointed receiver for the L. C. Wise Company, dealers in boots and shoes, at 396 Broadway and 206 Canal Street. The appointment was made by Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, upon the application of David L. Wise, Marcus Wise, Charles Cartier, and Simon Goldenberg.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., Oct. 10. -- The failure of J.S. McCaleb, who conducted banks in Uniontown and Connellsville, is found to be more serious than was at first supposed. His assets amount to about $75,000, while the liabilities will reach, if not exceed, $173,000. A great many of the Hungarian and Italian coke workers had deposited their savings in McCaleb's banks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The October report of the Statistical Division of the Department of Agriculture makes cotton show a decline of 2.7 points from the September condition, which was 73.4, as against 70.7 for this month. The condition of cotton in the month of June was 85.6, declining to 82.7 in July, and to 80.4 in August, losing from that time to the present 9.7 points.

There was a large home wedding in Brooklyn last evening when Miss Flora McKeon, daughter of John S. McKeon of 587 Bedford Avenue, and Frank Fifield Healey were married. The Rev. Dr. McCullagh of Worcester, Mass., performed the ceremony at the McKeon house at 8 o'clock.

One of the most interesting things about a yacht race is the crowd that go to see it. These go on excursion boats principally. Private yachts are not at their command. Neither are invitations aboard them. A typical crowd of sightseers was that which, on Monday, went down New-York Harbor to see a yacht race and remained there to see a procession.

The work of making up the provisional estimate of the budget of 1894 wag continued yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the Mayor's office, the interesting feature of the day's business being the Street Cleaning Department's estimates for next year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Six persons were fatally injured yesterday, and many were seriously hurt in the crowds incident to the celebration of Chicago Day at the fair. The lists of dead and injured are as follows:

The Australian cricketers will start the fourth match of their American tour with an eighteen representing Massachusetts at Boston to-day. The visitors took the 5.30 Fall River boat last night from New-York, and it is expected that an early start will be made to-day so that the match can be finished on Thursday. The Massachusetts team will be one of the strongest that ever took the field in Boston.
Thomas E. Pearsall, Chairman of the Kings County Democratic General Committee, was nominated yesterday by his party for Justice of the Supreme Court, to succeed Justice J.F. Barnard.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Oct. 10 -- P.M. Weakness prevailed in the last hour of trading on the Stock Exchange to-day, and at the close prices were generally at their lowest point. In the morning a good deal of strength had been displayed, but the afternoon brought rumors of a possible compromise on silver to depress the market, while in two or three stocks there were glumps, accompanying reports of an impending receivership.

The loan market has been a matter of much interest to real estate men for two months or more. When the life insurance companies announced a 6 per cent. rate for realty loans it served as an example to others to do the same, or else to try to do so. Such a position, however, was not tenable, for obvious reasons, for any protracted period.

Two burglars roamed for several hours Friday night and Saturday morning through the large five-story building at 145 Elm Street. They broke into eight offices, but secured little booty for their pains.

It has been decreed by the sophomores of Columbia College School of Arts that the freshmen in that department shall not be permitted to carry canes. The decree was only reached by the winning at William's Bridge yesterday afternoon of the severest cane rush Columbia has ever seen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Democrats swarmed into Washington by every train that arrived yesterday, and there were 150 of them in the House caucus that decided, upon the amicable consideration of the Tucker and Fitch bills, to support that reported by Mr. Tucker. When the House met this morning the attendance of Democrats was very large.

RONDOUT, Oct. 10. -- The Ulster County Republican Convention met in this city at noon to-day and nominated for Coroner Dr. Warren Kemble of Saugerties and for Justice of the Sessions Aaron B. Frost of War-warsing.

BUFFALO, Oct. 10. -- Frank N. Loomis, who is a prominent Democrat and a civil service reformer widely known throughout the State, has bolted the nomination of Judge Maynard. He said to-night to The New-York Times's correspondent:

VIENNA, Oct. 10. -- The Reichsrath reopened to-day. In the lower house, Dr. Steinbach, Minister of Finance, presented the budget for 1894. The estimated surplus shown in the budget is 411,542 florins. The revenues and expenditures both show a material increase, the most notable item in the expenditures being an increase of 986,617 florins for national defenses.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 10. -- A meeting of representatives of the churches of this city was held at the Second Presbyterian Church this evening to form, a Moral Reform Society with a view to exerting an influence on the coming election. There were representatives from the Baptist, Methodist, Reformed, Congregational, and Presbyterian.

The Citizens' Union of Brooklyn is going ahead with its plans for a mass meeting tomorrow night in the Academy of Music, to nominate William J. Gaynor for Mayor, if he will accept. In its call for the meeting, the Citizens' Union is joined by the Brooklyn Democratic Club, Young Men's Democratic Club, United German Democracy, and Consolidation League.

Pursuant to the programme published exclusively in yesterday's New-York Times, the Republican State Committee met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday and re-elected William Brookfield Chairman. He appointed an Executive Committee, which chose Charles W. Hackett Chairman, and appointed an Advisory Committee of three, consisting of Thomas C. Platt, Chauncey M. Depew, and Warner Miller.

Henry Haulett, an Alsacian hatmaker, living at 124 West Thirty-first Street, attempted to kill his wife, Rosie, yesterday morning by shooting her. Haulett was jealous of his wife, and before going to work he stopped her in the basement and asked her if she did not love him any more. Rosie replied that she would not if he kept on acting as he did.
BUFFALO, Oct. 10. -- The last of the Democratic conventions -- seven of them -- were held to-day.

Evelyn Granville Webster, the commonlaw wife of Burton C. Webster, was a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Police Court charged with assault, drunkenness, disorderly conduct, and culpable neglect of her infant child, Burton C. Webster, Jr. Her husband is now serving a twenty years' sentence in Sing Sing Prison for killing Charles E. Goodwin in the Percival flats for an alleged insult to her.

Assistant Deputy Controller D. Lowber Smith died yesterday, after an illness of nearly three weeks. Mr. Smith lived with his wife and family at 62 West Eighty-third Street. He had not been out of his house since Sept. 29, when he attended a meeting of the Panama Railroad Directors. A little over a week ago he was attacked with typhoid faver.

Race horses do not seem to be in great demand just at present. Racing has received such a black eye during the past season that there is little demand for animals for gambling purposes, particularly in the face of the revolt against the track gamblers in New-Jersey. William Easton sold a number of cast-offs from Pierre Lorillard's stable and three of the horses brought over here by Col. North.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 10. -- Now that the Democratic and Republican Campaign Committees have their headquarters open and ready for business. It is possible to say with some certainty what the issues will be in Iowa this year and what direction the campaign will take.

The Bar Association of the City of New-York at a meeting last night passed resolutions denouncing the nomination of Judge Isaac H. Maynard for the Court of Appeals, and one resolution was even offered, and found many supporters, that some action should be taken to procure the indictment and trial of Judge Maynard for the offense which has raised so great a commotion about his head.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 10. -- Considerable mystery surrounds the reported important gold discovery in the State of Hidalgo, near Zimapan. Several large capitalists of this city are interested, and have had experienced prospectors all through the region where gold is said to have been found. It is generally believed that the discovery is one of much importance.

After an exciting game of ten innings the Brooklyns won from the New-Yorks at Eastern Park yesterday, and are now on even terms with the Giants for the metropolitan championship. It was a pretty game throughout, with the exception of a stupid piece of fielding by Stafford in the tenth inning that allowed the Brooklyns to tally the winning run.

A complaint has been filed in the County Clerk's office by Mrs. Adeleine Williams, in which she charges her stepmother, Mrs. Naomi Duncombe, with having so unduly influenced the complinant's father, Alfred R. Duncombe, as to cause him to make over all his property to his wife, and to turn his daughter out of her home.

Dr. Wilhelm Bode, Director of the Konigl Museen at Charlottenburg, and Privy Councilor in the learned acquisitions of masterpieces of art by which the Prussian Government is rapidly gaining for its capital an elevated place, returned to Bremen by the German line steamer Spree yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Little or no business was done to-day in any department on Change. Prices were generaly steady.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Members of the New-Jersey Kennel League have decided to hold a kennel show in Machinery Hall Thanksgiving Day. One thousand entries will be made, it is thought. Prizes are offered by clubs all over the United States. The New-Jersey Kennel League will give $2,000 in prizes for the best in all classes.

The funeral of Mary Rogers Rhinelander, widow of Lispenard Stewart, took place from Grace Church yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock. There was not a vacant pew in the imposing edifice, when the plain black casket was carried in on the shoulders of four stalwart employes of the Rhinelsnder estate.

Play in the international chess tournament was resumed at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday when Lasker beat Pillsbury in one of the finest games played in modern times. The Bostonian tried very hard to prevent a victory, but the Teut on fairly outplayed him in the end game by one of the most brilliant combinations seen over the board.

The number of qualified voter a registered in thin city yesterday, the first day of registration for the coming election, was 68,920, which was 23,774 less than the number registered on the first day last year.

Joseph Dockery, seventeen years old, of 523 East One Hundred and Fifty-first Street, was accidentally shot and instantly killed by Charles Allen, sixteen years old, of 614 East One Hundred and Fiftieth Street, yesterday afternoon. The shooting occurred in the cigar-box factory of W.E. Uptegood Co., at One Hundred and Fifty-first Street and River Avenue.

Policeman Edward Fitzgibbons walked into the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday covered with cuts and bruises, and his uniform showed the effects of a struggle that by the merest accident did not end fatally. With him were four prisoners, who were also badly battered.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- On account of the action of the Kings County politicians in taking the Democratic nomination of a successor to Judge Barnard away from Dutchess County, there is talk of a combination of the country Democrats with the Republicans to elevate Robert F. Wilkinson to the bench.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 10. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention of the Twentieth District reassembled this afternoon and proceeded to ballot for Senator. After 255 ballots without a choice, the convention adjourned till 11 o'clock to-morrow morning.

The new building of the New-York Pasteur Institute. West Central Park and Ninety-seventh Street, was formally opened Monday night. Prof. Ogden R. Doremus, Chairman of the Reception Committee, delivered the address of welcome. Dr. Paul Gibler delivered the inaugural address.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Point Breeze started its Fall meeting to-day with a fair attendance and good track. Every heat winner except Sleepy Ned had to lower their records.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 10. -- While Joseph Healy, Daniel Ritchie, and David Wansor, assistants to J.V. Baldwin, the village blacksmith, were at work yesterday morning, a black bear walked quietly into the shop. The men gave one look and fled. The fleeing trio found Seaman Hall and Andrew J. Thomas, local crack shots, and, with several other persons and Ritchie's hunting dog Pete, returned to the blacksmith's shop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- On the eve of the final struggle for repeal the silver men are unquestionably anxious. Their state of mind was well illustrated this morning by the tiresome Stewart of Nevada, who petulantly asked Mr. McPherson of New-Jersey, at the conclusion of the latter's speech in favor of repeal, if he meant to say that the minority had resorted to obstructive tactics.
Money on call loaned at 2@2 1/2 P cent. The last loan was made at 2 P cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- In undertaking to reform the civil service of the country, one of the most important questions to be considered by the Democratic party has been the methods in vogue, which have repeatedly been admitted to be cumbersome and obstructed by a multiplication of checks and safeguards that in many instances have been added for no better object than to increase the number of employes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A motion was entered in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day which may occasion a delay in the settlement of what is known as the North Dakota elevator case -- Norman E. Brass vs. the State of North Dakota. The case was submitted at the last term of court and an early decision at this term had been anticipated.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 10. -- The last outings of the season were held to-day at Witzel's Point View Island. One was the thirty-second annual carnival of sports and clambake of the ex-members of the Shin Fane Club, under the name of the United Association of the Twenty-first Ward, New-York.

Excitement was created among the residents of North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, in the neighborhood of Bedford Avenue, Monday afternoon, by a drove of 200 steers that became unmanageable while being driven from the dock at the foot of the street to the Johnson Avenue slaughter house.

CORNING, Oct. 10. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-seventh District, comprising the counties of Steuben, Chemung, Schuyler, and Seneca, has nominated for Senator Dr. Baxter T. Smelzer of Havana. The convention met in this city Monday. After taking twenty-seven ballots, an adjournment was ordered until this morning.

TOPEKA, Oct. 10. -- The equal suffrage campaign is in full progress in this State, and home talent vies with imported speakers for the privilege, of making converts. The meetings are numerous, but as a rule are not very well attended. At the meetings held in this city at the time of the State Fair, which were addressed by Miss Susan B. Anthony, the largest attendance did not reach 100.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 10. -- The Riverside and Saxon mills, which are affected by the strike of weavers at Olneyville, were closed to-day for an indefinite period, following the course taken in the Providence, National, and Saranac mills, which are controlled by Charles Fletcher. The total number of operatives idle is close upon 6,000.

Laparelle, a stallion which took the first prize at the horse show two years ago, was burned to death yesterday afternoon in a fire which occurred in the Central Park Riding Academy at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The animal was valued at about $2,000.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Federation of Coal Mine Owners, at a meeting in Derby to-day, decided that it was impossible for the masters to acquiesce in the proposition adopted at yesterday's conference of Mayors, that work be resumed at the old wages and that an endeavor be made afterward to settle the dispute.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Traction rights advanced from 14 3/4 at the opening to 16 1/8, with a subsequent decline to 15 3/4. The buying has been largely by outsiders, and several large blocks have been sold by estates and holders who are unable to subscribe. Insiders are talking very bullish, and it is expected that the Fifteenth Street trolley will be running shortly.

The most carious and inexplicable feature of the talk about compromise on the repeal bill, which is naturally renewed with in tenser zeal as the supreme hour of the struggle draws near, is that compromise would inevitably defeat the only possible object for which it is proposed -- Democratic success.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- A dispatch sent from Rio de Janeiro last evening says:

It looks as though the Republicans of Brooklyn were trying to make sure the reelection of Mayor Boody. The flasco of the Committee of One Hundred was a step in that direction. Jacob Worth intends, if possible, to take the other and final step when the Republican City Convention is called together, to name a candidate for the Mayoralty.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The eleventh annual meeting of the Lake Mohonk Indian Conference will be held at Lake Mohonk on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of this week. The present condition of the American Indian will be discussed, as well as methods for improving that race. Many prominent citizens throughout the country attend this conference yearly, and a large attendance is looked for this year.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 10. -- Bon Eden, the country seat of John A. Cisco of New-York at Grymes's Hill, was the scene of a brilliant wedding at high noon to-day. The bride was Miss May Cisco, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cisco, and granddaughter of John Jay Cisco, formerly Assistant United States Treasurer at New-York.

SALEM, Mass., Oct. 10. -- Joseph Chamberlain, M.P., made an additional statement to-day in relation to the cablegram which credited him with making overtures to the Welsh members of Parliament for the defeat of Gladstone and his own election as Premier.

The plain and severe rebuke addressed to the minority Senators by the Exchanges of Memphis was not relished by Senator HARRIS, and he intimated that it did not have the approval of the business men of the city. Thereupon a few of the leading men of this class circulated for signatures a paper "heartily and emphatically indorsing" the resolutions of the Exchanges, which were cited.

The third race of the series for the America's Cup will be sailed to-day. The course will be the same as the first race, fifteen miles to windward or leeward and return. The start will be made from Sandy Hook Lightship or from some point further out, at 11:25 o'clock.

Sixty years ago the Sixteenth Baptist Church was founded in a little frame building in Eighteenth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, with the Rev, David Bernard as pastor. The anniversary was celebrated yesterday at the church in Sixteenth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 10. -- Tschigorin beat Tarrasch to-day in a French defense after forty-three moves.

Dr. William G. Vermilyea, formerly of 127 Barclay Street, Brooklyn, but now of Chicago, has instituted proceedings in that city for divorce from his wife, Eva Viola Vermilyea, of 1,971 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, on grounds of habitual intemperance. The couple were married six years ago, but after living with her husband four years Mrs. Vermilyea left him.

PHOENIXVILLE, Penn., Oct. 10. -- The puddle mill of the Phoenix Iron Company resumed operations this morning, giving employment to a large number of hands, after a long term of idleness. The entire plant of this immense establishment, it is believed, will soon be in operation.

Charles W. Arns, a collector, living at 111 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, complained to Inspector Williams, at Police Headquarters, that, without provocation, he had been assaulted by Ward Detective George P. Baker of the Oak Street Station while watching yacht-race bulletins on Park Row last Thursday afternoon.

WORCESTER, Maas., Oct. 10. -- Persons from nearly all sections of the country are beginning to arrive for the American Board meeting, and the Committee on Entertainment has been kept busy all day assigning visitors to the places provided for them. All the officers have arrived.
Capt. Cranfield of the Valkyrie, when asked about the race, said good naturedly: "We are beaten and admit it; we can't say more than that, can we?"

Jacob M. Patterson and John Sabine Smith had a fine time last night running the Republican County Convention, which was held in Grand Opera. House Hall. T. C. Platt was not in town, so there was no one to prevent their having it all their own way for one night. It was different last week at Syracuse, but that is a story that has been told already.
When the yachts passed out of the bay the wind was northeast, and there were well-defined "mare's tails" in the sky with a cirrous bunch of fleece on the northwestern horizon.

The first steps were taken by the Board of Health yesterday toward the establishment of a clinic for the study of contagious diseases at the hospitals for such diseases in the control of the Health Department. It is proposed to open the hospitals to the medical profession, and It is expected that much, benefit will be derived from the new system.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The Republicans of the Fifteenth Senatorial District, comprising Westchester and Putnam Counties and the Twenty-fourth Ward of New-York, held their convention here to-day.

According to all the correspondents, there is only one compromise that the dealers in that article seem to have any hope of, and that is the proposition to reduce the purchase of silver bullion and continue it for three or four years. No Democrat should be taken in by so cheap and transparent a trick as that.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- There has been a trial of the American-made armor-piercing shot at the Sandy Hook army ordnance proving ground, the report of which is at the War Department. The shells were of eight and ten inch calibre, and were manufactured by the Midvale Steel Company. The type of shell is the Holtzer, the most formidable of the foreign projectiles.

Brooklyn voters who hope to overthrow the rotten Democratic ring in that city this Fall will learn with regret that Mr. GAYNOR adheres to his determination, announced some time ago, not to accept the nomination for Mayor. Of course, the citizens of Brooklyn have no right to complain of Mr. GAYNOR'S decision.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- J.J. Arnold of Lockport, County Treasurer of Niagara County and until yesterday Republican candidate for re-election, was twice arrested yesterday. He was cashier of the broken Merchants' Bank of Lockport.

VIENNA, Oct. 11. -- A band of Circassian brigands attacked a train near Nigoliti, Trans-Caucasia, recently, and killed three guards. The baggage car, which contained a chest of money for the Batoum garrison, was plundered. Several passengers were maltreated and robbed. Four of the brigands are said to have been shot in the fight with the guards, but as the band carried off its dead and wounded, nobody knew just what its loss was.
The Western Union Telegraph Company held its annual meeting yesterday, electing these Directors:

The finding of a circular of the Bowery branch of the Young Men's Christian Association in the cellar of the factory building at 143 Elm Street on Saturday betrayed the burglar who had entered the building and robbed the occupants on the previous night, and finally led to his arrest yesterday afternoon.

The present ballot law of this State will not facilitate the efforts of those independent citizens of Brooklyn who desire to overthrow ring rule in that city and to establish a businesslike administration of its municipal affairs, if they are compelled to nominate a separate ticket to effect their purpose, but it need not prove a serious obstacle, provided the people are sufficiently aroused and in earnest to support them.

Mayor Gilroy. Controller Myers, President McClellan of the Board of Aldermen, Tax Commissioner Barker, and Corporation Counsel Clark, as members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, met yesterday in the Mayor's office to continue the work of making provisional estimates for the coming year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- The long contest between the Lehigh Valley Railroad and its individual operators was terminated to-day by a compromise, the operators accepting Lehigh Valley Goal Company's bonds, guaranteed by the railroad company, in lieu of cash for monthly purchases of coal.

The Democratic State campaign was formally opened yesterday morning at the Hoffman House by the organization of the Executive Committee of the State Committee, which elected Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan Chairman and Charles R. De Freest Secretary. Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., came over from Washington in the expectation of looking after matters, but a dispatch from Senator Hill recalled him, and he started back, on the early morning train.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The sixth annual State Convention of the Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor was began in Taylor's Opera House, in this city, to-day. The theatre was beautifully decorated, and fully 1,500 delegates were present.

John Jacob Aster's unlucky pleasure craft the large steam yacht Nourmahal, added to her list of misfortunes yesterday morning by crashing into the Pennsylvania ferryboat Washington, in the North River. She was hound, with about twenty guests well known in social circles, for the scene of the yacht race when the accident occurred.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Mine owners in South Derbyshire and Leicestershire have accepted the proposals of the Mayors' conference, that the men be taken back at their old wages, and be allowed advances to relieve the pressing needs of their families, both provisions being dependent upon the condition that the men accept a reduction of 10 per cent, in December.

BOSTON, Oct. 11. -- The market opened steady at the decline. New-England was a weak feature. There is a growing demand for good bonds, and offerings of choice lots are few and at advances over lost sales. Money loaned at 2 1/2 per cent. at clearing, and is becoming a drug. Union Pacific improved on better news as to the company's finances and prospects, also on the strike of the employes being settled.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The race for the Cesarewitch Stakes was run to-day at the Newmarket second October meeting. It resulted in a dead heat between Mr. Eills's Red Byes and Mr. T. Jenninss's Cypria, and the purse was divided. Mr. Jersey's Lady Rosebery was third, coming in three lengths behind the winners. The course was two miles, two furlongs, and thirty-five yards. Time-4:02.

The body of a young man with a bullet hole in his head was found in the woods at St. George's Avenue and One Hundred and Ninety-seventh Street yesterday. By his side was a revolver with one chamber empty, and it is believed by the police that he committed suicide. He had in his pocket a bank book showing $35 to the credit of John Persson in the German Savings Bank.

The twenty-ton flywheel employed in driving the dynamos in the power house of the Atlantic Avenue Trolley Railroad Company at Third Avenue and Second Street, Brooklyn, burst at 7:30 o'clock last evening, wrecked the building, crashed through other buildings blocks away, injured several persons, one perhaps fatally, and created general consternation.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 11. -- The sudden departure for England of President Van Horne of the Canadian Pacific Railroad is said in certain quarters here to be in connection with that old story, the establishment of a last Atlantic mail service between Great Britain and Halifax. This time, however, there is said to be almost an assurance that the project will materialize.
Under the auspices of the Department of Astronomy of the University Faculty of Pure Science is to be given one of the most valuable courses of lectures that New-York has known for years.

The Committee on Repeal of the Board of Trade and Transportation submitted a report at yesterday's meeting on the efforts of the board to help on the sound-money cause, which led to the convention of business men in Washington, at which the business opinion upon the silver question was clearly set forth. Dealing with cloture in the Senate, and quoting an article in The New-York Times of Oct. 9 on the subject, the report says:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 11. -- The first cases against dealers, under the dispensary law, to excite public attention are those brought in Columbia, where four indictments were found for solling rice beer, in violation of the new act. Counsel for defense moved to quash the indictments on the ground that the court had no jurisdiction, as no penalty was provided in law.
Mayor Gilroy lamed the following proclamation yesterday, calling on the people of this city to make Manhattan Day at the World's Fair, Oct. 21, an occasion worthy of the metropolis:
Money on call loaned at 2@2 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 11. -- The Supreme Court met to-day. Present -- The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Field, Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Gray, Mr. Justice Brewer, Mr. Justice Brown, Mr. Justice Shiras, and Mr. Justice Jackson.

Army News. -- Leaves of Absence. -- Capt. C.C. Hewitt, Nineteenth Infantry, ten days, from Oct. 15; Capt. L.L. Bruff, Ordnance Department, fifteen day; Capt. J.F. Munson, Sixth Infantry, seven days; Capt. Charles Richard, Medical Department, fourteen days; Lieut. C.A. Hedekin, Third Cavalry, three months from Oct. 15; Col. C.E. Compton, Fourth Cavalry, one month's extension.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct 11. New cases of yellow fever were reported to-day as follows: Colored -- Flem Cross, Eliza Blookworth. Mary Harris, infant of Myrtle Christopher, Rebecca Thorpe, and Alfred Rocamore. Whites -- W.A. Silverstein, Adolph Heisterhagon, W.J. Price, Grey Hackett, Johanna Oleen, Mrs. J.H. Craig, Mrs. M. Oberleanter, and Ollie Wood.

Louis Roller, plumber, of One Hundred and Eighteenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, who failed about six weeks ago. Is accused of forging notes for a large amount. It is alleged by creditors that he forged notes with the names of various builders and contractors. The amount is not known, but it is currently reported to be over $35,000.
The Governors of the Stock Exchange to-day added these securities to the list:
Wheat declined yesterday 1/2@5/8c on the Government report and the statement of an increase in the supplies east of the Rocky Mountains; the exporters bought much more freely on the break.

The treatment of appendicitis was the topic of discussion at yesterday afternoon's session of the New-York State Medical Association. Dr. Frederick S. Dennis of 542 Madison Avenue propounded the following questions:

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 11. -- The Hon. Chandos Stanhope, accompanied by Mr. Cuttrann, a well-known engineer, sent out by the Dresdner Bank of Berlin, have gone down to the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, with a view to the completion of the Tehuantepec Railroad. The Dresdner Bank is prepared to find the money for the purpose, but it is not certain that the terms proposed by the bank will be accepted by the Government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11. -- The game scheduled for Bowdoin was played to-day by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The warm weather brought out 2,000 spectators. "Teck" was well represented. The game was won by Corbett, Dunlop, and Brewer, aided by the fine interference of Acton and the tackling of Johnson and Baldwin. Capt Waters did not play, and Beal was replaced by Laimbeer on account of slight injury in practice.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The Tribune this morning says: "Nothing could have been more creditable to the press at large than the sentiments manifested at the extraordinary meeting of the Associated Press held last week in this city. It showed that the members were actuated by a sense of loyal federation, and it was based upon representations which called for just such an expression of feeling.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The banks charged 2 1/2 for renewals of the settlement, and carry-over rates were very light.

NEW-UTRECHT, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Miss Anna Cortelyou Van Brunt, daughter of Mrs. Mary and the late Jeremiah Van Brunt of Bath Beach, was married to Charles F. Seaman of Brooklyn to-day, in the old Dutch Reformed Church, on Eighteenth Avenue, which was founded and built up under the guidance of many of the bride's ancestors.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I was glad to see your criticism on the Washington-Lafayette Monument for Chicago designed by M. Bartholdi; I have read with interest your editorial comments on that sculptor's complaints to the reporters of his treatment by The Times.

-- The dynamite cruiser Vesuvius, Lieut. Commander Frank Courtis, has sailed from Newport, R.I., having taken on board at the torpedo station a quantity of gun cotton for use in destroying derelicts at sea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- An important boundary commission will be appointed in a few days. Under an agreement between this Government and that of Mexico, the much-disputed line dividing the United States from the southern republic will be definitely determined. The officials of both Governments have become tired of the continued contests whch have arisen over the boundary question, and more than once the difference has been serious.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The long-deferred attempt to secure action, upon the bill to repeal the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act was made to-night, and the efficacy of constraint to continuous work or a prompt vote was tried, with indications of earnestness on the part of the repeal leaders.

Two inferences were warranted by the conflicting replies to the Regatta Committee's proposition to call the race off for the day. The ready assent of the Vigilant Implied that her managers would rather take the chance of catching the Valkyrie in a blow and a seaway than try conclusions with her again in a light breeze.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct 11. -- Six candidates for the Assembly were put in the field by the Republicans of Erie County to-day. In five districts the nominations were made unanimously. To Assemblyman Edward Gallagher was refused a renomination from the Fourth, the only sure Republican district in the county.

-- It begins to look as though Richard Mansfield was to revive the fortunes of Herrmann's Theatre. He is drawing large and discriminating audiences to that pretty Broadway house, although he has thus far appeared only in his familiar repertory. To-night he will be seen in one of the most artistic of his characters. Baron Chevrial in "A Parisian Romance."

At the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, in the Trinity Building, yesterday. Messrs. Richard V. Harnett Co. sold, for $20,000, to John D. Lohman, under foreclosure, the plot of lots fronting the northwest junction of Emerson Street and Prescott Avenue, 354.7 on avenue, 478.1 on street, and 707.10 in rear, the lots varying from 25 feet front to 93.2, and in depth from 153.2 to 215.3.

Lovers of light-harness racing were out in full force yesterday afternoon to witness the fourth matinee of the Park-way Driving Club at King's Highway, L.I. From noon until 2 o'clock, when the bell brought the horses on the track for the first heat, the visitors came pouring into the pretty little clubhouse, and by 3 o'clock the largest crowd that has been at the track this year was on the grounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- There were no developments in the Senate in relation to repeal prior to the beginning of the test of endurance at 6 o'clock. All talk of compromise had ceased for the time being. One Senator who went to the White House this morning returned with the announcement that the President was in excellent humor.

Mme. de Louie entertained the members of the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon with a lecture upon "Co-education of Mind and Body by Development of the Psychic Force." She said, the best conditions were to be secured through an understanding of the ethics of morality. Women know right and wrong, regardless of creed; woman must be a law unto herself.

Among the passengers on the outgoing steamships for Europe yesterday wore Mrs. Eben Alexander and the Misses Alexander, C. Baghot do la Bere, Dr. L. Bryan, Dr. Frank Donaldson, Surgeon General Farrell, Col., A. Feez, Mrs. Thomas Grosvenor, Major S.M. Haycook, Dr. Oronbyatekha, the Rev. G.F. Pentecost. Major E.W. Reddick, Lieut. H.S. Rogers, the Rev. Charles F. Raine, Count and Lady Edeline Strickland.

The run of Sydney Rosenfeld's opera, "The Rainmaker of Syria," was brought to an abrupt termination last night at the Casino. For days Mr. Rosenfeld's troubles have been rapidly increasing in almost pathetic variety. The end came last night at 8:30 o'clock.

Thirty elk went out on the steamship Bovic Tuesday in charge of Major Root. They were caught in Wyoming and are intended for the estate of Sir Peter Walker, near Liverpool, England. Sir Peter will try to breed from them. He will pay $20.000 for the lot if they are landed in good condition on his place.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Oct. 11 -- P.M. Trading was less active than yesterday and prices were somewhat irregular. The movement in the industrials continued, the heaviest trading being in Whisky and Sugar. The former advanced 2 1-2 points and the latter 1-2 point on manipulation by the pools operating in these specialties.

If one wants to imagine the finish of yesterday's tantalizing, almost drifting, match let him picture to himself a blue-gray sky overhead out of which the sun has jnst dropped behind the Highlands of the Navesink. This abdication of the monarch of day has left the western firmament flushed with a widespread anger.

The latest novelty in Brooklyn politics is the tete-a-tete. This unique feature was introduced last night by Francis H. Wilson, who is spoken of by the Republican regulars as their most likely candidate for Mayor.

-- A man in Norway, Me., raised nine large pumpkins from one seed. If pumpkins were worth $1 a pound, one wouldn't grow from less than nine seeds -- or would it be better to put it the other way and remark that if there were less seeds in pumpkins and less pumpkins in seeds, there would be more dollars in them. -- Lewiston Journal.

Dr. James Lee Morrill, a well-known physician and specialist in obstetrics tract lives at 67 East Seventy-ninth Street, is suffering from blood poisoning which he incurred while performing an autopsy about a week ago. No danger is apprehended as to his recovery.

Charles Taigel, the young German, of 334 East Eighth Street, who, it is alleged, was brutally beaten recently by two Park policemen, was pronounced insane yesterday at Bellevue Hospital and transferred to the Ward's Island asylum. It is thought that his condition is hopeless.

A decided improvement in the railroad business of this country is indicated by the more recent returns of earnings. The St. Paul Road, for instance, reports for the first week in October a small increase over the earnings of the corresponding period of last year and an increase of $40,606 for the year up to date.

Senator George W. Plunkitt will not go back to the State Senate this year. He called at Tammany Hall yesterday and notified Mr. Croker that he would not be a candidate. He has been very ill and is only just able to be about. To a reporter Mr. Plunkitt said:
Only three games wore played in the international chess tournament yesterday -- games which were not finished on Monday and Tuesday evening. They resulted as follows:

STAPLETON, S.I., Oct. 11. -- The Richmond County police found a horse and wagon in the possession of a farmer in the interior of the island which had been stolen from John O'Brien, a liveryman, of Bergen Point. It was learned that he had purchased the rig from John B. O'Connor and Edward Sheridan, two men who had recently established themselves at Clinton as horse dealers.

-- Only four members of the national House of Representatives can count seventy in the years of their age. The oldest is Thomas Dunn English of New-Jersey, who was born in 1819. William Lilly, Congressman at Large from Pennsylvania, is seventy-two, and his colleague, Charles O'Neill, Representative from one of the Philadelphia districts, is a few months older than he.

James C. Hueston, who died on Tuesday of cerebral meningitis, after an illness of two years, at his home, 20 East Twentieth Street, was born in Baton Rouge, La., on Dec. 20, 1841. He was the son of a prominent editor in that State. Mr. Hueston was graduated from Princeton in 1861. At the outbreak of the Civil War he enlisted in the Confederate Army and served through the war.

The examination in the case of Wong S. Charles, formerly Chinese interpreter at the Custom House, who is charged with attempted extortion, was continued in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. The defense sought to show that Chu Shea, the complainant in the case, and Chu Fong are engaged in smuggling Chinese into this country, and that their testimony against Charles is not worthy of credence.

-- Two hotel employes in Hartford who had a dispute at table over the question whether they were eating chicken or turkey, called in the steward as umpire, and he assured them that they were eating domestic duck. The "meat's own flavor" evidently is not better retained in that hotel than in many others, perhaps of bigger pretensions, in this country.

PEEKSKILL, Oct. 11. -- Under whip and spur, and under the influence of golden concomitants that prevail at lotteries and at race tracks, Alfred Hennen Morris, the son of his father, was nominated for Senator from the Fifteenth Senatorial District by the Democrats who gathered in Cripple Hall to-day.

UTICA, Oct. 11. -- There is no open revolt against the nomination of Judge Maynard in this city, but there will be some votes cast against him by Democrats. The remainder of the State ticket will be loyally supported by both factions of the party. There is, indeed, more unanimity between the Democrats here than has been shown before in several years.

Plans are in hand to reinforce the movement of church interests to prevent the international prise fight booked to take place at Coney Island in December, by mass meetings both in this city and Brooklyn to protest against this defiance of public decency.

A disappointed crowd of yacht-racing enthusiasts returned to Pier 8 at 8 o'clock last evening on the steamer St. John's. The guests and members of the New-York Yacht Club who were on the steamboat are supposed to be connoisseurs of yacht racing, and came off the boat silent and wishing they had remained in town.

Preparations are being made by the United States ordnance officers at the Sandy Hook Proving Grounds for an extended international competitive tests of six-pounder rapid-fire guns in the course of the next ten weeks. The guns to be entered for the trial will include the Hotchkiss, Driggs, Schroeder, Seabury, Adamson, Maxim, and Maxim-Nordenfeldt types. There are hopes that the Sponsal people, Schnelde et Cie, and Krupp may also enter light, rapid-fire guns.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 11. -- The nomination of John E. Russell as the Democratic candidate for Governor of the Commonwealth has suddenly lifted the quaint and picturesque little town of Leicester into national prominence.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- A late start at Point Breeze to-day and numerous delays from broken harness lost too weights, and thrown shoes prevented the decision of two events on the programme. The 2:29 trot was narrowed down to a duel between the two favorites. Gilmore and Overholt, the pair finishing three times only a head apart. Overholt was set back in the second heat for running.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- A delegation of Republicans and anti-race track Democrats, including a number of prominent clergymen, called upon Founder James A. Bradley in New-York to-day, and succeeded in inducing him to consent to accept the fusion nomination for State Senator.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 11. -- The closing event of the most successful outing season ever held was the reception given by Joseph Witzel today to mark the end of the year's fun at Point View Island. A party visited this well-known popular resort every day from May 28 until today. The smallest party was the Peter Hart Association of 300 members, and the largest was the Order of Germania Society's Convention, which attracted 30,000 people.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 11. -- At the second day's session of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, after the appointment of a committee to consider all resolutions and memorials relative to the controversies before the board, the Rev. E.K. Alden read an address on "The Personal Factor in the Missionary Problem."

BALLSTON, N. Y., Oct. 12. -- The Democratic Convention for Saratoga County was held here to-day. Walter I. Cavert, Supervisor of the town of Charlton, was elected Chairman, and Robert Johnson and W. D. McNulty were made the Secretaries. The convention was enthusiastic and harmonious.
-- "Is your appetite capricious? " asked the physician who had been called in to sea Farmer Meddergrass.

The most important occupation of the House of Representatives just at present is the consideration of the McCreary bill to amend the Chinese deportation law, commonly known as the Geary act. This is such an extremely mild measure and so manifestly just that it is surprising to find Mr. GEARY strenuously opposing it and assailing the Administration for not vigorously executing the law as it stands.

The last matinee of the Fall meeting of the Parkway Driving Club, at King's Highway, yesterday, brought oat even a larger crowd than that or the previous day. An interesting feature of the afternoon's sport was the tilt against 2:15 by Gillette, E. T. Bedford's crack gelding. In a previous race against the track record Gillette trotted in 2:13 3/4, and in yesterday's race he equaled this mark.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 12. -- Probably the queerest boycott on record was that begun to-night against the Merchants' HoteL.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- John Barry, Nationalist member of Parliament for the South Division of Wexford County, has announced, in a long letter to the Secretaries of the County Convention, that he will retire from Parliament. He complains that the policy of his party is now directed by individuals intriguing in secret.

Auctioneer William Eastern of Tattersalls disposed of a number of race horses in training, the property of McCafferty Wishard, Isaac H. Abraham Dahlman, Brown Rogers, and Gideon Daly, at Morris Park The prices realized were in the main good.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 12. -- At the largelyattended meeting of the American Board of Foreign Missions Here to-day, the vexed question of future probation for the heathen was thrashed over again with a great deal of hot rhetoric.

The shameful revelations which promise to cause the withdrawal of the Republican candidate for Governor in Iowa, owing to the conviction on the part of leading Republicans of that State that the party cannot hope to elect a man so badly smirched by his own admissions, are interesting to the people of the whole country because of certain facts which we have not mentioned heretofore.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Dr. Joseph Parker of the City Temple (Congregationalist) surprised a large audience of his parishioners this evening by making a hot attack on the Established Church. He is understood to have been irritated by the unyielding attitude of the recent Church Congress at Birmingham, and, therefore, to have taken, his first opportunity to even the score.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- The game between the Australian cricketers and All Massachusetts was brouuht to a conclusion here to-day in delightful weather, and, as was expected, the famous Antipodeans gained an easy victory by eight wickets. The Massachusetts team, which made a wretched start in its second inning yesterday afternoon, losing ten wickets for 13 runs, resumed batting this morning at 11:20, Lott Mansfield Joining George Wright.

ALBANY, N, Y., Oct. 12. -- From present indications the differences which, have existed for months in the ranks of the Albany County Democracy, and which cost the party the county and the seats of two Assemblymen last Fall, have been settled, and next month the party will go to the polls a united one.

The Rev. J. A. Churchill, pastor of the Methodist Church at Sheepshead Bay, of whose Sunday-school John Y. McKane is Superintendent, called at The New-York Times office yesterday. He said he wanted to know if there was any " legal evidence " that there had been prize fighting at the Coney Island Athletic Club.

The Citizens' Union of Kings County, in mass meeting in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last night, regardless of all attempts at turning it into sidetracks, absolutely determined to consider but one man as its choice for Mayor and, entirely ignoring that man's own published declaration that he would take no nomination, declared vociferously and unanimously that it wanted for the next Mayor of Brooklyn William J. Gaynor.

-- James Hayden, alias "Funeral Wells," so called because of his habit of robbing mourners at funerals, was held by Justice Walsh in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for examination on a charge of grand larceny, Sunday. Wells stole a diamond scarf pin worth $125 from Charies E. McDevitt of 44 Willow Place, while standing on the platform of the Bridge Street station of the Myrtle Avenue elevated railroad.

Sevanty-five thousand dollars worth of real estate was sold under foreclosure at the saleeroom in the Trinity Building yesterday for $8,000 only. Why this was the outcome involves the story of the Donnell brothers, James and Ezekiel, and carries back the narrative more than a Quarter of a century.

The Tammany Hall Assembly conventions held in this city last night nominated the candidates named below. Reference to the list of names placed in nomination shows that some wellknown legislators have had their pictures turned toward the wall. In the Eleventh District, where there is a good fighting chance for the Republicans, Percival Farquhar was rejected and Frederiak W. McCloy, editor of a dramatic paper, was nominated in his place.

Some words of hearty praise should be said for the fine sportsmanlike spirit shown by. Lord DUNRAVEN, Designer WATSON, and Capt. CRANFIELD of the Valkyric. Nothing more admirable has ever been displayed in the world of sports than the indomitable pluck shown by these men in Wednesday's attempt at a race for the America's Cup.

The committee appointed by Mayor Gilroy to make arrangements for Manhattan Day at the World's Fair Oct. 21 met yesterday in the Mayor's office, Seth Low presiding, and completed the programme for the celebration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- An Ohio concern will probably build a fifty-thousand -- dollar gun carriage for the army. The carriage is intended to support the ten-inch, rifle, and, if everything is satisfactory after a competitive test, in which rival mounts will participate, the carriage will be adopted for the sea-coast defenses.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst yesterday renewed his complaints against gambling houses and disorderly places in the Eleventh Police Precinct, over which Capt. William S. Devery presides. His effort, on behalf of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, takes the form of letters to Mayor Gilroy, Superintendent Byrnes, Police Commisssioner Martin, and Capt. Devery.

Controller Myers will sell at public auction in his office in the Stewart Building, at noon, Oct. 25, the franchises of the Fulton, Wall, Catharine, Hamilton, and South Ferries, which are held at present by the Union Ferry Company. The franchises will be disposed of for a term of eight years from May 1, 1893, when the contract with the Union Ferry Company expired.
RAHWAY, N. J., Oct. 12. -- The Synodical Women's Missionary Societies of New-Jersey convened in the Second Presbyterian Church to-day. Seven hundred delegates have been provided for.

The Rev. Dr. Richard Lalor Burtsell, the stanch defender of Dr. McGlynn and former rector of the Church of the Epiphany, in this city, will sail for Europe to-morrow afternoon by the steamer Werra. He has a six months' vacation, and will visit Rome and have an audience with the Pope.

It was decided yesterday that Assemblyman Frank A. O'Donnel of the Twelfth Assembly District should get the Tammany nomination for the State Senate in the Tenth Senate District, to succeed Senator Thomas Cunningham, who filled the vacancy in the Senate caused by the death of Senator Edward P. Hagan.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge held a meeting yesterday afternoon, during which they received a committee of citizens of Brooklyn, who came to protest against the encroachments of the elevated road on the land which was originally intended for a plaza, opposite the entrance to the bridge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The Varity eleven practices on Jarvis Field every afternoon at 4 o'clock, and the preliminary games are of immense advantage in the development of team work. The practice is under the charge of Crosby. '91; Porter, '88, assisted by Upton, '93; and other graduates. Saxe, '87; Cranston. '91; Newell. '92, and Newell,'94. hove also been on the field at different times.

TOULON, Oct. 12. -- Many anxious eyes will be turned seaward to-morrow to watch for the coming of the fleet of Russian war ships, preparations for the reception of the officers of which have been made on a scale of lavishness seldom, if ever, equaled by this city. People from every principal city and town in the country, and from the villages scattered between, have been pouring into Toulon all day long.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Auditor Ackerman'a monthly statement of the exposition's finances to Sept. 30 was given out to-day. It shows that the exposition is not only out of debt, but has a handsome balance in the treasury.

The now college theatre at St. Francis Xavier's in West Sixteenth Street was crowded last evening on the occasion of the first production in Latin by students of the college of Plautus's play, "The Two Captives."

Reports having semi-official sanction were Given out down town yesterday that the Reorganization Committee of the National Cordage Company had considered favorably a plan to retire the $6,000,000 of bonds belonging to the security corporation and to issue in their place $6,000,000 first preferred stock of the National Cordage Company or its successors.

The Brooklyn Aldermen who were concerned in the Columbian Celebration scandals and in the granting of franchises to the Brooklyn City Railroad Company and the Flynn political syndicate have been turned down. They have bowed their heads, not with the best of grace, on the orders of their bosses, to the storm of public condemnation of the administration of which they were a conspicuous part, and have retired from public life.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 12. -- The United States revenue steamer Seward has returned to this port after an eventful cruise in the track of the recent great Gulf storm. She rendered assistance to many vessels in distress and seven lives were saved by her timely arrival at various points.

Dr. Isabella M. Rankine of 626 Willough by Avenue, Brooklyn, who has been under arrest since early in July on a charge of swindling Mrs. Lucia M. Balcom of 1,077 Bedford Avenue out of $2,000, was yesterday held to the Grand Jury by Justice Connolly in the Gates Avenue Police Court. The came disposition was made of the case of William B. Warner, her alleged confederate.

For the last six or seven days Printing House Square has been interested, despite itself, in the erratic movements of a tall man who has, apparently, not only drunk deep, but bathed all over in the Fountain of Perpetual Youth.

Tammany is going to make the best showing it can so far as Senatorial district delegates to the Constitutional Convention are concerned. The list has been prepared with the greatest care. Borne very prominent Democrats who are not members of Tammany have bean placed, upon it. It was the completion of this list that kept the Executive Committee or Committee of Thirty of Tammany so long in session at Wednesday night's meeting at the Wigwam.

The alterations made in the Valkyrie on Tuesday seamed to benefit her very much in the race on Wednesday. Her mast was given more of a take forward and her ballast was shifted furtheraft. Lord Dunraven thought he had hurt the boat by lightening her so much, and yesterday he decided to put more lead in her and see how she will sail on a longer water line.

The ninth round of the International Chess Tournament was played at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, when oily fairly took the spectators by storm by defeating Showalter of Kentucky. It was a grand contest, beautifully conducted by the winner.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12. -- By comparison with the stirring events of yesterday, the fifth day of the Kentucky Trotting-Horse Breeders' meeting passed off rather quietly. The feature of the afternoon was the victory of the crack Buffalo pacer Robert J. over his old rival, Flying Jib, whom he defeated in straights, while even Manager got second money over the once invineible Californian.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 12. -- The Grand Lodge of the Knights of Honor of New-Jersey held its annual session in Chester Row Hall to-day. Supreme Dictator Bellamy of North Carolina called the meeting to order. Delegates from sixty-five lodges, representing 5,000 members, responded. The reports of the grand officers show the order to be in a flourishing condition. There were seventy-four deaths in the order during last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- A delegation of Philadelphia, business men will go to Washington to-morrow to urge upon the Senate the necessity of the repeal of the Silver bill. Senators Quay and Cameron will meet the delegation at noon. George A. Gamble went to Washington to-day for the purpose of presenting to Senator Cameron a petition signed by 500 Philadelphia merchants, urging the Senate to immediately vote on the repeal bill.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 12. -- Savannah is in the grasp of a storm which threatens in a few hours to equal in intensity that of Aug. 27, which swept the entire Georgia and South Carolina coast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- At 1:45 o'clock, the Sergeant at Arms having reported his inability to bring a quorum into the Senate, Mr. Voorhees reluctantly moved an adjournment. The effort at continuous sessions has been a failure. The repeal bill is not nearer passage than it was when the continuous session began.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Senator Wade Hampton, as United States Commissioner of Railroads, has transmitted his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior. Much space is devoted to the history and aims of the commission. Certain of the land-grant roads have for a number of years failed to submit a report of their operations upon the forms prescribed by law.

Gen, Georg Kamecke died at Berlin yesterday. He was born on June 14, 1817. and entered the Engineers' Corps of the Prussian Army in 1834. In 1850 he became Captain and was attached to the general staff. In the war with Austria he was chief of staff of the Second Army Corps. He left the war as Major General, and in 1868 was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant Gen eral.

-- Baltimore has a blind boatman. His boat was stolen by some worthless fellows the other day, and subsequently abandoned and picked up. He claimed it, and when told that he must Identify it, did so, not by telling its color and model, as a man with good eyes might do, but by giving the positions of all the nails and the chinks in the boat, where splinters had been knocked off, and so on.

From now until the close of the World's Fair the railroad excursion tickets which have been selling at 20 per cent, less than the regular fares, but good only on slow trains, will be accepted on all of the ordinary trains run by the Eastern trunk lines. The only exceptions will be the limited fast trains on the New-York Central and Pennsylvania Roads, for which extra fares are charged.

Miss Lillian Osborne, daughter of Judge William J. Osborna of the City Court of Brooklyn, was married to James P. Topping, also of Brooklyn, last evening. The wedding took place at 8 P.M., in the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, the pastor of which, the Rev. Dr. Charles Cuthbert Hall, officiated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- "Are they going to divide very soon ?"

M. Alexandra Guilmant, the French organist, of La Trinite, Paris, was tendered a reception last evening by Mrs. M. R. Williams and Miss Charlotte Welles of 1O9 East Twenty-eighth Street. The feature of the social entertainment was a musicale, which followed the reception at 9 o'clock.

A short-lived but extremely dangerous fire at 4 Maiden Lane yesterday afternoon caused a second alarm to be quickly rung, and brought half the wagons of the Insurance Patrol Service to the menaced spot, which is in the heart of the jewelry district.

The wearisome session of the Senate drags on. At the present writing it had continued forty hours, with no apparent reason for expecting any definite result. With the exception of a stirring speech from Senator SMITH of New-Jersey, exposing the absurdities of the silver men in a canstic fashion, the time has been taken up wholly by the Populist and Republican advocates of free coinage, and by roll calls to secure a quorum.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 12. -- A meeting of the Home Rule Democrats was held in this city yesterday afternoon, at which definite plans were made as to the conduct of the campaign. The meeting was a private one. Discussion was of the most thorough character, and the decision arrived at met the views of all present.
Joseph Chamberlain, M. P., started yesterday afternoon, with his two sons, Austin and Neville, on the Ward Line steamer Niagara for Nassau, New-Providence.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 12. -- A sensation has been created in banking and business circles by the announcement of the suspension of the banking firms at Wilbour, Jaokson Co. and Sheldon Binnoy. These concerns were classed among the strongest in New-England, the banking house of Wilbour. Jackson Co. having been in existence a score of years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- It was early breakfast time, not yet 8 oclock, when the Senate got into a dispute about the question of the number of Senators required to make a Quorum. Mr. Wolcott insisted that forty-five Senators constituted a quorum, and he was sustained by Mr. Manderson, though their method of reasoning could not be made out, as there are but eighty-five Senators.

The steamer St. John, carrying about 400 guests and members of the New-York Yacht Club, accompanied the yachts over the course. From the time the boats crossed the line, on their journey, until the Vigilant returned a winner, all was excitement on board, and interest never flagged. There were yachting sharps galore, who delved into little blue-covered books when, signals were run up, and explained what they meant to the less nautical spectators.
Wheat lost 1@1 1/8c on the day's trading, through lower markets at the West, together with free realizing by local longs, with a better speculation.

Just before the finish of the race yesterday afternoon a sloop that was standing near the lightship waiting for the finish had her mast carried away. She was the Neva Rowland of Norwalk, Conn., commanded by Capt. Rowland. It looked for a moment as though the vessel had capsized. Several tugs ran alongside of her and she was found to be all right.

The Vigilant has accomplished all for which she was created. America's Cup will remain on this side the Atlantic for another year at least. The American type of sailing vessel has once again shown itself superior to the best that British skill could construct, and the American pennant again snaps a saucy defiance to the sailormen of the world.

President PEIXOTO of the Brazilian Republic has the good wishes of the people of the United States in the struggle in which he is engaged. They would rejoice to see him repel and crush the insurgent followers of MELLO. It is natural and proper that our sympathies should be upon the side of constitutional forms and good order.

Spanish naval advices state the recent reorganization measure for the Spanish marine infantry, which has been signed by the Queen Regent, provides that in future the marine infantry of Spain shall have in its staff one Field Marshal, one Colonel, one Lieutenant Colonel, two Majors, and three Captains.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 13. -- The remainder of the campaign in Ohio promises to be vigorously contested. Republicans have at last awakened to the fact that Mr. Neal has not yet been beaten. Republican complacency has been disturbed by the discussion of local issues and the tariff by the candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor.

Senator QUAY said to a delegation of Pennsylvania business men who called upon him and his colleague yesterday that unconditional repeal was doomed, and that conditional repeal would in his opinion be passsed in from three to ten days, probably within three. If Mr. QUAY'S judgment be correct, then in from three to ten days, probably in three, the majority in the Benate will have made an unconditional surrender of the rights of the people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- It might have been expected that after a continuous session of thirty-nine hours, closing at 2 o'clock this morning, and after the partial failure of the test of physical endurance on the Silver-Purchase Repeal bill, that measure would have been allowed to go over till next Monday, and that the Senate would have adjourned till then.

That there would be a wet sheet and a flowing sea and wind enough to bend the "gallant mast," nobody familiar with the sea doubted yesterday morning on the way down to tie Sandy Hook Lightship. There was at 9 o'clock a piping breeze out of the northeast. The sky was overcast and windy, and the clouds were broken into those peculiar little blocks or squares indicative of more wind to come.

The steamship Biela from Santos, which arrived yesterday, brought more news about the revolution in Brazil. The Biela left Santos Sept. 20. Capt. Davies said the people of Santos remained loyal to Peixoto, and that when they heard the cruiser Republica had been ordered to Santos they fortified the fort at that port with one small gun.

LAKE MOHONK, N. Y., Oct. 13. -- At the morning session of the third day of the Lake Mohonk Conference of Friends at the Indian, Bishop Walker of North Dakota, speaking upon the question whether educated and converted Indians remained true to their Christianity after returning to the reservation, contended that they did, and advocated the continuance of both reservation and detached schools.

Mrs. Ella Rogers, a pretty and well-dressed woman, twenty years old, reported at Police Headquarters yesterday that her husband, James Rogers, had been missing since Monday. She said they had always lived in Worcester, Mass., where her husband had been engaged in the livery business. They came to this city to better their condition.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The final session of the eighty-fourth annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions opened this morning. A communication was received from the Rev. J.W. Cooper, D.D., of New-Britain, Conn., declining, because of other engrossing duties, to accept membership in the Prudential Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The range of prices on wheat to-day was lower and a good business was transacted. The opening was about 3@1c lower than yesterday, fluctuated slightly, then recovered the early decline, then declined 1c, hold steady, and closed 1@ 1 1c lower. The principal influence on the market to-day was the reported adjournment of the Senate without taking action on the silver bill.

At the regular monthly meeting of the union League Club held on Thursday night with Gen. Horace Porter in the chair, resolutions were adopted strongly denouncing the nomination of Isaac H. Maynard for the Court of Appeals bench. The resolution was presented by E. B. Hinsdale, Chairman of the Committee on Political Reform. It read:

Paragraphs have recently appeared in some Newspapers here stating that a New York firm of mineral water dealers are the lessees in America of the Hunyadi Waters of Buda Pest, and respectively sole agents in the United States for the famous Hunyadi Springs of Hungary.

Quiet prevailed in the Republican State Headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday. State Chairman Brookfield was quiet. Chairman Hackett of the Executive Committee was quiet, and Secretary Reuben L. Fox roamed around noiselessly. It was evident, however, that they had something on their minds.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 13. -- The end of the rebellion in Argentina was celebrated yesterday with a solemn Te Deum and elaborate military fetes. The Government is making strenuous efforts to suppress the wandering bands of brigands, who, since the dissolution of the rebellious armies, have been plundering the rural districts of the disturbed provinces.
The arrangements for the celebration of Manhattan Day at the "World's Fair Oct. 21 are being vigorously pushed forward by the committee appointed by Mayor Gilroy.

The Jewelers' Review has forwarded to Senator David B. Hill a petition urging "the immediate repeal of the silver-purchasing clause of the Sherman law." The petition is signed by 1,000 diamond dealers and jewelry and silverware manufacturers of the East representing an invested capital of $100,000,000 The petition declares that 35,000 workmen in the trade are now idle.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13. -- More than a hundred college Presidents and leading instructors of New-England arrived here to-day to participate in the eighth annual convention of New-England colleges and preparatory schools which begun in Dwight Hall at Yale this afternoon.
Grammar School No. 93 team will play the Morningside eleven at Central Park this afternoon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13. -- It is thought at Yale that Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania have combined in a scheme to prevent the application of the undergraduate rule to the football teams of those institutions. Their intention, as reported at Yale, is to openly defy the power of Yale and Wesleyan, the remaining members of the association to put the rule into execution.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- There was no hitch at the Albany County Republican Convention to-day, and the slate went through. United States Commissioner Charles W. Mead presided. Assemblyman Myer Nussbaum nominated for Senator in the Nineteenth District Edward A. Durant, Jr., a grain commission merchant of Albany.

The examination of Worry S. Charles, formerly a Chinese interpreter in the Custom House, on a charge of extorting $75 from Chu Shea for smuggling in the latter's partner, Chu Pong, was continued in the Tombs Police Court. Mrs. Charles testified to a conversation sue had with Dr. Tom, a Chinese physician, in which the doetor expressed, his hatred and hostility to Charles, and said he would do all he could "to send him up."

There is good reason for believing the "machine" Democrats of Brooklyn have made a deal with the wirepullers of the Republican organization. The machine Republicans are to secretly aid in the reelection of Mayor Boody, receiving in return Democratic support for the Republican candidate for Sheriff.

The trolley wire which carries the current for the Myrtle Avenue cars in Brooklyn, broke at 12 o'clock last night at the Junction of Myrtle Avenue and Fulton Street. The dangling ends of the wire fell on to the Myrtle Avenue tracks, and a series of explosions took place, illuminating the entire neighborhood. The fallen wire stopped traffic for some time.

John McGlone, who is undersized and not strong, was on trial in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with assaulting Policeman Edwin V. Luman. The jury evidently thought that Luman had perjured himself and was a brute, for McGlone was acquitted, the twelve men not leaving their seats.

FIRST RACE. -- Six furlongs. Galilee, 118 pounds, (Taral,) 1 to 3, won: Ornus, 107. (Littlefield.) 5 to 1, second; Pirate Chief, 100, (T. Sloane.) 25 to 1, third. Penniless and Florinda also ran. Time -- 1:11 1/4.

-- Mrs. Sarah S. Fuller, a clerk, of Boston, while walking in Hyde Park, caught her foot in a root that had grown up in the centre of the path, and stumbled and fell.
