This happened two years ago, and a jury has awarded her $3,633 for injuries then sustained. Her physician testified that she had been unable to do any work since, and would be unable to do any for two years to come.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- There have been numerous conferences to-day bearing upon two subjects -- the length of the daily sessions and the probable compromise. In the discussion of the first matter the Republicans have been consulted; in the other they have been ignored.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 13. -- The fame of this city as a centre of medical research has gone to the ends of the earth. Dr. C. Howard Strong of Cape Town, South Africa, has been here a week investigating the Amick cure for consumption, and takes back with him sufficient medicines for sixty patients.

John McAnernoy, President of the Seventh National Bank, has sent a letter to James Smith, Jr., United States Senator from NewJersey, congratulating him upon the excellent speech which he delivered on Wednesday. The letter is as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Edward Munn of East Orange and Thomas Slidell of Princeten, both members of the junior class of Princeton College, while intoxicated last night, went to the laundry or Sing Lee and Lee Why for their linen. Munn and Slidell did not have the checks for their washing, and the Chinamen refused to give it up.

The New-York City Association of Union ex-Prisoners of War held its regular quarterly meeting last evening at the Colonnade Hotel. Gen. Alexander Shaler presided. The attendance was small. Major Charles C. Davis of Boston, the newly-elected President of the association; Col. M.C. McKnight of West Gardner, Mass., and Major Long or New-Jersey, the ex-President of the association, who were delegates to the Indianapolis Convention, were present as visitors.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The Daily Graphic, commenting on yesterday's yacht race, says: "We are fairly beaten. Nevertheless, Lord Dunraven has no cause to be ashamed of a yacht that was defeated by so narrow a margin. English builders must try to outmanoeuvre American builds here, else some day an American yacht will come here and sweep the board."

The New-York nautical schoolship St. Mary's will lie idle the rest of this year. The Board of Estimate appropriated $20,000 for the maintenance of the ship. The sum of $34,000 was asked by the commanding officer of the St. Mary's.
Money on call loaned at 2@2 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

There was a large gathering of theatrical people at the office of the Actors' Fund yesterday morning to attend the funeral ot Mrs. Frank Rea. To old theatregoers the names of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rea are familiar. Six years ago Mrs. Rea made a special request that the Actors' Fund should take charge of her funeral, and that her body should be placed with that of her husband.

TOULON, Oct. 13. -- A finer day for the reception of the Russian fleet could not be imagined. The sky was cloudless and the air was warm. An hour after daybreak the whole town was awake and stirring. Sixty thousand strangers slept in the town last night. All were out in holiday attire by 9 o'clock this morning.

Though usually under a one-gun start the boat which crosses the line first has the better of it, Capt. Herreshoff would have done better by keeping closer to windward and letting the lineal advantage go. Although he crossed ahead, he was much too far to leeward for advantageous position.

For the first time in its eventful history the Union Pacific Railroad is in the hands of receivers. Judge Dundy, sitting in the United States District Court at Omaha, yesterday appointed S.H.H. Clark, Oliver W. Mink, and E. Ellery Anderson receivers on the application of the executors of the estates of Frederick L. Ames and Sidney Dillon (the largest holders of the company's bonds) and Edwin F. Atkins of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- In the house the McCreary bill to amend and modify the Geary Chinese Registration and Exclusion act having been taken up, Mr. Rayner (Dom., Md.,) made an interesting speech. Before going into the discussion the House decided by unanimous consent to extend the time therefor until 3 o'clock Monday afternoon, at which hour the vote will be taken on the bill and pending amendments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- A delegation of about seventy-five prominent business men and manufacturers came over from Philadelphia this morning in a special car to urge the two Senators representing their State to unite their efforts in securing the immediate and unconditional repeal of the Sherman act. They were received by Senators Quay and Cameron in the room of the Committee on Patents, and some significant things were said by the Senators.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The cornerstone of the Scarborough Presbyterian Church, two miles south of here, was laid this afternoon in the presence of a large gathering. The church was projected by the late Elliott F. Shepard, who was, at the time of his death, erecting an elegant country mansion at Scarborough. His widow is carrying out his plans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The navy may not get a submarine boat, after all. The recommendation in favor of a sub-aquatic craft, to be built on the plans submitted by J.H. Holland of Newark, N.J., has been on Secretary Herbert's desk for some weeks. He has gone carefully over the subject with Commodore Sampson, the Chief of Ordnance, and has not yet reached a decision.

The test of "physical endurance" has failed because the firmness and determination of the majority were not equal to the task set for them. Had all the professed friends of repeal been willing to do all that they could, it might not have failed; it certainly would not have failed so soon.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- Yale has refused to play the Boston Athletic Association football team. The reason assigned is that the Captains of the Harvard and Boston Athletic Association elevens are brothers and the Boston Athletic Association men would ascertain Yale's weak positions and points, to Harvard's benefit. The game would be played before the annual Harvard-Yale game.

Army News. -- First Lieut. Sidney E. Stewart, Ordnance Department, will proceed from South Bethlehem, Penn., to the Heading Iron Works on business pertaining to the inspection of the eight-inch Haskell gun.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Oct. 13 -- P.M. The temporary success of the silver men in the Senate, indicated by the adjournment of that body at an early hour this morning without a vote being reached, was a cold douche to all financial interests. The influence of the set-back was shown promptly at the opening of the stock market by the universal pressure to sell, and prices declined sharply.

Bradstreet's will say to-morrow: "Continued cheerful advices from a number of leading Southern trade centres, reports of a very large distribution at Chicago as the outcome of the immense World's Fair attendance, and an improved demand at several points west of the Mississippi as a result of the cooler weather, are among the most favorable features revealed by telegrams to Bradstreet's this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- Only two beats were got ten off at Point Breeze to-day before the rain came and caused a postponement until to-morrow, but those two heats decided both the classes brought over from Thursday. In the 2:24 pace a third driver held the reins over Jim Wilson, the original favorite in this class. Demarest was invited to step down by the owner, who put up Curran.

Mr. Carl J. Rosenfeld of Niblo's Theatre has purchased from Louis Dryfoos the four-story brownstone dwelling, 39 East Sixty-fourth Street, north side, between Madison and Park Avenues, 20 by 100, on private terms.
LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Mexicans, Canadians, and Americans were weak to-day. Other departments were firm.
BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- The market opened off all around, on news of the failure in Washington of the test of physical endurance in the Senate in the effort to repeal the silver law.

The visit of the committee of Brooklyn citizens to the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge Thursday to ask that something be done to prevent the encroachment of the elevated roads on the bridge plaza has borne fruit. The Trustees held a meeting yesterday and adopted the following resolutions, which were offered by Mayor Boody:

JACKSON, Mich., Oct. 13. -- A terrible railroad wreck occurred in this city at 9:30 o'clock this morning, in which many persons either lost their lives or were badly injured. The accident was to two Delaware, Lackawanna and Western World's Fair excursion trains, one closely following the other.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- In pursuance of the notice given by ex-Senator Edmunds, at the opening of the Supreme Court of the United States last Monday, members of the bar of that court gathered in its chambers this morning to pay their tribute of respect to the memory of the late Associate Justice Samuel Blatchford.

James McMahon, President of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, last evening gave out at his residence, 87 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, the following correspondence between himself and William J. Gaynor.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 13. -- The prediction of the Weather Bureau officials, that while the storm would pass close to Charleston it would do no material damage has come true, for there are no casualties to report. Wet and dirty streets, a number of leaking roofs, wrecked wires, a strong wind, and lowering clouds are all there are of storm this morning.

-- Miss Minnie Ackerman of East Orange, N. J., got a verdict for $,8000 damages yesterday in the Superior Court against the Third Avenue Railroad Company. She was injured while riding in one of the cars of the company June 23, 1891, and was confined to her home for several months.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Secretary Gresham this afternoon received the following cable dispatch, from Mr. Young, United States Minister to Guatemala, dated yesterday.

The storm that struck the Georgia coast Thursday brushed this part of the country last night with a vicious whisk. Its advent was heralded, by a rush of wind, at about 6 o'clock, carrying enough rain with it to send people without umbrellas hurrying homeward.

Unless the members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment have good ground for believing that the amount of money asked for by Commissioner ANDREWS for the expenses of the Street-Cleaning Department is larger than is needed for the purposes designated in his estimate, it is a mistake to make any serious reduction in it.

Preparations for the celebration of Manhattan Day at the World's Fair next Saturday have now so far progressed that the committee in charge of the arrangements feels confident that the demonstration will be one of the most imposing since the opening of the exposition.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The preparations for the dedication of the Battle Monument Thursday are nearly completed. The indications are that it will be the greatest day in the history of New-Jersey. The State of New-York will contribute largely to the success of the day, as it has contributed liberally to the erection of the Revolutionary shaft.

Quite a breeze of excitement has been caused among the Russian Hebrews of the east side by the report that through the arbitrary action of Col. J.E. Bloom, manager of the Baron de Hirsch trade school at 225 East Ninth Street, five of the pupils of the school had been turned out of their boarding house, without a moment's warning, to pass Thursday night in the street.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The Prohibitionists of Occan County held their County Convention at Barnegat yesterday. The following nominations were made: State Senator -- Charles K. Wood of Island Heights; Assembly -- W.A. Simpson; County Collector -- Alexander Cowperthwaite of Tuokerton; Sheriff -- L.K. Clough of Lakewood; Coroners -- John N. Turner of, Lakewood, Ephraim W. Potter of Berkeley, and Abram Fort of Union.
A book plate drawn by Abbey represents an American Indian contemplating a Greek mask which he has unearthed. The legend is a quotation from Moliere, -- "What think you or this comedy ?"

The cable of the freight elevator in the five-story building 622 and 624 Broadway broke yesterday afternoon and the four men who were in it were badly hurt. The elevator is in the rear of the building at 156 Crosby Street.

The second tennis meeting between the representatives of the Kings County Interclub Association of Brooklyn and the Manhattan Association of New-York took place yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the Kings County Tennis Club, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street. At the first meeting, held the week before on the Hamilton Club courts, the Brooklyn, players had swept all before them, winning both the events of the day, the men's singles and women's singles.

The appointment of Gen. de Boisdeffre to the post of Chief of the General Staff, to which I have already drawn your attention, is now regarded practically in the light of an accomplished fact. This selection will be universally approved. Gen. de Mouton de Boisdeffre is a very distinguished officer, and belongs to an old military family, which for two centuries past has won laurels on many a battlefield.

-The forty-third anniversary of the founding of Atlantic Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons, No. 178, was held at Clark's, in Twenty-third Street, last evening. Frank H. Hinds, Past Master of the lodge, gave a synopsis of the history of the lodge. Past Master John A. Mapes gave some reminiscences. The present Master is William Wilson.

From The Engineering Record. A gas engine for dynamo service has been in operation at the station of the Waukesha (Ill.) Electric Light Company for over a year. It Is a 100 horse power, two-cylinder, Otto engine, with an electric igniter and an unusually heavy flywheel and pulley, the regularity of motions being increased by the use of a heavy balance wheel carried on a jack shaft.

This past week another name has been added to the list of bright women who have joined the ranks of the cyclists, and thereby hangs a tale -- a little, modern fairy story, telling of great things accomplished and goods deeds rewarded in this life, and in which Mrs. Frank Sittig of Brooklyn is at once Cinderella and the good fairy.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- The County Medical Society's petition to the Board of Health to isolate consumptives has increased their fears, occasioned by startling head lines in a local paper, declaring the disease infectious.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $6,939,057, of which amount $1,279,018 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $109,518 and the exports of specie $588,987.

-- Richard Mansfield's engagement at Herrmann's is proving remarkably successful, not merely artistically, which was assured in advance, but from a popular point of view. He has drawn large and discriminating audiences through the week, and has fairly revived the fortunes of the house. The music, which is under the direction of Gustave Dannreuth, is a leading feature of the entertainment.

The Bar Association of Rochester has set an example that should be followed throughout the State. The legal profession is primarily concerned in maintaining the character of the bench. Though the general public has ultimately as great an interest, it naturally looks to the lawyers to take the lead in keeping an unworthy candidate off the bench.

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- For the sake of art it is a great pity that the personal element should enter so strongly into the public consideration of artistic matters. Rossini wrote music simply that Patti might sing it; Chopin wrote scherzos only that Paderewski might interpret them; Beethoven composed symphonies that conductors might have "readings."

The tactics of obstruction practiced by the minority in the Senate, which has caused tiresome delay in the repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman silver law, and prevented the majority from acting in response to the overwhelming sentiment of the country, has caused discussion among men of law and business in this city as to methods which might best be adopted to bring about the immediate repeal of the obnoxious law.

From the London Telegraph. M. Zola's paper on anonymous journalism, which is published in full by The Figaro and The Journal, has already given rise to considerable criticism here. Discussing the subject in The Paris this evening, one writer says that signed articles have never been absolutely suppressed in England any more than in France.

From The Chicago Herald. Although the Trustees of the University of Chicago were unable to meet the conditions imposed by Martin A. Ryerson when, on Jan. 24 last, he offered to give $100,000 to the general fund of the institution providing an additional $400,000 could be secured within a specified time, the splendid contribution will not be lost.

Property owners along the line of the old Bloomingdale Road between Eighty-ninth and Ninety-sixth Streets, who have been waiting since March for the Court of Appeals to pass upon the validity of their holdings, are getting no comfort from the decision of the court just handed down. The issue involved three cases of ejectment brought by James W. Holloway against the Astor estate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- That the United States may be mulcted heavily for the seizures of British sealing vessels in Bering Sea is an evident deduction from the recent decision at Paris and one that carries with it an important lesson.

Talk of the absorption of the Madison Square Bank by the Sherman Bank having subsided, Receivers Miles M. O'Brien and James G. Cannen have agreed upon decisive steps to turn securities into cash assets for the depositors. The receivers have in hand various securities put up as collateral for call loans. They have been indulging the borrowers in time in which to settle the loans.

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- Mr. A.M. Palmer's company, from New-York, which to-night finished a successful engagement of a fort-night at the Globe Theatre, furnished Boston its only dramatic novelty, Thomas Bailey Aldrich's new play of "Mercedes," which New-York knows well. It had only two performances -- Monday and Tuesday evenings -- the entertainment being filled out with "A Pair of Spectacles."

From the London Telegraph. Now that it is known that the Comte de Segonzac is to be tried by court-martial at St. Louis, in Senegal, in the early part of next month, on the charge of having killed his brother officer, Lieut. Quiquerez, during an exploring expedition in the wilds of Africa, even more interest is being displayed by the public at large in an affair that is still enveloped in so much mystery.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 14 -- The Naval Cadets defeated Dickinson College this afternoon by a score of 26 to 0. The Cadets made but 4 point in the first half.

Soon after the Senate districts of the State were reapportioned, a year ago last Summer, the managers of the Democratic State Committee decided that it would he a good plan to have a careful examination made of the new districts, with a view to securing estimates of the probable Democratic or Republican pluralities. Each an examination was made and the probable vote in the new districts was carefully figured out.

Italy is, in one respect, rapidly acquiring one of the characteristics of Sparta, for it has only copper token money, and even that is difficult to obtain, says London Truth. Small change has to be bought at a premium of about 10 per cent., when it can be got. The consequence is that buying and selling in their smaller details are almost at a standstill.
Talking with a correspondent of The Boston Herald, the Rev. Elijah Kellogg of Harpsweli, Me., thus described how he wrote that favorite declamation of school boys. "Spartacus to the Gladiators":

COLUMBIA, S.C. Oct. 14. -- The destruction wrought by the storm of August has been repeated on the South Carolina coast. This time It is confined to a much more limited district. Two persons are reported to have been killed at Georgetown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The session of the Senate to-day lasted for only six hours. It opened with a personal explanation from Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) in reply to news-paper strictures on him for his hostility to the unconditional repeal of the Sherman act. He denied having ever intimated that he would vote against unconditional repeal, but said that he would vote against conditional repeal, as proposed in the Voorhees substitute.

"I have learned very little during my three months' trip in the United States." said Herr Bruchard von Oettingnn, the stud master of the Imperial Stud of Germany, sent here by the Government to investigate the methods or breeding, raising, and training horses in America. Herr von Oettingen has visited every stock farm or prominence in America, North, South, East, and West.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 14 -- After a hard-fought battle, the Staten Island Cricket Club football team won a victory from the second team of the Orange Athletic Club at Livingston this afternoon. The game was the first of the season for the home team, but they played well together. The Orange team depended upon their superior weight and made very few tries around the ends, while with Howden the cricketers' end plays were their best.

The Kings County Democratic Convention was held in Jefferson Hall, Boerum Place, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. It was known the delegates had been instructed, from the Willougby Street headquarters of Hugh McLaughlin, to vote for Thomas J. Patterson of the Fourteenth Ward, now holding the office of Assessor, for Sheriff.

The Rev. Dr. Richard Lalor Burtsell, former pastor of the Church of the Epiphany and defender of Dr. McGlynn, sailed for Europe on the North German Lloyd steamer Werra, yesterday afternoon. Dr. Burtsell goes to Borne to visit the Pope. His visit will be comparatively brief, as he expects to return to America before Jan. 1.

From the London Dally News. Careful inquiry has led to the discovery that there are no fewer than nine of Napoleon I.'s hats still in existence. A writer in The Vie Contemporaine gives a list of them. One is in the possession of Mme. Claitte, whose grandfather, Gen. Giraud, picked it up at Marengo.
I. The Protest of a Free City. On my return from the West, full of the impressions made by great surprises. The New-York Times is good enough to intrust to me a most interesting commission.
"I am in despair," cried a woman last week, as a friend entered her home, "and that is the cause of it."
The first serious attempt at providing an effective submarine boat for our navy was made during Mr. Whitney's administration of the office of Secretary of the Navy.

HERKIMER, Oct. 14. -- Democratic County Convention No. 8 was held here to-day. It was alleged to be a convention of the regular Democratic organization. It was controlled by the State machine men, led by Clinton Beckwith. Resolutions indorsing the entire State ticket were adopted and the following ticket was nominated: Member of Assembly -- Hiram Broat; County Treasurer -- Irving E. Petrie; School Commissioners -- Nelson P. Smith and Miss Hattie Rathbun.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Harvard scored 52 points against Williams to-day on a damp field. The teams played one forty-minute and one twenty-minute half. In the first halt Harvard played very loosely and Williams broke through her centre with ease, although they never made more than ten yards at any one time. Lewis and Acton were in poor condition, and Emmons's absence at left end crippled the team.

FONDA, Oct. 14. -- The Republican Convention of Montgomery County, held, here today, placed the following ticket in nomination: Member of Assembly -- E. Watson Gardiner of Amsterdam; County Treasurer -- William Clark of Fort Plain; School Commissioner -- John H. Weinmann of Fonda; Coroner -- Dr. W.J. Peddle.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 14. -- D.S. Leonard the contractor who built the Government Quarantine Station on Chandeleur Island, has returned from an inspection of the locality. The Island, which was forty miles long and over four miles wide, was situated at the western end of the Mississippi Sound, and had an elevation of from six to ten feet above the water in its highest part.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 14. -- The sanitary condition of the City of Vera Cruz has been greatly improved, and the city is beginning to fill up with visitors. The port is growing shallower, the new harbor works having, according to local opinion, prevented the scouring out of the roadstead by the winds which formerly swept down from the north. The new dredge does not come up to expectations.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- For the fashions of men London rules, even in Paris proper. I know some Frenchmen -- those of a certain age, as the people here deftly put it, which means anywhere from thirty-six to fifty, according to physical preservation -- who hate the English, London, Regent Street, pointed shoes, and turned-up trousers, but they look very much like faded-out pictures of 1830.

John Mauderer and John Baum worked together in the Hutchins Polishing Works at One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street and Third Avenue. They were very friendly till Baum was made foreman of the shop. Then the two did not get on well, and when work was dull Mauderer was among the first of the workmen to be discharged.

Capt. Wurtenburg's eleven of the New-York Athletic Club played the first of the series of scheduled games yesterday with the Butgers College football team and gained a creditable victory. The game was played at Manhattan Field and attracted a fair crowd of spectators.

ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- Five Democratic Assembly Conventions were held in Albany County's four Assembly districts to-day. Two conventions have nominated the same man, so that there will be but one Democratic candidate in each district.

-- The outbreak of yellow fever in Bruns wick, Ga., is regarded as mysterious, and worthy of careful investigation by surgeons competent to make it. It is said that the first person attacked was a hospital physician, who, as far as known, had not come in contact with any case of the plague. The exact character of the disease is disputed.

From Reynolds's Newspaper, London. Comrades of France: The autocrat who deceives you and lies every day through the organs of his Parisian reptile press has sown, and sows daily, the corpses of the oppressed ones on the high roads of holy Russia!
Money on call loaned at 2 per cent. throughout the day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Yale won another football game to-day, this time defeating the strong Dartmouth eleven. The visitors played a stiff wedge-play game and battered away at the Yale centre and tackles for heavy gains. At one time during the second half they lodged the ball at the Yale fifteen-yard line, but Stillman dropped on a Dartmouth fumble and Thorne punted the leather back to the centre of the field.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Since the days when the Misses Roosevelt of Poughkeepsie won national fame as tennis champions that healthful and invigorating sport has had no more formidable exponents in the Hudson River Valley than the four young ladies whose portraits accompany this sketch.

In a recent paper in a contemporary on "The Spinster Versus the Married Woman," Mrs. Kate Upson Clark gives a graphic picture of the handicap of the latter in the race for fame in the world of art or letters.

TOULON, Oct. 14. -- Until 9 o'clock this morning the weather appreciably diminished the manifestations of popular enthusiasm attending the visit to this port of the Russian fleet of war ships. The air was damp and rain was threatened, but at about 9 o'clock the clouds began to clear away, and the sun was soon shining brightly.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 14. -- Fire started in the electric light plant of the Brush Company about 10 o'clock lastnight. It was caused by the crossing of electric wires. Boon the extensive plant was in flames, and no effort could save it from complete ruin. Suddenly the cry went up that the city jail and the Maryland penitentiary buildings, fronting on Madison Street, half a block away, were afire.

From The Buffalo Courier, A professional man of Buffalo, who, for the past few months, has been paying $31 a month for two rooms, which he had to furnish himself, recently discovered that his landlady paid only $20 a month for the entire house. The landlady is now looking for another tenant.

SALAMANCA, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Fire yesterday at East Otto destroyed a row of wooden business houses and the Methodist Church. The loss is $32,000, with insurance of $27,000. The heaviest loss is John Laing Son, general merchandise. $10,000.

BAY ST. Louis, La., Oct 14. -- The terrible cyclone of Oct. 1, which destroyed so many liv vividly recalls an incident that will ever live in the memory of the Gulf State residents, the destruction of Last Island, off the Louisiana coast, by a cyclone and tidal wave, Sept 12, 1856. Last Inland was a long, low streak of green, bound around the edge with a line of dazzlingly white sand.
By a New-Yorker, long resident in Brazil, who lately returned from Rio Janeiro, the following statement was made yesterday to The New-York Times:
LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Americans were weak and dull to-day, owing more to the silver question than to Reading or Union Pacific difficulties.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- With to-day's debarkation of common sailors from the Russian fleet assembled at Toulon the Provencal part of this unique international spectacle, which all Europe has been vatching, gets well under way. It would be impossible for the most fanatical devotee of the triple alliance to find any fault with at least this portion of the programme.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 14 -- The Autumn season in Lenox is a very quiet one apparently, in spite of the large number of people here. There have been no large dances this week, mainly because the younger dancing set are getting back to school and to college, but there have been several musicales and dinners, numberless arrivals of a more or less distinguished character, and many driving parties.

The steam yacht Corsair, belonging to J. Pierpont Morgan, was in collision Friday night with New-York Lighterage Tug No. 2. The accident took place about 8:30 o'clock off the toot of Thirty-third Street, North River.

The Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen held a meeting last evening at the Gilsey House. President Henry W. Garfield of Albany presided, and the other officers present were Secretary Fred W. Fortmeyer, Newark, N.J.; Walter Stimpson and James R. Doyle, Boston; Theodore Van Raden and George D. Phillips, this city; Robert H. Pelton, Brooklyn, and H. K. Hinchman, Philadelphia.

Miss Godkin was a tall, ang woman, with a green veil and a spatulate hand. The former she wore invariably, as if it were the natal caul that prevented her from drowning; the latter served to put a solemn emphasis to her speech. When she spoke, her auditors never quite overcame the impulse to look about for her big brother, she had such a heavy bass voice.

There was less variety than might have been expected in the large number of new plays of the last week, although in one sense there was more of "variety" in those among them of American origin than was desirable. Reminders of the music halls cropped up not only in Mr. Harrigan's latest comic play of New-York low life, but in "The Corncracker" and in Mr. Russell's entertainment at Daly's as well.

There are many stories afloat as to the likelihood of "Parsifal's" being produced at Munich. It is said on good authority that the copyright will not expire and that the exclusive rights of Baireuth will be maintained. It appears that according to Austrian law up to date copyright continues only for ten years after the death of the author.

By timely batting the New-Yorks won from the Brooklyns on the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was anything but baseball weather, but the dyed-in-the-wool cranks turned out in full force and watched the contest with their overcoat collars turned up.

TANGIER, Oct. 14 -- The celebration of the Mohammedan festival Moolood was the cause of rioting in a suburb of Fez, known as New-Fez, and several Europeans were maltreated by the fanatical Moors, whose religious fervor was aroused by the festival.

In November, 185-, the sloop-of-war "S." was lying in the harbor or Callao. We ware under sailing orders for Valparaiso and all hands were ordered to be on board by midnight. We had a very good lot of officers and a very efficient crew.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- I confess to a strong liking for the opera comique -- for the very old opera comique. It Is cleaner and sweeter than the vaudeville, especially with song and modern dance thrown in, and it is less solemn than the grand opera. Everything seems fit, nice, and easy. The singers ace admirably as a rule, and the actors sing with care.

That high-class storm which the weather prophets said would be a factor in the yacht race of Friday, and which astonished a great number of people by getting here on schedule time, left many mementos of its hurried visit. It took the usual liberties with telegraph wires, swung signs from, their fastenings, capsized chimneys, and made itself generally objectionable to everybody and particularly to the world afloat.

The local political situation in this city, just on the eve of the City County Convention, is almost without a parallel. It is the first time in many years that there has not been an anti-Tammany Democratic combination of some art in the field at this stage of the campaign.

Joseph Hoffman, a prisoner in the Kings County Penitentiary, who was sentenced Friday by Judge Moore, in Brooklyn, to five years' imprisonment for trying to murder three persons, committed suicide in his cell yesterday morning by strangling himself with a cord from his cot. Hoffman lived at 175 Harrison Street. He was in love with Maggie Brownfleck of 91 South First Street, who refused to marry him.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The following shows the result of the examination of the Merchants Bank of Lookport, made after it was closed by the Banking Department on the sixth day of this month:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The statement of the United States Treasurer, showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day, ia as follows:

The bids for the construction of the three new gunboats, Nos. 7, 8, and 9, will be opened at the Navy Department, it is announced, some time this week. The designs for the three new ships have been in the hands of prospective bidders for several days. The appropriation available provides $400,000 for each craft.
The aisles will he paved with tiles and the ohancel with meanic. Everything else will be of oak.

The members of the stranded English Military Tournament have as yet fonnd no one to send them back to England. Superintendent Blake of the Board of Charities and Correction said yesterday that the Messrs. Mackenzie, the backers of the show, ware bound to send the men book to England, as they were brought over to this conntry under a contract which guaranteed their return.

The first of the Autumn course of lectures to teachers of the schools of New-York City and State, under the auspices of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, was given by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore at the American Museum of Natural History, in Central Park, yesterday.

EASTPORT, L.L, Oct. 14. -- The Kev. Daniel E. Day. pastor of the Methodist Church in this village, has resigned and left for parts unknown. The pastor's departure is the result of the congregation's expressed wish that he retire from the Church.

The fact that the fastest yacht that has ever come after the cup, and perhaps the fastest yacht, all round, that has ever been turned out of a British shipyard, is forced to go back without the trophy she came for, is not likely to discourage British yachtsmen. On the contrary, it is likely to stimulate them to fresh exertions, when taken in connection with the circumstances of the latest contest.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The terrific wind and rain storm of Friday night did great damage in the trait-growing district of Ulster County. Trees were uprooted and grape vines were blown down, destroying many tons of unpicked grapes. The peach crop, which was just being gathered, suffered great damage, and the peaches cover the ground under the trees. Many apples were blown off and the trees broken.

The past week among real estate men has lacked any marked indications of business. Sales have been infrequent and have been mainly confined, as for some weeks past, to residences. Efforts to get loans on realty have been a little more urgent, and responses have been somewhat more encouraging. The loan during the week of $100,000 of savings-bank money in one sum for five years, at 4 1/2 per cent., was a notable one.

Forty-fifth Street, near the North River, and opposite the premises of the New-York Manure Company, was flooded yesterday morning by the heavy rain of Friday night. The high tide had backed up the water and filled the server, so there was no outlet for the water in the street.

From The Gentlewoman. Passing through town I met a young American in Bond Street gazing wistfully about. I knew she was American by the peculiarly pretty pallor of her skin, her neat but perfectly plain black gros grain skirt, and faultlessly-fitting and equally, plain cloth jacket.

From The London Globe. According to a Foreign Office report, the production of lead pencils, which is considerable in Bavaria, is much affected by Austrian competition. The high tariffs in many foreign countries have contracted the export markets, and the consequence is a glut of pencils in Bavaria and Germany generally. It may be of interest to give the substance of a statement by Mr. Johann Faber, the large Nurnberg pencil manufacturer.

-- The Boston Symphony Orchestra will give five concerts at Carnegie Music Hall on Wednesday evening, Nov. 8, and Thursday evenings, Dec. 14, Jan. 11, Feb. 8, and March 29. Both in an artistic sense and considered as a popular attraction, this organization has long held a leading place among the musical enterprises of this country.

It is all very will to insist upon Ireland, for the Irish, but let us also insist upon having England for the English. Mr. Astor, the American millionaire who some months ago purchased the Cliveden estate above Maidenhead from the Duke of Westminster, has now canceled the late owner's generous permission to those who use this reach of the River Thames to land upon the Cliveden bank.

From The Baltimore American. Miss Julia Cooney, aged sixteen years, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J.T. Cooney, 1,720 West Fayette Street, died of typhoid fever, after an illness of nine days. She was a twin sister of Miss Agnes Cooney-Agnes also had the fever, but is convalescent, although fears are expressed that she may be again endangered, because of her great grief, the bond of sympathy between the two girls being moat remarkable.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14. -- By starting the horses soon after 10 o'clock this morning the balance of the programme for the breeders' meeting was disposed of except the 2:26 and 2:30 class for trotters, which could not be called before the time limit expired, at 4 o'clock this afternoon. The track dried very last under the combined influence of the sun and a strong breeze, but it handicapped the fliers all through.

Eleven young men from Princeton, N.J., who are students at the college down there, entertained eleven members of the Crescent Athletic Club at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. A game of football, with two intervals of thirty minutes each, was the form the entertainment took, and when the hour or play was ended Princeton's lads had scored 26 points.

The most Interesting matter in military circles during the last week was the sharp light in Company C. Sixty-ninth Regiment, over the choice of a Captain in place of Capt. McCarthy, recently commissioned Major. There are two candidates. First Lieut. John O'Connell and Second Liout. Edward Cassin. Cassin charges his ranking officer with bringing members into the company favorable to his candidacy for Captain.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Oct. 14 -- P.M. The storm of last night prostrated telegraph lines in all directions, leaving New-York practically cut off from other financial centres. Trading in the stock market to-day was therefore less active than it would otherwise have been, and yet there was a fair amount of business done for a Saturday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct 14. -- The Hudson County Democratic Convention met at Democratic Headquarters, 340 Grove Street, at 3 o'clock this afternoon. Although the cut-and-dried nomination of Edward R. Stanton for Sheriff was carried through, according to programme, the affair was not a love feast.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Herald of yesterday contained the following from its Washington correspondent:
A paper read lately by Miss Ada Heather-Bigg before the British Association presented some new considerations of the much-debated topic of woman's work at home.

From The Christian Intelligencer. An American capitalist, who is a keen observer, is reported to have said that he did not believe that there was an American citizen whose income represented a salary who was not living beyond his means. And he added that, if the man had a family, he was bringing up that family to standards and wants that he could not honestly gratify.

The Vigilant, the successful defender of the America's Cup, was taken up to New-Rochelle yesterday afternoon. She quietly bobbed, at her anchor off Bay Ridge yesterday morning, modestly proclaiming that she was the champion of the world. A little further down the bay the black-hulled Valkyrie was tugging at her anchor chains.

Charles A. Schieren was nominated for Mayor of Brooklyn by the Republican City Convention shortly before midnight last night after a long and exciting session, during which Jacob Worth, the party "boss," was completly "turned down."

William J. Buttling, Chairman of the Kings County Republican General Committee, was unanimously nominated yesterday afternoon by the Republican County Convention in Brooklyn for Sheriff of Kings County.
A detailed list of the offerings of real estate at auction for the present week is subjoined:

Charles A. Schieren was born in Dusseldorf, Rhenish Prussia, in 1842. In 1856, when fourteen years of age, he emigrated, with his parents, to this country. He had received an admirable public-school education in Germany, and was thus early fitted to battle with the world. In his youth he learned the cigarmakers' trade, and assisted his father in business on Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

"Polo Jim" Jefferson, Starter Caldwell's assistant, will be master of ceremonies at to-morrow night's cake walk at the Central Opera House, East Sixty-seventh Street, between Third and Second Avenues. There will also be a side-splitting watermelon-eating match and buzzard and wing dancing galore. The Unique Quartet will sing, as will Fred J. Piper, late tenor with the "Black Pattl."

The situation in Brooklyn is cleared and greatly improved by the nomination by the Republican Convention last evening of Mr. CHARLES A. SCHIEREN. This is conclusive evidence that the hold of the Worth machine upon the party is loosed, and that the men of sense and honesty can, on occasion, determine its action.
The weekly bank statement, issued today, showed an increase in reserve of $5,267,325. The banks now hold $33,896,050 in excess of the legal requirements.

From The London Telegraph. Considerable grumbling continues at the fact that the 3,000,000f. paid by the Siamese Government in accordance with the stipulations contained in the ultimatum has not yet been distributed among the interested parties. Particulars now to hand from the far East show that the committee which was to have sat at the beginning of this month for the purpose of arranging the details of this partition has not yet been appointed.

Gov. Roswell P. Flower had some things to say about Judge Maynard, and he said them yesterday to the reporters at the Windsor Hotel. The burden of his statement, was a defense of Judge Maynard and, incidentally, of his own action in appointing him.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Cornell and Union played football at Percy Field this afternoon. A large delegation of students witnessed the game, and several of the Faculty were interested spectators.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- A terrible experience was had by George Johnson and Fred Hansen of the lightship during the storm last night. At midnight the cable which held the ship to the breakwater parted, and in an instant the craft was pitching at the mercy of the waves, which seemed about to crush it against the rocks.

A meeting was held at the clubhouse of the Arion Society, Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, last evening, to decide whether the society should accept the invitation extended by the City of New-York to take part in the exercises on Manhattan Day at the World's Fair. As only about thirty singers responded to the call which had been sent out, however, it was impossible to settle the matter.

The first prize in the chess tournament was won by Lasker yesterday. The Tenton defeated Showalter in a Bay Lopez after thirty-three moves, and having therefore registered eleven wins, which no other competitor can score, he takes the first prize. The other games resulted as follows:

Plaid taffeta baby ribbon is used on children's white felt hats for Autumn wear. Plaques of the soft white felt are plaited into low and very small round crowns that are tied around with the ribbon, which seems to be holding the slight fullness in place. Loose rosettes of the ribbon are arranged on the brim, and one or two lengths serve as strings.

Among the passengers of the American liner Paris, which yesterday arrived from Southampton, were Lady Henry Somerset, Mr. and Mrs. E. Remenyi and Miss Adrienne Remenyi. Lady Somerset went direct to Chicago, where she is to preside at the meeting of the World's Christian Temperance Union. Mr. Remenyi accompanies his daughter, who will shortly make her American debut as a soprano in Chicago.
DETROIT, Oct. 15. -- A general alarm of fire was turned in at 12:30 o'clock this morning for a big fire in Boydell Brothers' large paint and oil factory.

WEST POINT, Oct. 7 -- The new gymnasium, which has just been finished, attracts more attention than any other building on the post. Its style of architecture does not belong to any particular class. It being made up of the most artistic parts of ancient and modern designs. Granite, with brick lining, has been used throughout, and it is absolutely fire-proof.

William Smith, thirty-five years old, head stoker on the steamship City of Rome of the Anchor Line, was drowned late Friday night at the foot of West Twenty-fourth Street while endeavoring to save the life of a woman who had fallen overboard. Smith had been for sixteen years in the employ of the line.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 14. -- The affairs of the Northwestern Guaranty Loan Company remain in a hopeless tangle, and it will be many a long day before the people of Vermont, New-Hampshire, Massachusetts, and Northern New-York will realize upon the millions of "guaranteed" paper which they hold against the greatest financial swindle of recent years.

JAMAICA, L.L, Oct. 14. -- There was a big gathering of Democrats at the County Convention, held here to-day. The township leaders were all present. Factional Long Island City had delegations from each division in attendance.

How felt has been the want that the woman's apartment house, for which Mrs. Candace Wheeler and Miss Janet Lewis have labored unceasingly, is going to supply, may be gathered from the statement that over 100 applications are already filed for the 140 rooms and apartments that the building will afford.

Ministers of the Gospel are usually chary about taking an active part in political movements, even when broad questions of public morality are involved, lest they be liable to the charge of using their influences to promote party ends. But occasionally there are questions of public morals of the highest importance to society, which are connected with the political action of the people or the conduct of public officials without having any partisan aspect.

The disadvantages of having a tender heart now appear with distinctness to Mr. Arthur E. Graham of 636 Washington Street, who went aside from his own personal concerns and got into a police court yesterday for his pains.

The press dispatches yesterday morning confirmed the prediction of Senator QUAY that a compromise financial bill was to be presented to Congress. The plan outlined is that this compromise shall be by caucus made a Democratic measure. The Republicans will not be consulted regarding it. Their support will not be asked. The Democrats, being a majority in the Senate, will frame the measure, accept it in caucus, and present and pass it through the Senate.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Oct. 14. -- There is a big revolt against the "bosses" in Richmond County. As a result, there will be an independent ticket in the field this Fall. It will be made up irrespective of party. At first the bosses pooh-poohed the idea, but during the last two weeks meetings of Cleveland Democrats have been held in every district in the county.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 14. -- The Republican County Convention of Westchester County was held here to-day. D.W. Travis of Peekskill presided. Dr. Archibald D. Banning of Mount Vernon, Dr. Charles A. Miles of Yonkers, and Joseph A. Apgar of Peekskill were nominated for Coroners, and Walter H. Haight for Justice of Sessions.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes made a visit to the new courthouse in Pemberton Square the other morning, and was escorted through a portion of it by his son, Justice Holmes, whom he met at the entrance to the lobby of the Supreme Court.
The coming international test at Sandy Hook of six-pounder, rapid-fire guns will be supplemented, it is announced, by a test of 4.7-inch rapid-fire guns open to the world.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 14. -- Cornelius J. Driscoll, a young business man of this place, was arrested this afternoon on a charge of grand larceny and looked up in default of $2,000 bail. The complainant is Charles Crowley. Collector of the New-Brighton Public School District. The charge is that Driscoll has stolen $2,000 of the school funds. Crowley is an old and illiterate man.

E. Ellery Anderson, a Government Director, and one of the receivers of the Union Pacific Railroad, said yesterday that he regarded the receivership as the best step that could have been taken to protect all interests in the property. He believed that the necessary reorganization would be conducted on lines that would preserve the unity and integrity of the entire system.
The following delegates to the Constitutional Convention were nominated at the Tammany Senatorial District Conventions last night:

-- Gov. Thomas G. Jones of Alabama delivered, an interesting address before the Virginia Division of the Army of Northern Virginia, in the State Capitol in Richmond, on Thursday evening, his topic being the incidents of the last days of Gen. Lee's army before the surrender at Appomattox. Incidentally, he said that on the retreat Gen. Lee assumed at times a cheerfulness toward young officers that almost amounted to playfulness.

NEWPORT, R.I, Oct. 14. -- One of the heaviest windstorms Newport has experienced has prevailed here for the last twenty-four hours. The Fall River Line steamer Pilgrim, Capt. Baylies Davis, due here at 3 o'clock this morning, did not reach her dock till 6 o'clock this afternoon, after one of the most tempestuous trips the boat has ever had.

John Roberts, champion billiard and pool player of England and Alfredo De Oro, the American pool champion, will begin their match in Madison Square Garden Concert Hall to-morrow night. The contest is for a stake of $2,000 and the net gate receipts. The match will be played on an American 5 by 10 and an English 6 by 12 table, the players alternating at each fourth frame.

From The Chicago Record, Oct. 11. Four covered wagons of the Exposition Company raced about the grounds yesterday all day to and from the bank in the Administration Building Every wagon was loaded to its canvas top with bags of money gathered from the different concessioners and Superintendent Tucker's office.

The Independent Order of Benal Berith celebrated its semi-centennial anniversary last night at the Grand Central Palace by a golden jubilee banquet at which, joy was unrestrained and conviviality chased the rosy waiters with flying feet. Fifteen tables were laid for nearly400 persons, and there were no empty seats.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 24. -- The Chicago's run down from Havre to this port was made under very exceptional circumstances of wind and weather, and at a rats of about 10.5 knots per hour, which, for a ship that has not been docked since June, may be considered as a very satisfactory showing, under cruising conditions.

The new building of the Twenty-sixth Ward branch of the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn will be ready for occupancy Oct. 31. A committee of women of the ward will open the building with a fair, the proceeds to be devoted to furnishing the building. The fair will continue until Nov. 4.

Jacob M. Patterson, Chairman of the Execative Committee of the Republican County Committee, and John Sabine Smith, President of the Republican County Committee, are searching in the highway a and the byways of this city for good, fat Republican lambs whe are willing to sacrifice themselves upon the crumbling altar of the "Grand Old Party," and go down to certain defeat in November on the local ticket.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Charley Courtney will remain at Cornell this year as the coach of her crews. Commodore Hagerman has this Fall made a thorough canvass of all the members of the different schools and colleges here, and the necessary $1,200 has finally been secured. But Courtney announced that he had not waited for the full subscription of the guarantee fund, but had early in the week declined to go elsewhere.

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date last year. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Despite the fact that at their last regular meeting the Linden Township Committee revoked the license of the Linden Blood Horse Association, racing will be begun at that plcturesque track to-morrow. The meet will last ten days.

"My duties in thin, as in all other matters, are clearly defined by the code. No charges against the officials of Kings County for neglect of duty have as yet been received by me, and till I get such charges on which to work I can do absolutely nothing."

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, Issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $5,267,325. The banks now hold $33,896,050 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $2,374,200, an increase in specie of $6,006,700, an increase in legal tenders of $2,325,700, an increase in deposits of $12,260,300, and an increase in circulation of $16,800,300.

George Dunn, the night watchman at the Marlborough Hotel, who was assaulted by his wife Saturday, died early yesterday morning in the New-York Hospital without having recovered consciousness. Mrs. Dunn used a hammer in her attack on her husband. On his head and face there were found twenty-six distinct wounds.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn yesterday morning delivered a qule, argumentative and earnest discourse directed against the law breakers of Kings County, the Brooklyn Democratic ring, and the promoters of the allowed "scientific contests" for points at the Coney Island Athletic Club which he characterized as brutal prize fights.

The Executive Committee of the Seventh Regiment Rifle club will issue this week the armory programme of matches to be shot during the sea son of 1893-94. The programme, with the exception of three new matches, is practically the same as last year, the conditions governing the matches, special prizes, ties, and challenges being identical with those of the last shooting season.

whether an appreciation of a man simply as a soldier is particularly attractive to the general reader may be doubted. Biographies of individuals famous in art, science, or war would be dry reading if we omitted the personal traits. Mr. Hughes in this volume on Gen. Joseph E. Johnston gives an introductory chapter devoted to the lineage, parentage, and youth of one who was Perhaps the ablest soldier of the South.

Don Cleofas Leandro Perez Zambullo on a certain dark night in October, 1707, had as everybody knows, two adventures, one of them common enough since his day as before it, and the other quite without precedent then, and not duplicated for many a score of years, but which in these times can be not only repeated, but infinitely improved upon by anybody with a nickel at his disposal.

The delegates to the Trades and Labor Conference that was organized on Tuesday decided yesterday to go into politics, but, they said, they would not have anything to do with Tammany Hall or any other old party.

The Rev. A.C. Dixon, pastor of the Hanson Place Baptist Church of Brooklyn, preached a vigorous sermon last evening on "Politics, Pugilism, and Power in Brooklyn." In the the course of his sermon he said:

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Three cases of choleraic disease developed to-day in the Greenwich workhouse, where 150 such cases had been previously reported. The total number of deaths in the workhouse from this disease is eight.

The Rev. Robert B. Montgomery, paster of the Greene Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, struck a telling blow at Isaao H. Maynard in his sermon yesterday morning. He also mentioned the immorality that stalks abroad in the land, and paid his attention to the impending international prize fight at Coney Island.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- The business situation continues very mixed. The fact that tine crops are not up to expectations, the uncertainties existing as to financial and tariff legislation, and the severe scrutiny of commercial credit naturally operate for conservatism. The business world is waiting for a clearing up of the debris which is obstructing trade.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- Through mud and mire the fifth annual road race of the Boston Athletic Association, eighty-three cyclists, rode yesterday. Three scratch men started, but only one, James Clark, finished. Croons of Buffalo met with an accident early in the race, and Ed McDuffee dropped out near the finish. The winner was Edward Clark, and his victory caused much surprise.

-- Gov. Jones relates that shortly before Appomattox Gen. Robert E. Lee astonished a young Confederate staff officer by looking quite intently at him and asking if "those people surprised your command this morning?" The officer was taken aback at the question, for he had just reported that the troops were in good order, and he replied "No," and asked if such a report had come to him.

Thomas J. Patterson, Democratic nominee for Sheriff of Kings County, appeared to be very much pleased with his nomination when seen last night at his home by a reporter for The New-York Times. When asked regarding his opinion about the Coney Island Athletic Club prize fights. Mr. Patterson was less ready to talk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- There was another armor-plate test at the naval proving ground at Indian Head yesterday. The target was a twelve-inch Harvey nickel-steel plate, representing the side armor of the Maine. Two shots were fired, one being a Carpenter Projectile made to this country and the other a Holtzer shell made in France.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Mr. John L. Thomas, ex-Congressman, ex-Collector of the Port, a genial wit and after-dinner speaker, died to-day at his residence from heart failure, brought on by an abscess of the bladder.

TOULON, Oct. 15. -- Few persons slept in Toulon last night. The streets were almost as crowded at 3 o'clock this morning as at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The illumination of shops and private houses did not cease until daybreak, and the thousands sang and caroused under the electric light without a sign of weariness.

The steamship Colorado, which sailed from Galveston Oct. 7, reached this port yesterday, after having passed through a series of remarkable adventures. She encountered a hurricane off the Florida coast, which Second Officer Frank Kenny, who told the story to a reporter for The New-York Times last night, said was the severest he had ever seen.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The interest of the students is once more centrel in the football team. The team is steadily improving upon the vigorous coaching of Orton Brown. 92, Garnent and several all others of the old plavers, who are now back.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 14. -- The condition of the local money market continues to grow gradually easier, and at last there has been a break in the minimum rate on loans and discount, (from 7 to 6 1/2 per cent.,) at which latter figure some business has been done this week. Call money between banks remains at 5 per cent., and at 6 on loans to customers.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The principal event of interest at Yale last week was the annual convention of the New-England Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools, which met in Dwight Hall Friday and yesterday. The fact that never before in its eight years' history has the association met at Yale caused elaborate and extensive preparations to be made by the local committee.
With satisfaction, residents of the east side have noted the progress made recently by the Third Avenue Surface Railroad toward getting its cable road in operation.

A number of notable sales of real estate at auction are set down for to-day in the two salesrooms. Chief among them is that of the group of Bowery and other east side property belonging to the Pearsall estate offered by Messrs. Harnett Co. Messrs. James L. Wells and James S. McQuillen also appear in connection with desirable realty. The detailed list follows:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The Rev. M.L. Gates, Ph.D., pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Jersey City Heights, prayed this morning that the Senators of the United States might cease their oratorical displays while hundreds of thousands were in distress and were brought to the verge of starvation perhaps by the failure of the Senate to pass the silver repeal bill.

BATH, Oct. 15. -- The anti-snapper leaders in First Assembly District of Steuben County came into to-day's Assembly Convention and surrendered to the machine unconditionally. Anti-Snappers Charles F. Kingsley and George W. Peck were among the delegates from Bath. They occupied front seats and applauded Controller Frank Campbell, who opened the convention with a speech.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Semi-official newspapers Say that the complete financial proposals of the Government will be laid before the Reichstag when the Deputies reassemble on Nov. 20. These proposals are said to be such as will command the majority obtained for the Army bill. After they shall have been passed, the Deputies will be expected to consider several social reforms which the Emperor has long had at heart.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 15. -- A head-end collision occurred on the Chicago, Rook Island and Pacific Railroad at Paxico, twenty miles west of Topeka, at 2 o'clock this morning between a freight and a passenger train. Two colored tramps riding on the mail car were Instantly killed and several persons were Injured.

Now that most of the nominations for the As embly have been made by both the Democrats and Republicans, the Republicans are hard at work Uguring on districts they think they on arry in this city. In the present Assein by the entire New-York city delegation is Democratic. Twenty-nine members are Tammany men and one is an anti-Tammnany Democrat.

The Rev. T. Calvin MoClelland, pastor of the old Bushwick Reformed Church, Bushwick Avenue, near North Second Street, Brooklyn. made last evening one of the most scathing denunciations of the promoters of prize fighting at Coney Island and the Brooklyn ringsters and their satellites thus far pronounced in any pulpit.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct 15. -- Hundreds of spectators witness the daily practice of the football team. The managers of the eleven announce the it is now but a few days when they will be obliged to close the gates to spectators in order to enable the eleven to practice its new tricks in secret, although the big games are a month away yet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Money continues to flow into bank vanits here. The World's Fair is responsible for a great increase in funds held by banks and by private individuals. So many visitors have been here in the last few weeks, and they have spent so much money in sightseeing and in the payment of hotel and other bills.

The Rev. Wellesley W. Bowdish, pastor of the Embury Methodist Episcopal Church of Brooklyn, preached last night on the political situation in Brooklyn and the alleged scientific contest with gloves that has been arranged to take place at Coney Island. His subject was, "Is Brooklyn a Decent City to Live In?" After describing what a beautiful city Brooklyn is naturally, and how desirable a place for a home, he said:

From many Brooklyn pulpits yesterday earnest protests were uttered against the practice of holding prize fights at Coney Island under the flimsy disguise of "scientific contests," and under the patronage and protection of Kings County officials.

The Rev. R. Stanley Povey of the Throop Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, in his sermon yesterday spoke of the power of Satan and the utter subjection of many over whom he exercised sway. After reference to the temptation of Christ, to whom the evil one had offered the kingdoms of the world for His homage and the Saviour's stinging rebuke, Mr. Povey said:

Two stables at Fleetwood Park, Morrisania, occupied by the New-York Driving Club, were burned yesterday morning. The stables contained several valuable trotting horses, and two of them were also burned. Another horse was scorched, and his keeper was burned about the head, neck, and bands.

MANISTEE, Mich., Oct. 15. -- The identity of the four-masted schooner reported ashore near here has been established. The vessel is the Minnehaha of Cleveland, Capt. William Packer, with a cargo of corn, Of the seven on board the schooner, but one, Capt. Packer, escaped. Those drowned were:
The "Letters of James Russell Lowell," edited by Prof. Charles Eliot Norton, will be issued in a few days by Harper Brothers. Arrangements have been made for their simultaneous publication in London.

The Secretary of the Metropolitan District Cricket League has made out the averages of the players who took part in the championship series of games. The batting averages he made up some time go but not until Saturday was it finally known that M.R. Cobb had gained the bowling prize in the first section, L. Webster in the second, and A.G. Rainbow in the second eleven section.
Charles A. Schieren, Republican candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, will accept the nomination of Saturday night, and will work for success. To a reporter for The New-York Times, he yesterday said:

BUFFALO, Oct. 15. -- In the great storm which centred in Buffalo on Saturday and swept Lake Erie with irresistible fury, the propeller Dean Richmond was lost. She foundered off Van Buren Point, which is a few miles below Dunkirk. Some time Saturday night or early Sunday morning she went down, with her crew of eighteen.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 15. -- It is announced here that a record trotting meeting will be given Oct. 25, 26, and 27 at the Terre Haute track. The Doble, Starr, Sahsbury and other stables will take part, and if the weather is favorable, Naucy Hanks, Arion, Stamboul, Belle Vara, Flying Jib, and Directum will make a final effort to reduce the world's mark this year. Thin is intended to wind up the trotting season.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 15. -- On Friday last, about 10 A.M., while off Shinnecock Light, the training ship Portsmouth, Commander C.J. Barclay, was nearly cut in two by the steamer City of Paris. The Portsmouth was running before the gale for Newport, when the steamer suddenly hove in sight off her port quarter.

The beautiful Roman Catholic Church of St. Agnes, Hoyt and Sackett Streets, Brooklyn, was consecrated with the most solemn ceremonies of the Catholic ritual yesterday morning, and the grand seal of the Church was placed upon a work remarkable for the celerity with which it was accomplished by the energetic pastor, the Rev. J.S. Duffy.

In spite of the publication of the shameful evidence as to the practices on account of which the Republican candidate for Governor in Iowa was disbarred by the Republican officers of the Interior Department, and in the face of the candidate's admission that all the evidence is genuine, the party leaders, acting under the advice of JAMES S. CLARKSON, have determined to make no change in their ticket.

The candor of Gov. FLOWER, while it is very far from disarming criticism, makes reasoning with him extremely difficult. The Chief Executive of a great State who praises a Justice of the Court of Appeals for larceny is -- at present at least -- entirely too blind to the simplest requirements of his post to permit the hope that he can be made to see them.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The difficulty relating to the publication of two rival Cornell Daily Suns has finally been amicably settled. For two weeks past both papers have been working for their very existence, and both striving for student popularity. The Cornell Daily Sun has been published for thirteen years, and has always been a student paper, but the constitution of the publication never rested in the student body.

The new building of the New-York Retail Grocers' Union at 138 and 140 East Fifty-seventh Street, was opened last night and the grocers invited their friends to help christen it. Every grocer within comfortable reach of the city who could get there responded to the invitation. The union has 800 members.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- There are unmistakable indications of a very big split in the Democratic Party in Tonawanda, For some time past there has been a disposition among the Sheehan men to patch up differences and make friends with the Cleveland, faction. It is quite evident that the followers of Sheehan have not been successful, and they are beginning to feel very much alarmed at the attitude taken by their opponents.

The organization of incendiaries whose purpose is to prevent the marketing of cotton in the Southern States is now at work in North Carolina. In Cleveland County at least one cotton gin has been burned, and the owners of others are forced to guard them by night to prevent the destruction of their property by the scoundrels, from whom they have received warning.

The popular prejudice against silver is not shared by the newsboys who run about the City Hall Park. It is the custom of these youngsters in Summer, to perch on the rim of the famous "Bill Tweed fountain" and Invite passers-by to throw small coins into the brimming basin and watch the boys dive for them Sometimes they get the money and sometimes it rolls out of their sight and reach.

NEW-BRIGHTON, B.I., Oct. 16 -- The newlyorganized Richmond County Democrats, the anti-machine Democracy, and the Republicans of Staten Island held their County Conventions here this afternoon. The conventions were held in separate halls, but the programme arranged by a conference committee from both was carried out and a fusion ticket was nominated.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The civil marriage between Lord Terence Blackwood, son of the Marquis of Dufferin and Ava, British Ambassador to France, and Miss Flora Davis, daughter of Mr. John Davis of New-York, having been celebrated at the Mairie Saturday, the religious ceremony took place to-day in the English Church of the Holy Trinity in the Avenue de l'Alma.

Joseph G. Overbeck, at one time a teacher at St. Francis College, was held in the Butler Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for stealing Father Duffy's beretta and hymn book from St. Agnes's Church Sunday during the consecration services. It is also suspected he robbed the poor box, but that charge was not made against him.
John McGovern lies dying at the Gouverneur Hospital, another victim of the greed of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad.

The fourth annual convention of the Medal of Honor Legion was held yesterday. Eighty veterans of the order, which is composed of men who have been awarded medals because of special acts of daring performed in defense of the Union, gathered in the Holland House. It was the first reunion held in New-York.

The following Republicans were nominated last night in Brooklyn, for State Senators: Second District -- William H. Qninn; Third District -- William H. Reynolds; Fourth District -- Adjourned; Fifth District -- Daniel Bradley.

NORTHPORT, Wyoming, Oct. 16 -- News has reached here by courier that the band of Indians who murdered Brice and Nelson last Monday night have been captured by the Sheriff's posse, assisted by the Indian police. There were four Indians in the band which murdered the two miners. They were surrounded in a canon in the mountains, and in the fight which ensued one of the murderers was killed.

President Wilson of the Board of Health has unsheathed his lancet and, at the head of all his surgical troops, has advanced upon the town, as eager for the fray as ever was King Richard. The fact is, the Board of Health has tasted blood, and nothing short of wholesale vaccination, sparing neither man, woman, nor child, will satisfy their lust for health.

The nomination of the reform Republican, Charles A. Schieren, for Mayor of Brooklyn is hailed with delight by all good citizens of Brooklyn, and there is every indication that he will receive the support of the great mass of his party as well as that of the independent element of the city.

It was decided at a meeting of the Arion Society held at the clubhouse, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, last evening to accept the city's invitation to take part in the Manhattan Day celebration at the Chicago Exposition, provided suitable sleeping-car accommodations should be furnished for the singers. Sixty members of the chorus were present and promised to go.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Interest was centred to-day in Atchison securities, which declined from the opening on rumors of an impending receivership and consequent liquidation. Bull leaders of Amsterdam sold large blocks, both of shares and bonds, the former falling 1 point, and incomes 3 1/2 points from the opening.

Richard Mansfield's play at Herrmann's last night was the ever-popular "Prince Karl." This week he will change his bill every night. Next Monday night he will put forward" The Merchant of "Venice," acting Shylock for the first time.

Assemblyman McManus of the Eighteenth Assembly District has decided not to run as an independent candidate for the Assembly this year, and he says he does not believe that Civil Justice Murray will be in the field as a candidate for his present place against Mr. O'Gorman, who has been nominated by Tammany Hall.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The call for a special meeting of the Society of the Sons of New-York to arrange plans for aiding the celebration of Manhattan Day at the World's Fair was responded to by over 100 members. Ex-Mayor De Witt C. Cregier, President of the society, announced the purpose of the meeting and introduced W.H. McDonough, private secretary to Mayor Gilroy, and O.C. Cockey of the New-York committee.

"These are times tnat try men's souls." The speaker was one of the leading professors in a New-York medical college, and he was addressing an audience of ladies and gentlemen who had assembled to listen to his wisdom.
John Gennadius, until recently Greek Minister to the United States and to Great Britain, arrived from Europe on Saturday, and is at the Park Avenue Hotel.

The nomination of Mr. Schieren as candidate for Mayor on the part of the Republican City Convention, after a conference with the representatives of the different Independent organizations, and with their approval, brings about the possibility of wresting the city administration from the claws of the Democratic ring.

The fact that the securities of the Speyer loan have been advertised for sale at auction to-morrow has attracted universal attention to that important factor in the Reading situation. Since the receivership there have been constant references made to the loan, yet the facts concerning it have never been made public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- It is perfectly plain now to any schoolboy that the country has its eyes on the Senate and that that impotant body is aware of the fact and of the unpleasant truth that it is making a parliamentary ass of itself.

At the monthly meeting of the Republican Club held last evening at the clubhouse, 450 Fifth Avenue, John S. Smith presiding, the following resolutions, offered by John Freeman Baker, condemning the nomination of Judge Maynard for the Court of Appeals and indorsing the nomination of Ed-ward T. Bartlett for that office were unanimously adopted:

Thomas Coran is a truck driver for Kemble Smith, contractors, and his team is composed of two of the prettiest dapple grays in town. Yesterday morning he and one of the horses had an experience that neither will forget for some time.
CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 16 -- The banking house of Barron, Forbes Co., founded half a century ago, has gone into liquidation, prior to reorganization.

TOULON, Oct. 16 -- The round of fetes that began on the arrival of the Russian fleet at this port is beginning to pall upon the residents of this city, and upon the thousands of visitors from other parts of France. To-day the streets of the city were comparatively quiet. The people are tired out, and thousands of the visitors are leaving for their homes.

Arrangements are in progress to send home to England by the White Star steamer to-morrow the men recently engaged in the English military tournament at Madison Square Garden. A conference took place at the British Consul's office yesterday for the purpose of helping collections for that purpose. The St. George Society of this city has agreed to help.

Capt. Foutz finished in the second division in the League race, but his team won the metropolitan baseball championship from Capt. Ward and his band of giants in the easiest possible manner. They scored victories in four of the six games played. The deciding contest was played yesterday at Eastern Park in the presence of a hundred men, a dozen small boys, and three ladles.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 16 -- The Linden Township Committee held another meeting to-night, and as usual for the past two months, the Linden Blooded Horse Association was the main topic discussed. The opening of the track to-day was an incentive to pack the Linden Hotel to its utmost capacity by race-track and anti-race-track sympathizers, the racing people predominating.
