For good ordinary German farces, "Die Strohwittwe" and "Der Sechste Sinn" are good ordinary German farces, solidly and honestly built, not wild laughter producers, but nevertheless furnishing considerable material for innocent enough merriment. That seemed to be about the judgment pronounced upon them last night at the Irving Place Theatre, where they were played by Mr. Conried's company of comedians.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen began its first biennial convention in Faneuil Hall to-day. It will probably continue for ten days. Over 500 delegates were present, representing every State in the Union and all parts of Canada. It is expected that the convention will be the largest representative gathering of railroad employes ever held in the country.
Lasker established a new world's record yesterday by winning twelve straight games in the international chess tournament. The results in yesterday's games were:

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The National Glass Company, an Illinois corporation, composed of the largest window-glass manufacturing and jobbing firms, will go to pieces to-morrow. A meeting of the stockholders of the company will be held and a formal dissolution declared. This, according to a statement of George P. Kimball, a manufacturer, and perhaps the heaviest jobber in the country, is inevitable.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- In spite of the fact that the Speyer loan is advertised for sale, the opinion here is that it will be renewed. There was some buying of the stock at 9 with this idea. Philadelphia Traction rights were dull at 14 1/4, but the stock advanced in the afternoon to 68 3/4, on light buying.
The Brooklyn "ring" has counted on labor men at every election for years. This year they are threatened by labor men.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 16 -- In the Democratic County Convention, held here to-day, H.M.I. Beckman, a Jersey City lawyer, was nominated for Senator on the first ballot, by a vote of 30 to 15. George H. Cramer was unanimously nominated for the Assembly.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Leon Cavalla's Italian opera "I Pagliacci" ("The Clown") was produced in English for the first time at the Star Theatre here to-night, by the Boston Grand Opera Company. The translation, which is by Willard G. Day, follows the original text closely, and is well adapted to the music.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- it is settled that West Point will play Annapolis Dec. 2 at either Washington or the Naval Academy. Secretary of war Lamont has given his consent, and the boys are working wifh renewed vigor. King is not so badly hurt as to prevent his playing in that game, and the rest of the team ate in good condition, notwithstanding Saturday's defeat.

The work of stripping the Valkyrie was begun yesterday at Bay Ridge. The crow unbent her sails and packed them away in Sawyer's lott, they put back all the fittings that were taken away before the races, and will to-day take off her racing spars. The yacht will then be taken to Hawkins's yard and be hauled out for the Winter.

The accompanying illustrations show the three new war ships autnorized by the last session of Congress to be built for the United States Navy. The bids for the construction of these dreg, vessels will be opened at the Navy Department to-day. Two of the three ships are identical in design.

DUNKIRK, Oct. 16 -- Only one man is known to have escaped from the steamer Dean Richmond, which foundered in Lake Erie Saturday. He was found on the beach near Van Buren Point to-day. His haggard face and sunken eyes told a story of terrible suffering. He was aimlessly wandering up and down the beach, and when spoken to burst into tears, and said he was looking for his dog.

In the real estate salesroom at 111 Broadway yesterday there was quite unusual animation, owing to the interest excited by the announcement that the Pearsall estate property, including realty on the Bowery and elsewhere on the east side, would be sold at auction, in partition proceedings.

Miss Emma Goldman will have to preach her Anarchistic doctrines for a year to come behind the stone walla of a prison. Judge Martine of the Court or General Sessions yesterday sentenced the yellow-halred evangel of disorder to the maximum penalty under the statutes. To-day, unless something unlooked for happens, Miss Goldman will be installed in a cell in the women's penitentiary on Blackwell's Island.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 -- The west-bound Chicago limited train on the Wabash Road left the track one mile south of Nameoka, Ill., at 6:50 to-night, resulting in the injury of some 30 people. The wreck is remarkable in some respects and is without parallel, in that no one was killed out of the 450 passengers.

Army News. H.L. LAUBACH, Twenty-third, is transferred from Company K to Company B of the regiment, and having reported at Fort Sam Houston, under his original order of assignment, will proceed to Fort Bliss, Texas, and report for duty.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- The market here opened weak on lower London quotations and the free offering of all issues of bonds. It looked like a bear raid through London. Under cover of distressing rumors, there was such good buying of stocks that the market rallied, and closed about 1 per cent, higher than it opened.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Oct. 16 -- P.M. Atchison and Missouri Pacific were singled out for attack at the opening of the market to-day, much of the selling of the former coming from London, but whether it was long stock thrown over by investors or only speculative sales for the account of New-York bear operators, which is more than probable, no one can say.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 -- The jubilee of Cardinal Gibbons excites the interest of the city, and the coming of the dignitaries of the Church from every part of the country will give the precincts of the cathedral a liveliness that they have not known since the Archbishop of Baltimore went to Rome and came back a Cardinal.

Majority rule and the representative system have broken down in this country because of the lawlessness of the minority and the timidity of the majority in the Senate at Washington. Debate upon the silver-purchase repeal bill within the legitimate meaning of the word debate ceased weeks ago and obstruction succeeded to it.

Mounted Policeman Thomas Martin laid siege Sunday night to a small shanty at Girard Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-eighth Street, and after many shots on both sides had been fired, he captured the small fort and its solitary inmate, Adolphus Koenig, an old soldier.

Now, every one who has written or talked about newspapers has made a great account of the matter of news, and in these remarks that it has been my opportunity to make, I have not said anything yet on that subject. News is undoubtedly a great thing in a newspaper. A newspaper without news is no newspaper.

The Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street, near Third Avenue, was the scene of much gayety last night. A colored jubilee, pie-eating and watermelon-eating matches had been arranged in conjunction with a mammoth cake walk, and Sixth and Seventh Avenues, as well as Thompson and Bleecker Streets, had sent their complements of dusky dames and gallants to swell the crowd.

The music-hall kind of entertainment is not quite so popular as it was in New-York. There are signs of a gratifying change of public taste. Perhaps the biggest crowd last night was at the Imperial, a genuine London "music hall," although it is conducted by a German-American, George Kraus.

WASHINGTON, Oct 16 -- The conduct of Judge Isaac H. Maynard in the purloining of a corrected election return, in furtherance of an unscrupulous conspiracy to count in one of his party's candidates, in defiance of the verdict of the voters and the mandate of the court, surprised no one who was familiar with his career in Washington.

District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll will not be renominated to-night by the Tammany City and County Convention. He had a conference with Richard Croker upon the subject yesterday, and at a late hour last night he made public his determination not to run, although he had been tendered the nomination.

OTTAWA, Oct. 16 -- In view of the decision of the United States War Department to make a new continuous survey of the St. Lawrence River ship channel from Lake Ontario to Morristown, N.Y., which is almost entirely in United States waters, the Dominion Government has intimated that it will facilitate the survey all it can.

The list of winning owners for the season of 1893 shows, in a surprising way, what a business horse racing has become, and in how commercial a spirit it is pursued. In this part of the world the turf is about twenty-five years old. There was a long lapse between the decline of the old Fashion course, on Long Island, and the revival of racing by the establishment of Jerome Park.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Essex County has an interesting campaign this Fall. It is one of the eight counties that elect Senators. It will also select a Sheriff, Register, and eleven Assemblymen. The contest presents some interesting features on both sides, but the struggle is principally for the nominations.

WASHIHGTON, Oct. 16 -- The report received from Brunswich, Ga., by the Marine Hospital Bureau to-day covers thirty-one new cases or yellow fever there -- eleven white and twenty colored. Three deaths are reported -- two white and one colored. Of the whites one was a man seventy-five years of age. Two new cases are reported at Jesup -- one white and one colored.
EMINGTON, Ill., Oct. 16 -- The entire business portion of Emington was wrecked by a premature explosion of dynamite this afternoon. Five people were Killed and five injured, two of whom cannot live.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- The following is the official programme for the ceremonies attending the unveiling of the Trenton Battle Monument next Thursday:

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 16 -- In the cricket match to-day between the Australians and All-Canada the visitors went first to the bat. They rolled up 298 runs. The Canadians had made 41 with five wickets down when the game was adjourned till to-morrow.

The Times suggests the following means whereby the Senate can reach a vote if the majority is determined to bring that about. It urges "that a motion should be made to proceed to vote on the repeal bill without debate. Any one can make that motion. If the Vice President entertains it, the minority can, if any one of them chooses, appeal from the decision of the Chair.

-- Postmaster Dayton has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship City of New-York arrived there Sunday with mails from Hongkong, Sept. 21; Shanghal, Sept. 23, and Yokohama, Oct. 1, due to arrive in New-York next Friday morning. The next mail for China and Japan will close at the General Post Office, this city, at 6:30 P.M. on Friday for dispatch by the steamship City of New-York from San Francisco.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 16 -- The jury in the Turner will case, which has occupied the attention of the District Court at different terms for a number of years, reached a verdict at midnight last night, after deliberating about forty hours.

Moses Herrman received the Tammany nomination last night for the Assembly in the Twenty-first District. Mr. Herrman is a son of ex-Judge Herrman and is a lawyer, with an office at 229 Broadway. He is popular in the district, and the Tammany leaders believe that he will poll a large vote. His district is a close one this year, and the fight will be an interesting one.
The General Committee of the Kings County Citizens' Union last evening unanimously indorsed the nomination of Charles A. Schieren for Mayor of Brooklyn.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16 -- This week ends the important harness racing of 1893, and the meeting which began this afternoon at Cumberland Park started off with a sensation. First on the card was the dash for yearling trotters, and as Boreal had won so cleverly at Lexington last week in 2:32, he was favorite at 3 to 5 here.

CONCERNING MRS. DRAYTON AND MRS. DEACON. -- The presence or Mrs. J. Coleman Drayton in this city and at Mrs. Edward Parker Deacon at Newport has given life to the old rumors among people of society that the domestic affairs of the Draytons and the Deacons are soon to be settled, either by divorce or by reconciliation. In both oases stronger oredence is given the report of probable reconciliation.

John Roberts, the English champion, is a wonderfully fine billiard player. His clever stroke, position plays, "draws" masses" and round-the-table carroms have surprised the billiard critics of Europe and America, but at pool last night he met his master in the person of Alfredo De Oro, the Cuban expert. They began their match In the pretty concert hall of Madison Square Garden before only a fairsized crowd.

While the Bar Association of this city will take no part in the canvass for the election of a Judge of the Court of Appeals, as an association, the individual lawyers who constitute its membership do not propose to he inactive. They nave appointed a, committee of their own, and propose to arouse the bar of the entire State to a vigorous defense of the purity of the bench.

The ring politicians of Brooklyn, have at last recognized the fact that they made a mistake in going before the voters of Kings County with a prize-fighting club tied to their necks. They have undertaken to convince the protesting clergymen of Brooklyn that prize fights are not fought at Coney Island.

The Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association of New-York, at its first meeting for the coming year at St. Lake's Hospital yesterday, heard a report made by Frederick F. Cook, General Agent of the association, on his recent trip to Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis, St. Louis, and Omaha, where he was sent to urge the founding of Saturday and Sunday Associations.

Superintendent Brady of the Building Department received plans last week for the erection of thirty-one new buildings, to cost $486,000. Plans for alterations to be made to twenty-six structures, at a cost of $48,000, were also received.

Those dissatisfied members of a political party who desire to rebuke or punish the behavior of those who in the capacity of leaders or representatives have misdirected its action are compelled to consider the choice that is presented to them when they are tempted to withhold support from their own party or give it to the opposition.

The "machine" Democratic candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, Mr. Boody, enters upon the campaign handicapped with some very burdensome scandals. In his canvass he will have to carry the Columbian Celebration, the electric light and railway franchises, the excise, and Corbett-Mitchell prize-fight scandals.

There were fresh rumors in circulation yesterday regarding the possibility of the Atchison system being obliged to seek the protection of the courts. President J.W. Reinhart said emphatically that there was no danger of a receivership. He remarked:

Miss Marie Tempest created no little surprise in theatrical circles yesterday by sending to J.M. Hill her resignation as a member of his opera company, now playing "The Algerians." The why and wherefore are not at all understood on the Rialto. Both Miss Tempest and Mr. Hill give assurances that their relations have been harmonious and that they entertain only the friendliest feelings for each other.

-- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad was held in Evansville, Ind., yesterday, and resulted in the election of the following Directors: D.J. Mackey, F.W. Cook, and E.P. Hustan of Evansville; M.H. Tilford, Frederick Roosevelt, John L. Hamson, T.H. Wheelarm, W.H. Curtis, and Harvey E. Fisk of New-York.

Mayor Gilroy stated yesterday that he would leave for Chicago this evening to perfect arrangements for the celebration or Manhattan Day Saturday. He feels confident, from the favorable reports received from the various committees appointed to carry out the arrangements, that the demonstration will be a great success.

"Boss" McLaughlin and his lieutenants are realizing that they are on the verge of an overthrow and are making the most desperate efforts to introduce dissensions in the organizations of Brooklyn not bearing the stamp of "machine regulars."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Commander Miller of the New-York Naval Militia has written to the Navy Department regarding the report of Lieut. Scheutze of the navy on the performance of the New-York City and Rochester divisions this Summer. Mr. Miller believes that the report is severe, and that the Navy Department officials do not fully appreciate the disadvantages under which the militia labors.

MADRID, Oct. 16 -- The French Charge d'Affaires to-day had another interview with Senor Moret, Minister of Foreign Affairs. It is understood that the interview was a very cordial one, and that it resulted in an entente between France and Spain on the Morocco question.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- Mr. E.S. Willard acted Hamlet, for the first time in this country, at the Tremont Street Theatre to-night. The house was crowded, and the actor's graceful, eloquent, and sufficiently original embodiment of Shakespeare's most-discussed hero was greatly admired.

One of the most pathetic scenes ever witnessed in St. Luke's Hospital was the funeral yesterday of Capt. Charles Edward Gordon. Capt. Gordon was the commander of the British military tournament at Madison Square Garden. All the men in the company were sincerely devoted to him Decause of his uniform kindness and consideration.

The payment of $34,000 by five towns in Connecticut to procure the easy passage by the recent Legislature of a bill transferring from them to the State the burden of maintaining the old wagon bridge across the Connecticut River at Hartford has now become the subject of very lively discussion throughout the State, and it is probable that the job will be ventilated by official investigation.

The Democratic city and county candidates are above the average of excellence. Judge BEACH has ripe learning and long experience on the bench. His renomination is a merited reward of ability and faithful service. Mr. J.H.V. ARNOLD has high character and a knowledge of the law and of public affairs to commend him as a candidate for Surrogate.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- The British steamer Cambroman, from Liverpool, which arrived here this afternoon, reports that on Oct. 13, at 5:10 P.M., while in latitude 48 47' north, longitude 48 7' west, she signaled the Anchor Line steamer Ethiopia, Capt. Boothby, from New-York Oct. 7 for Glasgow, with her shaft broken.

The formal indorsement of prize-ring brutality by the peace officers of Kings County is bearing fruit. Last night there was a "scientific boxing contest for points" at the rooms of the Varuna Boat Club, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, in which Police Justice Tighe is the leading light.

The Republican General Committee last evening decided to reconvene the Republican County Convention at Everett Hall, Bridge and Willonghby Streets, at 3 o'clock this afternoon to nominate a candidate for Supervisor at Large in place of Col. Harry W. Michell, who declined. It is believed the convention will indorse George Kinkel, the Democratic nominee.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- For some time rumors regarding the intentions of that organization which has assumed the title of the Home-Rule Democracy have been current. The active members, or rather those who were foremost in the formation of this movement, have withheld their hands and have not mixed in canvass, caucus, or convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The local market has been buoyant in spite of the weakness in New-York, Philadelphia Traction closed 4 points higher than last night and Metropolitan 3 points. The old crowd in Philadelphia appear to have pulled themselves together and are bidding up the price without opposition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Hamlin has returned from Chicago with the impression that the Government should do the generous thing by the exhibitors from abroad by remitting all duties upon goods owned by them, and which they may be able to sell in preference to sending them back to the countries from which they were exported.

Louisa Winter, twenty-four years old, a comely servant in the employ of Mrs. Ellen Cahn, at 350 West Fifty-eighth Street, was shot and killed last evening in the kitchen of the house by her brother Jacob, a truck driver, twenty-eight years old. After killing his sister. Jacob shot himself in the right temple, inflicting a wound which proved almost immediately fatal.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- After what may be termed a triumphal journey from Toulon, Admiral Avelan, commander of the Russian squadron, and the fifty officers of the fleet accompanying him, arrived here at 9:17 o'clock this morning. The square between the station and the Mazas Prison was packed with a dense mass of humanity long before the time for the arrival of the train.
Charles A. Schieren, the Republican nominee for the Brooklyn Mayoralty, was yesterday notified by a committee of the Citizens Union that he would receive the unqualified support of that organization.

The United States Court of Appeals handed down a decision yesterday in the case of the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the Texas and Pacific Railway, continuing an injunction forbidding that company carrying import freights at rates lower than the rates exacted upon domestic invoices from the same home ports.
Mayor Gilroy left last night for Chicago to complete the arrangements there for the celebration of Manhattan Day Saturday.
PARIS, Oct. 17. -- Field Marshal MacMahon, Duke of Magenta, died this morning.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 17 -- 3:46 P.M. -- Beef and pork in moderate demand. Hams in poor demand; short cut about 14 to 16 lb. easy at 45s 6d. Bacon in poor demand; Cumberland cut, about 28 to 30 lb, easy at 56s 6d. Shoulders, about 12 to 18 lb, steady at 37s. Cheese in moderate demand. Tallow in moderate demand. Spirits of turpentine in fair demand. Resin is moderate demand.
PARIS, Oct. 17. -- An announcement, which proved to be unfounded, was made this afternoon of the death of Charles Francois Gounod, the great French composer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Chairman Wilson and other members of the Committee on Ways and Means to-day assured inquirers that the report that the committee had practically completed the preparation of the Tariff bill was incorrect. These inquirers were informed that, in the opinion of the committeemen, the bill would not be ready for report to the House until the latter part of November.

The Rio News of Sept. 14, a weekly paper published in Rio de Janeiro in American interests, criticises what it terms the "inexplicable neglect of the United States Government in the matter of keeping one or more naval vessels in Brazilian waters." The News complains that since the "theatrical visit of Admiral Walker in 1890."

BELCHERTOWN, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Fire started early this morning in the grocery store of Daniel Hazen, spread rapidly to R.K. Shumway's carriage and paint shop. B.B. Snow's harness shop, C.H. Snow's apothecary shop, and the Grand Army Hall Block, which includes several small stores. The fire swept away fully one-half of the business centre of the town.
In opening his campaign for re-election a Mayor of Brooklyn, Mr. David A. Boody, the "machine" Democratic nominee, gave out a statement to the press on Monday, of which the following is a part:

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 17. -- Tarrasch won the fifth game of the chess match which was opened by Tschigorin to-day, the winner adopting the French defense. The game lasted for fifty-nine moves. Score, Tarrasch, 4; Tschigorin, 2.

The thirteenth and final round of the international chess tournament was played at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. Lasker defeated Gossip in a Ruy Lopez game after fifty-five moves. This completes the Anglo-German's remarkable run of successive wins. He has by winning thirteen straight games, created a now record for international tournament play.
Judge of the Court of Common Pleas -- MILES BEACH.

The Earl and Countess of Dunraven the Ladies Wyndham-Quinn, and the Hon. Charles Kerr will leave to-day on the steamship Britannic for England. The last day in this city was a busy one for the Earl. In the morning he went down to Bay Ridge to see the Valkyrie, and then went with the yacht to City Island, where it will be hauled out to-day at Hawkins's yard for the Winter.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Things look very squally for the Republican ticket in Niagara County. The first and perhaps the most important cause leading up to this state of affairs, is the collapse of the Merchants' Bank at Lockport and the disgrace and downfall of its cashier, County Treasurer John Jacob Arnold.

It has now been demonstrated that the Senate is the weakest and most dangerous feature in the Federal system. The framers of the Constitution regarded it as a most meritorious device. It was to be a conservative check upon the possible excesses of the popular branch of Congress, and a defense of the new democracy against autocratic and monarchical tendencies on the part of the President.

A "very mysterious" diamond robbery took place night before last in the jewelry shop of Morris Hartman, at 1,631 Second Avenue. Morris Hartman, who is short and slightlybuilt and whose age is given as twenty-three years, says he was alone in his shop, behind which he lives with his widowed sister, Mrs. Davis, night before last, his sister having gone to Kible's Garden with one Miss Livingston, to whom Hartman is engaged to be married.

The Inspectors of the Health Department began the work yesterday of vaccinating the saleswomen and other employes of the large firy goods stores in this city. At 8 o'clock in the morning two of the largest stores in the city were visited.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Descending from his high estate, Lieut. Gov. Sheehan ran the Democratic ward caucuses in Buffalo last night. He had his political police to help him.

-- The retirement of Marie Tempest from "The Algerian" company has had the effect of shortening the stay of that organization in Boston. "The Algerian" was presented, at the Hollis Street Theatre in that city Monday night for a three weeks' run, but as soon as Manager Rich discovered, that Tempest was not to sing, he notified J.M. Hill that the engagement Would terminate next Saturday night.

Charles A. Schleren ana George Kinkel were Indorsed last evening for the respective nominations for Mayor of Brooklyn and Supervisor at Large by the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred, which met in the Directors' Room of tho Academy of Music. The committee's proceedings were secret. Dr. George W. Brush offered the following:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 17. -- Four deaths resuited from a collision of the Pennsylvania Limited with a freight train in the yards of the Cleveland and Pittsburg Railroad at Wellsville, Ohio, early this morning. Several were seriously hurt. A freight collision at Beaver Falls had blocked the main line of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad, necessitating a detour over the Cleveland and Pittsburg at Alliance.

-- The Rev. C.H. Hobart of Oakland, Cal., recently asserted in a sermon that the doctrine of evolution taught by Prof. Joseph Le Conte in the California State University tended to turn out an annual crop of agnostics. This was received with much indignation by some of Prof. Le Cente's students, but the professor himself remains undisturbed, and says he wishes the reverend gentleman would come and see him and find out his views.
-- The members of the Press Cycling Club offer to back J.W. Linneinan the winner of the famous Princeton-Newark road race, against J. Goehler of the Ramblers' Bicycle Club for $500 or $1,00O a side.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 17. -- E.A. Mosely delivered an interesting address to-day before the Railroad Trainmen's Convention in Faneuil Hall. In the course of it he presented some facts concerning the magnitude of the railroad business of the country.

Commissioners of immigration may have their will, but Austrian concert-hall singers are prone to hove their way. This has been illustrated in the case of Martha Huere, the young Viennese songstress, who recently made a visit to the shores of this country. She was a second-cabin passenger on the steamship Angusta Victoria, and in the ordinary course of immigretion affairs would have passed unmolested.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 17. -- One of the moat notable fests of the season by a trotter was seen here to-day, when the b.f. Fantasy broke the record for three-year-olds at either gait. She did this in the second heat of the race for her age against nine other young trotters, distance being waived that the peerless filly from Buffalo might be driven out with-out leaving the rest behind the flag.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- A Conservative meeting was held to-day at Preston, in Lancashire, at which the principal speaker was Lord Salisbury. He delivered quite a long address, in the course of which he declared that the aim of the Unionists was to get the voice of Great Britain on the question of Irish home rule.

ROME, Oct. 17. -- A political meeting was held at the Circo Reale Theatre, in this city, last night, which resulted in a free fight and the destruction of the building. Signor Barzilai, a Radical member of the Chamber of Deputies, was addressing the meeting. His remarks did not please the Anarchists, many of whom were present, and he was frequently interrupted.

If it were possible to take M. Vladimir de Pachmann seriously, he might be pronounced the most accomplished farceur in the world. But it is not possible for any one else to take this pianist seriously, because he takes himself so. No one can believe that M. de Pachmann intends to caricature Chopin, or else we might bestow upon his work such praise as we might give to the caricature busts of Dantan.

The First Brigade of the National Guard of New-York will parade and fight a sham battle in Van Cortlandt Park Oct. 21. The brigade will be divided in two divisions or forces, and will represent the armies of the North and South Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald will be in command.

Boss McLaughlin is in a disturbed condition of mind bordering upon panic. He fully realizes that the Brooklyn ring is menaced by even greater dangers than those which confronted it when Seth Low was elected Mayor.

Jacob M., Patterson penciled off the above ticket yesterday, and sent word in the afternoon to the various persons concerned that they had been selected to bear whatever burdens might fall to the Republicans in the local campaign. Those who dared decline hardly thought it worth while, and nearly all of those chosen felt they had been honored.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Dullness reigned on 'Change to-day and fluctuations were in most cases nominal. There were some purchases of Atchison incomes and shares on the Vice President's denial of the impending receivership, but the memory of similar denials recently regarding Northern Pacific and Union Pacific prevailed.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Oct. 17 -- P.M. The stock market to-day was inactive, with the exception of a few specialties. The prices at the opening were fairly strong, but the Grangers were sold down by the bear leaders on the unfavorable showing as to earnings.

The auction sales of real estate in the Trinity Building room yesterday were few and not especially notable. Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold under foreclosure, for $8,500, to Fanning C.T. Beck, as trustee, the plaintiff in the proceedings, the three-story and basement brick dwelling, 43 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, 16.8 by 99.11.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- A tragedy, resulting in the death of two persons and the probable death of another, has occurred on the Weitzow estate of Count Blucher, in Pomerania. A few days ago Count Blucher discovered that a man employed by him in the double capacity of gardener and gamekeeper was carrying on a flirtation with a pretty young girl employed as a maid in the castle.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 18. -- W. Starkley of Philadelphia has bought of Capt. B.J. Treaey, this city, the three-year-old b.f. Clara Belle, by Leonatus, dam Couhtess Griselds by Trumpeter, for $1,000. B.J. Johnson of Chicago has bought of Bashford Manor Stables the five-year-old b.h. Gascon, by Falsetto, dam Molly Wood; price $5,000. E.C. Hopper of Latonia has bought the chestnut colt by Blue Eyes, dam Miss Tillford, for a private price.

The sale of securities advertised by the receivers of the Madison Square Bank, to take place yesterday, was postponed until a week from to-day, to enable the borrower who placed them with the bank as collateral for a loan to work out plans he has for recovering them by paying back the money.

The sale of securities advertised by the receivers of the Madison Square Bank, to take place yesterday, was postponed until a week from to-day, to enable the borrower who placed them with the bank as collateral for a loan to work out plans he has for recovering them by paying back the money.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Unconditional repeal is not merely possible in the Senate, it is probable, and the character of the proceedings to-day point to its passage as imminent.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 17. -- The Belmont Nail Works, a part of the Wheeling Iron and Steel Company, started up yesterday after an idleness of five months, and a partial idleness of a year. This will give employment to over 500 men.

Army News. LEAVES OF ABSENCE. -- Lieut. John Conrlin. Jr., Second Artillery, two months; Capt. O.B. Mitchell, Ordnance Department, six months' extension on account of sickness: Lieut. Z.B. Vance, Jr., Eleventh Infantry, two months; Lieut H.R. Lee, Eleventh Infantry, two months extension; Capt. Willis Wittich. Twenty-first Infantry, ten days; Lient. J.W. Furlong, First Cavalry, fifteen days extension; Lieut. J.O. Green.

William L. Patton, the Wall Street broker who failed on May 5, has been placed in Ludlow Street Jail in default of $15,000 bail. He was arrested by the Sheriff under an order of arrest issued by Justice Patterson of the Supreme Court, on the application of Robert B. Honeyman of 40 Wall Street.
BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The Methodist Protestant Conference of New-Jersey began its annual session here to-day. The Rev. Charles D. Sinkinson of Camden presided. The session will last a week.

Johnny McGovern, two years old, was yesterday prying about his home, at 237 East Forty-sixth Street, when he discovered a flask of whisky. It looked good, and Johnny took a generous swig. A few minutes later his mother came into the room and was horrified to see her boy staggering about. The whisky flask explained what had happened.

The past week has been an exceedingly trying one for vessels that sail in the waters of the North Atlantic. Storms, which some mariners describe as hurricanes, and others as whizzing cyclones, regardless of meteorological nomenclature, have held high carnival in that region, and as a result many storm-beaten craft have been added to the melancholy roll of derelicts.

Alfredo De Oro, the graceful Cuban pool player, is still ahead in his match with John Roberts, the English champion, and he looks like the winner. When the gaine ended on Monday night De Oro was 20 points ahead, but he added 44 more last night, and now his string shows 64 more buttons than that of the Englishman.

SING SING, Oct. 17. -- The Democratic County Convention of Westchester County was held at White Plains this afternoon. William H. Wright presided. The following nominations were made: For County Treasurer -- John Hoag of Sing Sing, renominated; for Coroners -- Wright Horton of Peekskill, Dr. George C. Weiss of Mount Vernon, and Edward Mitchell of Yonkers; for Justice of Sessions -- James Hyatt of Yorktown.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 7. -- The Australia-Canada cricket match was brought to a close this afternoon. Australia pulling off the event by an inning and 70 runs. Both in fielding and batting the visitors were indisputably superior to the home team, bowling honors resting about even. Recent rains had made the crease rather soft. The Australians went in for rapid scoring, and the result shows they got what they were after.

Counsel representing what is known as the Belmont committee of Northern Pacific stockholders, appeared before Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday to argue for the appointment of a special inspector or master to supervise the annual election of Northern Pacific Directors to-morrow.

Sir Alfred Malone, Governor of British Honduras, who has for some time been stopping at the Windsor Hotel, left yesterday for his post of duty. He is returning from a visit to England. Sir Alfred is anxious to promote the interests of the British colony of which he is the Governor. To a reporter for The New-York Times he said yesterday:

Gov. Flower said recently, in an interview with a reporter for The New-York Times, when asked what he proposed to do in the way of preventing the proposed international prize fight between Corbett and Mitchell at Coney Island, that he had not been officially informed of any contemplated violation of law.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 17. -- Advices received here are to the effect that Admiral de Mello, commander of the insurgent Brazilian fleet, again bombarded Rio de Janeiro yesterday. The damage done Is said to have been great.

Henry White, the Secretary of the American Legation in London, was a passenger by the White Star steamship Teutonic, which yesterday arrived from Liverpool. Mr. White was accompanied by his family. He went direct to Baltimore. Other arrivals by the Teutonic were E.R. Bacon, Mr. and Mrs. W. Rathbone Bacon, Mr. and Mrs. H.B. Coxe, Marshall Field, C. Lawrence, F.C. Lawrence, Jr., Mr. and Mrs. R.A. McCurdy, Ray Miller, and Robert Stewart.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct 18 -- Last June Charles F. Peek, the cat's-paw Labor Commissioner of David B. Hill, suddenly left for Europe, while his trial for destroying public papers of his office was pending. His bail bond of $100 was declared forfeited, and bench warrants were issued, but the bondsmen were never prosecuted, as it was supposed that Peek would return.

The members of the Professional Woman's League delight to discuss the functions of the soul; they applaud a fencing bout, and are charmed with a graceful dance, but, above all things, they enjoy talking about pretty gowns and how to wear them. So, when Mrs. Charles Barnard told them yesterday about "Beauty of Form and Artistic Dress," they filled the room of the league to overflowing, and listened breathlessly to every word.

Police Justice James G. Tighe of Brooklyn continues to show contempt for public sentiment. He feels it safe to do so, as he is backed by "Boss" McLaughlin, himself Coney Island Athletic Club. Police Justice Tighe is the leading spirit in the Varuna Boat Club.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- On his return from Preston, whither he went to address the Conservative meeting held there yesterday, Lord Salisbury stopped at Orraskirk, a town thirteen miles from Liverpool. Several addresses were presented to him by the officers of the Conservative and Liberal-Unionist associations, in replying to which ha dwelt upon the progress of foreign navies and the strength of the combined fleets of the allied powers.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Yale added another to her score of football victories this afternoon, sending her backs through the Amherst rush line for 52 points, and, as usual, retiring her opponents without a score. Loose plays were frequent, both sides fumbling the ball atrociously and giving an execrable exhibition of team work.

Over $4,000,000 worth of property on West Forty-first Street, West Forty-second Street, and Tenth Avenue was destroyed by fire last night. The fire was discovered at 8:05 o'clock, and apparently started in William Campbell's wall paper factory at 516 West Forty-second Street.

A Fashionable Bazaar at Westchester -- A big bazaar will be held to-day and this evening in St. Peter's Parish House at Westchester in behalf of the Westchester Free Hospital. Ladies prominent in society will preside at the various booths and tables, and well-known society people from New-York have promised to drive out and invest in the several thousand articles collected during the past year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Delegations of New-Yorkers are arriving on every train. They are coming to swell the crowd at the White City on Manhattan Day, and to participate in the celebration.

The annual meeting of St. Luke's Home for Indigent Christian Females was held yesterday at the home, at Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street. There were anniversary services in the forenoon in the neighboring Church of the Beloved Disciple, and in the afternoon the Associate Managers, who are all ladies, met first alone.

PARIS, Oct 18 -- An enormous-number of telegrams of condolence have been received by the family of Field Marshal MacMahon, who died yesterday. Included in the number are messages from President Carnot, the Count of Paris, Marshal Canrobert, Cardinal Rampolla, and Gen. Loizilion, Minister of War, who telegraphs on behalf of himself and the French Army.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 18 -- It looks very much as if prize fighting in this city is doomed. Press and people have taken up the cudgel at the very fear of the Corbett-Mitchell affair coming here, in case it is stopped in New-York and the Indiana courts decide against the Columbian Club at Roby.

Controller MYERS is wiser than his friends. To the proposition that he shall accept a Republican and independent nomination for Controller in opposition to Mr. FITCH he replies that he would accept if convinced that "the citizens wished it." But he adds a word of caution. "My friends," he says, "must have a care that they do not mistake their friendly feeling toward me for the enthusiasm of the people at large."

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 18 -- Eighteen men of the Detroit Athletic Club Cricket team played the Australian cricketers to day. In their first inning the Detroits made 74 runs. The Australians ran up 151. The game will be continued to-morrow.

Hugh McLaughlin and his henchmen fully appreciate the fact that a moral and political revolution has broken out in Brooklyn. The avaricious, selfish, and arrogant "Boss" knows that the election of Charles A. Schieren, the Republican reform candidate for Mayor, means more than a change in the Municipal Government of Brooklyn.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The city is still en fete, and the crowds that filled the streets yesterday have been augmented to-day by a steady influx of visitors from all parts of the country. The streets are crowded with people in holiday costume, and everywhere the greatest gayety prevails.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Loren Cushman, an aged farmer of Plymouth, Chenongo County, has quite a reputation as a reliable weather prophet, and whenever he makes a prognostication his friends and acquaintances regard it as worthy of credence. Mr. Cushman believes the coming Winter will be an unusually severe one, and bases his opinion on the following grounds:

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The World's Columbian Exposition will positively close on the night of Oct. 30. One can enter Jackson Park after that time, but just as one did before the great fair opened, with two exceptions. The admission fee will be fifty cents, and visitors will see the destruction of an exposition instead of the upbuilding of one.

While the death of CHARLES FRANCOIS GOUNOD will arouse general regret, it cannot be accounted a serious loss to music. GOUNOD'S day was done; his career was ended. So long, indeed, is it since he produced his last important work, "Mors et Vita," that he had ceased to be anything but a sterile monument to his own notable past.

?FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 18 -- One hundred Italians, employed on the turnpike road between Flushing and Bayside, went on a strike this morning and were about to start a riot when a police call was sent to the Sheriff. He detailed Captain William Allen and Sergeant Stanton to the scene, and they dispersed the rioters so as to prevent further trouble.

Such news as came from Washington in the dispatches printed yesterday morning was the kind for which the down-town exchanges had been waiting, and they responded to it with alacrity. Securities almost "boomed" from the opening of business. In the middle of the day many of the morning buyers could not resist the temptation to take profits.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Illinois Central Railroad Company, held here to-day, Stuyvesant Fish, President, occupied the chair. The stockholders elected John Jacob Astor as a Director, to take the place of Arthur Leary, deceased, and re-elected B. F. Ayer, Walter Luttgen, and John W. Auchincloss, whose terms expired at this meeting, to succeed themselves.

The number of qualified voters who registered in this city yesterday was 76,763, which, added to 68,920 registered on the 10th inst., the first day of registration, makes a total of 147,667 registered for the two days.

A confirmation service of unusual interest was held yesterday, at noon, in the Church of the Beloved Disciple, of which the Rev. S. Gregory Lines is rector, in Eighty-ninth Street, near Madison Avenue, when the Rev. Francis R. Bateman, for the last eighteen months pastor of Trinity Baptist Church, was received into the communion of the Episcopal Church.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Louise, aged sixteen, the daughter of Railroad Baggagemaster John A. Hopkins, has been visiting her aunt. Mrs. Henry Lockwood, Long Ridge, nine miles north of here. Last night Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood were aroused by screams form the girl's room. Lockwood and his wife alarmed the neighbors and searched for the girl, who had disappeared.

-- A paper was read before the Northwestern Medical and Surgical Society at the Hotel Marlborough last evening by Dr. William Stevens, President of the County Medical Society, on "Is Death from Ether Administered as an Anesthetic Due to Idiosyncrasy or Pathological Conditions?" The case of Elliott F. Shepard was cited. In the opinion of the doctors present Mr. Shepard had Bright's disease, and ether should not have been administered.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 18 -- The Grand Jury is believed to have returned at least six indictments to-day against John B. Koetting, ex-cashier of the South Side Savings Bank.

The American Hackney Society has offered a challenge cup to the Hackney stallions taking first prizes in classes 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, and 28, in the coming horse show at Madison Square Garden, and also stallions having won first prizes at previous shows of the National Horse Show Association. The cup must be won by the same horse two years in succession before it becomes the property of the owner of the winner.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 18 -- Michael Bohan, proprietor of a grocery store, and Alfred Brown, constable, were arrested to-day at this place on a charge of burglary. They pleaded not guilty, and were bailed to appeal for examination. The complainant was Mrs. Angelo Delnoce, wife of the alleged counterfeiter who was arrested at Hart Park a few weeks ago.

-- The Japan mail brings the following news of Mr. Lenz, the round-the-world cyclist: "A Chinese gentleman in the telegraph service in Shanghai has received a letter from Mr. Lenz, the cyclist, dated from Mandalay, Burmah. He says: The last three months I mostly walked from Ichaug west. At Tengyueh office I was sick for three weeks, but your kind letter made me very comfortable in all the telegraph offices.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club held an adjourned meeting at the Real Estate Exchange, in Montague Street, last night, and, amid cheers and enthusiasm, indorsed Charles A. Schieren, the Republican candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, and William J. Gaynor, candidate for Judge of the Supreme Court.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 -- The grandest ceremonial of the Catholic Church that prelates, priests, and laymen have ever engaged in or witnessed in this country took place to-day in and about the cathedral in this city, marking the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the elevation to the Episcopate of his Eminence Cardinal Gibbons.

Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst intends to push with vigor his latest crusade. His charges against Hugh Slevin, who his society declares is unfit to be a Grand Juryman by reason of his violation of the excise laws in four saloons, are, he confidently asserts, supported by indisputable proofs.

That Senator HILL is a vigorous and skillful fighter is known to none better than to those who have been compelled to oppose him when they have found him fighting on the wrong side. And it is to these a grateful duty to recognize his courage and skill when employed as they were in the Senate on Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- The market to-day has been dull and strong, closing generally at improved prices. Philadelphia Traction was steady all day around 73 1/2. There was less disposition to-day to advance this stock, the insiders evidently being absorbed in the advance in Chicago Cable stocks and willing to halt a little in local tractions, as there has been a net advance of about 15 points in Philadelphia in the past two weeks.

There was a hearing before Attorney General Rosendale in Albany yesterday on the application of some of the stockholders of the Nyack and Northern Railroad for the State to begin an action for the dissolution of the company and the appointment of a receiver. William H. Safford appeared for the petitioners, and Gen. Wager Swayne appeared for the company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The attempt of the Democratic Senators who oppose the passage of the repeal bill to bring about a caucus and bind those who participate in it to abide by its decision in relation to repeal has thus far been unsuccessful.

Mayor Gilroy telegraphed to Secretary Willis Holly from Washington, when he arrived yesterday on his way to Chicago, that he had seen Congressman Fellows there and that Col. Fellows had promised to go to Chicago to deliver an address at the opening of the ceremonies in Festival Hall on Manhattan Day at the World's Fair.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 18 -- News from Brazil is to the effect that the men-of-war which have remained faithful to President Peixoto are about to put to sea to meet the vessels expected from Europe and to make a combined attack on the insurgents. The authorities of Desterro have declared in favor of the insurgents.

-- The Union Pacific is no longer a member of the Western Passenger Association. Its withdrawal notice was supposed to have been canceled when it accepted the amendments to the agreement. This was not the case. In order to leave the receivers of the Union Pacific entirely free. General Passenger Agent Lomax has declared the withdrawal notice to be effective, leaving it to the receivers to renew the membership or not.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- It was announced in Paris yesterday that Charles Francois Gounod, the great composer, had died from the stroke of apoplexy which he suffered Monday at his residence at St. Cloud.

The crowded auction room at 111 Broadway yesterday looked as though a resumption of active trading in real estate had set in. But, when business was started, it was seen that most of those present came with no intention of bidding, but simply to see what kind of prices would prevail. The results, as a whole, were disappointing.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Trenton claims, and perhaps justly, that she has the prettiest and most imposing of the Revolutionary monuments that have been erected in this country. To receive recognition at this late day for memorials of this character indicates a remarkable spirit of patriotism and considerable business tact on the part of the descendants of those who took part in the battles that agitated the souls of the forefathers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Senate was not stormed to-day as it was yesterday, but the proceedings were interesting. The question whether the Journal should be amended brought forth many speeches, none of which related to the Journal itself.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Robert F. Ritter, proprietor of a fish market in this village, was publicly horsewhipped yesterday afternoon on Main Street. The lash was applied by Mrs. Ritter in the presence of a large crowd. The chastisement was the culmination of a domestic disturbance of several weeks' duration. Mrs. Ritter is a museular woman and applied the whip vigerously.
The money market was easy. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 1 1/2 @ 2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The total number of fourth-class Postmasters appointed to-day was seventy-seven, of which thirty-three were to fill vacancies caused by resignations and death. Among the appointments were:
BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Mrs. Lucy Stone Blackwell died at 10:45 to-night at her home, Boutwell Avenue, Dorchester.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- The market opened with little pressure to sell stocks. There was a steady demand and prices gradually improved. It looks as if there would be no further liquidation from Amsterdam or London. About two-thirds of Union Pacific stock was held abroad, and it looks now as if all that was likely to come out has done so.

But one ticket will be voted at the annual meeting of the Northern Pacific stockholders to-day, and that ticket will represent the wishes and the policy of the socalled anti-Villard party. The Belmont-Ives committee has won a signal victory in its quest for proxies, having secured a practical working majority.

We have never seen much use in bragging beforehand about the result of an election, and we are not so sure as we should like to be that Mr. CHARLES A. SCHIEREN will be the next Mayor of Brooklyn. We are entirely convinced that he ought to be, and that, if the respectable and honest voters do their duty, he will be.

The material facts upon which the charges against Isaac H. Maynard are based are not disputed. The main difference is in the construction put upon some of these facts, and the opinion held as to the conduct of those who dealt with them. After the election of 1891 there were disputes as to the results in three or four Senate districts.
The navy of the United States is independent of foreign coaling stations. Honolulu and St. Nicolas Mole need no longer be urged as necessary to the welfare of the country.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18 -- It has been definitely decided to reopen the National German-American Bank on Oct. 30, and an official announcement to that effect was made by Bank Examiner Lynch, the special officer sent on from Washington, at the conclusion of the bank Directors' meeting held to-day.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 -- An afternoon paper asserts that the missing money shipped by the American Express Company from New-York to New-Orleans amounted to $250,000 instead of $50,000, as first stated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The bears who have been waiting and watching for an opportunity to cover were again grievously disappointed to-day. The two sessions were indeed disastrous to the short side in elevated railway and cable stocks. The market opened with a decidedly healthy tone and a legitimate demand for stocks.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 18 -- Fifteen hundred persons saw the University of Pennsylvania defeat Lehigh here this afternoon by the score of 32 to 6. Lehigh's team was crippled by the absence of Houston at left tackle and Gadd at right half back when the game begun, and was further crippled by injuries to Best, left end.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- One of the large recital rooms of the Art Institute was filled this morning when W.R. Rhawm of Philadelphia, President of the American Bankers' Association, called to order the nineteenth annual convention of that organization.

The nature of the disclosures made by Mr. Stephen Little, the accountant who is engaged in examining the Reading accounts, to the committee of security holders at their meeting on Tuesday is not fully known, but what little has leaked out has been more than sufficient to convince people who do their own thinking that Mr. Rice has, if anything, understated the imminent peril which confronts the security holders.

That the voters of Brooklyn are thoroughly aroused to the opportunity offered this year of overthrowing the ring which has so long made its municipal Government a disgrace and a reproach is shown by the unusually heavy registration yesterday. It is a most favorable omen, and the figures given below will cause additional worry and anxiety in the Willoughby Street headquarters.

There is no spectacle so sad as the ruin of a career by him to whom its completion was intrusted. There is no moral so deplorably easy to illustrate as that the weakness, the vacillation, or the personal ambition of a man can abort and bring to nothing prospects that once enveloped him with undeniable promise.

BREMEN, Oct. 18 -- The statue of Emperor William I., grandfather of the present Emperor, erected in this city, was unvelled to-day. Emperor William, who traveled in a special train, arrived here at 10:50 A.M. The railway station was handsomely decorated. His Majesty was welcomed to the city by Dr. Pauli, the Burgomaster, who awaited his coming at the head of the other municipal authorities.

ASBURY PARK. N.J., Oct. 18 -- The Citizens' League held a rousing meeting here to-night in Educational Hall to indorse the nomination of the fusion ticket made at Freehold last week in opposition to the race-track ticket. Great enthusiasm prevailed. George F. Kroehl, President of the First National Bank of this place, was Chairman.
Wheat made an advance of 7/8 @ 1 1/4 c, as following the West, and shorts covering freely, with the trading fairly active and chiefly switching from December to May.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The smoking room of the Union County Roadsters was a bower of roses to-night, it being the occasion of the first long table banquet given by the Roadsters this Fall. Since the club was organized, in 1891, these banquets have been given with regularity by the club during the Winter months. Their object is to promote a more fraternal feeling among wheelmen.

The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the elevation of the Cardinal Archbishop of Baltimore to the episcopate would necessarily be a memorable event in the annals of the Roman Catholic Church in this country, without regard to the personal qualities of the prelate whose prelacy was thus commemorated.

"That's what I call a very poor game of pool," said Champion De Oro as he finished the third night's play in Madison Square Garden Concert Hall with John Roberts, the English expert. "I have missed some of the most simple shots on the table, and for some reason I could not set the balls rolling properly."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- George C. Lambden of New-Rochelle, whose name was placed on the Republican county ticket for County Treasurer of Westchester County by the County Committee, in whose hands the matter of filling the vacancy had been left by the convention last Saturday, filed this morning his declination to accept.

The cohorts of Gen. Doty, M.D., go marching on through the town, bearing quills full of immunity from smallpox and leave in their track hundreds of left arms which ache for a day and then show little circles of white scars, by which sign the owners of the arms know they need not fear contagion, wherever they may happen to go.

Lord Dunraven, Lady Dunraven, Lady Aileen Wyndham-Quin, Lady Rachel Wyndham-Quin, Mr. Charles Kerr, and four servants sailed for England on the White Star Line steamer Britannic yesterday morning. Mr. H. Maitland Kersey, the agent of the line, was on the steamer looking after the comfort of the distinguished party. Lord and Lady Dunraven have two staterooms on the main deck, next to the Captain's, and his daughters have two rooms on the lower deck.

An effort is being made to nominate Theodore W. Myers for Controller on an independent Democratic ticket, and to secure for him the Republican indorsement. The Trustees of the City Club have taken the initiative in the matter, and a mass meeting has been called for to-morrow night in the large hall of Cooper Union.

ROSELLE, N.J., Oct. 19 -- One of the most fashionable and largely-attended weddings of the season took place here this evening, when Miss Mary Frances Moore, daughter of the well-known shipbuilder, Miller F. Moore, was married to Mr. Charles Wight MacQuoid of the neighboring town of Westfleld.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Two thousand striking miners attacked the Sutton Heath collieries, at St. Helens, County of Lancaster, this afternoon. They drove away the mine officials, broke the machinery at the pit shafts, and split up the wagons.

Jefferson, Klaw Erlanger announce as one of the new features of their "Country Circus" company the first appearance in America of Joseph Darby, champion jumper of the world. Darby's feats are said to be marvelous. The champion, who is a native of Dudley, England, sails for this country to-morrow by the Umbria, and is due here about the 28th.
A true Parisian tragedy was enacted yesterday at 218 West Sixteenth Street.

To the clergymen of Brooklyn, as well as to The New-York Times, the official declaration that the Mitchell-Corbett fight shall not take place comes as a great and inspiring assurance of victory to crown the vigorous efforts of a month in behalf of public morals and public decency.

VIENNA, Oct. 19 -- A Ministerial crisis seems to be inevitable. All the parties are irritated over the Franchise bill, introduced on the 10th inst. in the lower house of the Reichsrath, by Count Taaffe, Minister of the Interior. The bill provides that the right to vote shall be extended to all who have attained their twenty-fourth year, have accomplished their military obligations, and have lived in one place for at least six months.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The arrangements for the funeral of Gen, MacMahon have been completed. According to the programme, the body will be conveyed in a hearse from the chateau in which the General died to the town church, at Montcresson. A number of priests, Senators, Deputies, and Ministers will be in waiting, and will receive the body at the church.
SAN JOSE, COSTA RICA, Oct. 19 -- A decision was reached to-day in the case of Francis H. Weeks, whose extradition the United States authorities have sought to bring about.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Now that the Princeton game in New-York on Saturday is a sure and settled affair, there is considerable speculation here as to its probable results. The weakness of the Cornell team was apparent in the game played with Union on Saturday, and to keep Princeton from scoring is no longer talked of. How large a score will Princeton run up ? is the question most frequently asked.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Twenty thousand people to-day saw the Stars and Stripes unfolded from the statue of Washington which surmounts the memorial shaft erected on the spot where the Revolutionary Army defeated the British troops on Trenton battlefield.
The Gibert divorce case came to an unexpected end yesterday before Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas.

Charges have been made against the efficiency of the Municipal Government, but none of them are specific. I insist, in this campaign, that the charges of our opponents must be made specific, in order that they may be fairly met. Let our opponents investigate and point out the alleged defects of which they complain. Let them not deal in generalities.

The Grand Jury yesterday began an investigation of the charge made against one of its members, Hugh Slevin, by the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst's society, which says he is unfit to be a juryman, because the excise law is violated in four saloons of which he is the reputed proprietor.
All the excursion trains leaving the city for Chicago yesterday were crowded with passengers on their way to attend the celebration of Manhattan Day at the World's Fair on Saturday.
The Brooklyn Prohibitionists opened their campaign with a meeting in the Academy of Music. Dr. I.K. Funk presided, and in a speech offered statistics to prove that the Prohibition Party is growing.

More than an acre of ragged and tottering walls blackened with smoke, heaps of brick work, twisted girders, and charred timbers, presenting a suggestion of a sacked city after fire has passed through hand in hand with the sword, bore witness yesterday to the destruction wrought on Wednesday night at Forty-second Street and Tenth Avenue by the biggest blaze NewYork has seen in a long time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Senator Hill has pointed out the way by which the supporters of the repeal bill may secure a vote for that bill without condition, and he has stirred up the Senate and aroused an interest in the ineffectual rules of the Senate such as has never been felt in that body or its rules before.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- A dispatch from Weitzow, Pomerania, states that Countess Blucher, who was shot on Tuesday by a gardener, is recovering from the effects of he wound in her neck. A representative of Emperor William will be present at the funeral of Count Blucher, who was killed by the gardener at the same time his wife was wounded.

The citizens of Brooklyn and Kings County will do well to bear in mind the openly-expressed sentiments of the local officials and bosses when The New-York Times inaugurated its battle against the bruisers.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Oct. 19 -- P.M. Business on the Stock Exchange was at a standstill until the last hour, when, on a rumor that Vice President Stevenson had vacated the chair in the Senate in favor of a member who was willing to force a vote on the silver repeal issue, shorts began to cover their contracts, and prices advanced sharply.

The Prison Association of New-York held its first conference of the season yesterday at its rooms at 135 East Fifteenth Street. The subject for discussion was: "Institutional Diet in its Relation to Health, Morals, Economics, and Discipline."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- The Catholic Club tonight, in the Carrollton Hotel, by a grand coronation banquet, fittingly brought to a close the jubilee of Cardinal Gibbons. The company included statesmen of national reputation, prelates of world-wide fame, men eminent in the field of letters, and citizens high in public station and respected for private worth.

The candidacy of Isaac H. Maynard for Judge of the Court of Appeals received a severe blow yesterday from the GermanAmerican Reform Union, an organization made up of representative German-Americans whose words carry great weight with their fellow-citizens in political campaigns, as well as in other important matters.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- The market opened firm and was steady and strong all day. Business was dull at the advance. The bond market was very dull. There was some inquiry for choice bonds. Money is still a drug, and all needed was supplied at 2 1/2 per cent., and most of it was carried away unloaned.
The New-York Times has won its battle against the proposed international prize fight at Coney Island between James J. Corbett and Charles Mitchell.

The improvement in the railroad business of the country, which began early last month, is developing with an encouraging vigor. The more recent reports of earnings indicate that October will be a red-letter month for many of the Western roads. In several instances the earnings reported for the first two weeks of the present month are actually in excess of the earnings of the same roads in the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Excitement and mirth played see-saw in the Senate Chamber to-day. At one moment Senators and visitors were convulsed with laughter; at another their attention was chained to fierce forensic encounters. A theatrical manager could not have arranged a more "taking" performance.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 19 -- The Union County Democrats this afternoon nominated James S. Martine of Plainfield for State Senator; John S. Sauer of Elizabeth for Sheriff, and Edward B. Keeley of Summit for Coroner. The convention adopted resolutions indorsing the action of President Cleveland's course on the silver repeal bill and approving the action of Senators McPherson and Smith.

The Democratic "machine" in Brooklyn and "Boss" Hugh McLaughlin are becoming greatly agitated over the way the campaign is progressing. In fact, they are in sore distress. They have become so frightened that they have decided to take big risks in order to land Mr. Boody again in the Mayor's chair.

Notice has been given by the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway, through Joseph Gaskell, Treasurer for the receiver, that it will pay with 6 per cent. interest a number of coupons from the several series of bonds issued by it at the National Bank of North America, 25 Nassau Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct 19 -- On Tuesday the second eleven scored a touch-down against the first. This fact if the key to several new developments in the Harvard football team. Since Saturday the coaches have been striving with might and main to strengthen the weak points in the team. Harvard's work with Williams showed lamentable laziness, and everybody was disappointed at the lack of team work displayed.

About 600,000 shares of stock were voted on at the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Northern Pacific Railroad yesterday, and the anti-Villard ticket, prepared by the Belmont-Ives committee, and printed in The Times yesterday, was elected without opposition. The tellers were unable to complete the official count of the proxies yesterday, but they will make a formal report to the stockholders at noon to-day.

John Roberts, the English billiard champion, is a remarkably steady player. When he arranged the pool match with Alfredo De Oro many predicted an overwhelming defeat for the Britisher, and their predictions appeared to be correct at the end of the second night's play, when De Oro was 64 points in the lead. Roberts, however, never lost confidence in his ability to cope favorably with the dark-haired player from Cuba.

It is just a month since The New-York Times began its fight to prevent the international battle scheduled to be fought in December at the Coney Island Athletic Club between Charles Mitchell and James J. Corbett.

When an elderly and poorly-clad man dropped in a dead faint at the end of a foreclosure sale in the auction room at 111 Broadway, a little after noon yesterday, and a woman, evidently his wife, began to cry and wring her hands in despair, every one in the neighborhood knew what had happened to cause these manifestations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- A rousing mass meeting was held in the gymnasium here this evening at which many prominent graduates spoke, and at which much enthusiasm was manifested in regard to the coming football contest. The object was to create a brotherly feeling between the alumni and undergraduates in regard to athletics in all branches, and as much for the benefit of the alumni as the undergraduates.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- At the meeting of the Presbyterian Synod this morning the report of the Judicial Committee, which had been in session the greater part of the night, was read by the Rev. Dr. Miller. After discussing a case of minor importance the committee, in reference to the case of Dr. Briggs, reheased the following complaints:
The money market was easier. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Americans opened today at a higher range than that established the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Secretary Carlisle sent to the Senate to-day a reply to a resolution of the Senate asking whether silver dollars or silver coin certificates have been redeemed by the Treasury Department or exchanged for gold or paper that is, by law or practice of the Government, redeemable in gold.

Gen. Denis F. Burke died yesterday morning after a protracted illness at his residence, 452 West One Hundred and Fiftieth street. For several months Gen. Burke had been an invalid, but recently his health had been improved so much that his recovery was regarded as complete. The announcement of his death, therefore, came as a surprise to his comrades of the Grand Army and his large circle of friends in this city.

Charles Eisele, nineteen years old, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in the dingy and poorly-furnished little room in the boarding house at 238 East Forty-sixth Street, and as he lay cold and still on the cot a blacksnake crawled up and wound itself about the arm above the stiffened fingers closed tightly over a revolver.
Messrs. Curtis Romaine, brokers of 2 Exchange Place, in a circular to their customers, express their explicit faith that the will of the majority will ultimately prevail in the Senate. They add:

That the people of Brooklyn are determined to rise in their might and overthrow the Democratic machine and "Boss" McLaughlin was demonstrated last evening, when the Brooklyn Rink, on Clermont Avenue, was crowded to its utmost capacity by one of the most representative audiences that has ever convened in that city.

The Columbia freshmen and the Rangers of Fordham started to play a game of football yesterday which ended in a free fight. The trouble began with the alleged partiality of Fordham's referee. Mr.McCafferty. In the second half, when Mr. Sill of Columbia was referee, the Fordham supporters got so excited that they rushed on the field; and for a few minutes things looked serious.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- In the second and closing day's session of the nineteenth annual convention of the American Bankers' Association, the first paper considered the panic in Australia and in the United States and was presented by Joseph C. Hendrix, President of the National Union Bank of New-York. He said, among other things, after speaking of the recent depression:

Many Episcopal clergymen of this city and a number of the trustees of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Public School, together with the Rev. Dr. Bradley, rector of St. Agnes's Church, in West Ninety-second Street, gathered yesterday afternoon in West Ninety-first Street to take part in the ceremony of laying the cornerstone of the new schoolhouse of Trinity School, which will be numbered 131 in that street.

Two Park policemen and an ex-Park employe were asphyxiated by illuminating gas in Central Park early yesterday morning under the most remarkable circumstances. A third Park policeman, found with the others, is lying in the Presbyterian Hospital in such a condition that he can give no explanation of the tragedy, which is wrapped in the deepest mystery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Major Gen. O.O. Heward, United States Army, commanding the Military Department of the East with headquarters at Governors Island, New-York Harbor, in his annual report commends "the prompt and efficient service rendered by the National Guard" in the labor troubles during the year.
--W.V. Belknap. C.S. Swain, and L.N. Thorne of the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark are making a trip on their bicycles through the lumber camps of Maine.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- Considerable surprise was created this evening when it became known that Anthony J. Drexel, Jr., would to-morrow announce his withdrawal from the banking houses of Drexel Co. of Philadelphia, Drexel, Morgan Co. of New-York, and Drexel, Harjes Co. of Paris.

The Board of Education, at a full meeting on Wednesday, appointed William Geoghegan a School Trustee for the Thirteenth Ward, and the poet had the honor of receiving a vote that was unanimous. Mr. Geoghegan has always shown that he was a friend of the public school system by having his own children educated under it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Manhattan's legions encamped in Chicago to-night are praying fervently for good weather to-morrow. This is the only essential factor yet unassured in making the celebration of Manhattan day at the World's Fair a splendid success.

The ancient proverb which narrates the monastic tendencies that mark the invalidism of his Satanic Majesty has seldom received a more forcible illustration than is afforded by the announcement made yesterday by Mayor Boody, and confirmed by Sheriff Courtney and District Atorney Ridgway, that Messrs. Corbett and Mitchell will not be allowed to meet at Coney Island in December, as had been arranged, to settle the question of superiority in the pugilistic arena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- At midnight the would-be compromisers have been unable to roach an agreement us to the date upon which they will consent to make the repeal bill operative. The silver men, out of the Democratic Party, are broken in spirit, and are expecting to be invited to see a prompt execution of the will of the majority.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- The market was strong all day, closing at a slight reaction from the highest. There was a good demand for bonds, especially Atchison 4s and Boston United Gas first 5s, the latter advancing to 77 1/2 . Atchison and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy were active, although the shorts were the principal buyers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The annual meeting of Pullman's Palace Car Company was held here yesterday. About $24,000,000 of capital was represented. The retiring Directors were re-elected, as follows: George M. Pullman, Marshell Field, J.W. Doane, Norman Williams, O.S.A. Sprague of Chicago, Henry C. Hulbert of New-York, and Henry R. Reed of Boston.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 20 -- Twenty-six heaps of charred, blackened flesh, all that remains of what less than twenty-four hours ago were men, women, and children in the enjoyment of life, health, and happiness, rest upon the floor of an improvised morgue in the basement of a furniture store of this city.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The private funeral of M. Gounod will take place at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning. Only the members of his family will be present. The State obsequies will be held in the Church of the Madeleine on Thursday next. Queen Victoria has sent a wreath for Gounod's coffin.

-- At Republican headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday there were busy times. Col. Reuben Fox received a large bundle of printed matter early in the day. It comprised pamphlets of the Bar Association's verdict on Maynard and a small publication setting forth the famous law cases in which Edward T. Bartlett, the Republican candidate, has distinguished himself.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- It is estimated that 300,000 persons were around the Hotel de Ville last night while the banquet given to the visiting Russian naval officers by the Municipal Council was in progress. The police returns this morning show that many accidents occurred in the crowds last night. Many persons fainted away and were with difficulty rescued from being trampled upon.

The Union Pacific situation promises to take on interesting and complicated phases. A variety of technical points is arising puzzle the receivers, and chief in importance is the question of the rights of the United States Government under the receivership. Vice President and Receiver Oliver W. Mink, it is said, is on his way East for the purpose of conferring with influential stockholders and studying the situation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- There was a row at the meeting of the National Commission this afternoon. Mr. Burton objected to the treatment accorded to President Pangborn of the Associated American Exhibitors by President Palmer.
