OTTAWA, Oct. 20 -- The appeal case of the owners of the Oscar and Hattie, a Canadian sealer seized in the Summer of 1892, in Bering Sea, was heard in the Supreme Court here to-day. This is an appeal from the Admiralty Court of British Columbia, which condemned the vessel.

Late last night George F. Slosson, the billiard player, received a telegram from Chicago in reference to the proposed three-cornered match with Schaefer and Ives, and the probabilities are that New-Yorkers will have an opportunity in the near future of witnessing a struggle between these three clever players.

No justifying reason for the nomination of Controller MYERS in opposition to Mr. FITCH was presented at the Cooper Union mass meeting last night. He was nominated, however, and a considerable number of well-known and public-spirited citizens, together with some who are less sincere and unselfish, joined in the movement.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The New-Orleans Limited over the Illinois Central Railroad was wrecked by colliding with a coal train three miles beyond Kankakee, at 11 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- State Department officials have come to the conclusion that a very slim chance remains for the extradition of Francis H. Weeks from San Jose, Costa Rica. They are inclined to attribute this anticipated failure to the belief that the defaulter has plenty of money, which he is using lavishly in his defense.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 20 -- The police are looking for Edward Hautteman, an insurance broker and steamship agent, who has lured from their homes Freda Laucks, sixteen years old, and her brother, Hubert, fifteen years old. The girl is tall and pretty. She is a brunette, while her brother is a blonde. Both are well dressed.

The Rev. Dr. Philip Schaff died yesterday morning at his home, 15 East Forty-third Street, of paralysis. This affliction came upon him about a year ago. He rallied, and for a time seemed likely to regain his powers, but for several weeks his friends knew the end must soon come. When he realized that he could not work again, he withdrew formally from his active connections.

Alfredo De Oro gave a remarkably pretty exhibition of pool playing in his contest with John Roberts the English champion, last night. At one time Roberts was on even terms with the Cuban, but the latter made one of those Garrison finishes for which he is famous, and finished 59 points ahead of the Britisher. Barring accidents he ought to win the match in the easiest possible manner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The nomination of J. J. Van Alen to be Ambassador to Italy has been confirmed by the Senate.

Brayton Ives, who for nearly a year has led a vigorous fight against the Villard management of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, was yesterday elected President of that company by the new Board of Directors. Mr. Ives is the President of the Western National Bank, and, although not a practical railroad man, he has had much experience in railroad financial affairs.
"There is no way by which people exhaust themselves, kill themselves, so quickly as by exercising the affections."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- R.B. Bowler, First Controller of the Treasury, to-day rendered an opinion disallowing the accounts of Lieut. Col. J.W. Barlow, disbursing officer of the International Boundary Commission between the United States and Mexico, covering the period that has clapsed since Sept. 1, 1892, and the present time, in round figures about $10,000.

The McLaughlin machine in Brooklyn has done an excellent thing in "calling off" the "international" prize fight at Coney Island. We tender to the large number of clergymen of every denomination, who have taken such a firm and outspoken course in this matter, our hearty congratulations.

CORNING, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The regular Democratic organization of the Second Assembly District of Steuben County neglected to file the certificate of their candidate, John F. Murray of Tuscarora, until a day after the required time. The Cleveland men had previously filed the certificate of the nomination of George W. Drake of this city.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst served as a subject to take up most of the time of the Police Board at its meeting yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 20 -- Francis H. Weeks, who is wanted in New-York to give an accounting of the management and disposal of valuable trust funds confided to his care, will be surrendered by this country to the United States Government, following the request made by Secretary of State Gresham, based upon indictments found against the alleged wrongdoer and evidence furnished by District Attorney Nicoll of New-York.

Hundreds of children are running at large in the streets of Brooklyn, unable to jet Into the public schools. Schoolhouses lave not been provided for their accommolation. There might now be adequate facilities for the instruction of the young in the City of Churches but for the extravagance in other directions of the Boody and Chapin administrations.

William M. Gelhardt, a policeman attached to the Fourteenth Precinct, Brooklyn, yesterday shot and killed John E.K. Green of 52 Georgia Avenue, at the corner of Broadway and Conway Street, because he had alienated his wife's affections and destroyed his happiness.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., Oct. 20 -- The Rev. Joseph Spear, pastor of the Presbyterian churches in this village and Comac, and local agent for the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, is being criticised for his action toward Samuel P. Soper, a farmer, living at Comac. The latter is eighty years old. He earns a living by cultivating a small farm and selling cordwood in surrounding villages.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Americans opened strong to-day on a report that the Senate Democratic caucus had agreed upon a compromise, and that purchases of Grangers had been made in New-York, after the close, at 1 per cent. advance.

The new Cunarder Lucania seems to have gone into the record-breaking business. On her first trip to the westward she distinguished herself by breaking all maiden records, and on her next westward passage she displaced the American Line steamship Paris from the championship of the ocean speed course.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- There was a small riot to-day among the Italians at the new Cornell Dam of the New-York Water Works Department. One man came near being killed. Angelo Paladino and Henry Episcobo keep a boarding house at the dam, which is four miles from here.

-- After the close of the World's Fair there will be an unusual freight movement out of Chicago, both East and West. Such exhibits as are to be returned to their owners in the East will be brought back free of charge by the railroads that carried the goods to Chicago. Many of the goods have been sold and must be shipped to their destinations at the expense of the buyers.
Exasperated and alarmed by the exposures of official ruffianism and corruption in Brooklyn, the political brigands of that city have ordered a boycott on The New-York Times.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- The market has been very quiet to-day. Reading receivers' certificates this afternoon were bid up to 97 without bringing out any. Operators say that the coal trade is in a very good condition. Pennsylvania was steady at 50 1/2, and it is expected that the dividend, which will be declared shortly, will be 2 1/2 per cent. cash.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- In the House to-day Representative Simpson (Pop., Kan.,) charged that Mr. Curtis (Rep., Kan.,) was the agent or attorney of railroads running through the Cherokee Strip. This the latter Vigorously denied. This was in the course of the debate on the bill to require those railroads to establish and maintain stations at the town sites located by the Interior Department, which was passed.
The proposed international prize fight between James J. Corbett and Charles Mitchell, at Coney Island in December next, will not take place.

-- Preparations on a grand scale are being made at Dresden for the celebration of the military jubilee of King Albert of Saxony. King Albert, when fifteen years old, entered the Army of Saxony in 1843, and has therefore been a soldier for fifty years. During the Franco-Prussian war he command- the German Army of the Meuse.

The University of Pennsylvania's football team will line up against the Crescents at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, this afternoon. Despite the fact that the Quaker City students defeated Princeton last year, the Crescents believe that they can make a better showing against them than they did against Princeton last week. Capt. Sheldon's men have improved very much in their team work during the past week.

Lord DUNRAVEN'S announcement that he expects to race the Valkyrie again in American waters next Spring has already given an impetus to American yachting. He does not yet admit the superiority of the Vigilant all round, although it has been pretty clearly proved to American yachtsmen that she is better than the Valkyrie on at least five days out of six of the American yachting season.

Dr. Galen W. Lovatt, forty-five years old, attempted to commit suicide last evening at 167 West Twenty-first Street, where he had been living since Oct. 1. He had engaged board there with his wife and his son, eighteen years old. Mrs. Lovatt and her son did not like the place or the surroundings. The doctor, however, insisted on staying.

The American Surety Company has sold to the State Trust Company a one-half interest in the property, 100 to 104 Broadway, with a branch on Pine Street. This property was bought from the Continental Insurance Company on Dec. 1, 1892, for $1,005,000. It has a frontage or nearly 62 feet on Broadway and is 100 feet deep.
Wheat was higher by 7/8 c early in the day, as influenced by better cables and on foreign buying, but lost 1@1 1/4 c through free realizing here and at the West, and closed weak at 1/4 @ 3/8 c down.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Yale has taken the first step toward arranging a football game between, the football elevens of the Law schools of the two universities. To-day Manager Moore of the Yale team sent a challenge to the Harvard manager, challenging the Harvard Law School eleven to a game to take place on Thanksgiving Day. If a favorable reply is received the place will be agreed upon later.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 20 -- An old-time record was lowered at Cumberland Part to-day when Hamlin's Nightingale trotted three miles in 6:55 1/2. In 1872 the stout race mare Huntress, by Volunteer, covered this distance in 7:21 1/4 in a race, while the game daughter of Mambrino King had nothing to beat here but the watch.

-- A number of the athletic young men of Sing Sing have organized an athletic and social club, and have secured the privilege of using the well-appointed gymnasium of St. John's school. They have elected the following officers: President -- George Hyatt: Vice President -- Herbert Rogers; Secretary -- Charles C. Hubbell; Treasurer -- J. Curry Barlow.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The question was raised in the office of the Secretary of State yesterday as to the printing of the names of the candidates for constitutional delegates in two columns on the ballots to toe used at the coming election.

Striped bass fishing continues good, both in home and suburban waters, and that afforded from some of the city docks is as remunerative as any obtained in the neighborhood. From Pier 16 North River one man caught, on Wednesday morning. In four hours twenty bass, averaging three-quarter of a pound each, and the same day John Brunner of West Street caught fifteen in Hell Gate, the largest weighing five and a half pounds.

The grand demonstration at the Brooklyn Rink Thursday evening, and the forcible and magnificent address by Frederick W. Hinrichs, Edward M. Shepard, and other prominent Democrats on behalf Charles A. Schieren and honest government caused dismay in the Democratic campaign headquarters yesterday.

Army News. LEAVES OF ABSENCE -- Capt. J.O. Scantling, Second Artlilory, fourteen days; Capt. E.S. Dudley, Quartermaster Departmont, ten days; Lieut. R.B. Turner, Sixth Infantry, twenty days; Lieut. G.W. Gatchell, Fourth Artlilory, one month's extension: Capt. O.M. Smith, Subsistence Department, seven days extension: Lieut. J.J. Bradley, Fourteenth Infantry, ten days' farther extension.

Theodore W. Myers, who for the last six years has been Controller of this city, was renominated for that office for a third term at the citizens' mass meeting, held in the large hall of the Cooper Union last night. The hall could not have held more persons than crowded into it. All wore enthusiastic over the business on hand.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 20 -- James J. Corbett is very much put out by the report that the Kings County officials have decided to stop the fight at Coney Island. He said this afternoon, however, that he still hoped the matter could be satisfactorily arranged between the Coney Island Athletic Club and the county officials, so that the "bout " could take place as per agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- There was a complete change of programme at the National Theatre in the north wing of the Capitol to-day. When the vanguard of spectators entered the auditorium at 10 o'clock it found only about thirty Senatorial performers occupying the arena, while on the platform overlooking them the Vice President sat idly toying with the famous handleless gavel.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 20 -- The cotton planters of this State are now thoroughly aroused by the work of incendiaries, who are, without a doubt, a band of "White Caps," who, two weeks ago, warned the farmers that if they did not shut down their gins until cotton advanced to 10 cents a pound they would apply the torch to the gin houses.

ST. LOUIS, Oct 20 -- General Manager A.A. Antisdel, General Superintendent J. Trumbull of the American Express Company, and Special Guard Korsendorfer had a conference of five hours' duration yesterday, the result of which the express officials refused to divulge. General Manager Antisdel said to a reporter:

Dr. Carl Peters, Imperial Commissioner of Germany to East Africa, was lying on a pale-blue plush lounge and reading a book, the paper cover of which was marked "Aunt Annie," in a pretty little room of the Waldorf, when a reporter for The New-York Times called on him.

BUFFALO, Oct. 20 -- The men at the head of the Sheehan faction in this city are alarmed. They are beginning to see that they are as sure of defeat in this city as election day is to come, provided the votes are honestly counted.
The money market was easier. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 1 1/2 @2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

The powers which inhere in the post of presiding officer of any parliamentary body are sufficient to enable him to remove any obstructions to the performance of the functions delegated to that body. When the powers are not expressed they are implied. They are so essential that reason revolts against their denial.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- At the Presbyterian Synod to-day the report of the synodical committee was adopted. It showed that for the year ending April 1, 1893, $69,212.18 had been raised for missionary work. This was an advance of $2,204 over the previous year. Boxes of household supplies and clothing amounting to $45,519 had been sent out to missions.

-- Arthur Willis Blake, forty-six years old, a bookkeeper for Reid Barry of Passaic, N.J., who had been missing since Oct. 9, was found Thursday night wondering aimlessly along the west side of Central Park, near Sixty-fifth Street. Mr. Blake left his home on Ayerigg Avenue, Jersey City, after taking dinner on Oct. 9. He was sent to Roosevelt Hospital.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Oct. 20 -- P.M. The total trading to-day exceeded that of yesterday, but the activity was spasmodic, and there were intervals where dullness approaching stagnation prevailed. The demand for St. Paul after the close of the market was brisk and the stock opened 7/8 higher this morning, at 60.

Congressman Ashbel P. Fitch, the Democratic nominee for Controller, was at his office, in the Bennett Building, yesterday. In talking about the campaign and the suggestion that Controller Myers would be an independent candidate against him, he said to a reporter for The New-York Times:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The annual report of the Major General commanding the army was made public to-day. Speaking of coast defense, Gen. Schofield says:

By the will of Charles Bathgate Beck about $5,000,000 will go to charity. Mr. Beck lived for years in the old Bathgate homestead at West Farms. His estate was estimated at $2,000,000, but after his death it was found to amount to about $6,000,000. No immediate relatives survived him except Charlotte and Matilda Carter, who claim to be the children of his uncle, Alexander Bathgate, to whom he was bitterly opposed.

Camden County's degradation is a matter of notoriety throughout the length and breadth of the Union. As in Hudson County, the domination of the gamblers is complete and absolute. Gloucester City is a synonym for all that is debasing, corrupt, rotten, and vicious. Assemblyman William J. Thompson is absolute master of affairs in that pesthole of iniquity.

The recent order of the Secretary of the Treasury setting apart new anchorage grounds in the North River on and after Nov. 1 next has aroused anxiety among the members of the Columbia Yacht Club of this city. The Columbia's clubhouse is situated on the Riverside Drive front of North River at the foot of West Eightysixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Somewhere in one of the papers there appeared, just after Senator Don Cameron's wonderful speech in favor of free silver coinage and several other unrelated things, a suggestion that he had been moved to his silver utterances by considerations presented to him by Mr. S.T. Hauser, ex-Governor of Montana, with whom Mr. Cameron may have some silver investments that are in suspension.

Union County is the latest of the counties in the State to feel the grasp of the gambling octopus that has seized on the State. Two race tracks are situated there, one in the township of Linden, where the Linden Blood Horse Association operates, and the other at Elizabeth, where the New-Jersey Jockey Club has its track.

All of the newly-elected Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad were present at the meeting held in New-Haven yesterday for the election of officers. The balloting resulted as follows: President -- Charles P. Clark of New-Haven; First Vice President -- John M. Hall of Willimantic; Secretary -- Will- iam D. Bishop, Jr., of Bridgeport, and Treasurer -- W.L. Squire of New-Haven.

Berlin Dispatch to The London Daily Telegraph. It is gratifying, after having to record a series of pessimist reports about Prince Bismarck's health, to be able to announce with certainty that the illustrious patient bore the fatigue of his journey from Kissingen to Friedrichsruhe on Saturday much better than was anticipated.

The fondness for "corners" in house decoration is a growing one. They are to be had complete at the shops, requiring only to be set up like a piano or a cabinet, but there seems to be a preference for those that are evolved or created actually in the room they are designed to ornament.

The people are behind Grover Cleveland in this fight. He is but the mouthpiece of their will. No code of antiquated rules, no precedents set up to nullify the popular will, no customs of miscalled courtesy which are but covers for selfish and personal schemes or sordid and unpatriotic interests, will long be suffered to stand in their way.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 21 -- There is a prospect of a lively social season here this Winter. The first event this Fall at which the attendance was large and essentially of a society grade was given in the Club Hall Thursday evening for the benefit of Montclair society's pet charity, the Children's Home.

The Committee of Nine appointed at the citizens' union mass meeting, held in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, Oct. 12, has made a report to the people, in which it states that the Republicans have nominated as candidate for Mayor "a strong and fearless business man, who will honestly, to the best of his ability, and in the sole interest of the people, administer the or rings, and no master, save the people."

The two days' meeting of the Hempstead Farm Racing Association held at Hempstead, L.I., wound up yesterday with one of the most disgraceful scenes ever witnessed on a race course. Society had turned out in full force to see the "gentlemen" jockeys ride, and from the boxes in the grand stand and from on top of drags that were lined along the fences about 600 society people witnessed the races.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- An alarming, though, as it subsequently proved, unimportant, incident, occurred at midnight last night at the Cercle Militaire, where Admiral Avelan and the other Russian guests are stopping. The Russians had just returned from the festivities at the Hotel de Ville, and were entering the clubhouse, when a haggardloooking man about fifty years old discharged a revolver over the heads of the cheering crowd assembled in front of the clubhouse.

The regular Winter drills of the First Battalion, New-York State Naval Militia, have begun. The order regarding the work directs that the First and Second Divisions shall drill on Monday nights. The Third and Fourth Divisions will drill on Wednesday nights. Thursday and Friday nights will be devoted to the instruction of the awkward squads.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 21 -- Later details from the front lessen the importance of the successes of the British South African Company's forces in their engagements with the Matabeles. It is now known that the first engagement, which was credited with being a great victory for the whites, was simply a skirmish with a small body of Matabeles who were guarding cattle.

We wonder whether selfishness increases or decreases among the poor. We rather think the former is the case, and is due, first, to an increasing consciousness which exasperates self-pity into a disease; and, secondly, to the perfectly marvelous development of pity for poverty as the most hopeless of all misfortunes.

Senator Edward Murphy arrived at the Hoffman House last night from Washington. He will return this afternoon on the 3:30 train. Lieut. Gov. Sheehan, James J. Martin, John M. Bowers, Secretary De Freest, and others were in conference with him at a late hour. He came over on business, relative no doubt to the State campaign.

He has no ground rent to pay, for he does not build his house upon any, and asks no better foundations for what he lives in than his own back. Being his own landlord, he is not liable for house rent, and when he is not inside them his apartments are unfurnished ones.

Senator VOORHEES is too infirm of purpose for the leader of a great cause. He did not call up yesterday the closure resolution of which he had given notice on Friday. But the introduction of the resolution was equivalent to a promise that he would press it to adoption. There was nothing else for him to do, for otherwise his "giving notice" must be set down as a fatuous and barren performance.

The second lecture by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore to the teachers of New-York City and State was given at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday. It was devoted to a general description of the World's Fair.

ORANGE, Oct. 21 -- The Yale football players came out to the Orange oval this afternoon and allowed the Orange Athletic Club team how to play in the presence of about 2,000 persons. The interference of the visitors was as near perfection as usual, and the Orange could only hold them back at her centre, which proved to be quite strong.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The crowning event in the celebration of Manhattan Day took place in Festival Hall. There were gathered Gotham's most illustrious orators and prominent citizens from all walks of life. The speakers praised aud cajoled and bantered Chicago by turns, and the New-York people, who composed a large part of the magnificent assembly, relished the oratory, the wit, and the good-natured sallies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- There have been many great days in the history of the World's Columbian Exposition, days filled from dawn to midnight with cheers, marked by congratulations following upon great achievements, teeming with great hopes of a future brighter than the skies which, almost cloudless, have formed a serene and superhuman capping to the greatest monument to progress ever erected by man.

Some of the most splendid and costly silks of the season are characterized by a delicacy of coloring that often is reserved for silks of less pretentious grade. The beautiful velvet brocades are tinted as exquisitely as the Autumn sky.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- There has always been more or less speculation concerning the origin of the old names in which the noble Hudson River abounds. It may be interesting to know something about the derivation of some of them.

Mayor Boody's campaign received another serious set-back yesterday by the announcement of a number of New-York banks that they would loan no more money on Brooklyn property until Boody and his "machine" office holders are driven from control of the city's financial affairs.

Mme. Alice Le Plongeon, who, with her husband, Dr. Le Plongeon, spent a long term of years in Yucatan and Central America searching for relics of past ages, is a pale, slender, delicate-looking woman -- the last one would select as having a physique fitted to undergo the perils of the wildernesses and waste places of the earth as she has done.

The handsome brownstone house at the corner of Monroe Place and Clark Street, Brooklyn, which for more than twenty-five years has been the home of the family of the late Henry J. Stevenson, is closed and the from door is boarded up so that nobody can enter. The house is in the hands of the American District Telegraph Company, which refuses to give access to it to any person.

"Boss" McLaughlin once openly boasted at a meeting of the King's County Democratic General Committee that he had hired a gang of his followers to break up a meeting called to indorse the nomination ot "Nod" Webster for Member of Congress. On that occasion he set an example which his followers imitated. For the first time since Seth Low was elected Mayor his henchmen last night resorted to violence.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Henry K. Vingut of 46 West Thirty-first Street, NewYork, the gentleman rider who was so badly injured in a cross-country steeplechase at Cedarhurst a few weeks ago, today caused a warrant to be issued by Acting Recorder Hansey of Hoboken for the arrest of John Walters, Mr. Vingut's stableman.

That much-talked about undergraduate rule, especially as affecting football, the question that has been the absorbing topic of conversation in college circles for some time past, appears to be destined for an easy death. It will not be rescinded. That would be a slap at Capt. Hinkly and other wiseacres at Yale, but from very good authority it has been learned that in the future the undergraduate rule will be a dead letter.

I think it was David who said that he had not seen the righteous "forsaken." Could David have lived in these times, and have known me, he would not have so written, unless perhaps ironically. I am conscious of my own rectitude; but every one else seems ignorant of it. I wrap myself in my virtue, but no one seems impressed with my manner of dress.

CHATHAM, Mass., Oct. 21 -- The steamer that grounded last night on Chatham Bars was probably the United States gunboat Machias, from Portsmouth, N.H., for New-York. The Machias was reported passing out by Highland Light at 3:30 P.M., and would have reached about the point where the steamer stranded at the hour the reported vessel was sighted ashore.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 21 -- The first elevated railroad run by the trolley is in very successful operation in this city. It is about a mile long, and is a part of an extensive system or trolley transit. Several years ago Messrs. Jarvis and Conklin came from Kansas City to Baltimore and acquired extensive real estate interests in the suburbs, which they proceeded to develop.

President Carnot has been singularly illrequitted for a generous action. It will be remembered that in 1889 a man named Perrin fired a revolver at the President, fortunately only with blank cartridge, as the latter was leaving the Elysee to proceed to Versailles on the occasion of the centenary of the opening of the famous States General.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., Oct. 21 -- A rear end collision took place near here yesterday on the Baltimore and Ohio Road between two sections of the Barnum Bailey Circus train. One man was killed and a number were seriously hurt.

William Freudenthal, a dealer in shields at 67 Walker Street, was a prisoner in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning. He was charged by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Kate T. Wagner of 321 East Sixty-first Street, with having taken $17,000 of her money. Mrs. Wagner's husband was at one time manager of the Terrace Garden, and afterward steward of the Liederkranz.
The weekly bank statement issued to-day showed an increase in reserve of $8,744,725. The banks now hold $42,640,775 in excess of the legal requirements.

Under date of Aug. 15, 1893, a correspondent of The Brooklyn Eagle, writing from Greenpoint, L.I., where "Boss" McLaughlin spent his Summer vacation, delicately described one of "the old man's" numerous tattooings in the following words: "On the biceps of his left arm is traced an involved design in blue and black.
George Frederick Watts has presented his painting of "Love and Life," which is now on exhibition at Chicago, to the American people.

When thoughtless people of New-Jersey welcomed to their State men of capital who built race courses, they did not know the power for evil these would become. The builders were received with open arms because "they brought money to the State." That this bringing of money to the State would result, as it has, in the prostitution and debauchery of New-Jersey was not dreamed of.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21 -- Harvard defeated Dartmouth to-day 36 to 0. The weather was a little warm for good football, but the field was in prime condition. The game brought, out a large number of ladies, and nearly all the graduate players were present.

"You cannot possibly have forgotten the scandal and the theft of the people's money in the matter of the Twelfth Ward Park purchase," (Alderman Coffey's park,) said Frederick W. Hinrichs, before a meeting of the Sixth Ward Branch of the Citizens' Union of Kings County on Thursday night.

De Oro won the pool match, defeating John Roberts, the English champion, by a score of 1,000 to 924. In the closing night's play De Oro beat Roberts by 250 to 223. At the English game Roberts scored 125 to De Oro's 122, but at the American game the Cuban made 128 to the Englishman's 108.

The rector of Clayton (the Rev. T.H.R. Shand) writes to The London Times to announce "that in the ancient parish church of Clayton, at the entrance of the wellknown tunnel through the South Downs, on the Brighton Railway, there have recently been discovered, hidden under many coats of whitewash, some remarkable mural paintings of probably the thirteenth century.
"After conferring with several members of the Republican nominating committee and hearing from others, I have come to the conclusion to stick. I will not withdraw from the race for Controller."

That no international prize fight is to be fought at Coney Island was made absolutely certain by the vigor and persistence of the crusade conducted by The New-York Times. The unconditional surrender of all persons directly concerned in that proposed contest, and the official statements made by permission of "Boss" McLaughlin that the fight would not be allowed, formed a sufficient assurance that The Times had performed well a great public duty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- In Tenth Street, in this city, directly opposite the famous Ford's Theatre building, stands a modest, red-brick, three-story and basement house. It has a high stoop, which is reached by circular stairs. It would not attract particular attention were it not for a small white marble tablet set in the wall, bearing this inscription:

The battle over the checkered boards which has been raging for these last two weeks at the Manhattan Chess Club is over, and while the devotees of the royal game will regret that there are no more news from the seat of war, the chess players who have been fighting for supremacy are glad.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- There stands in one of the recesses at the bottom of the well of the grand staircase in the western part of the State Capitol the cast of a heroic statue of Henry Hudson. This was produced for the New-York Managers of the Columbian Exposition by one of America's youngest artists, Charles L. Hinton of Albany.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 21 -- Francis H. Weeks will sail for New-Orleans in custody of the New-York detectives on Wednesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While walking through Sixth Street this morning my attention was drawn to the demolition at the old Sixth Street Baptist Church, a landmark of the day when in that part of the city (the old Dry Dock) ships were built. In watching its desstruction, each brick removed brought to my mind a pleasant thought.
Notes on the progress of the Barye Monument, the expense of which was, in its larger share, defrayed by Americans, have been received in private, letters from Paris.

Had it not been for the thousands of persons gayly dressed in holiday attire who thronged the hillsides around the parade grounds at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday afternoon, an observer might have taken the conflict which was being waged there between two opposing divisions of soldiery for the real and deadly conflict of actual battle.

Counselor Bergen, law partner of W.N. Dykman, receiver for the defunct Commercial Bank, Brooklyn, applied to Justice Bartlett yesterday for instructions regarding the payment of a dividend of 33 1-3 per cent, to the depositors. Since his appointment as temporary receiver, Mr. Dykman has collected $246,840.22.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The Government organs that have hitherto professed to consider that the new taxation projects have been definitely settled among the Federal States are now obliged to admit that there are serious differences between the officials of the South German States and the Imperial Ministers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Senator Cockrell has counted Senators present and not voting to make a quorum. He was presiding in the Senate on March 3, 1881, when there was a hot contest, close to the end of the session. There was filibustering, and Senators who appeared one moment on a roll call were absent on the next vote, although in sight.

We presume that every State in which existing laws do not discourage such undertakings will eventually be afflicted for a time by the so-called endowment companies and other ventures of the same class. The experience of Massachusetts has been instructive to some other Northern States, but the people of the South and Southwest have still to learn the lesson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Treasury "ten days' " statement, issued to-day, shows that the gold reserve has decreased to $81,700,000, the lowest point it ever reached, and a loss for the month of October of $12,000,000.

There is pretty general complaint just now on the part of real estate brokers on account of the absence of business. A little exchanging, a fair amount of renting, and a few sales, mainly by west side builders who wish to unload before going ahead with further operations, comprise the sum total of transactions.
Mr. Alden did not play whist on the railway train from Jersey City to Metuchen that evening.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The private funeral of Marshal MacMahon took place at noon to-day, when the procession left the house at Montcresson. Priests and local officials preceded the coffin. Behind it walked peasants of the neighborhood, bearing the dead soldier's many orders and crosses. At the end of the line were the Marshal's two sons, Patrice and Emmanuel.

An interesting wedding ceremony took place yesterday noon in the Friends' Meeting House at Rutherfurd Place and Fifteenth Street. The bride was Miss Elizabeth Willets, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Willets of 55 West Fifty-fourth Street, and the bridegroom was Dr. Samuel W. Lambert.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President and Mrs. Cleveland are living more quietly just now than has ever before been possible for them in this city. Mrs. Cleveland still keeps to her custom of either driving in town with him every morning, or coming for him in the afternoon, when they extend their drive around the country, now so glorious in its Autumn dress.

The play called "In Old Kentucky," to be presented at the Academy to-morrow night, with the melodies of "My Old Kentucky Home" and "Massa's in the Col', Col' Ground" running all through it, will interest many who remember the unfortunate Stephen C. Foster, who died, deserted by his friends and kinsmen, at Bellevue Hospital, in 1864, from the result of an accident in the old American Hotel, in the Bowery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The news that Francis H. Weeks, the defaulting New-York lawyer, would be surrendered by the Government of Costa Rica to the New-York authorities for extradition to the United States, was received by Secretary Gresham this morning in a cable message from Consul Williams at San Jose, Costa Rica, where Weeks is now in confinement.
One of the new dynamite guns built to defend New-York Harbor has thrown a projectile over three miles. The same gun has demonstrated its ability to throw a projectile three and three-quarter miles.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 21. -- It is not generally known that the best paying branches of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern and the Michigan Central systems are the lines between Toledo and Detroit, yet such is the case. So great have been the profits of these two short lines that even now another line of steam railway is being considered by capitalists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Unless the advocates of immediate unconditional repeal gain some resolution over Sunday there is great probability that Monday will find Them securely committed, by the action of a majority of the Democrats, to a proposition that is called a compromise for the pending bill for repeal, without conditions and without postponement.

The score of the first game played at St. Petersburs between Tarrasch and Tschigorin has just arrived. The German expert played an exceedingly fine game, especially when he offered the sacrifice of a piece with 22 -- KtxQ P.

ORANGE, Oct. 21 -- The first formal social event of the season in the Oranges will be the reception, Monday evening, at the Orange Athletic Club, to members and friends, by the Ladies' Auxiliary of the club. A second reception of this nature will be given Nov 20.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Charles Wiltz, Chairman of the Eastern Window Glass Workers' Executive Board, has received a telegram from President Eberhardt of the National Association stating that the agreement for the next blast was almost completed and would be signed by the manufacturers.
The Post-Graduate Hospital appeals to its friends to help it over a hard place in the road to its splendid and efficient establishment.

TOPEKA, Oct. 21 -- The people of Kansas have at last commenced to realize the full extent of the disrepute that attaches to their State. They have learned that not only are Kansas securities refused in all the money markets of the Nation, but that even an acknowledgment before a Kansas notary public will suffice to throw out otherwise good paper.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 21 -- In the South the difference between "hunting" and "shooting" is sharply defined. A friend says, "Let us shoot to-morrow." Without further telling you know just what he means. It means that with well-trained setters (the pointer is not much the vogue in the South) you will follow through cornfields and briars that quickest of our small game birds, the quail.

The funeral of Gen. Denis F. Burke, which took place yesterday morning from 485 West One Hundred and Forty-firth Street, was largely attended by members of the Grand Army, veterans of the Irish Brigade, delegations from St. Patrick's Club, the Irish National League, and other military and civic organizations.
The money market was easier. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 1 1/2 @ 2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

If any of the candidates upon the Tammany city and county ticket were in any doubt as to whether they had been nominated at last Tuesday night's convention, they were reassured yesterday afternoon, when the Committee on Notification met them in the room of the Executive Committee, in Tammany Hall, and formally notified them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Secretary Carlisle will give a hearing on Monday next to United States District Attorney Mitchell of New-York City and E.S. Bangs, attorney in what is called the Block case. S.E. Block is a New-York merchant, who, a year or so ago, was charged by the Treasury Department with having imported silks and having these goods passed through the New-York Custom House as Bolting cloths, thus defrauding the Government.

PRINCETON, Ill., Oct. 21 -- William Glenn Reeve has left the city in such circumstances as to suggest that he is either an insane financier or a sane criminal. He leaves behind him a once wealthy father, eighty-seven years old, to face the probable loss of his great fortune. He leaves a mother, a niece of William Cullen Bryant, sick with the blow.

Ansuini, Tiburzi, and Fioravanti are the names of the brigands actually in the exercise of their calling. The last remains of a famous race, their names enjoy in Latium and on the confines of Tuscany a certain renown and an undeniable popularity. A few years back they had a numerous band of associates.

"On a visit recently," says a woman," at the home of Mrs. Chambers Ketchum, the well-known botanist, I was much impressed, with the decorative possibilities of the brown and sere grasses and vines with which the Autumn fields are rich, as demonstrated by their clever arrangement in her apartments.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Cyclers were out in force on the Irvington -- Milburn course this afternoon to witness the widely-heralded ten-mile race between James Gregory of the South Park Wheelmen and William Weller of the Century Cycling Club. The race was for a medal ostensibly, but for the championship actually, for while both men are considered stars they refused to enter a professional contest.

The ships which sailed for Europe yesterday carried out well-filled staterooms, due, in part, to the large number of World's Fair visitors who are returning to their homes, and to the exodus of those tourists who spend the Winter abroad.

The report of the official Naval Board, ordered to inspect the workings of the new coaling device for snips at sea, declares that the system has shewn such merit as to warrant the equipping of a collier for the purpose of still further trials in moderately rough weather.

We have a narrow and professional, but strong, market. Speculation has been most active in the industrials. This is very wrong, of course, since the Street has been so often warned by high authorities that it must not trade in these things; but somehow people are so obstinate, they will insist on doing their own business in their own way.
"The one thing that I have pinned in my hat band for this Winter, only I don't wear a hat," laughed a woman a day or two ago, "is moderation."

Attorney General Rosendale has announced that early this week he will make a formal motion in court that the Madison Square Bank be dissolved and that the receivers who have been in charge since the bank closed its doors be appointed permanent receivers. Thereupon it is intended a dividend to depositors will be declared.

It was the finding of the bills in these cases that led up to one of the most astounding of all the scandals connected with the dirty political work that the race-track managers had been doing. A conviction had in the lower court was carried on appeal to the highest court, where cases of a similar nature, in which other tracks were concerned, were pending.

BUFFALO, Oct. 21 -- The anti-Sheehan Democrats filed two independent Democratic nominations to-day -- Daniel Morgenstern, ex-Superintendent of Police, as Senator in the Thirtieth District, and Thomas J. Nunan for Assemblyman in the First District.

Three daring burglars are now under arrest, with excellent prospects of being sent to Sing Sing for long terms of imprisonment as a punishment for the most audacious robbery chronicled in the police records of this city for a long time.

The last week was wholly devoid of interesting theatrical events. There were no new plays, and such changes as were made in the bills do not demand serious review. This week, among other important events, the first appearance of Richard Mansfield in the role of Shylock will be conspicuous. The splendid revival of "Richard III," by Mr. Mansfield is well remembered.

CHICAGO, Got. 21 -- There was a weaker tone to the wheat market to-day and the closing showed a lose of 1 @ 1 1/8 c for the day. After opening 5/8 c lower than the close of yesterday the decline was steady and the close was at the bottom figures. The decline may be said to have been a continuation of the weakness that existed daring me latter part of yesterday's session.

The originators of the scheme thrived for but a few years. Long Branch became degenerate. The clubhouses of the two Dalys came into being. Faro and roulette, rouge et noir, and stud poker flourished boldly at the Summer resort. The authorities winked at it all, in spite of the protests of the respectable people who had gone there to escape from similar contaminations at Saratoga.

In our Spanish columns yesterday there was published a copy of a letter which Dr. Pablo Arosemena is forwarding to The New-York Herald. It will be recollected that some time ago a rumor was circulated in this city that the New-York millionaire embezzler, Francis H. Weeks, had paid a local lawyer the absurdly large earn of $5,000 in gold as a consultation fee for advice regarding his chances of evading the extradition laws.

After attaining the ripe age of thirty-three years, the Home Life Insurance Company decided recently to build for itself a new habitation. It was founded in 1860 by a party of Brooklyn's wealthy citizens, who desired to do an insurance business on more conservative lines than were followed by many of the companies in existence at that time.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 21 -- Engineer Wooley, who was arrested on account of his connection with the railroad accident of yesterday, was released, on bail to-day. He still maintains that he was ordered to start his train by Conductor Scott, and that Scott told him that the Pacific Express, the team with which his train collided, had passed.

ASBURY PARK, Oct. 21 -- Monmouth County politicians are busy figuring on the result of the approaching election for Senator, Sheriff, and Assemblymen. The county is considered safely Democratic -- that is, when party lines are drawn -- but this Fall the contest for supremacy is a sort of go-as-you-please one, all owing to the action of the Democrats in nominating an avowed race-track ticket.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The annual supplementary championships of the Amateur Athletic Union resulted in some surprises this (Saturday) afternoon on the New-Jersey Athletic Club grounds at Bayonne. George W. Orton, formerly of Toronto, Ontario, and now of the University of Pennsylvania, carried off the honors in the two-mile steeplechase.

Monmouth County is one of the fairest spots in the State that has been defaced by one of the fever sores that have sprung up since the gamblers decided to take New-Jersey for their own. It was practically the first of the biotches that appeared. As is so often the case with men attacked by some slow-growing but pestiferous disease, little attention was paid to the appearance of the contagious excrescence.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The new management of the Gymnase Theatre has started off in tragic fashion, and with considerable success. "Une Vengeance," by M. Henry Amic, is not the drama of a beginner. It is of the Dumas kind -- rapid, sharp, and almost always interesting, which are not frequently the qualities of a new man.

I. The status of the old-fashioned ghost story has, within the past ten years, perceptibly changed. Formerly, by the credulous generality of people, it was almost universally accepted without reason and without critical examination. It was looked upon as supernatural, and supernatural things were neither to be doubted nor reasoned about, and there the mater ended.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21 -- This was farewell day for the harness racers at Cumberland Park. The four events remaining to end the meeting were decided in straight heats except the consolation, for two-year-old trotters. In this the favorite, Cervis, failed to get a heat, but he was the victim of an accident in the first one which probably cost him the race.

Although the price of wheat suffered a further decline last week, the export trade was not stimulated by the change, for the quantity shipped to Europe was only 2,709,700 bushels, which may be compared with 2,862,641 for the preceding week and a weekly average of nearly 5,000,000 for the months of July, August, and September.

The judiciary is generally the last stronghold of sound government that a political ring is able to seize. Often it is the last that is attacked, because respect for the law and the sense of the priceless value of pure courts are so deeply rooted in the public mind of all countries that can be called free that corrupt politicians avoid a conflict on that field.

In many museums may be seen, in the most perfect state of preservation in amber, fossilized remains of plants and animals. The science of Egypt in its highest development did not succeed in discovering a method of embalming so perfect as the simple process taking place in nature. A tree exudes a gummy, resinous matter in a liquid state.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 21 -- John L. Sullivan arrived in this city last evening with his theatrical company and made himself quite agreeable to the reporters who called. He expressed himself on the merits of Corbett and Mitchell, saying: "It is going to be a long fight, in my opinion. Both the men are good fighters, and are excellent ring fighters.
In the bright, clear Autumn air everything and everybody looks brighter and letter -- except the wretched stage horses of the Fifth Avenue Transportation Company.

Brooklyn's "ring" was attacked by the Rev. John F. Carson, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, at the quarterly meeting of the Christian Endeavor Union of Brooklyn, held last night in the Duryea Presbyterian Church, Clermont, near Atlantic Avenues. Mr. Carson also declared that any man who voted for Judge Maynard would "outrage American citizenship."

An interesting ceremony was performed on Saturday afternoon at Boulge, a little village near Woodbridge. In the churchyard there is the grave of Edward Fitzgerald, the translator of the works of the Persian poet, Omar Khayyam. In 1884 Mr. William Simpson, the veteran artist of The Illustrated London News, while out with, the Afghan Boundary Commission, discovered the grave of Omar Khayyam, and gathered from it the seeds of a rose which nourished there.

Eleven little youths in crimson, from Cornell University, met eleven big brawny fellows from Princeton, at Manhattan Field, yesterday afternoon in a game of football, and when the smoke of the battle cleared away the youths from Ithaca lelt the field in a very unhappy frame of mind. For several years they have been trying to meet the "Tigers," and for some reason they were unsuccessful.

Two walking delegates of the Operative Painters' Union were arrested yesterday for trying to induce workmen to stop work on the building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, which the firm of L. Marcotte Co. is having renovated for Mrs. H.M. Brooks.
"What a delightful idea!" exclaimed a young girl to her companion, as, while looking at some fine china, they were shown a dainty tray, designed expressly for invalids.

Sarah Bernhardt, with characteristic energy, intends to introduce during her management of the Renaissance Theatre. All who are familiar with Parisian playhouses have had occasion to complain of the innumerable petty extortions of those licensed harpies, the "ouvreusea," or boxkeepers.

The one hundred and twenty-seventh anniversary of American Methodism will be celebrated in the old John Street Church in this city to-day. It was in the John Street Church that the Methodist Episcopal denomination in this country had its first home, and that old parish has been called the "Cradle of American Methodism."

At the time of our visit to this Brazilian penal Island there were 1,800 convicts in the settlement. Of these, 1,000 are divided into ten companies of 100 each, under the command of a Sergeant, himself a convict. They live in outlying villages, and are employed at work in the fields and plantations, and tend the sheep and cattle.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21 -- The annual State convention of the Christian Endeavor societies in Connecticut will be held in the National Guard armory in Bridgeport Nov. 1. The Rev. H.H. Kelsey of the Fourth Congregational Church in this city will preside, and addresses will be made by the Rev. Asher Anderson of Meriden and the Rev. A.C. Dixon of New-York City.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct 21. -- The funeral of Mrs. Lucy Stone Blackwell took place this afternoon from the Church of the Desciples, at Weat Brookline Street and Warren Avenue. The floral tributes were yellow and white, the favorite colors of the friend thus remembered.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The performances in the Senate Chamber to-day were gloomily idle and useless for any purpose except that of killing time.

The interest among members of the National Guard during the past week was centred for the most part in the maneuvers at Van Cortlandt Park, the trip of the Old Guard to Chicago, and the excursion made by Troop A to the unveiling of the Trenton Battle Monument on Thursday. Yesterday was a busy day with the local military organizations.

The elections for the Council General were going on all over the island of Corsica, The canton of Soccia comprises several villages, among others Guagno, noted for its famous mineral springs, and also for the turbulence of its people. The elections took place in each village, and on the morrow the Presidents of the several bureaus were to meet at Soccia for the formal declaration of the poll.

It became positively dangerous during the Revolution to pronounce the word royal or king, and especially the name of any monarch who had reigned in France. The innocent King of "Twelfth Night" was suppressed, and the nomenclature of the "devil's picture boards" thoroughly revised.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- The local market opened weak and irregular, but the tenor soon changed and prices strengthened. The close was at the highest of the day. The market was dull, but there was an increased demand for investment. There was no special feature outside of Sugar and Boston and Montana copper stocks, which advanced on small transactions.

A steerage passenger of the Campania who was either very tired of life or in a great hurry to get ashore jumped overboard from that vessel on Friday night when the ship was passing Sandy Hook. The man a German immigrant, whose name the officers of the Campania did not know, was seen to pick up a small bench which was lying upon the deck and jump overboard with it.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 21 -- Mr. J.J. Van Alen arrived Wednesday afternoon on his four-in-hand. He had with him Mr. and Mrs. Fernando Yznaga, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mortimer, Miss Goddard, Mr. Center Hitchcock, and Mrs. Allen. The Duke of Alba, who started with them from NewYork, came on as far as Poughkeepsie, where he was obliged to leave the party and return.

From The London Daily News. A rogue with the unmanageable name of Shunkernath Wishwumbernatli has been convicted in Bombay and sentenced by Mr. Justice Starling to five years' penal servitude for a curious sort of fraud. It seems that he had, by certain skillful feats of jugglery, to the accompaniment of cabalistic acts and utterances, persuaded a man named Hurribux that he was able to make duplicates of currency notes to any extent.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- There was a good showing in the Cornell annual Fall games at Percy Field to-day so far as numbers were concerned, but the quality of much, of the material was of a second-class kind. Some Cornell records were broken, but there were many events in which the contestants fell so far short of even the college record that they are scarcely deserving of a notice.

A well-dressed old man called at the Bank of the Republic early this month and introduced himself to William B.T. Keyser, the cashier, as Gen. E.C. Williams of Washington, D.C. He told Mr. Keyser that he proposed to mate his home in this city, and desired to open an account at the bank, for which purpose he presented a draft for $13,750, drawn by himself on the National Bank of Washington.

WORLD'S FAIR, CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The Standard Manufacturing Company of Pittsburg, Penn., received the highest awards (four in number) on bathtubs, hollow ware, plumbers' iron ware, and sanitary goods. The goods of this company stand the highest in the country. The awards made are considered a fitting recognition of their merit.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Speculators in theatre tickets are having a hard time carrying on business here. Tickets have been at a premium during the engagement of "America" at the Auditorium, and of Irving and Terry at the Columbia, and at some of the other houses this Summer. The other night Manager Will Davis of the Columbia was offered seats in the first and second balconies at a premium of 50 cents.

The Season for Coaching and Hunting -- With every approaching Autumn the gallants of the hunting and coaching sets get out their riding breeches, tight at the knees and loose at the hips, or their big checked tweeds and boxcoats, to squeeze out all the fun there is in the Fall season. To the steeplechaser hunting has all the excitement of war, without any of its dangers.

Protection had failed utterly to protect the gamblers in their game at the Monmouth track. The managers concluded that they must join in the great scheme of bribery that was then outlined for securing the passage of laws that would permit all the gambling on race tracks that one could ask for.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 26 -- Long preparation at the torpedo station for the torpedo-net tests closed to-day with a trial of the Destroyer's submarine gnu and the Lassve projectile. One shot was fired with a charge of twelve pounds of powder. Gun and projectile worked faultlessly. The projectile was driven toward a net, 100 feet from the gun.

The preliminary trial of the new United States cruiser Marblehead will probably take place in Long Island Sound during the latter part of the present week. The Marblehead is still in the hands of the builders, the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company of this city. The vessel is coaled and during the past few days has been subjected to a series of dock trials.

The improvement in the trotting horse is the most remarkable evidence of progress in intelligent and skillful breeding that is furnished by the combined annals of men and animals. There has scarcely been a more striking instance of it than the performance of Fantasy at Nashville on Tuesday, when the mile record for three-year-olds was reduced by a second and three-quarters, and the "race record" for three-year-olds by two seconds and a half.

Everything was gloomy at the campaign headquarters of the Democratic "machine," the Thomas Jefferson Building, on Court Square, Brooklyn, yesterday. Register Thomas J. Kenna had a troubled look on his countenance, and Thomas E. Pearsall, the "machine" nominee for Justice of the Supreme Court, looked as if he was attending a funeral.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 21. -- For many years rumors had been heard regarding the management of the Western Branch at the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers. There had been many so-called investigations by committees appointed by the Grand Army of the Republic, but nothing had come of them.

Prof. Norton's aim in making this selection from the letters that Lowell wrote -- and the number of his letters was very great -- was to give to the volumes an autobiographical character. He found the undertaking not a difficult one. Lowell's letters completely reveal the man to us. The record, moreover, is remarkably full from early youth down to old age.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- There was almost a riot in Lady Aberdeen's Irish village of industries to-night. A second attempt was made by about fifteen Irishmen to pull down the union jack which has been floating from the tower of Blarney Castle in honor of Lady Aberdeen's husband, the Governor General of Canada.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The rally started on Wednesday by New-York purchases, based apparently on the probability of a silver compromise, held until to-day, when Americans were steady in the face of the weakness of other departments. But the rise caused no enthusiasm here, as unconditional repeal is thought necessary to restore confidence.

If their rank is such as to keep up the state of guards for their houses, they are in general yagers or miltary huntsmen, continually employed when off duty in bringing in venison and other game, or some other useful employment.

The new United States gunboat Machias reached this port yesterday from Boston. The report printed in The New-York Times that the Machias probably ran aground off the Massachusetts coast shortly after clearing Boston Harbor was correct. The gunboat touched bottom off Chatham, Mass.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 22 -- The training ship Portsmouth is under orders received Saturday to sail for the Brooklyn Navy Yard to-morrow morning. Recently a survey of the vessel was made here, and some of her bow woodwork and spars were found in very poor condition. A report was made to the Navy Department, resulting in the ordering of a more thorough survey at Brooklyn.
Probably the most remarkable congregation assembled in America last night was that addressed in the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the Rev. Cortland Myers, on "How to Save the City."

Mr. Howard E. Raymond, Chairman of the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board, was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times concerning the fashion of cyclists making records in private. "I have not heard officially of any objection to the present system of private time trials," he said. "Of course, there are certain reasons why races against the watch may be objected to.

St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, was opened for worship yesterday morning for the first time since it was closed to undergo repairs several months ago. The Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, the pastor, officiated.

"Triumphant Democracy; or, Legislation by the Thugs of Divverdom" was the subject of a discourse by Alexander F. Irvine, city missionary, in the Church of Sea and Land, Market and Henry Streets, last evening. Mr. Irvine violently attacked Patrick Divver for having brought about the nomination of Michael J. Callahan for Assemblyman in the district.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Yale has been learning the lesson that a team cannot improve and get into clean-cut form without graduate coachers. Last week the lesson was fully mastered, and the calls of Capt. Hinkey for aid to the football alumni of Yale were heard and answered. It seemed as though the team had reached the lowest ebb it was possible for it to attain in ragged play.

The Fall meeting at the Hudson River Driving Park. Poughkeepsie, N.Y., begins to-day for trotters and pacers, and fifty-three horses have arrived at the park. There will be two races each day for pacers and trotters. Among the trotters and pacers entered are Crescent. Dutchess County Bell, Carlton Chief, Ruprecht, Miss Wilton Hipped, Corner Belle, Sunset Patchen, Hurlingham, Sir Wilkes Fleet, Favorite Wilkes, Filmore, Starin's Medium, and others.

The Rev. Joseph H. Rylance, D.D., of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Place, yesterday morning delivered a forcible discourse on "The Pulpit and Politics."

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed, an increase in reserve of $8,744,725. The banks now hold $42,640,775 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $1,676,300, an increase in specie of $5,339,100, an increase in legal tenders of $5,713,300, an increase in deposits of $9,230,200, and a decrease in circulation of $256,300.

The Rev. Spencer S. Roche, at St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, delivered at the services yesterday morning and last evening a masterful discourse on the life and public services of the late Hamilton Fish. He gave many interesting reminiscences of the dead statesman.

Jewelry valued at $2,500 which was stolen from Joseph Wilkinson, whose home is at Hull Avenue and Southern Boulevard, on Oct. 15, was recovered Saturday night by detectives. The property was found in the possession Of George Cowle, twenty-two years old, who was arrested in the Bowery. Much of the jewelry was found on his person and in his trunk, and pawn tickets were found for the other articles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Sanitary Inspector Rosse makes the following report to the Marine Hospital Bureau from Leghorn, Italy, under date of Sept. 30: "I arrived here yesterday afternoon, to find the town with a deserted look and a general panic among the inhabitants, many of whom had fled to other places.

"Do you really want to know why Mr. Myers has not wired either an acceptance or a declination of our nomination of him for Controller?" said Boomer John E. Owen to a reporter for The New-York Times last night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22 -- The statistics of the university are out at last. In the whole university there are 3,061 students, as compared with 2,069 last year. The total in college is 1,648, as against 1,598 last term. The net gain is 92. The graduate department and the Lawrence Scientific School show the greatest gains. There are now 235 graduates, to 206 in 1892-3.
The Rev. Dr. De Costa, rector of the Protestant. Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist, preached yesterday morning on "The Home and Its Relation to Politics."

Mrs. Annie Bobb, wife of Henry Bobb of 50 Meserole Street. Williamaburg, died in St. Catharine's Hospital yasterday from the effects of burns received in a mysterious manner. The Bobbs live on the top floor of a brick house The floor underneath was occupied by Mrs. Louisa Lohmar, who died Thursday. Saturday evening a "wake" was held over the corpse.

Fire started about 8 o'clock yesterday morning in the basement of the dispensary of the Presbyterian Hospital. The dispensary is a brick building, one story and basement. It stands 200 feet east of the main building, and is connected with it only by a stone passageway.
Kleptomania -- "E.V.": (1) How may we determine kleptomania? (2) What is its cause? (3) Is there any cure for It? (4) Is there any recognized medical authority on moral diseases?
It is announced that Senator David B. Hill, in response to an invitation from the frightened "Boss" of Brooklyn, has promised to visit that city and deliver a campaign speech to-night.

The Brooklyn Democratic "ring" is in a state of outright fright over the publicly-expressed determination of the New-York savings banks to loan no more money on Brooklyn real estate until there is a radical change in the administration of that city.

The auction sales of realty to-day include the offering by Messrs. R.V. Harnett Co. of a west side dwelling and of part of the Yuengling brewery property, in foreclosure, and also that of a portion of the Vyse estate lots by Mr. James L. Wells. These sales are to take place at 111 Broadway. Details are appended:

The long and bitter war between the clothing cutters who are Knights of Labor and those affiliated with the American Federation of Labor will probably end soon. A conference was held yesterday between representatives of the two organizations, and a basis of settlement of the difficulties was agreed upon.

The Rev. Dr. Alfred Momerie of London, who has been attending the Parliament of Religions in Chicago, occupied the pulpit yesterday in All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. At the morning service Dr. Momerie delivered an interesting discourse on the harmony of science and religion.

The plan for a special Manhattan Day at the World's Fair was happily conceived and carried out with the most gratifying success. The effect upon the relations between the metropolis of the seaboard and the metropolis of the interior is sure to be salutary, and will go far to put them on the friendly footing toward each other which for many reasons they should always occupy.

The People's Singing Classes of New-York held a mass meeting yesterday afternoon in Beethoven Hall, Fifth Street and the Bowery, to form a new east-side branch to the organization. More than 400 persons attended, and there was much enthusiasm.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The past week has been extremely quiet in the market for local securities, very little inquiry having developed and few sales being reported. Quotations held steady, and there are few changes in prices to record. The only feature was the improvement in Troy Gas debenture 6 per cent. convertible bonds.

A new feature of the High School this year is a display of class records once a month, showing the comparative grade of scholarship of the seniors, the two sections of Juniors, and the three sections of the freshman class, so that a direct comparison of the scholarship of these different bodies from month to month can be shown. Some lively contests between the sections are promised before the year is over.

The schooner Harry W. Haynes, which yesterday arrived from Brunswick, Ga., seven days out, had on board the crew of the wrecked schooner Martie A. Holmes. The story of the shipwreck is of a piece with the other tales of disaster and rescue which the October storms have made so prolific of late.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Mr. Gorman's "makeshift" compromise does not look so promising to-day as it did yesterday. As a matter of fact, the scheme that was considered to be as good as passed is already spoken of as in danger of absolute failure, and to-morrow the fight for unconditional and immediate repeal may be resumed with something of the vigor that should have been imparted to it weeks ago.

The Rev. Vandervoort Bruce, one of the oldest Protestant Episcopal clergymen of this city, died yesterday from paralysis at his home, 457 West Twenty-third Street. Mr. Bruce came of an old New-York family, and was born in this city seventy-nine years ago. He was educated at Trinity College, Hartford.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., Oct. 22 -- A misplaced switch in the yard at the terminus of the Staten Island Rapid-Transit Railway here caused the instant death of Conductor Frank Davis, and the probable fatal injury of Fireman Wallace Bedell, this afternoon.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 22 -- Mrs. Malcolm W. Ford, who accidently poisoned herself by taking a swallow of carbolic acid in mistake for medicine last night, is pronounced out of danger by the attending physicians. Mrs. Ford was suffering from a cold and sore throat, for which she was taking a remedy prescribed by her physician.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The Rome correspondent of The Daily Chronicle says: "Commander Barluzzi and Signor Petaoci have gone to Paris to arrange for the eventual investment of the Papal funds and the transfer of the Vatican treasures, in the event of war, to a place of safety. The property of the Propaganda will be specially protected by mortgage, if necessary.

Novel enough was the plan the Rev. C. H. Yatman adopted yesterday to raise funds for the support of the deaconesses of the New-York Deaconess Home. The home's anniversary day was celebrated in the Academy of Music in the afternoon. Twenty-eight young deaconesses sat on the platform.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 22 -- There was a general onslaught in the churches of this city to-night upon the political corruption and race-track gambling that controls the State. It was evidently a preconcerted movement in aid of the mass meeting to be held in the Congregational Tabernacle Tuesday night, under the auspices of the Moral Reform League, recently organized by the ministers of the various denominations.

The question arises why Dr. Poore, so well known in sanitary science, should nave given the title "Essays on Rural Hygiene" to the work under notice. It may be said that he abandons in despair all the chances of improving sanitary conditions in large centres of population, believing that the principles of hygiene are only possible today in isolated houses or in small village settlements.

One of those infrequent reminders of the existence of Pitcairn Island and its little colony of recluses was brought yesterday by the American ship Reaper, which arrived from Portland, Oregon, 123 days out. Capt. Taylor said that he had called at the island July 25 for a supply of fruit and water.

MADRID, Oct. 22 -- The latest advices from Melilla show that the Spanish troops gained a decided victory over the Moors on Saturday. Early yesterday morning Gen. Margallo, the Spanish commander, sent to Baja-el-Arbi a final warnig that unless be carried out by noon the promise he made Thursday to persuade the Arabs to destroy their intrenchments and cease resistence the Spaniards would forthwith open a cannonade on the Moors.
The money market was without special change. Call loans ranged from 1 1/2 to 3 per cent., the average being about 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- An exception to the ordinary run of annual reports is that of Commodore George W. Melville, the arctic hero, Engineer in Chief of the United States Navy. It is in dealing with that feud of long standing between the officers of the line and the Engineer Corps that Commodore Melville writes most interestingly, and he deals with the subject in language which, while respectful and dignified, is not to be misunderstood.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The New-York Times's broadside against the race-track gamblers and their interference with New-Jersey politics came just in time. The anti-race-track sentiment was aroused by an enthusiastic mass meeting, held Tuesday night in the Opera House. The strongest resolutions ever prepared in New-Jersey were passed with cheers.

LONDON Oct. 22 -- The Marquis of Conyngham has arranged to sue for divorce shortly in the English courts. The co-respondent, whose name is Burrowes, was introduced to the Marchioness by her brother. The Marquis is thirty-six years old. He married his present wife, eldest daughter of Baron Ventry, in 1882. It is possible, but not probable, that the case will be settled out of court.

It is a queer notion of how to get votes that the McLaughlin gang in Brooklyn have. On Saturday a lot of them invaded the rooms of the Young Men's Democratic Club and tried to prevent tin indorsement of Mr. SCHIEREN and to force one of Mr. BOODY. Had they succeeded, do they really think that any member of the club who wanted to vote for SCHIEREN would on that account vote for BOODY?

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Preparations for the national funeral of Field Marshal MacMahon were evident early this morning all the way from the Church of the Madeleine to the Hotel des Invalides. Troops were taking position all along the Rue Royale when the spectators began to gather at 8 o'clock.

"Boss" Hugh McLaughlin and the members of the inner circle of the Democratic "machine" in Brooklyn were much worried yesterday. They had taken a desperate chance Saturday night to prevent a Democratic indorsement of Charles A. Schieren, and had suffered ignominious defeat.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Escorted by two detectives of the Central Station, seven members of the Woman's Christian Temperance Congress which closed its session Saturday in the Ar Institute, went "slumming" this morning through the "levee" district.

Personals -- Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs and Mrs. Oelrichs's sister, Miss Fair, have returned to town from Newport. If Miss Fair remains in town all Winter it will be her first season here, as most of last Winter she remained in California. She is very wealthy, and her movements in society will be watched with constant interest.
There are five objections to Senator GORMAN'S compromise. Each one is grave. All together must be fatal.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- There has been very little change in the Princeton team during the past week as far as the individual men or the team is concerned. Hall, who plays right guard, and who has been counted upon to fill the position in all the important games, was injured early in the week, and has since been confined altogether to his crutches.

BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- The semi-official dailies continued until Friday morning to deny the reports of dissensions between Chancellor von Caprivi and Count Botho zu Eulenburg, Prussian Minister President. All references to a quarrel between the Premiers were pronounced as pure inventions. On Friday and Saturday, however, the inspired editors were dumb, although the old reports were being revived in various forms.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Possibilities of compromise and uncertainties of repeal at Washington had no effect on the local market. Both traders and the public believing that with growing ease in the money market and restored confidence in the financial situation in Chicago, all good interest-paying stocks and bonds listed on our Exchange are purchasable at present prices.

There was marked activity about the Democratic State Headquarters in West Twenty-fourth Street yesterday. Senator Edward Murphy's flying visit to this city on Sunday and Senator Hill's presence here yesterday gave the leaders a chance to agree upon the policy to be pursued during the remainder of the campaign, and it is evident that the hardest kind of work is to be done in behalf of Judge Maynard.

The reorganized Central Democratic Club, which carried on such a successful campaign in Brooklyn last year, met at Harriland Hall last evening, with Lewis Smith as presiding officer and J.F. McKinney as Secretary. The following resolutions were unanimously adopted:

Yesterdays announced auction sales of real estate were not carried out. Messrs. Richard V. Harnett Co.'s offerings were adjourned and a postponement had to be taken of most of the lots of the Vyse estate in the Twenty-third Ward, which were put up by Mr. James L. Wells.

The Bar Association, through its Judiciary Committee, has decided to make a strong protest against the election of Isaac Horton Maynard to the Court of Appeals. The Judiciary Committee met yesterday afternoon at the office of the President of the Bar Association, Wheeler H. Peckham, at 80 Broadway, and there outlined its plans.
