The New-York Times has received the following appeal from the Charity Organization Society: "The society appeals for a family whose case has been carefully investigated. The head of the family is a paralyzed man, who has been for three years incapable of self-support. The bread-winner has been his wife, but she has broken down and is now unable to work.

DEXTER, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- William and George Winnegar, two elderly residents of Dexter, who left their homes with a complete outfit for camping for their annual season of trapping in Perch Lake and River on Saturday, Oct. 14, were found dead last Friday in decidedly mysterious circumstances.

If Mr. BARING-GOULD were to turn his attention to current American politics, he would be able to tell a very interesting story of the development of the compromise myth. It has several of the chief characteristics which he is fond of tracing. First, there is the general observation of compromise as the result of violent differences of opinion as to action which must be taken.

It was a reopening performance and an evening of renewed triumph at Tony Pastor's. The impressario won new laurels in new songs, which he only knows how to make impressive. Eunice Vance had delightful gowns, and sang amusing ballads of England. Frank Bush unfolded his diversified collections of dialectic dialogues and caricatures of manners.

The high fire-insurance rates which prevail in Brooklyn are striking object lessons to the property owners of the maladministration of the City Government under Mayor Boody. These rates are now higher in Brooklyn than in any city in the United States. This fact is entirely owing to the inefficient Fire Department, which Mayor Boody has allowed to remain in practically the same condition as it was when he went into office.

There should be a rigorous investigation of all charges of fraudulent registration, colonizing, or other rascally efforts at violating the election laws in this city or Brooklyn, no matter whom they may be intended to benefit. Our laws regarding registration and elections have been carefully framed to secure to every citizen entitled to vote the privilege of doing so unmolested and the assurance that his vote will be honestly counted and returned.

The labor organizations of this city have been talking in their conferences and committees about making strenuous efforts to secure direct representation in the Constitutional Convention. They have not obtained any satisfactory "recognition" at the hands of either political party. The assurances given last Winter that the minorities could get representation upon, the regular tickets have come to nothing.
The Methodist Preachers' Association wants to have an investigation of John Y. McKane's Sunday-school Superintendency, as it stands in the shadow of his building in which prize fights have been held.

The law's hand fell heavily last night upon the wreckers of the Madison Square Bank. The result was the actual arrest of President Joseph F. Blaut, Cashier Lewis Thompson, and Director Ronald T. McDonald, and the constructive arrest of Directors Frederick Uhlman, A.S. Kalischer, Simon Ottenberg, Andrew Soulard, and Charles E. Selover.

NYACK, Oct. 23 -- The strife for County Judge constitutes the most interesting phase of politics in Rockland County at present There are four candidates for that position. Abram A. Demarest, an ex-County Clerk, received the regular Democratic nomination; ex-Assemblyman Arthur B. Tompkins is the Republican candidate, and the nominee of the Prohibition Party is Alonzo Wheeler, who was District Attorney of the county for six years.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 23. -- Lawrence Hanley, the tragedian, who was married at the Terre Haute House last night to his leading lady, Edith Lemmert, the Rev. F. S. Dunham, an Episcopal clergyman from Albion, N.Y., officiating, figured in a sensational scene three or four hours after the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- There was an attack on Harveyized armor at the naval ordnance proving ground at Indian Head Saturday, and a new projectile was tested as a rival of the Carpenter and Holtzer shell. The plate fired at by the new projectile was of 7-inch nickel-steel plate, and the shell was of sterling steel of 8-inch calibre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- In reply to a complaint of the Chinese Minister in Washington, Yang Yu, the State Department has made representations which indicate that the United States Government will not accept Consular certificates as conclusive evidence that the Chinese subjects presenting them are merchants or tourists, and therefore entitled to admission to this country.

This startling object lesson was presented last night by Edward M. Shepard to a Schieren mass meeting of the Citizens' Union of Brooklyn. He had selected these two pieces of property, Mr. Shepard said, because they happened to be under his professional charge. He had the tax receipts in his pocket, and offered to show them to any man, friend or foe of the "ring," who doubted the accuracy of his statement.

Superintendent Byrnes, when asked by a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday about the reports of illegal registration on the east side, particularly in the Third Assembly District, published in a morning paper, said:

The saleswomen in Lichtenstein's millinery store in Grand Street, the employee of the Morton House, the pupils ot St. Mark's Parish Day School, the inmates and employes at the Hart's Island Insane Asylum, and the clerks in the Chemical National Bank were vaccinated yesterday by the vaccinators of the Health Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Unconditional and immediate repeal again seems to be the inevitable outcome of the prolonged contest in the Senate. There should never have been any other prospect, even for a moment, and the Administration has never conceded that any other would be satisfactory or wholesome.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 23 -- Finding that the Minnesota gambling law is defective, the merchants of St. Paul have determined to use their powerful influence to secure the closing of the pool rooms. The members of the Jobbers' Union have resolved that they will not hereafter employ any person found frequenting pool or gambling rooms.

Controller Theodore W. Myers will not accept the independent renomination tendered him at the mass meeting held in Cooper Institute last Friday night. His declination was foreshadowed in The New-York Times last Sunday. Yesterday forenoon Gen. Wager Swayne, who was Chairman of the mass meeting, R. Fulton Cutting, and Edmond Kelly of the City Club made public the following dispatch:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- John P. Brooks, who was for sixteen years chief of the Eastern Division of the United States Secret Service, died at his home, 247 Walnut Street, at 5:30 o'clock this morning. He was stricken with apoplexy Sunday, and was found unconscious. Dr. George Brooks of Washington, D.C., his nephew, was telegraphed for, and arrived in the evening, but nothing could be done for Mr. Brooks, who never recovered consciousness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Public Printing bill, a resolution distributing $237,000, now hold by the receiver of the Mormon Church, for charitable purposes, and a bill appropriating $175,000 to construct a revenue muter for service on the great lakes were passed by the House to-day.

There was an unusual amount of reticence at Police Headquarters last night over the arrest of the Madison Square Bank officials. The only scrap of information came from Superintendent Byrnes, as he and Inspector McLaughlin left for their homes shortly after 10 o'clock. It was an admission that Thompson and McDonald had been arrested.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 23 -- The proposed investigation of lobby expenses in the Legislature last June by means of which the East Hartford Bridge was transferred to the State was defeated in a big town meeting here this afternoon, by a vote of two to one.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The application of Tracy Bronson of The New-York Times to make permanent an injunction forbidding the Monmouth Park Racing Association to exclude him from its track was before Vice Chancellor Pitney to-day on argument. Thomas N. McCarter, for Mr. Bronson, claimed that the track is a public place, open to every one, and therefore the association could not exclude any one from the track.

There is, it may fairly be said, only one issue before the people of the State of New-York at the coming election, and that is the issue raised by the nomination, of MAYNARD. Nobody really doubts, and nobody in private affects to doubt, the election of the other candidates on the Democratic ticket. In truth, the Republican ticket is in itself a surrender.
Gen. Thomas Leonidas Crittenden died at his home at Annandale, S.I., yesterday afternoon.

Superintendent Brady of the Building Department approved, during the past week, plans for the construction of forty-two new buildings, at a cost of $270,000, and received applications for alterations to thirty-eight structures, which will entail a cost of $68,000.

Charles L. Fair, the son of ex-Senator Fair of California, whose name has recently gured in newspaper stories in a sensational way, because of his marriage to Caroline E. Smith, formerly of Jersey City, and known as Maud Nelson, is registered at the Hotel Bartholdi, with his wife. Last night he said there was no occasion for sensational stories about his marriage.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Saturday was the first registration day here. The registration of the seven districts of Peekskill showed a gain of 56 over the first day last Fall, the total being 2,690 for the day.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- The feature in the local market was the strength of the entire list. Prices opened weak, but the activity and the strength of the New-York market, which soon followed opening prices, caused our stocks to advance, and they closed at the highest prices of the day. The feeling here is that unconditional repeal will pass.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Mr. Sheehan congratulated himself after he heard of the light registration in the upper wards on the first two days of registration. He thought that the vote in this, the Republican, district was going to be light, and that the home-rule movement, which is confined to the residence portion of the town, would also fail of accomplishing what it has set out to accomplish, namely, the overthrow of the machine.

Although the friends of the firm of George Meyer Co., carriage manufacturers at 316, 318, and 320 Western Boulevard, were surprised when they learned that the firm had made an assignment, they were even more astonished when they heard yesterday afternoon that George Meyer, one of the firm, had disappeared.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The next war ship to be launched is the Oregon at the Union Iron Works at San Francisco. Members of the Congressional naval committees have been invited, and at one time Secretary Herbert thought of taking a transcontinental trip, reaching Ban Francisco by the date of the launching. Three young women of the Pacific coast will perform the ceremonies of the launching.
About the District Attorney's office there was an air of mystery yesterday morning immediately following the arrival of the officials.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 23 -- The publication of a report that notes drawn by Matthew S. Tully, Treasurer of Richmond County, had been protested; that there were rumors of a defalcation in that office, and that the Staten Island banks had refused a loan of $20,000 to the County Treasurer, in anticipation of taxes, created considerable excitement in the county today.

On every hand yesterday the people of Brooklyn were discussing the disreputable means resorted to by the Democratic "machine," in trying to stampede the meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club, so as to prevent the members indorsing the nomination of Charles A. Schieren for Mayor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Wheat opened firm to-day, with occasional slight reactions. The opening was weaker and 1/4 @ 3/9 c lower than the closing figures of Saturday, but the market developed strength and prices were advanced 1 1/4 c above opening figures, then eased off a trifle, but held steady, and the close was about 1/2 @ 5/8 c higher than that of Saturday.

The Panama Star and Herald of Oct. 12 published in its Spanish columns a letter addressed to the editor of The New-York Herald, by Pablo Arosemena, who the Panama correspondent of The New-York Herald intimated had extorted a fee of $5,000 in gold from Mr. Weeks for advising him what course to take to avoid capture and extradition to the United States.

There are contemplated in Kings County outrages upon the ballot box which cannot be too seriously impressed upon its voters. There is no sensational intention in making plain the crimes which a desperate oligarchy intends to commit unless it shall be vigorously prevented. It is not the purpose of this article to awaken a mere vague feeling of uneasiness and alarm.

The Brooklyn ring Democracy opened its campaign at the Academy of Music last night. As Senator David B. Hill was the great attraction, the building was crowded. It was the same kind of crowd that always listens to Senator Hill when he is in Brooklyn. He was received with great enthusiasm.

Miss Bettina Gerard, the actress, a daughter of Gen. Ordway of Washington, and once the wife of the rich Mr. Padelford of Baltimore, has had another matrimonial experience which is terminating as unhappily as her preceding ones. This one has been brief, and the fact that she was married again was not known until proceedings for divorce were begun.
In a stock company with a particularly easy-going manager Mr. J.K. Emmet might, just possibly, be regarded as competent to appear at a door and announce that "Madame is served."

The weekly meeting of the Baptist pastors of this city at the Twenty-third Street Church yesterday was not largely attended, but the pastors took a lively interest in the brief discussion that followed the reading of a paper by the Rev. Dr. Morse on the subject. "Christianity and Science." The lecturer argued that inasmuch as both Christianity and science were truths, there should not be any antagonism between them.
William K. Vanderbilt and his friends are now in a position to dictate the future policy of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- These are dull days at the Erie County Penitentiary. Instead of receiving from twenty five to sixty short-term prisoners from the morning Justices, they are now getting but very few. Saturday night the arrests averaged seventy-five, and the number of men sent to the penitentiary for the last ten years on Sunday morning will average sixty.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2 @ 2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

Slosson, Schaefer, and Ives will begin their three cornered billiard match in Madison Square Garden Concert Hall on Dec. 4. Yesterday Slosson received a telegram from Chicago stating that the billiard manufacturers had refused to contribute to the purse, and suggesting that the players work in dependently. This suits Slosson, and he has already made arrangements for engaging the hall.

If one says to another, "Did you see the little darkys at the Academy of Music last night?" or, mayhap, "There is funny love making in 'Old Kentucky' " -- if these things be said, it will be altogether natural. Success comes to plays in that way, and such remarks and others of like kind may justly be made about "In Old Kentucky," which began an engagement at the Academy last night.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Oct. 23 -- P.M. The Street lost its head to-day on a report that the Jersey Central interest had purchased control of Lackawanna. The conclusion was reached that, the effort to force a coal combination having failed through agreements between the companies, the same end was to be secured byactual ownership of the properties concerned.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- The present week marks the close of the great series of world's congresses of which Chicago has been the scene during the Columbian season, and on Saturday next the volume will be closed with a final gathering at which the work of the Summer will be reviewed and appropriate statistics presented.

Congressman Ashbel P. Fitch's canvass for the office of Controller is booming along at a rate that indicates that he will poll an unusually large vote. His mail is filled with letters of congratulation and assurances of valuable support. Collector Kilbreth has written to him:

During the pelting rainstorm early yesterday morning the firemen in the lower part of the city were called out of their beds three times to answer false alarms of fire. Two of the alarms were sent from the same box, at New Chambers and William Streets, near the quarters of Engine Company No. 12. The third alarm was sounded from the box at Market and Monroe Streets.

Richard Mansfield's portrayal of Shylock, seen for the first time at Hermann's Theatre last evening, is a sound and coherent piece of acting, perfectly clear in conception, forcible and eloquent in execution, splendidly picturesque, and almost free from eccentricity of speech and action. The picture of the Jew Mansfield makes could not be surpassed.

Those of our citizens who are interested in boating on the Harlem River are making a vigorous protest against the plan for a driveway along its western bank that shall exclude pedestrians from the river side. They constitute a class much larger in number and as much entitled to consideration as those who own fast horses and desire a public roadway upon which they can speed them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Gloom, and palpable gloom, seized upon the Senate Chamber at 10 o'clock this morning when Vice President Stevenson, looking more than ever like a Methodist preacher, started the Senate on another round of the long legislative day of Oct. 17 . The few Senators who were punctual, despite the inclement weather, brought no sunshine with them.
Everything was joyful in the down-town markets yesterday after the news came from Washington that the silver men in the Senate had surrendered.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 24 -- That the spoilsmen at the "machine," which now controls nearly every branch of the Government on Staten Island, would resort to any means to perpetuate their power was anticipated by the leaders of the organization of Richmond County Democrats recently formed to secure reform in local government.
The second day's sale of the library of the late George Frederick Parsons was held in the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 739 and 741 Broadway, yesterday afternoon.

John Adler, twenty-eight years old. who refused to give his address, created an unusual disturbance in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. He was arraigned by Policeman McCue for stealing a case of corsets from a truck in front of 359 Broadway. While the policeman was making the complaint Adler became abusive and dealt him several blows in the face.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Officials of the Reading and Lehigh Valley Railroads have nothing to say to-day about the new coal deal, except that such a combination between the prominent New-York interests must necessarily benefit the coal trade. It is the general belief that both the Reading and Lehigh Valley will operate harmoniously with the new combination, if they do not have even closer relations.

The record of Monday's town meeting in Hartford adds another chapter to the history of the Hartford bridge scandal. It will be recalled that the first Selectmen of five towns paid $35,000 to facilitate the passage by the Legislature of a bill transferring from those towns to the State the burden of maintaining the old wagon bridge across the Connecticut River at Hartford.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 24 -- This was the one hundred and fourth birthday of "Aunty Baldy," who is supposed to be the oldest woman in the State. She had many callers at the old ladies' home of which she is an inmate. She was born Oct. 24, 1789, at Saratoga, N.Y. Her maiden name was Ann Sixbury.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 24 -- The mass meeting held at the Congregational Tabernacle, under the auspices of the Moral Reform League, this evening was the largest political gathering ever assembled in this city. The audience numbered fully 2,000 persons. The meeting was called to order by the Rev. J.W. Hathaway, with a brief plea for the overthrow of political corruption.
A lot or armor for the new United States armored cruiser Maine, in all 400 tons, is now lying at the shops of the Bethlehem Iron Works, Bethlehem, Penn., awaiting shipment.
The report that the Hotchkiss Ordnance Company is about to ship a large supply of rapid-fire guns and ammunition to Brazil by way of New-York is denied in well-posted circles.

Another large audience assembled in Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon at the second of M. Vladimir de Pachmann's piano recitals. It might be an exaggeration to say that all of those present went to hear the player, for doubtless many went only to see him. And, truly, he is one of the sights of the town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Dr. Boynton, the eccentric American, who was arrested in the harbor of Rio Janeiro last month, while navigating a tugboat floating the British flag, and presumably bent on blowing up the insurgent Brazilian fleet with a torpedo which he had on board, is to be released from confinement on the United States cruiser Charleston, by direction of Secretary Herbert, and brought back to this country.

This will be a bad year in New-York for "floaters," "colonizers," "blocks of five," and "repeaters." Superintendent Byrnes will see to it that all such marauders on the franchise are hunted up and reported to the proper authorities, and that on election day they are confronted at the polls with warrants for their arrest, should they have the audacity to add an attempt to vote to fraudulent registration.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 24 -- The races at Pimlico to-day were a great success. The day, which looked doubtful in the morning, turned oat fair, and in the afternoon was all that could be asked for. A more distinguished attendance has not been seen at Pimlico for many a long day. It was distinctively a social event. The infield was crowded with fashionable equipages.

Thirteen sailormen, who had spent the better part of a week astriue the weather rail of a half-foundered wreck, were yesterday brought into this port by the Italian bark Angeli. The men formed the crew of the Norwegian bark Comorin, which was journeying from Hamburg for Bermuda, when the vicissitudes of the sea made a change in the matter of destination.

MONTREAL, Oct. 24 -- One of the first measures that will be submitted to Parliament by the Dominion Government at the coming session will be a bill to ratify the treaty negotiated last Winter by the Marquis of Dufferin and Sir Charles Tupper, on behalf of Canada, with the Government of the French Republic, which treaty was practically repudiated and condemned by the Dominion Ministers last session.

The news of the prospective change in the control of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, in consequence of large acquisitions of the stock by W.K. Vanderbilt and his friends, is discussed with much interest by railroad men. On every hand the opinion is expressed that the trunk-line situation will be greatly improved by bringing Lackawanna under the influence of the conservative Vanderbilt element.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 24 -- James A. Bradley of Asbury Park, the Republican, Citizens' League, and Prohibition nominee for State Senator, addressed the colored voters of Red Bank to-night. The meeting was held in the Opera House. As the posters and newspaper advertisements announced it was for colored voters only.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 24 -- A surprise was in store for the Union County Grand Jury when it came into court to-day, and asked to be discharged for the term. Eighteen new indictments, making fifty-five in all, were presented, and a presentment against the Township Committee of Linden Township as follows:

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The Judges of Award have announced two awards and two diplomas to the Stewart Hartshorn Company, successors to Stewart Hartshorn, who originated and perfected the celebrated selfacting shade roller bearing his name. The company's exhibit is in the Manufactures Building, and is in the form of an Egyptian temple, composed entirely of Hartshorn shade rollers.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 24 -- The first dispute has arisen over the identity of bodies of victims of last week's railroad accident. It develops that the body which S.D. Wood of Cato, N.Y., identified as that of his wife is the same that Dr. Sutherland of Edwardsburg, Mich., yesterday identified as that of his sister, Mrs. Aldrich.
Lawyer Untermyer, who represents the receivers, made the following statement to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday:

All the officers of the Madison Square Bank accused of being concerned in the wrecking of that institution have been arrested and, with one exception, preliminary steps have been taken to bring their cases under the review of a criminal court. Here is a list of the officials who are to make an accounting:

The Kings County Visiting Committee, representing the State Charities Aid Association, has prepared statistics which reveal in a startling manner the mismanagement of the Kings County Hospital for the Insane at Flatbush. These statistics were read before the committee by Mrs. Dora Miller.

Sir Roderick W. Cameron has sold his four-story brownstone residence at the northeast corner of Firth Avenue and Sixty-second Street to Addison Cammack. The plot measures 25 by 108 feet. On April 1. 1893, the property was conveyed by William Belden to Margaret E.S. Cameron for a nominal consideration, subject to a mortgage of $163,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The repeal of the tax of 10 per cent. on Clearing House certificates, and the repeal of the statute prohibiting national banks from lending money on real estate, was the subject presented to the House Banking and Currency Committee to-day.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- The local market opened strong, with no special features. The activity in the industrials and the coal stocks caused a very irregular and erratic market. In the afternoon prices became buoyant and transactions were large. At the close there was a slight concession, but prices closed strong.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 24 -- The Supreme Court this morning handed down a decision on the woman suffrage law passed by the last Legislature permitting women to vote at municipal elections. The court declares that the law is utterly unconstitutional and void.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- P.M. The news of the surrender of the silver men at Washington reached Wall Street ahout 2 o'clock, and at once overshadowed everything else. The early trading, particularly in Reading and sugar, had been active and strong, but when the important change in the situation was announced, the market broadened perceptibly and became quite buoyant.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24 -- The women of Western New-York are taking advantage of their privilege to vote for School Commissioner, and are registering in great numbers. This is especially true in Genesee, Erie, Cattaraugus, and Chautauqua Counties.

George C. Coffin, the Democratic candidate for Assembly in the Twenty-third District of this city, is receiving many assurances of support from citizens, irrespective of party affiliations. An active worker in his behalf is William B. Ellison, the present Assemblyman of the district.

From The Portland (Me.) Argus. Sometimes it pays to bear a resemblance to a person. I know of one case, at least, where it did. A man went into a restaurant with 40 cents in his pocket. He was looking over the bill of fare, anticipating a frugal meal, when a waiter put before him a delicate dish, the cost of which alone was more than his money could pay for.

The only comforting thing that Mayor Boody heard yesterday came from the Gold Street branch of the Ancient Order of Hibernians. A committee representing that order called on Mayor Boody, assured him of their honest support during the campaign, and told him that their organization had indorsed his nomination.

Great preparations are being made by the Tammany Hall Committee on Ratification for the ratification meeting to be held to-morrow night in and around the Fourteenth Street Wigwam. The committee met yesterday afternoon and completed the arrangements.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24 -- It is not alone in Buffalo that the Sheehan men are hustling to outdo each other in rascality. An attempt was made at Tonawanda last Saturday, which, if not detected, would have resulted in a serious impairment of Republican registration. In the Second District of the First Ward of Tonawanda the Inspectors are as follows: August Schwartz, Edward Holloway, Democrats; Albert Kropp, Republican.
Mrs. Eva Slaven Depierris has begun a suit aginst her stepmother, Ellen A. Slaven, and the latter's husband, Henry B. Slaven, that threatens sensational developments.

Mrs. Sara K. Bourne of this city was married Monday noon in the Hotel Savoy to William J. Kirkpatrick, the well-known composer of church music. Mr. Kirkpatrick's home is at 2,009 North Fifteenth Street, Philadelphia. The wedding ceremony was performed in the parlors of the hotel by the Rev. Dr. Palmer, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church of this city.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2 @ 2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

ELGIN, Ill., Oct. 24 -- The forty-seventh annual meeting of the American Missionary Association began this evening in the First Congregational Church. There is a large attendance, and missionaries and prominent divines from all parts of the United States are present. An address of welcome by the Rev. J.H. Seldon of Elgin was responded to by President Merrill E. Gates of Amherst College and Chairman of the United States Board of Indian Commissioners.

A handsome national flag was given yesterday afternoon to the pupils of the female department of Grammar School No. 93, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-third Street, by James Monroe Post, No. 607, G.A.R. The presentation and acceptance of the gift were made the occasion of special exercises of a patriotic order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Secretary Herbert has appointed a board consisting of Rear Admiral Belknap, Commodore John G. Walker, Capt. Edmund O. Matthews, Chief Engineer Edward Farmer, Commander Philip H. Cooper, Commander Francis A. Cook, Lieut. Commander Joseph N. Hemphill, and Naval Constructor Joseph Feaster, with Lieut. L.L. Reamey as recorder, to make examination and witness and report on the official acceptance trial of the new cruiser Columbia and her machinery.

The chapel of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Fifth Street, was the scene of a gay assemblage last evening. The occasion, was a reception which the members of the church tendered their pastor, the Rev. Joan Balcom Shaw, and his wife on their return from their wedding trip abroad.

The Columbian year in the United States is the year of the architects. Never before has this section of professional artists received so much notice in the press, and never so much favorable notice. The World's Fair, as an exhibit before all things of architecture, is partly the reason for this prominence of architecture, but deeper reasons lie back of the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- "The jig is up." This comprehensive declaration by Senator Dubois at 1 o'clock this afternoon was a condensed revision of the reports flying through the Capitol that the silver men had surrendered unconditionally. While the announcement had been expected, it nevertheless created intense excitement.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 24 -- The Business Men's Association of this city, organized to advocate annexation to New-York, and to support all candidates in favor of the movement, has issued a call to the business men to meet Thursday. The call sets forth the following reasons for annexation:

The country owes a debt of profound gratitude to Mr. CLEVELAND and to a few -- a very few -- Democratic Senators who have stood firmly by him for the only rational, the only patriotic and practical, solution of the financial question, the unconditional repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman law.

A farcical meeting of the Committee on Lamps and Gas of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was held last evening in the City Hall. The ostensible purpose of the meeting was to take action on an application of the State Electric Light and Power Company for a franchise.

Quiet reigned in the Republican Headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel early last night, Executive Chairman Hackett was indulging in a dream of large pluralities for his State ticket and or a State Senate with a snug and thrifty Republican majority. Chairman Brookfield of the Republican State Committee puffed leisurely away with his cigar and wondered how it would all come out, anyway.

ADDISON, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- C.J. Starkweather, who keeps a repair shop here, became converted a few evenings ago at a Salvation Army meeting and publicly confessed to being a poker player and the keeper of a poker room.

It is now plain to the Brooklyn "machine" that neither Judge Maynard nor its local ticket can be elected without recourse to the boldest and most monstrous frauds. In Brooklyn and in Coney Island the mask of moderation will be dropped and a gigantic exposure hazarded by the ring.

Senator Justin S. Morrill of Vermont passed through town yesterday on his way to Washington. He was seen in the lobby of the Fifth Avenue Hotel by a reporter for The New-York Times. He believes the country is fired of the display of oratory in the United States Senate, and that it is full time that some definite action was taken.

The disclosures made by the receivers of the Madison Square Bank seem to indicate that the most reckless and unscrupulous methods may be pursued by the officers and Directors of a bank under our State system without exposure until the institution has been plunged into bankruptcy. It raises the question whether any substantial safeguard is afforded by the supervision of the State Banking Department.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 24 -- Sir Henry Loch, Governor of the Cape of Good Hope, has sent a telegraphic message to the Hon. Cecil Rhodes, the Prime Minister and Chairman of the British South Africa Company, who is now at Fort Salisbury, stating that sole control of the operations against the Matabeles has been placed in his hands by the home Government.

One of the first questions Capt. William Taylor, who commands the clipper ship Reaper, asked of the Sandy Hook pilot, who showed his vessel the way in, was if the bark Western Belle had arrived. The pilot did not know it, but $2,000 depended upon his answer. He said she had not, and the skipper of the Taylor was glad.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- A programme of exercises for the last official day of the World's Exposition was reported to the National Commission to-day by the Committee on Ceremonies. It recommended that the exercises should be held in Festival Hall, beginning at 1 P.M. Oct. 30, and timed to conclude at sunset, when the national flags will be lowered throughout the grounds.

EFFINGHAM, Ill., Oct. 24 -- An east-bound passenger train on the Indiana and Illinois Southern Road was derailed one mile east of this city at 6 A.M. to-day, and thirteen passengers were injured. The rear coach left the track and rolled down an embankment. The rest or the train staid on the track. Benjamin Jewell, a resident of this county, received fatal Injuries, while the others were badly hurt.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- The contest over the will of Dr. Samuel Parkman Tuckerman has been settled. Dr. Tuckerman died at Newport in June, 1890, leaving a property valued at over $50,000 and a daughter. The estate was not given to the daughter, but Frederick Tuckerman of Amherst was made the principal legatee, Miss Tuckerman getting simply a memento.

Senator HILL has the name of being a practical politician, and, like the Living Skeleton, he is "proud of the title." But his right to it will be disputed by those who consider that part of his speech in Brooklyn that was devoted to the candidacy, or the "case," of Judge MAYNARD. It is a matter of course that he should be very much in favor of Judge MAYNARD.

VIENNA, Oct. 24 -- The discussion of the Electoral Reform bill was continued to-day in the lower house of the Reichsrath. Herr Kronawetter, Democrat, declared that he was strongly in favor of universal suffrage, and thought the bill introduced by Count Taaffe did not go as far as it might, yet it was a step in the right direction, and he would support it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Unconditional and immediate repeal will win.

President William R. Harper of the University of Chicago arrived in town yesterday, and registered at the Murray Hill Hotel. He leaves for home to-day. "I came to New-York to attend the tenth annual meeting of the Institute of Sacred Literature, of which I am the Principal," said Dr. Harper to a reporter for The New-York Times.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- A certain senior in Harvard University is wondering just now if $300 is not a pretty good fine to pay for a kiss. He has paid this $300 for imprinting a kiss on the lips of a Cambridge housemaid.

The report of the second game of the chess match between Dr. Sigismuad Tarrasch of Nuremberg and M. Tschigorin of St. Petersburg, which was played on Oct. 10 at St. Petersburg, arrived yesterday. It will be seen from the score of the game that the Kussian introduced a novel move in the French defense by Q -- K2. The fall score of the game:

On Monday evening Mayor BOODY presented to the citizens of Brooklyn the reasons why they ought to re-elect him. These are far from conclusive. He almost entirely neglected to notice the many and strong reasons why it would be much better to elect Mr. SCHIEREN, which, nevertheless, seem to us unanswerable.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Charles E. Solover, until last July assistant cashier and a Director of the Madison Square Bank of New-York City, was arrested here at 10 o'clock last night on a warrant issued by Judge Martine of New-York for complicity in the wrecking of that institution.

Mr. Charles Frohman has brought back to this town, where they belong, the members of his excellent Empire Theatre company, and they had a warm welcome last evening. To be sure, four of them, Miss Allen, Mr. Scott, Mr. Crompton, and Mr. Miller, have been here since September, acting in "Liberty Hall," but that was irregular and "preliminary."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- The market has been buoyant all day. Lehigh Valley, which closed last night at 34, advanced this morning to 36 1/4, and closed at 35 1/2. There is very little stock on the market, and any orders to buy are only filled at higher prices. Reading was bought largely by New-York, and there was some realizing by parties who had been purchasers at lower prices.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 21 -- After an absence of forty-one years George G. Gasking returned here recently to find that the wife he had left two score and a year ago had married another, believing him to be dead; had become the mother of ten children, and that his daughter, whom he left a tiny babe, is now a grandmother.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 24 -- Francis H. Weeks, the embezzler, for whose extradition the Costa Rican Government has issued a decree, applied to-day for a writ of habess corpus. He desires to have the action of the Government reviewed by the court to which his application has been made.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The football team of the Orange Athletic Club has done some clover playing already this year, and the men are working hard to assure themselves of a position in the championship games with the New-York Athletic Club and Crescent teams. The men practice on the Oval by electric light three nights a week, under the coaching of "Ham" Wallis, Jr., the Yale tackle.

Visitors to Central Park yesterday were endangered by some reckless blasting operations. The Swift Construction Company is laying pipes in the transverse road at Sixty-fifth Street for the Brooklyn Gas Light Company. Yesterday afternoon heavy charges were exploded and pieces of rock of various sizes were scattered over the walks and lawns near by.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 24 -- It was reported to-day that Detective Philip Reilly of New-York, who was sent to Costa Rica to bring back Francis H. Weeks, had arrived in this city. A reporter called at the hotel this evening and found that Philip C. Reilly was registered from Boca del Toro, Costa Rica, and assigned to Room 410.

Real estate men were amused yesterday at the publication of an alleged sale of the Electrical Exchange Building, on Washington Street, for $550,000 to the Beers estate. The lots on which the building stands were purchased at different times by John Pettit, until he acquired a frontage of 118 feet on Washington Street, 77.2 on Liberty, and 69 feet on Cedar.

Lord Mayor Shanks of Dublin, the Lady Mayoress, and George Barrington, merchant, of Dublin, are staying at the Holland House. More than a month ago the Lord Mayor and his jovial friend, Mr. Barrington, arrived in this country, prepared to see the World's Fair and have a good time.
To the new United States armored cruiser New-York was presented yesterday a handsome silver service, the gift of a number of New-York citizens.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- P.M. Now that the unconditional repeal of the Srman silver law is assured, the effect in Stock Exchange circles is pronounced. The trading to-day was even more active than yesterday; in fact, the transactions were of larger volume than on any day since the July panic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Nothing stops the way to the passing of the repeal bill but speech. Teller, who has spoken interminably, so that wonder is excited at the suggestion that he has still a few more remarks to make, is to speak some farewell words. Stewart wishes to renew his compliments to "the hireling press" and the ''gold power," and Mr. Squire thinks he must talk about an amendment he has offered.

It Sad been intended by Dr. Doty, Chief of the Division of Contagious Diseases, to have the work of vaccinating the members of the police force begin during this week, but at the request of Superintendent Byrnes it has been postponed until after the election. The Superintendent concluded that it would be unwise to have so many policemen going about with sore arms when much extra duty devolves upon the force owing to election.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Miss Marie Alice Whitney, youngest daughter of Charles Stewart Whitney at Port Chester, N.Y., was married to-night to William Scofield Boswell, son of Honry C. Boswell, a wealthy resident of Greenwich, Conn. The Whitney home, at 259 Westchester Avenue, was decorated with choice flowers and palms.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- The largest of any of the recent gifts to Harvard is that of Dr. Harry Willard Williams, who has given $25,000 as a special fund toward the maintainance of a Professorship in Ophthalmology in the Medical School. In 1891 Dr. Williams resigned this professorship, which he had held for twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency today heard Representative Brawley of South Carolina in support of his bill to suspend the operation of laws imposing a tax of 10 per cent, on notes issued by banks during the late period of stringency.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The most notable feature at the gala performance given last night at the opera in honor of the visiting Russians was the ballet, which is pronounced to have been the finest ever produced in France. Upon the conclusion of the performance the artists, attired in Russian costumes, passed before the curtain, and were received with frenzied plaudits by the spectators.

Has been used for over fifty years by millions of mothers for their children while teething, with perfect success. It soothes the child, softens the gums, allays all pain, cures wind colio and is the beat remedy for diarrhea. Sold by all druggists in every part of the world. Twenty-five cents a bottle.

Park Commissioner Dana will push his fight for the outer, or riverside, sidewalk on the proposed Harlem River Drive. Mr. Dana thinks it would be an outrage upon the public not to provide for this sidewalk. At yesterday's meeting of the Park Board Mr. Dana gave notice that at next Wednesday's meeting he would call up the following resolution for discussion:
WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct 25 -- Representative Coombs of New-York to-day offered the following resolution:

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Any settlement of the European Immigrant Commission question seems further off than ever. The delay of the Union Pacific in replying to the request of the committee of the Western Passenger Association for a conference on the subject is now accounted for by the fact that the Union Pacific has already made its contract with the New-York immigrants' agents for next year's business.

Before a throng of applauding independent Democrats of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, at Washington Hall, Broadway and Park Avenue, last night, Edward M. Shepard exposed in a most convincing manner the evasion and fallacy of Mayor Boody's defense to the showing up which Mr. Shepard made the other evening of Brooklyn's extraordinary and extortionate system of taxation.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 25 -- There was a bad wreck on the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad near Lawrence station, three and a half miles east of here late this afternoon, which resulted in the death of at least four men, perhaps more, and the serious injury of several others.

Nathan Strauss, local manager and buyer for the San Francisco firm of Levi Strauss Co., dry goods merchants, shot himself in the right temple in his office, 88 West Broadway, at 9:40 A.M. yesterday. Without recovering consciousness, he died at the Chambers Street Hospital at 12:12 P.M.

The information that is brought every hour to "Boss" McLaughlin's headquarters in Brooklyn is causing consternation to the members of the Brooklyn "ring." From every quarter of the city information comes to the "boss" that thousands of independent citizens are joining with the Republicans in the effort to defeat Mayor Boody.

The Municipal Consolidation Commission met yesterday morning at 214 Broadway to consider what further action should be taken toward consolidating New-York and Brooklyn. The members present were Andrew H. Green, J.S.T. Stranahan, Frederick W. Devoe. George J. Greenfield, Edward F. Linton, and Calvert Vaux.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25 -- It is stated on what appears to be good authority that Marcus Flood of East Otto, Chautauqua County, and his sister. Mrs. Margaret Hilliker of Glonwood, this county, have fallen heirs to $6,000,000 each of the fortune left by the late James G. Flood of California. James G. Flood was an uncle of Mrs. Hilliker and Marcus Flood.

Range-finding devices of the Fiske type are now in service aboard the United States cruisers San Francisco, Baltimore, Chicago, Newark, and Vesuvius. This device has been condemned by an official Russian Naval Board on the ground that its electrical connections are apt to fail in time of action, and, further, that the telescopes constituting a part of the system would be useless once a ship became enveloped in smoke.
Not until yesterday was it known outside the Clearing House banks that the collapse of the Madison Square Bank left the St. Nicholas Bank, its clearing agent, a creditor to the extent of $150,000.

The Pontiac Club held the first of a series of ratification meetings to indorse the Democratic State and local tickets in its new clubhouse, on Amsterdam Avenue, between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets, last night. The large hall of the clubhouse was filled to the doors by the enthusiastic auditors of the various speakers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- An exhaustive review of operations in the Bureau of Naval Ordnance during the year ended Oct. 1 is contained in the annual report of Capt. W.T. Sampson, chief of the bureau, to the Secretary of the Navy. He estimates that $7,145,801 will be required for ordnance work during the next fiscal year. In which is included $6,500,000 toward the armament of vessels already authorized by congress.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 25 -- Sir Henry Loch, Governor of Cape Colony, who yesterday informed the Hon. Cecil Rhodes, Prime Minister, and Chairman of the British South Africa Company, that he intended to assume control of the operations against the Matabeles, arrived at Mafeking to-day. He will at once inspect 250 imperial troops, who have been enrolled as Bechuanaland police, and who will, immediately the inspection is over, proceed to the front.

ELM PARK, S.I., Oct. 25 -- There is probably no class of public officials against whom so many and such scandalous stories have been told as that of the Coroners of Richmond County. The latest incident in which they figure in this way occurred last Monday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 25 -- In the United States Court late this afternoon, W.I. Shaw, ex-Deputy Collector, was found guilty on two counts of indictment charging him with assessing Government employes for campaign purposes. The jury was out only twenty minutes. Shaw was held in 52,000 bail, which was furnished.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- The third annual dinner of the Republican Club of Massachusetts was held in Music Hall this evening. The first appearance of ex-Speaker Reed in New-England during the campaign and the announcement that Congressman Dalzell of Pennsylvania was to speak and all the prominent State candidates were to be present drew the largest crowd ever assembled at a dinner of the club.

W.C. Van Horne, the President of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, has gone to England for the purpose, chiefly, of endeavoring to raise some money for the prosecution of his schemes by the sale of preferential stock. The report that his trip across the Atlantic was in the interest of a new fast steamship line is denied by his railroad associates.

The mass meeting to-night at Cooper Union, under the auspices of the Bar Association, to protest against Isaac H. Maynard as candidate for Judge of the Court of Appears, promises to be an enormous one. Wheeler H. Peckham, President of the Bar Association, will preside and make the opening address.

LYONS, Oct. 25 -- More than 200,000 visitors are in this city this morning, having come from all parts of the surrounding country to take part in the fetes attendant upon the visit of the Russian naval officers, who will stop here for fourteen hours, and then proceed to rejoin their ships at Toulon.

News of the wreck was received at Jersey City early in the evening at a time when the Pennsylvania station was crowded with people waiting for trains. Exaggerated reports flew about everywhere and grew more terrible as they traveled.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Oct. 25 -- Francis Henry Weeks has come before the people of West Superior in a new role. It was all along hoped that no more irregularities with reference to his conduct while President of the Land and River Improvement Company would come to light, but daily something is being raked up by the new management, which is indicative on Weeks's part of either incompetency or wilfull wrongdoing.

Under its new management The New-York Times is becoming a power in the land. It has not forgotten that it was the chief instrument in the overthrow of the Tweed gang of lawbreakers and embezzlers many years ago, and it is striving now to rival that good work in the overthrow of the gambling fraternity whether found in the Legislature, the Municipal Government, the poolroom, or the race track.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- This is the alternate rear when Gen. Casey submits estimates for river and harbor work, and his annual report, the vehicle of these recommendations, has been banded to Secretary Lamont. Of the district, the improvements in which are supervised by Col. G.L. Gillespie, the projects are situated in the vicinity of New-York City.

Adolph Kliesrath, ten years old, narrowly escaped death yesterday by falling from a newly-patented fire escape, which the inventor was exhibiting at Third Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. His mother, who keeps a cigar store at 1,101 Third Avenue, gave him permission to ride on the fire escape, which is a rope affair working through a frictional pulley.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- The traction stocks were again the feature of the local market, Philadelphia selling up 4 points, Metropolitan and People's Traction, which has been neglected lately, 3 points, to 16. The bonds of the latter sold up to 76. There appears to be a disposition to buy New-Jersey Traction bonds, but there are not many for sale.

CHRISTIANIA, Oct. 25 - The Dagbladedt of this city publishes a letter written to it by Bjoernstjerne Bjoernsen, the Norwegian novelist and poet, in which he says it is undeniable that Sweden continues arming on a large scale, and that it is therefore useless to deny that the country intends to side with the triple alliance in the event of war.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25 -- A story which shows the desperation of the Sheehan "machine" in the First Ward, where Lieut. Gov. Sheehan-s relative, John Sheehan, is the "machine" candidate for Alderman against Jack White, came out to-day.

While good feeling prevailed yesterday in the down-town markets and stocks continued buoyant, repeal measures moved a little slowly for grain and cotton, in which prices sagged a trifle. The banks reduced the small outstanding issue of Clearing House certificates, and sterling exchange touched a price at which gold would have started this way but for an advance in the Bank of England's rate of discount.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 25 -- The Eureka Collecting Company, familiarly known as the "Greencoats," has had its brief day in Louisville. Once more an innocent public has been imposed upon, and in proof thereof some $5,000 of worthless subscribed stock is held by business firms. Its managers, W.P. Cothalie, George Hastings, and X.R. Allen, all of Chicago, have disappeared, and so has the paid-up money of the outstanding stock.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- The local market was very strong and broad. The public is certainly buying stocks, and when London comes in as a pronounced buyer, prices will further advance. There was a good demand for all stocks. Prices opened strong and continued so. The loaning rates show that stocks are very plenty, and the short interest small.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 25 -- About 200 cyclists participated in the lantern parade of the Essex County Wheelmen to-night. The streets along the route were lined with spectators. The start was made at 8:30 o'clock from Lincoln Park, and the parade proceeded up Broad Street to Harvey Street, thence to Belleville Avenue, to Broad, to Warren, to High, to Market, to Broad Street, where the cyclists disbanded.
October has been a busy month for those who audit the debit sheets of marine under-writers. Especially has it been an exciting period for the mariners who sail upon the North Atlantic.

The new building of Grammar School No. 7, at Chrystie and Hester Streets, in the Tenth Ward, which was erected at a cost of $500,000, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon, the orchestral music being provided by the school's own band, under the leadership of Michael Brown of the class of '90.

The resolution submitted by Mr. DANA in the Park Board yesterday, about the water front of the new speedway, puts a serious responsibility upon Mr. DANA'S colleagues. People are willing enough to believe that their first action in the matter was merely the result of a natural desire to oblige the "trotting men," without due consideration of the public interests involved.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Not since New-Haven people started a systematic search for Capt. Kidd's treasure a couple of centuries ago has so much digging for hidden riches been instituted as to-day. Borneo Moskego, the alleged Zulu chief's son, who was arrested here while delivering a missionary sermon a month ago, has sent word from jail that he has a treasure buried in a lot near here, whose whereabouts he discloses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Southern coast defenses, the grievous condition of which has been so vigorously described by Inspector General Breckinridge, are the subject of some interesting reports to the War Department. They support all Gen. Breckinridge has said of their "disgraceful" state, and their sole service of reminding "us of the high estate from which we have fallen."

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Miss Juliet Niles, a niece of the late John M. Niles, at one time Postmaster General of the United States and afterward a Senator from Connecticut, and her friend, Miss Annie Ennis, who is visiting her, were mysteriously attacked by a burly negro early this morning. Miss Niles lives on the Windsor Road, one mile this side of Poquonock, in the town of Windsor.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Cornell saffered a defeat at the hands of the Tufts College football eleven today. There seems to be no excuse for the defeat. The playing on the part of the Cornell eleven was very poor. Time after time the Tufts half backs went through the Cornell line for large gains. Most frequently this happened between centre and right guard.

The suit of Mrs. Mary T. Upington against Archbishop Corrigan was tried yesterday before Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court, who reserved decision. The action was tried once before. Mrs. Upington is a grandniece of Mrs. Henry Davy. About thirty years ago Mrs. Davy deeded thirty-two lots on One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, near Boston Avenue, to Archbishop Hughes.

Commodore Oscar F. Stanton entered the navy at a time when boys were not sent to Annapolis. He began a cruising life immediately after entering service on Dec. 29, 1849. Being brought up in the old school under Captains accustomed as soon as clear of the United States to he pretty much a law unto themselves, some naval men thought last night they saw a possible explanation for the Commodore's action in Brazilian waters.

That Superintendent Byrnes is keeping such a close watch on the registration lists that there is little chance of a case of fraud passing unnnoticed is evidenced by the fact that twenty indictments were found yesterday by the Grand Jury against Bartholomew Buckley of 165 Mott Street, for aiding and abetting the false registration of as many men.

Two of the heavy-calibre rapid-fire guns entered for the United States international rapid-fire gun test have arrived at the Sandy Hook proving grounds. One gun is from the shops of Sir William Armstrong at Elswick, England, and the other from the Paris shops of the Hotchkiss Ordnance Company.

It is not surprising that the result of the Prussian elections, which are to take place next week, should be expected to be a defeat of the Liberals. The discouragement given to those Prussians who are anxious to see their country as much as possible freed from what HERBERT SPENCER calls "militarism" and advanced in the career of "industrialism" by the passage of the Army bill was very great.

The Secretary of the Interior sent to the Treasury Department a few days ago his estimates for the appropriations required by his department in the next fiscal year and we presume that Senator STEWART has noticed that the estimate for the General Land Office exceeds by about 40 per cent. the sum appropriated for the current year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The peremptory removal to-day of Commodore and Acting Rear Admiral Stanton, stationed at Rio Janerio, Brazil, from the command of the South Atlantic station, was one of the most startling surprises ever experienced in Washington official life, and for a time it has almost obscured the interest in the silver fight.

NEWPORT, E.I., Oct. 23 -- Off the torpedo station this afternoon a second shot in the series of comparative tests of the strength of the English and American manufactured torpedo-defense nets was fired under the direction of Commander George A. Converse. Thomas Midgeley of Beaver Falls. Penn., the inventor of the two Ameriean nets to be used, vrau present.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- The University of Pennsylvania eleven gave a dreadful exhibition against the State College to-day, and the quiet feeling of confidence in the result of the Princeton game Has pretty much departed. Not one word of praise can be spoken of the Pennsylvanias as a team, although Gilbert, Knipe, and Abbott played individually good football.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 20 -- A strange story of revenge and punishment comes from the St. Francis River bottoms, in Arkansas. It is a region inhabited only by a few scattered swampers, who live by hunting, fishing, and getting out staves for the English market. They are a law unto themselves, and a Sheriff's officer would have no more chance among them than he would have in the interior of Africa.

A small but fashionable wedding took place at 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the obautry of Grace Church. The bride was Miss Edith L. Draper, daughter of Mrs. John L. Draper of East Thirty-sixth Street, and the bridegroom was Francis Vaughan Clark, son of Charles Clark of St. Louis, a wealthy owner of mines in Montana.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A novelty to ordnance has been successfully tested at the naval ordnance proving grounds at Indian Head. Two grins have been mounted on a single carriage, capable of turning the weapons together with one mechanism. The carriage was built with a view to thorough experiment, and it was intimated that if the trial suggested a greater efficiency for guns so mounted the system might be adopted generally on board ship.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 25 -- Nelson Bradley, cashier of the Central Michigan Savings Bank, which last April went into the hands of a receiver, was arrested to-day charged with misreporting under oath the condition of the bank. Bradley reported overdrafts, notes, , at about $34,000 when they should have been placed at over $160,000.

Eugene Leroux and Jeanne Dolle, who were arrested in Williamsburg last April r smuggling jewelry valued at $13,000 from Paris, were placed on trial yesterday in the United States District Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Benedict and a jury. United States District Attorney Jesse Johnson and his assistant, John Oakey, appeared for the United States, and Maribeau L. Towns and Edward J. McCrossin conducted the defense.

Though there is still some sulky talking among the men whose attempt to override the majority in the Senate is now seen to be hopeless, it will not last long. The vote on unconditional repeal may not be taken this week, or even early next week. But it will be taken soon, and the certainty that it will is the main thing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- It is not often that an army officer gives the service administration such an overhauling as that in which Col. W.R. King of the Corps of Engineers indulges in a report which he has sent to Gen. Casey, Chief of Engineers in this city, of work at the Engineer School at Willet's Point, New-York Harbor.

The naturalization of voters in the Brooklyn Court House was carried on with great dispatch yesterday, and full-fledged, voters who were born in Naples, Calabria, Sicily, and Russian Poland were turned out as rapidly as nails drop from a nail-stamping machine, or as coins are turned out in the mint.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The local stock market opened active, with cable stocks again the leaders. Trading in second account (i. e., for delivery Nov. 30, without interest) begun to-day, with differences between first and second accounts narrowed down to 1 to 1 1/2 points. The advance in New-York stocks had no possible influence on the market, as the narrow range of opening and closing prices would indicate.

Defenders of MAYNARD depend upon muddling the public mind with confusing statements of alleged facts upon which, they put their own interpretation. The material facts in the case are few and simple, and in the main undisputed. If these are clearly kept in mind, every citizen can judge of their significance for himself.

David A. Boody, the "machine" nominee for Mayor, has a very important engagement that he intends to fill next Monday afternoon at 3 o'clock, and if he can keep it, nothing will be allowed to interfere with the engagement.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The second eleven and regular football team played a practice game on the plain to-day. Capt. Carson had his men in fairly grod shape, and Laurie Bliss was assisted in giving them points by Corbin, Yales former famous player and coach. The work done by the first team was not quite as satisfactory as it might he.

NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 25 -- A smart little man, with leather-tanned face, a ruddy spot in the centre of each cheek, with clear blue eyes, dark hair, and sprightly step, is wont to march like a youngster about the streets of Norwich daily, tapping the flags with a cane as heavy as a club. The old gentleman is somewhat stout and his back is bowed a trifle, but he does not appear to be sixty-years-old.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Another urgent appeal is made by the Relief Committee for additional subscriptions for the relief of the destitute of this city who were thrown out of work by the shutting down of the factories. The committee has already done a great deal of good work, and has spent about $200 a week providing food for those who have no money.

NEW BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 25 -- The movement on Staten Island for the overthrow of the corrupt political "ring" which not only dominates the government, but also strangles all enterprises that it does not control, is daily gaining strength.

There is a feeling of doubt in well-posted naval circles over the stability of the new United States gunboat Machias. The Machias reached, this port on Sunday last from Boston. She had a narrow escape from serious injury on the run down by reason of having grounded off Chatham, Mass.

Among the prominent clergymen of Brooklyn whose sense of honor and selfrespect have compelled them to take a stand against the machinations of the Brooklyn Democratic "machine" is the Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving, rector of Christ Church, which is in the centre of a wealthy parish at Clinton and Harrison Streets.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2 @ 3 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.
The New-York Times pays its respects to-day to the politicians of Gravesend, who appear, from the figures presented by The Times, to be industriously engaged at their old tricks.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Thomas Flynn, starter at the Gloucester race track, was renominated to-night for the Assembly by the Democrats of the Third District.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Oct. 25 -- P.T. McGratn, editor of The Herald, was violently assaulted last night by Robert Thorburn, son of Sir R. Thorburn, formerly Premier and late leader of the opposition in the Newfoundland Parliament. The cause of the assault was the publication of writings against Thorburn's father in The Herald.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 25 -- Bishop Paret, the head of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this diocese, which includes Washington, has written Mayor Lutrobe the story of his narrow escape from death by an electric car. The Bishop says:

LONG ISLAND CITY, Oct. 25 -- After two months' work the Grand Jury of Queens County to-night concluded its investigation of the collision at Berlin, on the Long Island Railroad, on Aug. 26, between Manhattan Beach and Rockaway Beach trains, by which sixteen persons lost their lives and fifty were injured.

The cable reports from Montevideo that the Brazilian cruisers Republica and Tiradentes are likely to outrage in a naval duel has aroused interest in naval circles in this city. The Republica and Tiradontes were both present in New York during the Columbian celebration.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- This was the second day of the Newmarket Houghton meeting. The principal event of the day was the race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes, which was won by Molly Morgan. Raeburn was second and Prisoner third. Distance 1 mile and 240 yards.

John Simpson, a master plumber, of Sixtyninth Street and the Western Boulevard secured a divorce from his wife on Tuesday in the Supreme Court on the ground of unfaithfulness. His chief witness was Theodore F. Secor, a real estate dealer at 328 West Twenty-sixth Street. Yesterday Mr. Simpson was a prisoner in the Tombs Police Court, Mr. Secor being the complainant.

ST. NORBERT, Quebec, Oct. 25 -- Berthier, St. Norbert, and the surrounding country are en fete to-day, to celebrate what is said to be an unprecedented event in the history of the province, the seventieth anniversary of the marriage of two of its inhabitants. The fortunate couple are Pierre Coulombe, a well-known farmer of St. Norbert, and his wife, who seventy years ago was called Mile. de Marie Roberge.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 25 -- With a chilling southeast wind and clouded skies, horsemen lost hope of seeing records go down in this, the first day of the special meeting. Under these unfavorable circumstances, however, several of the trials to-day were remarkable. This was notably true of Manager's effort against his mark of 2:06 3/4, made last week. With Doble up, the gray pacer came with a terrific burst of speed into the homestretch.

According to The United Service Gazette (British) the new Spanish cruiser Infanta Maria Teresa has completed her eight hours' natural draught trial, steaming out from Ferrol Arsenal. The results were extremely satisfactory, the power indicated by the engines being above that specified for. The mean speed on the eight hours' run was 18.48 knots, the highest attained having been 18.8 knots.

One of the most notable victories ever achieved by an American newspaper has just been scored by The New-York Times. Ring politicians, in compact with a gang of prize-fight promoters, have been brought to a halt. The combine was arrogant, confident of its ability to set public decency at naught, aiming only at the bagging of profits from a brutalizing "exhibition."

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The Hon. Theodore Runyon, American Ambassador to Germany, to-day proceeded to the New Palace at Potsdam for the purpose of presenting to Emperor William his credentials as Ambassador. He was accompanied by Lieut. R.K. Evans, Military Attache of the American Embassy, and Lieut. Vreeland Naval Attache, both of whom were in uniform. Mr.J.B. Jackson, Secretary of the embassy, was also of the party. He wore a dress suit.
There was a great deal of trouble in the campaign headquarters of the "machine" in Court Square last night. Register Kenna and Secretary Furey were furiously angry.

The financial statement submitted by President J. W. Reinhart at the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Atchison, Topeka, and Santa Fe Railroad yesterday was pleasant reading after the unprofitable season through which the road has just passed. The figures for the year ended June 30 show a handsome increase over the previous year and a consequent surplus to meet the bad business of the present year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The strength of the stock market, resulting in substantial advances all along the line, may properly be regarded as an effort to discount the passage of the silver repeal bill. If the bill should be passed, our local securities will take another jump, in which the speculating public will assist.

Miss Emma Bryan, who says she was a nurse during the war, appeared in the Circuit Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, in an action against Louis J. Grant, a New-York lawyer: the real estate firm of Payne Shotwell, and Mrs. Mary E. Payne, the wife of a member of the firm, to recover property which she says she was swindled out of.

Another new operetta made by Americans was introduced to the New-York public last night. It was at the Garden Theatre that the introduction took place, and it was unquestionably an occasion of no little pleasure to a considerable number of persons and personages. The name of the operetta is " The Algerian," and the composer is already more than favorably known to the lovers of light music.

The naturalization mill in Kings County has been trying for the past few days to surpass its most exceptional record. The court in which aliens become, with feverish and irresistible impetuosity, fully-privileged citizens of the United States, is presided over by Henry A. Moore, Judge of the Court of General Sessions.

Messrs. R.V. Harnett Co. sold under foreclosure yesterday, in the salesroom at 111 Broadway, a one-sixth interest in the north-west corner of Sixth Avenue and Thirtieth Street. The flat is hatchet-shaped, 30 feet front on the avenue by 144 deep on the street by 99.6 by 100 by 99.6 by 41.5. On the avenue is a four-story stone-front building; on the street a two-story brick.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- To-night Champion James J. Corbett received a dispatch from the Olympic Club of New-Orleans, offering a purse of $20,000 for the Corbett-Mitchell glove contest, to be decided at their club.
Lawyer Ambrose H. Purdy made an exhibition of himself in the Court of General Sessions yesterday by taking a big dose of "knocker-out" mixture to prove to a jury how harmless the stuff was.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- There is probably more news about Rear Admiral Stanton and his error at Rio de Janeiro in saluting the rebel Admiral, Mello, than can be given at present, or than the Navy Department cares to publish until Admiral Stanton has a better opportunity to meet the charges that have been made against him.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 26. -- A sailboat containing seven men capsized Tuesday in Jamaica Bay, and two of the men were drowned. Their names were Christian Hinnansen and Hjalmar Hjerton. The names of those rescued were Carl Abelstedt, John Hinnansen, William Carruthers, Adolph Olsen, and Christian Peterson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The President has granted a pardon to William Hattersloy, sentenced in Brooklyn, N.Y., on March 2, 1893, to twelve months imprisonment in Raymond Street Jail for smuggling. Hattersloy is in bad health.

The people of Brooklyn are every day becoming more clearly informed in regard to the exact nature of the Mayoralty election there. There is very little attempt at direct defense on the part of Mr. BOODY and his friends, while the Republicans and independents who are supporting Mr. SCHIREN are pushing his canvass actively, systematically, and intelligently at every point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- There is now a strong probability that the final vote on the repeal bill will be taken not later than next Monday. The programme as now arranged reads this way: Mr. Jones of Nevada will speak three hours to-morrow, Mr. Allen one hour, Mr. Wolcott twenty-five minutes, and Mr. Stewart an hour, "more or less."

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 26. -- The Richmond County Democrats made their first move to-day for the punishment of the "ring" Inspectors of Election, who have neglected to perform their duty and committed fraud.

PERSONALS. -- Among the prominent society people now at the World's Fair ara Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sloane, Mrs. F. R. Jones. Miss Peatrice Jones, Mrs. Charles A. Post, Mrs. William Post, Mies Post, and Commodore and Mrs. E.D. Morgan. Ward McAllister has returned to this city from Newport for the Winter. Miss McAllister will remain at Newport a few weeks longer.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 26. -- Francis H. Weeks, the notorious New-York embezzler, is still here, and it is impossible to state precisely when he will start on his journey to the United States. The steamship Foxhall, which should have left Port Limon yesterday, is forty-eight hours behind time, having had severe weather in her run out from New-Orleans.

Many trotters this year have been led by circumstances to consider The Stock Exchange as a very unhealthful place. Men who have seen the lines of stocks which they have been carrying sag until the agile bear could play skipping rope with them have gone home complaining of backache and general debility.

The General Theological Seminary football team was defeated yesterday by a scrub team from Columbia College. The seminary had a heavy team, but their interference was weak, and they seldom broke through the "scrub's" line. The teams were:
At the Holland House last evening the Lord Mayor of Dublin, the Hon. James Shanks, received a reporter for The New-York Times.

Our Washington dispatches report that Senator SHERMAN has concluded not to offer his proposition for the issue of bonds as an amendment to the repeal bill. This is right. Probably the authority to issue bonds will either have to be exercised under the act of 1875 or be conferred by act of Congress.

Carpet manufacturers, here and in England, are deeply interested in the recent exportation to London of a considerable quantity of Moquette and Axminster carpets from the largest carpet factory in America, which is situated a few miles from this city. The appearance of these goods in the English market has greatly disturbed the manufacturers in Kidderminster and other English towns where carpets are made.

The time has arrived for the use of plain and unmistakable language concerning not only the men at the head of the Municipal Government of Brooklyn, but also the men whose sworn duty it is to prosecute offenders against the law, men whose duty it is to punish violations of the law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The country may grow impatient of the provoking delay in passing the repeal bill after it has been decided that it shall pass, but there does not appear to be any foundation for the fear that the silver men are to prolong the debate indefinitely, without declaring their intention to filibuster.

TOPEKA, Oct. 26. -- Little by little the peculiar methods of government adopted at the Western branch of the Soldiers' Home at Leavenworth come to light and do not appear to add lustre to the reputation of the Governor, who seems to have terrorized the 2,000 men who make their homes there. Capt. James A. Vaughan of Blackburn, Saline County, Mo., who served as an officer in the Fourth Kentucky Volunteer Infantry, tells his story.

FORT GIBSON, Indian Territory, Oct. 26. -- Every retail merchant in the Cherokee Nation has sold out his stock of goods on credit to the Indians. To-morrow it will be known whether the English syndicate which offered to take the Cherokee Strip bonds at par, with interest, will complete its contract. Over $6,000,000 are involved in the deal.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 26. -- The secret marriage of Charles F. Coghlan, the actor, who appeared in this city in the early part of the week, and Miss Kuhne Beveridge, a member of the Coghlan company, was made public to-day. The two were married shortly after midnight of Tuesday, but the license has not been put on record yet.

The stockholders of the Madison Square Bank had a meeting yesterday afternoon, at which a clash was threatened because some of those who had not been involved in the bank's management wished to take matters in hand independently of those of whom the District Attorney has taken notice. Lawyer Lauterbach's diplomatic skill, together with the threatened exposure of bitter differences and political complications, operated, however, to bring all interests into apparent harmony.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- The market was reactionary all the morning. Reading showed pretty liberal signs of realizing, and Lehigh Valley, which was bid up to 39 yesterday, was offered down to 36 on very light transactions.
