It is authoritatively denied that there is any traffic agreement between this company and the Reading and New-England.
-- It is a good thing that the papers refrain from publishing what the Senate is not doing, for if they did America would have a paper famine. -- Augusta (Ga.) News.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The full list of those injured in the Pennsylvania Railroad wreck at Bear Swamp yesterday afternoon is as follows:

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Wheat was very dull during the early part of the session, with the feeling easy, but later it became firmer and showed some activity. The opening was unchanged to 1/3c lower, then eased off about 3/8c, became firm, and advanced 7/8@1c, after which a feeling of steadiness pervaded the market, and the closing was 3/8@1/2c higher each for May and December.

The protest of the New-York Bar Association against the nomination of Isaac Horton Maynard for Judge of the Court of Appeals was taken up last night by thousands of men who, regardless of previous party affiliation, filled the great hall of Cooper Union, until not another person could enter.

MARSEILLES, Oct. 26. -- This city is en fete in honor of the Russian naval officers. The streets have been crowded since an early hour this morning, and it is certain that nearly a quarter of a million of strangers have already arrived to take part in the welcome to the guests. Many arches span the streets through which the Russians will pass, and flags and bunting are everywhere displayed.

Mrs. U.S. Grant, widow of Gen. Grant, started yesterday to pass the Winter in California with her son, Jesse Grant. Mrs. Grant traveled over the Pennsylvania Railroad in a special car, and was accompanied by U.S. Grant and his family. A number of friends called at the Fifth Avenue Hotel before Mrs. Grant departed and presented flowers.
The Boston Herald's yachting correspondent at Gourock, Scotland, says, concerning possible cup challengers, as follows:
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

The students and professors of Columbia College who understand French had a treat yesterday in listening to a lecture in French by Emile Levasseur or the College de France and of the Ecole Libre des Sciences Politiques of Paris, delivered in the library building. The subject of the lecture was "L'Afrique Francaise." Prof. Levassour has a lucid and deliberate delivery and uses peculiar French gestures.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 26. -- That the race-track politicians of Monmonth County are getting desperate and afraid of defeat in the coming election is very conclusively shown by their operations here this week. They have resorted to the old plan of attempting to muzzle the press, forgetting the sorry mess made of such an attempt by the men for whom they are fighting no later than last Summer.

-- The entertainment that is to be given by George J. Kraus in the Imperial Music Hall on the afternoon of Friday, Nov. 3, for the benefit of the Brunswick (Ga.) and sea islands sufferers promises to be one of the most notable benefit entertainments ever given in New-York. Digby Bell, who is now under the management of Mr. Lederer, will supply one of the numbers of the programme.

Tomcod are increasing in size and the sport is greatly improving. Not in years have the fish been so abundant. From Hell Gate to Westchester Creek the waters teem with these delicate pan fish. Catches of a hundred or even more a day are not uncommon when undertaken from boats. Along the river front they form the principal catch of the wharf angler.

The fifth general meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held last night. Commodore E.D. Morgan was not present. In his absence Vice Commodore W. Butler Duncan, Jr., presided. The members present attended chiefly to routine business. The Regatta Committee made a brief report and so did the America's Cup Committee. These two committees were authorized to publish their reports in ful by the annual meeting which will be held in February.
The big American coastwise steamer El Cid has been sold by C.P. Huntington. There is every reason to believe that she has been purchased for use as a war ship by the Government of Brazil.

The statistics of the meeting of the Linden Park Blood Horse Association, furnished by L.N. Salmon, clerk of the scales, show that there were 62 races run, in which 205 clipper-cut horses participated. The association gave $33,000 in purses. Fifty-three stables won money, as follows:
The death of John D. Newman yesterday at his residence, 58 West Ninety-third Street, removes a figure that has been prominent for many years in Tammany.

The New-York Baseball Club to-day secured the release of "Dad" Clarke, the pitcher of the Erie Club. Five hundred dollars was paid for his release. The club will also sign Pitcher Westervelt in a few days.

NEW-YORK. Thursday, Oct. 26 -- P.M. The disposition at the opening of the market scemed to be to buy stocks for a further advance, but before long it become apparent that many operators were putting their houses in shape for a reaction; on the ground that one was due, in view of the recent sharp advance.

An enterprising manager, of Chicago antecedents, has just been acquiring a small piece of philological information at a very large price. He had organized a " troupe " of American citizenesses of African descent, mulattoes and quadroons and octoroons. The unhappy thought struck him of taking this half-bred organization to the South, and the still more unhappy thought of calling it " La Belle Creole " Company.

The Rev. Samuel W. Haddaway, Chaplain of the House of Representatives at Washington and pastor of the Marvin Methodist Episcopal Church, died at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. He had been for many years suffering with Bright's disease, and about two weeks ago was forced to abandon his duties at Congress and in his church.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- The body of M. Gounod, the composer, who died at St. Cloud on Wednesday last, was removed to-day to his study, in the Place Malesherbes, where it will lie in state until Friday, when the state funeral will be held.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- The big battleship Oregon was successfully launched at the Union Iron Works just before noon today in the presence of over 20,000 people. A private stand had been erected right under the bow of the battleship, and thereon stood invited guests and those who were to participate in the ceremony of launching.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Oct. 26. -- West Superior is thinking a good deal just now about Francis Henry Weeks, the ex-New-York attorney and clubman, the ex-President of the Land and River Improvement Company of West Superior, Wis., and the embezzler of widows' and orphans' funds, who is about coming back from Costa Rica to appear as defendant in a criminal action.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Annexation to New-York took a vigorous step forward in this city to-night. The newly-organized Business Men's Association hold a large and enthusiastic meeting in the parlor of Miller's Hotel. Numerous speeches were made, setting forth the advantages that would accrue to this city should it become a part of New-York.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Admiralty denies the report that Capt. Lang of the British cruiser Sirius, now at Rio Janeiro, lent an engineer and fireman to Admiral Mello.
The following circular was issued to the security holders of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company yesterday.

SARANAC LAKE, Oct. 26. -- The registratioin in Franklin County this year is unusually full. In Malone the total is 2,579, which is 119 in excess of the registration for the first day last year. In Saranac Lake the increase is exactly 100. The number of women registered is small, except in one town, Bangor, where 180 are registered. Ten towns have no women upon the registry lists.

-- Reports come from Maine that the Rev, Dr. Henry Blanchard of Portland, an eloquent Universalist preacher, is at the head of a movement designed still further to lib eralize that religious denomination, and that he has interested a number of the leading members of the organization to act with, him.
Work on the new buildings of the Postal Telegraph Company and the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association was at a standstill yesterday, the workmen having gone on strike.
-- Gov. Russell of Massachusetts, it is said, will make an extended tour through the Southern States soon after the November election.

BUFFALO, Oct. 26. -- Nearly 3,000 of the better class of Democrats of Buffalo crowded into Music Hall to-night and listened to and applauded speeches denouncing the nomination of Maynard and the work of the Sheehan machine of this city, and then adopted vigorous resolutions condemning lath, and urging all Democrats to vote against them.
Police Commissioners Martin, Sheehan, and MacLean held a special meeting yesterday to transact election business. Local nominations were acted upon as follows:

An awful lion with an awful roar entertained the populace in the vicinity of Eighteenth Street and Irving Place nearly all day yesterday. Very few persona saw him, but he was declared to have " escaped," and all could hear his roar.
Wheat declined 1/4@3/8c on local realizing and easier London cables, but reacted 5/8@7/8c on the better Western markets, and closed firm, with a slow trade.

The Fall field sports of the students of Manhattan College were held yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds, under the management of the Jasper Athletic Club. The friends of the athletes filled the lower part of the grand stand and watched some very interesting contests. The boys showed some very creditable work and, considering that the events were run on the grass, fast time was made.

Adolph L'Arronge made his greatest hit with a rather short character piece from the life of the burgher class in Germany, and then left that field for more ambitious ventures. But hitherto the piece in question, which is "Mein Leopold," has been the most popular of all his plays. And it will remain the most popular, although "Lolo's Father" is a return to the same kind of comedy.

J. Sergeant Cram. President of the Dock Board, did not introduce at the meeting of that body yesterday his plan for the acquirement of the wharf property on the East River, between Perry and East Eleventh Streets. He notified the Commissioners that the subject would be submitted for discussion at the next meeting of the board.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct 26. -- The Superintendents of all State hospitals, with the exception of the Superintendent of the Rochester Hospital, who was represented, met with the State Commissioners in Lunacy to-day. The first matter considered related to the best way of securing economy in the purchase of standard articles for the institutions.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 26. -- Gov. Matthews has received a communication from Fisher's Station, where the brutal Evans-Johnson tight took place yesterday morning, asking if prosecution was possible. The Governor replied that it was, and urged the owners to carry the affair into the courts.

The controversy between the city and the Union Ferry Company is at last settled. At noon yesterday Controller Myers sold the leases of the Fulton, Wall. Catharine, South, and Hamilton Ferries to the Union Ferry Company at the upset price of 73/4 per cent, of the gross receipts. As a result the city will receive about $20,000 a year less than it has received, from these franchisee.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- Never in the history of football at Yale has the phenomenon been witnessed here that happened this afternoon. Daily practice was held at the Yale field as usual. First the despised and down-trodden "scrubs" appeared and meekly started executing a few tricks. Soon the regulars, big with the recollection of yesterday's rout of Williams by tremendous figures, appeared.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Carroll Institute, the leading Catholic organization of Washington, to-night tendered Cardinal Gibbons a reception, which concluded the series of exercises given in his honor during the past two days. The reception took place in the hall of the institute's new building, which had been decorated for the occasion with a profusion of flowers and potted plants, while the Stars and Stripes, intertwined with the Papal flag, floated from the ceiling.

Minor C. Keith, who has large interests in Costa Rica, has just arrived from that country with his wife and son. A reporter for The New-York Times called on Mr. Keith yesterday for information regarding the proceedings in the Weeks extradition case. Mr. Keith is thoroughly informed as to the diplomatic movements which ended in the absolute surrender of Weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Information furnished the State Department by Theodore M. Stephan, United States Consul at Annaberg, Germany, shows that opposition in that country to American products did not end with the removal of the restrictions on the importation of American pork, and that American hay is now under the ban.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The numerous "hangers-on" and attendants who come to the United States from foreign countries with World's Fair exhibitors and with the Midway Plaisance shows, are causing the Treasury officials much concern as to the proper means of returning them whence they came.

The Brooklyn "ring" is on the run. The Brooklyn "ring" has positive and overwhelming evidence that, if an election were to be held to-morrow. Mayor Boody would meet with a crushing defeat. It has discovered, as was stated in The New-York Times yesterday, that it is away behind in the registration of voters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- The Pacific Mail steamship City of New-York, which sailed from this port this afternoon, went on the rocks at Point Bonita in a dense fog. She will probably be a total wreck. Point Bonita is at the entrance of the Golden Gate on the northern side.

-- Upon the application of the Cleveland, Canton and Southern Railroad, the Jurisdiction of the receivers appointed for that road in Ohio has been extended to the Southern district of NewYork by Judge Lacombe, of the United States Circuit Court. The receivers are J. W. Wardwell of Cleveland, Ohio, and Frederick K. Swift of New-Bedford, Mass. The company has securities in this State valued at $184,000, and pledged as collateral upon loans.

Frederick A. Lovecraft, business manager of Palmer's Theatre and Assistant Secretary of the Coney Island Jockey Club, committed suicide yesterday morning in his bedroom at the Norfolk, 45 West Thirtieth Street, by swallowing carbolic acid.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 26. -- At a well-attended meeting of the pastors of the city this afternoon arrangements were perfected for mass meetings Wednesday evening of this week in favor of anti-race track legislation. Two will be held, one at the First Presbyterian Church and the other at St. John's Episcopal Church.

It is hard to recall a time when, within about ten days of the election, there has seemed to be so little interest in this State in the question of the control of the next Legislature. Where the politicians of either party have not had their own way completely in making nominations, the opposition has been chiefly personal, and independent candidates have set themselves up or been set up by their personal followers.

The Secretary of the Navy had no option, but to remove Commodore STANTON, after that officer's recognition of an insurrection of the existence of which our Government has never taken notice. If the Brazilian insurgents had assumed to fly the Brazilian flag, Commodore STANTON'S action would have been explicable; but this is not the case.

Depositors in the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn were surprised yesterday to learn that the Attorney General of the State had postponed from Saturday until Tuesday, with the announced consent of both sides, his application for a permanent receiver. Several depositors went to the office of Horace Graves, the counsel for the depositors organization.
"What's the matter with these young men?" asked a guest at the Windsor Hotel yesterday forenoon. "Are they boycotting the barbers?"

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 27 -- There have been exciting events to-day in the political battle on Staten Island, in which honest men of every party and the friends of honest government are united against corruption in government and fraud at the ballot box.

The presentment of the Queens County Grand Jury with, respect to the collision on the Long Island Railroad at Berlin shows once more how slight a restraining influence is commonly exercised upon derelict railway corporations in cases of this kind through the agency of proceedings under the criminal statutes.

Mr. PEFFER, the Populist Senator from Kansas, enjoyed the privilege of seeing twenty-eight Senators vote for his free-coinage amendment yesterday, while nine more would have done so, but wereipaired. The Senators recorded, therefore, stood 37 for to 49 against this proposition, according to the press dispatches.

James Haustedt, Haitian Consul in NewYork, was asked yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times whether he had any information as to the scuttling of the gunboat Alexandre Petion near Cape Tiburon about a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Voting on the amendments to the Voorhees Repeal bill besan at 4 o'clock this afternoon, much to the gratificatian of Senators who for the past three days have been working industriously to bring the debate to a close. The Peffer amendment providing for free coinage at a ratio of 16 to 1, the first on the list which must be disposed of, was voted down -- 39 to 28.

To-day's football game at Eastern Park will un doubtedly be one of the closest matches the Crescents will play this year. They have arranged to play the team of Union College, schenectady, and they are very evenly matched, in the judgment of experts. It will be the first appearance of the Union Kickera in this vicinity. Play will begin at 3:30, as usual.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 27 -- Judge Van Syckel to-day again summoned the Union County Grand Jury before him and delivered to them a second charge on the importance of indicting the Township Committee of Linden Township for granting a license to the Linden race track. The jury, however, wholly disregarded the instructions of the court and refused to bring in any indictments.

Real estate men learned with pleasure yesterday that the life insurance companies had resumed loaning on realty at 5 per cent. This is taken as indicating that the monetary stringency and hoarding of cash accompanying it have ceased. The notices increasing the interest rate on loans to 6 per cent. were sent out in August and created much ill feeling.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The death by her own hand of Miss Daisy Garland, only daughter of the ex-Attorney General, shocked all Washington to-day. The young lady, because of her prominence during her father's occupancy of a Cabinet position during Mr. Cleveland's former Administration, and because of her own personal charms, was a well-known and very popular figure in society.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- The state funeral of M. Gounod was held to-day. The body was removed this morning from the Gounod residence, in the Place Malesherbes, where it had been lying in state, to the Church of the Madeleine. An immense crowd filled the Place de la Madeleine, and the streets and boulevards in the vicinity.

Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court yesterday signed an order permitting the receivers of the Madison Square Bank to go ahead in their work of winding up the affairs of the institution, preparatory to liquidation unless a reorganization is effected within thirty days.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Oct. 27 -- P.M. There was quite a falling off in the volume of business to-day, but the trading was still good and the undertone firm. The reactions which occurred were due to realizing sales. The short interest is believed to be largely reduced, but it is still sufficiently important to cause an advance in prices on any effort to cover it.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Oct. 27. -- Prof. Herrmann, the magician, appeared before Referee Matthew J. Smith, 241 Jackson Avenue, this city, to-day, on an order in supplementary proceedings, issued, by Justice Barrett of New-York on behalf of Acter Daniel Collyer. Collyer played the part of Rebecca Clinton in "Cordelia's Aspirations" and Pete in "The Mulligan Guards."

As predicted in The Times, all the colleges in the football association were arrayed against the University of Pennsylvania at the mooting held in the Windsor Hotel last night, and, while the undergraduate rule was not repealed. It was modified so as to preclude all chances of the success of Pennsylvania.

MADRID, Oct. 27. -- The Spanish troops at Melilla began this morning to throw up earthworks for the defense of the men who will build the fort on the heights of Sidi Guariach. This fort will be the strongest of the series of fortifications to be erected at once, and will accommodate when completed about 300 men, and will mount six heavy guns.

Late Wednesday evening a meeting of the representatives of Yale and Columbia, those of Princeton having failed to arrive, was held at the Windsor Hotel to discuss the plan of changing in the future the Thanksgiving Day game between Yale and Princeton from the Manhattan Field to the Columbia Oval, at William's Bridge. Yale was represented by Capt. Hinkey, and Columbia by L.M. Lawson and Livingston Pell.

The almost certain, prospect of defeat at the polls has rendered the Brooklyn Democratic "ring" so desperate that it does not hesitate to resort to any kind of bulldozing or intimidation in its effort to injure the cause of the Republicans and independents.

Receivers Young and Loper of the National Cordage Company filed a statement and inventory, made up as of date of June 30, in the New-Jersey Chancellor's Court yesterday. The situation in the affairs of the company has materially changed in the last four months, and an inventory has been made as of Sept. 30.

Dr. Judson Daland of this city, who has been investigating cholera in Italy, has written to Dr. Jenkins's secretary, telling of his achievement recently in having swam the Strait of Messina, or what was known to the ancients as the whirlpool between Soylla and Charybdis.
LONG ISLAND CITY, Oct. 27. -- Upon the decision of County Clerk Sutphin of Queens County, to be rendered to-morrow, hangs the fate of two political factions in this city.

-- The Missouri Court of Appeals has sustained a verdict for damages against a St. Louis hotel for the loss of a coat and hat, which a guest left in the charge of an attendant at the dining room door. The coat and hat were stolen or delivered in mistake to another guest while the owner was at dinner.

To the long roll of marine casualties there was yesterday added one which varies the sombre list of mishaps on the ocean of which the Atlantic has lately been so prolific. The Hamburg-American steamship Gellert arrived in port, having been two days on fire.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 27. -- Francis H. Weeks, the New-York, embezzler, has started on his journey home. Costa Rica turned him over to Detectives Keilly and Von Gerichten last night, the transfer taking place at Port Limon upon the deck of the steamer Foxhall.

The galleries of the American Art Association on Madison Square are carpeted, hung, and all but ceiled with rugs and prayer carpets, big and little, till each looks like the tent of an Eastern potentate on a State progress. Rugs are fastened near the skylights, flow along the wall, and lie on the ground, where they partially cover carpets spread wide and overlapped.

The sixty-fourth anniversary of their marriage was celebrated yesterday by the Rev. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Beecher at their home, 182 Macon Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Beecher is the second son of the Rev. Dr. Lyman Beecher, and brother of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher. He married Isabella Porter Jones at Wiscasset, Me., on Oct. 27, 1829.

-- A.J. McDougall, Eastern Passenger Agent of the Illinois Central Railroad, sends to The Times a plump magazine, entitled "The Ten Best States in America." It contains 250 pages of interesting descriptions of the characteristics and products of the ten States through which the fines of the Illinois Central pass. A person who reads this book cannot fail to get a valuable amount of Information concerning the vast and resourceful West.

Double the ordinary number of longshoremen were unloading the cargo of El Cid all day yesterday. The large cargo was removed late in the afternoon, and the steamship was ready for the new owners, Flint Co.

The peculiar conditions that prevail in the affairs of the Northern Pacific Railroad have impelled the holders of the consolidated mortgage bonds of that company, both here and in Germany, to organize for self-protection.

Now that the Canadian steamship and railroad companies have undertaken to give force to the agreement with representatives of our Treasury Department designed to prevent the entrance into this country by way of Canada of immigrants who would be excluded if they should apply for admission at our ports, the Canadian Department of the Interior shows a desire to make the agreement worthless.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The University of Pennsylvania held its annual Fall games here tills afternoon in a drizzling rain. The event in which most interest centred was the open 1,000 yard run. Four men started, S.W. Orton and Joseph Vernier of the University of Pennsylvania and W.M. Morris and M.A. Boyd of the Young Men's Christian Association.

The Cricketers' Club, a social organization for the willow wielders of the metropolis, will be organized to-night at a meeting at the temporary club rooms, which have been secured on East Fourteenth Street. The organization has every prospect of success, and starts with a list of twenty charter members selected from the most prominent cricketers in this vicinity.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- In nearly every large county, and particularly in race-track counties, there are evidences of colonization. Direct evidence has already been secured in Essex, Camden, and Hudson Counties of a movement to swell the votes in the interest of the race-track candidates.

A useful as well as entertaining paper by Col. H.E. Colvile of the Grenadier Guards tells of the Katchins, a little-described people of the countries absorbed with more or less brazenfacedness by England and France, far off in the region where Hindus, Chinamen, and Malays meet and interbreed.

The property owners on the lower end of Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, have had set before them, by the city authorities, an edifying illustration of the extraordinary privileges which are enjoyed by "Boss" McLaughlin, by virtue of his position as the head of the Democratic "machine" organization.

NORTON, Va., Oct. 27. -- "Doe" Tayler was executed outside the Wise County Jail a few minutes after 2 o'clock this afternoon. At 10 o'clock he began preaching to 4,000 people, who stood in a heavy rain and listened for one hour and twenty-five minutes. The discourse was intended to be a funeral oration, but was a disconnected and meaningless talk.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Despite the fact that torrents of rain fell, the Montclair Club hall was packed to the doors to-night by an audience which listened attentively to the debate on "Currency Problems," under the auspices of the Outlook Club of Montclair. between Congressman R.P. Bland of Missouri and Michael D.H. Hartor, the "hard money" Congressman from Ohio.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 27. -- The Republican "Kicking" Prohibitionists, those who would not stand on the local-option platform, are extremely active. They allege that they will take 30,000 votes away from the Republicans and give them to the third-party Prohibition ticket. They wanted to have a ticket of their own, with their candidate.

In The New-York Times yesterday there was told at length the story of the job by which John Delmar, "boss" of the Twenty-second Ward "machine" Democracy of Brooklyn, collected over $60,000 from the Treasurer of Kings County. This money was paid over to Delmar when he was County Clerk of Kings County.

The fact that there have been extensive forgeries in the business affairs of George Meyer, carriage manufacturer at 381 Boulevard, who made an assignment a few days ago and mysteriously disappeared, was stated at a meeting of the creditors held at 28 Waverley Place yesterday afternoon.

The German-American friends of Otto Kempner, who wants to go to the Assembly from the Seventh Assembly District of this city, crowded into Concordia Hall at 30 Avenue A last night and shouted for him till they were hoarse. Felix Schwarzschild presided, and speeches were made in many languages.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Chief of Police Tonney received a cablegram to-day stating that Ewald Huetterman, the insurance broker, who spirited away Freda Laucks, sixteen years old, and her brother Hubert, fifteen years old, has been arrested at Sonthampton, England, on board the Fuerst Bismarck. Huetterman registered as William Windell.

There is some evidence that the enactment of the Voorheos bill may be delayed by the introduction of amendments bearing on the needs of the Treasury, but we do not think that this will amount to much. The Senate yesterday voted down the Peffer amendment for free coinage of silver, and distinctly cleared the path of the repeal bill.

The fourth and fifth games of the chess match now being played at St. Petersburg between Dr. Sigismund Tarrasch of Nuremberg and M. Tachigorin of St. Petersburg arrived in this yesterday. It will be seen from the score of the fourth game that Tschigorin really ought to have won that game if he had continued with 48, Q -- R3, instead of the text move.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The market has been dull to-day, with spasms of strength. The buying of Reading, which was so prominent early in the week, has entirely disappeared, and the transactions now are between traders. Lehigh Valley is bid up and offered down on small lots, with no real business in it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Wheat, with the exception of about the first half hour, was very firm. A fair business was transacted. The opening was fractionally lower than the close of yesterday, followed by an easier feeling, and prices declined about 1/2c, then became strong and advanced 1\2c, eased off about 1/4c, held steady, and the closing was about 3/4@3/8c higher than yesterday.

The need of additional revenue cutters is so obvious that Congress may well take up promptly the task of supplying them. This need has lately been illustrated and emphasized by the orders to repair, fit out, and send to San Francisco the Grant and the Perry. The former must make the long journey from New-York for this purpose, and the latter the still longer from Lake Erie by way of the St. Lawrence.

The news of the marriage of Charles Coghlan to Kuhne Beveridge, announced yesterday in a dispatch, from Indianapolis to The New-York Times, was a surprise to his friends in this city. Whatever Mr. Coghlan's failings, he enjoyed the reputation of holding the domestic relation in the highest regard.

Mayor Boody spoke in a number of places in Brooklyn last night. The result must have been disheartening to him. The first place he spoke was at 144 Greenpoint Avenue, where a fairly-respectable audience greeted him, but at all the other places slim crowds were the order. In the Fourteenth Ward, the stronghold of Senator McCarren, he spoke in Palace Hall, 89 Grand Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Philo J. Beveridge, son of ex-Gov. Beveridge and the father of the new Mrs. Coghlan. seemed greatly affected when questioned this morning about the marriage of the young girl, and the probability of Coghlan's already having a wife.

"The campaign in New-Jersey is a very lively one," said Gen. E. Burd Grubb at the Windsor Hotel yesterday. "The Law and Order League, which is a strictly non-partisan body, is making a winning fight against the gamblers. There are, however, many purchasable votes in New-Jersey, I regret to say, and the race-track element will stop at nothing.

To the serious consideration of every honest voter in Brooklyn, The New-York Times to-day submits a statement of indisputable facts concerning the government of that unfortunate city, which, if carefully considered, cannot fail to create amazement and widespread indignation.

Ex-Secretary of the Navy William C. Whitney called upon Lieut. Gov. Sheehan at the Democratic State Headquarters on West Twenty-fourth Street yesterday, and spent some time with him. The gossips at once set the story afloat that Mr. Whitney had left a check of considerable size behind him as a contribution to the Democratic campaign fund, but the gossips have to talk about something.

When the Young Men's Democratic Club held their meeting, Saturday night, and indorsed Charles A. Schieren, the Republican Mayoralty nominee, it was not pleasing to the McGarryites. It will be remembered that the Tenth Ward ruffians and heelers did all in their power to defeat the resolution, and their disgraceful work ended in the police being called in.

Mildred Hill, twenty-three years old, tall, slender, pretty, and vivacious, eloped Wednesday evening from the beautiful home of her father, George T. Hill of 275 West Seventy-first Street, and is now the wife of Frederick Mansfield, who is about thirty years old, short, stout, not good looking, but is the crack four-in-hand English driver in the stable of Charles F. Bates, Sixty-ninth Street, near West End Avenue.

Sampson Handley, night ticket agent of the Union Elevated Road at Driggs Avenue and Broadway, Williamsburg, saw a man lying across the track in front of the station at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. He called Michael Greon, a signal man, and they lifted the stranger from the track, Green went for a policeman. The stranger then attacked Handley and tried to throw him into the street.

-- The Women's University Club has moved from 96 Fifth Avenue to a large room in the building of the Berkeley Ladies' Athletic Club, 23 West Forty-fourth Street. The room is handsomely furnished, and is supplied with a Steinway piano and with the leading periodicals. The first afternoon tea of the season took place last Saturday.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 27. -- The building at Pike and Eleventh Streets, owned and occupied by the Chautauqua Lake Ice Company and the Pittsburg Storage Company, was detroyed by fire this afternoon.

The lodgers in the Ashland House were surprised yesterday morning by the announcement that Frederick Decker, a bell boy, bad committed suicide. Decker was nineteen years of age, and had come from England about two years ago. Ho was a general favorite in the hotel because of his cheerful manner and obliging disposition.

Before William J. Thompson set his foot within its precincts Gloucester was a prettily-situated and sleepy hamlet on the Delaware River, a short distance below Philadelphia. It was famed principally for its planked shad and the innocence of its inhabitants. They were law-loving, law-abiding, and sin-hating people.

The members of the Woman's University Club gave their first afternoon tea of the season yesterday in the clubroom in the Berkeley Ladies' Athletic Club, 23 West Forty-fourth Street. The apartment of the club, on the second floor of the building, looked very bright and cheerful with its handsome furnishings. About fifty members of the club visited the apartment from 4 to 7 o'clock and renewed old acquaintanceships over cups of steaming tea.

-- A singular mistake is made by The Art Amateur for November with regard to the doors of Trinity Church, New-York. One asks if that magazine can be published in New-York on reading that the panels for the door by Niehaus "are too small in scale for their massive frame and, when cast in bronze, we fear will show only as a confused mass of glittering lights and broken shadows."

The weekly statement of the Associated Banks, issued yesterday, showed another marked increase in the reserve, and indicated the extent to which funds have continued to pour into this city. The banks added to their reserves $6,146,700 in the week, and are now $48,787,475 above legal requirements.

The panic of the Brooklyn "ring" has begun. It hears, above all other sounds, the rumbling of the thunder which foreruns the hurricane. The members of the "machine" are alarmed as they have never been alarmed before. They are, in fact, desperate, for they realize that they can win the election only by daring and gigantic frauds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Presentations, illuminated addresses, and farewell dinners are the order of the day and night at the World's Fair. There were three presentations to-night at the offices of the Department of Admissions and Collections in the Service Building.

Benjamin G. Sanford, for many years correspondence clerk of the Continental National Bank, is under arrest charged with misappropriating $53,000 by an ingenious combination of altered letters, fraudulent orders, and false entries.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- The pluckiest game of football played here this season was put up by Brown University men to-day, although they were beaten by 58 points. Two thirty-miuute halves were played. From the beginning the came was Harvard's, but it was won only through the hardest work. Brown played a beautiful offensive game, and the grit shown by Capt. Hopkins's men to the very last won general admiration.

From The Cincinnati Enquirer. Teachers throughout Indiana are protesting vigorously against a new rule just adopted by the Superintendent of Public Instruction regarding appeals from the decisions of County Superintendents. Whenever a teacher applies for a license and is refused one for any cause, or is graded lower than he believes he should be, an appeal lies to the State Superintendent, whose duty it is to investigate and decide the question at issue.

The week just past closed with a better outlook for real estate men than has been the case for three months past. Inquiries for property are beginning to be common once more, and have more of a business air about them. The general impression is that the month of November will be marked by much activity.

The coming international test at Sandy Hook of rapid-fire guns is the first event of its kind in the history of ordnance development in the United States. The object of this great test is to determine the type of rapid-fire gun best adapted to the needs of the coast defense of America.

The great feature that distinguishes November from other months is the fact that during that month the earth plunges through the meteor zone, whose perihelion rests upon the portion of her orbit that she passes about Nov. 13. This zone is an immense ellipse, containing an innumerable number of meteors, which make a revolution in about thirty-three years.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The most exciting and hotly contested game of football ever seen on the Ridgeffeld grounds was that this afternoon between the Cornell and Williams teams. Cornell's men, in charge of Coach Charles Courtney, reached here last evening, and Williams came along on the midday train to-day. The college boys descended on the florists, and by early afternoon had cleaned up the entire supply of chrysanthemum blossoms.

It has been all boom in the stock market the past week, and the close yesterday was strong at the highest figures. Nearly half a minion shares were done for three days in succession. This is big business, compared with what has been. There is no mistake, either, about a good deal of genuine public buying.

Judge Avery of Highland Falls is the oldest Justice of the Peace in New-York State. He was born at West Point in 1811, where his father was bugler to the cadets. The father had charge of the instruments in the philosophical department, and when Prof. Morse established the first telegraph line between New-York and Baltimore he assisted him, and was the inventor of the instrument key used by the professor.

The critical faculty has outstripped the constructive. No one, I think, can doubt that actual and great advance has been made in medicine. The statistics of mortality are at hand to show it. Nevertheless, what many physicians say is, that while we are better able than we were to distinguish disease and to predict how it will run its course, we have made no substantive advance in the healing art.
There is no longer the slighest doubt of the uses to which El Cid. the steamship which was purchased through Flint Co. from C.P. Huntington. will be put.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Admiral Stanton's explanation as to why he saluted Admiral Mello, sent in answer to a message of inquiry, was made public to-day by Secretary Herbert. It reads as follows:
The big armored cruiser New-York has received orders to prepare to proceed to Brazil at once.

Although the price of wheat advanced last week about 2 1/2 cents per bushel, and the reports for the preceding week showed a large increase of the available stocks in this country and afloat for Europe, the quantity exported for the week was larger than the exports in any one of the three weeks immediately preceding, being 3,327,525 bushels.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The Yale football team met the cadets in a game of two thirty-minute halves on the parade grounds to-day. The weather was all that could be desired, and the result of the game points to the steady progress made by the soldiers tinting the past few weeks and the influence of the coaching of Laurie Bliss was to be seen in the accuracy of their tackling and interference.

Wesleyan may turn out dominies that she can point to with pride, but her football material will never electrify the sporting world. The team from Middletown played the opening game for the college championship with Princeton at Manhattan Field, yesterday, and when the smoke of the battle had cleared away, Princeton was declared the winner by a score of 76 to 0.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 28. -- Mrs. E.M. Blackman of Leavenworth is the first woman in the world to be named as Police Commissioner of a city. Under the system in this State the Governor appoints and removes at pleasure, and so far he has done so without consultation with the citizens of the cities interested.

A general belief in the divine character and healing powers of the sacred serpent is to be met with all over Egypt. Even the myths which the old Egyptians associated with the snake are still prevalent. Egyptians of all classes still believe that when "a serpent grows old, wings grow out of its body," and that there are serpents which kill by darting flames in the victim's face.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Before the Senate session of Monday is over, unless all of to-day's signs fail, the House bill for the unconditional repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act will have been passed by the Senate and sent to the House, with a request for the concurrence of that body in the amendments made by the Senate.

MADRID, Oct. 28. -- Further details regarding the attack made yesterday by the Riffians at Melilla upon the Spanish troops and workmen have been received. The Spaniards were engaged in throwing up earthworks for the defense of the mea who will build the fort on the Heights of Sidi Guariach.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The rapid, sustained advance of American securities during the last ten days has failed to bring in any outside support, or to increase the volume of business done by the brokers for English account. Most of the movements registered here have been on business for New-York account, or what amounts to the same thingarbitrage transactions.

The members of the American committee of holders of the consolidated mortgage bonds of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company assembled in the office of Edward D. Adams, in the Mills Building yesterday and organized for work. Mr. Charles Lanier of Winslow, Lanier Co. was added to the committee, which comprises, besides the Messrs. Adams and Lanier, Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, Ernest Thalmann, James Stillman, and J.D. Probst.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Naval Surgeons can not hereafter make a junketing trip out of convention work. Secretary Herbert's attention has been called to the fact that it has grown into a custom to detail promiscuously officers of the Medical Corps in attendance on medical conventions. They are held in all parts of the country every year, and there have been several abroad, notably the convention in Italy last month.

When Miss Winifred Driscoll left the Western University, where her education had been completed, she realized that she merely had learned what she wished to know. The acquisition of this knowledge was to be the purpose of her future life. Among the many well-fixed ideas in her very clever little mind, the best fixed was her ability to care for and direct herself.

The historic old John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, at 44 and 46 John Street, will celebrate to-day the one hundred and twenty-seventh anniversary of the foundation of Methodism in America. The morning services will begin at 9 o'clock with a love feast, conducted by the Rev. A.B., Sanford, D.D., to be follwed by a sermon delivered by the Rev. Albert S. Hunt, D.D.

Mr. Howard a year or so ago reached the furthest edge of Eastern Siberia, in the Gulf of Tartary and the Okhotsk Sea, opposite the coast of Kanischatka. Although familiar with the prison and exile system of Russia, he heard that some other dread place existed having to do with punishments, and that few travelers had ever reached it.

Every visitor to St. Paul, Minn., who has seen the big red sandstone pile familiarly known throughout the American Occident as "Jim Hill's house" -- (and statistics are not at hand to show the number of St. Paul's visitors who have not seen it) -- will be interested in the bit of domestic gossip, that twenty servants and one housekeeper are needed to keep each floor of the enormous dwelling in order.

The Sunday kindergarten is the latest form of this now very prevalent system of education. Two or three churches in Detroit, and there may be more elsewhere, have kindergarten church services held during the hour of morning preaching. A pleasant classroom is provided, and here, under the care of a trained kindergartner, the restless little folks who find "church" such a trying ordeal meet for their kindergarten worship.

The Prince of Wales a few days ago laid the cornerstone of a new building intended to house the magnificent collection of trophies of war and military souvenirs won by the English arms on land and sea, got together by the Royal United Service Institution.
One of the important issues of the present campaign in Brooklyn is to decide whether the city shall be run by its White Caps, as in the past.

The ladder of fame that "Billy" Thompson of Gloucester has had to climb has not been a long one. Bat it is an extremely dirty one. There have been slime and filth, from, the very lowest round. Thompson firmly established himself on the first round as a fighting billiard-room, boy in the Continental Hotel at Philadelphia.

A large and enthusiastic mass meeting to ratify the nomination of Charles A. Schleren for Mayor, William J. Gaynor for Justice of the Supreme Court, and George Kinkel for Supervisor at Large, was held last evening by the Brooklyn Democratic Club at Tivoli Hall, Fifth Avenue and Second Street, Brooklyn.

A well-dressed, gentlemanly-appearing man seemed to be traveling aimlessly about the race track during the afternoon that a Times reporter was there. He scanned the faces of the young men carefully, watched the women of no uncertain reputation sitting at the tables at the rear of the grand stand, drinking, betting, and trying to attract the attention of the men who were drifting about.

WASHNGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Navy Department still declines to make public the special report of the Board of Officers that conducted the recent trial trip of the new gunboat Machias, which, it is alleged. Bays that the vessel is topheavy and somewhat cranky, and needs a better distribution of Heavy material to make her a good sea boat.

"Old Swedes Church," in Wilmington, Del., is the oldest ecclesiastical building that time has spared to the Eastern States. Indeed, in point of years it takes rank with those ancient Spanish edifices of the far South-west and on the Pacific coast, the iron figuring upon its sturdy entrance tower testifying to 1698 as the date of erection.

Cedar Keys, Fla., was ten years ago a thriving, bustling little city, containing four hotels, a good wharf, and railroad connections. The sponge and turtle hunters were thriving, the pencil factories were busy, and the stores supplied the rest of the coast with provisions and other articles. It was one of the thriving towns of Florida.

Mayor Boody of Brooklyn, having announced that the campaign in which he is now engaged is to be a campaign of education. The New-York Times comes to his aid with a few pictures intended to show how the excise law is not enforced in BrooKlyn.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 28. -- At the Montclair Athletic Club grounds this afternoon the Irving Club of Brooklyn defeated the Montclair Athletic Club football eleven by a score of 6 to 0 in a well-contested game. Pedlew for the Brooklyns made a touch-down early in the had from which McKenzie kicked a goal. The players were:
Chauncey M. Depew would not at first believe the story telegraphed from Chicago that Mayor Harrison had been assassinated.

The new building soon to be occupied by the Postal Telegraph-Cable Company, at the corner of Broadway and Murray Street, now approaching completion, is one of the largest and handsomest of the lofty modern fire-proof office buildings which have so changed the appearance of down-town streets during recent years. The volume of business of the company had increased so rapidly that the need for larger and more convenient quarters had become imperative.

It is but a few steps from the ferry house to the gates of Jersey's Gehenna. No perpetual fire is kept burning to destroy the pestilential odors that arise, as was the case in the Biblical type of this place. Instead there is the constant beacon light of the wreckers to attract to their doom visitors to this blot on Jersey's fair face.

The life of a Bank of France note is about two years, it being issued so long as it is usable. In the matter of destroying their notes set apart for cancellation, a new departure has been made by the Bank of France.

There is a prevalent superstition that nobody in all this town is so fortified, buttressed, and generally secluded from the common accidents and incidents of daily life as is the telephone girl. No lady abbess was ever quite so set apart from the common herd; none is made quite so inaccessible to man, who goes about like a roaring lion seeking whom he can devour.

Of the two new theatrical productions of last week that were looked forward to with interest, only Mr. Mansfield's tasteful and ingenious revival of "The Merchant of Venice" at Herrmann's now remains on view. In the case of "The Younger Son" at the Empire, Mr. Charles Frohman has acted with businesslike energy.

The example set by the Charity Organization Society of establishing a woodyard where men out of regular work can get a job which, although done at low wages, will put a little money in their pockets and help feed their wives and children and keep a roof over their heads, has been followed by the Rev. Dr. Madison C. Peters, the pastor of Bloomingdale Church, at Sixty-eighth Street and the Boulevard.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- When Parliament reassembles next week, it will not be Ireland Which will claim preeminent attention, nor yet any of the numerous English and Welsh domestic reforms which are crowding together and tugging at the leash just behind home rule.

A very old dramatic friend has made its appearance in a new guise. This dear old friend is no other than the once-famous Adelphi play, "The Green Bushes," written by the late John Baldwin Buckstone. It has been remade into a comic operetta, under the name of "Miami," by John Hollingshead, and has been brought forward with success at the Princess's Theatre, London.

The ferry that takes one to Gloucester is the property of "Billy" Thompson, just as is everything else in and about Gloucester that is worth the owning. How it came into his possession is a good instance of the way in which he has worked everything to his own purposes in the creation of this Monaco of America.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Oct. 28 -- P. M. The stock market was unusually active for a Saturday. The trading in the two hours of business amounted to 233,195 shares of stock and $1,21,500 par value of bonds. The first prices were the lowest of the day, and the close was in most instances not far from the top.

Those who have paid attention to this subject are aware that the remarkable doctrine first propounded by Helmholtz removed all real doubt from the matter. It is to this eminent philosopher we owe an explanation of what at first seemed to be a paradox. He explained how, notwithstanding that the sun radiates its heat so profusely, no indications of the inevitable decline of heat can be as yet discovered.

An advertisement in yesterday's papers, signed by Mrs. T. Lynch, the dealer in jewelry at Union Square and Fourteenth Street, offered $1,000 reward for the return of a gold snuffbox stolen from her branch store, at 1,123 Broad-way, at an early hour Wednesday morning.

When the assassination of Mayor Harrison became known in the up-town hotel district last evening great sorrow was expressed on every hand. Those returning from the theatres stopped in front of the hotels and eagerly asked for information of the murder.

The auction sales announced for the present week are mainly in consequence of legal proceedings, and will be had at 111 Broadway. A sale by Mr. McQuillen of property in Lorillard Place, announced for Tuesday, has been withdrawn. Details of all sales follow:

Several papers in the upper part of the State are questioning The Montgomery Advertiser's statement that the members of the State Democratic Executive Committee at their recent meeting at Montgomery expressed themselves as unanimously in favor of the repeal of the Sherman act. These papers have no evidence to offer.
A number of Chicagoans are stopping at the Holland House. Proprietor Kinsley is in Chicago, but his partner, Gustav Bauman, was seen by a New-York Times reporter.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Carter Henry Harrison, Mayor of Chicago, was shot at his residence, 231 Ashland Boulevard, at 8:07 o'clock to-night, and died at 8:47 o'clock.
Wheat was unsettled early, but closed firm at 3/8@1/2c advance on the improved bank statement and firmer cables, with a moderate trade.

Gen. George W. Wingate made a motion before Judge Cullen in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday to continue a temporary injunction against Edward Sinnott to restrain him from maintaining a piggery at Albany and East New-York Avenues, Flatbush, within a short distance of the house of Wesley S. Black, 1,583 Eastern Parkway.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 28. -- That a county with a population of 350,000 persons should engage in an election having for its sole object the selection of a Sheriff with the same spirit and vigor that would be given to a Gubernatorial or even a Presidential campaign is certainly a novelty in politics; yet that is what is being done in Hudson County, N.J., at the present moment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Developments made late to-night go far toward indicating that Prendergast has had murder in his heart for several days. On Thursday afternoon of the present week he entered William Boyle's chop house on Calhoun Place and took a seat at a table occupied by W.A.S. Graham, the murdered Mayor's secretary, and another gentleman well known in local financial circles.

To the non-legal mind the term "accident" would appear to be easily defined, but the late Lord Chief Justice Cockburn thought not, and on several occasions insurance companies have sought a definition in the courts of law. It has been decided that a sunstroke is not an accident, but that injury to the spine through lifting a heavy weight is one.

Possibly in moments of enthusiasm and wassail the Bengal boar may have been overpraised. He has not a pleasant temper, his habits are open to unfavorable criticism, he may fail in his family relations -- but he has plenty of pluck. He will fight anything that comes in his way; not even a tiger daunts him, and, what is more, the tiger sometimes succumbs to the terrible tushes of the boar.
Mayor Gilroy was not only surprised, but very much affected, when he was told of the assassination of Mayor Harrison.

From The Shoe and Leather Reporter. The Hon. Ashbel P. Fitch, who is the Democratic candidate for Controller of New-York, is fully capable of filling an office in the gift of the people. There could not have been a better selection made. He is a gentleman of liberal education, of delightful personality, of unblemished character, and of superior abilities.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28. -- The game between Lehigh and the naval cadets this afternoon at the Naval Academy Grounds was closely contested. The first half began with Lehigh having the ball on their wedge. In opening they made ten yards, but the navy stayed their progress, and a sturdy encounter took place for a half hour. Then Izard, getting the ball, went over the line and the cadets scored.
The Democratic Club of the City of New-York gave a dinner last night to Collector James T. Kilbreth in its clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue.

The Badminton Clubs. -- A bright season is in prospect for the two leading Badminton clubs. The few months prior to the beginning of Lent will pass quickly, and as the season of penitence will be unusually long, extra efforts are going to be made to relieve the monotonous sameness of Lent. New-York society is not a religious body, although it caters freely to charities, and a long sigh goes up on Ash Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- Stockholders of the subsidiary lines of the Santa Fe system held their annual meetings in this city to-day. Four of such meetings were held, the first being that of the Chicago, Santa Fe and California Company. The Directors whose terms of office had expired were George C. Magoun, J.J. McCook, and Norman Williams.

The registration of voters in this city was completed yesterday. The total number of voters registered was 265,808, or 43,717 less than in 1892. A decrease in the registration was to be expected, as 1892 was a Presidential year. The number of voters registered yesterday was 58,183, or 20,721 more than on the last day of registration in 1892, and 5,669 more than on the last day of registration in 1830.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- It is a pleasure to be able to write about a dramatic enterprise -- I regret the commonplace if expressive word -- given in all its strength and integrity to the development of art in its highest expression. It is not an easy task to bring new things to a market rich in itself, self-provided, so to speak, and already satiated with more or less popular foreign novelties.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The World's Fair period in Chicago theatricals will probably come to an end with the present week. That the crowds are thinning out gradually is evident from the falling off in theatrical audiences the last few days. From this time on the playhouses will depend again upon local patronage.

One whole block is given over entirely to the gambling dens, that are, in all respects like the three that have been described. There is not a break in the row. It is in the very heart of the town, and on the main street. Here a song of gambling and defiance of the law is constantly being sung, so that the visitor must hear it.

Next to the elephant in general usefulness we should be inclined to place the "trotting ox" of India. "All Indian oxen can be trained to trot," says Mr. Lockwood Kipling. "The sloping quarter and straight hock may possibly account for something in their more horselike gait. One of the first thing's to strike a stranger is the hurrying ox." The rekla, a light two-wheeled cart drawn by a pair of oxen, cheap, speedy, and convenient.

J.K. Emmet, who is playing an imitation of his father in the Grand Opera House, is doing on the outside a part which is almost a direct antithesis of "Fritz in Prosperity." With his wife, who was six years ago Miss Daisy Kelly, of Penn Yan, N.Y., playing the leading female role, Mr. Emmet was starred before a "paper" house in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning as "Fritz in Adversity."

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- In front of the Harrison residence an eager, but unintrusive, crowd quickly gathered. Most of them were neighbors and personal acquaintances of the Mayor, but there was no unseemly pushing to get within the limits guarded by police officers. None sought admission to the house except such as were warranted by their intimacy with the family, or by their official relations with the victim of the murder.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

The guard, a tall veteran in blue uniform, at the railway station at New-Haven has often seen a, marvelouely-charming figure. There is no other face like this. The skin is of lilies and roses; the month is thoughtful; the eyes are limpid, humid, brilliant, and the abundant hair and beard are long and immaculately white.

"The house on the right," says Ivan, with some pride, "belongs to my brother, who is the richest man in the village. He has five grown-up sons, and therefore a large amount of land, four good horses and six cows; he lives well." "Does he drink?" we inquire.

In the light of recent events in New-Jersey there was never a ferryboat better named than the one that takes one to Gloucester. Fearless was plastered all over it. The ferry ticket read, "W. J. Thompson, Treasurer." Thompson selected the name for the boat, as representing his chief characteristic.

From The London Daily News. The wisdom of the Bengal peasant cultivators finds expression in proverbs, of which a collection has been made by a Babu in the Agricultural Department of that province. His appreciation of the outwardly revered Brahmin betrays itself incidentally in the maxim, "Rain and inundation disappear when south winds blow, like the Brahmin as soon as he has received his fee."

Of Gloucester City's cancerous sores the race course is that of which most has been written. That is the source of "Billy " Thompson's chief income. It is a bit of reclaimed marsh and river-front land where once the honest fishermen used to draw their seines and get the shad which "Billy " Thompson served his guests.

Whether the next Summer's camp of the American Canoe Association will be Held on Ball or fresh water shores is the question now being discussed by the members of the Atlantic Division.

The skies were full of sunshine for her, and so hard was it for her to find motes in the eyes of those who looked kindly upon her that we sometimes accused her of willfully closing her own, for never did an unkind word escape her lips; unkind thoughts seemed utterly repugnant to that generous mind.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The action of the Inter-collegiate Association apparently had it stimulating erect on the University of Pennsylvania to-day, for her eleven took advantage of its last public appearance before the Princeton game to roll up the big total of 82 to 0 against Lafayette. Bound football characterized the entire work of the Quakers. They lined up with a death and vim that kept the Easton rushers on a steady trot.

A mass meeting was held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. The big building was crowded to its utmost capacity. The stage was crowded, and the improvised seats, running up into the flies, were crowded. It was the largest meeting ever held in that big building.

Richard Croker, the leader of Tammany, is a man who seldom talks for publication. There is a great deal of curiosity just now as to how he regards the political situation. To satisfy this curiosity a reporter for The New-York Times called yesterday on Mr. Croker and asked him whether he would answer a few questions hearing on the political campaign now in progress.

SALINA, Kan., Oct. 28. -- The paper mill at this place has made from sunflower stalks several tons of paper, which will be sent to experts in the Bast. The paper is regarded as superior to straw paper, and marts a great departure in paper making. The raising of sunflowers will now be one of the Industries of the country. The mill is now buying sunflower, and proposes to matte sunflower paper a specialty.

APIA, Samoa, Oct. 9. -- The support given to King Malietoa's Government in suppressing Mataafa's rebellion has been followed up by further action on the part of the men-of-war in the harbor. For a long time two rival parties in Tutuila have waged war which finally necessitated the intervention of the Samoan Government.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 28. -- John Fritz, consulting engineer of the Bethlehem Iron Company, has resigned. For thirty-three years he was Superintendent, and was made consulting engineer only last June.

Chicago has a perfect right to congratulate itself upon the possession of a number of rich and public-spirited citizens, whose riches are disbursed liberally under the direction of their public spirit, and whose like, in their proportion to population and prosperity, cannot be found anywhere else in the world.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The triangular sweepstakes race for $8,000 between George Walbaum's Lamp-lighter, Christopher Smith's Yo Tambien, and Eugene Leigh's Clifford was postponed to-day till Monday. Owing to the heavy going Mr. Leigh refused to start Clifford, who does poorly in the mud.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23. -- Yale freshmen had their first opportunity to show their speed on the cinder track to-day at the annual Fall games. Perfect weather, a large and enthusiastic crowd, and efficient management all helped to make the event a success. No Yale records were broken, though Sheldon came dangerously near one in the broad jump, and Alling might have smashed another had he been preened in the bicycle race.

NASSAU, N.P., Oct. 17. -- The hurricane which passed over this island Oct. 11 left considerable damage in its wake. The direction of the wind was such as to force the water into the harbor, and the sea rose rapidly, until East and West Bay Streets, the principal business avenue of the city, were submerged.

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- Amherst's football eleven was badly defeated on the South End Grounds yesterday by the Boston Athletic Association team. The collegians failed to score against the Unicorn Weavers. When time was called the Boston men had rolled up 26 points. Six touch-downs were made, but only one goal was kicked. The Boston Athletic Association team played strongly in offensive work.

-- Mme. Tolstoi, wife of Count Tolstoi, received a diploma from the Moscow University at the age of seventeen, and was married when she was eighteen, her husband being twenty years older, and she is now, after thirty-one years of married life, the mother of nine living children, and her husband's potent aid in his literary labors.

LENOX, Mass., Oct 28. -- Many of the cottagers have remained here ratter longer than they intended on account of the delightful Indian Summer weather. The mercury has ranged from 40 to 60 during the week, and the skies have been so clear that driving parties have been as numerous as at any time this season. The cottagers who have four-in-hand coaches and drags have had them out often this week.

-- Next Friday afternoon, Nov. 3, a big benefit performance will be given at the Imperial Music Hall in aid of the sufferers from yellow fever, starvation, storm, and nakedness at Brunswick. Ga., and the sea islands. The benefit is to be under the auspices of the Citizens' Relief Committee, of which Dr. Willam T. Jenkins. Health Officer, is Secretary.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 28. -- Messrs. Frank and Harry Howard and their families were attending a performance at the French Opera House to-night when they received the terrible intelligence of Mr. Harrison's assassination. They immediately rushed to the telegraph office and sought particulars of the sad deed.

Black evening goods are much admired just now. A black Brussels net is bouretted with dots and knots of jet beads, and has three rows of jet spangles set four or five inches apart around the bottom. The spangles are oval, and are not sewed flat, but by one end, leaving the other loose, and they are put on in thick rolls an inch wide.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 28. -- The Elkwood Circle of Railway, composed of the cream of the social world of Union County, gave its initial ball of the season last night at Pinehurst, the home of Mrs. C.R. Hunt. Although but two years old, the club has grown with such rapidity that it has dwarfed into insignificance such hitherto well-known social clubs as the Minerva.
Gen. Martin T. Mcatahon, in the current number of Donahoe's Magazine, has written an article entitled "Why I Am a Democrat." Among other reasons he says:

From The Pittsburg Commercial. In New-Jersey the Democrats are being marshaled under a gang of race-track gamblers, who sought to make their vocation respectable by giving it the sanction of law. The Republicans look to decent and order-loving Democrats to assist them in their struggle for a pure ballot and good government.

Heedless of the exposure of the illegal registration in Gravesend and Coney Island which was made by The New-York Times a few days ago, the arrogant and tyrannical "boss" of the district, John Y. McKane, proceeded yesterday to enroll upon the books of registration the names of 6,218 more of his henchmen.

Isidor Straus is a fair type of the broadminded, public-spirited men through whom this city maintains its commercial supremacy and its metropolitan character. Knowing the entire alphabet of his business, quick to seize upon and improve opportunities of trade, and strictly attentive to the duties which an exacting position imposes upon him, his equipment covers a much wider range than is comprised within the limitations of shop.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Mayor Harrison's last day of life was spent at the World's Fair, as he would certainly have wished to have it had he foreseen, what his end was to be.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 28. -- During a religious festival in the Church of the Nativity, at Bethlehem, last evening, a trivial dispute arose which engendered a riot. A monk was shot and killed by some one armed with a revolver and two other persons were wounded. The dead monk and both wounded men were Italians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The annual report of Brig. Gen. R.N. Batehelder. Quartermaster General of the Army, shows that during the year $7,462,732 was expended in his department, leaving a balance of $1,221,161 from the appropriation. Gen. Batehelder says there has been a general dissatisfaction expressed with the boots and shoes now issued to soldiers, and after a careful study of the matter a new article, believed to be perfectly satisfactory, will be furnished.

There promises to be a grand procession of delinquent military gentlemen toward the parlors of Ludlow Street Jail in the near future unless they visit the Captain's office and settle promptly. There is hardly a regiment in the National Guard, except, perhaps, the Seventh and Twenty-third, which has not a large number of delinquents at the present time.

One of the most picturesque figures in one of the most historical portions of New-Jersey is Mrs. Sarah Van Nostrand of Millstone. On the 6th of September she celebrated her one hundred and fifth birthday, and surprised everybody by remaining up till midnight, until the last guest had left.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- The report circulated yesterday that Emperor William had summoned the King of Saxony to Berlin to consult with him as to the safety of consenting to a reduction of the army of one of the members of the Triple Alliance (Italy) to-day receives an emphatic denial from the Foreign Office.

The Rev. Dr. J.B. Nies, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Chrysostom, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, preached a vigorous sermon yesterday morning on the ring brigandage and the duty of voting citizens. Dr. Nies, who is son-in-law to Alexander B. Orr, as a rule refrains from sermons of the so-called "popular" type.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- It was nearly three hours after Mayor Harrison's death before the startling news reached the World's Fair Grounds. All the evening, beginning with the setting of the sun, high carnival had reigned inside the gates of Jackson Park. A hundred thousand of the day's visitors had remained to enjoy the last Saturday night of the fair.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Prendergast, the assassin of the Mayor of Chicago, attempted to see Gov. Altgeld last Friday for some reason. He called at the Governor's office in the Unity Building. The Governor was busy, and had left word with Charles J. Ford in the outer office that he was not to be disturbed.

The votaries of the great national game of England have at last a headquarters in New-York. On Saturday night, at a highly representative meeting of the willow-wielders of the metropolis, over which D.A. Munro, the President of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, presided, the Cricketers' Club was formally inaugurated.

The men who are responsible for loading the Democratic State ticket with the nomination of MAYNARD are believed to have counted upon the present form of ballot as a hindrance to independent voting. Wherever there is opposition to any regularly nominated candidate of a party the method of voting seems to be looked upon as presenting some difficulty to the voter who would give expression to his actual choice.

-- Mr. George W. Cable has been lecturing recently in Sati Francisco. In conversation with a newspaper man there the other day, he said that he thought the modern magazine presented the most encouraging indication of the maturing literary taste of the country, but in consequence of their great cost their number has not kept pace with the literary product.

Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt staid most of yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Republican State Committee in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He wore a brand-new smile and chatted with those who greeted him with most unusual vivacity.

Scene two of the last act of J.K. Emmet's new piece, "Fritz in Adversity." was given before a small but distinguished audience in Justice Koch's private room in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning.

In the latest issue of the Iron Age the price of the standard grade of tin plate in this market is reported to be $5.40 per box. In the same issue the price of this grade of tin plate at Liverpool, free on board for shipment, is reported by cable to be from $2.79 to $2.85 per box. Tho duty on a box of this tin plate, weighing 108 pounds, is $2.37.
ALBANY, Oct. 29. -- Albany City's four days' registration resulted in the enrollment of 27,513 names. This is within 250 of the total registration of last year.

Fleetwood Park is once again the centre of attraction for metropolitan horsemen. Mascot, the champion pacer, arrived from Buffalo on Friday last, and yesterday morning at day-break, Directum, the four-year-old trotting king, reached the old track at Morrisania, after a thirty-six hours' journey from Chicago. On Thursday next the two champions are matched for a stake of $5,000, mile heats, best three in five.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The story of Mayor Harrison's murder and statements of physicians occupied the attention of a Coroner's jury at the Harrison residence for an hour this morning. Excepting a technical description of the wounds, little was added to the information already at the disposal of the officers of the law.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- The State campaign in Massachusetts has not been in active and lively progress for three weeks, and yet there is at this moment a serious difference of opinion among thoughtful voters as well as in the ranks of the thick-and-thin political hustlers, as to the real issues involved.

AURORA, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- On Monday evening, Oct. 23, a very enjoyable vocal recital was given by Fraulein Vera Ress. The programme was historically arranged, and consisted of characteristic songs from the best-known classical composers. Fraulein Ress was assisted by Prof. Stevens, who played some beautiful selections from Beethoven and Chopin.

Methodist Episcopal churches were crowded yesterday at services in celebration of the one hundred and twenty-seventh anniversary of the establishment of American Methodism. Especially interesting was the day to the old John Street Methodist Church, which celebrated as well its one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary.
Ex-Judge Gunnins S. Bedford, Assistant District Attorney, died at 2 o'clock yesterday morning at the Windsor Hotel, where he had been ill five weeks.

MADRID, Oct. 29. -- Gen. Margalio, Commander in Chief of the Spanish troops at Melilla, was shot dead yesterday while leading a sortie against the Riffians. Seventy of his men were killed and 122 others were wounded.

The unhappy Casino is once more in trouble, and the trouble has come about in this way: When the financial deluge guaranteed by "The Rainmaker of Syria" turned out to be not so much of a shower, after all, and a widespread area of increased pecuniary aridity began once more to confront the stockholders, Receiver H. W. Cutter and his colleagues accomplished an ingenious plan of irrigation.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Stuart MacArthur delivered an interesting sermon last evening in the Calvary Baptist Church, West Fifty-seventh Street, on the political and religious aspects of the World's Fair at Chicago. He referred to the assassination of Mayor Harrison as the result of the doctrines of violence and anarchy which he sanctioned during his public career and promulgated through his paper, The Chicago Times.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- This was a Sunday of sincere mourning in Chicago. Flags at half-mast, the visible signs of grief, were to be seen everywhere. Portraits of Carter H. Harrison surrounded by mourning emblems hung in the windows of the newspaper offices and in other public places.

A congregation which filled the seats and obstructed the aisles of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, Marcy Avenue and Penn Street, Brooklyn, last night heard the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn, the well-known Roman Catholic priest, preach a dogmatic sermon from a platform where sat several Methodist ministers.
An attempt was made in Brooklyn last night to silence one of the most outspoken and determined foes of the Brooklyn "ring."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Within two years a complete change has come over the system of training an practiced in colleges and amateur athletic associations. Strange to say, from the time of the Olympic games there has always been perfect unanimity of opinion on matters pertaining to the diet of candidates for athletic honors in an arduons undertaking until as recent a time as the above date.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 29. -- Nine thousand people witnessed the first championship games of the Southern Amateur Athletic Association, organized during the past Summer, with four clubs from New-Orleans, two from Birmingham, one from Louisville, and one from San Antonio, here yesterday. There were eighty-five contestants, and the competitions were close.
