The action of Acting Rear Admiral Stanton in saluting the Brazilian insurgent Admiral Mello before Rio de Janeiro has been much discussed in naval circles and has called out several stories of old-time naval officers who have distinguished themselves in similar ways.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- The work on the football field the last week has been full of interest, not only on account of the shifting of the members of the team, but also on account of the recent developments regarding new plays and players. Secret practice has begun, and every afternoon the eleven rides in a barge to Soldiers' Field, returning after an hour to play with the second eleven.

BUFFALO, Oct. 29. -- It came to light late last night that on Monday a number of men most prominent in colonizing the First Ward were to be arrested. The ward is swarming with men brought there to vote against Alderman John White. A large number of these persons are men who, in all probability, are entitled to vote in other parts of the city.

Overconfidence on the part of the honest citizens of Brooklyn who are fighting its corrupt "ring" and frauds at the polls are the only things which may bring about the defeat of Charles A. Schieren, the anti-ring candidate for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The men who have the management of the fight in the House for the repeal of the purchasing clause in the Sherman act are doing their best to muster a force that will dispose of the bill in short order when it comes from the Senate. The bill has some comparatively unimportant amendments, which the House must agree to before it can go to the President.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- Eight members of the Royal Playhouse company gave a private performance of a new dance on the Opera House stage last Friday for the exclusive benefit of Emperor William. The only person present with the Emperor was Adjt. Hochberg.

Scarcely any one knows more about Carter H. Harrison than Victor F. Lawson, proprietor of The Chicago Daily News, who for many years was one of the late Mayor's most persistent political opponents. But Carter H. Harrison, as Mr. Lawson said yesterday at the Gilsey House, "was a pleasant man to quarrel with."
FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 29. -- The Flushing Field Club furnished the scalps in the game with the Metropolitan Insurance Company eleven yesterday. Seven hundred persons cheered the good plays.
The comment yesterday morning of the Chicago Tribune on the murder of Mayor HARRISON is in the same line as that we ventured to suggest. It says:

ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- The most cheerful bit of news affecting local securities during the past week was the declaration of the usual quarterly dividend by the Troy City Railway. Upon this announcement the bid price for the stock advanced 5 per cent., to 85. The usual quarterly dividends were also declared on Hudson River Telephone of 3/4 of 1 per cent., and on Albany Railway of 1 1/2 per cent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Following are the editorial expressions of the Chicago press this morning upon the assassination of the Mayor:

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- The trial of gamblers in Hanover has stirred society here, and many persons are trembling for fear they will be summoned to testify or be mentioned in the evidence. The general public felt little interest in the trial until the presiding Judge lowered the dignity of his court by causing one or the witnesses to repeat there all the tricks of the card sharper.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Considering the number of men who have been unable to participate in the game, the 'Varsity team has done admirable work during the past week. Princeton was beginning to congratulate herself on the fewness of men injured, when Hall was forced to retire, and since that time only a portion of the team has been able to play at any one time.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- One of the boldest jobs ever done by sneak thieves was committed at the West Shore ticket office here last night, between 11 and 12 o'clock. The ticket agent, who also acts as night telegraph operator, noticed that the block-system signal was turned at "danger."
Replies to queries addressed to The New-York Times, which have appeared Monday morning under the foregoing heading, will hereafter be published in the Sunday edition of The Times.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 29. -- State Treasurer Wilbur H. Burnite recently made an effort to treat Ambassador Thomas F. Bayard to a taste of Delaware peaches, in his far-away English home, but the attempt was not entirely successful. The varieties of fruit selected were Fox's Seedling, Walker's Variegated Free, and the Prize, and each peach was carefully wrapped in tissue paper.

The Attacks on Mr. Wharton. -- Several uncalled for attacks in words have been made upon the Newport Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which was organized by Edward R. Wharton. Mr. Wharton is one of the most public-spirited of the fashionable wealthy residents of Newport, and in his many efforts for the public weal of the City by the Sea he has had the unanimous badilng of the fashionable colony.

The funeral of Mario Bragaldi, artist, engineer, and architect, was held yesterday from 42 Union Square. The services, which were held in the parlor of the house, were very simple. There was no clergyman present. Brief addresses were made by Editor Riverri of II Progreso Americano, John Caponi, and Engineer Jagiani.

The Lewis Avenue Congregational Church, Lewis Avenue and Madison Street, was crowded last evening when the Rev. R.J. Kent delivered a sermon on "The Christian Citizen." His text was, "Whatsoever you do, do all to the glory of God." Among the many points he made in his discourse were the following:

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 29. -- There has long been bad blood between the union and non-union glassblowers at Wellsburg, and, when the Riverside Glass Works broke away from the union two weeks ago, this feud was intensified. Among the non-union men recently employed there was Hugh Gordan of Philadelphia.

GRAND RAPID, Mich., Oct. 29. -- It is announced hereby personal advices from Washington that the Hon. Edwin F. Uhl of this city has been tendered and accepted the Assistant Secretaryship of State, to succeed Josiah Quincy. He is now in Washington. Mr. Uhl is one of the most popular and influential Democrats in the State, served two terms as Mayor of this city, and was delegate at large to the Cleveland Convention last Fall.
The Rev. Dr. Rees F. Alsop, pastor of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Livingston Streets, Brooklyn, delivered a vigorous sermon last evening on "City Government."
The Cumberland Street Presbyterian Church was crowded last evening when the pastor, the Rev. G.N. Makely, preached on the duties of citizens.

In the piping times of peace promotion is proverbially slow; and yet, thanks to the retirement system, with its age list and disability list, and to other causes, it is never quite stagnant. Just now it promises activity, as the approaching retirements of Adjt. Gen. WILLIAMS and Brig. Gen. CARLIN will set the current in motion.

Various estimates were made yesterday upon the registration. The Tammany men said that it was all their way, and the Republicans figured it out to their advantage. In 1892 the total registration in this county was 309,625. The total vote was 284,984, which was a faling off of 24,641, or about 8 per cent.

"Arts and Crafts Essays," edited by William Morris, (New-York: Charles Scribner's Sons,) is a series of papers written by members of the Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society of London and published for the purpose of stimulating a liking for good artisanship and encouraging a true revival of decorative art.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Ex-Representative George Fred Williams of Massachusetts, who has been in this city on a short visit, and who is about to return to his State and resume speaking in the campaign for John E. Russell for Governor, talked to-day about the financial situation, his remarks being provoked by some of Mr. Sherman's criticisms of the condition of the Treasury under a Democratic Administration.

Of all left-handed compliments as to progenitors, if they were Furitans, the one Miss Earle uses on her title page is the most significant: "Let us thank God for having given us such ancestors, and let each successive generation thank Him not less fervently for being one step further from them in the march of ages."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28. -- There was more speculative interest taken in the local market this week than there has been for some months past, and the volume of business showed a large increase. The Westing-house group of stocks made the greatest gains. Air Brake advanced 2 1/4 points, Philadelphia Gas 1 3/4, and Electric 2 1/4.

The Christian Reformed Church, of which the Rev. H. Iserman is pastor, began its existence at 21 Bank Street yesterday morning. The place does not look much like a church, but it is, nevertheless, one of the most interesting houses of worship in New-York.

Prof. Felix Adler had a very large congregation in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning, when he spoke on "The Ethics of Hard Times." His sermon was forceful, analytical, and, in many parts, particularly applicable to the audience he was addressing.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $6,146,700. The banks now hold $48,787,475 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages snow an increase in loans of $3,785,100, an increase in specie of $846,000, an increase in legal tenders of $8,194,400, an increase in deposits of $11,574,800, and a decrease in circulation of $79,700.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- The arrival of a new installment of the Blaschka glass flowers always stimulates interest in the wonderful collection at the Agassiz Museum. Here for nearly two years the beautiful specimens of iridescent glass have attracted crowds to Cambridge. As one of the professors has remarked in private: "The Blaschka flowers are evidently the most attractive feature of the university.

When on Saturday evening before one of the greatest meetings ever assembled in the Academy of Music of Brooklyn, Mr. GAYNOR and Mr. Low -- a Democratic and a Republican independent -- spoke for the election of Mr. SCHIEREN, what was the burden of their argument and appeal? It was that the present Mayor had been the tool of men who had induced or compelled him to betray the trust reposed in him.

VIENNA, Oct. 29. -- It was stated this morning that the Emperor was considering Count Taaffe's resignation, and still hoped that the Austrian Premier would be able to effect an understanding with the coalition of German Liberals, Conservatives, and Poles. The Emperor presided at the Cabinet council this afternoon.

There has been a suspicion for some time, in well-posted naval circles, that the designs of the new cruisers Detroit, Montgomery, and Marblehead, have not been a success, but it is only within the last few days that the facts concerning these cruisers have become known.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- "I knew Thomas Prendergast very well." said Brother Baldwin of St. Patrick's Academy this morning. "When I read the awful story in the papers this morning I recognized in Prendergast one of our former pupils. I was not surprised that he committed so infamous a crime.

CoL Alexander S. Bacon has discovered that 200 persons registered from 19 Atlantic Avenue Friday, and that 75 registered from 15 Atlantic Avenue Saturday. In order to make sure that all was proper he visited the two places and made inquiries of the reputable men in the neighborhood.

The trades unions' conference met again yesterday at 275 East Tenth Street to hear the reports of the delegates in regard to the prospects of the election of the candidates of the conference for delegates to the State Constitutional Convention. The delegates generally reported that there were good prospects of the candidates receiving a large vote in every district.

The students in the department of architecture of the School of Mines, Columbia College, were rejoiced last week when they saw a notice posted up on the bulletin board by the head of the department requesting all students who intended training for any of the athletic teams or trying for positions in the Musical Society to consult him before beginning work in any of these organizations.

"Does it not interest you to know that the government of your city is in the control of a machine, with the lever in a hand that draws its life-blood from the blackened heart of a conscienceless boss, who prays before the devil's throne and ignores the God of heaven? "

Prize Fighter "Jim" Corbett at an early hour yesterday morning strode into Martin's restaurant on Broadway, accompanied by his brother Joseph, who has yet to win his laurels in the roped arena, and "Billy" Delaney, his trainer. They ordered sapper. While waiting for the meal, "Jim" Hall walked in with Tim Cronin and another variety actor. Hall is Mitohell's friend and sparring partner.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 30. -- Six persons were badly burned by an explosion of gun-powder in Charles S. West's sporting goods store, 99 Main Street, about 6 o'clock this evening. The store was wrecked and set on fire.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Miss Annie Howard, who was to have become the bride of Mayor Harrison, is dangerously ill, and there are great fears that she will never quite recover from the shock she has sustained. She was completely prostrated. When the Mayor lay wounded, his first cry was for "Annie."
The fitting up of the big American coastwise steamer. El Cid, as a warship for the Brazilian Government has commenced in earnest.

The railroad business of this country has made a decided advance toward prosperity within the past month. Earnings from freight as well as passenger traffic have increased each succeeding week to a point that enables a fair proportion of the roads to figure an excess over the unusually large earnings in October of last year.

WEST POINT, Oct. 30. -- The cadets' last outdoor drills this season took place on the plains this afternoon. Mortar and siege battery, sea coast battery, and light artillery drills will not be held again this year. Cavalry drills will be held in the riding hall, with an occasional trip over the mountains when the weather shall be favorable.

At Koster Bial's Music Hall last evening, Mr. Oscar Hammerstein's one-act operetta, entitled "The Koh-i-Noor," was produced. Before the performance Mr. Hammerstein appeared in front of the curtain and made a speech, which began thus: "It is not usual for an author to come out before his work is performed, but it is safer."

S.H.H. Clark, Oliver W. Mink, and E. Ellery Anderson, the three receivers of the Union Pacific Railroad, have been in conference in this city for some days past. They propose, it is said, to make a rigid investigation of the affairs of the entire Union Pacific system, and their policy will be to cut down operating expenses as much as possible.

Despondency over the outcome of a suit involving the ownership of a zinc mine at Joplin, Mo., caused Samuel C. Cook, one of the proprietors of the mine, to commit suicide last night in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, in the presence of his wife.
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Sir John Lubbock, banker, author, and member of Parliament, said to-day in an interview concerning the financial condition of the United States:

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- A woman was executed in this city to-day, being the first woman to Buffer the death penalty bare since Berlin was made a Kaiserstadt. The last woman to suffer the extreme penalty of the law before this was executed in 1846. The victim to-day was Emilie Zillman, nee Kuehne, of Hammer, Prussian Silesia.

This morning The New-York Daily Times consists of TWELVE PAGES. Every newsdealer is bound to deliver the paper in its complete form, and any failure to do so should be reported at the Publication Office.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30. -- The story was made public here to-day of the illegal imprisonment of a sane man in the Broadmoor Insane Asylum, near London, England Moses Mauerberger, a brother of the victim, is employed as clerk in a Pittsburg dry goods store.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 30. -- The Ericsson torpedo vessel Destroyer, which is now at this port, is under orders to proceed to New-York to-morrow. The Destroyer has been purchased of the Ericsson Coast Defense Company by Flint Co. of New-York City.

The anti-Maynard movement projected at the Cooper Union mass meeting of professional and business men last Thursday night was put into working condition yesterday, when Wheeler H. Peckham completed the list of the Committee of Fifty which he was authorized to appoint, and called the committee to his office for its first meeting.
Six hundred thousand dollars of Brooklyn City bonds were sold by Mayor David A. Boody and Controller Halsey Corwin yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- The large amount of long stock sold to-day, together with a raid made this afternoon by the traders, caused a reaction in the market. This was also helped along by rumors of a hitch over the silver repeal bill. The short interest was largely increased, and the market closed heavy.

There is one liquor dealer in Brooklyn who has contributed to the campaign fund of the "ring," and yet proposes to vote against the "ring" candidates. For obvious reasons his name is withheld. Its publication would undoubtedly result in the revocation of his license. To a reporter for The New-York Times this liquor dealer said, yesterday, as he pulled a card from his pocket:

MADRID, Oct. 30. -- A dispatch from Melilia states that the Riffians late yesterday resumed their attack on the Spaniards. The fighting was desperate on both sides, but the Spaniards successfully maintained their positions.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday, went into executive session, and signed the provisional budget for 1894 after pruning it down by striking out about $1,000,000. There was no contention.

SAN JOSE, Oct. 20. -- It Is no breach of confluence to say that there has not been at any time much foundation for the popular belief that Weeks would eventually be liberated. Nor is it out of place to say that, had the authorities not seen the statement of the case set forth in The New-York Times, the arrest of Weeks would never have been accomplished as it was.

BUFFALO, Oct. 30. -- Somebody has been work ing Erie O. Van Brooklin's game in the Buffalo Board of Public Works. Mayor Bishop's office was the scene or an investigation this morning based on specific charges made by Expert Hamilton and addressed to Mayor Bishop as follows:

The Brooklyn Eagle, which until yesterday stood on neutral ground between Mayor Boody and Charles A. Schleren, the Republican reform candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon joined The New-York Times in denouncing the ringsters, who hope to nullify the will of the honest voters of Brooklyn, in a long and vigorous editorial, of which the following is a part:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Unconditional repeal has passed the Senate and is practically an accomplished fact.
It has taken but a few hours for the New-York "crank" of the deadly species to emulate his Chicago prototype who shot down Mayor Carter H. Harrison.

The neglect of the Senate Judiciary Committee in dealing with, the appointment of Mr. HORNBLOWER to fill the vacancy on the bench of the Supreme Court of the United. States is thoroughly discreditable. The appointment was made many weeks ago. long before the meeting of the court for the important term that opened in October.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- At the special meeting of the City Council at 10 o'clock to-day arrangements were made for the funeral of Mayor Harrison. The Council Chamber, which was lavishly decorated with the mournful insignia of death, was crowded, nearly all the Aldermen being present. The gallery was filled with citizens, and prominent men were in the reserved galleries to the righ't and left of the Chair.

Through its President, Darwin R. James, the New York Board of Trade and Transportation has forwarded to the Senators and Congressmen from this State a letter urging them to support the Torrey Bankruptcy bill.

-- Judge Brentano of Chicago delivered a decision in the quo warranto proceedings against the Lake Street elevated road yesterday. It was upon the motion of the company's attorneys to vacate the order granting leave to file the information calling in question the legality of the road's existence. Judge Brentano ordered that the proceedings be abated and the information vacated.

-- William Lawrence Vennard, a member of the wholesale drug firm of McKesson Robbins, died Saturday at his home. 156 West Seventv-fourth Street. His wife, who is still living, is a daughter of Mr. McKesson. Mr. Vennard was a Director of the Bowery Savings Bank. Vice President of the New-York College of Pharmacy, and a member of the Union League Club.

An echo of the disgraceful scenes enacted a week ago last Saturday at the instigation of John J. McGarry and his followers from the Tenth Ward at the meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club was heard at another meeting of the club last night.

There is an exhibition at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, 366 Fifth Aveuae, near Thirty-fourth Street, a private collection of handsome Oriental carpets and rugs belonging to Halm Vidal of Constantinople. These include carpets of Ispahan. Herese, senna, Cashmere, Bokhara, Cabistan, Khorassan, Sirak, Shiraz, Khiva, Titlis, Beloochistan, Herat, Shirvan, Samarkand, Yourook, Iran, and Koniah.

At Charles A. Schieren's headquarters, in the Germania Bank Building, Brooklyn, yesterday a reporter for The New-York Times was told that the police were doing all in their power to intimidate storekeepers who had Mr. Schieren's lithographs on exhibition in their show windows.
The White Caps of the Brooklyn ring, made desperate by the imminent prospect of the defeat of their candidate for Mayor, have invoked the aid of the hired bravo with his pistol and his bludgeon.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 30. -- Sir John Abbott, ex-Premier of Canada, died at 9 o'clock this evening. His end was peaceful.

The bill for the repeal of the purchasing clause of the act of 1890 on which the Senate voted yesterday was by no means so satisfactory as the bill sent to that body by the House. The latter, or Wilson bill, as it is usually termed, was in every regard a clear, complete, and statesmanlike measure.

Out of respect to the memory of Assistant District Attorney Gunning 8. Bedford, who died on Sunday, no business will be transacted in the Court of General Sessions to-day. The District Attorney and his assistants, and Recorder Smyth, Judges Fitzgerald, Cowing, and Martine, the clerks of the courts, and a number of lawyers met in Part I. yesterday, when formal announcement of the death of ex-Judge Bedford was made by Mr. Nicoll.

The funeral of Mrs. Harry Spencer Cram, who died in London on Sept. 28, took place yesterday morning at 11 o'clock in Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth Street. The services, which were fully choral, were conducted by the Rev. Dr. William H. Vibbert. the rector of the chapel, assisted by the Rev. H. Bauman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Secretary Herbert has been advised of a condition of things in the ships of the new navy that The New-York Times had discovered before him. and it gives him a degree of anxiety greater than any matter to which his attention has been directed since he became Secretary of the Navy.

Offers a reward of $10 for proof sufficent for conviction in any case of fraudulent registration in the City of Brooklyn. This offer is good for the first one hundred cases presented. Special arrangements will be made for further cases.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Lydia Bloss committed suicide at her residence, Whitehead Grove, Chelsea, on Friday last. She shot herself with a revolver. Her death has led to the discovery that her suicide was linked with that of the Hon. Frederick Charles Howard, brother of the Earl of Effingham, who on Thursday last shot and killed himself at his residence, 34 Evelyn Terrace.

The home of Chevalier Louis Contencin, ex-Consul to the Two Sicilies, at 161 East Eightieth Street, was the scene of much joy and gayety last evening. The occasion was the marriage of Miss Jennie Francis Regis Contencin to Walter Hurlburt Hooker, the well-known clubman.

WINAMAC, Ind., Oct. 30. -- The Rev. J. Orton, a Presbyterian minister of this city, was publicly horsewhipped to-day. Meri Moss and John Thompson, aged eighteen and nineteen, respectively, were laughing and talking during last night's service in the church, and Mr. Orton called them by name three times, and finally ordered them to leave the church.
It was announced last night that George Gould's fine steam yacht Atalanta bad been Bought by agents of the Brazilian Government. The price paid for the Atalanta IB said to have teen $250,000.

Capt. Brown of the steamer Colerldee, which reached this port yesterday from Rio de Janeiro, brought the Important Information that the grandaon of the late Emperor Dom Pedro, a Prince of the house of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, is reported to have Balled for Brazil from Europe on the powerful Brazilian Ironclad Riachuelo.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- In his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, Edwin Stewart, Paymaster General of the Navy, says:
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Yarrow Co., the torpedoboat builders at Poplar, have receivers cable order from Flint Co. of New-York for a sixty-foot Yarrow torpedo boat.

It is only necessary to note the names of the Committee of Fifty appointed in accordance with the resolution of the Cooper Union meeting to carry on the work of opposing the election of Judge MAYNARD to be assured that there is nothing partisan in this movement, especially so far as the lawyers are concerned.

-- Dance Dates Set. -- The dates of the Assembly dances, which figure among the most brilliant balls of the season, have been set for Jan. 4 and Feb. 2. The dances will take place in the Madison Square Assembly Rooms. Mrs. Astor. Mrs. F. Brockholst Cutting, Mrs. J.G.K. Duer, and Mrs, Charles A. Post have the arrangements for the two dances in hand.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A meeting of the Executive Committed of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee was held to-day. W.B. Thompson of Michigan, formerly Superintendent of the Railway Postal Service, was elected as Chairman. The officers were authorized to open headquarters in this city, and as soon aa a desirable and convenient location can be secured work will begin upon a "campaign of education" for the elections of 1894.

The residents of Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, who own property beyond Myrtle Avenue, would be grateful to the "ring" if they could be told what was done with $17,500 of their money, which was collected some time ago to pay for paving Clinton Avenue, from Myrtle Avenue.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Oct. 30 -- P.M. The stock market was heavy nearly all day, the result of sales to realize profits, and of renewed, activity on the part of the bear leaders. The latter contend that the recent advance has fully discounted the repeal of the Silver-Purchase law, and that a reaction is due.

-- Long years ago there was a veritable Mother Goose residing in Boston. Her maiden name was Elizabeth Foster, and in 1692 she married Isaac Goose, a widower with several children, and became the mother of six. A writer in poet lore says she delighted to care for the many grand-children, and sang to the babies numerous songs and ditties that she knew.

WOLFBOROUGH, N.H., Oct. 30. -- At East Alton the farm buildings owned by Sewall T. Roberts and occupied by Enoch Durgin, were burned last evening, with twenty tons of hay, two hogs, farming utensils, and a considerable portion of the household furniture. In attempting to save some of the furniture, Mr. Durgin was overcome by smoke and was burned to death.

The receivers of the Madison Square Bank engaged an office yesterday at West Broadway and Leonard Street, where they will pursue their work at much less expense than is involved in the rental of the bank building, at Broadway and Twenty-fifth Street, which will be turned over to the owner as soon as possible.
Wheat was unsettled and dull, with the early market up a trifle with Europe, but reacting on the increased supplies, and closed at 5/8@1/2c loss for the day.

The long controversy over the right of the city to maintain a dumping board on the west side of Pier 12, in the East River, is apparently drawing to a close, as the Court of Appeals, in a decision just announced, has declared that the dumping board is a public nuisance, which the private owners of the pier are entitled to have removed.

LONDON, Oct 30. -- English holders of Americans took advantage of higher prices cabled from New-York to realize, and Paris also sent selling orders. Amsterdam bought Missouris, but sold Atchisons. Louisvilles were well supported.

Mongolia Andrews, who has been bothering the Gould family for a year or more, was arrested yesterday and locked up at Police Headquarters. He has been hanging around the office in the Western Union Building for over a week, and, fearing he might work some mischief, Superintendent Byrnes took him into safe keeping. Edwin Gould told this story of the man's doings last night:

The sale of seats for the opening night in Abbey's Theatre, at Thirty-eighth Street and Broadway, took place yesterday afternoon in the Casino and was attended by a large number of people, many of whom, however, were speculators or had come to buy for others.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- With all the manifestations of sorrow, and regret that can be shown by a great city to its murdered Executive, the remains of Carter H. Harrison will be borne on Wednesday to the beautiful city of the dead on the northern outskirts of the city. By general consent, although there is no one in authority to issue the necessary proclamation, business throughout the city will be generally suspended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The offers of silver to the Treasury Department to-day were 737,000 ounces, and of this amount 50,000 were purchased at 70 cents on ounce. The same price was tendered for the remainder.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I. Oct 30. -- Lester A. Scofield and David J. Jones, who made the complaints against District Attorney Fitzgerald and Excise Commissioner George Van Name, charging them with violations of the election laws, have been arrested on charges of perjury. The complaints were made by the District Attorney.

-- The board in charge of athletics at the University of Pennsylvania has passed resolutions in which the following language is used: "We deem and consider the rules adopted by that association, (the intercollegiate Football,) at its meeting on Oct. 12, 1893, unconstitutional, void, and of no effect, and that the Captain of the football team be, and he is hereby instructed to act accordingly.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Patrick Eugene Prendergast's indictment followed quickly after his crime. Inspector Shea appeared before the Grand Jury soon after 10 o'clock this morning and the indictment was found immediately afterward.

-- Among the rugs and carpets that will be sold to-morrow and the next four days at the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street, is a famous antique silk rug, 8 feet 3 inches wide by 9 feet 5 inches long, said to have been made by the daughter of the Shah Abbas over 150 years ago. The central panel is diamond-shaped, with a white background, emblematic of purity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Those who bought City Railway the fore part of last week around 300 concluded to take their profits to-day. They sold, offering the stock at 335 at the opening. The stock fell to 330 at the close. West Chicago opened at 155 1/2, advanced to 157, and then receded to 154 1/2. The first quotation on North Chicago was 259.

Several hundred persons by whom Scotland is held in reverence and affection gathered in Chickering Hall last evening for a Halloween celebration under the auspices of the New-York Scottish Society. Andrew Carnegie, Honorary President of the Society, presided. Wallace Bruce, lately United States Consul at Edinburgh, delivered an address on "Scotland and Scotsmen."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- With monster bullets has come the necessity for handling great weights. The engineer officers in charge of the coast defense guns have been confronted with the problem of bringing huge projectiles from the magazine to the breech of the big guns. With shells weighing 1,000 pounds apiece, such as the projectiles for the 12-inch rifles, the employment of mechanical power for their speedy handling is obvious.
CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- Orders have been received here for the yacht Feiseen to be immediately altered tot war service in accordance with plans received from New-York.

Under the new law the terms of office of the present Commissioners of Electrical Control expire to-morrow and Mayor Gilroy can appoint their successors. The present Commissioners are Walton Storm and Theodore Moss. Democrats, and Jacob Hess, Republican. They are all willing to be reappointed, but the Mayor is not ready as yet to say what he is going to do about it.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 30. -- Under date of Oct. 23 last. Senator Sherman addressed a letter to Secretory Carlisle, in which be asked the Secretary to advise him upon the following points:
SANDUKY, Ohio. Oct. 30. -- The Sandusky Register, edited by L.F. Mack, a member of lone standing in the Associated Press, has the following editorial article in to-day's issue:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- John Dechert, aged sixty years, committed suicide by hanging, at his home, 865 Preston Street, this morning. In the same dwelling on June 26 last, Charles P. Hower, a Southern railroad promoter, ended his life by inhaling illuminating gas. An investigation of Hower's death and legal contests over his property revealed that he had had three wives, and it was alleged that Jessie Mordaunt, wife No. 3, was living with Dechert.

The Cathedral Dramatic Club gave a matinee performance yesterday in Daly's Theatre for the benefit of the now seminary at Dunwoodie. The theatre was crowded by the clergy of the diocese and the prominent Catholic families of the city.

The contract was signed yesterday for a noteworthy exchange of city real estate through the agency of Messrs. Charles E. Schuyler and Andrew F. Gilsey. The contracting parties are the Gilsey estate on the one side and Mr. Hug-to Lamb on the other. On behalf ou the latter is to be given the four-story brownstone dwelling 247 West Seventy-second Street, 25 by 70 by 100, on the stated basis of $90,000 value.

The University Athletic Club has decided to accept the management of the Yale-Princeton Thanks-giving Day football game in this city. As yet the grounds have not been selected, but the chances of the contest taking place on grounds other than Manhattan field are very slim. There was some talk of the players going over to Eastern Park, in Brooklyn, but the scheme has practically been abandoned.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The market was droopy all day except for Lehigh Valley, which advanced 3 per cent., to 39 1/2, and closed with that bid. The utter absence of stock for sale forced up the price when any buying orders came in. Reading was dull and the preference bonds were entirely neglected. Pennsylvania failed to sympathize with the general market, and held about 51 1/2.
PORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Oct. 30. -- Capt. Alfred Hedberg of Company I, Fifteenth Infantry, was shot by First Lieut. J.A. Maney. Regimental Quartermaster of the same regiment, at this post to-day.

With the passage of the repeal bill in the Senate the country enters upon a new financial policy. We have passed through a period of fifteen years of darkness and error. We defied the teachings of experience and scouted the warnings of wisdom. We attempted the impossible on a magnificent scale.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- In harmony with the World's Fair city's sorrow came the closing of the World's Columbian Exposition to-day, as directed by the United States Congress. At sunset, 4:45 o'clock, the colors of all nations, which had been flying at half mast since sunrise on Sunday, were lowered together, as they were unfurled within sight of President Cleveland at noon, May 1.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

Otto Kempner's name will not figure on any official ballots issued by the Police Board unless a specially-convened General Term of the Supreme Court decides otherwise. As this contingency is exceedingly slight. It is safe to say that Mr. Kempner and the other independent candidates will not have a place on the regular ballots.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Despite repeal and its influences, a slump in local securities has occurred, simultaneously with the break on the New-York Board. It is not improbable that the depressing state of financial affairs to-day is due to the closing of the exhibition and the mournful crowds about the City Hall, where the body of Mayor Harrison lies in state.

The manager of the "Utopia Restaurant." Mr. T. Edmond Gould as it is printed on the bill of fare, or "Tom" Gould as he is better known among certain people of this town, appeared before Justice Hogan in the Jefferson Market Police Court late yesterday afternoon in a preliminary examination on a charge of assault preferred by William P. Rahner, lately Mr. Gould's bartender.

The General Theological Seminary in Chelten Square entered upon the seventy-sixth year of its history yesterday. In addition to the usual matriculation exercises, the New school year marked the fifth anniversay of the memorial chapel of the Good Shepherd and the feast in commemoration of founders and benefactors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- A detailed account of what has been accomplished in ordnance for the army during the past fiscal year is contained in the annual report which Brig. Gen. D.W. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance, has submitted to the Secretary of War. During the year the Ordnance Department expended $3,702,202, leaving in the Treasury $4,348,541 to the credit of its appropriation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The funeral of Mayor Harrison will take place at 11 o'clock tomorrow from the Church of the Epiphany, at Ashland Boulevard and Adams Street. An hour before that time the remains will be taken from the City Hall to the church, accompanied by the same guard of honor which to-day brought them from the house.

The Atlas Line steamship Ailsa, which yesterday arrive a from the West Indies, reports a trying experience in a hurricane encountered on Oct. 9, during the vessel's outward passage. A gale arose on the morning of that date, and before noon had developed into a furious hurricane. At 2 o'clock in the afternoon a wave dashed over the deck of the steamship and carried overboard a cattle pen which contained several fine Alderney cows.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Postmaster General Bissell has completed and sent to the Secretary of the Treasury his estimates of appropriations required for the Postal Service for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1895. The estimates aggregate $90,399,485, as against $84,004,314, the amount of the present appropriations. The estimated revenues for the coming fiscal year aggregate $84,427,748, leaving an estimated deficiency for that year of $5,971,736.

Six more United States merchant steamers have been purchased by the Government of Brazil for use as war ships -- the powerful El Rio of the Morgan Line and the Advance, Finance, Allianca, Seguranca, and Vigilancia of the recent United States and Brazil Mail Steamship Company.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Capt. Hinkey of the Yale eleven to-day announced what all Yale has been dreading for a fortnight, the baginning of the secret football practice for the eleven. It will commence on Thursday, and from that time no one but the coaches, the first and second elevens, and a few rubbers will be allowed within the gates of the Yale field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Assassin Prendergast found but little sympathy from his fellow-prisoners to-day when, upon his request, he was permitted to walk around the big cage, guarded by a jailer on each side. He began to talk to the guards, confining his remarks to matters connected with the structure of the jail and its population.

The Commercial Cable Company of this city received yesterday its ribbon of award from the World's Columbian Exposition for the best system of working ocean telegraph cables and for the Cuttriss improved cable and telegraphic apparatus.

Walter L. Pratt, the six-year-old son of Willard Pratt, a policeman attached to the Bergen Street (Brooklyn) mounted squad, and living at 601 Fifth Avenue, that city, was run over last evening by a trolley car near his home. He was almost instantly killed.

Police Justice Hogan, sitting in the Jefferson Market Police Court, showed yesterday to Ballet Alsop Borrowe that mercy, whose quality is not strained, droppeth like the gentle rain from heaven upon the "tenderloin" beneath.
NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The Putnam Woolen Company of Putnam, which shut down six months ago, has resumed work in all its departments.
Mayor Boody, in his public speeches, has, from time to time, directed attention to points of difference between his administration and that of Seth Low.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The marriage of Miss Mae Clagett to Mr. Clifford Perin of Cincinnati took place this evening at the residence of the bride's mother. The family being in mourning, only the two immediate families were present. The drawing rooms were decorated with chrysanthemums. The front room, in which the ceremony took place, was decorated with immense clusters of white chrysanthemums and tall palms.

A public reception was tendered to Charles A. Schieren by Brooklyn real estate dealers at the Real Estate Exchange at noon yesterday. Leonard Moody and Charles J. Edwards introduced Mr. Schieren to the visitors. There were 2,000 real estate dealers and their friends who took part in the reception.

The Rev. Dr. Henry A. Stimson, formerly pastor of the Plymouth Congregational Church, St. Louis, was installed pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle last night. Dr. Stimson has been in charge of the church since last Spring, but the installation services were unavoidably postponed till last night. The pulpit was decorated with palms and cut flowers.

The American Casualty Insurance Company, which was operated for several years under the direction of Beecher, Schenck Co., has changed managers by the election of Gen. Henry W. Slooum of Brooklyn as President, and by the appointment of John E. Searles, John H. Flagler, and George F. Sheldon as trustees for the interests heretofore carried by Beecher, Schenck Co.

If the present fine weather continues Thursday, the great match between Mascot, the pacer champion, and Directum, the champion stallion trotter, at Fleetwood Park, cannot fail to result in the most sensational race ever witnessed on the trotting track.

-- Fred C. Graves of the Springfield Bicycle Club rode from Springfield to Boston and back in 17 hours. 28 minutes and 30 seconds. He left Worthington Street. Springfield at midnight, and reached the Boston Athletic Association Clubhouse at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning. He then rested for forty-two minutes and arrived at Springfield at 5:28:20 o'clock last evening.

No one is working more zealously in behalf of George C. Coffin, the candidate for the Assembly in the Twenty-third District, than William B. Ellison, the present Assemblyman. Some of the Republicans who are striving to elect Judson Lawson are circulating the story that Mr. Ellison has been "turned down" by Tammany Hall in the hope of securing votes for their candidate in that way.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- "Charley" Mitchell and "Jim" Hall arrived here at 10 o'clock last night from New York. Asked as to the status of his match with Corbett, Mitchell replied that he still thought the match was on, and that he was prepared to fight Corbett anywhere, at any time, for any money. "I am dead in earnest,." said Mitchell, "and I think that Corbett is.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Messrs. Bierman, Heidelberg Co. have closed their branch here, recalled their salesmen, and shipped all the stock to their store in the old Herald Building, Broadway and Ann Street, New-York, where they are retailing their entire surplus stock at less than wholesale prices.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Judge Depue has taken occasion to renew instructions to the Grand Jury in regard to prize fights. When the jurors appeared in court late this afternoon the Judge said:

Mr. DELOS McCURDY, who was associated with Judge MAYNARD as counsel for the Board of Canvassers in the case of the Dutchess County returns in 1891, once more comes to the defense of his former associate in a statement that is neither ingenuous nor consistent with the facts or even with itself.

To-day the last of the Clearing House certificates will be redeemed, and it is probable that on Saturday, for the first time since June 17, the statement of bank averages will take the form that it had before the certificates were issued. The committee having the certificates in charge will submit a complete report of their work to the Clearing House.

If murderous "cranks" like PRENDERGAST are to be considered insane, a clear distinction should be made between their insanity and the kind of mental aberration that renders a person irresponsible for his acts. If an abnormal mental and moral constitution is insanity, then all criminals are insane, but it does not afford a reason for treating their crimes as the result of a malady for which they are not to be punished.

That a cyclone of cranks has fairly struck New-York is proved by the record of the past two days. On Monday Thomas Bradley in a fit of desperate insanity shot down F.L. Matthes, a Superintendent of Construction, on the corner of Murray Street and Broadway, and kept the police at bay for some time with the bullets from his revolver.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The Police Captains and Sergeants of the east side precincts are making a systematic canvass of the saloons by order of Mr. Sheehan's machine, and are ordering the saloon keepers to vote and work for the regular Democratic ticket on penalty of losing their licenses and getting into other trouble.

While the decent citizens of Brooklyn seem to be flocking from every quarter of the city to the support of Mr. Schieren, the anti-"ring" candidate for Mayor, a few other citizens, who have been disagreeably prominent at times in the affairs of the city, are attaching themselves to the falling fortunes of Mr. Boody.

It is said that the general public which attends football games is not pleased with the great amount of wedge play and "bucking the centre," but would prefer to see more open play, including plenty of long runs and punting. Football, as played to-day by the crack college teams, is, in spite of its apparent confusion and roughness, one of the most scientific games ever known.

Mrs. Sarah J. Edwards, the member of the Midnight Band of Mercy who was recently arrested in Harlem for chloroforming stray cats, has begun a crusade in behalf of the homeless felines left by visitors at the Summer resorts along the New-Jersey coast. She will start to-day for Asbury Park and Ocean Grove, with another sister of the Midnight Band, Mrs. Devide, to begin the work of extermination.

The new committee of stockholders of the Madison Square Bank, which was appointed to see what might be done toward putting the bank on its feet again, visited the receivers yesterday to ask if the sale of securities advertised to take place to day could not be postponed until the committee might have a fair trial at the work which it has undertaken.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 31. -- Michael Kozak, a Slavonic banker and steamship agent, has left town, taking with him about $15,000 of his depositors' money. Kozak left several days ago, telling his wife he was going to Mount Pleasant on business. A few days later Mrs. Kozak received a letter from him dated Philadelphia, in which he stated that he would not return, and that he did not wish to live with her any longer.

STAPLETON, S.I., Oct. 31. -- A story was circulated to-day that Henry Ocherhausen, a prominent South Beach hotel keeper, had attempted to shoot Thomas Mulling, a member of the County Board of Excise and of the Edgewater Village Board of Health. The story, which is told by several who claim to know the facts, it that the two principals, with four county and village officials, spent several hours in conviviality at Credo's hotel last evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- With the grand total of 21,477,212 paid admissions, the World's Fair was officially closed last night. Though these figures represent the paid admissions during the time allotted by Congress in which the exposition should be kept open, yet it is calculated that at least 1,000,000 tickets will be purchased before the beautiful White City is dismantled and leveled to the ground.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct 31. -- A highway attack upon a mail coach, ending in the killing of a passenger and the wounding of the mall carrier, took place last night on a plantation road near Burnside, in Ascension Parish.

Matthew Kyle, fifty-five years old, residing on Sedgwich Avenue, near High Bridge, died at his home yesterday morning. It is believed that he committed suicide. He was taken ill on Sunday night and Dr. Ferguson of 34 First Avenue decided that Mr. Kyle was suffering from opium poisoning. He was unable to rally his patient.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 31. -- Charles Coghlan did not appear at the Olympic Theatre to-night, and, as a result, a good-sized audience was disappointed. He was billed to appear as Col. Pearce, in "Lady Barter," his own play.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- With the exception of an occasional spasmodic rally the market has been weak all the day, Atchison, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Sugar being the most active stocks. New-England common has held fairly well, and the preferred closed firm at 69, a net advance of 1 point.
William N. Dykman, was yesterday made permanent receiver of the defunet Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, and the bank was declared dissolved by Judge Cullen.

Ex-United States District Attorney Asa W. Tenney, speaking before a mass meeting of 5,000 citizens last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, contributed the following interesting object lesson to the "campaign of education" which is being waged in Brooklyn:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Moreton Frewen, the English bimetallist, who is the guest of Alan Johnstone, Second Secretary of the British Legation, to-day said:

The expected having happened dealers in the down-town markets who had been pushing prices upward for a week in anticipation of silver repeal took profits yesterday, and general declines resulted. This is the way the market always acts after operators have bad a chance to discount events, the culmination acting for the time adversely.

-- The Very Rev. Edward S. Sorin, Supreme General of the Order of Holy Cross and founder of the celebrated University of Notre Dame, died yesterday morning at South Bend, Ind., of Bright's disease, aged seventy-nine. As it became evident that his minutes were numbered the priests and professors of the university assembled at his bedside, and his last breath was drawn in the presence of most of his friends and fellow-laborers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Alvan P. Hyde, the most prominent Domocratic lawyer in this city, was prostrated this morning with what is feared will prove to be a fatal illness. He is the father of Mayor William Waldo Hyde of Harttord and of Frank K. Hyde, United States Consul at Lyons. He accompanied Consul Hyde on the trip to France in August, returning a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The fleet of top-heavy gunboats which the Harrison Administration turned over to Secretary Herbert to complete is undergoing inspection to ascertain just how much harm has been done them by unskillful treatment. The facts which The New-York Times first made public concerning these gunboats -- the Montgomery, Detroit, Marblehead, Machias, and the Castine -- are admitted by the highest officials of the Navy Department.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct 31. -- William Keeley of Binghamton, formerly a resident of Scranton, was shot through the heart and instantly killed last night in a Delaware, Lackawanna and Western express car, near Hackettstown. The fatal shot was from the revolver of G.T. Allwood, a messenger of the United States Express Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The repeal bill was delayed in the House to-day by the assertion of the right by the silver men to object to its consideration as soon as presented as a message from the Senate. The opinion of the Speaker coincided with that of Mr. Bland, and the bill lies on the Speaker's table, to be called up under the rule of the House to-morrow, immediately after the reading of the Journal.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2 @ 2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

A.A. McLeod, President of the NewYork and New-England Railroad, unfolded his scheme to extend that line into this city at a meeting of the Board of Directors in Boston yesterday. The board listened to Mr. McLeod's statements with becoming credulity, and promply authorized him to go ahead and carry out his ambitious plans.

M. Vladimir de Pachmann, the noted Russian pianist, gave his third recital at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. He was heard by a very large and demonstrative audience. His programme was made up of the following numbers, all by Chopin: "Allegro de Concert," barcarole, Opus 60: fantasie impromptu, Opus 66; nocturne, Opus 27; fantasie, Opus 49; scherzo, Opus 31; four preludes, ballade, Opus 38; mazourka, Opus 41, No. 3; two valses, Opus 64 and Opus 42.
The Tammany braves of the Tenth Assembly District are in mourning to-day over the sad ending of a grand ratification meeting they had planned for last night.

The Criterion Theatre, Brooklyn, was crowded to its greatest capacity last evening by enthusiastic supporters. Democrats and Republicans alike, of the reform Republican candidate for Mayor, Charles A. Schieren. The sentiments expressed by the speakers were heartily applauded, and the greatest enthusiasm prevailed when Mr. Schieren came upon the platform.
LONDON, Oct 31. -- All the leading afternoon newspapers comment at length on the passage by the American Senate of the bill stopping the purchase of silver.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Mrs. Charles R. Pratt, formerly Miss Gertrude Hall of this city, has begun proceedings for divorce on the ground of desertion, and will, it is stated, institute proceedings for $25,000 against Mrs. Pratt. her mother-in-law, for the alienation of her husband's affections.

DANNEMORA, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The special committee of the State Board of Charities which is investigating the administration of affairs at the Elmira Reformatory met in the Warden's office in Clinton Prison this morning to examine convicts who had been transferred from the Elmira Reformatory to Clinton Prison. After deciding to continue the practice of allowing newspaper reporters to be present at the hearings, the examination of witnesses began.

William Leary, who was at one time conspicuous in the affairs of the Republican Party in the Twenty-first Assembly District, and who is now in the Sixteenth Assembly District, has been making some investigations into the registration in the Sixteenth District. As a result he says:

The passage of the bill to repeal the purchasing clause of the Sherman silver law has infused a little more activity into real estate dealings. Brokers and agents are again approached frequently by customers, and inquiries for desirable property are beginning to be numerous. Applications for loans by lenders are once more in order, and borrowers with good security have no difficulty in being accommodated at 5 per cent.

Denis Gillespie, a rough-looking fellow, broke into Mrs. Eliza Mullins's boarding house, 45 Gold Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and called for Mrs. Mullins, Mrs. Mullins and her mother and a boarder named Perkins grappled with the intruder, who slashed Perkins with a razor.

Henry R. Jones, President of the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, said in The New-York Times yesterday that assessments for paving Clinton and Gates Avenues were levied early in the year. The total amount collected was $17,500. A month later he was assessed again for repaving Gates Avenue from Vanderbilt to Waverly Avenue.

Isaac S. Fishel, a cloak manufacturer of Boston, was arrested in that city on Monday on the request of Superintendent Byrnes. He is under indictment here on charges of fraud, the complainant being Frederick C Co., bankers and warehouse men, ing the Merchants and Manufacturers' al Company at Beach and Varick Stree's, who charges Fishel with having defrauded the company out of $42,000.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday President George B. McClellan offered the following preamble and resolutions relative to the death of Mayor Harrison of Chicago, and they were adopted by a rising vote:

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- All that was mortal of Carter H. Harrison was borne from his old residence on Ashland Boulevard this morning and reverently deposited upon a catafalque in the wide La Salle Street corridor on the first floor of the Cit dall. The funeral cortege was composed setachments from the Police and Fire Departments and several score of close personal friends of the late Chief Executive.

A statement was recently published in Washington that Mr. Hornblower, the nominee for the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench, never had a case in the United States Supreme Court, or that he never had any experience in constitutional cases. This statement is denied by Mr. Hornblower's legal associates, who give the following account of his experience in Supreme Court practice:

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Harvard University has within a month established the highest meteorological station in the world, according to news just received at Cambridge from Prof. S.J. Bailey, in charge of the astronomical station at Arequipa, Peru. It is situated on the top of El Miste, a nearly extinct volcano of the Cordilleras, 19,200 feet in altitude, or almost 3,500 feet higher than the station of the French Academy on Mount Blanc.
In its scathing denunciation of the men who have placed the names of hundreds of illegal voters on the registry lists of the City of Churches, The Brooklyn Eagle said on Monday last:

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The Viking ship cast off from its moorings on the lake shore at Jackson Park this afternoon, and sailed away in a swift breeze in command of Capt. Anderson. It entered the Chicago River, where it will be stocked with provisions for its long voyage ending next May. Tomorrow the ship will be towed up the river to the canal and on the Illinois River to the Mississippi.

Henry P. Schmidt of 564 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, is one of the most active members of the Citizens' Union. Mr. Schmidt is a practical man, and in a practical way he has done a great deal in the direction of getting good citizens to register this year. Yesterday he predicted, as a result of his careful study of the situation in Brooklyn, an overwhelming defeat for Mayor Boody.
Charles L. Webster Co. have sold the entire subscription-book department of their business as booksellers and publishers.

Lawrence Murphy, who was forty-seven years old and Captain of Engine Company No. 47, died of heart disease yesterday afternoon at company headquarters, One Hundred and Thirteenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. His command had just returned from a fire and he was leaving the engine, when he staggered and the engineer caught him just in time to prevent him from falling on the pavement.

Charles L. Guy, the Democratic candidate for Senator in the Thirteenth Senatorial District, is receiving the support of not only the regular organization, but of many independent voters, who recognize that he is exceptionally well qualified to serve in the office to which he has been, nominated. Mr. Guy is thoroughly a New-Yorker, and was born in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Treasury official statement of the comparative re- ceipts and expenditures of the United States, issued to-day, shows that for the first four months of the current fiscal year the expenditures have exceeded the receipts by $24,000,000, or at the rate of $72,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Unconditional repeal is an accomplished fact. Silver pur- chases have ceased. The Treasury is released from this day from the necessity of purchasing a commodity it does not require, out of a money chest already depleted, and at the risk of dangerous encroachment upon the gold reserve.

-- Mr. Edward S. Brewer, who is about removing from Springfield, Mass., has. The Republican says, one of the largest and most perfect of existing collections of furniture, household belongings, china, literature, documents, and other curios pertaining to the colonial period and the earlier years of the United States.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 1. -- Resistance to the Midway closing order by the Ferris Wheel Company led to exciting scenes, free fighting, a small riot, and numerous arrests outside the wheel gates to-day. The trouble began when World's Fair guards tried to stop the sale of tickets to visitors.

"Hamlet and Ophelia" was the subject discussed by the Professional Woman's League yesterday, and Mrs. M.J. Hoagland gave a delightful analysis of the words and characters of the unfortunate lovers. There was a large attendance, and many and varied opinions found expression.

The New-York Times first disclosed the fraudulent character of the Ring registra- tion in Gravesend and Brooklyn; it secured and published the first returns from Coney Island which indicated clearly the charac- ter of the frauds perpetrated in "Boss" McKane's dominion.

There will be a general "round up" of Republican opinion to-day, when the Republican State Committee's Executive Committee will meet at the headquarters, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and lay out the final plans for the campaign. It will be the last regular meeting of the committee until after the election.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Committee of Fifty appointed to direct the anti-Maynard movement pushed ahead its work yesterday with much energy. It has organized a clerical force to put out the documents which it intends to send wherever there may seem to be a chance of helping the revolt against Maynard's nomination.

Thousands of persons in Brooklyn were delayed early yesterday morning by a series of accidents upon the Fifth Avenue line of the Union Elevated Railroad. The accidents occurred between 6 and 7 o'clock, when the trains are crowded with workers on their way down town. In the last and most serious accident an engine was hurled from the track and by the merest chance escaped crashing down to the street below.

The mental collapse of Leonard Forbes Beckwith, consulting engineer or the Empire City Subway Company and several similar companies in this city, has caused much sorrow in business and social circles. The dissolution of his mind is particularly painful, because it marks the early close of an unusually brilliant business career.
Mrs. S. Jennings Gorman, who is well known in New-York society, has begun suit for absolute divorce on the statutory grounds.

In all Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal Churches yesterday special services were held morning and evening in celebration of the Feast of All Saints, this being the festival in honor of the saints for whom it was not possible to set aside an especial day.

The torpedo boat Feiseen promises to be one of the most efficient craft which Flint Co. have ordered for the Brazilian Navy. The designs for the altering of the Feiseen from a yacht into a torpedo boat were completed yesterday. They were prepared by the original builders of the Feiseen, Messrs. Gardiner Mosher.

Last Summer, when the fact was published that ex-Mayor Chapin had visited Mr. Boody, shortly after the tatter's election as Mayor, and advised him to reappoint all of "Boss" McLaughlin's heads of departments, there was some curiosity among politicians of Brooklyn as to who had made the story public.

Among the 250 persons at the sale of the Fox estate lots, in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday, were thirty women, who were by far the beat of the bidders. The sale was conducted by Mr. James L. Wells. In all, sixty-four lots in the Twenty-third Ward of this city were disposed of for a total of $53,915.
Gus Volz, a scenic artist at Proetor's Theatre, received a postal card yesterday morning, on which was written:

Register Kenna, Commissioner of Jurors Furey, and the other office-holding members of "Boss" McLaughlin's Campaign Committee were looking very gloomy last night. And they had a good reason for feeling that way.

BOSTON, Nov. 1. -- There has been a more hopeful feeling in the market to-day, and prices, with but few exceptions, have been firm and higher all day, with a strong closing. Atchison has been a feature and very active, closing strong at 21. Bell Telephone was offered at 192 1/2, and Central Massa- chusetts common at 15.
AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Ex-Senator William B. Woodin died to-night. He did not regain consciousness after the paralytic stroke last Friday.

CHICAGO, ILL., Nov. 1. -- With much pomp and a wealth of honors, the body of Chicago's late Mayor was placed in Graceland Cemetery to-day. In the funeral procession more than 50,000 men walked with slow step in keeping with the solemn measure of the dirge, and probably ten times that number of men and women stood with bared and bowed heads while the bier was borne on its way.

The first musical ride or the season was given at Durland's Riding Academy last night. The big building was crowded and many had to go away because they could not obtain seats. Amoug those present were Mr. Chauncey M. Depew and his son "Buster," Commissioner McClave and family, ex-Mayor Grant, Mr. Frank Ehret, and Mr. Samuel W. Taylor.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 1. -- At a meeting of the Directors of the Boston Merchants' Association this afternoon the report of the Executive Com- mittee upon the Consular Service of the United States was received. Some recent changes and appointments are deplored, and Josiah Quincy is taken to task for the statement in defense of a policy which la declared to be at variance with civil service requirements.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 1. -- The Destroyer is still here, and if the wind holds southwest and continues to blow as it now does she will be unable to get away to-night. The start last night was interfered with by the failure of the improvised steering gear to work and other difficulties, so a return had to be made.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 26. -- Since the beginning of this year an unparalleled craze has been on the increase in Jamaica. It has assumed such proportions and has aroused the population to such an extent that the Government holds in readiness several regiments of white troops to quell any disturbance or to suppress what might develop into a religious war.

Each succeeding day of the political revolution how going on in Brooklyn brings forth evidences of the irrepressible greed of the Ring for the control of the various municipal departments. The police seem to be aiding the Ring in its process of intimidating humble citizens into at least appearing to uphold the Ring's nominations.

In an attempt to controvert certain statements as to the movement of prices recently published in an article written by Mr. DAVID A. WELLS, the American Manufacturer of Pittsburg, the organ of the Iron and Steel Association, makes a rather unfortunate reference to the prices of Bessemer pig iron and steel rails.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 1. -- The second eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club played a game with the football team of the Cutler School of New-York this afternoon and had an easy victory. The Cutler team was weak in its blocking and was unable to hold the Crickets' rush line. The Cutlers' only score was made by two fine runs around the ends and punts.

The second football team from Cutler's School played a brisk game yesterday with the second eleven of Harvard School on the lower football field in Central Park. Only one half was played, as the boys were seriously hampered in their work by the crowding of a number of interested spectators, who persisted in occupying a good part of the field needed by the players. Neither side was able to score.

-- John Greenough, Vice President of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway, spoke encouragingly yesterday of the prospects of that road. He made the significant statement that about onehalf of the steel structural rolling mills along the Ohio River branch of that road had resumed operations, and the other half were getting ready to resume.

-- New-York has become famous for its pretty girls, and connoisseurs have declared that no city in the Union can boast as many. A Baltimorean recently visiting here, who claims to know what feminine beauty is in its perfection, declared that of all the girls he saw, none were so pretty as the wax ladies in the hairdressing establish- ment of Mrs. L. Shaw, at 54 West Fourteenth Street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- The local Board of Education two months ago limited bids for the contract of erecting the now manual training school here to union men. A strong protest was immediately entered by non-union men and by Mrs. Lucy Boardman, whose donation of $60,000 assured the establishment of the school.

The sale of the first batch of securities taken as collateral by the Madison Square Bank for loans drew to 111 Broadway, yesterday, an attendance equal to the capacity of the salesroom. At their face value, the securities represented about $1,500,000. The sale brought $65,000.

It was a bit of Vienna, sure enough, at the Madison Square Garden Amphitheatre last night, where the band of the Fourth Regiment of the Austrian Imperial Guard played a programme of music before an audience of several thousand persons.

DANNEMORA, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The Elmira Reformatory Investigation Committee concluded the rating of testimony at this place to-day. This morning and at the afternoon session the testimony of a number of men transferred from Elmira was heard.

Samuel McCabe of 21 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, who believes that politics can be purified only by shooting President Cleveland and Mayor Boody, was sent yesterday by Justice Haggerty of the Myrtle Avenue Police Court to Raymond Street Jail, pending an examination as to his mental condition.

Charles A. Schieren, the Republican and reform candidate for Mayor, was quite busy yesterday. He visited F.G. Smith's piano manufactory in Willoughby Street and talked to the employes. He told them that he wanted their help to elect him, and he pledged himself to give them an honest and economic government.

The extraordinary cloud of litigation which has been hanging over the New-York Casino, in Thirty-ninth Street, for the last six months was, according to legal belief, dissipated by the startling action taken on Monday by Ira Leo Bamberger, attorney for Lederer Canary, the present lessees and occupants of that much-disputed property.

CITT OF MEXICO, Nov. 1. -- One of the most important results of the national convention of the Liberal Party which assembled over a year ago is a aeries of constitutional amendments now submitted to Congress. The amendments give the Executive power to appoint Judges of the Supreme Court with the consent of the Senate and make the Judges irremovable except for crime or for incapacity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Lehigh Val- ley was again the feature of the market, advancing from 40 1/4 to 43 5/8, and closing at 4343 1/4. There are all sorts of rumors of coal deals impending, but the real rea- son for the advance, apparently, is a short interest trying to cover on a market bare of stocks.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 1. -- Delta Kap- pa Epsilon Chapter House, Williams College, was gutted by fire early this morning. The fire caught from a defective flue and burned up through the roof. The smoke awakened Students Chapman, Christy, Dutcher, and Bearles, who roomed in the house. They saved most of their furniture, but Christy lost all his personal effects.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Ulster and Delaware are the counties where Isaac H. Maynard hopes to make his vindication most pronounced, for in Delaware County, his home county, he has many personal friends, and Ulster's Democracy has always been favorable to him. Delaware County generally rolls up a good Republican majority, but Judge Maynard's friends have hopes that his personality will bring him many votes.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- A crowd of nearly 1500 persons gathered at the Yale field this afternoon, expecting to witness a game with Brown university, but were disappointed, as Brown failed to appear, owing to the alleged crippled condition or their team. It was the last opportunity of seeing the Yale eleven practice this season, as secret work begins to-morrow, and on that account an unusual number of spectators was on hand.

The panic-stricken Brooklyn ring is withholding the tax rate, which, it is now generally believed, will reach nearly $3 per $100. Yesterday a reporter for The New-York Times called upon the Board of Assessors and endeavored to get at the rate of taxation on certain pieces of property in the First Ward.
Harriet A. Weed, daughter of the late Thurlow Weed, died late last night at her home, 12 West Twelfth Street, where she had been ill for several months.

William Cutajar, the Custom House broker, who has figured in several cases in which he was charged with undervaluation of imports, was again arrested yesterday. The complainant was James W. Coronkite, an Acting Deputy Collector, who alleges that Mr. Cutajar made untrue returns respecting an invoice of choose and vegetables which arrived in this port on the steamer Bermania Jan. 22, 1891.

Senator ALLISON began, in Iowa last week, a series of campaign speeches in support of JACKSON, the Republican candidate for Governor, who was forbidden by a Republican Administration to practice before the Interior Department because of the shameful evidence furnished by his own letters concerning his dealings with an applicant for a pension.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The minutes of the Admiralty in the Victoria-Camperdown court-martial confirm the findings of the court. Capt. Charles Johnstone of the Camperdown is criticised somewhat severely by the Admiralty. The report closes thus:

When the defenders of any man charged with wrongdoing attack the motives of those who make the charge, it is in effect a confession of weakness. Even if the motives of the accusers are in any respect unworthy, or other than what they profesa, it makes no difference with the truth of their accusations.

The London Field still comments on the America's Cup races. In the latast issue to hand it says: "The erroneous impression that a centreboard adds to the stability of a vessel has many times been dealt with in our columns; but it is not surprising to see it coming to the surface again amid the number of absurd ideas which have been published about English and American yachts during the contests for the America Cup.
Money on call loaned at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

The purchasing clause of the law of 1890 is no longer on the statute books. The repeal bill was signed by the President yesterday immediately on the adoption of the Senate amendment in the House. The vote in the House, proportioned to the number present, was almost the same as on the Wilson bill, though not quite so heavy, lacking three votes of being two to one.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- There is a strong probability that the nomination of William B. Hornblower of New-York to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States will not be confirmed in the present session.

It is stated that the resumption of gold payments by Austria, which had been expected to take place yesterday, has been postponed, but probably not for a long time. The plan was first formally completed in the Spring of last year, and it was then announced that the Government proposed to complete the reform only in five years.

The all-absorbing topic among clubmen yesterday was the business venture of Rawlins L. Cottenet, who opened a flower establishment on Thirty-second Street, just east of Fifth Avenue. When his father married the sister of William C. Schermerhorn and Mrs. William Astor, the Cottenet family was very wealthy and was connected with many of the best-known families of the city.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The Democratic row in Herkimer County over the printing of the ballots of the Lewis ticket has been ended, and in the lone legal battle Clinton Beckwith comes out a loser.

Two checks, calling for $8,217.30 on the Bank of the Manhattan Company, 40 Wall Street, to which the signature of Coffin Stanton, brokers, at 72 Broadway, had been forged, were profitable last month to a combination of rascals because the Garfield Bank was unwary and accepted them on deposit for a confederate, who posed as a bookmaker.

Whatever may be the cause, there has been a marked renewal of confidence on the part of the managers of the Democratic State machine in their ability to elect Mr. Maynard. It arises probably from information they have received relative to the canvass in this city. The Tammany machine is working under great pressure to pile up a big vote for the whole Democratic State ticket.
LISBON, Nov. 1. -- Supplies of money, provisions, ammunition, arms, and coal, sent to the Brazilian insurgents from Europe, will reach Rio de Janeiro within a few days.

NEW-ORLEANS. Nov. 1. -- Detective Phil Reilly recounted the events that led to himself and Von Gerichten being commissioned by President Cleveland to go to Costa Rica for Weeks. Armed with the commission, the detectives left New-York City on the steamship Alvinia of the Atlas Line on the evening of the 14th of September for Port Limon, in Costa Rica.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Jeremiah Cronin, thirty-one years old, a saloon keeper, was looked up this morning without bail on a charge of assault, which may be changed to murder. On Sunday morning at 3 o'clock a party of young men in Cronin's place quarreled about politics. Cronin became involved in the dispute, and struck Edward D. Murphy of 9 East Hamilton Place on the head with a club.

The name of ex-Secretary of the Navy William C. Whitney appears upon the Democratic ticket that will be voted next Tuesday in the Seventh Senate District, as a candidate for delegate to the Constitutional Convention, but Mr. Whitney does not desire the place. He was put upon the ticket while he was in Chicago, and he was not informed of it for some time.
Mr. Morgan's fine steam yacht Corsair will probably be undergoing conversion into a Brazilian war ship in the course of a few days. Flint Co. of this city have offered Mr. Morgan $250,000 for her.

-- The members of the Tammany Hall organization of the Twenty-third Assembly District held an enthusiastic meeting last night at the new Pontiac Hall in Amsterdam Avenne, near Eighty-first Street. Addresses were made by Vernon S. Davis Bartow S. Weeks, Police Justice Thomas F. Grady E.H. Kelley, John Connolly, and Charles F. Throck morton.
