When Co-operative Hall was built at Howard Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, they did not think, apparently, that the neighborhood would ever turn out such a crowd as was assembled there last night to hear S.L. Woodhouse talk on municipal affairs.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Nov. 1 -- P.M. The stock market reacted to-day from the declines of Monday and Tuesday, and there was a general advance all along the list, several of the shares which had suffered most in the bear raid leading in the gains.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 1. -- The troops under command of Major Forbes and Dr. Jameson. Administrator of the British South Africa Company, occupied Buluwayo after several fights in which the Matabeles suffered heavily.
Negotiations are in active progress for the acquisition by the Brazilian Government of the three new war ships, Montgomery, Machias, and Marblehead, which were built for the United States Navy.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Detective James Dempsey of Police Headquarters placed John Sheehan, Michael Duffy, and John Shiels under arrest this morning on warrants charging them with violating the civil service law of 1883. John Sheehan is running on the Democratic ticket for Alderman of the First Ward, and hopes, through his colonization tactics, to beat Alderman John White.
William J. Gaynor is after John Y. Mc- Kane, and the ruler of Coney Island found out last night that there are some laws of the State of New-York which he must obey.

Chess players had scarcely had time to digest the games played in the impromptu international tour nament, when the full scores of the first games contested in St. Petersburg between Dr. Sigismund Tarrasch of Nuremberg and the Russian expert, Tschigorin, came to hand. It goes without saying that these names are the main subject of conversation at the Manhattan Chess Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- There were two important things determined to-day at the Navy Department in the discussions of the unstability of modern ships of war. One is the location of the responsibility, and the other is the decision to pursue the inquiry systematically to all the new ships. The officials do not propose to be betrayed into any disaster which will advertise to a greater extent the carelessness or inefficiency of the experts.

The European mail yesterday brought the scores of the sixth and seventh games for the Tarrasch vs. Tschigorin match now being played at St. Petersburg in the sixth game Tschigorin played a really remarkably weak game, while Tarrasch allowed Tschigorth to get the best of the seventh game, although the doctor had at one time the much better position. Here are the games:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Most of the time of the Senate to-day has been occupied in a discussion of the Chinese bill, which was taken up late yesterday afternoon through the efforts of Mr. Gray of the Committee on Foreign Relations, who has charge of it in Mr. Morgan's absence. This bill extends for six months the time given Chinese laborers in the United States to apply for certificates of residence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The following memorial, prepared by the American National Red Cross, was presented to Congress to-day:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- Senator John Sherman came in to-night for the closing hours of the campaign, and is at Parlor 7, Neil House. Mr. Sherman is accompanied by his secretary, E.J. Babcock, and as he had been on the road for several hours he had not heard that the House had concurred in the Senate amendments to the repeal bill.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 1 -- Francis Henry Weeks and wife and Detective Sergeants Von Gerichten and Reilly, all of New-York, arrived at 3 o'clock this morning on the steamship Foxhall. The party was met by a squad of policemen, who guarded the ship until daylight, when the immigration authorities passed all the passengers and allowed them to land.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 1. -- An electric car on the Oregon City Line, containing about twenty passengers, went through an open drawbridge at Madison Street at 7 o'clock this morning, falling into the Willamette River. The number of passengers drowned is not known, but the bodies of the following persons have already been recovered:

BUFFALO, Nov. 1. -- The Sheehanites are desperate. Every person upon whom they have any hold has been pressed into the service of getting votes for the machine ticket. The police force is at work, and where argument, will not avail intimidation is resorted to. Affidavits which were made public to-day show their methods.

-- Secretary Caldwell of the Barnard School team writes: "The football team of the Barnard school is one of the best to the city. The team has played six games and has only lost one, and that to Westminster School by 35 to 0, while Westminster School beat Berkeley not long ago by the score of 65 to 0. The Banard team applied for admission into the Interscholastic League, but was coldly refused.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Weather Bureau, which suspended its weekly crop bulletins with the in-gathering of the harvest, to-day issued, through Acting Chief Dunwoody, a monthly crop report, as follows:

Fire was discovered in the cellar of the five-story building at 19 East Third Street at 11:40 o'clock last night, and before the flames were under control several firemen had narrow escapes from death.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Representative Tracey of New-York was the guest of honor at a dinner given to-night at Chamberlin's to commemorate the victory of the repeal bill. Those who thus celebrated Mr. Tracey's victory were Controller Eckels, Postmaster Dayton of New-York, Repre- sentative Fitch, Private Secretary Thurber, and Eugene T. Chamberlain of Albany.

BOSTON, Nov. 1. -- In a marine junk and old sail shop on Atlantic Avenue, this city, have been found two old sails which are of great interest. These sails undoubtedly belonged to the yacht America, the oldest of them being probably in use when she sailed her famous race in English waters and brought the cup to this country. This is a flying jib, and is marked on the clew.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 1. -- For the first time this year the Harvard football team has been scored against Harvard winning the game against the academy team by a score of 60 to 5. This is also the first time that Andover has ever scored against Harvard.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Lehigh Valley opened at 43 1/2 and made a quick break to 39 3/4, recovering to 41, and closing offered at 40 1/4. The quick advance yesterday brought in selling orders, and as the short interest is pretty well supplied there was very little market to sell on. Insiders profess to know nothing about the recent advance, and it is attributed entirely to short covering.
There are more honest men in Brooklyn than there are rogues, no matter how many fraudulent voters, corrupt police officials, and dishonest election officers may be included in the latter category.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Judge Brentano to-day discharged the common-law receiver appointed in the suit of New-York creditors for the Frankenthal Frendenthal property. His action left the store unprotected for a time, as the receiver had been in possession. A race for possession began at once between the Sheriff, acting for judgment creditors, and a new receiver appointed in usual form by Judge McConnells.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Navy officers who have been enjoying long leaves and drawing Government pay have been ordered back to service. Secretary Herbert has decided that the privilege has been abused and that the department has been in some instances imposed upon. He believes that officers who cannot give their time to the navy should withdraw entirely from the service.

-- To increase the funds of the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church, at One Hundred and Eleventh Street, a benefit concert has been arranged by the church's choral society for this evening. Miss Jessie Shay, pianiste, will be among those who will take part.

The announcement was made yesterday of the sale to Flint Co. of the British steamer Britannia, in behalf of the Brazilian Government. She will be converted into a gunboat cruiser. Flint Co. paid to her former owners, the North Atlantic Steamship Company, $325,000.

Congratulations over the repeal of the silver-purchase law furnished chief interest to the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. In the absence John Claflin, Chairman, the report of the committee appointed July 6 to assist in securing, repeal was presented by J. Edward Simmons.

The Clearing House Association had a jubilee meeting yesterday afternoon over the completion of the work of the Loan Committee, which, since June last, had saved the financial and commercial community from the distress of panic, by the issue of $41,000,000 of Clearing House certificates and their gradual retirement as the improving situation warranted.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- Is the glove content here to-night at the Cribb Club between "Spider" 'Weir and "Billy " Murphy the latter was beaten in five ronuds. Murphy, who was formerly the champion of Australia, once defeated "Johnny" Grimn, but he appears to have lost all his skill as a pugilist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Under the leadership of Mr. Reed, the Republicans have to-day made a protracted fight in the House over the proposition of Mr. Wilson of the Ways and Means Committee that that committee be allowed to sit during the interval between the adjournment of the extraordinary session and the beginning of the regular session in December.

The Lotos Club will have a house warming in its new quarters, 558 Fifth Avenue, to-morrow evening. The new house is now completely furnished and decorated, and its commodious and elegant rooms are well adapted for the entertainment of a large company. On this occasion they will be rendered especially attractive by a collection of new paintings, the work of artist members of the club during the past season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- After debating the Chinese bill most of the day, the Senate at 5 o'clock this afternoon passed it by a viva voce vote. There was a demand for a division on an amendment offered by Mr. Hoar, but it was withdrawn when the Massachusetts Senator discovered that he stood practically alone.

Just enough plot to bind the four acts together, plenty of amusing situations, a lively progress of the play from scene to scene, and a final triumph of woman's wit over man's egotism -- that is "Der Lebemann," by Gustav von Moser, given last night at the Irving Place Theatre.

Justice Cullen of Brooklyn yesterday declared that, though the law giving women the right to vote for School Commissioners was unconstitutional, yet the special ballots provided for women should be printed, but not voted. His decision was on an application from George F. Stockpole of Suffolk County, asking what County Clerk Fanning should do in the matter of issuing ballots for women.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 2. -- Native runners who are reaching Fort Victoria confirm the belief that King Lobengula has been trapped. He is blocked to the northward by the tzetze fly country, through which it will be impossible for him to drive his cattle, and to the south-ward by the imperial troops and the forces of the British South Africa Company.

BUFFALO, Nov. 2. -- Franklin D. Locke and his fellow-organizers of the Erie County Home-Rule Democracy are in fine feather to-night. They have made a showing of hands, and Lieut. Gov. Sheehan and his followers are confronted with a bona, fide list of 3,300 Democrats who have pledged themselves to vote against the dummy candidates which have been set up by the Sheehan machine.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Nov. 2. -- Johnson lowered the world's two-thirds' mile record this morning, with a flying start, to 1:16. He was paced by Bird. Dorner, and Burton, the triplets. The record for the half mile it was 0:56.

AJACCIO, Corsica, Nov. 2. -- It has been, learned that the accident that occurred yesterday on the Russian war ship Emperor Nicholas I., while she was entering the harbor here, was due to the explosion of a carboy of turpentine. Two of the Russian sailors were suffocated, while the others in the place where the explosion occurred were removed in an unconscious condition.

An agreement was practically closed yesterday by which the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company obtains cantrol of the Chesapeake, Ohio and Southwestern systern of railroads in Kentucky and Tennessee. The transaction involves about $6,000,000. As soon as certain necessary details have been attended to a transfer of the property will be made.

The Brotherhood of Philip and Andrew is holding its first federal convention at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. Delegates are present from Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Chicago, Cleveland, Pittsburg, Omaha, and many other cities. Four denominations are represented in the brotherhood, the Reformed Church in America, the Reformed Church in the United States, the Congregational Church, and the Presbyterian Church.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Patrick E. Prendergast was arraigned before Judge Horton to-day, and the trembling wretch, in tones that could scarcely be heard five feet away, pleaded not guilty.

A few days ago a reporter for The New-York Times had occasion to call upon John Y. McKane, at his office, 44 Court Street, Brooklyn. As the reporter entered, a satellite informed the great "Boss" that "Murphy" of Coney Island wished to talk with him over the telephone.
BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Director Dolbrueck, one of the best-informed bankers in Berlin, said to-day of the repeal of the Sherman act:

VIENNA, Nov. 2. -- Emperor Franz Josef will return to the city to-morrow and will receive at once Prince Windischgraetz and Count Badeni, Governor of Galicia. The latter will advise that the Cabinet be reconstructed by Count Taaffe. His proposal is supported by the Clericals and Bohemians, and is said to have some advocates among the Conservatives and Poles.

The very foundation of our institutions rests upon an orderly and lawful determination of the popular will at elections, and no crime should be regarded as more heinous or visited with severer condemnation than crimes that are intended to defeat that object. The right of suffrage is properly regarded as something sacred and to be jealously protected from corruption and fraud.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Committee of Democrats organized to oppose the election of Judge Maynard to the Court of Appeals bad a busy time yesterday. By evening mere had been mailed about 100,000 copies of the committee's appeal to voters and of the Bar Association's original report again Judge Maynard, and about 500,000 Bartlett pasters.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- The Republicans of Ohio are being treated to a surprise in this last week of the campaign, and manifest not a little uneasiness on account of it. To all appearances the Democratic canvass has been comparatively listless and uninteresting, but it is clear now that much really hard and skillful work has been done, and the managers are by no means discouraged at the outlook.

Of two Democratic candidates, good Democrats should choose the better. Mr. MOSES HERMAN and Mr. JOHN BROOKS LEAVITT are candidates for the Assembly in the Twenty-first District. Mr. HERMAN'S Democracy is attested by the fact that he is the candidate of the Tammany organization in the district. Mr. LEAVITT'S comes to him by inheritance.

The appeal made by Commodore RAMSAY for the amendment of the naturalization laws in their relation to the navy merits the attention of Congress. We talk of the need of American crews for American ships, and yet the statutes stand in the way of enabling foreign-born seamen to become citizens, and even deprive them of that privilege, except at a personal sacrifice.

CAIRO, Ill., Nov. 2. -- The engineers, firemen, and yard switchmen of the Big Four Railroad went out on a strike this afternoon because of an order received last night that a heavy cut would be made in wages to take effect yesterday. About fifty men are involved and all traffic is suspended. A passenger train was to have left at 4 o'clock, but the strikers refused to let it go.

A general movement is under way in the Sixth Ward, Brooklyn, to get the illegal vote through on election day. Two or more men have registered from the houses of politicians, who assume the responsibility of standing sponsors for these men, and who allow their houses to be used for these illegal voters to register from.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The question was put to Mr. Edward Atkinson this evening how he thought the coming deficiency of revenue would be met. His reply was that he thought there would be no deficiency, even for the current fiscal year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Congressman Charles O'Nelil, the venerable "Father of the House," who was taken ill shortly after he had recorded his vote for the Wilson bill, is now convalescent. Mr. O'Neill was threatened with acute pneumonia and has been confined to his residence for six weeks. This is the first time in twenty-eight years' service that Mr. O'Neill has been compelled to remain away from Washington because or sickness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- The Chicago stock market did not at all sympathize with the New-York board to-day. While the Eastern prices were discouraging, there could not be found a sufficient number of bears to emulate their Gotham brethren by pounding securities, so as to frighten investors and the bulls by profession.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The investigation of the new navy is to be made systematically. A board empowered to look into the condition of naval vessels in course of completion and recently completed will begin its sessions to-morrow at the Navy Department. The inquiry will be thorough, and the department will in time acquire correct knowledge of the state of affairs.

Champion amateur runner "Tommy" Conneff will run an exhibition mile race at the games of the Washington Wheelmen to be held at Berkeley Oval on election day. He is doing a little work every day, and if the conditions are favorable he believes that he will be able to show a fast performance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The report in The Times of this morning of yesterday's meeting of the New-York Board of Education, in which Commissioner Moriarty found fault with Col. J. Schuyler Crosby and objected to the reading of a letter by that gentleman to his associates on the board, has attracted the attention of many of the Washington friends of Col. Crosby and led him into many explanations.

Excellent promise was given at the meeting yesterday of the Executive Committee of the Republican State Committee that Judge Isaac H. Maynard would be defeated for Judge of the Court of Appeals and that Edward T. Bartlett would be elected.

Monroe Salisbury, that shrewd son of California, made no mistake when he told the owner or the pacer Mascot that Fleetwood Park was the place for a horse race, and that if one had a good horse there was no place on earth where he would be better appreciated than in New-York. That was when Mr. Salisbury was trying to arrange with Mr. Taylor for the match race between the champion trotter.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Nov. 2 -- P.M. The see-saw is in fashion in the stock market this week. Prices declined sharply on Tuesday, rallied notably on Wednesday, and suffered to-day a relapse which affected nearly everything on the list. Louisville and Nashville was an especially weak spot at the opening, then a raid was begun on Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, other Grangers were influenced, and the weakness became general.

George Bock, the "crank" who wrote a threatening postal card to August G. Volz, a scene painter at Proctor's Theatre, and attempted to attack Capt. O'Connor when arrested Wednesday night, had apparently lost all his desire to kill people when he was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Secretary Herbert knows nothing about the release of the gunboat Machias, Montgomery, and Marblehead to the Brazilian Government. He said to-day that such a proposition would hardly be made, and, if presented, would not be entertained.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 2. -- Another effort is being made by the Vestry of St. Paul's Episcopal Church here to oust their pastor, the Rev. Charles Witherspoon, who has held disputed possession of the pulpit for several months. At a meeting of the Vestry it was decided to offer Mr. Witherspbon $250, equivalent to three months' salary, if he would resign.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 2. -- The failure of the firm of S. Blaisdell, Jr., Co. of Chicopee, extensive wholesale dealers in cotton and wool stocks of all kinds, is announced by the personal statement of C.M. Blaisdell, who is now at the head of the firm, with his brother G.A. Blaisdell as partner.

-- An old man and woman stood near the big gilt statue of the Republic in the Court of Honor, and a Boston woman heard tha prairie sister ask her husband in an awed tone: "Do you suppose that figure is solid gold?" And he answered with masculine superiority: "No, of course not. Why, if it was solid gold it would have cost a hundred thousand dollars.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The opening of Parliament to-day attracted little attention. All the customary formalities were complied with, though few members were present at the time fixed for the opening of the House. There was no rush for seats. The lobbies were virtually empty until the afternoon.

PARKER'S LANDING, Penn., Nov. 2. -- Fire started in Clinton Elder's billiard room last night, burning down the billiard room. Post Office, Mobley's furnishing store, Wilkins Fullerton's millinery store, Blair's stationery store, Cohen's building, Mrs. Ella Berland's photograph gallery, the Western Union Telegraph office, Lewis's restaurant, Mrs. Pontius's building, and Clark Wilson's variety store.

The Essex Market Police Court was crowded yesterday when the case of the three men arrested Wednesday on charges of riot in mobbing agents of the Society for the Prevention of Crime came before Justice Ryan. The prisoners were Isidor Putter, a bartender, twenty-four years old, of 36 Forsyth Street; Charles Kranier, a Russian peddler, twenty-six years old, of 125 Forsyth Street, and Hyman Sugar, a Russian saloon keeper of 41 Essex Street.

The new fleet of vessels being fitted out in this port as war ships for the Brazilian Government will, it is learned, be manned almost exclusively by American seamen. None but men of experience in the handling of ordnance will be selected for the more important places in the fleet. For good gun captains and ordnance officers special inducements will be offered.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 2. -- The Virginia campaign, now nearing its close, has been unusually dull. It is, however, warming up now, and the fight is assuming an interesting phase. The Democratic managers were somewhat fearful a week ago that the contest might be rather close. The Populists bad conducted a vigorous fight and aroused some enthusiasm in the rural districts.

QUEENS, L.I., Nov. 2. -- Mrs. Increase Hendrickson has a grievance. She wasone of the contestants for a chair voted for at the fair of the Women's Co-operative Guild. Her opponent was Mrs. William H. Taylor, President of the guild. The fair was held here, where both women live. The voting for the chair wan lively the first night, but on the second evening the two contestants named distanced all others.

The confident assurances put forth by A. A. McLeod and his friends, that an extension of the New-York and New-England Railroad will be built to this dity, and that the important matter of finances has been arranged, has given rise to the suspicion that some powerful corporation 19 back of McLeod's scheme.

Every possible obstacle is being placed in the way of William J. Gaynor's efforts to secure a copy of the Gravesend registry lists. The application for a mandamus to compel John Y. McKane and the eighteen Registry Inspectors to furnish a copy of the lists was yesterday postponed, through the counsel for the Gravesend men's taking advantage of insignificant legal technicalities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly permit me the necessary space in your journal to deny, once for all, and bury for good, all the sensational stories, alleged interviews with me, and highly-colored rumors concerning a robbery of $100,000, which have been printed, circulated, and told over the country during the last two weeks, in which I and one of the two shows I own are made to figure as the losers.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2. -- The funeral of Sir John Abbott, ex-Premier of Canada, took place from his residence in this city this afternoon, and was one of the largest and most representative over witnessed in Montreal. The Governor General, the Dominion Government, the Senate and House of Commons, the Montreal City Council, and other public bodies with which the deceased statesman had been connected during his long and distinguished career were all represented.

After to-day there will be little activity at the Democratic State Headquarters in West Twenty-fourth Street. So far as the real business of the canvass is concerned, it is already completed; and so far as its direction from the headquarters in the city is concerned, it will be closed to-day.

The big coastwise steamer El Cid, now being fitted out as a Brazilian war ship, was yesterday towed from the Erie Basin to the Morgan Iron Works, at the foot of East Ninth Street, East River. The work of fitting her up as a war ship will consume, it is calculated, fully three weeks.

The first missionary rally of the Sunday Schools and young people's societies of the Presbyterian Churches of New-York will be held to-night in the Central Presbyterian Church, West Fifty-seventh Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Wilton Merle Smith will preside. The special speakers of the evening will be the Rev. Dr. Wishard, Synodical Missionary for Utah, and Robert E. Speer of the Foreign Board of Missions.

The commute? appointed by the University Athletic Club to take charge of the Yals-Princeton football came hold a meeting in the clubhouse yesterday afternoon, and all the details for the big game were arranged. The lease for the use of Manhattan Field was practically signed, and the contracts were gives for the printing of tickets, posters, display bills,
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Americans opened today firm on account of the passage of the silver repeal bill. Atchisons were bought for Continental account.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- The receivers of the Reading Company appeared before Master in Chancery Crawford to-day on a petition asking for the ratification of certain acts done by them in connection with certain transactions involving the Reading Company and Messrs. Prince Co. of Boston and Ervin Co. of Philadelphia.

-- The will of Mrs. Anna E. Brown, widow of Charles Brown, which was admitted to probate in Quincy, Ill., on Tuesday, bequeaths $300,000 to public charities. Her four nearest relatives, including her father, receive legacies of $1,000 each. She gives $55,000 and her house and furniture in Quincy for a home for the aged poor of the city.

The Grand Army Mission is in need of funds to carry on its work for veterans. it invites the public to witness to-night its methods at its quarterly over-night meeting, in its rooms in the basement of the Pension Agency in Canal Street. Payment of pensions will begin to-morrow evening.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The annual banquet of the Sheffield Cutlers was held this evening. Among the conspicuous guests were Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador; Lord Roberts, formerly commander of the British forces in India; Earl Spencer, First Lord of the Admiralty, and the Duke of Norfolk. In answering a toast to his health, Mr. Bayard spoke substantially as follows:

A meeting of the Columbia College At hletic Union was held yesterday afternoon at the college for the annual election of members of the standing committees on rowing, track athletics, baseball, and football. Heretofore for the election of these committees a mass meeting was usually held, and the result was that men were elected who were not in the slightest degree capable of filling the positions to which they were elected.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- At a test of the new Brown five-inch wire gun at the proving grounds here to-day this piece of ordnance is claimed to have beaten the world's record for high velocities on low-chamber pressures. The test was conducted by Capt. Frank Heath, Ordnance Corps, United States Army.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 2. -- Francis H. Weeks, the New-York embezzler, passed through this city to-day bound north. As the train upon which he entered Atlanta did not make close connections with the Washington train upon which he was to continue his journey, the detectives having him in charge took him to one of the hotels.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Among the spectators who gathered at the Gaiety Theatre last night to see the burlesque, "Don Juan," written by James T. Tanner and Adrian Ross, was the Turkish Ambassador to Great Britain. The plot of the play is in part laid, in Constantinople, and one of the characters was the Sultan of Turkey.
German-American citizens joined in an emphatic protest against the election of Judge Maynard to the Court of Appeals at a mass meeting in Cooper Union last night.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- It is alleged by the Republicans that there are at least 1,200 illegal names on the registry lists of the City of Albany. At a meeting of the Republican County Committee, a few days ago, a committee was appointed to raise funds to procure proof to be used in actions to have the names alleged to be wrongfully on the registry lists taken off.

Five men were killed and fifteen persons were injured by the explosion of a boiler in East Fourteenth Street, near Avenue B, yesterday afternoon. The boiler, an upright, wag in the basement of the feed mill at the stables of the Dry Dock, East Broadway, and Battery Railroad Company, on the north side of Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The Harvey process in treating steel armor plates is not to be abandoned, as has been reported. It was alleged that the constructors having the work of affixing the armor to the sides and the decks of ships, complained that the Harvey process of hardening the plate to make it invulnerable to projectiles rendered it difficult to work, and prevented the entrance of bolts necessary to keep the plates in place.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- The market here, following New-York, has been generally weak, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy and Atchison being the most active stocks. Mexican Central decline 1 point, and Union Pacific 1 1/2. Old Colony was also off to 175 1/2. Bell Telephone was stronger, advancing to 194.

Personals. -- The date of the marriage of Miss Dyckman, daughter of Mrs. Isaac Dyckman of 15 East Seventy-first Street, has been set for the afternoon of Nov. 9. Miss Leary has returned to town. Cornelius Vanderbilt is in town with his son. Chauncey M. Depew and his daughter, the Countess de Sears, have returned from Newport, where they were the guests of Cornelius Vanderbilt.

Among the property which came up for sale under foreclosure proceedings at 111 Broadway yesterday was the unfinished Hotel Casa Alameda, at the junction of the Boulevard, Columbus Avenue, and Sixty-third Street. The Brush Brothers began and nearly completed the structure, when their funds gave out and the financial stringency arose.

TUXEDO PARK, Nov. 3. -- The Tuxedo Association save its annual Autumn ball this evening at the clubhouse. The ball was by far the most brilliant social function that has taken place in the fashionable suburbs of New-York this season. There were about 400 guests present.

As the last week of the campaign closes, the managers of the Broklyn "ring" are unflagging in their desperate efforts to save David A. Boody and return the McLaughlin "machine" to power at any cost. All the corrupt methods to thwart the public will, with which the White Caps of the "ring" are so familiar, have been put in operation.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- With naval honors the funeral of Capt. Oliver A. Batchellor, formerly commander of the United States ship Concord, took place this afternoon from the residence of his father-in-law. Dr. Lyons, at Monument Square, Charlestown. Capt. Batchellor died last Monday in South Carolina, and his body was brought home for burial.
Money on call loaned at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

It was on Aug. 16 that The New-York Times first and exclusively told District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll where Francis Henry Weeks was. After that publication his capture was but a work of time and diplomacy.

-- The Tammany Committee on Organization met yesterday afternoon to compare notes on the outlook for the election in this city. Henry D. Purroy, the Chairman, asked that the leaders be particular to report any weak spots in their districts, especially as to Judge Maynard. In general, the leaders said everything was in good shape, and that Maynard would run well.

Capt. Mackey of the University of Pennsylvania team has wired a protest to Dr. Brooks of Harvard, who is to referee the Pennsylvania Princeton game this afternoon, against King, or, rather, a steel plate that the latter wears nowadays.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Wheat was exceedingly quiet to-day. What little trading there was was principally local. The opening was 1/3@1/4c lower than yesterdays close, a further decline of 1/4c taking place, then rallied, and with some fluctuations advanced about 3/4c for December and 1c for May, then eased off, and the closing was fractionally higher for December and 1/8@1/4c higher for May.

VIENNA, Nov. 3. -- The German Liberals were to hold a meeting in the Ronacher Music Hall to-day, but it did not take place. Many Socialists had gathered in the neighborhood long before the hour of opening. The first Liberals to arrive were jeered and hooted. Police protection was called for, and twelve men were stationed at the entrance to keep back the Socialists.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3. -- The whaling bark Alaska arrived from the Arctic Ocean this morning with a report of the catch of the whaling fleet up to Oct. 9. Of forty-three vessels, eighteen were clean at that date. Of the others, a number made very large catches, principally by steam whalers. Report by the Alaska shows that never in the history of the world has the present catch been equaled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- No man in the Senate was more pleased at the adjournment than Mr. Voorhees, Chairman of the Committee on Finance of the Senate, who was the manager of the Silver Repeal bill in the Senate during the long weeks that the measure was under discussion. After it was all over Mr. Voorhees was asked to give his views on the contest and the prospect for the future.

Mrs. Christine Lathrop Gunning, a niece of the late Leland Stanford, and a beneficiary under his will to the extent of $100,000, is defendant in a suit brought by the Lincoln National Bank to recover the face value and interest on a note of $5,000, executed in 1885 by Mrs. Gunning's husband.

BOSTON Nov. 3. -- The Supreme Court of Massachusetts decided to-day that the interchangeable mileage law passed by the last Legislature, and requiring that each railroad in the State shall honor mileage books issued by any of the other roads, is unconstitutional.

The misgovernment of Brooklyn seems to be so rooted and inveterate that it is, perhaps, not wonderful that many of those who are most anxious for the overthrow of the ring are not so confident about it as the facts would justify them in being. They are prone to consider the prospect of opposition as not more than "a fighting chance."

The Campaign Committee of the Good Government Organization has learned that the Republican machine leaders in the Twenty-first Assembly District are coming out with a statement prepared by James A. Blanchard, John Proctor Clark, and Otto Irving Wise, attacking the organization with the intention of inducing Republicans in the district to vote for Mr. Wise for the Assembly.

The candidacy of MAYNARD has so absorbed the interest of the people of this State in the present canvass that little attention is given to the contests going on elsewhere, but these are not many, and, with two or three exceptions, they cannot be considered very important. There are only eleven States besides New-York that hold elections this year, and in only four of these are prominent State officers to be chosen.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Cornell University has been favored with a gift of two line libraries, one of 1,000 volumes on the German philosopher Kant, and the other of 500 volumes on Spinoza. With these libraries go also a flue collection of portraits of both these philosophers, comprising all the authentic copies that have ever been published.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 3. -- Henry W. Cannon, President of the Chase National Bank of New-York, lectured to-day to the students of Union College on "Banking and Currency." The lecture was one of the "Butterfield" course, which was commenced something over a year ago. Mr. Cannon gave his audience a clear description of the banking business of the country and a history of its growth from the early days of the Republic to the present time.

A large van, surmounted by a transparency setting forth in big black letters that all men who were opposed to Mayor Boody's re-election were traitors to Brooklyn, rolled solemnly up Fulton Street, in that city, yesterday. It drew up at the curb around the City Hall, under the windows of the Mayor's office.

The new steamship Britannia, purchased by Flint Co. from the North American Steamship Company for the Brazilian Government, reached this port last night. The Britannia was towed by two powerful tugs from Boston. She lies in the Erie Basin.

In order to learn if there exist valid grounds upon which the Navy Department can deny the right of the Palmer Company to sell the cruiser Marblehead to the Brazilian Government, a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday requested an opinion of Attorney William H. Stayton of 150 Broadway.

-- A workman in the Senate barber's shop in Washington is credited with saying that the Senators are "the most peaceful" men to shave he has ever met, though some of them are very particular. One Senator, he says, he has twice shaved three times in one day, not because his beard grows very fast, but because the Senator "likes the sensation."

FALMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 3. -- The Rev. Harry L. Strickland, about thirty-five years old, who has filled the pastorates of the Congregational churches in the villages of Hatchville and Wamquit for the past eighteen months, was dismissed from his charge last Sunday when it became known that he was a bigamist.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- Never has there been so much excitement in this city over a football game as prevails to-night concerning the Princeton-University of Pennsylvania contest at Manheim. That it will be the most exciting game that has ever taken place between the two big colleges is the general opinion. Intense rivalry prevails between the elevens owing to the siding of Princeton with Yale on the undergraduate-rule question.
It was rumored last night that Flint Co. were negotiating with the Metropolitan Steamship Company for the purchase of one of the two fine steamers Herman Winter and H.F. Dimock.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Nov. 3 -- P.M. The stock market was very irregular today, but net changes were generally in the direction of lower prices. Trading was slightly more active than on Thursday, total transactions on the Exchange being over 307,000 shares.

The following is an appeal which has been issued by the older son of "Richelieu "Robinson. It tells many reasons why the unscrupulous ring which has for so many years grossly mismanaged and plundered the City of Brooklyn should be overthrown, and why it is the duty of every honest and self-respecting citizen to vote against its candidates. This is the appeal:
Before being dismissed yesterday the October Grand Jury handed in sixty indictments for illegal registration to Judge Martine of the Court of Common Pleas.
Charles A. Schieren is doing great work. He is attending from eight to a dozen meetings every night, and during the day is visiting the many factories in Brooklyn.

Detectives Kehoe and McDermott of the Fifth Police Precinct yesterday arrested a bold young thief who for a number of weeks has been stealing goods from down-town merchants under the guise of an expressman. In the station house he gave the name of John Magnus, age eighteen, of 207 East One Hundred and Seventh Street.

The crack football team of the Boston Athletic Association arrived in town last night in company with the Harvard boys. The Boston Athletics, under the direction of Capt. Waters, one of Harvard's old players, will meet the Crescents at Eastern Park this afternoon. It will be the first meeting of these two representative organizations. An official timer will be introduced for the first time in this vicinity.

Some of the Southern Senators who have lately been engaged in filibustering at Washington will get valuable information about silver during their brief sojourn among the people of their home States. They will discover that so far from crying aloud for more silver dollars the South has now more of them than it needs, can use, or take care of.

Francis Henry Weeks, embezzler of trust funds, deliberate despoiler of the many fortunes intrusted to his care, is a prisoner in the Tombs, awaiting trial in the Court of General Sessions on five indictments, presented by the Grand Jury Sept. 12.

WEST POINT, Nov. 3. -- Judge Brown of the Supreme Court has issued a mandamus for the Inspectors of the Board of Registry of Highland Falls to appear before him tomorrow, at Newburg, to show cause why the names of a number of residents of West Point should not be stricken from the list of voters.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 3. -- Parmenas King, seventy years old, a farmer of West Hampton, saw a masked man taking a watch from a nail at the head of his bed this morning. He spoke to the intruder, who thereupon struck him on the head threee times with a sled stake. Mr. King is in a precarious condition.

All efforts to prevent violations of the election laws should be vigorously sustained, but the most effectual deterrent for these infamous offenses would be a resolute enforcement of the legal penalties. The laws of this State not only provide strict requirements to prevent frauds upon the ballot box, but in the Penal Code there are provisions for their severe punishment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The President this afternoon issued the following Thanksgiving Day proclamation: By the President of the United States of America.

-- The new committee of American holders of the Northern Pacific consolidated bonds has opened an office on the fourth floor of the Mills Building. A large number of letters has been received from holders of such bonds assuring the committee of cordial co-operation.
The October Grand Jury in Brooklyn yesterday handed up three presentments to County Judge Henry A. Moore.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Ex-Sheriff Jacob C. Daubman called Frank Patterson, late editor of The Courier, a "blackmailer" to-day, and a fight ensued. Daubman accused Patterson of being the author of the articles published in The New-York Times, exposing "Billy" Thompson, the "Duke of Gloucester." The epithet was used in connection with this accusation.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 3 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef and pork in moderate demand. Hams in poor demand. Bacon in poor demand; Cumberland cut, about 28 to 30 lb, easy at 50s 6d; long clear middles, about 45 lb, easy at 50s 6d. Shoulders, about 13 to 18 lb, dull at 37s 6d. Cheese in poor demand. Tallow in poor demand. Spirits of turpentine in moderate demand: steady at 22s 6d.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Football is becoming a delicate subject for discussion at Cornell. Since the Princeton game in New-York there has been the greatest dearth of football interest that the university has experienced since the introduction of the game here. Not only the men who play on the 'Varsity, but even the second eleven, seem to have caught the spirit of listlessness, and refuse to come to the practice games.

Messrs. M. L. Hess have sold for Clark Brothers, on private terms, the three-story brick building and lot, 603 Broadway, west side, south of Houston Street. The lot measures 25 by 103, and the property was bought on April 1, 1889, for $110,000. The name of the purchaser is withheld for the present.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 3. -- There was something of a row -- a "little tiff," the lady calls it -- between Charles and Rose Coghlan this morning, and several interesting stories got afloat.

All through Thursday night and yesterday morning the work of clearing away the debris at the Dry Dock and Bast Broadway car stables, in East Fourteenth Street, went on without interruption. It was not until 4:30 in the morning that the body of John Armstrong, the engineer who had charge of the engine in the feed mill whose boiler exploded, killing five persons and injuring fifteen, besides wrecking buildings, was found.

More than 20,000 bales of cotton have been landed this week on the piers of the New-Orleans steamship lines, where they are awaiting transportation to Liverpool by one of the ocean lines, under contract for delivery in the present month. The activity infused into the Southern markets by improving conditions is illustrated by the arrival this week of five ships from New-Orleans, all with heavy cargoes.
Mr. Henry Villard has sent to The New-York Times the following letter:

George Lingard, fifty years old, a bookkeeper and expert accountant, who had lived at 485 Halsey Street. Brooklyn, was looked up in Police Headquarters last evening charged with a series of forgeries amounting to upward of $27,000. If the police record is correct. Lingard has teen carrying on his swindling for several years, when detected, compromising with his victims.

The decision of Chief Justice Daly of the Court of Common Pleas Thursday, in the action brought by Alexander Stewart to eject Henry Hilton from the realty of Alexander T. Stewart, was a victory for Mr. Hiton. The suit was dismissed, as it had been treated once before by Judge Pryor.

This is a season of record-breaking exploits on the transatlantic race course. The Cunard people are just now enjoying a monopoly of such events. Possessing such giant racers as the Lucania and Campania, it could hardly be otherwise. It is not surprising to see the time lowered on each successive trip.

The Republican Campaign Committee of Brooklyn, is doing great work. For the first time in years a full set of paster ballots has been sent to every voter in the city. Last night, many letters were received at Republican campaign headquarters, complimenting the committee on its excellent work. This means many votes for Mr. Schieren, as the paster ballot is a thing which hundreds of Democrats have been asking for.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The Walker board, detailed to ascertain the true condition of the new navy, held its first session at the Navy Department to-day. The work was merely preliminary to the important inquiry which the board is engaged upon. A request was sent to the chiefs of the bureaus for all the information in their possession bearing in any way on the subject under discussion.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- A waterman employed to attend the workmen who are engaged on a temporary scaffold beneath the Westminster Bridge found on Wednesday last a large parcel, wrapped in brown peper, on a ledge of the centre buttress. He was horrified when he learned that it contained a conical iron bomb weighing about seven pounds.

"We had no trouble whatever with Weeks on the way up from San Jose," said Detective Von Gerichten to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday. "He was quiet, said little, and he and his wife spent most of their time in their stateroom.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- The market opened with Philadelphia a liberal seller of St. Paul. Later in the day on the reaction it bought back considerable stock. Read- ing was also fairly active, fluctuations sympathizing with the New-York market.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -- Thomas L. McClung, Yale's old half back and Captain, gave Capt. Hinkey of the eleven a pleasant surprise to-day by appearing unannounced to coach the team. "Hammy" Wallis, last year's tackle, also visited Yale unexpectedly, and lent a voice to the coaching. Five former players were on hand -- McClung, Wallis, Rhodes, Terry, and McCormick.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- A dispatch from Johannesburg says it is rumored there that heavy fighting has occurred in the bush along the Shangani River, and that King Lobengula has been captured by the Chartered Company's forces.

The Montana silver statue of "Justice," modeled after Ada Rehan, and which was a conspicuous exhibit at the World's Fair, arrived at the Grand Central Station last night. In the same car was the solid gold pedestal, valued at $224,000.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 3. -- Miss Susan B. Anthony talked this evening to a reporter on the right of women to vote for School Commissioners in the rural districts. She was confident that the Court of Appeals would sustain the law of 1892 as constitutional. She said that all women who had registered should vote, unless they had been specially enjoined against voting.

So far as the work from the headquarters in this city is concerned, the Democratic State campaign was finished yesterday. Both Senators Murphy and Hill spent the day here, and departed last night. The headquarters in West Twenty-fourth Street are now in charge of Secretary De Freest, who will remain here until Monday to attend to the final details.

From all over Brooklyn reports of police interference with the Republican and reform candidates have been received. Several of Mr. Schieren's men, employed in distributing circulars, have been intimidated and their circulars thrown into the sewer.

Otto L. Braumiller, head of the Braumiller Piano Company, has begun suit in the Superior Court for absolute divorce from his wife, Luetta E. Braumiller, a well-known Fifth Avenue dealer in art materials and the editor of The China Decorator. W. Earie Holcombe, the manager of Mrs. Braumiller's store, is named as corespondent.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3. -- There may be a big strike on the East Tennessee Railway system. Receivers of the load say that engineers, conductors, and firemen must work under a 10 per cent, reduction in wages. Chiefs Arthur, Clark, and Sargeant arrived hero to-day and were informed by the Joint Grievance Committee that the men would positively refuse to work for the reduced wages.

Otto Irving Wise, who is the Republican candidate for the Assembly in the Twenty-first Assembly District, left the Democratic Party during the Presidential campaign of last year. The following extract from The New-York Tribune of Oct. 15, 1892, was printed under the heading or "He Can't Stand their Plank":

"Illegal registration in this city is something astounding," Col. Alexander S. Bacon of the Republican Campaign Committee's bureau to investigate registration frauds said yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times.

There was some apologizing and explaining over the final adjournment of the extra session of Congress yesterday, but there was no occasion for it. It had accomplished the one thing for which it was called together, and nobody outside of its own halls desired to have it remain in Washington any longer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Important action was taken by the Treasury Department to-day in regard to silver. Orders were sent to the Superintendents of the United States Mints at San Francisco and New-Orleans to resume the coinage suspended some time ago of standard silver dollars. This action is taken under authority of Section 3 of the Sherman law of 1890, which is as follows:

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The markets were irregular to-day and transactions were small. Americans opened steady, but soon advanced under the lead of Louisville and Nashville, which stocks were bought on rumors of an alliance with the Illinois Central. The close was dull at considerable declines from the highest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The first session of the Fifty-third Congress closed quietly in the Senate and ludicrously in the House, which was engaged in a heated scramble with the Senate over a dispute about the payment of the employes of the two houses. It was anything but a dignified or creditable last scene for a House of Representatives that has made an extremely good record for itself.

Chairman William Brookfield of the Republican State Committee gave out the following at 10 o'clock last night. It is a broadside against the candidacy of Judge Isaac H. Maynard for the Court of Appeals:

MR. HARGOUS'S DINNER PARTY. -- Robert Hargous made a graceful recognition of the many social courtesies shown him since his return to town from a long foreign tour by Riving a large dinner party last evening at Delmonico's. The table, oval in shape, was set in the red dining room on the second floor. The decorations, which were the work of Hodgson, were of an exceptional character.

In the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, in the very heart of the down-town business section of the city, R.G. Pearson, the Southern evangelist, is to begin next Monday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, a vigorous Gospel campaign.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Spanish Embassy in this city has received the folowing dispatch from the Government at Madrid:

-- The Woman's Literary Club of Baltimore on Thursday scattered flowers on the graves of Edgar Allan Poe, Sidney Lanier, the poet; William H. Rinehart, the sculptor; Mrs. Almira Hart Lincoln Phelps, a noted educator; John P. Kennedy, the author; Mrs. Anne Moncure Seemuller and Mrs. Mary Spear Tiernan, novelists; Junius Brutus Booth, and others.

Bradstreet's to-morrow will say: "Telegraphic advices from many of the more important business centres are that some effects of the passage of the silver purchase repeal law are reflected in an improved tone in financial circles and the growth of confidence of merchants in the outlook.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 3. -- William Burke, a laborer employed on the Consolidated Road, just outside of this city, was shot by Samuel Grinrod, an East End resident, at 3:45 this morning, and will probably die. Three bullets are lodged in his body. Grinrod immediately fled, and the police are searching the surrounding country for him

There has never been in the history of Brooklyn such a large and representative gathering of the men identified with the ownership, the sale, and the renting of Brooklyn property, as that of last night in the Real Estate Exchange, in Montague Street, to hear Edward M. Shepard arraign the administration of Mayor David A. Boody on purely business and practical grounds.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 4. -- South-bound Iron Mountain Train No. 51 was stopped by seven masked bandits at Oliphant, a small station seven miles north of Newport, late last night. As soon as the train was brought to a standstill, the bandits began firing into the express car. Conductor W.P. McNally rushed to the platform and fired into the attacking party.

The Citizens' Committee of One Hundred in Brooklyn has issued a timely circular enumerating offenses against the election laws and the penalties provided therefor, and offering rewards aggregating $50,000 for evidence resulting in the conviction of violators of the law; The reward for each of the first five convictions is $1,000, and the lowest reward offered is $200.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 4 -- The City Council has completed negotiations with N.W. Harris Co. of New-York, Chicago, and Boston, for a twenty-year 5 per cent. gold loan of $345,000 for sewer purposes, and also later on the funding of $630,000 of old indebtedness, thereby saving the city quite a large amount in interest annually.

"Shore Acres" is a good play, one that is quite in keeping with the spirit of these times, exceedingly well devised and well written, involving a simple tale of domestic life, the truth to nature of which is easily recognized. But it is not a great or surprisingly original play or an epoch-maker in any sense.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 4 -- The charges against Col. J. Hampton Hoge of Virginia are rapidly increasing. It has been said that he imbibed too freely of the cup that cheers. What appears, however, to be the correct explanation of Mr. Hoge's recall from his predestined post at Amory, China, was learned this evening. G.W.S. Musgrave is a well-known attorney at law in this city.

Twenty years ago it was considered quite a big undertaking for an advertiser to contract for $50,000 worth of space in the newspapers of the country, whereas to-day there are a number of concerns which spend anywhere from $300,000 to $600,000 a year in advertising in this country alone.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- One of the noticeable things, now that the World's Fair has closed, is the position in which it leaves American manufacturers, as compared with those of Europe. The exposition accomplished its greatest commercial result in demonstrating the tremendous strides which this country has taken in the manufacture of articles which have heretofore achieved their greatest perfection across the water.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 4 - A condition or affairs exists in the City of Buffalo unparalleled in the history of the State of New York or in that of any other State in the Union. No one, unless he lives here or has visited here, can begin to appreciate the situation.

The attempt of the Brooklyn "ring" managers to withold the tax rate until after election has been frustrated. They became frightened by the statement of William J. Gaynor that it would be $2.99 on $100.

One of the most humorous phases of the Brooklyn campaign is the efforts of the ringsters to create an anti-Schieren sentiment among Republicans through the charge that the Republican and Citizens' candidate for Major voted against James G. Blaine. The grief of the Democratic "machine" managers because of the "Plumed Knight's" defeat is pitiful.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 4. -- Bank Commissioner Sherwood has issued an abstract of the reports made by the State and national banks as to their condition at the close or business Oct. 31. The figures are startling. The total deposits of the 159 State banks amounted to $54,737,225. Since May 4 the deposits have fallen off $10,795,852. or nearly 20 per cent.
I. The Illegal Voter. It is not exactly with pleasure, at all events, but it is, perhaps, with some sort of pride that I make this admission:

A communion service of great beauty has been recently completed for the Church of the Messiah, in Brooklyn. The set is the gift of Capt. Andrew C. Zabriskie of this city as a memorial of his life-long friend. Arthur M. Pike. The general style of the set is Byzantine, in harmony with the new chancel of the church, recently described in The Times.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- [By Commercial Cable from our Own Correspondent.] -- England has resumed the thread of English Parliamentary legislation, after the past year's boisterous embattled interruption, as calmly as if there had never been any Irish question at all.

In the pursuit of the scoundrels who have been illegally registered in Brooklyn, the supporters of the anti-" ring" candidate for Mayor have found obstacles interposed in their path at every turn by officers of the law.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Gov. Flower this afternoon qualified at the Rensselaer Wyck Rille Range, scoring 44 one of a possible 50. When the Governor qualified at Creedmoor last year he scored 39 out of a possible 50.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Wheat was weak to-day, with a good trade. Longs were the principal sellers, although Pardridge and shorts lent a hand to the downward course. The selling was mainly of the December option, with considerable of it changed to the May. As delivery day for December approaches holders are concluding either to protect their losses or transfer their contracts to later months rather than run any farther risk.

SANTANDER, Spain, Nov. 4 -- At least 300 persons were killed and hundreds of others were injured in an explosion that took place here last night. The precise number killed and injured cannot be given, because many of the victims are buried beneath the ruins of sixty-five or seventy buildings that were tumbled to the ground.

"Is it not curious," said one woman to another the other day at a luncheon. "that we women, who should know our own sex, seem always to be surprised at any unfamiliar instance of feminine capacity? It is my belief that women are especially executive, and have especial talents for organization, which lack only opportunity to develop themselves.

The sale of seats for the opening of Brooklyn's new and handsome theatre, the Bijou, will begin to-morrow. A week from tomorrow evening the theatre will be thrown open as a place of public amusement, the attraction being Henry E. Dixey, with his own company, in the latest version of "Adonis," known as "Adonis Up to Date."

A beautiful hat for a child is of white, stiff felt. It has a round crown and rather a wide, straight brim, neither caught up anywhere, nor convoluted. The principal trimming is the head and brush of a white fox. The brush is long enough to encircle the crown, and is touched with black. How faithfully it accords with nature in its make-up is immaterial, since, as a trimming.

Austen G. Fox, Francis M. Scott, and William Travers Jerome, the Committee on Watchers at the Polls, in behalf of the Democratic committee of fifty in charge of the anti-Maynard movement reported, last night to the Executive Committee that arrangements had been made to guard the polls on Tuesday.

The auction sales of real estate for the present week are nearly all in legal proceedings, and include some desirable property. A detailed list of offerings, which will be made at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated, is appended:
To their credit and hotlor, thousands of Democrats have openly declared their determination to vote against Isaac H. Maynard. Their number should swell to the proportions of a general party movement.
BUFFALO, Nov. 4 -- Senator Hill addressed a large and enthusiastic meeting here this evening. He was warmly received. The striking thing in his speech was his indorsement of Mr. Cleveland.

A meeting of the committee appointed by the American Railway Association to consider the subject of interlocking and block signals will be held at the Hotel Brunswick, in this city, within a few days. This committee is composed of the following experienced railroad men:

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The repeal of the Sherman act and the cancellation of the balance of the Clearing House loan certificates have removed the principal obstacles to the return of confidence in American railway values, but the situation is not yet considered satisfactory, and the recent rise discounted probable benefits.

The promise of additional business in real estate has met with some fruition during the past week. Brokers report not only negotiations, but a number of sales, indicating a revival of interest and of investment. A number of these sales have been printed from day to day in the columns of The New-York Times.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- The Clearing House rate remained unchanged to-day at 2 per cent. Call money on first-class collateral is quoted at 2 1/2@3 per cent., and time money at 3 1/2@4 per cent. New-York funds were weaker, selling at 15@20 cents a thousand discount.

In Hudson County the energies of the ring of gamblers will be entirely directed to the election of their candidate for Sheriff, Mr. Stanton, who was formerly a Mayor of Hoboken. When acting in that capacity he was one of the guests who "honored" Walbaum, better known to the police as "Dutch Fred."

The phenomena of hypnotism may be viewed from two distinct standpoints -- one, that from which the physical and especially the therapeutical features are most prominent, the standpoint from which we have already viewed the subject; the other is the psychical or mental aspect, which presents phenomena no less striking, and is the one which is especially attractive to the more earnest students of psychology.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- It is apparent from developments this side of the ocean that dissatisfied politicians and ambitious naval officers, aided, by Brazilians in Europe who favor the restoration of the Brazilian monarchy, originated the insurrection headed by Admiral Hello.

Now that Manager A.M. Palmer, with courageous enterprise, has stepped outside of his customary field and is going to bring over Slivinski, the Polish pianist, who has aroused great enthusiasm in London, many persons are wondering whether Rubinstein cannot be induced to come over once more and show us all how the piano really ought to be played.
Edmund Clarence Stedman is sixty years of ape to-day.

The broad subject of mines and mining, with especial reference to coal, Iron, and salt, was the subject of the lecture by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore before the teachers of New-York City and State, at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday morning. The Illustrations were chiefly from the World's Pair, and they showed some of the more important exhibits of these minerals made there.

The National Quarantine Committee of the New-York Academy of Medicine has just finished drafting a bill for presentation to Congress which, if is becomes a law, will entirely revolutionize the present quarantine laws of the United States. The bill is rendered doubly interesting as President Cleveland has already given its provisions his personal indorsement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The Stock market here to-day has been very dull, but steady. Reading and St. Paul were slightly higher the first hour, but reacted at the close in sympathy with the weakness in the New-York market. Lehigh Valley opened at 41, and declined to 40 1/2 on very limited transactions.

Good Government Club D is working very hard to secure the election of James R. Sheffield to the Assembly in the Eleventh Assembly District. The track campaign which the members of the club have been conducting has been interesting and has borne good results. Watchers, workers, and challengers have been provided for service on election day, and they will be instructed to-day and to-morrow as to the provisions of the election law.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Lake Street Elevated opened two points above last night's close. Then several large lots were dealt in around 28 and under. By persistent hammering about 2,000 shares were sold, sending the price to 27 5/3. The first sale of West Chicago was at 157 1/2, ex dividend. A decline to 157 followed.

BUFFALO, Nov. 4 -- Senator Hill arrived here this morning to fulfill an engagement to deliver an address to the Democrats of Buffalo. He was to have spoken at the mass meeting last Monday night, but was prevented from being present by reason of the necessity for his presence in the Senate at Washington until after the silver repeal bill should be disposed of.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- A private dispatch received in this city from Buenos Ayres reiterates the report published here Nov. 1 that the rebel Brazilian war ship Republica ran into and sank the Government transport Rio de Janeiro while the latter vessel was conveying troops from Rio Grande do Sul to assist the Government forces at Rio de Janeiro.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Brig. Gen. Robert Williams, the Adjutant General of the army, will be sixty-two years of age to-morrow, and his retirement from active service will take place from that date.

The Brooklyn tax rate was held back as one as possible because under ring administration in that city the tax rate is always a terrible campaign document against the city's rulers. Mayor BOODY finally comes out with, the statement that the tax rate this year will be "about $2.84 to the $100."

Patti, who arrived in the record-breaking Lucania Friday night with her husband. Signor Nicolini, went from the steamer to the Windsor Hotel yesterday. The great diva was very seasick on the voyage over and continued indisposed yesterday and last night. She received no visitors. Speaking in her behalf, her manager, Marcus Mayor, said:
Gen. Jose Manuel Hernandez was a passenger on the Caracas, which sailed yesterday for Venezuela.

Elections will be held next Tuesday, Nov. 7, in eleven States -- Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Nebraska, New-Jersey, New-York, Ohio. Pennsylvania, South Dakota, and Virginia. State tickets will be elected in Iowa, Massachusetts, Ohio, and Virginia. New-York elects all State officers, except Governor and Lieutenant Governor, and a Legislature and delegates to the Constitutional convention.

Reports recently received by the Marine Hospital Bureau from Dr. YOUNG, the Sanitary Inspector at Naples, narrate the lamentable experience of the two steamships which went to South America several weeks ago, carrying emigrants from that port, and were forced to return to Italy without landing any of their passengers, owing to the prevalence of cholera on board.

The question of dress reform does not seem very much in evidence at the moment, with the shops filled with women hurrying from one counter to another intent on chiffons of every sort, and the extraordinary models of cloaks and gowns seen in every shop window have not in them much of the severe simplicity and convenient design of which the advocates of the "dress of the coming woman" preach.

"Olaf," a romantic drama in five acts, from the German of Roderick Fels, will be produced at Niblo's to-morrow night, with fine scenic pictures. The story concerns the love of a poor huntsman for the imperious and seemingly heartless daughter of cruel King Marbod. The time is the ninth century.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Burglary, followed by a fire, probably of incendiary origin, at Frank B. Wheeler's house in Wilmette, a suburb of this city, early this morning, resulted in two deaths. The dead are:
Winfield Booz, the saloonkeeper who was shot in the head Friday night at his place of business, 145 Meserole Avenue, Greenpoint, by John Mehlen, died yesterday in the Eastern District Hospital.

Gov. Fishback's declaration that the Corbett-Mitchell fight shall not take place on the soil of Arkansas will be welcomed by the people of that State. Gov. Matthews of Indiana will prevent it in that State, and Gov. Foster of Louisiana has served notice that there shall be no more finish fighting in New-Orleans.
All the surface indications point to the election in Brooklyn on Tuesday next by a handsome majority of the people's anti-ring candidate for Mayor, Charles A. Schieren.

The New-York Times has issued a NewJersey campaign supplement, a copy of which ought to be in the hands of every voter in this State. Four solid pages are devoted to exposing the tricks and the infamous methods employed by Boss Thompson and his gang of assistants to defeat the honest people of New-Jersey and in showing what splendid progress moral sentiment is malting against the horde of conspirators.

-- The Illustrated Buffalo Express announces the conditions of Its third annual contest for amateur photographers, with $125 in cash prizes. The contest closes Dec. 15. and the awards will be announced in the Christmas Express.

Charles Frohman's stock company will again take possession of the stage of the Empire Theatre to-morrow night and present "The Councilor's Wife," a charming play by Jerome K. Jerome and Eben Philpotts, which has already been seen here at one matinee performance.

The election day sports of the Washington Wheelmen, to be held at Berkeley Oval, are attracting much attention among wheelmen. The entries to the various bicycle races are numerous, and some fast men will race on the excellent track at the oval.
The educational campaign which Mayor Boody invited is at an end, so far as the Mayoralty canvass is concerned.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Emperor William will start on Tuesday for Wurtemburg, where he will join King William. Together they will go on a hunting expedition to Castle Babenhausen.

-- Otto Kempner, the independent candidate for Assembly in the Seventh District, called on Superintendent Byrnes yesterday and complained that the police of the Fourteenth Precinor, claiming to act under the orders of their superiors, had been interfering with his canvass of the district. He said that policemen in plain clothes had bean going about the district tearing down his posters and compelling storekeepers, by throats, to take his lithographs out of their windows.

The preparations for the Candy Exposition which is to be held in Lenox Lyceum are nearly completed. Handsome booths have been erected, and by the time the doors are opened to the public all the machinery which is to show how candles are made will be in working order.

-- The Directors of the New-York Philharmonic Society have just signed an agreement with his managers for the first appearance in New-York this season of Henri Marteau, the famous French violinist, on Dec. 15 and 16. Mr. Marteau will perform the Brahms concerto, Opus 77, his interpretation of which under the conductorship of Hans Richter in Vienna and London met with marked approval.
The fourteenth annual report or Morris Goodhart, the President of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, has been published. It shows a gratifying progress made by the society. The President says:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- The cadat and Union College teams played an exciting football game on the plains to-day. The rain poured in torrents and snow fell thick and fast during the game. It was agreed that two halves of twenty minutes each would be sufficient on account of the bad weather.

The football team of the Boston Athletic Association played against the Crescent Athletic Club team at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. About 100 admirers of the came shivered on the grand stand and shouted themselves hoarse in a vain attempt to keep warm. The game was an interesting one. and ended in a victory for the visitors by a score of 12 to 8.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The case of Judge Maynard has been fully discussed, but, as Mr. Carter said at the meeting at the Cooper Institute on October 26, it cannot be discussed and explained too much.
In the long night-time, when the ward was chill And drear with sleeping faces, thin and white, One lay in wakeful silence, wan and still, And waited for the light.

The Montana silver statue of Justice, modeled after Ada Rehan, which attracted so much attention during the World's Fair, will be on exhibition for the next four weeks at the dry goods store of Abraham Straus, 422 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 4. -- The Richardson Memorial Medical College building was formally turned over to Tulane University to-day by Mrs. Ida Richardson. Dr. Edmond Souehon presented the building to Col. William Preston Johnston, President of the university, who in turn gave it into the custody of Dr. Stanford C. Challle.

A man and a boy on wheels in Gramercy Park the other day were noticeable because of their different styles of dress, the former wearing an ordinary business suit, while the boy, a bright-faced young fellow, made an attractive picture in a regular bicycle suit -- knickerbockers, leather leggins, a short coat, buttoned to the chin, and a cap.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The old and long-established piano and organ makers of the East can no longer ignore the younger and more pushing manufacturers of the West. This is one of the facts established by the late exposition, and it is giving the Eastern makers no little concern. Especially has the World's Fair made it clear that firstclass pianos and organs are now produced this side of the Ohio.

"Billy" Thompson has been compelled to change his programme for the capture of the State of New-Jersey. Circumstances which he cannot in the least control have compelled him to abandon one-half of his projected raid on the body of lawmakers that are to meet in Trenton in January next.

With the exception of Judge Maynard, every candidate on the Democratic State ticket has established a reputation as a business man. Every one of them, from Cord Meyer, Jr., the candidate for Secretary of State, down to Martin Schenck, candidate for State Engineer and Surveyor, ought to command the indorsement of every man in the State who believes in the application of business principles to public office.

The report of the Bureau of Vital Statistics for the week ended at noon yesterday shows that the health of the city is good. There were during the week 675 deaths, 1,100 births, and 351 marriages. The deaths were 29 more than during the preceding week, (when they were exceptionally low,) and 44 less than the average for the corresponding week during the past five years.

Business was quiet at the Republican Headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotal yesterday, and all the managers regarded Mr. Bartlett's election as certain. Thomas C. Platt, Chairman Brookfield, and Chairman Hackett of the Executive Committee of the Republican State Committee had signed articles in one of yesterday afternoon's Republican papers predicting Mr. Bartlett's election.

Mrs. Laura Ormiston Chant, the English lecturer on economic subjects, spoke before the Ladies' Heann Association of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, to an audience which, despite the bad weather, almost filled the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association.

Police Sergeant James G. Cooper of the Tremont Police Station in Bathgate Avenue, near One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street, was arraigned yesterday morning in the Morrisania Police Court, charged with shooting twelveyear-old Frederick Dullin, the son of Richard Dullin of Woodlawn. Justice Simms held him in $1,000 bail for examination to-morrow morning.
As the result of an effort to crowd twenty-two persons into a small Whitehall boat. Which could not safely carry more than half that number, ten men were drowned in Raritan Bay yesterday.

A certificate of incorporation, approved by Justice Barrett or the Supreme Court, was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office, signed by John S. Huyler, Samuel H. Hadley, William Evans, George F. Langenbacher, and Henry T. Hadley, as incorporators of the Christian Men's Union for Total Abstinence and Rescue Work.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 4. -- "Billy" Thompson's money has arrived, and the "Court House gang" got their fingers on it to-day. The bundle was a large one, and most of the bills were crisp two-dollar certificates. There were some larger ones among them, but these will stick in the pockets of the men who are to have the handling of the corruption fund.

Francis Henry Weeks is still a prisoner in the Tombs and is likely to stay there until next Friday at least. The question of bail has not yet been raised by him. If he should ask for temporary release, District Attorney Nicoll would certainly require at least $20,000.

Having bad experience in previous years with the obstacles thrown in the way of challengers and watchers at the polls. Lawyer Alfred K. Conkling sent a letter on Nov. 1 to the Board of Police Commissioners, saying:

Dr. Alphonse M. Wallace, as examining physician of the outdoor department of the poor at Bellevue Hospital, is very ill at his home, 257 East Forty-eighth Street, from the effects of a bite on his right hand which was inflicted by a woman patient at the hospital two weeks ago. The bite was given by a woman about twenty-nine years old, who came to Dr. Wallace's department much under the influence of liquor.
