The third annual report to the stockholders of the American Cotton Oil Company has just been prepared, and it is an uncommonly clear and instructive document. It presents, in systematic detail, all the essential facts relating to the condition of the property and the methods pursued in its management.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Nov. 4 -- P.M. Stocks made a display of strength at the opening to-day, but generally failed to hold such gains as they made, the market sagging toward the close in sympathy with sharp declines in Sugar and Chicago Gas, both of which were raided with considerable success. Business was not very active, transactions barely exceeding 90,000 shares.

Francis H. weeks, the embezzler of trust funds, who fled to South America when his misdeeds became known, is now confined in a cell in the Tombs Prison in New-York. His capture is due to The New-York Times as much as to the vigilance of the District Attorney's office. The Times discovered his whereabouts, and kept track of him until arrangements for his surrender by the Government of Costa Rica were made.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 4. -- The four-inhand of Henry A. Barclay arrived in Lenox from Southampton on Monday of this week. In the party were Miss Gertrude Bayne. Mr. D. Sackett Moore. Mr. and Mrs. John Bloodgood, Jr., and Mrs. Gustave Berckman.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 5. -- Both sides claim that they shall win in the election next Tuesday, but the Democrats admit that the Republicans may elect all but the Governor. In the campaign now closing the issues urged by either party have not been met by the other.

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date last year. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

TRENTON, Nov. 5. -- The closest calculations indicate that the Republicans will carry the House of Assembly by a majority of 2 or 3. and that the Senate will be Democratic by 1. There is no doubt about the repeal the race-track gambling laws, and the breaking of the power of W.J. Thompson.

E. Berry Wall had a far-away look in his red-rimmed eyes when he stood up and gazed mournfully at Justice Koch in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning. He had been arrested Saturday afternoon, and, in a state of total mental collapse, had spent six hours in the West Thirtieth Street Station.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5. -- "Off-year" elections in Kentucky attract little attention outside of a few special localities or counties where the vote may be close. This is the condition regarding the election of Tuesday. Only members of the Legislature and city and county officers are to be voted for, and interest in the struggle is purely local.

The correlation of bank reserves and of Clearing House loan certificates is pictured to the eye in an interesting manner in the above diagram. The heavy black horizontal line represents the 25 per cent, lawful reserve of the Associated Banks of New-York. Each horizontal line above or below this lawful-reserve line represents a gain or loss respectively of two million dollars, and every fifth line, printed slightly heavier, represents a change of ten millions.

The Brain Workers' Union, Limited, was the topic that puzzled the Central Labor FedEration yesterday. The federation wants to or ganize such a union, to be composed of men of all races and creeds who work with their brains, but what a brain worker is the delegates were not able to determine.

As to who were the first Jews that came to England, Mr. Jacobs does not trouble himself. We know that in the Liber Ruber of 1198 rules are laid down to Christian and Jew about the sale of tin from the Stannaries, and presumably Jews came to Cornwall with or after the Phenician, to buy tin.

The foreign exchange market closed fairly firm after a week of considerable fluctuations. The posted rates for sterling on Saturday were $4.82 for sixty-day bills and $4.85 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.81@$4.81 1/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.83 3/4@ $4.84 for demand, $4.84 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.79 3/4 for commercial.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- With an honest vote and an honest count in this city on Tuesday, no power on earth can save Willlam F. Sheehan from an irreparable defeat.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- Chancellor von Caprlvi submitted to the Federal Council on Friday the bill regulating the financial relations of the empire to the federated States. The preamble of the bill affirms that it has become necessary to free the empire from dependence upon the particular States, and therefore imperial revenues must be raised by new taxes on wine, tobacco, and Bourse transactions.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The congregations of the First, Second, Third, High Street, and South Park Presbyterian Churches assembled in the First Presbyterian Church to-night on their final ante-election rally in opposition to race-track legislation and to record their determination to do their utmost to defeat the race-track candidates at the polls.
The sales of realty at auction set down for to-day are all in legal proceedings, and will take place at 111 Broadway. The list is as follows:

The Rev. Cortland Myers, undismayed by the cowardly attack made on him the previous Sunday by the Brooklyn White Caps, paid his respects to the ringsters yesterday morning. Before a congregation that crowded the great Brooklyn Academy of Music he preached a ten-minute prelude on the rampant lawlessness of the ringsters, as evidenced by the shameless colonizing at Gravesend and by the general disregard of the rights of citizens.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 4. -- The market for local stocks was more active in the last week, also for bonds, than for six months before, and in several instances the closing prices showed gains even at concessions from the top prices. The activity was in keeping with the more plentiful supply of money in the banks, but rates for use were unchanged at 6@7 per cent.

The work of fitting out the big steamship El Cid as a war ship for the Brazilian Government continued all day yesterday at the docks of the Morgan Iron Works. The wharves at the foot of East Ninth Street were thronged throughout the day by crowds of the curious, but few persons were permitted on board the vessel.

Dr. Birkbeck Hall is said, on the authority of The Westminster Gazette, to have gained in health during his visit to the United States, and brought back a Johnsonian find -- no less a find than the corrected proof-sheets of Boswell's "Life of Johnson," containing the passages which Bozzy suppressed at the instance of his friends.

-- The Yonkers Bicycle Club held its annual meeting and election of officers Friday night. The following wore elected officers for the ensuing year: President -- Charles P. Ward; Secretary -- G. William Curran; Treasurer -- J. Edward Murphy; Captain -- Theodore Cox; Lieutenant -- William S. McDonald. The last year was reported a very prosperous one, with a steady growth of membership.

"A Debauched Ballot" was the subject of the Rev. H.G. Mendenhall's sermon yesterday at the Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. He laid the facts of the fraudulent registration, as exposed by The New-York Times, before his large congregation in a clear manner, and called on his hearers to stand up for decency in the City Government and to aid in the work of bringing the White Caps to justice.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Henry Thomas Butterworth, uncle of Ben Butterworth, and known throughout the Miami Valley as "Uncle Tom," died yesterday. He was eighty-five years old.

Marvin R. Clark, for more than thirty years a well-known newspaper writer of this city, has been compelled through misfortune to seek the aid of his friends. Five years ago he became totally blind, but even after that was able to earn a living. Recently nervous disorders have incapacitated him.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5. -- Those who saw the Saturday game on Manhattan Field saw the team which will probably play in Springfield, with one or two exceptions, and, allowing for possible injuries, the team is virtually chosen. Waters, who was not able to play on account of a bad knee, will soon be in good condition, and the team will be greatly strengthened by his presence.

It is doubtful if anybody, without giving the matter more or less lengthy consideration -- "taking thought," a simpler writer puts it -- could tell exactly what he means when he quotes a newspaper as "saying" something, or commends or censures it for "doing" something.

Juxtaposition plays merry pranks with news-paper headlines. The caption of Niagara County news in a Buffalo paper reads: "Death of an old resident of Lewiston -- Gone to Chicago." This recalls the story of the Chicago man, who, having died and gone to the other world, met a former acquaintance who asked how he liked the place.

Though far from intending it, the Riffians of Northern Morocco are fighting the battles of their enemies as well as their own. The fierceness of their assaults upon the works at Melilla, has given Spain the best excuse for carrying on war in Africa upon a formidable scale: while the Sultan's concession that she was aggrieved at the outset provides the basis for presenting to him in due time a heavy bill of damages.

It looks as If New-York City was to have a new Clearing House building. A. number of plans have been submitted to the Building Committee, and it was said on Saturday that one design was regarded with especial favor and would probably be adopted.
"We are governed by a horde of thieves, compared with whom the robber barons of the mediaeval period were Christian missionaries, who deserve to be canonized."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5. -- Naval warfare is about to be revolutionized in the Brazilian troubles, and the Winchester Arms Repeating Company of this city is furnishing a part of the prodigious ship-demolishing projectiles which will be carried on the steamship El Cid to destroy Admiral Mello's fleet.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- The stockholders of the Boston and Maine Railroad voted on Oct. 11 to make a radical change in the management of their vast and varied interests. They voted to change not only the policy but the personnel of the Directory.

ALBANY, Nov. 5. -- The quietest campaign New-York has known, in which the two great political parties have made nominations, has drawn practically to a close. The only contest that has been heard of, outside of the legislative or local squabbles, is that against Judge Maynard. From reports that have been received here from fifty counties in the State.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5. -- The Democrats of this city and of the State expect their usual majorities in the election Tuesday, and there is no doubt that they will realize their expectations. Marion De Kalb Smith will be re-elected Controller by a large margin. The Republicans will probably gain two or three Senators and from six to ten members of the House of Delegates.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Nov. 5. -- The house of George Cooper, a farmer, residing near this city, was burned to the ground early yesterday morning. Two little girls, Nellie and Sadie Johnson, aged respectively nine and four years, losing their lives. The girls were stepdaughters of Cooper.
The Rev. Charles Herold, pastor of Bethesda Chapel, Ralph Avenue and Chauncey Street, delivered a stirring political sermon last evening on "What Can I Do to Save Brooklyn?" Mr. Herold said:

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 5. -- An evidence of how thoroughly the Muller ring on Staten Island is alarmed and to what extent the police force is used by the "boss," was given at this place to-day. The Organization of Richmond County Democrats, which is fighting the ring's candidates for county offices, has published a semi-weekly paper for two weeks, as all of the local papers are controlled or owned by Muller.

There is one set of political predictions that can be made with perfect safety as to the outcome of this campaign. The Tammany city and county ticket will be elected by big pluralities, the eight candidates for the State Senate will be elected, all the Tammany candidates for Civil Justices, all the Senate district delegates to the Constitutional Convention, and all the Wigwam's Assemblymen, with possibly a few exceptions, will also be elected.

A genuine roorbach of the good old-fashioned kind, with claws and stripes and a forked tongue, was projected upon the community yesterday by our contemporary the Sun. It was designed to demolish BARTLETT and elect MAYNARD. It will do nothing of the kind. It has the fatal propensity of its species for kicking up behind and doing more damage to its contrivers than to its intended victim.
BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- Writing from Glasgow anent the impressions of the Clyde about the America's Cup contest. The Boston Globe's yachting correspondent says:

-- Mr. Isaac Sharp, a distinguished and venerable Quaker of London, England, is making an easy journey around the world at the age of eighty-eight years, and this week la to attend the yearly meeting of Orthodox Friends in Baltimore. He has once before made the circuit of the globe in the cause of missions, being then seventy years old.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 5. -- The sixteenth game of the chosa match ended in a draw after twenty-seven moves. Tschigorin opend with a King's gambit, which Tarrasch defended with Kt -- K B3. Present Score -- Tarrasch, 7; Tschigorin. 5; drawn. 4.

The Police Inspectors and the commanders of the various precincts and squads were yesterday afternoon assembled In the office of Superintendent Byrnes to receive final Instructions In regard to election day. and they were given an opportunity to procure information on any point about which they might be in doubt.

GENERAL COURTS-MARTIAL. -- At Fort Bllas. Texas, at 10 o'clock A.M., 6th inst. -- Detail: Major James Henton. Twenty-third Infantry: Capt. R.F. Bates, Eighteenth. Infantry; First Lient. W.T. Wood, Eighteenth Infantry: J.H. Duval, Eighteenth Infantry; R.R. Stevene, Twenty-third Infantry; Second Lieuts. H.N. Royden. Twenty-third Infantry; H.L. Laubach.
The Rev. Charles H. Buck of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church, Brooklyn, charged the McLaughlin ring yesterday with robbing the city of good government and its good name.
An outrage was perpetrated yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn by a gang of young ruffians, the victims being a Chinaman and the Superintendent of a Chinese Sunday school.

As a final resort of the political campaigners, who foresee defeat, the supporters of Isaac H. Maynard for Associate Justice of the Court of Appeals have made what they term "an inquiry into the life and legal doings" of his opponent, Edward T. Bartlett, and have evolved from that "inquiry" a silly attack on Mr. Bartlett's character based on a transaction of his as a private attorney.

MADRID, Nov. 5. -- The Spanish fort at Melilla cannonaded the Riffian lines all yesterday, but no response came from the trencnes. It is now estimated that between 45,000 and 50,000 Riffians have gathered in the hills near Melilla.

CHRISTIANIA, Nov. 5. -- A banquet was given at the Royal Castle last evening to celebrate the anniversary of Norway's union with Sweden on Nov. 4, 1814. King Oscar spoke of the blessings of the union. Neither country, he said, could afford to out loose from the other. The Minister of Foreign Affairs spoke with equal emphasis of the necessity of the union.

MADRID, Nov. 5. -- An official dispatch from Santander this evening says that the bodies of 165 persons, killed by the dynamite explosion in that city on Friday night, have been recovered. The search is still in progress. Many persons are missing. At present 190 persons are under treatment for injuries received on Friday night.
The following is from The New-York Herald of yesterday:

Co-operative Tree Planting. -- There are many odd features of social life at Newport which serve to individualize that fashionable colony. The residents have a habit of conspiring together for the good of everybody, and out of common interest the streets are well cared for, the sewera are kept clear, and the drives well lighted.

The Rev. T.J. Whitaker of the Bushwick Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, preached a vigorous sermon last evening against the McLaughlin ring. Mr. Whitaker explained how the Golden Rule applied to the polls on election day.
The Rev. Charles Edwards of the Franklin Avenue Presbyterian Church preached yesterday morning on "Paul in Politics."

Prof. Felix Adler, in his address before the Society for Ethical Culture, in Music Hall yesterday morning, made a vigorous arraignment of the Municipal Government of the city, and urged his hearers to throw off their apathy and strive earnestly for the overthrow of "machine" government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- The managers of both parties to-night claim that victory will crown their efforts next Tuesday, but neither Chairman can be induced to give an estimate of the majority he expects his candidate to receive. Both parties claim to have a complete poll of the State upon which they base their opinions. There are many elements of uncertainty in the situation.

Everything about the conduct of Francis Henry Weeks, forger, embezzler, and absconder, since he was locked up in the Tombs last Friday afternoon, seems, to indicate that he intends to plead guilty, alter having made with the District Attorney the best arrangement possible as to the charges which will be insisted on.

St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church in Pacific Street, near Bedford Avenue, was filled with a congregation of earnest listeners yesterday morning who had come to hear the Rev. Turner B. Oliver preach on "The Duty of Christian Citizens in the Present Political Crisis."

The weekly statement of the New-YorkCity Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $3,225,975. The banks now hold $52,013,450 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $5,058,500. an increase in specie of $552,000, an increase in legal tenders of $6,211,700, an increase in deposits of $14,150,900, and a decrease in circulation of $200,900.

The copies of the registry of voters, proposed for distribution, were received on Saturday night from the printers by the Brooklyn Board of Election in Smith Street. They were receipted for and were placed in the general office. Yesterday afternoon it was discovered that nearly all the books containing the names of voters in the Third Ward, which had been apportioned to the Republican Commissioners; had disappeared.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 5. -- For the first time since the campaign of 1883, when the Democrats wrested this State from Mahone, there is a trifle of doubt about a State contest. The Democrats claim that on Tuesday they will elect Col. O'Ferral Governor by not less than 15,000 majority, and secure more than two-thirds of the General Assembly.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The rates of discount last week were 2 1/2 for ninety days and 3/4 for thirty days. The demand for gold for the Continent has abated, and the market does not expect any immediate demand for America. Silver prices grew firmer on the strength of demands for the East. The Stock Exchange was dull and gloomy. Consols fell 1-16.

The peculiar sensitiveness of Mr. Dickson, counsel for the Reading receivers, toward all persons who have dared question the propriety of any of the proceedings of his clients, is only another evidence that those now in control of the property and their henchmen regard it as their distinct privilege to manage its affairs as suits themselves, and without regard to the rights or interests of the real owners of the same.

"Treason against the ballot arises from counting illegal votes," said the Rev. Dr. Van Alstyne in the Sands Street Memorial Church, Brooklyn, last night, in his sermon on the "Nature and Significance of the Ballot."

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- For the first time in four years it is impossible, on the eve of the State election, to make a reliable forecast of the result. That an exceptionally heavy vote will be polled is conceded on all sides. The registration throughout the Commonwealth has been phenomenal for an off year.

A thief stole several checks from the office of the Galvanotype and Printing Company, at 18 Rose Street, on Friday and, when he found that be could not realize any money on them, he was considerate enough to return them. J.H. Story, the bookkeeper of the concern, had prepared the bank book to make a deposit and left it on the desk, and then went out to luncheon and forkot about the checks.

John Y. McKane, arrogant "boss" of Coney Island, Chief of Police, owner of the building where brutal prize fights have time and again taken place in violation of the law he is sworn to protect, and Superintendent of a Sunday school withal, defying the Supreme Court of the State of New-York.

Evidence of many illegal registrations in Brooklyn has come to light within the past twenty-four hours. The proper authorities have been notified. The Republican have been sending full sets of paster ballots to the voters. The names have been copied from the registration lists.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The law-abiding citizens of Union County will have to be watchful to-morrow to prevent the debasement of the ballot box by unblushing corruption.

-- Prof. Elliott Coues of the Smithsonian Institution, who has crossed the continent during the last few months, has recently been in Tacoma and Seattle. He followed as far as practicable the trail of Lewis and Clark's expedition across the Rocky Mountains in 1804-6, and accompanied by Mrs. Coues, made a horseback journey of 600 miles.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Further investigation of the career in this city of Mrs. Halliday, known while here as Maggie Hopkins, the now notorious murderess, shows that while imprisoned at the Eastern Penitentiary she became insane, and was so pronounced by the prison authorities and physicians. Warden Michael J. Cassidy of the Eastern Penitentiary to day told the following story of her prison record.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: It has been brought to my notice that several Jewish journals representing the less liberal element of New-York Judaism have indorsed the candidacy of Maynard for Justice of the Court of Appeals on the ground that the Republican candidate, E.T. Bartlett, has on some occasion manifested prejudice against the Jewish race.
In the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly sold, in partition, for $8,675, to E.G. Bach, the three-story brick dwelling 349 West Thirtieth Street, 13.6 by 98.9.

Sound the average reader of a daily newspaper or other periodical, and discover how uniformly he, and more especially she, reads the advertisements. These are read precisely as other departments of the newspaper or periodical -- for the information they contain not only, but for the entertainment they afford.

The candy show opened in the Lenox Lyceum last eveiniging. It will close Nov. 25. Candy from nufacturers from all the principal cities of the United States have combined to give this exposition. Every species of candy, from "kisses " to the most expensive win be manufactured in the presence of visitors.

LEAVES OF ABSENCE. -- Lieut. J.D. Anderson, Twenty-fifth Infantry, six months' extension on Surgeon's certificate; Capt. William stephenson Medical Department, four months; Lieut. Maury Nichols, Seventh Infantry, one month's extension; Lieut. William A. Glassford, Signal Corps, is relieved from supervision of construction of telegraph line between Fort McIntosh and Fort Ringgold, Texas, and will return to Washington for examination for promotion.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Nov. 6. -- The country residence of Cussius H. Read here was seized to-day by Deputy Sheriff Louis Walters of Queens County, on foreclosure proceedings instituted by Daniel Leary of ocean-raft fame. Mr. Read personally turned the house over to the Sheriff. In 1889 a woman obtained a verdict for $15,000 against Mr. Read for breach of promise.

-- All of the Princeten warriors did not return to college until yesterday. None of them is much the worse for the hard game, though all complain of the harsh treatment of the Pennsylvania players, several of the team being black and blue from the pounding. The feeling in Princeton is strongly on the aide of abandoning all further relations with Pennsylvania in football.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 6. -- The Liberty Bell was welcomed home this afternoon. The city was bedecked with flags and bunting. The parade, which was postponed from Saturday on account of the storm, was one of the most imposing ever witnessed in Philadelphia. Ten thousand school boys were in line, in addition to firemen, militiamen, policemen, and others to the number of 3,000.

Police Capt. Henry D. Hooker of the Morrisania Station was stricken with paralysis last Saturday evening, and is lying at his residence, 437 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, in a very critical condition. It is feared that he cannot recover, or, if he does, that he will be incapacitated from active duty.

Justice Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning discharged the fourteen men arrested at Gravesend Saturday night. The men had been incarcerated in Raymond Street Jail on commitments which did not allow of their being admitted to bail.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 6 -- Mrs. Arthur Young of Cleveland was arrested here on a charge of stealing a pocketbook containing $187. Her husband hastened to her assistance, and as she denied her guilt, he engaged an attorney to defend her. Later in the day, however, the pocketbook containing the $187 was found in her room.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The continued and seemingly unwarranted decline of the New-York market is unquestionably having a depressing influence on local securities. The feeling to-day was thoroughly unsettled, due wholly to the discouraging reports from the Eastern markets. A few who felt disposed to buy were deterred from so doing by the constant dropping in New-York stocks.

-- Chauncey Giles, the leader of the New Jerusalem society in Philadelphia County, died at his residence in West Philadelphia yesterday. The reputation of Dr. Giles as a writer on religious topics was world-wide. He was born at Charlemont, Mass., in 1813. Early in life he was a teacher. In 1853 he became a clergyman of the Church of the New Jerusalem.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 6. -- The men employed on gun work by the Colts Patent Firearms Manufacturing Company began to-day working ten hours per day. They have been on an eight-hour schedule for several months. The machinists employed, by the Pope Manufacturing Company, about thirty-five in number, will hereafter work fourteen hours per day on account of the approaching busy season on bicycles.

Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle, who arrived in New-York on Sunday night, passed considerable time down town yesterday. He is expected to remain in the city for two or three days. To-night he will be the guest of Assistant Treasurer Conrad N. Jordan at dinner at Delmonico's, where he will meet some of the leading New-York bankers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- A gang of toughs headed by William Hurley, a policy man, started out to-night in the First Ward. Hurley had about a dozen men with him, most of them policy writers. They were shouting for John Sheehan, the Democratic candidate for Alderman, and raising a great disturbance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 6. -- The lowering of the great steel electric-light masts in this city is now almost completed. It has been a slow and difficult task. The mast in the Public Square, which was 225 feet high, has had 75 feet taken off its lower end, and the one at the corner of Water and Superior Streets is now undergoing similar treatment.

LAKE CITY JUNCTION, Fla., Nov. 6. -- W.J. Duncan was murdered here this morning. Two Stale Prison guards were sent after the murderer with bloodhounds. A negro named Henry Bogue was arrested, who bad Duncan'a pistol. Bogne at first denied having anything to do with the crime, but finally said that he and three other negroes went to Mr. Duncan's store.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly give me a little space in which to call attention to a community of sisters living among us, whose name is seldom seen in print, although its individual members are constantly to be seen on the streets going about on errands of mercy? I refer to the Sisters du Bon-Secours, who have their home at the corner of Lexington Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

MADRID, Nov. 6. -- Fernandez Sanz, Captain of the steamship Cabo Machicao, which was blown up at Santander on Friday, arrived at San Sebastian to-day. He says that the explosion sent the steamer's engines fifty yards into the airSixty-five houses were wrecked from root to cellar by the shock.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 6. -- The world-famous thoroughbred horse Longfellow file a at his home, the Nantura Stud, near tills city, last night. Long-fellow was twenty, six years old, and had been in perfect health until a week ago, when he caught a severe cold, which resulted fatally. He died where he was foaled, and never changed ownership, except by inheritance.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The authorities of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association relaxed a cast-iron rule this evening, and, for the first time in the history of the resort, permitted a political meeting to be held inside the fence. The meeting was held under the direction of the Citizens' League, for the purpose of indorsing James A. Bradley, the anti-race-track candidate for State Senator.
Henry Irving, Miss Ellen Terry, and the London Lyceum Theatre company arrived in this city yesterday. They came from Chicago. Mr. Irving and Miss Terry went to the Plaza Hotel.

Doubtless the present method of voting in this State has become sufficiently familiar to enable intelligent voters to use the official ballots without much trouble or liability to mistake, but it may be worth while to remind them of the requirements. Every voter will receive at his polling place one of each of the kinds of ballots provided, which he must take with him into one of the secret compartments.

AS a result of the loop-continued trouble in the Sixty-ninth Regiment of the National Guard, Lieut. Robert E. Ford, Commissary of Subsistance, sent in his resignation to Col. Cavanagh Friday, night. In his resignation he is said to have stated that his patience had boon exhausted with the warring elements in the regiment.
LONDON Nov. 6. -- Sir Andrew Clark, the well-known physician, died at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Denial is made at the Navy Department of the report that Admiral Walker will succeed Admiral Stanton in command of the squadron at Rio de Janeiro. No such order has been issued nor is any likely to be issued. Admiral Walker has been assigned to duty that will keep him employed in this country for thirty days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The following is a list of the nominations upon which the Senate did not act, which, although unofficial, is believed to be accurate:

Fitting out the new Brazilian cruisers El Cid and the Britannia was pushed along yesterday with vigor. Early in the morning a large force of workmen from the Morgan Iron Works began tearing down the forward and after deckhouses of the Britannia.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- "We are going to beat London and the rest of the world when we get this station finished," said Contractor Edwards of the Boston and Maine Union Station. "The largest railroad station in the world is in London," he continued, "but it only accommodates 500 trains a day, while we will have 552 running in and out here.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 6. -- The climax of the outrages perpetrated by the Muller "machine" against the independents who are fighting to maintain their right of self-government was reached to-night, when Nicholas Muller, Jr., personally joined in the effort to prevent the circulation of the paper published by the anti-ring organization.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Can any one imagine anything more inhuman than for the Captain of a ship, in fine weather, to ignore a signal of distress? Yet such was the case on the 18th inst. in the Straits of Florida.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- J.C. Grunberg, thought to be an erring son of some prominent Parisian family, was found dead in bed to-day, just before noon, at the Southern Hotel. The direct cause of the death was a large quantity of morphine which he had taken, though, whether accidental or with suicidal intent, is not entirely clear.

Unless Francis Henry Weeks should change his mind, he will plead guilty tomorrow to the indictment charging him with grand larceny and the misappropriation of $85,000 held by him in trust for Mrs. Nicholas Fish.
Money on call loaned at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

-- According to The Chicago Times, there have been sold at the World's Fair from the British section of art some fifty pictures, mostly water colors. The Germans have sold between thirty and forty small pictures, and the St. Louis Museum has bought the plaster statue " Peace," modeled by Prof. Emil Hundreiser.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 6. -- The Sheehan Police Board has arranged matters so as to make it easy to hold back returns of the election to-morrow night. The board refuses to let the slips be seen at the station houses. On Friday last the following letter was sent to the Police Board by the Republican County Committee...
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The following proclamation, was issued to-day:

Otto Kempner, the Independent Democratic candidate for Assemblyman in the Seventh District, called on Police Superintendent Byrnes yesterday in relation to his prosecution of Detectives John Hock and David J. Malon of the Fourteenth Precinct, whom he charged with interfering with his canvass by inducing storekeepers and saloon keepers to take his lithographs and posters out of their windows.

-- All lines in the Southwestern Railway and Steamship Association, except the Mallory and the Cromwell Steamship company, whose representatives are expected to send proxies, are represented in St. Louis at the special meeting called to elect a Chairman for the association. The complete demoralization of the Texas rates renders it necessary that a determined effort be made to correct existing evils.

There has been nothing in recent American politics at all comparable with the emotion which has been caused among the Democratic machinists who insulted the people of the State of New-York with the nomination of ISAAC H. MAYNARD by the dreadful disclosure that Mr. BARTLETT not only corruptly drew for hire, but shamelessly witnessed, a contract assuring the profits of a post-tradership to his client.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The walker board, convened to discuss the remedies for the top-heavy ships of the navy, has adjourned until after the trial trip of the triple-screw snip Columbia, as several of its members are the Columbia trial board.

While "Boss" John T. McKane and his hirelings were chuckling over having thrown into jail the men sent by Mr. Gaynor with the writ of the Supreme Court to copy the false registry lists of Gravesend, Mr. Gaynor was not idle.

One of the hottest meetings of the campaign was held at the Real Estate Exchange, Brooklyn last night. Many were turned away. W.G. Low presided. William J. Gaynor, in attacking the "ring," referred to John Y. McKane as "that little shrimp of a criminal down in Gravesend." David Healey, Robert Stewart, George F. Elliott, George O'Shaughnessy, and Daniel Bradley also spoke.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- R.E. Preston was sworn in to-day as Director of the United States Mint. He failed of confirmation by the Senate, but the President has commissioned him as Director in the recess, which insures his renomination to the Senate in December.

Albert Denisse, a French tourist, who was a passenger on board the steamship Oranje Nassau, which arrived yesterday from Haiti, tells of the recent threatened outbreak in that turbulent little republic. According to Mr. Denisse, it was an incipient revolt, which had its origin in the exiled conspirators, Legitime and Nanigat.

The Brooklyn ring leaders last evening caused to be circulated throughout the upper wards of the city a circular misrepresenting Mr. Schieren. The circular purported to be sent out by the Citizens' Union. The Citizens' Union promptly prepared the following address:

A story, industriously circulated last week, was that Superintendent Byrnes had given pool sellers and bookmakers a placatory "tip" that in view of the nearness of election day he would relax his surveillance and permit these sentry to do "business" if they were circumspect and unostentatious. This, however, is Superintendent Byrnes's "tip," sent out Saturday, and carefully pasted in the hat of every precinct commander:

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Through shipments of grain, flour, and provisions from Chicago to the seaboard suffered a serious decrease last week as compared with those of several previous weeks. All told, they amounted to 24,965 tons, against 30,223 tons for the previous week and 30,241 tons for the corresponding week last year.

The appearance of the Prinoeton University foot-ball team at East Orange this morning will occasion more than usual interest among football enthusiasts on account of Princeton's glorious victory over the University of Pennsylvania on Saturday. Princeton has a great following in this vicinity, and naturally her admires will turn out in full force to see the "Tigers" play at Orange.

The action growing out of the will of Ann Drake Seaman, the wife of John T. Seaman, brought by Peter Shute and others against Lawrence Drake and others, to dispossess the defendants of property in this city worth $4,000,000, was put on trial yesterday morning before Judge Patterson in the Supreme Court.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 6. -- United States Marshal Hawkins arrived in the city this afternoon from Birmingham, Ala., accompanied by Dr. S.R. Wilson of Fairbank, Ind., and Mrs. James Scott, with whom the doctor eloped a week ago, while Mr. Scott and two children were at the World's Fair. Marshal Hawkins traced the elopers to Birmingham, Ala., where they were registered as C.G. Fitzel and wife.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6 -- Editor Henry Watterson and Charles D. Pierce of The Courier-Journal business office arrived in Nashville to-day with a view to establishing the new morning paper here, in which The Courier-Journal is to be an interested party. Several local capitalists, including Gen. W.H. Jackson and Vanieer Kirkman, are said to be backing the project.

Soroals, after a dainty luncheon followed by music, discussed the following question yesterday: "Can the growth of philauthropy be rightly gauged by the increase of phlianthropic institutions, and does Sorosis as a body take up her share of the philanthropic work which is knocking at the door of every association!"

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador, was entertained in Liverpool this evening at a banquet and reception. More than 600 citizens, representing the wealth and society of Liverpool, were present. In answering a toast to his health. Mr. Bayard said that, although a strong party man at home, he came before Englishmen as a man representing no party.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- It looks tonight to toe a certainty that Maynard will be defeated in Erie County to-morrow by at least 3,000 votes. The Republican State ticket ought to, and probably will, pull through with a smaller majority. Roberts, of course, will receive the largest vote.

A resplendent audience, with more than a small proportion of its component individualities as richly and handsomely decorated as the theatre it filled to overflowing, gathered at the Empire last night, and gave Mr. Chariots Frohman's good stock company a welcome of most demonstrative cordiality. It was really a notable audience, thickly sprinkled with people of whom everybody has heard.

Rip Van Winkle, just as jolly and just as disreputable as ever, received as many of his old friends as could crowd inside the hospitable doors of the Star Theatre last night. Mr. Joseph Jefferson and Rip are always so heartily welcomed when they give the New-York public an opportunity of seeing them that one would suppose they would be tempted to stay longer when they do come.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The political fight raging in Camden County is the fiercest battle at the kind that has taken place in this usually quiet county for many years. There are four tickets in the field -- the Democratic, Republican, Prohibitionist, and Citizens' League. The officers to be elected are Sheriff, State Senator, three Assemblymen, and two Coroners.
It is stated with authority that the Kings County Grand Jury has indicted "Father" Francis Dent for perjury, and that the police are vainly searching to arrest him.

William E. Carpenter, who was sent to prison in June. 1892, for nine years, convicted of grand larceny in the first degree, has been pardoned by Gov. Flower. Carpenter was employed by Dix Phyfe, brokers, of 45 Wall Street. Oscar Creamer, the cashier of the firm, had filled in blank checks and collected upon them, signing his employers' names.

-- Fifteen hundred medical and dental students had a parade in Philadelphia on Friday night, with music, banners, and fire-works. One of the transparencies of the dental students read: "Last in War, First in Peace, First in the Mouths of Our Countrymen." Another, abstracted from Shakespeare, was this: "I love a maid the better, whilst I have a tooth in my head."

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Government issued a bluebook to-day concerning the war between the Matabeles and the forces of the South African Chartered Company. The negotiations between Sir Henry Loch, Governor of Cope Colony, and King Lobengula are related, at great length. During September and October Loch tried to reach a peaceful settlement with the King.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 6. -- Pierre Tschaikowsky, the Russian composer, died in this city last night. He died of cholera, hours after he fell ill.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- A committee of the Coal-Mine Owners' Association met in Manchester to-day to consider the result of the conference held last week in London between the association and delegates from the Miners' Federation.

For two hours last evening firemen fought a fire in the sub-cellar of the five-story building 679 Broadway, adjoining the Broadway Central Hotel. Dense, stiffing smoke filled the basement and sub-cellar of the structure, and many of the firemen were overcome. One of them was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, but the others soon recovered and remained on duty.
Mrs. Grivalus, who owns a hotel at Rock-away Beach, mourns the loss of $600, which was stolen from her last evening at the foot of the City Hall station of the Third Avenue elevated railroad.

In the face of great election frauds, arranged for by the Brooklyn Ring, there is every indication that Charles A. Schieren, the reform Republican candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, will be elected by an overwhelming majority.

MARSEILLES, Nov. 6. -- The Cannebiere, the finest street in this city, that only a few days ago was the scene of the great reception to the Russian naval officers, was the scene to-day of as entirely different gathering. The tramway men went on strike yesterday, and to-day a riotous mob gathered in the Cannebiere and amused itself by overturning a number of oars that were being driven by non-strikers and assaulting the drivers.
The Young Women's Christian Association held its regular monthly business meeting at its hall, 7 East Fifteenth Street, yesterday morning.

Tea a la Columbine. -- Society made an effort yesterday to come together informally for the first time this season. The meeting, which was in the form of an afternoon tea, took place at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. The novel feature of the tea was its adaptation from the celebrated and fashionable teas at the Columbine, on the Rue Cambon, Paris, and, as a consequence, the tea was Frenchy.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 6. -- The work of the Grand Jury impaneled to investigate the failure of the various banks was to-day declared void by Judge Johnson of the Circuit Court. The question was brought before Judge Johnson on a writ of habeas corpus to secure the release of Elliott and Noyes, Directors of the Plankinton Bank, who voluntarily surrendered in order to test this point.

The freshman football team of Columbia College will play the freshmen team of Vale at New-Haven this afternoon. The Columbia boys go with the flash of victory, for daring the entire season they have not lost a single game, although they have played the freshman Teams of all the local colleges and various preparatory schools.

The Fall exhibition of the Florists' Club was opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace, in the Industrial Building, with a chrysanthemum show of unusual beauty and magnificence. The large halls and arcades of this building are specially well suited to the uses of a big flower show, and the club has made efforts to surpass all former shows and to give an exhibition which shall properly represent the great chrysanthemum gardens of the country.

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The campaign in this city was closed to-night with a mass meeting, under the auspices of the Union County Citizens' League, in the Auditorium. In each seat was a copy of The New-York Times's campaign supplement, which exposed the villainy and crookedness of the "Duke of Gloucester" in his efforts to maintain his supremacy at Trenton in spite of the protests of honest voters.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 6. -- Thomas Sargent, a well-known colored jockey who has ridden at Hawthorne, died last night at the Presbyterian Hospital. Last Wednesday, while exercising a horse from Barney Schriever's stable, the boy was thrown. He was picked up suffering from internal injuries which resulted in his death.

The reverses which befall the New-York Democracy to-day will be remedial and wholesome. For eight years the party has been under bad guidance. Its State organization has been seized and controlled by selfish, tricky, and unscrupulous men. They have been out of sympathy with the Democracy of the Nation, and their abuse of political power has sorely tried the patience and loyalty of their party in this State.

-- The Charity Organization Society asks for $100 to send an elderly man and his wife back to San Francisco, where they lived for a long time, and where they have children who have promised to support them, but cannot afford to pay their fare across the continent. If they remain in this city they will be dependent upon strangers and public charity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The President has appointed Gen. George D. Ruggles to be Adjutant General, to succeed Gen. Robert Williams, retired.
QUEBEC, Nov. 6. -- Audet's machine shop, at St. Anslem, Dorchester, Quebec, was destroyed by fire this morning. Loss, $25,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Freiherr von Meyerinck, who was sentenced on Wednesday last to four years' imprisonment for complicity in the Hanover gambling case, has committed suicide. He hanged himself in his cell.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 7. -- Secretary Young to-day announced that the Anti-Lottery League of Louisiana would not relax its vigilance in the fight against lotteries. It has been the general impression that the transfer of operations of the Louisiana State Lottery Company from New-Orleans to Puerto Cortez, Honduras, would not result In a decrease of sales of lottery tickets in this State, or, in fact, in any part of the United States.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 7. -- Colorado elections were for county officers, with issues local and varied. In Denver a fierce campaign has been waged. in which the A.P. A. have taken a leading part. It is believed that this (Arrapahoe) County will elect the Republican ticket.

"All quiet," was the report received by Superintendent Byrnes when he reached his office at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. Byrnes was soon in consultation with Inspectors Conlin, Williams, McAvoy, and McLaughlin, and the work of the day was laid out, Inspector Conlin going to the Twenty-ninth Precinct to look out for the Third Inspection District, and the others remaining at the Central Office.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morningl, consists of TEN PAGES Among other features, it contains --
The Republican headquarters, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, were crowded to the doors last night with members of the Republican State Committee and others prominent in the party.

Chief of Police John Y. McKane in the town of Gravesend yesterday threw to the winds all regard for law as represented by the Supreme Court of the State of New-York and crowned his notorious career with brutal criminality the like of which the State of New-York has never before known.
The long and aggressive fight made by The New-York Times against the Brooklyn Ring has been crowned with success.

"I was up in Oxford County, a couple of miles above South Woodstock," said a Lewiston man, "when a man came into the little store where I was sitting near the stove and said: Want to see some fun, boys? I will show you some if you'll get your rifles and come up to my place right off. There's a bear in my cellar and I can't get him out.
From latest returns received the next New-Jersey Senate will consist of 10 Democrats and 11 Republicans, of which number 9 Democrats and 4 Republicans hold over.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Extreme dullness continues. Americans were weak at the opening to-day, Louisville falling to 48 5/8 on the statement of The Times that the securities bought from Huntington do not give effective control of the Chesapeake and Ohio Southwestern. The only security of which a majority even was secured is the second mortgage bonds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The advices received by the Department of State from the scene of the last trouble in Honduras are to the following effect:

The people of the State of New-York had a debt to discharge to the Democratic politicians, and they yesterday wiped the slate extremely clean. They owe little to the Republican politicians, in spite of whom the Republican ticket has been elected. The agreement in virtue of which Judge ANDREWS was unopposed last year was that the Democratic candidate should be unopposed.

Ohio chose a Governor for a term of two years to succeed William McKinley, Jr., (Rep.;) a Lieutenant Governor for two years, a Treasurer for two years, a Judge of the Supreme Court for six years, a Member of the Board of Public Works for three years, an Attorney General for two years, a Dairy and Food Commissioner for two years, and a General Assembly consisting of 107 Representatives and 31 Senators.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- There was a little ceremony connected with the close of the exposition here which did not attract public attention because it was quietly conducted and notoriety was not desired. The event was the presentation of the first souvenir Columbian half dollar coined to President Higinbotham by the Remington Typewriter people, whose purchase of it for $10,000 caused it to be christened the "Ten-thousand-dollar Beauty."

When a General leads an army to repeated defeats, the instinct of self-preservation commonly induces the nation whose army he leads to replace him with another. When the manager of a prosperous business carries it from prosperity to bankruptcy, the stockholders commonly discharge him and put in another man.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 7. -- Returns from the city and State give the Democrats their usual majorities, except in two or three of the counties. The Legislature will be Democratic by about two to one. The gains made by the Republicans are mainly in the districts which they lost two years ago, in the general landslide of that year.

The Washington Wheelmen of Tremont had a bicycle tournament and field games at Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon. The sport was very interesting and the contests all closely fought out to the finish. So many had entered in the different events that it took several heats to decide them. The races were all run off promptly, and, with the exception of a collision in the quarter-mile race, when four men went down, there were no accidents.

Charles A. Schieren, Mayor-elect of Brooklyn, entertained a number of his intimate friends at his house, 405 Clinton Avenue, last evening. Figures were constantly pouring in upon him. While his friends were jubilant and enthusiastic, Mr. Schieren did not for a moment let the great victory turn his head.

Picture for a background the striking old City Hall, its illuminated clock face telling off the minutes, fantastic figures of grass plots in front telling of the glories of a Summer that has passed, and turn to Printing House Square. Here was the "action" of the play last night.
The day at Gravesend was one of continued outrage and violation of every moral and State law.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 7. -- At the Second Precinct, First Ward, a collision occurred between the police supporting the Republican ticket and the Democratic fusionists. Seven police, headed by Pat Farrell of Homestead fame, interfered with the fusionists, who were casting their votes.

The Republican Campaign Committee and the Citizens' Union united last evening at the latter's headquarters in the Germania Savings Bank Building, Fulton Street, opposite the City Hall, Brooklyn. Joseph Benjamin, Col. Charles Morton, Robert Stewart, and William Ferguson were in charge, representing both organizations.

"Get your vote out early." This was the order Richard Croker sent over the wire from Tammany Hall yesterday morning to every Assembly district leader in the city. Forthwith every district leader sent out the same order to each of his election district Captains, and within a remarkably short time 1,142 election district Captains were bustling harder than ever to get the voters to the polls.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The election in this place resulted disastrously. In the Fifth, Sixth, and Ninth Wards disorder amounting to riot occurred, and, as a result, several persons, mostly Deputy Sheriffs, are in the hospitals with ugly wounds. The cause of the trouble appears to have been the attempts of Republican Deputy Sheriffs to prevent illegal voting.

The results in the Assembly districts which were closely contested in this city are very interesting. In the Eleventh District James R. Sheffield (Rep.) won easily over the Tammany candidate, Frederick M. McCloy, receiving a plurality of 1,130. Mr. McCloy's vote was 2,273 and Mr. Sheffield's 3,403. The Good Government Club aided the Republicans very much in securing the victory.

Francis Henry Weeks, weary of worrying over his criminality and desirous of knowing his fate as soon as possible, will be brought before Recorder Smyth in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions this morning.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Frederick T. Greenhalge, the Republican candidate for Governor, is elected by a plurality of from 28,000 to 30,000. The complete figures may increase the estimate. The Republican gain over the vote of 1891 has been steady and uniform. There can be no doubt about the purpose of the voters.

The result of the election in this city, so far as county officers, Senators, and district delegates were concerned, was a foregone conclusion, and had it not been for the interest developed in the contest over the Court of Appeals Judgeship and the local contests over the Assemblymen in the Ninth. Eleventh, Twenty-first, and Twenty-third Assembly Districts, the election would have been little more than a pro forma affair.

If justice is done, JOHN Y. McKANE of Gravesend has a fair chance of being sent to prison. He stands exposed now indubitably the kind of man THE TIMES has said he was A greedy, unprincipled, unserupulous schemer, ruffian, and lawbreaker, he has been protected by the authorities of Kings County even when he was known to be false to the party which the ring ruled, and to which he pretended to belong.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Walker Board has submitted its report on the condition of the gunboat Detroit and sister ships, and the document was read to-day by the bureau Chiefs with great interest.

BUFFALO, Nov. 7. -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the consecration or the Right Rev. Stephen Vincent Ryan as Bishop of Buffalo began this afternoon. Among those present were Mgr. Satoill, Cardinal Gibbons, Archbishops Ryan of Philadelphia, Corrigan of New-York, Ireland of St. Paul, Cleary of Kingston, Ontario; and Walsh of Toronto, Bishops Keane of the Catholic University, Washington; McDonnell of Brooklyn, Ludden or Syracuse, McNeirny of Albany, and Foley of Detroit.

That New-York is a Democratic State on national issues does not admit of doubt. The party has been overwhelmed in the State election by Democratic votes through a revolt against the machine that has been mismanaging its interests for the last eight years, and growing constantly more reckless in its disregard of the better sentiment of the party.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 7. -- The prediction that the election on Staten Island would be exciting has been fulfilled. In several districts the "machine" workers, aided by the police force, ejected the independent and Republican watchers from the polling places or refused them admittance.
The reports of the audacious outrage perpetrated by "Boss" John Y. McKane and his ruffianly followers at Gravesend yesterday caused a whirlwind of indignation to sweep through Brooklyn.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 7. -- Kansas tried the Australian, ballot system for the first time to-day. County officers were elected throughout the State, and Judges in thirteen districts. There was little electioneering, and very little money was used, but the complications of the new system mystified many voters, and many ignorant men refrained from voting at all.

MADRID, Nov. 7. -- The fighting at Melilla was renewed yesterday. The Riffians blocked the approaches to the forts and advanced close to Melilla itself. So close were they that bullets from their rifles fell into the square in the centre of the town. The Spanish troops poured a hot fire into the enemy, bat it had no effect in checking their advance.

New-York State elected a Secretary of State for two years, a Controller for two years, a Treasurer for two years, an Attorney General for two years, a State Engineer and Surveyor for two years, an Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals for fourteen years, 32 Senators for two years, 128 Members of Assembly for one year, and 175 delegates to the Constitutional Convention, 15 at large and 5 from each Senatorial district.
NEW-YORK CITY. -- The Tammany county ticket is elected by a plurality of about 65,000.

CHICAGO, III., Nov. 7. -- Only Judges of the Superior and Circuit Courts and County Commissioners were voted for in this county to-day. There was no State election. The chief interest in the contest centred in the candidacy of Judge Joseph E. Gary, who was the nominee of the Republicans to succeed himself on the Supreme Bench.

ALBANY, Nov. 7. -- Gov. Flower returned to Albany at 8 o'clock this evening, and proceeded directly to the Executive Chamber, where he found a number of State officers and political friends awaiting him. Among them was Senator David B. Hill. The returns were received in the Governor's private office by a special wire, and private telegrams kept pouring in constantly.

THE TIMES feels justified in particular gratification at the overthrow of the McLaoghlin machine in Brooklyn, since it entered the fight against it this year the earliest and has waged it with constant zeal and with a confidence that some of our friends did not share, in the triumph of the people.

SAND BEACH, Mich., Nov. 7. -- The propeller Albany of the Western Transit Company, loaded with grain, and the propeller Philadelphia of the Anchor Line, loaded with coal and general merchandise, two of the largest freight boats on the lakes, collided off Point aux Barques in the dense fog last night, and both sank shortly afterward in 200 feet of water.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Nov. 7. -- The bulk of the ballots was cast in the forenoon. The multiplicity of local candidates confused a majority of the voters, especially those who had not kept track of the four-cornered fight in this city. The rivalry was very bitter between the two factions of the Gleason party.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7. -- Returns of the election to-day have come in from only a comparatively small portion of the State, but these returns indicate that the Democratic State ticket is elected by a large majority, probably 40,000, and that the Democrats will control both houses of the Legislature.

It was only a few minutes after 6 o'clock as night when Richard Croker, seated in the room of the Committee of Thirty in Tammany Hall, glanced at the returns from the first 300 election districts reported in this city and remarked:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 7. -- The story of the election to-day can be told in a few words. It was a sweeping Republican victory, giving to that party the Governor, State officers, and the General Assembly, with the power to elect a United States Senator to succeed J.F. Wilson. The day was quiet throughout the State, and the total vote small.

It was pleasant to find, amid the excitement and hurly-burly of the election in Brooklyn yesterday, absolute tranquillity and undisturbed repose personified in that ancient and honorable Captain of the Watch, Police Superintendent Patrick Campbell. Others might lose their heads and their judgment and be betrayed into rash and inconsiderate action.

MADRID, Nov. 7. -- The latest details concerning the terrible disaster at Santander on Friday last show that the number of dead, missing, and wounded is fully 1,000. There is no doubt that many of the dead will never be identified.

The Police Justices were kept busy yesterday attending to election cases, but not many men were held on charges of illegal registration. Of the nine men charged in the Tombs Police Court with illegal registration, only four were held for examination.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Returns from Monmouth County are very incomplete, but indicate the election of James A. Bradley, the fusion candidate for Senator. Strahan (Dem.) for Sheriff and Aumack (Dem.) for County Clerk are probably elected by greatly-reduced majorities. The Republicans claim that Fay, (Dem.,) for Assembly in the Second District, is defeated.

Scores of artisans were working yesterday upon Abbey's Theatre at Thirty-eighth Street and Broadway, bestowing the final touches preparatory to its opening to-night, when Mr. Irving and Miss Terry will appear in Lord Tennyson's play, "Becket."
The work of fitting out the Brazilian cruisers El Cid and Britannia continued yesterday and last night despite the fact that It was election day.

BAYCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- About 300 pounds of dynamite and 200 ponnds of nitroglycerine scored in the packing house of the Baychester Powder Works exploded shortly before 10 o'clock this morning with, terrific force, and three men had marvelous escapes from death.

-- So many persons attend the popular Saturday evening smokins concerts at the Catholic Club that hereafter the concerts will be held in the ballroom of the clubhouse. The programing for next Saturday evening includes the recitation of "The Dandy Fifth," by Louis Aldrich; sons by J.D. Fitzgerald, baritone, and James Maxwell, tenor, and selections by Josh Duly and Henry Patterson, humorists, and by Prof. Brounoff, pianist, of the Imperial Academy of Music, St. Petersburg.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 8. -- Nothing definite will be known as to the result of yesterday's election in this State before to-morrow morning. The vote in the sure Republican and Populist counties was light, while in those in which a careful canvass was made an unusually large vote for an off year was polled, with no definite figures to base estimates on.

W. Harris Roome of the City Club, who was active in the work of organizing and getting out the independent vote in several of the up-town Assembly Districts, was asked yesterday his opinion of the result of the election. His smile was broad and cheerful as he replied:

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 8. -- Senator Hoar said to-day that the Republican victory in Ohio was the expression of approbation of the McKinley bill, "the best and most scientifically-constructed economic measure ever enacted in this country or any other." The victory in Ohio means this, and also the "repudiation of the Democratic machine and dishonest election methods."

The most disappointing set-back the Democratic machine received was the failure to secure a majority of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention, which will meet in Albany next May. Out of the 175 delegates elected, the Republicans will rely upon 110, at least, including the 10 Delegates at Large.

The schooner Viola, which arrived from St. John, N. B., yesterday, was in collision Tuesday morning with the little coasting schooner Louis Monette. The Monette was laden with cement and was bound from Rondout for Providence. Capt. Forsyth of the Viola says the Monette sank shortly after the collision. The crew were taken off by the Viola and landed at Mount Misery, L. I. The Viola was considerably damaged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The State and Navy Department people have read with much interest the reports in The New-York Times of the preparations making by the Brazilian agents in New-York for a substantial warfare on the Mello insurgents.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 8. -- The people of Buffalo took a very hard fall out of Lieut. Gov. Sheehan yesterday, but, for all that, they are not yet through with him. Having smashed the machine, the decent citizens of both parties intend to prevent its repair. To this end every man who participated in the outrageous frauds in the First Ward yesterday is to be arrested and punished.

Nobody will question the justice of the sentence of FRANCIS HENRY WEEKS, but there has already been heard some expression of doubt whether it "paid." It has cost a good deal of trouble and not a little money to lay hold of WEEKS and bring him to justice. When he was brought back it was seen, as, indeed, it had been very well known before, that he was not worth the trouble of squeezing.
ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Yesterday's avalanche has disturbed the prospects of many faithful politicians who are wont to spend the Winter around the Capitol at Albany.

Edward T. Bartlett, the Judgre-elect of the Court of Appeals, received a number of callers and many notes of congratulation yesterday. In his office, at Wall and Willlam Streets. He was in the office all day. When asked if he would talk about the causes that led to his election, he said he did not care to do so.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- In his effort to escape from an angry crowd by swimming the Delaware River an unknown tramp, who Insulted and struck in the face Miss Rose Callagan at Raven Rock yesterday, was drowned. Miss Callagan was walking near the railway tracks when the tramp jumped from a coal train coming toward Trenton.
The money market continues easy. Call loans were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. --The schooner Henry Lippett. Capt. Howes, which arrived here today from Turk's Island, brought the three terribly-blistered and all but lifeless bodies of Antonio Crimner, Pedro Nagloges, and Dagio Peres, part of the crew of the Spanish bark Juan J. Murga, an account of whose wreck appeared recently in a dispatch from Galveston, where three other members of the crew were landed from the steamship Lampasas.
In no election that has occurred in this vicinity for many years did the "paster" cut so conspicuous a figure as it did in the election of Tuesday.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- The services held Sunday over the remains of M. Tirard, formerly Prime Minister, were private, none but the family of the deceased being present. A public funeral was held to-day. Mme. Tirard was too much prostrated to attend, and two nephews, two nieces, and a sister of M. Tirard represented the family.

No class of citizens was happier over the result of the election yesterday than the lawyers. All who spoke of the result were delighted that the cause of good morals and honest politics had triumphed.

In the midst of their rejoicing over their tremendous victory, the Brooklyn reformers do not forget the part which John Y. McKane and Sheriff John Courtney played in the conflict between the people and the bosses.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- When Chairman Harrity of the National Democratic Committee was seen this afternoon there was not the faintest trace of disappointment or worriment evident in his countenance.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Nov. 8. -- The Newfoundland legislative elections are resulting most favorably to the Whiteway Government. The returns now in show: Government members, 15; Opposition, 4.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 8. -- George Lamb, colored, seventeen years old, of Millburn, passed two hunters near that place yesterday, and shouted as a joke, "There goes a rabbit!" One of the gunners, D.J. Turnstall, of 331 West Twenty-first Street, New-York, turned and raised his gun. Seeing no rabbit, he asked the boy, "Do you want me to make you jump?"

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- P.M. Stocks ruled higher to-day. The market was buoyant at the opening, and its general tendency was toward better prices, except just before the close, when there came a reaction which affected nearly all the list and left quotations in many cases considerably below the highest for the day.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The first annual club races of the Montclair Wheelmen were held yesterday morning on the Valley Road and consisted of five road events, which were watched by everybody in Montclair who rides a wheel and a large number who don't.

BARCELONA, Nov. 8. -- The opera season at the Lyceum Opera House opened last night, "Willlam Tell" being billed for production. There was a large audience present. Everything went along without a hitch until the second act, when two bombs, presumably loaded with dynamite, were thrown from the gallery. As the bombs struck the floor below one of them exploded with a terrific report.

Mr. Frank L. Fisher has sold for Drought Carrew to Florence Poole the three-story and basement high-stoop brownstone dwelling 770 West End Avenue, east side, 80 feet south of One Hundred and Third Street, 20 by 55 by 100, for $28,000.

The initiative and referendum of the American people works in an indirect and roundabout way, but in the long run it is sure to produce its effect. Policies of legislation and of administration originate with the people, and they will be executed by the people, in spite of the obstruction of short-sighted politicians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Last night a man of plausible speech and engaging address introduced himself to Manager Rapley of the National Theatre as J.W. Osborne, representing Henry Irving and Ellen Terry. He desired to book those stars for a week at the National Theatre, saying he had just come from Baltimore, where he had fixed a date with Mr. Ford.

Yesterday was eminently children's day at the flower show. At the exhibition last Spring 1,000 little plants in pots were distributed to the children of the New-York Kindergarten and Potted Plant Association's school, which they were told to care for and exhibit the plants at this present show. Prizes were offered for those plants which had thrived best.

Timothy F. Paddell, saloon keeper, of 211 Bleecker Street: James D. Freeman, saloon keeper, of $40 Broadway: James Thompson, saloon keeper, of 64 Seventh Avenue, and Owen McAleer, saloon keeper, of 74 Sixth Avenue, were arrested on bench warrants issued by Judge Martine yesterday for violation of the excise law.

There was a story started yesterday to the effect that more votes were polled in the Second Assembly District, where Police Justice Diwer is the leader for Tammany Hall, than there were names on the registry list in that district.
The Medico-Legal Society, which met last evening at the Hotel Imperial, adopted a resolution favoring the abolition of the Coroners' office. It was as follows.

The recent exclusive announcement in The New-York Times that five war ships of the new navy had been so faultily designed as to be practically unseaworthy is now followed by the authoritative information that the big armored cruiser New-York has been so badly constructed as to prevent her entering a single dry dock in the United States.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 8. -- Dispatches received here state that the Matabeles attacked the British Tull column under Major Goold Adams on Nov. 1. This column has a number of Maxim guns that were turned on the enemy. The natives could not withstand the showers of bullets poured into their ranks, and they broke and fled in great disorder.

There is not so deep an interest in the Boston Symphony Orchestra here as there is in Boston, because the organization is not the central sun of our musical system; but there is a very lively appreciation of its work and an active curiosity as to any change in its direction. Under the admirable leadership of Wilhelm Gericke, the orchestra was made known here, and leaped into public favor.

A lively game of football was played Tuesday on the lower lawn in Central Park between the Xavier juniors and a team from the first grammer class of St. Francis Xavier Institute. The latter team was picked up for the occasion, and lacked the practice of the former. The juniors played a very good game and won by the score ot 26 to 0. The teams lined up as follows:

The Republicans swept the State of Massachusetts yesterday, carrying everything before them. Complete returns give Greenhalge (Rep.) 190,868, Russell (Dem.) 156,763, and Bank (Proh.) 8,158, giving a plurality of 34,105 for Greenhalge. The Legislature, so far as heard from, stands: House -- 153 Republicans, 48 Democrats, 39 not heard from; Senate -- 30 Republicans, 7 Democrats, 3 not heard from.

One effect, and a very marked one, of the overthrow of the Brooklyn ring is in its effect on real estate in that city. Property owners, brokers, and agents are pretty well agreed that values of realty will rise and that active investment and trading, which have been wanting there for some time past, will be resumed immediately.

The inside history of the theft of $90.000 in cash and a lot of valuable jewelry from the vault of the Bank of Minneapolis, Minn., which occurred last September, was disclosed last evening by Inspector McLaughlin, who has in a cell at Police Headquarters Lou Floyd, one of the three men concerned in the robbery.

-- Mme. Patti is still slightly indisposed, and her physician has advised her not to sing tonight, as announced. In consequence, Manager Marcus R. Mayer has postponed the two concerts to next Monday evening and Saturday afternon, Nov. 18. Tickets sold for to-night will be good for Monday evening, and those for next Saturday's matinee will be accepted Saturday afternoon of next week.
LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The markets to-day were dull and generally weak. Americans opened firm, advanced on better prices from New-York, but lost half the advance before closing.
Thomas B. Reed of Maine, ex-Speaker of the House of Representatives, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. When asked for his opinion on the result of the election he dictated the following:

The subject of nearly one-third of the lone annual message read by Gov. NORTHEN before the Legislature of Georgia a few days ago was the penal system of the State. Almost at the beginning of his remarks upon this topic we find the following words:
The American flag blossomed out all over Brooklyn yesterday. It was hung out by the gladdened people to celebrate the demolition of the ring.
LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Daily News says of the American elections of Tuesday...

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- North Chicago opened 3/8 lower than Monday's closing, and remained stationary at 258 to the end of the morning session. West Chicago was a mystery to non-participant members, and delusive to the speculators behind the railing, opening at 155 "regular," jumping to 158 3/8 for "account," descending to 155 "regular," going up again to 157, dropping back to 156, and finally closing at the first call, at 158 "account."

People are wondering why Mr. Chaplin, who, in partnership with the Duke of St. Albans, owns Galopin, is desirous of turning his stud into a limited liability company, with a capital of L 50,000. As times go, this seems a rather large sum, as Hermit is dead and Galopin is approaching twenty-one years. The average life of the English thoroughbred stallion is only sixteen years.

George J. Could was re-elected President of the Manhattan Railway Company yesterday, and the proceedings of the annual meeting of the stockholders were in harmony with the Gould-Sage policy, which has been in control for the past ten years.

BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- Ex-postmaster Thomas N. Hart for Mayor is the echo heard all about town to-day as a result of the Republican victory. He can have the nomination by acclamation if he wants it. Mr. Hart will undoubtedly be the candidate. He made up his mind to give in to the urgent request of not only Republicans but Democratic friends to accept the nomination if the vote for Russell came down to 10,000.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Judge Barnard was asked to-night: "What is your opinion of McKane's action at Gravesend on election day?"

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8. -- Fierce football practice was taken by the Yale eleven this afternoon. Various statements by Walter Camp and other football authorities to the effect that Yale cannot win against the University of Pennsylvania Saturday unless much improvement was shown had their effect on to-day's play, which was lively and well worked throughout.
Francis Henry Weeks, the embezzler of trust funds valued at more than a million dollars, will rise early this morning.

Joseph Chamberlain, M.P., who has been making an extended visit to this country, sailed yesterday for England on board the White Star steamship Majestic. He is accompanied by Mrs. Chamberlain and Austin Chamberlain. Among others who sailed on the Majestic were Mr. and Mrs. D. Catlin and Miss Catlin, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark, J.C., Hoagland, Mrs. George F. Jones and Henry E. Jones, Lord and Lady Playfair, W.E. Sandford, and Admiral Selwyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Commissioner John S. Miller of the Internal Revenue Bureau has begun the preparation of the Treasury regulations for the registration of Chinamen under the recent act of Congress extending the operation of the Geary law for six months.

"Now we will have music," said Miss Emma Steiner, as she closed her talk upon music before the Professional "Woman's League yesterday afternoon, when the audience had resolved itself into a large chorus to be trained for the league benefit.

Some interesting developments in the affairs of the Northern Pacific Railroad may be looked for as the investigation instituted by the bondholders' committee progresses. That the investigation will be searching and fair there can be no doubt, and the result will be accepted as an accurate measure of the real condition of the property.

Abbey's Theatre, one of the costliest and best-appointed playhouses in the metropolis, was opened to the public last night, when Henry Irving and Ellen Terry appeared there in Tennyson's sombre and tragic dramatic piece called "Becket."
