The recital of these facts is a needful part of the day's news chronicle, but the element of novelty is not permitted in these times to any theatrical event of so much importance.
J.W. Reinhart, President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe has just returned from a three weeks' tour of inspection of the lines of that system. He said yesterday:
Chairman Hackett of the Republican State Committee's Executive Committee made the following statement yesterday afternoon:

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- By a rear-end collision on the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad this evening at Seventy-first Street, five people were killed and thirty-two injured. Passenger Train No. 11, known as the limited vestibule express, crashed into the rear end of a Blue Island acommodation, badly wrecking two coaches and the engine.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- It now transpires that the outcome of the election in the First Assembly District in Onondaga County is very much in doubt, the latest figures making it a tie vote, and both sides claiming the count. The indications are, however, that James Meagher, the Democratic candidate, will be seated by a majority of 6 votes.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 8. -- At 3 o'clock this morning the returns of the Inspectors of Election in forty-five districts had not been filed in the City Clerk's office, and steps were taken by the Republican General Committee to arrest all tardy Inspectors. It was feared that fraud similar to that of last year would, be attempted.

-- Charles S. Hamlin, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury; ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild, and Collector Kilbreth conferred yesterday afternoon regarding the work of the customs investigating commission of which Mr. Fairchild is Chairman. The commission did not complete its work, but it gathered information enough to show that the service can be vastly improved.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- Comte d'Eu, Dom Pedro's son-in-law and Admiral Mello's candidate for a new throne in Brazil, returned to his home in the suburbs late last week and on Monday gave his first reception. He lives in the village of Boulogne-sur-Seine, just outside Paris. His house in the Boulevard de Boulogne faces the Auteuil Park and race course, and, although hardly palatial, is roomy and pleasant.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- A dispatch from Johannesburg says that the Fort Tuli column, consisting of 300 Bachuasaland police and a number of Chief Khama'B men, under command of Commander Raaf, captured Baluwayo on Nov. 2, the day after the column had repulsed an attack made upon it by the Matabeles, under command of Gombo, Lobengula's son-in-law.

Ex-county Clerk William A. Butler lent a spice of interest yesterday to the proceedings brought against John Keenan by George P. Upington. Mr. Butler in open court called one of Pinkerton's detectives a liar.

There was a great outpouring of the members of the Brooklyn Democratic Club last night at 201 Montague Street. Brooklyn, to rejoice over the tremendous victory achieved by the independent voters of the City of Churches over "Boss" McLaughin and his corrupt ring. It was the first meeting of the club since the election, and almost every member was present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Many reports about the work of the Ways and Means Committee on the Revenue bill are getting into print, nearly all of which are characterized by Chairman Wilson as being without foundation in fact. If Washington readers could be easily startled by reports of grievous dissensions in the committee as to the plan and scope of the bill, they would have a new spasm of alarm almost every day.

William J. Gaynor is determined that John Y. McKane shall be prosecuted for his outrageous actions at Gravesend prior to and on election day. To a reporter for The New-York Times Mr. Gaynor said yesterday:

Real estate men were interested yesterday in the announcement that the mansion until recently owned by Mr. Pierre Lorillard had again been sold. The new owner is Mr. H.O. Havemeyer. The price paid is said to be $375,000, and the purchaser has thirty days in which to take title. Mr. Havemeyer has already been offered an advance of $25,000 for his bargain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day outlined the position of the Administration as to Government employes participating actively in politics, in a letter addressed to Mr. Murphy, Collector of internal Revenue for the Milwaukee, wis., district. Mr. Murphy was recently elected Chairman of the Democratic County Committee.

The announcement made yesterday in these columns that the cruiser New-York could not be docked in any dry dock in the United States was further substantiated yesterday by naval men. The New-York, it was said, had been docked at the League Island Navy Yard, but that was at a time when there were no guns, stores, provisions, or ammunition on board.

The question which is in the minds of numbers of sincere supporters of the Democratic Party because of the principles it professes and the policy it has promised is, What, after this week's elections, is the outlook for that party? The answer is very simple. The future of the party is in its own hands, and according as its merit is will its reward be.

Now that John Y. McKane has gone deliberately upon the record as an enemy of American institutions, a traitor to the American flag, and a violent and outrageous Anarchist generally. It is just as well to dissipate the idea that all these qualities are combined in a renegade American citizen.
Money on call loaned at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

Fiss Doerr, on East Twenty-fourth Street, will to-day sell a catalogue of all classes of horses, embracing roadsters, business animals, carriage horse, cobs, and trotters. It is very hard, indeed, if a buyer cannot find here something suitable to his wants. This firm gives an ample guarantee with every horse sold that it is exactly as represented.

The cause of nearly all of the rear-end collisions which have taken place since the beginning of the year has been reckless disobedience of orders and a refusal on the part of train officers to be influenced by well-known conditions of danger. Such was the cause of the collision on the Rock Island Road, near Chicago, Wednesday evening, by which nine passengers were killed.

The editor of The Brooklyn Times is evidently a man with a memory, as will be seen by the following contribution to the history of the recent moral and political revolution which, on Nov. 7, dethroned the McLaughlin dynasty:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- For the sake of the Administration, it is to be regretted that the policy of the Government in Hawaii, as set forth in the instructions to Minister Willis, could not have been made public earlier, and that they are not known now by others than the President, his Cabinet, and Minister Willis.

The reorganization of the musical clubs of Columbia College is now complete. The Glee. Mandolin, Banjo, and Dramatic Clubs Have united under the name of the Musical Society, but each club will retain its separate organization. There will be seventy-two students in the Musical Society, divided, as follows: Twenty-eight in the Glee Club, twenty in the Dramatic Club, twelve in the Mandolin Club, and twelve in the Banjo Club.

Winter fish are appearing in the markets in greater number, particularly fresh water fish. Quantities of yellow perch from Lakes Superior and Huron are offered, also ciscos and whitefish from the various Western lakes. The former, according to variety, are termed ciscos, ciscosttes, and cigarettes. The Lake Champlain whitefish are small, but of superior quality.

SPOKANE, Washington, Nov. 9 -- William E. Carlin, son of Brig. Gen. W.P. Carlin, commanding the Department of Columbia, with his brother-in-law, John Harvey Pierce, and A.L.A. Himmelwright of New-York and three other men, comprising a hunting party, are snowed in at the head of the Clearwater River, in the Bitter Root Mountains, and grave fears are entertained for their safety.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The local market to-day has been moderately active and stronger, with the closing prices generally showing improvement. Lehigh Valley was a prominent feature, advancing after the opening to 43, subsequently reacting to 41 1/2, and closing at 42 1/2. There was a much broader market in this stock than for some time, with the trading well distributed.

Henri Vincent, who was once one of the editors of La Patrie, the Paris newspaper that supported Gen. Boulanger, committed suicide early yesterday morning by shooting himself through the heart in his room at 81 Varick Street. He was a brother-in-law of the Rev. Father John Crimmins of St. Francis College, Brooklyn.
We have received the following letter from an old and esteemed friend of The Times:

A mass meeting of the younger element of Hebrews in this city was Held last night in the new building of the Retail Grocers' Union at 140 East Fifty-ninth Street. Its object was to raise money enough by subscription to give the Young Men's Hebrew Association a new and more commodious home and to improve its condition.

BUFFALO, Nov. 9 -- Sheriff Beck, the Police Commissioners, Police Superintendent, Captains, and officers, and all the thugs, colonizers, and special Deputy Sheriffs concerned in the illegal practices in the First and Nineteenth Wards on election day will be called to account therefor -- so an evening paper says.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Fred Lauph, a convict sentenced to a year's imprisonment in jail and to pay a fine of $100 for violating the Chinese exclusion laws in California, has been pardoned by the President, who says: "I deem it proper to recognize the praiseworthy conduct of this prisoner in defending the Warden of the prison where he is confined against a dangerous attack by desperate prisoners in revolt."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- To the soldier of the Union Army who served in the war of the rebellion the five-pointed bronze star awarded to such officers and privates "as have most distinguished or who may hereafter most distinguish themselves in action" is one of the most highly-coveted prizes of that war.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- This is Lord Mayor's Day, when a great portion of the population of London gathers to witness the procession attendant upon the taking over of office by the newlyelected Lord Mayor. The new Lord Mayor is G.R. Tyler, who succeeds Sir Stuart Knill.

The crushing defeat administered the Kings County prize-fighting trust and the Coney Island Athletic Club by The New-York Times seems to hare destroyed the prize-fighting industry and made Messrs. Corbett and Mitchell work much harder to got a job than they have been accustomed to do after they had it.

There is a big demand for tickets for the Yale-Pennsylvania game to be played at Manhattan Field to-morrow. Receiver Freedman says that he has already had applications for 1,000 seats. He thinks that with good weather 15,000 people ought to turn out to witness the contest. Both the Pennsylania and Baltimore and Ohio roads will run special trains from Philadelphia.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed at the Building Department yesterday:

There was another hearing yesterday in Philadelphia before Master Crawford relative to the use of the securities "ransomed" from Messrs. Prince Co. of Boston and Messrs. Ervin Co. of Philadelphia as collateral in the loan which Messrs. Speyer Co. of this city hold against the Reading Railroad Company.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Money at the Clearing House remained unchanged at 2 per cent., but, if possible, the demand for funds was less than yesterday. The stock market opened firm and held steady until about noon, when free selling of Atchison broke the price of that stock to 18 5/8, and the whole market declined in sympathy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Senhor Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister, does not believe that Admiral Mello has again bombarded Rio Janeiro, although he has received advices by way of London which would indicate that the rebel leader had on yesterday poured a furious fusillade of shot and shell into the Brazilian capital.

For several years Clinton Palmer, a lawyer, and Joseph Warner Bott have occupied the same room at 499 Fifth Avenue. Now Mr. Palmer has disappeared and Mr. Bott charges him with forgery. Yesterday the Sheriff received an attachment against the lawyer for $700 in favor of Mr. Bott, who had advanced that amount upon a check purporting to be drawn by Elizabeth G. Palmer in Boston on Oct. 26, and indorsed by Mr. Palmer.

Francis Henry Weeks, with smoothshaven face, close-cropped hair, and in the stripes of a felon, has begun to serve in the State prison at Sing Sing the sentence of ten years imposed on him by Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions Wednesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The remarkable change of votes yesterday from one year ago is a triumph of ballot reform as well as for good government generally, But it is worth noting now that the New-York ballot law requires prompt revision, and that the opportunity should be taken to make it the best instead of the worst of the reformed ballot laws.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Senator John Sherman, who has been in Ohio for the past fortnight, returned to the city to-day. He is naturally elated at the splendid majority gained by the Republicans of the Buckeye State.

Alderman-elect John J. McGarry of the First Aldermanic District of Brooklyn, better known as "I -- McGarry," leader and chief of the hoodlums who tried to break up a meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club when it was about to indorse the nomination of Charles A. Schleren, was interviewed last night by a reporter for The New-York Times at his home, 388 Union Street.

The question of through export rates from Western points was discussed yesterday at a meeting of the joint committee representing the roads in the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations. About twenty-five railroad companies were represented. Including the New-York Central, Pennsylvania, Erie, Baltimore and Ohio, Lehigh Valley, West Shore, Lackawanna, Jersey Central, Lake Shore, Michigan Central, Chicago and Grand Trunk, "Big Four," and the Vandalia Line.
Charles L. Bucki thinks that a little five-dollar limit game of draw poker, when played with an ex-Governor and a United States Senator, should not properly be construed as gambling.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Wheat was quiet most of the session to-day. The opening was about 1 4@1 4c lower than the close of yesterday, declining 3 8@1 2c further with some alight changes, became strong toward the close, and advanced 5 8c the outside figures of the day. where it closed unchanged from yesterday. English cables were quiet. Liquidation of the May option was the principal weakening feature early.

Mr. T. C. PLATT, with unusual modesty, ascribes the Democratic defeat of Tuesday to "Divine Providence." Mr, PLATT himself, it need hardly be said, bad nothing to do with it, and is doubtless in a state of great disgust with himself for not having foreseen that the people would elect his ticket in spite of him.

Depositors of the defunct Commercial Bank, Brooklyn, are preparing to proceed civilly against President Seth L. Keeney and the Directors of that institution for the recovery of the amounts of their deposits.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The Times has this dispatch from Rio Janeiro: "On Nov. 3 the insurgents placed three guns on the Island of Mocangue. They have dally skirmishes with the Government troops. The Government forts continue to fire on Villegagnon Island. The casualties are small.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Omitting bonds, the trading to-day on the Stock Exchange was practically confined to West and North Chicago and Lake Street Elevated. The clique was ominously non-participative to-day, which emboldened two or three hardy members to attack the cable stocks, but they received no support from other brokers.

-- Complaint having been made to the Baltimore and Ohio Road that portions of tickets of the Pittsburg and Western issue and reading from Pittsburg to Seattle over the Wisconsin Central from Chicago were disturbing the markets in Chicago and threatening a demoralization in rates, the Baltimore and Ohio managers at once issued instructions to have the entire issue of tickets canceled and the office at Pittsburg which sold them closed up.

William Mannick, thirty-two years old, and James Baxter, forty-four years old, both coachmen. occupy the same rooms over a stable at 144 West Fiftieth Street On Tuesday night they had as a guest another coachman. James Whitdalo of 134 West Fiftieth Street, and another man.

Prof. Herman August Hagen of Harvard College, one of the greatest scientists in the world, died yesterday in Boston. He was born in Konigsberg, Prussia, May 30, 1817. For the last 250 years some ancestor of his has been connected with the University of Konigsberg. Mr. Hagen received his medical degree from the university of his native city in 1840, studying later at Berlin, Vienna, Paris, and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Whatever may be thought about the stability of the New-York by those who have studied her at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, Assistant Secretary McAdoo and Chief Naval Constructor Hichborn have the greatest confidence in a good report of her as to stability and efficiency They both tell about the same story, based, presumably, upon the same facts.

Brooklyn society was interested in the marriage of Miss Clara J. Birkett, daughter of ex-Senator James W. Birkett of 185 Hancock Street, last evening, to Willett Morrison Raynor of Patchogue, L. I. The wedding took place at the home of the bride at 8 o'clock, and the Rev. Crandell J. North, the former pastor of both the bride and bridegroom, officiated.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 9 -- The election of all the "machine" Democratic candidates in Richmond County, except Judge Stephens, will be contested. The returns, which were filed with the County Clerk to-day, bear upon their faces evidences of fraud.

The tolls art closing in slowly, firmly, surely, on John Y. McKane. There is nothing impetuous or hysterical in the preparations going on to bring this tremendous outlaw to justice. Every mesh in the net is being specially woven and tested, and when it is flung around him there will not be even the suspicion of a single weak spot for the captive desperado to try and break through.
Dr. William J. Morton, who was said to have gone to Germany to prescribe for Prince Bismarck, has returned to this city. He arrived here Wednesday on the North German Lloyd steamer Labn.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Nov. 9 -- P.M. There was less activity in the stock market to-day. Business was very light in the morning. In the afternoon it showed a little more life, consequent upon a selling movement, under which prices weakened pretty generally. The total transactions of the day on the Exchange barely reached 223,000 shares, or a little more than two-thirds of the aggregate of trades on Wednesday.

Dr. Charles Bushong read a paper before the Friends' Literary and Library Association last evening, at their hall, 286 East Sixteenth Street, on the pension system of the United States. He gave the fruits of his experience as a Pension Examiner in New-York from October, 1890, to August, 1893. "Much has been said and written recently," Dr. Bushong said, "regarding the classes of men drawing pensions.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Francis Parkman, the eminent historian, died at his home on Prince Street, Jamaica Plain, yesterday. His last sickness was brief, peritonitis being the cause of death.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Thomas E. Pearsall, the defeated candidate for Supreme Court Justice in the Second Judicial District, arrived in this city this noon from New-York. He hurried through the station to the cab line and, ordering a cab, got into it, saying to the driver: "Take me to Judge Barnard's house, quick."

The two German military bands from the German village at the World's Fair are now on their way home from Chicago. Before going to Europe the bands will give a few concerts in several important cities. The first station was St. Louis, where the bands arrived on Nov. 1. The news of the arrival attracted an enormous crowd, and the Union Station was overcrowded.
A Sims-Edison torpedo has been purchased by Flint Co. for service on board the new Brazilian cruiser Britannia.

Mr. GEORGE P. WEBSTER'S defeat in the Twenty-seventh Assembly District was brought about by the police patrolmen of his district in revenge for his opposition at Albany last Winter to a bill needlessly and extravagantly increasing the salaries of the police. The salary of a patrolman is now $1,200 a year, which is much more than most of them could earn in any private vocation.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The Supreme Court has decided that the method of electing Assemblymen in New-Jersey is unconstitutional.

The result of the inquest which was held yesterday to determine the responsibility for the death of Dr. Galen W. Lovatt, who died on Oct. 21 last at the New-York Hospital, from a pistol wound in his head, was a verdict by the Coroner's Jury that he was killed by a bullet fired by "some person to them unknown."

While rejoicing last night over the unexpected victory which the tricky god of politics had vouchsafed them, the Republicans of the Union League Club had little chance to examine the gallery of paintings provided for them by the Art Committee. It is a small collection, and its range is not great, but it is well worth lingering over.

NIAGARA, FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Richard Hartigan, chief eagineer at the pumping house of the city water works, lost his life yesterday afternoon by a strange accident which is yet only partially explained. For eighteen hours no one discovered his fate.

The annual dinner and reunion of the Emma Willard Society was held at the Windsor Hotel yesterday afternoon. The society is composed of former pupils of the Troy Female Seminary, which was founded in 1821 by Emma Willard.

Thomas C. Platt returned to this city yesterday morning from Owego, where he received the election returns. Of course, there were many callers at his office yesterday, and, of course, they all congratulated him. It was the first time they had had a chance to do so in many years.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Miss Annie Pixley, the well-known American actress, died in this city last night. Miss Pixley died at the residence of her brother-in-law, Mr. Edwin Fulford, 188 Pentonville Road. Her husband was present at the time of her death, which was caused by brain fever.

The one hundred and tenth anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther was celebrated last evening by the Luther League of New-York City at Association Hall, in East Twenty-third Street. The members wore a badge with the coat-of-arms of the great German reformer, a small black cross on a heart resting on a white rose, emblematic of purity, in a field of blue.
MINNEAPOLIS Minn., Nov. 10 -- Rigid economy will be exercised in the missionary work of the Methodist church at home as well as abroad for a year to come at least.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The first experiments in the use of electricity as a propelling power on the canals of this State will probably be made on the level east of Rochester some time during the coming week. It has been announced that the test would be made to-morrow, but the amount of preparatory work to toe done will postpone that event for nearly if not quite a week.

The Sub-Treasury continues to use gold in settling its balances at the Clearing House. Yesterday it paid out $1,500,000 in coin in this manner. These demands upon the Treasury's gold supply are being offset by the action of a good many banks in paying to the Treasury gold for customs and internal revenue duties.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The effect of Judge Depue's decision yesterday in the "gerrymander" case is being variously construed. Many Democratic lawyers maintain it necessitates the holding of another election for members of the Assembly. If the law under which the election held Tuesday is unconstitutional, they claim the results of that election are nullified.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Action was taken by the Board of Directors of the World's Columbian Exposition to-day which may result in the preservation of the White City. A resolution was introduced by Ferdinand Peck with this end in veiw. It provided that the Executive Committee should open correspondence with the South Park Cammissioners and endeavor to gain their consent to the retention of the Court of Honor for one year longer.

"Mrs. Bucki declined, all overtures looking toward reconciliation. She said there had already been too much sentiment, and she was tired of it. She wanted something practical -- a legal separation and an allowance of $200 a week."

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The only member of the Elmira Reformatory Investigation Committee to begin taking the testimony to-day of twenty prisoners transferred here from the reformatory was Mr. Litchfield. The other members were detained at home by illness.
Messrs. Charles Buermann Co. have sold for Miss Margaret E. Cody, to Hugh Fehling, the lot 402 South Fifth Street, 25 by 90.

Chauncey M. Depew, J. Pierpont Morgan, William C. Whitney, J.W. Reinhart, H.F. Dimock, E.V.W. Rossiter, O.H. Payne, ex-Senator William H. Robertson, and other distinguished railroad men and financiers were called to White Plains, Westchester County, yesterday, in consequence of a hearing in the suit to foreclose the second mortgage of the New-York and Northern Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- The United States protected cruiser Columbia will start to-morrow from Cramps' ship yard prepared for her official trial trip, which will take place off the coast of Massachusetts about the middle of next week. The cruiser will arrive at Delaware Breakwater in the afternoon, and it is expected that she will anchor there over night.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 10 -- The extent of the dishonesty of Louis F. Menage, President of the Northwestern Guarantee Company, was made public to-day in the schedules of his individual liabilities filed with the Clerk of the Court of Hennepin County. They show that his robbery of the people who had dealings with him amounts to $1,650,811.

Attorney General Olney made a flying visit to this city last Wednesday. He stopped at the Murray Hill Hotel, and declined to explain publicly the purpose of his visit. It was said last night, however, upon excellent authority, that the Attorney General's visit had an important significance relative to Union Pacific Railroad matters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- One-third of the month of November expired with today, and it shows that the Government expenditures this month have exceeded the receipts by $2,250,000. The total receipts for the month so far have been: From customs. $3,565,000; internal revenue, $4,561.000; miscellaneous, $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Now 10 -- The Walker board has another big problem before it. The members were hastily summoned back to Washington for a session yesterday, although most of them understood they were to hold no more meetings until after the trial trip of the Columbia, upon the trial board of which ship several members of the Walker board had been detailed.

Adrian Van Sinderen, embezzler of trust funds amounting to $200,000, who became a fugitive from justice after his indictment for grand larceny in 1891, and who was believed by everybody to be dead, has come to life again.

Gen. E. Burd Grubb is an ardent admirer of football, and he was one of the interested spectators of the Princeton-Pennsylvania game last Saturday. In order to see the two teams meet again, the General offered as a trophy a cup valued at $1,000 to be contested for. Here is his letter to Capt. Mackey:

Angelo Pagano and Salvatore Imperiall were held yesterday by Justice Walsh in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, for trial, on a charge of stealing 500 pounds of German type, valued at $450, from the American. Type Founders' Company of this city. Henry L. Bullen of 87 Hart Street was the complainant.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 10 -- A rumor was circulated in this city to-day to the effect that all saloons would be closed Sunday. It is not that the authorities are any more moral than they were, but it is charged that the saloon keepers gave their influence on Tuesday in favor sheriff-elect Toffey because the Democrats did not keep pledges made to the Liquor Dealers' Association.

Mr. TOM JOHNSON of Ohio is a thoroughgoing tarifi reformer and has done good work for the cause. But in proposing an income tax to provide the revenues we lost in remitting the sugar duty, Mr. JOHNSON is on unsafe ground. We tried that experiment once, with most unsatisfactory results.

The fifty-six survivors of the steamship City of Alexandria, which was burned at sea, near Havana, on the night of Nov. 1, reached this port on board the steamship Seneca, of the same line, yesterday. Eleven men lost their lives. Five of them were members of the crew. The others were negro stevedores who had been taken aboard at Matanzas.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 10 -- Mrs. Robert S. Ritter of this village, who, a few weeks ago, horsewhipped her husband on Main Street because he attempted to take a horse blanket out of her carriage, has created another sensation. A few days after the horsewhipping episode she was arrested, charged with assault by her husband.

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- The delegates appointed by Russia to negotiate a commercial treaty with Germany made such concessions at a meeting ot the Commissioners held yesterday that the conclusion of the treaty is assured. Moreover, Russia has now empowered her delegates to settle the minor attentions connected with the treaty without referring them to St. Petersburg.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- General Superintendent I.D. Barton of the New-York and New-England Railroad says of the New-Haven order made yesterday to abolish the distinctive trains of the New-York and New-England now running into the Grand Central Station at New-York on and after Nov. 19:

At a conference of Bridge Trustees, elevated railroad officials, and prominent citizens, held last evening at the office of the Brooklyn Bridge, Washington and Nassau Streets, Brooklyn, it was decided to submit plans for the new bridge and elevated railroad termini to a committee of expert engineers.

CHICAGO. Ill., Nov. 10 -- Harlow N. Higinbothnm, President of the Board of Directors of the World's Fair, gave $100,000 to the Columbian Museum Fund to-day, and John D. Rockefeller gave $500,000 to the Chicago University.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- This was the second day of the Liverpool Autumn meeting. The principal race of the day was for the Liverpool Autumn Cup, which was won by Baron de Hirsch's four-year-old brown filly La Fleche, by St. Simon, out of Quiver. Lord Cadogan's three-year-old bay colt Prisoner, by Isonomy, out of Lonely, was second, and Lord Penrhyn's three-year-old chestnut colt Quaesitum, by Hagioscope, out of strange Lady, third.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The attack of John Y. McKane upon the agents of William J. Gaynor in Gravesend and his defiance of the orders of the Supreme Court come in for unstinted denunciation by the State officers and other prominent Democrats here.

A morning newspaper recently announced the marriage of Herbert A. Levy, a wellknown artist with a studio in the Sherwood, Fifty-seventh Street and Sixth Avenue, to Miss G.G.I. McClenahan. Mr. Levy has denied the marriage.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- The market opened weak for New-England, which declined in sympathy with the New-York quotations, as did also St. Paul. There was good buying of New-England to-day by parties generally well posted on the movement of that stock. Lehigh Valley was also weaker at the opening, selling at 41 7/8 , but subsequently recovered to 42 3/4 on light transactions, and declined just before the close to 42 1/4 .

It is doubtless to be desired that the Academy of Design should have a new building. Its present building is ample for the exhibition of works of art. If it should at any time become inadequate for that purpose, room could be easily made by raising the standard for the admission of such works.

PRINCETON, Nov. 10 -- Manager Thompson announced to-day two new dates as follows: Nov. 18, West Point at West Point; Nov. 22, Georgetown at Princeton. To-day's practice was the last one before the Yale game open to the student body. It was very ragged and discouraging, though very few of the 'Varsity men participated.

It is the custom of politicians who have committed indictable offenses to run for office, and, if they succeed, to maintain that they have been "vindicated." In other words, a popular election is the same thing as a verdict of acquittal, and morally ought to stop proceedings in the case upon the constitutional ground that the accused person has already been "in jeopardy."

Senator John McCarty of the Sixth District claims to have defeated his opponent. Henry Wolfert, by 76 votes. He bases his claim on the returns from Richmond County and Gravesend. Richmond County gave McCarty 4,991 votes and Wolfert 4,035. In Gravesend, McCarty received 3,504 and Wolfert 165.

Nobody has been able to estimate how many pounds of candy have been eaten during the present week at what the managers call the World's Candy Exposition in the Lenox Lyceum. But the quantity has certainly been great enough to produce a similar disordered condition of the public stomach to that which prevails immediately after Christmas, when everybody munches candy and lies awake o' nights afterward.

It is to be hoped that violators of the election laws and perpetrators of frauds upon the ballot box will find that such crimes bring their due penalties. But, apart from that consideration, it has been amply demonstrated in the last five years that it does not pay for any political party to attempt to carry elections by corruption or fraud or to permit it to be done for its benefit.
Before the suit or George P. Upington against John Keenan is ended some very interesting facts as to police "protection" in 1880 and 1882 may be developed.

Nothing could more strengthen the Administration in the confidence of fairminded and right-thinking men than the act of justice to Hawaii which is announced in the letter of Secretary GRESHAM, published this morning, and there is no strength so great or so enduring for an Administration as that given by the confidence of fair and intelligent men.

The story of the alleged forgery by Clinton Palmer at the expense of J. Warner Bott, a lawyer, as told in The New-York Times, took on a new phase yesterday. Palmer, who is a weak-mouthed, round-shouldered young man, with a pallid face, was supposed to have left the city, but he was arrested yesterday, and in the Jefferson Market Police Court he was remanded for examination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- First Assistant Postmaster General Jones in his first annual report discusses the experiment of free delivery in towns and villages. He says this plan has had a practical test extending over a period of two and one-half years. In forty-six towns and villages, ranging in population from 800 to 4,000 inhabitants, the system has been in operation for two full years.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Nov. 10, P.M. Chicago Gas and New-England monopolized the attention of traders in to-day's stock market. The first named led in point of activity and it was exceptionally strong. Opening at 60, it was fairly steady during the morning.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 10 -- There was a jam of vehicles at the entrance to the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry, in this city, this afternoon. When the funeral of William T. Kennedy of 787 Columbus Avenue, New-York, drove off the 3:30 o'clock boat the hearse was forced under a low awning and John Marran, the driver, was swept from his seat.

A remarkable piece of engineering, in which nature was made to assist the engineer, has been partly accomplished on the River Weser, in Germany, between Bremen and Bremerhaven, a distance of thirty miles. By the construction of lateral jetties, confining the bed or the river, the stream has been made to dig out and straighten its own channel.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- One per cent. was the rate at the Clearing House to-day. Call money was quoted at 2 1/2 @ 3 per cent., and time money at 3 1/2 @4. A 60-days' loan on giltedged collateral was made at 3 1/2 per cent. The rate for four to six months is 4 per cent.

COLOGNE, Nov. 10 -- The Volks-Zeitung says that Mgr. Satolli, the Papal Delegate to the United States, will be elevated to the Cardinalate at the next Papal Consistory and that the present Papal Nuncio at The Hague, Mgr. Rinaldini, will replace Satolli as Papal Delegate to the United States.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Twenty anxious wheelmen are getting in form for the great fifty-mile relay race which, will he run to-morrow. Two messages will be sent out by the President of the Newark Wheelmen to be carried fifty miles. Two teams of ten men each have been selected from the Newark Wheelmen members to carry these messages.

The hand of the law has again been laid upon John C. Eno for the misappropriation of $2,945,000 of the funds of the Second National Bank. On a warrant issued by United States Commissioner Shields and placed with Marshal John W. Jacobus for service, Mr. Eno was arrested Thursday nigh at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

After two days' careful investigation by detectives of Inspector McLaughlin's staff it was learned yesterday that Philip Scheig, the defaulting paying teller of the Bank of Minneapolis, and Frank Floyd, one of his two companions, did not, as was at first thought, sail on the steamship Spree.

Postmaster Dayton has thanked the Superintendents, clerks, and letter carriers of the General Post Office and branch stations for the excellent manner in which the postal service was conducted in this city from Nov. 1 to Nov. 6. During that time 1,217,346 pieces of election mail matter and 8,920,356 of regular matter was handled without delay.

In the sale of the Lorillard mansion at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street to Mr. Henry O. Havemeyer, the latter gave in part payment the four-story brownstone dwelling, 117 West Seventy-sixth Street, 20 by 65 by 102.2, at a valuation of $40,000. The Lorillard mansion is mortgaged for $200,000 to the United States Trust Company, and Mr. Lorillard holds a second mortgage of $40,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The trading in West Chicago made things lively on the Stock Exchange this morning. The clique did not care to trouble itself about devising a new scheme for the purpose of obtaining stock below yesterday's figures. It simply took all the regular and cash stock offered. The first few sales we'e "regular," at 158 3/4 @ 159 1/2 , followed by transactions for the account at 159@159 5/8 .

The defend of Patrick Henry McCarren for Senator in the Fourth District of Brooklyn was the engrossing subject of conversation among politicians in that city yesterday. Some of the newspapers said that George A. Owens, the successful Republican candidate, had been nominated as a "dummy" and did not try to win, but worked and voted for McCarren.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Ten days or a fortnight will probably see the new Democratic tariff bill given, to the public. The Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee have not yet made their final revision of any of the schedules, but a number of them are decided upon for all practical purposes, and will not be changed except in minor details.

The opponents of Tammany Hall are much encouraged by the action of the Union League Club Thursday night in passing a resolution favoring an organization against the Wigwam withoutregard to the political affiliations of those taking part in the movement. Many members of the City Club are already agitating the question among their friends, and politicians like the Steckler, Kempner, and Voorhis people are doing their utmost to bring about some sort of combined movement.

Addison B. Colvin, State Treasurer-elect, who arrived in the city yesterday and visited Republican State Headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel -- While I held to the opinion -- or perhaps I should say strong hopes -- that there would be a Republican sweep. I must say that the result even exceeded my expectations and was a good deal of a surprise.

Walter Damrosch has very wisely abandoned the meaningless practice of calling the afternoon concerts of the Symphony Society public rehearsals. They are really performances, and the audience would be quite as much astonished as the musicians if Mr. Damrosch should stop the latter for the purpose of making corrections or giving advice.

The members of the Patria Club, which meets once every month to discuss leading questions of the day, assembled at Sherry's. Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, last evening to listen to addresses on "The Financial Problem."

DEPARTMENT OF STATE. WASHINGTON, Oct. 18, 1893. To the President: The full and impartial reports submitted by the Hon. James H. Blount, your special Commissioner to the Hawaiian Islands, establish the following facts:

Without haste, but none the less surely and relentlessly, preliminary steps toward punishing John Y. McKane, Chief of the Coney Island police, for his outrages at Gravesend on American citizens are being taken. That there is to be no leniency shown him becomes more and more evident every day.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Fourteen loaded coal barges in tow of the tugs Pearsall and Vandercook, from New-York for Sound ports, were caught in a rough sea off here early this morning. While floundering about, the towing hawsers parted and several of the barges filled and sank, drawing others down with them, until ten in all had gone to the bottom.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Anarchists of all groups gathered at the South Place Institute this evening to commemorate the execution of the Chicago Anarchists six years ago. The hall was crowded. On the walls nuns red flags and scrolls with Anarchist mottoes. One scroll bore the words: "There will be a time when silence will be more powerful than voices or scrolls."

BUFFALO, Nov. 10 -- Warrants were issued last Monday for the arrest of 129 colonizers. These warrants were given to a policeman to serve, and, although 100 at least of the men who are wanted are walking around Buffalo, that policeman has been able to find but five of them. This is a sample of the operations of the Sheehan police force.

The Republican politicians of Brooklyn, who would have nominated some other map than Charles A. Schieren as their candidate for Mayor if they had had their way, are, with characteristic modesty, claiming that the "organization" elected him. Now that the battle has been won by the independent Republicans and independent Democrats who brought about Mr. Schieren's nomination, the politicians are trying to impress the public with the idea that they overthrew McLaughlinism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- It is believed that, as it was reported last night, the English Government, through its Ambassador, has urged the United States to exert its mediating influence between the conflicting elements in Brazil in order to bring to a speedy close the internal strife which has been progress in that country for several months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Those persons who have been led to believe that the Administration would find a way out of the Hawaiian difficulty that would not involve restoration of the deposed Queen are to be disappointed.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 10 -- Mrs. Mary E. Lease, the Populist of Kansas, passed through here to-day on her return home from stumping in Iowa. She said that the vote in Kansas was a protest against the corrupt men of the People's Party who obtained office, fused with the Democrats, and by so doing trampled under foot every principle of her party.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The Elmira Reformatory investigating committee was at work early this morning. The Rev. Dr. William Searies, the first witness, Chaplain in Auburn Prison for fifteen years, remembered a transfer prisoner from Elmira about ten years ago who showed him his back, which was badly lacerated.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Callender Stevens, daughter of Francis B. Stevens and sister of Mrs. Albert Stevens of Castle Point, Hoboken, to her second cousin, Richard Stevens, son of John Stevens and grandson of the late Edwin Stevens, took place yesterday noon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Hudson Street, Hoboken.

BARDWELL, Ky., Nov. 11 -- Three closely-masked men stopped north-bound train No. 22 on the main line of the Illinois Central early this morning at Mayfield Creek trestle, two and a half miles north of Mayfield Junction, and robbed the express car of two money packages, one containing $33, addressed to J.S. Titus, Chicago, and the other a bag containing $7,000, which was being transported from New-Orleans to Chicago.

The new maternity hospital, the New-York Mothers' Home of the Roman Catholic Order of the Sisters of Misericorde, at 531 East Eighty-sixth Street, will be blessed today by Archbishop Corrigan. The ceremonies attending the formal opening of the new building and its dedication to its humane purposes will begin at 10 o'clock in the morning and will be conducted in the temporary chapel in one of the wards of the institution.

The auction list for the present week includes several parcels that are voluntary offerings, and that afford an agreeable change from the monotony of forced sales in legal proceedings. A detailed account of all the property to be offered is subjoined:

The bill was changed at Abbey's Theatre last evening, and "Louis XI.," succeeding "Becket," filled the house with all the glories and enthusiasm of the real "first night." Again everybody was there, a brilliant and magnificent audience, worthily representing New-York's wealth, and illustrating its beauty by scores of dazzling examples.

The game of basket ball, although comparatively new, has within two years acquired a popularity which places it on a par with the oldest and best known indoor sports. The devotees are numbered by the thousand, and they are as load in its praise as an energetic bowler can be over his favorite pastime.

Thirty-five years ago John P. Hale was a central figure in American politics. No name was more familiar throughout the land than his. "Jack" Hale most persons called him, whether they were his fellow-citizens, resident in the New-Hampshire town where he had his home, or those who hated him -- although they admired him -- for his uncompromising opposition to slavery.

The Secretary of State's report upon the Hawaiian business is a sharp rebuke to the spirit of filibustering in this country, as well as a disclaimer of the acts of the Harrison Administration. The settlement which it proposes is simply the restoration of the status which was disturbed by a few intriguing foreigners in Hawaii who had succeeded in making the American Minister an instrument of their designs.

The bronzes and cloisonne enamels in the loan exhibition which closes this month at the Academy of Design are so uncommon in quality and rich in variety that no one who cares for artistic work in bronze and wrought iron should fall to see them.

PARIS, Monday, Oct. 16 -- There was nothing Ibsenian certainly about Gounod, and perchance death come at the proper moment, before the high tide of Wagnerism, of Rubinstein, Kolatchefsky, Tschaikowsky, and others made people ungrateful to that gentle melody, to the exquisite modulation, to the delicate, sensual charm, to the graceful form of the great French composer's style.

It may be unconventional to place a desk, no matter how fine, in the parlor, though the utility of such a piece of furniture cannot be questioned. Some of the beautiful inlaid escritoires shown in our fine art furniture establishments may serve to introduce the fashion, a well-recognized feature of English drawing rooms.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Great anxiety is felt regarding the whereabouts of two vessels, the loss of which would entail the sacrifice of twenty-six lives. They are the Philadelphia schooner Genevieve, Capt. Charles Haley, from this port Oct. 7 for Charleston, and the Austrian bark Ljubay R., Capt. Ranich, from Fiume, Austria, April 13, for Philadelphia.

Up in Vermont, where the mirrored surface of Lake Champlain stretches far to the north and south, and where the eye, gazing upon the vista of its distant further shore, sees precipitous mountains, the pinnacles of which, nestle in banks of fleecy clouds, is the home of Dr. W. Seward Webb. President of the Wagner Palace Car Company.

Incidents and Gossip of Last Week. -- Society people spent last weeK in getting themselves together for the gayeties which will naturally centre about the horse show, which opens to-morrow. Then debutantes and gallants will plunge into the pleasures and expenses of the "town season." They will go to the horse show in their new clothes, some of which, if the ultra lines of English style are carried out.

Samuel Federer, an insurance agent and notary public, with an office at 59 Liberty Street, committed suicide yesterday morning at the Sinclair House, Broadway and Eighth Street, by swallowing carbolic acid and inhaling illuminating gas. Bad business and financial difficulties doubtless drove him to suicide. Mr. Federer was born in Hungary forty-four years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- Claus Spreckels said to-day in regard to Secretary Gresham's letter to the President: "I have so frequently expressed my views publicly lately that I cannot find anything further to say other than to express my satisfaction over the cheerful news received last night.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 11 -- The Chinese Minister, Mr. Yang Yu, is not satisfied with the action of the United States Government in not regarding as conclusive evidence certificates issued by the Chinese Consul General at Havana, Cuba. Secretary Gresham is the medium through whom he has made complaint. Several official communications have within the past tea days passed, between the two Governments on the subject.

Arthur W. Lester. twenty-two yeara of age, is in the Tombs awaiting the action of the Grand Jury for forgery. He dresses well, has a fondness for taking girls out driving and for living uxurioualy without work. His father is Sidney Lester, an insurance agent at 410 East Fiftieth Street.

The educational world was startled about two years ago by the announcement of the Trustees and Faculty of the Normal College that in the future all examinations were to be abolished excepting those for entrance to the college and for graduation, and that an average of 75 per cent. in all studies would be required for advancement to the next class.

WEST POINT, Nov. 11 -- When the estabilshment of a military academy was first proposed, and Congress had adopted a resolution "that the Board of War be directed to prepare a continental laboratory and a military academy and provide the same with proper officers," the statesmen and warriors of that day could not foresee to what giant proportions this noble institution would reach in our time.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Joseph Folger Barnard, for thirty years a Justice of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District of the State of New-York, and for a large part of that time Chief Justice of the General Term of that department, will retire, Jan. 1, 1894, from office, having reached the age limit of seventy years prescribed by the Constitution.

There are three men in Peru at the present time who might be called representatives of the best interests of the country. These are Remigio Morales Bermudez, now President of the republic, and Don Nicolas de Pierola and Gen. Andres Avelino Caceres, both of whom are candidates for the Presidency.

Ke-gu, the half-way halting place on the famous tea road between the Chinese border town Ta-chien-lu and the Thibetan capital, is the centre of the tea trade, and, accordingly, the residence of numerous tea merchants. It has many Chinese inhabitants, a mandarin from Si-ning, and a mandarin from Lan-chav.
In Lincoln Place, in de-Boodyized Brooklyn, is a studio where Sprengel, Linnaeus, and Darwin axe greatly honored.

A large, attentive, and appreciative audience gathered in the lecture room of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday morning to listen to the first of the series of discourses to be delivered by Mr. John La Farge, the eminent artist, whose distinctive and unique work has won universal admiration, not only in this country, but throughout the world.

Further Large Increase in the Reserve -- The Banks Now Hold $57,828,725 in Excess of the Legal Requirements. The weekly bank statement issued to-day showed an increase in reserve of $5,815,275. The banks now hold $57,828,725 is excess of the legal requirements. The following table shows the condition of the New-York City banks this week as compared with last week:

ATHENS, Nov. 11 -- The now Cabinet is composed as follows: M. Tricoupis, Premier and Minister of Finance; M. Bonfides, Minister of the Interior; M. Stephenao, Minister of Justice and ad interim Minister of Foreign Affairs; M. Kailfronas, Minister of Public Instruction; M. Tsamados, Minister of War.
The big fifteen-inch dynamite gun for the new Brazilian cruiser El Cid was mounted yesterday. The gun, with its carriage, weighs nearly forty-five tons.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- General Orders No. 2 were issued from the Grand Army Headquarters in Lynn to-day. In the orders are the following appointments:

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- During the next few weeks it is understood that there will be concerted wholesale arrests of professed and suspected Anarchists in the various capitals of Western Europe, great pressure being brought to bear on the English Foreign Office to join this crusade and draw a dragnet through Soho and other revolutionary hiding quarters in London; but thus far the Cabinet has not decided that England ought to take such a step.
Miss Louise Imogen Guiney, the poet, is trying to be Postmistress at her home, in Auburndale, and her appointment seems to be probable.
From Woman. "But, surely, there is only one way of laying a table?" I hear my readers question.

We had a two per cent. rally on the good feeling caused by the election, but it did not hold very well. The market became dull at the advance, which la a bad sign. Yesterday's closing prices were about what they were on the previous Saturday. So taking the average on the general list for the week, no progress is reported.

M. Houssaye, though acknowledging the utility of the men of science, who, shut up in their laboratories, study natural history by means of the microscope, rather likes the freer life of the man who wanders through the forest, jungle, or field, and so studies animal existence. If we are to pin our faith to the evolution theory, we are bound to consider animal nature in all its inter-relationships.

At this season of many new books, this may be taken as a not remarkably-important addition to the list; but it is very delightful reading. To Gipsyland, by the road of youth and romance and wholesome sentiment, is a pleasant journey for the reader, as it is unaffectedly proclaimed to have been for the writer.

Superintendent F.W. Houghton of the New-York Mercantile Exchange has received a letter from George E. Pullman, General Field Secretary of the Red Cross Society in Washington, indorsing a copy of the report of Officer Macdonald, who is in charge of the relief work at Hillton Head and islands south and east of Broad River, to Miss Clara Barton, President of the society.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Two "crooks" with histories were photographed for the Rogues' Gallery at the Police Headquarters this morning. One was Dr. David C. Bliss and the other was Lillian Stevens. They both are from New-York, and they were arrested last night on the charge of stealing a sealskin cape valued at $140 from the store of Chandler Co., Winter Street, Thursday.

-- The first-class British battle ship Centurion, which early next year will relieve the Imperieuse as flagship of the China station, has recently undergone a four hours' continuous steam trial under forced draught with results which, in the opinion of British experts, make the vessel one of the most satisfactory of all the types in the British Navy.

A decade ago Maharajah Dhuleep Singh, who died in Paris recently, was a well-known figure in London, whose photograph was on sale in the shop windows. He was born in 1838, the son of Ranjeet Singh, "the lion of the Punjab," that doughty East Indian sovereign who was the founder of the Sikh kingdom and the cause of so much trouble to England.
John Y. McKane and his trusted lieutenants, Justices Newton and Sutherland, have fled from the scene of their outlawry, but they are not to be permitted to escape punishment.

From an expert point of view, the game yesterday does not compare favorably with that of Princeton on the Saturday before, when the Tigers defeated Pennsylvania 4 to 0. In the Princeton game it was generally conceded that Capt. Trenchard could have scored more points if he so desired, but be preferred to act on the defensive after securing the lead.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 11 -- The Orange Athletic Club defeated the Yale University Law school this afternoon by a score of 18 to 0. As the teams lined up, Yale appeared to be overmatched by Orange.

Surrogate Abbott of Kings County yesterday admitted to probate the will of Ellen Hartigan. Mrs. Hartigan lived at 140 Fourth Avenue and died June 8. Two days before she died she made a will leaving nearly her entire estate to John D. Murphy, a relative by marriage. The John D. Murphy specified in the will lived at 91 Dean Street, while a nephew of the deceased, John J. Murphy, lived at 89 Dean Street.

TOPEKA, Nov. 11 -- When 200,000 people made their mad rush into the Cherokee Strip on Sept. 16, many of them, after having waited on the border a year or more, grave no thought to the future and the possible sufferings that might result from a Winter settlement in a new country.

Many causes led to the success of "The Beggar's Opera." It ridiculed the prevalent Italian opera, of which people were somewhat tired, and it satirized leading men of the day, especially Walpole, besides attacking, in a more personal manner, the corruption of Courts and politicians. The songs were extremely popular, and the acting was good.

Donzella, chief lighthouse keeper at Bonifacio, in Corsica, who has just died, was one of the heroes of the war of 1870. While Marshal Bazaine was shut up in Metz, the Corsican swam down the Moselle with sealed instructions for him one night.

There will be a riding to hounds this week, according to the announcements of the masters of several of the hunt clubs hereabout. But the work that will be done across the fields of Long Island and New-Jersey will have to take a secondary place in the pleasures of the "horsey set" in society.

It was in the week preceding Easter, 1855, which fell that year on April 8, and I am able to fix the precise date within twenty-four hours because the day was notable as sharing alone with that of the Duke of Wellington's funeral the distinction of being a whole holiday during my nine years' school course.

NORTH MIDDLETON, Ky., Nov. 11 -- Eight strangers rode into this place at 2 o'clock this morning, and it is supposed their intention was to rob the bank. They shot at every person seen on the street and mortally wounded an old negro. Citizens opened fire on the desperadoes, and they answered with a volley from their pistols.

Whittier charmed all his friends. Mrs. Claflin, wife of the ex-Governor of Massachusetts, at whose house in Boston he was a frequent visitor, here writes of him in the simple and sincere style which one may well surmise his personality inspired. It would take much art to write a panegyric of him which would be very rhetorical and not seem inappropriate.

It Is quite true that the temperate regions of the world are becoming more populous, just as it is equally true that the stock of coal in the world is being gradually exhausted. The coal supplies of the United Kingdom are, for all practical purposes, much larger than they were fifty years ago.

WARSAW, Nov. 11 -- A dispatch from BrostLitovsk, a town of Russian Poland, reports an accident there to-day that resulted in the loss of many lives. A terrific explosion occurred in the shop of a chemist, and the building in which the shop was located was completely shattered, as were also the adjacent houses. Each of the buildings contained several families.

The last important department of the public affairs and interests of Brooklyn on which, the McLaughlin gang laid its blighting and defiling hand was that of the public schools. Until within the last few years the system of schools in that city, though far from being what it should have been in either its standards or its methods, had been respectably and honestly managed.

The late Peter Ilitisch Tschaikowsky, the great Russian composer, whose untimely death by cholera was a shock to the entire world of art, was one of the most modest and unassuming of men. In a charmingly-unaffected manner he once gave the writer of this column some recollections of his early career.

-- Mme. Amalia Materna has been engaged for a special series of concerts at Music Hall, in which she will sing in scenes and acts from Wagner's operas in which she has never been heard before in America. When she was over here in the first season of German opera under Dr. Damrosch, "Die Walkuere" was the only opera of the Niebelung trilogy which was performed.

When John Y. McKane assumed the reins of government at Gravesend, the township was one of the richest in the State. With no war debt, owning as it did the whole of Coney Island, the prosperous residents of that now tax-ridden town had every reason to congratulate themselves.

The movement for the bringing to justice of JOHN Y. McKANE is very naturally exciting the utmost interest, not only in Kings County, but throughout the State. Attorney General ROSENDALE does not hesitate to express his sympathy with it, and to declare that it is the duty of the authorities of Kings County to take an active and leading part in it.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Old George Brinley, who ransacked most of the anti-quated attics in the Connecticut Valley forty years ago, in quest of ancient books and prints, was not able to capture everything of interest that was stowed away here. Now and then odd and interesting discoveries are still made.

The New-York Athletic Club and the Crescent Athletic Club elevens opened the series of games for the amateur football union championship at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. The game was well attended. Throughout the name the New-York men played very good football, but lack of beef, as well as a weak centre, told heavily and doomed the blacks to defeat.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 11 -- The identification of George Herbert Stokes, the crank who tried to borrow L20,000 from Sir Oliver Mowat, is now thoroughly established. It is said that he is the son of a wealthy broker doing business in New-York, and that he is liberally provided for. The understanding here is that when his mother dies he will come into possession of a million dollars.

It was of our old friend Alfred Vargrave -- whom we all admired once in our lives, perhaps because he could talk in rhymes much easier and better than we could in prose -- it was of Vargrave that his biographer wrote:

Much or the old joyousnesa of the Irish has vanished. The old stories and legends are rarely told now; politics and trade absorb all the conversation. The narrative of bygone glories and sorrows, of St. Patrick and Brian, of the great O'Neil, and of the Geraldines, and '98 and the famine, have given place to United Ireland, The Nation, and the vulgarities of Mick McQuade.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Cornell was defeated today on Percy Field by Lehigh by a score of 14 to 0. The game was fiercely contested on both sides, and three times Cornell had the ball on Lehigh's tenyard line only to lose it on four downs.

The past week has been a broken one among real estate men. As with other occupations, the election interfered materially with business. Perhaps the most notable of the transactions carried through to completion was the sale of the Pierre Lorillard mansion, at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 -- The attention of Canadians interested in historical subjects has been aroused this week by the step taken by the Quebec Government in selling at public auction the old historic Chateau de Ramezay, one of the last surviving relics of the French regime in Montreal. The Government was driven to this step in order to secure money for its depleted treasury, and to dispose of property which brought in no revenue.

James A. Cowie, the defeated Republican candidate for the Assembly in the Ninth Assembly District, now makes the charge that ex-Postmaster Van Cott was a party to an arrangement under which William F. Moore, the Tammany candidate for re-election as Civil Justice of the Third Judicial District, was to be unoppposed by the Republicans, and William H. Corsa, the Republican Clerk of the court, retained in office.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors will meet for organization Monday. The five Supervisors from Yonkers will then take their seats, in accordance with the recent decision of the Court of Appeals, to which the question of the legality of their election had been carried.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The big Eastern Elevator, the largest in the world, considering its working capacity, was in operation to-day. It is a valuable addition to the commercial interests of Buffalo, by giving storage room and elevating capacity greatly needed. It was begun June 1. It is owned by Gen. John C. Graves, William P. Northrup, and George A. Lea.

The writer recalls once flying to an article in a family magazine headed," Helps for the Children's Lunch Box," confident that it would afford relief to the problem offered afresh for solution in her home five days out of every week throughout the school year, and recalls, too, how these hopes were dashed as paragraph after paragraph was read.

A scene in all the glory of the Elizabethan period and costume; Dukes, regal in department; lords, ladies, and courtiers of perfect mien; a model clown, a noble wrestler, shepherds and foresters, fair youths and maidens -- this is "As You Like It" as it is to be put on the stage on Nov. 21 by the Professional Woman's League without a man in the cast.

It is satisfactory to be told by Mr. Ellis that blindness in England is "slowly declining," though Great Britain still stands in this respect behind two other European countries, and three more come before Ireland. Short-sightedness, however, appears to be increasing everywhere, Germany having a signal and sinister pre-eminence in this respect.

The difficulty in the Sixty-ninth Regiment is nearly over. Col. Cavanagh has received an intimation from headquarters that an early resignation will save him the humiliation of removal. He has the satisfaction of knowing, however, that the shaft was not aimed at him, solely and personally, but his arch-enemy, Lieut. Col. Moran, with all the other field officers, with the possible exception of Adjt. John Murphy, will have to go with him.

The dinner which President J., Edward Simmons of the Fourth National Bank gave Friday evening at his home, in West Fifty-second Street, in honor of the members of the Clearing House Committee, is likely to take its place among the important meetings of bankers held in this city in the last dozen years.

Did I tell you of the Passion Play at Ammergau? I forget to whom I've written since then. We had a wretched time, and were, in one dense, disappointed with the affair. As a theatrical performance it was remarkable; as a dramatic performance it fell far below the expectations raised by the exaggerated letters published, some by distinguished people.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 11 -- Capt. John Mister of the oyster-dredging sloop Ostrich of Baltimore, a notorious violator of the State dredging laws, was shot and killed to-day by the crew of the State oyster navy steamer Maria, Mister was caught violating the laws this morning, and was fleeing from the officers when shot.

Tartaglia discovered the solution of cubic equations. Cardan employed toward him all the persuasions in his power to obtain a communication to himself of the famous discovery. "I swear to you on the holy Gospels," he promised, "that if you teach me your discoveries I will never publish them, and will, besides, record them for myself in cipher, so that no one shall be able to understand them after my death."

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 11 -- There is no talk of possible racing by Eastern yachtsmen except in the big sloop class, where Commodore Forbes will race the Volunteer and Gen. Paine the Jubilee. No twenty-one-tooters, the popular class two years ago, are in sight, and nothing in the classes between this and the large one. With the Valkyrie, Vigilant, and Colonia with improvements, the big class would be a most interesting one.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11 -- The immense majority which the Republicans have in the General Assembly is already causing grave concern among thoughtful members of the party, and the question is anxiously asked, What in the world will we do with it? With almost four out of five in both houses, the chances are that the "monopoly Legislature" will be outdone in corruption and viciousness.
The Strollers, formerly known as the Columbia College Dramatic Club, will produce Benjamin Armar's "Ivanhoe Up to Date" at the Broadway Theatre on Dec. 18, in. aid of the St. John's Guild.

Car 60 of the Broadway cable line was equipped yesterday with a new life guard, designed by Theophile Euphrat of Darien, Conn. The guard is made of heavy, perforated sheet iron, curved so as to form a pocket large enough to hold the body of a man or woman.

The large audience which witnessed the closing performance of "Sheridan" at the Lyceum Theatre last evening insisted on the appearance of E.H. Sothern before the curtain, and when he had yielded so far to its wishes it demanded a speech. Mr. Sothern made a little address. In which he expressed his pleasure at the favor which the public had shown to himself and Mr. Potter's play.

Rare and new fruits are to be found among the literary leaves of Prof. Hales, as well as elucidations of passages in old texts the meaning of which was long ago forgotten, discoveries in biography, essays in analytic criticism, and clear, synthetic chapters. The author is learned in book lore and sympathetic with life.

At the beginning of the cold season in Europe last year the prediction was made by persons familiar with the history of cholera epidemics that in the warm season of this year the disease would be found in all parts of Europe, and there was a general expectation on the part of sanitary authorities that it would enter this country and considerably increase the death rate in our cities.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's team were ready to play the Young Men's Christian Association's strong eleven yesterday afternoon at Mott Haven, and waited forty minutes for the Young Men's Christian Association athletes to appear. When the team did arrive Capt. McCurdy found that they were two men short, and gave the game to the Metropolitans by default, causing much disappointment among the 300 or more enthusiastic spectators who were present.

It is only natural that the framers of these ideals and their disciples should be among the most energetic and the most sanguine of men. They have made their heaven such as they would wish it to be, and they believe it to be so nearly within reach that it only remains for them to order their ascension robes.

The well-selected adage with which President CLEVELAND closed his appeal to Congress when he called it in extra session to wipe out the mischievous silver-purchase law applies equally to the work of tariff reform which awaits action at the regular session. He gives twice who gives quickly is especially true when the thing given is a change in legislation affecting the business of the country.

Joseph Cary, a negro waiter, forty years old, who lived at 2 Minetta Street, was killed at 10:30 o'clock last night by Edward Kenny, also a negro waiter, who stabbed his victim to the heart with a pocket knife. The two men had worked together in White's restaurant, on Canal Street, but Kenny was a stranger in Minetta Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- The funeral of Francis Parkman took place at noon to-day at King's Chapel. It is not often, that the obsequies of any citizen of Boston is attended by such a large number of men eminent in every walk of life as were present to-day at the last ceremonies over the remains of the historian.

The most distinguished of the belated tourists who yesterday sailed for Europe was Chaunoey M. Depew, who went as a saloon passenger on La Gascogne. Mr. Depew explained that his annual trip abroad had been delayed this year owing to the unusual press of business caused by the World's Fair.

Mr. Piatt is already favorably known to lovers of what may be called domestic verse, through his "Western Windows." and "Poems of House and Home." The titles of these books and of the volume now under consideration, go far toward indecating the field in which Mr. Piatt finds free play for his fancy and his feeling.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The departure of everything spectacular from the down-town theatres is the last and most convincing proof that the World's Fair dramatic season had come to a natural end, and that managers have ceased all efforts to exchange tinseled and showy entertainments for the dollars of rural visitors.
-- William Dannat, a painter from New-York who has made his home in Paris for some years, has been appointed a teacher in the Ecole des Beaux Arts.

Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren has received many invitations to banquets to be given in his honor, but, with one exception, he has declined. The one exception is that tendered by the Brooklyn Young Republican Club. Up to the time Mr. Schieren accepted the reform Republican nomination for Mayor, he was President of the Young Republican Club.

The Knickerbocker Whist Club, one of the few clubs organized for the enjoyment of the silent game alone, has recently secured permanent headquarters in the annex or the Hotel Wellington, at Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street. This club, although one of the youngest of its kind in the country, has been a success from the very day on which barely a dozen whist enthusiasts decided to form it.

Ever since there have been courts-martial particular stress has been placed upon the matter of administering the oath to the witnesses. In order that it may be binding and the loophole of informality may be, as far as possible, reduced, it has been the custom to swear witnesses in the manner considered most binding in their native lands.

I. A Revolution. I shall take away with me from America no recollection so strange as the memory of the poular revolution, at which I assisted, on Tuesday last. It has been my fortune to be a spectator of several insurrections, some of them triumphant, some of them tragical, some of them as droll as the libretto of an opera bouffe.

Orioles and Credendas, two Harlem football teams composed of grammar school pupils, played a close came on, the North Meadow, Central Park, yesterday morning. The Credenda boys came out ahead by 10 to 0. Their players made some tine runs and good tackling. The make up of the teams was:

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 11 -- A football pennant will float over Darthmouth's new athletic field. Amherst was defeated to-day by a score of 34 to 0. The day could not bare been better. Over 2,000 people watched the game, of this number 230 were Amhorst students, who came on a special train, hoping to enthuse their team to victory. Dartmouth's eleven played a perfect game from start to finish.

The visit of the Australian cricketers brought to a close the most successful season ever experienced by the willow wielders of the metropolis. Not alone was there more cricket played and a larger number of people interested in the game, but the standard of skill advanced amazingly, and those who recall the desultory sort of game played in New-York some five years ago must feel naturally surprised at the rapid strides it has made.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Nov. 11 -- Carl Drier and his wife had a costly experience with three masked burglars early on the morning after election. Drier's saloon occupies the corner store in a large double building at Vernon and Nott Avenues, Back of the barroom is a kitchen and dining room.

Excitement among Cuban residents of this city and Brooklyn has again been roused by news from Key West that another revolution had broken out in Cuba, and that at least 500 armed patriots were in the field trying to throw off the Spanish yoke. Their only apprehension is that the outbreak may have been premature, as was the uprising by a handful of men last Spring.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The Colonial Office has received a dispatch from Accra, Gold Coast Colony, dated Nov. 10, saying that the Ashantees who were recently reported to be threatening the British protectorate, declare that they want peace and have no desire for war with the British.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The investigation of the unlawful acts in the Fourth District of the First Ward on election day was continued in police court to-day. Sheriff Beck, Under Sheriff Steele, Superintendent of the Police Chambers, and Capt. Regan had been subpoenaed to appear and testify, but the Sheriff pleaded a previous engagement and his testimony was postponed until Monday.

Capt. Mackey of Pennsylvania won the toss and took tse ball. Yale had the western goal and Pennsylvania the eastern. The wedge was formed and the ball put in play at 2:38 o'clock. Knipe forced the centre for ten yards before he was downed. Simmons gained five yards around Yale's loft end and Knipe went through the centre for three yards more.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- If Admiral Mello has bombarded Rio this week the fact is still unknown at the legation here, where constant communication is had with the Peixoto Government. Senhor Mendonca now disbelieves the report, which at first seemed to have a strong basis of probability.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 11 -- After two days' session the Executive Committee of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association adjourned yesterday, having come to a happy agreement that will prevent the split which seemed for a time unavoidable. The question under discussion has been the apportionment of cotton business.

From The London Globe. To-day Lord Dunraven, with Lady Dunraven and their two daughters and Mr. Kerr, Lady Dunraven's brother, landed at Liverpool from New-York by the Britannic. Questioned regarding his yacht experience in America, his lordship expressed an opinion that he was fairly beaten so far as competition went, but he believed if the races had been more extended the result might have been different.

The following remarkable incident in the life of the late Samuel Wilberforce, Bishop of Oxford and afterward of Winchester, is related as absolutely authentic, and the good Bishop himself is said to have many times rehearsed the story to his friends. Bishop Wilberforce was most prominent among his contemporaries of the English clergy, and was once a leader of the High Church Party.
