CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Strawboard opened the stock list with a sale of 31 1/2, followed by Alley "L," at yesterday's close. Several lots went at 40 for the account, then some cash and regular were traded in at the same figures. Diamond Match appeared with a purchase at 129. The first sale of Lake Street was at 26 1/4, dropping to 26 instantly, at which price 500 shares were taken.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Hugh Saussey, the football player, of the College of the City of New-York, was injured this afternoon in the game here. He died to-night in the City Hospital. County Physician O'Reilley made an investigation and decided that death was accidental.

New-Mexico, the natural Rip Van Winkle country, is the one Mr. Lummis describes. There is little life in this portion of the United States. "The present is a husk -- the past was a romance and a glory." This perception of the land of the Pueblos depends, of course, on the enthusiasm of the individual, and Mr. Lummis writes so glowingly of the silence and sunlight, as if it were an enchanted land.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- There was a rumor about the Navy Department this afternoon that the cruiser New-York would be sent to Brazil as soon as she could be made ready for sea, which means as soon as the necessary changes could be made in her gun circles.

I Have always been considered lucky. It was the double crown of my head, like twin eyes on a potato, that started this belief, and my Aunt Alida soon confirmed it. For it seems that shortly after my christening Paul Atherton, the worthy gentleman for whom I was named, died; whether instigated by this last straw of a compliment I know not, though in seasons of depression I have misgivings.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 11 -- There is just beginning to be a realization of the suffering and destitution to be found in the arid regions of Western Kansas, principally confined to the southwestern counties. There has not been a stalk of corn nor a spear of wheat raised in that section for two years, and yet the settlers cling to their land with all the desperation of homeless people.

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Many who live in this village, and doubtless many, also, who make periodical visits to their erring ones, have paused before the inclosure in the lower part of what used to be Hunter Street, now named Durston Avenue, as a compliment to Warden Durston of Sing Sing Prison for the improvements he has recently made there.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Happy is the theatre, or the manager, if you will, who can discover nowadays an acceptable play. But what of the man, or the theatre, who finds ready to hand a clever comedy, to make public compensation for dramatic failures? Such is the happy situation of the Vaudeville and of MM. Carre and Porel.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Emperor William's desire to make a signal example of the officers involved in the Hanover gambling case appears to have been overruled. In military circles it is maintained that the Emperor cannot directly order the dismissal from the service of the officers concerned, but must act through the regular authorities.

A great deal is heard from time to time about the underpaid clergy. It has been recently said by an English writer that "there are many clerks in holy orders who receive less than clerks in linen drapers' shops." This is especially true in Europe, where the clergy, or at least the curates, are paid such miserably poor stipends that, but for the generosity of the parishioners, they could not live.

-- Charles H. Bell, ex-Governor of New-Hampshire, died yesterday at Exeter, N.H., aged sixty years. He was a son of John and Persis Thorn Bell. His father was once Governor of New-Hampshire, and so was his uncle. Samuel Bell. He was graduated from Dartmouth in 1844, and became a lawyer. He served several terms as representative in the Legislature of his State, and also as Senator.

When Samuel Barton, the well-known Wall Street broker, and now of the firm of J.W. Davis Co., was a poor boy, he studied law in S.L.M. Barlow's office. One day he received a curt summons from his uncle. Commodore Vanderbilt, and, dutiful nephew that he was, he hastened to find out what that brusque but potential old gentleman wanted of him.
The Moors in Spain, the Spaniards in Morocco -- in the phases of this great historic teeter may be included all the epics, idyls, and elegies of Christian and Moslem.
It was too great a success for many of the University of Pennsylvania students who came to this city to see the football eleven of that university contend with Yale's team.

The memorial services in honor of the late Edwin Booth, will be held in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall to-morrow afternoon. The doors will open at 2:45 o'clock, and as no seats will be reserved, holders of tickets will consult their own interests by being on hand promptly. Thirteen hundred cards of invitation have been issued, and all were disposed of a week ago, so that no further applications can be considered.

Negotiations which were conducted between Steinitz and Lasker on the one side and the " Centre Asturiano" at Havana on the other side have led to nothing. The Manhattan Chess Club has also officially declined to do anything for the Stelnitz-Lasker match, and unless something is done by some other party the contest between these experts will fall through.

The Lotos Club gave its first dinner in its new home on Fifth Avenue, near Forty-fifth Street, last evening. Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain) was the guest of honor. The dinner was a notable event, and it brought together a large gathering of well-known men.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Nov. 11 -- P.M. There was a fair amount of business done on the Stock Exchange for a Saturday. The heaviest trading was in Chicago Gas, New-England, and General Electric. Sugar was less active than usual, but it closed at 98 1/8, its lowest price of the day, and a net loss of 1 5/8 points.

"A woman standing near me," comments a fair visitor, "in the little wooden building which held the Government exhibit of the industrial school for Indian boys and girls at Genoa, Neb., voiced my thought when she spoke out excitedly to her husband: 'Your own children, Hiram, couldn't do better work than these little redskins have done.'

As the sun went down last night behind the high cliff at Manhattan Field, twenty-two muscular young men, representing the football teams of Yale and the University of Pennsylvania were struggling for supremacy. While the electric lights on the elevated road and the street lamps on the viaduct and street above were flickering, the referee called game, and a mighty shout went up from the followers of the New-Haven university.

MERIDEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- The Meriden Woolen Mill Company, after a two months shut-down, will start up on Monday next with the full number of hands. Two hundred men and, women will then be given work. The wages of the hands have been out down 10 per cent, and those of the foremen 25 per cent.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Wildcats are remarkable plentiful in Connecticut this Fall -- big, ferocious, tawny-colored beasts. A number of them nave been scouring the thick woods about Essex Village on the river bank, twelve miles south of Middletown, for a week.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Wildcats are remarkable plentiful in Connecticut this Fall -- big, ferocious, tawny-colored beasts. A number of them nave been scouring the thick woods about Essex Village on the river bank, twelve miles south of Middletown, for a week.

IV. While there is doubtless a recognized standard of normal perception, yet the acuteness with which sensations are perceived by different individuals, even in ordinary health, passes through a wide scale of variation, both above and below this standard.

The consumption of fish in New-York is not as general as its variety, cheapness, and excellence should warrant. Situated almost directly upon the ocean, with abundant fisheries at its very gateway, and with ample wharfage facilities for landing and marketing the catch, fish should certainly be as general an article of food here as it is in London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- There is to be another arctic expedition. This one will have a practical side, if these penetrations into the frozen seas of the polar region ever surrender the hazardous, in favor of a utilitarian feature. There will be no attempt in this latest expedition to reach the north pole.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1@2 per cent.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 12 -- The Mascotte did not reach here till 10 o'clock last night. The latest advices from Cuba are that a few patriots, headed by Gen. Esquiverra, who was banished but returned from Porto Plata, in Santo Domingo, and was sentenced to death by the Spanish authorities, but through the efforts of influential citizens of Cuba was reprieved, are the parties who have created all the recent disturbances on the island.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Altgeld and Anarchy were named together at the grave of Spies, Parsons, Lingg, Engle, and Fischer, in Waldhelm Cemetery, to-day. A peculiar interest was given to the memorial demonstration by the participation of Michael Schwab, Samuel Fielden, and Oscar Neebe, who were sentenced with their dead comrades -- the first two to be hanged, and Neebe to fifteen years' imprisonment.

BUFFALO, Nov. 12 -- Lieut. Gov. Sheehan takes his defeat very much to heart. Not only has he secluded himself from everybody save on one occasion, but he has also gone so far as to insult one of his oldest friends.

The Sunday evening concert season has set in with its usual severity. All the enthusiasm which has been bottled up all Summer has now an opportunity to give itself free reign, and success is the order of the day. In the bright lexicon of the Sunday evening concertgoer there is no such word as "fail."

The reason for this book's existence rests upon the details which the author is able to give concerning the life of the early Norsemen. The story of Ivar is made the vehicle for a great deal of information about the habits and customs of the Vikings, their ceremonies connected with birth and baptism, or "name-fastening," with warfare, marriage, death, and burial.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 -- The Independance Belge says it has perfectly trustworthy advices to the effect that President Peixoto has formed a plan to break the insurgent power completely at the end of this month. The vessels which he has bought abroad are to be concentrated at Rio Janeiro in such a manner as to block Admiral Mello's fleet in the bay, and, with the aid of the forts, force the insurgents to surrender.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Judging by the crowds which surround the bulletin boards in this city at the time of the recent election, there were a good many voters who did not go to their homes in distant States to cast their ballots in the late election. From the cheers which greeted the numerous announcements of Republican success, the suspicion was raised that there are still a good many Republican office holders in this town.

The meeting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to-night, at which arrangements will be perfected to appoint a committee of lawyers, with power to commence the prosecution of cases against violators of the election laws not only in this city, but in Gravesend, promises to be a big affair. James McMahon, President of the Emigrant Savings Bank of this city, will preside.

The Cassell Publishing Company announces that it "will celebrate its reorganization by moving into new quarters in Union Square, where, amid other surroundings, it will try to forget the misfortunes that overthrew the former company." Among the earliest issues of the house will be the "Life and Later Speeches of Chauncey M. Depew," and a new novel by Sarah Grand, the author of "The Heavenly Twins."

To a congregation that filled the Academy of Music, the Rev. Cortland Myers, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Brooklyn, preached yesterday morning a ten-minute prelude to his sermon on the downfall of the ring.

Robert Saussy, whose son Hugh, a member of the football team of the College of the City of New-York, was accidentally killed on Saturday by a fall during- the football game between his team and that of the Elizabeth Athletic Club, at Elizabeth, N.J., was prostrated yesterday. The other son, Gordon, was also overcome by the terrible shock.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 12 -- With the first of the trio of great games disposed of, Yale turns her mind toward the future. Harvard and Princeton remain to be conquered, and the work of yesterday is valuable only as experience and practice. Two weeks' intermission now elapses before the next game, and before then the physical condition of the eleven must be much changed for the better.

According to a report made yesterday by Capt. McAlpine of the bark Clan Ferguson, which arrived at this port, ninety-nine days out from Auckland, a steamship, whose name could not be distinguished, has been disabled by the gale of Friday. The vessel was sighted by the officers of the bark during the height of the storm.

We have watched with much interest and some amusement the behavior of the extreme Republican and semi-Republican papers and ex-officials under the shook of the announcement of the intention of the Administration to undo the wrong done to the Government of Hawaii by the Governnent of the United States.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 12 -- In a signed article in The Kennebec Journal, to be printed to-morrow. John L. Stevens, late United States Minister at Hawaii, will make the following reply to Secretary Gresham's report:

The New-York Mothers' Home, the new institution of the Roman Catholic Sisterhood of Misericorde, at 531 East Eighty-sixth Street, was blessed by Archbishop Corrigan yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. The Archbishop was assisted in the ceremonies by Father Charpentier of Montreal and many priests of the diocese were present.

The great facility with which an entirely respectable citizen can get himself locked up has had another illustration in the case of young Mr. Snead, who was imprisoned on Wednesday on the rather comprehensive charge of "suspicious character," and who only regained his liberty on Saturday.

The Anarchists of this city yesterday commemorated the seventh anniversary of the execution of the Chicago Anarchists at a mass meeting at the Thalia Theatre, in the Bowery. In former years the Anarchists here observed the day by processions, with red and black flags, and with transparencies bearing threatening inscriptions, such as "If you hang us we shall dynamite you."

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Through the alertness of Jailer John McDougall a well-laid plot to escape from the Queens County Jail, in this city, failed this morning. Instead of three prisoners being at liberty, Edward J. Orpheus, a Special Deputy Sheriff, occupies a cell, accused of aiding and abetting in the escape of criminals.

The Lewis Avenue Congregational Church, Lewis Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, was filled last evening with an audience curious to see the Rev. Dr. Robert J. Kent. Dr. Kent was one of the watchers who accompanied Col. Alexander S. Bacon to Gravesend on election day to see that the election there was conducted lawfully. With the others he was set upon by McKane's henchmen and severely beaten.

As the work of fitting out the two new Brazilian cruisers El Cid and Britannia approaches completion, the curiosity of the public to see these two ships increases. The crowds were so great on the docks of the Morgan Iron Works yesterday that it was necessary to call in the aid of the police.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 12 -- The struggle for the Senatorship made vacant by the death of Senator Barbour, now temporarily filled by Gen. Eppa Hunton under appointment from the Governor, has fairly begun. The Legislature just elected will name a man to serve for a short term which will end March 4, 1895, and also a man for the new term, which will begin on that day and run for six years.

For four nights, ending Saturday at midnight, secret sessions of a committee of ten appointed by the National Educational Society have been held in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, to investigate secondary education in the United States, and to report as to its reorganization and improvement. This is the second and final meeting.
William Dudley Foulke of Richmond, Ind., addressed the Society for Ethical Culture in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning. His subject was "The Debasement of the Suffrage."

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Minister Lorrin A. Thurston of Hawaii, who has been detained in Chicago closing up the affairs of the Hawaiian exhibit, was seen last night while preparing for his trip to Washington, where he will look after the interests of the provisional Government. When asked to express an opinion concerning the action of the Administration in relation to Hawaii, he said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Three hundred men and women were momentarily panic-stricken this evening in the Belden Avenue Baptist Church when they discovered the structure was on fire, but presence of mind on the part of the pastor, the Rev. H.H. Barbour, soon restored order and the entire congregation escaped to the street In safety.

The British steamship Melbourne, which has been chartered by the Lamport and Holt Line, arrived yesterday from Brazilian ports. The Melbourne carries in her hold the largest consignment of coffee ever brought by a vessel to this port. The 57,490 bags which are stowed on board are valued at $1,400,000.

MADRID, Nov. 12 -- The Anarchists held a meeting in Barcelona to-day to celebrate the outrage in the theatre. The police did not hear of the meeting until it was nearly over, and arrived at the hall too late to make any arrests.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Henry Savage of this place had a narrow escape this morning for his life. He was suddenly awakened by feeling somebody touch his face. The next instant he received a deep gash across the throat, and it subsequently appeared that the gash was made with a razor.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 12 -- The Organization of Richmond County Democrats has been at work quietly, but vigorously, since election day to obtain evidence that the majority returned for the Muller "machine" candidates was obtained by fraud. The reform leaders say they have evidence which cannot be ignored that should secure the throwing out of several districts and elect the fusion ticket, except, possibly, the candidate for Judge.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Although the reopening of the Reichstag is but a few days off, political parties remain virtually dormant. No partisan movement of general interest has been made for several weeks. The leaders of the Opposition groups, instead of attempting a coalition against Chancellor von Caprivi, seem to have made their plans independently.
CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 12 -- There is excitement in the City of Juarez and the military and civil authorities are busily engaged in arming citizens with all the weapons obtainable.
The Rev. J.R. Taber, pastor of the Church of the Good Tidings, Quincy Street, near Stuyvesant Avenue, took for his subject at the service last evening, "The Lessons of the Recent Campaign."

It is a striking testimonial to the importance attached by Congress to popular military education that among the very few laws enacted at its recent session was one which increases to 100 the number of army officers that may be detailed as instructors of tactics in schools and colleges.

J.E.T. Bowden and Henry Mason, two wellknown business men in Jacksonville, Fla., reached this city early yesterday morning from the South. They are authorized by the club they represent to treat with the managers for Corbett and Mitchell to have the meeting between the American and English pugilists take placa in Florida, and as a guarantee have brought certified checks amounting to $15,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The fifty-mile relay road race of the two teams of the Newark Wheelmen, captained by George Coffin and E.L. Blauvelt respectively, was held yesterday afternoon and resulted in victory for the former team.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 11 -- The market for local securities has been extremely dull during the past week, with no changes in prices worthy of note. While the bids for stocks show little or no increase in demand, the amount of stocks offered for sale is exceedingly small.

"The New-York Times is a mortal foe to the man who violates a public trust. It threw the full weight of its mighty influence first against the proposed international prize fight, leading all the forces which were arrayed against it. And with what success we all know. And then mercilessly it struck the corrupt ring that has ruled this city blow after blow, with the force of a mighty triphammer.

There is no more important question for the people of this city than reform in municipal administration; but it is a matter of serious doubt whether a mere anti-Tammany movement would be in the interest of that reform, or whether the overthrow of the present Tammany control would of itself accomplish it.

Mr. Dana's office cat was just beginning to get excited on Saturday over the news from Brazil when a letter was received in the editorial mail which caused the vigilant creature to expand its tail to the full limit and bulge its eyes with the apprehension that a gory time had come indeed.
Chauncey B. Ripley, an old and wellknown lawyer, was found dead in bed in a room in the Hoffman House yesterday. He had expired during Saturday night from cerebral apoplexy.
The Rev. Dr. Charles Giffin of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, preached last night on "After the Election." He said:

QUINCY, Mass., Nov. 12 -- The police have in custody a man who was found late Saturday night wandering about the streets. The fellow says his name is Stevens and that he is from Reading, Penn. He refuses to tell anything about his family, but among his effects is a greasy paper bag, upon which is written a number of sentences, each having a large square marked at the end.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- During the last week the 'Varsity practice has been decidedly "scrubby." This is due partially to the fact that Capt. Trenchard is allowing the 'Varsity team to rest. But the team is certainly in a dilapidated condition, and, unless some vast improvement is made at once, the game scheduled with West Point may result disastrously in the way of score.

Some of our exuberant contemporaries are "off their base" in crediting the tariff with the result of Tuesday's election in New-York. The tariff was not on issue in the Empire State, but the Judiciary was, and the people of New-York, free traders and protectionists alike, had sufficient discrimination to save the bench from the disgrace which the election of so notoriously unfit a candidate as Maynard would bring upon it.

Robert Calder, eighty-two years old, of 62 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, was swindled out of $2,000 by two bunko men Friday. Mr. Calder is in his dotage. He was employed for fifty-five years in the office of the Union Ferry Company, but retired, seven years ago. He has since passed most of his time at home.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Preachers and saloon keepers, gamblers and theological professors, women of doubtful reputation and members of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, Anarchists and persons noted for their conservative views sat side by side today on the platform at Central Music Hall. The occasion was the meetings, afternoon and evening, held by W.T. Stead, the London journalist.

Tenements and flat property are the feature of the auction sales of real estate in this city to-day, all of which are in legal proceedings. They will be held at 111 Broad-way. The detailed list is subjoined:

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The first bust of Archbishop Satolli, the Papal Ablegate, erected in the United States was unveiled this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Grace, in Hoboken. The bust is of Carrara marble. It was made by Prof. Luzi of Rome, and is a perfect likeness of the Ablegate.

GREIGSVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- An Italian laborer named Pasqual E. Purchio, about thirty years of age, who was employed by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was killed here Saturday night. He lived alone in a shanty along the track. His body was found just outside his shanty this morning with his head nearly severed from his body.

The bank statement of Saturday continued to reflect the influences at work since the Senate's delay in repealing the Sherman act made it plain that the Fall trade would be killed and that no real revival could come before the opening of Winter. The surplus reserve is now $57,828,725.

The fourth and fifth sets of games in the preliminary tournament of the New-York section of the American Amateur Bowling League were played on the Occidental Alleys, One Hundred and Thirteenth Street and Eighth Avenue, on Friday and Saturday nights.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Rates of discount seesawed throughout last week, but on Saturday showed a hardening tendency, closing at 2 1/2 for ninety days, and 1 for thirty days. Gold was in strong demand for the Netherlands and Germany. The demand for silver for the East ceased, and prices weakened so as to cause a relapse on the Stock Exchange.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 12 -- The New-York Commission appointed by Gov. Flower to find the sites occupied by the New-York State troops in the battles around Chattanooga in the Fall of 1863 spent all of to-day in company with representatives from the twenty-one New-York State organizations on the field.

Bugler Hayes, gorgeously arrayed, will sound a fanfare on his bugle at 9 o'clock this morning, one of Superintendent Frank Clarke's overgrown jockeys will swing aside the gates at the Fourth Avenue entrance to the tan-bark ring in the Madison Square Garden to admit of the entrance of a lot of horses to the inclosure, and so the Horse Show of 1893 will be inaugurated.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- The Governor has refused to grant a respite to John Johnson, the murderer, and he will die early this weak. Determined to avoid a repetition of the Tavlor horror. State Electrician Davis this evening made a thorough test of the prison dynamo. The test was made with a full-grown calf for a subject.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Allow me to thank you heartily, as one of your many constant readers, for your editorial in Saturday's issue on Secretary Gresham's precis on the Hawaiian question. It was able, patriotic, convincing, being in marked contrast to the comments of an evening paper of the same date, that attributed the proposed action of the Government to personal ill-feeling entertained by the President toward ex-President Harrison.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Local securities are showing more life and a slight advance in prices has been made, due to a fair demand and light offerings.
The new Brazilian cruiser El Cid will probably be ready to sail from New-York on Friday. The work of fitting out the big ship is now practically completed, and the stores are all on board.

That unique organization, the Thirteen Club, banded together to bid defiance to all superstitions, whether of unlucky numbers, unlucky people, or unlucky places, held high, revelry last night in the Columbia Restaurant, on Fourteenth Street. The club, anxious to remove superstition from the feminine part of its household, gave a ladies reception, the third annual affair of its kind.

In pursuance of an understanding between United States Attorney General Olney and counsel representing the management of the Union Pacific Railroad, Frederic R. Coudert of this city and J.W. Doane of Chicago were yesterday appointed additional receivers of that railroad company by Judge Dundy of the United States District Court in Omaha.

William M. Deverall -- Notice was given on the Produce Exchange yesterday of the death in the morning of William M. Deverall, who did business at 56 New Street, and who was a leader in the grain trade. He was born in England about forty years ago. Coming to this city, he became a clerk for W.H. Power Co. A few years later he was made English agent for G. K. Clark.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As I infer from to-day's essay of Raymond de I'Epee that he is likely soon to return to Paris, I feel it my duty and pleasure as a Brooklynite formally to thank him for his superb articles given in The Times -- true as to statements: as to sentiment, the highest; as to unique and magnificent portrayal, wonderful.

Ground will be broken to-day for the new home of the St. Nicholas Club, and next May will see this exclusive organization firmly established in a house which will bear comparison with the home of any other social club of prominence in this city.

STAPLETON, S.I., Nov. 13 -- Ex-Assemblyman Michael S. Tynan, a well-to-do shoe merchant of this place, committed suicide this morning at his home on Harison Street. When the family retired last night Mr. Tynan was left in his room reading, and apparently well and cheerful. When one of his sons awoke this morning the house was filled with gas.

Civil Justice-elect George F. Roesch was the guest of honor yesterday in his friend Justice Goldfogle's Fifth District court and sat beside him on the bench. The room was decorated with, chrysanthemums. Mr. Roesch is to preside after Jan. 1 in the Fourth District Court. The first person to appear bofore Judge Goldfogle was Mr. Roesch's late opponent in the Fourth District, Mr. Nathan.
There was no lack of interest in Custom House doings yesterday. All over the establishment the officers had something new to talk about.

The Yarrow torpedo boat, ordered by Flint Co. for service in the new Brazilian fleet, arrived at this port yesterday on the big freight steamer Mohawk. The new boat weighs in all about twenty tons. It is technically known as a third-class Yarrow boat. By third class is meant the rating the boat is entitled to by virtue of its size.

A peculiar suit, in which the name of the late Levi M. Bates figured, was on trial yesterday before Judge Newburger of the City Court. The plaintiff was Samuel H. Millard, an insurance agent of 140 Broadway, and the defendant was Mrs. Frances G. Brigham of 322 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.

The appointment of two additional receivers for the Union Pacific Railroad Company in the interest of the Federal Government is a step of more than ordinary interest and importance. For the first time in its history that great transcontinental system is practically in the hands of the Government.

The Brooklyn tax rate for 1893, which the ring politicians sought to conceal until after election, but which Mayor Boody was forced to announce as about $28.40 per $1,000, was officially made public yesterday. Thomas F. Farrell, Clerk to the Board of Supervisors, fixes it at $28.4703, as against $27.7209 last year.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Times has this dispatch from Rio de Janeiro, under the date of Nov. 10:
Simple but impressive services in memory of Edwin Booth were held, under the auspices of The Players, in the concert hall of the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The question of veracity between the Administration on one side and Mr. STEVENS, late United States Minister at Honolulu, and Mr. THURSTON, representing the "provisional Government" of Hawaii on the other, with reference to the setting up of that so-called Government, is hardly worth considering, and Mr. STEVENS'S spiteful flings at Secretary GRESHAM'S motives are beneath contempt.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Francis Gerhard, a convict in the State prison at Wethersfield under an eight years' sentence for burglary, who died Saturday, was buried this afternoon, with Grand Army honors. The ceremonies were conducted by Chaplain Atwood, an officer of John M. Morris Post of Wethersfield.
The Upington-Keenan suit was ended yesterday, so far as the taking of testimony goes, without developing any of the sensational evidence regarding police hush-money which had been expected.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The crew of the whaler Aurora, which has just arrived at Dundee, report that they discovered in Baffin's Bay the wreck of the schooner Ripple. This is the vessel in which two Swedish men of science, Bjorlfg and Kalvennius, left St. John's, Newfoundland, in June, 1892. Their purpose was to collect specimens of the flora and fauna of Greenland along Davis's Strait.

A man lies on his back, with his feet in the air. Across the soles of his feet is laid a heavy pole, 15 feet long. Suspended in slings at the ends of the pole are a boy and a girl. The pole is made rapidly to revolve horizontally, with an upward and downward sweep, and the boy and girl wave flags as they whirl through the air.

SOUTHAMPTON, Nov. 13 -- Frank Floyd and Philip Seheig, who, with Louis Floyd, robbed the Bank of Minneapolis of $90.000, arrived here on the steamship Saale this evening. Detectives went out on the tender to meet them. Floyd and Soheig boarded the tender, and were at once placed under arrest. They fought the detectives desperately.

Assemblyman-elect Judson Lawson of the Twenty-third Assembly District, who was the candidate of the Republicans and the Good Government Club, is a wealthy man and is anxious to tear off the Tammany tiger's scalp, or at least, to slit its ears. Being a builder, he naturally attacks the Building Department, which, he thinks, is a blackmailing agency.

In the absence of anything better to speculate about, the public men of New-Jersey have begun to speculate about the standpoint from which the political and legislative events of the State, during the last twenty-five years, are to be treated in a volume of State history, covering that period, which William. E. Sackett of East Orange is preparing for publication.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 13 -- P.M. The stock market was feverish at the opening. Sugar and Chicago Gas were freely offered, and Burlington was also sold down. Sugar was hammered all day, and in the final hour was particularly weak.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Contango Day disclosed no bear account in Americans, but English rails and foreigners were scarce, and heavy backwardations were paid on Brighton.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Ben Hyams, a well-known London bookmaker, who had been, attending the Liverpool Autumn race meeting was drugged at a leading Liverpool hotel on Saturday, and while unconscious was robbed of L2,000. An investigation into the case has disclosed a long series of similar robberies of sportsmen at the Scarborough, Manchester, and Doncaster race meetings.

Herbert S. Worthley, one of the party that went to Gravesend Sunday, Nov. 5, with Col. Alexander S. Bacon, to serve injunction papers upon John Y. McKane and his minions, began suit yesterday against McKane for $5,000 damages, for assault and battery. Mr. Worthley was the most terribly injured man in the party.

The attendance at the Real Estate Salesroom in the Trinity Building yesterday was fairly numerous, but not many were inclined to bid on the offerings, which were all in legal proceedings. All the property put up was of the tenement and flat description, and the knock-downs were at comparatively low figures.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- A dispatch to The Temps from Madrid says that the Chief of the Military Police at Melilla has been shot, after a drumhead court-martial, which found him guilty of complicity in smuggling arms and ammunition for the use of the Riffians.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- The Clearing House rate fluctuated between 1 and 2 per cent., nearly all of the renewals being made at 2 and most of the new loans at 1 1/2, little being done at 1 per cent. Time and call money remained in good supply and exchanged in rate.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Three thousand miners in the Leigh, district of Lancashire resumed work this morning at the rate of wages paid before the great strike commenced.

The war between the Brooklyn Citizens' Association and the proprietors of the piggeries and bone-boiling establishments on the city line, which has been waging for ten years, was ended yesterday. Justice Bartlett decreed that the piggeries must go.

George Fraleigh and Edward Farris of 79 Waverly Avenue, Boroklyn, the boys who ran away from home last week with $400 worth, of Mrs. Fraleigh's diamonds, were found yesterday in Kingston, N.Y. They will be returned to Brooklyn under police escort. Benjamin Wilson, another Brooklyn boy, who ran away from his home, 58 Georgia Avenue, two weeks ago, was arrested yesterday at Ralph Avenue and Broadway by Patrolman Bohun.

The story of Mr. HARRY V. SNEAD, told in yesterday's TIMES, demands a thorough investigation, the more that in essentials it is so like many other stories that are told in New-York. Mr. SNEAD'S story is that, being in immediate need of money, he had taken some of his own silver to a pawnshop, and that on coming out of it he was arrested by two men who represented themselves to be detectives.

The Presbytery of New-York met yesterday afternoon for the first time in the lecture room of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Twenty-second Street, and in a protracted session thrashed over considerable old straw, incidentally barking a good many shins in both parties with the flails of debate.

From The Philadelphia Public Ledger, Nov. 13. Reference has been made already in this correspondence to the leading part taken by The New-York Times in the movement to smash the Brooklyn "ring," but the work of The Times was so great and has been crowned with such magnificent success that it deserves a particular mention.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- West Chicago opened at 155 1/2 this morning, and the demand from the usual quarter, together with some miscellaneous buying, raised the first call close to 157. In the afternoon the insiders were not so much in evidence, and the stock closed at 156 1/2. Lake Street Elevated was again a study.

Society began its annual outing last evening. The horse show was the cause for it. That society enjoyed it was shown by the fact that it was out in force. That the public enjoyed it fully as much, was shown by the ceaseless promenading, the sometimes rather rude inspection of the occupants of the boxes, and the general hilarity that prevailed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- There was apparent to-day a great deal of surprise among those who had been looking for news of profound disturbance in Honolulu following the arrival of Minister Willis, when the dispatches from Hawaii brought the information that the United States Minister had been three days at Honolulu and that nothing had occurred to disturb the peaceful conditions that had existed there for months.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 -- There is a decided revival in this city of the project to build a ship canal across the Maryland and Delaware peninsula to the Atlantic Ocean. In the last week the newspapers have vigorously championed, the enterprise, and declared that, unless it is done, Baltimore's foreign trade, which is next to that of New-York in importance, will be jeopardized.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Lehigh Valley was dull, the first time for many days. It has been pretty well bulled through the newspapers, and with the short interest covered up and a fair amount of long stock in the room the price hangs. Pennsylvania was slightly weaker and was sold by London.

MONSON, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Central Block, the main business block of this town, was burned early this morning. The building was about 60 by 60, three stories, and was occupied on the ground floor by J. Simmons, clothier; G.L. Keeney, drugrgist; the Post Office, and Norcross Brothers, grocers. On the second floor were Matthew Connelly, tailor; Father Matthew Total Abstinence Society, Windsor Social Club, and a tenement, occupied by J.S, O'Brien.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- A new occupation has opened for members of the Columbian Guard. They are now being enrolled at Jackson Park to so to Honduras to act as soldiers. Dr. Thackery, Division Superintendent in the Department of Manufactures, appears to be the promoter of the plan, and through his influence, it is said, the guards have been enrolled.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Gov. Flower received to-day the following letter from District Attorney Ridgway of Brooklyn:

The provisional estimates for 1894 arranged by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment were considered by the Board of Aldermen sitting in special session as a Committee of the Whole yesterday. The formal approval of the Board of Aldermen is necessary under the law, although, as a rule, the changes made are not allowed afterward when the Board of Estimate makes up the final budget.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 13 -- The United States cruiser Columbia, which left Cramps' shipyards, Philadelphia, Saturday morning to make her official trial trip off the Massachusetts coast, dropped anchor in the harbor off Quarantine early this morning. Her run at sea was the quickest ever made by a war vessel of this country.

She red-shirted legions of the Salvation Army are pouring into town in preparation for the great Columbian Congress of the Salvation Army, which, beginning to-day, lasts until Saturday. It is expected that fully a thousand field staff, field officers, and local officers will take part as delegates in the congress, which will be under the direction of Commander and Mrs. Ballington Booth.

Mr. Tony Pastor's temple of dramatic art, abiding place long ago chosen by I. Merriment, was crowded with people last night -- the people who are always there, and who apparently seek amusement nowhere else. In several particulars they are unlike other audiences. At Mr. Abbey's temple of dramatic art, for instance, every woman, just now, wears a hat constructed on the wing-and-wing, schooner-sailing-dead-before-the-wind principle.
The big wholesale grocery house of the Thurber-Whyland Company is to be reorganized.

The trotting horsemen are very much interested in the consignment of trotters that will pass under the hammer of Peter Kellogg Co., at the American Institute Building, on the afternoons and evenings of Nov. 20, 21, 22, and 23, comprising the entire stock of the famous Fashion Stud Farm and consignments from David S. Hammond, proprietor of the Plaza Hotel, and John H. Shults.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- It has been learned that Mrs. J. Roosevelt Roosevelt, (nee Astor) wife of the Secretary of the American Embassy, who died yesterday, had suffered greatly for many weeks. Her condition, however, was not such as to forbid hope of her recovery until Friday last, when she began to lose strength rapidly, and it was seen that the end of her sufferings was approaching.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Signs that the opening of the social season is close at hand continue to multiply. Houses that have been closed for months are now being prepared for the gayeties which mark the Winter in Washington. A good deal is heard about the preparations making by some of the Cabinet officers for entertaining this Winter.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Controller of the Currency Eckels spoke this afternoon at a meeting of the Boston Bankers' Association. He devoted the major part of his address to a discussion of the great service rendered the country by the banks in the time of the recent money panic.

Miss Frances E. Willard, President of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, will not be able, by reason of ill health, to return to this country from England to attend its anniversary meeting in Chicago, but she has had her annual report printed and, has sent it to some of the members. The Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale read extracts from it at a meeting in Boston the other day.

ODESSA, Nov. 13 -- A gang of workingmen yesterday found a shell, supposed, to have been fired in the Crimean war, embedded in the earth at Dobraja Nadeshda, near Taganrog, on the Sea of Azof. One of them struck it with a hammer so as to break it open and see what was inside. The shell exploded, killing nine men and wounding several others severely.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- The steamer China, which left Honolulu Nov. 7, arrived in port this morning. She made the trip in five days fourteen hours and twenty minutes, which is the fastest time ever made between Honolulu and San Francisco. Among her passengers was Admiral Skerrett, who has been relieved at Honolulu by Rear Admiral Irwin.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The European backers of the Brazilian insurgents are pouring out gold by the millions, in the hope that Admiral Mello may overthrow the republic. Recent reports that the Brazilian Government has been strengthening its fleet by the purchase of vessels in Germany have aroused the monarchists to greater exertions than ever.
Wheat declined 3/8 @3/4 c, on easier cables, increased stocks and visible, and large receipts, but rallied 1/2 c with the West, and closed steady.

LINCOLN, Ill., Nov. 13 -- Train No. 3 on the Peoria, Decatur and Evansville Railroad, which leaves Peoria at 6:30 P.M., consisting of five cars, was stopped by robbers at 9 o'clock to-night, six miles east of here, on Salt Lake Bridge. The train was in charge of Conductor Richmond and George Trott, brakeman, and left here at 8:45 P.M.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Gov. Flower has sent this letter, dated at the Executive Chamber, to the Hon. William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 14 -- The case against Thomas McGreevy, who represented Quebec in the Federal Parliament from the beginning of the confederation until he was expelled in 1891, and against N.K. Connolly, Government contractor, went before a jury for trial here to-day, after traversing the courts since the Summer of 1891.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The supporters of Sheehan are casting about for a chance to get under the flag of the home rule Democracy. Since the election Mr. Sheehan himself has been seen but very little. He has not frequented his usual places of resort, and has spent most of his time in his law office and at his hotel.

A well-known firm of real estate brokers and agents flown town tells a story in which a sneak thief figures, which may serve to put others on their guard against a new form of theft. The three-story brick building 218 East Twenty-first Street was the scene of the occurrence. It is a tenement house, with one family on each floor.

John Keenan will have to pay George P. Upington $8,600, unless a higher court reverses the verdict rendered yesterday by the jury in the famous suit against the "Bismarck of the County Democracy." The verdict was reached after the jury had wrestled with the problem for four hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- There was active and persistent inquiry to-day for the synopsis of the report of Mr. Blount on Hawalian affairs, as its publication was expected, and it had been announced that it would be produced if it could be made ready. The report is very long and minute, and, although work had been prosecuted upon its preparation for the press, it was found that it could not be completed to-day.

Patrick J. Conley, Superintendent of the Woonsocket Rubber Company of Woonsocket, R.I., while crossing Broadway at Thirtieth Street last evening, was knocked down by a cable car on the tip-town track and was crushed to death. He was on his way to Palmer's Theatre. He had arrived from Woonsocket at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and registered at the Plaza Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Reading was actively dealt in by the room traders, and sold at 11 1/2 on liberal purchases. The bonds are neglected, and there appears to be but little interest in the stock taken by the outside public. Later in the day it declined to 11 1/8, in sympathy with the New-York market.

Since Mr. CARNEGIE made known his purpose to withdraw from the combination of steel-rail manufacturers and began to sell rails at a reduction of 24 per cent, from the combination's price, some of his old high-tariff friends and certain organs of McKinleyism have boon throwing bricks at him.

An eager crowd or curiosity seekers seram bled for seats yesterday in Part III, of the City Court, where Judge Newburger is sitting. They had come in the hope of hearing some sensational testimony in the suit or Samuel H. Millard against Mrs. Frances G. Brigham to recover $1,800 commission on a twenty-thousand-dollar accident policy on the life of the late Levl M. Bates issued to Mrs. Brigham.

It was a strangely picturesque crowd that attended the opening session of the Columbian Congress of the Salvation Army at Carnegie Hall last night. Five thousand officers, delegates, and common soldiers were there -- an army with banners, with timbrels, with badges, swaying the place with the pomp and ceremony of their war, which to them was glorious, and to outsiders who saw them, entertaining, and at times touching.

The Thurber-Whyland Company has gone into the hands of receivers, the step being one in the plans for reorganization of the wholesale grocery firm, an account of which was published in The New-York Times yesterday. In carrying out the plan of reorganization, Francis B. Thurber, President of the corporation, made a personal assignment, as inderser of the company's paper, to Boudinot Keith of the law firm of Leavitt, Wood Keith of Ill Broadway.

Charles Emory Smith, editor of The Philadelphia Frees, and recently United States Minister to Russia talked to the members of the Quill Club at Its meeting at Clark's, in Twenty-third Street, last evening, about "The American Abroad." He said that America rather than the individual made the impress upon the foreigners.

The elevens of Berkeley and Harvard schools played football yesterday afternoon at the Berkeley Oval for the interscholastic championship. The members of the two team indulged more in wrangling, however, than playing. At every decision of the umpire the boys would argue and the umpire would argue with them. In the first half Martin for Berkeley made a touch-down, but failed to kick a goal.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 14 -- The report that several members of the Young Men's Christian Association were burned in last night's fire seems to be without foundation, except as to Thomas H. Bond, who cannot be found. It is thought that he perished in the flames.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Nov. 14 -- P.M. The stock market opened firm, and for a time prices advanced on short covering. But before noon the bears began putting out new lines of short contracts, and after that the course of the market was downward until the close of business.

The largest number of certificates of election expenses filed in one day so far since the election came into the County Clerk's office yesterday. In every case where the expenses of the Democratic candidates ran up to $100 or more the bulk of the money was paid to the Tammany Hall organization. The list ran as follows: Joseph H. Stiner, Justice, Eighth District.

Here is a good sample of the feeling that exists in some of the Republican local organizations. The enrolled Republicans of the Second Assembly District met last night at Cosmopolitan Hall, Catharine Street and East Broadway, with Leader Denis Shea in the chair, President Philip V.R. Van Wyok being absent. There has been much talk about treachery and bribery in the district, and a large crowd was present at the meeting.

A letter from a private citizen of Hawaii recently received in this city gives interesting facts relative to the overthrow of Queen Liliuokalani's Government and the conduct of the provisional rulers of the islands. The letter was received by Mr. Caldwell, a well-known business man of this city. It is as follows:

The aspirations of "Ted " Ackeman to be a Tammany leader in the Eighth Assembly District have so far, from all accounts, been attended with discouragement. Ackerman has a saloon at Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street. It suited him formerly to be a Republican, but his interests lying in the other direction lately, he devoted himself to carrying three election districts on election day for his new alliance.

Sheriff-elect William J. Buttling presided over last night's meeting of the Republican General Committee of Kings County, held in the Athenaeum, Brooklyn. Mr. Buttling had apparently not recovered from the joyful surprise of the election. His face wore a broad smile, and the more he looked at the delegates the broader his smile grew, until finally he seemed hardly able to keep from laying down his gavel and laughing outright.

It is painful to have to report that Walter Damrosch at present inhabits, figuratively speaking, a sort of Jericho round which are grouped all the musicians of New-York, preparing to shake it to its demolition, not only with the blowing of rams' horns, but with sackbuts, with dulcimers, and with shawms also.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- The showing made by Yale with Pennsylvania on Saturday has given the Harvard men wonderful encouragement, and, unless some bad accident happens to cripple the strong crimson line. Yale will have to improve greatly to win at Hampden Park. Harvard will be able to thwart Yale's offensive work, provided the present improvement in team work at Cambridge is carried on during the next two weeks.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The marriage of Miss Eleanor Crane Ivison, daughter of D.B. Ivison, the New-York publisher, to William Wallis Hill took place this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. As Mr. and Mrs. Ivison are among the most prominent residents of Rutherford and have one of the handsomest homes in this vicinity, the wedding naturally attracted wide attention.

Thomas O. Platt, having credited the success of the Republican Party in the State to Divine Providence, is now having a fine time of it arranging to distribute such patronage as may result from it. He proposes to attend to this part of the victory himself.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- The new United States cruiser Columbia took an unofficial spin this afternoon, under forced draught, over the measured course between Cape Ann and Cape Porpoise, which is a trifle less than 44 knots long.

Eight auction sales of real estate in Brooklyn were held yesterday. At the Willoughby Street rooms, Mr. T.A. Kerrigan sold to S. Yeoman 839 and 841 Bergen Street, north side, beginning 150 feet west of Classon Avenue, each 25 by 110, and each containing two three-story frame tenements.

On a warrant issued by Justice Frederick C. Priesel of the Third District Criminal Court of Newark, N.J., four persons were arrested in this city yesterday charged with having been concerned in the alleged robbery of the office of Raimando C. Marino, an Italian banker in a small way, at 7 Fourteenth Avenue, Newark, last Saturday.

It has been remarked, generally more in sorrow than in anger, that the German orchestral player, good citizen as he generally is and artistic and conscientious performer as he is very apt to be, has his defects, and that the chief of these defects is pigheadedness. Sometimes this has been remarked in anger.

A piece of lighted paper, a log of flaming wood, a shovelful of burning coal thrown any time in the latter part of yesterday afternoon, from over the side of one of the myriad craft that ply up and down the East River might have been the means of as costly and as strange a fire as New-York or Brooklyn has ever known.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Hiram Hitchcock, the President of the Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua, in his somewhat belated annual report to the Secretary of the Interior, just received, states that since the organization of the company 10,145 shares of its capital stock have been subscribed for amounting to $1,014,500, of which $1,006,940 has been paid into the Treasury in cash and $48,871 has been realized from other sources, making the total cash received $1,055,811.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Paul Halliday, the murderess, this morning attacked Mrs. Beecher, wife of the Sheriff. She clutched her by the throat and soon would have strangled her had not the Sheriff gone to his wife's rescue. As it was, Mrs. Beecher was choked until she gasped for breath.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day received from the Commissioner of Immigration at San Francisco, Cal., a report, accompanied by sworn testimony, about the landing in San Francisco of twelve Russian convicts who escaped from confinement and were picked up by passing vessels and brought to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Ex-President Harrison's brother, J. Scott Harrison, has been made Surveyor of Customs for the Port of Kansas City. Representative Tarsney had recommended for this particular position James Burns of Kansas City, who was Surveyor of the Port in Mr. Cleveland's first term.

The steamship Louisiana, Capt. D.B. Gager, which left New-Orleans Nov. 8, arrived in this port yesterday with half her crew disabled. Saturday morning she encountered a storm which lasted until noon Sunday. During the gale the main jib, which had been hauled down taut, split and began thrashing violently.

The Fifteenth Annual Church Congress in the United States of the Protestant Episcopal Church began its session last evening in Chickering Hall. Preliminary to the session a communion service was held yestarday morning in St. Bartholomew's Charon, at Thirty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. The Right Rev. Dr. William Lawrence, Bishop of Massachusetts, delivered the communion address from the text, "Speak to the Children of Israel that They Go Forward."

Stage fright had worn off with the people who make the boxes at the Madison Square Garden their evening lounging places, yesterday. They stood the stare of the crowds with more composure than on the opening night, and used their lorgnettes in returning that stare to better advantage. It was a goodly show that the crowds made.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The new Chamber of Deputies opened its session to-day. Almost every one of the members was present, and the galleries were filled with spectators. M. Pierre Blanc, member for Savoy and doyen of the Chamber, presided at the opening of the House. In his speech he extolled the Franco-Russian entente.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- It has just been discovered that the gallery floor of the Agricultural Building has sagged where the pickle display of H.J. Heinz Company stood, owing to the vast crowd which constantly thronged their stand to taste their goods or procure a watch charm.

The new Brazilian cruiser El Cid will leave the docks of the Morgan Iron Works and proceed to her new moorings on the Brooklyn side of the East River to-day. The new berth will be at one of the docks, t is said, a short distance below the Brooklyn Bridge.
BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House at 1 1/2 @ 1 per cent, and was offered at 1 per cent. New-York funds sold at par for cash.

The Custom House was again the scene of unusual excitement yesterday. In the first place, Surveyor Lyon went out of office; secondly, there was an enlivening at the speculation as to new officers, and, lastly, the seizure of Paris-made gowns, reported the day before, proved, when the examiners had completed their work, to be a good deal more important than was at first supposed.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- John Johnson, colored, was executed here to-day by electricity. Just before he was taken to the death chamber a photographer, who had been sent for at his request, made a picture of him. He walked to the electric chair with a broad smile on his face. Just before he sat down he remarked, in a pleasant tone of voice: "Well, gentlemen, I see you are all here.

Gov. Flower yesterday complied with Judge-elect William J. Gaynor's request for the appointment of "one or more special prosecuting officers" to assist in she preparation and prosecution of the election fraud oases in Brooklyn, and Kings County.
A bunch of violets, with a woman in black in tow, drifted slowly down the aisle in Historical Hall, Brooklyn, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14 -- The British steamship Wendene, Capt. Clark, from Galveston to the United Kingdom, arrived here at noon to-day for coal, with cotton on fire in her Hold No. 3. Capt. Clark says when in the Gulf of Mexico, on the 6th inst., smoke was discovered issuing from the hold, and an examination showed that the cotton was afire.

District Attorney Nicoll announced yesterday that an extraordinary Grand Jury would be called in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Barrett, on the first Monday in December. He desires to clear up the cases awaiting the action of the Grand Jury before he leaves office, and he thought the regular body in the Court of General Sessions would be unable to handle all the business.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 -- The Rev. Dr. John S. Morris, the only surviving son of a Revolutionary soldier and the oldest minister in the Lutheran Church, was ninety years old to-day, and the event was elaborately celebrated. The Maryland Historical Society adopted resolutions to-night and to-day sent the doctor flowers.

William J. Gaynor, the Brooklyn reformer, and William Dudley Foulke of Indiana, spoke before the Nineteenth Century Club last evening on "Proportional Representation as a Remedy for Existing Political Evils."

ROME, Nov. 14 -- In an interview to-day Premier Giolitti declared that the financial situation in Italy was not as grave as was believed abroad to be the case. Although the Government was compelled to propose new taxes in order to balance the budget, it would take measures to assure Italy's credit abroad, such as requiring the payment of customs in gold.

There was no further check yesterday in the courts, by injunction or otherwise, against the payment of the dividend of 25 per cent, to depositors of the Madison Square Bank. The receivers have now virtually completed arrangements to reimburse depositors to this extent at the bank during business hours to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A revenue of $50,000,000 is expected by the Democrats of the Ways and Means Committee from the moderate income tax which they propose to incorporate in the new revenue bill. The proposed rate of the tax will probably be 2 per cent, and the exemption will be high enough to exclude the great mass of laboring men and people on small salaries.

The exhibition of ancient Greet portraits which will be opened to the public in the Fine Arts Building on Nov. 20 in connection with the annual exhibition of the New-York Water Color Club is of extraordinary interest, and will command the attention of both artists and archaeologists.

There were people at the Garden last night who went to see the society show there, who complained. They had no special interest in the horses. They went to see the occupants of the boxes. Because the ladies in the boxes wore the same gowns they had worn on Tuesday evening, these complainants, and they were mostly ladies, were aggrieved.

About 200 members of the congregation of the West Presbyterian Church, in Forty-second Street, gathered in the lecture hall of the church last night to hear the report of the sessions upon the resignation of their pastor, the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton. The Rev. F.H. Marling of the New-York Presbytery acted as Moderator.

Deputy Surveyor Blatchford is now duly empowered to act as head of the Surveyor's department at the Custom House until a successor to George W. Lyon is appointed and qualities. The doubt as to his authority was cleared away yesterday by a letter sent to him by Collector Kilbreth, acting on instructions from the Treasury Department. This letter ran as follows:

MELILLA, Nov. 14 -- The making of intrenchments around the small forts beyond the large forts began to-day, and the work was pushed with the greatest activity under the protection of the guns of the forts. The Riffians kept up a desultory fire upon those employed on the trenches, but were too far off to do any damage of consequence.

James Pavara, an Italian, who killed Louisa Donati, with whom he boarded at 2 Harris Court, Brooklyn, on April 11, was yesterday convicted of murder in the second degree by a jury in the Kings County Court of Sessions. Pavara shot the woman through the heart because she had turned him into the street for non-payment of board.

John H.V. Arnold, Surrogate elect, filed yesterday his certificate of election expenses in the County Clerk's office. He states that the paid to Tammany Hall $5,000 for "printing, distributing circulars, " In addition he paid $65 for incidentals.

With a fifty-thousand-dollar pair of scissors in their hands, the female suffragists propose to rip up the New-York State Constitution and insert a box plait that will give every woman in the State the right to vote.

John I. Davenport, the Chief Supervisor of Elections, has no right to a room in the Federal Building, according to a memorandum which Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court handed down yesterday.

The question has been raised whether Mr. GEORGE G. REYNOLDS and EDWARD M. SHEPARD ought to accept their appointments as assistants to District Attorney RIDGWAY for the prosecution of offenders against the election laws in Kings County. If these gentlemen were to act by and with the advice and consent of JAMES W. RIDGWAY, as his subordinates and subject to his control, we should say that they ought, by all means, to decline.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: A constant reader of your paper, I am among those of our city who have greatly admired your forcible, persistent, and successful efforts in uncovering the tracks of our political foxes and exposing them to public view.

Stephen A. Hooker, colored, charged with the murder of John Dozier, a colored postal clerk, was found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. Hooker was jointly indicted with Toussant Vogelsang and Martha E. Pell. He attacked Dozier with a brick on the evening of Aug. 15 in Sixth Avenue, near Minetta Lane.

Edward Lauterbach has been elected President of the Alabama and Great Southern Railroad, and S.M. Felton. Jr., has been made Vice President with full authority to operate the road. Besides Mr. Lauterbach, the newly-elected Directors are John Greenough, Gustav Kissel, Samuel Thomas, C.S. Brice, C.C. Harvey, Francis Pavy, H. Doughty Broune, George Webb Medley, Charles Schiff, and Augustus Brown Abraham.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The new Chamber of Deputies began its existence yesterday, and the interest of the lobbies centred upon the experiments that are being made to bring about a coalition of several of the political groups. The most important of these is the effort that is making to re-establish the old Republican Union, which will, if the experiment proves successful, consist of the Moderates, Extreme Left, and Left Centre.

Another Judgment has been rendered against William L. Patton, the Wall Street broker, who was arrested recently after his failure, charged with misappropriation of funds. The judgment is for $54,925.09, and is in favor of the executors of the estate of Robert Craig, who died last December.

The first monthly reunion of the Goethe Society for the season of 1893-4 was held in the large room of the Hotel Brunswick last evening. The Horse Show was a strong rival attraction in the neighborhood, but, despite its interest, the long salon was crowded with members of the society and their guests, who came to greet each other after a Summer's absence, and to hear Mr. William H. Gillette deliver a lecture upon "Drama."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- The ten Russian convicts who escaped from Siberia and were brought here under arrest by two whaling vessels issued an appeal to-day to the "deal United States people," in which they detail what would become of them if they were returned to Siberia. They say they will be starved, loaded with chains, and lashed.

-- The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday in the Mayor's office and authorized Controller Myers to issue $50,000 more in bonds for the protection at the Croton Water Shed, making $150,000 up to date. Assessment bonds to the amount of $250,000 were also authorized. Health Board pay rolls for $1,364.84 for special vaccinations and $2,497.19 for medical Inspectors for October were approved.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Fire started at 10 o'clock this evening in W.S. Thomson Co.'s corset factory, 48 and 49 Old Bailey, E.C. It spread rapidly to the shop of the Crown Perfumery Company, at 49, and thence to Lockhart's cocoa rooms and Blackie Co.'s publishing offices. Before the firemen could get well to work, several other buildings had caught fire, and the rear of Cassell's publishing house was in flames.

The feature of the auction market yesterday was the sale of the Colleran houses, six in number, from 10 to 20 West Seventieth Street, south side, between Central Part West and Columbus Avenue. Among the many persons in attendance at the sale, which took place in the Trinity Building salesroom, at 111 Broadway, were a number of west side brokers.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I have taken The Times for months, and I like the paper, "Right first, party afterward," is sound politics and safe for the Nation. You have done grand work for our city. Keep up your good work. T.J. WHITAKER.

As a member of the Band of Mercy it is the mission of Mrs. Sarah Jane Edwards of 212 West Thirty-second street to kill sick and homeless cats and dogs with chloroform. She took the lives of five cats on the evening of Oct. 4, and for doing so was fined $10 in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday. It being held that she acted unlawfully and willfully in killing them.

A well-dressed man of about thirty years of age staggered into Thomas Lane's saloon, at 38 West Thirtieth Street, a little after 11 o'clock yesterday morning and fell to the floor. A physician was sent for, and when he arrived the man was breathing his last. The body was taken to the Nineteenth Precinct Police Station House and searched.

A visit to the Carnegie Music Hall last evening would have served to disabuse any possible skeptics of their doubts as to the firm hold the army that marches under the leadership in this country of Commander Ballington Booth and beneath the banner of "blood and fire" has obtained on the hearts and minds of a large class.

BARCELONA, Nov. 15 -- A number of troops under orders to proceed to Melilla, in Morocco, to reinforce the garrison there were marching from the barracks to the quay last evening to embark upon a steamer that was to convey them to their destination. The route was lined with immense crowds.

There was an interesting prelude to the beginning of the official count by the Board of Aldermen, sitting as a Board of County Canvassers, yesterday. Alfred R. Conkling, who said he represented Judge-elect Edward T. Bartlett and 110,000 Republicans in this city, was the cause.

Although the reports of railroad earnings for the first week of this month indicate a slight falling oft in traffic as compared with the excellent showing of last month, the figures are by no means discouraging. They show that the railroads are doing a fair amount of business in an exceedingly dull period.

The girl who has counted the number of days scheduled for the Candy Show -- from Nov. 6 to Nov. 25 -- has now thoroughly accustomed herself to a sweet and steady diet and takes yards and pounds of candy every day without the slightest fear of a doctor's bill at the end of the week.

Any removal of the Academy of Design would be a matter for serious debate, but the suggestion that it might obtain a site from the city in Central Park, following the precedent of the Metropolitan and the Museum of Natural History, came with a shock to its friends. Events have proved that organizations for science and art are better off when absolutely free from entanglements with State and municipal politics.

A new freight tariff has been made by the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company, by which that corporation and the New-York and New-England Railroad will be mutually benefited. The new tariff, which will take effect just as soon as it can be promulgated in printed form, applies to an interchange of traffic between the two roads via the Poughkeepsie Bridge.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Annie Myers, the oldest woman prisoner ever arraigned in Union County Court, was convicted here yesterday of grand larceny. She is seventy-four years old. She was charged with robbing Clement Schwartz, an aged pensioner, of $700, all his savings. He lived a short distance from Elizabeth, and the woman was engaged as his housekeeper.

Missionary Day services were held yesterday for the Northern Archdeaconry of Brooklyn in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets. In the morning there was holy communion, and addresses were made by the Rev. Dr. Reese F. Alsop and the Rev. Dr. S.D. McConnell of Philadelphia.

Elijah R. Kennedy of Brooklyn is not a modest man. He wouldn't be heard of so much if he were. He is very much like a -- well, like a theatrical first-nighter. He always likes to get well in front and likes to be around every time.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Traffic managers are greatly disappointed with the results of the last two weeks' business. They expected a material improvement in its volume. Instead there has been a steady falling off. Last week shipments of all kinds of east-bound traffic, except live stock, aggregated 54,932 tons, as compared with 57,855 tons for the previous week and 74,569 tons for the corresponding week last year.

Once more the representatives of James J. Corbett and Charles Mitchell, the champion pugilists of America and England, have appended their signatures to articles of agreement for a fistic encounter between these two celebrities. Unless the authorities interfere, and it is claimed that the laws of Florida do not prohibit "scientific boxing exhibitions," the two fighters will meet before the Duval Athletic Club of Jacksonville, Fla., on Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- An air of profound mystery surrounds that portion of the House of Representatives where the Ways and Means Committee room is situated. The members of the committee have been pledged to the strictest secrecy regarding the proposed changes of duty, and this pledge has been as faithfully respected by them as is consistent with human frailty.

The people are singularly tranquil under all these newspaper incitements to revolt against the President's Hawaiian decisions. The American enemies of Queen LILIUOKALANI employ great violence of language, but we suspect that the intemperance of their discourse must be in inverse ratio to their confidence in the justice of their cause and the chance of enlisting popular sentiment in its support.

A petition is being circulated in the upper part of the city, especially among the residents of the west side, asking the Board of Street Opening and improvement to extend the westerly boundary of Riverside Park to the bulkhead line of the Hudson River, or as near thereto as may seem advisable.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- "The School for Scandal," produced at Daly's Theatre Monday night, is the one subject of comment among playgoers and critics. Miss Rehan's triumph as Lady Teazle is complete. The London Times says: "Miss Rehan's Lady Teazle must be set down as another triumph added to the many she has already won in widely-differing fields.

The independent press of the United States pays a most generous tribute to the immense public value of the services rendered by The New-York Times in its campaign against the Brooklyn ring and the defeat of "Boss" McLaughlin and his gang at the recent elections. The work of The Times was so great, and has been crowned with such success, that it deserves particular mention.

The second monthly meeting of the Sculpture Society was held Monday night, to the accompaniment of tobacco pipes and mild refreshments, in the new hall of the Fencers Club, 37 West Twenty-second Street. Vice President Gilder was in the chair, President J.Q.A. Ward being absent. Among the sculptors present were Olin L. Warner, Daniel C. French. J. J. Boyle, F. Edwin Elwell, F.R. Kaldenberg, John Rogers, Carl Bitter, and F.W. Ruckstuhl, Secretary.

President Cleveland came into town quietly and unannounced yesterday morning. He transacted some private business during the day and dined with Dr. Bryant in the evening. He departed for Washington at midnight. Secretary Lamont and Mrs. Lamont accompanied the President.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- A young man entered the office of the Fred L. Ames estate this morning and asked to be accommodated with a loan, for which he was willing to pledge his word as a gentleman and a poet. The clerk told him that such security would scarcely be considered a sufficient guarantee.
In the Building Department yesterday plans were filed for the following new building and alterations:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 15 -- The steamship Allegheny of the Merchants and Miners' Transportation Company, Baltimore, is aground on Kent Island, forty miles below Baltimore. Last night about 9 o'clock, when the vessel was coming up the bay in a heavy storm, the whistle of a steamer approaching was heard, the darkness preventing her lights from being distinguished at any distance, and the whistles were misunderstood.

-- A stereopticon lecture for the benefit of the Xavier Deaf-Mute Union will be given this evening by the Rev. John F. O'Connor, S.J., in St. Francis Xavier's College Theatre in West Sixteenth Street. His subject will be "A Trip to the Shrine of the Sacred Heart." Two or three sketches will be given in sign language by members of the society.

While the Horse Show is attracting fashionable crowds to Madison Square Garden and everybody who has a right to typify society is talking the most learned and profound variety of horse information possible, one of the minor reflexes of the equestrian monde has gracefully, if only temporarily, capitulated to the hard times, to fashionable capriciousness, and to other discouraging influences.
Over all the mingled and confused proceedings through which the litigation of the Casino has had to go has hung, with persistence, the sword of Damocles. It has been likely to fall at any time.

The Fire Commissioners listened four hours yesterday to testimony in the complaint made by Commissioner H.W. Gray against Charles A. Soteldo, a clerk in the department who has charge of the purchase of supplies, charging him with making purchases at prices higher than market rates.

Baseball players, managers, magnates, "cranks," umpires, and others connected with the diamond field sport crowded the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. The National League held its annual Fall meeting, and all were anxious to learn the result of the deliberations of the lawmakers of the national game. But as usual they went away disappointed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Information bearing on the situation in Hawaii has been earnestly sought at the State Department to-day, but none has been secured with which the public is not already familiar. To all inquiries Secretary Gresham returned the reply that he had nothing to say on the subject at present.
A sad case of destitution has been brought to the notice at several charitably-disposed Brooklynites.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 15 -- The Wisconsin Marine and Fire Insurance Company Bank, better known as the "Mitchell" Bank, will resume. Its creditors will receive dollar for dollar. City real estate owned by Senator Mitchell and John Johnson, aggregating in value, as appraised by Edward Barber and Edward P. Hackett, $1,800,000, will be pledged as security for the liabilities of the bank for the purpose of enabling it to resume.
