There is no pretense that the Government set up in the Hawaiian Islands last January, with the help of Minister STEVENS and the United States marines, was the choice of the majority of the people who had been subjects of the native monarchy. It is not pretended that the revolutionary movement originated among those people at all, or had the support of any considerable number of them.

-- The Una Bowling and Social Club is bowling this year on the Tecumsen Hotel alleys on the Boulevard, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty seventh Streets. The club has twenty members, and meets every Wednesday night. Several social entertainments will be given during the Winter. The officers are: Dr. G.A. Hull, President; Dr. H.H. Tyson, Vice President; F.D. Ames, Captain, and T.E. Belts, Secretary and Treasurer.

Mallory W. Gridley, who wore a pink in his buttonhole, learned something about the machinery of the criminal law in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. He was arraigned on the specific charge or passing worthless checks upon Devlin Co. He attempted to defend himself.

"Silver Dollar" Smith, who has been abroad for his health, returned on board the steamship Havel yesterday. The tug F.W. Vosburgh, containing a party of Mr. Smith's friends, met the steamship at Quarantine. Stretched along the sides of the tug were strips of canvas, on which were painted election results which, it was thought, would have a peculiar interest for the returning politician.

The Yale Freshmen's football team played against the Polytechnics at Eastern Park yesterday. The Tale men were confident of an easy victory and counted on a big score before the game. The "Poly" boys conceded that they could not win, but were going to do their best totally against the men from New-Haven, and they succeeded. Yale won by a score of 20 to 4.
CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 15 -- John A. Drake, the Treasurer of the Indiana, Illinois and Iowa Railroad, was beaten into insensibility by thieves this morning, and the company was robbed of about $21,000.

There is no power so absolute or so unquestioningly obeyed as fashion, and this year it has been sensibly decreed that furs shall more than ever be held in favor. For that reason A. Jaeckel of 11 East Nineteenth Street is displaying a remarkably fine and extensive stock.

The serenity of the Board of Education's meeting was ruffled yesterday by further reference to the resignation of Commissioner Crosby. No sooner had President Sanger congratulated the reappointed members of the board than Commissioner Girard moved that Mr. Crosby's letter explaining his resignation be taken from the table.

Friends of Edward M. Shepard and Judge Reynolds do not want them to undertake the prosecution of McKane and his men unless they are authorized to employ as assistants men in whom they can place entire confidence.

It has been announced that Thomas M. Turner, who figured a few years ago first as corespondent in a divorce suit brought by his former friend, James M. Bloomfield, and afterward as defendant in a suit brought by his own wife, has married again. His bride is said to be Miss Maude May, who lived with her mother at 125 West Forty-fifth Street.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 15 -- Ex-President Harrison was to-day again interviewed on Hawaii. Among other things, he said:

The Southwest Dispatch Fast Freight Line, operating over the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern for the West Shore and New-York and New-England Roads, went out of existence yesterday in name only. Commencing to-day, the line will be known as the West Shore Fast Freight Line. It will operate over the same roads and cover the same territory.

A big "shake-up" in the Republican Party in this city is now promised. The Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee has come to the conclusion that it should be investigated and set itself right with the rank and file of the party. The rank and file was of that opinion long ago.

Particular interest was taken by the members of the Conference on the Care of Dependent and Delinquent Children in the paper read by Mrs. M.C. Dunphy at the third session of the conference yesterday in the United Charities Building. Mrs. Dunphy is Superintendent of the Randall's Island Institution for Children.

Yesterday noon polite society gave its attention to the marriage of Miss Jaffray, daughter of Mrs. William P. Jaffray, to her distant relative, Capt. Edward Jaffray, formerly of the Thirteenth Hussars of the English Army. The wedding, which took place in the Church of the Transfiguration, better known as "The Little Church Around the Corner," was witnessed by about 500 guests.

Mr. John Gill, President of the Mercantile Trust and Deposit Company, and Mr. John A. Hambleton, late of John A. Hamilton Co. of Baltimore, are in the city on business connected with the settlement of the debt represented by Virginia deferred certificates; and have given the following statement to The Times:

Cardinal Gibbons arrived in the city from Baltimore at 9:10 last evening. He will this morning officiate at the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Elkins, daughter of ex-Secretary S.B. Elkins, to Edward E. Bruner in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Gibbons was met by the Rev. J.N. Connolly and escorted to the residence of Archbishop Corrigan, where he is to be a guest during his stay in the city.

At yesterday morning's session of the Protestant Episcopal Church Congress, now sitting in Chickering Hall, the subject for discussion was, "Moral and Religious Education in the Public Schools," and some striking views were expressed, notably by Prof. H.H. Boyesen of Columbia College.

Not far from $500,000 turns out to be the amount of the plunder the wreckers took from the Madison Square Bank in the twenty months they had control. Probably nothing short of searching cross-examination can trace exactly the course of this money, but the testimony, both of the books of the bank and of those who have spoken with regard to its management, leaves no doubt that President Blaut got his full share.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 15 -- A.E. Hawkins, the Republican Postmaster here, was appointed cashier of the Babylon National Bank last May. He immediately sent in his resignation as Postmaster. As there were several applicants for the place, $1,800 a year, he supposed, he would be relieved without very much delay.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The funeral of Mrs. J. Roosevelt Roosevelt, wife of the First Secretary of the American Embassy, took place to-day at Heathfield, the Roosevelt residence at Ascot. Vicar Pearse of Ascot officiated.

The Evening Post bases upon the record of PADDY DIVVER'S district as the "banner district" a demand that PADDY shall somehow be got off the bench, if a Police Justice can be said to occupy a bench, together with a number of his associates. There is no doubt that DIVVER fails to adorn the bench, or stool, or whatever it may be.

MUNICH, Nov. 15 -- The marriage of Archduke Joseph Augustin of Austria and Princess Augusta of Bavaria, granddaughter of Emperor Franz Josef, was solemnized here to-day with all the splendor of Court ceremony. Freiherr von Crailsheim, Minister of State for the Royal House, performed the civil service in the throne room of the royal palace.

El Cid, soon to be known as the Nictheroy, steamed yesterday afternoon from the dock of the Morgan Iron Works at the foot of East Ninth Street, where she has been prepared for service, to the foot of Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, to ship the remainder of her coal. She has already 500 tons aboard, and will take on about 2,500 tons more at her new dock.

The body of a young woman was taken from the East River at Pier 46 yesterday morning, and on examination it was discovered that the woman had received knife wounds before her death and been, badly bruised while in the water. The police believe she was murdered.

Charles Buerman Co. have sold for Matthaus Beck the four-story double flat 379 South Third Street, Brooklyn, to Emanuel Reich of this city for $16,000. The dimensions of the property are 25 toy 65 by 100.
The conference on the care of dependent and delinquent children closed yesterday in the Associated Charitles Building, after morning and afternoon sessions. The subject was "Delinquent Children."

The Committee of Twenty-eight appointed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music indignation meeting Monday evening has promptly begun making substantial preparations to prosecute the persons implicated in the election frauds.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Metropolitan was weak at the opening on the rumor of an issue of bonds by the company, and the stock was pressed for sale, declining to 95, with a subsequent recovery to 97. Nothing official is given out as to the issue, but it is believed by well-informed people that, as the company will need money, such an issue is not unlikely.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Under the influence of a favorable bank statement the markets improved this afternoon, and closed at about the highest prices.

William H. Beers, the former President of the New-York Life Insurance Company, died yesterday morning at his residence, 26 East Forty-eighth Street, in this city, of heart trouble, with which he had been suffering for several years.

"Boss" McLaughlin and his lieutenants in Brooklyn do not appear to realize that they are politically dead and buried. Having been sat upon by the decent citizens at the polls on election day and buried out of sight, they now crawl forth with a proposition which will arouse laughter wherever it is read.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 16. -- Mail dispatches from the Congo Free State have brought the details of Capt. Dhanis's victories over the Arabs at Nyangwe and Kasongo some months ago.

The Teachers' Committee of the Brooklyn Board of Education last evening took up the long-deferred trial of Miss Georgiana F. Putnam, the colored Principal of Public School No. 68, who has been accused by the local committee of incompetence and insubordination.
The new twin-screw steamboat for the use of the Police Department of New-York, which has been constructed by the Maryland Steel Company, will be launched to-morrow at Sparrow Point, near Baltimore.
The crew for the new Brazilian cruiser Nictheroy, formerly El Cid, will go on board that vessel to-day. The Nictheroy will be ready to sail to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- At the Treasury here, when the doors were closed yesterday, the margin of currency left for business was very small. There was only $13,000,000, including that distributed through the Sub-Treasuries. The currency balance is a little larger to-day, because of redemptions made yesterday, which are placed in the cash as soon as made.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- There was less trading in West Chicago Street Railway stock on the first call to-day than at any morning session for a long time. No more than 250 shares were dealt in, with prices steady. North Chicago was also flat at 250@253, closing weak at 252. The usual amount of good business was transacted in Lake Street Elevated at from 27 to 27 1/2.

"Unsere Frauen" is a lively five-act comedy of middle-class life in Berlin, by G. von Moser and Franz von Schoenthan, which was given last night for the first time in New-York at the Irving Place Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A call was issued this morning for a full meeting of the Democratic members of the Committee on Ways and Means to be held to-morrow, at which, it was said, the first draft of the new Tariff bill would be considered.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 16. -- The marriage of Miss Bessie Williamson, daughter of Chief Engineer and Mrs. Thom Williamson, to Mr. Herbert M. Wilson, of the Geological Survey, took place at noon to-day in St. John's Church. Pink and white chrysanthemums and leaves decorated the chancel.

Jacob M. Patterson's Republican county "machine" was partially wrecked at last night's meeting of the Republican County Committee in Grand Opera House Hall. The "machine's" complete overthrow now appears to be only a question of time.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador, attended this evening a banquet given by the Lowtonian Society, a select association of London solicitors, to celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the foundation of their organization. Last evening Mr. Bayard was at the annual dinner of the benchers of Gray's Inn.

It is rather curious that there should at the same time be an organization in New-York for the suppression and in Brooklyn for the encouragement and diffusion of cats. Not long ago a lady of Brooklyn communicated to her fellow-citizens her recipe for the soothing of cats, and declared that felicide was entirely unnecessary to pro- tect the community from the howling of cats at night.
The Flower Show, with the additional attraction of the professional matinee given by the Imperial Austrian Infantry Band, proved a formidable rival to the Horse Show yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Nov. 16. -- The trial of the United States cruiser Columbia, for which such extensive preparations had been made, was started to-day according to programme, over the measured course between Cape Ann and Cape Porpoise, but before fifteen minutes of the four-hours' run had been accomplished, Edwin S. Cramp was compelled to abandon the race against time, because the high wind had blown the buoys and marking boats out of position.

Mayor Boody, Controller Corwin, and Auditor Weber of Brooklyn, acting under an act passed by the last Legislature, as a commission to audit and approve the infamous "Columbian fraud bills," will begin their labors this morning in the Brooklyn City Hall.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Owing to the reported irregularities in the management of the Bank of England, several cases have occurred where refusals have been given to cash Bank of England notes bearing the autograph of Frank May, late Chief Cashier of the bank.

A systematic and thorough investigation of the condition and finances of the Northern Pacific Railroad is to be conducted under the direction of the committee of bondholders of which Edward D. Adams is Chairman. Stephen Little and John Scott, the expert accountants, have been engaged to make an examination of the company's books and accounts, and it is expected that they will begin their work at once.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16. -- Analysis of the vote usually has little interest for the defeated party, but there are some facts brought out by the official returns of last week's Ohio election that are worthy of attention. The vote was large, the total being within 28,000 of the Presidential year. McKinley's vote is over 27,000 greater than that given Harrison in 1892, while Neal receives 52,000 less than Cleveland.
BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The Reichstag was opened to-day by his Majesty Emperor William in person. In the speech from the throne opening the session, the Emperor said:

From 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon until nearly midnight the Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, continued the work of canvassing the vote cast at the last election. When they finished their work for the day the vote of the first six districts had been counted. Work will be resumed at 9 o'clock this morning, and night sessions will be held until the count is completed.

MARSEILLES, Nov. 16. -- This city was thrown into a state bordering on panic last night by an attempt to blow up the residence of Gen. Mathelin, Commander of the Fifteenth Army Corps, whose headquarters is in Marseilles. The house occupied by Gen. Mathelin is surrounded by high walls, and about the premises there are placed sentry boxes.
The regular Democrats of Brooklyn are in open revolt against "Boss" McLaughlin and the corrupt ring of "machine" leaders, who were snowed under by the citizens on election day.

The delegates to the meeting of the National Baseball League held an all-day session in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday discussing the claims made by the Philadelphia Club in regard to the price of admission to games on the home grounds and the division of the receipts with the visiting clubs.
The taxpayers of Gravesend are loud in their denunciation of the extravagant manner in which the town officers are carrying on their work.
Gov. and Mrs. McKinley of Ohio arrived from the West yesterday at 2:30 P.M., and went to the Windsor Hotel. They were met by the Governor's brother, Abner McKinley, a lawyer of this city.

Five bullets were fired by a "crank" into the restaurant at Delmonico's, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, last evening. Two large plate-glass windows on the Fifth Avenue side were demolished. Although there were many persons in the restaurant, not one was hurt. The man who did the firing was caught and taken to the Thirtieth Street Police Station, where he gave his name as George A. Roeth.

The football teams of Columbia Grammar School and Cutler School played a game yesterday for the interscholastic championship. Columbia Grammar School won by a score of 12 to 4. The game was played on Berkeley Oval, and members of the teams of the Berkeley and Harvard Schools watched the contest.

-- Fourteen more actions for damages arising out of the Chester bridge disaster have been entered in the Massachusetts Superior Court against the Boston and Albany Railroad Company. The total amount of damages claimed by the plaintiffs in these suits is $191,700, which, added to the total amounts of damages claimed in suits entered last month. $70,000, makes the total sum sued for $261,700.

Prof. GARNER'S announcement that his visit to Africa to study the language of monkeys has been entirely successful is necessarily of great interest. It is of the greater interest because he has brought back with him two chimpanzees, with whom he "claims" to have established conversational relations, and with whom, doubtless, he will consent to converse in public -- not necessarily for publication, but as a guarantee of good faith.

Mrs. Henrietta Wiedner, an aged woman, living at 258 West Forty-sixth Street, this city, shot herself twice in the head on the grave of her son Hermann, in Greenwood Cemetery, at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Several policemen and laborers employed in the cemetery heard the shots and hastening to the place found Mrs. Wiedner lying face downward on the mound.

A special meeting of the Municipal Art Society of New-York was held on Tuesday evening in the American Fine Arts Society's Building in West Fifty-seventh Street. About fifty members were present in the rooms of toe Society of American Artists. William A. Coffin, First Vice President, presided in the absence of President Richard M. Hunt.

An extra bidder or two makes quite a difference at an auction sale, as was aptly shown yesterday in the Trinity Building salesroom. The same case showed also that when the right kind of property is put up for sale at auction nowadays, satisfactory prices are obtained.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- There will be no trouble about the West Pointers going to Annapolis to play the Naval Academy football team in December. Every one in authority about the War Department takes a keen interest in the contest, and Secretary Lamont is very willing to give the necessary permission to visit Annapolis that there may be a game between the two Government schools.

At last evening's session of the Protestant episcopal Church Congress, the subject discussed was "What Is Involved in the Doctrine of the Sufficiency of the Bible?" Of the six essayists and speakers on the programme, several expounded views so liberal as to evoke somewhat emphatic expressions of conservatism from the others.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- No change in Harvard's eleven since the season began has brought about such general commendation as the substitution of Beale for Fairchild in Quarter back's position. For a couple of weeks it has been known that Fairchild was getting lazy in his work, and on that account absolutely unfit to hold his important position.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Another case of circumstantial evidence convicting the wrong man has just came to light in Union County.
Conrad N. Jordan, Assistant Treasurer at New-York, is on his way to Europe. He was a passenger on the steamship Berlin, which sailed on Wednesday. The fact was not generally known until yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 16. -- After an investigation of the condition of the leper hospital in the outskirts of New-Orleans, it is charged that the patients are often not visited by a physician for ten days at a time, that insufficient food is given them, and no nurses are provided.

An attack on the Tobacco Trust has been begun by Attorney General Stockton of New-Jersey, where the trust was incorporated. On the ground that the trust is crushing out trade and tyrannizing the trade in the most high-handed manner, the Attorney General asks that it be restrained from doing business in the State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Bids for smokeless powder for the army will be opened on Dec. 5 by Gen. Flagler, the army Chief of Ordnance. The powder is intended for the 30-calibre small arms, and 10,000 rounds will be purchased in the first lot. It is expected that certainly three and perhaps four firms will present bids.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Secretary Herbert intends to make an award of the contract for constructing the three light-draught gunboats authorized by Congress, at the earliest possible moment. Action upon the proposals would already have been taken but for the adjournment of the naval board which was charged with an examination of the bids in order to allow some of the members to participate in the trial of the new cruiser Columbia.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The Volksfreund, the organ of the German Catholics of Buffalo, makes a severe attack on Archbishop Ireland of Paul, because of his temperance address here during Bishop Ryan'a jubilee. It says:

A marked service was rendered to commerce and navigation by Congress, at the recent session, in passing its joint resolution for the reporting and removal of dangerous wrecks and derelicts. This resolution authorizes the President to enter into an agreement with other nations for destroying abandoned hulks in the North Atlantic, beyond coast waters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Navy Department people who are questioned concerning the alleged imperfections in the cruiser New-York refuse to concede that there are any serious defects in her. Secretary Herbert does not appear to believe that the ship is any the worse for service because she is deeper by the stern than the bow.

The Candy Show continues to be a magnet for men, women, and children, who keep going -- just once more -- and imperiling their digestions, because the candy looks so good and may be had for the asking, almost in unlimited quantities.

The infinite variety of the affairs and the litigation of the Casino exceeds that which is associated by William Shakespeare with the reputation of the late Cleopatra, aforetime Queen of Egypt. There has not been a day during the last six months which has not brought forth what is professionally styled "a fresh development" in the matters of that justly celebrated shrine of comic opera.

Worn out by the dissensions that have rent his command and disturbed his peace of mind for the past three years, the venerable Colonel of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, James Cavanagh, last night forwarded his resignation to Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, commanding the First Brigade of the New-York State National Guard.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 16. -- Attorney General Smith to-day announced his determination to appear and defend the suit brought yesterday under direction of the Republican State Committee, attacking the apportionment of the State for legislative purposes.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16. -- Capt. Hinkey this morning took thirteen men from the regular training table over to the New-Haven House to live for the rest of the season. The selection gives a good hint as to the eleven and the first substitutes that Hinkey will take to Springfield. It will be about the same eleven that faced the Quakers on Saturday last.

The receivers of the Madison Square Bank began yesterday to take proof of deposits. They had a busy day of it. The law requires that each depositor must sustain his claim by affidavit, and that in order to be entitled to a dividend the affidavit mast declare that its maker has not transferred, assigned, hypothecated or otherwise disposed of the claim or impaired it.

Judge Jerolomon of the Eighth Judicial District Court of this city has rendered a decision which establishes the truth of the charge made by The New-York Times that all the fights which have taken place under the auspices of the Coney Island Athletic Club were prize fights, and, consequently, violations of the Penal Code.

After having the Surveyorship question supposedly settled by Collector Kilbreth's designation of Deputy Surveyor Blatchford to act as Surveyor until the appointment of a successor to George W. Lyon, the Custom House force fell to discussing it again yesterday. The new point of argument was that the law under which the Collector acted did not apply to the case.

The dealers in horses and carriages always look for a revival in trade immediately after the Horse Show, and it does not look as though they are to be disappointed this year, as more traps have been sold within the last week than any previous tour weeks or this Fall.

The first annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers was held yesterday in the rooms of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, at 12 West Thirty-first Street. It was well attended.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- There has been plenty of gossip to-day about the Hawaiian situation, but no fresh news. The Administration still maintains the silence observed after the communication of the Secretary of State to the President was made public. Many inquiries have been made of Secretary Gresham to-day relating to the all-absorbing topic, but he has refused to throw any fresh light upon it.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 16. -- Frank P. Scearce, the Lexington forger, escaped from jail last night and is now at liberty. Scearce was a prominent society and business man until a short time ago, when it was discovered that he had been guilty of swindling to the extent of $50,000. He left the following note to Jailor Wikerson.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 16. -- Edgewood Villa, the former home of the late Gov. C. C. Washburn while Executive of Wisconsin, was burned this evening. It is about three miles from the city and was used as a boarding school for young ladies by the Franciscan Catholic Sisters. Twenty-five pupils were in the school, but all escaped except two.

There is no more interesting Salvation Army meeting, nor one which more clearly points out the class and power of the organization's work, than what is known in army language as a consecration meeting -- a meeting the whole and sole aim or which is to work on the hearts of those who attend, whether from more curiosity or deeper motives.

The new Diana, brightly glided, will take her place on the top of the Madison Square Garden tower this afternoon. With her left arm, which holds the bow, protected by the graceful folds of a scarf, she will defy the Winter's blasts and the Summer's sun.

-- Jennie Yeamans appeared in "Jane" at the Harlem Opera House last week. The Forbes Lithographing Company holds a judgment for $3,221.23 against Miss Yeamans for lithographs and printing, and recently obtained an order for her examination in supplementary proceedings. Henry Newman, a process server, was sent to serve her with an order for her examination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- When Secretary Gresham returned from the Cabinet meeting late this afternoon he found a dozen newspaper men waiting in his room. "I am sorry, gentlemen," he said, without waiting to be questioned, "but there is nothing I can give you to-day in the line of news.

Work has been practically finished at the District Attorney's office on the books of the Madison Square Bank, and the various attorneys for officials against whom warrants were issued have been invited to a conference with the District Attorney this afternoon. This is intended to pave the way to an understanding upon which the case may be presented to the Grand Jury.

LYONS, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Alonzo Mead of Fair Haven has brought suit in the Supreme Court against the town of Huron, Wayne County, for $15,000 damages for personal injury in having his feet frozen while a town poor charge.
WEST POINT, Nov. 17. -- Col. O.H. Ernet, Superintendent of the Military Academy, has completed his annual report relating to the affairs of the post.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 17. -- Thirty white men, who have formed themselves into a syndicate to carry out gold mining in Demerara, have left here for Georgetown, Demerara, whence they will proceed by boat up the Essequibo River to the foot of the Sierra Acarai Mountains, where there are extensive gold mines worked by natives.

There is plenty of fun ahead in the local Republican camp. There is no telling how far-reaching will be the results of the big fight which Edwin Einstein and several others made for immediate "reorganization" as against Jacob M. Patterson's scheme of "investigation" at Thursday night's meeting of the County Committee in Grand Opera House Hall.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- A hitch has occurred in the arrangements for a game with Georgetown for nest Wednesday, and as a consequence the team goes in to-morrow for the last game of the season, barring the one with Yale on Thanksgiving Day.

It was simply a crush at Madison Square Garden last evening. Nothing else would describe it. Before the doors were thrown open for the show every seat in the big house was sold. Even the speculators had no supply with which to meet the demand for seats. Fancy prices offered for places brought out no responses from these sharks.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 17. -- Dr. Mary E. Walker, who has been in this vicinity for several days, went to the Court House this morning, where the Supreme Court was in session, took a seat with the members of the bar, and wrote the following petition to the Court, which she presented to Judge Carpenter:

Deputy Coroner Donlin said yesterday, after making an autopsy, that he was satisfied the woman whose body was found in the East River on Thursday was murdered. The body still remains unidentified. The woman was about twenty-eight years old. of medium height, and her body was well nourished.

A lively game is expected to-day between the Crescents of Brooklyn and the Orange Athletic Club for the championship of the American Football Union. The rivalry between the two clubs is strong, and, as Orange has an excellent team this year, the New-Jersey men have great hopes of winning. The line-up will be as follows:

Senator Plunkitt had a bill passed at the last session of the Legislature to make the city pay for regrading Twelfth Avenue from Forty-eighth to Fiftieth Streets inclusive, and Forty-eighth, Forty-ninth, and Fiftieth Streets, to conform to the water-front grade established by the Dock Department. Mr. Plunkitt is very much interested in this scheme.

Various rumors were in circulation yesterday relative to the import of the statements submitted on Thursday by Expert Stephen Little to the joint committee of Reading general and income bondholders. That Mr. Little's investigations showed the financial affairs of the Reading Railroad and the Reading Coal Company to be in bad shape is freely admitted by persons who heard the report read.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 17. -- The annual meeting of the National Transportation Association was concluded yesterday. Congressman Stover of Ohio, Chairman of the Sub-Committee on Inter-State Commerce, and Congressman Patterson of Tennessee, a member of the same committee, made addresses mainly on the relations of the shippers to the rail roads and the inter-State commerce law.

A very fair representation of an infernal machine, which may even yet turn out to be the real article, was discovered in the cellar of the house 79 East Third Street yesterday morning. The finding of the "bomb" caused some excitement among the occupants of the basement.

There is really very little question about the facts connected with the movement of last Winter for the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands to the United States. It is clearly established that the overturning of the native monarchy and the setting up of the provisional Government had for its sole purpose the accomplishment of annexation, and that those engaged in the movement represented a small minority of the people, and were themselves mostly aliens.

The French painter Jean-Charles Cazin has come to America, bringing with him seventy or eighty paintings for the purpose of making a comprehensive exhibit of his work. He has become because Americans are his best buyers, encouragement in this country having improved his position in France and England, and to make the collection as full as possible he has borrowed from amateurs and dealers fifty or sixty more of his own works.

Theodore Moss, the proprietor of the Star Theatre, has been awarded the custody of his two grandchildren, over the possession of whom there has been a long legal fight between Mr. Moss and the father of the children, T.E. Keator. The children were born in Mr. Moss's house. When she was dying about two years ago Mrs. Keator obtained a promise from her parents that they would care for her children.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17. -- The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day were as follows:

Henry De Forest Baldwin, Virginius Dabney, and Daniel G. Hawthorn were appointed Deputy Collectors yesterday. The morning mail from Washington brought the confirmation of their selection by Collector Kilbreth. The three new officers visited his office late in the afternoon and were duly sworn in by Mr. Kilbreth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The report of J. Fount Tillman, who on the 1st of July last succeeded Gen. W.S. Rosecrans, resigned, as Registor of the Treasury, is just made public. It necessarily covers only the period during which Mr. Tillman's predecessor held control, but the voluminous tabulated statements presented contain much information of interest.

Henry Kinsella, janitor of the American Steamship Company's offices, 6 Bowling Green, throw a pint of vitriol at Mrs. James Conway, wife of the janitor of the French Steamship Company's offices, at 3 Bowling Green, last night.

The new Brazilian cruiser Nictheroy anchored last night in the upper bay, a short distance above Quarantine Station. She left her berth at the foot of Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Four tugs were necessary to assist her to back out Into the East River, but once her bow was headed down stream the Nictheroy took charge of herself.

General changes of time tables on the trunk line railroads, which will go into effect on Nov. 19, will bring about a num-of changes in mail dispatches. On the Pennsylvania Railroad the first evening postalcar train for Pittsburg and the West will leave New-York at 6 P.M., instead of at 6:30 P.M., and mails will close at the General Post Office for this train at 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- A cipher telegram received by the Navy Department this evening from Capt. Picking, under today's date, from Rio de Janeiro, is looked upon as significant, and as possibly indicating a weakening of the strength of the insurgent fleet under Admiral Mello. The translation of the dispatch is as follows:

A tall, slender-necked bottle, gilded to the cork and almost hidden beneath bows of red, white, and blue ribbon, occupies a place of honor in the cozy home of Rear Admiral Daniel L. Braine, at 67 First Place, Brooklyn. The bottle has an interesting history. It was purchased three years ago by Mrs. Braine and was destined to mark an era in the history of the new American navy.

LIEUT. COL. ALBERT HARTSCFF, Deputy Surgeon General, is announced as Medical Director of the Department of California, relieving Col. Joseph R. Smith, Assistant surgeon General, who will proceed to the Department of the East.

In the war play called "Maine and Georgia," produced, alter a long delay, at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night, the principal scene represents, with startling vividness and unusual pictorial accuracy, the battle of Gordon's Mill, Georgia, in 1862. The point of view is behind a rebel fortification on the bank of the river.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 17. -- "I will certainly insist on my resignation being accepted. It would be unjust to the church to do otherwise. I want no vacation, no salary, only a rest. My resignation is final."

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The great coal strike has been settled. It is announced this evening that the miners will resume work at the old wages on Monday, and continue to work at those wages until a new rate shall be established by a "Board of Conciliation."

NEW-YORK. Friday, Nov. 17 -- P.M. With the exception of the movement in Reading, to-day's stock market was entirely in the control of the professional traders. There was a slight increase in the volume of trading, but the fluctuations outside of a few specialties were only fractional. Of the thirty active stocks printed on "the blue list," the net changes in sixteen of them did not exceed 1/4 point.
BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 1 1/2@2 per cent., most of the loans being made at the former rate. New-York funds sold at par.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- There soon will be another big army commission at the disposal of the President. The retirement of Gen. W.P. Carlin, on Nov. 24. will make a vacancy in the grade of Brigadier General. Nearly every Colonel of the line has filed an application with the Adjutant General, and some of them are making strenuous efforts to secure the place.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- All is in readiness on board the cruiser Columbia for the official trial trip which, if the weather permits, will take place to-morrow. The stiff southwest wind which prevailed this afternoon abated considerably at sun down. The Weather Bureau predicts rain and snow for to-morrow, but it is hoped that if bad weather is coming the trial can be made before it strikes the Massachusetts coast.

The closing day of the Protestant Episcopal Church Congress in Chickering Hall was marked by a very great attendance and by addresses and papers which clashed with each other like angry swords. The extreme High-Church views or the Rev. Dr. G.W. Dumbell of Castleton, S. I., were received with marked signs of disapproval, as well as with, applause from the "advanced" men who congregated in one part of the hall.

The whereabouts of the papers in the case of Joseph P. Kearney, a driver employed by Rees Rees, dyers of 232 East Fortieth Street, has caused Howell C. Rees any amount of trouble since the first of the month. Kearney was arrested on the charge of stealing $3.40 which he had collected.

If only half the tales told in Parlor L of the Astor House yesterday be true, the state of affairs in the Elmira Reformatory is not much better than the shocking conditions in English prisons which inspired Charles Reade's "Never Too Late to Mend."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Gov. Flower remained in Syracuse until late this afternoon, and then left for Rochester, where he is to be tendered a reception by the Chamber of Commerce this evening. Before leaving Syracuse, he read what the New-York morning papers had to say about the Kings County election cases, and then sent the following telegrams:

The athletes of the Eighty-sixth Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association have settled down to their regular Winter course of work. R.B. Howland, the physical director, says that the season has never started in so briskly before. The membership of the various classes in the gymnasium is considerably larger.

The Dock Board has given up all opposition, if it ever had any, to the plan of having the water front of Riverside Park perpetually preserved to the park and kept free from docks except at the foot of the streets which now extend to the river. The Board of Street Improvement has assented to the plan, with some expression of doubt as to whether it has any jurisdiction in the matter.
Charles W. Gardner, Superintendent of Dr. Parkhurst's society, will be a free man to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 17. -- The expenditure of $35,000 in lobbying the Hartford Bridge bill through the Legislature, in June, is still exciting wide interest in this State. The Glastonbury Town Committee, which was appointed to investigate the scandal, so far as that town was concerned, is at work on the case, and will bring in a report severely criticising the entire transaction.

The ablest of Brooklyn lawyers were agreed yesterday that William J. Gaynor had taken a wise course in appealing to the Governor to so arrange matters that the men selected to prosecute McKane and his Justices should have the power to go before the Grand Jury and exercise the powers of a District Attorney.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- Markets were quiet but firm to-day. English railways improved on the coal conference, which resulted after business hours in the settlement of the strike. Foreigners were good, on Paris buying, caused by the report that the French Government would proceed forthwith with the conversion scheme.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17. -- Nearly all the Yale corporation except Chauncey M. Depew were present at the regular Fall meeting here on Tuesday. Judge Howland of New-York was present and took an active part. Treasurer William W. Farnam submitted his annual report, showing that $205,910.39 had been received the past year.

With its first exhibition in the galleries of the Fine Arts Society, the little Water Color Club takes on the proportions of an art organization which has a serious future before it and has come to stay. Its former exhibitions have contained a good deal of useless material. This time there has been a sterner winnowing of the chaff, and the result is a collection decidedly above former averages.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed in the Building Department yesterday:

If the present plans are carried out, three, and possibly four, different American, appliances for using very heavy charges of high explosives in torpedo warfare will be put to practical service tests by the fleet fitting out at this port to attack Admiral MELLO. Guncotton, the high explosive used in our own navy, will doubtless be the material employed in all four devices.

Russell Sage will have to submit to a jury the question of damages for using William R. Laidlaw as a human screen against a dynamite bomb. The General Term of the Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday overruling Justice Andrews, who dismissed the suit last Spring.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- A.R. Elliott of Kansas City, Mo., champion of America, and Frank Class of Morristown, champion of New-Jersey, met to-day for the third time at Willard Park in a pigeon shooting contest. The stakes were $25O a side, and the men shot at 100 pigeons. Class killed 99 and Elliott 98, but three fell outside the boundary line, making at score 95.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 17. -- The election last week demonstrated the existence of a political factor in Kansas politics heretofore unknown. That this power is not wielded for the benefit of either of the great political parties the results in two cases make clearly evident. In Leavenworth County the Republican Sheriff was elected by and through the American Protective Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Bourke Cockran of New-York spoke his mind with characteristic bluntness to-day to his fellow-members of the Ways and Means Committee regarding the proposed income tax. Mr. Cockran came from New-York this morning. He was at the Capitol bright and early, but the anticipated committee meeting was again postponed.

PARIS, Nov. 17. -- Le Journal to-day publishes an interview with Signor Crispi, exPrime Minister of Italy. Speaking in regard to the France-Russian entente, Signor Crispi said that an alliance between France and Russia seemed unnatural. It would in no way strengthen the peace of Europe, which the triple alliance did not intend to affect, but rather would compromise it, and would compel Great Britain to lake extra precautions in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Wheat was rather quiet during the early part of the session, but became active within the last two hours, with prices lower. The opening was firm at from 1-16c lower to 1/8c higher than yesterday's close, then rallied 1/2@5/8c, but after some slight changes developed weakness and declined 1@1 1/8c, then held steady, and the close was 3/8c lower for December and 3/8@1/2c lower for May.
The seething maelstrom of Casino affairs which daily evolves new characters, incidents, and news, yesterday tossed another prominent and estimable gentleman into evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- There was some activity in Reading at the opening of the market, and it was sold freely by New-York and by the room traders here. The rest of the list was dull and inclined to sag.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 17. -- The annual meeting of the Queens County Agricultural Society will be held to-morrow evening in the society's offices on the fair grounds at Mineola. It promises to be the liveliest gathering in the half-century history of the organization. The coming contest is due to an amendment to the constitution to be voted upon.

In Boom 1 in the Astor House, famous for many historical gatherings, there gathered last evening a distinguished company. The Cumberland Crew, which embraces in its membership some of the most popular men in town, was there, and the room was gorgeously decorated with flags, bunting, and flowers, under the direction of P. Henry Cosgrove, to represent the deck of a ship.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Board of Elders of the First Presbyterian Church of Roselle has suspended James W. Hope and Milton C. Crane from the church because they voted to grant a license to the Lindon race track.

The question of protecting the water front of Riverside Park came up again before the Board of Street Opening and Improvement yesterday, and some progress was made toward a final settlement. The Dock Board wants to use part of the water front for dock purposes, but the property owners in the vicinity want the park to be extended to the bulkhead line and kept free from docks and piers.

The Real Estate Exchange and Auction Room Corporation will hold its annual election of Directors on Monday, Dec. 11. The Committee on Nominations, in anticipation the event, is now sending to stockholders a circular, presenting the names of the following gentlemen proposed as Directors for the ensuing year:

Charles W. Thomas. Charles W. Thomas, of the firm of Hoyt Thomas, theatrical managers, died yesterday morning at Tucson, Arizona, of consumption. He had been in ill health for something more than a year. He went to the Adirondack Mountains early last Spring in the hope of benefit.

The Tobin bronze steamer that is to be built by the Herreshoffs is thought to be for Mr. C.H. Ossood, who formerly owned the steamer Cosette. The yacht is to be plated with bronze to the water line, just as the Vigilant is. The plates from the water line up will be of steel. She will be a twin screw, 185 feet long, 22 feet 6 inches beam, and 12 feet draught.

VIENNA, Nov. 17. -- Prince Alexander of Battenberg, formerly Prince of Bulgaria, died at noon to-day at Gratz. The body will be taken to Darmstadt for burial. His widow, before her marriage Anna Loisinger of the Darmstadt Court Theatre, will accompany it from Gratz. The funeral will take place in Gratz on Monday.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- A heavy gale set in yesterday on the western and southern coasts of Great Britain. A tremendously heavy sea sprang up in the English Channel and the Irish Sea. The gale was blowing this morning with unabated vigor.

Next to the Yale-Harvard boat race, the big sporting event between the two universities is the annual football game. This will be played at Springfield next Saturday, and every graduate and undergraduate of the New-Haven and Cambridge colleges who can possibly be on hand will be in Springfield to bet, "root," and shout for his Alma Mater.

The three new Deputy Collectors were busy yesterday getting acquainted with their duties at the Custom House. H.D. F. Baldwin was assigned to the Law Division, for which, he is specially fitted by his professional training. There he will first undertake the duties formerly performed by Deputy Collector Hunt.

Dear Sir: I beg to call your attention to the remarkable reply made by the editor of The Broad Arrow in the issue of that paper of Sept. 23 to an inquiry regarding the "Brown regimental wire gun," (sic,) page 401, to wit:

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- Chevalier de Guimaraes, chief political adviser of Count d'Eu, returned from Brussels to-day. He declined to say anything as to his mission there, and denied that he had any direct news of Admiral Mello's proclamation of the Emperor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- There is rejoicing at the Patent Office over the fact that the Patent Office Gazette now appears regularly each week. For the last four months this valued publication has not made its appearance according to schedule, and people who are interested in the subject of patents have been inconvenienced by the delay.

"One of the pathetic things that one reads about really happened to me this Autumn," said a young woman the other day. She is an artist and her apartment and studio are in an up-town street, occupied on both sides of her particular block by other apartment houses.

If "A Hillside Parish" is to be classed as a clerical romance, so pleading is it in form, so honest in sentiment, so bright in conception, that we trust it may be considered a model for future constructors of such fiction. The love of a man for God, apart from ritual, is clearly exemplified in Harry Dinsmore, who takes charge of the church at Clintonville.
The statue of Nathan Hale, erected by the Sons of the Revolution, will be dedicated in City Hall Park, at the corner of Broadway and Mail Street, on Evacuation Day, Nov. 25.

The seventh annual season of the Lyceum stock company will open to-morrow night with the production of a new play, by Clyde Fitch, called "An American Duchess." The comedy is founded on a French play by Henri Lavedan, called "Prince d'Aurec," but it is said that the author has utilized only the theme of the foreign piece, and that "An American Duchess" is, to a great extent, original.

-- New and striking dances by Delmore, the serpentine dancer, will be the feature of this week's bill at the Eden Musee. They will be respectively known as "The Serpent Dance," "The Dance of Gold," and "La Danse Blanche," will all be variations of the serpentine dance, and the effects will be heightened by novel light arrangements.
Army News. COL. EDWARD M. HOYT, Inspector General, will visit Milwaukee, Wis., on public business, on completion of which he will return to Chicago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- The reproduction of the Princess Metternich Salon of Vienna, which took the gold medal and was exhibited at the World's Fair by R.J. Horner Co., the artistic decorators and furniture importers of West Twenty-third Street, New-York, is being packed here for shipment to the Prize Winners' Exposition.

The literature of France had, these last five years, exquisite interludes. They were prose and poems: "Axel," by Villiers de I'Isle-Adam; "Vers et Prose." by Stephane Mallarme; "Amour," by Paul Verlaine; "Les Complaintes," by Jules Laforgue; "Les Cantilenes," by Jean Moreas; "Sous I'Oeil des Barbares," "L'Homme Libre," and "Le Jardin de Berenice," by Maurice Barres.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- The official test of electric power on the canals was made at righton, near this city, today, and was pronounced by all who witnessed it a great success. The line was only completed yesterday at a late hour, so that only one preliminary test had been made, and that when the boat made its first trip after dark last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18. -- The United Press correspondent at Honolulu, writing under date of Nov. 11, says that President Dole received United States Minister Albert S. Willis on the 6th inst. Mr. Willis accompanied the presentation of his letter of credence with a short address, of which the following is the text:

Margaret Lynch, twenty-two years old, of 138 East Twenty-ninth Street, employed in Mrs. L. Shaw's establishment, at 54 West Fourteenth Street, was terribly burned at noon yesterday by blazing alcohol. She and her sister, Ellen, were mixing pomade in the cellar, Margaret standing at a gas stove, over which the alcohol was heating.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Secretary Carlisle has approved the finding of Capts. Henriques, Moore, and Congdon in the case of Capt. John C. Mitchell of the revenue marine cutter Crawford. The charge was of gross immorality and drunkenness. The trial was secret and prolonged, Capt. Mitchell remaining in charge of his vessel while the investigation was going on.

Although the annual music festival at Norwich, England, took place last month, detailed accounts of the work done are just reaching this side of the Atlantic. One of the new productions, F.H. Cowen's "Water Lily," is said to have been received with great favor and to have added to the reputation of its composer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 18. -- A United Press representative who boarded the steamer Australia in the ocean from a tug was immediately surrounded on coming over the rail and questioned as to the truth of the rumor that two members of President Cleveland's Cabinet had resigned because of the Administration's Hawaiian policy.

The attorneys for officers and Directors of the Madison Square Bank had a conference yesterday with District Attorney Nicoll. As a result, Bank Examiner Judson will be called to the District Attorney's office tomorrow. He may have to shoulder the responsibility for the bank taking $90,000 from depositors after it was known to be insolvent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Monday with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

Society's show at Madison Square Garden was extinguished shortly after midnight. The crush was something terrific. Every seat had an occupant; every bit of standing room was filled. The promenade was packed to suffocation, so much so that it was with difficulty that the gates were opened to admit contestants to the ring.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- The "Madame SansGene" of MM. Victorien Sardou and Emile Moreau was to be one of the Parisian Winter events. Its success has justified the hope, and the Vaudeville Theatre has printed its Winter's programme in golden letters. As usual with Sardou, crowds flock to the doors at an early hour, only to find disappointment -- unless previously supplied with ticket and seat.

BOSTON, Nov. 18. -- The United States triple-screw cruiser Columbia ran at the rate of 22.81 knots an hour on her official trial trip to-day. The run was over the Government's measured course, 43.968 knots long, extending between Cape Ann, Mass., and Cape Porpoise, Me.
SAYRE, Penn., Nov. 18. -- The much-talked of strike of the Lehigh system went into effect at 10 o'clock to-night.

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 18. -- Charles Muller and Julius Richter, two of the watchmen and caretakers employed at Stimmel's big Summer pavilion and hotel in Whitestone, which was burned shortly after midnight Friday, are looked up in the Town Hall in this place. They were arrested on suspicion of having had something to do with the fire, which is thought to have been of incendiary origin.

WASHINGTON, N.I., Nov. 18. -- The Republic can New -Jercy, believing that they are are plotting to distribute the which they consider the outrecent upheaval in the Republican State Committee and the League of Republican Clubs take all the credit of the great landslide to the meetings.

The solution of all the disorders, criminations, and recriminations in the Sixty-ninth Regiment of the National Guard seems to have been reached by the resignation of Col. James Cavanagh. That the Sixty-ninth Regiment has been badly conducted nobody will deny. Some of its quarrels have been most ridiculous and senseless.

John Y. McKane, accompanied by his son and his counsel, George W. Roderick, arrived from Virginia early yesterday morning, and, after partaking of breakfast at the Clarendon Hotel, started for St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, Fourth Avenue and Forty-second Street, Brooklyn, to attend the funeral of his friend, John Curran.

When the train rolled under the shadow of a Virginia mountain, and made one of those incoherent stops to which "through" trains are somewhat given, the bushybrowed passenger craned his neck out of the window and tried to discover what was the matter, with the usual unsatisfactory result.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- The usual Saturday's half-holiday dullness prevailed to-day. Lehigh Valley declined 2 per cent., to 41, on rumors in morning papers of a probable strike, which, however, is more than doubtful. Pennsylvania was for sale all day at par. Transactions were light and without special feature.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 18. -- Judge Sylvester Barbour of the Police Court this morning paid Michael Murphy $20. Murphy is the man whom on Wednesday the Judge sentenced to five days in jail for alleged contempt of court in putting on his hat as he left the police court. Murphy was released by Judge George W. Wheeler of the Superior Court under habeas corpus proceedings.
CHARACTERS: A WRITER. A PAINTER. AN ELDERLY MAN, dressed in the style of the end of the eighteenth century, tall and of commanding presence, with keen, blue eyes and broad, high brow.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Bank Examiner Albert C. Judson denies the statement made by Directors of the Madison Square Bank that he advised the deception of deposits after the insolvency of the bank was discovered. To the correspondent of The New-York Times Mr. Judson said: "I have heard this same statement made before, but there is not a word of truth in it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Secretory Carlisle has received the report of the work of the Board of United States General Appraisers for the year ending Oct. 31 last, with respect to the reappraisement and classification of imported merchandise. The report occupies twelve typewritten pages, and bears date of yesterday. It shows that there were 2,682 reappraisements last year, as compared with 2,632 for 1892 and 2,635 for 1891.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- A decided improvement in business at all the large local manufactories has been noticed during the past fortnight. Whether it is strictly owing to the passage of the repeal bill or not is conjectural, but the encouraging outlook certainly dates from that time.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Every paper throughout England to-day, one may be sure, has given foremost editorial place to the termination of the great sixteen weeks of cool war. It has been by far the worst and costliest industrial conflict ever known here, and its conclusion is greeted quite like the coming of peace at the end of a campaign in actual warfare.

--One of the bureaus of the Treasury Department received a document last week In which a claimant's name was spelled in two ways. The office sent word to the claimant that he must make an affidavit as to the correct spelling. On Wednesday the affidavit came. The claimant spells his name in one way in the body of the paper and signs it in another. -- Washington Capitol.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 18. -- President Charles L. Burdette of the League of American Wheelmen authorizes the statement that under no conditions will he remain at the head of the league after the annual meeting in February. His term will not expire until one year from that date. Col. Burdette's decision is final, however, and nothing will tempt him to withhold his resignation.

La Tonraine, Balling yesterday for Havre, had a large number of well-know a people among her saloon passengers. Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Goelet started on their annual pilgrimage to the South of Franco, Miss May and Master Kobert Goelet accompanying their parents. Miss M. G. Caidwell, who endowed the Catholic University in Washington, was among La Touraine's voyagers.

Some of the papers of the anti-Democratic kiad -- which is not necessarily Republican, by any means -- amuse themselves with dispatches from Washington describing the leaders in Congress and the Administration as in a great state of excitement over the condition of Hawaii. The thought has a strictly umbilical connection with the wish.

A story was published in certain sensational morning newspapers yesterday stating one of the daughters of the late Jay Gould was engaged to be married to Harry Woodruff, an actor. The names of both Miss Helen and Miss Anna Gould were given by different newspapers as the lady. The following denial has been furnished by George J. Gould.

From The London Daily News. In spite of the learned historian by whom the story has been refuted, there is still a widespread popular belief that there existed in the Middle Ages a female Pope. Pope Joan, as she is called, has even given her name to a game of cards, which is mentioned in Sheridan's "School for Scandal."

QUEENSTOWN, Nov. 18. -- The Cunard Line steamer Lucania, Capt. McKay, from New-York Nov. 11 for Liverpool, arrived here at about 4.30 o'clock this morning. She reports that after leaving New-York she met with continuous violent head gales and a heavy sea. At times the wind came out in terrific squalls.

An account of a frightful experience undergone by a shipwrecked crew and of a daring rescue during the height of a furious gale, was told yesterday when the British steamship Mohican arrived at this port. The vessel is from Swansea, sixteen days out. She brought with her nineteen, men from the Atlantic Ocean.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Lawyer William J. Kearns of Newark will contest the election, of Dr. F.S. Edwards, who, according to the official returns defeated him for the office of Assemblyman for the Seventh District of Essex County. Mr. Kearns has filed a bond with the County Clerk for the recount, which will begin next Saturday.
The Republican Ward Committee of the Twenty-fourth Ward, Brooklyn, has adopted the following resolutions:

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- Chancellor von Caprivi did not delay his challenge to the Opposition in the Reichstag. Yesterday he intimated through President von Levetzow that the commercial treaties with Roumania, Servia, and Spain would be brought up on Monday for both the first and second readings.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- The University of Pennsylvania eleven gave Cornell its worst defeat of the season on the Manheim grounds here to-day, beating the Ithaca collegians 50 to 0. The contest abounded in sensational runs by the Pennsylvania backs. The new system of Quaker interference so successful against Yale, of course, worked like a charm when opposed to the weaker Cornell team.

The old quarrel, resulting from the refusal of Theodore Cochen, Superintendent of the old Union Cemetery, to allow any more burials to be made therein was before Justice Cullen in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, on a motion for a peremptory writ of mandamus. H.F. Lawrence, representing Robert Hauge, made the application.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18. -- The chances now are that one of the first duties of the Republican Legislature just elected will be the investigation of sundry serious charges against the Ohio World's Fair Commission. For weeks rumors have been in the air, and they have now taken such definite form as to call for an inquiry, with respect to the uses to which the $160,000 of appropriation was put.
The second of the series of games for the football championship of Columbia College was played at William's Bridge yesterday morning between the teams representing the junior and senior classes.

The establishment at Reykjavik of a school for the higher education of girls is likely to be soon complete. A peculiar interest is found in the work from the fact that it indicates a total change in social aspects in that country, where the few existing educational institutions of a good order have been provided exclusively for men.

From The Westminster Gazette. Why one should associate a teetotaler with hatred to tobacco would be difficult to say; but one does, and that is why I brought this matter under Dr. Kerr's notice. The inmates who had been great smokers, or who had been in the habit of chewing tobacco, had not been touched by the epidemic.

A short time ago a British sailor was shot by the Mexican military authorities in the City of Mexico under circumstances of peculiar interest. Although the facts in the case are known to but few, the way the fellow behaved himself and the manner in which he met his death will never be forgotten by the officers in charge of the prison.

-- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the dedication of the Centenary Methodist Episcopal Church, at Washington Avenue and One Hun- dred and Sixty-sixth Street, will be celebrated to-day with interesting ceremonies. The exercises will begin at 10:30 o'clock in the morning, with the Rev. John G. Oakley, the pastor of the church, presiding.

--The Touth's Companion prints an exceedingly interesting sketch of Gen. George B. McClellan, by President G.B. McClellan of the Board of Aldermen of this city, as one of a series of prominent men "pictured by their children." "My first definite recollection of my father." he says, "is at a dinner he gave to his corps commanders and staff on the seventh anniversary of the battle of Antietam.

-- The programme of the second Damrosch Sunday concert at Music Hall to-night will be devoted to the memory of Charles Gounod and Peter Ilitsch Tschalkowsky, and will consist entirely of their compositions. Miss Lillian Blauvelt, soprano; Signor Eugenio Vicini, tenor, and Mr. Adolf Brodsky, violinist, will be the soloists.

The second lecture on Art by Mr. John La Farge was delivered in the lecture room of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday morning. Fully as large and as appreciative an audience gathered to hear the lecture yesterday as was attracted to the first discourse. Mr. La Farge continued his subject on the same thorough and comprehensive plan as characterized the initial lecture.

There are doubtless many pathetic cases of patient resignation among the destitute and disabled in this great city, but one of the most peculiar and touching is to be found in a modest apartment on the fourth floor of 1,688 Third Avenue. For seven years has the heroic spirit of gentle Carrie Dickinson struggled there against a cruel fate.

The owner of real property in Brooklyn and in this city, who looks over his tax bills is struck by the enormous fine which he has to pay for owning any property in Brooklyn. People call Brooklyn a city of homes, and hold the superstition that it is an economical place to live in.

"These are trying times for dressmakers," said an industrious member of that class of workers the other day. "It is almost impossible to collect a dollar from a customer, and the more extravagant and exacting the customer, the harder it is to get pay for the work done."

A frame of football under the Gaelio rules was played on Manhattan Field yesterday between the Shamrocks and the Mitchells. Receiver Fresdman expected a big crowd to watch the contest and there was a large force of policemen on hand to prevent a recurrence of the scenes of the Yale-University of Pennsylvania game. Capt. Killilea marched the men onto the grounds, and like the Duke of York of old "he marched them back again."

A Wisconsin woman, Miss Kate Irwin Wheelock, is a pioneer in a fresh field for woman's occupation. For eight years she has been teaching whist to women in Milwaukee. Her initial class grew out of a company of friends who, knowing her proficiency at the game, begged her to give them a little instruction.

In the old times the Scotch sacramental certificates used to bear a sixpenny stamp; a tax on religious almanacs, glass, stone bottles, and advertisements were among the fiscal duties of the past. Of the sufferings entailed by another tax, happily dead and gone, Ebenezer Elliott, the corn-law rhymer, wrote:

The preparations to produce "As You Like It" which the Professional Woman's League is making are attracting so much attention as to almost obscure the very substantial body behind it and the great purpose it is working to accomplish.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, who has been giving Illustrated lectures on geographical and natural history topics for several years at the American Museum of Natural History, has recently completed an arrangement with several clergymen of this city for a series of Illustrated studies from the Life of Christ.

Matthew Loomis was a persistent man, a trait exemplified by his family. There was a succession of six girls before the son and heir, so essential to its dignity and fortune, was born. These preliminaries to parental pride and satisfaction realized, as soon as they could communicate with one another, that they were incidents and not events.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The arrival of the Australia at San Francisco was awaited this morning by a large company of newspaper men in the office of Secretary of State Gresham. Early in the day the report was circulated that the Secretary had been notified, when the Australia had been sighted, that she had been overhauled by a Government dispatch boat, and soon after he had received in brief the news from Minister Willis.

The North River Bridge Company will not be permitted to put out its proposed issue of $100,000,000 worth of bonds as proposed by the Directors, if a decision rendered by the General Terra of the Supreme Court is not reversed. John K. McLanahan, a stockholder, brought suit to restrain the company from making the proposed issue.

Of the anction sales announced for the present week, twenty-seven in number, only five are voluntary, the others being in legal proceedings and ordered by the courts. All sales are to take place at 111 Broadway, unless otherwise stated in the accompanying list:

The incoming of the reform administration in Brooklyn will put an end to the "snap" which some of the heads of the city departments and their political friends and the Democratic Aldermen have enjoyed, at the expense of the tax payers, in connection with the extension of the water supply.

While Arthur Sherburne Hardy opened the garden of his ideas and of his dreams, full of tall scarlet flowers, unexpected perspectives, and crystal brooks tranquil as a illy in the blue air at noon, his listener realized that man is ever similar to himself, and that the pretended contradictions between his aptitudes and his destiny are only apparent.

That inexplicably large army of persons who still have an insatiable desire to see Mme. Adelina Patti, and who will continue to go to her concerts when her reddish-brown hair has turned gray and her voice has become an echo, turned out in full force yesterday afternoon when "the diva" appeared at Music Hall.

Gov. William McKinley of Ohio, after three or four days of "rest "at the "Windsor Hotel, was in such a comfortable condition yesterday that he was able to make several calls "of a purely social nature."

The past week, while not especially notable for the number and variety et the Rales at real estate which were made, is regarded as not unpromising by brokers and agents. Inquiries are getting more frequent, and transactions would be more numerous were there not a disposition on the part of holders of desirable property to hold to the highest kind of prices.

The Municipal Art Society has followed closely in the footsteps of the Sculpture Society in passing resolutions as to the proposed arch in memory of the soldiers and sailors of New-York. Both societies have bad this matter in consideration for some time, and each took the occasion of a first well-attended meeting to bring public attention to bear on the monument.

The commission from the State Board of Charities that is investigating the inner workings of the Elmira Reformatory, especially the alleged brutal acts of its Superintendent, Z.R. Brockway, continued the examination of witnesses in Parlor D of the Astor House yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- How time changes all! The women of the present generation are as utterly unlike their mothers of a generation ago as they would be, for instance, if they belonged to a different race.

Within a handsome portfolio, having delicate ornamentation, the Century Company has collected sixty-four of the choice engravings which have appeared in The Century and St. Nicholas. As a whole they are conspicuous as representing that high standard of illustrative art which has been reached by the best class of American magazines.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 18. -- The idea is gaining ground throughout the State that ex-Gov. Morgan G. Bulkeley will control the nominations of the Republican Party in Connecticut at the State Convention, which will be held in this city early in the Summer of 1894. The old nominees and political affiliations are to be discarded and new men placed at the head of the ticket.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18. -- Gunners arriving from the South report unusually good sport all along the coast and very fine bird shooting in the interior. The "ducking" clubs along the Virginia shore and Albemarle Sound are having excellent success. Bags of more than 100 ducks have been made in a day's shooting.

Mrs. Gray informs us that her aim has been to show as far as possible in Asa Gray's own words his life and his occupation. He wrote an immense mass of letters, but many of them were of a purely scientific character, and would be "uninteresting except to the person addressed." What Mrs. Gray has done through judicious selection is this: she has produced a fairly accurate view of that singularly distinguished man.
The weekly statement of the Associated Banks, issued to-day, shows an Increase in reserve of $7,641,750. The banks now hold $65,470,475 in excess of the legal requirements.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18. -- The phenomenal majority which Ohio has given Gov. McKinley has placed him in the front rank of Presidential possibilities and made his personality and record a matter of considerable public interest to men of both parties. The great mass of Republicans in Ohio are wildly enthusiastic in their protestations that McKinley will be the next President.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Under Sheriff Huben of Ulster County arrived in the city to-day to take back the Italian, Francisco Gregrio, arrested Here yesterday on the charge of murder committed at Glasgow, Ulster County. The Under Sheriff says an affray on Aug. 10, 1890, resulted in the death of two Italians, one of whom was instantly killed and the other died from his injuries some days later.

William Bardon of 400 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, was a prisoner in the Lee Avenue Police Court yesterday charged with grand larceny. Friday afternoon Hugh J. Cavanagh, a meter man employed by the Nassau Gas Company, left his horse and wagon standing on the corner of Lafayette and Schenck Avenues while he went into a house to inspect a meter.

The Horse Show. -- Madison Square Garden was the centre of attraction last week for people of society. Horseflesh and fashions were the leading topics, and it is difficult to say which subject was the more discussed. From the masculine point of view the horses and turnouts were the favorites in the fashionable exchange, but from the women silks, satins, velvets, and "make-ups" received us much attention as the hunters, trotters, and hackneys their pedigrees.

Two eagles have built their nest for years in an old tree which stands not far from the St. Lawrence River in Lisbon, at a spot about eight miles north of Ogdensburg. The spot is a sightly one and the tall trees in this bit of the old forest where the birds make their Summer home is known by the dwellers for miles around.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 18. -- The football team of the Twenty-third Street Yonus Men's Christian Association visited Livings ton this afternoon and played a game with the team of the Staten Island Cricket Club. The visitors wore unable to score. It was a hard-fought battle from beginning to end, bat was free from slagging and no one was injured. Both teams started with end plays, bat splendid tackling prevented material gains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- William C. Renfrew, the Governor of Oklahoma, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior, estimates the population of the Territory proper at 151,304, and that of the Cherokee Strip at 100,000, making a total of 251,304. The report shows that there were 115,000 certificates issued at the booths to intending settlers on the strip, many of them, however, being obtained for speculative purposes.

Mrs. Elizabeth Storrs Meade, the stately President of Mount Holyoke College, told her girls lately a funny story at her own expense. She had been visiting Springfield to attend a temperance meeting and was rather confused by conflicting directions as to the place where the conference was to be held.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18. -- Within a few weeks a very important report will be presented to Gov. McKinley on the subject of taxation. Hearings have been held by the commission appointed last May in Cincinnati, Cleveland, Columbus, and other points in the State, and the opinions of a very large number of the representative men in all branches of business and professional life taken.

"As to the confessor," said Marshal Ney, "leave me alone. I have no need of black coats." At this last phrase, one of the two grenadiers in charge, rising, said to him: "You are wrong, Marshal," and showing him his arm ornamented with several chevrons, added: "I am not as illustrious as you, but I am also a veteran.

Unless something unforeseen arises the new Brazilian cruiser Nictheroy will sail from this port for Brazil waters this afternoon. The big cruiser lay yesterday in the upper bay just off Robbin's Reef Lighthouse from early morning until well into the night. She was constantly surrounded by tugboats discharging ammunition or stores.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The announcement that Admiral Mello has proclaimed the object of the Rio insurrection to be the restoration of the Empire of Brazil, with a grandson of Dom Pedro and son of Isabella and Count d'Eu for Emperor, has occasioned no surprise here.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 18. -- Fearful hearts are beating in this village to-night. Fathers have deserted warm firesides and mothers have sent their sons forth to rid Freeport of an apparition. Men are patrolling the streets armed with weapons of war of modern and ancient make, ready to shoot the strange being if it appears in their path.

The yacht Navahoe, with Mr. and Mrs. Royal Pheips Carroll on board, arrived here yesterday after a voyage of nearly seven weeks across the Atlantic. For the first part of the voyage it was smooth sailing, but when in sight of this country a gale struck the yacht that for a time made things very unpleasant to say the least.

The moral revolution, which found final expression in a political one, in Brooklyn has already begun to produce results. It was only yesterday that the smoke of battle cleared off. To-day the field of the conflict is clear and the work of removing its fatal vestiges almost completed.
