In the old time men and women who were mere acquaintances exchanged kisses in public, and with a certain amount of ceremony, and a visitor to whom it was desired to show special civility was always received with a kiss.

One of the most interesting places in Southeastern Alaska is the Indian village of Kasa-an, situated on the shores of the Skowe Arm, one of the inland passages with which this part of Alaska is so liberally canaled. This place is out of the track of vessels, and is rarely visited by the tourist, the only white visitors being occasional traders.

From the personal receipt book of an English housekeeper the following formula for a real English plum pudding -- the Christmas pudding -- has been copied. These puddings are better made several weeks before using, and will, in fact, keep for months, needing only to be warmed through before serving:

Some remarks on the needs of the American stage in this column last Sunday have called forth an expression of approval and some appropriate suggestions from a reader of this journal who is deeply interested in the theatre. He says:
The following protest was received yesterday, by Mayor Boody, Controller Halsey Corwin, and City Auditor Weber, members of the Columbian Audit Committee:

Gen. John A. Dix, while Governor of this State, once said: "If there is one thing to which a city may point with pride it is a well-organized, well-equipped, well-disciplined, and well-housed body of citizen soldiery."

"Silver, Gold, and Diamonds" made a sparkling theme for the lecture by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore before the teachers of the City and State of New-York, at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday morning. The photographic representations of these precious metals and stones which were used in illustration were from the Mines and Mining Building at the World's Fair, and the lecture itself was devoted largely to this portion of the great Chicago Exposition.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Wheat was weaker to-day and prices were lower. The opening was 1/4c higher for December and 1/4@1/8c higher for May, but weakened off 3/8c, then advanced 1/4c, but again became weak and declined 5/8c for December and 3/4c for May, held steadier, and the close was 1/4c lower for December and 1/4@1/8c lower for May than yesterday's final figures.

V. If there be any one thing in the empirical psychology of the past which has been considered settled past all controversy, it is the unity and continuity of human personality. Whatever might be believed or doubted concerning the after life, for this life at least believers and skeptics alike are united in the full assurance of a true, permanent, and unmistakable self.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- Yale is liable to follow Harvard's example the coming week and line up her 'Varsity football team against an eleven composed of graduate players. Harvard was fortunate in having enough veterans early in the season to undertake the feat successfully. At Yale football alumni have not been as numerous this year as usual, and eleven have not been here at any time this Fall.

The police were notified yesterday that an attempt had been made to kidnap one of the colored boys in the "Pickaninny Band," playing at the Academy of Music. Detective Wade of Inspector McLaughlin's staff, who is investigating the matter, when seen last night thought that if there was anything at all in the story it was probably a case of contagious nightmare.

In any large assemblage of elegantly-costumed women it always is an interesting study to note the wonderful variety of garniture. If it be true that a woman's costume is indicative of her character, then the trimming should be studied with especial care, as certainly no detail of dress is possessed of more influence in the general effect.

The Brazilian flag was broken out yesterday for the first time on board the cruiser Nictheroy. Aa its folds fluttered to the breeze the executive officer called upon the crew to greet with three cheers the flag under which they sailed.

A story to the effect that young Mr. "Gus" Pfizer had married Miss Nina Farrington, the English burlesque artist, and gone off to Europe, was current yesterday in the up-town cafes frequented by actors and clubmen.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted at 69 1/2 @ 70 on Saturday.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Having read with so much satisfaction your excellent newspaper for the past month or more, and feeling fully satisfied of your purpose to drive to the wall the corrupt men who have for so long been masquerading as Democrats, I now presume to beg space to ventilate my feelings.

-- Maine has other vigorous veterans besides ex-Mayor Thomas, Portland's nonagenarian, Col. Benjamin F. Eastman. Portland's oldest citizen, has just celebrated his ninety-third birthday, and is in good health. Gen. Neal Dow is eighty-nine. ExGov. Alonzo Garcelon is eighty-one, and of the same age is the Hon.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- The greatest activity during the past week was in Troy Gas stock, for which a good demand appeared. All the floating stock was absorbed, and the bid price advanced 5 per cent., from 120 to 125. Consolidated Car Heating stock was offered at a concession, and the asked price declined 3 per cent., to 57.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The Cragatons of Highland Falls and the engineers of West Point played an exciting game here to-day. The field was in bad shape, and as a result there was constant fumbling on both sides. The engineers had the heaviest team, bat the cragatons by their quick and low tackling and clever interference were more than a match for the soldiers.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 19. -- Thousands of men thronged the platform of the Lehigh Valley station all day to-day, and although nothing of an alarming nature occurred growing out of the trainmen's strike, excitement was intense. Every incoming train was awaited with interest, but they were few and far between.
The Sunday Democrat announced yesterday that the following petition to be presented to the Legislature was to be circulated among the ninety Roman Catholic parishes in the State:

All Brooklyn remembers with horror the atrocious murder of Grocer Christian Lucca by Charles McElvaine, on the night of Aug. 22, 1889. Last night that murder was again brought forcibly to the minds of the residents by the marriage of Lucca's widow to William Leslie, a Scotchman.

Robert Grier Monroe has sent out to many of those who were interested in the May Convention movement of last year, a circular, as a preliminary step to the formation of a new Democratic organization in this city. He is acting for several men whose names have been conspicuous in antiTammany movements in this city for years.

There is evidently something the matter with the intellectual processes of a man who thinks to reform society and equalize the distribution of the goods of life by firing a pistol through the windows at DELMONICO'S. But the logical irregularity involved in this procedure ought not to protect the victim of it from the consequences of his own acts.

-- Lieut. C.L. Collins, Inspector of Small-Arms Practice in the Department of the Colorado, says in his annual report that the competitions in target shooting have shown that men with light blue eyes rank highest, followed in their order by dark blue, slate blue, light brown, dark brown, and black. In the colored troops light blue eyes again stand at the top.

The orator before the Senate called this an "age of progress." He was wrong. "Progress" does not half express it: it is an age of revolution. Revolutions carried on, not by armies, but by discoverers, inventors and brain-workers. It is a marvelous age, an age when the ordinary will not be accepted, when the best is demanded.

The future of the season at the Fifth Avenue Theatre seems to be very uncertain. Rose and Charles Coghlan were originally booked to appear at the house Dec. 4, but they have voluntarily relinquished that date, and are now announced for Dec. 11, when the first production of Oscar Wilde's "A Woman of No Importance" is to be made.

Andrew M. Rule, at one time chief bookkeeper of the Second National Bank of New-York, was arrested yesterday at the Getty House, in Yonkers, for forgery. He was apprehended by Capt. J.M. Fuller of this city, representing the Fifth Avenue Bank, corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, and Capt. Mangin of the Yonkers police.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1@2 per cent., the average being about 1 1/2 per cent.

Park Commissioner Paul Dana will carry his fight for a sidewalk on the outside of the proposed Harlem River Speedway before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. The Park Board, against Mr. Dana's vote, declared in favor of only one sidewalk, and that on the inside. Mr. Dana sent the following letter to Controller Myers Saturday:

The hush at the close of the services in the Hansom Place Methodist Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning was broken by a cheer. It was such a cheer as is heard at a political meeting. Its cause was the announcement from the pulpit of the presence in the church of Governorelect William McKinley of Ohio.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 19. -- Deputy Collector Caldwell and posse, who on Wednesday captured a dozen illicit distilleries in a raid among Randolph County moonshiners, and killed Andrew Howell, near Christiana, while he and others were attempting to rescue the prisoners, had another battle with, moonshiners in the same locality last night.

Charles Wendel, forty-eight years old, living at 308 East Twenty-sixth Street, and employed in A.D. Matthews's soda water factory in the same street, was found by a policeman from the East Thirty-fifth Street Station at 5 o'clock Sunday morning, sit- ting, with overcoat and jacket gone, on the stoop of an apartment house at 164 East Twenty-eighth Street.

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Two "Jack the Kissers" are alarming Rahway's pret- tiest girls. These "kissers" have, during the past few days, been waylaying unes- corted girls in the dimly-lighted and tree-shaded streets, and kissing and hugging them.

No inference can be drawn from Minister WILLIS'S pacific speech, in presenting his credentials to "President" DOLE of the provisional Government at Honolulu, except that it is his purpose to proceed with his official task in a friendly spirit and by means of peaceful negotiation. But there can be no doubt as to the actual task that has been imposed upon him by the Administration at Washington.

Dr. Gerardus Wynkoop of 128 Madison Avenue is in financial difficulties. G. Sewell Bonner has been appointed receiver of his property by Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court, in supplementary proceedings against him by Walter S. Johnston, a judgment creditor for $3,644.
Quite a number of sales of real estate at auction are set down for to-day at 111 Broadway. The list in detail follows:

It pleases some of our Republican contemporaries to represent the White House as the scene of a series of anxious conferences within the past ten days, at which various "Administration" leaders in Congress are reported to have given, the President their observations on the significance of the recent elections.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- It is believed here that Dr. L.S. Merriam, an instructor in political economy in Cornell University, and Miss M.L. Yeargin, a student, who went out in a rowboat on Cayuga Lake yesterday afternoon, are drowned. As they did not come back last night it was supposed that they had been overtaken by a storm and had put ashore and taken shelter in some farm house.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Although the Reichstag has resumed work, the movements of the opposition parties show no more tendencies toward a coalition against the Government than they did during the session when the Army bill was passed. Every group of anti-Government Deputies -- Clericals, Ultra-Conservative Agrarians, anti-Semites, Socialists, and Richter Radicals -- will introduce independent motions.
Interesting lectures on astronomical subjects were delivered by Herman S. Davis and William P. Hallock at the New-York Academy of Sciences, Sections of Astronomy, last Monday in Hamilton Hall.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 18. -- The local stock market, although somewhat quiet, shows an undertone of better feeling from the increased inquiry for the better class of securities. Lime Rock National Bank Stock is offered freely at 86. There seems to be some difference of opinion among the Directors as to the probabilties of a decreased dividend.

A man of medium size dressed in black, and wearing a full, dark beard, walked quietly into the vestibule of St. Patrick's Cathedral, through the Fifth Avenue door, on Friday afternoon. He stopped a moment and looked around him, and then stepped back into the deep shadow in the vestibule at the side of the outer door.

We hope that the prosecution of the Government's suit against the Bell Telephone Company for the annulment of the Berliner patent will not be delayed as the Government's original suit against that company has been. The original suit was begun in 1886, and the taking of testimony has not yet been completed.

Owing to the extraordinary number of collisions on the railroads since the beginning of the present year, the great loss of life caused by them, and the fact that almost all of these collisions were due to astounding carelessness or the reckless disobedience of orders by train officers, the legal proceedings which, follow these so-called accidents deserve the careful attention of the public.

EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 19. -- The sympathizers with the revolutionary movement against Mexico are enthusiastic to-day. While no definite news came in from Corralitos, a circular was freely distributed today upon the streets, which, it was said, would not have appeared if that strategic point had not been captured by the rebels.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The storm which swept the United Kingdom all day yesterday was still furious at 12 o'clock to-day. Throughout last night and this morning reports of shipwreck were received almost incessantly.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $7,64,1,750. The banks now hold $65,470,475 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show a decrease in loans of $1,253,200, an increase in specie of $1,279,400, an increase in legal tenders of $3,598,400, an increase in deposits of $8,994,200, and a decrease in circulation of $279,700.
PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 19. -- There is trouble in the First Methodist Church over the forthcoming production of the sacred can- tata, "Queen Esther," in the Opera House, Nov. 27 and 28.

The funeral services over the body of the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems will be held in the Church of the Strangers at noon to-morrow. There will be eight pall bearers, from five of whom acceptances to act as such were received by last evening at the house of his son-in-law. Marion J. Verdery, at 145 West Seventy-sixth Street.

NEW-CASTLE, Penn., Nov. 19. -- Mrs. Mary Williams, an old lady who lives with her son, near Enon Valley, was startled by a knock at her back door. She asked what was wanted, and was told that a traveler was taken sick by the wayside, and desired shelter. Mrs. Williams opened the door, and was confronted by three masked men, who pointed revolvers at her head and warned her to make no noise.
The full score of the thirteenth game and corrected moves in the fourteenth game of the Tschigorin-Tarrasch tournament are given as follows.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- During the last week the Varsity football team has been steadily improving. Previous to the game with the University or Pennsylvania the playing of the team was spasmodic. After the men were thoroughly rested from the Philadelphia game they practiced with a snap and dash far superior to anything seen in games here this Fall.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The strike of the employes of the Lehigh Valley sys- tem has extended to this city. Last night the employes of the New-Jersey Division held a meeting in Masonic Hall, Pacific Ave- nue and Maple Street, and declared them- selves in sympathy with their striking col- leagues on the other division of the road.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 19. -- Two bicycle records were broken at West Side Park yesterday. M.F. Dernberger of Buffalo, N.Y., in a flying-start half-mile dash made a record of 0:54, beating Johnson's record of 0:55 by one second. J.R. Bliss of Chicago, with a standing start, in a half-mile dash, made a record of 0:56 3-5. The best previous record was by Johnson, being 0:59 2-5.

Through the kindness of Miss Grace H. Dodge, Mrs. Peter M. Bryson, and Mr. F.F. Thompson of the Board of Trustees, the equipment of the domestic science laboratory has recently received important additions. By the gift of three valuable microscopes, one of which is furnished with a one-twelfth objective and magnifies 875 diameters, the investigations in bacteriology will be materially aided.

With favorable weather the projected contest at Fleetwood to-morrow between Alix, 2:07 3/4, and Directum, 2:05 1/4, should furnish, the harnessracing event of the year. The mare and the stallion were taken up to the track yesterday morning.

Three vessels arrived from Brazilian ports yesterday. They were the Belgian steamship Liebnitz from Rio, the steamship Delambre from Fernambuco, and the Rosse from Santos. Rear Admiral Stanton, the United States naval officer who was relieved from command for saluting the flag of the insurgent Admiral, was expected to arrive by the Liebnitz, but he was not on board.

There was not a seat to be had anywhere in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning when Prof. Felix Adler lectured before the Society for Ethical Culture on Buddhism. Even the highest gallery was crowded, and people stood patiently in the aisles during the hour and a half occupied by the lecturer.
NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Minnie Keveloh, fifteen years old, has dis- appeared as completely and as myster- iously as if a yawning of the earth had engulfed her.

No further official action concerning the resignation of the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, pastor of the West Presbyterian Church, can be taken until Wednesday, to which time the meeting of last Wednesday was adjourned. There seems to be little doubt, however, that Dr. Paxton's resignation will be accepted at that time.

Charles W. Gardner, former agent of the Parkhurst society spent yesterday in the Tombs contrary to his expectation. There is no doubt of his release to-day. Stephen B. Brague, Gardner's lawyer, said he would get the order of release signed by one of the Judges of the General Term of the Supreme Court the first thing in the morning, and after having it certified in the County Clerk's office would take it to the Tombs.

A mysterious and suspicious-looking application for a street-railway franchise was sneaked into the meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon. It is one of the coolest propositions ever entertained by even that body of franchise givers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Bureau of Engraving and Printing has become a competitor for the award of the contract for printing United States postage stamps. This interesting piece of news was communicated to Postmaster General Bissell at a late hour this afternoon. It is likely to work a great change in the methods of the Post Office Department, and result in a big annual saving to the Government.

Such distinguished Republicans as Denis Shea, John Simpson, and Fred S. Gibbs will be delighted with the way in which the committee appointed last Thursday night by the Republican County Committee to "investigate the Republican organization in this city and its leaders," and "to recommend a plan of reorganization if it be found necessary," began its work in one of the luxurious parlors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

The scheme of starting new anti-Tammany organizations in this city appears to be very popular just now with politicians outside of the Wigwam. Besides the movement being engineered by ex-Mayor William R. Grace and others through Col. Robert Grier Monroe, another "anti-Tammany Democracy" is to be launched to-night.
The new Brazilian cruiser Nictheroy sailed from this port early yesterday morning. She anchored during the forenoon about three miles to seaward of the Scotland Lightship.

In his search for the truth about the smash of the Madison Square Bank, District Attorney Nicoll was assisted yesterday by Bank Examiner E.L. Judson and William B. Putney, attorney for Director Ronald T. McDonald. Mr. Judson came from Albany to deny the statements of attorneys for various Directors that upon his advice the bank received deposits after It was known to be insolvent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The report of James H. Blount, Special Commissioner to the Hawaiian Islands, is herewith presented in full:

The reopening of the Casino under a new management and the first performance of a new operetta attracted an old-fashioned Casino first-night audience last evening. Every one knows what kind of an audience that is, for it is never seen anywhere else. It was a well-disposed audience, ready and even anxious to be pleased.

STAFFORDSVILLE, Conn., Nov. 20 -- The Phoenix Woolen Company, Riverside Woolen Company, Central Woolen Company, and the Staffordsville Woolen Company's mills all started up last week. The Warren Woolen Company, Mineral Springs Manufacturing Company, the Rawitzer Brothers, all woolen mills, and the Smith Cooleys shoddy mill, will start up this week.

-- Mrs. John J. Atkins of Philadelphia is the possessor of the pen which Robert Ralkes of England used 113 years ago in inscribing the names of the children who attended the first Sunday school, which was founded by him in Gloucester. It is a goose quill, and was a Christmas present to him.

Charles W. Gardner, the ex-Superintendent of the Parkhurst Society, whose sentence to imprisonment for two years for blackmail was reversed by the General Term of the Supreme Court last Friday, was released at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon from the Tombs, where he has been confined since last February pending on appeal on his case.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Maria Esposito, for shooting Nicolo Salinadi, in Orange, last Summer, because he had spoken slightingly of her, was to-day sentenced to a year's imprisonment in the penitentiary by Judge Kirkpatrick. Her husband and her three-year-old child stood beside her when the sentence was pronounced.

Charles J. Edwards, an independent Democrat, who worked hard for the election of Charles A. Schieren to the Brooklyn Mayoralty, has announced that a "non-partisan dinner has been tendered to the Hon. St. Clair McKelway."

Apparently the strikers on the Lehigh Valley Road had as good cause for striking as is often offered. They complain that their employers have not only treated them unjustly but have broken faith with them, and that their efforts to obtain a peaceable redress of their grievances have been made in vain, so that there was really nothing left for them but to quit an employment in which they could not obtain justice.

The extracts from Commissioner BLOUNT'S correspondence with the State Department preliminary to his final report on the situation in Hawaii, which we published yesterday, confirms in the most positive manner the conviction that the provisional Government was the product of a conspiracy and was forced upon the country by Minister STEVENS through "an abuse of the authority of the United States."

-- The Pilgrim is in the navy yard dock at Boston. Her seventeen-ton tin has been removed, and noon she will be a steamer. She will be 123 feet over all, 23 feet beam, 5 feet 6 Inches draught, she will be equipped with, two independent compound condensing engines. each of 130 horse power. They will turn two screws 4 feet in diameter, and the boat is expected to develop a speed of 14 knots.

The poor of this city have many reasons for being grateful to Nathan Straus. In Summer and in Winter he has been their friend. His charity has enabled them in I warm weather to secure for their children many of those helps to helpfulness which otherwise would never find their way into the homes of the poor.

Andrew Carnegie last evening told the Congregational Club, at its regular meeting in the St. Denis, what noble thoughts it is possible to think after millions have been acquired. There were 225 people there to hear him, and they found many jokes concealed in his well-worded expressions of philanthropy.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 20 -- The freight business of the Lehigh Valley Railroad was practically tied up to-day, and the passenger business materially crippled by the strike of the employes. The last section of the road to go out was that between Easton and New-York.

The east-bound shipments of freight out of Chicago last week aggregated 55,238 tons, against 54,932 in the preceding week, and 71,624 for the same week last year. Lake Shore brought 11,910 tons, Michigan Central 5,132, Wabash 4,383, Fort Wayne 3,551, Pan Handle 7,513, Baltimore and Ohio 2,745, Grand Trunk 2,921, Nickel Plate 4,566, Erie 5,903, Big Four 1,617.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Wheat opened firm, became weak, reacted and closed steady. First prices were 1/8@3/8c higher than Saturday's close, declined 5/8c, rallied 34c, receded 1/4c. advanced 3/4c, and closed 3/8@1/2c lugher for December and the same for May than the closing prices of Saturday. At the opening very little wheat was offered and shorts were obliged to bid the market up to obtain any property.
BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Minnie Maddern-Fiske produced "Hester Crewe" at the Tremont Theatre to-night. The audience was large and appreciative, and Mrs. Fiske was welcomed back to the stage most heartily.

From The Brooklyn Eagle, Oct. 27. It may be true that no flrst-class and unobjectionable Democrats can be obtained to stump for the party so long as, and because, Maynard is urged on the people; but there is no more necessity for leading up the Boody canvass with the Maynard issue than there was of loading up the Boody canvass with the Aldermen and Supervisors who were dropped, turned down, and wiped out.

From The Brooklyn Eagle, Sept, 10. Events touching the Mayoralty are shaping favorably to Democratic prospects, irrespective of democratic deserts, and in all likelihood, irrespective of the popular will. The politicians have, apparently, that advantage over the people which stocked cards or loaded dice give the gamester.

The comprehensive report submitted by President Charles F. Mayer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, at the annual meeting of the stockholders in Baltimore yesterday, made a fairly satisfactory showing. For the fiscal year ended June 30 the gross earnings were $26,214,807, the expenses $19,041,981, and the net earnings $7,172,825, the latter being $271,575 less than the net earning's of the previous year.

At a meeting of the Executive Board of the reorganized Cordage Trust held yesterday arrangements were made to resume operations. The meeting was secret, but it is understood that a complete report of the proceedings will be given out to-day. The reorganized trust will have a capital of $3,000,000 in cash and $5,000,000 in collaterals secured by New-York and New-England banks.

-- The football match between the Chicago Athletic Association and the Boston Athletic Association, to be played at Boston on Thanksgiving Day, promises to be a sharp contest. The make-up of the Boston team will De about as follows: Whittren, left end; Turkey, left, tackle; Whitman, left guard: Hastings, centre; Fay, right guard; Waters, Captain and right tackle; Wardner, right end; Belfield, quarter; Peters, left half; Anthony, right half; McNear, full back.

Republican journals and other upholders of McKinleyism are making a great noise about the recent protest of certain persons from Northern Alabama against the proposed removal of the duties on bituminous coal and iron ore. If we are to believe the assertions of these persons, the placing of these raw materials on the free list would rain the iron industry of Alabama and bring a great many people to the poorhouse.

The Fencers Club held a housewarming last night, and at the same time did honor to the new master at arms, Prof. L. Vauthier of the Cercle d'Escrime de la Madeleine, in Paris. It is the first reception the club has given in the new quarters, 37 West Twenty-second Street, since it took possession last Spring.

The New-York Reform Club Saturday evening hung on the walls of its lecture room two portraits which complete its gallery of former Presidents and as masterpieces adorn a room where so many men famous in the reform progress of the day have made themselves heard in favor of political purity.

-- Mr. J.A. Parshall of The Delhi Gazette modestly disclaims the honor of being the oldest working printer in the United States. He says that Isaac K. Williams, his old schoolmate and venerable friend of The Cooperstown Freeman's Journal, is nearly six years his senior, and that Charles Holt of The Kankakee (Ill.) Gazette is but five years younger than Mr. Williams.

-- The German military bands which are to give a series of concerts in the Madison Square Garden, beginning Thursday evening, will arrive in New-York by the West Shore Railroad on Thursday morning at 7 o'clock. It is probable that a large delegation from various German societies will meet the bands at the railway station and escort them to the Garden.

Policeman Jesse Hatfield of the Prospect Park, Brooklyn, mounted squad, who saved several lives in the park Sunday by stopping a runaway horse, lost his own life yesterday by falling under the wheels of a trolley car.
Frank Ellison, the ex-clubman and former gentleman of leisure, will be a convict to-day, unless the unexpected happens.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The smallpox epidemic here has become so alarming that extreme measures have been adopted by the health authorities. All Italians in this vicinity are being vaccinated. Children from the infected districts have been excluded from the public schools. Mayor Rankin and a number of prominent officials were vaccinated to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The advance publication in The New-York Times of this morning of Commissioner Blount's current report on his investigation into the Hawaiian revolution and the annexation movement created about the liveliest excitement at the national capital that has agitated this quiet town for many years.

One section of the new West Washington Market, a two-story building occupied by a number of produce dealers, was badly wrecked by fire late last night. The building in which the fire broke out is 125 feet long and 40 feet wide, bounded by Hewitt, Thompson, Lawton, and Thirteenth Avenues. The fire first appeared in that portion of the structure occupied by D.A. Valentine, on the corner of Thompson and Thirteenth Avenues.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 20 -- P.M. There was some slight activity at the opening of to-day's market and considerable strength, but before the end of the first hour weakness developed and dullness ensued. Again, in the last half hour there was a slight revival in trading, but it was at the expense of prices.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 20 -- The strike on the Wyoming Division of the Lehigh Valley Road is assuming a rather serious aspect. While the officials, in reply to all inquiries, say, " All passenger trains are running," the fact remains that, although this may be partially true, it does not reflect the situation by any means.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Naval officers extract much satisfaction from the result of the trial trip of the Columbia. The result is not surprising. The preliminary trips and the predictions of the engineers prepared every one in the Navy Department for the great speed developed by the Columbia's engines.

It is all an old story, of course, about the return to us each Autumn of the regular company of the Lyceum Theatre. These actors go away just as the strawberries are ripe and return about the time to shoot ducks. They always have the same sort of welcome from a house crowded by the nicest kind of nice people.

Means to continue the sessions of the evening schools were found yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, but not until after Controller Theodore W. Myers had sharply criticised the action of the Board of Education. Last week the, latter board gave notice that it needed a transfer of $15,758.19 for salaries, and $5,674.46 for gas, in order to keep the night schools open until Jan. 1.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 20 -- A correspondent called at ex-President Harrison's home to-day to obtain an expression on Commissioner Blount's report, printed in to-day's New-York Times. When the object of the call had been explained, Gen. Harrison said:

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- One of the first steps contemplated by the Republicans after the organization of the Legislature is the adoption of closure in the Senate. Under the present rules the chances of tumult and turbulence are increased with a hot-headed Democratic President and an aggressive Republican majority on the floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The Powderly-Hayes fight in the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor reached a climax this afternoon when the General Secretary-Treasurer openly withdrew his charges of malfeasance in office against the General Master Workman and his colleagues on the Executive Board, A.W. Wright and John Devlin.

The meeting of the Congregational Union in the Bible House yesterday was well attended. The Rev. Frank S. Child of Fairfield,Conn., read a paper on " The Congress of Religions; Its Bearings Upon Christianity at Home and Abroad."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Lehigh Valley opened at 39, a decline of 4 from Saturday's closing, in consequence of the strike. The management is quite confident that it will be able to carry the matter to a successful issue. Where employes refuse to obey orders they will be paid off and discharged.

-- All of the Western railroads are at present engaged in a revision of their cards, and a number of radical changes will go into effect next Sunday. The time between Chicago and Omaha, and Sioux City will be shortened fifty minutes.

In a few days little glass jars labeled "Hospital Saturday and Sunday Collection" will make their appearance on the elevated railroad stations and in all other places where they will be sure to catch the public eye. At the meeting of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association held in St. Luke's Hospital yesterday, it was decided to make the annual appeal to the public for contributions much earlier this year than usual.

The tenants at 180, 182, 184, and 186 East Seventy-fifth Street were greatly alarmed yesterday afternoon by an influx of illuminating gas into the houses. The gas filled the apartments on the lower floors to such an extent that the tenants, many of whom were made sick, were compelled to leave the houses.

The Hon. WILLIAM McKINLEY, Governor and Governor-elect of the State of Ohio, is spending a few days in New-York, where he has, as he has in nearly every part of the country, many friends and still more numerous admirers. Some of these with pardonable zeal are talking in a manner highly flattering about the Governor as the "logical candidate" of his party for the Presidency in 1896.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20 -- Honore Mercier, son of ex-Premier Mercier; Alfred Lelland, and Paul de Mantigny, all three students, were arrested this morning charged with attempting to blow up the Nelson Monument, on Jacques Cartier Square. The police, having heard that a plot had been arranged to destroy the monument, were on the watch, and at an early hour to-day captured the three young men on Jacques Cartier Square.

The handsome gold medal offered by The New-York Times for individual excellence at the World's Fair sports will be cut in two, and F.C. Puffer of the New-Jersey Athletic Club and C.W. stage of the Cleveland Athletic Club each given a half. This will be done in accordance with the wishes of the members of the Board of Governors of the Amateur Athletic Union, who were asked to make the proper disposition of the trophy.

Army Notes. CAPT. EDMUND L. ZALINSKI -- So much of War Department order as directs Capt. Edmund L. Zaliuski, Fifth Avenue, to report to the Retiring Bourn at ban Fransisco for examination is revoked and he will report in person to the Board at governors Island, New-York City.

The activity that has developed in the Republican Party since election day was stimulated last night by the proceedings of the County Committee at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and by the election of the Nominating Committee at the Republican Club, in Fifth Avenue. Over 200 of the 500 members of the club were present.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- The practice at Yale to-day was secret. McClung came this morn ing and joined Rhodes. Corbin, Tompkins, and Knapp. Capt. Hinkey is now satisfied that enough coachers are here, and he will leave the work entirely with the number now here till the team leaves for Springfield. This afternoon the eleven lined up in exactly the same way Yale will face Harvard, which is the same as Yale played Pennsylvania.

There has been a general impression that "A Parlor Match" was written some time ago, and another that last night's presentation of it at the Bijou. Theatre was not its first. Both were wrong. "A Parlor Match" proved itself to be a wild and beaming novelty, better by far than its predecessor of the same name and "plot," and a laughter-compeller of more horse power than the cruiser Columbia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The 'Varsity practice to-day indicates a slight reaction from the effects of the sharp game with West Point. The team only succeeded in scoring two touch-downs against the "scrub," and the scrub scored upon them.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 20 -- A warrant was obtained to-day in the County Court for the arrest or Congressman W.A. McKeighan on the charg of not paying a board bill. A.L. Hoover Son proprietors of the Lindell Hotel, are the complainants, and the defendant is the Populist Representative from the Fifth Nebraska District. The bill, which is $50, was contracted during the Senatorial fight last Winter, and the Messrs.

Mrs. Annie Gibert got a decree of divorce yesterday from her husband, Audinel Gibert, by Judge Bischoff of the Court of Common Pleas. The trial of the suit before Judge Bischoff attracted a great deal of attention during its progress, because of the social prominence of the people concerned.

Our readers will find in THE TIMES this morning the report of Mr. BLOUNT, the American Commissioner to Hawaii. We print the document in full because of the extreme importance of the principle involved in the policy of the Government toward Hawaii, and because it contains so careful and complete a review not only of rocent events on the islands but of their history as bearing on these events.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The great coal strike is ended. Acting on the decision of the conference held last week at the Foreign Office, work was generally resumed at the collieries this morning. There were some few pits, however, that were not opened owing to the fact that fallen earth blocked the ways.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -- When asked to-day what he thought of the report of Commissioner Blount, H.W. Severance, late Consul General at Hawaii, who came up by the Australia Saturday last, said:

NEWTON, N.C, Nov. 20 -- Pleasant weather farored the beginning of the Eastern Field Trials Club's trials to-day, which opened with the Derby. There were nineteen starters. Birds were found in abandance. twenty-two birds being the camber to-day. The work, except that of five or six dogs, was inferior. The Judges are Titus, Bradley, and Stoddard. Beryl was the only one of the first three braces which showed any particular merit.
MADRID, Nov. 20 -- Senor Moret, Minister of Foreign Affairs, to-day denied that Admiral Mello had proclaimed the empire in Brazil.

John Y. McKane found it impossible to attend the meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday, owing to a pressure of personal business. While the Supervisors were engaged in passing numerous bills, the Chief of the Coney Island police force was seated at his desk, on the second floor of 40 Court Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- In addition to the "current" and "final" reports by ex-Commissioner Blount. Secretary Gresham received from him a number of minor re
A squabble over the payment of 15 cents resulted yesterday in a verdict for $1,000 damages against John Ehrman of Long Island City.

Henry Stock, a retired druggist, whose mind had become unbalanced through illness, and who suffered from melancholia, committed suicide Monday afternoon by shooting himself througrh the head, at his home, 349 Seventh Avenue. Mr. Stock was left alone in his apartments on Monday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The bull clique in West Chicago Street Railway felt uneasy this morning when the market was flooded with the rights of that company, not one of which could be sold for more than $4. The indisposition of the present shareholders to enlarge their line has not as yet, however, affected the stock much.

John Peterson, twenty-three years old, a driver for C. Koester's Pie Baking Company, Brooklyn, was thrown out of his wagon by a trolley car yesterday and hurled through the air, landing in the street with such force as to break his right leg. Peterson was driving down Fulton Street.

-- The wish has been so often expressed by the patrons and passengers of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company that the fast express steamers of the Mediterrauean line of this company should stop at the Azores on their voyage to Gibraltar. Genoa, and Naples, that the North German Lloyd have now finally decided to offer an opportunity to the traveling public to reach the Azores.

The foreign exchange market was dull and firm. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.84 for sixty-day bills and $4.861/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4-83@$4.831/4@$4.831/2 for sixtyday bills, $4.851/2@$4.853/4 for demand, $4.86@ $4.861/4 for cable transfers, and $4.813/4 for commercial.

-- Attorneys Samuel Dickson and Thomas Hart. Jr., representing the Philadelphia, and Reading Railroad receivers, appeared before Judge Dallas in the United States Circuit Court in Philadelphia, yesterday, and asked for the confirmation of the report of Special Master Crawford, in which the latter recommended the approval of the exchange of bonds and extension of time in Speyer Co.s loan to the Reading.

Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren returned to Brooklyn yesterday from his vacation in the South. The trip did Mr. Schieren much good. His cheeks are ruddy, his voice fresh and clear and all effects of the heavy campaign through which he passed with such tremendous success have disapppeared. Mr. Schieren said he felt thoroughly rejuvenated by his trip.

The frequently-mentioned performance by women of " As You Like It " was given at Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon. The house was crowded and the performance was smooth, the only hitches being in the management of the scenery, and that was the fault of the only men on the stage, the scene shifters. That was what the ushers told each other in anxious tones, and the ushers were an important feature of the afternoon.

The Brazilian cruiser Nictheroy sailed from American waters at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. When last seen the Nictheroy was standing to the southward and eastward under a full head of steam. The first port of the Nictheroy will make will probably be the Barbados, West Indies.

At a meeting of a special committee which has been examining the affairs of the American Casualty Insurance and Security Company held yesterday at the company's offices, 44 Pine Street, it was practically determined that the company's business shall be closed up.

The publication of Mr. BLOUNT'S report, making a complete exposure of the conspiracy for setting up a provisional Government at Honolulu for the purpose of securing the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands to the United States, can have no other effect than a total collapse of the defense of that disreputable performance.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 21. -- A little difference which occurred yesterday at the practice between Capt. Trenchard and Balhet has resulted seriously, perhaps, for Princeton. Balliet was reproved by Capt. Trenchard for his lack of spirit in the play, and after several ineffectual attempts to arouse him he was transferred to the scrub, and his place was taken by Crowdis.

The saddier's art in the Middle Ages was brought to a degree of perfection which the present age has never seen and scarcely realizes. The horse cloth, which was introduced about the twelfth century, and the covering for the haunches and neck, represented in Norman manuscript, are rich with armorial decorations and are often blazoned with numerous quartering.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 21. -- The following call, signed by W. R. Wilson, Chairman of the Executive Committee, is being sent out by Secretary W. S. McKean, who has established the headquarters of the Democratic Society of this city, where he is again residing:

It may seem strange that the first proposition for an amendment to international law that is plainly in the interest of progress and civilization should emanate from Spain. It is not strange, however, that the country which has been most shocked and most injured by the latest form of crime against progress and civilization should be the first to propose a concert of action against it among civilized nations.

An explosion of chemicals in the cellar of Bolton's drug store, Flatbush Avenue and St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, resulted in a serious fire. The drug store occupies the first floor of a fourstory brick apartment house. At 5:15 o'clock a flash of flame shot up through the airshaft in the building and created consternation among the inmates.

BEAVER, Pean., Nov. 21 -- Six men were burned to death and several were badly injured in a fire early this morning which destroyed the Merrli House, a three-story frame building near the Government dam, two miles from this price.

Ten Chinese, who came to this country from Havana and were detained by the customs au thorities on the ground that they were laborers not entitled to entry, were released yesterday, and the ball discharged on an order signed by Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court. Special Inspector Scharf had endeavored to have the immigrants deported, he claiming the statements of the Chinese were untrue.
BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Call money ruled at 11/2 per cent. The increased strength is said to be owing to cotton drafts.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Bards rise up and flourish on the Yale campus during one week of the year. In anticipation the deeds of the football players loom up before the students, and martial lyrics are chanted day and night on the Yale campus for the seven days previous to the Yale-Harvard football game. Now naught but the great approaching contest can be heard in speech or song.

-- Ex-Police Sergeant James J. Fielding of Brooklyn died yesterday at his home. 154 Roebling Street, Williamsburg. He was fifty-two years old. He was a war veteran, having served with the One Hundred and Twenty third New-York Volunteers, in the Metropolitan Brigade. During the war he rose to the rank of Lieutenant. At the close of the war he was appointed to the Brooklyn police force and became a Sergeant.

Wheat declined early with the easy cables and on local realizing, but reacted on foreign buying and following the West, and closed firm at 1/2@5/3c gain for the day, with a fairly active, switching business.

The publication in The New-York Times yesterday of the statement submitted to District Attorney Nicoll on Monday by William B. Putney on behalf of Director Ronald T. McDonald of the Madison Square Bank opened the gates for the grievances of depositors, especially those from whom the bank took $90,000 after some of the Directors had been planning for a friendly receivership.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 21. -- Twenty-five tramps last night took possession of a freight car near the railroad station at Linden and made a raid on the village. They robbed henroosts and woodsheds, broke into cellars in search of liquor, and stole the clothes from several lines.

Charles Blumenthal, a young man living at 239 East Seventy-ninth Street, this city, was sent to Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, yesterday by Justice Connelly in the Gates Avenue Police Court to await trial for swindling. The charge was preferred against Blumenthal by Diedrich Meyer, a clerk employed by Kempner Brothers, who own a delicatessen store at 1,174 Broadway.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- A special dispatch to The Times from Meshed brings further details of the earthquake that occurred Friday at Kuchan, in the northern part of the Province of Khorassan. The town was completely destroyed, and the loss of life was immense. Great crevasses were opened in the earth, through which water flowed in torrents, causing the Atrek River to overflow its banks.

The Reorganization Committee of the National Cordage Company issued a second circular yesterday, in which was proposed a plan of settlement with creditors, differing in several respects from, that offered a few months ago. The plan, as it now stands, is stated by the Reorganization Committee to be the best possible in the circumstances, and is heartily concurred in by the Advisory Committee and by the receivers.
OTTUMWA, Iowa, Nov. 21. -- A mob hanged Fred Gustaveson to the stair railing of Justice Truitt's courtroom this afternoon.

The identity of the "People's Railroad Company," which applied Monday to the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen for several street franchises, is almost as much of a mystery as the late candidate for Senator, Van Slooten. A reporter for The NewYork Times yesterday succeeded in finding a man who said he knew all about the concern, but was not at liberty to divulge his knowledge on the subject.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Charles Mapleson, second son of Col. James Mapleson, the operatic manager, died last night of rheumatic gout. He leaves a wife, who is now playing at the Empire Theatre. London, under the stage name of Malvina Cavallazzi.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- P. M. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was larger to-day than for some time back, and the movement of prices was upward. The speculation in Sugar overshadowed the remainder of the list, although there was a fair amount of trading in half a dozen other stocks.

A conference of representatives of nearly all the diverse interests in the Union Pacific Railroad was held in the office of Senator Calvin S. Brice, at 80 Broadway, yesterday. Besides Mr. Brice there were present Samuel Carr, one of the Trustees of the F. L. Ames estate; A. A. H. Boissevain. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald. Gen. G. M. Dodge, H. L. Higginson of Lee, Higginson Co. of Boston, and others.

There is a new anti-Tammany organization in town. Its founders say it is an outand-out Democratic affair, and the mission, upon which it has embarked is to set the Tammany men out of office and to get in themselves. This is the same motive that is behind the movement which ex-Mayor William R. Grace is planning, but the two movements must not be confounded simply because they have the same object.

Suit has been brought in the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York by the Edison Electric Light Company against the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, sub-contractor, and the New-York Insulated-Wire Company, sub-contractor, for infringement of the Edison plants in the lighting of the World's Fair.

By going to sleep while on duty early yesterday morning, William Fletcher lost his life and also caused the death of Henry Rogers, as well as the sinking of the tug Charles R. Stone, on which he was employed as fireman.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 21. -- The Lehigh Valley strike covers much more territory to-day than yesterday, and the position of the company seems to be growing more and more uncomfortable. The Wyoming division is "tied up" fast; the Lehigh division is nearly in the same condition, freight and coal crews being out almost to a man.

Ex-Secretary of the Navy Benjamin F. Tracy, who in all probability will leave to-day for Europe on legal business, was asked yesterday concerning that part of Commissioner Blount's report relating to the interview between himself and Admiral Skerrett just before the latter sailed for Hawaii in December last.

The speech of the Secretary of the Treasury last evening at the banquet of the Chamber of Commerce was worthy of the high place he holds in the National Government. In simple and clear language, and with the greatest force, he stated the principles by which he held that the Government and the country should be guided in the treatment of the currency.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Lehigh Valley stock opened at 397/8 and declined to 39, on comparatively light transactions, on the strike news published in the New-York papers, which have taken a very much more serious view of the condition of affairs than the papers in this city. The public has at last wakened up to the fact that the strike at this time is most injudicious.

ST. LOUIS. Mo., Nov. 21. -- P. M. Arthur, Grand Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, who is in St. Louis today for the purpose of settling a difference between the engineers and the management of the Terminal Railway Association, was asked if he thought that the Lehigh strike would spread.
VIROQUA, Wis., Nov. 21. -- Ex-Gov. Jeremiah Rusk died this morning at about 8 o'clock, He had been ill about two months, suffering from inflammation of the prostate gland.

A decision on the legality of money wagers was handed down yesterday by Judge Fitzsimons of the City Court in the suit of Robert C. Irving, a bookmaker, against Joseph A. Britton. Irving sued on a note for $365. The note, with two others, was given in payment of a bet made by Britton on the Morris Park track in 1890.

-- If all the plans now in contemplation for future stock companies in this city are carried out, the combination system will receive a severe blow. Helen Dauvray, now playing in " The Prodigal Daughter," is the latest aspirant for managerial honors and burdens in connection with a stock company. She proposes to star next year, and the following year she intends to organize a stock company for a permanent home in New-York.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new building and alterations were filed:

Three notable sales of down-town real estate were had yesterday. One of these was the southeast corner of Broadway and Pine Street, the second the northwest corner of Nassau and Pine Streets, and the third the property at 45 Liberty Street. All were discussed with interest by real estate men. and two of them especially so, because these purchases mean improvement by buildings.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Jacob Schaefer and Frank C. Ives met in Central Music Hall to-night to contest at billiards for a purse of $5.000 and the net gate receipts. The match is at the fourteen-inch balk line game for 4,000 points. 800 of which will be played for five consecutive nights.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 21. -- Gov. Flower has appointed an extraordinary Court of Oyer and Terminer to take cognizance of the election cases in Kings County. He has designated Justice Edgar M. Culien, of the Second Judicial District, to preside. At Judge Culien's suggestion, the date of holding the court has been fixed for Monday, Dec. 18, to afford time for summoning a Grand Jury and the necessary publication of notice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Mr. Thurston, the Hawaiian Minister, this evening gave out the following statement in reply to the report of Mr. Blount:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Secretary Herbert has received a letter from Capt. H. F. Picking, commanding the United States steamer Charleston, at Rio Janeiro, dated Oct. 20. He gives an account of the happenings in the harbor from day to day as follows:

The Church of the Strangers, in Mercer near Eighth Street, was crowded to the doors at noon yesterday, when the funeral services over the remains of its late pastor, the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems, were held. Most of the available seats, barring the reserve pews, had been filled long before that hour.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- The headquarters of the State Board of World's Fair Managers is again a scene of activity. John Foord, Secretary of the board, and Mrs. Florence C. Ives, chief clerk of the Women's Board, have arrived here from Chicago. Other officials of the board are expected within the next few days.
Preparations are going forward actively in Brooklyn for the prosecution of John Y. McKane and the other men who are alleged to have been connected with the ballot frauds in Gravesend.

Directum is still the king of trotters. He yesterday defeated Alix in three straight heats, and the mare was unable to force him to his best at any time. Directum is king. He is the idel of the trotting man's heart. He is now the greatest horse the turf ever saw. He was even before yesterday's race, but his performance at Fleetwood was a wonderful one.

Delafield -- Sands. The marriage of Miss Lettice Lee Sands to Maturin L. Delafield drew a gathering of 500 fashionable wedding guests to Trinity Chapel at 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, rector of Trinity Parish, assisted by the Rev. R. Maurice Berkeley, rector of Zion Church, at Dobbs Ferry, performed the ceremony.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 21. -- J. Homer Brooke, a prominent resident of Greenville, is lying at his home, 40 Linden Avenue, suffering from concussion of the brain. He may die. His condition is the result of violence, but little is known of the facts. As Mr. Brooke is unconscious, nothing additional can be learned until he recovers, unless the police can find his assailant.

Thirteen persons, whose lives were nearly sacrificed to the fury of an Atlantic gale on Nov. 13, were brought into port yesterday by the British steamer Mexican Prince. They were taken from the Norwegian bark Helene as that ship was about to founder. The unlucky crew of the Norwegian vessel had passed through several days of torture and suffering, and were in a desperate condition when rescued.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 21. -- The situation at the Lehigh Valley yards in this city was virtually unchanged to-day. No freight was moved and very little received. Many shippers who had delivered freight yesterday withdrew it this morning and sent it by the Central, thus relieving that company from any possible charge of attempting to carry Lehigh freight.

-- Herbert Lee Pratt, '95, of Brooklyn, N.Y., was yesterday unanimously elected Captain of Amherst'a football team for next season. He has played on the quarter back of the team for three years -- as a substitute in the freshman year and regularly the last two seasons. The first of this season, while Capt. Haskell was disabled by a lame shoulder. Pratt assumed the entire generalship of the eleven.

Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent The last loan was made at 1 per cent. Time money was in abundant supply, but the demand was light. Rates were 2 1/2@3 per cent, for thirty days, 3@3 1/2 for sixty days to four months, and 3 3/4@4 1/2 for four to six months.
ALBANY, N.Y, Nov. 22. -- Gov. Flower has filed the following upon granting a commutation of the sentence of Police Sergeant David H. Crowley of New-York City:

James Hart, a dissipated-looking man, was taken to the Yorkville Police Court yesterday on a warrant sworn out by his wife, who charged him with disorderly conduct and assault. The facts of the case, however, as related by Policeman Bellar, who arrested Hart, showed that the prisoner bad not only assaulted his wire, bat that his brutality had probably led to the death of his child.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22. -- All of the morning publications notice the meeting held here yesterady of the representatives of the United Press and the owners of the Baltimore newspapers, wherein it was unanimously agreed that every paper should continue its relations with the United Press to the exclusion of any and every other news agency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Supreme Court of the United States has, in an opinion read by Justice Field, held that the great lakes of the United States and their connecting waters were included within the term "high seas." as used in the statutes providing punishment for crimes committed thereon.

About $2,000,000 worth of dry goods were sold at the annual auction sale which took place yesterday in the auction rooms of Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, 64 White Street. There were buyers from every section of the country, and the bidding was spirited. It was generally commented that the prices obtained indicated a very hopeful outlook for the future.

ROANOKE Va., Nov. 22. -- The Jury in the riot cases returned a verdict this afternoon. James G. Richardson was given thirty days in jail and fined $100 S. W. Fuqua and D. D. Kennedy were given one day in Jail, and Abe Perry was acquitted. The Jury stood 10 to 2 for giving the accused the full penalty of the law, twelve months in, jail and $100 fine.

-- The Sub-Committee on Reorganization appointed by the Republican County Committee at last Thursday night's meeting to investigate and, if necessary, recommend a plan of reorganization met last night at the Republican Club, 450 Fifth Avenue. There were present Elihu Root, Chairman; Cornelius N. Bliss, Col. George Bliss, Gen. Horace Porter, Edward Lauterbach, George W. Lyon and Hiram Morritt.

A special meeting of the Broklyn Democratic Club was held at its headquarters, 201 Montague Street, last evening for the purpose of receiving the report of the Committee of Five appointed to take into consideration the matter of the reorganization of the Democratic Party in Kings County.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22. -- There seems to be no doubt that N.D. Sperry, the present Postmaster, will not succeed himself upon the expiration of his present term in December. When Congress convenes, Congressman J.P. Piggott will present to President Cleveland the name of Francis G. Beach of this city for the position.
Chief of Police John Y. McKane of the Gravesend police denies that his blind son, George McKane, is or ever was a paid Police Sergeant at Gravesend.

The gifts already received by the cruiser New-York were added to yesterday afternoon when, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, a handsome set of silver candelabra was presented on behalf of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation. The candelabra will be used on the tables in the ward rooms.

WEST SOMERVILLE, Mass., Nov. 22. -- Ex-United States Minister John E. Stevens lectured here this evening on "Hawaiian Affairs." He said that during his thirteen years' service as United States Minister, under five Presidents, he had invariably refused to recognize political parties in his own country, believing that in our foreign relations our policy should be national and continuous, always with a united front to our foreign rivals.

-- Gossip about Custom House appointments centred yesterday in the Naval Office. Silas W. Hurt, who once held the position, and ex-Senator John J. Kiernan, had heard reports that a new Naval Officer was to be appointed soon, and the friends of both were greatly interested. Mr. Kiernan put in a petition in favor of his appointment last March.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- The University of Pennsylvania played its last football game on the home grounds to-day against an eleven composed mainly of graduate players. The ex-footballers gave their successors on the team one or the stiffest games of the season, and were only defeated 18 to 0. ExCapt. Charles Schoff, full back; Harry Thayer of the '92 team, and George Woodruff, played a most wonderful game, considering their condition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Minister Thurston representing the provisional Government of Hawaii, organized to remain until the treaty of annexation should be acted upon, evidently desires to become a "martyr."

To throw a boomerang efficiently so that it will sail off through the sky, wheel high in air, poise, flutter down in graceful sweeps, and rise again in at least one more circling course before gradually sailing its ellipse and falling almost at the feet of the man who throws it -- to do this, so Mr. Frost says, one must be a cannibal.

Art was the topic of interest at the Woman's Professional league rooms yesterday, and the members discussed with wise and learned air the merits and imperfections of masters of painting, ancient and modern.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Augustus Pfizer of New-York, who arrived at Liverpool on the steamship Lucanla last Saturday, is at the Savoy Hotel. He says that at Queenstown he received from America several cablegrams accusing him of having eloped with Nina. Farrington, formerly of the Casino Company in New-York.

Miss Mary Blackmore, a junior nurse in Dr. Daniel Lewis's private sanitarium, at 151 East Fifty-first Street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting herself in the right temple with a small revolver. She was pursuing a course of study and training at the sanitarium, with the view of becoming a trained nurse, but ill health so interfered with her studies and duties that she became despondent, and in a fit of melancholia killed herself.

The annual report of the Great Northern Railway for the year ended June 30 shows: Gross earnings, $13,522,581; expenses, $7,335,417; taxes, $375,554; interest guaranteed on Manitoba bonds, $3,440,286; dividends guaranteed on Manitoba, $1,200,000; maintaining Manitoba organization, $6,863; rental other leased lines, $681; four dividends, (5 per cent.,) $1,000,000; surplus, $163,779.

Any young man in search of points in amatory letter writing should apply to Charles F. Bates, known to his intimates as "Fatty" Bates, sporting gentleman, clubman, man-about-town, and, at present, defendant in a suit for limited divorce, put on trial yesterday in the Superior Court.
RIVERSIDE, Cal., Nov. 22. -- George B. Dole of this city, a brother of President Dole of Hawaii, said to-day:
The property at 45 Liberty Street, sold by Mr. W.K. Aston, was purchased by Margaret K. Watson. Terms are withheld.

Henry McCahill of the Department of Public Works was charged in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday by Mrs. Lucy Mack with stealing? a diamond ring from her valued at $60. She says the ring was stolen two years ago, when she occupied apartments over the rooms of the Oriole Club, of which Mr. McCahill was a member.

Five fat porpoises, that have been in the habit of leading a quiet existence in the placid waters of Long Island Sound, amusing the Passengers on Sound boats by their gambols, on the breast of a swirling tide, and before they realized what had happened they and rushed up the Harlem River to the Third Avenue Bridge.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 22. -- Mrs. March, who died in Dutchess County some time ago, left a will by which a million-dollar estate was divided among many favored persons in various sums, ranging all the way from $50,000 and $20,000 down to $1,000. This will came up for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. PARIS, Nov. 22. -- So many members of the Chamber of Deputies have inscribed their names as speakers to-morrow that it is not probable that a division will be taken on the Government's demand for a vote of confidence. Everything indicates, however, that when the vote is taken the Government will obtain a substantial majority.

As told in The New-York Times last Monday, steps have been taken to procure a pardon for Annie Walden, a life convict in the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island, on the ground that she is dying of consumption. She was convicted of killing her husband, James Walden, in front of the Metropolitan Opera House, in October, 1891.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- It seems to have been about decided that there shall be a departure from old customs in the submission of the departmental reports in advance of the President's message, and that the full reports of each of the Secretaries shall follow the message of the President to Congress.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Nearly 500 persons witnessed the departure of the New-York Central and the London and Northwestern World's Fair exhibit trains from the Lake Shore station this morning for New-York City. The first section pulled out at 9:48. having: on board many Chicago railroad officials. Board of Trade men, and other prominent citizens as guests of the Lake Shore Road.

The Madison Square Bank was Judicially dissolved yesterday, when Judge Beach, in Supreme Court, Chambers, signed an order to that effect on application of the Attorney General, and made permanent the receivership of Miles M. O'Erien and James G. Cannon.

There was one point in the admirable speech of Mr. CARLISLE at the Chamber of Commerce banquet on Tuesday evening which his hearers marked with especial satisfaction. It was his declaration that the financial policy of the United States was fixed for all time to come. And this was the more noteworthy because he also declared that policy had been slowly developed and established, and was not the result of any special legislation.

At the American Institute, Kellogg Co. yesterday completed the dispersal sale of the trotting stock from the Fashion Farm, the 157 head realizing a total of $68.995, an average of $370 per head. The 55 brood mares averaged $475.53 yearlings averaged $257 and 44 weanlings $233, the colts, as usual, bringing only a little more than half as much as the os.

Policeman John Foley or the Jefferson Market squad arrested Charles T. Gregory, a real estate man, last evening at the Sturtevant House and locked him up in the West Thirtieth Street station house. Gregory, it appears, was stopping at the Continental Hotel. At the end of the week his bill came to $33, for which amount he gave Edward Mcrrifield a check, which turned out to be worthless.

Three new aspirants for public favor made themselves known at Herrmann's Theatre last night. Two of them were women and singers, the third was a man and a composer. Because the work of the last should be the most lasting, if fine, and the most speedily forgotten, if poor, it must be considered first.

From having been leading lady in many famous theatrical companies, Ellen Cummens has fallen to the humiliating position of a prisoner confined at Police Headquarters, charged with having robbed her benefactor and friend for many years of a diamond pin.

There is no more conflict between Mr. THURSTON'S statement of the proceedings at Honolulu in January and Mr. BLOUNT's report than was to be expected, considering the relations of the former to the revolutionary movement. The conflict is not so much in regard to essential facts as the interpretation put upon them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- West Chicago opened at 150 and closed at 153 1/4. The company has made an unexpected change in regard to issuing its new stock. The circular announced that the new certificates could be obtained on Nov. 24, the date of the payment of the first installment.

MILLBROOK, Dutchoss County, Nov. 22. -- A week of uncommon pleasure and gayety is promised at Halcyon Hall in this place in celebration of Thanksgiving. Mr. and Mrs. Davison have arranged to close the season at their beautiful new country inn with a series of unique and brilliant social features.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

A man about thirty-eight years old, well dressed, with brown hair and mustache, registered Tuesday night at the Springler House, Fourteenth Street and Broadway, as "Ned Von Lickland, Boston." He went into the cafe and took three large drinks of brandy. Then he went to his room.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- A dispatch via Malaga from the United Press representative at Melilla, bearing date of Monday evening, says that a hurricane had prevailed there for two days. The weather was so severe that it compelled a cessation of work at the forts that are being constructed by the Spaniards.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Nov. 22. -- The gigantic pool, consolidation, or combination of the lake shipping interests which centre here and at Buffalo is now a project which, has passed beyond mere talk of possibilities and entered upon the stage of nearly assured fact. The depression of lake rates the past season has been the strongest factor which has influenced the vessel men in moving for a consolidation of their interests.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Jake Schaeter and FranK Ives played their second game of 800 points in Central Music Hall to-night before a large assemblage. The Wizard broke his high-run record or the world and went 113 better. Ives labored under the discouraging effect of being a long distance oil the string behind the Wizard.
The new Brazllian cruiser America is under orders to sail from this port not later than to-morrow. The submarine gun vessel Destroyer will probably take her departure next Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- Grand Master S. E. Wilkinson of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen returned to Philadelphia this morning after visits to Easton, Perth Amboy, and Weissport, and he reported that no freight is being moved on the Lehigh Valley. Three freight trains that have left Easton since Monday night, he said, have been deserted at Packerton, Forty-four miles distant.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Ewald Huetterman, whose extradition on charges of larceny and abduction was granted a few days ago by the Bow Street Extradition Court, sailed from Liverpool to-day for New-York on the White Star Line steamer Majestic. He is in charge of an officer from Elizabeth, N.J., where he will be tried.

Gov. William McKinley of Ohio was tendered an informal luncheon yesterday afternoon by Messrs. Hawk and Wetherbee, the proprietors of the Windsor Hotel. At 1 o'clock the Governor was escorted to a private breakfast room and placed in the seat of honor. The table was a large circular one, and in its centre a huge bed of white and yellow chrysanthemums was placed.

An encouraging phase of the railroad situation is the extraordinary recuperative power shown by the Western roads in general. Recent reports of earnings indicate a steady improvement in the business of nearly all of the principal Western lines. The October report of the Chicago and Northwestern shows an increase of $375,320 over the earnings in October of last year.
-- Albert Keep, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad, has been in town for the past few days.

The history of the exportation of American meats to Europe has not been creditable to the European countries concerned. The American hog labored for years under imputations upon his character for wholesomeness that were the more difficult to refute because there was no foundation for them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22. -- Two days more regain for practice on Soldiers' Field, and then the team goes to Springfield. The work is constant, and the players are exerting every effort to perfect the team. So strict is the secrecy regarding the practice chat it is impossible to get information regarding the progress of the team, except such as the coachers wish to give.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 22. -- The Lehigh Valley officials believe they have broken the backbone of the striker at the eastern end of their road, because success crowned their first attempt to move freight this afternoon.

C. Augustus Haviland, President of the organization of depositors of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, yesterday made public the report of the expert accountant who was employed by the organization to examine the books of the bank.
Among the securities sold at auction today by Adrian H. Muller Son at 111 Broadway were the following lots:

The Princeton aad Columbia freshmen teams played a football match on Columbia Oval yesterday afternoon. The game was a very close one and Princeton won by a score of 8 to 4. About 250 persons, chiefly Columbia students, watched the game and swarmed all over the field, greatly interfering with the players. In the stand were some twenty ladies. All but two wore the b!ue and white ribbons of Columbia.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 22. -- The Suffolk County Democratic Central Committee was in session here from early last evening until after 4 o'clock this morning trying to straighten out indorsements for Federal positions. The lines between Cleveland and Hill Democracy were very closely drawn, and to-day there are a good many sore Democrats in Suffolk County.

The departure of Mrs. Victoria Woodhull Martin on the New-York yesterday was a general surprise. She had announced that she would deliver a number of lectures, and she entertained a large audience at the Carnegie Music Hall last Monday evening. She relinquishes her task at the wishes of her husband, who feared her health would be impaired by the work.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 22. -- After being out since 11 o'clock last night, the jury in the case of Thomas McGreevy and N.K. Connolly, charged with conspiring to defraud the Dominion Government in connection with the construction of the Quebec harbor works and the graving dock at Esquimault, B.C., came into court at 10 o'clock this morning with a verdict of guilty as charged.
Label every elevated railroad trainman you see "Dangerous." It should be done in big yellow type on their blue uniforms. But it isn't. Take a friendly "tip" and do it mentally.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the hustle and bustle of our last horse exhibit, which was a great financial success notwithstanding its superb mismanagement, is over. It behooves us to look into the results. There seems to be no doubt in the minds of the stallion Matchless was the finest hackney shown. Perhaps next year some exhibitor may be able to bring over a superior animal.

Antonie and Fanny Ledecky, mother and daughter, committed suicide at 240 East Eighty-seventh Street some time Tuesday night, Antonie, aided by her daughter, hanging herself, and the latter cutting the bloodvessels of her left wrist with a razor.

A meeting of the Ballot-Reform Committee of the City Club was held at the club rooms, 677 Fifth Avenue, last night. To this meeting a number of representatives of other political organizations had been invited.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Clarence Theall. twenty-seven years old, last night committed suicide by shooting himself in the head with a revolver. He has been despondent for some time, has been out of work, and drinking hard. He leaves a wife and two children.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Nov. 22. -- There were five regular passenger trains moved eastward, and a like number westward today, but the empty condition of the cars proved that the trains were being run at a loss, as the passengers did not, by actual count, average one to the car. Since Sunday night ten big Lehigh locomotives have been lying at Jersey City with their fires "cold."

NEWTON, N.C., Nov. 22. -- A severe fog and wet grounds from the protracted rainstorm of yesterday delayed the start to-day till late in the forenoon, when the competition of the Eastern Field Trials Clubs' Derby was resumed. The competition, taken as a whole, was positively interior. The unfinished heat between Bessie Shoupe and Selah was continued, but their performance was weak and ordinary.
