LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Although the markets continue dull, a much better feeling prevailed to-day, owing to a variety of reasons.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange to-day listed these securities:

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. PARIS, Nov. 22. -- Levi P. Morton's gout became so troublesome recently that an operation was necessary, and he will be obliged to keep his bed at the Hotel Londres. His condition, although serious, is not dangerous.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- The short interest in St. Paul started to cover this morning, and the stock advanced sharply. Lehigh Valley was entirely neglected, with a few hundred shares offered at 39 1/2. Very little strike news is obtainable here. A leading daily paper here sharply criticised the management of the company for causing a strike at this time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- As the time approaches that was designated by the majority of the Ways and Means Committee for making public the provisions of the new Tariff bill, the pressure upon the members in the interest of early information grows stronger.

The Directors of the American Casualty Insurance and Security Company voted yesterday to place the affairs of that badlymanaged corporation in the hands of a receiver. The resolution, which was adopted, asking the counsel of the company to take steps in the proper courts for the receiver, was accompanied by another which authorized W. A. Fisher, the counsel of the company in Baltimore, to take all necessary steps to wind up its affairs.
The Brooklyn Young Republican. Club gave Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren a rousing reception last night at the Johnston Building, Nevins Street, near Flatbush Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- M. Lockroy, Radical Republican, opened the debate in the Chamber of Deputies to-day on the Government's demand for a vote of confidence. He described the preceding sitting, at which the Government announced its programme, as an oratorical tournament between Government Republicans and revolutionary politicians.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The special meeting of the Executive Committee of the Democratic Society of New-Jersey, held here to-day at the clubhouse of the Democratic League, was well attended. A large number of letters were also received from various parts of the State, expressing regrets at not being able to be present, and giving assurances of a willingness to join in any movement looking to the good of the party.

If the Thanksgiving Day football same between Yale and Princeton does nothing else it will develop a lot of student ticket speculators. Students who have need of more dollars than they are allowed by their parents have gone into the business this year even stronger than usual and the general public will be the sufferers, just as they are at the annual Yale-Harvard boat races at New-London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Secretary Gresham showed very little interest in the news of the arrival of the Alameda from Hawaii this morning, and the serenity with which the officials received the report that nothing had happened on the islands of moment up to the date of the sailing of the steamer was in marked contrast with the attitude of eager expectation with which, the news brought by the China was awaited.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Walter Camp. Treasurer of the Yale Financial Union, made his first animal report to-night. The experiment of uniting all the athletic organizations has proved a great success. Mr. Camp gives some valuable suggestions regarding the plan. His report reads:
Wheat lost 3/4 @ 7/8c through the weakness West and local realizing, and closed weak, with a fair business.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Inspector Schaack and Capt. Schuttler, who have charge of witnessess and the collection of evidence against Dan Coughlin, were importuned this morning by reporters to speak in detail about the discovery of the grave prepared for Dr. Cronin's body in the Lake View wood and disclose the name of the farmer who saw the gravedigger and the identity of any occupants of the buggy.

All the guns for the new Brazilian cruiser America have arrived. The White Star steamer Germanic, which reached this port yesterday, brought from England the two big 4.7-inch Hotchkiss rapid-fire guns which will be mounted on the forward deck of the Brazilian ship. These two guns were manufactured at the English shops of the Hotchkiss Ordnance Company.

Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent. Time money was in abundant supply, but the demand was light. Rates were 2 1/2@3 per cent for thirty days, 3@3 1/2 for sixty days to four months, and 3 3/4@4 1/2 for four to six months.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The firm of Julius Ellinger Co. of 60 Vesey Street, New-York, has been granted the highest award by the judges of the World's Fair for the best line of cigars, both clear Havana and seed and Havana. Some manufacturers of cigars took awards for special brands, but Julius Ellinger Co. are among the few whose awards will read for the highest excellence of their entire line.

-- Ex-Mayor George H. Babbitt of Taunton, Mass., died yesterday, aged seventy-four. He was Mayor of the city three years, from 1874. He was the first Sheriff of Bristol County appointed by any Governor, and was Deputy Sheriff for a term of years. He leaves one son, the present Mayor of Taunton.

Frank Ellison, the clubman and man-about-town, who was convicted in the Court of General Sessions of assault in the second degree on Broker William H. Henriques, was taken to Sing Sing on the 2:15 train yesterday afternoon. He was accompanied by Deputy Sheriff Burke.

The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Forty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, is receiving some important additions. The most important is an immense window, which is to occupy almos the entire end of the channel. It was given by Mrs. George Lewis, Jr., and is in memory of Mrs. Moses Taylor.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 23. -- Judge Dyckman has set aside the assignment of Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co., of New-York, made in 1891. Edward M. Field was the senior member of the firm.

The essential features of the plan of party reorganization adopted by the Democratic Club of Brooklyn were denned as follows by the Chairman of the Committee proposing it: First, the election district plan; second, the exclusion of office holders, and third, leaving the details to the Committee of One Hundred appointed by the President.

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- There was to have been a conference of all the State officers-election out through misunderstanding or otherwise it was only partially successful. Chairman Hackett of the Republican Executive Committee came along Monday, as did also Controllar-elect James A. Roberts and Treasurer-elect Addison B. Colvin.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The Elevated stocks were the principal features of the market to-day. "Alley" especially attracted particular attention by a rise of 3 points, opening at 45 and closing at 48. The final "first call" trade was at 48 1/2. It was given out this morning: that the road has finally made arrangements for the much-needed and much-contested northern loop.

The football team of the Berkeley School defeated tie eleven of the Cutler School yesterday afternoon, and won the interscholastic championship and the silver cup emblematic of that title. The game was played on the Berkeley Oval, and about 500 of the boys and their friends from the Berkeley, Cutler, Colombia Grammar, and Harvard Schools went up to see the contest.

A meeting of several well-known German-Americans was held at the house of Oswald Ottendorfer, 150 West Fifty-ninth Street, Wednesday evening to discuss the best means of pushing a movement for reform in the administration of municipal and State politics and affairs. Besides Mr. Otendorfer, there were present Arthur von Briesen, Gustav H. Schwab, Carl Schurz, Louis Windmuller, John Pannes, Theodore Sutro, Percival Knauth, Carl Hauser, and Edward Grosse.
An overdose of chloral, which she herself and all her friends insist was not taken with suicidal Intent, came near putting an end yesterday to the romantic life of pretty Bettina Gerard, the actress.

If President Cleveland is not detained In Washington by official business, he will, on next Wednesday evening, open in the Grand Central Palace an exhibition which will be made up of all the best features of the World's Columbian Exposition.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 23. -- About 200 representative Democratic leaders from various parts of the State met in this city to-day for a conference. Charles L. Jewett of New-Albany was elected to preside over the meeting.

James F. O'Brien, eighteen years old, the son of James O'Brien, a wealthy real estate dealer living at 164 West Seventy-ninth Street, died on Tuesday at his home from peritonitis, the result of an injury received while playing football over a month ago.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- The eighteenth session of the Italian Parliament opened to-day. The Chamber of Deputies was crowded with all the leading politicians of the country. Signer Giuseppe Zanardelli, the President of the Chamber, announced that he had received under seal the report of the commission appointed to investigate the bank scandals.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23. -- The United Press correspondent at Honolulu, writing under date of Nov. 16, says: As yet Minister Wills has made no intimation to this Government of any special communication with which he may be charges Nor is it known that he has any. The city is daily alive with strange rumors of the Minister's intentions.

The thirty-eighth anniversary of the Woman's Hospital, at Park Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, was celebrated yesterday in one of the lower wards of the main building. The cots had been removed from the room, which was beautifully decorated with roses, palms, chrysanthemums, and smilax, and it was filled with patients, white-capped nurses, physicians, and prominent men and women who are benefactors of the hospital.

The proposed plan of reorganization of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn, prepared by the Committee of Five of the Brooklyn Democratic Club and published in The New-York Times yesterday, is not meeting with the approval of the Ring organization men in Brooklyn. Most of the heads of the departments were, yesterday afternoon, attending the funeral of Daniel L. Northup.

The enormous sale on Tuesday by order of Bliss, Fabyan Co. of domestic stuffs, comprising bleached Pepperill sheetings. Bates quilts, and damasks, denims, ginghams, cottonades, tickings, and sateens, a class of goods used principally by the working classes, has caused business men to wonder whether or not the condition of affairs among the farmers and workingmen of the country is improving and giving the jobbers and wholesale men prospects of a better market.

The Beethoven String Quartet has entered the eighth year of its career, in the course of which it has done not a little for the advancement of chamber music in this city. The first concert of the present season, which was given last night, found the organization ensconced in a new abode.

English yachtsmen are still discussing the defeat of the Valkyrie. Some of them send their opinions to the daily papers. In the latest issue of The London Field at hand, two of these letters are printed, which give suggestions to coming cap challengers. They are as follows:

The New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, of which Elbridge T. Gerry is President, has issued an appeal for money, clothing, and supplies. It has also called for new members. The Gerry Society has been in existence nineteen years, daring which time it has looked after the welfare of over 227,484 children.

Col. Loomis L. Langdon, First Artillery, United States Army, who will command all the troops in the Evacuation Day. procession to-morrow and at the unveiling of the Nathan Hale Statue In the City Hall Park, has issued his orders for the regulation of his forces.

The Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association spent a portion of yesterday discussing the trite subject of through export rates. At a meeting of the joint committee of the trunk lines and the Central Traffic Association, held a few weeks ago, a special committee was appointed to try to devise a schedule of export rates such as all of the railroads will be satisfied to stand by.
The Building Department received yesterday the plans for the following new buildings and alterations:

Plymouth Church circles in Brooklyn were rudely disturbed yesterday by a scandal which involves the character and reputation of one of the most active mission workers in the congregation. It was brought to light by the arrest of William H. Grimm of 1,360 De Kalb Avenue, a prominent supporter of the Bethel Mission.

The Interior Department has recently received annual reports from Indian agencies on a number of reservations where lands are soon to be or already have been allotted in severalty. These allotments release large areas of land for settlement, and settlers will be admitted after the negotiations with the Indians shall have been completed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28. -- Brown wound up the football season here this afternoon by defeating Tufts 30 to 0 in a well-played game. Both sides played hard and well, but the Brown men were heavier, and their superior all-around, play won. Tufts came very near scoring once, having the ball inside the five-yard line, but the Brown rush line rallied in fine style and held four downs.

George Kemp. Mr. George Kemp, one of the most widely-known men in business and social circles in this city, died shortly after 6 o'clock yesterday morning at his home. 720 Fifth Avenue. He had been ill several months, and his death was due to malnutrition. Wednesday night his strength failed rapidly, and it was known that he could not live many hours.

Two hundred members of the New-York Jewelers' Association sat down to their nineteenth annual banquet at Delmonico's last evening. President Joseph B. Bowden presided, and in the places of honor were Edward T. Bartlett, the recently-elected Justice of the Court of Appeals; Elihu Root, the Rev. George R. Van De Water, Judge Noah Davis, James W. Ridgway, District Attorney of Kings County; Frederic Taylor, David C. Dodd, Herbert Ketcham, and August Oppenheimer.

Mary Murray, twenty years old, employed as a servant by Dr. Wesley Smith, Alderman of the Eleventh Assembly District, who resides at 24 West Thirtieth Street, was assaulted by a negro as she was closing up the house at 10:45 o'clock last night. The man was standing in an adjoining doorway.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 23. -- The November term of the Richmond County Court opened Tuesday. It was expected action would be taken by the Grand Jury regarding the charges of fraud against some of the Inspectors of Election.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- The market opened with orders from London to sell Pennsylvania Railroad stock, evidently on the unfavorable statement of October earnings. The stock sold below par, the first time since the panic. Western New-York and Pennsylvania stock also declined on the belief that it will not be treated very well in the proposed readjustment of that company's finances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- By direction of the Navy Department Commander A.S. Crowninshield will be detached from the command of the corvette Kearsarge on her arrival at New-York, and will be succeeded by Commander O. J. Hayerman. The Kearsarge arrived at New-port Tuesday, and after fitting out at New-York she will sail south to protect American interests in the West Indies.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- There is no change in the Lehigh strike situation so far as Philadelphia is concerned. The labor leaders are as sanguine as ever and the railroad officials reiterate the assertion that the road will soon be in operation. The hiring of non-union men by the company was continued here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Minister Thurston, upon being apprised of the news brought from Honolulu by the Alameda, said it was what he had expected. He was satisfied that, unless Minister Willis used force to effect the restoration of the Queen, Liliuokalani would never be reinstated. Further than this he did not care to say anything, either upon the progress of events so far or upon the possibilities of the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee are making rapid progress on the new tariff bill. They have devoted ten hours a day during the current week to a consideration of the measure, and it is said to-night that their labors are wellnigh completed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The following brief cablegram has been received by Acting Secretary McAdoo, announcing the Sinking of the insurgent monitor Javary:

Boussod, Valadon Co. are affording just now an occasion for estimating the work of Albert Lynch, a South American painter with an Irish name, who has taken quite the position of a Frenchman in Paris. One of his delicately-wrought water colors was shown last season by the american Water Color Society at the Academy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Fall meeting of the Washington Jockey Club was oponed at Bennings Race Coarse this afternoon under auspicious circumstances. The weather was clear and pleasant and a goodly crowd was in attendance. The track, owing to a recent rainstorm, was very heavy and fast time was out of the question. All the events had big fields.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- There were more than 1,500 billiard lovers at Central Music Hall to-night to see Schaefer and Ives play their third game in the four-thousand-point match for $5,000 and the gate receipts. Schaefer left off at the 1,600 mark last night, with an unfinished run of 111, and ahead of Ives by 87 points.

There is a widespread belief that J. Pierpoint Morgan will be asked to take the Chairmanship of the proposed Reorganization Committee of Union Pacific security holders. Mr. Morgan was in Washington yesterday, and there was no meeting of the representatives of the various Union Pacific interests, as had been expected. There will be a meeting in Senator C.S. Brice's office to-day, however.

James Michaele, barber, who lives in the rear of his store in the basement of 756 Seventh Avenue, was shot in the left side of the abdomen last night by a woman who was Maggie Cuff, but who claims that she was married to him at the City Hall two years ago. The injured man was taken to Roosevelt Hospital, and he will surprise the surgeon if he recovers.

In the miscellaneous mail received at the District Attorney's office in the last few days were two letters with unintelligible signatures, detailing what is known of Actor Coghlan's recent marriage, and rehearsing at length his connection with the woman who, for a long time, bore his name. These letters were evidently intended to suggest to the District Atorney the preparing of a case against Mr. Coghlan.

VIENNA, Nov. 23. -- The Reichsrath opened to-day. Prince Alfred Windlschgraetz, the new Austrian Prime Minister, explained to the House that the new Cabinet had been formed by the joint action of the three great parties. He said the first measure that the Government would submit to the House would be the Electoral Reform bill, which would safeguard existing interests, while conferring the franchise upon classes that had hitherto been deprived of it.

Alfred Youngs, a business man of this city and one of the old members of the Union Club, died suddenly early yesterday morning at Broadway and Twenty-first Street. He had spent Wednesday evening at the Union Club, and at 1 o'clock in the morning started for his boarding house at 64, West Thirty-seventh Street.

-- Demand was made in Toledo Wednesday upon the Treasurer of the Toledo and Ohio Central Railroad Company for payment at interest coupons, amounting to 87,650, from the bonds of the Toledo and Ohio Central Extension Company, which bunds and interest, it is alleged, are guaranteed by the Toledo and Ohio Central Railroad.

The annual meeting of the New-York Kindergarten Association was held in the assembly room of the Associated Charities Building, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue, yesterday. The Treasurer's report showed a cash balance of $5,000 for the year. President Sanger of the Board of Education, gave a brief history of the efforts of the board to introduce the kindergarten system into the public schools of this city.

As the examination of the affairs of the Madison Square Bank progresses, new developments are constantly coming to the suffice. At the office of the District Attorney it was said yesterday that some new names were to be brought into the litigation. These names have not figured prominantly in the case heretofore, and belong to men not now connected in an official capacity with the bank.

-- The sub-committee on investigation of the committee appointed last week by the Republican County Committee to investigate the Republican organization and its leaders, and if necessary to report a plan of reorganization, met in the office of Col. S.V.R. Cruger. Fulton and Church Streets, yesterday afternoon, and organized for business.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 23. -- Alexander H. Robinson, on behalf of Edward Austen, Vice President of the American Casualty Insurance and Security Company, this morning filed a bill in the Circuit Court, requesting that receivers be appointed for the purpose of closing up the business of the company.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- A representative of the United Press to-day had an interview with Louise Michel, the notorious French, female Anarchist, in regard to the Barcelona outrage and Anarchism in general. She declared that the throwing of the bombs in the Lyceum Theatre at Barcelona sprang from the death of Pallas, the man who attempted to assassinate Gen. Martinez Campos.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 23. -- By the burning of the five-story iron-front brick dwelling 195 to 202 Jefferson Avenue, occupied by Edson Moore Co., wholesale dry goods, this afternoon, seven employes lost their lives, a fireman was badly injured, and the monetary loss will reach in the neighborhood of $800,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

In an interview last evening in his apartments in the Brunswick Hotel the Brazilian Minister, senor Mendonca, said that from the advices he had received from Brazil, he did not believe the Javary was sunk because her armor had been penetrated by the fatal shot. The armor was twelve inches thick.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The reports of the receipts of the racing associations in the State during the past season are being received at the state Controller's office, so that the amount of tax which each association must pay annually under the Ives poo law may be computed. The associations will far reporting and the amount of tax each will pay are:

Chief of Police John Y. McKane of Gravesend, in speaking to a reporter of The New-York Times, Wednesday, said he was going to take the aggressive and sue some of the newspapers for libel. He believed in this way only could he obtain vindication.

Whether the employes of the Board of Electrical Control come under the regulations of the civil service law has been a much-discussed question for some time. When the board met yesterday, a communication was received from Lee Phillips, Secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Board, asking for a list of the employes of the board.

The steam yacht Valiant left this port yesterday with Mr. and Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt and family and a party of friends for a ten months' cruise. For several weeks the big steamer has been preparing for this cruise. The yacht was thoroughly overhauled and painted white, and supplies were put on board, while in the Erie Basin.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Lizzie Halliday, the murdresg confined in the Monticello Jail, is endeavoring to defeat the ends of justice by trying to take her own life. Since her fruitless efforts to strangle the Sheriff's wife, she has refused to take solid food, and seems bent on starvation. Dr. F.A. McWilliams, the Jail physician, has pumped food into her stomach for four days under a strong protest on her part.

Wheeler H. Peckham had the time of his life yesterday in the cross-examination of Mrs. McGrath-Bates, in the Superior Court, before Judge Freedman. Mr. Peckham is a veteran at the bar, and he has cross-examined no one knows how many witnesses, but the memory of them all has undoubtedly been wiped out by yesterday's struggle with the fair plaintiff in the now celebrated divorce case of Bates vs. Bates.
Riders were unfortunate on the Bridle Path in Central Park yesterday. One was so seriously hurt that he had to be taken to the hospital.

The Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst, T.D. Kennison, and Frank Moss of the Society for the Prevention of Crime yesterday sent a letter to the Commissioners for selecting Grand Jurors, requesting the removal of Hugh Slevin from the body of Grand Jurors. Mayor Gilroy is Chairman of the Commissioners, which include Judges of the various courts.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Depression rules the Yale campus and sways the students' hearts to-night. It is now next to a certainty that a permanent change has been made in the personnel of the Yale 'Varsity football eleven, and that one of its members who has played his position the entire season will be relegated to the side lines and a player with little experience established in his stead.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22. -- A decree affecting between 200,000 and 300,000 persons was signed by Judge Harlan to-day. In accordance with his decision made yesterday, the Judge this morning ordered that the charter of the Supreme Court of the Equitable League of America be annulled; that the corporation be dissolved, and that its assets be distributed among the members entitled to them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Supreme Court of the United States, Nov. 28: present -- The Chief Justice. Mr. Justice Field, Mr. Justice Gray, Mr. Justice Brewer. Mr. Justice Brown. Mr. Justice Shiras, and Mr. Justice Jackson.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Nov. 23 -- P.M. The market to-day was much less active than yesterday. The advance which has been in progress for a couple of days culminated during the morning, and was followed by a reaction which carried the prices of a majority of the active stocks below the closing figures of yesterday.

DEMING, New-Mexico, Nov. 23. -- Reports are current that the Yaqui Indians of the northern portion of Chihuahua have joined the rebels, and there appears to be foundation for the rumor. The Indians are very-bitter against the Diaz Government and never miss an opportunity to revolt when there is any chance for success.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Mr. Herbert Asquith. Home Secretary, moved the third reading of the Employers' Liability bill. Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, the Liberal-Unionist leader, opposed the bill as being a mischievous one for what it did and for what it left undone. The principle existing in the act was pressure that ought not to be put upon employers, excepting on matters they could control.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 23. -- The Chicago and West Michigan passenger train due here at 11 P.M. is wrecked twenty miles from Grand Rapids. The extent of the accident is not known, but it is thought to be serious.

Mrs. Emily Ellsworth Ford, the widow of Gordon L. Ford and a granddaughter of Noah Webster, the lexicographer, died at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the family residence, 97 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The Lehigh Valley freight yard in this city was a scene of bustle and activity all day today. Thirty-two policemen under command of Capt, Farrier took possession of the yards at daylight, and shortly after six drill engines began shifting cars and making up freight trains.

The Summer fish, like the summer birds, have now all migrated, the bluefish bringing up the rear. The latter are now received from Virginia, and in a week or so the markets will be abundantly supplied from the North Carolina fishing grounds.

The men employed by the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company could hardly have chosen a more unfavorable time for striking work, whatever their grievances may have been, for they were almost certain to fail. A time when business is exceptionally dull and it is possible to curtail a labor force without loss, while many men are out of employment and anxious to obtain it, gives the employer every advantage in such a contest.

Mr. John N. Golding has sold, for the New-York Life Insurance Company, to Henry Rothschild, for $18,800, the five-story brick flat 1,730 Madison Avenue, west side, 25 feet south of East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 25.11 by 79. This property was put up at auction under foreclosure on Monday, and was bought by the insurance company at $18,700.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 23. -- George S. Coe, President of the American Exchange Bank of New-York City, was stricken with paralysis while on his way to business on the 9 o'clock express train this morning. He occupied a seat with Charles B. Platt of the banking firm of Platt Wood ward. New-York. Mr. Platt noticed a nervous twitching about Mr. Coe's lips, and, speaking to him, received an inaudible reply.

No indictments implicating the officers and Directors of the Madison Square Bank were returned yesterday by the Grand Jury. That body sat until 2:45 P.M. and then adjourned until Monday morning, when it is thought the indictments will be handed down.

The merchant seamen of to-day, more particularly those who sail out of this port under the British flag, have another complaint to add to their long list of grievances. Another Plimsoll is in demand, and such another reformer would have plenty to do just now if he undertook to ameliorate some of the conditions of a life which seems to be sadly in need of a betterment somewhere.

A fire in the tenement house at 802 Ninth Avenue early yesterday morning imperiled the lives of a score of tenants. That so many escaped without injury is due to the wit and presence of mind of Policeman William E. Daly of the Twenty-second Precinct. Mrs. McCabe, who keeps a fancy goods store on the ground floor, discovered the fire at 1:30 o'clock.

The Schaeffer family, comprising a man in the prime of life, who represents muscular development in its highest form; a youth of nineteen or twenty years, strong, lithe, agile, and graceful; two younger boys, who are already masterful acrobats, and three nimble little girls, one small enough to be carried in a satchel, appeared at Abbey's Theatre yesterday afternoon.

-- Col. Theodore B. Hamilton, flfty-six years old. a veteran of the late war, died at his home in Queens. L.I., Thursday, from a stroke of apoplexy. He was a son of Dr. Frank Hamilton, once a well-known New-York surgeon. When the war broke out Col. Hamilton lived in New-York. He enlisted as a volunteer, and served in the campaign of the Peninsula and at the battle of Vicksburg.

With a smile of satisfaction that rarely left his big, fat face, Charles F. Bates yesterday recounted under oath a series of adventures that might have furnished an excuse for a blush on the countenance of the most hardened roue.

-- Frederick Keer of the Hudson County Wheelmen has been elected Vice President of the New-Jersey Association of Cycling Clubs in place of E.F. Merceles, resigned. Carl von Lengerke of the Atalanta Wheelmen was also elected Secretary in place of L. B. Barnett, resigned. The association has appointed a committee to arrange for the Winter entertainment of its members.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Schaefer looked pale and careworn when he stepped on the platform in Central Music Hall to-night, with his trusty cue to resume his 4,000-point contest at billiards with Frank Ives. The score stood: Schaefer, 2,228; Ives, 2,400. When asked as to his physical condition the Wizard replied:

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The Committee on Awards at the World's Fair is still giving out awards at the Administration Building. The highest award and medal for the choicest line of pure Havana cigars goes to a New-York firm -- M. Stachelberg Co., 159 to 161 South Fifth Avenue, one of the oldest houses in the country, having been established in 1857.

The sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the Psi Upsilon fraternity was celebrated last evening in the clubhouse, in this city, 33 West Forty-second Street. The fraternity was established at Union College by seven undergraduates, three of whom -- the Rev. Samuel Goodale, ex-Judge Sterling G. Hadley, and George W. Tuttle -- are still living.

Chief or Police John Y. McKane of Gravesend was apparently quite happy yesterday, He joked with his friends and laughed heartily over the attempts of the Committee of Twenty-eight to put him behind prison bars.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Western roads succeeded to-day in reaching an agreement regarding the organization of a pool to handle the European immigrant business. At the last moment, the Chicago Great Western consented to go in with the other roads and become a party to the proposed arrangement.
The Tenth Ward Jefferson Society of Democratic Voters met at Highlands Hall, 301 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, last evening to discuss the question of reorganization. John H. Hiliman presided.

The representatives of the diverse interests in the Union Pacific Railroad have almost completed their Committee on Reorganization. Up to last evening no word had been received from J. pierpont Morgan in reply to the invitation to accept a place on the committee. Other members of the committee will be: Calvin S. Brice, Chairman; Louis Fitzgerald, A.H. Boissevain, Samuel Carr, G.M. Dodge, and Col. H.L. Higginson of Boston.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Nov. 24 -- P.M. London bought a few stocks at the opening to-day, and its example was followed by local traders, the result being considerable activity at advancing prices during the first hour. At the higher prices, however, there was a disposition to realize profits and the market became dull.

The Commissioners of Accounts are looking into some of the affairs of the Brooklyn Bridge. They have requested Thomas H. Terry, a real estate agent of this city, to appear before them at 9:30 o'clock this forenoon as a witness.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- London sent orders to sell Pennsylvania at the opening, but there was no disposition to offer the stock down, and the price was unchanged all day at about 49 7/8. St. Paul and Reading were bid up by the traders, in sympathy with the New-York market, and tales were told about how well the coal and iron company was doing.

It was a very fortunate chance that made it possible for the colleagues of Mr. FREDERICK D. TAPPEN, Chairman of the Clearing House Loan Committee, to present him with a tankard that nearly 200 years ago had been given to a Governor of the Bank of England "in token of his great ability, industry, and strict uprightness at a time of extreme difficulty."

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 24. -- The annual Harvard-Yale Gun Club contest in this city this afternoon resulted in a victory for the Harvard team by a score of 119 to 118. The teams and the scores made by each are as follows:

JERSEY CITT, N.J., Nov. 24. -- The condition of Lehigh Valley affairs in this city to-day was somewhat improved. Not only were outgoing trains sent away on time, but of the incoming trains only one was late. That was due at 10:40 A.M., and did not arrive until 11:15.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- An eloping couple from Winston, Conn., has been captured by the Hudson police. The woman is Augusta Unger, wife of Farmer Henry Unger, and the man with whom she eloped is a fish dealer named Victor Spies, who has a market in Hudson.

It will aid in judging of the probable future of the kingdom of Hawaii to recall the political evolution through which the islands have passed daring the last forty years. When the American missionaries first went there in 1820, the people were in a state of barbarism and were ruled by native chiefs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Now that Commodore Walker has been released from duty on the Columbia Trial Board, he will immediately call together the board recently appointed to consider what should be done to remedy the defects in the topheavy vessels of the new navy.

VIROQUA, Wis., Nov. 24. -- The funeral of ex-Secretary of Agriculture Jeremiah M. Rusk took place to-day. Over the same road that he traversed nearly half a century ago with his stage, hundreds of mourners, among them many prominent men, followed the body to the grave. Through all Vernon County the day was one of mourning.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 24. -- The new Henrietta Theatre, corner Spring and Front Streets, the Chittenden Hotel and Auditorium, and the Park Theatre were destroyed by fire to-night, which started in the new playhouse. One life was lost.

When a steamship of the Columbia's great length and tonnage has her upper decks drowned by waves, the frightful weather that has been prevailing out upon the Atlantic can be realized. The Columbia belongs to the Hamburg-American Packet Company, and plies between this port and Southampton.
Dr. Paul Hoffman, forty years old, of 55 West Fifty-third Street, Assistant Superintendent of Public Schools, was run down last night by a Broadway cable car and seriously injured.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Great changes are contemplated in the judicial, legislative, and executive departments of this city and of Essex County. The Republican County Committee has been perfecting plans. Not only are many typewriters being kept busy inditing repeal measures to be presented to the next Legislature, but a general framework has been constructed for new laws.

Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer and Mr. S. Marx have bought the southeast corner of Dey and Greenwich Streets, 43.3 feet on the latter by 77.6 on the former, from Mr. Edmond Huerstel. The building is a five-story brownstone front, with stores. In part payment, Mr. Huerstel took six lots on the north side of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, 175 feet east of Willis Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- This has been the busiest day which the members of the Ways and Means Committee have experienced since they began work on the tariff measure. There has not been a meeting of the committee proper, but the various sub-committees have prosecuted inquiries in many different quarters relatives to the schedules which yet remain to be adjusted.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 24. -- Twenty-nine head of thoroughbreds were sold here to-day by Col. S.D. Bruce of New-York. They brought $10,795. But few strangers were present. While the horses evidently brought all they were worth, prices ruled lower than usual. Only six horses brought $500 and over as follows:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 24. -- The crimson of Harvard and the blue of Yale are to be seen every-where to-night. The town is crowded with followers of both colleges, and the prospects for a big assamblage at the game to-morrow are very bright.
The Brazilian flag was hoisted yesterday afternoon on board the newly-converted cruiser America. The ceremony took place off Robbin's Reef Lighthouse, where the vessel lies at anchor.

The Republicans of the Eighteenth District had a stormy, packed meeting at 341 West Thirty-seventh Street last evening. The more honest members of the party, disgusted with the leadership of George W. Wanmaker, had started out with a determination to overthrow him. But Mr. Wanmaker not only succeeded in putting two of his friends into the offices of Chairman and Secretary, but ran the meeting as he pleased.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24. -- At the conclusion of to-day's Cabinet meeting in Washington Secretary of Was Lamont hurried off to the Pennsylvania Railway Station. He missed the 4 o'clock "limited," which arrives here at 5 o'clock and in New-York at 9:08, and was forced to take the 4:20 express, the time of which is an hour and a half slower to New-York.

-- A large delegation representing nearly all the electric street railway companies in Canada waited on the Government in Ottawa yesterday and asked that steel rails used for electric roads be imported on the same terms as rails for railways operated by steam. At present $6 per ton is charged on rails over twenty-five pounds for street railways, while rails of the same kind for ordinary railways are admitted free of duty.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 24. -- A mysterious woman appeared Tuesday night in the village of Linden. She was discovered sitting on the high trestle of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in a severe rainstorm.

NEW-HAVEN Conn., Nov. 24. -- Ezekiel H. Trowbridge, one of the wealthiest and best-known business men of the State, died at his home in this city this morning after an illness of several weeks. Death has been expected for several days. Mr. Trowbridge's fatal illness was caused by an attack of complicated liver and kidney troubles.

TERRE HAUTE,. Ind., Nov. 24. -- Grand Master Sargent of the firemen left to-night for St. Paul, Minn., to take up the question of a schedule for the Chicago and Northwestern Road. He said before leaving:

-- The pastors of Savannah, Ga., have recently expressed themselves nearly unanimously as adverse to the practice of women preaching or exhorting. Commenting upon their judgment. The Savannah Press says: "Some women are persuasive speakers, and no objection can be urged to their leading their own class meetings or conducting Bible lessons at their Sunday schools or prayer rooms.
ARKISON, Marks, and wife to Hudson City Savings Institution; n s of 142d St, w of Concord Av. 1 year..................... $3,000

LONG ISLAND CITY, Nov. 24. -- When ex-Mayor Patrick J. Gleason set up his City Government in his private office in 112 Front Street, Long Island City, after his forcible ejection from the City Hall by his successful opponents, there was among the few retainers who remained loyal to him Principal Peter E. Demarest of the Fifth Ward School.

Policeman Thomas McCormick of the West Thirtieth Street Station arrested a young man last night and put him so far behind the veil of mystery that it is not known whether he is at Police Headquarters or at the West Thirtieth Street Station.

Nathaniel S. Jones, a member of the "Big Four" combination of speculators, who swung heavy deals their own way in grain in the Chicago market a few years ago, and for a time one of the boldest operators in stocks in the New-York market, sent word to the Stock Exchange yesterday that he could not meet his liabilities.

The first regular meeting of the season of the Princeton Club of New-York was held Thursday at the Brunswick Hotel. The reading of the Secretary's report and the election of officers for the ensuing year were the only business transacted, and then the members adjourned to the grillroom, where a supper was spread. Beer was served in steins and everything done was in the most approved Bohemian fashion.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Nov. 24. -- Fire was discovered this morning in the Williams Block, on Western Avenue, and before the firemen arrived the entire building was enveloped in flames. The first floor was occupied by Falk's barber's shop and Welch's restaurant, the upper part being used for offices and sleeping rooms. The block was owned by Dr. C.C. Williams, and was valued at $15,000.

The foreign exchange market was dull and steady. Bills were scarce. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.84 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.83 1/4@$4.83 1/2 for sixty-day bills, $4.85 1/2@$4.85 3/4 for demand, $4.86 @$4.86 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.82 for commercial.

It is reported that in the bill soon to be submitted to the House by the Ways and Means Committee many of the duties imposed on agricultural products by the McKinley tariff will be removed or largely reduced. There are many of these duties that should be repealed. Those who imposed them sought by this action to "fool the farmer."

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin Gaston, the Liberian Emigration Commissioner, who was arrested on Thursday, at the request of the police of Atlanta, Ga., on a charge of having swindled Elihu H. Belcher, a negro living in that city, was again arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. Before his case was called he was extremely nervous and tears rolled down his cheeks as he talked with his counsel.

WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 24. -- Ex-Gov. John J. Jacob fell dead on Twelfth Street at 4:15 this afternoon, while on his way to hold a consultation with attorneys a few squares away. He was born in Hampshire County in 1829, was a graduate of Dickinson College, Pennsylvania, and for a number of years before the war a professor in the University of Missouri.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- At the next annual meeting of the stockholders of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, which will be held in this city on Jan. 16, Mr. Elisha P. Wilbur will decline a renomination to the Presidency, if, indeed, he does not resign that office some time during the less than two months that now remain before the date of the meeting.

A special train in six sections will be run over the New-Haven and Hartford Railroad to-day to carry football enthusiasts to Springfield to witness the contest between the Harvard and Yale 5,000 New-Yorkers will watch the game. Some Big parties left last night. Henry C. Duval and a party of Brooklyn clubmen left at 6 o'clock last night.

One very good reason which is urged for having all sales at auction in Brooklyn held in the Exchange room, in Montague Street, is that an auctioneer's services come into play in judicial sales. At present, Brooklyn still has the antiquated system of having the referee himself do the selling.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- A meeting of the Cabinet was held this morning. The situation arising from the reading yesterday in the Chamber of Deputies of the report of the committee appointed to investigate the bank scandals was most thoroughly discussed, and the Ministers decided that their usefulness was at an end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Unless a steamer should unexpectedly come along from Honolulu, it is not now supposed that there will be any Hawaiian information before the meeting of Congress.

The desire of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners to have the public understand that they hope to accomplish something before the end of the year had the effect yesterday of drawing to the rooms of the board, in William Street, many of those who attended the sessions regularly when there really seemed to be a prospect of business.

Fanny Styer, a young servant, was quick and desperate yesterday morning in taking her life in a remarkable way in the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station. At 10:45 o'clock she was reorded as a "suspicious person." At 11 o'clock the entry "Committed suicide" was made.

-- The Gas Commissioners decided yesterday to light portions of the following annexed district streets with electric lights; One Hundred and Sixty-sixth, Birch, King's Bridge, and Orchard Streets, Bailey, Anderson, Boston, Elton, Claremont, Manhattan, Marcher, Rider, Riverdale, and Vandercliff Avenues, Broadway, Featherbed Lane, and Macomb's Dam Road.

Matthew Coleman, President of the Mutual Brewing Company of College Point, L.I., and of the Coleman Brewing Company at 455 and 457 West Fourteenth Street, was arraigned in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon, before Justice Ryan, to answer a charge of larceny. The two brewing companies are in the hands of receivers, and the receiver of the Mutual Brewing Company, Major Edward Duffy, was the complainant.

Sarah L. Whelpley, a lunatic, was committed yesterday to the Flatbush Insane Asylum by the Kings County Charities Commissioners. The woman was arrested yesterday noon in front of St. Phoebe's Mission, on DeKalb Avenue, while compelling three members of the mission to kneel on the sidewalk and pray under threats of murder.

"Bradstreet's" to-morrow will say: A feature has been the stimulus to sales of seasonable staples by colder weather at Chicago, Kansas City, Omaha, Milwaukee, Minneapolis, Duluth, and St. Paul, at almost all of which centres Winter clothing, flannels, shoes, hats, and in some instances hardware, have been in great demand by country merchants.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- As the time for the contest with Yale approaches, greater secrecy surrounds the practice at the college. Everything possible is being done to perfect the general play of the team. The most that can be learned regarding the practice to-day seems to indicate a gradual improvement of the interference and much snap in the general team play.

Edward Guerin, a lawyer of Montreal, representing himself as interested in Mello's affairs, called on United States District Attorney Mitchell on Thursday and asked that steps be taken to stop the sailing of the America, upon the ground that the neutrality laws were being violated.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 24. -- After denying to-day that the Pennsylvania and Maryland Steel Companies had been leased to a combination, Frederick W. Wood, President and receiver of the Maryland Steel Company, and Second Vice President of the Pennsylvania Steel Company, made an important statement as to the steel industry.

NEWTON, N.C., Nov. 24. -- Cold weather and a raw wind greeted the contestants of the all-age stake of the Eastern Field Trials Club when the competition was resumed this morning. Birds were found in ample numbers.

December is always sure of having one very important event distinctly to mark it in the yearly calendar, and that is the arrival of the sun at the extreme southerly point in his journey. The Winter solstice, as this is termed, occurs on the 21st, when the sun enters the constellation of Capricornus, and astronomical Winter begins.

A fire was discovered last evening in the four-story double flat brick building, 154 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. An old woman, an invalid, who lived with her son on the second floor, was rescued from the flames by a tireman, who carried her down an extension ladder.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 25. -- Congressman Charles O'Neill, the "Father of the House of Representatives," he having been a member of the lower house of Congress from the Second District of Philadelphia since 1862, with the exception of the forty-second session, died at his home, in this city, at 5 o'clock this evening:

Mr. Wilson explains that the Norwegian title of Bjornson's drama means, literally, " over power," and is intended to suggest " the striving for something beyond the striver's strength and his consequent state." This explanatory note is necessary to the reader who is not in full sympathy with the Scandinavian cult, as are also the two literary references at the end of the volume to works on epilepsy and hysteria by Charcot and Richer.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 25. -- An investigation is being made here which may prove the innocence of a woman convicted, a week ago, of stealing an old man's money.

A turn on the short interest and a lively speculation in Sugar, have been the main features of the market the past week. A narrow and professional market easily becomes oversold. This was its condition last week, and a rally of two or three points resulted. Easy money is our strongest bull factor at this time, and its influence is most strikingly exhibited in the bond list.

Two lions had been shot, when we both heard an animal breathing alongside of our shelter, within a few feet of us, and the next instant a gentle shake given to the hut, and a noise, as of one of the loose branches with which it was covered being torn off, let us know there was another lion in our neighborhood even ore enterprising than the two that had been shot.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The President to-day appointed W.J. Bulger Collector of Customs at Oswego, N.Y. Dr. Bulger is the present Mayor of the city and is a prominent politician. He led the May Convention delegation from this district to the Chicago Convention. He is a brother of C.N. Bulger, leader of the State machine forces in Osgewo, and who was also an applicant for the Collectorship.
BUFFALO, Nov. 25. -- Charges of malfeasance in office have been made against Sheriff Beck, and the specifications have been forwarded to Gov. Flower, with a request for the Sheriffs removal.

BUFFALO, Nov. 25. -- So far as Buffalo goes, the backbone of the Lehigh Valley strike has been broken. The freight blockade is ended and there is no longer a "tie-up." Still the strikers assert that they have the company at their mercy and that victory is but a few days or hours away.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 25. -- Walter H. Hellmer of 134 Elm Street is held at Central Police Station on suspicion. He will be charged with attempting to blackmail M.J. Baughen, father of Joseph E. Baughen, the young bookkeeper who disappeared in Chicago Sept. 14.

Among the notable figures in the National Guard ranks in this city there is none mere prominent than Chaplain Frederick Rotzler of the First Battery of Artillery, Capt. Louis Wendel commanding. Chaplain Rotzler is not a minister and is of the ranks, but he holds a high place in the esteem of his fellow-members.

When the Board of Supervisors, acting as a Board of Canvassers, met in Brooklyn yesterday, John Y. McKane of Gravesend was in his seat. For a time he assisted in correcting the returns of the canvassers.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The Earl of Rosebery, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, has offered his Under Secretary, Sir Philip W. Currie, the post left vacant at St. Petersburg by the death of Sir Robert Morler. Carrie hesitates to accept the offer, as he prefers the comfort of his present place in the Foreign Office.

The declaration by a "close friend" of Judge MAYNARD'S that that jurist may give the lawyers and newspapers that have been "persecuting" him an opportunity to prove their "charges" is a rather welcome piece of intelligence. At any rate, it shows a just appreciation on the part of Judge MAYNARD'S friends, if not on his own part, of the predicament in which the elections have left him.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- A large crowd of students have been waiting around the bulletin board since 5 o'clock to ascertain the final score of the Yale-Harvard game. Previous to the arrival of the score repeated cheers for Yale could be heard, but when the final score came the crowd went crazy, and cheers for Yale, long and hearty,

Not many babies, even royal ones, nestle in as beautiful a cradle as that which will hold the baby form of Prince Charles of Roumania, the first-born of the Crown Prince and Princess of Roumania. It is the gift of the Queen of Roumania, "Carmen Sylva," as she is even better known, and is the work of the famous Testolini of Vienna, whose skill in wood carving is of almost world-wide renown.

The Parliamentary and personal results of the report to the Italian Chamber upon the "Panamino" are likely to be more important than the results properly political. It is true enough that the tendency of the disclosures is to discredit the monarchical Ministry, and indirectly the monarchy itself, and thus to strengthen the republicans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The new regulations as to the registration of Chinese under the extension of the Geary act, issued from the Treasury Department to-day, provide that all Chinese laborers in the United States must register before a Collector of Internal Revenue before May 3 next or else be subject to deportation.

It seems as if it were only yesterday that the civilized world was made the happier by the news of the escape of that devoted Catholic-priest, Father Joseph Ohrwalder. After the fall of Khartoum, in January, 1885, many attempts were made to bring about the release of Europeans in the Mahdi's hands, but all efforts were unavailing.

The work of Miss Emily Faithfull is so well known on both sides of the Atlantic that this presentment of her face, taken from The Lady' Pictorial, will be as acceptable in New-York as it is in London, where is her home and the place of her most active labors.
PARIS, Nov. 25. -- The whole French Cabinet has resigned, and President Carnot has accepted their resignations.

Edward S. Willard will return to us this week, after a long absence, and will appear at the Garden Theatre, which is now under the management of A.M. Palmer, in "The Professor's Love Story," the entertaining and whimsical comedy by Barrie, the author of "A Widow in Thrums" and "My Lady Nicotine," which was seen here too briefly in Willard's last engagement.

It was expected that the continuation of the examination of ex-President Matthew Coleman of the Coleman and Mutual Brewing Companies before Justice Ryan in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning would bring out the fact that Coleman had appropriated the proceeds of notes made payable to the Mutual Brewing Company to his own use.
The monthly "smoker" of the Commercial Travelers' Club at the club's rooms, at 15 West Thirty-first Street, Friday evening, was well attended, and was a vary enjoyable event.

"The spotted veil habit will have to have its asylums, or gold cures, or something," said an oculist lately. "Its victims increase constantly, and they seem to be as devoid of will power to resist the mania as is the devotee of any evil practice. Intelligent women come to me to be treated for eye troubles that in some cases are wholly produced by the use of the dotted veil, and in others seriously aggravated.

The feature of the past week in real estate circles has been the very perceptible movement in down-town business property. Not only have there been several notable sales and exchanges in such realty, but a much larger amount of negotiation has been in progress than has been the case for many a month.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- There can be but four more days of race-track gambling in New-Jersey. On the 1st day of December, according to the provisions of the last act of the Legislature of 1893, the close season of race-track gambling begins. It continues until March 1. When the close season has expired the three race-track laws will have been repealed.
PARIS, Nov. 25. -- Count d'Eu's Chamberlain said this evening that the family sustained no relations of any kind with Admiral Mello, the commander of the insurgent fleet in Brazilian waters.

La Champagne, which sailed for Havre yesterday, had some distinguished passengers on board. Among them were the Baron and Baroness Seilliere; Jean Charles Cazin, the artist; M. Michel Cazin, Lieut. Ivanowsky, of the Russian Navy; Dr. Sixto A. Pabilla; Prof. Alexander Krupsky, M. Charles Roussel, and the Rev. William S. Adamson.

There was a large gathering at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday afternoon of Daughters of the American Revolution, the descendants of patriotic sires, who met to celebrate Evacuation Day. There were members of the society present from all parts of the country, and the salon of the hotel, which was draped with American flags, was filled to its utmost capacity.

ROME, Nov. 25. -- Signor Zanardelli, President of the Chamber of Deputies, to-day made to King Humbert a lengthy explanation of the difficulties of the situation, and gave his opinion against an extra Parliamentary Cabinet. The King asked Signor Zanardelli to form a Ministry, and the latter begged for time to consider the matter.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The report of Willlam K. Ackerman, auditor of the World's Columbian Exposition, was officially sent to the Board of Directors to-day. That the exposition was a financial success is proved by the figures of the report. It shows, by making an approximate estimate of the liabilities and receipts up to Nov. 12. that the net assets over and above all liabilities amount to $1,862,482.

Although we shall hear a good deal before Friday night about all New-York cheering itself hoarse at Manhattan Field on Thursday, a trip to the Grand Central Station or the Sound boats piers on Wednesday will amply testify that a goodly portion of New-York means to turn its back on football and he metropolis, and that for a day or two at least the deserted farms of New-England will be misnomers.
Yesterday's match, at Springfield and the Yale-Princeton match in this city on Thanksgiving Day will be, we trust, the last "great" college football games.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 25. -- The United States Grand Jury this morning adjourned for one week, after having voted upon sixty-three indictments, among which were these:

The second condition which presents analogies to the duplex or multiplex personalities, which are under consideration, is that of the somnambulism which occurs in the hypnotic sleep. While usually the hypnotic subject is passive and unconsciously receives the suggestions which are impressed upon him, not unfrequently a personality comes to the front which acts independently, and presents all the characteristics which we have found pertaining to a distinct personality.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- It is my intention to write a special article concerning the personality and the literary work of M. Francois de Curel, so I must not listen now to the interesting suggestions made by either of his four plays, as given to the public in the short period of eighteen months. Until then, he was almost unknown.

The pupils of Louis Pasteur, in commemoration of his seventieth anniversary, have issued a medal made by O. Roty, in which the great scientist appears in left profile, wearing a cape and skull cap. The inscriptions are his name and place and date of birth. The legend is, "For Science, Country, Humanity," in French.
Commissioner of Public Works Daly was feeling much better last evening. It was said at his home that all danger had passed and he was resting easily.

Arangements have been completed for the exhibition in this city of the famous torture instruments from the Royal Castle of Nuremberg. This remarkable historical collection was purchased in 1890 by J. Ichenhauser of London for the Right Honorable the Earl of Shrewsbury and Talbot, England's Premier Earl.

LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 25. -- The roost exciting game of toot ball ever played in the South was played on the Virginia Military Institute grounds to-day between the Institute team and the the University of Virginia. This game virtually decides the championship of the South, both teams baring been very successful this year. All storekeepers closed their shops in Lexington to see the game. The line out was as follows:

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 14. -- P.H. Burns of Cleveland was married on the 6th inst. to Miss Mary Knowles, daughter of Lewis P. Knowles, one of the leading planters of the colony. Mr. Burns, although an American citizen, holds the responsible position of Superintendent of Telegraphs in the Bahamas.
SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- The name of this picturesque village has lately been threatened with a change to disassociate it with "prison," by villagers who know nothing of the town's history.

The assault at arms which was given at the Fencers Club on Friday evening of last week, followed by a reception of the French fencing masters who have of late years come to this country, was a revelation to the uninitiated of the hold which fencing has, within comparatively recent years, taken upon New-York society people.

When Gen. John B. Gordon of Virginia was introduced to an audience in the Music Hall by ex-Chief Justice Noah Davis, last night, he was greeted by an outburst of applause that would have won any Confederate soldier to the Union side.

Russell Sage, in speaking of the disposition of funds in his possession as one of the Trustees of the Kansas Pacific consolidated mortgage, said yesterday: " The amount I am alleged to hold as Trustee, resulting from land sales, has been greatly exaggerated. The sum is only about $200,000. This money could properly and has heretofore been used for the retirement of the bonds.

It is a significant fact that "An American Duchess" has been drawing good houses at the Lyceum Theatre. The manager makes no announcement of a change of bill. The actors draw there even when the play is not of a particularly captivating quality. They are all good actors and they form a well-disciplined troupe.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The appearance of Mme. Modjeska in a drama that is entirely new to English-speaking theatregoers, and from the pen of a young German author whose daring and persistent efforts along new lines have raised him to a position of eminence among the dramatic authors of his country, is quite enough novelty for one week.

St. Paul's great declaration, " the things seen are temporal; the things not seen are eternal " -- accepted timidly here by the pious, but regarded as a mere phrase by the materialists -- is in India a commonplace of daily certainty. Nobody there doubts the continuity of life any more than he doubts that the setting sun will rise again, the same orb, to-morrow.

It is not too much or too sanguine to say the expected occasionally happens. Yesterday a piece of news to which the New-York public has looked forward with acute confidence, but up to then looked forward only to be disappointed, was given out for publication by all the friends of both the gentlemen most deeply interested.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- It appears that the power of torpedo boats must be increased if they are to discharge the great missiles prepared for them. The recent test of the Howell torpedo at Newport, according to reports just received at the Navy Department, shows that the torpedoes consume a great deal of steam power and materially lower the speed of the boat discharging them.

The body of Mrs. Margaret Lakeland, wife of Alfred Lakeland, the horse trainer, who died under suspicious circumstances at 701 Douglass Street, Brooklyn, Tuesday, was buried in Holy Cross Cemetery, Flatbusb, yesterday afternoon. Before the funeral. Coroner Kene and the jury visited the flat at 363 Sixth Avenue where the body lay, and viewed it, preparatory to holding an inquest.

The inevitable failure of the strike on the Lehigh Valley Railroad is calculated to increase public sympathy for the men engaged in it, notwithstanding the palpable mistake which they committed from the point of view of their own immediate interest. Their failure cannot be taken as evidence that they had no real grievance or that their demands were unfair and did not deserve to be heeded.

This little story by Mrs. Wiggin, while it possesses much of the characteristic charm of the graceful writer whose " Cathedral Courtship" and other delicatelyhumorous sketches have been so greatly admired, is rather strained and fine-spun and a little too artificial and pedantic to be a very popular tale with growing girls.

The Sons of the Revolution closed the celebration of Evacuation Day with a dinner at Delmonico's. Covers had been laid for 248 persons, to be seated at the honor table and at six transverse tables. When the hour of assembly came fifty or more members who had not eng-agred sittings appeared and asked to be accommodated.

The Twilight Club is negotiating for the purchase of the building formerly occupied by the Manhattan Athletic Club, at Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. A syndicate of members has been organized for the purchase, agreeing to pay the price asked, $500,000, if the club will take the property.

To commemorate the success of Pain's fireworks at the World's Exposition and as a mark of appreciation for the services of his men, George W. Pain tendered a dinner to his employes last night at Wilson's restaurant, Brooklyn. Mr. Pain complimented the men whose devotion to him had helped to make his name famous the world over. He expressed his heartfelt regard for their attachment to him and their work.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.L. Nov. 25. -- Football teams from the Theological Institute of New-York and the Staten Island Cricket Club, played a frame at the grounds of the latter club, at Livingston this afternoon.

Seven of the employes at Ellis Island received letters from Commissioner Senner yesterday asking for their resignations, to take effect Dec. 15. All the men were appointed under the Republican Administration.

"Economic Education and American Citizenship" is the subject of the address President Seth Low of Columbia College is to deliver on Wednesday evening next at the free lecture course of the School of Social Economics. Union Square, and, whether or not the woman of the future is to give personal voice to the government of her country, she at least intends to understand how it should be done.

Collector KILBRETH gave a conspicuous illustration of what real civil service reform means by promoting Mr. CHARLES F. KING from a clerkship in the Warehouse Division to a Deputy Collectorship, with a view to placing him in charge of that division. Mr. KING has been in the Custom House for about eight years, and has proved his competency by his service.

I. " Long " Hodgman and his sister and his sister's daughter, Hannah, lived, together in a cottage on the outskirts of Aberdeen. " Long" Hodgman was an accountant in the Asbestos Fire Insurance Company, highly valued for industry and accuracy, and renowned for reach of arm and length of leg.

NEW-WESTMINSTER, B.C., Nov. 25. -- Princess Luisi of Tahiti left yesterday for San Francisco and home. Over two years ago the Princess, who is a niece of the reigning King of Tahiti and granddaughter of Pomare II., took passage on a ship at Papio, the capital of Tahiti, for the neighboring Island of Maltia to visit her friends.

The eyes of William Dean Howells, which are large and blue, with silvery reflections, sudden as the breath of a wave, or faint refractions indicative of serious interior vision, contain in their clear pupils something infinite and vague as the tranquil sea.

Senator TURPIE of Indiana has been proclaiming to his constituents the beautiful principle that when the people elect a Democratic President they also elect Democratic Postmasters in Hanpeck and Pinhook, and these should be allowed to take their seats. There is nothing novel in this principle.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- The billiard match between Schaefer and Ives was not finished till early this morning. The game was marked by variable play. The balls rolled poorly for each player, and wrangles between the two delayed the game.

When a man is barely thirty, and yet manages to draw nearly if not quite the largest congregation in Brooklyn, where large congregations are the rule, there must be something unusual in him. This is true especially if he draws these congregations Sunday after Sunday, morning as well as evening.

Manuel de la Cueva, ex-Vice Consul of Spain in this city, who is a prominent member of the Calumet Club and a well-known man about town, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge, preferred by an old acquaintance and former fellow-club member, of having sent threatening, insulting, and annoying letters through the mails.

From The Baltimore Sun, Nov. 24. Maryland is not much given to bragging of what she did in Revolutionary times, but if she exhibited as much energy in blowing her own horn as Massachusetts does in blowing hers, she could soon make Bunker Hill and Lexington seem comparatively petty events.

From The Baltimore American, Nov. 22. Terrapin, the now greatest delicacy known to the epicure, are a little lower in price this year than they were last, although their comparative scarcity makes them one of the most precious luxuries. "Counts" -- that is, terrapins -- that measure six inches or over, which brought $55 per dozen last year, are now selling for $50.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25. -- A suit brought by C.A. Spreckels against his father and brothers with allegations of fraud has created a great sensation in commercial circles. Though the disagreements in the family date back several years, intelligence of the strained relations between C.A. Spreckels and his brothers were confined to the intimate friends of the parties.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 25. -- It's the same old story. Harvard came here prepared to "wipe up" the gridiron at Hampden Park with Yale this afternoon, and her followers brought thousands of dollars to cover the New-Haven money. To-night the Harvard players are trying to figure out how they failed to score, and the backers of the crimson -- well, if they have not bought mileage tickets, they will have to walk home.

Although the accumulation of idle money in the banks still goes on, and the surplus reserve has now passed the seventy-million-dollar line, there are some signs of a favorable change in general trade conditions. There is a slight increase in loans, and bankers report that in their exchanges they find indications of greater activity and greater variety in activity in the ordinary lines.

From the Electrical Engineer, Nov. 22. The first practical test of electricity for the propulsion of boats on canals was made last Saturday morning, at Brighton, a few miles to the eastward of Rochester.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- There have been numerous false alarms from the Vatican during the past few years, but this time preparations are being seriously made for the election of a new Pope. While still able to get about and take part sparingly in public functions, Leo XIII. has visibly fallen into the stage of senile decay, which the physicians do not believe can last till March.

The excitement caused in National Guard circles by the retirement of Col. Cavanagh of the Sixty-ninth Regiment has simmered down and the effect is already noticeable in the regiment. All quarrels that have been prophesied between Major Duffy and Lieut. Col. Moran over the command of the regiment will probably fall to the ground, as both declare that they are the best of friends.
and not as a mere party triumph, the war horses champed the bits in their hungry mouths almost with ferocity.

The five committees appointed for the unveiling of the five memorial tablets placed by the Society of the Sons of the Revolution in various parts of the city to mark spots made famous in Revolutionary history simultaneously performed their tasks at precisely 10 o'clock.

Gentlewomen in business are now quite common in London, well-born milliners, dressmakers, florists, and more having been duly recorded. A "lady laundress" is perhaps rather more uncommon, but that she, too, exists is shown in an interview with one recently printed in The London Queen.

The fifth annual In-door games of the Twenty-third Regiment Athletic Association were held last night in the regiment's armory on Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn. All the available sitting and standing room was occupied by members and friends of the association. The Floor Committee were G.A. Barnett, H.M. Cowperthwait. G.A. Simpson, J.J. Murphy, M.C. Ebel, F.H. Cordnan, W.B. Willard E.E. Ironmonger, C.L. Schofield, A.P. Dunkley, and W.G. Ketcham.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 25. -- The most exciting session of the General Assembly, Knights of Labor, that has ever been held will probably end on Monday, and the final adjournment will be taken, with matters in a state of chaos.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Thursday will mark the first Thanksgiving Day passed by the members of the present Administration in Washington. So far as present indications point, the day will be spent by the President's official family in the quietest manner. In the White House the President and Mrs. Cleveland, after attending the morning service at church, will have luncheon, followed in due time by their customary late dinner in the private dining room.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 25. -- A good story is told of William O. Curtis in relation to the recent visit of burglars to the house of the Rev. William Grosvenor of this place. Mr. Curtis has been out of town Friday, and on returning rode up from the railroad station in the bus with a gentlemanly stranger, who remarked that it was his first visit to Lenox.

Joseph R. Clarke and Jackson Wallace are still working hard to be elected President of the next Brooklyn Board of Aldermen. Both claim they have received the pledges of a majority of the Aldermen. Neither has an Idea his opponent is likely to succeed.

From The London Telegraph. Artistic piracy on a considerable scale has been brought to light by a recent case beard in the Tenth Chamber of the Paris Law Courts. Favareilles, an obscure artist, has been cried and condemned for pirating or forging drawings or cartoons purporting to have been done by those later-day rivals of Gavarni and Cham -- Forain, Willette, and Stengelen.

Nathan Hale, tne patriot spy, was a native of Connecticut, his birthplace being the little farming town of Coventry, in Tolland County. The date of his birth was June 6, 1755. He was the sixth of a family of twelve children of Richard Hale, a typical New-Englander of colonial days, and like his neighbors, a Puritan.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Thanksgiving will find the Lakewood season well open, and, in point of distinguished persons, far in advance of previous years. Not only have all the cottagers returned to spend the Puritan festival by their own firesides, but the hotels and boarding houses are well filled.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Some inaccuracies in the Trenton letter printed in The Times last Sunday should be corrected. The writer begins his constitutional strictures by saying that very little of the English was taken out of the Constitution of 1776 by that of 1844. He cannot be old enough to speak from memory, or he would, have refrained from making such an assertion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Department of State this afternoon gave out another volume of ex-Commissioner Blount's report. It consists of a number of affidavits, a long list of statements and interviews, the correspondence relative to the landing of the marines of the Boston, the protest of Gov. Cleghorn, the letters that passed between the Queen and the provisional Government, and statistics of the products of the islands, area, and population and its composition.

Octave Uzanne, the French author who adversely criticised the architecture of the Chicago Fair because it was classical and he had expected to find it distinctively American, is not an art critic. But he is the best authority that book lovers knowon subjects specially interesting to book lovers, and whenever he writes about these he writes as an expert.

Mr. Black's novels are the easiest of reading. The clever Western critic's eulogy of a stirring book that " it made me miss a meal" would not be applicable to "The Handsome Humes." You can pick it up when you please, before or after dinner, and still enjoy your repast. There is nothing introspective or retrospective about Mr. Black.

Henry J. Yates, Henry J. Yates, who was Mayor of Newark, N.J., from 1876 to 1880, died suddenly Friday night of heart disease. Mr. Yates had spent Friday in New-York. He returned home at 5 P.M., ate supper, and retired at 9 P.M. He became ill in bed and expired before a doctor arrived.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 25. -- After Yale had won the toss, taking the north end of the field, so as to get all the advantage possible of the wind, Harvard in consequence had the ball. The crimson boys opened with a flying wedge, gaining about twenty yards. Then Wrightington went through the centre for two yards.

Charles F. King, the new Deputy Collector, was sworn into office yesterday at the Custom House by Collector Kilbreth, who assigned him to the charge of the Warehouse Division, in place of Deputy Collector Charles A. Burr. Mr. Burr was transferred to the Entry Division, over which ex-Deputy Collector Wilson Berryman presided until his retirement.
