Some call it the Workingman's School, others call it the School of Ethical Culture, but the best name for it is the School of Good Nature. It is just thirteen years old, and is situated at 109 West Fifty-fourth Street, although there are a great many New-Yorkers who do not know anything about it.

The suit brought by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, as Trustee, to foreclose the New-York and Northern second mortgage of $3,200,000 was decided in favor of the plaintiff yesterday by Judge Dykman of the Supreme Court, sitting in White Plains. This practically insures the NewYork Central's control of the property.

Over in England they discovered not long ago that Tschaikowsky was a great composer, and so they persuaded him to come and be a doctor of music. He was such a modest man that he really thought It an honor to share the title "Mus. Doc. Oxon." with a host of non-entities and mediocrities owho can get the distinction by pure mechanical skill in music.

Never in these days of testimonial giving was a more unique and appropriate one secured for presentation to a deserving man than the tankard which was recently given to Frederick D. Tappen, Chairman of the Clearing House Loan Committee and President of the Gallatin National Bank.

William Young, six years old, the son of Robert Young, a compositor, living at 176 Concord Street, Brooklyn, was run over and killed at the corner of Duffield and Concord Streets, yesterday afternoon, by trolley car No. 29 of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company running on the Park Avenue Line.

Celebrating Evacuation Day, the anniversary of the departure of the British troops from the independent United States, the Sons of the Revolution yesterday afternoon unveiled in City Hall Park and presented to the City of New-York a bronze statue of Capt. Nathan Hale, the young patriot whose life was sacrificed 117 years ago for the cause of his country's freedom.

(Copyright, 1893, by John La Farge.) The third lecture by Mr. John La Farge, "Considerations on the Art of Painting," was delivered yesterday, in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It proved to be as delightfully interesting and as instructive as the preceding lectures. There are three lectures yet to be delivered, and instead of Saturday mornings, they will be given Friday afternoons.

Gustav Schwab, in speaking yesterday of the meeting recently held by the Executive Committee of the German-American Union, denied emphatically that the meeting' was held for the purpose of arranging to set German-Americans on the next Tammany city and county ticket. Mr. Schwab said:

This novel, which is by no means its author's best, seems to have been transformed into its present shape from a play which, perhaps, shared the fate of nine hundred and ninety-nine plays in every thousand, and never got on the stage. There have been rumors from time to time of forthcoming plays toy Marion Crawford, and so skillful a workman as he lets no material go to waste.

The workmen on the great chimney of the Brooklyn City Railroad Power House, at Kent and Division Avenues, Williamsburg, enjoyed their banquet in the basement of the smokestack last night. The tables were spread with covers for about 150 persons, and were handsomely decorated with cut flowers and bunting, and the menu was elaborate.

The bearing of international law on America began even before the discovery of the continent. The value of the discovery of America to Spain was seriously jeopardized by the existence of papal bulls authorizing discoveries, and conferring title in 1452, 1454, 1479, and 1481, on Portugal; and the claims of this power were so technically strong that, on the familiar principle of " a hair of the dog that bit him."

The sales of realty in Brooklyn are showing a marked improvement. Not so much building is projected as was the case last year, but this is not a bad sign, as it will afford a better market for what is now erected. For the past week there were filed plans for thirty-eight structures, to cost $53,100.

The motto fashion, if one may be permitted the word, that for a time seemed to find its only expression in stiff inartistic illuminations formed and set with ungraceful rigidity, and hung on the walls of our houses, is, in our modern artistic homes, in quite different evidence.

There is scarcely a reminder of the old Metropolitan Opera House in the magnificent new building which will be opened to the public to-morrow night by Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, with "Faust," for the beginning of the grand-opera season.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 25. -- Application has been made to Surrogate Dorland for the probate of the will of Mrs. Helen Roosevelt, wife of James Roosevelt Roosevelt, who died at Heathfield, Ascot, England, on the 12th inst. The petition is made by George L. Rives and Samuel S. Howland, two of the executors, through Olin, Rives Montgomery, their counsel.

The testimony of Mrs. M. Saxton was taken yesterday in the divorce suit begun by Mrs. McGrath-Bates to establish her marriage with Charles F. Bates. Mrs. Saxton is a sister of Mr. Bates and lives in the Dakota apartment house, with her father, C. Francis Bates, and her brother, the defendant.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- This was the third and last day of the Manchester November meeting. The principal race of the meating was run to-day. It was the Manchester November Handicap. It was won by Mr. M.D. Peacock's four-year-old chestnut gelding Golden Drop, by Tertius, out of Goldem Fringe Col. North's five-year-old bay horse Simonian, by St. Simon, on of Garonne, was second, and the
The first of the season's matches between Companies B and I, Seventh Regiment, took place Thursday evening last, Company I won with a score beating the record by two points. The scores are appended:

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- A tempest has been gathering for some little time in the Carrie Turner theatrical company. It broke to-day, with the result that Harry Vaughn resigned as manager. Miss Belle Archer, the advance agent, was retired, and three members of the company, including Miss Leach and Mr. Richmond, handed in their resignations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Everything on the Board of Trade was dull to-day with the exception of wheat, and there was enough activity in it to cover all shortcomings in the other speculative articles. The late bulge of yesterday was still in force this morning at the opening, and continued throughout the session, with but slight reactions.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 25. -- Nineteen of the leading hat manufactories in this city closed to-day, throwing out of employment nearly every hatter in Danbury. This blow is the most severe one that has ever been struck at the prosperity of the city. Its effect will be to stagnate business of all kinds and create want and destitution among nearly 20,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- There is to be another shrine on the historic Potomac. The birthplace of Washington, at Wakefield, Westmoreland County, is finally to be marked by an appropriate monument. Wakefield is seventy miles down the river from this city. All that remains of the house in which Washington was born is a ruined hearthstone and chimney.

There was a scene yesterday in the County Court House corridors between representatives of the Gerry Society and at young girl in their charge that roused the ire of the bystanders. The girl was Annie Hummell, who ran away from her home in Philadelphia and was committed by a police magistrate to the House of Mercy at the request of the Gerry Society.

MONDAY, NOV. 27. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale. William M. Hoes, referee, 229 East Eighty-ninth Street, north side, 150 feet west of Second Avenue, 25 by 100.2 1/2, five-story brick tenement. Due on judgment, $16,175.
The newest successful play in London, where successful plays are now very rare, is "Gudgeons," a comedy by Murray Carson and Louis N. Parker, produced at Terry's Theatre by Janette Steer.

The first football match between medical students of the city colleges was played yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds. One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street. The teams that lined up at 2:30 represented the College of Physicians and Surgeons and Bellevue College. The weather was simply perfection for the players, but from the sand point of the spectators, anything but pleasant.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- By a score of 413 to 357, the Peekskill Rifle Ciub yesterday defeated the Newburg Bills and Gun Club at the range of the Peekskill team, opposite the State Camp of Military Instruction in this city. Ten strings were shot, with the following result.
The risk of not having cranberries mold adds to the anxiety of the housewife at Thanksgiving time. Good Housekeeping gives the following directions as safe to insure success:

Here is a story of remarkable carelessness in the handling of public money. It has to do with the Brooklyn Bridge, and the blame for the carelessness apparently rests on the responsible head of the Bridge Trustees, President Howell.

The ways of promoters of monuments are mysterious. Several years ago a bill was passed by the Senate appropriating $75,000 for the removal of what is known as the Peace Monument from Pennsylvania Avenue, at the foot of Capitol Hill, to some other site in Washington, and the erection at the point vacated of a monument to Columbus.
A typical Italian fracas occurred last evening in the yard of the tenement house 113 Sullivan Street, and as a result two of the combatants are in St. Vincent's Hospital suffering from stab wounds.

SEYMOUR, Ind., Nov. 26. -- As the result of a family trouble, five people are dead to-night in their country home seven miles east of this city. Clinton Jordan, four years ago -- then twenty-one years old-married a daughter of Joshua Foster, with whom he never lived happily. The pair separated last week and the wife returned to the home of her father.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- The delegates to the Knights of Labor Convention who are opposed to General Master Workman Powderly held a caucus to-day, and at its conclusion sent a telegram to Labor Commissioner Sovereign of Iowa, asking him if he would permit the use of his name in connection with the office of General Master Workman.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 26. -- Superintendent Esser notified the Chief of Police this afternoon that an angry crowd had gathered at the station, and requested that it be dispersed. The Chief dispatched four officers to the station, and, with aid of the company's detectives, cleared the place. At Sugar Notch, three miles from Wilkesbarre, there was more or less excitement this afternoon.

Inspector McLaughlin's men are busy in the up-town hotel district trying to catch the thief or thieves who took property from the rooms of guests in several of the hotels. Detectives are in the Gilsey House, the St. James, the Hoffman House, the Fifth Avenue, and the Victoria, helping the regular detectives employed by the proprietors.

The Associate Alumni of Columbia College will hold a meeting this evening at the Hotel Brunswick in aid or the university settlement. This movement comes very near home to Columbia, for the President, Seth Low, is at the head, and will this evening preside at the meeting Dr. Stanton Coit, the chief worker for this cause, will be one of the speakers of the evening.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26. -- The development of the study of international law is one of the most interesting signs of historical growth in Harvard College. Until last year the courses bad been somewhat meagrely attended, if the registration then is to be compared to the registration now. This term the elementary course in diplomacy, entitled "Government and Law 4," has been elected by seventy-three students.

Charles L. Cozzens, paying teller of the Bank for Savings in Bleecker Street, and his wife met with a serious accident yesterday afternoon while riding in a coupe on the Boulevard, near Seventy-sixth Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The New-York Times of June 17 told how Miss Virginia Murphey of Albany, N.Y., a niece of Assemblyman Thomas Atkins Murphey of this city, found on the sands of Deal Beach, June 2, a bottle containing a letter. It was from the cruiser Nuevo de Julio, bearing date of May 25, and ran as follows:

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Rates of discount hardened during last week, and closed at 2 1/2 for ninety days and 1 3/4 for thirty days. They are likely to go higher soon, as a stringency of gold is expected. All gold now arriving is being purchased for the Continent. The Government has repaid to the Bank of England u1,500,000 borrowed early in September.

DEMING, New-Mexico, Nov. 26. -- While no absolutely authentic information has yet been received from the scene of Thursday's battle, rumors are current and all reports agree that there was a rebel victory. The flight occurred near Casa de Jalose, twenty-five miles northwest of Casas Grandes.

The Middle village (L. I.) Methodist Episcopal Church, which, next to the old John Street edifice. Is the oldest Methodist Church in America, celebrated its one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday.

The gymnasium work at the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association has opened this season in a very encouraging manner. The membership of the various classes, all told, la much greater than last year. Dr. Smith, the physical director, has fifteen classes to superintend. These meet afternoons and evenings and contain over 700 members.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- "Spinnaker," the Scotch yachting correspondent of The Globe, in a letter just received, writes: "In connection with the Vigilant-Valkyrie matches and the defeat of the Valkyrie, there has been some talk over the prospects for a renewal of the challenge for the America's Cup, but it is largely founded on rumor.

Special services were held yesterday in the McAuley Mission, 316 Water Street, in celebration of the twenty-first anniversary of the work begun by Jerry McAuley. The mission hall was filled with men who had come to speak a good word for its founder. There were old men present who had been reformed by Jerry McAuley himself, and who spoke of him lovingly.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- At M. Carnot's request M. Challemel-Lacour, President of the Senate, called upon M. Dupuy early this evening, and tried to persuade him to form a Cabinet. Dupuy refused unconditionally to do so. It is believed that the crisis will continue through the week.

"Rabies and alcoholism" was the entry on the blotter in the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station last night, as explanatory of the transfer to Bellevue Hospital at midnight of Frank Lee, twenty-eight years old, of 226 East Seventieth Street.

In the palmiest days of "The Black Crook" the Academy of Music never held such an audience as Socked into it yesterday, not drawn by any mere secular attraction, but by the good speaking, good singing, good music, and good teaching that go with that religious movement, the Metropolitan Meetings, originated by the Rev. Mr. Yatman just a year ago.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 27 -- A.M. Speculation, except in a few specialties, was not active last week. There was no pressure to sell, and yet there was an absence of any marked desire to accumulate stocks. A feature which was regarded with satisfaction was the buying of investment bonds at advancing prices, a result of the large accumulation of idle money.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1@1 1/2 per cent., the average being less than 1 1/2 per cent.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 26. -- The Treasurer of the United States. D.N. Morgan, has submitted to Secretary Carlisle the annual report on the operations and condition of the Treasury.
A half dozen sales of real estate at auction are announced for to-day. All are in legal proceedings and will be held in the Trinity Building salesroom, at 111 Broadway. The list follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Mr. C.B. Wilson, Queen Liliuokalani's Marshal and Chief of Police, gave Commissioner Blount his version of the affair of Jan. 16 last, and it is embodied in the correspondence to be laid before Congress. Mr. Wilson writes with a "flowing pen." He pays his respects to Minister Stevens at the outset as follows:
Dr. Henry M. Field has ready for immediate publication by the Scribners a new book of travel, entitled, "The Barbary Coast," treating of Algiers, Tunis, and Tripoli.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 26 -- Augustus M. Scriba, ex-United States Bank Examiner and once cashier of the Shoe and Leather Bank, New-York, committed suicide here to-day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Bishop Doane of the Albany Episcopal Diocese was asked to-day for his view of a bill to be submitted to the next State Legislature providing for State aid for parochial schools. Such a bill has already been drafted by Dennis A. Spellissey, a member of the New-York City bar, and it is said that it will be vigorously pushed at the comine session.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 26. -- The officials of the Lehigh Valley Road had no conference to-day. All passenger trains were moved, and considerable coal and freight. No trouble is reported on this division. President Wilbur says the prospects of the strike's speedy end are brighter than yesterday.

Work on the Brazilian submarine-gun vessel Destroyer was continued all yesterday at the docks of the Erie Dry Dock Company of Brooklyn. It is expected that the vessel will be ready to start for Brazil in tow of some ocean-going tug the latter part of the week. Mr. Charles R. Flint paid a visit to the Destroyer in the forenoon.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The old interest in Bismarck's fall will be revived by the statement of his semi-official organ, the Leipsic Neueste Nachrichten, that he demands the publication of his memorial to the Emperor, in which he contended that he should not and would not, resign except at the Emperor's command.

The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, following the example of those who assisted Mr. McKINLEY in constructing the present tariff, are trying to "fool the farmer" by causing the publication in high-tariff journals of predictions as to the terrible effect of impending reductions of duties on agricultural products.
Capt. Barclay of the British steamship Indian Prince, which arrived from Brazil yesterday, brought news of an American citizen who had been impressed into the service of Mello.

After Thursday the harness contests at Fleetwood Park will be decided round the stove instead of on the track. Unless the weather remains unusually mild the two trotting matches scheduled for Thursday will be the final events of the season. The season just ending has been the most successful in every way of any during the twenty-three years' history of the track.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Never has there been so much interest and enthusiasm manifested in the annual football contest on Thanksgiving Day as this year. Every son of Old Nassau is making his plans to see the great game, and not even the scarcity of tickets seems to put any damper on their intentions, and those who cannot obtain seats will be seen and heard in the crowd on Manhattan Field.

Next week bids will be opened by Gen. FLAGLER for a preliminary supply of smokeless powder, and the result of the competition is important. The new magazine small arms of .30 calibre are designed for such powder, and are in process of manufacture at the Springfield Armory. Meanwhile, there is no home-made smokeless powder for them, the cartridges used in the selection trials being made with the Wetteren compound, of Belgian origin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The Secretary of Agriculture, in his report to the President, regrets the vague character of the department organization, which he says "offers opulent opportunities for the exercise of the most pronounced paternalism," but he adds that there are many proper ways In which the Federal Government may legitimately serve the cause of agriculture.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 25. -- The local stock market for the week showed a decidedly strong undertone, and the holders of stocks are less disposed to sell at current quotations. Buying orders for any amount of stock would be difficult to execute, except at considerably higher prices. The strong support recently apparent in the stock of the Industrial Trust Company is having its effect, and sellers are disposed to hold for a further advance.

Two persistent beggars who for several weeks have been annoying residents along Fifth Avenue and side streets were arrested Saturday as they stood at the door of 39 West Fifty-seventh Street, where they had presented a begging letter. In addition to the annoyance caused by the pair, much petty thieving from hallways is believed to have been done by them.

St. Peter's, in Barclay Street, the oldest Roman Catholic church in this State, celebrated the one hundred and eighth anniversary of its foundation and the eighth anniversary of its consecration with special services yesterday. The solemn high mass at 11 A.M. was largely attended, not only by present members of the congregation, but by many of the old parishioners, who have moved to other parts of the city.

Patrolman Edward Doyl of the Thirty-fifth Precinct was yesterday afternoon passing through Worth Street, and when near Mulberry Street saw a crowd of young men playing "craps" on the front steps of a tenement house. Being in citizen's clothes he showed them his badge and attempted to arrest some of the party, when he was knocked down, thrown in the gutter, and badly bruised about the face.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Through the influence or the Czar -- Gardien de la Paix -- or through the mysterious impulse of smiling circumstance, an unusual mood of good humor reigns. The great patriotic breeze has blown good seed in hospitable soil -- but will it take permanent root? That is the grave question.
The suspicion is gaining ground among the Eastern members of the Republican National Committee that Chairman Carter is making preparations to launch a Harrison boom on the committee.

A young man tripped gayly down Sixth Avenue Saturday night as the clocks were pointing both hands to the zenith. He was stylishly dressed. A shiny pot hat was his headgear, and a pair of sharp-pointed patent leathers were at the other extremity. He wore one of those long overcoats with a sort of bell skirt and a wide velvet collar.

The remarkable game of billiards finished at 1:30 A.M., Chicago time, yesterday, by Frank Ives and Jacob Schaefer aroused much excitement among billiard players in this city. At the billiard rooms up town where bulletins were received from Chicago there were big crowds during the evening, and many became so interested in Schaefer's great work in overcoming Ives's big lead that they remained till the match game was finished.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- The Presidents of the Pennsylvania and the Maryland Steel Companies have called a meeting of the creditors of the two companies on Wednesday next at the American Iron and Steel Association's rooms in this city to consider their financial conditions .The creditors will be asked to appoint a committee to meet a committee of the shareholders to arrange, if practicable, a plan for the rehabilitation of the Pennsylvania Steel Company.

Joseph Brunot, a Frenchman who gave his address as 157 West Eightieth Street, was held for trial yesterday in the Harlem Police Court on the charge of stealing an overcoat laid aside on the grass at the football ground in Central Park by Thomas Scanlon of 105 East Eighty-ninth Street, while he was playing football.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 26. -- A secret conference of Democratic leaders in Union County was held here Friday night for the twofold purpose of reorganizing the party in the county and starting a Democratic newspaper.

The sudden and rather ludicrous collapse of the Dupuy Ministry in France is not easily to he understood. It seems, on the face of it, to have been due to the resentment on personal grounds felt by Deputies at conduct by M. DUPUY which was certainly unworthy of his station, but which would hardly seem to involve his fitness to guide the affairs of the Government.

ROCHESTER, Penn., Nov. 26 -- There was a most singular occurrence at the burial of Mrs. William Shell in the Beaver Cemetery to-day. The grave was dug by Walter W. Fish, stepfather of the deceased woman, yesterday, but it was necessary for Fish to go to it to-day in advance of the funeral to set the rough box in position.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 26. -- Gov. Pattison was seen at the Executive Mansion to-night, and said the reports from the Lehigh Valley region were satisfactory, and that no trouble is anticipated.

We see evidence in several quarters that the suggestion made by THE TIMES on the morning after the recent election that the leading Democrats of this State confer as to the reorganization of the party has been accepted and acted upon. Various reorganizing enterprises are afoot, some seriously meant and wisely ordered, others ill-conditioned and transitory.

From The Westminster Gazette. It is more than probable that we shall be beaten by the United States next year in the number of barrels of beer brewed. Great Britain was only some 300,000 barrels in front last year, and our trade in that article is, if anything, slightly decreasing -- there was a drop of nearly 109,000 barrels last year -- while the United States's output is increasing yearly by more than 1,000,000 barrels.
The leading high-tariff paper of Pennsylvania, the Philadelphia Press, published on Saturday the following dispatch from its correspondent in Pittsburg:

Catholics in the Archdiocese of New-York will next Sunday contribute their share toward the purchase of a residence for the Apostolic Delegation in Washington. D. C., which is the official home of Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate. At the request of Archbishop Corrigan a circular was read in all the churches of the diocese yesterday directing that a general collection be taken up next Sunday, the first Sunday in Advent, for this purpose.
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The Times's correspondent in Sofia describes thus Prince Alexander's funeral:

INWOOD, L.I., Nov. 26. -- The new Christian Endeavor Methodist Protestant Church at this village was dedicated to-day. Three services were held. The dedication ceremonies took place at 2:30 P.M. The Rev. Dr. T.B. Appleget, ex-President of the New-Jersey Methodist Protestant Conference, officiated.

For two hours yesterday afternoon John Y. McKane forgot about politics and the endeavors of the Committee of Twenty-eight to put him behind prison bars and presided over the Sunday school attached to the Sheepshead Bay Methodist Episcopal Church, of which he is the Superintendent.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Nov. 26. -- Long Island sportsmen are enjoying a great deal of good shooting at West Hills, owing to a fight among the property owners. Before the season opened several farmers organized a club to protect themselves from the gunners, claiming the sportsmen shot their poultry, tore down their fences, and did other damage.

Henry C. Jewett some time since intimated his intention to make a radical reduction of trotting stock at Jewett Farm, and will do so to the extent of over 130 head, the sale to take place Dec. 11 to 13, in New-York City. It is by no means an ordinary culling-out sale, as a large percentage of the best producers at the farm are listed.

Mgr. Satoili, the Apostolic Delegate, dedicated St Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, Herbert and North Henry Streets. Brooklyn, yesterday morning. The exercises were of an imposing character. A throng of parishioners and others was present during the exercises, which continued until evening.
GOSHEN, Ind., Nov. 26 -- An attempt was made this morning, just after midnight, to wreck the New-York fast express on the Lake Shore Road, which was due here at 12:09.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- There can be no feeling of alarm about the report that Mr. T.R. Jernigan of North Carolina may be named soon after the reassembling of Congress as Minister Resident and Consul General for Corea. Mr. Jernigan has had experience in the foreign service, having been Consul General in Japan when Mr. Cleveland was in his first term.

Mrs. Elizabeth C. Daly has brought suit against A.D. Matthews Sons, the Brooklyn dry goods merchants, for $10,000 for slander and $17.95, the value of a cloak which she purchased there, but which, she claims, was not delivered to her.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- Almost everything in the way of news affecting local securities this week was unfavorable and had an adverse effect upon prices. New-York Air Brake Company stock was offered down 20 per cent. on the announcement of Judge Townsend's decision in the United States Circuit Court in the suit brought by the Westinghouse Air Brake Company.

The fact that the site of St. Luke's Hospital is one of the most desirable in the city, whether for a business or residential block, has started various rumors as to what will be done with it when the old hospital is removed.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 26. -- The Woman's Rights League, formed in 1891 to agitate for womanhood suffrage, is threatened with disruption, owing to a general quarrel in a meeting held here to-day. For some time the men in the league have accused the women of lacking energy in spreading the propaganda.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 26 -- Once more this city has assumed its wonted quiet. The winners and the losers of the big football battle have departed, but they left behind thousands of dollars. The hotels did a thriving business. All the rooms at the Massasolt House were engaged seven weeks ago, and all the rooms in the other hotels in town were applied for a fortnight before the battle.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The Standard's correspondent in Madrid had an interview yesterday with Senor Moret, Minister of Foreign Affairs. Senor Moret said he would not remain in office if the appointment of Campos to the command in Melilla meant a warlike departure from Spain's friendly attitude toward the Sultan.
In the Brooklyn Police Department there is one patrolman who does not wear a uniform, and has never purchased or worn one. This is a flagrant vioiation of the rules of the department.

A medal and diploma have been awarded to the Normal College from the World's Factor what might be termed the most unique educational work exhibited by any institution at cationtl work exhibited by any Institution at the exposition. The exhibit consisted of a regular day's work, written first on yellow paper and afterward transferred to paper required by the State Superintendent of Public Instruction.

Antonio Logo Arriaga, the Minister from Guatemala to the United States, who, with his wife, is at the Victoria Hotel, said yesterday that there was no truth in the story that negotiations were about to be reopened between the five republics of Central America looking toward a reestablishment of the one nation which existed in Central America in 1842.
SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Nov. 26. -- Owing to the fog and high winds that prevailed yesterday, the second trial trip of the cruiser Olympia was postponed until Monday.

Afternoon Teas Saturday. -- Fashionable people were kept busy Saturday afternoon attending three large receptions. Teas grow rather monotonous toward the end of the season, but, as those given Saturday by Mrs. John Alsop Kins. Mrs. John Lyon Gardlner, and Mrs. Pierre A. Jay were the first this Fall in town, everybody came out. The teas had the additional interest of marking the debut of three charming young women.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The officers of the New-Jersey Kennel League have completed arrangements for the coming dog show, which will be held in the Industrial Hall, adjoining the Grand Opera House, this week.

Prof. Felix Adler's regular Sunday morning lectures before the Society of Ethical Culture have now advanced to such a degree of popularity that even the great seating capacity of Music Hall is taxed beyond its limit.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 26. -- Three men assaulted Daniel Thomas, a farmer and capitalist, living half a mile from this city, when he went to his barn early this morning, and, binding him securely, carried him to the house, where Mrs. Thomas, the only other person on the farm, was also seized and bound.

Joseph Dion, the ex-champion billiard player at America. Is at present an inmate of the asylum on Ward's Island, a sufferer from paresis. symptoms of the disease manifested themselves several years ago, and the player was removed to a private asylum in Connecticut. A fund was raised among the billiard players, and Col. Buck of The Spirit of the Times took charge of it.

William H. Butler, Secretary of the American Tobacco Company, speaking last Thursday to a reporter for The New-York Times about the bill in equity filed against his company in Trenton, N.J., made a charge to which President Frank McCoy of the National Cigarette and Tobacco Company takes exception, and for Which he condemns Mr. Butler very strongly.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 26 -- The weanling Strathmore-Spinaway colt has been sold by Milton Young to Eugene Leigh for $4,000. The colt is a half brother to Lazzarone and a half brother to a yearling filly which Mr. Leigh paid Mr. Young $4,000 for some months ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The annual report of Joseph S. Miller of West Virginia, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, makes no recommendations. The bulky volume of over 200 pages (not including: tables) is made up entirely of statistical information. No mention is made of income tax or increase in the rate of taxation on distilled spirits, malt liquors, tobacco, or any other product coming under the scope of the internal revenue laws.

WOBURN, Mass., Nov. 26. -- The Fourth District Court at Woburn has a peculiar and perplexing case on its calendar, involving a decision whether a well-known citizen of Woburn is criminally liable for receiving money which belonged to another map of the same name, but which the recipient evidently supposed was intended for himself.

"Jack" Ennis, a notorious Brooklyn criminal, and a companion named Patrick Kidney broke into the engine room of George Cooper's stoneyard, foot of Third Street, Brooklyn, last evening, and stole four diamonds valued at $100, used in cutting glass. They were detected by William Ryan, the night watchman, who fired several shots at them without effect.

The Rev. Dr. Mark Staples. The Rev. Dr. Marls staples, the oldest Methodist clergyman in Brooklyn, died at the home of his daughter, Mrs. L.A. Dunslow, 140 1/2 Kosoiusko Street, Sunday. He will be buried today. The funeral services will be held, at the Janes Methodist Episcopal Church.
BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- Great excitement was caused among the attaches of the Chancellerie to-day by an attempt to assassinate Chancellor von Caprivi.

There were a lot of very angry Republican district leaders at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. They had been humbled, and they felt so badly about it that they spoke right out in public. Incidentally, the effort to reorganize the Republican Party in this city is apparently stirring up much dissention and much bitterness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Bostonians presented a new comic opera by Thomas P. Thorne and Clay M. Green to-night at the Columbia Theatre. It is called "The Maid of Plymouth." It cannot be said that the authors have succeeded in fashioning a perfect comic opera, but there is much that is meritorious in the work of both composer and librettist.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 27 -- The second week of the strike has began with a rather unfavorable outlook for the company. Superintendent Esser, when visited by a United Press reporter this evening, did not appear as hopeful as before, for defections from the ranks of the non-union workmen were becoming more frequent every hour.

Prof. Agesilao Greco is in this city and is desirous of meeting expert swordsmen. The Professor has charge or the Military Fencing High School of Rome and has vanquished all the leading fencers of Europe. In his challenge Prof. Greco says:

Just before 12 o'clock last night the occupants of the tenement houses at 71 and 77 King Street were frightened by a loud crash. They rushed into the street and found that the floors of the old building at 73 and 75 King Street, used by James M. Fitzgerald as a storage warehouse for paper stock, had collapsed.

Charles Lord, a young man of independent means, connected with one of the best families in this city, and apparently without any financial troubles, was found dead yesterday in his bedroom, at 12 East Twentyninth Street, having committed suicide some time after 10 o'clock on Sunday morning. What induced him to commit suicide is a mystery.

A few days ago the doings of two enterprising firms, which are engaged in the work of supplying seamen to ships which are in need of men, and exacting large sums from impecunious mariners for such services, were printed in the daily papers.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 27 -- Unless District Attorney John Fleming of Queens County changes his mind, there is a prospect that the three "boxing bouts" advertised to take place Thanksgiving Eve at Rockaway Beach will not come off.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The enthusiasm over the commit football contest with Yale runs higher each day and to-night the students are gathered around the cannon and the songs are being rehearsed. All day long, in fact, various refrains have been heard all over the cam and never has there been so much interest taken la the game as this year.

There was a zone of pungent and nauseating smoke across the city last evening. From East Twentieth Street it spread like a fan to West fourteenth Street and as far south as Canal Street, and the source of the nuisance was a fourth-alarm fire in the Tobias New Manufacturing Company's works at Twentieth Street and Avenue B.

That the bounties authorized to be paid to producers of sugar by Section 231 of the act entitled "An Act to Reduce Revenue, Equalize Duties, and for Other Purposes," approved Oct. 1, 1890, shall be reduced one-eight part of their respective amounts, as prescribed in said act. each year, beginning with July 1, 1895, and extending to July 1, 1902, inclusive, and shall thereafter cease and determine.
PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Charles E. Selover is at his home here. He refused to say anything concerning his indictment. The members of his family will say nothing about his future course.

From "Becket" to "The Merchant of Venice" must have been a grateful change to many persons who are making Abbey's Theatre their chief source of dramatic entertainment during Mr. Irving's New-York engagement Of course, there is no gainsaying the admirable art in the production of *Becket," or the poetic beauty of Tennyson's sombre play.

The Democratic majority of the Ways and Means Committee, having agreed upon the terms of the bill for the reform of the tariff which Will be submitted to Congress on its reassembling next week, have given it in full to the public. There is a good deal of complaint on the part of the Republican press that the Republican members have not taken any part in the preparation of the bill.

Much has been said in the last few weeks about the probable action of the Wilson committee with respect to the duties on sugar. The new bill reduces the duty on refined sugar to one-Quarter of a cent per pound and provides for a gradual withdrawal of the bounty now paid to producers of cane sugar in the South and producers of beet sugar in the West.

Col. Albert E. Lamb, who is associated with Edward M. Shepard and Gen. Tracy, in prosecuting election frauds, yesterday began the active work of trying to bring Chief of Police John T. McKane, Justice Richard V.S. Newton, and other residents of Gravesend to trial.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Democratic members of the committee met soon after the bill had been released, and decided to hold a session Wednesday morning, at which time the internal revenue question will be taken up.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Mr. Wilson, Chairman of the committee, has prepared the following statement:

The principal auction sale had yesterday was by Mr. C.A. Berrian of the Pearsall estate in the town of Westchester, on the road to William's Bridge, and part fronting on Westchester Creek. There are two parcels, one on the west side of the road, containing the homestead and six acres of land, and the other, with two fronts on Pelham Parkway, and containing 150 acres.

When President Blaut heard the news of his indictment he went to his home, 53 East Seventy-third Street, and staid there, denying himself to all callers. The guard chain was on the door and the servant who answered the ringing of the bell was very uncommunicative.

BUFFALO, Nov. 27 -- The first step in the plan of the Cleveland Democracy of this city to succeed Lieut. Gov. Sheehan in controlling the Democratic organization in Buffalo and Erie County was taken tonight. The plan is spoken of by the unpresentious name of "reorganization." In realty, it contemplates the complete overthrowing of the Sheehan faction, which now dominates everything within the party.

The leather suite worn by the Harvard football players in the game against Yale on Saturday were manufactured by a Boston tailor. He was asked to keep secret his order, and did so. Speaking about the new suits, be said:

Buckwheat, corn or maize, conrmeal, oats, oatmeal, rye, rye flour, wheat, and wheat flour, shall be admitted free of duty from any country, which imposes no import duty on the like product when exported from the United States.

Kellegg Co. began yesterday morning the sale of a consignment of trotting stock from Palo Alto Farm. When the first animal on the catalogue was led out, a good-looking six-year-old-mare by Electioneer, there were so few people present that no bid of any sort could be scoured, and she was sent back.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Daily News says of the tariff bill given out by the Ways and Means Committee in Washington:

The publication of the proposed new tariff schedule concentrated for an hour or so the attention of the Stock Exchange upon Sugar and Whisky. Certificates in both of these trusts had been manipulated upward lately upon rumors that the new tariff would make them comfortable holdings at good prices.

The match at the fourteen-inch balk-line game between SCHAEFER and IVES was undoubtedly the most remarkable exhibition that has ever been made of the art of playing billiards. In order to comprehend how remarkable it was, it is necessary to bear in mind that the game was devised in order to reduce to a level with, their competitors certain players with whom the others had no chance at straight billiards.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The activity in Philadelphia and Metropolitan resulted in a very material advance in both. Philadelphia selling up to 95 and closing at 94. Metropolitan advanced from 105 to 107 1/2, and after a reaction to 105 3/4, closed at 107. The amount of these two stocks offered for sale is so small that any demand causes rapid advances.

The Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, met at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and made the official declaration of the vote cast at the last election in this city. Chairman George B. McClellan preside and Deputy County Clerk Scully acted as Secretary. The official figures on the vote for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals are, perhaps, the most interesting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Clifton R. Breckinridge of Arkansas, a prominent majority member of the committee, explained the main features of the bill as follows:

The scientific study of architecture in New-York and the country at large is likely to be farthered by a movement among the younger architects of the city who are in active practice. Many of them are graduates of the Ecole des Beaux Arts and have brought back a strong feeling of sympathy with the ideas that rule the official architecture of Paris.

The scheme for annexing the Hawaiian Islands to the United States had its origin under the Republican Administration of President HARRISON and was supported by it. If it did not owe its inception to Secretary BLAINE. working through his Minister at Honolulu, its hope of success depended upon the known sympathy of the Minister and the assurance of support by the Administration.

J. Pierpont Morgan has consented to act with the Union Pacific Reorganization Committee, and the organization of that committee was completed yesterday. Senator Brice was elected Chairman, L.M. Schwan and W.E. Glyn Secretaries, and John W. Simpson and Victor Morawetz counsel.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 27 -- The strikers reported at their meeting tills afternoon that, in all, sixteen men had been won to their cause to-day, including five hostlers, three engineers, one fireman, and seven brakemen. It was also said they had the promise of several more men to quit.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 27 -- A severe earthquake shock shook the buildings throughout the city at 11:53 o'clock this forenoon. The duration of the shock was about fifteen seconds. It was accompanied by a low rumbling noise. Telegrams and telephone messages from surrounding towns report the shock as having occurred simultaneously throughout Western Vermont, Eastern New-York, and most of the Province of Quebec and a part of Ontario.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- A telegram from Potsdam received here late to-night states that the condition of ex-Senator Erwin is very serious.
College boys who have been planning to descend on this peaceful metropolis for Thanksgiving and make Gotham howl would better stay away.

Earths, Earthenware, and Glassware -- Brick, not glazed, 20 per centum; glazed or decorated, 30 per centum; tiles, plain and encaustic, not glazed, 25 per centum ad valorem; glazed or decorated, 40 per centum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Controller of the Currency Eckels appears to be able to maintain one end of the controversy between himself and Senator Chandler growing out of the insolvency of the Commonwealth Bank of Exeter. N.H., and the comment on Controller Eckels's action by the paper owned by Senator Chandler.
Mr. Charles F. Bates is either the victim of a most reckless and daring matrimonial conspiracy or else he is ia a fair way to travel from the divorce courts to the criminal courts.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Money at the Clearing House remained unchanged, the rates being 1 and 1 1/2 per cent. New-York funds sold at par and 5c premium. Time money was quoted at 3 1/2@4, and call 2 1/2@3. Clearing House exchanges were $12,084,322, against $15,217,222 last year; balances to-day, $1,700,609, against $1,977,127 same day last year.

Edward S. Willard, beginning his engagement at the Garden Theatre, which is now under the managenemt of A.M. Palmer, and may be expected, therefore, to take the rank among our playhouses befitting one so handsome and well equipped, received ample assurance last evening of the high esteem in which he is held by the New-York public.

Southern Associated Press Dispatch to Washington Post, Nov. 25. AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 24 -- The Southern Associated Press has resolved to stand squarely by the contracts that it has been working under for the past year. These contracts have not been altered in any shape or form, and it has been resolved that they will not be altered.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Navigation on the canal is closed here. Ice formed an inch thick Saturday, and yesterday Superintendent Mahon broke it over the five-mile level and passed down all boats here that wished to reach tide water. The canal was closed again this morning all the way down to Fort Edward, and the ice breakers had to be used to open the channel and assist up four boats bound for this place.

Mayor David A. Boody said after the election that he would permit no more of the so-called athletic contests to take place in Brooklyn during the brief remainder of his term in office. The people had spoken, his Honor said, and he would guide his course accordingly.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- A reporter of the United Press called on Mrs. Scriba at her residence this afternoon in regard to her husband's suicide in San Francisco, but she could not be seen, and would not be Interviewed. She was prostrated by the sad news.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Those Republicans and protectionist Democrats who have been laboring under the impression since the election that the Ways and Means Committee would take the results of the elections as an instruction not to amend the tariff law on a revenue basis will discover that their predictions were as empty as their doctrines are fallacious.

Iron in pigs, iron kentledge, spiegeleisen, ferro-manganese, ferro-silicon, wrought and cast scrap iron, and scrap steel, 22 1/2 per centum advalorem; but nothing shall be deemed scrap iron or scrap steel except waste or refuse iron or steel, fit only to be remanufactured.

Permits calling for the construction of thirty-six new buildings were issued last week by Superintendent Brady of the Building Department, involving a total estimated cost of $403,000; and also for alterations to be made to twenty-eight different structures at a cost of $125,000.

It would be fruitless to attempt to deny that there was not an inclination in last night's audience to treat the performance to a serious consideration of its artistic merits. The evening was an occasion of general felicitation and amiability.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Times has this dispatch, dated last Thursday, from Rio de Janeiro:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 27. -- This was the first day of the Tattersall thoroughbred sales here, and fifty-four head passed under the hammer for $26.175, an average of $484 per head. The only imported animal sold to-day was a yearling by Esterling, dam by Muncaster, and it went to Eugene Leigh at $1.100. The largest price was realized for Afternoon, by Troubadour, bought by J.G. Radcliffe. New-York, fer $2,500. Following are the sales:

ROME, Nov. 27. -- King Humbert has charged Signor Giuseppe Zanardelli, President of the Chamber of Deputies, with the formation of a Cabinet. The selection of Zanardelli for the Premiership was urged most strongly by Gen. Nicotera, who conferred with the King this morning. For Minister of Foreign Affairs, Nicotera recommended ex-Premier Crispi.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 27. -- No risks will be run by Capt. Hinkey of the Yale football eleven la the three days that remain before the Thanksgiving game with Princeton. Every man is now in good condition, and as the eleven will in all probability not line up till the Tigers are faced on Manhattan Field Thursday afternoon the present welcome state of affairs is not likely to be disturbed.

The investigation which Commissioners or Accounts Wahle and Owen have been making in reference to Thomas H. Terry, the real estate agent who collects the rentals of the Brooklyn Bridge, was concluded yesterday.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 27 -- P.M. The publication of a synopsis of the proposed tariff schedules was the event which interested Wall Street to-day. The cutting in half of the rate on refined sugar created more discussion than any other proposed change, and that it was not relished by the holders of Sugar stocK was soon evident.

Alexander Salvini, who is devoting himself assiduously to the work of fostering a new taste for the old romantic drama, and with some show of success, elsewhere if not in New-York, began an engagement at the Star Theatre last evening in the sometimes vague but always spirited dramatization of "The Three Guardsmen."

Franklin H. Sargent, President of the American Academy of the Dramatic Arts, has secured all the scenery, costumes, and properties of the late Theatre of Arts and Letters, and this has placed him in a position to make more ambitious productions at the Berkeley Lyceum in which to introduce the pupils of the academy.

DUBLIN, Nov. 27. -- A tin box, filled with some sort of saturated material resembling gunpowder, was found yesterday morning inside the Aldborough Barracks. A fuse, attached to a cap, was connected with the powder. This fuse had the appearance of having been lighted and extinguished. The box weighed a pound.

There was a large and pleasant gathering at the Teachers' College, 9 University Place, yesterday afternoon. The Brooks Alumnae of the kindergarten department of the college held their annual meeting and tea, and sold cake, candy, and fancy articles made by the young women for the benefit of the Bryson Kindergarten, which they are pledged partially to supoprt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Postmaster General Bissell has avoided in his first annual report any language that would strike the reader as coming from an officer who expected to make a great dramatic hit. His predecessor, to whom the business of the department appeared to have been very novel, grasped eagerly at a number of schemes of improvement that turned out to be little better than so many nostrums.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Sporting men, politicians, and idlers crowded the hallways of the Court House to-day while County Judge Garretson and District Attorney Fleming held a secret investigation into the proposed boxing tournament of the Rockaway Beach Athletic Club, set down for to-morrow night.

The salesroom in the Trinity Building was well crowded at noon yesterday, when the auctioneers' clerks began the work of reading descriptions of the property to be offered. The largest number were grouped around the stand of Mr. William Kennelly, who had scheduled for sale some Broadway business realty.

Nathaniel Duel Eldrerdge. Col. Nathaniel Buel Eldredge died at his home in Adrian, Mich., Monday night. Col. Eldredge was the scion of an English-Welsh family, who settled in Connecticut during colonial days. His father was a soldier in the war of 1812, and settled in this State, near Auburn, where Nathaniel was born March 28, 1813.

DUBLIN, Nov. 28. -- There is evidence today at Lower Castle Yard, the Dublin Metropolitan Police Headquarters, of much suppressed excitement. In the hotels and other public places the topic of most interest is the reports bearing upon the work of the alleged dynamiters. Not since the explosion at Dublin Castle, eleven months ago, have dynamite and dynamiters engrossed so large a share of public and police attention.

There was much excitement and activity in Sugar Trust certificates at the opening of the stock market yesterday, the quotations plunging from 85 1/4, to 80. From the low price came a reaction, and the price recovered to 84 5/8, at which it closed. Recovery was due to reports industriously circulated that the Sugar Trust would be able to prevent any change in the existing tariff.

More than one score paintings by Mr. George H. Bogert were hung yesterday in the little sky gallery of Reichard Co., 226 Fifth Avenue. An hour spent in gazing at these pictures will not be an hour lost.

Fifth Assistant Bookkeeper Albert Storer of the Finance Department has resigned. He is seventy-nine years old, and has been in the employ of the city for many years, having been appointed by Controller S. Hastings Grant to the place he has just resigned. Before that, he was Secretary of the Department of Taxes and Assessments for many years.

NEW-YORK. Tuesday, Nov. 28 -- P.M. Sugar was pressed for sale at the opening, and within an hour had declined 5 points, to 80. The break seemed to exhaust the stop orders in the stock, and from that time on the price advanced with only very infrequent reactions.

In the opinions given by business men as to the Wilson Tariff bill, there is a striking agreement that the most important element in the situation is that of time, and a very general agreement that if the bill be passed promptly the trade of the country can readily adjust itself to the changes proposed.

The American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless will give its annual Thanksgiving dinner to the 210 children under its care at the home, 29 East Twenty-ninth Street and 32 East Thirtieth Street, to-morrow afternoon at 12:30 o'clock. At 2 o'clock there will be an entertainment in the chapel by the children, and an address by the Rev. Dr. John Hall.

Owing to extraordinary good luck, no member of any of the many families In the tenement at 79 King Street was killed or injured when the five-story brick building at 75 and 77 King Street, used as a paper warehouse, suddenly collapsed at midnight on Monday and came crashing down in an avalanche of bricks and mortar.

To know that the hone and carriage market has wonderfully improved in the last week one only needs go around among the dealers to find a much more buoyant feeling than at any other time since last Spring. They one and all unite in saying that the business has at last picked up, and all have satisfactory sales to report.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The New-York and New-Jersey State Boards of Arbitration, which are endeavoring to bring the Lehigh Valley strike to a settlement, went to South Bethlehem to-day to confer with leaders of the strikers, and, possibly, with several railroad officials. The future course of the boards will then be decided.

Since the last election many well-known Democrats in this city have held conferences with a view to establishing a new Democratic organization in this city, with the result that the first steps toward perfecting such an organization have been taken. Additional interest was given to the project yesterday by the issue of an appeal to all Democrats by ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild, who is Chairman of the General Committee.

Speaker Sulzer of the Assembly, when asked for his opinion of the bill, said: "I have carefully read the new bill as published in The New-York Times, and I wish to say that the comparison of figures made between the McKinley and the Wilson bills is the best piece of journalism I have seen in several months. The Wilson bill will meet the approval of the people, irrespective of politics.

ST. THOMAS, West Indies, Nov. 28. -- The Nictheroy arrived here yesterday morning. Considerable practice was had during the voyage in the handling of the dynamite gun; dummy shells were used. This practice has been continued in the harbor here.

John Y. McKane, the "Boss" of Gravesend, walked, with an easy swagger, into the Sheriff's office in Brooklyn at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. Six of his henchmen, charged, like him, with violating the order of Supreme Court Justice Barnard prohibiting interference with the Republican watchers at the polls in Gravesend on election day, trailed behind their leader.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28. -- A fight which has been in progress for more than ten years came to an end to-day when the people of Rhode Island gave a blow to the Republican bosses of the State in the adoption by an overwhelming majority of the plurality amendment to the Constitution.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Marquis of Salisbury delivered an address before the National Conservative Union in Cardiff this evening. Referring to the coal strike, he said he rejoiced over the settlement of the trouble, as the conflict was digging a chasm between classes without whose agreement the prosperity of the nation was impossible.

The steamship Maskelyne, which arrived from Brazil yesterday, brought information of the killing of three British officers and ten seamen by the explosion of a powder magazine at Ponto de Mattozo on Nov. 3. At the time of the explosion, Lieut. Mowbray of the British ship Sirius and Lieut. Tupper of the Racer were, with another British officer and ten seamen, collecting sand.

A genuine market was opened in the Manhattan Athletic Club Building; Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, yesterday morning, and the most fastidious epicure could not fail to be pleased at the delicious array of viands sold by the daintiest of salespeople. A circle of King's Daughters chose this unique method of collecting funds for the support of a free kindergarten at 141 Chrystie Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28. -- The football game between the West Pointers and the cadets which is to be played here next Saturday promises to be a good one. The naval cadets have worked hard and faithfully, and there is a great feeling of confidence here over the result of the game.

One of our Republican contemporaries in this city begins its lamentations about the Wilson bill by placing at the head of the list of industries that are to be "ruined" the manufacture of peppermint oil. The change of duty from 80 cents a pound to 25 per cent. ad valorem "will be felt," it says, throughout the East "and as far west as Michigan."

The case of Bates against Bates is ended for the time being. If Judge Freedman, before whom the case has been on trial, and who will render his decision in about thirty days, decides that the marriage of Charles F. Bates and Annette F. McGrath was proved, and that the marriage contract put in evidence was genuine, the defendant, Charles F. Bates, will probably be called on for an explanation by the District Attorney.

The cable daily brings us news of out-rages by dynamite, or attempts at such outrages, or sequels of such outrages, from almost every quarter of Europe. An infernal machine, intended to kill whoever might happen to open it, has been sent to the Chancellor and another to the Emperor of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Another surprise to New-York politicians was furnished by Mr. Cleveland to-day by the appointment of W.A. Poucher of Oswego to be United States Attorney for the Northern District of New-York, to succeed Col. Alexander.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- It has been learned that Louis Hye, twenty-four years old, who was arrested here yesterday on a charge of burglary, comes from a prominent and respectable family of Newburg, N.Y. It was also learned that he was recently released from a New-Jersey prison, where he served a term of fourteen months for a burglary committed in Jersey City. He was arraigned in court to-day, and waived examination.

There was a great outcry yesterday morn ins in the high-tariff newspapers about the transfer of copper ores and pig copper to the free list. The New-York tribune mentioned copper in a short list of products and said: "The change in these articles will not merely take millions from the revenue, but will deprive several hundred thousand American workers of their power to purchase foreign or domestic products."
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new building's and alterations were filed:

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The opening this morning showed that the depressed New-York prices had considerable effect upon local securities, al though some of the weakness was due to the fear that large amounts of stock would come out. This was true in regard to West Side, which opened at 151 3/4, and North Chicago, the first price of which was 250.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- All thought of the regular duties incumbent upon the students are now laid aside, and all attention is turned to the Thanksgiving Day football game. The rivalry at present seems to consist in seeing who can produce the beat and must appropriate song for the occasion. Here is one which seems to gain popularity, being sung to an air familiar to Princeton, the words running as follows:
BENNINGS, D.C., Nov. 28. -- At an informal meeting of the Board of Commissioners this morning it was unanimously decided to refuse a license to the Ivy City race track to conduct Winter racing there.

The Third Avenue Cable Road, now nearly completed, has furnished a theme for many articles both in the press and in technical publications. Its one-time competitor, the Broadway Road, outstripped it in the race and was in successful operation long before the end was visible on the Third Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The University of Pennsylvania's eleven, with its substitutes and attendants, will leave Springfield on Wednesday for their Thanksgiving Day struggle with Harvard. They will lodge at the Tremont House in Boston, which will be the headquarters of Pennsylvania men. and indications point to a large influx, of visitors from Philadelphia.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The courage and Intelligence of two bright girls enabled the police to capture two sneak thieves while they were posing as mourners at a funeral at the Catholic cemetery to-day.

The chief trouble of the "silk-stocking" element of the Republican Party in this city in its effort at reorganization lies in the fact that what it seeks to get rid of practically constitutes the party organization as it now exists. These Republicans are trying to make over an existing organization in which they constitute the minority, and they will find it a difficult task.

There was an improvement in the average prices realized yesterday when the balance of the trotting stock passed under the hammer. The attendance was also much more numerous and representative than on Monday. This was owing to the fact that the offerings included several by Electioneer, whose get still continue to sell at comparatively high figures.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 28. -- Gen. Micario Pacheco, one of the commanders of the Mexican revolutionists under Santa Ana, Perez, arrived here last night, and In a letter to The El Paso Times, which has characterized the rebels as "religious fanatics," he says:

Republican harmony was on exhibition again at the Firth Avenue Hotel last night. The sub-committee on investigation of the committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to investigate and, if necessary, recommend a plan for reorganization, met in Parlor D.R. The leaders from the Eleventh to the Twentieth District, had been summoned to appear before it.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28. -- Sir William Dawson, the geologist, says that yesterday's earthquake was no doubt the result of a settlement or giving way in the rocks along the junction of the Laurentian and Silurian formations. From what he can judge, the earthauake came from a great depth, and nearly vertically.

Palmer Cox has given as the Brownies, with their varied experiences, but in all their travels they never played football. F.W. Schoomaker. in the drag store at the corner of Park Avenue an Forty-second Street, has Riven the Brownies at Football. The window has boon arranged to represent the gridiron, and the quaint little figures are playing ball.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- The Court of Appeals affirmed to-day the judgment of the General Term, with costs. In the case of Contractor John O'Brien against New-York City, to recover certain moneys alleged to be due on the construction of the Croton Aqueduct Judge Peckham writes the opinion, which is concurred in by all of the Judges, except Judges Earl, O'Brien, and Maynard, who dissent.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 28. -- Capt. Marshall Perry Wild, known to almost every actor of note in this country, died to-day very suddenly. He was sixty-two years old. He was in the employ of the Portland Steam Packet Company as advertising agent.

OIL CITY, Penn., Nov. 28. -- One of the most destructive fires that has visited Oil City in years occurred at 4 o'clock this morning, the block bounded by Centre Street on the north, Elm Street on the west, railroad on east, and by Sycamore Street on the south being entirely consumed.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad was held In the company's general office in this city yesterday. The attendance was fairly representative of the Various interests concerned.

Russell -- Sands. Miss Florence Sands, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Woodville Sands of 76 East Fifty-sixth Street, was married at noon yesterday to William Hamilton Russell, in St. Thomas's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John Wesley Brown, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. William Dinsmore Maxon of Trinity Church, Utica, N. Y. Augustus Munroe was the best man.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Attorney General Stockton, for Philip Hexamer, a keeper of a large livery stable and riding school in Hoboken, has applied to the Chancellor for an injunction against the Jersey City, Hoboken and Rutherford Railway Company to prevent that corporation occupying with its tracks a part of the Paterson plank road which leads out from First Street, in Hoboken.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Sheriff George Barrett of Camden County is preparing to move on the Gloucester race track. He intends to see that it is closed after Thursday. The whole of South Jersey is interested in the movement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The funeral of Congressman Charles O'Neill took place to-day, and was largely attended. The body lay in state for an hour this morning, and was viewed by many persons. The only floral tribute was one presnted by the Congressional delegation which attended the obsequies.

Samuel H. Wilson, a young insurance agent, who came from Erie, Ponn., a year ago, was found dead on the floor of his room at Feter Baler's boarding home. 1,927 Madison Avenue, yesterday by his neighbor. John R. McKee. an insurance broker at 60 Broadway. He was in his underclothes, and near him was a pistol with which he had shot himself in the head.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 28. -- General Manager Voorhees returned to Philadelphia this afternoon. He said to a reporter: "I go to my Philadelphia office for good because I consider the strike practically over. Trains are running much better today, and no trouble has been reported."

Of all the gorgeously dressed and beautiful women that attended the opening of the opera season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night, there was none handsomer or dressed in costlier garb than a young woman who sat in an orchestra seat next to the middle aisle, and who, as subsequent events proved, prefers, in spite of her outward seeming, to be known simply as Annie Smith, dressmaker.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The traction stocks opened with sales at yesterday's closing prices, with the exception of Baltimore, which was 1/4 per cent. higher, at 17 3/4. The hurrah which was started in Philadelphia and Metropolitan received somewhat of a set-back; Philadelphia declined from 94 at the opening to 91 3/4, but advanced quickly the moment support developed, closing at 93 3/4, bid.
The Rapid-Transit Commissioners have committed themselves informally to an independent elevated system over the following routes:...

Col. George Bliss has sent a letter to James W. Auten, Chairman of the Republican organization in the Eleventh Assembly District, declaring his intention to retire as the leader of the district, and asking that his name be omitted from the ticket to be voted for at the next primary. He, however, proposes to remain an enrolled Republican of the district.

WEST POINT, Nov. 28. -- As the day for the West Point-Annapolis game approaches, professors. instructors, and tactical officers are anxiously discussing the chances of defeat or victory, while the corps of cadets are filled with confidence and high hopes for their team's success. Both teams have been coached by Yale men who have distinguished themselves on the football field -- Laurie Bliss and "Doc" Hartwell.

ROME, Nov. 28. -- King Humbert had a long conference to-day with Signor Zanardelli, who was summoned yesterday to form a Cabinet. The conference turned upon the reduction of the army by two corps. Subsequently the King had a conference with Gen. Consenz, ex-Chief of Staff.

The Cathedral Board met yesterday afternoon at the See House, in Lafayette Place. George M. Miller, the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, J. Pierpont Morgan, Dean Hoffman, Cornelius Vanderbilt, Stephen P. Nash, the Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington, and the Rev. Dr. P.K. Cady were present.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Attorney General Rosendale to-day filed in the Secretary of State's office the designations of Gen. Tracy and Ed-ward M. Shepard as Deputy Attorney Generals to represent the Attorney General's office in the Gravesend election prosecution. Mr. Shepard filed his oath of office to-day. Gen. Tracy will file his on his return from Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The report in The London Times this morning to the effect that the State of Para had joined the revolutionary forces in Brazil is not credited at the Brazilian Legation in this city. Senhor Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister, said to-day that no dispatch which he had received from his Government made mention of the defection of Para, and if such had been the case he would certainly have been notified.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- At the office of the Spreckela Sugar Refining Company it was stated to-day that the reduction of 1/4 cent in the duty on refined sugar would not result in an increase of importations of foreign-refined sugar. The American Sugar Refining Company will reduce the price of sugar, so as to keep out the foreign sugars and retain the American market for itself.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The memorial to James Russell Lowell in the Chapter House of Westminster Abbey, was unveiled today. It consists of two stained-glass windows. Among those who subscribed to the fund are the Duke of Westminster, the Duke of Argyll, Earl Rosebery, Lord Coleridge, Lord Brassey, Lord Playfair, Sir John Lubbock, Prof. Bryce, Prof. Tyndall, George Meredith, Dr. Conan Doyle, Canon Farrar, and Alma-Tadema.

BELLPORT, L. I., Nov. 28. -- The four-masted schooner Louise H. Randall, Philadelphia, from Newport, R. I., is ashore at Smith's Point, opposite here. Capt. Hathorn, his wife, their child, and the crew of nine men have been clinging to the rigging all day.

When the Madison Square Bank officials were first arrested, the bail in the case of President Blaut was fixed at $15,000, and in the cases of the Directors at $5,000 each. Indictments having been returned on Monday, the District Attorney required double the amount of bail from the Directors, and the bond of President Blaut was increased to $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Attorney General Olney has rendered an opinion that certain notes issued by corporations at the time of the recent currency "famine" are not taxable 10 per cent, under the bank-circulation law. In the course of his opinion, which is addressed to Secretary Carlisle, he says:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 28. -- This was the second day of the Tattersalls thoroughbred sale here, and seventy-seven head Bold for a total of $27,055, an average of $351 per head Capt. P.C. Kidd's Caroline Hamilton only brought $1.875,she bringing the highest price or the day and going to H. Rowland of Guttenberg.

Yesterday, in the splendid Office of the American Exchange National Bank, a structure which serves as one of the most conspicuous symbols and expressions of material wealth which this city contains, an assemblage of the rich men of New-York sat down to listen to the annals of the little children of the worse than merely poor -- the homeless and destitute.

"War in Peace Time," by G. von Moser and Franz von Schoenthan, is a harmless, unnecessary play, in which all the younger males wear uniforms all the younger and some of the middle-aged females are crazy for the military some of the characters talk Berlinese, turning their gs into ys. and others Hungarian-German, pronouncing thickly and giving a very un-Teutonic rhythm to their speech.

Manhattan Field this afternoon will be the scene of the yearly conflict between the bold students of Yale and Princeton Universities, who risk life and limb to gain football honors for their colleges. It will be the final struggle for the college championship, and to-night the football season will practically end.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29. -- Yale is quiet and deserted to-night. The football eleven and nineteen substitutes departed this afternoon for New-York, and more than half the students of the university left town about the same time. The Faculty has decreed a three-days holiday, and only a few members of the university have failed to take advantage of it. Betting here was lively to-day.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 29 -- Col. John Tracey of New-York, who has been for some months the Superintendent of Charities in the District of Columbia, as the successor of Prof. Warner, has devoted himself steadily to his work, which is one requiring great industry and not a little political tact to conduct successfully.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 29. -- This was the third day of the Tattersalls sale of thoroughbreds, and was taken up mostly with imported stock, property of Gamble Orr and Capt. M. Bayley, all of which went at low figures. The bargain of the day was an eleven-year-old chestnut mare by Eolus, out of Calash by imp. Phaeton, she being purchased by W.F. Presgrave of Bryn Mawr, Penn., for $1.500, the highest price of the day.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Frank North of Lanesville, in the Catskills, had a hand-to-hand encounter with a large black bear Saturday and was scatched by the animal's claws so badly that he will be scarred for life. He was hunting for partridges with a shotgun, and while passing through a narrow ravine was called to a sudden halt by a deep growl.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Wednesday, 8 P.M. -- Forecast For Thursday:

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 29. -- The repiy of the lawyers In this city who spent $35,000 in the Legislature last Winter in lobbying through the bill placing the maintenance of the East Hartford Bridge on the State was made this afternoon to the Glastonbury investigating committee, being sent to the Chairman, Frank D. Glazier.

In all serious discussion of rapid transit in this city for the last five years it has been generally admitted that elevated railroads in the streets are only makeshifts. They do not and cannot afford genuine rapid transit, such as is needed for the development of the city within the area which it is destined to occupy, and such as must be provided for sooner or later.

The troubles of the Coghlans resulting from the marriage of Kuehne Beveridge and Charles Coghlan, both of whom belonged to the Coghlan company, seem to be far from any amicable adjustment. The Coghlan company is now playing in Baltimore. Rehearsals have been going on for "The Woman of No Importance," with which the company is to appear at the Fifth Avenue Theatre in this city on Dec. 11.

Four indictments were returned by the Grand Jury yesterday against Capt. W.S. Devery of the Eldridge Street Police Station. It is conjectured that he is charged with neglect of duty in failing to clear his precinct of places of questionable repute when formally and repeatedly notified of their existence by agents from the Society for the Suppression of Crime, of which the Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst is the President.

A statement was sent out over the Wall Street tape yesterday representing John Good, the cordage manufacturer, as saying substantially that the placing of binding twine on the free list and the reduction of the duty on rope, cordage, from 17.01 per cent. to 15 per cent. would ruin the cordage industry of this country.

The Blackford-Tompkins Wedding. -- Wallace Blackford, son of ex-Fish Commissioner Eugene Blackford, is to be married on Monday to Miss L.J. Tompkins, daughter of J.C. Tompkins. Last Tuesday evening the prospective bridegroom gave a dinner to the men and women who are to form the bridal party. The Blackford home, 725 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, was the scene of the gathering.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The Secretary of the Navy has appointed a board, consisting of Commanders P.H. Cooper and R.B. Bradford, Chief Engineer R.W. Milligan, and Assistant Naval Constructor G. W. Street, with Lieut. L.L.
