Reamey as recorder, to assemble on board the United States steamship New-York at New-York on Monday, Dec. 11, to make an examination of that vessel, and to witness and report upon her final trial.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Agnes Scott, thirty years old, living with her mother at 111 Avenue E. Greenville, shot herself four times with a revolver this morning, but the affair was kept quiet until to-night, when Drs. Finn and Forman decided to give out the facts because they despaired of Miss Scott's recovery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The annual report of Secretary of the Navy Herbert, which will be released for publication Friday, makes few recommendations for increase of the navy. Mr. Herbert asks for authority to build one additional battle ship and four torpedo boats of the Ericsson type.

Arrests made on Tuesday by Detectives Wade and Hanly of Inspector McLaughlin's staff recall the disappearance of the mysterious Otis Greye, or Phillips, more than a year ago from the steamer Pilgrim of the Fall River Line. Lawyer Henry H. Finley of 33 Broad Street, who was identified with "Promoter" Greye, now appears in another syndicate transaction, his associate being Robert Williams, "journalist," of the Hotel Brunswick.

Von Glahn -- Dykeman. Miss Jennie Dykeman, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Dykeman, was married last night at the German Evangelical Church, in Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, to Charles W. Von Glahn. The church was elaborately decorated with masses of pink chrysanthemums. The bride wore a gown of white satin with a Court train, trimmed with duchesse lace and crystal guipure.

About 5,000 persons, half of whom were women, witnessed the game between the Brooklyn High School and Polytechnic elevens which was played at Eastern Part yesterday atternoon. The crowd came early and school yells occupied the boys' time till the players appeared. The game was one of the most exciting played at Eastern Park this year and the biggest crowd was out to see the struggle.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 29. -- It seems to be the opinion of railroad men interested in the Lehigh Valley strike that a settlement will take place very soon. Some profess to believe that the strike will be declared off to-morrow.

Members of the congregation of the West Presbyterian Church to the number of fully 300 assembled in the parlors of the church in West Forty-second Street last night to listen to the reading of the report of the committee which had visited the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton at Bridgeville, Penn., to ask him to withdraw his resignation as pastor of the church.

The examination in the case of Matthew Coleman, ex-President of the Coloman Brewing Company and of the Mutual Browing Company, who is charged with grand larceny by Major Edward Duffy, receiver of the companies, was continued yesterday in the Essex Market Police Court. It is charged that Mr. Coleman appropriated to his own use $13,000 raised on notes discounted for the Mutual Brewing Company by the West Side Bank.

The storm of Monday night sent adrift the tow of the tugboat William A. Levering, which was struggling past Block Island, and the four persons who were on board the tow would have lost their lives, probably, had it not been for the timely aid afforded by the tug D.S. Arnott.

The Board of Health received and approved yesterday a report from Dr. Hermann M. Biggs, Chief Inspector of Pathology, Bacteriology, and Disinfection, concerning the dangers due to tuberculosis and methods of treatment. In 1892 there were more than 6,000 deaths in this city due to the contagion. Dr. Biggs believes that tuberculosis is a disease that can be prevented.

PARIS, Nov. 29. -- In searching the house of the modeler, Charregon, in Marseilles today the police found a door hidden behind a pile of old iron in the workshop. This door opened into a tunnel extending sixty-five feet under the street. In the tunnel lay a parcel containing safety fuses, tubes, and several sorts of powder. The powders were submitted to an expert.

Thanksgiving is, beyond question, the typical American holiday. It has a non-sectarian quality which characterizes no other, except the Fourth of July, and that, after all, is a patriotic, and not a domestic, festival. It is a holiday in celebrating which men and women of all religions and all creeds may join consistently and harmoniously, no matter what those religions or those creeds may be.

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The prison here will be closed to-morrow, and the holiday observed by giving the convicts a day of rest in their cells, with some extra rations. The bill of fare for dinner will be boiled ham, potatoes, mince pie, and coffee, with probably some cigars thrown in as digesters.

The current college fashions of garment, deportment, and personal decoration were amply and richly illustrated on Broadway yesterday. Every hour supplied fresh reinforcements, so that by the time sundown began to pull to the curtains of the night New-York was one vast magasin des modes, one huge emporium of styles, from a collegiate point of view.

Ex-State Senator John J. Kiernan, the originator of the " ticker" news service, died quite suddenly of heart failure and pneumonia, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, at his home, 56 First Place, Brooklyn. He caught cold last Friday, and, on the advice of his physician, staid in the house, but did not go to bed.

The Court of Appeals, by a recent decision, has made an important addition to the organized charities of New-York City. Jose Sevilla, a wealthy Peruvian who made most of his money in New-York, died in Lima, Peru, in December, 1886. By his will he made elaborate provisions for the establishment of a home for orphan girls in the City of New-York, to be known as the Sevilla Home for Children.

CITY OF MEXICO. Mexico, Nov. 29. -- Senator Henry M. Teller of Colorado and J.S. Nesmith, President of the Colorado Iron Works, after spending several days here, have gone to the State of Oaxaca, to look at coffee plantations in which they are interested. The Senator will also visit the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, and inspect the railroad in process of construction there.

The United States Government and the American people have shown a very friendly disposition toward Russia. This is instanced, for example, by the sympathy and assistance extended by the people of the United States to the Russian sufferers from famine and by the extradition treaty recently negotiated in the interests of the Russian Empire.

TROY N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, was seen at noon to-day, just prior to his departure for Albany, where he had an appointment with Senator Hill and Gov. Flower. He said that he had not read the call issued by Charles S. Fairchild, in the name of the New-York State Democracy, and, therefore, declined to be interviewed concerning it.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- Surface indications are that something is going on in Lehigh Valley. Just what this is puzzles the Street. An order to-day to buy 500 shares advanced it from 40 3/4 to 41 1/4. Then it was reported the strike had been declared off by both the company and the men, and the story that Mr. Cassatt was considering Mr. Wilbur's proposition, that he should accept the Presidency, was revived.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29. -- It Is now agreed upon by the Republican Assemblymen-elect of Essex County to nominate J. Broadliead Woolsey for the Speakership of the next House. He is in partnership in a gold-refining business with Henry J. Gloriaux, who has also been an Assemblyman. A caucus was held at Trenton yesterday.
BUFFALO, Nov. 29. -- Bishop Coxe has written a second letter to Mgr. Satolli. In it he says:

The crew of the four-masted schooner, Louisa H. Randall, which was driven ashore at Smith's Point, near Bellport, L.I., on Tuesday, was rescued yesterday morning, and brought to this city. No fatality attended the work of rescue, but the eleven Limp, trembling wretches who were brought off in the surfboat of the wrecking tug Merritt, Looked as if they could not have much longer withstood the exposure.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Mayor Jackson of Gloucester, who was responsible for the inauguration of a free-and-easy reign for the liquor men and the gamblers, has responded to the sharp letter sent to him by Sheriff George Barrett of Camden County, saying he was not going to permit any more misrule and lawlessness in and around the Gloucester race track.

The Wilson bill puts bituminous coal on the free list. The duty is now 75 cents per ton. The quantity of bituminous coal imported now is equal to about 1 per cent. of the domestic output, which is about 110,000,000 tons, and we export more of this kind of coal than is brought in. Indeed, we export even to Canada more bituminous coal than is imported from that country.

Lord SALISBURY'S speeches at Cardiff are of some importance, since in them the leader of the Opposition deals with all the projects of the Ministry relating to British, as well as to "imperial," interests. The Irish question is naturally the most conspicuous of these topics, and in its persistent conspicuousness supplies an argument in favor of Mr. GLADSTONE'S policy and against that of Lord SALISBURY.

George Slosson is practicing hard for the billiard tournament that is to begin in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall a week from next Monday. He plays 600 points each evening with some good player, and has been making some remarkably food runs and averages. With Or. Jennings of Brooklyn recently he made one run of 280, and averaged 50 in the game.

LONG ISLAND CITY, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- There was no fight at Rockaway Beach last night, and the big pavilion on the ocean front that had been prepared for the proposed encounter was given over to the wild ocean breezes and a squad of fourteen uniformed Deputy Sheriffs from Long Island City, armed with warrants for the arrest of everybody connected with the affair.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Liverpool Courier, which announced that High McAlmont was about to marry the Duchess of Marl-borough, formerly Mrs. Hamersley of New-York, has been requested by Mr. McAlmont to deny this report, and will do so in its next issue.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The annual convention of the Catholic Benevolent Legion of New-Jersey was held here Tuesday. There are seventy-three councils in the State, with a membership of 4,984. Fifty councils were represented at the convention. The condition of the order was reported as thriving.

MILAN, Nov. 29. -- A railroad accident occurred last night at Melzo, a town in Lombardy, twelve miles northeast of this city. An express train from Milan for Venice and a freight train laden with inflammable material came in collision just outside Melzo. The wreckage was set on fire by the lights on the trains.

The annual indoor games of the Twenty-second Regiment Athletic Association were held in the armory at Sixty-seventh Street and the Western Boulevard last night. The big building was crowded with sightseers, who took a great interest in the contests. The officials were: Rartow S. Weeks, referee; Lieut. Col. King, Major Bartlett, Major C.E.B. Hart, Major B.G. Beach, and Major W.R. Pryor, judges.

GREENPORT, L.I., Nov. 29. -- In a hand to-hand struggle, C.W. Hartley a well known resident of this village, captured a burglar who was attempting to break into his house shortly after midnight Tuesday Soon after the family had retired, Mrs. Hartley caught the sound of stealthy footstep on the veranda.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

Simple services were read at the University Place Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George Alexander, D.D., yesterday morning, over the body of Charles E. Lord, who committed suicide in his apartments, at 12 East Twenty-ninth Street, last Sunday. The church was filled with a large congregation. Among those who listened to the words of the preacher were delegations from the Calumet Club and Company K. Seventh Regiment, to which Mr. Lord belonged.

If the Republican journals that are now drawing such horrifying pictures of the effects of the reduction of duties in the Wilson bill could be induced to discuss those reductions in connection with the declaration of their own national platform there would be a great shrinkage of their partisan capital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Secretary Herbert provided a happy Thanksgiving for two naval officers by issuing orders to-day directing Capt. F.M. Higginson and Capt. John R. Bartlett to hold themselves in readiness to command the cruisers Boston and Atlanta, respectively. The restoration to duty of these officers marks the ending of two naval sensations connected with each other, and in both of which Capt. Higginson was concerned.

Another public hearing is to be given, by the Park Commissioners next Wednesday, at 11 A.M., on the proposed construction of the Harlem River speedway. The Park Commissioners decided yesterday to have the hearing, although Commissioner Straus opposed it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The annual report of the Secretary of War gives the usual review of the condition and operations of the army, and, in addition, has much to say about the progress of the work on the sea-coast defenses.

Messrs. Henry D. Winans May have sold for Mr. J.V.S. Wooley to Mr. E.C. Bodman the new four-story brownstone dwelling 7 East Seventy-fourth Street, 25 by 100, for $71,000. This property adjoins the new residence of Richard Croker.

From The Westminster Gazette. Upward of 100 cattle have died in the neighborhood of Eyssham, Oxfordshire, during the past few days from eating acorns. The cattle belonged to several proprietors -- Lord Abingdon of Wytham Park having lost twenty. Mr. James Mason of Eyssham Hall, ten or more, and another gentleman in the neighborhood a similar number, while all around the district the farmers generally have lost one or two animals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The annual report of Commissioner of Navigation B.C. O'Brien, which proved to be his valedictory, is full of matters of public interest. The tonnage of the country exhibited an increase from 4,765,921 tons in 1892 to 4,825,071 tons in 1893. There was a decrease in sailing tonnage, but an increase in steam tonnage.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Donations of some of the most celebrated exhibits shown at the World's Fair continue to be made to the Columbian Museum, founded to commemorate the exposition, by nations and individual exhibitors. The latest gift is made by E. Gerard, Dufraisseix Co. of Limoges, France, through and jointly with their American agents, Haviland Abbot, New-York.

Russell Sage and George J. Gould, Trustees of the Kansas Pacific consolidated mortgage, have informed the Union Pacific receivers that they are willing to use funds in their possession to pay November interest on Kansas Pacific bonds, provided the United States court decides that they have the authority to do so.

The members of the Professional Woman's League at their meeting yesterday listened to a paper read by Dr. Church denouncing corsets and tightly-fitting shoes. She told her hearers impressively that there are ninety-two diseases which men of science say are caused by wearing the corset.

One of the afternoon papers charged yesterday that $28,000 more than was necessary had been paid for cart horses by the Street-Cleaning Department during Commissioner Thomas S. Brennan's administration. It was alleged that the department paid $250 per head to Fiss Doerr. horse dealers at 149 East Twenty-fourth Street, while the firm would sell horses of the same class to other cities for $142.50 each.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- A special dispatch from Paris to the United Press says that more than a year ago bitter quarrels occurred between Prince Colonna and his wife, the stepdaughter of John W. Mackay. The Prince objected to what he termed his wife's overfondness for society. Six or seven weeks ago the Princess left her husband, and went to stay with her mother at the Hotel Brighton.

The American steamer Santuit, owned by L.G. Burnham Co. of Boston, it is learned from reliable sources, has been chartered by Charles R. Flint Co. of this city to tow the Destroyer, the submarinegun vessel, to Brazil. The Santuit was the former British steamer Alp, which was sunk a few years ago in New-York Harbor.

They were talking about the attitude of the Church toward politics last night at the Church Club, 146 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Satterleee had been saying that New-York was a mighty bad town, at which there were numerous "Amens," and that the Church should awaken good citizens from their lethargy, but should keep her skirts free from politics.

The usual holiday anties had play at the Exchanges yesterday, with results harmless and free from general disorder until, a few minutes before the close of business, about twenty soft rubber balls, inflated to football size, appeared suddenly on the floor of the Stock Exchange. This was the signal for a scrimmage worthy of the Polo Grounds, in which the brokers joined lustily.

Chief of Police John Y. McKane of Gravesend felt chagrined yesterday because he was not allowed to appear before the Kings County Grand Jury to testify against Col. Alexander S. Bacon, the Rev. Robert J. Kent, and others who went to Gravesend on election day bearing the injunction order issued by Justice Barnard of the Supreme Court.

President Seth Low of Columbia College save a lecture last evening on "Economic Education and American Citizenship" at the School of Social Economics, in Union Square. It was the third lecture of the Wednesday evening freelecture course.

THOMASVILLE, N.C., Nov. 29. -- The Philadelphia Kennel Club's field trials were favored with delightfully pleasant weather to-day. Currer Belle ran a good heat with Antevolo, the latter being disobedient and doing indifferently well on birds. Eugene T. outranged Roi d'Or and was speedier. Rough ground and cover were worked in the heat between Miss Ruby and Sandy Gladstone, an hour's diligent search resulting in no find or birds.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 29. -- John L. Stevens, ex-United States Minister to Hawaii, to-day completed his answer to Commissioner Blount. It is an exhaustive review of the controversy from his standpoint, a large part of it being devoted to ridicule of Mr. Blount and to flat denials of many of that gentleman's statements.

The Grand Jury for November finished it work yesterday, and was dismissed by Recorder Smyth It handed in a batch of indictments and two presentments, one dealing with the House of Detention, and the other with the Madison Square Bank. The first of the presentments was as follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- If present expectations are fulfilled, the first naval engagement for years is likely to take place within the next week off the coast of Brazil.

No more arrests in connection with the Madison Square Bank were reported yesterday. Assistant District Attorney Davis is busy preparing the cases for trial. Cashier Thompson and Discount Clerk Morton of the bank were with Mr. Davis yesterday, going over a number of the bank's books and documents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- George D. Johnston of Louisiana is no longer a member of the Civil Service Commission. He has been removed.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Robert George, forty-one years old, a well-known Republican politician living on the King's Bridge Road, on the outskirts of this city, was fatally stabbed to-night by William Vanderoef, thirty-eight years old, a house painter of East Chester.

The straightforward and businesslike report of Postmaster General Bissell was most favorably commented upon in this city yesterday by those who are connected with the service. Postmaster Dayton characterized the report as admirable.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction to-day at 111 Broadway:

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Robert George, forty-one years old, a well-known Republican politician living on the King's Bridge Road, on the outskirts of this city, was fatally stabbed to-night by William Vanderoef, thirty-eight years old, a house painter of East Chester.

It the fathers of college boys at Princeton and Yale had dreams last night, perhaps the angel who traces and weaves dream figures and scenes made for them something of immediate paternal interest. If he did not he missed a chance of a life-time-even an angel's lifetime -- for in the Tenderloin precinct were scenes portending ill for paternal pocketbooks.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- The first annual bench show of the New-Jersey Kennel Club was opened in Industrial Hall, adjoining the Grand Opera House, Tuesday. The visitors from New-York, Brooklyn, Philadelphia, and other places were surprised that this city could get up such a show. The crowd was made up mainly of dog fanciers. Many women were present.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The annual banquet of the Scottish Corporation was held this evening, as usual, in observance of St. Andrew's Day. Lord Roberts, formerly commander of the troops in India, presided. Many Scottish statesmen, clergymen, and naval and army officers of national reputation were present.

The Rev. Robert S. MacArthur, D.D., from the pulpit of Calvary Baptist Church yesterday, made his Thanksgiving sermon an arraignment of the Catholic Church. Standing in the church, decorated with flags, flowers, fruits, and the products of the field suggestive of bountiful harvests, he addressed a large congregation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The resolution of the Farmers' Benefit and kindred, associations, passed at Indianapolis, Nov. 29, asking Secretary Morton to retract what he said recently at Chicago relative to "journeymen", farmers, who promote granges for the purpose of "farming the farmers," was shown to him this morning, and he relished it as though it were Thanksgiving roast turkey.

Mr. FAIRCHILD'S manifesto to the Democrats of this State contains the gospel truth about New-York Democratic politics. It recites in temperate language, but clearly and accurately, the story of the frauds and debaucheries of the party machine which DAVID B. HILL began building up in 1885, and which did its natural and perfect work in bringing about the defeat of the Democratic Party on Nov. 7.
Grace Church, at Broadway and Tenth Street, is to have a vested and surpliced choir of boys and men.

Commodore and Acting Rear Admiral Oscar F. Stanton, who was recalled from the command of the South Atlantic squadron Decause he saluted the flag of Brazil flying an a vessel manned by the rebels, arrived in this city yesterday morning on the North Serman Lloyd steamer Spree. He embarked at Southampton.

One of the cheeriest spots in the city was 170 Bleecker Street, the headquarters and home of the Industrial Christian Alliance, where more than 100 men, wards of the alliance, and a number of invited guests sat down to a bountiful Thanksgiving dinner furnished by friends in various parts of New-York State and city, and in New-Jersey and Vermont.

The price of wheat at Chicago advanced a little more than 2 cents a bushel last week, but it is still very low. The exports for the week ending with Friday were 2,764,080 bushels, a quantity slightly in excess of the exports of the preceding week, and nearly equal to the average for the last seven weeks.

From London Truth. Very much has already been said, and very little need, therefore, be said new, about the late Prince Alexander of Bulgaria, who died last week at Vienna. In the early days at Darmstadt, soon after the close of the Franco-German war, when I knew the late Prince and his brothers well, it was impossible to have foreseen the distinguished parts that they were destined to play in the great world beyond.

What was it that Trustee E.H. Perking, Jr., of the West Presbyterian Church said to the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton when he was sent by the Board of Trustees to ask Dr. Paxton to agree to a reduction of salary?

RICHMOND, Nov. 30 -- In the game of football played here to-day between the teams of the University of North Carolina and the University of Virginia, for the championship of the Southern colleges, the former were defeated by a score of 16 to 0. The first half was stubbornly fought by both teams, and when time was called neither had scored.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- The event of Thanksgiving Day here was the blessing of the new seventy-five-thousand-dollar Catholic parochial school of St. Peter's Parish. Bishop O'Farrell performed the ceremony, assisted by many prominent members of the clergy, among them being Dean O'Grady of this city.

It is inevitable that the character of a holiday should change with the character of the people who observe it, but it is getting to be a question whether Thanksgiving Day is not a misnomer. There is a reminder of its ancient character in the official proclamations which appeal to the people to refrain from their "customary avocations" and assemble in their "respective places of worship" for certain specific purposes.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- The Credit Mobilier of this city has suspended payment. The news has created a deep impression owing to the various branches the concern had in different parts of Italy, all the depositors in which will suffer severely. The failure is attributed to the fall in rentes.

Those who dwell in the crowded, squalid tenement houses on the east side find little in their narrow and generally miserable lives to be especially thankful for, but even to them there is a significance and something to look forward to and remember in Thanksgiving Day.

It is plain that since the last revision of the Constitution of the State of New-York, the importance of cities has enormonsly increased, so that now it is no exaggeration to say that the most serious task for the convention of next year will be the treatment of city government. Even the general provisions of the Constitution are of more importance as they affect the population of cities than in any other regard.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- A dispatch has been received in this city from Rio Janeiro, dated Nov. 29, saying that the insurgent Admiral Mello, with several of his ships, had left Rio Janeiro Bay. The dispatch adds that the insurgent squadron is believed to have gone south.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate to the United States, declared himself on the subject of Catholic schools at a reception this afternoon given to him by the Faculty and students of Gonzaga College in the Hall of Notre Dame.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30 -- Like a thunderbolt from a clear sky came tidings of Yale's defeat this afternoon. Everybody knows that Yale expected to win and hoped to whitewash the Tigers. In fact, a majority of the bets registered here were even money that Princeton would not score. Yale blue has sunk to the hearts of thousands of loyal New-Haveners to-night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- John Y. McKane will not appear before Justice Barnard to-morrow in Brooklyn. Judge Barnard has partially made up his mind not to again hold court during the few remaining days of his term. Moreover, he does not desire to sit in judgment on McKane for contempt proceedings emanating from his own court.

The West Side German Clinic opened its new quarters, at 328 West Forty-second Street, for public inspection yesterday afternoon. The German Clinic was established twenty years ago by Germans, who recognized the great need on the west side for a place where poor people could be treated. The old clinic was at Thirty-eighth Street and Ninth Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- Late this afternoon M. Spuller informed President Carnot that he could not form a Cabinet. His efforts were thwarted by the persistent refusal of Burdeau to enter a Cabinet without Constans or Casimir-Perier. He retired willingly in favor of Casimir-Perier, who this evening consented to try to form a Ministry.

All the Princeton players who were not under orders to return to their Alma Mater by midnight fluttered in and out of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. Left Guard Wheeler, with a gash on his left cheek, was one of the heroes who was surrounded by an enthusiastic body guard of his colleagues, who introduced him right and left to the crowd in the lobby.

, Nov. 30. -- Secretary of State Foster's profession of surprise in February last when he submitted the treaty for the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands was a revelation of ignorance if it was not a deliberate disregard of the papers in the case submitted at the same time and printed in the same Congressional document.
A young man who was said to be the son of Major Gen. Rawlings of the Light Horse Guards of England was taken to the West Thirtieth Street Station House at about 1:30 this morning.

ASHLAND, Ill., Nov. 30. -- The Opera House Block was totally destroyed by fire at 3 o'clock this morning. The tire is supposed to have been caused by the explosion of an oil lamp. The Opera House was owned by Frank Lohman. His loss is estimated at $8,000, partially insured, Among the other losses are: A. Kumle, grocery, $1,000; W.A. Nelson, Jeweler, $3,000; J.A. Gleason, restaurant, $1,000; Taulman Swayne. restaurant, $1,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The association football players of Philadelphia had a grand battle here to-day with the Cosmopolitan football team of New-York, and the contest will be long remembered by the enthusiastic crowd, who witnessed it. The Cosmopolitans surprised their opponents, the spectators, and themselves by the game they put up, and finally crowned themselves with glory by gaining a victory by four goals to three.

An entertainment that ought certainly to apeal to sightseers on the score of novelty was begun last night, when Charles Hagenbeck's company of trainers and the animals they have taught opened a season at Tattersalls, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street. Mr. Hagenbeck is the supply agent in Europe for nearly all the circus men wishing trained animals.
BRUNSWICK, Ga., Nov. 30. -- The Yellow-Fever Relief Committee has adopted the following resolutions, with the request that they be published by the press:

John Alpenatern and his wife, Mary, have been in the hotel business in Hoboken for twenty years. They conducted their business on Washington Street in an orderly manner, they say. Wednesday afternoon they were in the Jefferson Market Police Court. It appears that as many as three Indictments were found against Alpenstern by the Grand Jury over there, one of which charged that he kept a disorderly house.

The series of combats between mounted broadswordsmen at the Madison Square Garden were begun last night. America, Ireland, Denmark, Italy, Germany, and England were represented. Italy put forward three contestants. There was also an Irish-American swordsman on the list.

The published abstract of the report of the Postmaster General indicates that he has taken hold of the business in a business like manner. This is even more encouragingly indicated by the experience of those who have to make much use of the postal facilities supplied by the Government.

One of the Prince Line steamships which go down to Brazil and load up with coffee and war news returned to this port yesterday. The vessel is the Sardinian Prince, Capt. Chambers. To a reporter for The New-York Times, who boarded the ship at her anchorage off liberty Island, Capt. Chambers said that during his two weeks' stay in Rio his vessel had been almost constantly in the cross fire of the combatants.

As Thanksgiving is observed in these days no part takes rank with the weather. Yesterday will pass to the record as faultless in this respect. The sky showed its happiest mood, and the air, while crisp enough for the season, enjoyed the mellowing touch of Indian Summer.

EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 30. -- The United States Federal authorities this evening arrested Victor L. Ochoa, an American citizen and editor of The Hispano Americano, on a complaint signed by Manuel Nelarde, Mexican Vice Consul. The complaint charges that:

Two deaths from smallpox and one case of that disease were reported at the Health Department yesterday. The dead were James Supple, twenty years old, of 190 Park Row, who was admitted to the host pital on North Brother Island on Nov. 21, and Alice Christianson, twenty-eight years old, of 109 West Sixty-eighth Street, who was admitted on Monday last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The coffee crop of Guatemala, according to information received by the Bureau of the American Republics, will not be so abundant as was anticipated. There has been an extraordinary rainfall in Guatemala since the early part of last April, and in some districts the coffee berry shows signs of shriveling, as the result of excessive moisture and insufficient sunshine.

Everything reaches him who waits. Those who did not so to the World's Fair, or, having gone, were too lazy to labor over the exhibits, are likely to prove the truth of the French adage. The best things in the fair proper, and in the Midway more or less proper, are rapidly converging on New-York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Over 2,500 people were at the Westchester County Fair Grounds to-day to see the match stallion race for $1,000 a side between Supervisor, Addison Johnson's bay gelding Turner, and John Everspecker's bay gelding Daconis. Turner has a record of 2:27, and Daconis a record of 2:24. The race was won by Turner, in three straight heats, each by less than a length.

To David H. Crowley, ex-Sergeant of Police, yesterday was indeed one of thanks-giving. He was released from Sing Sing Prison by order of Gov. Flower, after serving eight years of a sentence of seventeen years for assaulting Maggie Morris, and had the pleasure of eating his Thanksgiving dinner with his wife and family at his home, 231 Willis Avenue.

When the National Line steamship Europe came up the river from Quarantine yesterday, there emanated from somewhere a report that the crew of that vessel had had a long and desperate fight with fire at sea. There were visions of scalded stokers, of men overcome by heat, of charred and blackened woodwork, and all the other accessories that are wont to accompany the "fire fiend."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Superintendent Stump of the Immigration Bureau, Treasury Department, with the approval of Secretary Carlisle, has prepared a set of regulations for the guidance of steamship companies in the matter of returning undesirable immigrants. Because of their importance, the regulations are given in full:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- President Cleveland's prompt action in removing Civil Service Commissioner Johnston and appointing Prof. John R. Proctor of Kentucky in his place encourages advocates of the reform, who have felt for some time that the Civil Service Commission has become less influential in sustaining the refrom movement than it was before Mr. Johnston became a member of it.
John Y. McKane of Gravesend, who has figured so prominently in politics for many years, and who is now under bail for contempt of court, spent Thanksgiving at his pretty home in Sheepshead Bay.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 30. -- A large number of New-Yorkers visited Staten Island to-day. A majority were members of target companies or visitors to the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, at Mount Loretto.

The latter part of the voyage of the Steamship Furnessia, which arrived from Glasgow yesterday, was made under reduced speed. On Nov. 25 a flaw was discovered in the crank, shaft, and the vessel was hove to for twelve hours, until temporary repairs could be effected. For fear of straining the injured part the engines were run under reduced speed throughout the rest of the voyage.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 30. -- The statement of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company shows gross receipts for October of $2,127,430,42; expenses, $1,053,161,15. With the added expenses for equipment, improvement, fixed, charges, , a surplus is shown for the month of $294,838.55. The surplus in October, 1892, was $396,893.31.

Fortune appeared to favor the Tigers right from the outset. Capt. Trenchard won the toss and gave the ball to Yale, taking the eastern goal as there was a slight breeze blowing toward the western goal.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Since the death of my father, Mr. A.M. Scriba, there have been printed in the New-York papers references to letters written by my father to an old servant of ours. I am led to anticipate that in the minds of many to whom he was not personally known, (of his many friends I have no fears,) absolutely unjust and erroneous inferences may have found lodgment.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The condition of Miss Agnes Scott of III Avenue E, who shot herself on account of her broken engagement with J. Linn Bruce, was somewhat improved this evening. Dr. Finn says the shots were fired at such an angle that the bullets passed downward between the heart and lungs without touching either.

Perhaps the big black and white mongrel had had to wait some time for a messenger boy to go on an errand, and had lost his dinner by it. Perhaps he had an inherent canine antipathy to boys, anyway. Or he may have been cheated out of his Thanksgiving turkey and cranberry sauce and decided to make it up on boy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Notwithstanding the strenuous efforts that have been made in the Ways and Means Committee to provide revenue for the Government by an income tax, it looks as though, that unwise proposition would, be abandoned as being one fraught with too much hurt to be now undertaken.

Mr. Josef Slivinski's first concert, which took place last night in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, would have been more interesting had there been less of it. But It is impossible for any pianist to hold the undivided attention of an audience for over two hours and a half. That was what Mr. Slivinski was expected to do last night, with occasional relief by Mr. Seidl and his orchestra.

From The Chicago Tribune. James W. Ellsworth promises to revolutionize the coal-mining business and bring down the prices materially in less than two years. The new scheme in mining is the application of automatic machinery and compressed air. Mr. Ellsworth was the first to try electricity in mining, but he has abandoned that for air pressure.

Fifty thousand persons watched, or tried to watch, the long-haired sons of Yale and old Nassau battle for supremacy. More than ten times that number in this city had more than a passing interest in the game.

Capt. Randall of the wrecked schooner Louise H. Randall, his courageous wife, for whom the schooner was named; First Mate Thomas Smith, and Second Mate George S. Phillips are the only ones from the illfated vessel that still remain in the Presbyterian Hospital. All are in a fair way toward recovery, and will probably be able to leave the hospital this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Chairman E. E. Clarke said to-day that there was no change in the Lehigh Valley strike situation. The efforts of the New-York and New-Jersey Boards of Arbitration, he continued, had not altered matters a particle. Mr. Clarke said that the only thing in President Wilbur's statement which differed from what he and his fellow-committeemen expected was the favorable attitude of the company toward the men who belong to labor organizations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30 -- Before 16,000 people Harvard redeemed her football reputation to-day. The final score of 26 to 4 against the University of Pennsylvania, commencing with a safety touch-down and ending with a beautiful crawl through the centre for a touch-down by Brewer, was the result of a series of football surprises and brilliant plays.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: For several years past legislation for the restrtction of the liquor traffic has been hopeless, because Tammany Hall has been la supreme control at Albany. The result of the late election has given an opportunity for a full and fair consideration of legislative remedies which shall commend themselves to the Intelligence of the community.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Nov. 30. -- Thomas. E. Neal, collector for the Stager Sewing Machine Company in this city, shot and killed Charles Grogan near here last night. Neal was returning from a collecting tour in the country, and-had considerable money. When near the city, Grogan, whom he did not know, caught the bridle of Neal's horse and stopped him.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- The Times this morning, in a leading editorial, charges President Cleveland with inconsistency. It prints a letter from the President to the late Carter Harrison, asking his aid in carrying Illinois for the Democracy, but states that, when Harrison asked Cleveland to aid him in the Mayoralty fight, the President replied that he could not interfere in local politics.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 30. -- When the people of Canada come to know that the Canadian Pacific Railway is now approaching the Dominion Government with a view of setting an act put through Parliament next session guaranteeing the bonds of the company to the extent of $15,000,000 at 4 per cent., there will be a sensation from Halifax to Vancouver.

Yesterday afternoon there dashed out of the back door of the Fifth Avenue Theatre a man whose face was still glossy with the vaseline with which he had just removed his grease paint. Patches of one false eyebrow clung to the sparse thatch of the real one. His cheeks wore a heightened and obviously artificial color.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- John Cumming macdona, Conservative for the Rotherhithe Division of Southwark, brought up again today in the House of Commons the subject of derelicts in the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The first annual report of Hillary A. Herbert, Secretary of the Navy, has been presented to the President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- R.E. Preston, the Director of the Mint, has submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury a report of the operations of the mints and assay offices for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1893. It shows that the value of the gold deposited, including redeposits, during the fiscal year 1893 at the mints and assay offices was $50,839,905.

Capt. William S. Devery of the Eldridge Street Station, against whom four indictments were handed down on Wednesday by the Grand Jury, on charges made by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst of the Society for Prevention of Crime, in relation to disorderly houses in his precinct, returned home last night from Chicago, having been summoned by a telegram from Superintendent Byrnes.

At the Young Women's Christian Association, 7 East Fifteenth Street, the Thanksgiving service of the Bible class was held on the Sunday before Thanksgiving Day with special music and an inspiring lesson on causes for thankfulness. Over 500 women were present, many of them sorely needing help to find a thankful side to their troubled lives.

Peter McCabe, twenty-four years old, of 229 East Twenty-fifth Street, walked into the Twenty-second Street Police Station about 8 o'clock last night, bleeding from a stab over the left eye and a bad gash in the back of his head, both inflicted by a knife. He was at once sent to Bellevue Hospital.

As soon as the crowd got on to the field the college students began to make things lively. The greatest fun was around the fence that kept the mob from the green. The college men waved their colors, cheered, and guyed every one who appeared as all prominent.

It was ideal and historic football which was played at Mannattan Field yesterday afternoon. Ideal as far as the game, the weather, and the spectacular effects of the contest; historic, inasmuch as the victors broKe the traditions of Yale's invincibility and avenged Princeton's series of past defeats in a manner that was as thorough as it was unexpected.

They had a regular old-fashioned Thanks-giving tune yesterday in Dr. Tannage's Brooklyn Tabernacle. Everything in and about the great church wore a festal air. From Dr. Talmage down to the man who looks after the wind in the big organ, everybody was in a Thanksgiving humor.

From The New-Yorker Staats-Zeitung. Energetic measures against evildoers are being taken simultaneously in Brooklyn, Buffalo, and Albany, and to the Governor must be given the credit of endeavoring to bring to account the rotten ring politicians in the two first-mentioned cities. Republican organs are trying to make capital from the fact that in these cases so much hoggishness of Democratic officials and politicians has been exposed.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1. -- Having secured the approval of a large majority of the electorate of Newfoundland at the recent general election, the present Government of that colony has renewed its demand upon the British Government for the ratification of the commercial treaty negotiated in 1890 by Mr. Blaine on behalf of the Government of the United States and Robert Bond representing the Government of Newfoundland.

It was decided at the meeting of the Police Board yesterday to remand the ordinance force -- some thirty in all -- to patrol duty and to assign the duty heretofore intrusted especially to them -- of looking after and reporting obstructions on the sidewalks, c. -- to the whole police force.

Abe Stein Co. of 97 Gold Street, a firm which has been doing the largest importing business in goatskins and hides in the United States, was placed in the hands of a receiver yesterday. The failure was due to the suspension of the London house of Jacob Stein Co., through which the firm did a large part of its foreign business.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- The undergraduate body at Princeton are probably the happiest people to be found anywhere to-day. To be sure they were set crazy with joy last night and made themselves heard on the way to the Pennsylvania station and all the way down on the special. The forty students left in college turned the whole town into pandemonium on Thursday night.

For a long time organized bands of boys in the neighborhood of Tenth and Eleventh Avenues and Fifty-third and Fifty-eighth Streets have annoyed citizens on the west side of the city and endangered life and property. These bands fight each other whenever they meet, and at other times break windows and throw missiles about recklessly.

H.L. Hoyt, manager of the Victoria Hotel, gave up that position yesterday. He claims he was unable to get along with Mrs. Florence Stanfield, who owns the hotel, and her son, Douglas M. Stanfleld. With Mr. Hoyt went Steward Ovenden, who had been engaged by him.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday adopted the plan for an independent elevated west side route, the informal approval of which had been announced at last Tuesday's meeting. That was about the only business yesterday. Between the two meetings the Commissioners had formulated various promises and suggestions calculated to protect any underground system and to define and prescribe now a new road must be equipped.

The Wilson bill puts all kinds of raw wool on the free list. Nearly three-quarters of the wool imported into this country is the coarse wool used in the manufacture of carpets, the average value of it being less than 10 cents a pound. The following table shows the quantities of all kinds of wool, and also the quantities of carpet wool, imported In the last four years:

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Fire started at 9 o'clock this morning in the Haymarket Theatre Building, situated at 161 to 169 West Madison Street. The front part of the building, which is occupied by stores, saloons, and the offices of doctors, dentists, photographers, real estate agents, and jewelers, was completed gutted.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- Money remained unchanged at the Clearing House this morning, the loans being made at 1 and 1 1/2 per cent. New-York funds were in demand, selling at par and 10c premium. Business paper was quoted at 3 3/4@5, corporation loans at 3 1/2@4, collateral loans at 3 1/2@4, and call loans at 2@3 per cent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- It was stated on the board, this morning that at the next meeting of the Chicago City Railway Directory, which takes place in a fortnight, a proposition will be made to issue an extra $1,000,000 of stock. The report created a good demand for the security, sending it up ten points.

Dun's Review will say to-morrow: "It cannot be said that business during the past week has grown better or worse. For some days the gain in demand and in transactions which had been previously noticed evidently continued. But afterward tariff uncertainties were thought to affect some branches of business, and, whatever the causes, the state of trade was less clear.

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- Casimir-Perier's latest forecast of a Cabinet is: Casimir-Perier, Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs; Reynal, Minister of the Interior; Burdeau, Minister of Finance; Dubost, Minister of Justice; Marty, Minister of Agriculture; Spuller, Minister of Instruction; Gen. Mercier, Minister of War; Delcasse, Minister of the Colonies; Jonnart, Minister of Public Works; Admiral Laffon, Minister of Marine.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 1. -- Savannah to-day raised the quarantine against Brunswick which has been in effect since Sept. 13, except on household goods and merchandise. Baggage will be admitted when bearing certificate of the Marine Hospital Service. All railroads and the Surgeon General of the Marine Hospital Service were notified this afternoon of the removal of the quarntine.
Unless the white-winged dove of peace performs some extraordinary aerial maneuver, there is a lively time ahead for the Paxtonites and the anti-Paxtonites in the West Presbyterian Church.

At last evening's meeting of the Goldey, a club composed mainly of high school pupils, at 8 West Fourteenth Street, there was a debate as to whether incomes exceeding $500 should be taxed. Charles Ernst started with an argument in favor of such a tax. He took the ground that the word income should not apply to wages earned by workingmen.

That Congress will press the Wilson Tariff bill to a vote as speedily as possible and that not one hour be wasted in delay or discussion beyond the point when such discussion may be valuable is the earnest hope of a number of business men who expressed themselves to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday.

The game of football between Princeton and Yale on Thursday was conducted, according to all the observers and reporters, in the friendliest and most admirable spirit. Nobody concerned willfully inflicted injuries on anybody else. Yet there were a considerable number of casualties so severe as to involve the delay of the game until the injured players could recover, while in at least one case a player was disabled and forced to retire.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 1. -- Certain Maine men started last Spring to raise by voluntary contributions from the people of Maine a fund for the erection of a memorial statue of James G. Blaine. A Blaine Memorial Association was organized, composed of leading citizens of all political parties, and a subscription committee, composed of a prominent man from each county, was appointed to make a thorough canvass for contributions to this memorial fund.

JAMAICA, L.I., Dec. 1. -- Miss Phoebe Abrams of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Abram Golder of Freeport were married Sunday night without the knowledge of their parents. The wedding became known Thanksgiving Day. It would probably not have leaked out had not the constant presence of the young man at the Adams home excited the suspicion of the bride's family.

To remedy the destruction of edible fish along the coast line is the subject that will be discussed at the office of the Fish Commissioners, 53 Broadway, on Wednesday, Dec. 13, at 10 A.M. A circular has been issued for the meeting by prominent citizens calling the meeting. It reads:

The letter from the Secretary of the Church Temperance Society which appeared in our columns yesterday indicates that one result of the unexpected change in the control of the Legislature of this State will be a renewed effort to secure amendments of the excise law in the direction of further restriction of the liquor traffic.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1. -- Edward C. Billings, United States Judge for the Eastern District of Louisiana, died here early this morning, after an illness of some weeks. His death had been expected for several days, and he was surrounded by relatives, who had been summoned to his side when the end came this morning.

ALTON, Ill., Dec. 1. -- Several politicians met in a saloon to-day to talk over the Postmasterships at Alton and Upper Alton. Among the number were John W. Coppinger, Consul to Toronto; Congressman W.S. Forman, and Col. A.F. Rodgers, Superintendent of the Plaza Bluffs Assembly, a religious gathering place.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Victor Cyrier and Mrs. K.E.L. Caron committed suicide to-day at the Virginia Hotel, she by morphine and he by a bullet. The two bodies were found in the same room at the hotel by a chambermaid early this morning. The two people had been at the hotel since Tuesday night and were known as Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lapointe, under which name Cyrier registered as from St. Paul.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Although public attention is centred on the Ways and Means Committee, the majority of that committee is still unprepared to take the public into its confidence regarding the sources of internal revenue to be tapped by the bill which is to supplement the tariff measure.

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- John Boyd Thacher, Chairman of the Executive Committee on Awards at the World's Columbian Exposition, has returned to his home here from Chicago. When asked regarding the opposition which was manifested toward his system of awards he consented to talk, for the first time since he assumed his duties at Chicago six months ago, and for the first time since he experienced any such opposition.
Wheat was irregular and rather more active, but closing at 1/4c advance, on local switching and firmer cables.

Now that the college football season is over, it behooves the promoters of the game to hold a conference and adopt some measures with a view of eliminating the dangerous plays in the growing sport. Football is an interesting pastime for both player and spectator, but some of the rough work ought to be abolished.

The committee to draft a blanket-ballot act for this State has been announced. Its five members represent the City Club, the Reform Club, the Republican Club, and the New-York Citizens' Democracy. We do not know exactly what is meant by the statement that it will draw a bill "based on the Massachusetts system."

An application was made yesterday to Judge Miles Beach, sitting in Chambers in the Supreme Court for an order to compel the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company to show cause why it should not be enjoined and restrained from a further construction of a third track on its Ninth Avenue line during the pendency of an action about to be brought by the city against the company.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" was brought forward to fill the third evening of grand opera at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. The performance did not introduce any new members of Messrs. Abbey Grau's company, but it enabled the admirers of Mme. Nordica to hear her in the role of Elsa, which, report says, she is to sing at Baireuth next Summer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Secretary Carlisle had a long consultation with the President to-day. It is supposed that it had reference to the forthcoming report of the Secretary of the Treasury in relation to the Treasury balance, now down to $95,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The annual report of Secretary Hoke Smith discusses the operations of the General Land Office, the Pension Bureau, the Census Office, the Bureau of Indian Affairs, patents, Geological Survey, education, and Pacific Railroads.

The fifth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools in the Middle States was opened at Columbia College yesterday morning. The session lasted through the day and in the evening, and after the evening session a reception was tendered to the delegates and their families by President Seth Low of Columbia College and Mrs. Low at their residence, 30 East Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The football game tomorrow at Annapolis between the West Pointers and the Naval Academy eleven was the absorbing topic of conversation to-day at the War and Navy Departments. Nearly every officer on duty in Washington of the two services will go down to Annapolis, and all of them have placed money on the result of the game.

The metropolitan fishing fleet is in part laid up for the Winter, the active portion devoting itself to cod, which is abundant off the Long Island and Jersey coasts. The cod arrive at the bluefish disappear, but do not proceed much below the latitude of this city. The bluefish in their southward migration have now arrived off North Carolina. Here they annually appear in vast numbers, supporting large and profitable fisheries.

The foreign exchange market was strong at the opening, but eased off slightly during the day. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.84 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.83 1/2@$4.83 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/4@$4.86 1/2 for demand, $4.86 3/4@$4.87 for cable transfers, and $4.82 1/2 for commercial.

Despondent and tired of life, John Baptist Dunne, thirty-five years old, of 445 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, chose to end his existence yesterday by shooting himself in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, at Park Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- The Reichstag to-day on motion of Count Hompesch, member of the Centre or Catholic Party, passed a revocation of the decree ordering the expulsion of Jesuits from Germany, by a majority of thirty-seven.

William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn, Justiceelect of the Supreme Court, had occasion yesterday to feel well pleased with the outcome of his efforts to upset the schemes of the Democratic ring politicians. They wanted to sell to that city at a fabulous price the Long Island Water Supply Company, and to obtain for themselves free a valuable street railroad franchise for which bona fide capitalists had offered the city a large amount of money.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 1. -- Charles R. Flint of New-York, United States agent of the Brazilian Government, was in this city on Wednesday for the purpose of attending a meeting of the Directors of the United States Rubber Company, of which he is Secretary.

In compliance with the recent action of the Northern Pacific Directors demanding the retirement of ex-President Thomas F. Oakes from the office of receiver of the company, papers have been prepared for presentation to the United States District Court in Milwaukee asking that he be removed from the receivership.

ELIZABETH, Dec. 1. -- Charles Martz, an insurance and real estate agent here, will probably die from a fall he received Thanksgiving night, when he missed his footing and tumbled head foremost into the excavation caused by the tunneling of Morris Avenue under the Central Railroad tracks.

A Dance at the Waldorf. -- Mr. and Mrs. J.B. Kissam gave a small and highly-enjoyable dance at the Hotel Waldorf lost night. Fifteen couples were present. The favors and decorations were of that delicate pink which is the distinctive color of smart affairs this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Following is the monthly statement of the public debt, issued from the Treasury Department to-day:

NEW-YORK, Friday, Dec. 1. -- P.M. The stock market was fairly active and strong at the opening, with Chicago Gas, St. Paul, and Sugar the features. Sugar weakened early in the day, and declined from 83 to 80 about noon. There seemed to be good buying about the latter figure, and it did not break that price during the remainder of the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- Following yesterday's holiday, the market lapsed into a state of extreme dullness. Philadelphia Traction sold at 93 1/2, ex dividend. Metropolitan was dull at 106, and Electric firm at 48. People's advanced to 30.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- It is reported that mail parcels addressed to members of the imperial family and to high officials will be opened hereafter at the Post Office in the presence of police, and, when special reasons for suspicion exist, will be sent to experts for examination.

KIMBALL, S.D., Dec. 1. -- The Supreme Court has decided that L.D. Bardin must pay temporary alimony and attorney's fees to his second wife, who is suing for a divorce. Mr. Bardin is one of the leading merchants here, and is prominent in social affairs. His first wife died four years ago, and about a year later he brought a Mrs. Osborne of Troy, N.Y., here and introduced her as his wife.

John Y. McKane was afraid Col. Bacon and his Republican watchers were going to capture Gravesend and set up a Republican form of government there, and that is why the "Boss" threw the Colonel and his men into cells. At least this is what his excuse for violence on election day amounts to.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- The avariciousness of Harrison E. Dauchey of this village, in placing a blank piece of paper in an envelope, which he gave to the Rev. W.W. Wilson in lieu of a wedding fee, led to the discovery that the groom was not only a bigamist, but had just wedded his third wife, a widow, named Mary Holly.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- A dispatch to the Exchange Telegraph Company from Rio Janeiro states that the insurgent Admiral, Mello, has finally succeeded in forcing a passage past the forts guarding the entrance of the bay of Rio de Janeiro, and that his flagship, the Aquidaban, is now on the high seas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Navy Department this afternoon received a cablegram from Capt. Picking, in command of the United States vessels stationed at Rio, confirming the message sent earlier by Minister Thompson announcing the departure from the harbor of the insurgent Admiral.

Major J.R. McNulty, formerly of the Harlem Democratic Club; ex-Sheriff James O'Brien, ex-Alderman Duffy of the Board of 1884, ex-Assistant District Attorney Andrew D. Parker, and ex-Senator Francis M. Bixby recently discussed the local political situation and decided that the city should have pure government.

St. Stephen's Church, Summit and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday morning with friends of the late John J. Kiernan. They had assembled to hear the last rites performed over his body. The coffin rested on a catafalque below the altar, and was surrounded with floral offerings.

TUNKHANNOCK, Penn., Dec. 1. -- The passenger service of the Lehigh Valley Railroad is still badly crippled. The night trains from the east were practically abandoned on account of the wreck at Wilkesbarre. Passengers were transferred to the local due here at 8 o'clock this morning. The morning trains east from Sayre were from one to two hours late.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 1. -- A fire which destroyed about $225,000 worth of property and which for a time menaced an entire block of residences broke out tonight in the old Thornton Worsted Mills, Tenth Street and Columbia Avenue, this city, owned and operated by James F. Cochran Brother.

LONG ISLAND CITY, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- The old United States man-of-war Portsmouth was a prisoner for four hours this afternoon on the jagged rocks of Middle Ground Reef, two miles east of Hell Gate. She poked her black hull into the treacherous pile shortly before noon, and it was not until about 3:30 o'clock that the high tide floated her off, when she continued on her way up the Sound.

Fifty sad-eyed students stood before Justice Koch in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning, and fifty aching heads ached harder as their owners tried to remember who they were when arrested and what they had given as their occupations. The Justice did not allow any of them to get as far as brain fever before discharging them.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 1. -- Everything is in readiness for the battle between the army and the navy to-morrow. While the football season practically closed wish the great contests on Thanksgiving Day. the game between the elevens of Uncle Sam's future Generals and embryo Admirals is attracting agreat deal of attention.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- The trial of Hiram T. Downing, one of the members of the collapsed Barnegat Company, indicted for perjury, in connection with the Barnegat Park litigation, was begun to-day in the Mercer County court.

The first public rehearsal of the Oratorio Society took place yesterday afternoon in the Music Hall, and, considering the fact that it was pouring rain at the hour when the concert began, there was a large audience present. The work chosen for performance was Edward Grell's "Missa Solemnis," which has already been performed here twice.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Dec. 1. -- A wreck occurred near Bloomsbury station, on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, to-night, which blocked both tracks and by which the life of another one of the green trainmen was sacrificed.

Police Captain Devery of the Eldridge Street Station, against whom four indictments were returned on Wednesday by the Grand Jury in consequence of charges preferred by the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst of the Society for the Suppression of Crime, visited the District Attorney's office yesterday and furnished ball.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

The announcement at the mass meeting of unemployed in Union Square Tuesday evening that a free labor intelligence bureau would be opened yesterday morning at the University Settlement, 26 Delancey Street, proved premature. About forty men called at this place yesterday, and were turned away.

There is a young Englishwoman at the St. James Hotel, who is either the greatest sleight-of-hand performer on earth or else a mind-reading wonder beside whom Washington Irving Bishop and the rest were clumsy apprentices.

Two cases of rackless driving were brought before Justice Burke in the Yorkhill Police Court yesterday. The first one was that of Robert Hewston pf 342 West Forty-eighth Street, who was charged with running over Andrew Ryan of Waterbury, Conn., who had been visiting friends at 24 West Fifty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- President Cleveland to-day appointed First Lieut. James E. Sawyer of the Fifth Artillery Captain and Assistant Quartermaster. Capt. Sawyer was born in Washington, and was appointed to the army from New-Jersey in 1867, without passing through the Military Academy.
Deputy County Treasurer James Gardiner of Kings County died suddenly yesterday morning at the home of County Treasurer Adams, 1,475 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, of paralysis of the stomach.

ORANGE, Dec. 2 -- One of the most successful charity events of the season was the annual fair and sale for the benefit of the Crib Fund of Memorial Hospital, which was held in Music Hall to-night and attended by hundreds of people from the Oranges, Montclair, and Bloomfield. The hall was very effectively decorated, and the stage was set with tables inclosed in palms and potted plants.

Irregularity is the main feature of the market with a general undertone of strength. The latter is due mainly to cheap money, and in some lesser degree to the October reports of railroad earnings. These showed increases in net earnings, due to severe cutting down of expenses. The gross earnings were nothing to boast of, and the months of November and December may be expected to show up very poorly.

The freight rate situation between Chicago and New-York wears a threatening look. For some time past there have been rumors about rate cutting on east-bound traffic, and the fact that an uncommonly large percentage of freight has been moving to the Atlantic seaboard over the "Big Four" and Chesapeake and Ohio route pointed the finger of suspicion in that direction.

Who but Pepys would have thought of solemnly recording the first sirloin of beef "that ever I had of mine own buying since I was a housekeeper," and what a pity it would have been had he not, or if he had forgotten to record Mrs. Pepys being "in her new suit of black sarcenet and yellow petticoat, very pretty."

A.H. King Co. and Cohn, Ball Co., the former retail dealers in clothing and the latter wholesale dealers at 627 and 629 Broadway, have suspended again, being unable to meet the second payment on their compromise notes. The two companies form one concern.

The Cornell Building, a five-story iron-front structure at 139, 141, and 143 Centre Street, was badly wrecked by fire shortly before 6 o'clock last evening. The fire started in the elevator shaft at the north entrance, and did over $50,000 damage to the building and its contents.

Hospitals, as we now understand the term, are of modern growth. True it is, as Mr. Burden tells us in the historical section of "Hospitals and Asylums of the World." that in the records of Egypt and ancient India we find allusions to institutions that foreshadow the hospitals of later times, and even our asylums for sick animals are borrowed from the East.

From The Chicago Herald, Nov. 29. Charles Z. Fritzinger, a German farmer who resides in Benton County, forty-five miles south, of Sedalia, Mo., while digging a drainage ditch on his farm last Saturday, unearthed, at a distance of three feet from the surface, a medal or token of Wesley Chapel and parsonage, John Street, New-York, the first Methodist building in America.

Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren has set the politicians to guessing. He has said that he has offered the appointments of Police, City Works, and Fire Commissioners to three men, who have accepted. These three men, Mr. Schieren has said, are Republicans. But the politicians are still in the dark. They are anxious to know who the three men are.

Mr. JOHN BOYD THACHER has submitted to an interview since his return from what he still insists upon regarding as the scene of his triumphs, though he has that view entirely to himself. A more amusing specimen of the Bourbon who is incapable of learning or forgetting it would be impossible to find.

When Arthur Blunt disappeared and Eliner Rodney, wife of Robert Rodney, was missing, the good folks of Aberdeen whispered together harmoniously, some saying, "An elepement," and others, "What did I tell you?" Shrewd people were they, capable of proving two and two to be four, and even two and one, if the idiosyncrasy was necessary for the fulfillment of a scandal.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The announcement yesterday in The New-York Times of the appointment of H. Laurens Storke to the Postmastership did not create much surprise here in business and political circles, although it came sooner that expected. This was due to the volunutary resignation of the present incumbent, Gen. John N. Knapp, who has long been incapacitated for business through ill health.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 2. -- Clifford W. Thomas, alias George Claris, was brought to the county jail here to-day, charged with using the United States mails for fraudulent purposes. He was arrested by Sheriff Tinney at Adams yesterday, when he called for his mail, and received 136 letters directed to Mrs. M.E. Tyler.

Mr. Parkhurst seems to have succeeded in stirring up the various commanders of police precincts by procuring the indictment of Capt. Devery. It is said that the doctor does not intend to stop at Capt. Devery, but that he will strike at various other Captains, and even take in some of the Inspectors, if not the Police Commissioners themselves.

The building 753 and 755 Broadway, at the corner of Eighth Street, was badly damaged by a fire that started just after 7 o'clock last evening. Steinhart, Heidelberg Co., manufacturers and dealers in Summer clothing, occupy the upper floors of the building, and it was in the workroom of this firm that the fire started.

From New-York to Yokohama, seems thing to-day like a stone's-throw in distance. One leaves his cab, as it were, and steps into his jinrikisha, it being only a question of a few weeks of travel. Mr. Thompson's handsome volume is the diary of a globe trotter who followed the sun, and in a little over seven months the world had been girdled by him.

MONTREAL, Dec. 2 -- The preliminary examination of young Mercier, son of ex-Premier Mercier; Demartigny, and Pelland, charged with attempting to blow up the Nelson Monument with dynamite, was begun in Judge Desnoyer's court this morning. The court was crowded and the greatest interest was taken in the proceedings.

The lively athletes who keep the gymnasium of the Central Twenty-third Street Young Men's Christian Association Building in a state at unceasing activity are now concentrating all their efforts toward putting themselves in the best possible trim for the coming gymnasium exhibits. The regular annual exhibit of the association will take place Jan. 1, and many interesting features will be on the programme.
Leonard Reiger of 20 George Street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday, on complaint of Charles Hofer, a hardware dealer at 122 Graham Avenue, charged with causing the death of Hofer's child.

WHITE HAVEN, Penn., Dec. 2. -- Early this morning two freight trains collided on the Lehigh Valley Road in the heart of town. Fire followed, burning the cars, and it is thought at least three men were burned to death. The flames communicated to the Ruhnke Hotel, and the result was one of the worst conflagrations which has visited this place in many years.

The football game found more enthusiastic champions in the regular young ladies' boarding schools than in other schools and colleges where the students are engrossed in their work for academic degrees.

Tuesday, Nov. 7 -- The first sensation of the Winter. Bernhardt and Lemaitre. The latter is almost impertinent in his wit. Once a teacher in the provinces, he has grown to splendid fame and power. His first success was the pulling to pieces of Georges Ohnet, who, he declared, did not know how to write his own language.

The second of Mr. Damrosch's matinees took place yesterday afternoon at Music Hall. There was not as large an audience present as the entertainment deserved. It begins to look as If there were more musical enterprises at present than the public demands, and if those who make a business of providing pleasures of this kind are not careful they will kill the goose that lays the golden egg by overfeeding.

Flat-house fires are occurring in Brooklyn with alarming frequency. They suggest the operations of a "firebug," who is operating in a manner similar to Henry Miller, who is in the Elmira Reformatory, and who started so many incendiary fires in Brooklyn flat houses two years ago.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 2 -- The odds and ends of old New-London whalers have not been supposed to be of much value in the past, mainly for the reason that these remnants of an extinct industry have not been known to collectors, even in New-London itself. Recently, the most interesting of old-time relics connected with the whalers that used to sail out of New-London Harbor have come to light there.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 2. -- Every resident of this little city is suffering from an aggravated case of football fever. It began late in the Summer, when the cadets at the Naval Academy began practice work; it progressed slowly, aided by a few "scrub" games in the Fall, and it reached its height this afternoon when the middies won the championship of the army and navy by defeating the crack team from West Point.

Inspector Williams went to "Cairo Streets," in the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, last night to witness the danse du ventre, which was a part of the "World's Fair prize winners'" show.

There is a feeling of confidence to-day among those who deal in horses and carriages in this city that is easily seen by the cheerful tone and pleased look as they go to their increased business. The first indications of an improved tone in the horse and carriage trade were shown by the good prices realized for horses immediately after the Horse Show.

SING SING, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- The subject of good roads, or, at least, better roads through Westchester County, is just now receiving a good deal of attention from the town officers, and where they are inactive the village authorities have taken the matter up. The result is becoming visible in better thoroughfares in various parts of the county.

There is a high degree of practical common sense in the plan of the "East Side Relief Work Committee" which is extremely encouraging, especially when it is considered what various agencies have been united in the scheme. The territory covered by the committee is on the east side of the city below Fourteenth Street.

Children's parties may be regarded as social obligations, as educational advantages, or, casting all theory and formality aside, they may be made occasions of intense delight, red-letter days in the calendar of childhood and happy memories for years to come. New-Yorkers above all other people possess the art of uniting punctilious formality with an abandon of welcome and entertainment.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- I must ask our friend Antoine to accept apology for tardy criticism -- delayed by Illness.

The Birmingham Gazette states that the directors of the Birmingham Mint have adopted a practicable method of remedying a long-endured nuisance. The thick black volumes of smoke proceeding from the high chimney stack of the local mint have long been a serious annoyance to the district, and the shopkeepers in particular have suffered to no inconsiderable extent from the same source of trouble.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- There is to be another competitive test of rapid-fire guns. This time the trial will take place at Sandy Hook, and will be conducted by the Army Ordnance Board. Gen. Flagler, the army Chief of Ordnance, has completed the programme for the tests. The board will examine carefully each gun and note the strength, simplicity, and certainty of action of the parts of the breech mechanism.

COLLEGES POINT, L.I., Dec. 2. -- Coroner Corey is investigating the death of Daniel Flannery, who was found lying on the causeway between here and Flushing late last night. He had a cut on his head, from which he was bleeding profusely. Although he was alive when picked up, he was unconscious and unable to make a statement.

Jim Maitland has been sitting about the bar of the Fifth Avenue Hotel for several days. His Chicago clothes and fashionable shoes cannot conceal the bow legs and the high-heeled walk of a man who has lived astride a bronco on the range for years.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- The police this morning captured a bold confidence man and bogus check worker named Herbert Crowhurst, twenty-one years old. He was searched at the station house and a number of bogus checks, drafts, and other commercial papers were found upon his person. When his room was searched the officers found a paper containing a list of a number of prominent Buffalo business men.

At the closing session of the fifth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools in the Middle States and Maryland, held in the lecture hall of Columbia College yesterday, a committee of ten was appointed to agree upon a plan to facilitate the work of the instructors in the preparatory school fitting students for a college course.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The question of supplying the Government with postal cards is just now causing Postmaster General Bissell much, annoyance. Some months ago the contract for furnishing postal cards was awarded to C.C. Wolworth of Castleton, N.Y., but up to this time all of the card paper has been rejected by the department agents, on the ground that it was not up to the contract standard.
