LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Rarely does the Autumn find a more perfect day than was Thanksgiving at this resort. It was a day bright and clear, with the atmosphere of Spring. The visitors came in large numbers, the hotels were well filled, and there were family reunions at the cottages.

Ex-President W. Wetmore Cryder of the Madison Square Bank will surrender himself to the District Attorney to-morrow. Mr. Cryder is at present in Washington. Detective Reilly of the District Attorney's office went to Washington on Friday with the intention of bringing Mr. Cryder back to this city to answer to certain charges of irregularities alleged to have been committed in the bank's management during Mr. Cryder's administration.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The division on the motion for the return of the Jesuits in the Reichstag cannot be described as one on strictly party lines. During the regime of Prince Bismarck, the tenacity with which he opposed the revocation of the law of expulsion, even after the abatement of the Kulturkampf, prevented the splitting of the party groups on this question.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2. -- The Republicans are greatly agitated over the question of keeping their platform pledges. Last Summer they went before the people and promised to live up to the full letter of the Constitution in the matter of biennial sessions of the Legislature, if they were again intrusted with power.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Earl of Warwick died to-day at his seat, Warwick Castle, George Guy Greville, Earl of Warwick, Earl Brooke, was born March 28, 1818. He succeeded his father Aug. 10, 1853. In 1852 he married Lady Anne Charteris, daughter of the Earl of Wemyss and March, and of this marriage there is issue four sons and one daughter.

Mr. H.S. Van Duzer, the Treasurer of the committee of the University Athletic Club that managed the big Thanksgiving Day football game, is still hard at work trying to close up the accounts. It will be several days yet, he says, before everything is closed up. He has figured out very closely the attendance at the game, though, and can form a close estimate of the receipts and expenses.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- An afternoon paper prints in detail the testimony which will be given by Mrs. Andrew Foy, who will be the first witness presented by the State in the Coughlin trial. The facts, Mrs. Foy avers, were told her by her husband at times when remorse for his part in the crime would overcome him.

"Don't pin it in front, Mike," said one of the "two little girls in blue" who, appropriately enough, headed the grand march at the Lady Blue Jeans Association's grand masquerade ball in the Lyceum Opera House last night. "Don't pin it in front, Mike. I want it acrost me back, so's to show it to Mamie Kiernan.

New-York Sons of the Revolution will celebrate the anniversary of the Boston Tea Party at Delmonico's Dec. 16. Among those who will attend are Robert S. Willlams, President of the Oneida National Bank of Utica, N.Y., and his son. Prof. Williams, of Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore. Both of them are members of the society, and are lineal descendants of Thomas Williams, who assisted at the original tea party in Boston Harbor.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- It is stated that the Ministry just formed by M. Casimir-Perier has decided to accept an interpellation after it has made a declaration on Monday as to its programme. The Ministry is constituted as follows:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 2. -- The many wrecks on the Lehigh Valley have a tendency to keep the strikers firmly united. They are now convinced more than ever that the company cannot operate the Wyoming Division of its road with any degree of success with its non-union force of employes. The wreck at White Haven to-day will alone cost the company no less than $35,000, and has delayed all passenger traffic.

From The Savannah News, Nov. 29. Surgeon H.R. Carter of the Marine Hospital Service was in the city for a few hours yesterday morning, having come up from Jesup for a consultation with Dr. Brunner with regard to the quarantine and other topics. Dr. Carter thinks a good State Board of Health would be a good thing if it did not interfere with maritime quarantine regulations established by ports themselves and by the United States.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Nearly all of the students have now returned to college, with the exception of the victorious football team. Only two of them are back, Lea and Ward, who made the touchdown for Princeton. A mass meeting of the college was held to-day, and a committee of twelve was appointed by the President of the senior class to take entire charge of the football celebration Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Two striking features are presented by the official comparative statement of the receipts and expenditures of the United States issued by the Treasury Department yesterday. One shows that the receipts from customs have declined for the first five months of the current fiscal year as compared with the corresponding months of the last fiscal year $24,000,000, and for the same period payments on account of pensions have decreased $6,000,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2. -- The fight over the House Speakership among the Ohio Republicans has assumed a leading place in political interest here, and is of especial importance in its bearing on the Republican future. It is not so much who shall be Speaker as which wing of the Republican Party will dominate.

Till quite recently nothing was known of either Hobah or the Land of Ham, but the Tell Amarna letters mention both these regions. Letters addressed to Amenophis III., about 1480 B.C., by subject chiefs of the Southern Lebanon and of Bashan, occur in this correspondence, which describe the great Hittite invasion of Damascus about that time.

The City Club's Committee on Co-operation and Affiliated Clubs met last evening in the clubhouse to formulate a plan whereby there may be brought into being an organization whose object shall be the better government of the city.

It was at the box office of Abbey's Theatre about 6 o'clock the other evening, and a line of perhaps eight or ten men were waiting their turn at the opening, following a woman whose negotiations were being carried on as follows:

Charles J. Hayes, who since 1876 had been the press reporter of the House of Representatives, died yesterday at his residence, in Anacostia, in Washington. He was stricken with locomotor ataxia (a form of paralysis) during the prolonged debates in the Senate on the Silver bill, when he assisted his father, Henry G. Hayes, the veteran reporter of Senate and House proceedings, and never rallied from the shock.

Johnny Cunningham is fourteen years old, and not large for his age. He lives at 839 Tenth Avenue. In the same building is the Star Beef Company. An employe of that concern asked John to go to the cellar for him on some mission, and John went.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2 -- The Republican Party has a victory on its hands, but does not know what to do with It. The voters have imposed on it a patriotic task, but the party leaders find the emergency greater than the resources or their partisan ability.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Charles Kozminski, a well-known banker, dropped dead in the Republican Convention at 1:50 o'clock this afternoon. Mr. Kozminski made one of the speeches seconding the nomination of Mr. Swift for the Mayoralty. He had been ill at his house for several days, and said so in his speech.

Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- Mlle. Cerny has been borrowed by the Palais Royal for Mellhac's "Gigolettes." Isn't the name fascinating and sparkling, like champagne? The play is mousse, even less. Two pin points, nothing more, but amusing and Freuchy. Just such things as strangers ask for, and then -- don't understand, when they get there.

The Doll Sale in aid of the Virginia Memorial and Jewell Day Nurseries was opened yesterday afternoon at Sherry's. The affair is in the main due to the charitable instincts and untiring work of Mrs. Richard Irvin, who, however, has associated with her a corps of assistants as zealous as herself.

In beginning his lecture to the teachers at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday, Prof. Albert S. Bickmore presented a statement designed to show that this branch of the State education is very widely disseminated. When the system of illustrated lectures under the auspices of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction was begun, there were present twenty-five teachers and three officers of the Board of Education, Prof. Bickmore said.

From The Boston Transcript, Nov. 29. At the meeting of the Boston Scientific Society last evening, the principal paper was entitled "Six and Seven Day Periods in the Weather," the speaker being Mr. H. Helm Clayton of Blue Hill Observatory. Popular sayings have for a long time associated weather changes with a seven-day period, and evidence of some relationship of this nature has been noted for many years.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2. -- A mechanic's lien for $391.03, against the Rev. Frederick Kern, a Presbyterian minister, was filed in the County Clerk's office a few day's ago. The property against which the claim is made is a small, half-finished chapel at Springfield Avenue and Pierce Street.

The simple faith of the Norwegian peasants is that the seeing or not seeing of beings of the other world is a mere question of strong or weak nerves. Only, reversing the generally accepted belief, it is the Northman of strong nerves who has power to see the unseen. And he who sees it fears it not.

From The Medical Record, Dec. 2. The history of the discovery of anaesthesia in this country is a tragic one. Of the three Northern physicians who claimed the chief merit, Jackson died insane, Wells committed suicide, and Morton died as the result of a painful accident. As to the respective claims of these grentlemen, The Record has in times past expressed its views.

Dr. Paul Hoffman, Assistant Superintendent of Public Schools, who was struck by a car at Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street on the evening of Nov. 24, died at 2 o'clock yesterday morning in his apartments in the Alpine, Broadway and Thirty-third Street.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 2 -- It has been judicially determined that it is a good legal excuse for an employer to discharge his employe, who is under contract, if that individual, during working hours, attends a baseball game. This question was decided to-day by Judge Parmenter in the Municipal Civil Court, in the suit of Alphonso H. Hussy against Bowditch, Clapp Pierce, the wholesale milliners.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 2. -- Fire consumed $400,000 worth of property in West Baltimore to-night. It was one of the most destructive fires ever occurring in this city, and the loss of many lives was narrowly averted.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- In 1889 H.H. Warner, proprietor of "Warner's Safe Cure" and other proprietory medicines, started a company here, capitalizing it at a large sum. To-day the report of the Directors for the year ended in July last was submitted to the shareholders. The report states that the accounts for 1892 are inaccurate, and that Mr. Warner purposely misstated them in order to swell the apparent profits of the company.

Henry Cohn and Henry Metz both own crockery stores on Grand Street, near Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn. Cohn claims to be the only original Cohn, but Metz says he is a fraud, and his name should be spelled Cohen.

In other countries the functions of a bank are primarily to gather together the unemployed monetary resources of a community, and thus enable the community as a whole to undertake enterprises and conduct a volume of production and trade to which the scattered, efforts of its individual members would be unequal.

Mr. Irving's production of "The Merchant of Venice," which was on view all last week at Abbey's Theatre, drew so well after Monday, when everybody who ought to have gone to see Irving went instead to hear "Faust," that we shall probably have the London Lyceum Shylock and Portia with us again before the present engagement is finished, three weeks hence.

The holiday during the past week is regarded by many real estate men as having interfered somewhat with business. Usually a broken week shows a falling off. Under present conditions, which are, of course, not the best, such a circumstance adds to the general disinclination to trade. The past week has, therefore, not been marked by any large volume of transactions or by any special significance attending those which were made.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 28 -- It is a misfortune that Nassau is not better known to the people of the United States. Every Winter it becomes a question of no little importance to invalids and others who cannot comfortably endure the rigor of a Northern season, where the Winter shall be spent.

From The London Globe. Delhi at present rejoices in the possession of a remarkable fortune teller, whose exploits, according to a correspondent, are causing much excitement. "The native community here," he says, "is put into a ferment of excitement just now, owing to the wonderful and strange revelations made by a native 'Joshti,' or astrologer.

It has been officially announced from the office of the Adjutant General that all the talk and gossip about the disbandment of the Eighth Regiment is the veriest kind of nonsense. Nothing of the kind will be done, yet it is said that a suggestion has been whispered in the ear of the venerable Col. Scott that he follow the example set by Col. Cavanagh of the Sixty-ninth Regiment and retire.

What did the majority of the fashionable people in the Opera House on the second night of the opera talk most about? Was it Plancon's remarkably fine eyes, his beautiful phrasing, (which one morning paper said was bad,) or his muscular right arm? Was it Sigrid Arnoldson's pretty style of singing with her colorless voice?

The Brazilian submarine gun vessel Destroyer is under orders to sail at 3 P.M. to-day. Final instructions were issued yesterday to Capt. Guy M. Buck, the Destroyer's commander. The towing steamer Santuit yesterday completed taking on coal. All the cargo space of the Santuit was loaded with coal.

Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., arrived at the Hoffman House at 7:30 o'clock last evening from Troy. With him were Mrs. Murphy, their children, and Anthony N. Brady, the millionaire capitalist of Albany. The Senator dined with his family at a table adjoining that of Lieut. Gov. Sheehan. To a reporter for The Times Senator Murphy said:

For many years Americans have been enthusiastic collectors of old sporting prints of France and England, and particularly of England. Dealers in London give this as a reason why such prints have become so rare and now sell for high prices. Modern prints of the same character are also largely dealt in here.

In Mrs. Peary's delightful story, "My Arctic Journal," she tells, with the simple directness that characterizes this whole recital of courage and endurance, how the holidays were passed up there in the land of ice and Eskimaux, in the depth of the sunless and sinister arctic Winter.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Dec. 2 -- The triumph of solving the problem or practical submarine navigation must be accorded an Oshkosh inventor. His name is Richard Raddatz, and he is a student as well as a genius. His great work is not merely in the experimental stage. Definite, practical results have been obtained, and the vessel that is the embodiment of his ideas has been tested and proved.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 2. -- The old Aspen Short Line Railroad Company has consolidated with the Colorado Midland Railroad Company. Yesterday morning papers of incorporation were filed with the Secretary of State. At a meeting of stockholders held in Colorado Springs July 28 it was unanimously decided to do this.

From The San Francisco Chronicle. Another success scored by the Japanese in the province of industry is recorded in that country's press. It consists in the production of fine thread from nettle hemp. The patent is said to have been obtained by Itagaki Hokotaro, son of Count Itagaki, but the technical method was elaborated chiefly by Miyazaki Saburo of the Hokkaido Hemp Factory.

The large collection of works on architecture, presented to Columbia College by Mr. Samuel P. Avery, in memory of his son Henry, has been of great use to the flourishing class in architecture belonging to the School of Mines in that university. Mr. Avery is constantly adding to the volumes, but now he has placed in the library a relief, which will act as a perpetual memorial to the talented young architect.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 2 -- The cottagers have gone home to New-York this Fall leaving thousands of dollars of unpaid bills behind. Grocers, butchers, and provision dealers report that they are able to collect very little money from that class of people. They are, therefore, unable to meet their accounts, and the wholesale people are pressing them hard just at present.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Wheat had an easy market today. Just before the close a slight spurt carried the price up 3/8 of a cent. This mild excitement was the only feature of a dull hum-drum market. The opening was 1/8@1/4c lower, held about steady, and with the slight advance at the close, showed a gain at the end of 1/2c for May and the same for December.

From The Chicago Tribune, Nov. 29. "Speech is silver, but silence is golden," said George Francis Train at the Palmer House yesterday," and I am going to relapse into silence again. For fourteen years I refused to speak to a man or woman, and I am going back to New-York on a scalper's ticket next week, and in Madison Square resume my old occupation of silence.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 2 -- Gov. Waite is experiencing the difficulties that lie in the path of a reform statesman. Prior to his special session of the Legislature, which he proposes to call sometime in January, he has in hand a convention of miners, which is to pass resolutions urging a special session of the Legislature to protect the silver-mining industries.

There was an increase of $5,261,725 in the average surplus reserve of the banks last week, bringing it up to $76,096,000 and the total reserve to $197,933,200. The deposits are now $487,345,200, which is in round numbers, $33,000,000 more than a year ago and $48,000,00 more than in 1891.

Mrs. Margaret O'Grady, a widow thirty-seven years old, lives with her six children on the fourth floor of the tenement house at 154 First Avenue. On the floor below lives Joseph Hunter, a cook, thirty-nine years old, who has the reputation of being quarrelsome.

Among all the means afforded by geology for direct estimates of the earth's duration, doubtless the most reliable is through comparing the present measured rate of denudation of continental areas with the aggregate of the greatest determined thickness of the strata referable to the successive time divisions.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 2. -- Admiral Stanton is at his home in this city, but is daily expecting an order to go to Washington. He is, of course, particularly interested in the situation in Brazil, and since his return has closely followed the newspaper reports of the progress of the rebellion.
Copyright, John La Farge, 1893. The fourth lecture on art, in the series by Mr. John La Farge at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was delivered yesterday. Mr. La Farge said:

A brilliant and not unsuccessful news-paper proprietor once remarked to me, apropos of his staff: " I do not care for men of broad views, sound common sense, and correct principles. Give me a clever, disappointed man, of morbid mind, who wants to get his knife' into as many of his fellow-creatures as possible.

The judgments of the General Term of the Supreme Conn; in the two important Brooklyn cases, which we published yesterday morning, are of extreme interest and value to the city, and, for that matter, to all cities. One related to the purchase of the Long Island Water Company's franchise and the other to a franchise given away by the Aldermen for a railroad on Union Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The following is an official list of dates of receptions, , at the Executive Mansion during the season of 1894:

King Khama is a model savage, if a black man who has been thoroughly civilized by European and missionary influences can still be called one. He is an autocrat of the best possible type, whose influence in his country is entirely thrown into the scale of virtue for the suppression of vice. Such a thing as theft is unknown in his realm; he will not allow his subjects to make or drink beer.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Never in our national history has the way looked so dark for the very poor and the industrial classes generally as to-day.
"The life of a village physician has its trials," said one a few days ago, "and I may add," with a twinkle of the eye at some recollection, "its compensations, too.

George Alfred Townsend has been trying to find out for The Commercial Advertiser who overthrew the Brooklyn ring. He questioned Albert Daggett among others, and asked if The Broklyn Eagle had not borne an important part in the defeat of the Democratic ticket.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Dec. 2. -- There appears to have been method in the madness of Mrs. Annie Cox of East Williamsburg. She is locked up in the village hall here, awaiting transportation to the Poughkeepsie Insane Asylum, from which she has escaped three times within a year or so. Her last escape from that institution was on Sept. 11.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- A superstitions matador entering the bull pit with a fixed presentment that he will never get out alive would afford a fair working parallel for the manner in which Casimir-Perier advanced to assume the Premiership of the republic. No man ever fought more resolutely to escape a deadly peril than he, during a whole week, to avert that fateful honor.

That pretty fete known as a lullaby concert was recently carried out with unusual success. Beginning with the American little mother in her frock of stars and stripes, who crooned her small baby to slumber with the old, yet always new.

The Kings County Grand Jury for the November term filed two presentments in the Court of Sessions yesterday. The jury said that it had found that the railroad companies were endeavoring to provide, as speedily as possible, safety appliances for their ears.

The first of the free Sunday night lectures to be held in the hall of the Neighborhood Guild of the University Settlement Society, at 26 Delancey Street, will be given this evening, beginning at 8 o'clock. The lecturer will be Abraham Cahan, and he will take for his subject "Darwinism and Socialism."

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The Bordeaux Society of Political Economy yesterday decided, owing to the disastrous tariff war between France and the United States, to ask the French Government to open negotiations with the American Government with a view to concluding a treaty of commerce between the two countries.

Leonard Moody, a pronounced Republican and a member of the Committee of One Hundred, in speaking to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, said Mayor-elect Schieren had offered the City Works Commissionership to Alfred Treadway White, and Mr. White had accepted.

There was a blockade on the Sixth Avenue elevated from 2 until 4:30 yesterday afternoon, and thousands of angry passengers, in a hurry to reach their destinations, crowded each other on the platforms on both sides of the tracks.
Of Ada Rehan's acting' in the "School for Scandal," Labouchere's Truth says:

At a meeting of the Directors of the City Chess Club, held yesterday, it was decided to arrange for a little international tournament, for which Albin, Delmar, Hanham, Hedges, Halpern, Showalter, Tau benhaus, and another have entered. The City Chess Club has offered three substantial prizes, and the above-named experts have declared their willingness to commence play on Saturday.
A letter has been written, to The New-York Times calling attention to this destitute condition of the family of Joseph McArthur, who lives at 115 West Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

From The London Daily News. Nothing could be more correct or gentlemanly than the behavior of the Corsican brigand Barthelemy Durill in surrendering himself, as he has recently done, to the offended justice of his country. Writing from Plana to the Commandant of the district, he said:

The annual meeting of Lafayette Post, No. 1,409, G.A.R., held in Masonic Hall, was very largely attended, and the following officers and delegates were elected: Commander -- William A. Copp; Senior Vice Commander -- Henry H. Adams; Junior Vice Commanders -- Waldo Sprague; Quartermaster -- Frederick Foster; Surgeon -- James L. Beyea; Chaplain -- Anson B. Hoyt; Officer of the Day -- Josiah C. Long, Jr.; Officer of the Guard -- Gilbert N. Knight.
ST. THOMAS, West Indies, Dec. 2. -- The Brazilian cruiser America arrived in this port last night. All on board are well. The trip from New-York was without especial incident.

Those who have watched the antics and byplay of the little pickaninnies in the drama "In Old Kentucky" at the Academy of Music may have wondered what kind of a game the two little darkles to the left of the stage were so industriously engaged in that not even the excitement of "buck" dancing could distract their attention.
COLUMBUS, Dec. 2. -- The Ohio wool raisers are to be appealed to for statistics to fight the Wilson Tariff bill. The questions already sent but by Congressman J.C. Burrows are as follows:
Heine tried to kill with raillery monsters more dangerous than Pytho.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Republicans and Democrats to-day nominated candidates for Mayor to succeed Acting Mayor George Brainard Swift, who was elected by the Common Council to fill the office in the interim between the death of Carter H. Harrison and the special election which takes place Dec. 19.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Dec. 2 -- Now that Jerry Rusk has gone, a great many stories are being told which nicely illustrate the qualities which made him great. While a member of the Wisconsin Legislature he never made but one speech. He had introduced a bill leaving a blank for the name of the place of abode for the corporation created by the bill.

STEHEKIN, Washington, Dec. 2. -- The other day my comrade and I broke camp on Thunder Creek, where we had wasted a week in attempting to trace most attractive mineral-bearing float to the lead from which it came. We were out of food and could not find the mineral-bearing lead.
BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The Globe's yachting correspondent, writing from Glasgow under date of Nov. 18, gives some of Mr. George L. Watson's ideas concerning the Vigilant Valkyrie races. He says:

A thief broke into the hardware store of S.O. Burnett, 288 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, Friday night, and stole $70,000 in bonds, mortgages, certificates, In addition, he took $20 in cash and a watch valued at $50.
"That's what does a man's heart good to see. She's ready for a pull around the world, if we liked. Just look at her; isn't she a beauty ?"

The midweek service at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, is held in the schoolroom adjoining the church. During one of these services recently there was a fair attendance of worshippers.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Clarence Murphy, receiving teller of the Salem Savings Bank, disappeared to-day. For some time the Directors of the bank have suspected that Mr. Murphy's accounts were somewhat irregular. Murphy was questioned by the bank officials this morning relative to entries on the books.

One of the handsomest punch bowls ever made in this city, if, indeed, it may not be called the handsomest, has just been finished by Tiffany Co. for the New-York Society of Colonial Wars. It is a typical historical punch bowl, and is as thoroughly emblematic of early colonial days as it was possible to make it.

A trial of the apparatus invented by J. Woodbridge Davis to establish communication from ship to ship or from ship to shore, over long distances, by means, of a large kite apparatus, was had off Sandy Hook yesterday. The kite and method of manipulation have been described in The New-York Times.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

When Mayor Boody of Brooklyn was asked yesterday what he proposed to do about the charges against the Excise Board made by the John Kress Brewing Company that $900 had been paid for three one-hundred-dollar licenses, he said:

Miss Adele Grant, the American belle who is soon, to become Countess of Essex, will be mistress of one of the most superb and noted of English country seats. Cassiobury, the estate of the Earl of Essex, with its hundred acres, is near the busy market town of Watford, not far from London. The house is a stately castle in Gothic style, full of historic and architectural interest.

A friend of mine, an ardent admirer of Thackeray, once told me of a journey from Cambridge to London which he took in the Pendennis era in company with a rather younger academic, who had been revisiting his Cambridge chums after a first year of town life. The two men had ensconced themselves in a first-class carriage, when Thackeray entered it.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 2. -- A meeting of citizens was held in the Town Hall last night to nominate Commissioners for the election on Dec. 12, and, incidentally, to talk over municipal matters in general. Ex-Mayor Helsley said the time had arrived when it was necessary that the town's affairs should be directed by business men who would perform their duty faithfully and impartially.
They call "Hannele," by Gerhardt Hauptmann, a play in Berlin. The scene is a poorhouse. An English newspaper correspondent notes its "uncanny realism."

The broadsword tournament very nearly terminated in a riot at the Madison Square Garden last night. How trouble was averted it is hard to say. Chevalier Greco of Italy and Duncan C. Ross of America met in the ring. P.J. Donohue acted as referee of the bout. W.A. Brady, the manager of James J. Corbett, was master of ceremonies.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- Congressman Harter said to-day: "I think the Wilson bill will pass the House promptly and with few changes. Of course ample time will be given its opponents, as a matter of justice to them, and also because their speeches in opposition are likely to convince the public that the bill ought to become a law.

The sixty-second anniversary of the founding of the New-York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society will be celebrated this evening in the Church of the Holy Trinity, at Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street. The exercises to-night will be the first portion of the anniversary celebration programme which the society prepares each year.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2. -- The thirteenth annual football game between Yale and Harvard freshmen was played this afternoon at Yale Field, in the presence of 2,500 spectators. Yale was again victorious over Harvard, by the score of 30 to 4. The weather was exceptionally fine for this time of the year.

There was a marked increase in the number of deaths reported during the week ending at noon yesterday, as compared with the number reported during the preceding week. During the week ending on Nov. 25, the deaths reported numbered 676, while for last week the number reported was 759, an increase of 83.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $7,536,493, of which amount $1,120,602 was in dry goods, and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $665,227, and the exports of specie were $871,144.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 2. -- The copartnership between Rose Coghlan and Charles Coghlan ceased to-day. Charles Coghlan has not been well this week. He has been suffering from a severe cold, which, the doctor was afraid, might turn into peritonitis. Regarding the separation Mr. Coghlan said:

I know a busy leader of society in a large city, says a writer in The Cincinnati Gazette, who has the finest working plan of conducting her children's reading of any mother I know. The children attend a private school in the morning, and romp and play to their hearts' content after that until 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The regular session of the Fifty-third Congress, which opens on Monday next at noon, will probably become historical by its legislation. There will be no preliminary work to delay business, no Speaker to choose, no committees to appoint. For the first time since 1860 the House can resume the consideration of unfinished business immediately on meeting.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- I do not think that the famous play of Dumas fils, now given at the Odeon Theatre, has ever been translated -- in point of fact, I almost fear that the American stage knows of little more than the Camille from this author -- but the celebrated comedy is familiar to all library shelves and quite companionable to every reader of dramatic literature, and their name is legion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The next thing to engage the attention of the gay world when the various fashionable bazaars and fairs for charity have been disposed of and Christmas is over will be the launching of the season's debutantes. This year there are comparatively few, and, though there is no lack of good looks and charming qualifications for success generally, there is not one wealthy heiress among the number.

Mr. David Douglas, to whom we became deeply indebted a few years ago for a complete publication of Scott's Journal, has now increased our debt by making this selection from Scott's unpublished letters. For the most part the original letters belong to the Abbotsford collection. The present volume, indeed, were undertaken at the special request of the Hon. Mrs. Maxwell Scott, the great-granddaughter of Sir Walter, through the Lockhart line.

Without being luxurious, the whole globe has played him serving man to spread his table. Russia gave the hemp, or India or South Carolina the cotton, for that cloth which his wife lays upon it. The Eastern Islands placed there those condiments and spices which were once the secret relishes of the wealthy.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 8 -- One political contest is no sooner out of the way in Iowa than another opens up. The new fight this time is for the seat in the United States Senate new held by James F. Wilson. It will be a notable contest. The Republicans have 79 out of 100 members of the lower house of the Legislature, and 33 of the 50 Senators.

A steam yacht, built to be the finest afloat, and in size, beauty, and speed apparently meeting the contract, came into New-York Harbor early yesterday morning. She was the Columbia, just completed by the Cramps, at Philadelphia, for Mr. J.W. Ladew, the wealthy New-York leather merchant.

-- A Philadelphia reports that a family living near the Falls of Schuylkill were aroused the other night by a tremendous clatter on the roof. The head of the house rushed to a window, and was about to give an alarm to the police in apprehension of burglars when two immense cranes, with, loud flappings of wings, passed over his head and disappeared down the river.

From Harper's Weekly. The oddest, sincerest, intersest religious enterprise of the present day is the Salvation Army. The key to it is its purpose -- just to save men; nothing else. It does not want to do anything more, and attempts nothing else -- no schools, no education, no religious training, nothing but to get men into the kingdom of God.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A member of the Diplomatic Corps, who possesses an intimate acquaintance with Brazil and Brazilians, to-day gave an interesting picture of the situation in that republic as viewed by him. He said:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The Congregational Tabernacle was mainly filled this evening by members of the Junior Order of American Mechanics, who gathered to hear the Rev. John L. Scudder preach on "The Roman Catholic Church as a Menace to American Institutions and the Public School System."

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3 -- Residents of several Upper Westchester County towns within a few miles of the new reservoir being built for the City of New-York, near Purdy's Station, on the Harlem Railroad, are looking for protection from a band of marauders. The thieves have caused trouble by unceremoniously forcing their way into several luxurious homes and abstracting whatever came within their reach.

A Sanitary Inspector discovered yesterday that Teresa, the young wife of Matthew Tressanti, an Italian who contracts to supply railroad laborers, had died of smallpox on the top floor of 72 Oliver Street, and that she had been ill since Monday last, and had exposed many to contagion.

It seems curious that, while complaints should so frequently be raised in Paris respecting the quality of much of the wine that is sold here, many critics going so far as to assert that it contains very little of the juice of the grape, the proprietors of vineyards in many departments throughout the country should be indulging in loud lamentations over the fact that they are unable to find purchasers for their produce.
The following correspondence was made public yesterday by Mr. J.J. Van Alen:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1@1 1/2 per cent., the average being less than 1 1/2 per cent.
The annual business meeting of the New-York State Trotting Horse Breeders Association will be held at Powers's Hotel, Rochester, N.Y., on Tuesday, Dec, 5. The session will commence at 10:30 A.M.

Dr. F.A. Cook of Brooklyn, the ethnologist who accompanied Lieut. Peary to Greenland in 1891-2, is preparing to explore the antarctic continent, or archipelago, next Fall. He says he will start about Sept. 1, but the months of exploration will be December, January, February, and March.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 2 -- The American Protective Association, the anti-Catholic society, exhibited such power in the recent elections in this city and State that steps have been taken to counteract its Influences. A new society called the Society of Liberty and Loyalty has been recently organized, and within three weeks has gained over 3,000 members in this city alone, while in the State there are now at least 10,000 members.

The officers of the cruiser New-York are incensed over a reported disagreement between them and the officers of the Seventh Regiment, which was alleged to have occurred Wednesday, on the occasion of the visit of the military men to their naval friends. The entire regiment was invited, and there were 2,000 men and women on board the ship that day.

The twentieth anniversary of the founding of the Reformed Episcopal Church was commemorated last evening in the First Reformed Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. The Rev. Dr. William T. Sabine, the pastor, presided. Addresses were made by the Rev. George W. Huntington of the Church of the Reconciliation, Brooklyn; the Rev. George Savary of Newark, and Thomas R. Shear, Vestryman of the First Reformed Church.

A life of Bishop Brooks will presently be published, but in the meantime those who have admired and loved him will be glad of the glimpses of him given through these letters of travel relating to two journeys, each of more than a year, and to shorter Summer trips. The letters were written chiefly to members of his family, at very close intervals, and he frequently speaks of his "weekly letter" as an established thing.
The Rev. Dr. James M. Farrar of the First Reformed Church, Seventh Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, preached a sermon last evening on "The Athlete."

"The night is far spent, the day is at hand," was the subject of a homily read at the morning service in a little church in West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday. It was not so different from many of the Advent Sunday texts from which sermons were preached, but to the members of the Catholic Apostolic Church it was deeply significant.

The man on the top of the Equitable Building who is credited with saying funny things about the weather said last night that there had been fog hereabout. Those who looked at the swirling masses of vapor which hid objects a hundred feet away had no doubt that the meteorological observation was correct.

Miss Violet Seabrook of 46 West Sixty-sixth Street had an adventure with footpads Saturday night in "West Sixteenth Street. Miss Seabrook is about seventeen years old. She is studying stenography in a business college in Sixteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- When the hour of noon arrives to-morrow and the familiar thump of the gavel is heard in each house of Congress few Senators and Representatives will be out of their seats. In the last three days the incoming trains have brought more than a quorum of each body. It is the fashion at some of the hotels to prefix the magic "Hon" to the name of every Congressman who registers.
The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn has Indorsed the plan of the Brooklyn Democratic Club for a reorganization of the party upon the election district system.
$100 REWARD AND NO QUESTIONS ASKED for the return, of small white poodle, answering to name of "Baby"; lost Saturday, Nov. 25. Apply office Hotel Bartholdi.

The German steamship Salerno, which yesterday arrived from Brazilian ports, brought no additional information concerning the state of affairs in that country. Capt. Schamberg says that when his vessel arrived off Rio on Oct. 28, one of the forts which guards the entrance to the harbor signaled a warning for him not to attempt an entrance.

We give in another column an abstract of the report of the Controller of the Currency, the Hon. JAMES H. ECKELS. It is a very straightforward, businesslike document. Mr. ECKELS gives a review of the peculiar situation during the past six months and its effects upon the national banks and describes the policy he adopted with reference to those that were compelled to suspend.

The annual memorial service of Brooklyn Lodge, No. 22, Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, was held in the Aurora Grata Cathedral, Bedford Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

The friends of the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton were inclined yesterday to abandon their efforts to get him back into the pulpit of the West Presbyterian Church when they read an interview telegraphed from Bridgeville, Penn., in which Dr. Paxton declared most positively that he would not return to this old charge under any circumstances.

-- Those who figure that the bicycle can beat a horse or horses over a distance of ground will have an opportunity to see their theory put to a practical test on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. Two horses going 12 1/2 miles each and changing every mile will be pitted against Charles Ashinger on the bicycle. Ashinger is a hard and tireless rider and will go the twenty-five miles at top speed.

The true history of Scheele's life is to be found in his works. "What we call a genius," said Pope, "is hard to be distinguished by a man himself from a strong inclination." Scheele himself would have been the first to admit that his strongest inclination was to experiment, and the rest of the world has said that herein lay His genius.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 2 -- The local stock market for the week shows a continuation of the improved feeling exhibited last week. While the quoted list of bank stocks shows few changes, still a number of sales have been made on the Street at prices close to the asking figures, and investors are showing a feeling of renewed confidence.

In the wide range of historic personages, Henry IV. of France stands pre-eminent for the great human interest with which his life is filled. His story has been told by many, and from many points of view, but the subject Is not yet threadbare, nor will it ever be. His life is a marvelously entertaining theme, and whatever well-equipped writer undertakes its portraiture may reasonably expect attention.
-- Congressman Holman of Indiana has succeeded to the title of Father of the House, and no one has heard him object.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The London Anarchists tried to hold a meeting in Trafalgar Square to-day, despite the refusal of the Home Secretary to grant them permission. A large force of mounted and unmounted police was present to disperse them. At 3 o'clock a few of the Anarchist leaders gathered at the pedestal of the Nelson Column to confer as to the programme.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The annual report of James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, which will be submitted directly to Congress to-morrow, differs from former reports in that no tables appear in the body of the text. It shows that 3,796 national banks were in operation at the close of the report year, with a capital stock of $695,558,120, represented by 7,450.000 shares, held by 300,000 shareholders.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- I gave proper Introduction to the "oeuvre" on the occasion of the first representation of Ibsen's "Rosmershoim." M. Lugne-Poe, the former associate and disciple of the Theatre Libre, continues his management with masterly skill.
Both Senators from New-York were in this city yesterday for a time, and both went to Washington, taking different trains, however. It is doubtful if they were in a perfectly peaceful frame of mind.

The plan of supporting the Actors' Fund by a tax of 10 cents on each complimentary ticket issued by a theatre, which was originated by Louis Aldrich and first adopted by Manager A.M. Palmer, President of the fund, is meeting with liberal support in other cities. The system has been in operation in this city at Palmer's for several months, and has now been extended to the Garden Theatre, since Mr. Palmer assumed control.

President Low has announced a new course of lectures, to be given i co-operation with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, on Saturday mornings at 11 o'clock. The first course will be in "Oriental Seals and Glyptic Art," and will be delivered by the Rev. William Hayes Ward. The first lecture was delivered last Saturday, the subject being "Origin in Primitive Babylon."

From The London Spectator. Why on earth should a French colonist, whose fathers accepted British rule forty years before Trafalgar, want to blow up a statue of Nelson because eighty-eight years ago he, an Englishman, defeated Frenchmen on the sea? The attack on Nelson's morals is, as an explanation, mere nonsense.

From Nature. The construction of a good and simple universal mounting for small telescopes has been the aim of many instrument makers, and it is pleasing to note an advance in this direction made by the firm of K. Fritsch, formerly Prokesch, in Vienna. In their new so-called "universal static" they have overcome many of the main difficulties.

From The Boston Commonwealth. Astronomical photography has become of great importance within a few years through the labors of nearly a score of active workers in this field. While the value of photography has been overestimated, in all probability, in some departments of astronomical work, and especially in the determination of stellar magnitudes, there seems to be a fruitful field for its work, in the accurate mapping of meteor trails.

The New-York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society observed last evening in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, the sixty-second anniversary of its foundation aid the sixtieth anniversary of its incorporation. There was a large atteadance at the exercises.

Prof. Felix Adler spoke in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning on the idea of God and futurity as taught in the Old Testament. The usual large audience heard him, and applauded when he had finished his address.

There opens to the public to-day, in Koster Bial's old music hall, 115 West Twenty-third Street, an exceedingly interesting exhibition of genuine instruments of torture used some few centuries ago, before more humane methods superseded the rack and thumb screw and other horrible implements with which the Church and Crown were wont to argue and remonstrate with Christians and enemies.

Stephen Lovejoy, who was found dead last Friday in the cellar of his house, 2,013 Madison Avenue, was one of the bestknown members of the Real Estate Exchange. He was sixty years old, and lived with his widowed sister, Mrs. Mary Johnson.

No fair-minded man can read the correspondence between President CLEVELAND and Mr. VAN ALEN, printed this morning, without a feeling of regret that Mr. VAN ALEN considered it his duty to the Democratic Party and the Administration to decline the post of Ambassador to Italy.

From The Baltimore Sun, Nov. 30. Wild duck shooters are uneasy just now because red-head ducks have suffered a marked diminution by flight in the past few days, notwithstanding the fact that more ducks visited Maryland this season than at any other time in the last twenty years. Sportsmen say the late cold snap has driven the birds southward, and the large number received from that quarter confirms their opinion.

From the Boston Traveller. The offer of President George T. Angell of the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is bearing fruit. He has already received three designs in response to an offer of a prize of $30 for the "best outline cut of the devil teaching school boys and girls to dissect cats."

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- George B. Swift, the Republican nominee for Mayor, was born in Cincinnati in 1845. His father, a house and sign painter, moved from there to Galena, Ill., when George was eighteen months old. When fifteen years old his family moved to Chicago. Here he attended the Skinner School, and subsequently the Chicago Univtrsity for one term.

William Waldorf Astor has been sued for libel by William A. Wolff of London on account of certain statements published in The Pall Mall Gazette, of which Mr. Astor is proprietor. Recently The Pall Mall Gazette made a bitter attack upon the scheme and methods of the Mobile and Dauphin Island Railroad.

Edward Martin, millionaire and philanthropist, who was one of the pioneers in the railroad building and development of the great West, died at the Martin homestead in Red Hook yesterday of heart disease. For many years he had lived in comparative retirement. His fortune, which consists almost entirely of real estate in Chicago and the State of Illinois, purchased in the earliest days of Chicago, is estimated at several millions.
"The Hawaiian Situatoion" is the subject of a symposium in the December number of The North American Review, which appears to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Many New-Jersey school teachers are actively engaged in agitating a repeal of the anti-rod law passed by the last session of the Legislature, which prevents public instructors using the ruler or the rattan to correct unruly pupils.

A recent reference in The New-York lines to the Indians now in New-York State and to the Iroquois recalls something of the interesting history of that wonderful confederation, which was, In reallty, a republic in every respect, and probably the first republic, in the broad sense of the word, that ever found a footold upon, the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The seventh annual report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission claims that, although all expectations have not been fully realized the operation and administration of the statute have brought about reforms in transportation which, compared with the evils that existed prior to the law, amount to commercial emancipation.

For weeks before the Wilson bill was given to the public the high-tariff newspapers were predicting that the sugar duties would be arranged for the benefit of the Sugar Trust. Their readers were told that the officers of the Trust were on terms of intimacy with the Democratic National Committee and the Democratic majority of the Ways and Means Committee, and that a bargain had been made.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 3 -- A heavy snowstorm this morning brought all traffic on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, especially the Wyoming Division, almost to a standstill. A few passenger trains arrived and departed from here to-day, but they were from three to seven hours late. No attempt was made to move coal or freight trains from Coxton, Sugar Notch, or here up to six o'clock to-night.

There was held last night in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, a memorial service by the Evangelical Alliance of the United States, in honor of the late Dr. Philip Schaff, LL. D.

MICHIGAN CITY, Dec. 3 -- The big steamer F.W. Wheeler, bound from Buffalo for Chicago, went ashore at 3:30 o'clock this morning three miles east of Michigan City Harbor in a high sea and a blinding snowstorm. Capt. George N. Trotter, the master of the steamer, was misled by his compass and supposed that he was entering Waukegan, when his boat grounded half a mile from shore.

One of Father McGlynn's old assistants in St. Stephen's Church, the Rev. Father Bechger has renounced the Roman Catholic Church and embraced Protestantism. Father Bechger was stationed at St. Stephen's in 1884. Recently, while in Europe, he gave up the faith in which he had been trained for the Church, and gave up the priesthood, against the bitter opposition of his only living relative, a sister, who is the Mother Superior of a foreign convent.

One of Father McGlynn's old assistants in St. Stephen's Church, the Rev. Father Bechger has renounced the Roman Catholic Church and embraced Protestantism. Father Bechger was stationed at St. Stephen's in 1884. Recently, while in Europe, he gave up the faith in which he had been trained for the Church, and gave up the priesthood, against the bitter opposition of his only living relative, a sister, who is the Mother Superior of a foreign convent.

The Autumn exhibition of the National Academy of Design will have no special day for the press, but opens this morning without further ceremony. To-morrow the painters will be given an opportunity to varnish their pictures. More than 1,000 paintings were sent in, but the word this year is "high standard," so the jury has rejected 700.
The worshippers in St. Augustine's Episcopal Church, on Canton Street, Brooklyn, were treated yesterday morning to a novelty in vested choirs such as has never before been known in this country.

The representation of words by signs and characters, called by most instructors and beginners "the art of stenography," or simply shorthand writing, as those of long experience in the practice are content to regard it, is something full of mystery to those uninitiated in its principles. Submit a papyrus of Chaldean characters and a page of shorthand notes to the average person, and it is doubtful if he could decide which looked the more unintelligible.

The Monday lecture for to-day before the academic department will be delivered by Prof. George Woolsey of the Faculty of Medicine, who will speak on "The Ethics of Health." Prof. Woolsey is a son of ex-President Woolsey of Yale University.

Father McMillion of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, at Sixtieth Street and Ninth Avenue, is receiving many congratulations from his friends on the presence of mind he displayed when Michael O'Brlen, an insane man, visited his church last Friday. O'Brien attracted no attention when he first entered the church, but soon began to exhibit signs of religious frenzy.

Mr. Whymper, the mountain climber of two hemispheres, has prepared a new edition of his "Scrambles Amongst the Alps in the Years 1860-69." It will contain a complete list of the men who have climbed the Matterhorn. This is the fourth edition of his work, and Zahnsdorff will bind all the copies.
ROME, Dec. 3 -- A Cabinet selected from members of the Left has been almost completed. The list reported this evening is:

From London Nature. Messrs. Fletcher, Russell Co., the wellknown makers of gas appliances, have just introduce a new process to supersede the use of Berlin black and black-lead for protecting the cast-iron portions of their manufacture. The Casting is coated with a film of enamel, which is so thin that even the finest details of the metal are preserved.

MERMOSILLO, Mexico, Dec. 3 -- A courier arrived here to-day from Casinipi, a small settlement northwest of here, in the Sierra Madre Mountains, with information that the Yaqul Indians were congregating in bands of several hundred near that place and preparing to join the Mexican revolutionists, who had their rendezvous in the mountains over the border line, in the State of Chihuahua.

The determination of some of the Roman Catholic clergy of Maryland to ask for State aid for parochial schools called forth a sermon yesterday from the Rev. Madison C. Peters of the Bloomingdale Church, at the Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street, in which the parochial school system was bitterly denounced.

The funeral services over the remains of Dr. Paul Hoffman, Assistant Superintendent of Public Schools, were held at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Second Avenue and Tenth Street. The church was crowded to the doors with teachers, school children, Principals, School Trustees, and Commissioners, and other friends of the dead man.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 4. -- The sensational statements accredited to Dr. John R. Paxton of New-York by a Pittsburg Sunday paper, and copied by this morning's papers, are absolutely without foundation, if the word of Dr. Paxton's nephew, Mr. Pressley, is to be accepted as truth. A reporter visited the Pressley residence, at Bridgevllle, to-day, and requested an interview with Dr. Paxton.

The Committee on Education had charge of the programme at Sorosis yesterday, and under the direction of Mrs. Charlotte Jenkins, the Chairman, some of the lessons taught by the Columbian Fair were emphasized.

The Wilson bill is attacked by the Republican press and by two or three so-called Democratic journals that are McKinley protectionists in disguise because it does not provide for the collection of as much revenue as the Government needs. A tariff for revenue rather than for protection, they say, should yield as much revenue as the Government requires.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 4. -- This was the opening day of the Woodard and Shanklin sale or thoroughbreds, and sixty-five head were sold for a total of $29,255, an average of $450 per head. The biggest price of the day was paid for La Rosa, by Tremont, she being knocked down to Charles Hughes, Chicago, at $3,550, while the next largest price was paid by Ed Corrigan for Irish Chief, he bringing $2,375.

Mrs. Florence R. Logan yesterday began a suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, for a divorce from her husband, Joseph Logan, of 269 Forty-seventh Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Logan alleges her husband ill-treated her and neglected to support her properly, and also accused her of killing her father.

A stout and good-looking German appeared at Second Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street last night in an exhausted condition. A chair was given to him by a storekeeper, but before anything further could be done for him he died. He was about 5 feet 8 inches in height, and had a light complexion, dark-brown hair, a mustache, a small goatee, and blue eyes.

The Sinking Fund Commissioners at their meeting yesterday in the Mayor's office set apart the old schoolhouse at 66 and 68 Elm Street for temporary quarters fort Fire Engine Company No. 31, whose old house was recently sold. It was also decided to continue the lease of the building at 31 Chambers Street for the offices of the Department of Public Works for two years at the present rental of $12,000 a year.

When Bishop William Taylor sails for Africa on the steamer Majestic to-morrow he will be accompanied by his niece, Miss Jennie Taylor. Bishop Taylor has charge of the Methodist Episcopal missions in Africa, and this, his fifth visitation to that distant mission field, will last two years and a half.

In their efforts to protect the interests of the General Government. Treasury officials frequently construe rules and regulations so that they result in great personal hardship and injustice to officers concerned. A case in point has recently occurred in one of our squadrons in foreign waters, where an officer was put ashore by the recommendation of the surgeons of the ship, to prevent the spread of a contagious disease.
W. Wetmore Cryder, the ex-President of the Madison Square Bank, against whom the Grand Jury found an indictment on Monday of last week, surrendered himself yesterday and furnished bail.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 4. -- A reception was given to-night at the Naval Academy to the victorious football eleven. After supper the battalion of cadets marched in the form of a hollow square, with the eleven in the centre, down to the boathouse. There the walls were covered with various mottoes laudatory of the naval eleven and at the expense of West Point.
ROME, Dec. 4. -- The Cabinet partially formed by Signor Zanardelli as it now stands is made up as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- American torpedo nets have been under competitive trial at Newport, and a report of the test, so far as it has gone, has been sent to the Navy Department. There were four nets, three of domestic manufacture and one of foreign make. Only two of the former had been fired upon by the submarine gun of the Destroyer when that craft was removed by its owners and the trial interrupted.

In the Supreme Court yesterday Judge Barrett made known his decisions in four elevated railroad cases, tried by him last month. Patrick Connor was awarded $1,500 fee damages and $360 rental damages to the property at 621 Ninth Avenue. Frank S. Alien, owner of 89 Houston Street, obtained judgment of $6,000 fee damages and $400 a year rental damage.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4. -- A number of unusual complications render the annual town and city election of New-Haven this year of especial interest. It will take place to-morrow, and some surprises are looked for. Peculiar Influences nave been acting on both the leading parties for the past month, all of which tend to weaken them and make the outcome of the contest at the polls uncertain.

In the Trinity Building salesroom, at 111 Broadway, yesterday, Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly sold; under foreclosure, for $7,500, to Eveline D. Leggett, the plaintiff in the action, the three-story brick dwelling, 422 East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, south side, 250 feet east of First Avenue, 25 by 100.10.

Lenox Lyceum will be the scene to-morrow night of the opening boat club reception of the season, when the Dauntless Bowing Club will grace the occasion with its fourteenth annual reception. The Lyceum will be tastefully decorated with flags, bunting, and potted plants, and there is every reason to believe that the reception will prove to be a most successful affair.

A Notable Forthcoming Wedding in Baltimore. -- Miss Frances Ewing of Bloomington, Ill., daughter of James S. Ewing, United States Minister to Brussels, will be married to Bayliss B. Beecher, a cotton merchant of Memphis. Tenn., in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Baltimore, on Saturday, Dec. 23. at 12 o'clock. Miss Ewing is now in Europe, bat will sail from Antwerp for New-York on Dec. 7.

There was a great deal of suppressed exeitement among the minor officials at Police Headquarters yesterday over a lone conference between Commissioners Martin. McClave, and Sheehan and Superintendent Byrnes. It is not believed that Commissioner McLean was invited to be present at the conference; at any rate he was not present, nor did he appear at the Police Headquarters building while it was going on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Flowers played an important part in the Senate Chamber today. But for these lavish displays, the people who thronged the galleries to witness the scene incident to the beginning of the regular session would undoubtedly have been bored.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- Moorestown once again has the honors for pigeon flying for four distances and average speed, 1,353 yards; also the credit for the best journey, from 540 miles, this year. Moorestown was sent from home last Tuesday, arrived in Easley, S.C., on Wednesday, was liberated at 8 o'clock Thursday morning, and was in the home loft at 2:65 o'clock Friday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- A few more cuts in freight rates were announced to-day by the Chicago and Erie Road. The rate on starch was reduced to 20 cents per 100 pounds, tankage was reduced to the same figure, and the rate on green sheep pelts was reduced to 22 1/2 cents to bring it into conformity with the rate previously made on hides.

The trial of Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer, which promises to be one of the greatest murder cases in the history of criminal jurisprudence, was begun yesterday before Judge Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

There seems to be no doubt that the Emperor of Germany, in his desire to acquire the fastest yacht in the world, has his imperial eye upon the Vigilant. It is questionable whether he has gone to work in the right way to attain his object. Yacht-building is a very progressive art, and the fastest yacht extant holds her supremacy by a precarious tenure.

The sixth annual dinner of the Presbyterian Union of New-York was held at the Hotel Brunswick last night. There were about 250 guests seated at the eleven tables, and during the dinner a string band, hidden behind a clump of palms, played Italian and Spanish music. The decorations of the dining room were very pretty, consisting of American flags and bunting.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 4. -- The petition of William J. Souder of Columbus, Ohio, who is serving a seven years' term in the State prison at Wethersfield, Conn., for manslaughter, came before the Board of Pardons in this city this afternoon. Gov. Morris, Chairman ex officio of the board, heard the case.

ALBANY, Dec. 4. -- In spite of denials, trouble exists between the Democratic machine leaders, and predictions are boldly made that a formal break will occur before the Legislature adjourns next Spring. David B. Hill has, to all intents and purposes, severed all political relations with Messrs.

There is no truth in the story which has been in circulation among the Republican politicians of Brooklyn, to the effect that Patrick Campbell, Superintendent of Police, intends to apply for retirement on a pension when the Schleren administration gees into power Jan. 1.

Patrick Ross, the mysterious contractor who charged the City of Brooklyn $11,703 for building the grand stand at the Prospect Park Plaza on the occasion of the Columbian celebration a year ago, appeared before Mayor Boody, Controller Corwin, and City Auditor Weber yesterday. He refused to explain why he charged the city such an exorbitant sum for his work.

The United States revenue steamer Grant is under orders to sail from New-York today for San Francisco, a cruise of 14,000 miles. Last night she was lying at anchor off Stapleton, S.I. She has stores and provisions on board sufficient for six months.

George Foster Peabody, President of the Brooklyn Democratic Club, at the last meeting of that organization, Nov. 22, was empowered to appoint a Provisional Reorganization Committee of 100 Democrats of Kings County. The duty of the committee is to bring about a permanent and trust-worthy organization, upon the lines indicated in the plan submitted by Edward M. Shepard, A. Augustus Healy, J. Warren Greene, Henry Yonge, S. Perry Sturgis, and George Foster Peabody.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Prof. Tyndall died tonight at his house in Haslemere, County of Surrey. He had long been ailing, and recently his vitality had decreased steadily. His death was hastened by a severe cold.

The special Grand Jury, summoned to clear up the accumulated business in the District Attorney's office, got to work yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Barrett. As a result of their labors they handed down a batch of thirty-one indictments when they adourned in the evening.

The report which Secretary LAMONT makes upon the condition and work of the military establishment is of exceptional interest to the army and the cotmtry. It shows that reorganization has become the watchword of the hour. Our present distribution of the line into twenty-five regiments of infantry, ten of cavairy, and five of artillery he regards as having been established for "conditions which have almost ceased to exist."

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- On Nov. 4, when Diamond Match was selling at 129 3/4, figures anent the security were given in these dispatches showing that a better Chicago investment could not be found on the list. The deductions then drawn were verified by to-day's prices. Opening at 136, it advanced to 140, and closed at 137 1/2 ex dividend, which means a rise of 4 points over Saturday's session.

All of the Eastern trunk lines and their Western conections have issued east-bound freight tariffs to meet the open cut made by the Erie Railway last week on sixth-class commodities, including grain and dairy products. These reductions in rates are now in force between New-York and Chicago, in spite of the trunk-line agreement to maintain rates, which was to have gone Into effect on the 1st of this month.

At Sherry's last night the first for this season of the Monday cotillions, which signalizes the formal opening of the social season, was given with all the brilliancy proper to an affair of its importance. Outside of the Patriarch and Assembly balls, and, perhaps, one or two other dances, these cotillions are probably the most important functions of New-York Winter life.

A cablegram from London says that the Emperor of Germany is negotiating for the purchase of the yacht Vigilant. The authority for the statement is a German naval officer who is now in London. He says that if the Emperor is successful in his over-tures the Vigilant will be taken to England next Spring and race in the English regattas against the Britannia and other crack yachts.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Dec. 4 -- P.M. The stock market was fairly active during the morning and very dull in the afternoon. The opening was steady, but weakness developed early, the majority of the losses being made before noon. Sugar, although the leader in point of activity, was less active than usual, and it was fairly steady, its extreme fluctuations being within 1 3/4 points, and its closing price only 1/8 lower than on Saturday.

PARIS, Dec. 4. -- The trial was held to-day before the Assize Court at Clermont-Ferrand, Department of Pay-de-Dome, of Baron Oscar de Rahden, a Russian, on the charge of murder. The victim was Lieut. Castenskiold, an officer of the Danish Army. The Lieutenant met Baroness de Rahden, who, prior to her marriage and afterward, was a circus rider.

The management of the "Streets of Cairo." formerly exhibited at the World's Fair, and now showing in the Grand Central Palace, defied the police yesterday afternoon. The danse du ventre, which Superintendent Williams stopped Saturday night, was performed again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Every cable car, Herdic, and cab that ascended Capitol Hill between 10 o'clock and 12 to-day carried some passengers to the Capitol, and a large proportion of each load, together with a considerable contingent that made its way on foot, got into the House end of the big white building and endeavored to find seats in one of the galleries.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 4. -- The convention to formulate definite plans for the great Populist scheme of building the Gulf and Inter-State Railway will convene in Representative Hall, in this city, to-morrow. The first convention in the interest of this gigantic enterprise was held in Lincoln, Neb., in June last, and was the result of a series of resolutions passed by the last Nebraska Legislature.

A new lot of comedians whose names did not appear on the passenger list were arrivals on the steamer Suevia from Hamburg yesterday. They are direct from Carl Hagenbeck's training grounds. When they have recovered from the effects of their sea voyage and have had a sufficient number of rehearsals they will appear at Tattersalls as the comedians of the animal show under Hagenbeck's management.
MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 4. -- When the employes of the Miller Brothers' Cutlery Company reported for work this morning they were greeted by the following notice, which is self-explanatory:

TOPEKA, Dec. 4. -- All efforts to induce the members of the Ponca tribe of Indians to divide their lands and sell the surplus to white settlers have failed. While this comparatively small tribe is more advanced in civilization than any of the Territory Indians, yet it is apparently immovable in its refusal to accept the severally allotment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Commodore Stanton has not yet appeared at the Navy Department. The only intimation of his arrival in this country is his telegram sent from New-York the day he reached home, formally announcing the fact. He was some time ago placed upon waiting orders, but it was supposed that when he reached this country whither he had been ordered after detachment from the Brazillan station, he would immediately come to Washington.

John B. Schoeffel of the firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau appeared before Mayor Gilroy yesterday, with Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Schaffer and three of the Schaffer family, who are under the age prescribed by law at which children may sing or dance or perform acrobatic feats on the stage.

The professional matinee of "Shore Acres" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre yesterday was a departure from the method of giving such entertainments that has hitherto prevailed. It has been the custom at such matinees to invite all the players in and around the city to witness the performance freely.

Ricard Rousseau, manager of the Banque Francais, at 5 Broadway, has disappeared, and with him about $20,000 belonging to various customers who trusted him. The sign which decorated his door set forth that he had a branch business at 103 St. Francais Xavier Street, Montreal. It said also that he was the New-York agent for the banking house of A.M. Chatelard, Montreal.
Wheat advanced 1c early on firmer West, better cables, and foreign buying, declined 5/8@7/8c on increased stocks and visible, and closed steady at a gain of 1/8@3/8c for the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- Lehigh Valley closed weak on Saturday at 40, and. while the first transaction to-day was at 39 3/8, stock did not begin to come out until 39 had been reached. No support developed until the price struck 37 1/2. At that point the selling ceased and the stock was easily bid up by the room traders and shorts.

A great throng at Abbey's Theatre last night admired and applauded a superb production of "King Henry VIII." Though this historical drama possesses some evidences of Shakespeare's genius, many students have attributed the work to Fletcher and Massinger. The pursuit of literary speculation of this sort is doubtless strengthening to the imagination and stimulating to the intellect; but the English-speaking people for nearly three centuries have called "Henry VIII."

PARIS, Dec. 4. -- The most intense interest was manifested to-day in the Chamber of Deputies regarding the declaration of the new Government. Nearly all of the members were in their seats, and the galleries were packed with an eager audience, including many fashionably-dressed ladies. Prominent among the latter was Mme.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The official estimates sent to Congress to-day by Secretary Carlisle ask for $411.879,041 for the fiscal year 1895, as against $421,612,215 for 1894 and against $432,456,526 appropriated for 1894. In detail the estimate shows:

After the fire at Edwards's clothing house, at Eighth Street and Broadway. Saturday night, Robert Faut of 421 West Thirty-sixth Street, a member of the Fire Insurance Patrol, was detailed to watch the partly-burned building. Early Sunday morning he was arrested while leaving the building, with nineteen pairs of stockings under his coat.

Local Republican quarrels continue to agitate those gentlemen of the Union League Club and the others who are doing their utmost to bring about a regeneration of the G.O.P. in this city. The biggest quarrel of all is likely to grow out of the work of the committee appointed by the Republican County Committee recently to investigate and, if necessary, recommend a plan for reorganization.

Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court refused yesterday to restrain the New-York Central Railroad from voting upon the stock of the New-York and Northern Railroad which it purchased last Winter. The action was brought by Mr. Oelbermann, a minority stockholder of the New-York and Northern.

INWOOD, L.I., Dec. 4. -- Henry Kiernan, a married man, about twenty-three years of age, mysteriously disappeared from his residence in this village last Friday night, and has not since been seen or heard from. He had considerable money with him, and foul play is feared. The finding near a pond of a hat similar to the one worn by the missing man has led some to the belief that he met death by drowning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The President's message was listened to with such attention when read in both houses of Congress this afternoon that it would be supposed that members of Congress would be prepared to express their opinions of it at once, but among leading men there is tonight the usual desire to read it in print and perhaps to find out what other leading men say about it before expressing positive opinions.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Dec. 4. -- A.B. Youngson, Chief Arthur's representative, and the Stae Boards of Arbitration of New-York and New-Jersey are holding a meeting here. G. Robertson, Jr., of Troy, Edward Feeny of Brooklyn, Charles J. Madden of Albany, J.P. McDonnell and John W. Romaine of Paterson, P.F. Doyle of Jersey City, and L.D. Robertson of French-town, N.J., represent the arbitrators.

At 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon the first cable car to carry passengers over the Third Avenue Road was started from the One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Third Avenue depot. An experimental trip had been made Sunday night with one car, the car and cable working to the entire satisfaction of the officers of the company.

Miss L.J. Tompkins, daughter of J.C. Tompkins of the Park Board, Brooklyn, was married to Wallace Blackford in the Washington Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, last evening. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J.C. Humpstone. The bridegroom is the son of ex-Fish Commissioner Eugene Blackford.

BOSTON, Dec. 4. -- There was little done at the Clearing House this morning. Money between the banks loaned at 1 1/2 and 1 per cent., mostly at 1 1/2. Many of the banks carried their balances home, being unable to loan them, and others refused to loan below 1 1/2 per cent. One leading bank has gained $1,500,000 during the past three days.

If any one had doubted that Donizetti's opera, "The Lady or the Flute Player," commonly known as "Lucia di Lammermoor," was dead to the world, last night's audience at the Metropolitan Opera House ought to have removed the doubt. It used to be believed, and It was a fact, that this opera, would draw a large audience when a great prima donna's name was on the bill.

Between Saturday evening and yesterday morning -- probably during the rainstorm late on Sunday night -- a daring and skillful gang of burglars broke into the jewelry store of Lambert Brothers, at 968 Third Avenue, and carried off fully $5,000 worth of silverware that had been left in the showcases when the store was closed Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- President Cleveland sent his annual message to the Congress to-day.
