The foreign exchange market was bare of bills and very firm. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.84 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.83 3/4@$4.84 1/2 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/4@$4.86 1/2 for demand, $4.86 3/4@ $4.87 for cable transfers, and $4.82 1/4,@$4.82 3/4 for commercial.

Those who are intimate with the management of the Metropolitan Opera House have been greatly diverted by what is recorded there as the "floral trophy episode." The circumstances of the episode are most amusing, and serve to adorn a tale, if not to point a moral.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The Fifty-third Congress met in regular session at noon to-day, and in a brief time had resumed business in both houses. The organization of the Congress at the special session was a great saving of time and excitement at the opening of the regular session.

In addition to the regular Grand Jury for the December term of the criminal courts of this county an extraordinary Grand Jury has been summoned in the Court of Oyer and Terminer for the special purpose of considering cases of alleged frauds at the recent election and of violations of the excise laws.

The tactics adopted by some of the highly-protected manufacturers to create public sentiment against the Wilson Tariff bill will be regarded with undisturbed tranquillity by Congress, A Meriden cutlery firm is one of the concerus that has seen fit to threaten its employes with a reduction of 25 per cent, in wages after Jan. 1 and of 40 to 50 per cent, if the bill passes.

The President's message made a good impression in Wall Street. It appeared too late in the day for bankers to read it with sufficient care to express more than general opinions upon it. The drift of such opinions was highly favorable. Every one seemed satisfied that the President had acquitted himself in the creditable manner habitual with him.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The annual cattle show of the Smithfield Club opened with an unwonted number of excellent exhibits. The Prince of Wales took the first prize for Southdown wethers, and the Queen was awarded several prizes for exhibits. Prizes were also awarded to the Duke of Hamilton, the Duke of Richmond, and Baron Rothschild.

Since the Wilson bill was published, the producers of lumber on the Pacific coast have revived the old petitions and protests which were sent to Washington and given to the press in years past whenever it was proposed in Congress that lumber should be put on the free list. We hear the same old cry that the removal of the duty would ruin them by permitting the importation of lumber from British Columbia.

Chief of Police John Y. McKane of Gravesend again appeared yesterday before Justice Barnard of the Supreme Court, Who, owing to the fact that the courtroom was crowded, held court in the Board of Supervisors room, Brooklyn.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers, which is holding its fifteenth annual convention at its rooms, 12 West Thirty-first Street, spent a busy and enjoyable day yesterday. In the morning its members listened to professional papers from Prof. R.H. Thurston, director of the Sibley College at Cornell University; A.K. Mansfield, and George A. Mortson.

The four days' sale of trotting stock which Tattersalls Company began in Madison Square Garden yesterday attracted a very fair attendance. The Garden is admirably adapted for a sale such as this, where so much depends on the showing a horse can make in motion. In addition to the track around the arena, a straight dirt path was laid across the centre, and on this several of the lots offered showed quite a clip.

The parlors of Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, were lavishly decorated last night with orchids and foliage plants in honor of the marriage of Miss J. Samuels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Samuels, to J.L. Myers. Nearly all of the 500 invited guests witnessed the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Dr. Benjamin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The market was a lively one to-day. Everything on the list participated in the general activity, and nearly all stocks -were higher. West Chicago opened 2 points above yesterday's price, and quickly rose to 155 3/8. It then declined to 154 1/4, but closed the first session at 154 5/8.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 5 -- Several days ago a number of business men here received a notice from the Long Island Railroad Company to the effect that in future all freight must be paid for before it could be removed from the freight house. The notice also stated that checks on the Glen Cove Bank would not be received in settlement of freight bills.

A valuable indication of returning prosperity in commercial circles in this city was given yesterday when Controller Myers sold, at public auction, in his office, $1,225,000 of 3 per cent. city stocks and bonds at 100.38.

[All communications for this column must be ad dressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.]

One of the essential features of the plan of reorganization decided upon by the anti-machine Democrats of Kings County is the adoption of the election district as the constituent unit of party representation, instead of the city ward or the Assembly district. The same plan has been considered by the Republican Reorganizing Committee in this city, which is said to regard it unfavorably.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations, failed of confirmation at the last session:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day received a dispatch from San Francisco announcing the departure of the United States revenue cutter Corwin, Capt. Munger, for Honolulu. One passenger only was carried by the Corwin, and he a representative of the State Department at Washington, with messages and official documents for Minister Willis.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association met last night in Parlor H of the Murray Hill Hotel. The docket is a very light one, so far as cases arising from the past reason's racing is concerned, and these are all of minor interest. There are a number of cases, however, to be heard by the board, continued from previous sessions. Among these the two famous cases, Temple Bar and Nelson Alcryon reappear.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., Dec, 5 -- The heroic, but unsuccessful, efforts of the life savers to rescue the crew of the wrecked schooner Louise H. Randall, which went ashore on Smith's Point, opposite this place, last week, has aroused the department at Washington. A thorough investigation is now under way.

By the gathering of Republicans at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night the natural supposition would have been that a Governor or some State officer was to be chosen, instead of merely a Clerk of the Assembly, for all the other legislative offices have been, decided upon. The whereabouts of ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt could always be found by the hovering of legislators about him.

The captains without companies who look wistfully in the direction of the immobile McLaughlin as the heart-sore Marshals of Napoleon used to try and pierce the darkness at midnight to see the invisible Elba and the solitary exile, are constantly convening nowadays. It is about all that they can do, to sit in some secret place, aloof from their subalterns, and discuss things.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed in the Building Department yesterday:

The meagre news from Honolulu brought by a sailing vessel, which left four days later than the last steamer, sheds very little light on the Hawaiian situation. If the statement attributed to Minister WILLIS is authentic, it merely shows that he was then awaiting further instructions from Washington, and in the meantime was determined to maintain the existing status against disturbance from any quarter.
Albert G. McDonald has been notified of his appointment, and has accepted the office of Corporation Counsel of Brooklyn. He will be the successor of Almet F. Jenks.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Emile A. Nelson was arrested in this city on Nov. 25, 1892, on a charge of abducting his fourteen-year-old stepdaughter, whose mother he had abandoned in Hull, England. Nelson was taken to the Second Criminal Court the following morning, with several other prisoners, but when his case was called he could not be found.

The substitution of cable power for horse power on the Third Avenue Railroad is an event of very considerable interest and importance to the inhabitants of this municipality. The formal "inauguration" took place on Monday, and the running of a small number of cable cars yesterday marked the introduction of the new system.
PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Dec. 5. -- The barkentine Klickitat, Capt. Cutler, arrived yesterday from Honolulu, with advices to Nov. 20, four days after the steamer Alameda sailed for San Francisco.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The majority in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday against, the proposal of M. Grousset, Socialist, to grant amnesty to political, press, and strike offenders was made up of 209 Republicans and 48 members of the Right. The minoritywas composed of 27 Republicans, 12 members of the Right, and the entire Socialist faction.

In speaking of a dance which a so-called Algerian company gives at the Grand Central Palace, tagged upon a legitimate and praiseworthy exhibition of objects which won distinction at the Columbian World's Fair, the manager of the show resorted to a bit of word juggling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Commodore Stanton arrived in Washington from his Connecticut home this morning, and appeared at the Navy Department in the uniform of a Commodore, which is the rank he holds in the navy. He was visited by nearly every officer in the department while he sat in Commodore Ramsay's private office, and he evidently has the respect and sympathy of his associates in the service.
QUINCY, Ill., Dec. 5 -- William H. Grimm, formerly of this city and at last accounts of Brooklyn, N.Y., is alleged to have five wives and never to have been divorced from any of them.

George J. Gould, the millionaire, has been made the defendant in a mysterious suit for $40,000 by a pretty young woman of eighteen. What the nature of the suit is can only be dimly guessed at from the nature of a very brief affidavit filed yesterday in the Superior Court, before Judge McAdam, by the plaintiff in the mysterious action, Mrs. Zella Nicolaus.

The window display made by the firm of H.C. K. Koch Co., in West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, appropriate to the holiday season, is novel and attractive. In one window is a church, to illustrate "Curfew must not ring to-night." The sexton is pulling the rope, while up in the tower Bessie may be seen hanging to the clapper as the bell swings to and fro.

The firm of N.J. Schloss Co., consisting of Nathan J. Schloss and Henry J. Schloss, manufacturers and dealers in boys' clothing at 653 and 655 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday afternoon to Simson Wolf of the law firm of Wolf, Kohn Ulman, at 203 Broadway. Preferences were made to the following creditors:

The sailing of the United States revenue steamer Grant from this port for the Pacific was delayed yesterday owing to the heavy northeast blow on the coast. The Grant lay last night at anchor off Stapleton, L.I. Early this morning, if the weather be clear, she will steam down to the compass buoys in the lower bay, and there adjust her compasses.

CHICAGO. Dec. 5 -- The wheat market was dull today and the feeling developed was easier. There were some spasms of activity with firming reactions, but they were not lasting. The opening was about 1/8 @ 1/4 c lower than yesterday's closing, ruled firm, and prices advanced 1/4c: there was some selling by longs at the top, which carried the price down 5/8 @ 5/4 c.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Racing was continued today at Bennings in a driving snowstorm, but the attendance was quite large and the betting sufficiently lively to keep twenty-one books busy. The tract was covered with snow.

There was a pleasant luncheon at 59 West Fifty-sixth Street yesterday that was an entire surprise to its participants. The occasion was the annual meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association of New-York. Through the courtesy of Mrs. Esther Hermann the meetings of the association are held at her house throughout the year, and yesterday, after the regular business of the day, a vote of thanks to Mrs. Hermann was called for.

The recent published statements that the supporters of the Spellissy bill to divide the State school moneys with the Catholic parochial schools would find an ardent advocate in Senator Edmund O'Connor of Binghamton have brought forth expressions that utterly put to rest any doubt as to that gentleman's position on the subject.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Dec. 5 -- P.M. The bears had their inning In to-day's stock market, but they did not score heavily. They directed their attention principally to Atchison and General Electric, and in their raid no rumors were too improbable for their purpose.

GLASGOW, Dec. 5 -- The delegates of the Scotch miners held a meeting here this afternoon and decided unanimously to call out immediately 17,000 miners whose employers have conceded to them the 1s. per day demanded by all the union men. It was also decided to send a communication to Mr. Gladstone asking the Government to intervene in the Scotch miners' strike, as it did in the strike of the English miners.

Wheat was very dull and 1/8 @ 3/8 c lower on local realizing and weaker West. Corn advanced 1/8 @ 1/4 c on an improved export inquiry and closed firm. Cotton closed firm at an advance of 9 @ 10 points, with a moderate business. Coffee was neglected, but closed at about 10 points advance.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- Municipal elections were held to-day in twenty-one cities in the State outside of Boston. The severe storm that raged all day served to keep many voters at home, and as a general thing the voting was light. Results as far as learned are appended:

NORWICH, Conn., Dec. 5 -- The Shetucket Cotton Mill, at Greeneville, in this town, will begin running to-morrow with its full force of workmen, 600 in number. It has been run at half its capacity since Sept. 18. The Falls Cotton Mill, of equal capacity, is now running, with all its employes at work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- There are four firms in this country ready to supply the army with smokeless powder. Gen. Flagler received to-day propositions from that number of powder makers who are anxious to furnish the army with its first quantity of this mysterious compound. Two men were bidders who are familiar to the expert.
ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Dec. 5 -- The thermometer registered 22 below zero this morning.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday pushed ahead the work on which they have lately been engaged by adopting an east side independent elevated route. They were ready to take it up as soon as their open session began, having agreed to it in private meeting beforehand. As with the west side route, adopted last Friday, the vote of each Commissioner was recorded, all voting in the affirmative.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Both New-York Senators were kept busy to-day answering inquiries based on reports in New-York morning papers, to the effect that the leaders of the New-York State machine had "fallen out," and that Mr. Hill would henceforth eschew the machine, while Mr. Murphy would flock with Sheehan and Croker.

The annual election of officers of the Democratic Club was held at the clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue, Monday evening. The campaign which preceded the election was one of the most vigorously contested in the club's history, and an unusually large vote was cast. The following officers were elected.

The foreign exchange market was strong on light offerings and continued inquiry. The posted rates for sterling were advanced to $4.85 for sixty-day bills and $4.88 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84 @ $4.84 1/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/2 @ $4.86 3/4 for demand, $4.87 @ $4.87 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.83 1/4 for commercial.

The interests of the First Ward are more than represented in the Municipal Legislature of New-York by a dark-browed gentleman with a stern visage, deep-set eyes, and a figure that towers over six feet high. This, at all events, is the general effect produced upon observers by his presence. His carriage is stately and military, suggesting the port of a grenadier.

Nobody who read the report in yesterday's TIMES of the recent sayings and actions of Mr. DAVID B. HILL, sometime Governor of the State of New-York and at present Senator from the same, can have failed to experience a surprise bordering on consternation. Is SAUL, also among the prophets? such a reader must have been impelled to inquire.

The Pirating was at anchor in the upper bay, near Robbin's Reef, yesterday, with the Santuit, which is to tow her, ready to start for Brazil. George A. Burt of the firm of Flint Co., the agents for the Brazilian Government in this city, is on board the Santuit, bound on a special mission to Brazil.

BUTLER, Penn., Dec. 5 -- Mrs. C. Hepler and her daughter, Mrs. James Martin, who lived together near St. Joe Station, eight miles from here, were murdered early this morning. There seems to be no doubt that Harper Whitmire, son-in-law of Mrs. Hepler, killed the women. L. Notham, son of Mrs. Hepler, entering his mother's house at 9 o'clock this morning, found everything in confusion.

Gov. Flower came in for a sharp drubbing yesterday by the members of the canal conference, in session all day at the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation. His offense consisted in a letter in which he dared brave the predilections of the conference by declaring that the canal service needed rapid transit for the boats, rather than a deepened channel through legislative appropriations.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 5 -- Gov. Mitchell will be thwarted completely in his opposition to the Cor. bett-Mitchell fight. The City Council to-day passed to third reading the ordinance permitting contests with gloves of five-ounce weight and over for a license fee of $60. The vote was nearly unanimous. The ordinance was held up till the meeting next week on a slight technicality about the rules.

Ex-Senator David M. Read, President of the D.M. Read Company and the Read Carpet Company of Bridgeport, Conn., died yesterday. He had been ill just four weeks, and death was due to a general collapse of the nervous system. David M. Read was born at Hoosick Falls, N. Y., Oct. 12, 1832.
Is there a granite-block-paving ring in the Board of Aldermen?

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Judge Horton late this evening appointed William M. Robertson receiver for the Chicago Trust and Savings Bank. His appointment was the result of proceedings in chancery against Daniel H. Tolman, President of the institution. This action was the outcome of the meeting of the Board of Directors to-day, at which resolutions were adopted charging Tolman with mismanagement and converting and misappropriating large sums of money belonging to the bank.

Six jurors, one-half the number of those who are to try Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer for his life, have now been chosen. Three hundred talesmen have been called 160 have responded, and out of them all only six have been deemed fit to try one of the greatest capital cases of the century.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- Chin Gin, known as "Old Sport," a well-known Chinaman, left this city within two days with United States officers in pursuit. He is charged with being the head of a body of conspirators against the laws of the United States, who have prepared bogus certificates enabling Chinamen to visit their country and return under the classification of merchants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Commodore Walker and the other members of the Stability Board, originally detailed to discuss the condition of the Montgomery and Machias types of ships, met to-day at the Navy Department. There was a discussion of the Machias and the Castine, and it was shown that the condition of both ships was such as to justify the gravest apprehensions.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The story in to-day's New-York Times depicting the break among the Democratic machine leaders and making the formal announcement that Senator David B. Hill had cut loose from his old colleagues and had declared his candidacy for President in 1896 was read with a great deal of interest at the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- It will not be the fault of Senator Hill if the rules of the Senate are not speedily revised. He is doing his utmost to induce the Committee on Rules to take action on the amendments offered in the extraordinary session by himself and others, designed to strip the minority of the power to clog business at their pleasure.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- In a letter on the Irish land question, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Liberal-Unionist leader in the House of Commons, declares that his views on the subject have undergone no change. He does not seek, however, to bind the Liberal-Unionists to his views. It is his belief that the solution of the question must be found through purchase only.

The Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New-York has taken pains to disclaim, on the part of the Church, any responsibility for the bill in which some unauthorized Catholic layman has formulated the "claim" of the Catholic schools to a share in the public-school fund. He has not disavowed, however, nor has any person authorized to represent the Church disavowed the claim itself.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 5 The auction sale of thoroughbreds closed here to-day. The attendance has been large and bidding brisk. Prices were satisfactory. During the two days 131 head have been sold for $72,125, a general average of $550. Sixty-six head were disposed of to-day for $42,870, an average of $649 per head. Following are the best prices and the sales of yearlings:

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The jury that is to try Daniel Coughlin for the murder of Dr. Cronin was sworn in this morning and was then sent out of the courtroom in order that a motion might be heard as to the admissibility of a reference to Mrs. Andrew Foy, one of the chief witnesses for the State, in the opening address of the prosecution.

The three notes given by Director R.T. McDonald to the Madison Square Bank in payment for 1,000 shares of the capital stock of that institution, fell due yesterday. These notes were originally for $50,000 each, but the total was reduced by the collection of the interest coupons of the collateral to $140,000.
Thirteen Police Captains were ordered yesterday by the votes of Commissioners Martin, Sheehan, and McClave to change commands.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5 -- Mr. W.R. Huntington, State Fish and Game Commissioner, has begun an agitation that has a bearing upon the tariff, but is of vastly more interest for its connection with natural history. It is nothing less than an attempt to secure tariff legislation that will not put a premium upon the destruction of migratory fowl.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Zella Nicolaus was born of humble parentage in Wabash, Ind., and her childhood beauty had made her famous at the age of fourteen. About this time a young traveling man named Christman visited the quaint little town, and one evening Zella went riding with him. When she returned home she told her parents a tale of assault, about which she wove a good story.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- At the Clearing House this morning, money loaned at 1 1/2 @1 per cent., and was freely offered at the latter rate at the close. Note brokers complain of the small supply of choice paper. Money on call ranges from 2 to 3 per cent., and time money is offered at 3 1/2 per cent, on, four months, with first-class collateral.

Thomas R. Deverell, the Brooklyn bandmaster who received about $9,000 for music furnished the city during the Columbian celebration last year, was an unwilling witness yesterday before the Columbian Audit Commission in Controller Corwin's office in the Brooklyn City Hall.

F. O. Peters, first officer of the steamship American, has something to add to the literature of sea serpents. The American is a tank, but that is wholly irrelevant. The vessel reached Quarantine yesterday morning-, and throughout the afternoon First Officer Peters was kept busy explaining. He said that it was on Dec. 2, at 4 o'clock in the morning, that he took the bridge, relieving the second officer, who immediately went below.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Dec. 6 -- P. M. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange showed further contraction today. Sugar was the only stock which could be fairly called active, and the trading in it was only a little over 33,000 shares. It was strong up to announcement of the regular dividends, but a break of 2 5/8 points followed that incident.

The three girls arrested Monday night for giving an exhibition of thedanse du ventre at the Grand Central Palace were fined $50 each yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions. Notice of appeal was given by A. H. Hummel, and the case will probably come up before the Court of General Sessions in a few days.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- An explosion which injured four men, two of whom are likely to die, took place on the river front this morning at the freight-house entrance of the People's Line Steamboat Company.

The members and guests of the St. Nicholas Society celebrated the feast day of their patron saint in a characteristic and jovial manner at Delmonice's last night. The room in which the reunion took place was appropriately decorated. Flags of the United States and of Holland, draped the arms of the latter country, and banners of the society were behind the table, at which sat the speakers, and at intervals around the room.

We recognize the voice of DOLGE of Dolgeville in the outcry the much-protected manufacturers are sending up against the Wilson bill. DOLGE is nominally a manufacturer of felt, but his real occupation is that of making stiff partisan arguments for the Republican Party and protection.
BELGRADE, Dec. 6. -- M. Gruichs has succeeded in forming a Cabinet. It is composed as follows...

The character of the trotting stock offered on the second day of the combination sale by Tattersalls at Madison Square Garden was, both as regards breeding and Individuality, much superior to Tuesday's offerings. There was a better attendance and a higher average price was secured. The last stallion Steve Whipple, despite his an fashionable breeding, brought a good price on his showing In the ring and on his record.

A noteworthy transaction reported yesterday was the sale of the business property 332 Canal Street, extending through to 37 and 39 Lispenard; Street, by Clark Brothers to Herman Wronkow, for about $100,000. The lot sold In fee measures 25 by 106 feet. In addition, there is a leasehold of 25 by 50 feet on the Lispenard Street side.
Brooklyn is a great place for church bazaars, and the residents of that city take pleasure in attending these affairs.

The Santuit and her tow, the Pirating-, formerly the submarine gun vessel. Destroyer, were announced as being, ready to sail for Brazil yesterday afternoon. It was expected that they would clear the Narrows before sunset, but they were still at anchor in the bay long- after nightfall. Late last night, the observer at Sandy Hook reported a vessel passing- out with a tow. This, it is supposed, was the Santuit with the Pirating.

The affairs of N. J. Sohloss & Co., manufacturers of boys' clothing at 653 and 655 Broadway, are still in a very unsettled condition. The assignee was busy all day yesterday making an inventory of the large amount of merchandise on hand, and experts were at work on the firm's books. Concerning the mortgages on real estate owned by the Messrs.

The competition for furnishing 10,000 pounds of smokeless powder to the army has brought out four bids, with the prospect of an award on satisfactory terms. In spite of the drawbacks to the use of chemical powders, they have been adopted by nearly every European power, so that our own army ought to be able to procure one for its new magazine rifle.
Wheat advanced 5/8@ 3/4c on firmer cables, light receipts, better Western markets, and local covering, with a moderate trade.

Chemist Martin of the Health Department presented to the board, at its meeting yesterday, a report on the complaint made by George E. Dickinson of 466 Lexington Avenue of the nuisance caused by the discharge of smoke from the chimney of the roundhouse of the New-York Central Railroad, at Fourth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.

Alfred Tredway White, who has been selected by Mayor-elect Schieren for Commissioner of City Works of Brooklyn, is not only a prominent citizen of Brooklyn, but likewise a prominent business man of NewYork. He is descended from New-England ancestry, his parents having come from Connecticut to Brooklyn many years ago.

Dr. Walsh's bill for the diversion of the school tax of the State from the purpose for which It is laid to the support of parochial schools, the text of which was first made public through the columns of The New-York Times yesterday, does not meet with very general approval outside the circle of men who are its advocates.

The hearing given yesterday by the Park Commissioners to persons interested in the treatment of the proposed speedway along the Harlem River left no doubt upon what side the public interest and the public sentiment lay. Accordingly, it left no doubt upon what side the representatives of the public ought to stand.

Vogel Brothers, proprietors of the big "White Elephant" clothing store, at Broadway and Thirty-first Street, dissolved partnership Dec. 4, and not being able to agree upon an equitable division of the assets, the matter was brought into court, and yesterday Leo Schlesinger was appointed receiver of the assets of the firm by Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court, in a suit brought by Jacob Vogel against Louis Vogel.

William S. Devery, the Police Captain against whom four indictments were found last week for neglect of duty while in command of the Eldridgre Street Station, was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Judge Cowing. None of the representatives of Dr. Parkhurst's society, who made the complaint upon which the indictments were founded, was in court.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 6. -- The Gulf and Inter-State Railroad convention has been occupied to-day in the consideration of plans for putting the north and south railroad scheme in motion and for raising funds with which to construct the road.

Ambroise Thomas conceived Shakespeare's melancholy Dane in an exceedingly melancholy mood. The average American is far too familiar with " Hamlet " as a drama to take kindly to It in Its operatic guise, and if he missed nothing else he would miss the familiar quotations which are at least recognizable.

The thirteen Captains of police transferred by orders of the Police Commissioners yesterday reported at the station houses of the precincts of which they were directed to assume command at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, and took charge, with the exception of Capt. William S. Devery, transferred from the Eldridge Street to the Old Slip Station.

The determined effort which many prominent citizens are making to have provision for an outside or riverside sidewalk included in the plans for the proposed Harlem River speedway, and to have some attention paid to the landscape features, was resumed yesterday before the Park Commissioners. The plans, as adopted by the Commissioners some time ago, provide only for an inner sidewalk, skirting the bluff.

William Stewart, who was twenty-six years old, and lived with his wife and child at 434 Keap Street, Brooklyn, and who had charge of the syrup department for Hegeman & Co., was instantly killed yesterday by falling in an elevator hatch in the old Herald Building. Stewart wished to see his father, who is looking after the building, and at 1:30, in crossing the first floor, he stumbled into the hatchway, which was open.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The distress among the unemployed is so great that every night 600 find lodgings on the cold floors in the corridor of the City Hall. These are only a few of the great number who have no place to sleep. Five hundred sleep in the chairs in the Pacific Garden Mission. From 1,400 to 1,600 find lodging on the stone floors in the cells in the police stations.
Travel on the lower section of the Broadway cable line was delayed over two hours last night by an accident which occurred just before 7 o'clock on the curve at Fourteenth Street.

In the light of our present information only two things can be regarded as settled with reference to the Hawaiian business. One is that the native monarchy of the islands was overthrown and the provisional Government set up through the "forcible intervention" of representatives of our Government and for the purpose of preparing the way for annexation.

ST. THOMAS, West Indies, Nov. 27.--The Nietheroy has just arrived here after a most interesting and pleasant voyage, beginning with storms and ending with three of the most perfect days it is given mankind to enjoy. From chaos the ship is now in excellent shape and her officers are astonished to see what has been accomplished in the few days she has been out.
Speaking for George J. Gould, Mr. Somerville of the Western Union Telegraph Company said yesterday, regarding the forty-thousand-dollar suit instituted by Mrs. Zella Nicolaus against Mr. Gould:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 6 -- County Judge Garretson has issued an order directing ex-Mayor Gleason to furnish an accounting of his receivership of the City Hall property and to file additional sureties, in the sum of $5,000, as receiver. The order is to be complied with within twenty days.

For the first time since the election the City Club met last night at its house in Fifth Avenue. The meeting was called especially to act upon the report of the trustees, and to adopt recommendations defining the attitude of the organization in respect to politics in the future.

A daring robbery committed at the home of lsaac W. Dayton, 344 West Twenty-third Street on Tuesday, was followed yesterday, after the return of stolen jewels, by the release from custody of a young man who had been arrested as tbe robber. Mr. Dayton withdrawing the complaint. The man who took the jewels terrorized Mrs. Dayton and a servant by threatening to shoot them it they made any outory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--The trial of Prendergast, the assassin of Mayor Harrison, began to-day. The courtroom and its approaches were guarded by a strong force of city police officers, Deputy Sheriffs, and bailiffs, who allowed only persons having business to pass. This precaution prevented any demonstration and kept the courtroom from being crowded.

The majority of the society people of Brooklyn and many from New-York assisted at the Carhart-Brookman wedding, which took place at Grace Church, Brooklyn, at noon yesterday. Amory Sibley Carhart, the bridegroom, is a member of most of the Brooklyn clubs, including the Hamilton, Brooklyn, Oxford, and Riding and Driving Clubs.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 6. -- There was an Immense fire in the navy yard this morning, and before the names could be subdued the brick and slate building with Its contents of steam engineer stores was In ashes. The fire was discovered at 7:40 o'clock. When smoke was seen issuing from the building the fact was reported to the watch officers, and Immediately thereafter to Admiral Brown, who ordered out the Fire Department.

The Tribune continues to be disturbed by the paragraph in the Wilson bill that removes the duties on copper ore and copper ingots, and would have everybody believe that it is distressed by the contemplation of an impending "flood" of copper from Chile and elsewhere. But there could not be a less favorable time for putting such stuff on the political market, as the trade report of the Tribune shows.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

The Circulo Colon Cervantes, an organization made up of some of the leading Spanish-American residents of this city, offered to present to the city a Columbus memorial fountain last fall. The fountain was to have been surmounted by heroic statues in bronze of Columbus and his Captains.

The engineer of an elevated train, peering out of his cab as the engine passed the corner of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, at 1:15 A.M. yesterday, saw flames and smoke issuing from the windows of the rear flat on the top floor of the house 182 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Josiah Caldwell, a promoter who raised money in England for the Hudson River tunnel between New-York and New-Jersey, was examined in the Bankruptcy Court to-day in the interest of Mr. Robinson, an American creditor. Caldwell's story was as follows:

[All commanications for this column must be addressed to the " City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.].
ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 6. -- A sneak thief bit Alderman Poole's hand very severely last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- In his annual report Attorney General Olney expresses satisfaction with the progress in disposing of arrears of business by the Supreme Court since the establishment of the Circuit Court of Appeals. He says that of the adjudicated cases, the two of greatest moment to the Government were the Chinese exclusion case and the hat trimmings case.

SALTDA. Col.. Dec. 6. --The Miners' Convention, called by Gov. Waite, met here at 11 o'clock this morning. But eighteen delegates were present, and Gov. Waite. In calling them to order, expressed regret that so few had responded to the call. Upon the vote of 10 to 8, taken before adjournment, Gov. Waite announced his intention of calling an extra session.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 6 -- A case which excites great interest here is now being tried in the Criminal Court. Frank Koesters, Mrs. Clara Koesters, Mamie Koesters, and Charles Koesters, an infant, died suddenly last Summer within the space of a few months at their home in this city.

MACKINAC CITY, Mich., Dec. 6. -- The steamer Waido A. A very, with 70,000 bushels of corn, from Chicago to Buffalo, was totally destroyed by fire last night in the straits. She was beached at Culpin's Point. The boat was owned by Hawgood & A very of Bay City, and was valued at $80,000.
PLAINFIELD, N. J. Dec. 6. -- Plainfield held its charter election yesterday. Although the Democrats elected only one man, Councilman Vincent L. Frazee, they lost by a small margin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- In the Cronin trial to-day the court ruled that the State, in its opening address to the jury, might outline what it expected to prove by Mrs. Foy, but without mentioning the witness's name. This leaves the actual question as to whether she is a competent witness to be decided when her evidence is offered.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 6 -- Within the next ten days it is almost certain that the 6,000 miners of the Monongahela Valley will demand a two-and-a-half-cent mining rate, and a refusal on the part of the river coal operators to grant it will undoubtedly precipitate a general strike. This is the plan now being agitated by representatives of the miners, in order that the question may reach an issue as soon as possible.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Dec. 6 -- A queer commercial conspiracy, unearthed in Greenville, was made public yesterday by the arrest of John Johnston of 309 West Twenty-ninth Street, New-York, employed as a salesman by Louis G. Roch, a wholesale liquor dealer at 434 Sixth Avenue. Johnston, who received a commission, built up quite a trade in Greenville, but Mr. Roch always received notes in payment.

At a meeting of German holders of the bonds of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company held in Berlin yesterday a committee of five was appointed, with full power to act for the bondholders. Dr. Siemens is Chairman of the committee. The meeting was called by the officers of the Deutsche Bank to consider the non-payment of the December coupons by the Union Pacific Railroad Company's receivers.

Ten jurors have been selected to try Dr. Henry C. W. Meyer for the poisoning of Gustav Baum. When the proceedings closed Tuesday evening six men sat in the jury box, the result of two days' work. To select the four chosen yesterday 120 talesmen were examined. This breaks all records made in this country.

ROME, Dec. 6. -- Unexpected complications arose to-day in the Cabinet which Zanardelli finally completed yesterday. The Premier, after vain efforts to restore harmony, went to King Humbert this afternoon with his resignation. He had found it impossible, he said, to form a Cabinet which would work harmoniously and successfully.

James R. Sovereign, the new General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, and the new General Executive Board of the order, who are visiting this city, are engaged in settling disputes of jurisdiction among several district assemblies here and in Brooklyn, and otherwise looking after the interests of the order.

This morning The New-York Daily Times consists of TEN PAGES. Every newsdealer is bound to deliver the paper in its complete form, and any failure to do so should be reported at the Publication Office.

Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren has discovered, that there are a great many people in Brooklyn who believe he should recognize their claims for office. They have worried him by their persistent efforts to get one of the offices at his disposal Many names of well-known Brooklynites have been published for the various places at Mr. Schieren's disposal, and it has been said that he has even offered places to some of these men.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Dec. 6 -- The correspondence between President Wilbur and the New-York and New-Jersey State Boards of Arbitration, which settled the Lehigh Valley strike, was given out this morning. The arbitrators wrote to President Wilbur as follows:

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 6. -- Attorney General Stockton has begun an action against the Trenton Potteries Company, in behalf of a dozen dissatisfied stockholders, who claim that the company is a trust, and that the contract prohibiting them from engaging in the pottery business except in Montana and Nevada is illegal.

The lease of Niblo's Garden was yesterday transferred by Carl and Theodor Rosenfeld to Walter Sanford. A fair price is said to have been paid for the lease by Mr. Sanford, but the amount Is known only to the Interested parties. The Rosenfelds will continue the management during the present week, which is the last of the presentation of " Olaf."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- There was considerable excitement in Lehigh Valley stock as soon as the Exchange opened. The first transaction was at 39 1/2, an advance of 3 per cent. over the closing bid yesterday. Early in the day the company published the official correspondence referring to the settlement of the strike.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Dec. 6 -- Thomas Axworthy, ex-City Treasurer of Cleveland, Ohio, died here this afternoon. Axworthy left Cleveland a defaulter to the extent of over half a million dollars in October, 1889. He went to London, England, where he was overtaken by detectives, and about $200,000 of the city's funds recovered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The unveiling- of the statue of Gen. James D. Shields at the Capitol to-day was made the occasion for impressive ceremonies, in which both Houses of Congress participated. The statue was several days ago placed in Statuary Hall, in close proximity to one of Lincoln.
Charles Coghlan and the woman whom he deserted after twenty-five years of life together as man and wife had an interview yesterday.

In view of the daily increasing distress among the unemployed, a people's restaurant and lodging house will shortly be opened as a separate department of the work of the Industrial Christian Alliance. The restaurant, which will have a capacity of 1,000 to 2,000 meals a day, will furnish a full meal of hot food to any man bringing 5 cents or presenting a meal ticket.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The local market was for the most part as dull and featureless to-day as it was active and interesting yesterday. Diamond Match opened at 136 3/4 and closed at 136 5/8. West Chicago from the opening, 153 5/8, sold straight down to 152, and then reacted 7/8, where it closed. Diamond Match closed where it opened, 136 3/4, with transactions of about 1,500 shares.

Every effort is being made by the General Committee having in charge the organization and enrollment of the " NewYork State Democracy" thoroughly to carry out the plans which have been arranged. The following letter has been sent to the members of the General Committee by Chairman Charles S. Fairchild:

HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., Dec. 6 -- The British ship Jason, which went ashore last night about a mile from this point, is a complete wreck, and only the seaman Samuel J. Evans, who was washed ashore last night, is alive out of a crew of twenty-six.
BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- Loans at the Clearing House this morning were made at 1 and 1 1/2 per cent., principally at the latter rate. New York funds were par to 6 cents discount.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 7 -- Under most favorable conditions to-day the new cruiser Marblehead developed an average speed of 18.94 knots over a seventy-two-mile course on the Sound, thirty-six against and thirty-six with the tide, and will bring her builders a bonus of $175,000. The contract speed was 17 knots.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 -- The striking employes of the Lehigh. Valley Railroad accepted the terms offered by the company and applied for work this morning. About one-quarter of the men got places, and the names and addresses of the others were taken. All vacancies on the road will be filled at once, but none of the non-union men will be discharged to make berths for strikers.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Dec. 7 -- P.M. London prices came higher this morning, and the local market opened up in sympathy. The improvement, however, did not hold, although the undertone was fairly firm. Atchison, Chicago Gas, Sugar, and St. Paul were the features.

Dr. Walsh's plan for dividing the public school funds among a lot of the sectarian schools of the State, principally, of course, among the Catholic parochial schools, meets with a more formidable opposition than he had expected. Even good Catholics do not approve of it and express themselves very openly as against the plan to force the parochial schools into the public-school system.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The merry rate war in east-bound freight rates was revived to-day with increased vigor. No new tariffs were issued and none of the roads admitted cutting rates, but it was a notorious fact that everybody having grain to ship had no difficulty in making contracts for its transportation to the seaboard at 17 1/2 cents per 100 pounds, or 2 1/2 cents below tariff rates.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Two hostile factions striving for control of the Republican "machine" in this city had a lively wrangle at the primaries held here last night. The fight hinged on electing new members to the City General Committee. Arrayed against the "machine" Republicans was a faction styled the "irregulars," who were said to be in sympathy with the Sanford administration.

Two writers of sensational detective stories were in attendance yesterday at the murder trial of Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer to gather material for their peculiar romances, and from present indications they will be well rewarded for their trouble. A more remarkable story of crime and its ferreting out has never been told in any courtroom.

A decree has been entered in the Supreme Court by Judge Beach for the distribution of the estate of Dumas Napoleon Bunel, who died in France Dec. 31, 1887, leaving an estate estimated at $350,000. The estate has been in litigation five years. Bunel made his money as a caterer in this city.
John Y. McKane's case of contempt of court is now in the hands of Justice Joseph F. Barnard.

Among the indictments returned by the extraordinary Grand Jury yesterday were a number against candidates at the last election, for failure to comply with the law which provides that candidates shall within ten days after an election file with the County Clerk or the Chief of the Bureau of Elections a list of election expenses.

Troutman Co., manufacturers of trousers at 217 and 219 Mercer Street, made an assignment yesterday to Alfred F. Seligsberg, giving preferences for $14,263 as fol- lows: Schloss Sons, $5,000 on an accommodation note; Emanuel Frankfield, $5,000 on an accommodation note; Rosalie Schloss of Roanoke, Va., $1,000 for money loaned; Mechanics and Traders' Bank, $3,263 due on an unpaid check.
"The National Democracy" is the name of a new anti-Tammany organization, started by ex-Sheriff James O'Brien, ex-Senator Francis Bixby, Major J.R. McNulty, and others.

The New-York Society of the Sons of the American Revolution is making preparations for an elaborate dinner in honor of Prof. John Fiske, the historian, on Dec. 16, the anniversary of the throwing overboard of the tea in Boston Harbor. The dinner is the annual one. It will be made something of an anniversary celebration of the historical "tea party."
Isaac C. Lewis, President of the Meriden Britannia Company, died yesterday at his home in Meriden, Conn., of apoplexy. Mr. Lewis had been in his usual health up to an hour or so before his death.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Coroner's jury in the case of Prof. Tyndall, who died suddenly last Monday, returned a verdict to-day that the Professor came to his death from the effects of an overdose of chloral, taken by mistake, and that the drug was given to Prof. Tyndall by Mrs. Tyndall, who mistook it for sulphate of magnesia.

CHICAGO, Deo. 7 -- The trial of Daniel Coughlin for complicity in the murder of Dr. Cronin progressed rapidly to-day. Kickham Scanlan finished his opening address for the State about noon and Daniel Donohue occupied the afternoon in setting forth the defense. Judge Wing, also for the defense, will begin his argument at the opening of court in the morning.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 7 -- The boldest robbery in the annuls of crime in Indiana was committed to-day about noon, the victim being the South Bend National Bank, one of the leading banking concerns in the State. The amount taken was $15,900. No clue to the identity of the robbers has yet come to light, and they seem to have made good their escape.

The Babies' Hospital -- Yesterday afternoon the managers of the Babies' Hospital, 657 Lexington Avenue, gave a reception, at which the hospitality of the institution was extended to all persons interested in its admirable work. The visitors were received by a committee composed of Mrs. Joseph T. Low, Mrs. Bryce Gray, Jr., Mrs. John Hone, Mrs. McCoskry Butt, Mrs. Andrew Smith, and Mrs. William F. Havemeyer, Jr.
"I do not care whether they starve or freeze on the streets, as long as they are starved and frozen into a healthier way of thinking and living."

A very interesting private exhibition of fencing with foil and broadsword was given yesterday afternoon at Senac's fencing rooms, in the Broadway Theatre Building, by Chevalier Pini, the champion fencer of Italy, who claims to be the world's champion in fencing, and Messrs. Greco and Pessina, also Italian expert swordsmen

The decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court that the State Board of Canvassers committed a contempt of court in canvassing a false return which it had been ordered not to canvass of the election in Dutchess County in 1891, is a gratifying result that ought to have been reached earlier.

GREENPORT, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Capt. H.W. Morse of the brig Solario, wrecked off Mattituck during the storm Tuesday night, has little hope of saving his vessel. The brig lies well in among the rocks and is badly broken up. During the day a quantity of wreckage was washed ashore. It consisted mainly of lumber and loose articles from the brig.

President Howell of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees handed to the City Treasurer of Brooklyn yesterday a check for $180,000, and another check to the Controller of New-York for $90,000. This sum of $270,000 is the surplus earnings of the Brooklyn Bridge for the six months ending Nov. 30, 1893.

The Park Board's plan for constructing the Harlem River Speedway has, from recent discussion and strong opposition, become a matter of great public interest. Three of the Commissioners -- Messrs. Tappen, Clausen, and Straus -- are in favor of constructing it without aid from the landscape artist of the department Commissioner Dana wants the work thoroughly and artistically done, with a view to benefiting equally the general public and the owners of horses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Minister Thurston, the representative in Washington of the provisional Government of Hawaii, saw Secretary Gresham at the State Department this morning. Afterward Mr. Thurston said he did not care to speak of the results of his interview, but his answers to questions indicated that he had learned nothing new concerning the Hawaiian situation.

The convocation of Republican politicians of great and small degree at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday meant more than the average spectator imagined. The leading Chairmanships of the big committees of the Senate and the Assembly of being divided. Such a gathering of great men has not been seen since the Fall of 1892, when the Republicans believed they had a flghting chance to win the Presidency.

Robert Jaffray, the senior elder of the West Presbyterian Church, is expecting the written resignation of the Rev. Dr. Paxton. He said last evening: "I received Dr. Paxton's resignation by telegraph on Monday, and immediately wrote back asking him to send a written one, which I would place before the elders, who would submit it to the congregation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- When the tariff is to be revised "up" the Republicans regard prolonged debate as unnecessary and inadmissible and amendments as intolerable. When the Democrats propose to correct the tariff by reducing duties, the Republicans consider it of the highest political importance that there should be a great deal of debate and that all amendments proposed should be voted upon.
Wheat gained 1/8 @ 1/4 c, on firmer cables, shorts covering, light receipts, and foreign buying, with trading dull.

The Rev. David Jewett waller, one of the best-known men of Northeastern Pennsylvania, died at Bloomsburg, Penn., yesterday, aged seventy-nine years. He was born at Wilkesbarre Jan. 16, 1815. He was a graduate of Williams College in 1834 and of Princeton Theological Seminary in 1837. In the following year he settled at Bloomaburg, and until 1873 had been the first pastor of the Presbyterian Church.
Mrs. Charles Coghlan No. 1 was in an excited frame of mind yesterday. Some of the reports of her first meeting with the actor since he married Kuehne Beveridge had greatly displeased her.

The steamship Santuil, having in tow the Pirating, put to sea yesterday morning. The Santuil left her anchorage in the upper bay at 7 o'clock and two hours later was signaled as passing Sandy Hook. No bunting was shown by either vessel, except a small American ensign which fluttered from the masthead of the Santuil.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- There are places for twelve bright young men In the Revenue Marine Service. An examination of the candidates will take place in this city Dec. 17. There are at present fifteen candidates who have signified a willingness to appear in competition for the commission of Third Lieutenant.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 7 -- The Virginia Senatorial fight came to an end this evening. Gen. Eppa Hunton was nominated in the Democratic caucus to serve out the remainder of the term for which John S. Barbour was elected -- that is to say, until March 4, 1895 -- and Thomas S. Martin was nominated to succeed Gen. Hunton.
The Fire Commissioners yesterday announced the following promotions in the uniformed force:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Chief Ornithologist C. Hart Merriam of the Agricultural Department said to a correspondent of The New-York Times that he knew of the movement reported to have been begun by W.R. Huntington, State Fish and Game Commissioner of Ohio, to prevent the extermination of wild fowl by prohibiting the importation of their eggs.

The annual report of the Secretary of the University of the State of New-York for the year 1831-92 shows a rapid growth during that period. The schools above academic grade increased from 71 to 81, and the number of students from 14,624 to 22,062. The first degrees, conferred on examination, increased from 2,064 to 2,305.

There is clearly an agreement among the members of the Administration who are particularly responsible for the finances and the President himself, first, that a sound, comprehensive, and enduring system as to the currency is required, and second, that ample time should be taken to secure it.

The Dauntless Rowing Club had its fourteenth annual ball Wednesday night, at the Lenox Lyceum. It was almost a reunion of boat clubs, for delegations were present from all the rowing organizations in this vicinity and many from out of town. Each club that had a delegation present had its flag hung over the boxes in the hall. The flags made very pretty decorations, and were greatly admired.

If Frank Ives plays nearly as well in his contests with Schaefer and Sloason as he has in his practice games, he will win the coming billiard tournament in hollow fashion. In his games yesterday after noon and evening against J. Randolph Heiser at Maurice Daly's parlors, the young champion broke all previous records as regards runs at the fourteen, inch balk-line game and surpassed all past averages.

The conference called by the committee of the Young Men's Democratic Club to consider the subject of reorganization was held at 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, last evening. There was a good attendance, and the subject was thoroughly discussed. Frederick W. Bailey, Chairman of the conference committee, presided.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- In the last session of Congress Senator Morrill introduced a bill making provision for a site for a Supreme Court building. It failed of passage, and yesterday he reintroduced it. It calls for the condemnation or direct purchase of the plot of ground bounded by East Capitol Street on the south, B Street on the north, and First and Second Streets on the east and west.

The Baptist Social Union met last evening at the Hotel Savoy. The guests of the union were James C. Carter, President of the City Club, and the Rev. Dr. James M. King, Secretary of the National League for the Protection of American Institutions.

The bad policy of holding two sales of trotting stock in this city on the same days was further demonstrated yesterday, for although the superior breeding and higher quality of yesterday's offerings at the Kellogg combination sale over those offered on the previous days attracted a larger attendance, the prices realized were not such as the stock should have commanded.

The clerks at the temporary headquarters of the New-York State Democracy, 52 Willlam Street, were busy yesterday sending out Chairman Fairchild's letter, which was published in The New-York Times yesterday morning.

The work of making up a report was begun yesterday by the Sub-Committee on Investigation of the committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to investigate the Republican organization in this city and its leaders, and if necessary report a plan for reorganization. The meeting was held in Col. S.V.R. Cruger's office, and it is understood that the general outlines of the report were agreed upon.

The long-existing troubles in the Sixty-ninth and the Eighth Regiments of the National Guard have at last been solved by Adjt. Gen. Josiah Porter and Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald of the First Brigade by reducing each organization from a regiment to a battalion. The order was issued yesterday.

There was a larger crowd present yesterday than at any of the previous days of Tattersalls' combination sale at Madison Square Garden. The buyers, however, were critical. They examined closely and bid slowly. The general average, nearly $400, was helped very materially by the figures given for Delmarch and Captain Walbridge. The stock of A.C. Hall and A.A. Bonner went very cheap.
Mrs. Lena Selauble, twenty-two years old, is in Bellevue Hospital being treated for poisoning caused by rat poison. She is also held as a prisoner on a charge of having attempted suicide.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Marjorie Woodruff, five years old, of Bellport, died of lockjaw yesterday. She was vaccinated Monday of last week. Her arm began to swell a few hours afterward and she became ill. Wednesday her parents and doctor believed her past all danger.
Money on call loaned at 1 @ 1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Times has this dispatch, sent from Rio Janeiro on Dec. 3, and forwarded via Montevideo:

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, Dec. 7 -- The fishermen of Belford and Port Monmouth held a meeting Tuesday to oppose the proposed law prohibiting pound fishing along the shore. A large number of the residents of these villages make their living almost wholly by pound fishing, and the passing of a law against pound fishing would ruin many of them.

Alderman Arthur J. Heaney of Brooklyn appeared yesterday before the Columbian Audit Commission, which met in City Auditor Weber's private office. Mr. Heaney explained his connection with Bandmaster Deverell's contract for music supplied to the Columbian parade in October, 1892.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 7 -- The committee of the Presbyterian General Assembly to recommend such action as will result in closer relation with the Church theological seminaries, which had been in session since Tuesday, adjourned late this afternoon. The Rev. W.D. Moore, the Secretary of the committee, said this evening:

The southwest corner of Waverley Place and West Tenth Street has been sold by James M. Gano to Edward Dodd for private parties. The dimensions of the plot are 23 by 85, and three three-story brick buildings are on it. The price paid was $41,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Philadelphia Traction opened up at 97 1/2, an advance of over 1 per cent. from yesterday's closing. Its friends have now become prophets, and are betting on prices. There is very little stock for sale, and the clique brokers and a few traders bid it up with a good deal of confidence.

Capt. Joseph J. Lawrence, one of the best-known and most successful ship masters of this port, died suddenly yesterday morning of heart disease at his home, 53 West Seventy-fifth Street. He was in his seventy-fourth year. He was born May 20, 1820, being the eldest son of Joseph Lawrence, a prominent resident of New-London, Conn.

Sandow, the strong man who is performing at Koster and Bial's, has been practicing a new feat of strength, which he calls "getting it in the neck," of which he intends to make a public exhibition on Monday. He gave a private exhibition of this feat yesterday. Sandow "gets it in the neck" with three large sacks of flour, each of which weighs 145 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A severe rebuke has been visited upon a naval officer. Assistant Secretary McAdoo has carried out that part of the court-martial sentence which called for a public reprimand of Lieut. Edward D. Bostick. The accused officer was charged with abusing a sentry, and by giving the countersign in a tone of voice loud enough to destroy its secrecy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Although the tone of the market was firmer than yesterday, it was dull. The list of stocks dealt in was very narrow, and the dealing in those in which sales were recorded was limited. Less than 500 shares of West Chicago were traded in at 151 3/4 @ 152 1/2, and only 50 shares of North Chicago at 253.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- A conference of the temperance committees of the several ecclesiastical bodies of the State was held in the rooms of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union Tuesday. The object of the gathering was to formulate a society for the purpose of promoting temperance legislation.

Miss Maud Lancaster of London gave another exhibition of her so-called "mind reading" in the parlors of the St. James Hotel yesterday afternoon and succeeded in mystifying most of those present, but when Dr. Austin Flint put her to the test Miss Lancaster's "psychic power" did not prove equal to the emergency.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Dec. 7 -- Miss Gertrude Wellington Cochran and C.L. Sidney Carrere were married this evening at the home of the bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cochran, on Richmond Terrace. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. K. Winchester Donald, rector of Holy Trinity Church, Boston, assisted by the Rev. Archdeacon Johnson of Christ Church, New-Brighton.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day, both on the floor and in the galleries, with members and others eager to hear the inaugural speech of M. Dupuy, the newly-elected President of the Chamber. M. Dupuy thanked the Chamber for the honor it had done him. He hoped, he said, to show the strictest impartiality in his treatment of all party speakers.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Phonograph men were at war in the Chancery Court today over contempt proceedings. The outcome of it was that Vice Chancellor Van Fleet granted an order for taking testimony in the case of the Edison United Pnonoin the case of the Edison United Phonograph Works and the North American Phonograph Company.

One of the manufacturers who is attacking the Wilson bill is Mr. JOHN L. HOUSTON, President of the Hartford Carpet Company, a gentleman who for many years has been prominent in the carpet industry. He is "greatly disappointed," and he joins the chorus of the Republicans who fill the air with gloomy predictions.

The cozy little clubhouse on West Thirty-third Street for college graduates who belong to the Greek letter fraternity familiarly known as the Alpha Delt has half a hundred oils and water colors by American artists about the walls of its parlors, billard and dining room. They are lent by the artists, and have been hung with some skill.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Every one who thinks he knows anything about politics in Chicago was busy to-day figuring out the majority which his candidate for Mayor is going to receive at the coming election. There was not an Alderman in the City Hall who did not have a tab, the correctness of which he was willing to swear by.

An afternoon paper yesterday printed what purported to be a violent repudiation from the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst of an interview in The New-York Times of yesterday, in which the doctor was quoted as making, while on the subject of the recent wholesale evictions of women, the following remark regarding them:

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Dec. 8 -- The ship Beaconsfield, Capt. Besteinsens, arrived at Port Angels this evening, sixteen days from Honolulu, having sailed from there Nov. 22, four days after the barkentine Klickitat.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- A severe storm is prevailing on the west coast of Great Britain. At Greenock, Scotland, the quays are submerged by the extraordinarily high tide. Several of the Highland mail steamers have been compelled to return to Greenock. All vessels arriving in the Clyde report having experienced terrible weather.

All three of the contestants in the coming billiard match are in the city practicing for the fray. They have not held any meeting to decide upon the officials as yet, but they will probably arrive at some settlement at a conference to be held in the warerooms of the Brunswick Balke-Collender Company this afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- The schooner Transit arrived late this evening bringing the following letter from the United Press correspondent at Honolulu:
Inspector McLaughlin and many men who know Robert Williams, who is under arrest for conspiracy, believe that he is Robert Williams Davey, a noted English criminal.

Frederick Gebhard has begun suit in the Supreme Court against Charles W. Aby, a veterinary surgeon, who for several years was manager of his stock farm in Middletown, Cal., demanding an accounting. He alleges Dr. Aby owes him $12,932.70. Dr. Aby is now manager of Mrs. Langtry's stock farm, which adjoins Mr. Gebhard's farm.

"For every 2,000 women who are turned homeless and friendless into the cold wintry streets, with every man's hand against them, there are 20,000 men as guilty who are sitting in comfortable homes, surrounded with luxury, who pose as honored and respected members of society."

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 8 -- Shortly after the promotion of Gen. George D. Ruggles to be Adjutant General of the Army, statements were published to the effect that to him alone was due, on the night of March 24, and on the morning of March 25, 1865, the credit for repulsing Gen. Gordon in front of Petersburg, and preventing a great disaster to the Army of the Potomac.
The following letter was sent to the editor of The New-York Sun by Minister Mendonca:

William J. Gaynor's friends have made another move in connection with the election troubles at Gravesend. Now that the John Y. McKane contempt of court case is practically ended, Justice of the Peace Kenneth F. Sutherland will have to answer the serious charges that have been preferred against him.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 8 -- The Pennsylvania Company has secured control of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad, and is now in possession of the property, and will operate it as an extension of the Pan Handle Road. The officials of the Pennsylvania, at their last annual inspection, made a trip over the road, and its formal transfer was decided upon, but the deal was not fully consummated until a day or two ago.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 8 -- Four notices of protest of checks were received at the dry goods and notion store of Henry Wessels this morning. These were from the harvest that is now being reaped by the forgeries of a young man in Philadelphia and New-York who for the last three weeks has been buying goods in those cities and representing himself as Henry Wessels, Jr., and as a buyer for the firm.

"I am glad to introduce you to a woman older than Susan B. Anthony," said Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake at the meeting of the New-York City Woman Suffrage League Thursday evening. "We are all disfranchised women, but she is the most disfranchised of us all."

When, a year ago about this time, the Lieutenant Governor of the State, who was to preside over the Senate, and the prospective Speaker of the Assembly met the "bosses" of the Democratic machine in this city to determine the composition of the legislative committee, it was justly regarded as rather scandalous.

Shortly after the boxing championships of the Amateur Athletic Union the American Athletic Club will hold an inter-city tournament in which the amateur tatic experts of Philadelphia, New-York, Jersey City, and Brooklyn will be pitted against the men who win the local championship honors. Secretary Coleman is already in possession of an entry list that is formidable in both quantity and quality.

If Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer escapes conviction on the charge of having poisoned Gustav Baum, or Ludwig Brandt, it will be by an extraordinary line of defense. His case, as it was presented in court yesterday, seems all but a hopeless one, and there must be forces in reserve which his lawyers have kept carefully in the dark, else it would seem useless to go to trial.

This morning The New-York Daily Times consists of TEN PAGES. Every newsdealer is bound to deliver the paper in its complete form, and any failure to do so should be reported at the Publication Office.

Reproductions of the ponderous iron key with which the front door of the French Bastile was locked and unlocked, which was presented to George Washington by Gen. Lafayette, and is now with the other Washington relics at Mount Vernon, are being widely distributed, with the view of calling the attention of the world to the merits of Robert S. Davis's newspaper, The Philadelphia Call.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The wheat market opened strong and with all the appearance of a bull campaign. As one remarked, a stick could be run through the pit and not touch a bear. The strength, however, was but short-lived. Somebody parted with a little wheat in one corner of the crowd, then another sold some, and very soon the selling became general.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Bankruptcy bill was defeated in the House to-day on a motion to strike out the enacting clause, by a vote of 142 to 111. This was an unexpectedly large vote against it, but the drift of the talk in the House has been strong during the last few days, and the prospect for its defeat gave confidence to its opponents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Mr. Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister to the United States, left Washington this evening for New-York, where he will remain several days. Just before his departure a reporter for the United Press asked for the particulars of the explosion on the America en route from St. Thomas to Martinique.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- Following close upon the death of William T. Coleman, leader of the Vigilance Committee of San Francisco, Ned McGowan, a notorious character of early days, who has been seriously ill for several months, died this morning, aged eighty years.

Average prices ruled much higher at the Kellogg combination sale of trotting stock yesterday. The offerings were mainly from Bundle White's farm at Danbury, Conn., and the clearing out of the stock of Col. Walter Cutting of this city, whose farm is at Pittsfield, Mass.

No doubt many persons were surprised when they read the announcement that Vladimir de Pachmann would play one of Johann Nepomuk Hummel's piano concertos at yesterday's afternoon concert of the Symphony Society. Hummel's name is unknown to the average music lover of to-day, and it was only the initiated who could perceive a reason for the peculiar little Russian's choice.

GREENPORT, L.I., Dec. 8 -- Gardiner's Island Point Lighthouse is said to be unsafe. It is reported the foundation walls have been undermined by the recent storms and high tides to such an extent the structure is in danger of toppling over. Keeper Miller declares he is afraid to remain in it over night.

Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent. Time money was in abundant supply, but the demand was light. Rates were 2 per cent. for thirty days, 2 1/2 for sixty days, 3@3 1/2 for ninety days to four months, and 3 1/2 @4 for four to six months.

Mr. H.G. PROUT, the accomplished editor of the Railroad Gazette, contributes to the North American Review an interesting article on "Railroad Accidents in the United States and England." He gives as specific figures as possible to support the general impression that railway travel is safer in the United Kingdom than in the United States, and then examines accessible data to determine how much the difference in safety is and what is the cause of it.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music was filled, last night, with handsomely-costumed women and their escorts. The occasion was the annual fair, held in aid of the Brooklyn Industrial School Association and Home for Destitute Children.

Herman Jacobson, a journeyman watchmaker who lived at 343 East Fifty-first Street, and his seven-year-old daughter, Dagma, have been missing since Wednesday morning. He told his wife that he was going to a dentist, and, taking his little girl along, went out of the house and did not return.

A warning was given yesterday by Collector Kilbreth to the manager of the show at the Grand Central Palace. There are three exhibitors at the show from the Chicago Fair, whose goods are still in bond, under a special statute extending the bonded period to Jan. 15. Since the show opened the Collector has been obliged to keep inspectors at the show to prevent sales from these exhibits.

The Tribune has made the horrifying discovery that the Wilson bill puts crude petroleum on the free list, and it asserts that "men engaged in the petroleum industry stood aghast" when this was revealed to them. We notice that Congressman DALZELL of Pennsylvania is also "standing aghast" and saying that everybody connected with the industry in America will go to the poorhouse.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The trial of the Austin insurance case will begin in New-York next Monday. Twenty-two Adirondack guides will be in attendance. Their fares have been paid to New-York, and they expect to receive per diem remuneration while they are away from home. Many of them have never seen city sights, and to those the trip will be a treat, whether the insurance company is successful in the suit or not.

The father of long-distance pedestriaulsm, Edward Payson Weston, although well advanced in years, thinks that he can walk as fast as he did a quarter of a century ago. After a rest of some years he has decided to try the game once more, and he will start on his walk from Bowling Green in this city to the Capitol in Albany on Monday evening, Dec. 18, at 9 o'clock.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- More attention was paid to Philadelphia Traction to-day than to any of the other stocks. It opened at 98. Some attempt was made to bid it up, but it declined to 97 and closed at 97 3/4. There was not a single transaction to-day in Metropolitan Traction; 106 was nominally bid, and a few hundred shares were for sale at 107.

Charles Russell writes to The Times and says: "I notice in an announcement sent out by the committee having in charge the coming boxing and wrestling championships of the Metropolitan Association that they claim it is absolutely necessary to belong to some club holding membership in the Metropolitan Association. Will you kindly tell a constant reader just why they assume to dictate such terms and where their authority comes in.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Mandamus proceedings are to be taken by the Isaac L. Rice committee of Reading bondholders to compel the receivers of the company to allow them access to the Reading stock list. A representative of the committee a day or two ago made a formal demand for the list, but was refused, the ground being taken that he had no right to examine it.
The following letter has been sent to Congressman William J. Coombs in Washington by John Gibb of Mills Gibb:

The regular meeting of the Tammany Hall organization of the Eighteenth Assembly District, held at Washington Hall, corner of Eighth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, last evening, was largely attended. The unusual number of the members who came out was attributed to the rumors concerning a possible change of leadership to follow the admission of ex-Police Justice Henry Murray and his considerable following to full Tammany fellowship.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Times has this dispatch sent from Rio Janeiro on Dec. 5 and forwarded from Montevideo:

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The United States authorities have determined to suppress the bond and investment companies which are operating all over the country. Post Office Inspector Stuart received from Washington to-day a list of over fifty concerns operating in much the same manner as the Guarantee Investment Company of Chicago, whose officers were convicted in Judge Grosscup's court.

Capt. Charles E. Bowers, prominent in the Nationalist movement, died yesterday at his home in Arlington, Mass., of blood poisoning.
