He served with distinction in the war of the rebellion and was severely wounded at Gettysburg. He was noted throughout the country for his ardent espousal of the Nationalist cause, was one of the organizers of the first Nationalist Club, and at the time of his death was Secretary of the club.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 8 -- Miss Jennie L. Patterson, assistant teacher in the Uniondale school, who was recently suspended and refused her salary by the Trustees because she declined to act as janitress of the school building, has engaged counsel and appealed her case to State Superintendent of Schools Crooker.

Members of the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, met last night to celebrate the seventieth birthday of their pastor, the Rev. Robert Collyer. The pulpit was occupied by the Rev. John W. Chadwick of Brooklyn, who presided. The front of the pulpit was a huge bank of roses, smilax, and lilies of the valley.

The story is an old one, but it is none the less interesting because of that. It tells of a happy home broken up, of a wife severing all ties and linking her fate to that of an adventurer. The sad tale is briefly outlined in a letter which the parish priest of Shoreham, Sussex, England, addressed to the Commissioner of Immigration at this port.

Baroness Tautphoeus, the English novelist, whose vivacious stories of Bavarian life, "The Initials" and "Quits," are still numbered among the most widely read works of fiction, died at Munich, Nov. 12. She always lived a retired life, and had published nothing for many years, and her death seems not to have been regarded in Germany as a matter of news.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Secretary Lament and the Army Chief of Ordnance, Gen. Flagler, paid an interesting visit to the army gun factory at Watervliet, N.Y., and Secretary Lamont gained considerable information which will be serviceable during his term of office. The visit was mainly educational in its purpose, as the Secretary knew little of the practical working of such an institution as the army ordnance department has developed at Watervliet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The tea given from 4 to 7 o'clock this afternoon by Gen. and Mrs. Rochester to announce the debut of their daughter, was an elegant entertainment, at which there was a large attendance of the resident society people, in addition to representatives of the army, navy, and official circles.

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday a communication from Superintendent Byrnes was read recommending, "for police reasons," the transfers of several Sergeants and patrolmen asked for by the recently-transferred Captains according to general usage. Capts. Donohue, O'Connor, Schmittberger, Stephenson, Cortright, Cross, and Haughey were the ones who requested that their old Sergeants might be allowed to help them in their new commands.

Purdon Robinson, Fred Grant Young, and Frederic Edward McKay gave a reception, with music, yesterday afternoon, from 4 until 7 o'clock, at their apartments in the Mendelssohn Glee Club Building, 113 West Fortieth Street. Mme. Kate Rolla, Mrs. Tyler Dutton, Miss Ruth Thompson, Mrs Gerritt Smith, Ritchie Ling, and Purdon Robinson sang.

Following the announcement of a "raid" upon the disorderly houses in the precinct where these abound comes the news of a transfer of Police Captains in a dozen precincts. The raid and the transfer are two devices that have been adopted in the police force from a time whereof the memory of man runneth not to the contrary.

It is now an assured fact that an eleven of Philadelphia cricket players will visit England next season. Four years ago a team of Quakers went across and made a good record, but the matches were not played against strong elevens, and consequently the victories do not place them as high as they apparently seem to. They played the Gentlemen of Middlesex, Surrey, Gloucester, Sussex, and other teams, from which professionals were barred.

N.J. Schloss Co., the clothing dealers, who failed this week, were largely responsible for bringing together yesterday the Arbitration Committee of the Clearing House Association to pass upon a case growing out of the process known as check-kiting, in which the clothing house engaged.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The steamer Mangara of Glasgow, upon her arrival at South Shields to-day from Lisbon, reported that while she was passing the island of Ushant, off the coast of Brittany, her lookout reported that he saw a flashlight being displayed about too miles away. The Mangara bore down in the direction of the place where the light was being seen, and a large steamer was sent foundering.
Mayor Boody of Brooklyn has retired from politics. He is doubtless out for good. Before he became Mayor he was successful as a business man. He is going back to business again.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: "What can be the matter with Dr. Parkhurst?" even the friends of that clergyman will be impelled to inquire, after reading the interview with him in to-day's Times. Can the excess of cheap notoriety that has fallen to his share have turned his head and led to the unsettling of his mental balance?

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Prendergast, the assassin of Mayor Harrison, spoke his little set piece again this morning soon after the examination of veniremen was resumed in Judge Brentano's court. A venireman was being questioned as to the insanity phase of the case when Prendergast exclaimed: "Your Honor, your Honor.

The export to Germany of a half million dollars in gold is calling out some comment that displays more excitement than knowledge. The gold goes as silver or lead would, because it is worth enough more elsewhere than it is here to give a profit. No sane person ever supposed that the repeal of the Sherman act would forever prevent exports of gold.

The seventy-flfth annual dinner of the Wesleyan University Club was held at the St. Denis Hotel last evening. It was attended by about 100 members. After an hour of social greeting, the club held a business meeting and elected the following officers:

Josephine Ryan, the young woman who was arrested in Brooklyn for "vagrancy" and was also accused of stealing $400 from a politician, was discharged from custody yesterday by Justice Walsh in the Adams Street Police Court. The politician did not appear to prosecute her for the theft. Justice Walsh advised the woman to leave the city.

James Curtis otherwise known as "Blackey," because his countenance is a reminder of dark nights, and whose ways have for a long time bothered the police, was arrested in Frankfort Street yesterday afternoon. He was taken to the City Hall Station, but long after his departure Park Row was in a state of commotion.

George J. Gould and Superintendent Byrnes were in consultation in Police Headquarters for more than an hour yesterday forenoon. When the conference was over, both declined to say what was the subject discussed.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Dec. 8 -- P.M. Excessive dullness was about the only feature of to-day's stock market. The opening was very quiet, with St. Paul, Whisky, and Sugar the features, and they were all strong in the face of weakness in the general list.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 -- The depreciation of Ohio farm values, which was so strikingly shown in the work of the State Board of Equalization eighteen months ago, and the falling off in the population of the farming counties exhibited in the last Federal census, have their complement in the remarkable figures relating to children of school age presented in the annual report of the State School Commissioner.

To the number of those who have denounced the Walsh plan for securing State aid for parochial schools was added, yesterday, John A. McCall, President of the New-York Life Insurance Company. Mr. McCall was outspoken in his denunciation of the plan. He said:

The new Roman Catholic Church of All Saints, at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, of which the Rev. James W. Power is the rector, will be blessed by Archbishop Corrigan at 11 o'clock to-morrow. The new church, which is one of the handsomest in the city, cost $160,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Democrats of the Ways and Means Committee have completed their revision of the Revenue bill, or the customs part of it, and have sent it to the printer to be ready for submission to the whole committee next week.

American railway securities suffered a fractional reaction in the London market, Atchison only held its own, but the declines were not of consequence, as the market drooped more from lack of business than from any pressure to sell. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Atchison, 1/8, to 19 5/8.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 8 -- A tall, long-nosed, dark young man, speaking English with a German accent, has been swindling Newark citizens. He represents himself at different times as an agent of the Travel Art and Portrait Studio, the Metropolitan Portrait Company of Chicago, the Progressive Art Company, and the Wang Portrait Company, all of which are believed to be fictitious names used to facilitate the execution of his designs.

A report was in circulation last night that private dispatches from Rome had been received in this city which seemed to put beyond doubt the fact that Archbishop Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate, would speedily depart from this country for Rome, to be made a Cardinal. The report continued:

The preliminary bouts in the annual boxing tourney of the Pastime Athletic Club were decided last night in Maennerchor Hall, 203 East Fifty-sixth Street. The hall was well filled and several good bouts were witnessed. Maxwell E. More of the New-York Athletic Club acted as referee. The judges were W. Robertson, Outing Athletic Club, and P.H. O'Koefe. St. Agues's Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Though but little has been printed concerning the work of the War Records Office of the War Department, yet this has been a tremendous task. Forty-nine volumes, of nearly a thousand pages each, are completed, and furnish the most accurate history ever published of a nation's internecine war.

Those who have had much acquaintance with Moslems know that there are many common people -- as many women as men -- who seem to have more or less clear ideas of spiritual life, and strive to attain something higher than mere formality and verbal confession; who feel their personal unworthiness and hope only in God.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- There has been an interesting test at Sandy Hook of the Merriam percussion fuse. Some time ago, when there were tests of this device, defects were noticeable. These defects were corrected. The official report of the latest tests says: "The fuse is made to perform its functions with certainty, and absolute safety in transportation and handling is secured."

The full record of the recent comments of the British Admiralty on the loss of the war ship Victoria conveys a most impressive lesson. The court-martial which considered the case, while paying proper attention to certain questions of personal responsibility involved in the calamity, declared that it did not feel called upon to express any opinion as to "the causes of the capsizing of the Victoria."

If any further demonstration were really needed that New-York is a poor market for poor stock, yesterday's sale of trotting-bred horses at Madison Square Garden would supply the deficiency. Most of the offerings were fairly well bred, but individually they were culls, not exactly lame, halt, and blind, but there was some little "out" with a good many of them.

Alfred Orr, janitor of an apartment house, 193 Garfield Place, was badly scalded with steam and had his nose cut and broken by flying iron while attending to his boilers last evening. Going into the basement, he saw there was rather a high pressure on the boilers.

There has been a slaughter of the amiable but imperfect work of beginners which usually every Autumn converges on the National Academy. Students who did not dare to hope for admission to the Spring exhibition were wont to pluck up a spirit and trust to the gentler standards of the autumnal show. They trusted not always in vain; for these exhibitions have always had a singularly poor repute because of them and their likes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 9 -- No decision may be looked for in the McKane case earlier than Tuesday, and perhaps not then. The briefs of counsel have not all arrived, and none of the papers will be opened by Justice Barnard before Monday.
One day a Yale freshman, showing a friend from home around the campus, nodded at a time-worn, rather dingy building in Elm Street, New-Haven, and said:

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 9 -- The trial of Stephen C. Duryea ended to-night. The jury returned in half an hour with a verdict of guilty. The convicted man was sentenced to be confined in the county jail one year and to pay a fine of $500.

The pleasantest paths of life, say the poets, are those along which duty and inclination trip hand in hand. Admitting that this is so, it follows that the forthcoming Charity Ball should be as profitable as it will be delightful socially. The Charity Ball, while a social function of importance, appeals always to the tenderest feelings of those whose hearts and purses are open for the relief of those who are deserving of aid.

Charles Dickens wrote, in "David Copperfield": "There is no substitute for thoroughgoing, ardent, sincere earnestness." The great novelist did not know Thomas Byrnes, Superintendent of Police in this city. But had he known of the Superintendent and his life before he penned the words of his masterpiece, and thought to teach that life's lesson to his readers, he could have penned no sentence which would have been more applicable than the one quoted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Much has been said lately about the literary activity of the West, and particularly of this city. There has undoubtedly been much truth in the statements made that the "rowdy West" was fast becoming civilized and educated, and that genius was budding on the great prairies this side of the Ohio River.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Despite the reports of the McKinleyites in this city and Orange, the employes in the hat industry will not protest against the passage of the Wilson bill. A conference of the leaders among the men was held last night. The statement was made that the rumors which stated that the trade would be ruined by the passage of the bill came from the employers, and not from the men.

"An All-Around Boy. The Life and Letters of Ralph Robinson Green," (Randolph,) is an inspiring, though a sad, piece of writing. Ralph Green had not fame, save among his schoolfellows, and he had fortune yet to win, for he was a youth not yet twenty by some years. Then why this volume of his life and letters?

Heine gives a description of Shylock, which was the first heroic part in which he beheld Kean. He vindicates the application to Shylock of the term heroic, saying, concerning his appearance: "He did not play it like a broken-down old man, a kind of Schewa (?) of hatred, as our Devrient does, but like a real hero.

There have been many sales of trotting-bred horses in this city at which pedigrees have commanded excessive prices, whether the individual was good, bad, or indifferent. There have been other sales where fairly good individuals have sold for less than anticipated, because they were not bred in just those lines which breeders then considered most desirable.

A little bag of dynamite, which lies in the Old Slip Police Station, may furnish a startling clue to the mysterious explosion and fire which destroyed the steamship City of Alexandria of the New-York and Cuba Mail Line off the coast of Cuba on Nov. 1 last.

This handsome volume deals in an orderly and careful manner with an American industry which not hitherto could boast a written history. The author claims for it that it is not merely a compilation, but that it has been based almost entirely upon thorough personal investigations. It is this, probably, that gives the book its individuality and "go," in addition to its value as a book of reference.

To most readers of Emerson the entire contents of this volume will be new, and to all readers portions of it will be. The paper from which the title comes was read as a lecture at Harvard more than twenty years ago, and was then an outgrowth of an intellectual project which had first entered his mind very early in life.

Mcdest George F. Slosson, ambitious Frank C. Ives, and wiry little Jacob Schaefer will begin their triangular billiard tournament in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall to-morrow night. It will be a fourteen-inch balk-line game, and, judging from the opinions expressed by clever followers of billiards, it ought to equal any tournament ever held in this city.

The Corsican loves not work, neither is he greedy for gold; but he is ambitious, an eager politician, keenly desirous of place and power, of anything, in short, that may set him above his fellow-men. The word "politician," however, must be understood in a local sense. The questions that agitate the Continent have small concern for him; his politics begin and end with the triumph or aggrandizement of his clan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The few New-York State politicians who were sitting in the lobby of the Arlington at 9 o'clock to-night pricked up their ears when they saw Charles W. Hackett of Utica, Secretary of the Republican State Executive Committee, and George R. Malby of Ogdensburg walk in and register.

The introduction of bridge whist in the New-York Whist Club has led to the withdrawal of a number of members and the formation of a new whist club. The New-York Whist Club claims to be the oldest one in the city. Its present officers are T.H. Herrick, President; T.B. Houston, Vice President, and Wiliam G. Street, Jr., Secretary.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Deputy Attorney General Hogan to-day made an application before Judge Herrick, at Special Term, for the appointment of an auxiliary receiver for the American Casualty Insurance Company of Baltimore. J. Aspinall Hodges of New-York appeared as attorney for the Mercantile Trust Company of Baltimore, which was appointed receiver of the company in Maryland last month, and asked that it be appointed receiver in this State.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 9 -- The monthly meeting of the Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad was held this afternoon. It was generally expected that a successor to Ezekiel Hayes Trowbridge, the late senior Director of the road, who died here two weeks ago, would be appointed this afternoon, but President Charles P. Clark said to-night that the election might not take place even at the meeting next month.

From The London Sketch. The giant salamander (Megalobatrachus maximus) is the largest living species of the class Amphibia, and so justifies its claim to its specific name. It is a native of Japan and Tibet and belongs to the same order of amphibians as the common newt of our English ponds and ditches, from which, however, it differs greatly in habit, being entirely aquatic.

Mr. Story's dedication to an "esprit pur, pui plane sur mon horizon, loin" -- this word, should be "lointain" -- "et pale, mais toujours me poussant vers un nouvel essor," is Blake-like, but not inordinate to a modern mind. The charge that Blake was insane had not grave provocation, and it seems sad that it should still be regarded as worthy of careful reputation.

Apropos of the annual banquet of the Sons of the American Revolution at Delmonico's Dec. 16, it is now announced that the Daughters of the American Revolution have tendered to Prof. John Fiske and the ladies of his family a complimentary reception, to be held at the Hotel New Netherland on the afternoon preceding the banquet, from 3 to 6 o'clock.

Dr. Henry Van Dyke's religious criticism of religious paintings has the value and the interest of the classic shoemaker's criticism on the sandals of Apelles in the statue. This criticism, in the sculptor's view, was authoritative. But if there had been several classic shoemakers, there might have been several critical opinions, and perhaps the artist, realizing that even experts vary, would not have retouched his statue's sandals.

A goodly number of American citizens of German birth or descent met at the rooms of the Reform Club yesterday afternoon to arrange for the organization of the German-American Reform Union as a local political body. The object of the organization is to take an active part in the attempt to secure reform in the conduct of municipal affairs.

Two distinguished Buffalonians were at the Hoffman House yesterday -- Postmaster General Wilson Shannon Bissell and George Bleisteln, proprietor of The Buffalo Courier. Mr. Bissell left Washington on the midnight train Friday. He dined with friends last evening, and will start for Buffalo by the New-York Central Railway this evening for a week's visit to his old home.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- For the first time in a very long while Englishmen are finding it part of their political duties to take notice of what the House of Lords is doing. Today is the fifth or sixth occasion this year in which the Parliamentary reports of the morning press give their chief attention to proceedings in the gilded chamber.

Every glacier carries with it, imbedded in its undersurface, numbers of rocks and stones which, during the slow but unceasing motion over its bed, crush and grind down all rocky projections, producing in the end gently-rounded or almost flat surfaces even on the hardest and toughest rocks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- The United Press correspondent at Honolulu, writing under date of Nov. 22, per brig W.G. Irwin, which arrived late this afternoon, says:

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 9 -- The cruiser Marblehead's glorious record of 18.94 knots for four hours over the Long Island Sound official seventy-two-mile course Thursday has been discounted by the calculations of the Government trial board.

Once more the State Electric Light and Power Company makes an attempt to get the right to supply the people of Brooklyn with electric lights from some source other than the "ring" company. It has sent to Mayor Boody another request that it be allowed the right to compete for the privilege of furnishing lights to the city.
After the romantic play, "It is an old story," said one. "Why not represent modern life, which is more surprising, more varied, more and more amusing than anything?"

SING SING, Dec. 9 -- Henry J. Baker was one of the most liberal contributors to the building fund of the Highland Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church's new edifice, which was completed four years ago. According to prearrangement, the body of Mr. Baker, who had died before the church was completed, was placed in a vault under the tower.

Capt. Max Schmittberger, the "new broom" of the "Tenderloin," is certainly, as far as can be judged from his work during the few days he has been there, doing his best to sweep his precinct clean of disorderly houses.

The fifth lecture in the series, "Considerations on the Art of Painting." by John La Farge, was delivered Friday before an appreciative audience in the lecture room of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. La Farge said:

When the Seventh Regiment of this city hurried to the defense of the National Capital in 1861 a young New-York boy went with it as a Sergeant and served through that brief but exciting campaign. This boy became the soldierly, handsome man who now rides at the head of the local brigade of citizen soldiery wearing the uniform of a Brigadier General -- Louis Fitzgerald.

Market movements of the week nave been of little account. We have two forces at work tending to produce a dead-lock -- on the bull side, idle money in amount larger than ever before known; on the bear side, continually diminishing railroad earnings. The earnings make it impossible to bull stocks beyond occasional rallies on the short interest in them; the easy money and consequent low rates of interest make holders reluctant to sell.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- From the way Lehigh Valley acted to-day it looks as if the stockholders had begun to realize that not only will there be no dividend declared in January, but that it may be a good while before another one will be in sight. The moment traders discovered long stock for sale they Jumped on it.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- In an article published in The Journal a few days ago, M. Emile Zola introduces, in his own precise way, the author of the celebrated, if still discussed, "Reve," and the composer of the present triumph of the Opera Comique, the "Attaque du Moulin," Alfred Bruneau -- remember the name; if I mistake not, you will hear it long and often.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Dec. 9 -- P.M. The stock market to-day was extremely dull. Distilling and Cattle Feeding was the only stock on the list which was at all active, and it was weak. Immediately after the opening it sold at 30 1/8 and then declined steadily to 27 5/8 and closed at 27 7/8, a net loss of 2 1/8 points.

Col. Matthew Ralston Kihtzing of the United States Marine Corps died yesterday at his home, 216 Park Place, Brooklyn. Col. Kintzing was born in Philadelphia in January, 1823, and was thirty-eight years in the service of the United States. When eighteen years old he received a commission as Second Lieutenant in the Marine Corps, and was detailed for duty on the United States sloop of war Vincennes.

COLUMBUS, Ind., Dec. 9 -- Andrew H.H. Davidson, a New-York City attorney, has caused a search of the records in the County Clerk's office to be instituted for the record of a divorce supposed to have been granted to the present Baroness Von Roques. The proceedings were supposed to have been begun in Clark County and finally brought here on a change of venue.

Four legacies of 25 cents each result from the will of Matthew Stanley, late of Watervliet, probated before Surrogate Conway yesterday. The estate consists of real estate valued at $7,500, mortgaged for $5,000, and $2,500 worth of personal estate. The will devises to the testator's wife, Eviline, the income of one-third of the property during her lifetime.

The Century Company has rearranged in its rooms at 33 East Seventeenth Street, Union Square, the exhibit it made at the fair in Chicago. The public is invited to visit it, and it is too interesting: and too valuable an initiation into the mysteries of artistic and literary reproduction not to be appreciatively attended.

Two new applicants for public favor appeared at Mr. Damrosch's matinee yesterday. They were Mr. David Bispham, an English baritone, and Mr. Alberto Jonas, a Spanish pianist. Mr. Bispham selected as the medium for his introduction Loewe's ballad, "Archibald Douglas." The gentleman has a fairly-good baritone voice, which he uses with a goodly number of faults.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- At midnight it was announced officially that forty-eight persons were wounded by the explosion. This list does not include those who received merely slight scratches and bruises.

Messrs. Tiffany Co. of this city have just delivered the several prizes offered, by the State of New-York for superiority in marksmanship. The State annually appropriates a sum of money for four prizes -- a special State prize, and one each for the First, Second, and Third Brigade of the State militia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- There is a difference of opinion among post and company commanders regarding the consolidated mess. Last year the system was in operation at ten posts; this year the general messes have been extended to four more posts; at other posts the company messes continue.
It was a shocking story of cruelty that was brought out in the Harlem Police Court yesterday by Agent Thomas Moore of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Superintendent Stump has directed Commissioner Senner at New-York to take the Mudrick family, parents and six children, to the proper court and have them committed to the proper charitable institution. The family has been buffeted about between Ellis Island and police stations in New-York for several weeks, both city and Federal officers declining to receive them.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- The committee appointed by the Eastern creditors of Wallace, Sloat Wallace, the failed boot and shoe dealers of Chicago, presented their report at a meeting of creditors in this city this afternoon. It reported the liabilities to be $122,848, and assets about $49,000. There is also about $12,000 worth of consigned goods not estimated in the assets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The market for wheat was dull to-day, but the undertone was firm. The only apparent reason why the decline of yesterday was not continued this morning was that the unanimous sentiment was so bearish that traders had oversold themselves, and purchases to cover supported prices. The range covered but 1/4 @ 3/8 c, May closing that much higher than yesterday, and at the outside.

FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 9 -- The Long Island Baptist Association, it has been learned, will not take action in the case of the Rev. Charles Edwards of this village. He is the minister who, several months ago, published a little book written by himself and entitled, "The New-York Hooroarer; or, A New-York Reporter's Trip to the Infernal Regions."

Thirty of the 750 operators at the Western Union Telegraph Company's main office in this city will be placed on the "waiting list" to-morrow, each man to remain idle for a week. The cause for the establishment of the waiting list, it is said, is the general depression. The company was unwilling to discharge some of its competent employes.

The annual dinner of the New-York Fire Department will take place at the Murray Hill Hotel next Wednesday evening. The dinner is given by the Volunteer Firemen's Association, which includes members of the department, both officers and men, who have seen more than twenty years' service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Dwight L. Moody has decided to come to Washington this Winter, accompanied by Ira D. Sankey. The date has been fixed for the 1st of February, and the meetings will be held during the month.

Beginning to-day, the New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

Annie Murphy, thirty-one years old, the dissipated wife of "Larry" Murphy, a laborer, living at 400 First Avenue, was so seriously burned while asleep in a watchman's shanty on the north side of East Thirty-third Street, near First Avenue, yesterday morning that she died in consequence at Bellevue Hospital some hours after admission.

During my father's mortal illness there was ample opportunity for him to ease his affectionate anxiety regarding my future welfare by precepts drawn from his own experience, for the embers lingered long on the hearthstone. He and I had been comrades too thoroughly for any traditional restraint to come between us.

Beginning to-day, The New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

The fencing members of the New-York Athletic Club feel very proud of their victory last Thursday night over the team from the Fencers' Club in the third annual competition for the silver challenge cup presented by the Central Turn Verein. By this victory the New-York Athletic Club members have won the contest twice and the Fencers' Club once.

Beginning to-day, The New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

Frank Titman, or Francis Rotherford, was committed to Raymond Street Jail by Justice Tighe in the Butier Street Police Court, Brooklyn, in default of $300 bail for abandoning his wife, Mrs. Alice Rotherford. His examination will take place Dec. 13.

The voyage of the American Line steamship New-York from Southampton to this port which was ended yesterday was somewhat delayed to an accident to her machinery. On Wednesday night the starboard engine became disabled, and throughout the night only the port engine was in operation.

While the prices realized for trotting-bred horses in the past week at auction have been moderately low, it cannot be said that the most have not brought every penny that they were worth to the public. In buying horses people want something besides speed. Conformation, good sense, and style with speed brought the best of prices.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Citizens who, from necessity or choice, adopt as their avocation the pursuit of bargains, have been kept busy in this city for the past two weeks in trying to locate the cheapest provision dealer in town. Ordinarily this would be no difficult matter, for Orange is essentially a high-priced town, so far as household necessities and commodities are concerned.

Washington Letter to The Philadelphia Times. With the name of Sheridan is closely linked all the pomp and splendor of a victorious General. One thinks of Him at the head of dauntless men sweeping down between the blue Virginia hills, his pathway lit by the flames of burning houses and his stern hand carrying havoc and destruction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary Lamont is endeavoring to find means by which the army deserters shall cost the Government less.

Beginning to-day, The New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 9 -- The annual meeting of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad stockholders was held to-day at the Cleveland headquarters of that road. As there are no American stockholders the English owners were represented by proxy. Those in attendance were President Whitehead, New-York; John Tod, E.R. Perkins, Fayette Brown, Samuel Mather, W.J. McKinnie, and J.T. Wann, Cleveland; J.M. Ferris, Toledo; E.A. Wheeler, Sharon, Penn.; Henry B. Perkins, Warren, and Simon Perkins, Sharon.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 9 -- Although a great hue and cry has been raised by many over the danger of the football game to contestants as it has been played this season, Dartmouth men do not seem to have been greatly troubled. Neither the Faculty nor students have thought of advising any changes in the present method of the playing.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In your issue of the 1st inst. you give proper prominence to the importance of cities in the future construction of State constitutions. It is not alone the aggregation of population where "machine" politics may be most conveniently applied that enhances the chances of bad government in the cities themselves and in the State of which they are a part.

At 8:15 some one exclaimed: "I do believe I see moving specks out there beyond the gate." Up went all our glasses, and there they were! We recognized more and more distinctly six horsemen coming, and evidently coming fast, for they grew bigger and sharper as each second passed. One seemed to be in front, the other five behind.

The New-York Weekly Times is making an offer of books for the holidays which every one should read. It is to be found on the eighth page of The Weekly Times, and explains how any subscriber to The Weekly Times may secure any one of nearly 400 choice books for a very small sum. The books are fine enough for any library and have been selected with great care.

James C. Bergen, partner of Receiver Dykman of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, moved before Justice Bartlett, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, for an order permitting Mr. Dykman to bring one or more actions against the Directors of the bank.

The race last night at Madison Square Garden, in which "Jack" Alexandre, riding two ponies, tried to defeat Charles Ashinger in a twenty-five-mile bicycle race, proved to be a fizzle. Alexandre, in making the short turns, lost his stirrups and once broke his stirrup straps. He rode about two and one-half miles when he got a bad fail and quit. Ashinger continued and finished about twelve miles.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- The first 100 rounds of the prescribed official Government test for the Brown segmental wire gun were completed to-day. This gun was constructed to withstand very much higher pressures than the ordinary "built-up" guns, and consequently the test prescribed was much more severe than that ordinarily laid down.
It is likely that no further details of the mysterious suit toy Mrs. Zella Nicolaus against George J. Gould for $40,000 will be made public until the case comes to trial, if it ever does.

Mayor Boody's speech at the dinner of the St. Nicholas Society in Brooklyn last week was an extremely graceful and clever one. As he intimated, with something of a tone of pathos in his voice, it was the song of a dying swan, and the trumpet of the moribund rang clear and resonant. Nothing could more brighten and dignify the exit of his Honor from the stage of politics than that admirably-composed and well-delivered speech.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The Anarchists of London will attempt to hold a meeting in Trafalgar Square to-morrow. A repetition of last Sunday's scenes is expected. The police will not allow the meeting to be held.

The Imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $10,001,621, of which amount $1,149,406 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $82,158 and the exports of specie were $1,521,580.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The forthcoming report of State Entomologist J.A. Lintner contains some very interesting facts. Dr. Lintner says that insects, in number of species, exceed by far all the rest of the animal kingdom combined. They are believed to be tenfold more numerous than all of the mammals, birds, fishes, reptiles, myriapods, crustaceans, worms, mollusks, radiates, and protozoans united.

A question affecting the validity of the Clearing House regulation that a bank acting as clearing agent must give twenty-four hours' notice of its intention to cease clearing for its client bank is likely to be submitted to judicial determination soon. The suit in prospect grows out of the relations of the Madison Square Bank and the St. Nicholas Bank.

THURSDAY, DEC. 14 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Edward D. O'Brien, referee, 198 Lenox Avenue, southeast corner of One Hundred and Twentieth Street, 19.8 by 85, four-story and basement brick and stone dwelling. Due on judgment, $13,281; on prior mortgage, $21,000.

Secretary Barnard of the Board of County Canvassers of Kings County said yesterday that on account of the bad condition of the returns it had taken longer to canvass the figures of the late election than any preceding it. In over 600 election districts the returns were returned to the canvassers for correction of errors.

The high-tariff press is still trying to "fool the farmer" by telling him that a reduction of the high McKinley duties on certain farm products would put him in the poorhouse. A Vermont paper says that "all over the State live stock may be bought at panic prices," and that "good young horses trained to work are quoted in many localities at $30 to $40 per head."

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The time of the Reichstag was taken up to-day with a humdrum debate on bills of minor importance. In the lobbies also the subject, of the commission on the proposed Boerse taxes was languidly discussed, until the news came of the Anarchist outrage in the French Chamber.

Beginning to-day,The New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

Members of the New-York Athletic Club opened the doors of their clubhouse yesterday to the fair sex, the occasion being their thirty-first Ladies' Day. About 1,000 availed themselves of the opportunity, and from noon to 7 o'clock in the evening the hospitable home of the wingedfoot athletes at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street was crowded.

The benefit of Marvin R. Clark, the blind newspaper writer, at Palmer's Theatre tonight promises to be a success, artistically and financially. Mr. Clark has been active in newspaper work for more than thirty years. He became totally blind five years ago, and since then he has struggled manfully to support himself and his aged parents, and he would have continued to succeed in doing so had not blindness been followed by nervous prostration.

The Times' s representative first visited the laboratory late in the afternoon and made a hasty trip through the rooms. That evening, in his little office on the second floor of the building, Dr. Scripture submitted to an interview, which at times became more like a conversation. This talk was recorded by a stenographer, and is here given.

The foreign exchange market was dull and firm. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.85 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.88 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84 1/2 @ $4.84 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.87 1/4 @ $4.87 1/2 for demand, $4.87 3/4 @ $4.88 for cable transfers, and $4.83 1/2 for commercial.

These papers were first published in Scribner's Magazine during the Summer, before the fair fever had subsided, and it is not worth while to take them too seriously. But from realizing what our artists of America were capable of in their work, much of it very beautiful work, at Jackson Park, to reading what these artists have to say of the spectacle there presented is a tremendous drop.

Beginning to-day, The New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In reply to Mr. Keyser's letter in The New-York Sunday Times, which must appeal to many citizens. I would like to suggest the following plan as a possible means of relieving a large number of destitute families without imposing too heavy a tax on some of the more fortunate class.

Their broad hats of crimson velvet and gold embroidery blaze with strings and clasps of rubies and sapphires, every hat being surmounted by the towering golden badge of the wearer's race. Gorgeous jackets of red and gold brocade sparkle with the same precious gems, and the voluminous white petticoats of gold-embroidered muslin are tucked up in a huge bundle under a golden belt incrusted with emeralds and pearls.

Beginning to-day, The New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

Mrs. Amelia E. Barr has taken the place formerly occupied by Mrs. Burnett as the best-paid female author in America. She often receives $5,000 for the serial rights to a novel, and her shorter work is proportionately well paid for.

An actor of incomparable skill, a speaker and thinker of unquestionable power, a remarkable man, in fact, stands before you. Under his searching and crushing analysis the prisoner has no secrets. The Procureur General attacks him in front directly, describing him with a gesture, piercing his very soul with a glance, weaving around him a net of suggestive phrases, while ever and anon he makes him start by some sudden and unexpected apostrophe.

Beginning to-day, the New-York Times will be on sale early every Sunday morning at all points along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and extending as far as Providence, R.I., by means of special train leaving the Grand Central Station at 2:35 A.M.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The novelties for the coming week among the down-town theatres will not be many. The single new play will be "The Country Sport," which will be given at the Columbia to-morrow evening and during the week, with Peter E. Dailey in the principal role.

Mayor Boody of Brooklyn has at last demonstrated that he has a will. He made the demonstration yesterday when he asked for the resignation of Excise Commissioner Schliemann. Commissioner Schliemann must either revoke a license granted by him or resign.

Cardinal Wolsey, in the portrayal of Mr. Irving, is a sort of scarlet terror. His insolence and arrogance, his craft and cruelty -- yes, cruelty, indeed, for no other word so well expresses his manner toward Buckingham and toward the Queen at the scene of her trial -- fairly make the spectator shiver.

There is something quite inexplicable in the position taken by the Maritime Association and the Chamber of Commerce of this city with reference to the construction of a bridge across the Hudson. River at Seventy-second Street, if the action taken in those bodies realiy represents the views of a majority of their members, and unless that action was procured in the interest of some other bridge project.

A dispatch printed yesterday said that William Astor Chanler of this city, who is at the head of an African exploring expedition, was stranded at Dhaicho, a few miles north of the equator and not far from Mount Kenia, whither he was bound. The Royal Geographical Society of London was said to have information to that effect.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Scarcely is one holiday over at a resort before all eyes are turned toward the next to follow. The snowstorm of Tuesday, which covered the ground to the depth of three inches, affording a few hours' sleighing, which the people were quick to take advantage of, was a plain reminder of Christmas.

The same lack of features which have been noted for the past two months has marked the past week's dealings in city real estate. Nothing has occurred to indicate a movement one way or the other. The number of transactions shows up, perhaps, a little better than the week before. Several store buildings have been disposed of at fair prices.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 9 -- Nearly every Democratic machinist employed by the Norwalk Iron Works Company of this city, manufacturers of air compressors and general machinery, was discharged to-day. Each man received a typewritten letter on the letterhead of the firm, of which the following is a copy...

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Dec. 9 -- William Sparks, an athlete, who for thirty years had been a cannon-ball performer with the most popular circuses, died here this morning from paralysis, aged fifty-eight. He was known professionally as the "American Hercules."

There is a cozily-furnished house at 687 Second Avenue which just now shelters a woman, an actor, and two little children. The first is the young English wife who fled from her husband and home with a comedian, as told in The New-York Times yesterday. The second is the man who persuaded the young wife and mother to elope.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- All softs of reports about the character of the Wilson Revenue bill and the purposes and prospects of success of the Ways and Means Committee find expression in Washington, and one of the members of the committee said to-night that he had never followed the history of any tariff bill about which so much misinformation and so many erroneous conjectures had been printed.

Philip M. Scheig, ex-paying teller of the Bank of Minneapolis, Minn., and Frank Floyd, one of his two accomplices in the theft of $90,000 from that concern, returned from their trip abroad yesterday in custody of Detectives Hoy and Lawrence. They were passengers of the American Line steamship New-York, which reached her pier late last evening.

The Strollers, formerly known as the Columbia College Dramatic Club, will give the musical burlesque "Ivanhoe Up to Date" in the Broadway Theatre during the week beginning Dec. 18, in aid of St. John's Guild. The expenses of the guild incurred in its charitable work last Summer placed it in debt, and through the coming entertainment it expects to be able to cancel the indebtedness.

Many newspaper men have described the appearance of Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer, the alleged murderer who is now locked up in the Tombs, and is on trial for his life, but all seem to have overlooked the peculiar conformation of his hands and finger nails.

From the foregoing description of the Yale Psychological Laboratory it will be apparent that the laboratory is ill equipped in many ways, and hampered in its investigations. Dr. Scripture should not be credited with any adverse criticisms here printed, for he made none.

Among the young athletes of the Adelphi Academy in Brooklyn the principal topic of conversation just now is the coming competitions with the students of physical culture, under training at Dr. Savage's institute in this city. On Dec. 15 a game of basket ball and a handball match between the teams of the two schools will be played at the institute.

There is a great deal of distress and suffering among the poor classes in Brooklyn, more than has been known in years. The Charities Department Building on Elm Place is besieged dally by persons in need of assistance. The almshouse at Flatbush is nearly filled with unfortunates.

An uncommon bad set must have been the Tempest family, Diana exeepted, and even Diana was a rather uncomfortable person. Modern English fiction, we hope, does not reflect the ways and manners of the better classes. All the Tempests, at least those of to-day, seem to have gone wrong. Col. Tempest of the Guards behaved brutally to his wife, who left him a son, Archie, and a daughter, Diana.

Frocks for the girl of twelve or thereabout are not quite the easy planning they have been for her up to this age. She has rather outgrown the blouse suits, except for tennis and gymnasium, into which it has always been possible to put her, and the guimpe dresses are also rather in the background.

TUESDAY, DEC. 12 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., executor's sale, four lots, each 25 by 100.11, on north side West One Hundred and Seventh Street, 100 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue; also, plot in rear, on south side of West One Hundred and Eighth Street, beginning 75.3 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue, 49.9 by 100.11 by 20.10 1/2 by 104.11 3/4.

Controller Myers has given his decision in the case of Campbell vs. Meler. He holds that unless Thomas Campbell, who is a brother of Congressman T.J. Campbell, pays the five-thousand-dollar note given to William M. Fleiss last Winter for stock in the Ivy City Racing Association, by Dec. 20, he will revoke Campbell's permit for his restaurant stands in West Washington Market.

The vital statistics last week were 1,163 births, 288 marriages, and 731 deaths, against 950 births, 250 marriages, and 759 deaths the week before. The mortality last week was computed to a death rate of 19.86 in a population of 1,920,493. Deaths from respiratory allments last weeks were: Bronchitis, 30; pneumonia, 121, and phthisis, 71, while those of the preceding week were: Bronchitis, 24; pneumonia, 120, and phthisis, 88.

FRIDAY, DEC. 15 -- By Bryan L. Kennelly, foreclosure sale, Edward L. Parris, referee, 141 Madison Street, north side, 185 feet wrest of Pike Street, 25 by 82, four-story brick tenement, with stores. Due on judgment, $3,715; on prior mortgage, $12,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary Lament has instituted several reforms in army administration in the last week which will result in the saving of time, labor, and money. One of them relates to the detail of officers to accompany competitors to the rifle contests. It has been the custom to detail an officer to take charge of the party and to conduct the team to the place where the army competitions are to be held.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 9 -- There is a prospect that the labor difficulties in this city may be settled. The merchants will hold a meeting next week, at which they will try to bring the manufacturers and discharged employes together and see if they cannot effect a compromise. The merchants have had a whole year of dullness in trade to contend with, and some of them are on the verge of bankruptcy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Prendergast, the assassin of Mayor Harrison, persisted to-day in making exhibitions in the courtroom. The State's attorneys believe that he was "performing" for the purpose of persuading the jurors that he was insane. He broke away from the Deputy Sheriff sitting next to him and went over to Attorney McGoorty, who was examining veniremen.

"Every child in France at this hour," says the complacent minister in the well-known story, "is studying the same lesson"; and it is practically the same for every undergraduate still. Uniform knowledge and uniform precision, with uniform justice for every young citizen are thus secured, and what are commonly reckoned the "essential qualities of the French mind" are unquestionably developed.

The traditional annual banquet of the "sour herring." so called, came off on Wednesday -- All Saints' Day. It was numerously attended by the fraternity of the undertaker assistants, and derives its name from the fact that when the custom was first established, and these assistants were only called "porters." they assembled once a year for a social entertainment, the time coinciding with the arrival of the sour herrings in the Paris markets.

Joseph Hegeman, late Postmaster at Bayville, L.I., charged with having a shortage in his accounts of $144, had a hearing before United States Commissioner Morle in Brooklyn yesterday. Hegeman urged as a defense that his office had been robbed and $400 in stamps and a registered letter containing $750 stolen.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- A bomb was thrown in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon, happily without fatal results.

The process servers, armed with Justice Barnard's order for Justice of the Peace Sutherland of Gravesend to show cause why he should not be removed from office, found it as difficult to locate the Justice as did Mr. Gaynor's copyists when searching for the Inspectors of Election.

Every season there crop up new designs in embroideries, new appointments in table decorations, new ideas for luncheons and dinners, but the same "tea" is served in its decorative cups, and the cracker jar is handed at all informal affairs from December to Lent.

Miss Maud C. Rice of this city and John Seager were married yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Dr. Hamilton performed the ceremony. Only the immediate families of the contracting parties were present. The bride, a beautiful brunette, was attired in traveling costume, and was given away by her uncle, Col. Fox.

There is a Deputy Collectorship at Newburg for which a great hunger seems to have been cultivated among the Democrats resident at that port of entry. A salary of $700 attaches to the place, which is better pay than the President gets, when the labors and responsibilities of the two offices are compared.

The engagement of Francis Wilson and the performances of "Erminie" at the Broadway Theatre close this week. Dec. 18 the comedian will begin a four weeks' term at Broad Street Theatre, Philadelphia, to be followed by engagements at the National Theatre, Washington, and Ford's Opera House, Baltimore, and when he returns to New-York with his new opera he will appear at Abbey's Theatre.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Previous to the removal of Civil Service Commissioner Johnston last week, there had been statements in the public journals to the effect that the President would soon "reorganize the commission" for party reasons, apparently for the purpose of giving to the dominant party a majority of its members.

Miss Clara Barton, whose magnificent work as President of the Red Cross Society has endeared her to every citizen of this Republic, and won her fame and respect in every land where such work is known, is herself the most modest and unassuming of women. It is difficult to get her to talk of her personal connection with the society, though she tells gladly of what it has accomplished.

The great northern elephant perished as a species in the prime of life. It had lived under most prosperous conditions. Its enemies were few and comparatively impotent. Alone among contemporary animals, the sabre-toothed tiger occasionally perhaps got the better of an antagonist which must have been less sensitive to the flint-tipped arrows of mere human assailants than Ship Surgeon Gulliver was to the multitudinous pricks of Lilliputian missiles.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As one who has played football ever since there was a game, under printed rules, in this country, and who has seen all the most attractive features, to both spectator and player, gradually eliminated by the expansion and perversion of the idea of "interference ahead of the ball," I write to propose a radical change in the game, or, more properly, in the method of play.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10 -- A big four-story brick manufacturing building at Lawrence and Mechanic Streets was destroyed by fire this morning. A dozen manufacturing plants were also destroyed. The damage is estimated at $60,000. One fireman was overcome by the smoke and had to be carried out of the burning building.

The comments of the press upon Mr. VAN ALEN'S resignation, reprinted this morning in THE TIMES from newspapers in all parts of the cotmtry and of all shades of political faith, give proof of a complete reversal of public opinion formed hastily upon false report against the appointment.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 10 -- H.G. Allis, ex-President of the First National Bank of Little Rock, spent last night in the Arkansas Penitentiary, a jury having found him guilty of embezzling funds of the bank. He will to-morrow be sentenced to five years' confinement at hard labor. The verdict was returned just before mid-night last night.
For the first time in New-York's history, cosmopolitan as the city is, the melodious call of the Muezzin, celebrated by every traveler in Mohammedan countries, was heard yesterday morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The library has recently received two gifts of unusual interest, one from M. Taylor Pyne of New-York and the other from J.S. Morgan of New-York. Mr. Pyne's gift consists of a large number of autograph letters and documents, chiefly by famous graduates or relating to the college, but also including autographs of William of Orange and various documents executed by English Kings.

Mr. C.M. Barnard of Avondale, Penn., sends to the combination sale of Dec. 13 and 14, under the management of Peter C. Kellogg Co., at the American Institute, in this city, a valuable stallion out of the famous old trotting mare Mary A. Whitney, 2:28, the dam of five trotters in the list. The horse in question is Mogul, 1.724, son of Administrator, 2:23 1/2.

Wlliam Morrow, a young man of Flatbush, heroically rescued a drowning boy yesterday afternoon. Willie Smith, thirteen years old, of 1,183 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was playing with his companion around the steamer pond near Malbone Street. There was a coating of ice half an inch thick and twenty-five feet wide around the pond.

The reports of the Treasury Department for October show that there were exported from this country in that mouth 36,186 yards of carpets. The exports were only 18,631 yards for the entire fiscal year of 1893 and only 11,440 yards for the preceding fiscal year, so that here in one month we see about twice as many yards sold abroad as have been sold in any full year heretofore.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Dec. 11 -- A.M. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange contracted gradually, almost from the opening until the close of the week, until a condition approaching stagnation prevailed. Operations were confined almost exclusively to the professional element, and, as the traders on both sides were not disposed to do more than "scalp for eighths," the fluctuations meant very little.

William Macgovern, a former member of the Seventh Regiment, a brother of Frank Macgovern, a dealer in electrical machinery at 39 Cortlandt Street, was committed to Bellevue Hospital from the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, insane. Macgovern is twenty-nine years old. He was formerly a publisher.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- It is estimated that the number of unemployed in this city is nearly 117,000, and so great has their suffering become that the Illinois Conference of Charities and Corrections, at a special meeting yesterday, appointed a committee of one hundred to proceed at once to raise a charity fund of $1,000,000 for the relief of the most pressing wants of the worthy and deserving poor.

With all its follies, the world is growing wiser, as is emphasized by the event of such a book as this excellent translation of Michel's "Rembrandt." While Rembrandt was a "people's painter" in the sense that he is admired by the ignorant as well as revered by the instructed, the familiar saying is borne out in this case as in others, and one can bring away from Rembrandt only what one carries to him.

Senator MORGAN of Alabama visited Birmingham, in that State, a few days ago, and permitted a newspaper there to say for him that he would oppose the Wilson bill's additions to the free list and would "stand with the interests of Alabama and the South in defending them against free ore and coal."

The Sixty-ninth Regiment muddle seems to be getting worse. The Captains and Lieutenants of three of the companies which were not disbanded have signified their intention of resigning unless the order reducing the regiment to a battalion is revoked by the Governor. Their resignations would have been forwarded to headquarters Friday night if Col. Michael C. Murphy had not counseled them to wait a few days.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- The dates for the midyear examinations have been announced, and the period of "grinding" has begun. Daily exercises in all the courses will be suspended from Wednesday, Jan. 24, to Saturday, Feb. 10, inclusive. The list of dates, however, is provisional, and may be altered before the examination season begins.

While many of the evicted women of the "Tenderloin" district wandered about the streets yesterday in a penniless, and hungry condition, the owners of the houses in which they had at least been sheltered, enjoyed the day in warm and cosy homes amid surroundings which were the height of luxury, compared with the present destitution of their former tenants.

Francis Espinasse writes mainly of Carlyle. He knew him early in his London career, and apears to have shared his friendship thereafter without disruption. Other writers of whom he discourses are George Eliot, George H. Lewes, and Beaconsfield, but the bulk of the volume is devoted to Carlyle and to his friends.

We have already alluded to the interesting statements of Postmaster General BISSELL in his report in regard to the practical operation of the civil service law and the need of its extension. His firm belief in "the application of the merit system to the selection of employes for subordinate positions in the public service" has been confirmed by his experience in the department.
BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 10 -- The latest advices from Rio Janeiro are that President Peixoto's forces attacked Fort Villegaignon, and were repulsed.

The masters' tournament opened Saturday at the Manhattan Cafe under the management of the City Chess Club, with the following cracks to start Albin. Baird brothers, Delmar, Ettinger, Halpern, Hanham, Hodges, Pillsbury, and Showalter. The first round resulted as follows:

The trial board which will consider the final contract performance of the cruiser New-York will have an opportunity to investigate some recently-developed defects in the armament of that vessel. These defects show the evils of the system of bureaus under which the new navy of the United States has been designed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Chairman Wilson of the Committee on Ways and Means said this evening that the Democratice members of the committee had taken no action whatever upon the matter of changing the tax on whisky.

The demand of the Municipal Art Society that the Speedway on the west bank of the Harlem shall be laid out with due consideration for the art of the landscape engineer will soon be followed by a demand on the part of the Sculpture Society that the plan shall include sites carefully chosen in advance where monuments may be erected.

Rabbi Gustav Gottheil preached yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El on "Who Are the Enemies of Judaism?" He divided the enemies into two classes -- conscious and unconscious. The first class, he said, desired to close the doors of the synagogue and make it a church. There was only one kind of man who desired to do this.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10 -- Less than two weeks more of the Fall term at Yale remain. A day or two ago the Faculty issued the schedule for the semi-annual examination, announcing that they would begin next Wednesday, Dec. 13, and continue till Dec. 21, when all departments of the university will close for the Christmas holiday vacation of two weeks.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 10 -- Now that the football season is over, the Naval Academy cadets are beginning to talk baseball and rowing. Much is expected of the eight-oar crew this year. Interest had died out in aquatics till two years ago, when the four-oar shell crew was defeated. That spurred the boys on, and last season they bought an eight-oar boat, secured a coacher, and practiced hard.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Charles Mitchell will go to Atlantic City in a day or two with his trainer. Harry Darrin, and finish his training for the coming battle with Corbett. He likes to do his work at the seashore. The English pugilist is fearful of catching malaria, and on that account will not go South until a few days before the battle.

From the Boston Herald. We assume that criticism of Mr. Van Alen is now likely to cease. He has proved himself to be a citizen of dignity and of character, and to be better worthy of holding diplomatic office than the most of men who are selected for this honor in both parties.

The battle for the life of Dr. Henry C. W. Meyer will begin again this morning, before Judge Barren, in Oyer and Terminer. Since the adjournment of the case Friday evening both sides have been busy closing up the gaps that still remain in the chain of evidence for and against the man who is accused of having poisoned Ludwig Brandt or Gustav Baum.

Mrs. Humphry Ward Is understood to have nearly completed a new novel which Macmillan Co. will bring out early in the year. Her "David Grieve" is now in its fourth edition, and has become quite as popular as "Robert Elsmere."

The primaries of the Kings County "Boss" McLauglin Democracy will be held to-night. Word has been sent over from the Willoughby Street political auction room that several well-known ward leaders must get into the background, and that hereafter they must be leaders by proxy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Civil Service Commission has sent to the President two reports covering the operations of the commission during the last year, the majority report being signed by Mr. Lyman and Mr. Roosevelt, and the minority by Mr. Johnston. The majority report shows that the great feature in the operations of the commission has been the work done in connection with the extension of the classified service to all free-delivery Post Offices.
Superintendent Byrnes celebrated yesterday the thirtieth anniversary of his appointment as a policeman. He celebrated by doing a hard day's work at Police Headquarters.

From The Washington Post. The very oldest man in the Congress -- the "Father of the Congress" in years, in original entry, and in length of continuous service -- is the Hon. Justin S. Morrill, who came to the House in 1855, served there until 1867, when he was promoted to the Senate, and has there remained ever since.

The Columbia College Athletic Union met last Friday and sanctioned the formation of a 'Varsity baseball team this year. Monks, '94, was elected temporary Captain, while Nichol, 94. Law, was elected manager. Much interest is manifested in the formation of the team. One hundred and fifteen candidates have presented themselves already.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10. -- The editorial and news articles in The New-York Times upon the scheme of a certain faction of the Catholics to divide the school revenues with the parochial schools have attracted earnest attention here, where the movement had its origin, and much credit is given to The Times for its opportune publications.

There have been many sales of trotting-bred horses in this city at which pedigrees have commanded excessive prices, whether the individual was good, bad, or indifferent. There have been other sales where fairly good individuals have sold for less than anticipated, because they were not bred in just those lines which breeders then considered most desirable.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9. -- The local stock market presents but few changes in the general list for the past week. The strong undertone of last week was still apparent, and more particularly noticeable in the light offerings of stocks. Narragansett Electric Light continued strong, with 77 3/1 bid and 80 asked.

A large congregation greeted the Rev. Robert Collyer, pastor of the Church of the Messiah, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, at the morning service yesterday. The venerable preacher has just completed his seventieth year, the event having been celebrated Friday, and his people expected that he would say something to them concerning himself.

The testimonial benefit to Marvin R. Clark, the blind journalist, which was held in Palmer's Theatre last evening, was in every respect a decided success. There was a very large attendance, and many well-known persons were present. The box office receipts were more than $1,000. A quarter of that amount will be given to the Actors' Fund.

An Irish manufacturer of textile fabrics, who, since the close of the Columbian Exposition at Chicago, has visited many of the leading cities of the United States to study their markets, mills, and machinery, reached New-York last week, on his homeward journey. To a reporter for The New-York Times he Imparted some interesting and novel views on Ireland's Industries and politics, incidentally touching, as he went along, on American economic theories and tariffs.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- The Sunday newspapers, in commenting upon the explosion in the French Chamber yesterday, concur that similar demonstrations are likely to be made by Anarchists in other centres of political life. They recommend the general adoption of more stringent precautions against Anarchists in European capitals.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The subject of lengthening the time of study for the general collegiate year is now before the Faculty for consideration. It seems desirable to hold the students in the university to work closer and for longer periods of time. This it is proposed to do by using some of the time for study now occupied with examinations and by shortening the vacations.
The Rev. Madison C. Peters, in the prelude to his sermon yesterday morning in the Bloomingdale Church, Boulevard and Sixty-eighth Street, spoke of "Satolli and the Public Schools." He said:

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 10 -- In a decision handed down by the Supreme Court it is held that the mortgage redemption law passed by the last Legislature does not apply to mortgages or contracts made prior to the passage of the act. The decision does not touch upon the validity of the law itself, although there are cases pending in which the constitutionality of the act is to be tested.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The Montclair Dramatic Club, composed of a large membership of society men and women, opened its fifth season last night with a performance of "A Russian Honeymoon" in Montclair Club Hall.

The United States Government sells to private concerns exclusive privileges which offer all the facilities for one of the most wholesale bunko games ever perpetrated in this country. This is done at the Ellis Island Immigrant Station, where the horde of ignorant foreigners are given to the hands of private individuals for their first business transactions in this country.

Prof. Felix Adler spoke before an immense audience in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning upon Jesus Christ as a teacher and the many lessons and inspirations which could be found in His life. He first spoke of Christ as compared with the older prophets of Israel. He said:

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- The interest in home events is far outweighed just now by foreign affairs involving Germany's destinies, despite the fact that the Government is celebrating a triumph all along the line of its commercial policy and has made good progress with its taxation proposals.

ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- The tendency of the local security market this week was as a rule, toward higher prices. The strongest stock was Municipal Gas, and sales were made at the asked price. Albany Railway was sold at the bid price. In the local bond market Union Railway of New-York 5 per cent, bonds have been in demand.

John P. Adams, City Works Commissioner of Brooklyn, says he can stand any investigation Mayor Schieren may institute regarding the work of his department. He can even explain satisfactorily the halfmillion-dollar water works extension "steal," which has lately been brought to light.

Notwithstanding the downpour of rain on Saturday, the association football team of Governors Island took a full team down to West New-Brighton, where the Staten Island Athletic Club could only muster seven men. They obtained three substitutes, however, and the match resulted in a very good game. The "going," however, told against the heavier team, which the soldiers undoubtedly were, and the home players had an advantage.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The admittance of what has commonly been known as the "Harvard Annex" to the university as "Radcliffe College" marks an important epoch in the history of Harvard University. The impression that Harvard has become co-educational will probably be widespread among those who form their opinions from a hasty survey of facts.

In Assembly Hall, on Wednesday, Dec. 13, at 8 P.M., there will be held an organization meeting, to which are invited all persons who have had any serviceable connection with the institute, as student or library member. The object of the meeting is to organize a society for the promotion of neighborship and the extension of Pratt Institute work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Efforts are being made by Gen. Flagler, the army Chief of Ordnace, to obtain from some American powdermaker a satisfactory smokeless powder. He has become, tired of testing the foreign samples which have found their way to the army laboratory at Frankford Arsenal, near Philadelphia.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 10 -- The cold weather of the past few days has been sufficient to make excellent skating upon the river. The few inches of dry snow which fell after the river froze over have been cleared away from a large piece of the ice below the bridge, and many of the students are to be found there during the afternoon.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 10 -- William Brandes and family of 907 Hudson Street went to church this evening, leaving the servant girl alone. The girl heard a knock, and, on opening the door, found herself confronted by three ill-kempt tramps, who forced their way into the house and locked the door.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 9. -- The money market was easy, with very little demand. The rate was 6 per cent. General business was very dull. The local market was weak, with trading fairly active. Traction stocks showed the heaviest decline of the week, the selling being caused by the falling off in their earnings.

The first page of yesterday's New-York Times resounded with dynamite. That impulsive material formed the basis for three illustrations of modern life's vicissitudes, and, curiously enough, least space was given to that in which a man was really killed, most to that in which only injuries were the result, while between them in line or importance ranked the incident which cast a gleam of light on the mystery surrounding the destruction of a great steamship.
On the 7th inst. the Philadelphia Press, which is the leading advocate of McKinleyism in that city, published the following dispatch:
The regular meeting of the Brooklyn Democratic Club will be held Thursday evening at the clubrooms, 201 Montague Street. The Nominating Committee has named the following candidates to be voted for:

The examinations of the Fall term of the university of the City of New-York will occupy this week. This is probably the last time that examinations will be held before Christmas, as the Committee on Revision of the college courses are unanimous in favor of substituting two terms in the college year in the place of three. When this is done, the examinations will come in the month of February.

Frank Harth, a member of the Seymour Club, Williamsburg, was recently served, with formal notice that charges had been preferred against him because he did not support Mayor Boody and the city and State "machine" tickets in the late election. Mr. Harth lives at 149 Bedford Avenue. He is a manufacturer of blank books.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 10 -- A list of eight or nine names will be presented Judge Hallett to-morrow for his consideration, from which he will be asked to select a receiver for the Denver, Texas and Fort Worth branch of the Union Pacific. Col. L.C. Ellsworth will probably be the man selected.

Joseph Louffe, aged seventeen, of 513 West Twenty-sixth Street, and Joseph O'Keefe, aged sixteen, of 506 West Twenty-sixth Street, are already, according to the story of Policeman Rutledge, who brought them into Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning, full-fledged burglars. The policeman caught them breaking through a hall door into the shoe store of Simon Cohen, at 283 Tenth Avenue.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Auguste Vaillant, alias Marchal, a resident of the suburb, Choisyle-Roi, is the Anarchist who threw the bomb in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday. He made a confession this morning.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1@1 1/2 per cent., the average being less than 1 1/2 per cent.

Mrs. Mary A. Williams of 435 West Twenty-third Street and Mrs. Ellen J. Shanks of One Hundred and Fifty-fourth Street and Bradhurst Avenue are mutually wondering "where they are at." Mrs. Shanks is particularly undecided on the subject of her location.

Commodore Jerome Simpson of the Yonkers Canoe Club has resigned from office and membership in the club, and has removed to Riverside, Ill. His successor will be chosen at the annual election next February, and until that time Vice Commodore William R. Haviland will serve as Acting Commodore.

Some new features were introduced Saturday at Hagenbeck's show of trained animals at Tattersalls, Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue. These were trained storks and geese managed by Loisett, the German clown, and trained seals which performed on tamborines and guitars and fired off a battery under the command of Capt. Weston.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 10 -- A list of eight or nine names will be presented Judge Hallett to-morrow for his consideration, from which he will be asked to select a receiver for the Denver, Texas and Fort Worth branch of the Union Pacific. Col. L.C. Ellsworth will probably be the man selected.
