The greatest of actors, whoever he may be, could not have attracted to the Star Theatre a throng of people much larger than was gathered in that capacious place of amusement last evening, nor could the greatest of plays have excited many more recalls or much louder or more prolonged applause than did the one then submitted to the nominally critical judgment of representative New-Yorkers.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Among the versions told of the examination of Vaillant is one to the effect that he laughingly told the examining magistrate that he "would like to make a fricassee of the Deputies."

There has not in a long time been anything in municipal affairs more interesting than the finding of the Mayor, Controller, and Auditor of Brooklyn regarding the bill of PATRICK Ross, contractor for the grand stands at the Columbian celebration in the Fall of 1892. The finding is that the job for which Ross has actually received $11,700 was worth only $3,400, within 10 cents.
Wallace Eugene Blackford, the only son of Eugene G. Blackford, died yesterday morning, at his father's home, 725 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, from an attack of the grip.

The Methodist ministers of New-York received a terrible shaking up yesterday at the Book Concern, on Fifth Avenue. None of the brethren was injured physically, but the notions of some of them on the subject of modern preaching could not have been worse hurt if they had tumbled nine flights down an air shaft, and alighted on broken glass at the bottom.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- While a quantity of freight was being unloaded from an Adams Express car here this morning, cries of "Help!" were heard emanating from a box that had been shipped from Chicago. The box was securely nailed, and, after it had been jostled about considerably, it was opened, and Hermann Zeitung, an Austrian, aged thirty years, was found inside in a bruised and battered condition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The story in The New-York Times of to-day of the defects in the cruiser New-York was read with much interest at the Navy Department. It told the bureau officers some things which they hoped had escaped the notice of the papers.

Some time ago, when it was first settled that Columbia College and the University of the City of New-York would both abandon their down-town homes and move into the upper part of the city, a proposition was made that the two should merge into a great university, or syndicate of colleges, on the plan of Oxford or Cambridge in England.
AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 11. -- The north-bound International and Great Northern Express train was side-tracked this morning at Duval, a small station seven miles north of hers, by seven train robbers.
Chief of Police McKane of Gravesend refused to discuss his case yesterday. He appeared to be ill at ease, and was not as pleasant as he is in the habit of appearing.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Dec. 11. -- There was a romantic midnight marriage at Prohibition Park Saturday night, and the select community of retired clergymen and temperance advocates who make that quiet place their home at this season have not been so excited since the management was taken to task for permitting ice cream to be sold on Sunday and the children to play with the swings in the grove.

BUFFALO, Dec. 11. -- Bishop Coxe to-day made a written reply to the committee of Poles who waited upon him with the resolutions adopted by the mass meeting Friday night, with reference to what was regarded as an insult to their race. In this letter the Bishop says:

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- James A. Garland of New-York has arranged a practical gift to Harvard in the form of four series of art lectures, for which he will pay all the expenses. Mr. Garland has already given to the Harvard University Museum $25,000 worth of rare gems. He is not a Harvard graduate, but he is educating his son at Cambridge.

The antecedents of the author of the latest and most sensational of the explosions of dynamite have been developed by the industry of the French police, and they are what might have been expected. The assassin is a hopeless "ne'er do weel." Now, "ne'er do weels" are of two kinds. Many and perhaps most of them are amiable persons.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- A three-hundred-thousand-dollar fund is the cause of contention between the City of Quincy and Dartmouth College. The contest arises out of the construction of certain clauses in the wills of Dr. Ebenezer Woodward and his widow, who created the fund for the establishment of a female institute in Quincy.

In every annual report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission since the law under which it acts went into effect there has been an account of the working of the statute and suggestions of amendments for its improvement. These have received rather scant consideration from Congress, considering the importance of the subject.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The combination made by the Essex and Hudson Republicans to capture both State Controller and State Treasurer has caused considerable agitation in the lower end of the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Mr. Hill decided to be magnanimous to-day, and as a result of this decision the Senate was deprived of the spectacle of a lively tilt over the bill repealing the Federal elections law.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, George W. De Witt and a committee of property owners; whose lands were taken for the new Corlears Hook Park, asked why it was that the property had not been paid for, although the money was due Nov. 17.

The report of the United States Civil Service Commission seems at last to have taken its place among the annual documents which Congress expects to receive as it does the account of the operation of any well-defined and well-established part of the machinery of government. It is not very long since these reports were largely regarded by Congress and to some extent by the Commissioners as pleas for continued existence.

Frank C. Ives and George F. Slosson gave remarkably pretty exhibition of balk-line billiard playing in Madison Square Garden, Concert Hall last night in the opening game of the triangular tournament. Ives won by a fair margin -- 100 points -- but the contest was by no means one-sided. On the contrary, it abounded in brilliant plays ably executed by the exponents of the new and old schools of experts.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11. -- Another magazine is to be started at Yale. For years the students of the scientific department have felt the need of an organ, and at last they have established one. All the leading professors and a number of local friends of the school have pledged their support, and preparations are now being made to get out the first number in a few months.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Representatives of the boards of managers of seven of the eight hospitals for the insane in this State met at tae Gilsey House last night and arraigned the State Lunacy Commission in strong language for its management, or mismanagement, of the hospitals under the State Care act.

People in this city are being brought face to face with the fact that there are very many persons who are hungry and in absolute want. Beggary has increased more than 100 per cent, within the past few weeks. The charitable organizations have no plan for the immediate relief of the hungry people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- At the meeting of the Ways and Means Committee this morning, the majority of the committee produced a new print of the bill published by them a short time ago. Nearly all of the changes, the entire list making a short page of type-written lines, have been anticipated, except that changing the date of the operation of the bill from March 1 to June 1.

All the books, papers, documents, and pamphlets which John I. Davenport accumulated as Chief Supervisor of Federal Elections were removed from the rooms in the Post Office Building on the Park Row side yesterday and stored in an apartment in the dome. Mr. Davenport did not much like the change, still the court had, in a way, provided for it, and the custodian of the building put the order into effect.

The rumor that Richard Croker was about to resign the leadership of Tammany Hall was revived yesterday. A special meeting of the Board of Sachems of the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, has been called for this afternoon, and the rumor yesterday was to the effect that Mr. Croker would resign as a Sachem at this meeting, and that this would be a preliminary step to his retirement as leader of Tammany Hall.

George Sawkins, the Australian astronomer, is to deliver, in Chickering Hall, a course of six lectures, the first of which will be given Dec. 17. Mr. Sawkins brings a new idea into the American lecture field. He will talk of scientific religion, the mysticism of ancient and modern theologies.

Mayor Boody, Controller Corwin, and City Auditor Weber of Brooklyn yesterday decided that Patrick Ross, the contractor who built the grand stands for the Columbian celebration in October, 1892, was entitled to $3,399.90. Ross received $11,700 from the city. The Audit Commission, therefore, decides that he was paid $8,300.10 too much.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House this morning at 1 1/2 and 1 per cent., but the demand was light, and several of the leading banks carried home their balances. New-York funds sold at par. There is little doing in the outside markets, and rates remain unchanged, although conditions are easier if anything.

Heirs of John C. Austin will to-day before Judge Truax in the Supreme Court attempt to show cause why the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association should pay to them the $15,000 insurance on Mr. Austin's life.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Had it not been for the professional traders the market would have been as inert to-day as it was in the latter part of last week. The scalpers made quotations in stocks that were wholly ignored by the public. Yet even with the aid of the professionals, business on the local Exchange was only fairly active, with the tendency toward lower figures.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- J.H. Benton, counsel for the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, has filed in the Supreme Court two demurrers on the suit brought against the company by Theodore R. Glover to set aside the lease of the Old Colony Railroad Company to the New-Haven. The first demurrer is that of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Company, and contains seven causes of demurrer as follows:

A bazaar in aid of the House of the Holy Family was opened last evening in the main hall of the Boland Trade School on Madison Avenue, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets. The building has just been completed, and the first use to which it has been put was the holding of the bazaar, the use of the hall having been given to the lady managers without charge through the kindness of Archbishop Corrigan.
Plans were filed yesterday at the Building Department for the following new buildings and alterations:

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- M. Dupuy, President of the Chamber, to-day addressed the House on the occurrence of Saturday. He complimented the members for their attitude during the exciting moments following the explosion of Vaillant's bomb, and thanked those who attended to the wounded.

-- Robert Hilliard has been getting himself into trouble with his fists again. On Friday morning, as "The Nominee" company was about to leave Scranton, Penn., Hilliard approached Martin Farrell, a baggage transfer agent, and struck him a heavy blow in the face. When Farrell recovered sufficiently to demand an explanation, Hilliard said he had mistaken him for a collector.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Philadelphia Traction stock was active. A great deal was traded in at the opening at 98, and then it was hammered to 96 3/4. The pool then began buying and took all that was offered at 97. Insiders are very bullish on its future. Metropolitan was inclined to weakness. Opening at 105, it sold down to 103 1/2, and not a great deal was wanted at the decline.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The article in The New-York Times of Dec. 10 so effectually disposes of the objections of the Maritime Exchange to the river pier of the New-York and New-Jersey bridge that it would be a waste of space to add to it.

The sailing ship San Joaquin, Capt. Larrabee, which left Yokohama, Japan, May 4, with a cargo of curios, rags, and mats, arrived in safety and cast anchor of Liberty Island yesterday afternoon, after having narrowly escaped being crushed by an iceberg in the South Atlantic. She hobbled into port under a jury rig, having traveled for more than 6,000 miles in that condition.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- Work was commenced this morning at the Bessemer steel works and at the Breaker Island blast furnaces, a part of the Troy Steel and Iron Company's plant, which suspended operations some time ago.

The Gas Commission met yesterday in the Mayor's office and opened bids for lighting the city's streets and avenues with electric light and gas for next year. The bids were all referred to the Secretary for tabulation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin read with great interest the story in The New-York Times of to-day about the sale of exchange at the Ellis Island Immigration bureau. The subject was one to which his attention had been directed, but he had heard no complaint about it, and had not observed that The Times's report suggested any unfairness or dishonesty in the way of conducting the business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Navy Department has received a cable dispatch from Rio Janeiro that indicates preparations by President Peixoto for a big battle between his forces and those of Admiral Mello. The dispatch is from Capt. Picking, commanding the United States naval force at Rio, and in substance is as follows:

Carl Mueller, the informer against Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, was put on the rack of cross-examination yesterday, and on the whole, he came out of the ordeal in fairly good shape. It is true that he confessed himself under Mr. Brooke's searching questions, a perjurer and a bigamist, and that he convicted himself of false swearing, even during the hearing of the present case.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 11.-- When seen this evening by a New-York Times representative the Rev. D.J. Evans, rector of Grace Episcopal Church of this city, said this regarding his refusal to marry Hans Panzer and Miss Moran:

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Reductions in freight rates made during the last ten days by the Central Traffic Association roads appear to have a stimulating effect on shipments. They increased last week by 17,000 tons, as compared with those of the previous week, notwithstanding the fact that the lake lines still remained in the field to a certain extent as competitors and took 22,545 tons of the total shipments.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Frank King, a notorious character, was shot and instantly killed while attempting, with two companions, to rob Samuel N. Clifford's grocery store at 362 West Adams Street, at 6.30 o'clock this morning. Clifford had just opened the store when the men entered. One of the men fired a shot over Clifford's head, and demanded the contents of the cash drawer.

Those who come to New-York for the first time, or only occasionally, and whose impressions, therefore, have a vividness that gives them value, are sure to mention as one of the greatest charms of the town a certain ample and ripened hospitality which is peculiar to itself.

Rose Coghlan began a long, and, it is hoped, a prosperous engagement in the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night, presenting, after toilsome preparation, with a magnificent pictorial setting, a new play by Oscar Wilde, called "A Woman of No Importance."

The Columbia College sophomores, who have been in deep disgrace the past few days because of their defeat in a scrimmage with the despised freshmen last Friday night, had their revenge yesterday morning on the campus. Members of the two classes had a rough-and-tumble fight that resulted in many discolored eyes, bruised and bleeding faces, and great destruction to clothing.

Not more than thirty members of the Real Estate Exchange were present at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon when President George R. Read called the annual meeting to order. Subsequently, however, and while the balloting for officers was in progress, the attendance was larger.

Antoine Maloussence, thirty years old, a dishwasher in a restaurant at 58 West Twenty-second Street, committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping from the roof of the adjoining house to the street. Just before killing himself he left a letter for his brother Etienne, in which he said:

The New-York Weekly Times is making an offer of books for the holidays widen every one should read. It is to be found on the eighth page of The Weekly Times, and explains how any subscriber to The Weekly Times may secure any one of nearly 400 choice books for a very small sum. The books are fine enough for any library and have been selected with great care.

The Consolidation Commission has unanimously agreed to a new bill, to be presented to the Legislature, providing for the submission to a vote of the people of the several communities concerned, at the election of next year, the question of union into one municipality. The delay which this consolidation movement has encountered seems only to have strengthened the sentiment in its favor.

Frank Creelman of the Pneumatic Gun Company, 41 Wall Street, returned yesterday from St. Thomas by way of Newport News. He had accompanied the ship Nictheroy to instruct the officers in the handling of the dynamite gun. In talking last evening of his experiences on board the Nictheroy, Mr. Creelman said:

STAPLETON, S. I., Dec. 12. -- St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene of a brilliant wedding ceremony this afternoon, when Miss Mary Lewin Thomas and Max Emile De Jonge were married. The bride is a direct descendant of the Due de Morales, the last French Governor of Lousiana, and of W. C. C. Claiborne, who was that State's first Territorial Governor under the United States Government.

Gov. Flower sent a telegram to some of the local managers of the hospitals for the insane yesterday, which they agreed might be the beginning of new developments in the warfare which these officials are making against the State Lunacy Commission.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between, banks was unchanged at 11/2 and 1 per cent. New-York funds sold at par. Call money is quoted today at 2@3 per cent., time loans at 3@4 per cent. Commercial paper is very dull, owing to the small supply.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The Board of Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad this afternoon took no action on the quarterly dividend which is due next month. It is officially announced that the dividend will not be paid.

The resumption of traffic on the Lehigh Valley Railroad leaves the company and its former employes, who have been taken back, on terms which are not clearly better for the interruption, and with a very considerable loss in money and time. The new men who took the places of the strikers have had the benefit of a short season of work, but cannot feel very well satisfied that they are now turned back to idleness.

We remark with some surprise that a good many Protestant ministers of divers denominations have taken umbrage at, and texts from, the remarks of the Papal Delegate on Thanksgiving Day touching the Catholic schools. The grievance of these persons seems to be that the Papal Delegate took occasion to praise the schools and the energy and devotion of the priests who had carried them on.

It is not quite clear what grievance the managers of the State Hospitals for the Insane have against the Commissioners in Lunacy, but apparently they are not altogether satisfied with the working of the new law, which puts upon them the burden of caring for the pauper insane, transferred from the county asylums and poorhouses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- In the House to-day Mr. Wheeler, (Dem., Ala.,) Chairman of the Committee on Territories, called up the bill for the admission of Utah as a State. Mr. Kilgore, (Dem., Texas,) spoke in favor of it. He said it had the requisite population (225,000) and wealth, ($150,000,000 or $200,000,000.) it had public schools in every county and every community, and the Republican Party was as thoroughly organized as the Democratic Party.

The decision of Justice Barnard, in the contempt of court case against John Y. McKane, did not reach Brooklyn yesterday. The decision is not expected before this afternoon. It is thought possible that Justice Barnard will not file it until after the dinner which has been tendered him this evening by the members of the Brooklyn Bar.

BRAZILIAN STEAMSHIP NICTHEROY, Harbor of St. Thomas, Dec. 3. -- The event of the week has been the target practice with a rocky island outside as a target. Excellent work was done, particularly with the fifty-five-pounder Hotchkiss at the stern, which, at 2,000 yards, sent such accurate shots as would have sunk or disabled any vessel aimed at.

Several of the auction sales set down for yesterday were postponed for a week or more. Not very much interest attached to the remainder, although under other circumstances there would doubtless have been come spirit in the bidding for two or three of the parcels offered.

From The Macon Telegraph. The letter in which Mr. Van Alen offers his resignation and insists that it be accepted are creditable to him. He shows a proper sense of self-respect and at the same time a becoming modesty.
A genuine praise meeting was held yesterday at the office of the commission to make plans for consolidating this city and its outlying communities into the "greater New-York."

When the immigrant has changed his European money for that which passes in this country, on landing at Ellis Island, his next business transaction in most instances is buying something to eat. Within ten feet of the money exchange is the restaurant, although, because of an iron railing, the immigrant must so through, another room before he can reach it.

The cutting of freight rates on the trunk line railroads between New-York and Chicago promises a "green Christmas" for the roads concerned, but a salutary lesson may eventually be learned from the situation. The practice of secretly cutting rates in periods of traffic stagnation has been in vogue among railroad men as far back as the longest memory of any traffic manager can reach.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Alexander J. Robertson, cashier of the wholesale stamp department of the Post Office, was assaulted in his office to-night and robbed of $7,000 belonging to the department. Robertson was making up his accounts for the day, when he was knocked insensible by a blow from some instrument which cut a deep gash in his head back of the right ear.

The conference of Fish Commissioners and others interested in the preservation of food fish will be held to-day in the Gerlach, 53 West Twenty-seventh Street, instead of at the office of the Fish Commissioners, 53 Broadway. The change was made in order to accommodate the large attendance expected.
The family of A.A. McLeod of 12 West Fifty-first Street was greatly excited early yesterday because of the antics of the cook, who was either drunk or out of her mind.

Rosina Vokes is confined to her room in the St. James Hotel, and for most of the time to her bed. She is a very sick woman, and the fact that she continued to play until last Saturday, when she fainted on the stage in Washington, is a tribute to her remarkable will power rather than to her strength.

A very largely increased attendance, brisker bidbing, and much better average prices, were the features of yesterday's sale of trotting stock at the American Institute. It was the second day of the Jewett sale, and though bargains were far from infrequent, Mr. Jewett expressed himself an fairly well satisfied, excepting at the sale of Jerome Eddy for $2,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Wheat was spasmodically active to-day. The feeling was one of weakness, with the exception of a few moments after the opening, when a steady to firm tone characterized the market. Liquidation was the watchward, and it was not confined alone to wheat, but pervaded all the pits. Wheat, however, was the first to feel its effects, and the other articles accepted its lead.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- The search of the police in the northern section of Paris will probably result in the expulsion from France of thirty foreigners, who are believed to be relatives of Anarchists. Marchal, the husband of the mistress of Vaillant, the bomb-thrower, has vanished, and the police can find no trace of him.

The application made by the city for an injunction to restrain the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company from building a third track on the Ninth Avenue line was argued before Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- At the meeting of the Board of Town Commissioners last night Patrick Egan charged the Rev. James A. Reynolds, rector of St. James's Roman Catholic Church, with being responsible for a disorderly house. The alleged disorderly house is St. James's Hall, which adjoins Egan's house and which is used as a meeting room by the Young Men's Institute.

William B. Curtis, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was in this city yesterday. In company with Frederick D. Tappen, President of the Gallatin National Bank, he visited the Fourth National Bank, the Chase National Bank, the Bank of Commerce, the Sub-Treasury, and the Clearing-House. His visit, it is said, was due to the resumption of gold exports.

Edgar M. Johnson, of the law firm of Hoadly, Lauterbach Johnson, died Sunday night at the Knickerbocker Apartment House, after an illness that had kept him indoors only a few days. The intimation of his death caused general surprise and regret, for his appearance had been that of a man destined to a long life, and during his residence in this city he had become well known and well liked.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- When the last quarterly dividend of the Lehigh Valley Company was due the management informed the stockholders that it had been decided to declare future dividends semiannually instead of quarterly. To-day the semi-annual dividend was to have been declared, but it was passed.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- The city election today called out a rather larger vote than last year for Mayor, and the results show that Nathan Matthews, Jr., (Dem.,) is re-elected by a plurality of 5,138, in a total vote of 67,982. The total vote is as follows: Matthews, 36,560; Hart, 31,422.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Preparations are being made by the citizens of Trenton for the relief of the suffering poor during the coming Winter. A large fund will probably be collected and a comprehensive system of distribution maintained.

"Napoleon" Ives sat in a private box in Madison Square Garden Concert Hall last night and watched the battle on the billiard table between the champions of former years. "Student" Slosson, and "Wizard" Schaefer. He never missed a shot, and appeared to pay particular attention to the work of Schaefer.
The three days' fair in behalf of the NewYork Throat and Nose Hospital was opened yesterday afternoon at Sherry's, and the attendance promised well for the success of the enterprise.

About 300 of the alumni of Columbia College were at the annual banquet of the graduates of that institution, at the Brunswick Hotel, last night. It was held in the large banquet room, upon the walls of which were flags, pieces of bunting in the college colors, and numerous troubles won from other colleges in athletic contests.

Some of the politicians in the Senate, especially those on the Republican side, show a disposition to get unduly excited over an antediluvian issue. Senator CULLOM seems to think that he can make some capital for himself in Illinois, where he wishes to secure a re-election through the Legislature to be chosen next year, by making a loud and vigorous protest against the repeal of the Federal Election law.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Judge Maynard, I am proud to say, is my friend, and I am his friend.''

We have received from a manufacturer of steel a circular letter addressed to manufacturers by JAMES M. SWANK, General Manager of the American Iron and Steel Association, and an accompanying protest which Mr. SWANK asks the manufacturers to sign, and for which he urges them to procure the signatures of workingmen.

The contest for the new lease of the Madison Square Theatre, in which A.M. Palmer and Marshall H. Mallory were the principals, has been settled, and Mr. Mallory has secured the coveted lease. His success was due, more than anything else, to the fact that he succeeded in purchasing the ground upon which the stage entrance is constructed, which does not belong to the Enos, who own the theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The condition here to-day was a repetition of the New-York market, so far as inactivity and dullness are concerned. As to values, they exhibited a slightly easier tendency, but on the whole no great deflections, West Chicago opened easy at 1481/4, a decline of 1/2 point, but subsequently it rallied on narrow trading to 1491/2, closing weak at 1481/2.

Lawyer Jerome Buck, who lives at 108 West One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, has taken issue with his next-door neighbor because of a piano. Lester B. Hough is the neighbor. Mr. Buck says the piano is sounded morning, noon, and night, disturbing his peace of mind. Mrs. Hough, who plays the piano, says, on the other hand; that the Bucks are not the most quiet neighbors imaginable.

From The Montreal Witness. Eugene Baldwin, an amateur electrician, has put about twenty sixteen-candle-power incandescent lamps into his residence, at Dixville, Quebec, which he is going to light with storage batteries, manufactured by himself, and so arranged and connected with a dynamo and wind wheel that the whole arrangement will work almost automatically.

The Republican Party in this city got something of a shaking up at the annual primaries held yesterday. It was not the result of the agitation of the sub-committees on reorganization and investigation of the committee appointed recently by the Republican County Committee to investigate, and, if necessary, report a plan for reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the name of Charles W. Dabney, Jr., of Tennessee to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, vice Edwin Willits, resigned. Dr. Dabney is the President of the University of Tennessee. There were forty-eight applicants for this position, coming from almost every Southern and Western State.

War has been declared by the West Side Protective Association against a number of saloons in the district between Seventy-second Street and One Hundred and Fourth Street, west of Central Park. In some of the cases, when the owners first applied for licenses, vigorous protest was made by this association, without avail, and of late a close watch has been kept on the places, with a view of detecting violations of the excise law.

The general collection of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was begun earlier than usual this year to meet the pressing needs of the hospitals in this crisis. At a time when the demands of the suffering sick poor are altogether beyond the capacity of the hospitals to meet, nearly all of them are sorely pinched for means to maintain their charity work.
Sheriff-elect Buttling of Kings County, has promised to take into consideration the matter of holding such judicial sales as he has control over at the Exchange room in Montague Street.

It became known in this city yesterday that Mary H. Martin, the young woman who robbed Mrs. Frank Leslie of a diamond pin, valued at $450, several checks, and a considerable sum in cash, in her apartments in the Gerlach a year ago, and who was sentenced to two years imprisonment in the Kings County Penitentiary, had been released.

If the rulers of the State and country could have listened to the discussion by the Society for Political Study yesterday afternoon they would have heard many suggestions on government by bright women who wear pretty gowns and have charming manners, but who above all things think and talk upon all the chief topics of the day and form very decided opinions thereupon.

The foreign exchange market was firm. Posted rates for sterling were unchanged from yesterday, being $4.86 for sixty-day bills and $4.881/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.841/2@S4.843/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.871/4 @$4.871/2 for demand, $4.873/4@$4.88 for cable transfers, and $4.831/4@$4.833/4 for commercial.

Two failures were announced in the fur trade yesterday, the embarrassed firms being D. Gutlohn Co., importers of furs and skins at 15 Mercer Street, and at Philadelphia, and Charles M. Landsberg, importer of furs at 95 Mercer Street, and at Philadelphia. The Sheriff took charge of the places of business of each concern in this city.

A pretty fair idea of at least part of the proposed line of defense in the trial of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer for poisoning "Gustav Baum" transpired yesterday. From the method of cross-examination employed by Mr. Brooke and Dr. O'Sullivan, it is evident that it will be denied that the corpse buried from 320 East Thirteenth Street was that of Ludwig Brandt or "Gustav Baum."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The testimony in the Court of Inquiry case of Lieut. Richard G. Davenport of the Navy closed with this afternoon's session at the Washington Navy Yard. One or two days may be devoted to arguments before the court hands in its finding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- In spite of all the reports about the divided attitude of the Democrats of the House on the Revenue bill, the Ways and Means Committee, representing the whole House, and presumably fairly representing the Democratic majority of it, approved to-day, in the meeting of the committee, the Republicans being present to oppose, all the schedules as made up yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12. -- The steamer Oceanic arrived from the Orient, via Honolulu, shortly after 10 o'clock this evening.

When George R. Malby, who is to be the next Speaker of the State Assembly, gets the mail matter which is waiting for him in Ogdensburg, N.Y., there may be another chapter ready for publication in the political war between himself and Hamilton Fish.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 13. -- In a convention of the farmers of this Congressional district to-day, the following resolution was adopted:

There is a pacing weanling at Shakopee, Minn., that promises to be a wonder. He is only four and a half months old, and has shown a sixteenth of a mile in 0:14, five days after his first halter lesson. The colt was sired by Arcadian, 2:23 1/4, dam Flora M., by Colonna. Shakopeans believe that this youngster will set a yearling record for Minnesota.

A gas stove exploded yesterday in the house of John O. Morgan, at 67 West Forty-sixth Street, and the flames were quickly carried through the dumb-waiter shaft to the floors above. Mr. Morgan's family, with the exception of his eighteen-year-old son, J. Alfred Morgan, fled from the house by way of the roof, escape by the door being cut off.

Ninety-three gentlemen interested in the fish of the Atlantic seacoast met at the Hotel Gerlach, in Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday. They were there to consult as to the necessity for legislation which will tend to protect the salt-water fishes, which, according to a statement in the call for the meeting, are diminishing in numbers.

From The Washington Post. Few persons face without flinching the duty of addressing a letter of condolence to a bereaved friend. If they use language of moderation they fear their words will seem but "cold comfort" to those that mourn; if they gush, the note of insincerity jars upon their own feelings.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 13. -- People's Party government is making more reform history for suffering Kansas. As soon as it came into possession of the State offices it proceeded to find places for all the relatives of the State officials from the Governor down to the head janitor of the State House.

It now seems probable that the Meyer murder trial will take even a more sensational turn than has been suspected. Informer Mueller may himself be accused of having brought about the death of LudWig Brandt, or "Gustav Baum."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Even before the President has sent to the Congress the correspondence in the Hawaiian matter and the instructions given to Minister Willis, the discussion of the matter in the Senate, is well as the talk of the House Republicans, shows plainly enough that the opposition is stimulated by partisan feeling rather than superior patriotism or correct information.

It is stated from Brussels that George Bunn, one of the many American artists resident in Antwerp, was sentenced at the Assizes held in that city last week to fifteen years' imprisonment, with hard labor, for the murder, on June 5 last, of Anna Hoffmann, a young servant girl who had been employed in the house where he lived.

The Columbian Audit Commission, which met again yesterday morning in the Brooklyn City Hall, learned that Bandmaster Thomas R. Deverell received double commissions for his services in securing bands for the Columbian parade.

Mr. GEORGE J. GOULD explains that the Manhattan Railway Company has no intention of building a third track two miles long under pretense of putting in a siding at a station. This statement, we presume, may be accepted, and it is reassuring. At the same time, it must be said that the contrary impression was not only natural, but that it was produced by the proceedings of the company.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Judge Depue yesterday, in his charge to the Grand Jury, called attention to the recent violations of the election laws. He recommended that a thorough investigation be made. He also called attention to the charge that large and unjustifiable expenditure of money had been made by the Road Board Committee of the Board of Freeholders upon the county roads just before the late election.
Plans were yesterday entered in the Building Department for the following new buildings and alterations:

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- To-day's market was so dull that there was hardly sufficient business to establish quotations. American Strawboard and Canal and Dock advanced 1/2 each, and New-York Biscuit dropped 2 points. Alley L. declined, 3/4. Chicago Brewing and Milwaukee Brewing were both slightly lower.

There was a surprise in store for the patrons of the billiard tournament last night. Ives, who had beaten Slosson 100 points on Monday night, was badly defeated by Schaefer, who had fallen easy prey, in the second game, to Slosson. As a result, the bettors who had gambled in form left the hall in an unhappy frame of mind.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 13. -- A passenger train known as the Harrisburg Express, leaving here at 10:30 o'clock this morning over the Pennsylvania Railroad en route for Pottsville, was wrecked a short distance from Nanticoke half an hour later. The train was going at the rate of thirty miles an hour, when it collided with a freight engine that was running into a siding to allow the passenger train to pass.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. PARIS, Dec. 13. -- Premier Casimir-Perier conferred with Ministers Raynal and Dubost this afternoon, and with them decided upon the vigorous enforcement of the new measures against the Anarchists. The new special police will be formed by Jan. 1, and will be set to work at once in all large towns, searching domiciles, watching railway stations, and frequenting the meetings of the malcontents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The dinner given to-night at Chamberlin's to Representative Ashbel P. Fitch, who is soon to relinquish his duties in Congress to assume those of Controller of the City of New-York, was a brilliant affair. The elaborate menu card veiled a mystery to some in that it did not contain the name of the giver of the dinner.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- The steamer Oceanic brought an open letter from Charles L. Carter, ex-Commissioner of the provisional Government of Hawaii, to Secretary Gresham, in which he denies the statements made by the latter to the President. Mr. Carter visited the United States in the interest of the provisional Government shortly after the revolution of last January.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The Hudson, above Poughkeepsle, is frozen from shore to shore with heavy ice, and people are crossing at Barrytown. Navigation closed to-night, when the tugboats left for New-York with a tow.

When Mr. Wilson gave the Tariff bill for publication he at the same time furnished a statement which was intended to be explanatory of certain of the measures contained in the bill. In this statement a number of particulars and statistics were set forth relative to the tobacco industry.

The reports of railroad earnings for the month of November show an aggregate loss in the gross of a little less than 7 per cent as compared with the corresponding month of last year. The decrease in net earnings is not so great, as almost all of the railroads have made up in economies in operating expenses from one-half to two-thirds of the losses in gross earnings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The marriage of Miss Gracia Mildred Black, daughter of Representative and Mrs. John C. Black, to the Rev. Frank Buffington Vrooman, pastor of the Salem Street Congregational Church, Worcester, Mass., took place at noon to-day in St. John's Church. The church was decorated with palms and white flowers within the chancel.

The appointment of Frank Turnbull, an influential business man in Denver, Col., to be receiver of the Union Pacific, Denver and Gulf Railroad, appears to be satisfactory to all parties in interest. His name was one of three or four submitted to Judge Hallett of the United States Circuit Court by Gen. G.M. Dodgre, Chairman of the Bondholders' Committee, and the appointment was approved by representatives of the Government.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 13. -- A statement was to-day filed in the Surogate's office in this city by Ernest Hall, one of the executors of the late Cordelia E. MacPherson, which shows that, notwithstanding her will gives away legacies, the indebtedness of decedent was far in excess of the amount of her entire estate.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- So confident are the Republicans of electing the State ticket next Fall that already candidates for Governor are beginning to sprout in the political conservatories which the Republican bosses maintain the Winter before a State Convention.

The various and varying currents of that intangible and glittering something known as society converged last night at the Patriarchs ball. The big ballroom at Delmonico's was a whirlpool, the waves of which were costly and beautiful costumes and the foam sparkling jewels and fair faces.

The steamship Peninsular of the Emprezza Insulanna Line, which arrived early yesterday morning from Rio Janeiro, Santos, Bahia, Pernambuco, Para, and other Brazilian ports, brought news of the arrest of prominent citizens of Pernambuco and Rio Janeiro. Capt. Jose A. Bettencourt of the Peninsular said yesterday that when he left Brazil on Dec. 3 there was a strong feeling throughout the country in favor of Mello.

The probabilities of a meeting between "Billy" Plimmer and George Dixon were largely increased yesterday afternoon by a scene which happened in the Williamsburg Opera House, where Plimmer is playing. Louis Waldron, Plimmer's manager, introduced Plimmer as the only man that ever obtained a decision over Dixon, and that he was ready to meet anybody.
A trio of well-dressed young men were arraigned yesterday before Police Justice Connelly in Brooklyn charged with burglary. On the confession of one of them all were held for the Grand Jury.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The Governor, when he opened the bearing of the managers of the Middletown Hospital for the Insane, said that the reason he had called the meeting was because he had read newspaper notices which claimed that the managers were not satisfied with the manner in which the Lunacy Commissioners were conducting the affairs of the State's insane.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- A. Cleveland Coxe, Episcopal Bishop of Western New-York, has written another open letter to Satolli. He begins his communication by saying:

-- The Harvard Annex is hereafter to be known as Radcliffe College, in honor of Anne Radcliffe (subsequently Lady Moulton) of England, who, in 1643, gave u100 to Harvard College. But the first woman to contribute to its funds was Mrs. George Glover, who, according to President Eliot's History of the College, gave u10 in 1642 to the fund to pay the salary of Henry Dunster, its first President.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Navy Department has heard how it was that the turret guns of the New-York turned without notice and wrecked the awning stanchions on the deck of that vessel. It appears to have been due to carelessness in making connections with pipes.

The unfortunate lack of direct and continuous communication with Hawaii causes all information from that quarter at this critical time to come in spasms that are rather hysterical. It also comes almost wholly from sources that are controlled by the provisional Government and its supporters.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the Board of Managers of the Presbyterian Hospital, at Madison Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street, shows very good work done by this institution, which is undenominational in its benefits. The managers emphasize two points in their experience this year, the increase of their work and the necessity for increase of their means to do the work.

The meeting of the State Lunacy Commission and the boards of local managers of the State hospitals for the insane, which was to have been held to-day at the Park Avenue Hotel, has been postponed indefinitely. A few of the members of the local boards, who protested against the management by the commission, received notices yesterday that because of the illness of Commissioners Brown and Reeves, no meeting would be held.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange listed the following securities today:

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Fire started to-night in Henry Scowell's job printing office in Cannon Place. The building is owned and in the main, occupied by William H. Frear, the largest dry goods dealer in this city. The flames worked their way westwardly from the northeast corner along the entire length of the building. The loss will be very heavy, as the immense stock is badly damaged by smoke and water.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The State Board of Canvassers to-day canvassed the vote of the recent State election. Clerk Waterbury read the result as follows:

The amateur minstrels of the New-York Athletic Club gave an entertainment consisting of "divertissements al fresco and other violent disturbances" at Music Hall last night. At least, this is how the programme announced it, and the object was said to be for "our amusement, your entertainment, and incidentally to purchase a club steam launch."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 13 -- The official figures for the lake ore traffic are some-what of a surprise. The amount of ore brought down the lakes this season exceeds all estimates and is not as far short of the great total of last year as was expected. The receipts for Lake Erie ports reach the large aggregate of 5,333,000 tons.
Justice Barnard's decision in the case of Chief of Police John Y. McKane of Gravesend, who is charged with contempt of court, is in Brooklyn.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 13. -- Julius Jackson, who came to this city from New-York about six weeks ago and engaged in the fur business on Pleasant Street, was arrested to-day for grand larceny at the request of Superintendent Byrnes. Joseph Steiner Co., fur dealers on Spring Street, New-York, are the victims.
The Veteran Firemen's Association of the Paid Fire Department had its third annual banquet at the Murray Hill Hotel last night. The reunion was a signal success.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- Charles R. Thorne, the veteran actor and theatrical manager, died in this city to-day.

Caleb Cushing Adams of the jewelry firm of C.C. Adams Co., Brooklyn, and brother of City Works Commissioner John P. Adams, died suddenly yesterday morning at his residence, 895 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, of apoplexy.

CHICAGO, Dec 13. -- The wheat market was dull and uninteresting to-day, price changes covering a range of but 5/3 of a cent. The feeling was steady at the start, becoming easy, and ruling so throughout the greater part of the session. The close, however, was rather firm, at unchanged figures from yesterday for May, with December a fraction higher than Tuesday's close.

WASHINGTON Dec. 13 -- The Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee to-day decided to put a small duty on laundry soap. The committee has been informed that, while the United States is a large exporter of soap. It does not send abroad all grades. As long as alkalies are taxed the committee regards it as imprudent to put the entire class of soap on the free list.

LISBON, Dec. 13. -- The British steamer Nile, which sailed from Pernambuco, Brazil, on Dec. 5, arrived here to-day. She was boarded at once by the United Press correspondent, who obtained this news from the officers and mall advices:

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 13. -- A series of interesting experiments is soon to be begun off the torpedo station in this harbor. Upon the result depends the purchase of the several submarine torpedo boats, bids for the construction of which are now in possession of the Navy Department. The experiments will be conducted by Commander George A. Converse, commandant of the torpedo station.

ELMIRA, Dec. 13. -- The Elmira Reformatory investigating commission heard more about Brockway's paddle to-day. Several inmates of the reformatory testified that they had been disciplined in the bathroom, one for fighting, one for having tobacco in his possession, one for refusing to take castor oil, and so on.

ROME, Dec. 13. -- Official documents just issued confirm the report that the Banca Romana lost u1,000,000 in supporting the price of Italian rentes on European Bourses. It was understood that the Government would compensate the bank for the loss. It is shown also that the Banca Romana's issue of a double series of notes was made with the approval of the Government.

One hundred creditors of N.J. Schloss Co., manufacturers of boys' clothing at 653 and 655 Broadway, met at the Broadway Central Hotel yesterday. Lawyer Kohn read a long statement prepared by Arnold Davidson, the expert accountant who had been at work on the books of the firm for a week.

On the last day of the year, which falls on a Sunday, the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton will, in all probability, cease to be the pastor of the West Presbyterian Church, in Forty-second Street. After the regular week-night services in the lecture room of the church last evening a session of the Church members was held to take the final steps leading to the acceptance of Dr. Paxton's resignation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The advices from Capt. Picking, in command of the naval force at Rio, received to-day at the Navy Department show an involved state of affairs at the Brazilian port. It begins to look like actual warfare at last.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- If possible there was less demand for money at the Clearing House this morning than usual of late. Some few loans were made at 1 1/2 and 1 per cent., but there was little trouble in obtaining funds at the latter rate. Bankers predict a better demand in the near future. Call money rules from 2@3, time 3 1/2@4, and business paper 3 3/4@5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- It begins to look as if Dr. C.C. Woolworth, the Castleton (N.Y.) postal-card manufacturer, who has been unable to fill his contract for cards with the Post Office Department by reason of the inferior quality of his cardboard, will be able to sell cards to Uncle Sam after all.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 13. -- A.S. Clay, President of the Senate, has announced that he will not be a candidate for Govern- or. He is a young man who has a great personal following and has been regarded as a strong candidate. Other candidates are Gen. C.S. Evans. W.H. Atkinson, Speaker of the House of Representatives.
The sale by Mr. Isaac Kuhn of the four-story brick building 39 and 41 Ann Street, 23 by 38 feet, for about $50,000, was made yesterday.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted to-day.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

The cause of tariff reform was never in so good case as now. We desire to say this with some emphasis, because we notice a disposition among some of its friends to think that the cause will not steer its way safely through the eddying currents and the rocks of the present session of Congress, but will be run ashore by false servants or blocked by open enemies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- The American Federation of Labor convention this afternoon passed resolutions indorsing Gov. Altgeld's action in pardoning Fielden, Schwab, and Neebe, the Anarchists. The resolution was as follows:

William Strohhoefer on Tuesday went before Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, and asked for a writ of habeas corpus, in order that he might obtain his wife, Lucy, who, he said, was detained against her will at the home of her father, Henry Koelle, 306 East Eighty-sixth Street. The writ was granted, and yesterday morning Mrs. Strohhoefer was brought into court by her mother.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- Money continues in abundant supply at the Clearing House. Some few loans were made at 1@1 1/2 per cent., but money was easily obtainable at 1 per cent. There is little change in the outside market. Call funds ruled at 2@3 per cent., time at 3 1/2@4 per cent., business paper at 3 3/4@5 per cent., and collateral loans at 3 1/2@4 per cent.

The fact that B.J. Treacy recently disposed of all his horses in training led to the belief that he was about to retire from the turf for good, and a rumor was spread to that effect. This, however, is not the case, as Mr. Treacy still has a number of yearlings, and these he will develop and race under his old green and orange colors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- At the trial of Daniel Coughlin this morning, Sebastian Steib, policeman, testified that about 11:30 o'clock he was walking on Fullerton Avenue, near Cooper Street, when he noticed passing him at a brisk trot, going east, a horse and wagon, similar to a carpenter's wagon. On a low front seat, lacing the horse, sat two men, whom the witness did not recognize.

The Iron Age reports a sharp increase in the output of pig iron, the weekly capacity of furnaces in blast having risen from 73,895 tons on Oct. 1 to 80.070 on Nov. 1, and 99,379 tons on Dec. 1, with farther additions since the last-named date. This increase "is due almost entirely." says the Iron Age, "to the resumption of plants connected with rolling mills and steel works."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Now that the bill granting Statehood to Utah is in the possession of the Senate, there Is a general desire to ascertain the sentiments of the Senators regarding it. Several Senators who were Questioned to-day by a correspondent of The New-York Times expressed the opinion that the measure would not be subjected to very bitter opposition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Senhor Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister, gave out some information to-day and explained a perplexing confusion of names in recent news.
The case of the People against Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer was concluded yesterday. The defense will open to-day.

The weather was not kind to the gentlemen of Boston last night. If there had been less snow, no doubt the second concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Music Hall would have been attended by a much larger audience. It certainly deserved to be. The programme was admirably arranged, serious matter alternating with light and agreeable matter In an effective and stimulating manner.

District Leader-Police Commissioner James J. Martin appeared to be somewhat disturbed in mind yesterday, when asked if he had anything to say concerning the charge made in yesterday's New-York Times, to the effect that the Police Department was virtually run by two Tammany Hall "district leaders " -- himself and Commissioner John C. Sheehan.

Fishermen, professional and amateurs, who have been talking about the salt-water fisheries for a couple of days, concluded their conference yesterday, after making arrangements to have their proceedings printed and distributed among men interested in the matters under consideration.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Dec. 14 -- P.M. The movement in the stock market to-day was a repetition of that of yesterday. The volume of trading was almost the same, and the fluctuations were even narrower. Prices sagged most of the day, but recovered the greater part of their losses in the last hour. London did little or nothing.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Ex-Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild was the guest of honor at the first annual dinner of the Rochester Clearing House Association, given at the Genesee Valley Club this evening. Fifty gentlemen, representing the moneyed institutions of the city, were present. Henry C. Brewster, President of the association, presided.
John Y. McKane will probably eat his Christmas dinner in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn.

As some kind of an offset to the terrible distress among the unemployed, a people's restaurant and lodging house will soon be opened at 170 Bleecker Street as a separate department of the work of the Industrial Alliance.

Without a moment's notice Mr. Walter Damrosch resigned from the Musical Protective Union at the regular quarterly meeting of that body held yesterday afternoon at its rooms, Ninety-first Street and Third Avenue. The resignation was the sudden culmination of a conflict which for some time past has been waged between the union and the leader of the New-York Symphony Orchestra.

JOHN Y. McKANE and his lawyers are determined to make a desperate fight to keep the Gravesend "boss" out of jail, though they would probahly have acquiesced in Judge BARNARD'S sentence if he had been let off with a fine. They propose to get an appeal and carry the question to the court of last resort, if they can.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Dec. 14. -- A smoldering ruin is all that is left of the handsome country house of Col. S.V.R. Cruger near Bayville. The house, which was one of the attractions of Long Island's north shore, was destroyed by fire early this morning.

The steamship Havel of the North German Lloyd Line arrived at her dock at Hoboken yesterday afternoon twenty-eight hours overdue. She showed every evidence of the rough passage she had experienced, for her bulwarks were covered with a blanket of ice, and every line was glistening and stiff with an inch coating.

The University Settlement Society gave a reception at its rooms, 26 Delancey Street, yesterday afternoon, and evening. Hundreds of the friends of the organization honored the invitations, and the women who constituted the Reception Committee were kept busy welcoming the guests and explaining the theory and workings of the society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Now that the Senate has adjourned until Monday, the Senators who were in a hurry to have the President wait upon them with a message about Hawaii will be obliged to speculate a little longer about what is likely to happen, and to nurse their expectations that the President has determined to wage war against the provisional Government and the Constitution, without any regard whatever for consequences.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 14. -- In reply to a letter from the editor of The New-York Independent, Cardinal Gibbons writes as follows under date Dec. 7:

Vicar General Michael McCabe of the Providence (R.I.) Diocese, and pastor of St. Charles's Church, in Woonsocket, since 1855, was found dead in bed at his parochial residence, in Woonsocket, R.I., yesterday morning. He was on the street Wednesday evening, in apparent good health. Heart disease was the probable cause of death. His age was sixty-seven years.

The mercury in every truthful and conscientious thermometer in the city at 4 o'clock yesterday morning shrank into the bulb until the tiny column of white metal was only thirteen notches above zero. It was the coldest day of the year, and that was the hour when the cold was most marked.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- J.J. Van Alen, who declined the appointment to be United States Ambassador to Italy, arrived at Liverpool yesterday on the steamship Majestic. To the United Press's correspondent he said:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- A series of experiments will be conducted at the Yale Psychological Laboratory to-morrow the result of which will be followed with great interest by the entire scientific world. The object of the experiments is to determine the exact relation of muscular action to the nerves.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- Prices were fairly steady. Pennsylvania opened at 48 7/8 and declined to 48 5/8, closing, however, at 48 3/4 bid. The bears made their daily attack on Lehigh Valley, but it did not bring out any long stock, and the price was fairly well maintained. It opened at 37 1/2 and closed at 37 1/8 bid, but was not offered below 37 1/2.

NASHVILLE, Teun., Dec. 14. -- The arrest of Col. George J. Rice in Chattanooga, charged with forgery, has brought to light a startling history of systematic swindling extending over four months. The names of at least ten wealthy and prominent citizens of Chattanooga have been forged to notes in various amounts and aggregating over $2,600.

The Union League Club held a lively meeting last evening. The report of the Committee on Political Reform, which had been directed to consider on Nov. 9 whether or not the club should lead any movement to unite all good men, without any reference to political affiliations, on the one issue of good government for this city, was under discussion..

The handsome bronze statue of the Rev. Father John C. Drumgoole which was recently cast in Philadelphia was placed upon its pedestal yesterday afternoon, and will probably be unveiled sometime within the next two weeks. The statue, which represents Father Drumgoole in the act of receiving a little newsboy into the institution of which he was the founder, stands more than 20 feet in height.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Mrs. Mary A. Connelly, wife of Controller James F. Connelly, died suddenly at her frame, 14 Park Street, at 11 o'clock to-night. Death was caused by heart failure, superinduced by peritonitis. Mrs. Connelly was forty-six years old. She enjoyed good health until Sunday.

Theodore B. Willis owed his appointment as Naval Officer by President Harrison to the influence of the President's Secretary of the Navy, Gen. B.F. Tracy, Franklin Woodruff, and other prominent Brooklyn Republicans. He had commended himself to this element of the party in that city by a long and hard fight against the Nathan machine, in which he persisted in spite of many repulses.

An objection to the probate of the will of Charles B. Beck, who died at Richfield Springs Oct. 11, was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office by counsel representing Matilda Carter, who claims that she was a daughter of Alexander Bathgate, an uncle of Charles B. Beck.
LIVERPOOL, Dec. 14. -- American live cattle, sinking the offal, 6d per 1b.

Collectively or individually the Patriarchs are very distinguished, personages indeed. When they give any one of their big dances they gather around them, other scarcely less distinguished individuals. To be the central figure, the pivotal point, the focus of attraction, in such an assemblage as that named is, therefore, a distinction of no small dimensions.

BARBADOS, Dec. 14. -- The United States revenue cutter Grant, which left New-York Dec. 6 for San Francisco, arrived here this morning. She will remain only long enough to recoal, when she will sail for Bahia, where she should arrive Dec. 28. It is expected that the Grant will stop at Rio de Janeiro, where she may be called upon for service should occasion require.

A wedding which attracted its full share of interest and a large number of spectators took place yesterday afternoon in Grace Church. The contracting persons were Miss Katherine Sands, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sands, and Theodore A. Havemeyer, Jr. The church was decorated with white roses, chrysanthemums, and palms.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- The Governor to-day designated Charles F. Brown, a Justice of the Supreme Court, of the Second Judicial District, to be Presiding Justice of the General Term of the Supreme Court for the Second Department, in the place of Judge Barnard, whose term of office will expire Dec. 31. Judge Brown was formerly a member of the Court of Appeals, Second Department.

It was in 1889 that a memorable petition was circulated among the New-England manufacturers engaged in the various branches of the iron and steel industry, and in December of that year it was laid before the McKinley Ways and Means Committee, with, an elaborate argument in support of the petitioners' requests.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The Lisbon correspondent of the United Press obtained today a few additional facts as to the state of affairs in Brazil on Dec. 5, when the steamer Nile sailed.
The Brooklyn Democratic Club held an important meeting at the clubrooms, 201 Montague Street, last evening. There was a large attendance. George Foster Peabody presided.
Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for ex-Police Captain William H. Clinchy a lot 25 by 98.10, on the south side of West One Hundred and Twentieth Street, 275 feet west of Fifth Avenue.

Having successfully completed her two preliminary speed tests, the cruiser New-York returned to harbor yesterday from another trial, with which speed had nothing to do. It was conducted under the super-vision of the Naval Board of Inspection, and was mainly for the purpose of ascertaining if the builders had done their full duty in fashioning the craft.

The independent county organization which was projected by Civil Justice Steckler, Civil Justice McCrea, Charles Steckler, J.H.J. Ronner, Ernest Harner, John D. Townsend, Julius Harburger, and others was formally introduced to the public at a mass meeting in the great hall of the Cooper Institute last night.
Judge Henry W. Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas was attacked, robbed, and seriously injured at an early hour yesterday morning in Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Mr. Voorhees (Dem., Ind.,) introduced in the Senate to-day a bill for the coinage of silver dollars, the retirement of small denominations of gold and paper, and for other purposes, and it was referred to the Committee on Finance.

(From The Wall Street Journal, Dec. 12.) The last balance sheet of the Reading Company appeared last February, just before the collapse, and was that of Nov. 30, 1892. The company has been obliged under tae law to file a balance sheet at Albany, that of June 30, 1893, or seven months later than last available figures. We print it in full:

BUFFALO, Dec. 14. -- The block at Clinton and Main Streets and extending back to Washington, known as the Arcade, was destroyed by fire this morning, and Robinson's Musee Theatre and Shea'S concert hall are in ruins.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Nearly all the active stocks were hammered to-day, some of them badly -- Alley L. for instance. At the opening American Strawboard was in good demand at 35, or 1 1/2 points above yesterday; but, when West Side and Alley L were unmercifully attacked, Strawboard followed, dropping 2 points below the high mark, to 33.

The city will not begin the construction of any more armories at present. At yesterday's meeting of the Armory Board in the Mayor's office President Edward. P. Barker of the Department of Taxes called attention to the fact that two regiments had recently been disbanded, and then offered a resolution setting forth the already heavy indebtedness for armories, and calling on the brigade commander to state if any necessity exists for further accommodations.

J.W. Reinhart, President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, arrived here from England on the steamship Teutonic late yesterday afternoon. He was met by Vice President D.B. Robinson and other officers of the road.

In the Supreme Court yesterday Judge McAdam granted a decree of absolute divorce to Amy Boucicault from her husband, Aubrey Boucicault, son of Dion Boucicault. Mrs. Boucicault was permitted to resume her maiden name, Amy Busby. Miss Victory Bateman, who was named as co-respondent in the suit, is entirely exonerated.

The following letter was forwarded yesterday to Chairman "Wilson of the House Committee on Ways and Means by the Committee of Importers of Chemicals and Drugs of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation:
Money on call loaned at 1@ 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.
LEAD, S.D., Dec. 14. -- The eighty stamp mill of the Homestake Company has started up and a hundred men are given employment.

In a communication to the State Board of Railroad Commissioners the Metropolitan Traction Company sets forth the need of improved methods of propelling street cars in this city, and its desire to adopt the best possible substitute for horses on that part of its system where the use of the cable is not practicable.
Wheat lost 5/8c, through free unloading by longs here and at the West, with cables easier, and the close weak.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

There were always books for gifts at Christmas and at New Year's Day. It was in honor of these festivals that the Dukes of Burgundy gave orders to scribes for the most sumptuously-illuminated copies of ancient manuscripts made in their time. There were Missals, Horae, and Biblia Pauperum before the invention of printing; then, there were almanacs, albums, and keepsakes; but now we have all the books that have value.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Wheat developed a very weak tone to-day. New-Yorkers started the sellings, and it was not long before local longs, who had become tired of their holdings, vied with them and with each other in their eagerness to sell wheat. The opening was about the same as yesterday's close, declining 7/8@1c; reacted silghtly, and at the close May showed a loss of 3/4 c for the day.

The Police Department has been, ever since it was organized, one of the most powerful, persistent, and inveterate obstacles to the good [government of New-York. Considering the relations of the department to "politics," and of politics to crime, this is not at all a matter for wonder. There has not been for twenty years and more an administration of the department that commanded the public confidence.

The Rev. Vernon Murray Olyphant, second son of Robert Murray Olyphant, President of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, was found by his father dead in his study at the family residence, 160 Madison Avenue, shortly after 6 o'clock last evening.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The marriage of Miss Adele Grant, daughter of the late Beach Grant of New-York, to the Earl of Essex took place at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon at St. Margaret's Church, Westminster. Archdeacon Farrar, assisted by the Rev. Mr. Lee, the Rev. Mr. James, and the Chaplain of the Duke of Essex, the Rev. George Chapel, officiated.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- All new loans at the Clearing House this morning were made at 1 per cent., and funds were freely offered at that rate. Many banks, however, preferred to carry their funds home rather than loan them. Six months collateral loans at 3 1/2 per cent. were reported to-day.

The "American League" of Honolulu has availed itself of the good offices of a Seattle contractor, who has been out to Hawaii to get the job of constructing a railroad, to send an appeal to the people of the United States to support the provisional Government and not let President CLEVELAND re-establish the monarchy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The sub-committee on internal revenue of the Ways and Means Committee had a short meeting this afternoon, at which the general subject of an income tax was informally discussed. Two of the sub-committe, Messrs. McMillin and Bryan, favored reporting a tax on individual incomes as well as on corporations and legacies.

Dr. Wright perhaps suggests a magnifying of his office when he likens his Bronte investigations to the discovery of the source of the river Nile, but the simile is not wholly out of place. Of Irish Bronte history we have had an extremely meagre record, and repeated efforts to explore the ground have met with unsatisfactory results.
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres says:

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- In the course of his examination by the Juge d'Instruction, Vaillant, the man who threw the bomb in the Chamber of Deputies, said that he obtained the sum of 100f. from a prosperous and militant Anarchist, it being understood that he should expend the money in making arrangements for a grand coup.

The annual dinner of the second panel of the Sheriff's Jury at Delmonico's on Thursday night drew together a distinguished array of orators. First, Adorn Smith and then ex-Congressman John S. Wise of Virginia presided. Among those present were Recorder Smyth, Judges Ehrlich, McAdam, Van Brunt, and Bischoff, ex-Mayor A. Oakey Hall, James L. Gordon, C.D. Langhorne, ex-Judge Noah Davis, and Gen. Wager Swayne.

During the past week Superintendent Brady of the Building Department has issued permits calling for the construction of forty-five new buildings, at a total estimated cost of $794,000, and also for alterations to be made to thirty-one structures at an expense of $48,000.

The prominent sensation in the Meyer murder trial materialized yesterday sure enough, but not in the shape expected. It came in the practical abandonment of all effort at defense. On Monday the case will go to the jury.

This handsome volume covers a wide field. It traces the history of engraving from the middle of the fifteenth, century, when it was practiced merely as an aid to goldsmiths' work, forward to the latter part of the present century, stopping at the work of living artists, an account of which is not attempted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The precipitate decline of yesterday continued to-day, particularly in West Chicago and Alley Elevated stock. The latter opened at 40 5/8, and in a few minutes was selling at 40, a drop of 1 point from the final trade of the last session. It improved to 40 1/2 and then fell to 39 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- By the strong vote of 185 to 61 the House this afternoon, after animated discussion, passed the bill to enable the Territory of Arizona to enter the Union upon conditions similar to those imposed upon Utah in the bill passed on Wednesday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15. -- The middle span of the timber false work of the bridge now under construction between East Louisville and Jeffersonville, Ind., collapsed at about 10 o'clock this morning, crushing to death and drowning between twenty and thirty men, and injuring about twenty more, some of whom will die.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Dec. 15 -- P.M. There was even less done in to-day's stock market than yesterday. Sugar overshadowed the market, nearly a third of the transactions being in that stock. It was advanced sharply late in the day, on a preconcerted attack on the short interest, and it closed 2 5/8 points higher at 82 5/8, having sold at 82 7/8.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Dec. 15. -- The United States cruiser Olympia, on her official trial to-day, made a record of 21.67 knots for the length of the course in Santa Barbara Channel, which is slightly below the speed attained on her recent unfinished run. The maximum speed during the trial is estimated at 22.05 knots.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15. -- Society and science vied at Yale to-night for honors. It was the second annual meeting of the Yale Gymnasium Association, and the occasion was marked by the appearance of Dr. P.F. O'Connor of Columbia College, champion, swordsman of America, in the sabre class; Dr. Gramo Hammond, champion of the duelist class; Prof. Jacoby of the New-York Athletic Club, and Dr. Postel, the newly-appointed instructor of fencing at Yale.

The only voluntary auction offering of real estate yesterday was by Morris Wilkins of E.H. Ludlow Co. The property was 107 and 109 Walker Street, the latter being the southwest corner of Centre Street; 107 is 25.5 by 65 by 75, with five-story brick building. The corner is a vacant lot, 19.5 by 75.

THE TIMES has already shown how perfectly idle it is to attack the Superintendent of Police for anything that goes wrong in the department of which he is the ostensible head. To direct such attacks upon the Superintendent is not only to do an injustice to him -- which is perhaps a minor matter -- but it is to play directly into the hands of the persons who are really responsible.

The answer of the Reading receivers to the petition of Isaac L. Rice, in his suit to secure access to the company's stock list, was filed in the Circuit Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia, yesterday. Receivers Harris, Paxson, and Welsh enter explicit denials to each and all of Mr. Rice's allegations of improper financiering, mismanagement, and unjust discrimination.

The Pery Street Methodist Episcopal Church will have a silver jubilee next week. The church is the outgrowth of a mission established in Washington Street about thirty years ago, and later transplanted to Bank Streeet. Within a few years the mission grew so large that a new home was necessary.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The will of Edward Martin, who died at Red Hook, N.Y., Dec. 3, has been filed in Judge Hudson's court at Yorkville, Kendall County, Ill.

CANTON, Mass., Dec. 15. -- Brooks Block, a brick structure, and the largest business block in town, was partly burned this morning. F.R. Pitcher Co., dry goods, and G.T. Hunt, grocer, are the heaviest losers. The loss is $25,000; insured.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15. -- The steamer Alameda sailed for Australia via Honolulu this afternoon. Among the passengers was L.A. Thurston, Minister of the provisional Government to the United States. He is hurrying home to personally lay the full status of the case before the provisional Government.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Vice Chancellor Green to-day granted an order to show cause why the books of the Hoffman House Company, New-York, which is organized under the laws of New-Jersey, should not be placed at the disposition of W.E.D. Stokes, one of the stockholders in the company, for inspection.
