The uninitiated at the Madison Square Garden during the recent Horse Show who may have strayed near the boxes of the horsey contingent or near the judges must have wondered what "matched team," "appointments," and "conformation" actually, meant, and this question also bothered the judges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Cosmos Club of this city, had an opportunity last night to learn how the awards for beer wer made at the Chicago Exposition, and how they were rendered practically worthless by the arbitrary decisions of the "edperts."

John Y. McKane will have an opportunity to-morrow of presiding over the Sheepshead Bay Sunday school of which he is Superintendent. This opportunity has been afforded him through the kindness of Col. Albert E. Lamb, who was interested in having him adjudged guilty of contempt of court.

Unusual interest attached to yesterday afternoon's public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society at Music Hall because Dr. Antonin Dvorak's new symphony, entitled "From the New World," was performed for the first time from the manuscript score. It is altogether a unique and notable event that one of the world's greatest composers of symphonic music should produce a new work, written in America, for Americans, before Americans.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15. -- The annual Yale Law School catalogue was issued this week. Several additions to the Faculty and lecturers are announced.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- The truth of the report of the "deal " between the Essex and Hudson members of the Legislature for the capture of the offices of State Treasurer and State Controller is authoritatively denied, Essex having refused to join Hudson in the scheme.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Dec. 15 -- The ruins of Col. S.V.R. Cruger's country house at Bayville, which was destroyed by fire yesterday morning, were guarded last night by men employed on the place. It was feared the published reports of the loss of diamonds and jewelry might attract prowlers to the scene with the hope of securing some of the missing valuables.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- At the trial of Daniel Coughlin to-day the prosecution brought the case up to the Carlson cottage, at 1,872 North Ashland Avenue, where Dr. Cronin was beaten to death. The first witness to testify regarding the scene of the assassination was William B. Hatfield, who sold to "J.B. Simonds" the furniture which was found in the cottage.

PHOENIXVILLE, Penn., Dec. 15. -- The Louisville bridge which was wrecked to-day was erected by the Phoenix Bridge Company of this place, and it is supposed that a large number of Phoenixville workmen were among those who went down with the wreck. On this account the news of the accident caused great excitement here.

Dun's Review to-morrow will say: "It is proof of the enormous vitality of the country that, while mills are stopping in every direction, and the army of unemployed is larger than it has been for many years, other mills are constantly starting up to answer the demand which a single year of unprecedented disaster has only diminished.

The Professional Woman's League opened a genuine Christmas fairyland Thursday night at 153 West Twenty-third Street, and it was pretty and picturesque enough to please the most expert in stage effects.

William and Ida Bennett of 131 West Twenty-eighth Street, who say they are husband and wife, were arrested on Thursday, the woman on a charge of robbery and the man for assaulting a policeman. On Wednesday night Daniel Gleason, a waiter, met the woman and went to her home with her.

The friends of the American University feel greatly encouraged by a recent gift of $100,000 as a contribution to help on the work. At the meeting of the Trustees of the university in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, the Chancellor, Bishop J.F. Hurst, announced that the gift had been made by a gentleman who desired that his name should not be made public.

The monthly meeting of the Union League Club has a small collection of paintings lent by members and others which are, with one exception, by Europeans, and, with a few exceptions, by masters of the past. The exceptional American is George Inness, N.A., whose little landscape, not in the catalogue, is a gem of the first water, but is hoisted as high as the walls allow.

The Hon. JOHN SHERMAN has informed a Philadelphia correspondent that "whether the Tariff bill can be defeated or not will depend entirely upon the Northern Democratic Senators. The prospect for aid from them," he adds, "is not very flattering." It would not be very flattering to them to say that there is any prospect whatever of aid from that source.

The fourth round of the Master Chess Tournament was finished yesterday at the Manhattan Cafe when Ettlinger beat the first favorite, Pillsbury, in a P -- Q4 opening atter fifty-three moves. Showaltor beat Hodges in a P -- Q4 opening after forty-three moves, and Halpern disposed of Hanham after thirty-two moves.

The second concert of the Kneisel Quartet of Boston, which took place in the chamber music room at Music Hall last evening, was a most delightful entertainment. Its most important feature was the first performance of a new sextuor in A minor for two violins, two violas, and two 'celli, by C.M. Loeffier, one of the first violins of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Notwithstanding the agreement of the General Managers of the Central Traffic Association roads that no more rate cutting should be indulged in at this time, the knife was vigorously applied to-day, and rates on butter, eggs, and poultry were reduced 6 cents per 100 pounds to seaboard points.

Wall Street Journal, Dec. 15. We are told by excellent authority that the Rothschilds' interest in Reading has signed in favor of Mr. Isaac L. Rice and his plan, and that this is one of the reasons for Judge Paxson's trip to Europe. The Rothschilds are not large stockholders, but their influence in securing other English proxies is paramount.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- As already stated in these dispatcbes, the Ways and Means Committee has been quite indifferent about the proposition to hold a caucus on the revenue bill. The bill must fall or stand by the votes of the Democrats of the House, and if there are Democrats enough to make the Republicans a majority by combining with them, then the efforts of the Ways and Means Committee will have been in vain.

District Leader-Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan, late of Buffalo, has assumed the role lately abandoned by John Y. McKane, the "Boss" of Coney Island, viz.: That of a blustering politician defying the lightning of public sentiment.

We directed attention yesterday to the latest report of the Iron Age concerning the production of iron, which shows a marked recovery since the date of greatest depression, on or about Oct. 1. The rate of production at the base of the iron industry has, with very good reason, been regarded as an indication of great value as to the general condition of business.

Policeman Kane, passing under the Second Avenue elevated railroad, near Thirty-fourth Street, shortly after midnight Thursday, heard a great shouting above and saw a man's legs hanging through the ties. Kane made his way up and found the station hands and two men from Brooklyn pulling at a man who had fallen between the ties, but whose overcoat, becoming tangled, had formed a bundle that prevented him from falling to the street.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 15 -- In the United States court, to-day, Laura Ann Huggins, colored, of Norfolk, convicted of pension frauds, was sentenced to five years at hard labor in the Albany Penitentiary and to pay a fine of $2,000. In 1867, as the widow of Samuel Gregory, (who was killed at the battle of Deep Bottom,) she applied for a pension.

A meeting of the Trustees of the Temple Emanu-El had just ended last night when smoke began pouring up through the floor in a corner of the meeting room. The Trustees tried to extinguish the fire, but failing, sent in an alarm. So many engines had gone to the fire in Columbus Avenue that a second alarm had to be rung to get engines at the temple.

One of the densest fogs which ever obscured objects was spread over this city yesterday. As a result, river traffic was very much interfered with, and several mishaps were reported. None of them, fortunately, was very serious.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- "To consider the Nicaragua Canal and the duties of the Government toward it" was the subject which called out a full meeting of the House Commerce Committee this morning. Senators Frye and Morgan were the speakers. Both gentlemen have made an exhaustive study of the matter, and appeared at the meeting at the request of the committee.

The fencing with words between Capt. Hippolyte Nicolas, who for several years was instructor at the Fencers' Club, and Armand Jacoby, fencing instructor of the New-York Athletic Club, is growing alarming. Prof. Jacoby found the following in his Thursday morning mail:

If "Napoleon " Ives can outgeneral "Wizard" Schaefer at to-night's billiard game he will win first place in the tournament. At present both men are even, and the result of to-night's contest is looked forward to with unusual interest by the lovers of the game in this city. Numbers of small bets were made late last night, and a sporting man named Wheelock said that he was prepared to wager $10,000 on Schaefer.

The Young Women's Christian Association opened Tuesday in its needlework rooms, at 7 East Fifteenth Street, its annual two weeks' Christmas sale of useful and ornamental articles made by consignors who need the proceeds for their support.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- John Field, ex-Postmaster of this city and a leading business man, addressed a letter to Senator Sherman calling his attention to the stagnation in business throughout the country and attributing it to the uncertainty felt in business circles on account of the prospect of change in the tariff, and requesting Senator Sherman to state what course the Republican Senators will pursue toward the bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Second Controller Mansur of the Treasury has begun the consideration of the case of Gen. Daniel E. Sickles. Gen. Sickles draws two salaries -- one as member of Congress from the Tenth District of New-York and one as Major General on the retired list of the United States Army.

A fire unexampled in ferocity and the rapidity with which it spread and destroyed started at 12:10 yesterday afternoon in the big seven-story brick building 795, 797, and 799 Third Avenue, owned by Patrick A. Cassidy and occupied by Henry Thoesen Brother as a furniture warehouse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The House Committee on Military Affairs to-day ordered favorably reported to the House the bill introduced by Mr. Curtis of New-York for the relief of Brevet-Major Gen. George S. Greene of the United States Volunteers. By the bill the President is authorized to appoint Gen. Greene to the rank of First Lieutenant of Artillery, and to place him on the retired list of the army at that grade.
Ex-Mayor Alfred C. Chapin of Brooklyn and Mrs. Chapin had a narrow escape from serious injury as they were returning home from this city at 11:50 last night.

Suit has been brought against Lawyer James D. Hallen of 265 Broadway, in the Supreme Court, by Mrs. Florence H. Caldwell for $23,300, which he is charged with having dishonestly obtained by "his lying, malicious, and fraudulent statements." Hallen, it is said, has disappeared, and he is thought to be in Philadelphia.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 15. -- One of the prosperous companies of this city manufactures twist steel drills in large quantities. It buys the steel used almost wholly from foreign manufacturers, and pays the high rate of duty on it because it suits its purposes better than any made in this country.

Fourteen families, who occupied the double tenement houses 949 and 951 Columbus Avenue were driven by fire from their supper tables last evening, and for two hours stood in the street watching the total destruction of their possessions.

VIENNA, Dec. 15. -- Ernst von Plener, Minister of Finance and formerly leader of the German Liberal Deputies, announced in the lower house to-day that, despite recent disturbances in the money market of the world, the Government would continue reforming the currency and introducing a change of taxation according to the principle that the heaviest burdens, must be borne by the strongest shoulders.

The affairs of N.J. Schloss Co., manufacturers of boys' clothing at 653 and 655 Broadway, are likely to result in much litigation. Yesterday twenty-two judgments, amounting to about $360,000, were entered against the firm, most of them being in favor of creditors who were preferred in the assignment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Charles A. Schieren, Mayor-elect of Brooklyn, arrived in Washington this morning from Bristol, Tenn., and registered at the Arlington. Mr. Schieren is constructing a large tannery at Bristol. He left Brooklyn on Monday, so that his trip has been hurried. He was accompanied by Wliliam Berri of Brooklyn who was glad to get an insight into this branch of Mr. Schieren's large business.

A new time table will be put in effect on the Adirondack Division of the New-York Central to-morrow. The connection at Herkimer with the Empire State Express, leaving New-York at 8:30 A.M., will be discontinued, and a new Adirondack and Montreal express placed in service, scheduled to leave New-York at 7:30 P.M., with through sleeping cars from Malone and Adirondack Mountain points, arriving at Malone at 7:30 A.M., and connecting for Montreal.

Dr. Walter W. Beach of 140 Macdougal Street was taken to the First Precinct Police Station last evening suffering from dementia, and afterward removed to Bellevue Hospital. Dr. Beach is seventy-one years old. He has lived in Macdougal Street a great many years and is well Known through the lower part or the city, where, he has a large practice.

The reception given on Monday by the University Settlement at its rooms in Delancey Street has scarcely attracted the notice it deserves. One of the main objects of the society, or at least one of its main results, is to establish social centres in the quarters occupied by working men and working women which shall be free from any objectionable influences.

Exhibitions by the Architectural League are always popular. If for no other reason than that architecture is a temple or a palaver shed under which the fine arts come together for a pow-wow or a quarrel. When we have exhausted all the objects into which art enters, comparatively few are found that cannot claim some relationship with architecture.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- J. Newton Fiero, who is counsel for the members of the State Board of Canvassers of 1891 in connection with the proceedings instituted to punish them for contempt in canvassing the "Mylod" returns in the Dutchess County Senatorial case, said to-day that he would not appeal from the order of the General Term issued last week requiring those members to show cause.

At the monthly meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation Monday, O.B. Potter, for the Committee on Canal Improvement, presented a report favoring the Seymour plan of deepening the Erie Canal, as essential to the regulation of freight charges and to cheap transportation. With reference to electric power proposed for canal boats, the committee urged that any new power adopted be controlled by the State alone.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 15. -- The last season in Western Kansas has not differed from many previous ones. The bad feature, of it was the two successive years of fairly good crops. This led many people to believe that the "seven years of drought" had ended, and, they sold off very closely. Overconfidence is one of the prominent failings of the farmers of Western Kansas.
BUFFALO, Dec. 15 -- Following is a list of losses to tenants in the Arcade Building by yesterday morning's fire:

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- The case of the Soleavs, bronze statuette makers, against the Meriden Britannia Company of Connecticut and S.H. Miller of Wallingford, Conn., came up for a hearing in the courts here to-day. The plaintiffs claim that the defendants are pirating French statuettes. Counsel for the plaintiffs stated that the American firms, toy supermolding, reproduced thousands of statuettes, the original models of which are owned by the plaintiffs.

The Union League Club at its meeting Thursday evening adopted a report presented by a committee appointed to consider the question of municipal reform. Many specific lines were drawn, and the committee's ideas were tersely and pointedly put.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Train No. 16 on the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad, which leaves Buffalo at 5:15 o'clock and runs to Mayvllle, stopping at all stations, went through a bridge three miles west of Dunkirk at 6:40 o'clock to-night. Fortunately not many passengers were on the train or the loss of life would have been terrible.

The New-York Weekly Times is making an offer of books for the holidays which every one should read. It is to be found on the eighth page of The Weekly Times, and explains how any subscriber to The Weekly Times may secure any one of nearly 400 choice books for a very small sum. The books are fine enough for any library and have been selected with great care.

PECONIC, L.I., Dec. 15. -- By the supposed accidental discharge of a shotgun, Lawyer Thomas Osborn, well known in New-York City, was instantly killed at the home of his sister, Mrs. H.D. Horton, in this village about 9:30 o'clock this morning.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Under the caption of "That Pier in the River" in your issue of to-day you question the position taken by the Maritime Association and by the Chamber of Commerce with reference to the construction of a bridge across the Hudson River, and express surprise at the action taken by these bodies.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Dec. 15 -- The double execution, here to-day of the murderers Arthur Courtney and Henry Taylor, both colored, was preceded by a riot, participated in by 500 men and boys. A high fence had been constructed about the jail yard, with the view of having a private execution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- When the trial of Prendergast, Mayor Harrison's murderer, was resumed this morning Mrs. Prendergast, mother of the prisoner, was recalled by the defense and asked in regard to the sanity of her husband and his relatives.

The conclusions of the Fish Commissioners who were represented at the late convention and their ultimate recommendations to their respective Legislatures will not for some time be known. The arguments of the opposing interests were in many instances tinctured with undue acrimony and prejudice -- for the strife has long been waged -- but were, after all, the thrashing of old straw.

The magnificent temple elephant descends the long flight of steps in gorgeous state caparisons of scarlet and gold presented by the King of Siam, and bearing the golden shrine of the Sacred Tooth under a golden howdah. A score of attendants walk at the side, supporting a lofty cloth of gold canopy, outlined with lamps and flowers.

To speak of the chiffons of "Henry VIII." as presented by Mr. Irving's company, includes much more than the gowns of the women who perform in it. The wardrobes of the supernumeraries even, the pages, the pursuivants, and the macebearers, the guards, trumpeters, and henchmen, are formidable affairs.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16 -- The annual catalogue of Yale University for its one hundred and ninety-fourth year, 1893-4, was issued this morning. There is little difference in this catalogue from its immediate predecessors in external appearance, but it exhibits marked growth in the university, especially in the graduate, the academic, the scientific, and the law departments.

The Sons and the Daughters of the American Revolution yesterday commemorated the anniversary of the "Boston Tea Party." and also did honor to Prof. John Fiske, the historian. Prof. Fiske and his family were given a reception by the Daughters in the afternoon and a dinner by the Sons in the evening.

UTICA, Dec. 16 -- The residence of the late Roscoe Conkling has passed into the hands of Nicholas E. Kernan, son of the late Senator Francis Kernan. By the terms of Senator Conkling's will, all of the property of which he was possessed was given to his wife. Mrs. Conkling, in turn, willed her property to her daughter, Mrs. W.G. Oakman of New-York.

Whether John T. McKane, Chief of Police and Sunday school Superintendent of Gravesend, will immediately commence his thirty days' imprisonment in Raymond Street Jail, for contempt of court, will be decided by Justice Cullen, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, to-morrow.
The chess tournament under the direction of the City Chess Club was continued yesterday at Manhattan Cafe. There was a large gathering of spectators present.

TOPEKA, Dec. 16 -- Caesar met his Brutus, and so will the sockless statesman from Medicine Lodge when the wheat is yellow in the fields again." This was the climax of a brief discussion over the future of Jerry Simpson, held in the National Hotel, in this city, a few nights ago, between some of the men most prominent in the politics of the "Big Seventh" District.

Sardou and Dumas have lately been talking foolishly about the appropriation of their plots and characters by certain English playwrights. Their specifications were false. "Diplomacy" has always been known as an English version of Sardou's "Dora." He was paid his price for the English rights.

By rapid work applied in the last few days the Webster Free Library Building erected on the lot adjacent to the East Side House, in Seventy-eighth Street, near the East River, is shown in almost complete form. If nothing unforeseen retards this rate of advance, this free circulating library will be in working order at the beginning of next month, if not opening as a Christmas benefaction.

George F. Elliott, in the Kings County Supreme Court, before Justice Cullen, yesterday obtained an order to take testimony in the case of Stillman F. Kneeland, who is contesting the election of William Hughes, as Assemblyman from the Seventh District of Kings County. The order is made returnable before Justice Cullen Dec. 27.

We cannot go on forever professing for the Russian Government an admiration which no sincere republican can possibly feel, or waxing wroth against the tyrannical regime in Bulgaria, when, as a matter of fact, we are all full of sympathy for the energy with which that little country has asserted its independence.

The second annual intercollegiate chess tournament will be held in this city next week, beginning Tuesday, Dec. 26. The place ot meeting will be in the rooms of the Harvard School, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. For six days the highest chess minds of Columbia, Harvard, Tale, and Princeton will battle for the chess championship of those four colleges.

Harper Brothers have made of Charles Reade's "The Cloister and the Hearth" an enchantingly illustrated edition in two volumes, bound in light-straw colored silk, ornamented with tall, decorative lotus flowers and leaves in gilt. The title pages are printed in red and black in an agreeable combination of round and italic capital letters.

To Reaumur is due the improving legend that coral islands are built by the accumulated efforts of an industrious insect. Pliny, in like manner, quite gravely records the ancient belief that a little sucker fish could hold a ship against the impelling violence of a storm, and apostrophizes the deplorable vanity of mankind when confronted with the fact that their armored vessels could be held bound and immovable by a little fish 6 inches long!

An exhibition of the changeable gears which can be applied to any bicycle was given at the Bidwell-Tinkham Riding Hall, 310 and 312 West Fifty-ninth Street, on Friday evening. The gears were shown by Mr. Lewis Rosenfeld, and were attached to two roadster wheels, each having the gear attached in a different manner. One with the gear on the hub of the rear wheel, was geared to 50 and 67 inches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- It is understood that William N. Harlman of Indiana has been decided upon as the successor of Dr. Dorchester as Superintendent of the Indian Schools, and that his nomination will be sent to the Senate within a few days.

It is probable that the only copy of the original Constitution of Hawaii is that in the possession of Prof. W.H.B. Thomas of Philadelphia. Prof. Thomas has for years been collecting rare documents of a public and private character, and many of the librarians of the country have tried to secure some of them.

The Rev. Dr. William S. Langford, General Secretary of the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church, has received a letter from the missionary station at Point Hope, Alaska, asking the society to urge upon the Government the necessity for making provision for shipwrecked sailors at that place.

Jacob Schaefer, the wizard of the billiard world, covered himself with glory last night. He not only won the tournament in which the three leading players of the globe took part, but he established a record and an average that will, perhaps, stand good for years to come.

The officers and managers of the Young Women's Christian Association of Brooklyn are excited over a statement made by Mrs. Virginia Titcomb at a recent meeting of the Brooklyn Woman's Health Protective Association.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The first trial trip of the electric car from Jersey 'City to Newark was made this afternoon. One of the Consolidated Railroad Company's cars, having on board a number of prominent railroad men, made the distance to this city in 42 minutes and back to Jersey City in 38 minutes.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 16. -- Mrs. Clement Read's friends here were surprised and perplexed at the appearance of the following advertisement in the local newspapers to-day:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 16. -- The Coroners of Louisville and Jeffersonville will make a rigid investigation of the Louisville and Jeffersonville Bridge accident. The inquests will not be held until all the bodies are recovered. None were found to-day, although a large number of men were at work removing the debris.

From The London Telegraph. Affairs do not appear to have gone so smoothly with the European employes in the great ordnance and ammunition factories of the Ameer of Afghanistan as recent reports have led us to believe. Mr. Garnet Edwards, who till lately was the Superintendent of the cartridge factory at Cabul, has arrived at Bombay, and is stated to have been the last of the European workmen to quit Abdur Rahman's service.

Deputy Sheriffs have been searching for several flays for a large quantity of skins imported from Europe within the past two months, and which are involved in the recent failures of Abe Stein Co. of this city, Jacob Stein Co. of London, and Edmands Barrett of Boston. The Sheriff received two writs of replevin, aggregating $89,453, in favor of Kleinwort Sons Co. of London.

I occupy the part of chorus in this little history, a part which has as meagre a personality as a phonograph. I am well used to the standing around, the looking on, and the not being noticed which comprise its attributes. For one thing, I have two pretty sisters, one older and the other younger, and thus I am like a spot of obscurity between two electric lights.

EAST MORCHES, L.I., Dec. 16 -- As the fog lifted at times through the day all eyes were turned seaward. A large three-masted schooner could be seen rolling and plunging in the heavy seas just beyond the breakers.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- W.C. Rogers, the young cadet who was dismissed by a court-martial for going outside the academy limits without permission, has disappeared, and his family is almost distracted by his long absence. He left Stephens's Hotel Thursday, and was expected to return the same night.

Charles Sooysmith, President of the incorporated firm of Sooysmith Co., at 35 Wall Street, who built the eight supporting piers of the Louisville Bridge, which fell on Friday, When Questioned on the matter by a Times reporter, said that he felt certain that every precaution skill could devise for safe construction had been taken in this instance.

Some of the contemporaries of William Jay rated his services to the Abolitionist cause as equal in value to those rendered by any other person; they believed that scarcely any other man's influence was so effective in arousing popular sentiment. He was one of the few men of wealth, high social standing, and commanding position who attached themselves to the anti-slavery movement and strove openly and persistently for its advancement.

Henry Irving was the guest of the Lotos Club last night, after his performance in Abbey's Theatre, and an old-time friendship was renewed at a board where sat many men whom the world of letters and the theatre know and appreciate.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The annual concert of the Madrigal Society on Wednesday evening in the old First Presbyterian Church was attended by over 500 subscribers and guests. The concert was the opening of the society's third season, and the works attempted were the most ambitious ever rendered before a Bloomfield audience.

Of the book it may be said, saying only the Bible, it has been translated oftener and into more languages than any other. A recent Spanish editor, Don Lopez de Fabra, enumerates 150 editions of the Spanish masterpiece in foreign languages. That computation is certainly short of the truth.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 16. -- The greatest flood that has visited South Buffalo in a score of years occurred last night and this morning. Swelled by the heavy rain and thaw of the past twenty-four hours, Buffalo Creek overflowed its banks and flooded five square miles of territory in that section.

New-York is interested in the proposed cantilever bridge across the East River, over Blackwell's Island. The promoters of the great enterprise say they will push the construction with all possible speed, and expect to complete the bridge within three years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Miss Clara Barton, President of the Red Cross, has written to the Secretary of the Navy, requesting that the Columbus caravels, exhibited at the World's Fair, be turned over to the Red Cross for exhibition purposes, the money obtained from their use to be applied to a fund for caring for children made orphans by great calamities.

At the meeting in Cooper Union last Monday night, at which the Independent County Organization, which is the name of the Steckler-MeCrea-Ronner-Harvier anti-Tammany movement, was formed, speeches were made by John D. Townsend and others containing charges inferentially against Richard Croker and other conspicuous men in Tammany Hall.

From The Washington Post, Dec. 12. Gen. Schofleld's eyes twinkled merrily yesterday when he was asked if there was any truth in the wraith of suggestion which was taking the shape of a rumor that he was about voluntarily to retire as the head of the army.

W.C. Merritt in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer. Apropos of the question of the pronunciation of Hawaiian names, a brief statement of the principles of the language governing this matter may be of interest to many. In 1820, when the American missionaries landed at Kailua, Hawaii, there was no written language, and their first literary work after learning the spoken language was to reduce it to writing.

Since the political agitations of Iceland in 1885, which disturbed and discouraged the population, things have been going materially from bad to worse. We are occasionally called upon to listen to jeremiads about Icelandic starvation from those whose sentiment for the Icelanders is more active than their information is exact, and the English public has become suspicious of cries of "Wolf!"

WEDNESDAY, Dec. 20 -- By James S. McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co., foreclosure sales, two actions, Edmund T. Oldham, referee, 227 and 229 West Sixty-first Street, north side, beginning 350 feet east of West End Avenue, each 25 by 100.5, two five-story brick tenements. Due on judgment on each, $15,950.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The annexationists of the Republican Party and the few Democratic sympathizers who happen to have been opposed to the nomination and election of Mr. Cleveland are having a high old time of it among themselves and with their own surmises pending the sending to Congress of the documents in the Hawaiian case.

Apart from the excellence of Gottfried Kinkel's poetry, or the aptitude to conceive noble thoughts and give them exquisite color, it is to be said that the man was of singular erudition, and in closest sympathy with Greek art. It is not always those having the poetic temperament who are the men of action.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 16 -- Examiners of the State Banking Board have been making in investigation of the affairs of the closed bank at Hay Springs. They find a condition of affairs similar to that at Rushville. May and Miller, who conducted both institutions, arrived at Hay Springs from Rushville while the examiners were conducting the examination.

There left for Chicago last week an English engineer and railroad builder who has designed and completed a four-cylinder locomotive, which he claims can run at a grater speed and carry heavier loads than any other locomotive in the world, not even excepting the record-making engine of the New-York Central Road, "999."

Jacob Finelite, the Baxter Street clothing merchant, has transferred his real estate and business, having, it is stated, indorsed the paper of A.H. King Co. and Cohn, Ball Co., the Broadway clothing merchants, for a considerable amount. Mr. Finelite has been regarded as one of the wealthiest men in Baxter Street, and eighteen months ago he considered himself worth $200,000, largely in real estate.

Englishmen seem to think that an American yacht will visit their waters next season and race for the Royal Victoria Gold Challenge Cup. The following is from The London Field, and in commenting on the possible challenge, it gives some of Mr. Dixon Kemp's ideas on international races:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- The bear-hunting season in the Catskill Mountains is now at its height, and old and young, skilled and unskilled hunters living among the wooded slopes and valleys of these mountains are now striving to add to their reputation by killing these animals, which, with the exception of an occasional deer, are the only large game left in these parts.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 16. -- Marion Hedgepeth, the train robber who was recently sentenced to twenty-five years' imprisonment for robbing a Frisco train at Glendale, Mo., in the Spring of 1891, made a desperate attempt to escape from jail at 3 o'clock this morning. In some unknown manner he secured possession of a saw and file, with which he cut the bars on his cell door.

Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan says he has not been fairly treated by the newspapers. The Commissioner thinks The New-York Times has not been just to him in its disclosures of the relations existing between the district lenders of the Police Board and the police ofiicials who are members of political clubs like the Pequod, of which Mr. Sheehan is President.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The tea given this afternoon by Senator and Mrs. Stewart to announce the formal debut of their youngest daughter, Miss Mabel Stewart, was a notably handsome entertainment. The debutante stood beside her mother wearing a gown of pale blue chiffon, and carried a large bouquet of lilies of the valley and Parma violets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Secretary Herbert is anxious to have a torpedo cruiser, and the board of bureau chiefs has been discussing the plans for such a ship. The vessel was authorized in 1890, and no bids were received. The limit of cost was only $350,000, and it was estimated that it would take $162,000 additional to build a torpedo cruiser of 750 tons, having a speed of 23 knots.
The first and most necessary step toward an investigation of the way in which the affairs of Gravesend have been conducted is the incarceration of John Y. McKane in jail.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16. -- A Yuletide musicale, in which many young ladies of this city took part, was given this afternoon by the pupils of St. Elizabeth's Academy at Convent Station, N.J. A pleasing feature was a drama illustrating Christian charity and love. The hall was tastefully decorated with Christmas greens.

The real estate muddle that Mrs. Mary A. Williams of 435 West Thirty-fifth Street and Mrs. Ellen Shanks of Bradhurst Avenue found tnemselves in last week has been straightened out to the entire satisfaction of all concerned, and to the great relief of three lawyers, who held a mortgage on the lot owned by Mrs. Williams and also on the house erected on the lot by Mrs. Shanks.

A single week's transactions in real estate in this city, as far as they are apt to become known at the time, rarely have a special significance. There are occasions, it is true, when much activity in a particular locality, or a series or transactions involving large amounts by shrewd investors, gives to the dealings in some such short period an effect that is marked on business.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Vaillant, the man who threw the bomb in the Chamber of Deputies on Saturday last, has been attacked by a fever arising from the extraction of a nail from his own bomb, which penetrated his thigh. He is at present in the Prison de la Sante, but he will be removed as soon as possible to the Prison de la Conciergerie.

The sales at auction of real estate scheduled for the present week differ in no material respect from the offerings of the past four months. With hardly an exception they are in legal proceedings, usually foreclosure. All sales take place at 111 Broadway except as otherwise stated. A detailed list is subjoined:

The members of the Seventh Regiment Veteran Club had a house-warming last evening at their new rooms, 751 Fifth Avenue. The entrance and interior were brilliantly illuminated with electric lights, and musical instruments cheered the numerous members and their guests.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- The steamer Australia, with Honolulu advices of Dec. 9, was sighted four miles out at 7 o'clock this morning. The Australia brings advices to Dec. 9. The excitement at Honolulu was at fever heat, but up to that time there had been no change in the situation.

FLUSHING, L.I., Dec. 16 -- The business men of this place, having become tired of the "Please call again" of rich customers when a bill is presented, have formed a Mutual Protective Association. Many of the storekeepers have exhausted every known means to collect old accounts, without success.

In reply to a newspaper's charge that the contract for dumping scows, which was awarded to John D. Dailey, whose bid was 12 cents a cubic yard of refuse, was illegal, and that political influence had much to do with Mr. Dailey getting the contract, Commissioner Andrews of the Street-Cleaning Department yesterday declared that the agreement was lawful and properly made.

It may be said that there is no more essential incongruity between partisan politics and police work than between partisan politics and any other executive business of a city. The incongruity in any case is absolute, and precisely to the extent that partisan politics is allowed to control municipal business -- in appointments, employment, disbursements, or administration -- the people suffer and the taxpayers are cheated.

From Gassier's Magazine. In these days of revolutionary projects in matters mechanical and scientific, unusual engineering exploits have lost much of their tendency to create surprise. Still that sensation may be produced in a mild degree by the latest scheme of ocean transportation which has reached us from France, and which has M. Bazin, not unknown in engineering circles, for its author.

Watching the crowds gathered about the Christmas card counters of an up-town bookstore, suggested to an observer that a recent dictum to the effect that these dainty holiday greetings were no longer in vogue must admit of considerable qualification. It was easy to satisfy curiosity on this score.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 16 -- The interest in the approaching holidays has lost none of its zest in the cold weather of the past few days. There is in the cold air a promise of skating, which Lakewood visitors have frequently enjoyed during the holidays. Next week will find two large hotels, both fully equipped and with large booking lists, added to those already doing business.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- The market struck a wall to-day and everything opened weak except Metropolitan and Philadelphia. Metropolitan opened at 106 bid, sold up to 106 1/2, and declined to 106. It was offered at that at the close, with no reliable bid. The first sale of Philadelphia to-day was at 95 1/2.

Dr. Stanton Colt, the Superintendent of the University Settlement at 26 Delancey Street, delivered an address yesterday afternoon to a large number of unemployed men at the Allen Street Presbyterian Church, 128 Forsyth Street.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- Commander William H. Whiting of the United States steamship Alliance arrived on the Australia from Honolulu this morning with his bride, nee Afong, daughter of one of the wealthiest Chinese residents on the islands. They will remain at the Occidental Hotel during their stay in this city.

From The Macon (Ga.) Telegraph. A party of hunters -- gentlemen who shoot for the sport and recreation there is in it -- were talking the other day about the disappearance of game, four-legged and winged, when they were suddenly interrupted by Mr. W.R. Donaldson, one of the most enthusiastic of their number, with the question:

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 16 -- The Court of Appeals of Kentucky to-day handed down an opinion which gives the deathblow to lotteries in this State. The decision was rendered by Chief Justice Bennett without dissent.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Some twenty years ago a smooth faced young man came to this city from Wilmington for the purpose of studying law and making a place for himself at the bar of Philadelphia -- then noted as the most honorable and learned in the United States. He had no friends but his two stout arms, and no influence excepting his vigorous brain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- There comes out of the recesses of the dingy and small Supreme Court room a report, of which no one seems to question the accuracy, that the Justices of the court are all opposed to the proposition made by the bill of Senator Morrill to provide a Supreme Court building in the square of land corresponding to that now occupied by the new Congressional Library.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Hukan Mortensen, the expressman, fell an easy prey to the designing cross-examination of Attorney Wing at the Coughlin trial to-day. His memory was put to a severe test, and the jury evidently did not have a high opinion of it when the witness left the box. The credibility of his story was assailed on all points, and he took refuge behind negative answers.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 16 -- As the opening of 1894, which is an election year in New-Hampshire, approaches, political interest is beginning to revive. This is manifested particularly in the lively scoring for position already engaged in with reference to the race for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Civil Service Commission, through its Secretary, Mr. John T. Doyle, has made an investigation into violations of the civil service law as to political assessments at Toledo, Ohio, and as a result it has recommended to the Department of Justice that Mr. F.W. Rickenbaugh of the Republican Central Committee of Toledo be prosecuted for soliciting political contributions from Government employes.

At the matinee of the Symphony Orchestra at Music Hall yesterday afternoon the orchestra played Massenet's "Phedre" overture, the Pilgrims' March from Berlioz's "Harold" symphony, and the "Romeo and Juliet" overture of Tschaikowsky. Miss Ellen Beach Yaw, a young woman with a very high soprano voice, sang Proch's air and variations and Alabie's "Russian Nightingale" song.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- There are mutterings of another tie-up among the Lehigh Railway men of this division. They are dissatisfied with their treatment since the strike, and say that there will be a monster meeting of organized labor at Syracuse and other points to-morrow to discuss the situation.
Street-car conductors at Hannibal, Miss., are forbidden to aid women in getting on. or off the cars except when requested.

It was expected that the musicians of the New-York Symphony Orchestra might strike yesterday. Nevertheless, Managrer Damrosch and the Board of Directors decided that Anton Hegner would play the 'cello, and he did. Mr. Damrosch says he will also appear at Music Hall to-night.

From The Jenness-Miller Monthly. In one of his essays in a book entitled "Brushwood," the late James T. Fields wrote: "If I were a boy again I think I would learn to use my left hand just as freely as my right one, so that if anything happened to lame either of them, the other would be all ready to write and handle things just as freely as if nothing had occurred."

As hunters and naturalists, men who kill big game, and yet all merciful, with an eye too to nature, Messrs. Roosevelt and Grinnell are the best examples of the true American sportsman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The coming week will be given over to tea drinking on the part of society. Monday will be auspiciously inaugurated by the tea given by Mrs. Condit Smith to announce the debut of her third daughter. The tea will be given at their residence on Lanier Place, Capitol Hill.

Oscar Wilde has power to compel the world's passing attention, but is at the same time so weak and shallow as to deserve and receive no small share of its contempt. His voice is heard above the murmuring of the multitude which drowns the voice of many an abler man, but it has never yet spoken a word to make the world better or wiser.

ORANGE, Dec. 16. -- Orange's "White City" at the Athletic Club has drawn all society to itself during the last week, and as a consequence there has been little time or thought of private entertainments. Perhaps the prettiest of the latter class were Mrs. Joseph D. Pickslay's pink and white luncheon, Mrs. G.L. Manning's "at homes," and Mrs. Osgar Willegerod's tea and reception, introducing to society Miss Alice Willegerod.

A very old question has come up again. It will continue to come up as long as Italians and Frenchmen live in New-York and vie with one another in patriotic demonstrations of delight over the singing of their countrymen. The question, gravely propounded by The Musical and Dramatic World is "What is Italian Opera?"

During this week the veteran pedestrian, Edward Payson Weston, proposes to astonish Young America with one of his old-time feats of physical endurance. Weston is now more than fifty-four years old. Yet he proposes to walk on the public highways from this city to Albany, a distance of 160 miles, within three consecutive days, or seventy-two hours.

Mr. John Parrott, from San Mateo, Cal., who purchased of George Green, proprietor of the Forest View Stud, Katonah, N.Y., Green's Rufus, 63, by Champion Rufus, 1343, and of Henry Fairfax, Oak Hill Stud, Aldie, Va., 73, (202,) Lady Levina, by Quicksilver, bought last week from Mr. Walter L. Clark of Glendower Stock Farm, Glendower, Va., imp., (4536,) Thoebe, by Sunbeam, (819,) out of a mare by Merrylegs, for $4,000.

"J.L.A." -- Secretary Herbert's last report classes the United States as the seventh naval power in the world. England is incontestably first. It is her policy to keep her strength equal to that of any two of her quarrelsome neighbors, whose actual relative efficiency it is difficult precisely to estimate, real strength being so different from strength on paper.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- Telegrams signed by all the rice millers of New-Orleans have been sent from the Produce Exchange to the Louisiana, delegation in Congress, indorsing the provisions of the Wilson bill concerning rice.

An immense area of the Northeastern States, extending south to New-York, and then westward in an irregular line to Cincinnati and St. Louis, is almost wholly covered with a deposit of drift material, in which rocks of various sizes are imbedded, while other rocks, often of enormous size, lie upon the surface.

Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, accused poisoner of "Gustav Baum," spent the quietest day yesterday he has known since the opening of his trial a week ago last Monday. The nervous strain under which he had labored during the last eleven days had completely tired him out, and when he retired at midnight Friday he requested the keepers at the Tombs to let him sleep as long as he chose.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In the report of the proceedings of the Senate of the 6th inst. the senior Senator from Massachusetts, in his remarks upon the Hawaiian incident, is made to use the following language: "Referring to the mission of Mr. Blount, Senator Hoar expressed a curiosity to hear from any defender of the Administration on what the President relied for that most secret proceeding."

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Dec. 16 -- The twenty-fourth annual report of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association has been issued in book form by the Rev. Dr. Elwood W. Stokes, President of the corporation. The volume is entitled "Heart Harvestings by the Sea."

-- Justus F. Paggenburg, business manager of The New-York Staats-Zeitung, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 439 East Fifty-seventh Street, after an illness of two months. Mr. Paggenburg was born near Hanover, Germany, fifty-three years ago. He came to this country in 1856, and a few years later founded in this city a business agency.

Marie Antoinette is "the Queen" of M. Gaulot's story and Count John Axel Fersen, who ultimately became Grand Marshal of Sweden, is the "friend." No woman ever needed friends more than Marie Antoinette, and, according to M. Gaulot, no woman ever had a more devoted friend than she in Fersen.

After their crushing and overwhelming defeat at the polls in Brooklyn on election day, the Democratic machine leaders announced that they were in favor of a more liberal policy in the ward associations. County Treasurer Henry H. Adams, County Register Thomas J. Kenna, John Ennis, and other prominent leaders declared that they wanted to see the doors of the ward associations thereafter thrown wide open to allow all Democrats who might so wish to enter.

The drawing room of the Ladies' Club looks delightfully cozy and comfortable these Chilly afternoons. A bright wood fire burns in the grate and throws its rays out over the large white fur rug that covers the centre of the floor and upon the pretty tea table and various members and their guests who are sure to drop in about dusk to taste the cup that cheers.

TUESDAY, Dec. 19 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., partition sale, Hamilton Odell, referee, 307 and 309 West Thirty-eighth Street, north side, 100.5 feet west of Eighth Avenue, 49.7 by 98.9 by 50 by 94.9, four-story brick building and one-story frame, in front, and three-story brick in rear.
