The attempt to describe a new musical composition may not be quite so futile as an effort to photograph the perfume of a flower, yet it is an experiment of similar nature. Only an imperfect and perhaps misleading idea of the character of so complex a work of art as a symphony can be conveyed through the medium of cold type; yet, when there is no other way, even that must be tried.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- After smothering what threatened to develop into a decidedly ugly fight the American Federation this morning accepted an olive branch extended by the Knights of Labor.

NEW-YORK. Saturday, Dec. 16 -- P.M. The stock market to-day awakened for a time from its recent lethargy and furnished some excitement to dealers in several stocks that were made the objects of special manipulation. In the first hour of business the disposition lately manifested to close short contracts gave the market an upward turn, with some appearance of strength.

Norman Gale has printed the mark of his personality on a somewhat dull page in literary history. Therefore it shows with all the more clearness. It is a happy thing to find, in these days, a poet who is a child of nature. It makes one wonder a little whether poetry, in rising so high into the ether of subtle thought, has not perchance gone astray from its native soil.

The vote by which the bill for the admission of Utah as a State passed the House of Representatives leaves little doubt that it will receive the approval of the Senate. The old objection based upon the practice of polygamy being virtually abandoned, there was not much to be said against admitting Utah, and there was little opposition on party grounds.
OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 16. -- The Enquirer this evening says...

The revenue cutter McLane, Capt. Littlefield, sailed yesterday for Jacksonville, Fla., where she will undergo repairs to her bottom. The cutter Forward will cover the McLane's cruising ground while she is undergoing repairs.

The Rev. Charles N. Douglas, assistant rector of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, Park Avenue and Eighty-second Street, was prostrated by an attack of pleuro-pneumonla Friday evening, while taking part in a choir rehearsal in the church. He is now at the Presbyterian Hospital, and his condition is serious.

An accident occurred yesterday morning on the Ninth Avenue elevated railroad at One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street which created great excitement among the passengers of the 7:45 express train from One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street. Nobody was injured, though all the pessengers on the train, which was crowded, were badly shaken up.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Elizabeth and Sugar Raynor wore found dead yesterday in their farmhouse, midway between Chester and Sugar Loaf. They were sitting upright in their chairs, before a blazing fire, stone dead.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 16 -- Capt. Schell of the Hamburg-American steamer Virginia, in port to-day, reports very stormy weather. The steamer was on a voyage from Stettin to New-York with a number of saloon and 139 steerage passengers. The first bad weather encountered was on the third day out, when the wind increased to a gale, with a very high sea, which continually washed over the deck fore and aft.

The records of the Bureau of Vital Statistics of the Health Department show that during the week ending at noon yesterday the deaths reported were 776, the births 939, and the marriages 417. The deaths were 45 more than during the preceding week and 15 above the average for the corresponding week during the last five years.

The library of the National Academy of Design contains a set of groups in bronze and plaster, part of the exhibit of the Autumn Academy, which gives food for reflection on the course of art in the United States during the past three decades. They are by John Rogers, N.A., one of the Nestors of the Academy.
"Now that O'Connor's turn has come, how about Schmittberger?"
Excise Commissioner John Schliemann of Brooklyn has not sent his resignation to Mayor Boody. The feeling among the politicians is that Mr. Schliemann will not resign.

LEIPSIC, Dec. 16 -- The defense of Dubois and Daguet, the two French spies arrested at Kiel, opened here to-day. The defense was weak. Herr Putsler, who appeared for the prisoners, pleaded that they be confined in a fortress and not sentenced to penal servitude, because they had had no dishonorable intentions.

I would observe that the shaking of the clenched hand as a demonstration of hostility has apparently no relation in its origin with the custom of using the fists after the manner of the pugilist. The gesture is in use all the world over, but the custom of fighting with the naked fists is strictly local, and does not appear to have any very great antiquity.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

The Coney Island Jockey Club announces that not less than $1,000 will be added to any races during its Spring meeting. June 16 to 30, at Shoepshead Bay. This is in direct opposition to the Board of Control's ideas, as that organization proposes to reduce the amount of purse races and over-night events, and means that the races this season on the popular track will be contested by the best horses in the East.
This is a book that appeals largely to women, although all who are interested in the general labor question will recognize the effect the competition of women has had upon the average wage.
Accounts of the five-mile race between "Sid" Thomaa and C. Pearce, which was run at Northampton on Saturday, Nov. 25, show that the race was a very good one. The London Field's report says:
To people interested in forestry as a practical thing there is no spot on earth, perhaps, that is just now of so much interest as Biltmore Forest.

(Copyright by John La Farge.) The sixth lecture in the series, "Considerations on the Art of Painting," by John La Farge, was delivered Friday before a large audience in the Art Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. La Farge said:

The Brooklyn Democratic Club is the first organization in the field with a plan for reorganization. This plan, which has been published in The New-York Times, contains many clauses that are obnoxious to the "machine" leaders.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 16 -- The joint committee of the Legislature appointed to investigate charges that Thomas S. Martin had been nominated for United States Senator by the Democratic caucus through undue influence met in the Senate Chamber this morning. Delegate Withrow of Danville testified that, prior to his election, he had been offered monetary assistance in his canvass provided he would commit himself to vote for Martin.
John H. Burtis, one of the Republican Assemblyman-elect in Brooklyn, yesterday outlined his plans for legislation at Albany this Winter, as follows:
Play in the masters' chess tournament was resumed under the auspices of the City Chess Club, at the Manhattan Care, yesterday. The sixth round resulted as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Representative McCreary of Kentucky, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs, and Mrs. McCreary had a very narrow escape from a serious accident last night while out driving. The driver lost control of the horses and they dashed down K Street, one of the fashionable thoroughfares of the city, running for a half dozen blocks.

Man and horse are so closely associated that Col. Dodge is not to be considered discursive when, in describing the rider, he devotes no small portion of the volume to his mount. As to the rider, unquestionably the man who bestrides his steed naked, with his horse devoid of a saddle, or even a pad, is at the head of all equestrians -- artistically.

The Redemptorist Fathers of St. Joseph's Society, who are in charge of the German Catholic Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, East Third Street, celebrated yesterday the golden jubilee of the society. The services began with a high mass at 7:30, and were closed with vespers in the evening.

Richard H. Dockrill, the ringmaster and equestrian manager of the circus which appears in conjunction with the vaudeville show at Proctor's Theatre, in West Twenty-third Street, was kicked by a stallion yesterday afternoon and very seriously injured.

The defiance by the Lords of the Commons gave Mr. Frederic a text for his weekly letter from London, which had first place in yesterday's Times. He described the curious and threatening political situation in England with customary directness and vigor, and then reviewed affairs in other parts of Europe -- France, Servia, and Russia coming in for special attention.

The Rev. Hanson T. Colt, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Mission of St. David's, at Woodbine Street and Knickerbocker Avenue, Brooklyn, has become a convert to Roman Catholicism. For several years Pastor Colt has been a very high churchman, carrying the Episcopal ritual to the uttermost limits established by usage.

Among the publications designed to hand down an accurate official account of the artistic side of the World's Fair, a work now about half issued is likely to hold the first rank. It is the creation of Mr. Ripley Hitchcock, formerly the critic of fine arts for The New-York Tribune, now the art adviser for the Appletons.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 17. -- The Brooklyn Traction Company, which owns the electric line running from Jamaica to East New-York, has secured a thirty days' option on 1,240 shares of stock of the Jamaica and Hempstead Plank Road Company. Thomas H. Clowes, Secretary of the Plank Road Company, says the traction company wants to extend its Jamaica line to this point.
LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The Times has this dispatch, dated at Rio Janeiro on Dec. 10, and forwarded via Montevideo:

PARIS, Dec. 18. -- A writer for the Debats who has just returned from Brazil says that Admiral Mello is a republican, and that it was without any prejudice for the empire that he induced the fleet to revolt. "He knew that the sailors had been incensed by Peixoto's bad treatment," says the Debats writer.

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. During the afternoon he made several calls. He spent a portion of the evening in the company of ex-Secretary Tracy, who called about 8:30 o'clock.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 17. -- James J. Corbett. the American pugilistic champion, has moved to Mayport. The quarters chosen for the champion and party consist of four cottages. In the largest or the four are quartered Mr. and Mrs. Corbett, Mr. and Mrs. Delaney, Mr. Lake, Miss Howard, and several others. In the rear of this is being constructed the handbull court.

The Rev. Joseph. Silverman, pastor of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Fortythird Street, lectured yesterday morning on the topic, " Shall We Give State Aid to Denominational Schools?" He expressed himself as unalterably opposed to any alliance between the Church and State. He said:
The Rev. Madison C. Peters delivered the following as a, prelude to his sermon in the Bloomingdale Church yesterday:

The English invented the houseboat and the housewagon. While the boat may remain, for a season, fast at anchor, the vehicle is naturally movable. A jolly Englishman, with his wife and a really important personage, James, undertook long journeys skirting the French Mediterranean coast. Being philosophers and uncommonly goodnatured, they spent six months in the caravan, and tell in a pleasant way of their trip.

The excitement of the football season being now over, the boys of the Polytechnic Institute who delight in outdoor sports are concentrating their attention on the game of lacrosse. For several Saturdays past the team and the crowd of onlookers who are anxious to learn the game have been gathering at Prospect Park and industriously practicing passing and throwing the elusive little rubber ball.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 17. -- A plan is being considered which it is hoped will establish a musical department at the university. The matter is in the hands of Prof. White, who trained and brought before the public the Fisk Jubilee Singers. It is proposed by him to unite the several musical clubs of the university into a choral union.

The Rev. Isaac Naylor, an eloquent and famous evangelist from Yorkshire, England, began last evening in the Seventeenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, between First and Second avenues, a series of revival meetings, which will continue every evening for about two weeks, Saturdays excepted. The church was crowded.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Dec. 17. -- Glanders has broken out among the horses in this section. The disease made its appearance in the stable of Devereau Emmett. It also attacked the horses in the stable of James Hall, which is near that of Mr. Emmett. The Board of Health had seven horses belonging to Mr. Emmett and four owned by Mr. Hall killed.

The Rev. J. F. Carson, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Tompkins and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, is preaching a series of sermons on the New-York tenements. His church on Sunday evenings is crowded to the doors, and many persons are unable to gain admittance.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17. -- The results of the fencing tests made by Dr.E.W. Scripture in connection with the Yale Gymnasium Association exhibition on Friday night to ascertain the relative swiftness of action of swordsmen in response to given signals are as follows:

After careful study of existing conditions in the public schools, J. Edward Simmons, President of the Fourth National Bank, has sent to the Commission to Revise the Laws Affecting the Common Schools and Public Education in the City of New-York a letter in which he points out the excellences and defects of the system.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 16. -- The local stock market for the week presents but few features of interest. A fair demand for the better class of stocks by investors who are anticipating their January dividends, or placing permanently the balance of their October income, and a quiet inquiry regarding the securities that are offered, will cover the situation.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- Ex-Minister John L. Stevens addressed the Middlesex Club in this city last night. After speaking at length regarding the resources and value of the Hawaiian Islands, their population, their educational Institutions, annual revenues and expenditures, and their commercial importance to the United States, Mr. Stevens said, in part:
ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 17. -- The antagonism between the Roman Catholic authorities and the Order of United American Mechanics and the American Protective Association has broken out into an open boycott.

If the character of Horace Walpole had no more depth than may be measured by the impression of it which this memoir makes, then Walpole has an almost perfect memorialist in Mr. Dobson. Mr. Dobson's style is light and anecdotic, and has the prettiness of the pictures in camaieu which the little masters of the Eighteenth century painted.

From The Westminster Gazette. Prof. Garner, the American, scientist who went to Africa to study the language of the ape, brought back with him two very fine specimens of the chimpanzee, which he left in the keeping of Mr. William Cross, the naturalist, of Liverpool, since his arrival.

Tall, smooth-shaven, with a look of the utmost good nature on his strong face, wearing a low-cut vest, a small black tie, and a silk hat poised with becoming dignity, Senator William Lindsay of Kentucky walked up and down the corridor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon -- as fine a specimen of an old Kentucky gentleman as one could wish to see.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- A suit has been brought by Jeremiah Meade of Pawling against the Pawling National Bank to recover $8,361.16, which Meade claims is due him on account of certain stock transactions in which Cashier Chase, representing the bank, acted as his agent. Meade alleges that Cashier Chase invested $30,000 in his name without his knowledge.

Patrick Carey, sixty years old, of 36 Vandam Street, was committed for examination in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday, charged with abusing and beating his invalid wife. Agent Mulligan of the Gerry Society went to the man's house and found him and his wife and three children living in one room.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 17. -- The title to the land on or about which stands the Board of Trade Building, Grand Pacific Hotel, and other Chicago buildings, is claimed by a washerwoman's daughter. Mrs. Kennedy, a widow who had come West from Pennsylvania, left Lockport, Ill., for Dubuque County in 1845 to take up a claim.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec, 17. -- The Princeton Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs will begin their annual trip on Tuesday, Dec. 19. At Philadelphia the clubs will take a special train, consisting of a baggage car, drawing room sleeper, and two private cars, lent by Mrs. Garrett and Mr. Lord.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 17. -- The Independance Belge printed yesterday an anonymous article concerning the great fortified camp which the German War Department is building at Malmedy, close to the Belgian frontier, and but a short distance from Luxembourg's northern boundary. The editor gives the assurance that the author is a competent military authority.

A spirited game of association football was played yesterday at Americus Park, West Hoboken, between the Thistle Football Club of New-York and the Americus Athletic Association of Hoboken. The game afforded a splendid opportunity for contrasting the "dribbling code" with the intercollegiate rules, and the enthusiasm which some of the scientific plays called out showed that the game is bound to become popular.

Is there any good reason, is there any reason at all that is not a flagrantly bad reason, why Mr. JOHN C. SHEEHAN should be any longer supported out of the public fund of this city? Mr. SHEEHAN was billeted upon this community not quite ten years ago by his brother, the present Lieutenant Governor, who was then a man with a political future.

At the last meeting of the Council of the University of the City of New-York, Messrs. John C. Claflin and C. R. Otis were elected to fill vacancies, one of which was caused by the death of Charles F. Deems.

One of those who read the interview with Richard Croker published in The New-York Times yesterday was Lawyer John D. Townsend, who made the attack on Mr. Croker and Tammany Hall at the Cooper Union meeting the other night.

Some Western business men have been trying to boycott the East. They are newspaper publishers who say the East has such a bitter enmity against the West that the boycott is necessary for self-protection.

Readers who read for a moment of diversion, as well as intense book lovers, were seldom more delicately complimented than this year, for the book publishers were perhaps never more painstaking in their efforts to be artistic. In evidence of this fact, notes were printed in these columns last Friday of visits in book shops in a journey from Franklin Square to Twenty-third Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Dec. 17. -- The catalogue for 1893-4. just out, gives the total number of students as 466. Last year's total enrollment was 430, but its entrance class was ten more than the 130 freshmen of '97. The class of '94 has lost two members since last year, and now has 69; '95, with a loss of IA, has 97; '96, with a loss of 18, has 122.

The Rev. Father Mahoney, pastor of the Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel, Putnam Avenue, near Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, aided by his assistants, has, during the past week, made a house-to-house canvass of his parish to satisfy himself as to the extent of the prevailing distress.

William H. Dowling, a young laborer who lives with his widowed mother, Margaret, at 276 Tenth Avenue, was dying last night at he New-York Hospital of bullet wounds in the throat and abdomen inflicted by James Tyndn, watchman for Clarke Hamilton, lessees of the ballroom at the grand Opera House.

William Whalen, who said he was a laborer, living at Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, walked into the Thirty-fifth Street Station House Saturday night, and told Capt. Martens that, during he afternoon, he had met another laborer, Thomas Conlin, and that Conlin had engaged him to go to work.

The Widow Plummer has lost her pedigree. But this is hardly less serious than the loss of the silk quilt her grandmother gave her, which contained the cravat that George Washington, the Father of his Country, wore when he danced with the widow's grandmother at the first inaugural ball.

Miracle plays, mysteries, mummeries, for their appreciation require certain temperaments. We should hardly deem Katharine Lee Bates an enthusiast, but what she writes is none the less interesting on that account. There is no small amount of curiosity evoked when the Ober-Ammergau performances take place to-day, but these pale before the fanaticism shown at the Islamitish plays of Persia.
When the doors of Music Hall were locked, at 11:20 yesterday morning, five minutes after Prof. Felix Adler began his address, there was not a vacant seat in the great building.
Miss Maud Lancaster, the mind reader from London, gave an exhibition last night at the Casino of what was called on the programme, "thought transfer." There were about 400 persons present.

PARIS, Dec. 17. -- A package containing ten dynamite cartridges was found to-day on a porch in the Rue Cuvier, which bounds the Botanical Garden on one side. Each cartridge was wrapped in a copy of an Anarchist proclamation, menacing death to the bourgeoisie.

Several steam yachts are to be built this Winter at Nyack-on-Hndson. One is a twin-screw yacht 75 feet long for a New-York yachtsman. This boat will be a very complete one in every way. Her beam will be 11 feet and draught 4 feet 6 inches, and is to be built by Charles Seabury Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Chairman Wilson of the Ways and Means Committee spent to day, as he has spent all his spare time for the past week, working on the majority report on the Tariff bill. The report will be laid before the Democratic members of the committee at Mr. Wilson's house to-morrow night.

" The Sixty-ninth Battalion will not be restored to its standing as a regiment until it is clearly demonstrated that all feuds, factions, and bickerings in the organization are at an end and will not be revived. At present there is no prospect that it will again be made a regiment. Everything depends on the good behavior of the organization in the future.

In police and political circles yesterday there was considerable smiling over a story in a morning paper to the effect that certain of the Police Commissioners have planned to oust Superintendent Byrnes after having disciplined several of the Police Captains.

Some of the vicissitudes of ocean life are illustrated in the case of the British steamship Falls of Inversnaid, which yesterday made her way into port, overdue, battered, and strained by a long struggle against adverse gales and seas. The vessel sailed from St. Michaels Nov. 21, and returned one week later, having expended nearly half of her coal supply battling gales which blew from every direction but the right one.

According to accounts received from Oakland, Cal., where Mr. L.A. THURSTON, before embarking for Honolulu, met "quite a company of gentlemen, former residents of Hawaii," at the house of a "gentleman who has heavy interests in the Hawaiian Islands," the Minister Plenipotentiary of the provisional Government is on his way home to "assist in another revolution."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 17. -- There was no attempt made to-day to close the saloons, as was reported would be done. The side-door trade was as brisk as ever. Jacob Christman, a Greenville saloon keeper, kept his place closed because, as he said, one of the court constables notified him Saturday he must keep closed on Sunday as Judge Lippincott had issued orders to that effect.

A bill of considerable importance was passed by the House of Representatives last week relative to the Post Office Department and its work. Its main features were the abolition of the postal note and the substitution of money orders at a fee of 3 cents each for those not exceeding $2.50 and a quite decided change in the methods of auditing the accounts of Postmasters.

George B. McLellan, the husband of Pauline Hall, and manager of the Pauline Hall and Fay Templeton opera companies, is finding it a difficult task to direct two such organizations successfully through this disastrous season. The Fay Templeton company has been making a tour of the South, and has been playing to indifferent houses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Now that the bills conferring Statehood upon Utah and Arizona have passed the House, there is a general desire to know the attitude of the Senate regarding the Territories now knocking for admission to the Union. Inquiries thus far made of members of the Senate Committee on Territories have failed to throw much light upon the matter.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 17. -- The United States Government will apply to the Guatemalan Government for the extradition of John Hahn. Hahn is the brother-in-law of Mrs. Suzanna Schwartz of Natchez, a rich woman. He possessed her complete confidence. Mrs. Schwartz had a strong box on deposit in a Natchez bank.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- While trying to hold a burglar named Mark Poole until the police arrived in her fancy goods store at 546 Main Street last evening, Mrs. Abram Simisky was badly bitten on the hands and left ear by the thiewf. She kept a firm grip on the man, however, until an officer arrived. Poole was committed to jail.

Not a great number of the Donna Maria's 124 passengers who had been regularly booked at Lisbon for the voyage to this port, were aware of the existence of a fellow-passenger who was cloistered in another section of the ship.

A night in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station did not improve the appearance of the three well-dressed young men who were arrested for attacking ex-Assemblyman Mullaney in a Sixth Avenue car Saturday night. They were most wretched in appearance when they faced the tribunal in Jefferson Market yesterday morning, gave their proper names, expressed repentance, and were discharged.

A meeting of the New-York City Indian Association was held at Calvary Baptist Church. Fifty-seventh Street, near Sixth Avenue, last evening. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur presided. The speakers were Ex-Commissioner Morgan, the Rev. Dr. John Hall, Dr. Montezuma, and Dennison Wheelock.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The suppression of poolselling is of inter-State interest. Connecticut and New-York are dwelt on at present, in order to aid New-Jersey in its approaching January contest. There is no American cabinet for the purpose. Our dependence is on pulpit, league, and press.

The Music Hall, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, was over two-thirds filled with fashionable people last evening, impatiently waiting to listen to the New-York Symphony Orchestra, under the leadership of Walter Damrosch.

The Troy Times quotes from a tariff-reform paper the assertion that "the McKinley tariff levies a duty of 46 per cent. on dutiable goods," and attaches very remarkable comments. Here are some of them:

"Boss" John Y. McKane was too much worried over his political troubles yesterday to pay any attention to Sabbath-school work. He was not in his accustomed place when the Sunday school attached to the Sheepshead Bay Methodist Episcopal Church was opened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Minister Mendonca received no cablegrams from Rio today, and none from any Brazilian port, except two relating to the movement of vessels, which were of comparative unimportance.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The rate of discount last week was 2 1/2 per cent. for: both long and short. The silver market was without features. Consols rose 1-16. The Stock Exchange was dull, and less business was done than in the preceding week. American railway securities were inactive and weak.

Koster Bial's was filled to overflowing last evening with people who went there to see the long-heralded Bessie Bellwood, who had attained the proud eminence of not infrequent mention in grave "London letters," and of whose graces and amiability returning tourists have told tales without number.

The Ring members of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday shelved a new application of the State Electric Light Company for a franchise. The Aldermen would not even permit the application to be read. The State Electric Light Company incurred the enmity of the several Boards of Aldermen who have served during the past eight years, because it would enter into direct competition with the two existing companies, which are controlled by the McLaughlin ring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- In anticipation of the reception of the President's message this morning, there was an unusually large number of people in the Senate galleries. When the doors were opened several hundred were ready to enter, and the crowd steadily increased until there was a decided overflow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Mr. Dolph (Rep-Oregon,) addressed the Senate to-day on the tariff question. He made a thoroughly partisan speech -- the Republican Parity had always been night and never could be wrong, while the Democratic Party invariably damaged the country when it was in control of the Government.

The extraordinary session of the Court of Over and Terminer, ordered by Gov. Flower for the purpose of trying the cases of persons charged with violating the election laws in Brooklyn and Kings County, convened in Room 20 in the Kings County Court House yesterday, with Justice Cullen presiding.

It was charged in the columns of The New-York Times last week that several policemen were members of the political club-the Pequod -- of which District Leader Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan is President, and that some of these policemen who belong to the clubs of district leaders have been active in politics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The President's response to the resolutions passed by bath Houses of Congress, requesting information on Hawaiian affairs, and especially as to the nature of the instructions given to Minister Willis, is as follows:

"Bossism" is what the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst announced he would talk about to the Young Men's Society of the Madison Square Church in the lecture room of the church last evening. He had about 100 men as listeners.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- In the supplementary elections held yesterday for members of the Chamber of Deputies, a number of Anarchists in some of the districts of Rome voted for Tiburzi, the notorious brigand, who some time ago was condemned to imprisonment for several homicides. The police arrested several Anarchists for distributing pamphlets in favor of Tiburzi.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The manager of the Canadian and Australian Steamship Company has conveyed to the Hon. Thomas F. Bayard, American Ambassador to Great Britain, the thanks of the company for the help rendered by the United States cruiser Adams to the company's steamer Miowera, which stranded at Honolulu in October last, while on her way from Sydney, N.S.W., for San Francisco.

Some very suggestive views have been offered by the members of a new local society -- organized as a model for the proposed numerous auxiliary sections of the Parents' Association founded in May last -- in a series of meetings held at the residence of Dr. George William Winterburn, 230 West One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, in the course of the last few weeks.
Police Commissioner Hayden yesterday appointed fourteen additional policemen for Brooklyn. The new men are:

The indicted officers of the Madison Square Bank filed demurrers in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. They claim that the indictments do not concisely state the acts charged and the defendants state they do not understand the particular transactions upon which the indictments are based. Judge Barrett named Dec. 27 for argument on the demurrers.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- The question haw to assist the unemployed poor of the city was discussed in the Common Council chamber this afternoon, where a large number of prominent citizens gathered to consider the important subject. Mayor Matthews presided, and, in presenting the matter to the meeting, said it was almost impossible to exaggerate the condition of affairs among the unemployed.
Superintendent Brady of the Building Department yesterday approved plans submitted for the construction of the following new buildings:

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The East India Loan bill came up on its third reading to-day in the House of Commons. In the discussion of the measure the Right Hon. Henry Chaplin, President of the Board of Agriculture in Lord Salisbury's last Cabinet, traced the monetary troubles of India to the abandonment of bimetallism.

Two short operettas were given last night by the German company of Director Conried at the Irvlng Place Theatre. One was Leoncavallo's " I Pagliacei," translated from the Italian into German by Ludwig Hartmann, and the other a one-act drama by Herr Heinrich Zoellner of New-York, founded on Chamisso's tragic story of Corsican honor.

Nicola Maijesco and Francisco Prola, who were shot in a quarrel over a game of cards in the rooms of Mrs. Glovanna Lotito, at 174 Mulberry Street, on Sunday night, are still in St. Vincent's Hospital, and they are not yet out of danger.

Meyerbeer's "Les Huguenots" was given at the Opera House last evening for the first time this season. There was an evident intention on the part of the managers of the house to present the opera in an appropriate style. The scenery and dresses, as well as the stage fitting's, were brilliant and effective.

A curious and pretty story of schoolboy love was brought out yesterday in the Supreme Court when Judge Truax, on the petition of Lawyer William Thropp, appointed Mrs. Susan R. La Grange of 208 West Seventy-second Street guardian ad litem of Mary Louise Gray, in an action brought to annul the latter's marriage with Theodore Burt Sayre.

The annual collection in behalf of the associated hospitals of the city is now going forward in the various trades and upon, the Exchanges under the auspices of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, and will come to a close with "Hospital Sunday," on the last day of the year. Never in the history of the association was there a time when the need of help was so great.

Judge Freedman in the Superior Court yesterday handed down a decision denying the application of Minnie C. Warren for alimony and counsel fees pending a decision in her suit for divorce against Lyman E. Warren, a member of the law firm of Palmer, Boothby Warren of 280 Broadway.

Edward payson Weston, who, since he began his career as a pedestrian some twenty-six years ago. has walked something like 60,000 miles in this country and in Europe, began another tramp at 9 o'clock last evening.

Jean Ingelow retains her old faculty of story telling. She interests you without seeming to make an effort to be interesting, and with scarcely any apparent artifice. She wastes no time on elaborate descriptions of places or of people. From the opening of this new novel, a simple love story with plenty of variety of character and incident, the reader's attention is held closely.

The Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association met at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday afternoon. The reports of the collections made thus far from the various trades were good, and it is thought that the total amount will exceed that of last year, when it was $63,000. All appeals have met with a generous response.

Father Mahoney's picture of the appalling poverty in Brooklyn this Winter is not overdrawn, according to the opinions of those who are connected with the organized societies for charitable relief in the City of Churches.

The committee appointed by the Republican County Committee at its last meeting to report upon the question of reorganization will meet to-night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and receive the report of the sub-committee. The report of the sub-committee, it is said, will state that the investigation has shown that reorganization is necessary, and that the reorganization should be on the election-district plan, after the fashion of the Philadelphia system.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18 -- At a meeting of Protestant ministers at St. John's Independent Methodist Church to-day the Rev. Dr. Luther T. Townsend made some startling remarks about the Catholic Church. He began with the proposition that there was no constitutional right for a crusade against Catholics simply because they are Catholics.

-- Henry Silberhorn, President of the New-York Bowery Fire Insurance Company, died of pneumonia Sunday night at his residence, 749 Lexington Avenue. He was ill only a week. Mr. Silberhorn was born in Strasburg, Germany, Nov. 18, 1819. When six years old he came to this country with his parents. He made a considerable fortune in the provision business, and then became interested in various enterprises.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The President's Hawaiian message was identical as presented in both houses. But in the case of the House of Representatives, the Chief Executive added a supplementary message as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Mrs. Condit Smith gave a tea this afternoon, which was largely attended, from 4 to 7 o'clock, to announce the debut of her daughter. Miss Grace Condit Smith. The house was decorated with palms, American Beauty and La France roses. The hostess wore a gown of black satin and lace trimmed with gold passementerie.

Yesterday's auction sales of realty were not especially noteworthy. Messrs. Richard V. Harnett Co. sold, under foreclosure, for $17,500, to Henry G. Leist, the three-story stonefront dwelling 77 West Ninetieth Street, north side, 100 feet east of Columbus Avenue, 18.9 by 100.8 1/2.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- The suggestion of Coach Crosby of Harvard that Princeton call a took boll convention for the modification of the present playing roles meets with approval at Princeton. It is evident to men prominent in football circles here that a change is necessary before another season, and that the momentum and mass plays should he done away with.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- At the Clearing House this morning the demand for money was light, only a few loans being made at 1 per cent. New-York funds sold at 10c premium. There is little doing in the outside market. Call money is obtainable by good borrowers at 2 per cent., and time money ranges from 3 1/2@4.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Jacques Merigeau, a militant Anarchist, was arrested, here this morning. When the police arrived at his lodgings they found that he was in bed. They entered his room and informed him that he was wanted. He apparently took his arrest very coolly, and at once began, to dress himself.

STAPLETON, S.I., Dec. 18 -- A charge of extortion was made against Coroner Charles Schaefer of this place before the Richmond County Board of Supervisors this afternoon. The complaint was made by Mrs. Herman B. Walker of 280 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The immense bulk of correspondence accompanying the message, including all the Blount exhibits, has constructively gone down to the Government Printing Office, to reappear some time to-morrow in the shape of a Congressional document. As a matter of fact, the great body of the correspondence is already in print, but the most interesting portions, namely, the recent correspondence and instructions, will be looked for with much interest.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A dispatch from Berlin says an official message has been received there from Rio Janeiro saying that incessant firing between the Government forts and the insurgent fleet has been going on for the last few days.

The Symphony Orchestra which Walter Damrosch has worked so hard for the last three years to establish is a thing of the past. Yesterday formal written notices were sent to each of the members of the organization informing them that the contracts made with them, were at an end, and that they were released from their engagements.

Where the Broadway cable railway, carrying its millions of passengers north and south, meets the cross-town road through Houston Street with its connections to the ferries and the Grand Central Station, has become the centre of a new business district. Here come together, perhaps, the greatest and most extensive lines of trade, including the dry goods, woolens, clothing, fur, hats and caps, millinery, and notions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- They were a scared looking lot of brokers on the floor of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange when the market opened. Apparently everything was for sale, and the buying orders were few. The principal buying at the opening was to cover short sales. Pennsylvania opened at 47 1/4, and declined to 46 5/8, and, of course, looked very weak at the low price.

Ex-President Harrison remained at the Fifth Avenue Hotel nearly all day yesterday, and from about 9 o'clock in the morning there were only brief intervals when he was not entertaining callers. If he had made a declaration that he intended to be a candidate for the Presidency again and the plan of campaign had been under discussion, the scenes in the corridors would not have been much livelier.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Chancellor McGill to-day granted, an order confirming the sale of the National Cordage Company to the United States Cordage Company by Receivers Young and Loper.

Almost the entire attention of the New-York Presbytery at its monthly meeting held yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, was devoted to the problem of relieving the suffering poor this Winter.

A mass meeting of the members of the freshman and sophomore classes of Columbia College was held yesterday afternoon in Hamilton Hall to consider the question of reinstating: the seven men who were suspended by the President for rushing on the college grounds last Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Applause long, loud, and hearty, and apparently unanimous, from the Democratic side greeted the last words of the President's message in the House of Representatives. The message had not been given to the House as quickly as to the Senate, but it received much attention, and when the Clerk uttered the last sentence.

Folk-lore is a fine thing indeed, but there is, perhaps, nothing awe-striking about either it or its professors. It may be rank sacrilege to pooh-pooh so sacred a source as the Satapatha Brahmana, and perhaps we should be stricken by lightning for daring to assert that there is a great deal which is assumed in folk-lore.
The ninth exhibition of the Architectural League, including the first of the Sculpture Society, opened yesterday morning at the Fine Arts Society.

Gen. Lewis A. Grant, until recently Assistant Secretary of War, was at the Astor House yesterday. He said to a reporter for The New-York Times that he had turned over to his successor those affairs of the War Department which had been under his jurisdiction last Friday, and had at that time ended his connection with the department.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Dec. 18 -- P.M. The stock market was somewhat more active to-day, and business was more evenly distributed than for some time. The tendency of the market was downward. New-England led. both in point of activity and weakness.

The week before Christmas is "shopping week." It is regarded, as the worst week in the season for the theatrical business, and a good time for traveling companies to "lay off." Nevertheless, there was a great deal of interest shown in the many changes of bill last night, though nothing new of serious import was put forward, except the German operetta, by M. Zoellner, Musical Director of the Liederkranz, at the arving Place Theatre.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 18 -- The religious war begun Saturday is still of all-absorbing interest. In addition to the boycotts placed upon Grocer Laidlaw and Baker Carson, several others have been instituted. The first two have lost all their Catholic customers.

If a change of programme at Harrigan's was necessary, "Old Lavender" was surely just the play to put forward for the Christmas season. The dilapidated, moist, mellow, and occasionally pathetic central personage belongs in the same category with Caleb Plummer, Trotty Veck, and other characters in Dickens's Christmas stories, and consequently is, by association, appropriate to the season.

In his effort to be thorough, Mr. Duff ran great danger of being uninteresting. His subject requires either a chronological table or a series of monographs. The facts are names and dates, and the adventures conjectures and disputes about them. But Mr. Duff combines these elements very cleverly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- At a late hour this afternoon the conferrees on the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill completed their labors by agreeing to a bill, which places the New-York and New-Jersey Company, and the North River Bridge Company on the same footing, so far as privileges and obligations are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Hansbrough (Rep., N.D.,) made an address on a bill introduced by him Thursday to appropriate $1,000,000 for the extermination of the Russian thistle. The bill was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 18 -- The Pope's latest encyclical, dated Rome, Nov. 18, 1893, has been received by Cardinal Gibbons. In summarizing it the Cardinal said:

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Henry George will not be a witness in the Prendergast case. When the court was called to order this morning Mr. Wade announced that he had no witnesses to put on the stand. He said that Henry George had evaded service and that the doctors he desired could not come until the afternoon.
The women connected with the Memorial Hospital for Women and Children, in Brooklyn, are getting up a minstrel show at the Academy of Music. All the performers are to be society women.
J.W. Parker Co., one of the oldest firms of ship-brokers in the city, and in business at 66 New Street, made an assignment yesterday to Henry Stewart of Parker Stewart, adjusters, of 60 New Street.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Alley stock opened at 40 1/2, and declined to 40. It was soon apparent that the stock was heavily oversold, and it advanced 1 1/4 points above the opening.

The Methodist Preachers' Association, at its meeting in the Methodist Book Concern Building yesterday morning, voted to ask President Cleveland to take no heed to the requests for the removal of the Rev. Dr. D. Dorchester of Boston, Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

The reorganized Republican Party of Kings County, fresh from its victory over the Brooklyn ring:, will to-day hold its primaries in the various election districts. This will be the first demonstration made by the Republicans since election day.

" The principal thing that is needed now to start business activity is speedy action on the Tariff bill one way or the other," said Ansel Oppenheim of St. Paul, a railroad man with large interests throughout the Northwest, to a reporter for The New-York Times at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

The trial of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer for murder came to a dramatic end yesterday. At 11:50 o'clock, while Charles W. Brooks was in the midst of his summing up for the defendant, Alexander B. Low, who is Juror No. 7, fell in a fit in the jury box.
Donna Johanna, the lady chimpanzee from, the Congo, via Lisbon, met her spouse that is to be, Chiko, for the first time yesterday afternoon at the Arsenal in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Senate was spared to-day the infliction of another partisan outburst on the subject of Hawaii. Mr. Hoar, who was primed for a rancorous onslaught, announced soon after the session began that, as Senators Peffer and Berry desired to address the Senate, he would not press the motion he offered yesterday to refer the President's message and the documents accompanying it to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

Louis A. Morgenthal, an English speculator, who has been in this country about five weeks, and who has been living at the Graham Hotel, Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, was found dead in his room late Monday night. There was a bullet wound in his head and a revolver was clasped in his hand.

A correspondent of The New-York Times, over the signature of "A Catholic Reader," states that since the introduction of the parochial school system the religious instruction of Catholic children in the Sunday schools has been abandoned in several parishes in this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations: Wayne MacVeagh of Pennsylvania, to be Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the United States to Italy.

Careful investigations made a year or two ago by the Massachusetts Board of Health with respect to the water supplies of the cities in that State directed attention to the prevalence of typhoid fever in certain cities whose supplies were drawn from polluted rivers. One of these cities was Lawrence, which took water from the Merrimac.

From The London Globe. Nothing can surpass the patience of the British audience at certain of these lectures. We have been present on one such occasion when a distinguished, but perfectly unintelligible, member of the Royal Society engrossed the attention of about 900 ladies and gentlemen from o'clock until 10.

The first of the two Matriaichs' Assemblies took place at Sherry's last night. The decorations of the rooms were simple, being confined to a few palms and evergreens. There were about 200 persons present, the majority of whom had participated in the Patriarchs' ball last week.

Superintendent Crichton of the Planet Carpet and Yarn Mills, in President Street, Brooklyn, yesterday posted an announcement that the mills would close after Christmas for an indefinite period. The announcement created consternation among the men. They held a meeting and drew up a petition of which they sent copies to Senator Hill and Congressman Hendrix.
CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 19. -- John P. Hopkins (Dem.) was elected Mayor of this city to-day over George B. Swift (Rep.) by a plurality of 1,220.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The cruiser San Francisco is on her way to Brazil. She left Trinidad yesterday under orders to report to Capt. Picking at Rio. She will reach Rio in about ten days. It is said at the Navy Department that the naval force on the Brazilian station will be further increased, as the necessity for additional force at that port is apparent.

VIENNA, Dec. 19. -- A dynamite bomb was exploded this evening in Rakonitz, Bohemia, thirty miles west of Prague. The residence of a lawyer named Wolff, in front of which the bomb burst, was wrecked, and other houses were badly damaged.

Dr. Charles E. Boynton, the American citizen who was arrested in the harbor of Rio Janeiro for attempting to blow up Mello's flagship Aquidaban, arrived here yesterday morning a prisoner on the steamship Sirius of the Lamport Holt Line. He was in charge of Ensign James F. Carter of the United States steamship Detroit.
The extraordinary Grand Jury convened in Brooklyn for the purpose of inquiring into the alleged frauds in that city and in Kings County at the resent election began its labors yesterday.
Yesterday's auction sales of real estate were not as unpromising as some other recent ones. In three instances, certainly, the prices were quite good.

Michael E. Goodhardt, a lawyer, who had an office in Nassau Chambers, and who lived at 102 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, died at his home yesterday morning from the effects of a dose of carbolic acid. The police believe it was a case of suicide, al- though the relatives of Mr. Goodhardt deny that he voluntarily caused his own death.

The Brooklyn Board of Education yesterday decided that the salaries of teachers in the Manual Training School could legally be paid from the general fund. This question was first settled by the Law Committee, which reported that no legal objection existed to such an arrangement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Wayne MacVeagh of Philadelphia was nominated to-day by the President to be Ambassador of the United States to Italy. The nomination is well received in this city. Democrats, in particular, remember Mr. MacVeagh's services in the last campaign, and are gratified that recognition has been made of his valuable aid to their party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Minister Mendonca had no information about Brazil to impart to-night. He had received nothing, he said, from his Government since Saturday, save in relation to the movement of vessels. He was from this fact firmly convinced that no changes, at least none of importance, in the situation had taken place.

Gen. Jose Manuel Hernandez of Venezuela arrived in this country yesterday morning prepared to fight the suit begun against him about two months ago by Mr. and Mrs. George P. Underhill of 260 Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

Dr. A.S. Ball, who died in Saratoga Sunday, was one of the oldest homeopathic physicians in this country. He was born in Keene, New-Hampshire, to 1800. After graduating from the College of Physicians and Surgeons in this city, he went to Salina, N.Y., where he lived for ten years.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 19. -- S.S. Nottingham, one of the editors of The Norfolk Landmark, and State Senator Herbert of Princess Anne County had a personal encounter here to-night at the Exchange Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The following is the text of the letter adopted by the Senate Committee on Finance at its meeting this morning which will be sent, in connection with the queries accompanying it, to the industrial interests of the country:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- The break in New-England demoralized this market to-day. Among Traction stocks the People's advanced to 27 on a small transaction. Bears attacked Philadelphia Traction and offered it down, without finding buyers. Metropolitan Traction declined, in sympathy, to 101 1/8.

Many high-tariff papers, and notably the Indianapolis Journal, are greatly disturbed by the proposed reduction of the duty on barley from 30 cents a bushel to 20 per cent. ad valorem, which is a little higher than the duty of 10 cents a bushel imposed by the Republican tariff previous to 1890.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Representative Wilson, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, shortly after 4 o'clock this afternoon submitted the report of the committee on the bill to reduce taxation and to provide revenue for the support of the Government.

BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- At the Clearing House this morning the demand for funds was very light, new loans being made at 1 per cent. New-York funds sold at par and 5 to 10c per $1,000 premium. In the outside market there is little change. Money on call is 2 to 3 per cent, and time money is 3 1/2@4 per cent.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- In the House of Commons to-day Lord George Hamilton, formerly First Lord of the Admiralty, made the motion relative to Great Britain's Navy notice of which was given a few days ago. The motion declared that it was necessary that large additions should be made to the navy immediately, and that the House, therefore, demanded to be informed what the intentions of the Government were in regard to strengthening it.

There were not enough Aldermen present at yesterday's meeting of the board to adopt the resolution permitting the Governors of the Woman's Hospital to sell the present hospital site at Fourth and Lexington Avenues and Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets so that money can be obtained to carry out the Governors' plans of building a new hospital further up town.

Charles A. Schieren, Mayor-elect of Brooklyn, was "at home" to politicians, statesmen, and other persons yesterday. Mr. Schieren was in bright and vivacious humor. He talked about his forthcoming administration in his earnest, sober way. He seemed to have been greatly refreshed and invigorated by his trip to the oak groves of the South.

Paris Correspondent London Telegraph. Another interesting match, between horseman, and cyclists has just come off. Capt. Cody, who, as will be remembered, beat M. Meyer after a twelve hours' ride on the ground of the Trotting Club a fortnight ago, has contended yesterday and to-day, on very similar conditions, with M. Gaby and M. Fournier, mounted on a tandem bicyclette.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 19. -- Mayor Rankin has issued an appeal for help for the suffering poor of Elizabeth. He has especially asked the school children to contribute. To-day two wagons were filled with provisions given by the pupils of Public School No. 4, and were turned over to the Charity Aid Society.

In executive session yesterday the Park Commissioners discussed the Harlem Speedway plans, but nothing new was decided upon. The Commissioners determined to petition the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to appropriate $95,000 instead of $70,000 to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for next year.
Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer may never face a jury again in this city on the charge of poisoning "Gustav Baum."
The following stocks, bonds, , were sold at auction yesterday afternoon by Richard V. Harnett Co. at 50 Liberty Street...

William E. Blackstone, Honorary Commissionner of the World's Columbian Commission, is in the city for the purpose of securing signatures to the memorial of that commission for international arbitration. The memorial has already been indorsed and signed by the representatives of forty foreign nations, by the United States Commissioners, and the officials of the exposition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- "The American people, after the fullest and most thorough debate ever given by any people to their fiscal policy, have deliberately and rightly decided that the existing tariff is wrong in principle and grievously unjust in operation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Dr. Zeballos, the Argentine Minister to the United States and Mexico, has been notified of two Cabinet changes in his country. Senor Virasoro, Minister of Foreign Affairs, having been elected Governor of the State of Correntes, has been succeeded by Edouard Costa, Mininister of Justice and Public Instruction.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

Detective Sergeant George W. Brown and Patrolman William Anderson of the Fourteenth Police Precinct, Brooklyn, have good prospects for speedy dismissal from the force. They are accused by the Rev. Stevens Stevens Wright, pastor of the Primitive Methodist Church, on Mohroe Street, near Stuyvesant Avenue.

The Board of Police Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, mainly for the purpose of receiving and acting on the report which Superintendent Bynes was directed to make in the case of Police Captain O'Connor.

The Republican primaries for the election of delegates to the ward committees and officers of the various ward and town associations were held yesterday in Brooklyn and the Kings County towns. There are 656 districts in the city and 23 in the county towns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The question of the confirmation of William B. Hornblower of New-York, who was nominated by the President for Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, will not be decided until after the holiday recess. The Senate Judiciary Committee at the meeting yesterday discussed the nomination, but did not reach a decision.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 19. -- A fineappearing man visited the Bridgeport Coach Lace Company yesterday, introduced himself as E.F. Fisher of the Cincinnati Carriage Concern of Emerson, Fisher Co., and left an order for $1,800 worth of goods. He then asked F.I. Narramore of the company to accompany him to the White Manufacturing Company, where he was introduced to Horace Wilmot, a member of the firm.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment gave a public hearing yesterday on the city's budget for 1894. The provisional budget was passed last month at $38,296,633.69, and the business before the board now is to go over it again and mold it into the final budget.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Dec. 13-P.M. Nearly 40 per cent, of the transactions in to-day's stock market were in New-York and New-England and Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul stocks, the former furnishing 67,347 shares, and the latter 34,945 out of a total of 262,054.

From The Springfield Republican, (Ind.) President's Cleveland's message on the Hawaiian problem is one of the ablest of his State papers. Its massing of the evidence which convicts ex-Minister Stevens of misuse of the power of the United States in aid of the revolution of last January is masterly, and his statement of his conclusions as to the duty of this country under such circumstances is equally powerful.

From The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. Matt Crowley, a young detective, has returned to the city from Chicago, where he has been for fifteen months connected with, the World's Fair Secret Service. Mr. Crowley gives an interesting sketch of the organization and workings of the department.

The Rapid-Transit Commission met again yesterday afternoon, but all the proceedings were in private. These, according to the announcement of the Secretary, were confined to a discussion of the general plan now being considered, and to a review of the work and plans of the engineer of the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Assistant Attorney General Hall has rendered an opinion. In which he holds that an application for a pension is a money demand upon the United States, and, therefore, under the law, an ex-official of the Pension Bureau is precluded from acting as attorney in pension cases for a period of two years next after he shall have ceased to be such officer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Much of the time of the House was taken up to-day by the deferred talk of Mr. Boutelle of Maine. His resolution, which he might have introduced last night if he had not undertaken to put in too much preamble, came along in all its fierceness this morning, and Mr. Boutelle's speech followed it.

American railway securities were weak in the London market. The Vanderbilt issues and St. Paul were sharply depressed. Lake Shore falling 1 7/8 and St. Paul 1 3/8. The latter was unfavorably affected by the decrease in its earnings for the second week of December. Aside from these, the day's losses did not exceed a fraction.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 19. -- In the Legislature to-day Gen. Eppa Hunton was elected United States Senator to serve until March 4, 1895, and Thomas S. Martin was elected United States Senator to serve six years, beginning March 4, 1895. Gen. Hunton has been serving as United States Senator by appointment of the Governor since the death of Mr. Barbour.

The seventh round of the chess masters' tournament, which was played at the Manhattan Cafe yesterday, brought the remarkable result about that now Albin, Hodges, and Pillsbury are tying for first prize with five games each. The games resulted as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- In the Senate this morning Mr. Frye said he understood that the present Secretary of State had given permission to a French cable company to land its cable from Brazil on the coast of the United States, notwithstanding the permission had been refused by both Secretary Blaine and Secretary Foster.

Senator DOLPH of Oregon appears to have been retained to defend the interests of the Lumber Trust on the Pacific coast, a combination of lumbermen that has been denounced by the courts and that sells lumber in Australia and South America in open competition with the lumber of British Columbia, against which it asks for protection in the home market in order that it may be able to exact artificial prices from domestic consumers.

The drop in the price of the stock of the New-York and New-England Railroad within the last two days, from 27 to a fraction under 20, has set the wheels of rumor to revolving very rapidly. The New-York and New-England probably has been the object of more talk and conjecture than any other railroad property in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Mrs. Schofield gave a luncheon to-day, at which Mrs. Daniel Lamont was the guest of honor. The table decorations were appropriate to the season, in holly. A plateau of ferns formed the centrepiece. The candles were capped with white shades, covered with sprigs of holly berries and green leaves.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 19. -- Nothing has thus far been done by the Senate Committee on Territories in relation to the bill for the admission of Utah, which came from the House last week. Senator Faulkner, the Chairman, said this morning that the committee would meet on Thursday and would probably discuss the bill. He could give no idea as to its action.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

From The Utica Observer, Dec. 18. The Police Department of New-York has in prospect a more severe overhauling and investigation than it has known in many years. The New-York Times argues strongly for the divorcement of the Police Department and partisan politics. One of its arguments is applicable to every city of the Union.

The scheme for a patrol-wagon system submitted to the Board of Police yesterday was based on an estimate for twelve wagons, as follows: Twelve wagons, $6,000; twentysix horses, 16,500; double harness, $1,950; single harness, $500; dress blankets, $126; street blankets, $168; accommodation and feed, per annum, $9,360; shoeing, per annum, $560; repairs, per annum, $300.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

Alderman Arthur J. Heaney of Brooklyn furnished more amusement yesterday at the session of the Columbian Audit Commission in the City Auditor's office. He told what he knew about the Aldermanic banquet in the park, for which George F. Miller, the caterer, charged the city $1,289,50.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- The voting for Mayor to-day rendered the market very dull, and the spiritless tone begot lower prices. Alley "L" opened 1/4 above yesterday's close, held firm for half an hour, and, after persistent selling, yielded, closing weak at 40 3/4. North Chicago opened 1 3/4 below the final sale of the last session, advanced to 251, and receded to 250 at the close.

From London Truth. Lord Iveagh, having given up all idea of purchasing the Sarernake estate, is now thinking, so I hear, of buying Wimpole Hall, Lord Hardwicke's well-known place in Cambridgeshire. Wimpole is a magnificent house, with fine gardens and a Very large and richly-wooded park. The whole estate has been in the market for several years past.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Mayor Wanser to-day concluded the examination of the charges against the Street and Water Board. Among the witnesses examined were Contractor P.J. Condon, who had several of the so-called "fat" jobs given out by the board, and Commissioners Edward A. Dugan and William R. Cook.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Wheato pened easy and sagged off, then reacted, held steady for a time, and closed with a, slight display of strength. The early weakness was in response to lower English cables, but the volume of trade throughout the entire day was so light that the price changes were not rapid or important. The near approach of the holidays is instrumental in restricting an already limited business.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 19. -- At 6:54 o'clock this evening the Bissel accommodation train, No. 8, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, collided with a Carnegie Steel Company shifting engine between Bessemer and Port Perry, just east of Braddock.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Miss Eva M. Applegate, daughter of C.E. Applegate, was married at 4 o'clock this afternoon to George W. Chandler of New-York, son of John W. Chandler, Contracting Freight Agent of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home, on Maple Avenue, by the Rev. J.K Manning.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The anticipation of midwinter distress among the wage-earners of this city is now fully realized, and the outlook for the next two months is fraught with the gravest apprehension. Since the 1st of October we have been expending in relief more than twice as much as during the corresponding period of last year, yet this provision is now quite inadequate to meet the growing distress.

STAPLETON, S.I., Dec. 19. -- There have been interesting developments recently in the movement to prove that fraud was committed at the November election. An investigation has been carried on, behind closed doors, at the office of Justice of the Peace Cornell, in Clifton. A large number of persons have been examined.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 19. -- The Court of Appeals to-day, in the case of Ed-ward S. Stokes against John W. Mackay and another, appellants, reversed the judgment of the lower court and ordered a new trial. This case has twice been argued before the highest court in the course of a year, and has received the consideration of eminent counsel.

PERNAMBUCO, Dec. 19. -- It is expected that the Nictheroy will leave here soon for Bahia, en route to Rio Janeiro. The crew is busy taking on supplies, The Nictheroy is now commanded by Nunez Ribiero, formerly commander of the Republica. Capt. Baker probably will return to New-York unless he can make satisfactory arrangements with the Brazilian Government to serve as second officer on the Nictheroy.

Paris Correspondent London Truth. I wonder I did not think before of what I am going to tell you. When I was last in Switzerland a large Austrian party was in the hotel where I was staying. There were three Archdukes and any number of "creamy" Viennese. They all dined in the common room at a separate table, and a terrace was reserved for them in a hillside garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Every Republican annexationist is expected at this time to "holler" all he knows how. Senators Hoar and Frye began their shouting in the Senate yesterday, as soon as the President's message was received, and Boutelle, in the House, who has apparently supplied Hoar and Frye with the points they are making, exploded partly yesterday and the rest this morning, but without result in either case.

Surrogate Ransom yesterday heard an application made in behalf of Mrs. Harriet R. Sheffield, a niece of the late Andrew J. Davis of Montana, to bring the litigation over the $10,000,000 left by Mr. Davis into the courts of this county. Mrs. Sheffield alleges that her rights are not protected in the proceeding begun in the courts of Montana.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- This was a bad day for Patrick Eugene Prendergast, the assassin of Mayor Harrison, now on trial for his crime. His defense of insanity was weakened by the testimony of Dr. Dewey, ex-Superintendent of the insane asylum at Kankakee, Ill., by the cross-examination of Experts Church and Brower, and by the testimony of a large number of witnesses called by the State in rebuttal.

It is perfectly evident that no nation can deal with Anarchism by itself. The means of communication between civilized countries are now so rapid and sure that if any civilized country offer an asylum to Anarchists the endeavors of all other civilized countries to stamp out Anarchism will be unavailing.
"Justice Cullen takes the papers and reserves his decision."

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 19. -- The devastation of the peach orchards in this State by the disease known as "the yellows" has been widespread. Ten per cent, of the trees in the commercial orchards have been exterminated during the past season. The report of the State Commissioner, I.M. Hubbard, was presented at the Farmers' Convention here this afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19. -- James E. Blewitt, who, since 1890, has been frequently before the public through legal proceedings, was to-day declared sane by Justice Dykman. Blewitt filed an application to be adjudged sane and capable of carrying on his business. He has for some time been living in Lewisborough, Westchester County.

Lovers of lacrosse, a game that has been steadily gaining in popularity of recent years, will be treated shortly to a novel feature of the game. Two of the crack teams in this vicinity are arranging to play the game while gliding over ice. The game has been played this way in Canada with great success, and those who are familiar with its exciting features predict that Gothamites will be pleased with the innovation.

Business is rather quiet just now in the horse and carriage trade, as most of the purchases have been made, except in the matter of sleighs, and as most everybody and all the old farmers' signs predict a hard Winter, an unusual number of sleighs are being sold. There are but fewfirms in the city to-day who have a complete assortment of sleighs, and those who have are reaping the benefit of their foresight.

With the aid of three bulletin boards and many maps of various parts of this city, Oliver Sumner Teall explained last night at the Imperial Hotel how the Provisional Committee has outlined its work of attempting to feed the hungry and warm those who are cold during the Winter.

The Committee of Thirty appointed by the Republican County Committee to consider the question of reorganizing the party in this city has adopted the conclusions of its two sub-committees and recommended a plan of reorganization to the County Committee, which is to hold a meeting to-night.

A marriage certificate that has disappeared and letters that were never received play a part in complications in which the Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan, rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at Fifth. Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, and the Board of Health are involved.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20. -- The Fall term of Yale University closed this noon, and most of the students left immediately for a three weeks' vacation. Two special trains carried the Western men to Chicago and Cincinnati, respectively.

Mayor-elect Schieren said yesterday that he would make public to-day the names of all the gentlemen, with the exception of one or two, whom he had invited to accept appointments as heads of departments.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- Harvard College, as published in The New-York Times this morning, shows an increase in the number of students. In fact, everything points to the rapid development in standard, as well as in numbers, of the university in its graduate and professional departments, rather than in the college proper.

Justice Cullen will probably hand down his decision to-day regarding "Boss" John Y. McKane's fate. It seems to be the opinion among lawyers and laymen who listened to the Judge's charge to the extraordinary Grand Jury, and his remarks to McKane's counsel, that he will uphold Justice Barnard's decision.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- Gov. Flower to-day sent a letter to Franklin D. Locke of Buffalo, relating to Mr. Locke's protest against the appointment of Henry W. Bentley to take testimony as to charges preferred against August Beck, Sheriff of Erie County. In his letter the Governor says:

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- Senator Charles Guinot died suddenly to-day. He was sixty-six years old and had been in politics thirty years. It is said already that M. Floquet, President of the last Chamber and Premier in 1888, will seek election to the Senate from the Indre-et-Loire to take the seat left vacant by Guinot's death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The State Department has been informed that an attempt was made several days ago to assassinate President Heureaux of San Domingo. Consequently the United States steamer Kearsarge, which started this morning from New-York for the West Indies, is ordered not to tarry on her way to destroy derelicts in accordance with orders previously given her.

The action taken by the Tammany Committee of Thirty, or Executive Committee, at its meeting Tuesday, increasing the committee to sixty, or two from each Assembly district, and thereby practically creating a dual leadership in each of the Assembly districts, was the only thing that the Tammany politicians cared to talk about yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- The argument on the petition for a writ of mandamus to compel the receivers of the Reading Railroad to allow an examination of the stock ledger of the company in view of the coming annual election was heard to-day by Judges Arnold and Willson in Part IV. of the Court of Common Pleas.

Dr. Frank Abbott, Jr., of 49 West Fifty-seventh Street, Professor of Bacteriology in the Loomis Laboratory, was charged in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday after-noon with having stolen two letters from his father-in-law, Col. Rozel T. Pickert, President of the Pickert Land, Grain and Stock Raising Company, who is now living at the Savoy, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Whether William Waldorf Aster's agents can cause a number of house owners to pay for the next twenty years the amount of rental for land owned by him which is demanded under the terms of leases signed twenty-one years ago was the gist of a hearing held yesterday afternoon before Lawyer Stephen J. Nash, as referee, at 67 Wall Street.

Miss Pauline Platt, daughter of the late William H. Platt of this city, was married yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock to Carlos Rohl at the home of her mother. The Rev. Bishop Faulkner of Orange, N.J. officiated. The bride was given away by W.H. Whiton. Mr. Rohl is Consul General for the Argentine Republic in the United States, and was born in Buenos Ayres.

The most immediately interesting and important parts of Mr. CARLISLE'S very able and valuable report are those relating to the tariff and the currency, and both these subjects are treated with simplicity, clearness, and vigor not often found in State papers of this sort.

In the private dining room of the Hotel Imperial sat three or four middle-aged ladies last evening, deeply interested, as appeared, in examining some colored maps of the police precincts of this city. They were evidently women of refinement, and were very earnest in their discussion of the location of the police stations, the public houses, the prominent politicians, and the character of the residents in the districts represented on the maps.

From The Rochester Union. (Dem.) No message that President Cleveland ever sent to Congress has been abler than the one published yesterday. It ranks in importance and interest with his famous tariff message. While the one was a protest against the robbery of the American people, the other is a protest against the robbery of a weaker nation. Both appeal to the sense of justice.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Zella Nicolaus, the woman who sued George Gould for $40,000, is in this city, with her alleged husband. The two are registered at their hotel as man and wife. They came here to-day from Southampton, where they had landed from the steamer Lahn. Few persons on the steamer knew who they were.

Eugene H. Lewis of the firm of Eaton Lewis, counsel for Herbert Carus-Wilson, whose engagement to Miss Florence Merrill of Stratford, Conn., has been the talk of that place for over a week, was expecting Miss Merrill at his office yesterday, but received a telegram from her stating that she was unable to come, but would be in this city to-day.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Dec. 20. -- A curious phenomenon was seen in the heavens here from 6:30 to 7 this morning. It made a magnificent display, but no one seems able to determine just what it was. Some described it as a meteor and others as a comet. One eye witness says it had the appearance of a large star, with a tail which, to the naked eye, seemed about 100 yards long.

State Treasurer-elect A.B. Colvin, accompanied by George B.
