Green, Mayor of Binghamton, and President of the Republican State League, called at the headquarters of the Republican State Committee in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon. Mr. Colvin said he had determined on some of the appointments he will make when he assumes the duties of the Treasurer.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Gen. Tracy, formerly Secretary of the United States Navy, "was quoted recently with considerable show of deference by The Army and Navy Gazette. His opinions are regarded by many high naval authorities here as worthy of notice, and in the House of Commons last evening Lord George Hamilton, once First Lord of the Admiralty, did nothing unusual in referring to Gen. Tracy's recent comments on the English Navy.

The committee of the State Board of Charities which has been investigating the charges made about a year ago against the management of the New-York Juvenile Guardian Society met yesterday morning at the office of William R. Stewart, 54 William Street. President Craig of the State Board of Charities is Chairman of the investigating committee.

Mr. J. EDWARD SIMMONS, in his letter to the commission to revise the laws controlling public education in this city, touches with a firm hand one defect in the existing system, which, if it be not the cause of the notorious shortcomings of that system, must clearly be removed before any considerable improvement can be hoped for.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- When the Prendergast trial was resumed, this morning, Cashier Kessler of the Freie Presse, who had done business with the prisoner, testified that he thought him sane.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- It is not expected that the Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee will be ready to report the Internal revenue schedules until after the holiday recess. If the majority of the committee can be held together, the work on these schedules will be continued through the recess, but it is doubtful if a definite conclusion can be reached for ten days.

The explosion of a dynamite cartridge yesterday at the works of the Harlem Ship Canal, on the border of Spuyten Duyvil Creek, seriously injured three men. The explosion occurred on the dirt scow Catherine, which was lying in the canal, laden with refuse, stone, and dirt, near a spot known as the Ledge.

Victory Bateman, the actress whose enforced resignation from the Professional Woman's League caused such a turmoil about three months ago, is soon to bring suit against the league for $50,000 damages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Senator Hoar of Massachusetts, with the assistance of several employes of the Senate, presented in that body to-day a petition unique in form and mammoth in, proportions. The petition was wound around two wheels of a bicycle made of oak, the whole weighing 600 pounds and standing 7 feet in height.

The following Board of Managers for the New-York Institution far the Blind, Thirty-fourth Street and Ninth Avenue, were elected yesterday for the coming year: John Treat Irving, William Whitewright, William C. Schermerhorn, Peter Marie, Frederick W. Rhinelander, Frederick Sheldon, Chandler Robbins, Philip Schuyler, John I. Kane, Edward King, Edward Schell, Frederick Bronson, George A. Robbins, Gustav E. Kissel, John M. Bowers, George L. Peabody, and Howland Davis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Since the beginning of this Congress, and more or less since the beginning of this Administration, the Republicans of the Senate and the House have manifested a disposition to treat the Democrats of both houses as though they were merely accidental obstacles to their absolute freedom in legislation, and otherwise as contemptible intruders, permitted for a brief space to occupy the offices and to assert the rule of the majority.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Gross irregularities amounting to millions of dollars are stated to have been discovered in the NewYork Custom House.
A movement which promises to be most successful was started yesterday in Brooklyn to relieve the distress which prevails so widely among the residents of certain sections of the city.

The Goethe Society held its second monthly reunion for the season in the salon of the Hotel Brunswick last evening. The President, A.M. Palmer, presided. A delightful and exhaustive paper upon "Shakespeare and the Evolution of Thought in the Sixteenth Century," by Charles R. Pope, late Consul of the United States at Toronto, Canada, was listened to with great interest by the many members present and their guests.

Mr. Charles R. Flint, of Charles R. Flint Co., received a cablegram yesterday from St. Pierre, Martinique, announcing the arrival there on Tuesday, of the Pirating, formerly the Destroyer, in tow of the Santuit. The cruiser America was awaiting the arrival of the torpedo boat.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 20. -- Gov. Flower said to-day that he was in receipt of a large number of petitions asking him to pardon Ellen Cummings, the actress, who was recently sentenced to imprisonment in the city prison of New-York for twenty days upon her confession of the crime of grand larceny.

Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent. Time money continued in abundant supply, with the demand light. Rates were 2 per cent, for thirty to sixty days, 3 for ninety days to four months, and 3 1/2@4 for four to six months.

The Board of Health gave a hearing yesterday in the case of the New-York Steam Company, which appealed from the order of the board directing that the nuisance created by the smoke from the chimney of the company's works in Greenwich Street, caused by the burning of soft coal, be abaited.

Thomas Costigan's political luck never seems to desert him. He is one of the very few County Democrats who have remained in office. His mammoth weight is always comfortably bestowed in a good, paying seat. For the last few years -- almost ever since he ceased to be Supervisor of The City Record -- Mr. Costigan has been Assistant Cleric in Justice Jeroloman's Eighth Judicial District Court.

Ex-Mayor James Howell presided at a meeting of bridge Trustees and citizens, at the bridge office, Washington and Nassau Streets. Brooklyn, last evening, to consider the best plans for a terminal station for the bridge.
The Rev. George Deshon, pastor of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Ninth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, has sent the following letter bearing upon the school question to the press:
The paupers in the Flatbush Almshouse who nave enjoyed the luxury of smoking tobacco will have to get along on short allowances hereafter unless their friends supply them with the weed.

The New-York Weekly Times is making an offer of books for the holidays which every one should read. It is to be found on the eighth page of The Weekly Times, and explains how any subscriber to The Weekly Times may secure any one of nearly 400 choice books for a very small sum. The books are fine enough for any library and have been selected with great care.

Secretary Carlisle's report, with, its accompanying recommendations, reached Wall Street too late yesterday for it to be generally read and digested by the financiers, bankers, and brokers. Those who had time to read it generally approved of its recommendations for a bond issue. The general opinion was that if the suggested ideas were carried out by Congress it would tend to restore confidence and be of great benefit to the country.

ROME, Dec. 20. -- Notwithstanding the police precautions to guard against the admission of objectionable persons to the galleries of the Chamber of Deputies at the opening of the House to-day, it was not long after the opening that a man in the public gallery sprang to his feet, and, addressing his remarks to the new Ministers, shouted, "You are a band of brigands."

The Barefoot Mission, established about five years ago by Tello d'Apery, when, he was twelve years old, will be able this Winter to help many poor boys and girls. The mission is now at 59 West Twenty-fourth Street, and its young founder is receiving cordial aid in his work of providing very poor children with shoes and other articles.

BLOOMFIELD, Dec. 20. -- This town has long prided itself over a handsome park of several acres on Broad Street, in front of the old Presbyterian Church. The park was deeded to the First Selectmen of the township in 1790 by "Squire" Davis, and was designated and set apart as a "public military green or common." The deed was filed, but not recorded.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- There was no change at the Clearing House this morning. Money between banks was in abundant supply at 1 per cent. New-York funds were in demand, selling at 5c to 10c premium. Outside call money ranges from 2 to 3 per cent, time money on good collateral is obtainable at 3 1/2 to 4 per cent.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Dec. 20. -- Two masked burglars broke into the residence of Archibald Wallace, on the old Newtown Road, at Laurel Hill, early this morning. The thieves were surprised by one of Mr. Wallace's sisters and fled. They had secured $21.09 and a pair of gold-link sleeve buttons.

Col. E.C. James filed four demurrers yesterday against the indictments charging Police Captain William S. Devery with neglect of duty. The arguments will be before Judge Cowing, in the Court of General Sessions, to-morrow. Col. James has succeeded School Commissioner Charles Strauss as attorney for Capt. Devery.

At the recent conference held in this, city under the auspices of the State Charities Aid Association papers were read and discussions held upon methods having for their aim the cultivation of a healthier moral sentiment, a better physical environment and the creation of a desire among the poor for their betterment, not only as individuals, but likewise for families and neighborhoods similarly situated.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 20. -- The State Grange of the Patrons of Husbandry continued its session to-day in the Assembly Chamber at the State House. Worthy Master John T. Cox of Readington, Hunterdon County, made a number of suggestions in his annual address.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 20. -- The Senatorial investigation committee presented its report to the Legislature this afternoon. In substance, it states that no unusual methods were used to elect members to the Legislature last Fall, and that no fraud or improper means were used to nominate candidates for United States Senator before the Democratic caucus.

Reading, the Western bicycle rider, arrived from Omaha yesterday and joined the flying brigade on the Madison Square Garden's board track. "Pete" Berlo, the ex-amateur champion, also got in town, and began his finishing practice. He outsprinted the six-day men easily in the occasional sports which took place, and thinks he will have little trouble in winning a major portion of the short-distance purses.

For the first time in many weeks, James S. Clarkson, member of the National Republican Committee and its ex-Chairman, appeared yesterday in the corridor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where "politicians of prominence" usually abound. He has been living at the Plaza for several weeks, but is seldom seen, except at that hotel or at his business office down town.

At a secret session of the Board of Education, held immediately after the regular meeting yesterday, Michael Callaghan was appointed Trustee in the Twelfth Ward, in place of Leopold Wormser, whose term expires Jan. 1. Mr. Wormser's name was up for re-election, and he had the indorsement of many influential people of Harlem.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Dec. 20 -- P.M. The best day's business for weeks was done to-day at the Stock Exchange through the active offices of dealers in the stock of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company. There had been an evident effort for a long time to rouse interest in this stock.

As far as sales of real estate are concerned, few transactions are reported. The approaching end of the year has, however, stirred up the loan market, which is exceedingly active. Five per cent. rates are usually upheld.

-- Irving Place Theatre. -- Mr. Zoellner's ambitious operetta, in the manner of Mascagni and Leoncavallo, has been shelved. To-night and for the rest of this week "Gasparone," a tuneful and familiar work of Millccker, will take the place of "Mateo Falcone"; but the German version of "I Pagliacci" will also be given, making a long bill.

Police Commissioner James J. Martin is said to be enthusiastic in his approval of Richard Croker's scheme for a reorganization of Tammany Hall. As organized now, there are thirty Assembly district leaders, all professional politicians. Mr. Croker proposes that thirty additional district leaders shall be chosen, the new leaders to be business men, and that each of these new leaders shall co-operate in their respective Assembly districts with the politicians who are now the leaders.

Samuel Sinclair. Samuel Sinclair died yesterday morning at his home, 21 East Eighty-ninth Street, after in illness of two weeks. Mr. Sinclair was born in Gerry, Chautauqua County, N.Y., in 1822. He received a common school education in his native town, and afterward worked in a store and taught school. In 1840 he accompanied an uncle to Cincinnati with a cargo of lumber.
Meetings of the Directors of several of the Vanderbilt railroads were held in the Grand Central Station yesterday. Several of the Presidents were in conference with Mr. Venderbilt during the day.

T. Edmund Gould, keeper of the saloon at 61 West Twenty-fourth Street, and best known as "Tom" Gould, was fined $150 in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday for assaulting his bartender, William F. Rahner.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Wayne MacVeagh, who was nominated yesterday as Ambassador to Italy, has the satisfaction to-night of knowing that the Senate has lost no time in confirming him.

A great deal of interest has been felt by humane persons as to what disposition was made of the horses of the Fifth Avenue stage line that were recently pronounced to be totally unfit for work by the veterinary surgeons sent to examine the animals in the company's stables, by President John P. Haines of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The annual report of the Hon. John G. Carlisle, Secretary of the Treasury, was transmitted to Congress to-day. The Secretary estimates the revenues of the Government for the fiscal year which will end June 30, 1894, at $430,121,000, and that the expenditures for the same period will amount to $458,121,000, leaving a deficit of $28,000,000 on the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Col. Fellows's eloquence may not have been necessary to secure the agreement of the House in the report of the conference on the Hudson River Bridge bill to-day, but it is highly probable that the vote by which the report was adopted was increased by the very interesting and creditable speech which he made near the close of the debate this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- It begins to look as though the United States Navy would have a very formidable representation in Brazilian waters. It was partially decided to-day by the President to send the cruiser New-York and the new monitor Miantonomoh to Rio.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Dec. 20. -- Judge William A. Coddington was assaulted by Jeptha Wagoner of Mount Horeb at dusk this evening, just as he was leaving his office, in Front Street.

The Countess Fanny Zampini Salazar is to return within a week to her home, in Naples, Italy. She made the first announcement of this important change in her arrangements to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday morning, as she sat in her pretty room at the Hotel Normandie, with the pictures of her two bright sons and three charming daughters on the table beside her, to mitigate the pangs of home-sickness.

One of the biggest educational rows ever known in Brooklyn has been stirred up over the stinging rebuke administered by William H. Maxwell, Superintendent of Public Instruction, in a circular to the Principals of the grammar schools because of their poor success in teaching inventional geometry.

The adjourned conference of representatives of independent political organizations in Brooklyn to adopt plans for reorganization of the Democratic Party was held last evening at 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, in the rooms of the Young Men's Democratic Club. Robert Stewart presided.
AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 20. -- Following is the answer of ex-Minister John L. Stevens to President Cleveland's statements regarding his official conduct at Honolulu:

The sailors were humming martial airs on the big cruiser New-York yesterday. They had all heard, early in the day, that Assistant Secretary McAdoo of the Navy Department had telegraphed to Admiral Gherardi to dock the vessel with all possible haste, so as to be ready to proceed to Brazil at the earliest possible moment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The Senate Committee on Territories holds its first meeting of the session to-morrow, when it will take up for consideration the bills to admit the Territories of, Utah and Arizona to Statehood, both of which have passed the House. The bills will probably be referred, to a sub-committee, which will not report until after the holidays.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:
LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The Times has this dispatch, dated at Rio on Dec. 16, and forwarded via Montevideo:
It was made almost certain yesterday that Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer must be tried again for the alleged poisoning of "Gustav Baum."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 20. -- The cornerstone of the Fourth Regiment Armory, at Bergen Avenue and Church Street, was laid tills afternoon. Gov. Werts and his staff, Gen. Wanser and his staff, and the military guests were escorted to the armory by the Fourth Regiment, under command of Col. H.H. Abernathy.

Certain manufacturers of cotton, cloth have added their protests and predictions of dire calamity to the McKinley chorus of complaint about the provisions of the Wilson bill, and wherever the owners of cotton-cloth mills have been constrained by the recent paralysis of credit and the reduced demand for consumption to suspend work, shorten time, or reduce wages, the assertion has been made that the Wilson bill is the cause of all the depression.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- William H. Hackett of Utica wrote Agricultural Commissioner Schraub a few days ago saying that he acted as agent for Armour Co. in the sale of oleomargarine in original packages in Utica and vicinity, and that he was justified in selling the same under a decision of the United States Supreme Court.

The Pontiac Club, the Tammany social organization in the Twenty-third Assembly District, formally opened its new clubhouse at 442 and 444 Amsterdam Avenue last night. No other Assembly district political club has a finer clubhouse, and there are many cities that cannot boast of any sort of a clubhouse that can compare with this one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The question whether Kope Elias of North Carolina, who was recently appointed by the President Collector of Internal Revenue for the Western District of his State, is to be confirmed by the Senate is attracting much, attention here.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Dec. 21 -- Deputy Sheriff Louis Walters of Queens County seized the furnishings of the Chapel of St. James's Episcopal Church, in this village, this morning to satisfy a judgment against John B. Hyatt, a former Superintendent of the Sunday school, who fitted up the chapel.

A number of down-town business men met yesterday afternoon at the office of Vermilye Co., at 16 and 18 Nassau Street, in response to a circular sent by George D. Mackay, President of the Industrial Christian Alliance, asking them to co-operate in helping the alliance in its new plan for the People's Restaurant and Lodging Houses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A cable message from eight comanders of American merchantmen at present anchored in the harbor of Rio Janeiro protesting against alleged interference with their rights by the insurgents was received by Secretary Gresham yesterday and by him sent to Secretary Herbert, as it concerned the authority of the war vessels of the United States.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 21 -- John Loftus, Assistant Superintendent of the Prudential Insurance Company, has been missing from his home here since last Friday. He has left a young wife destitute. It is said, $200 of the insurance company's funds is missing.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21 -- The affairs of C. Dettelbach Son, which have been involved in litigation, several weeks, came up in Chancery again this morning, with, renewed complications. On Monday the Metropolitan Dry Goods Company, which held a claim of $150, obtained from the Vice Chancellor an order restraining the Sheriff from selling the goods of the Dettelbachs.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- The one hundredth anniversary of Masonry in Peekskill was celebrated in Depew Opera House, this city, to-night. There were present the Grand Lodge of the State of New-York, many prominent Masons from throughout the State, and others of the craft from Poughkeepsie, Newburg, Cold Spring, Tarrytown, Sing Sing, Yonkers, and other places, and the officers and members of Cortland Lodge, No. 34, F. and A.M., whose centennial celebration it was.
Mayor Gilroy practically told Commissioner Edward Sheehy of the Department of Charities and Correction yesterday that he was not fitted to be a Commissioner.

Indications at present point to a very successful and interesting intercollegiate chess tournament next week. The contest will be opened Tuesday afternoon at 3 o'clock in the Harvard School, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. Mr. Freeland, the Principal, will make the opening address, immediately after which the second chess tournament between Columbia, Yale, Harvard, and Princeton will begin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The marriage of Miss Georgia Hope Webster, daughter of Major H. Webster, Chief Examiner of the Civil Service Commission, to Mr. M.D. Manigault Mowry, took place at 8 o'clock this evening at St. John's Church, Rev. Dr. Mackay-Smith officiating. The chancel was decorated with palms, which offset the arrangement of bridal roses on the altar.

At the twenty-fifth annual dinner of the alumni of Hamilton College, held last night at the Waldorf Hotel, President M. Woolsey Stryker made a declaration which was construed to mean that the relations between that college and the Presbyterian organization will be less intimate than they have been, and the college less of a sectarian institution.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Money was in abundant supply at the Clearing House this morning at 1 per cent, although there are still some loans outstanding at 1 1/2 per cent. There are no indications that rates will be higher at the end of the year. New-York funds were in good demand, selling at 10 cents per 1,000 premium.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 21 -- The failures of E.W. Herman and the Kentucky Malting Company, which occurred a week ago, are the worst that have occurred here in a long time. Mr. Herman's personal liabilities are between $100,000 and $150,000. His assets, so far as anybody knows, consist of a mortgaged house at 735 East Market Street.
Men distinguished in ail walks of life assembled last night at a banquet in Delmonico's to do honor to Mr. De Lancey Nicoll, soon to resign his tenure of office as District Attorney.

There was no uproar at the meeting of the Republican County Committee last night in Grand Opera House Hall. As stormy meetings are of frequent occurrence with the committee, the gathering last night may be regarded as a holiday novelty.

The St. Nicholas Bank, at Broad Street and Exchange Place, which appeared in last Saturday's weekly reports of the city banks with $500,000 capital and $130,200 net profits, and which claimed $105,000 surplus in a statement of Nov. 28, was not opened for business yesterday. State Banking Superintendent Charles M. Preston had taken possession of it, the surplus having vanished and the capital having been impaired to an amount estimated at from $90,000 to $180,000.

ORANGE, N.J. Dec. 21 -- The interest in the boycott upon members of the junior Order of the United American Mechanics in this city by the Roman Catholic residents was increased to-day by the publication in The Orange Journal of letters from the Rev. H.P. Fleming, pastor of St. John's Catholic Church, and William S. Clarendon, Special Deputy State Counselor of the Order of United American Mechanics, who organized the Orange lodges.

Mr. Ernestus Gulick has purchased the property at 17, 19, 21, and 25 Elm Place, Brooklyn, for $95,000, and it was rumored that a new theatre is to be put on this and adjacent ground having a frontage of 160 feet and a depth of 125. The persons interested, however, decline to discuss the subject.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 21 -- Word has been received here from Brazil that Abraham and Solomon Benchimol, steamship owners of Rio Janeiro, who were formerly traders in Liverpool and Manchester, have been arrested in Rio Janeiro and sentenced to be shot for allowing their steamers to carry insurgents as passengers.

-- Capt. Thomas, Second Mate Bowen Evans, the first mate and four of the crew of the bark Ensigne, which was wrecked on a reef near Cat Island on Dec. 8, arrived here yesterday on the steamer Antilia, from Nassau. Capt. Thomas said that during a heavy gale on Dec. 4, the Ensign sprang a leak, and for four clays and nights, the crew worked unceasingly at the pumps.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Both reports on the Wilson Tariff bill are now before Congress and the country. Before the adjournment of Congress to-day for the holidays, the minority report was presented to the House by Mr. Reed. It was a very long report, much longer than Chairman Wilson's statement of the position of the majority.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Dec. 21 -- The Rev. J.M. Nardiello last week began a crusade against balls and sociables given by such organizations as "The Jolly Six," "Mystic Eleven," "Jolly Brethren," and kindred associations. The crusade began with a sermon in which the priest said that if such indiscriminate dances were not stopped in this town he should take a hand in stopping them.

In an Interview with a reporter from The New-York Times on Saturday last, District Leader-Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan said: "I want to say that the Police Board has very little to do with politics, really less than I expected when I became a Commissioner. There is little or no politics in the Police Department."

From The Milwaukee Journal, (Dec.) The message 13 a judicial presentation of the whole case, and it gives strong casons for every act of the Administration in the matter. The case is now submitted to the people, and there is little doubt that they will indorse the Administration in the course which it has pursued.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations of Postmasters:
Richard Croker introduced the following resolution at the meeting of the Tammany Committee on Organization at Tammany Hall last night, and it was unanimously adopted:

-- General Passenger Agent Lomax of the union Pacific has sent the following order to the company's agents: "Effective Jan 1, rates between Missouri River terminals and Montana, Spokane, and Portland will be restored to tariff rates in effect June 1 last. There will be no change in present special rates between Missouri River and Colorado and Utah."

John D. Townsend, counsel for Dr. Frank Abbott, Jr., was asked yesterday what were the contents of the two letters which Col. Pickert, Atobott's father-in-law, charged him with having taken from his office at 132 Pearl Street on April 10, 1891, and for which he had been arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Actor Frederick Warde was granted his plea to take the poor debtors' oath yesterday, and was discharged from custody.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- The correspondent of the United Press has learned from an authentic source that the Russo-German commercial treaty has been completed and has been signed proemially by the delegates. It is expected that the treaty will be ratified by the Ministers about the middle of January and be introduced in the Reichstag toward the end of the same month.
(Copyright, 1893, by the United Press.) SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- The Mariposa brings the following Honolulu advices, up to Dee. 14:

The House of Representatives is not fulfilling the just expectations of the men who voted for the majority of its members. The Democratic majority is overwhelming in numbers, but it permits itself to be rendered helpless and paralyzed by the Republican minority. It did manage to get through with the Silver Repeal bill with reasonable diapatch, or, at least, at a rate that seemed reasonable when compared with the delay in the Senate.

The Hoffman House is bankrupt. Late yesterday afternoon Judge Truax of the Supreme Court placed all the property of The company which owns the hotel in the hands of Edward S. Stokes, the present manager, as receiver. Mr. Stokes was given full power to continue the business until the outcome of the proceedings which resulted in his appointment is determined.

As an appropriate Christmas play, and pending the production of Paul Potter's new comedy, Mr. Daniel Frohman has brought forward again at the Lyceum Theatre Arthur Wing Pinero's charming play, called "Sweet Lavender," and its first performance in nearly five years was thoroughly enjoyed by a large audience last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Atchison and New-England monopolized the market largely to-day, and the local stocks took rather a back seat. There was very little pressure to sell Pennsylvania, and it was traded in around 47, and closed at 47 1/4. A drive was made at Lehigh Valley, which scared some of the local traders.

The funeral of Thomas W. Robinson, cashier of the Mount Morris Bank since 1880, was held in Holy Trinity Church, Harlem, last evening. Mr. Robinson had been ill with gastritis only ten days, and up to within a few hours of his death there was no apprehension of a fatal termination of his sickness.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- George C. Bartley (Conservative) called the attention of the House to a public speech made by Edmund F. Knox, (Anti-Parnellite,) to the effect that shares of the British South Africa Company had been given to a number of members of the House of Commons for the purpose of influencing them to support the company.

Conditions affecting the Atchlson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad property are now such as to cause much anxiety on the part of its friends. Important negotiations designed to strengthen the financial condition of the company have been interrupted, if not stopped altogether, by the lamentable death of George C. Magoun, Chairman of the Board of Directors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Justice and Mrs. Brewer gave a tea this afternoon from 4 to 7 o'clock in honor of the debut of their daughter. Miss Brewer, who stood beside her mother to receive the guests in a gown of corn color bengaline, trimmed with the same shade of chiffon. She carried a bouquet of long-stemmed white roses tied with a profusion of narrow white ribbon.

The kindly associations of the festive season and the traditional hospitality of the members of the New-England Society of the City of Brooklyn combined last night to make the fourteenth annual dinner of the organization in question a very genial and interesting function.

Messrs. Hoyt McKee have decided not to take a new lease of the Madison Square Theatre at the close of their present term, which expires next September. Mr. McKee, speaking on the subject last night, said: "We have come to this conclusion within the last three days. We have not chosen another theatre, though a dozen responsible gentlemen have offered to build one for us.

The preliminary boxing and wrestling bouts for the championship of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union were held in the Central Turn Verein Hall last night. The contestants satisfied everybody that they were bona ride amateurs. They did not know the first rudiments of boxing, and the wrestling was farcical. The entries were by long odds the poorest ever seen at a championship meeting.

The Tariff-Reform bill will be called up after the holiday recess. Wo trust that it will then be pushed with energy and decision, and especially that the partisan efforts of the minority to block the way with their manoeuvres on the Hawaiian question or any like matter will not be allowed to interfere with it The majority in Congress so far has not shown the firmness and spirit that it ought to show.

Mr. Robert Bonner was presented witn a handsome silver model of Sunol last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The gift was from the trotting horse breeders all over the country, and was in recognition of the good that Mr. Bonner has done the trotting horse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- It was nearly 4 o'clock, and the House had been adjourned for some time, when the Senate finished the business it had undertaken to transact and began its holiday recess. The proceeding's were in no sense interesting. Nearly all of the Senators were present.

Col. Alfred T. Walcott, President of the Monmouth Park Racing Association, had an uncomfortable hour of it yesterday in the Superior Court, before Judge Dugro. He was asked point blank if he had not connived at the maintenance of a disorderly house, and whether he had not, through his agents, bribed or attempted to bribe the members of the Chicago Common Council.

As predicted in The New-York Times yesterday, Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer will have to be tried again on the charge of having poisoned "Gustav Baum." Judge Barrett yesterday dismissed the jury before which Dr. Meyer was arraigned, and ordered a retrial.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Dec. 21 -- P.M. The closing of the St. Nicholas Bank and the death of Mr. Magoun were the two subjects which were discussed in Wall Street to-day. Probably no man stood higher in the esteem of the financial community than Mr. Magoun, and although his severe illness and the possibility of its fatal termination had been known for several days, his death had not been anticipated at this time.

Senator HOAR has relieved himself of a good deal of partisan bile by his denunciation of the President's course in dealing with the Hawaiian complication. Resolutions have been referred to committees in both houses of Congress inquiring into the conduct of Mr. STEVENS and the Administration under which he served, and into the conduct of Mr. BLOUNT and the Administration under which he served.
John J. Vail, the cashier of the defunct State Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, was yesterday indicted by the Kings County Grand Jury for perjury.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

Only one auction sale of real estate was had yesterday. It was in foreclosure proceedings, and affected the property at 220 and 222 East Eighty-fifth Street, south side, beginning 280 feet east of Third Avenue, 24.9 by 102.2 and 25 by 102.2, respectively, the first with a two-story frame building and the other vacant.

-- Mrs. Michala Vodera, thirty-five years old, of 237 Elizabeth Street, fired two shots from a revolver yesterday at Emile Lumbacia, a fruit dealer at 222 Second Street, but he escaped unharmed. In the Tombs Police Court yesterday the woman explained that the man had asked her several times to leave her husband and live with him, and he finally threatened to stab her if she persisted in refusing.

A direct and emphatic agreement was entered into by the managers of the trunk line railroads yesterday to restore rates on east-bound freight on the first of next month. By that time the cut-rate contracts now in force will have expired. The cutting of rates has mostly been in grain and provisions, and the restoration will again put in force the schedule that prevailed prior to Nov. 28, the date of the Erie's open cut.

A thirty-foot-deep centreboard sloop is being built by Elmer A. Ely of Middletown. Conn. She is from designs by Mr. D.T. Haines, Secretary of the Middlesex Banking Company, and has many novel features in her construction. She is to be used by her owner as a erasing yacht on the river and on the Sound, and is to have all the accommodations necessary for the rational enjoyment of life afloat.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- President Fiero of the New-York State Bar Association states that arrangements for the annual meeting of that body in this city, Jan. 17, are substantially completed. A brief address by Vice President Adlai E. Stevenson is announced, and an address will also be made by Senator Joseph N. Dolph of Oregon.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Dec. 21 -- There is some ill-feeling in the Methodist Episcopal Sunday school here, growing out of the election of a Superintendent of the Primary Department. All might have been well had not the defeated candidate thought that she had been badly treated.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- It is probable that before the end of this year Gov. Flower will fill vacancies in the State Board of Health caused by the resignations of ex-Senator Thomas Newbold of Poughkeepsie, Prof. Perkins of Schenectady, and Dr. Thomas S. Dawes of Saugerties. Dr. Dawes resigned lately in consequence of ill health.

"You must imagine I have a cavalier and a handsome one," said Mrs. Genevieve Stebbins at the Professional Woman's League Wednesday afternoon. Mrs. Stebbins was a picture herself in a flowing robe of some soft white material, the delicate pink front clasped with silver, and flowing angel sleeves, whose pink lining accentuated the expressive white arms.
The soap manufacturing firm of Charles S. Higgins Co., Brooklyn, is insolvent, and yesterday Justice Cullen appointed John J. Morgan of 171 Putnam Avenue receiver.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

As a result of the efforts of the University Settlement Society to relieve the condition of the poor of the east side there may be established a new and powerful charitable organization in this city which shall deal not only with the present emergency, but with enlarged charitable work in the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Speaker Crisp stood, alone to-day in the House as a check to the boisterous Republicans making one more of the frenzied assaults upon the Administration that they have chosen to indulge in every day upon the Hawaiian Question. There is only one way effectually to stop a dog's bark, but the Speaker is not permitted under the rules to behead a member of the opposition because he is noisy.
In the great hall at Cooper Union last evening the New-York State Democracy was formally christened and made a live and active body for good in the politics of this State.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Chronicle to-day publishes a lengthy interview had by its representative with Cardinal Gibbons of Baltimore, which is notable for its sympathetic treatment of labor problems. In commenting on the interview the paper says:
The proceedings in the Gravesend election frauds contempt case are but the begining of more serious troubles for John Y. McKane, boss of Coney Island.

John Schliemann, Excise Commissioner of Brooklyn, who was requested to resign by Mayor Boody a few days ago, had not resigned yesterday up to the time the Mayor left his office. Mayor Body did not give out Schliemann's letter, as, it is said, he has hopes that Schliemann will yet with draw it and resign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- An interesting report was made by Mr. Cadmus, (Dem., N.J.,) this morning, from the House Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds, in relation to the resolution referred to that committee last October, directing inquiry as to the public buildings and grounds at New-York City.

Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren is slowly forming his Cabinet, and, while he is obtaining men who are eminently fitted for the different departments over which they will preside, his selections are not at all pleasing to the professional politicians.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- The State is secured, against any loss by the St. Nicholas Bank by a bond for $200,000. A request for the names of the bondsmen made by the correspondent for The New-York Times was refused.

We do not think there is very much difference of opinion among good citizens about the beneficence of the changes that have been made in the charter of New-York during the past twenty years, and that have had for their object to increase the power of and the responsibility of the Mayor.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 21 -- It toolk just one spike to-day to make the Florida Central and Peninsular a great railroad system. That spike was driven shortly before noon on this side of the Altamaha River. It fixed the rail that connects Columbia, S.C., and Jacksonville with a ribbon of steel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The case of Commodore O.F. Stanton was disposed of to-day, by his restoration to duty, but, in taking this action, Secretary Herbert disapproved of the Commodore's action in saluting the insurgent Admiral, Mello in the harbor of Rio de Janeiro Oct. 20 last.
Edmond Kelly, Secretary of the City Club, has resigned his office. He sent the following letter to President James C. Carter yesterday:

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment continued the work of arranging the final budget for 1894 in the Mayor's office yesterday, and made rapid progress with it. One of the most interesting estimates considered was that of the Street Cleaning Department. Commissioner Andrews had originally asked tor $3,138,931.21, but in the arrangement of the provisional budget $2,361,410 was allowed.

The names of the members of the Provisional Committee of One Hundred, which is to preside over the Democratic reorganization in Kings County, were made public yesterday by George Foster Peabody, President of the Brooklyn Democratic Club. The committee is made up of business men, lawyers, and self-respecting citizens who refused to support the "ring" candidates at the late election.

Herr Anton Hegner, the 'cellist imported by Waiter Damrosch, will not play with the Symphony Orchestra until such time as he may become a member of the Musical Mutual Protective Union. Mr. Damrosch and the union at first differed on this point, and the members of his orchestra last Sunday refused to respond to Mr. Damrosch's baton.

Much as the ancient Puritan delighted to mortify the flesh, he excepted one portion of his earthly tabernacle from the rigorous discipline to which he subjected the rest of his organs and senses. He revered his stomach. Tradition alleges and history attests this fact. The one carnal pleasure he did not place under the ban was that begotten of a good dinner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The sympathizers in the United States with the "fifteen hundred" persons in Hawaii who assert that as a "better class" they are entitled to rule the other 85,000 of the population are determined to keep out of sight, if possible, the fact that there would have been no revolution in Honolulu if the forces of the United States had not assisted the revolutionists.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 22 -- Scarcely had the body of the Rev. Charles Witherspoon been consigned to the grave when the vestry of St. Paul's Church held a meeting, the first one held in a month. This is the vestry which the dead rector had dissolved. The vestry met to devise a plan for getting possession of the church.

-- Mrs. Annie Cummings was arrested on Dec. 13 on a charge of keeping a disorderly house at 40 and 42 West Twenty-fourth Street. At the time she maintained that she kept a respectable boarding house, and said that the detectives who visited her house told her that if she paid $100 she would have no trouble. Dr. Parkhurst took an interest in her case, and said her arrest was an outrage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- As the result of an investigation by the police authorities of a report that an attempt was likely to be made to kill Senator Roger Q. Mills, the Senator's son and secretary, Charles H. Mills, has been licensed to carry a pistol for thirty days.

-- Francis D. Vreeland, at one time a teacher in the School of the Immaculate Conception in Baltimore, was sent to prison by Judge Martine in the Court of General Sessions yesterday for seven years for kidnapping. He brought two boys to this city last November, promising them places on the stage. The boys were Theodore L. Eschbach, fifteen years old, and William E. Martin, sixteen years old.

Fifty-ninth Street, There were rows upon rows of tables, with their white cloths and pretty china; there were palms and candles and rich silks and soft velvets, making a gay mosaic of color; and everywhere there was a low, continuous hum of conversation, proclaiming a company of women with something worth while to talk about.

Readers have virtually two numbers of Harper's Magazine for Christmas. The December number, issued a month ago, with its holiday clothes, is now selling in its second edition, and we have already at hand the number for January. It opens with the first part of George du Maurier's new fiction, "Trilby," which is illustrated by himself, as was his Harper novel of some time ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- There is a growing impression among Senators that no attempt will be made to change the rules this Congress, at least. At the time of the silver debate, when the silver men carried debate to a point where repeal men called "deliberation" filibustering, there was talk of a cloture rule.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 22 -- While part of the insurgent fleet was proceeding along the coast of the State of Rio de Janeiro a few days ago three officers deserted their ships. They have been arrested by the Government and have given considerable information concerning the condition of the insurgent forces.

While Civil Justice Alfred Steckler of the Fourth District Civil Court was holding court yesterday morning in the courtroom in the Florence Building, First Street and Second Avenue, a policeman hurriedly approached the bench and informed him that the building was shaking and liable to come down at any moment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Washington Congressional Club to-night gave a dinner commemorating the landing of the Pilgrim Fathers at Plymouth, Mass., in 1620, to-day being the anniversary of that event. There were 100 persons present.

Commenting upon the report that Congressman HAINES of the Troy district intends to vote against the Wilson bill because it reduces the high McKinley duty on collars and cuffs, the Rochester Union and Advertiser, which is edited by the Hon. WILLIAM PURCELL, makes the following remarks:

A long fight in Company C, Seventy-first Regiment, was ended last night by the election of First Lieut. L.W. Francis to the Captaincy. The company was divided about equally three months ago, when Capt. A.C. Francis was elected senior Major. It was said at that time that he was bent on having his son, the First Lieutenant, made Captain, in opposition to the wishes of many of the members.

Justice Van Brunt was in receipt of the following communication yesterday from Dr. J.B. Andrews, Superintendent of the State Hospital for the Insane, in Buffalo, bearing upon the case of Edward M. Field:

The eighth round and one game of the final round of the Masters' Chess Tournament were played at the Manhattan Cafe yesterday. Ettlinger sent word that he was ill, and resigned both his games to Delmar and Showalter. The other games resulted as follows:

The class of '95 of Columbia College held its annual junior promenade last evening in the Library Building of the college. The ball was a complete success, and each junior added about two inches to his height as he entered the ballroom and looked upon the graceful scene, in which tropical palms, Christmas holly, and gliding, whirling forms were blended in an intoxicating maze.

-- David L. How, proprietor and cashier of the First National Bank of Shakopee, Minn., shot himself through the temple yesterday morning. Despondency and domestic and financial troubles are assigned as the cause. He had $55,000 insurance on his life, and this will more than straighten his affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The long and bitter controversy in the Naval Board of Bureau Chiefs has ended, for a time at least. It grew into importance through a paragraph in the revised Naval Regulations, although it was the continuation of a longstanding conflict of expert opinion between the Bureau of Construction and the Bureau of Ordnance.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The Lake Street Elevated Railroad Company has filed with the Commissioner of Public Works a plan for the extension of the tracks of that road on the North Side of this city, and it is said that the work of construction will be begun in a short time. Unfortunately for this road the organization of the company was full of blunders, and it stands now with threatened dissolution.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Mayor Rankin declares there are too many saloons in operation here. He has asked the Board of Excise to stop granting new licenses.

Dun's Review to-morrow will say: "The year is practically over, except the holiday business, which is remarkably well sustained as respects number of sales, considering the state of industries and the army of the unemployed, but is materially diminished in volume because purchases average much smaller in value than in recent years.

Assistant Secretary Hamlin, Collector Kilbreth, and Appraiser Bunn had a conference yesterday over tobacco refunds. The tariff of 1883 imposed a duty of 75 cents a pound upon tobacco importations in which more than 85 per cent. was suitable for wrappers, and of 35 cents. a pound upon all other leaf tobacco.

OMAHA, Dec. 22 -- Receiver E. Ellery Anderson of the Union Pacific, General Manager Dickinson, and other officers of the road, returned from Denver this morning. Mr. Anderson said: "I am reported at Denver as having stated quite positively my disapproval of the separation of the Gulf system from that of the Union Pacific.

-- Mr. Francis Herites, Mayor of Vodnan, a city in South Bohemia, who has been in this country for four months, most of the time at the World's Fair, is now visiting in Baltimore, and will sail from this city for home on the day following New year's. He is accompanied by his wife and two daughters.

Copyright, 1893, by The United Press. KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 22 -- Few details regarding the revolt against President Heureaux of San Domingo have been received. The latest advices are to the effect that the movement is well under way, and that the Government has not yet succeeded in suppressing it.

Mr. Henry Gielow, the designer of the schooner Loyal, sloop Saona, steamers Marietta, Vesta, Theresa, and other good yacht's, is the first of the designers in this city to start building new yachts for next season. He has an order for a 63-foot schooner for a prominent New-York yachtsman, and a 45-foot steam launch for Mr. Robert Schoonmaker, Jr., of Philadelphia.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 22 -- The famous old Vasaar Brewery, in this city, will soon be sold at partition sale, an action to that end having been commenced by Helen M. Harbottle of Auburn, one of the heirs of James Vassar Harbottle, who, prior to his death, in January, 1893, had an interest in the firm of M. Vassar Co., which now controls the brewery.

From The Lewiston (Me.) Journal. The maddest man in Penobscot County has been found by our Corinna correspondent. He lost a flock of geese lately, and consulted a medium as to their whereabouts. To do so he drove sixteen miles in a cold snowstorm and was told on arrival that the desired information would be forthcoming on payment of $1.
The police of the Eldridge Street Station had a strange report to make at Police Headquarters yesterday concerning the treatment of a diphtheria patient by physicians at Gouverneur Hospital.

The athletic members of the Eighty-sixth Street Branch, Young Men's Christian Association, are looking forward to Christmas Day with considerable interest, for in the afternoon an informal gymnasium exhibit will take place. The events will include a potato race, obstacle race, egg race, and other features conducive alike to both excitement and activity.

-- The three-men team match at Willard's Park, Preston, next Thursday, promises to be a good contest. There will be eight or ten teams. Each man will shoot at fifteen birds. The entry fee is $30 a team, and the purse will be divided 50, 30, and 20 per cent.

There were no developments in Atchison affairs yesterday. The price of the stock continued weak, and there was considerable selling in the Stock Exchange on a report that representatives of the law firm of Alexander Green of this city had gone to Topeka, Kan., to make application for a receiver.

The foreign exchange market was weak. The posted rates for sterling were reduced to $4.85 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84 2/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/2 for demand, $4.87 for cable transfers, and $4.83@$4.83 1/4, for commercial.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Mocenni, Minister of War, to-day in the Chamber of Deputies announced a victory of the Italian troops Thursday over the dervishes, between Kassala and Agordat, in Northeastern Africa.

American railway securities were weak in the London market. Atchison was depressed sharply on the death of Mr. Magoun and a rumored receivership for the company. St. Paul was freely sold and fell off 1 per cent. The London Stock Exchange will be closed from to-night until Wednesday morning.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 22 -- There is trouble in the Salem Baptist Church, colored, on the Heights. The row grew out of a fair given Monday, but the matter was kept quiet until to-day, when the Rev. Richard A. Motley, paster of the church, caused the arrest of Joseph S. Allen, Treasurer of the church, for assault.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Since Thanksgiving, the rumor has been current about the college that the Faculty intended to take some radical action in the restriction of college sports before the beginning of another athletic season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- New tariffs were issued to-day by the Chicago committee of the Central Traffic Association, to go into effect Jan. 1 and to expire Feb. 28. They dealt with rebates on butter, eggs, and poultry, advancing them 6 cents per 100 pounds above those now in effect, but still not restoring them to full rates.

According to custom the senior class of the Normal College celebrated Christmas by the presentation of an original play, entitled "The Knight's Tale," acted in the chapel before the Faculty, instructors, and students yesterday afternoon. The day on which the Christmas play is given is looked forward to by all the Normal College girls with great eagerness from the beginning of the college term in September.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- At the New-England dinner here to-night ex-President Harrison made a slight allusion to Hawaii. Remarking that the name New-England was a part of an old classification of the States, and that all that classification was gone now, except the two terms New-England and the South, he went on as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The number of actors now stranded in Chicago and in need is as large, in proportion to the whole number unemployed, as that of any other profession. The benefit matinee given at the Chicago Opera House last week by actors and actresses in Chicago for the destitute was a signal for a flood of letters of appeal for aid directed to Stuart Robson, who had the performance in charge.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- It was a market for industrials to-day. West Chicago was neglected. A few sales of North Chicago were made at 249. City Railway was nominal, with 327 asked. The industrials, omitting Diamond Match, which was a point and a fraction lower, were surprisingly strong.

The county in this State first to avail itself of the provision of the "good-roads" law, which was signed last April by Gov. Flower, is Oneida. The Supervisors of that county met in Utica last Tuesday, and Supervisor McCreary introduced a resolution for the adoption of the county system.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- The six-story building in Friend, Canal, and Travers Streets, occupied by the Boston Chair Manufacturing Company, M.W. Cain Sons, furniture dealers; G.W. Bent Go., dealers in cushions, J.M. Woods Co., lumber dealers, and the Standard Wire Mattress Company, was almost totally destroyed by fire this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- No information concerning the reported triumph of Admiral Mello and the resignation of President Peixoto has been received at the State and the Navy Departments. Secretary Gresham said this afternoon that he did not place credence in the report.

There were in the studio, critically examining two paintings recently finished, a model similar to a thin block burned by a thunderbolt, the painter, a poet too preoccupied by eternal things to say a word, and a physician, who remarked:

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Lizzie Foy left the witness stand temporarily in Judge Tuthill's courtroom this evening with the reputation of being the most sensational witness yet produced by the State against Daniel Coughlin, and with the conviction in the minds of many disinterested people who heard her story that she had placed the detective much nearer the gallows than he ever was before.

Plymouth Church lecture room, in Brookyn, was the scene last evening of a unique service. The service, which was of a special character, was for the purpose of dedicating the new Abbott hymnal, which has been substituted for the Beecher hymnal, which Henry Ward Beecher compiled in 1855.

The most sensational testimony adduced, by the Columbian Audit Commission in Brooklyn was elicited yesterday from John Dempsey of the stationery firm of Dempsey Carroll of this city. The firm furnished the Columbian Committee with engraved cards and invitations, for which the city paid $630.
Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst yesterday made a statement regarding the alleged obstructions placed in his way by District Attorney Nicoll in the effort to secure indictments against the police Captains.

To any one willing to read its deeper meaning, the dinner to District Attorney NICOLL at Delmonico's on Thursday evening had a significance far beyond the compliment it conveyed to the guest of the evening; although in that respect it was most remarkable and transcended probably any compliment ever paid to a public officer of this city.

VINITA, Indian Territory, Dec. 22 -- An unsuccessful attempt was made this evening at Kelso, four miles north of here, to rob the Missouri Kansas and Texas train No. 3. A switch was opened and the train ran upon the siding. This alarmed the engineer, and knowing there was a spring switch at the other end, he applied full steam and ran away.

Representatives of the various charity organizations who had attended the meetat the United Charities Organization's Building in Fourth Avenue, held a conference yesterday and decided to address a letter to the Mayor in regard to the distress that exists among the unemployed.
The affairs of the suspended St. Nicholas Bank have taken a sensational turn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Orders have been sent to the New-York to have that ship put in readiness for departure at once. The intervention of a Sunday and the Christmas holiday may interfere with the departure of the cruiser as soon as is desired at Washington, but everything will be pushed with the idea of getting the New-York to sea at the earliest possible moment.

Here are nine essays, the oldest bearing date of 1866, which were written in the scant leisure of pressing occupations. As far as the substance goes, "I find," the author writes, "nothing to alter in them. Whether that is evidence of the soundness of my opinions or of my having made no progress in wisdom for the last quarter of a century must be left to the courteous reader to decide."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 22 -- The Duval Athletic Club received a set-back to-day in its efforts to pull off the Corbett-Mitchell fight. The attorney for the club appeared before Gov. Mitchell at Tallahassee and made an application for a charter. This the Governor flatly refused, stating that, under cover of the charter, the club proposed to violate the laws of Florida.

Miss Helen Gould has added another to her long list of gracious acts, and hopes to make a number of boys happy by giving them an outing in the country and a very merry Christmns. Out of compliment to the Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water of St. 'Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church she asked him to send six boys to her Tarrytown residence.

A fire, inconsiderable in itself, in a five-story tenement house at 502 East Twelfth Street yesterday morning was rendered notable from the bravery and presence of mind it enabled Miss Emma Snyder, the daughter of the aged janitor, Henry Snyder, to display.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, of which Mr. George is Chairman, has been engaged for several months, under the resolution of the Senate passed during the Fifty-second Congress, in investigating the causes for the existing depression in the cotton-producing States.
Bridge Trustee Seth L. Keeney, President of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on an indictment found by the Grand Jury charging him with perjury.
Decent citizens of the village of Westchester are highly indignant over the failure of the authorities of that community to suppress pool selling and other forms of gambling.

It was announced yesterday that Justice Cullen, being charitably disposed, would not render his decision on the application for a stay, pending John Y. McKane's appeal from Justice Barnard's decision, until Tuesday, in order that the "boss" of Gravesend might eat his Christmas dinner with his family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The argument of counsel was begun to-day before Judge Bradley of the Supreme Court of the District in the cases of Judge Charles D. Long of Michigan against Pension Commissioner Lochren.

-- Most of the Philadelphia Judges have their own peculiarities. They tell a story of one well-known Judge of the Common Pleas, who likes an occasional afternoon nap, that after an important case had been argued for several hours by leading counsel with great eloquence the Attorney for the State coughed and prodded his Honor gently and said: "They are awaiting your verdict."

From The Columbia (Ga.) Enquirer-Sun, (Dem.) The Democratic Party is about to make a record on the Hawaiian issue. The record it will make in sustaining the Administration will strengthen it with the American people, and meet the approval and challenge the admiration of the civilized world. The Enquirer-Sun is gratified to learn that the Georgia delegation in Congress will stand as a unit with the President on this policy.

The New-England Congregational Church, on South Ninth Street, near Driggs Avenue, Williamsburg, was destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. Yesterday was the fortieth anniversary of the opening of the church building.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- When Prince Colonna, Mrs. J.W. Mackay's son-in-law, sold the furniture of his Paris house recently, M. Brossault, a wine dealer, was pressing him to pay a bill of 4,500f. for liquors. The Prince promised to pay the money in a few day's. He then left Paris suddenly, but M. Brossault was assured by his agent that the money would be sent in a week.
Mr. Charles Lanier, Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association. 17 Nassau Street, reports the following additional contributions to the General Hospital Fund:

-- W.I. Ogden, business manager of The Chicago Tribune, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 46 Thirty-fifth Street, Chicago. Mr. Ogden had not even been sick. He had been attending to his duties in The Tribune office regularly, as usual, up to Thursday evening. After dinner he went to the Douglas Club and passed the evening there.

This evening the final wrestling and boxing bouts for the metropolitan championships of the Amateur Athletic Union will be held in Central Turn Verein Hall, Sixty-seventh Street, near Third Avenue. Several of the contestants who failed to appear on Thursday night through a misunderstanding have promised to show up and give a good account of themselves.

A vexatious delay to passengers on the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad happened shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The packing had worn out of the cylinder head of Engine No. 203, and steam escaped in large quantities. From Fifty-ninth Street to Ninety-first the engine managed to drag the train along at a snail's pace, but there it broke down altogether.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- Dr. Landauer, the editor of The Socialist, who is serving a two months' sentence, has been condemned to a term of nine months more for having stirred the people to class hatred. He is the ninth editor of The Sozialist, although the journal is still young. His eight predecessors were prosecuted forty times for inciting the people to violence and class hatred.

Col. William C. Young died at his residence, 465 West Twenty-third Street, yesterday, after a short illness, in his ninety-eighth year. Funeral services will be held at 4 P.M. to-day, after which the body will be taken to Albany for burial.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Referring to an editorial article in your issue of the 21st inst., when the writer of the "Holland" letter to The Philadelphia Press on the 12th instant quotes me as saying certain things concerning the relations of the tariff to the business interests with which I am identified, he, doubtless innocently, but nevertheless utterly, fails to represent my convictions and views as expressed.

The horse and carriage trade is just now pretty quiet in New-York. The only thins that any of the dealers can find to complain of, even in these hard times, is the lack of available horses to fill their orders for first-class harness animals. The bad times in the Fall and Spring made the horsemen chary about "making" horses fit for the city market.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Dec. 22 -- Two masked men broke into the house of Christopher Meyer, on Grand Avenue, Maspeth, last night, and secured diamonds and watches valued at $4,000. Mr. Meyer is a brother of Cord Meyer, the Democratic candidate for Secretary of State at the last election. He lives with his two maiden sisters, in the old homestead.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Dec. 22 -- P.M. The stock market was less active than yesterday, but prices continued to decline. Atchison was sold by Boston, but the net loss was only fractional. The bonds were also largely traded in, but the buying was so good that they closed higher than yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Mayor Rankin's appeal for aid in behalf of the 3,000 unemployed workmen of this city and their families has had a spontaneous response from Elizabeth's more fortunate citizens. The Rescue Mission rooms were designated in the appeal as the receiving depot, and donations of money, clothing, food, and fuel have been continuously pouring into them.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 23. -- The old-time ferryboat Wiehawken of the Ninety-ninth Street and College Point Ferry sank the big dredge Flood Rock, owned by the Government, while on its way through Hell Gate toward College Point on the 7:20 o'clock trip this morning. The dredge was anchored opposite Ward's Island, on Middle Ground Reef, where the Government engineer boat, the General Newton, is blasting out rock to widen and deepen the channel.

Nothing is more becoming to the piquant face of a little girl than short hair, either the loose curls that are the natural heritage of many small missesor the straight hair which falls to the lot of others, trimmed close. It is a relief to the child in Summer, and all the year round is a sensible way that she should wear her hair.

From The Washington Star. In the last District Apropriation bill there appeared an item allowing 50 cents per ton for the removal of garbage in steel tanks. Shortly after the law went into operation a question arose as to what number of pounds constituted a ton. The contractors claimed that 2,000 pounds was the legal ton, and made returns on that basis.

The lace importing house of Albert, Haager Co., at 57 Greene Street, has been seized by the Sheriff on two executions for $53,504. Henry C. Albert, the only remaining member of the firm, confessed judgments for $51,445, in favor of his father, Nicholas Albert, for money loaned on Jan. 1, 1886, to Albert, Haager Waldburger, which debt he assumed, and for $2,059 in favor of John Crusius on a note.

Ex-Cashier John J. Vail of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, who has been indicted by the Kings County Grand Jury for perjury in making a false report of the condition of the bank to the Superintendent of Banks, will be indicted Tuesday on two charges of forgery in the third degree.

For a man of seventy-eight to be still possessed of a great fund of animal spirits is indeed remarkable. Although he is almost an octogenarian, one might say that Mr. Le Fanu writes as if he were in the springtide of life.

The season of giving has been regarded from various standpoints -- its religious, social, extravagant, or economical aspects -- but, so far as is known, the humors of merry Christmas have never been exploited. In any time of unusual excitement and nervous strain the step between the sublime and the ridiculous is often taken, and the absurdity inherent in human nature comes bubbling up to the surface of events.
From The Samaratan. Never lean with the back upon anything that is cold.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Christmas presents in the shape of pardons have been given by the President in the cases of ten convicts and the sentence in another case has been commuted.

The general verdict in the corridors of the Opera House on Wednesday evening was that the opera performance of "Carmen" was the best of the season. It was also agreed that Jean de Reszke's Don Jose was almost an ideal interpretation. The audience was quite absorbed by the tragic pathos of his last scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A cablegram has been received at the State Department from Minister P.M.B. Young, dated Nicaragua, stating that Honduras revolutionists are marching from Nicaragua to Honduras. The army of the latter country has been put in motion to meet them. The cablegram gives no hint of the probable outcome of the contest.
Mayor Boody of Brooklyn yesterday received the following letter form the India Wharf Brewing Company of Brooklyn, accompanied by a check for $500.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- SS Alecto, (Br.,) from NewYork Dec. 10 for London, passed the Scilly Islands to-day.

The foreign exchange market was weak. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.85@$4.87 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84 1/4, for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/2 for demand, $4.87 for cable transfers, and $4.83@$4.83 1/4, for commercial.

SING SING, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- There are any quantity of legends told concerning the early settlement of Upper Westchester County, particularly during the Revolutionary period. These legends are handed down by the farmers from generation to generation until in these days they possess much interest.

Mr. French, having kept British melodrama on the stage of his splendid American Theatre for more than half a year, last night put forward a piece of a quite different character. "The Voyage of Suzette," taken from the French of those facile farce writers and librettists, Chivot and Duru, by C.A. Byrne and Louis Harrison, is certainly, in its present shape, very unlike British melodrama.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
The following letter has been received by Judge Burke of New-York from Col. L.S. Hatch, now at the Arlington Hotel, Hot Springs, Ark., regarding the forthcoming meeting at Hot Springs:

Carmine Monetto, who keeps a boarding house at 311 North Second Street, Brooklyn, was in the Lee Avenue Police Court yesterday to explain why he had refused to deliver to her husband the wife of Salvatore Carusco, a young and handsome woman who arrived from Italy last week. Carusco complained to Justice Goetting Friday that his wife was in Monetto's house, and that he had refused to surrender her.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Father Corrigan, pastor of St. Mary's Church, to-day furnished for publication a long letter, in relation to the troubles between himself and Father Fabris. Father Corrigan in his letter declined to enter into any discussion of the matter of the alleged conflict of authority between the Apostolic Delegate and Bishop Wigger growing out of the differences between himself and his assistant priests.

From The Boston Commonwealth. A very strong argument for the "indefinite sentence" of criminals, with probationary release on parole, was made by Prof. Charles A. Collin at the anniversary meeting of the Massachusetts Prison Association, which we announced last week. Prof. Collin regards this system as "the foundation cornerstone of any rational, scientific method of treating prison convicts."

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Having just read in your highly-interesting paper of Sunday, the 17th inst., of the contemplated walk of E.P. Weston, from New-York City to Albany, to be performed in three days, I recall the record of some of the pedestrian, trips accomplished by the late Capt. Alden Partridge of Norwich, Vt.

James W. Smith, who has a manufacturing establishment at 80 Fifth Avenue and lives at 469 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, was in Mould's cafe, under the Parker House, on Broadway, last evening. When he came out with a companion there was a hansom cab in front of the place. He fell under it. Smith and his companion got into the cab a few minutes later and were driven down Broadway.

Five volumes on "The Industries of Russia," prepared by the Russian Government and translated into English under the personal supervision of J.M. Crawford, United States Consul General at St. Petersburg, have been received by The New-York Times.

At 11 o'clock Saturday night all was well in the Protestant Episcopal Sisters' Home at 34 West Twenty-second Street. The lights were out, doors barred, and the sisters, tired with their day's labor, had gone to their respective apartments.

Forty years ago one might play a game of whist, indifferent to Hoyle, but it was not possible to shoot unless in accordance with Col. Hawker. His "Instructions to Young Sportsmen" was a work approached with awe and read with reverence, for Col. Hawker's reputation was universal and deservedly so. Of wild-fowling, by which is meant the shooting of the larger sea birds, Hawker may be termed the father.

Though Christmas has become in its observance mainly a family festival, it would not be so valuable as it is if it did not inculcate anew the lesson of good-will to men with which, its observance began. It ought to open the hearts of all men who are even comparatively prosperous toward all men who are positively destitute.

From The Boston Transcript, Dec. 20. There is one boy at least on board the training ship Enterprise who has a right to feel proud to-day. His name is C.M. Greene, and he ranks as cadet first officer in the ship's company. The cause for his justifiable pride is this: To-day the Governor and Executive Council made their annual inspection of the ship, the boys, and their work, and incidentally presented the McClellan Conduct Medal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Tuesday, Dec. 26, with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

The subject of fast ocean steamships, with special reference to vessels of the latest type, such as the new Cunard steamers Campania and Lucania, was suggested to Dr. Francis Elgar some time previous to the past Summer meeting of the British Institution of Naval Architects as a desirable one for discussion before that body, and he was requested by the Secretary to read a paper concerning it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Minister Mendonca found several communications from the Brazilian Government awaiting him at the Legation when he returned to Washington to-day from New-York. They were not of special importance, however, so he informed a reporter for The United Press, but they were particularly satisfactory to him in that they denied by their own existence the reported capture of Rio by the insurgent forces and subsequent resignation of Peixoto.

The cause of university extension, both in this country and in England, owes much of its success to women. Not directly so, perhaps, for in the published records of the movement the names of but few women appear. The records, however, are chiefly concerned with the lecturer and his intellectual assets and liabilities.

That all the world is one country, as an Italian maxim assures us, Mr. Davis's volume shows us once again. If there is an exception to this general rule of similitudes discoverable on the Mediterranean coast you will find it in Morocco, which "is less civilized than any other part of the northern part of Africa."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- "I am in full sympathy," said Speaker Crisp this morning, "with the letter and spirit of these resolutions."

HAMPTON, Va., Dec. 23. -- The marriage of Miss Virginia Whiting and Senator Faulkner, which is to take place at 5 o'clock on Wednesday evening, Jan. 3, promises to be the most brilliant affair of the kind ever celebrated within old St. John's Church, whose walls have a history of nearly two and a half centuries.
Few sales at auction, and all of these in legal proceedings, are scheduled for the present week. All are to be held in the Trinity Building Salesroom, 111 Broadway. A detailed list is subjoined:

-- Original works in water colors will be received at the National Academy of Design for the twenty-seventh annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society from the 11th to the 13th of January, inclusive. A commission of 15 per cent. will be charged upon sales, which are placed in the hands of Mr. Alfred C. Howland.

At 66 Market Street, in a neighborhood in which saloons cluster thickly, the City Vigilance League proposes to rent a three-story frame house which will be opened as the first of the League's saloons. There it is intended to create a poor man's club to take the place of the liquor saloon, which is the only club that the tenement-house occupant now knows in the weary round of his life.

Grand festivities have celebrated at Blenheim Palace the young Duke of Marlborough's recent coming of age. A splendid ball, which included an organ recital on the magnificent instrument which stands in the centre of the library, began the event, and was followed the next morning for the pleasure of the large house party by a meet of the hounds and a large hunt breakfast.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- To-day's hearing in the trial of Coughlin for the murder of Dr. Cronin was chiefly notable for what one of the witnesses. Police Justice Mahoney, did not say. He suffered from a strange lapse of memory regarding a vital point which connects the late Patrick O'Sullivan with the murderer who presented the iceman's business card when he called to drive the doctor to the Carison cottage.
