The pending suit of the Government against the Bell Telephone Company for the annulment of the Berliner patent is the subject of discussion in several of the trade journals of the electrical industry. This is the suit that was begun by Attorney General MILLER in the last monts of President HARRISON'S term, and concerning which the present Attorney General recently said that it might come to trial in May next.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Christmas reigns upon every side. The weather even has yielded to the Christmas spirit, and there is promise of skating for the holidays. The streets of the village show how general is the celebration of the holiday this year. Ropes of green, with the ever-familiar wreath and star, again play their part in household decoration.

-- Proctor and Turner have found the stage circus a very popular feature of the continuous performance at Proctor's, and it is to be continued indefinitely. Josie Ashton, premiere equestrienne, will be added to the performers in the ring this week, and R.H. Dockrill, who was injured last Sunday, has recovered sufficiently to appear to-morrow.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- Although the Reichstag has adjourned, leaving the Ministry triumphant along the whole line, great uncertainty prevails in official quarters concerning the future. The confidence of the Ministerialists, hitherto unshaken, is now decreasing. No disastrous defeat is expected, but the Ministers feel that their position has been shaken by the growth of popular feeling against all the new tax proposals except the one affecting the Bourse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The President and Mrs. Cleveland will attend service on Christmas morning at Dr. Sunderland's church, on Four and a Half Street. They will in all probability be accompanied by their guest, Miss Benedict of New-York, unless that young lady accepts the invitation of the Postmaster General and Mrs. Bissell to occupy a seat in their pew at St. John's.

The experts appointed by Mayor Boody to investigate the bills rendered in connection with remodeling the Myrtle Avenue Police Court and the new furniture placed therein have made their report. The experts are William Schwartzweller, a NewYork furniture dealer; William Schultz, a Brooklyn furniture dealer; John Bullwinkle, and Mr. Rappleyea.
Mayor-elect Charles A. Schieren yesterday announced that he had offered the position of Registrar of Arrears to Frederick W. Hinrichs, and that Mr. Hinrichs had accepted.

In off election years, as they are called, when the State officers, except the Governor and the Lieutenant Governor, are candidates for office, the Secretary of State is regarded as the head of the ticket. Formerly the office was more important than it is to-day. When the New-Netherlands controlled affairs in this part of the country, the Secretary of the Province was Clerk of the Council and of the Courts.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- The suit of Henry Brabban against the New-Jersey Traction Company was concluded this morning in the Circuit Court, and a verdict in favor of the plaintiff for $10,000, the full amount claimed, was rendered. Brabban lost his left foot on May 2, 1893, at the corner of Main and Steuben Streets, Orange.

Imports at the week, exclusive of specie, were $8,459,565, of which amount $1,158,514 was to dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. Imports of specie were $207,828, and exports of specie were $1,158,704.
The sixth of the series of the Cooper Union free Saturday night lectures was delivered last evening by Frank R. Roberson on India.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The cadet hop, held in Grant Hall to-night, was largely attended. Only a few of the boys availed themselves of the three days' Christmas vacation to which they were entitled, consequently the hall was well filled. The dancing began at 8 o'clock and continued until after 10.

UPTON, Mass., Dec. 23. -- The straw shop of Benson Nelson at Upton Centre, with several small buildings, was burned last night. The loss on buildings is from $15,000 to $20,000, and on stock sufficient to bring the entire loss up to about $40,000. Insurance, $20,000. The principal salesroom of the firm is at 165 Greene Street, New-York, and about seventy-five hands were employed.
Veterans of the civil war are dying off one by one, but there are some of them left whose declining years deserve to be made smooth, and among these is Brevet Major Gen. George S. Greene.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Five young men, students of Seton Hall College, were ordained to the Roman Catholic priesthood at St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning. Twelve other young men from the Passionist Fathers' Monastery at West Hoboken received minor orders at the same time. Of the latter three were made sub-deacons and nine minority.

-- Col. Thomas Wentworth Higgimson celebrated his seventieth birthday on Fruday. Great numbers of his friends visited him at his attractive home in cambridge and congratulated him upon the completion of his threescore years and ten, and those who could not visit him sent their multitudinous good wishes.

It is impossible for me to see this day pass without having thanked you for the human, yea, most true Christian, manner you plead for my always and everywhere oppressed and hated people. Laughed to scorn by your own countrymen and colleagues in the house known as the "House of Commons" -- but which should be the "House of un-Commons" -- you hold on to your own cause.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- "This way, Sir, for a nice Christmas tree!" "Buy a wreath, Sir?" "Here's a holly and mistletoe." "G'long, you good-for-nothin niggah, the gemman's g'wine to buy o' me."

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- The spectacle given by the Comedie Francaise of the great Greek play of Sophocles, even in its minute proportions, was so complete that even a mild criticism would seem a harsh, false note in a symphony of perfect harmony. Even those who didn't understand anything about it became impressed by the general atmosphere, and they went away convinced that they must have seen something unusual and grand.

The first time I saw him he sat in his office at Boomtown juggling, using a railroad, a coal mine, and a coal bunker as balls. He caused those highly.. desirable things to rise and fall before the eyes of hesitating investors in a most enticing manner.
CHESTER, Penn., Dec. 23. -- The new steamer Jamestown, launched to-day at Roach's shipyard, will make an important addition to the fleet of the Dominion Steamship Company of New-York.

The past week has not been especially notable among real estate men. Holiday shopping has had something to do with this, but the general apathetic condition of the market has had more. There has been a little buying and selling, and somewhat more trading, but the sum total has not been very satisfactory.
Postmaster Sullivan of Brooklyn has again increased the number of daily collections from the street boxes. The boxes from which the mail is collected fourteen times each day are as follows:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 23. -- The Christmas fair for the Children's Home closed in the Club Hall on Wednesday evening, after a successful season. The new building of the home, which is to cost $20,000, and of which an engraving was published in The New-York Times a few weeks ago, is now about half completed, and the financial outlook for its completion is excellent.

The long, plucky, and skillful fight to keep the Atohison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company solvent has failed. The enormous decrease in the earnings of the road, the general business depression, and finally the breaking off of important negotiations by the death of Chairman George C. Magoun, combined to make the obetacles confronting the Atchison management insurmountable.

The athletes in both the boys' and men's departments of the Central (Twenty-third Street) Young Men's Christian Association are putting in a lot of good solid work, and the examinations and contests in gymnasium work have already commenced. From now on until late in the Spring every month will see something interesting take place in the gymnasium.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 15. -- The bicycle craze is assuming vast proportions in this little city, with the possibility, of course, of becoming presently what it often develops into elsewhere, a positive nuisance.

From The American Register, Paris. Very few people are aware that Louis XTV.'s great and vain "War Minister, Louvois, under whom the Hotel des Invalides was built, was anxious to immortalize himself by having his coat of arms carved side by side with those of the "Roi Soleil," but that the King, on learning it, had them effaced.

QUEENSTOWN, Dec. 23. -- The twin-screw first-class battle ship Resolution, which left Plymouth on Monday last for Gibraltar, to join the British Mediterranean squadron, put back to this port to-day. She encountered a severe storm in the Bay of Biscay, and made very heavy weather of it. Huge seas boarded her and swept the decks.

Grant Alien in Westminster Gazette. Sir: I want to break a lance with Mr. Frederick Boyle about the beauty of Englishwomen. A man of forty-five may fairly claim to stand midway between the young men and the old men whose views you epitomize.

A statement has been published in the local newspapers recently to the effect that there was unpleasant feeling between the Young Woman's Christian Association of Brooklyn and Mrs. Virginia Chandler Titcomb of the same city, on account of remarks made by the latter at a meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association.

ROME, Dec. 23. -- The latest news as to the fighting between Italian troops and dervishes near Agordat on Thursday is that, exclusive of officers, 102 were killed and 125 were wounded on the Italian side. All the killed and wounded were natives. In the artillery, which was manned partly by Italians, no one was killed or wounded.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 23. -- Capt. "Jack" Crotty, as manager of the Austin Regatta Club, is trying to secure another regatta for Austin this coming June that will outrival the grand international regatta of last year held on the Austin Lake. With that object in view, he has written to all the celebrities that participated in last year's regatta, requesting their presence as contestants.

Wall Street, in common with the rest of the country, does not feel this to be a particularly merry Christmas. We are drawing to the close of an unfortunate year. Many concerns went down in the stressful times of the Summer, and some which tided over then are going down now. A few weeks ago it seemed that the piles of idle money would interpose a barrier to the further fall of prices.

There have been more railroad bankruptcies within the year just about to close than in any previous year in the history of this country. Since the first of last January, seventy-one roads, representing $1,287,952,000 of bonds and capital stock, have been placed in the hands of receivers. These roads include a little less than 13 per cent. of the railway mileage of the United States, and about one-eighth of the aggregate railroad capitalization.

The moral of this story lies in the pity of it. It is a story of Christmas, of pride and its fall. It tells of a young man who, on one Yuletide, had fulsome reason for considering himself blessed, and it goes to show that things are not sometimes what they seem.

The departure of Rosina Vokes-Clay on what there is reason to fear will be her last homeward voyage to England deprives the Anglo-American stage of one of its very brightest ornaments, as well as most charming and amiable women. It also closes the career of a family which, only in the person of a single one of its five members, managed to emerge from the commonplace of the British theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Dr. Charles Getchell was the first witness examined in the Prendergast trial to-day. He interviewed Prendergast in jail two days ago and found the prisoner reticent and nervous and not inclined to talk with him. He found that the prisoner's conduct at the time he called on him was different from that he had observed it to be in the courtroom.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Outsiders only know half the truth about this city. Notwithstanding all the publicity which came to Chicago when it was chosen as the site of the World's Fair, very little of that which constitutes its real greatness became known to those who read the thousands of columns of description of its people, its buildings, and its business which have been printed in the newspapers of the world.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 23. -- Louis Foller, sixty years old, living in an old-farmhouse in Noble Street, back of Vernon Avenue, this city, sold an ugly horse late this afternoon to two men. The new owners put the anmal into a wagon, and in a few minutes the horse had kicked the vehicle to pieces.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 23. -- The annual banquet of the Journalists' Club of Baltimore will be held next Thursday nights. Many distinguished statesmen from other cities will be present, while the promised discussion of the tariff question by Messrs. Wilson and Reed has brought application for seats from hundreds of the prominent men of the city.

The efforts of organizations and individuals to relieve the distress of New-York's unemployed are bearing satisfactory results. Money to buy food for those who are absolutely penniless is coming in to the societies which the public knows will see that it is properly distributed, and attempts are being made to provide work for as many as possible to enable them to obtain the necessaries of life, without becoming objects of charity.

Charles Frohman has gone to Boston to superintend the final rehearsals of John Drew and his company in Henry Guy Carleton's new American comedy, "The Butterflies," which is to have its first production in the Hollis Street Theatre next Tuesday night. The piece will be played two weeks in Boston, after which Mr. Drew goes to Chicago for three weeks, and then comes to New-York for a long season.
The news of the defalcations of Receiving Teller Lewis A. Hill, amounting to $42,000, abstracted from the cash of the St. Nicholas Bank, caused much surprise among banking men yesterday.

Old seadogs say that of the Autumn and Winter months November is the best for crossing the Atlantic. All of the passengers leaving New-York on the afternoon of Nov. 4, 1893, will think by the light of their experience that that saying is but one of the old seadog's yarns. Going out of the harbor the afternoon of that eventful day the rain was falling.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- A hearing was had to-day before Judge Butler in the United States Circuit Court on the petition of Mr. Isaac L. Rice for the removal of the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company. Mr. Rice was represented by Mr. Nathan Bijur of New-York, while Messrs. Samuel Dickson and Thomas Hart, Jr., represented the receivers.
The weekly bank statement issued to-day showed an increase in reserve of $1,768,950. The banks now hold $77,937,775 in excess of the legal requirements.

The Diocesan School Board, of which Archbishop Corrigan is the head, has just received notice of the success which their exhibit attained in the World's Fair at Chicago. No less than forty medals have been awarded to the church schools of the diocese, and seventy diplomas for careful work have been won.

ALBANY, Dec. 23. -- The most picturesque figure in the City of Albany to-day is the Right Rev. William Crosswell Doane, first Bishop of this diocese. At 10 o'clock every morning, regardless of the weather, he can be seen leaving the Bishop's House, on Elk Street, with his three beautiful grand-children and a huge St. Bernard, held in the leash, for matutinal exercise.

When a big batch of indictments was handed to Judge Barrett yesterday by the foreman of the Extraordinary Grand Jury, in the Court of General Sessions, all sorts of rumors were current about politicians of high and low degrees being in jeopardy. The indictments were sent to Chief Clerk Carroll, and he and his clerks were soon busy drawing up warrants against those who were indicted.

Levi H. Marsteller, a well-known dry goods salesman, was found dead yesterday morning in an unoccupied flat on the fourth floor of the house at 653 Western Boulevard, of which he was the owner. He had committed suicide by shooting himself in the mouth with a revolver, probably on Thursday night, while in a fit of despondency caused by grief over the death of his wife, which occurred six months ago.

The employes of the various Brooklyn city departments look forward to the holiday festivities with feelings anything but akin to joy. The seasonable banquet of to-morrow threatens to be nothing better than a setting out of funeral baked meats; meats surprisingly unsatisfactory and unappetizing, which are to be devoured, more or less, to the melancholy accompaniment con brio and ad libitum of the "Dead March in Saul."

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- For a Saturday the bond market was rather wide, both on Change and over the counter. All of the list and a number of the coupons were dealt in extensively. Chicago Gas 5s were lower, on the decline in the stock. Alley Elevated 5s were a point better, but the first mortgage 5s sold off 3/4.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 23. -- In the will of Edward Martin, late of Red Hook, N.Y., which has recently been filed in Kendall County, Ill., appears the following paragraph:

The minor tone of the cry from the suffering poor has sounded through all the joyful notes of Christmas preparation this season. More than one shopper has been overheard commenting on her cut-down list, "and the surplus I am giving to my poor" is added.

This is a story for girls and boys that will probably not be neglected by their parents. It is a good story, full of simple humor and wholesome sentiment, with plenty of incident graphically told. The scene is laid on the Massachusetts coast, near a little village that aspired to be a great Summer resort and failed.

One of the most conspicuous figures in the National Guard of this State is the present Receiver of Taxes of the City of New-York, Col. David E. Austen. Col. Austen commands the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn. As an officer, commander, and tactician he has few equals and no superiors among officers of his rank, either in the regular service or National Guard, in any of the States of the Union.

Henry J. Cammann of the banking firm of Cammann Co. 11 Pine Street, has written the following letter in reference to the "New-York State Industrial Home for the Blind," an organization which is purported to have been incorporated in May with the object of providing a home for adult blind in need of care:

ORANGE, Dec. 23. -- Christmas week in the Oranges bids fair to be one of considerable social interest. There will be several private receptions, and, if the weather is cold enough, there may be some good to-bogganing and possibly a carnival at the slides of the Essex County Country Club, in Hutton Park.

Thirty-two patrolmen were appointed to the police force in Brooklyn yesterday by Commissioner Hayden. The men appeared, according to notice, before the Commissioner at 9 A.M. After a brief address, the Commissioner swore them in, and they were given their badges.

The controversy between District Attorney Nicoll and the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst has naturally attracted much attention and caused no little astonishment because of the surprising statements made by Dr. Parkhurst. The attitude of the reverend gentleman has not tended to leave in the public mind a very clear idea of just whom he is trying to get at in what is called his "crusade."

VICTORIA, B.C., Dec. 23. -- In the Vice Admiralty Court yesterday, Capt. Hughes Hallett sitting with Justice Crease, the case of the Queen vs. the seized sealer Ainoko came up. On July 22 the Ainoko was seized by the Russian transport Yakout within the prohibited zone, it is alleged that she was fully manned and equipped and had sixty-eight sealskins on board.

The writer of this work makes a rapid review of those schools in the United States which are devoted to the higher education of women. There is a fine fund of information obtainable in the neatly-written volume.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The old Ford's Theatre building, whose collapse caused the death of twenty-one clerks and serious injuries to many more, and which has since been patched up again by the Government, is now officially pronounced unsafe for occupancy as a Government office by the District Building Inspector and Col. George H. Elliott of the Board of Army Engineers and Capitol Architect Clark.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 23. -- A large force of men is now at work at the torpedo station upon Lay Boat No. 1, preparing it for the second of the tests committed to the charge of Commander George A. Converse, United States Navy, to learn the effect of explosions upon submarine boats and upon their crews.
Lawyer Maurice A. Gottlieb was held in $500 bail yesterday in the Tombs Police Court for examination Friday on a charge of assaulting Lawyer Francis T. Nekardi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Gen. John Gibbon, United States Army, retired, has some convictions about the effects upon workingmen of a tariff, and he has presented them in a plain way that can be understood by anybody who can read the words. His argument is as follows:

St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, Sixth Avenue and Stirling Place, Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday during the funeral services over the body of Philip Dwyer, Jr., son of the horseman, who recently died in Los Angeles, Cal. Friends of the deceased came from a distance to attend the funeral.

From The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. Gen. Lew Wallace consented to talk in Indianapolis on Tuesday about the charge that his novel, "The Prince of India." was a plagiarism from a work by Dr. Stephen Ludlow of New-York. Gen. Wallace denied the charge in toto. He declared that he had never seen Dr. Ludlow's book, and denounced the charge that he had stolen his ideas from Ludlow as a scheme to advertise the Ludlow book.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- It was said to-day at the Capitol that Mr. Blackburn, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Rules, would call a meeting of the committee immediately on the reassembling of Congress, to consider the numerous amendments to the rules which were offered last Fall.

The friends of Mr. William J. Youngs of Queens County are pushing his canvass for the Clerkship of the Assembly with great energy. The promise has been made by Boss Platt that he will keep his hands off and his eyes closed. In fact, the boss has kindly announced, to the friends of all the candidates for this particular office that he trill not interfere either for or against any one candidate.

BARCELONA, Dec. 23. -- Jose Codina, the Anarchist, who has already confessed than he threw the bomb that caused upward of thirty deaths in the Lyceum Theatre, has made a further confession, giving details of his crimes.

The second annual meeting of the American Jewish Historical Society will be held Dec. 27 and 28 in Room 11 of the Columbia College Library Building, on East Fortyninth Street, between Madison and Fourth Avenues. The first session will begin at 11 o'clock. There will be a meeting at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and another at 8.

If a speedway along the Harlem River bank should be built entirely fenced in, as the driving men want it, and with two sidewalks, as the public want it, these sidewalks to be connected at sufficiently frequent intervals by tunnels or arched passageways beneath the speedway, we should say that all classes and individuals interested or concerned in the matter ought to be content and happy.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Judge William Walter Phelps may become an author. His friends are urging him to do so. He has been telling some unusually good stories. Since the ex-German Minister has become a lay Judge in the Court of Error and Appeals he has had more leisure than when he was in active politics.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- During the past week a number of the oldest residents of this part of Monmouth County have died. Mrs. Elizabeth Warden, mother-in-law of Postmaster William T. Corlies, was the oldest of the number, being in her ninety-third year. She was a very active woman, having good eyesight and an excellent memory.

Last year I helped to kill the big she silver-tip bear that ranged the highland region adjacent to Thunder Creek, in Washington. This Summer the dead bear's mate, an enormous animal, was occasionally seen by prospectors who crossed the lofty Cascade Mountains by the Rainy Pass or the Middle Fork Pass, through which indistinct mountain goat trails lead.

The large hall of the Central Turn Verein was only half-filled last night when the final boxing and wrestling bouts of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union were decided. In contrast to the bouts of Thursday night there were several very clever exhibitions.

SPOKANE, Washington, Dec. 23. -- Opium smuggling across the Canadian border has reached such a stupendous scale that Government officials are at their wits' end to devise plans to capture the smugglers. Several small seizures have been made here, but the bulk of the contraband opium passes through this city undetected.

The deed of trust of the new stable on East Forty-eighth Street which was built with the fund of $20,000 which was subscribed for the family of the late Police Justice John E. Kelly was placed upon record yesterday. The Trustees are Police Justice Daniel F. McMahon, Rapid-Transit Commissioner Bushe, and Peter P. Brady, assistant counsel to the Excise Board.

About a score of mortgageors of Brooklyn property have been put in a state of mind by a notice which Mr. Joseph J. O'Donohue, the New-York City Chamberlain, has had sent to them by his counsel, Wensley Gilroy. The Chamberlain holds about a million and a half of dollars of court funds, which he is obliged to keep invested.

Joseph K. Hindrickson, a wealthy citizen of Huntington, L.I., has brought suit in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn against George Alleln, a wealthy Brooklyn real estate man, for $100,000 for alienating the affections of his wife, Caroline, Mr. Kindrickson first met Mrs. Allen when she Was attending school at Roslyn, L.I.

The Consolidation League of Brooklyn and the Consolidation Commission are at variance over the scope of the work. They have been unable to agree on the terms of the bill to be presented to the Legislature.

Strained relations exist between 100 prominent women of Brooklyn and a New-York evening newspaper. The newspaper has been advertising itself extensively through the medium of Christmas tree funds. It interested the Brooklyn women in a Christmas tree for poor children, which was to be exhibited in the Clermont Avenue Rink.

The churches of New-York are famous for their Christmas music. This year the music will be finer and more elaborate than ever before. In many instances these services will mark the first rendition in America of the latest and best efforts of well-known, composers, here and abroad. As is usual, the programmes will be most elaborate in the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal Churches.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 23. -- Mr. David H. King, Jr., of New-York, who has purchased the Dexter Bradford place, on Catherine Street, will immediately have plans and specifications prepared for the thorough remodeling of the old mansion, which he will have changed into one of the most attractive of Summer residences.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The proverb about full churchyards and green Christmases is no new thing, but it must be a long time since anything so discouragingly verdant in Midwinters was experienced in Northern Europe. There has been no Saturday as yet this season when London's swarms of golfers have been stopped by the weather from going out beyond the suburbs to play the game on open green turf.

The armored cruiser New-York, which was placed in dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Thursday, was yesterday floated out of the basin and moored to the coal dock of the yard, where she will take on a full supply of coal before sailing.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- Local stocks, tried to cut loose from the general market, and were quite-strong. People's Traction had sold at 26. Little stock has been for sale. It was bid up above 30 without tempting much stock and meeting no resistance. Electric Traction advanced to 48, with very small business done.

If one seeks upon Christmas Eve anepitome of the joys, the sorrows, the abundance, the need, the poverty, and the prosperity of New-York, all one has to do is to float upon the surges of humanity that flow about the Post Office, the City Hall, the big newspaper buildings, and the entrance to the great bridge.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Dec. 23. -- The report purporting to have been received in New-York by the Western Associated Press that Rio Janeiro had surrendered to the insurgent forces, and that President Peixoto was in the hands of his enemies, is without the slightest foundation in fact. A sensation more ridiculous could not have been attempted at this time.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Brazilian Royalists were unwontedly numerous in the usual 5 o'clock gathering at the Grand Hotel to-day. Prince Pierre's chances of a speedy accession were discussed and were considered to be improving daily. A representative of the United Press met Chevalier de Guinaraes, the chief political adviser of Count d'Eu, and asked him what he thought of the latest events in Brazil.
The masters' chess tournament was concluded yesterday when Pillsbury won the first, Hodges the second, Showalter the third, and Albin the fourth prize.

CHRISTMAS CHEER. I. It was late one September afternoon that David Conkling, the elder, came out from the office of The Ingle-Nook with a perturbed mind, though he had entered it but ten minutes before with even his spectacles beaming complacently. He was a little old man with an apologetic mien and watery eyes.

According to orders, our division marched through Savannah and was given a kindly farewell by the citizens, who were sorry to see us go, as they did not know how they would be treated by the new division. The residents came from different parts of the city and lined the sidewalks on the route of our march, and many flags were floating from windows of private residences, as well as business houses.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.L. Dec. 23. -- District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan was disappointed this morning. His contract to build a brick sewer in this city for $92,764 was not signed, sealed, and delivered as he confidently expected.

"Boss" John Y. McKane, the Sunday school Superintendent of Sheepshead Bay, was jovial yesterday afternoon. He was happy because he would spend Christmas at home with his family, and not within the gray stone walls of Raymond Street Jail.

Mr. Hiltzheimer's diary covers an eventful period, and was written in a town where great men were living and great deeds were performed. Mr. Hiltzhelmer had his share in public affairs, serving as he did in the French and Indian war, being a member of the Philadelphia militia during the Revolution, connected with the Quartermaster's Department on the field, sitting in the Pennsylvania Assembly, and holding other public places of minor consequence.

The Republic of Costa Rica is the southernmost of the Central American republics. It lies between the Republic of Colombia, South America, and the Republic of Nicaragua, Central America, to the north. Geographically, it is between the parallels of 9 and 10 north latitude. Its principal port is Port Limon, on the Atlantic Ocean.

Col. Rozel T. Pickert does not propose to let his son-in-law, Dr. Frank Abbott, do all the talking in print about their family affairs and the two letters the Colonel alleges the doctor abstracted from the Colonel's office. The Colonel had a statement of his own to give out at the Savoy Hotel Friday night.

Charlie, eight years old, has become interested in Sunday school, as many children are apt to be about Christmas time. He told his mother that the teacher said "the Lord spoke in paragraphs." When a certain verse was asked for he said: "It is in spasms," (Psalms.) -- Shoe and Leather Reporter.

The Republic of Costa Rica is the southernmost of the Central American republics. It lies between the Republic of Colombia, South America, and the Republic of Nicaragua, Central America, to the north. Geographically, it is between the parallels of 9 and 10 north latitude. Its principal port is Port Limon, on the Atlantic Ocean.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 23. -- The Republicans and conservative Democrats are haunted by the idea that the race-track people, led by W.J. Thompson, the "Duke of Gloucester," are scheming to prevent the repeal of the race-track gambling laws. The "Duke of Gloucester" was at the State House Tuesday, as were other racetrack legislators.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 23. -- A report was given out by the Lynn police to-day that at 6 o'clock Friday night, when a Lynn and Boston electric car reached the stables at Swampscott, an old gentleman was assisted from the car.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 24. -- Considerable excitement has been created here by the case of Mary Morrison, who, while suffering from smallpox, waited upon customers in the restaurant at 12 Union Park Street all through last week, and each night slept with two other women. It was only yesterday that she was taken to the pesthouse on Canterbury Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Many persons in this city whose recollections of political affairs go back to the early eighties have found much to interest them in the reports of The New-York Times concerning John C. Sheehan, District Leader-Police Commissioner in the City of New-York.
Mr. Frederick B. Dalzell of 69 Hart Street, Brooklyn, is brooding over the plot of a drama wherein Mr. Frank T. Moorhead is to figure as the vanishing ghost.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 24 -- Football talk recently among the cadets and the officers at the Naval Academy has been regarding the roughness and liability to serious injury from the game.
At the morning service at the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday Dr. Talmage, after commending the various associations for the relief of present destitution, included among his notices the following:

The triumph of the insurgents under MELLO and DA GAM A would be a national disaster for the Brazilians, not merely because the restoration of monarchical rule over a people that have had a republican form of government is a backward step, but also and chiefly because their success would firmly fasten the revolutionary habit upon the country.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Pres. RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24. -- The report of a bloody battle at Itajahy, State of Santa Catharina, in which 400 insurgents were said to have been killed, has no foundation in fact. It was discredited generally from the first, and is now authoritatively denied.

The very air of New-York throbs with the sentiments and the virtues which the chimes of Christmas have already rung in. The chief of these cardinal qualities and graces is easily charity. Its reign is universal; its boundaries, so far as this great metropolis is concerned, exceed all real, imaginary, and imaginable city limits.

Louis Raddie, forty-three years old, died yesterday at the Reception Hospital, at the foot of East Sixteenth Street, from malignant smallpox. Raddie was a married man. He lived in the boarding house 717 Lexingon Avenue.

From The Westminster Gazette. Mrs. Louisa Charlotte Tyndall, the widow, was called and accommodated with a seat facing the Coroner. She was attired in deep black, and was evidently deeply sorrow-stricken. Mrs. Tyndall stated that the deceased was seventy-three years old as far as they knew. He had been in delicate health for about three years, wrestling with death.

From The Helena (Mont.) Independent. There was an interesting case tried before Judge Knowles of the United States court, without a jury, and the decision was even more interesting. The case was that of W.A. Simon and Isaac Abernethey of Missoula against E.C. Gove of Spokane. It was in evidence that the plaintiffs ran a gambling house and saloon at Missoula, Simon dealing faro while Abernethey attended to the other business.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 24. -- In view of the pitiful stories relative to the destitution and suffering of miners and their families that have been telegraphed all over the country, interest will no doubt attach to an account of what a New-York Times correspondent learned in this city by talking with men engaged in mining and other men whose business it is to transport ore from the dumps of mines to the furnace stacks.

From The Washington Star. Congressman Holman of Indiana has an original way of giving out his interviews. From his long experience and close observation, Holman has a fund of information and a basis for forming an opinion on almost any subject liable to come up in Congress. He is usually free in the expression of his opinions and fond of lapsing into reminiscences.

Stanton Coit spoke before a large audience in the Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning on the army of unemployed at present crying for work in New-York, and the best methods of aiding them.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- The Petit Marseillais has published a notable leader under the caption, "The Origin of Great Britain's Anxiety." The writer says that England obtained minute information concerning the Toulon defenses and arsenal and France's naval system through the energy of an Englishman who commanded the Prince of Monaco's yacht when it was being repaired at Toulon.

The man who was robbed while under the influence of liquor or a drug in a cab in Broadway on Saturday evening, and who at the Tenderloin Police Station gave his name as James W. Smith, turned out to be John W. French, a piano manufacturer, doing business at 80 Fifth Avenue. The police have not yet succeeded in finding the thief.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 24 -- Peace reigned in the Episcopal Church of St. Paul to-day, and the two factions of the congregation did not make the expected demonstration.

Mr. Samuel Cabot writes to The Boston Transcript, saying: "It appears to me that it would be in the interests of your readers if you would, as publicly as possible, characterize the book which is now being advertised from Detroit which, pretends to be a cipher contained in the Shakespeare plays.

A number of the churches in this city and Brooklyn at their services yesterday had special programmes appropriate in observation of Christmas. The attendance at all the churches was unusually large. Most of the churches, however, principally of the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal denominations, will have Christmas services to-day.

-- The grave of Jonathan Jennings, who was Indiana's first Governor, has only recently been marked by a monument. It is in the town of Charleston, about fourteen miles from Louisville, and on the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. The Governor was born in Virginia in 1784, and soon after becoming of age went down the Ohio River from Pittsburg, Penn., on a flatboat, landing at what is now Jeffersonville.

The trail of the trolley, in spite of the opposition of property owners on One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, is visible in that thoroughfare. The Union Railway Company, otherwise known as the "Huckleberry Road," has long been anxious to go through One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street to connect with other lines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 24 -- The "deturs" have just been awarded. Every year, before Christmas, the college gives to meritorious students of one year's standing single copies of standard books, bound in crimson, with the college seal, as rewards for study. Usually these prizes number twenty-eight or thirty, but this year the list of winners has been increased to thirty-five.

At early evening of this Christmas holiday a well-dressed man of medium stature, dressed for a theatre party, will enter the dining room of the Fifth Avenue Hotel -- hungry, somewhat out of amiable mood because he must pass Christmas away from home, but resolved to dine well, even though it be alone.

(Reported by Messrs. Dick Brothers Lawrence, 30 Broad Street, New-York.) PITTSBURG, Dec. 23. -- Pittsburg approaches the holiday with few Changes in the money situation or in prices for home securities. General trade, as reflected in the Clearing House figures, is light, and no improvement is expected until after the close of the year. During the week interest centred in Natural Gas and the street railway shares.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Christmas Eve was made the occasion of the presentation, at the Chicago Opera House, by Russell's Comedians of a musical farcical comedy called "About Town," which is a new adaptation by Harry Fulton of a German play which has been seen in New-York at the Germania.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: I am the subject of an editorial in your paper of the 15th inst., as "A Complaining Petitioner."

The chess masters' tournament as concluded on Saturday night was a big success. There has not been an event in any country of late where the contestants were so well matched. There were only four prizes. With the exception of Delmar and Hanham, who seemed to be out of form, and Ettlinger, who succumbed to an attack of influenza, there is not much difference in the scores of all the competitors.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 24 -- The congregation of St. Mary's Catholic Church, whose handsome edifice was destroyed in the big fire in this city in July, held services to-day in the basement of the reconstructed church. Bishop McDonnell took part in the services. After the fire the congregation of the East Avenue Baptist Church, of which the Rev. L.F. Giffin is pastor, tendered the use of their edifice to the homeless congregation.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $1,768,950. The banks now hold $77,937,775 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans of $865,100, an increase in specie of $972,500, an increase in legal tenders of $1,620,600, an increase in deposits of $3,296,600, and a decrease in circulation of $199,900.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24 -- According to statistics compiled by John Q. Tilson, editor of The Yale Banner, the fifty-second annual edition of which was published at Yale yesterday, the claims of Yale as a national university have been strengthened during the past year. There are present in Yale students from twenty-seven States and six foreign countries, a record never before approached in an American university.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 24. -- Town Marshal Phillips and a posse of officers raided notorious gambling house at Pratt Mines it midnight last night. As the officers broke open the door, the lights in the room went out, and the gamblers opened fire, which was returned by the officers.

Yesterday's Times began with the London letter, of which, in turn, the beginning was a description of the curiously-unseasonable weather England is just now complaining about. There, as here, a "green Christmas" is giving a topic to people who must complain about something, even during the merry Yuletide itself.

A letter signed by Davis Sanford, 246 Fifth Avenue; Cassidy Dodd, 10 East Eighteenth Street; Haas Brothers, 53 West Twenty-Sixth Street; H. Jantzen, 284 Sixth Avenue; Albert B. Ashforth, 1,519 Broadway, and Samuel Cohen, 17 East Forty-second Street, has been sent to depositors of the collapsed Madison Square Bank.

Twelve additional arrests for election frauds were made by detectives yesterday. With one exception all of the twelve were indicted by the extraordinary Grand Jury for having made false statements of the canvass of ballots east at the recent election. The exception is a prisoner who is charged with perjury in swearing in his vote.

The hall of United Council, No. 1,035, American Legion of Honor, in the Jaeger Building, was packed to overflowing yesterday afternoon, when the council, which is the largest in the order and composed very largely of theatrical people, held its annual meeting for the election of officers. Seven new members were initiated, and then Commander James H.J. Sculiion, Treasurer of the Star Theatre, was renominated.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 24. -- Henry B. Shields of Coleman, Shields Co., iron manufacturers of Niles, Ohio, and manager of the Girard Furnace at Girard, Ohio, was arrested at the Hotel Grace at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, charged with kidnapping L.M. Byers of Pittsburg, Penn., a member of the wealthy iron manufacturing firm of A.M. Byers Co. of that city.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The rates of discount last week were 2 1/2 for three months and 3 for thirty days. The pressure usual just before the holidays and the close of the year was noticeable. Foreign demands for gold continue to be met toy the supplies in the open market.

From The Savannah (Ga.) News. The Rev. W.R. McConnell, a venerable Episcopal minister of South Georgia who recently visited Atlanta, tells a good story on himself in relating how he kept himself out of his own bed for a whole night. It was in this way: He went to a hotel in a small town to spend the night.

Eighteen muscular young men proficient in the art of bicycle riding started on a long journey in Madison Square Garden last night, and if their legs hold out until next Saturday night, the speedy ones expect to cover 1,600 miles. The contest is for the long-distance championship of the world and a purse of $3,200 offered by the Garden management.

NEW-YORK. Monday, Dec. 25 -- A.M. Last week's business in stocks showed an increase of about 600,000 shares over the total of the previous week. As this carried with it a substantial improvement in the income of brokers from commissions, the activity which attended the market had at least one grateful feature. Business improved in volume, at the expense of values.
HAVANA, Dec. 24. -- The American steamer. Seneca, Capt. Stevens, which sailed from this port yesterday for New-York, returned to-day, arriving at 11 o'clock this morning, with her forehold on fire.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 24. -- The party organized by Soworin, manager of The Novoe Vremya, to search for the ironclad Roosalka, which sank in the Baltic last Fall, reports that it has found traces of the vessel. The Government has ordered that the report be suppressed, believing it improbable that a private enterprise should have succeeded after the Ministry of Marine had made a failure of the same undertaking.

The teaching of "Peace on earth, good will toward men" hardly obtained among certain classes of the community Saturday night and yesterday. As usual at this season, there was anticipatory of Christmas, much of that liquid kind of celebration which leads to hot words, followed by blows.

From the St. Paul Globe, (Dem.) There can be no two opinions among men of fairness and patriotism as to this controversy. The President has demonstrated his patriotism and his common sense throughout. He could not have pursued another course and retained a consciousness of integrity.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 23. -- The local stock market for the week exhibits but few changes. Asking prices remain firm, and bids, in some instances, are slightly better. The illuminating stocks continue to be the favorites with investors, and show a slight improvement in price. Insurance stocks are neglected, as many expect the usual January dividends will be passed.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 24. -- The movement to have the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Road placed in the hands of a receiver originated in New-York City two weeks prior to the death of Director George C. Magoun, when it was first definitely learned that efforts to float $10,000,000 in mortgage bonds in the European market had failed.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 24. -- The Los Angeles and San Francisco express train on the Southern Pacific Railroad was stopped by two masked men at about midnight last night, near Burbank, a small station twelve miles from Los Angeles. After the train pulled out of Burbank, the robbers climbed forward over the tender to the engine, and forced the engineer to stop the train.

This volume, containing the Andover lectures on Congregationalism delivered in the Spring of 1892 and under the rather unique title adopted, furnishes "a review of the history, present condition, and outlook of the Independent (Congregational) Churches in England." Mr. Bradford is a Congregational minister in New-Jersey, and is fully alive to the importance of the denomination which he represents.

There was a baby show near the corner of Third Avenue and Fourteenth Street last night, confined by Tammany Hall on the east and Tony Pastor's Theatre on the west, and overflowing from one to the other, although the show proper was on the stage of the theatre.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Mrs. Mary Curran, forty-four years old, of 814 Newark Avenue, was fatally burned this evening. She was dressing a Christmas tree, when a lighted taper fell on her, setting fire to her dress. Her screams summoned the family to her aid, but before they could extinguish the flames she was burned beyond recovery.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- A second senior society has lately been formed here. It is known as the Quill and Dagger. While nominally secret, its principal purpose, it is said, is to bring together in friendly association members of the senior class who have won distinction in some line during their collegiate course.

The writer of this volume for the last six or eight years has been President of the University of Rochester, N.Y., and has contributed freely to reviews. Through lectures he has dealt with the fertile subjects of philosophy and science, their connections, accords, and discords. This volume is the latest which he has put forth, and, speaking generally, is worthy of more than ordinary praise.

Mr. Japp's topics are themselves of very pleasant character. Indeed, there are no books which give purer delight than, those which are devoted to the flelds, woods, and brooks. When. as sympathetic an observer as Mr. Japp takes these subjects in hand, there is increase of zest.

The impressive statement is authoritatively made that the Messrs, Harper have already sold over 100,000 copies of Gen. Lew Wallace's new novel. "The Prince of India." This record has been made within a period of about four months, and the book, moreover, is a rather expensive one, in its two-volume form.

From The Springfield (Mass.) Republican. When one enters upon the work of tracing family lines the end is seldom seen from the beginning. Henry M. Burt's discovery that President Cleveland is in the eighth generation of descent from Henry Burt, one of Springfield's first settlers, leads Israel Harmon to point out that Mrs. Cleveland is also of Springfield ancestry.

The Knights of Labor have lost three local assemblies. No. 2,853 of New-York, No. 2,904 of Brooklyn, and No. 6,224 of Newark, all clothing cutters and trimmers, and numbering altogether about 2,400 persons. They have all joined the American Federation of Labor.

William Sinclair Crewe, an artist living at 45 West Forty-second Street, was arraigned in Yorkville Police Court yesterday charged with obtaining money under false pretenses. The complainant is Lloyd Stevens of Garden City, L.I.

Sunday School Superintendent John Y. McKane did not act in his official capacity at the Sheepshead Bay Methodist Episcopal Sunday school yesterday afternoon. Alanson Treadwell, his assistant, read the lesson, offered prayer, and sang the Sunday school hymns with much feeling.

Athletics in the Washington Heights Young Men's Christian Association have taken a long step forward since last year, which was the first year of the association's existence. The enthusiasm is not confined to the young men alone, but is equally as prevalent among the members of the boys' classes.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 24 -- Louis Foller was not murdered, as was supposed last night. His death was due to a fall from his wagon. An autopsy made to-day by Health Officer Burnett and Dr. Strong, Coroner-elect, showed that the man's death was caused by a broken neck.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 24. -- The public accounts of the Dominion for the fiscal year ending June 30, together with the usual comparative statistical tables, have been printed and will be distributed to the press to-morrow. Receipts from the consolidated fund exceed expenditures by $1354,555.
George Clancy, a brother of Congressman John M. Clancy of Brooklyn, was murdered yesterday morning in Daniel Kelly's saloon, 50 Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, by Timothy McDermott of 57 Hudson Avenue.

President CLEVELAND'S message has had an effect upon the country which there is no mistaking. The people who were of the opinion that American "booms" in any direction ought to be encouraged have had the native hue of their patriotic resolution sicklied over with the pale cast of thought.
Martin B. Brown, the city printer, died Saturday night at his home, 931 Madison Avenue, of pneumonia. His death was sudden, and surprised his friends.

-- Christmas Matinees. -- The players will have to work for their Christmas dinner to-day, but they will add to the holiday pleasure of thousands by the Christmas matinees which will enlist their services. All classes of theatregoers will find something to suit their tastes in the lone list of entertainments offered for this afternoon. At Niblo's the Lilliputians will present "A Trip to Mars"; at the Star "Africa" will be produced; at the Academy.
COFFEEVILLE, Kan, Dec. 24. -- Eight men stopped a train on the Missouri Pacific Railroad five miles from here at 8 o'clock to-night and secured a large amount of booty.

The Grolier Club has made the acquisition of a charming work of art, which is also a precious historical relic. It is a bronze study made by David d'Angers for his noble statue of Gutenberg, which was erected in one of the public squares of Strasburg.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 24. -- The following toast was prepared for Christmas by the Grand Encampment Knights, Templars:

Henry Kohn, twenty-nine years old, of 215 East Nineteenth Street was arraigned in the Yorkville Court yesterday on complaint of the Rev. John N. Lewis, 207 East Seventeenth Street, assistant rector of St. George's Church. The technical charge was disorderly conduct, although the complainant was desirous of pressing a charge of perjury, so that the prisoner might be assured a long term of imprisonment, he explained.

Christmas was celebrated in the good old-fashioned way by the members of the Bowery branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. A big yule log blazed in the open fireplace from early morning until late at night, and the interior of the entire building was decorated with Christmas greens and holly.

At least 1,000 boys and about 100 little girls had a merry time last night at the Newsboys' Lodging House, on Duane Street. They were the guests of Mr. William M. Fliess, who for twenty-eight consecutive years has made happy on Christmas the hearts of newsboys in the vicinity of Park Row.

-- Imperial Music Hall. -- Travesty is well established at the Imperial Music Hall, and nobody can doubt, after the successful opening of the week, that Mr. Kraus's new kind of entertainment is more popular than ordinary "variety." Lots of new things were put in "Hamminstein in Distress" yesterday, which greatly improved a performance which was already good of its kind.

While public attention has been very strongly attracted to the efforts being made in Kings County to expose and punish the frauds committed on the suffrage at the last election, there has been a great deal of excellent work done in this city as well. In Brooklyn the Governor was very properly asked to appoint able and reputable men with special authority to conduct the legal proceedings in this class of cases.
Lizzie Brinker, dam of Bud Crooke, 2:15 1/2 has dropped eight foals by eight different sires. Four of them are in the list, while two others have produced five with records of 2:27 or better.

The second performance of "Carmen" made Christmas night at the opera a merry one for the management. It is evidently not unfashionable to go to such entertainments on Christmas, for the auditorium of the Metropolitan Opera House was filled to its capacity with one of the most brilliant audiences of the season.

The manufacturers of pottery in Trenton profess to foresee that their industry would be ruined by the enactment of the Wilson bill, and the high-tariff press publishes their predictions of calamity with the usual inflammatory comments. It happens that at this time there is pending a suit at law which throws much light upon the sincerity of this outcry and also upon the recent history of an important branch of the industry.

The members of the First Battery of the National Guard of the State of New-York, commanded by Capt. Louis Wendel, have, for a long time, been anxiously awaiting the new breech-loading cannon. Their hopes are about to be realized now, as to-morrow is named as the day upon which they will receive the new steel service field guns from the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Joseph Donjan, the man who has been sending threatening letters to Vice President Stevenson, Secretary Lamont, Senator Mills, and other prominent public men in this city for several days past, was arrested by Detective McDevitt to-night. When seen by Capt. McDevitt, Donjan was talking to a disreputable-looking stranger.

William Williams, twelve years old, of 116 Varick Street, became a burglar Christmas Eve and stole $30 from Lee Long's laundry. Using an old chisel as a "jimmy," he forced the door of the laundry open at 11:30 o'clock Sunday night while Lee was spending the evening with friends in Matt Street. William Brue saw the boy at work and reported the matter to the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- A sharp contest is now in progress for a Kansas position, which carries with it a handsome income. Richard L. Walker, United States Marshal for the District of Kansas, has decided to go into the railroad business, and his resignation has just been forwarded to the President.

Not quite a fair share of the holiday crowd went to the Star Theatre last evening, and yet before the first act of "Africa" was ended the lower part of the house had occupants enough to make it a far from discouraging spectacle, while aloft in the galleries there wasn't left room for even one more boy, even a small one.

One might have searched from end to end of Manhattan Island yesterday and not found a happier Christmas party than that which was composed of the old men and aged women who are inmates of the hospitable Home of the Little Sisters of the Poor, on East Seventieth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, of which Sister Joseph Adele is the acting Superior.

There were plenty of chants in the theatrical bills yesterday, but nothing new of much value was put forward. The new comic entertainments at the Bijou and the Star were found to be good of their kind. The attendance at the theatres in the afternoon was generally very light. In one prominent house where a good play is current there were, by actual count, less than 100 persons present.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 25. -- Receiver Joseph T. Wilson of the Santa Fe system passed through here this morning on his way to Topeka. He will go to New-York Wednesday to met the other receivers. He believes that there will be few changes. St. Louis banks were arranged with for $200,000 to pay Frisco employes, whose wages were in arrears, and they will be paid at once.

The Rona, a large steam yacht, designed by Mr. G.L. Watson for Mr. A.H.E. Wood, was launched on the 12th inst. from the Henderson Yards at Partick. The London Field gives the following description of this craft:

LISBON, Dec. 25. -- It is reported that President Peixoto has withdrawn the pay and dispensed with the services of the officers of the war ships Riachuelo and Benjamin Constant, now stationed at Toulon. The story runs that he suspected them of sympathy with Admiral Mello.

From The Boston Traveller. Mayor Carter of Chelsea told an excellent story at a dinner one evening last week. It seems that there was a fair in Chelsea recently, and one of the attractions was that several persons were to dresa up in such costumes as ingenuity might suggest to represent the title of some book.

Charles Jones, an employe of the eleVated railroad, yesterday afternoon fell from the truck at Second Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street and was instantly killed. He was forty-five years old, and lived at 206 East Ninetieth Street.

The hearts of 4,000 poor children in Brooklyn to whom "Merry Christmas!" is usually a hollow mockery were gladdened yesterday. A number of society women distributed presents to them in the "Universal" Building, on Washington Street.

The Children's Ward in the New-York Hospital, West Fifteenth Street, presented an attractive appearance last evening when the large Christmas tree provided for the entertainment of the little sufferers was lighted up and set revolving by Superintendent George P. Ludlam. The tree was freighted with toys and bonbons, which were distributed among the children by Miss Jenkins, the head nurse.

-- Two prisoners were arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for disturbing mission meetings on Christmas Eve. Benjamin Flood, twenty-six years old, of 454 West Seventeenth Street, smashed hats and used profane and abusive language in the Eighth Avenue Mission. He had created disturbances several times before.

All past records in six-day bicycle races were broken by the riders yesterday. The contestants on their safeties made circuit after circuit of the track with the regularity of clock work, and reeled off miles in a most startling manner, For the first twelve hours the leaders averaged over seventeen miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The football season was closed to-day in a game between the eleven of the Columbia Athletic Club, the champions of the District, and a team styling itself the "All Washmgrtons," composed of native Washington boys who have acquired some reputation on college clubs, notably Princeton, Harvard, University of Pennsylvania, Lehigh, and the Naval Academy.

That the placing of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad in the hands of receivers is a regrettable circumstance is manifest, but the natural feeling of regret will be tempered by the general sense of satisfaction that the legal proceedings will entail no change in the company's policy. Since its elaborate financial reorganization in 1889 the Atchison system has been managed in a way well calculated to win public confidence.

A circular has been issued try the committee representing the first mortgage bonds of the Chicago and Northern Pacific Ballroad, of which J. Edward Simmons is Chairman. It is addressed to the holders of the bonds in question, and suggests the first steps that should be taken toward the protection of their interests.

Mr. James A. Herne is now established for the Winter at Daly's Theatre with his remarkably-interesting dramatic drama called "Shore Acres." The play wears well and is likely to have long life, and the return to his former place in its performance of Mr. George W. Wilson greatly increases its interest.

From The Philadelphia Times. Richard Vaux, statesman, diplomat, litterateur, lawyer, and first and pre-eminently a gentleman of ye courtly olden school, on Tuesday, Dec. 19, added the seventy-seventh to the bouquet of birthdays, not one of which but has brought with the added year additional friends, honor, and love to the genial and gallant gentleman who has plucked them.

The Brooklyn trolley claimed a Christmas victim yesterday. An unknown boy, thirteen years old, was run over and instantly killed at 11:30 o'clock at the corner of South Fifth Street and Kent Avenue, by Trolley Car No. 2,124 of the Greenpoint line, going toward Greenpoint.

The memebers of the Sports Club, desirous of marking their appreciation of the enterprise and pluck displayed by Lord Dunraven in his endeavor to brine the American Cup back to this country, entertained him at a banquet at their clubhouse, in St. James's Square, Dec. 11, says The London Field. The distinguished guests present included his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, his Royal Highness the Duke of Cambridge, Lord Colville of Culross, Lord Suffield.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 25. -- Gov. Fishbrick of Arkansas has addressed the following open letter to President Cleveland: To the President:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25. -- The story from Mason City, Iowa, of the identification of the remains of an old man, who was buried in an unknown grave at Hampton about ten days ago as those of Dr. Thomas E. Tynan, the missing millionaire of Modesto, is not credited by those who have been interested in the case in this city.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 25. -- In view of the letter from P.W. Lang, Gov. Mitchell's private secretary, to J.R. Tysen of this city, emphatically stating that the Governor would use all means in his power to prevent the Corbett-Mitchell contest, a reporter to-day interviewed J.E.T. Bowden, General Manager of the Duval Athletic Club, regarding the Governor's position and the prospect for pulling off the contest.

BUFFALO, Dec. 25. -- This has been, a sorry Christmas for the friends in Buffalo of John C. Sheehan, Police Commissioner of New-York, Tammany leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District, President of the Pequod Club, and senior member of the extensive contracting firm of John C. Sheehan Co.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 25. -- There will be no racing at Monmouth Park in 1894, notwithstanding the loud boasting which those connected with the race track, from officials to stable boys, have been indulging in for months. The sense of decency and propriety of the Township Committee has led its members to revoke the license of the Monmouth Park Association, and there is no hope that another will be granted.

In his introduction to the year book of Grace Parish for 1893, which has just been issued, the Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington, the rector, thus comments on the fact that the prevailing financial disturbance has had no effect on the church's customary subscriptions:

Edward Schell. Edward Schell, the President of the Manhattan Savings Institution, and brother of Robert Schell, the President of the Hank of the Metropolis, died at his home, 53 Clinton Place, Sunday afternoon. Mr. Schell was born Nov. 4 seventy-four years ago in the village of Rhinebeck.
NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Dec. 25. -- Burglars made a raid upon the Post Office here last night, but they were frightened off. They obtained but little booty.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 25. -- The western half of the trestle over the Westfield River at Chester, which was built after the accident in August, in which so many lives were lost, was carried away by ice at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, and all travel is blocked on the Boston and Albany Railroad and will be for several days.
Charles Lanier, Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following additional contributions to the general fund of the collection:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Secretary Carlisle received this telegram this morning from Edwin A. Wood, Special Treasury Agent in Oregon, dated Union Station, Dec. 24:

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 25. -- The Mesaba Iron Range lies about fifty miles northeast from this city. Its area is about 120 by 30 miles. Here it contracts, there it swells widely, and at intervals along its waving edges fingers, some short and broad, others long and slender, are thrust out. Some of these fingers extend across the boundary and indent Canadian soil.

"Laughing Heirs" filled the Irving Place Theatre to overflowing last night. It is a bouffe operetta in three acts, by Carl Weinberger, a young composer of dance music and marches, who seems to have fed his soul on Strauss waltzes and become incapacitated to produce any other kind of musical numbers.

Nearly 500 men were given a Christmas dinner at the restaurant of the New-York Bible and Fruit Mission, 416 East Twenty-sixth Street. The first to be served were the hundred inmates of the mission lodging house, together with 200 other men, to whom dinner tickets had been given by the missionaries.

Timothy McDermott, who murdered George Clancy, the brother of Congressman Clancy, in Daniel Kelly's saloon, 50 Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, Sunday morning, was arraigned before Justice Walsh, in the Adams Street Police Court, yesterday morning.

SULLIVAN, Ind., Dec. 25. -- There is great excitement at Sullivan to-night, caused by a report of an attempt to lynch ex-Sheriff Willis, who, masked as a tramp, yesterday shot and killed ex-Prosecuting Attorney Hultz on the streets, as he emerged from his office.
Driving accidents kept the police active in the vicinity of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.
NEWCASTLE, Penn., Dec. 25. -- Sampson Getholtz, a Slippery Rock Township farmer, thought to surprise his family last night by sliding down the old-fashioned chimney and impersonating Santa Claus.

The Protestan Episcopal churches of this city held elaborate and impressive services in reverence of the religious significance of Christmas. Thousands of worshippers attended the different services, and enjoyed the grand and solemn music which in every church was made the feature. Some of the churches were decorated, while others dispensed with the old custom, in order that the money might be used in relieving distress and want among the poor.

From The Boston Saturday Evening Gazette. A young physician is engaged to a young lady and is permitted to visit her three times a week. The mother of the young lady arranged to have her little nephew with her on these visiting days to keep guard over the decorum of the young couple while she attended to her household duties.

From The Chicago Record. The days of giving the widow's mite to educational purposes have passed. Old Harvard, that once received a silver-tipped jug with thankfulness, and at another time praised the donor of a peck of corn, would smile broadly to-day at such benefactions with her annual income of over $1,000,000.

An abundance of good cheer was provided for the 16,000 persons under the care of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction in the city institutions. Over 18,000 rounds of chicken and 4,600 pounds of turkey were distributed among the institutions on Blackwell's and Randall's Islands. Ample provision was also made for the prisoners in the Tombs and the jails at Jefferson Market, Essex Market, and Yorkville.

Christmas was like an April day. There is an old proverb which says that a green Christmas makes a fat graveyard. Few of the thousands of unemployed and destitute poor thought of this ancient saw as they looked out on the Spring sky and felt the warmth of an almost tropical sun creep through their bare apartments.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- Charley Mitchell and his trainer, Harry Darrin, spent Christmas in Philadelphia, they having arrived from New-York yesterday afternoon. This morning the pair took a run in Fairmount Park, and during the rest of the day they remained at the residence of "Doc" Robbins. To-morrow morning, at 7:20 o'clock, Mitchell and Darrin will start for Jacksonville.

HAZLETON, Penn., Dec. 25. -- While a wedding celebration was in progress at Derringer to-night, a party of Austrians attempted to blow up the house with dynamite. The occupants were notified in time to escape.
The Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church has issued the following address of warning:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 25. -- John Gruber, who keeps a saloon at 1,196 Summit Avenue, was awakened at 6 o'clock this morning by a rap on the door. On answering the summons, he was confronted by a man, who assaulted him with a blackjack. Gruber defended himself vigorously, and was able to keep his assailant at arm's length until the noise brought Mrs. Gruber to the door, when the man fled.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 25. -- W.D. Richards of Chicago, representing the Russian Government Transcontinental Railway, arrived here last night, and will designate ports along the coast from San Diego to Vancouver, B.C., for a fleet of nineteen steamers which the Amoor Steamship Company will put on in connection with the new Siberian railroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The White House was closed to visitors to-day, but the front doors were opened at frequent intervals to permit the entry of packages of presents for the President, Mrs. Cleveland, and the two babies. Most of these were brought by expressmen, but a number of them were brought by their donors in person in their own carriages.

An appetizing odor of coffee pervaded the entire establishment at 213 West Twentyfourth Street all Christmay Day. It gave warning of a bountiful Christmas dinner, and the only one in New-York, Sister Charlotte said, to which women of all grades and conditions were heartily welcomed, without money or so much as a ticket for a passport.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 25. -- The Southern Athletic Football Team defeated the Pensacola team by a score of 32 to 0.

An unknown man who was riding on a crosstown car quarreled with the conductor at 11:30 o'clock last night opposite the Union Square Theatre. The conductor ejected him from the car, and Policeman William A. Wood of the Mercer Street Police Station told the man to walk on, as he was collecting a crowd.

The pretty house in which the big Chief of the Gravesend Police lives, in Sheepshead Bay, presented a lively appearance yesterday. The red-faced and portly Sunday school Superintendent was radiant with smiles, as he wished his many friends a merry Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The British Government has printed in a recent Blue Book a report by Sir Julian Pauncefote, its Ambassador to this Government, about the general situation and outlook in the United States. It is not new, but old topics acquire a freshness by reason of terse and candid statement.

From the Boston Transcript. As the new Public Library Building in Copley Square nears completion, the question of how the 700,000 volumes composing the library shall be moved from the old structure to the new one becomes a most perplexing one. When the removal is made the library will have to be closed, perhaps for two months.

Dr. Paul Gibier, Director of the Pasteur Institute in this city and President of the New-York Bacteriological Society, read a paper last night before the Medical Society of the County of New-York on "A New Agent in the Cure of Epilepsy." It was in continuation of his report to the society a year ago.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations were approved yesterday by Superintendent Brady of the Building Department:

NEW-YORK. Tuesday, Dec. 26 -- P.M. The course of Atchison stock and bonds in to-day's market shows that the effect of the expected receivership, which came on Saturday night, had not been fully discounted. The stock sold down to 13, the general 4s to 64, and the seconds to 30 1/2.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- The Riverside Gun Club held its regular Christmas shoot yesterday afternoon, the targets being blue rocks. The fine weather brought out a large crowd. The opening event was a sweepstakes at five singles, unknown angles. Edmund W. Throckmorton, won, with 5, William T. Conover and Edward M. Cooper being seoond, with 3 each.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- When the Senate reassembles next week it will find executive business to attend to that has been neglected for some time without any reasonable or decent excuse. The executive calendar is full of cases that should be acted upon, and there are nominations in committee that the Senators should have reported long ago, and that the Senate can have no good reason for refusing to confirm.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- A peculiar discrepancy exists in the statements of last week's tonnage, east bound, issued respectively by the Central Traffic Association and the Board of Trade. The former makes the through shipments of flour, grain, and provisions exceed to a considerable extent total shipments of all kinds of dead freight as reported by the Board of Trade.

Supreme Court Justice Cullen of Brooklyn yesterday granted a stay to John Y. McKane in the execution of the sentence of one month's imprisonment imposed upon him by Justice Barnard for violation of the latter's injunction order.

Upon application of the Union Trust Company, Judge Addison Brown of the United States District Court yesterday appointed Joseph W. Reinhart, John. J. McCook, and Joseph C. Wilson ancillary receivers for the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad in the Southern District of New-York. These gentlemen were appointed receivers for the general system by the Federal court in Arkansas last Saturday.

BOSTON, Dec. 26. -- At the Hollis Street Theatre to-night John Drew and his company appeared in a new three-act comic play called "The Butterflies," written by H.G. Carleton. Mr. Drew has in this a rather more serious role than he had in "The Masked Ball," but one not devoid of humor.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 26. -- A document was delivered into the hands of United States Marshal Danahower this evening which may have the effect of deterring the engineers, firemen, conductors, trainmen, and telegraph operators of the Northern Pacific Railway from striking. It was issued by Judge Caldwell of the United States Circuit Court, and is in effect an injunction to keep the men from striking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The total number of pieces of letter mail sent in the domestic mails of the United States the last fiscal year was 2,407,810,175, of which 2,521,314,563 were sent at letter rates and 86,495,612 free, on official business. There were also 535,917,899 postal cards handled. The number of newspapers and periodicals mailed by publishers in the several counties of publication free, was 382,861,271.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Alfred Hedberg, whose husband, Capt. Hedberg, was shot and killed at Fort Sheridan two months ago, is in the East, trying to enlist the War Department in her aid to secure the punishment of Lieut. Maney, who did the shooting. She alleges that Col. Crofton, commandant of the post, and District Attorney Milchrist, are lukewarm in their prosecution of the case.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26. -- The bill the Republicans will Introduce at the next session of the Legislature as a substitute for the Werts election law has been framed by Major Carl Lentz, of Newark. It is patterned after the election laws of Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Massachusetts and the Werts law.
Under the suggestive title, "The Political Barometer," America publishes the following:

The People's Restaurant, opened by the Industrial Christian Alliance at 170 Bleecker Street, is giving evidence each day of its value as a practical charity. Large numbers of meal tickets have been taken by different charitable institutions and by citizens, who prefer to give them out instead of money to those who appeal for aid on the ground of hunger.

William J. Holland, a son of the late Alderman Philip Holland, attempted to commit suicide yesterday morning by shooting himself in the head with a revolver while in the hallway of the house at 345 Hudson Street, where his wife lives. He did not succeed in inflicting a serious wound.
