Secretary Beam of the Board of Bridge Trustees yesterday furnished to a Brooklyn afternoon newspaper the prices paid for the properties condemned for the Brooklyn approaches to the bridge. A few days ago, when a reporter for The New-York Times applied to Secretary Beam for these figures, the Secretary declared that the information could not be given out for several weeks.
Wheat had a moderate local trade and values show but little change from Friday, as the foreign markets continue closed until Wednesday.

Prof. LINDLEY M. KEASBEY of the University of Colorado has done a public service by contributing to the current number of the Forum an article entitled "The New Sectionalism -- A Western Warning." The value of this contribution lies mainly in the exposition it makes of the point of view, upon the silver question, of citizens of the "silver States."

Charles F. Crisp, Speaker of the House of Representatives, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, with his wife and two children. He registered at the Hoffman House. Mr. Crisp looked, as he said he felt, in superb health and spirits.

The motormen and conductors employed by the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, who receive $2 a day, have asked for an increase of 25 cents a day in their washes. The company has not replied to the request, but it is expected that it will do so to-day.

Yesterday was an exciting day at Tello d'Apery's Barefoot Mission, 59 West Twenty-fourth Street. It was the first Christmas festival in the mission's new home, and at least 5,000 men, women, and children, in all stages of misery and destitution, went away with a realizing sense of the meaning of the season in their hearts and an abundant supply of warm clothes, toys, games, and refreshments to make the feeling lasting.

Mr. Edwin S. Belknap, a short, slender, agile, prematurely bald young man, with a pleasing countenance, presented to a large invited company in the Lyceum Theatre yesterday afternoon a pantomime called "The Rendezvous," in which he was the only actor. Without costumes or properties on the illusion of painted scenery he represented, by turns, an ingenious and somewhat malicious damsel and an amatory youth.

Dr. Talmage's generosity furnished substantial dinners for several thousand poor persons yesterday. Long before the time announced for the distribution of beef and bread to begin, crowds besieged the Chicago Beef Company's warehouse, 635 Fulton Street, and Morton's bakery, 581 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 26. -- Sheldon Binney and Wilbour, Jackson Co., the bankers, who were forced to suspend payments on Aug. 12, because of the failure of the Denver City Railroad Company to meet its obligations, both houses holding large blocks of stock in that corporation, will resume business to-morrow morning.

As there was no grain market in London yesterday, the brokers at the Produce Exchange had little to occupy them until Louis Mills appeared on the floor in new attire. Christmas had evidently gone well with him. His hat, of the very latest style, shone like a mirror. The crease in his English trousers could be seen across the big Exchange floor.

WILDWOOD, Fla., Dec. 26. -- The negro, Abe Lambright, who shot Ira Smith, last night, together with five other negroes, who were in the fight, was arrested this morning, and lodged in jail by Sheriff Chapman in charge of the Leesburg Rifles. There was considerable firing from the Rifles before the arrests were made, at least, seventy-five shots being exchanged.

Victor Schoelcher. Victor Schoelcher, writer, politician, and one of the most picturesque figures among the ideally theoretic republicans of France whom the Empire exiled, died in Paris yesterday. He was ninety years of age and impressively a type of the revolutionary in art, in literature, in politics, whom the French designate as "Men of 1830."

Twelve out of the fifty-seven men arrested for misdemeanors during the November elections spent Christmas in jail. Eight additional arrests were made yesterday, making in all sixty-five persons against whom indictments have been found and upon whom warrants have been served. The arrests not already reported were:

The District Attorney said yesterday that the Extraordinary Grand Jury would be reconvened this morning to consider the charges made by Dr. Parkhurst against two police officials, one of whom is known to be Capt. Schmittberger; the other, it was said yesterday, is Inspector Williams. Frank Moss, counsel for the Society for the Suppression of Crime, said he would be on hand with witnesses to present the cases.

HAVANA, Dec. 26. -- The cargo aboard the New-York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company's steamer Seneca, which was scuttled, in this port Sunday night, after putting back on fire, will prove an almost total loss. The action of the salt waler will cause the hemp on board of her to turn black, and the cigars, tobacco, and coffee are of course irretrievably ruined.

Mamert de Bebeyran, a former Parisian dancer, who for years has been a ballet master in this city, died Monday morning at the Post-Graduate Hospital. Three weeks ago he suffered with grip, and then his right leg became afflicted. The limb was amputated on Saturday, and blood poisoning set in.

The Fish Commissioners of the State of New-York, through their President. L.D. Huntington. have just achieved a satisfactory settlement of the dispute regarding the land on which their hatchery is situated in Franklin County, in the Adirondack Mountains. As a result, from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 brook and lake trout will annually be the yield for lovers of fish food.

William V. McCracken made an assignment yesterday to Theodore L. Frothingham, as liquidating partner of the firm of William V. McCracken Co. of 40 Wall Street. The firm dissolved on Aug. 21, 1891, and has since been in liquidation. The other partners were Nell Macdonald and George A. Evans. They did not sign the deed of assignment.

Brooklynites slept easier last night than they had done for a year previous. The wicked Board of Aldermen passed out of existence at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, leaving the City Hall still in possession of the city.

Thomas C. Platt's well-known habit of getting revenge upon politicians who do not obey his orders is again, being placed on exhibition. When he got up to the Syracuse Convention he found that the majority of the district leaders of the Republican "machine" in this city would not do as he told them about the nomination for Judge of the Court of Appeals.
The strong ebb tide in the East River caused the steamboat Nutmeg State of the Bridgeport line to sink a canalboat at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The foreign exchange market was heavy. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.85 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.88 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84@$4.84 1/2 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/3 for demand, $4.87 for cable transfers, and $4.83@$4.83 1/4 for commercial.

Henry W. Paine, the eminent lawyer, died at his residence in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday morning. Mr. Paine was born in Winslow, Me., Aug. 30, 1810. He graduated at Waterville College (now Colby University) in 1830, was a tutor in the college for a year, and later entered the Law School at Harvard and was admitted to the bar in 1834.

When Shock, the plucky German, entered the six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden he said that he would ride for forty-eight hours before he took his first sleep. He fulfilled his promise, and by sticking to his work he holds the lead in the big race and has shattered all past records. Since the start, on Sunday night, he has only lost 54 1/2 minutes in changing machines and costumes.

The attorneys of Frederick Vietor Achelis, William Iselin Co., Rufus S. Frost Co., Joseph Beun Sons, Henry Newman Co., the National Citizens' Bank, and other creditors of N.J. Schloss Co., manufacturers of clothing at 653 Broadway, have given notice of a motion for the removal of Simson Wolf as assignee of the failed firm, to be heard in the Court of Common Pleas on Jan. 2.

The United States cruiser New-York, her bunkers filled with coal and sufficient provisions on board for a six months' cruise, started for Rio Janeiro yesterday. She left Quarantine Station at 5 o'clock, and passed Sandy Hook at 9:15 last night. It was necessary to wait for high water in order to pass the bar safely.

The disclosures made in The New-York Times of Monday and Tuesday to the effect that District Leader-Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan left his position as Controller of Buffalo a defaulter to the extent of $5,900 have created a tremendous sensation in official and political circles in this city.

The Police Commissioners held their regular meeting yesterday. All the members of the board werg present. After disposing of the routine business Chief Clerk Major Kipp read the following communications from the Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst:

A large share of the attention of railroad men and financiers was given to the affairs of the New-York and New-England Road yesterday. The announcement that the company has a floating debt of $850,000 was something of a surprise in Wall Street. When Mr. McLeod and his friends obtained control of the property, the floating indebtedness was stated at about $450,000.

Judge Truax of the Supreme Court yesterday issued an injunction restraining the Mercantile Trust Company of this city and the Bay State Gas Company of New-Jersey and Delaware from issuing $1,300,000 worth of bonds of the Boston United Gas Company.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- A pamphlet written by Col. de Polignac, published to-day, attracts considerable attention. The writer proposes that France should ally herself with the Moors in order to extend her influence in Northern Africa. Col. de Polignac declares that if an alliance should be established France could compel the Moors to live at peace with the Spanish.

"Col." Henry Potter a fine-looking man, sixty-six years old, who says he lives at Yonkers, N.Y., was arrested on Monday, night at the Academy at Music on charges of passing a large number of forged checks. He wore a Grand Army of the Republic suit of clothes and represented himself as a member of that organization.
The elation of Gravesend over the news from Brooklyn at noon yesterday would have defied all attempts at concealment, had any such been made by anybody. But none were made. None at all.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26. -- A conference of Republican Assemblymen-elect was held here to-night. The legislation of the coming session was considered. It was agreed to support the race-track repealers, such other bills as had for their object a curtailment of the expenses of the State Government, and a change in the ballot-reform law.

The schooner Max, from Haiti, arrived in the lower bay yesterday afternoon in tow of the ocean tug Ocean King. At 9 o'clock on the morning of Dec. 18, when thirteen miles off Cape Hatteras, the Max was running freely before a sixteen-knot wind, when a heavy Jarring told that something had been struck.

Capt. Theodore Ismailoff, who was in charge of the Russian Orloffa at the World's Fair, sailed for his home in St. Petersburg last week in order to write a report of his visit to the stud farms of the United States for the Czar of Russia. Capt. Ismailoff disposed of most of the Russian Orloffs to Mr. W. E.D. stokes of this city and John A. Logan, Jr., of Youngstown.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- The local market opened after the Christmas holiday with little change, either in prices or the general condition of business. Prices ranged very close to Saturday's closing figures, and the dullness which has characterized the business of the Exchange for a time continued. West Chicago, which closed at 148 3/4 on Saturday, opened at 149, and then declined to 148 at the end of the call.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations will begin its work of investigating the Hawaiian question to-morrow, under the resolution introduced by Senator Morgan. It will be conducted by a sub-committee, consisting of Senators Morgan, Gray, Butler, Sherman, and Frye. The committee will refuse to permit access to its rooms while the investigation is going on.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The wheat market did not recover from the effects of the long holiday today. Very little interest was taken, and prices showed but little change. There were, of course, no cables, as the foreigners were still celebrating, and their exchanges will not reconvene until tomorrow. The only feature, and the one around which there remains any display of interest, was the visible supply.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- The Traction stocks to-day again cut loose from the rest of the market. They were firm until just before the close, when Philadelphia was offered at 90 1/4, with no reliable bid. Metropolitan was offered at 103, with 102 the best bid. People's sold at 29 3/4. Pennsylvania loaned at a premium for use.

Assistant Treasurer Conrad N. Jordan landed at the pier of the French Line, from La Bretagne, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and drove directly to the Sub-Treasury. By 1:30 he was at his desk, signing currency certificates for the Clearing House. He disposed of $200,000, in denominations of $10,000, before he dropped his pen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- An injunction was served on the Guarantee Investment Company at its offices in the Adams Express Building by the Sheriff to-day in the suit commenced by Sylvina Gerbrick, which practically prevents the company from transacting any business in Chicago during its pendency.

The Board of Aldermen, actually transacted some business yesterday. The efforts of the "combine" of discontented members to block local legislation have been abandoned, and that the leaders of Tammany Hall convinced them that they were likely to injure the organization is evident. For the first time in months an asphalt pavement resolution was passed yesterday, and the application of the Governors of the Woman's Hospital to sell the present hospital site was granted.

The tugboat Brilliant, owned by the Standard Oil Company, was sunk in the upper bay off Fortieth Street, South Brooklyn, by a huge wave yesterday morning. One man was drowned. Four others had a thrilling escape.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Vice President Stevenson said to-day, regarding the arrest of Donjan, that he was much surprised at the importance attached to that action. Mr. Stevenson said he had received communications from Donjan very frequently during the Summer, some of them threatening, but all of them very clearly showing a weak and shifting mind, and he had decided that Donjan was a harmless idiot.

The production of iron ore in this country has been a very profitable industry. The companies owning the mines of the Lake Superior district have paid very large dividends. The profits of some of them have approached those of the leading copper mines in the same region. Great private fortunes have been accumulated in this industry, the larger part of which has been controlled by some of the wealthiest citizens of the United States.
Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant was appointed temporary receiver of the St. Nicholas Bank yesterday by Judge Truax in Supreme Court, Chambers.

We published on Monday a letter in which ex-Gov. AMES of Massachusetts declared that he had never made the remarks about the Wilson bill which were the subject of an editorial article in this paper on the 15th inst. He had not denounced the bill, nor had he complained because the proposed removal of duties on certain raw materials was accompanied by a considerable reduction of the duties on finished products.

No auction sale of real estate was had in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday, although several were scheduled to take place. In one instance, that of the property at 101 Lexington Avenue, the foreclosure proceedings were withdrawn and the case settled.

"You cannot bulldoze me," and Commissioner W.S. Andrews of the Street-Cleaning Department brought his fist down on the table with a thump and glared angrily at President E.P. Barker of the Tax Department. It was at the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the Mayor's office yesterday.

From The Georgetown (Del.) Democrat, (Dem.) The message of President Cleveland in reference to Hawaiian affairs is to the point, and clearly shows his position to be the correct one. The message is an exceedingly able and well-written document, and will rank well among State papers. All the points in the case are covered, and the position taken by the President is well supported by the facts and arguments adduced.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Joseph Donjan, who was arrested in Washington, D. C., last night for having sent threatening letters to several prominent public men, including President Cleveland and Vice President Stevenson, bore an unenviable reputation among the persons to whom he was known in this city.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- The Gravesend election frauds would have been aired before the General Term this morning but for Judge Mayham's refusal to listen to an affidavit that we old have made quite interesting reading.

Republicans talked yesterday about the new anti-machine Republican organizations. The information in yesterday's New-York Times that T.C. Platt was at the bottom of the scheme to build up a new Republican county organization did not please the Platt people.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- A dispatch from Pernambuco says that a general engagement between insurgent and Government ships is reported to have taken place at Rio Janeiro. The forts are said to have shared in the battle. The dispatch adds that the firing is said to have been the heaviest on Dec. 24.

At auction in the Brooklyn Real Estate Exchange, yesterday, Mr. Jacob Cole sold to Samuel B. Condit, for $3,225, the three-story frame brick-lined dwelling 387 Halsey Street, north side, 258 feet east of Sumner Avenue, 16.8 by 100.10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A Democratic member of the House from New-York says that there is sure to be an animated attack upon one clause of the Wilson bill that has undergone a material change since the bill was made public. In the original print of the bill Clause 567, pertaining to oils, placed a list of oils on the free list, including petroleum.

Postmaster Dayton wants more room for mail wagons in Mail Street. He submitted a plan to the Park Department yesterday which contemplates the removal of the stone wall and the sidewalk on the Post Office side of Mail Street so as to throw the entire space between the Post Office and the City Hall Park open to traffic.

-- Dr. Robert C. McEwen, a prominent physician and surgeon, died at his house in Saratoga, N.Y., Tuesday night, of paralysis, aged sixty years. He was graduated from Williams College in 1853, and from the New-York College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1856. He was house physician at Bellevue Hospital in 1857. He then went to South Africa, and served two years as Assistant Surgeon in the English Army at the Cape of Good Hope.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has been prompt in complying with the Senate resolution calling for an investigation of the Hawaiian affair. Soon after the resolution was adopted, it was decided that the investigation should be conducted by a sub-committee, and Chairman Morgan named himself, Mr. Gray, Mr. Butler, Mr. Sherman, and Mr. Frye as its members.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The steel workers at Pont-y-Mister, Wales, struck a few days ago against a proposed reduction in their wages, and the owners of the works took steps to get Scotchmen to fill their places. When the Scotchmen arrived and attempted to go to work the strikers determined to stop them.

When Civil Justice-elect George F. Roesch takes his seat on the bench of the Fourth Judicial District Court next Monday, he will find that he has practically no patronage to dispense. Justice Alfred Stockler, being an anti-Tammany man, has provided for that. He has already appointed the Clerk and Assistant Clerk, and to-day he will appoint Leopold Masius as interpreter to succeed David Hirsch, who resigned yesterday.

The noble and holy order of the Knights of Labor seems to be bent upon illustrating AEsop. The difference between the benevolent Mr. POWDERLY and the "aggressive" Mr. SOVEREIGN is very likely to be the difference between King Log and King Stork. It was proved long ago to the satisfaction of outsiders, and it has now been decided by the Knights themselves, that the administration of POWDERLY was a failure.

been appointed temporary receiver, was a member of the pool, and it is not pretended that the receivership is a friendly one to Mr. McLeod. The announcement of the assignment of Mr. Samuel Hallner of Philadelphia, who was also a member of the pool, was unexpected, although it was known that he had been a heavy sufferer through the perfidy of Mr. McLeod.

The United States Cordage Company, which was incorporated at Trenton, N.J., Tuesday, had a meeting yesterday and organized by the election of Rudolph Keppler, President; William H. Corbin, Vice President and Treasurer, and Appleton Sturgis, Secretary, Messrs. Keppler and Corbin were elected as permanent officers, except that Mr. Corbin will not be expected to act as Treasurer.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The lifeless body of Elizabeth Petty, an aged recluse and miser, was discovered this morning in a dingy and foul-smelling room at 79 Commerce Street. There is no clue to the murderer or murderers.

The New-York Times was the first newspaper to call attention to the extraordinary and unlawful registration which preceded the latest election at Gravesend. Its note of alarm prepared the public for the colossal frauds there perpetrated, which are now being inquired into by an extraordinary Grand Jury, and in connection with which all sorts of local frauds of a cognate and related character are to be scrutinized and punished.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted to-day.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 27. -- District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan is still waiting to have his contract to build a sewer in this city for $92,764 signed, sealed, and acknowledged by the General Improvement Commission, under whose supervision the work is to be carried on.
Wheat declined 1@1 1/8c on free selling here and at the West, together with easier cables and increase east of the Rockies, with a more active trade.

Very few public men of this city have ever been followed to the grave by such a various and such a profoundly sympathetic train of mourners as was Martin. B. Brown, over whose body the last ritual of his Church was performed at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. The pall bearers and immediate friends of the family assembled at the residence, 931 Madison Avenue, at 10 o'clock, whence they soon proceeded to the cathedral.

In the passage by the House of a joint resolution for the appointment of three Senators and three Representatives as a commission to investigate the personnel of the navy an important step has been taken. The evil which this project is designed to remedy is declared by Secretary HERBERT to be "too serious to be neglected any longer," since its consequences "will soon be nothing less than alarming."

On Tuesday Secretary Henry Beam of the Board of Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge furnished an evening newspaper of the latter city with an official statement of the prices paid toy the Trustees for the properties acquired for increasing the terminal facilities at the Brooklyn end of the bridge.

The National Civil Service Reform League is about to initiate a movement toward the abolition of the spoils system. An enrollment of the voters of the country who favor administrative reform will be undertaken, the work beginning to-day, and will be carried on from the office of the league, 54 William Street.

The Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association of New-York City held a special meeting yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Luke's Hospital to hear the report of the committee appointed to devise means by which trusts and corporations might be persuaded to contribute to the association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Those members of Congress who were of the opinion a few months ago that they would never consent to an increase of the public indebtedness by an issue of bonds will undoubtedly be called upon to reconsider their former opinion and to adopt a new one as the alternative of an appalling deficiency of means at the disposal of the Secretary of the Treasury.

Much interest is taken in the decision of Justice P.B. McLennan or Syracuse, holding that pools are lotteries. The decision was made in a suit brought by Thomas D. Reilly against Milton C. Gray to recover $1,150 placed in French and auction pools at Saratoga. By some it was declared that the decision affected the Ives law, which legalizes betting for thirty days on the track.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The Executive Mansion has been thoroughly overhauled for the social season, which opens with the reception on New-Year's Day. The red parlor of the mansion has undergone the principal changes, which were personally supervised by Mrs. Cleveland. Since its renovation the ceiling and walls are of delicate yellow, with a jeweled effect.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- Two workingmen who were walking together in Muggelsee, near this city, to-day came upon a package lying in the street which they thought might contain something of value. They sought a quiet spot and then sat down to examine their find. One of the men unwrapped the package, while the other man stood over him looking anxiously to see what its contents were.
No one should fail to see the twelve falcons cast in bronze, silver, gold, and their alloys which will be on exhibition for the next ten days at the Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Henry Irving, Ellen Terry, William Terriss, Jessie Milward, and the entire London Lyceum Theatre Company, with many members of the American Dramatists' Club, attended the performance of "Shore Acres" at Daly's Theatre yesterday afternoon. The English actors watched the work of Mr. Herne and his excellent company closely, and frequently led in the outbursts of applause which greeted the telling points.

-- With the notice of its semi-annual dividend of three per cent., payable Jan. 2, the Western National Bank is sending a circular informing stockholders that the Directors have decided to build up the surplus to correspond with that of other banks having the same capital, even if dividends may be suspended. Construing this notice unfavorably, a few small stockholders rushed into the market with their shares.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 27. -- A digester at the Proctor Gamble Glycerine Works, Ivorydale, blew up to-day. Edward Marqua, an employe, and Stephen Reynolds, a boiler-maker, who had gone into the building after some tools, were instantly killed. Their bodies were torn to pieces. The digester was used to separate glycerine from grease.

Christian Freihalter is the name of a German cabinetmaker who, before his removal to the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station last evening, lived, at 1,132 First Avenue. He has been out of work for eight months, and, according to those who know him best, has been intoxicated, most of the time.

Some of the most prominent names in the world of capital and finance were represented at the funeral of Banker Edward Schell, which took place at 10:30 yesterday morning from the Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street. The building was crowded with men eminent in banking circles.
Henry K. Gilman, manager of he Rutland apartment house, 254, 256, 258, and 260 West Fifty-seventh Street, died at 1 P.M. yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital, from pneumonia.

The monitor Miantonomoh, which is now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, has been ordered, to proceed to Trinidad at once. What the vessel is to do after she arrives at that point has not been told, but it is quite likely that she will be ordered to proceed to Rio, where this Government is assembling one of the most powerful squadrons it has ever massed in a foreign harbor.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27. -- Scientists from all over the country gathered here today to attend the twelfth annual meeting of the American Society of Naturalists, the Society of Morphologists, and the Society of Physiologists, which began at Yale this afternoon and will continue to-morrow and Friday.

The loss of a life and heavy damage to property resulted from a fire last night on the top floor of the five-story building 436 Pearl Street, occupied toy August Vahlen, a manufacturer of moldings and picture frames. The fire was discovered at 10:30 o'clock. It proved an exceedingly obstinate one to fight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Racing was continued at Ivy City this afternoon, and the six races were run off without any bookmaking whatever. Owing to the uncertainty relative to the status of the case against Bookmaker Marvin no handbooks were permitted. When it was learned that Marvin and his three assistants had been indicted by the Grand Jury fears were entertained that the meeting would not last, and such proved to be the case.

The Rev. John J. Arnaux, whom the Rev. Edward S. Wright, ex-pastor of the Monroe Street Primitive Methodist Church, Brooklyn, accused of assault, was dismissed from custody yesterday by Justice Connelly in the Gates Avenue Police Court.

The atmosphere of Brooklyn, particularly within the boundaries of the Seventh Assembly District, had a most peculiar and remarkable effect on the optic nerve last election day. Many of the voters of the district were "blind," but ever since, as before election, these same "blind" men have been able to see with singular ability.

Mrs. Alfred Hedberg, whose husband, Capt. Hedberg, was shot at Fort Sheridan two months ago, is now in New-York. Mrs. Hedberg came here from Washington, where she has been to consult the officers of the War Department, with a view to obtaining a complete investigation into the conduct of Col. Crofton, the commandant at Fort Sheridan.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The schooner Grace Andrews, Capt. John Andrews, of Thomaston, Me., arrived here to-day from Natal, Brazil, and Capt. Andrews has a grievance against Peixtot's Government, for which he proposes to try and collect damages through the State Department.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- On New Year's Day, according to custom, Gov. Flower will hold a public reception in the Executive Chamber in the Capitol from 12 to 1 o'clock. The Governor and Mrs. Flower, Mr. and Mrs. Taylor, and Mrs. Schley will receive from 2 to 5 o'clock on the same day at the Executive Mansion.

George Freeman, who is twenty-two years old and says he is a nickel-plater, but who is known to the police as an associate of thieves, was arrested Tuesday night because he was trying to pawn a valuable mandolin. At Police Headquarters Inspector McLaughlin remembered that such a musical instrument was stolen Christmas Eve from 63 West Ninth Street, the residence of Edward M. Townsend of Townsend Yale, dry goods merchants, 345 Broadway.

BUFFALO, Dec. 27. -- Timothy J. Manoney, who is still confined to his house by illness, was to-night shown by the correspondent for The New-York Times copies of last evening's New-York papers which contained the denials of John C. Sheehan, and was asked what he had to say in reply.

From Harper's Weekly. We risk nothing in saying that no fair-minded person can read President Cleveland's message on the Hawaiian affair without coming to the conclusion that the President and the Secretary of State are absolutely right in every position they have taken with regard to this unfortunate business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- One of the largest teas of the season was given this afternoon by Senator and Mrs. Cockrell to announce the debut of their daughter. In the hallway and tearoom the decorations were of holly, while in the first parlor the mantel was banked with the bouquets received by the debutante.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 27. -- The clouds are gathering thick and fast over the heads of the Rev. Jonathan Edward Bell, editor of The Weekly Flag, published in this city, and his second wife, Marguerite Bell. Their trouble has apparently only just commenced, and from the present outlook the end is some distance away.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The lawyers who are defending Prendergast, the assassin of Mayor Harrison, consumed all of to-day in their closing addresses to the jury. Mr. Essex, who began his address yesterday, closed with an appeal to the jury not to commit judicial murder by hanging an insane man.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The tractions were weaker to-day than for some time. Philadelphia was offered at 89 and Metropolitan was offered at 100 1/2, with only one transaction -- an odd lot at 101. Odd lots of People's sold at 28, Baltimore at 16, and Electric was offered down to 45.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- This place was visited by a destructive fire last night, and much of the upper portion of the village was destroyed. The list of buildings destroyed is: Greene's dry goods store, Heinie Brothers' store, Decker's mills, Croeker's drug store, Mr. Kuhn's residence, two hotels, and several barns and out-buildings. Most of the property was insured, but not for anything like its value.

Without warning to President A.A. Mc-Leod, the New-York and New-England Railroad was placed, under the protection of the court yesterday. Thomas C. Platt was appointed receiver by Judge Wallace of the United States court, sitting in Albany, on the application of Mr. Boardman of the law firm of Tracy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The wheat market was more active to-day than yesterday, and the feeling was weaker. There were rumors of just sufficient vagueness from the East to cause apprehension, and to them -- although denials were quite as numerous as the rumors themselves -- the value of wheat is indebted for a loss of 1 cent to-day.

The Democratic-Republican electors of the City and County of New-York are hereby notified that on Saturday, Dec. 30, 1893, between the hours of 8 and 9 P.M., primary elections will be held at the places and under the conditions hereinafter mentioned in the several Assembly Districts, and they are hereby invited to participate therein.

Much interest was evinced on the part of a great number of spectators, who came to watch the students play the second games of the Intercollegiate Club's tournament at the Harvard School, 578 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. The players were opposed to each other in the following order: Hymes vs. Ross, Ewing vs. Hewins, Libaire vs. Spalding, Skinner vs. Roberts.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
Five persons who had tried to commit suicide were prisoners in hospitals and elsewhere yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 27. -- Politicians here who mixed in the factional fight of the Harrison and anti-Harirson forces two years ago are preparing to renew the struggle. All of those elements which opposed the ex-President at that time have now combined, and the indications are that they will support McKinley as against Harrison.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The Jeffersonian Club, the most influential political organization in Essex County, has indorsed the Wilson bill. Last night it adopted these resolutions:

"Billy" Martin, the smooth-faced youth, led the riders in the big race at Madison Square Garden at midnight, and the others will have to do some very fast cycling in order to overtake him before next Saturday night. He has fully recovered from his sickness, and last night rolled off miles with the greatest regularity.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Dispatches received by city houses through the South African merchants, Mosenthal, Sons Co., report that the British South Africa Company's force, under Capt. Wilson, forty strong, has been massacred by the Matabeles. All communication between Capt. Wilson and Major Forbes has been destroyed by the rising of the rivers, it now being the rainy season.

The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, through L.J. Carpenter, has sold its four-story brick building, 79 Fourth Avenue, east side, between Tenth and Eleventh Streets, to Mr. Meyer Kahn for a little below $30,000. It measures 24 by 100 by irregular.

Fifteen hundred invitations were sent to society people of New-York and elsewhere requesting their presence at the wedding of Miss Ella Louise Faye to Louis Joseph Sands. Judging from the crowded condition of St. Francis Xavier's Church, on Sixteenth Street, yesterday morning, a large proportion of those bidden availed themselves of the opportunity to witness the nuptial ceremony.

The opening session of the second annual meeting of the American Jewish Historical Society was called to order yesterday morning in the lecture hall of the Columbia College Library. At the morning session the attendance was confined to members of the society, and only routine business, including the election of officers, was attended to.

-- The Dix Neuvieme Siecle of Paris says that Arton, the notorious go-between in the Panama Canal scandal, is now in London. It adds that M. Casimir-Perier, Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, bas given orders that efforts be made to arrest him, with a view to securing his extradition.

This is the third time that the corporation now bearing the name of the New-York and New England Railroad has been in the hands of a receiver. The present company was organized in 1873 by the holders of the Berdell mortgage bonds issued by the Boston, Hartford and Erie Railroad. The last-named company was chartered in 1863, it being a consolidation of three or four small lines.

The advisory committee of architects which has been examining the plans submitted for the new municipal building has practically determined upon the best six in the collection. One of these will be selected as the plan for the building. Cash prizes will be awarded to the architects for the others.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange admitted the following new securities to the stock list to-day:

The athletic contest on Christmas night at the Washington Heights Young Men's Christian Association was productive of some excellent work and four records were broken. Shoemaker, Dingwall. and Reid did especially good work. The contest was an all-around one, points scoring 5, 3, and 1 respectively. The first and second men in each event were as follows:

The foreign exchange market was weak and without much activity. The posted rates for sterling were reduced to $4-84 1/2@$4.85 for sixty-day bills and $4.87@$4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.83 1/2@$4.83 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.85 3/4@$4.861/4 for demand, $4.86@$4.86 1/3 for cable transfers, and $4.82@$4.82 1/4 for commercial.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- At the drop of the gavel this morning it was clear that it would be a lively day, and all signs portended a loppy market. The indications were verified. West Chicago opened at 146 1/2, and sagged all day, until it reached 145 at the close. Alley "L" began by selling at 40 1/2, and it ended by going begging at 39 1/2.

The members of Companies A, B, F, G, and K, constituting the Second Battalion of the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, gave a Christmas reception in the Flatbush Avenue armory last evening. The building was crowded with the militiamen and their friends.

ROANOKE, Va., Dec. 27. -- A serious rail-road accident occurred at Troutville, on the Shenandoah Valley Division of the 'Norfolk and Western Railroad, eleven miles north of this city, this morning at 7:55 o'clock. The vestibuled train from the North due here at 8:25 o'clock ran into an open switch and collided with a freight train.

Mozart's opera "Don Giovanni, ossia il dissolute punito," was produced at the Metropolitan Opera House last night under difficulties. It appears that the American climate is no respecter of persons, and that it would not take into consideration the fact that Mozart's glorious masterpiece has held the stage with uninterrupted success ever since it was produced at Prague on Oct. 29, 1787.
An adjourned session of the Board of Education was held yesterday afternoon to clear up as far as possible the business of the present year.

Two more arrests in connection with the alleged violation of the election laws were made yesterday. One of the men apprehended was ex-Bridge Policeman Michael J. Lally, who was indicted some days ago, charged with illegal electioneering. This charge, added to Ms previous unsavory reputation, made his arrest more commented upon than any in the entire batch of sixty-seven.

We have already referred to the plan of the "East Side Belief-Work Committee." This has been very considerably extended, and it is hoped that it may reach a very large part of the oases of real need. We publish this morning the report of Mr. CHARLES S. SMITH, Treasurer of the Finance Committee, of the subscriptions so far received.

A decision on the application for an inspection of the stock books of the Heading Company has not as yet been handed down by the court in Philadelphia, not withstanding that the motion was heard a week ago yesterday. The delay is said to be due to the illness of one of the presiding Judges, and it may be indefinite, as there is no knowing how long the court may be disabled.

Old "Pop" Eldridge, the great-grandfather of the municipal police force of New-York, has been gathered to his ancestors. The sturdy veteran, who had borne every symbol of the watchman's office, from the cap of the defunct leatherhead to the red-tasseled locust, departed this life at his residence, 1,229 Amsterdam Avenue, early yesterday morning, at the age of ninety-six.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- The Trustees of the State insane hospitals met here today and discussed in secret session the interference of the Lunacy Commission with the interior management of the hospitals under their care and supervision. The following resolutions were the result of the conference:

-- The Common Council of Hartford having passed a resolution the other day directing the Park Commissioners to shovel the show from the walks in and around the City Halt Square, Street Commissioner Cone made Judge Sherman W. Adams, President of the commission, a Christmas present of a diminutive shovel, that he might be prepared to do his part in carrying out the mandatory order of the Council.
LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Mr. Gladstone is eighty-four years old to-day, and The Times devotes an editorial column, to a birthday article, which is a curious mixture of blame and praise.
Dr. Talmage yesterday issued the following address to the public, calling for cash contributions to be expended in feeding the hungry residents of Brooklyn, who are unable to purchase food:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The President and party are expected back to-morrow morning. Prior to their departure there was a general understanding that the regular semi-weekly meeting of the Cabinet would be held to-morrow as usual. There is no Special occasion for the President to return so soon, and in the excitement of the sport he may possibly overlook his original intentions.

The atmosphere of the Seventh Assembly District of Kings County was inviting to the "blind" voter on election day. It now appears the dead and bedridden of Castleton, S.I., were called into requisition to swell the majority for Michael McGuire, the Democratic candidate for the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- On Monday evening next the Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee will meet at the Treasury Department to settle definitely the form and scope of the proposed income tax. The members of the committee have had no meeting since the adjournment of Congress.

It is expected that the Kings County Grand Jury will present indictments against a number of officials of the defunct Commercial Bank. It is believed that more indictments will be found against Cashier Vail and President Keeney, and that other Directors who had a hand in wrecking the institution will be brought to account for their mismanagement.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28. -- The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day wore as follows:

The Republicans are planning to increase their majority in the Legislature of this State by unseating several members who hold certificates of election and putting contestants in their places. They are even credited with the expectation of securing a two-thirds majority in the Senate by this means, but that would not be of any practical use in legislation without a two-thirds majority in the Assembly also, of which there is no possibility.
Horse racing received a black eye last season, because it got into the hands of a lot of racing speculators. The outlook for the coming season, if the management is not changed, is aything but rosy.

Henry S. Kearney, engineer in the Board of Electrical Control, caused the arrest yesterday of Isaac Liebmann, an advertising agent, on a charge of sending a threatening note to him through the mails. Mr. Kearney returned from his Christmas vacation yesterday and found on his desk a postal card, reading as follows:

From The Boston Journal. The recent celebration of "Forefathers' Day" at Medfield, Mass., was an event of more than local interest. Mr. Hezekiah Butterworth, talking about it, spoke of that old town, its landmarks, and what it stood for. Then he said he had learned in connection with that of one of the funniest things he ever heard of.

Copyright, 1893, by the United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 28. -- The Brazilian Foreign Minister, acting for President Peixoto, authorizes the representative of the United Press to send the following information:

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 28. -- Pugilist Charles Mitchell was arrested this morning and taken before Jndge Baker. He was committed for trial before the Criminal Court, which meets next Tuesday He was at once released on ball. Later in the day Corbett was arrested and the same proceeding gone through. The object of their arrest is to test the legality of the laws regarding prize fighting.

Ex-Mayor Daniel D. Whitney of Brooklyn has always been strongly opposed to the plans of President James Howell for widening Liberty Street and providing what Mr. Howell calls a "plaza" approach to the bridge.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- State Controller Campbell some time ago appointed Henry W. Bowes an agent to examine into the financial administration of the institutions in the State which do not come under the direct supervision of any State board or official. Mr. Bowes has completed his investigations and submitted his report to the Controller.

The New-York Mutual Insurance Company has sold to its neighbor, the American Lloyds Insurance Company, the property at 61 William Street, about 24 by 68, for $127,000. The two companies owned and occupied in common the five-story and basement browns-bone business building 61 and 63 William Street, southeast corner of Cedar Street, occupying a plot about 48 by 68 feet.

On bicycles built for one, the riders in the race in progress in Madison Square Garden are still cutting out a fast pace. They are all ahead, of all past performance, and the chances are that the record will be broken, by about 300 miles. Interest in the contest appears to be on the icrease.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 28. -- Mrs. Mary E. Lease was to-day removed from the State Board of Charities by Gov. Lewelling. Mrs. Lease objected to the appointment of a Democrat in one of the State institutions and said he would have to be removed or she would resign. The Governor promptly wrote an order removing her.

For a day or two the usually dingy corridors of the Federal Building have taken on a cheerful appearance. Each, time the rapidtransit elevator on the Broadway side has made its fifteen-minute trip a bevy of handsome women and pretty, giggling girls has alighted at the third floor and inquired the way to the gown exhibition.

The third round of the second annual intercollegiate chess tournament was played at the Harvard Sohool, 578 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. in the presence of a large gathering of chess enthusiasts, including several ladies. The feature of yesterday's play was the remarkable form shown by Hymes and He wins, who disposed of their adversaries in rather fine style, especially so the latter, who scored very brilliantly against the strong Yale man, Ross.

From The Philadelphia Ledger. A testing machine company in this city has completed for Cornell University a vertical screw-power testing machine of 400,000 pounds' capacity. The machine will test specimen bars of metal 10 feet in length, and is also adapted for crushing tests of cement and similar materials. It is the largest screw-power machine ever constructed in the United States and perhaps in the world.

-- The period of the "Voting Trust" for stock, of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company expiring on the 31st inst., the Trustees give notice that they are prepared to deliver after that date stock certificates in exchange for the present trust certificates, on the surrender of the latter at the office of Messrs, Drexel, Morgan Co. Certificates must be assigned to the Trustees for exchange for stock.

Tobacco thieves gave the police a hard fight in the neighborhood of Isaac Dankowitz's cigar factory, at 1,078 Second Avenue, early yesterday morning, and seven shots were fired on both sides before an arrest was made. One man was captured, but his confederate escaped. The man arrested said he was William Mitchell of 311 Ninth Avenue.
LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 28. -- Editor and Preacher Jonathan Edwards Bell and his wife are still in the Queens County Jail, having failed to secure bondsmen.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 28. -- Miss Lizzie Knapp, a young milliner employed on East Washington Avenue, was stricken stone blind while at work on Friday last. She was sewing at the time, and the awful affliction was unattended by the slightest warning. The case mystifies oculists who have examined it.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 28. -- The Casino at Casino Park, three miles from here, burned at 2 o'clock this morning. The fire is supposed to have originated from an open fireplace on the office floor. The manager, Henry Alexander, and the twenty-three inmates of the house escaped from the upper windows in their night clothes.

The sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, to which has been delegated the inquiry into any "irregularities" which may have occurred in the "diplomatic or other intercourse" of our Government with Hawaii in connection with the "revolution" of last January, has decided to conduct its inquiry in secret.

In compliance with instructions from the Board of Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, General Counsel S.W. Pettit has begun suit for the removal of Receivers Thomas F. Oakes, Henry C. Payne, and Henry C. Rouse. The petition was filed in the United States Circuit Court in Milwaukee yesterday, and an order to show cause why the petition should not be granted was issued by Judge Jenkins.

An effort will probably be made to secure the passage of a bill at Albany reducing the rate of fare on the elevated roads to 3 cents. One of the men who believes that the roads can make money by reducing the rate to 3 cents presents the following statement in support of his views:

The upbuilding of ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt's new Republican county "machine" in this city goes on. Evidence accumulates that he will force the Republican State Committee to indorse what is now known as the "anti-machine" Republican organization as the only recognized Republican organization in this city. John E. Milholland, a trusted Platt man, is doing the work of organizing at present.

From The Atlanta Constitution. The Constitution Saturday morning had a big headline, "Senator Mills Is Scared," alluding to his son going armed with him. Speaking of Senator Mills's courage, an ex-Confederate veteran said: "I saw Gen. Longstreet and Col. Mills at Chickamauga when the Texan was in real danger, but he was as calm as that September day in 1863.

The body of "Gus" Milner of Insurance Patrol No. 1, who lost his life while on duty in the burning picture frame factory of August Vahlen, 436 Pearl Street, late Wednesday night, is still in the building under tons of debris.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Dec. 28. -- The Parkhill Manufacturing Company, which, owns a number of large mills in this city, and which is one of the largest and wealthiest producers of ginghams in this country, drove its employes into line yesterday afternoon, and obtained their signatures to a petition to Congress asking that the Wilson Tariff bill be not passed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Judge Green has handed down a decision denying the application of Sheriff Beck for a peremptory writ of mandamus against the Board of Supervisors of this county to compel the payment of his Deputies by Erie County.

-- The Graf collection of portraits found in the Fayum, Egypt, is shown at the Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia. These likenesses would form a very interesting part of some ethnological museum, and perhaps Philadelphia may have a public-spirited citizen who will see in them, a fitting gift, since they represent types that belong to many other races besides the Egyptian.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- State Commissioner of Agriculture Shraub is giving much of his attention to the sale of oleomargarine in this State in "original packages." He believes that the State dairy laws preclude the sale of articles made in imitation of butter.

ANGOULEME, France, Dec. 28. -- At the trial to-day of the prisoners accused of participating in the attack of Aug. 16 on the Italian laborers employed at the Aigues-Mortes Salt Works, when ten men were killed and twenty-six wounded, a number of witnesses testified that one of the prisoners named Constant fired at the Italians who had been thrown into a pit.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 28. -- J. P. Hawley of Stepney was to-day the honored guest of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company. He was the first man to drive an engine over the road Just forty-five years ago, and congratulations were showered on him and the railroad company to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 28. -- A special meeting of the Common Council was called for this noon by Mayor Potter, that there might be concurrent action which would permit the Park Commissioners to expend a portion of the $300,000 appropriated last week for park construction in the employment of the poor.

Captains of all vessels now reaching port from over the transatlantic route have some meteorological observations to make. There is quite a fleet of ships overdue, and the arrivals are all more or less overdue. Gales have beset their paths, and mishaps of all sorts have been met.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Mrs. C.M. McLean, wife of Col. C.M. McLean of this city and a niece of the late Col. George W. McLean of the Old Guard, was terribly burned this afternoon while impersonating Santa Claus at a Christmas tree entertainment given by the women of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension to the poor children of the city.

This will be a lively evening at the New-York Athletic Clubhouse. The opposition to the regular ticket will make known the result of their conferences and post, their ticket for election. It will be headed by Mr. Walter G. Schuyler, the candidate against Mr. Barton S. Weeks, for President. There will be candidates for two minor offices, and two members will be nominated for the Board of Governors.

ROME, Dec. 28. -- The anti-tax agitation of the Sicilian peasants and of the lower classes generally in Sicilian cities and villages continues to spread. News of Socialist demonstrations and anti-tax disturbances are received almost constantly at Palermo.

When the corvette Kearsarge, in obedience to orders, picked up her anchors several days ago and started for San Domingo, leaving some of her crew behind, wonder was expressed as to the nature of the emergency which demanded so much expedition. A possible explanation of the vessel's hurried exit was had yesterday when the steamship George W. Clyde arrived in port.

-- Amack Lambert, city salesman for Rosenthol Co., neckwear dealers, 4 Burnett House Block, Cincinnati, Ohio, committed suicide by shooting himself yesterday morning in his room at the St. Nicholas Hotel. No cause is assigned by his friends for the rash act. Lambert was twenty-two years old. His parents reside in New-York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- The first witness called by the prosecution in the Coughlin trial to-day was Jonas Carlson, the Swede who owns the cottage which has become the most famous of all the houses in Chicago. He is seventy-three years old.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- "I was not actuated by malice. I swear before high heaven that I was not. You are my murderer if I die!" This was the impassioned language with which Prendergast interrupted Mr. Trude this afternoon.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 28. -- Miss Cornelia Elizabeth Hubbard of this city and Courtland Henry Trowbridge of New-Haven were married here to-night in St. John's Church by the Rev. W.H. Lewis. The wedding was one of the most fashionable ever held here, and the guests included society people from North and South alike.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 28. -- Suits for amounts aggregating 52,500 were entered in the United States District Court this morning, growing out of the pending prosecution of Capt. Laporte of the French steamship Havre. Capt. Laporte, on the arrival of his ship here in October, was arrested and charged with violating laws of the United States, which requires a ship Captain to provide proper food for all immigrant passengers.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Prince Colonna was asked by the United Press correspondent this evening to give his side of the suit for separation. He said he must decline to imitate the Mackays by discussing family affairs in the newspapers. He was willing, however, he said, to make a statement denying the falsehoods which had been circulated concerning himself and his friends.

The New-York weekly Times is making an offer of books for the holidays which every one should read. It is to be found on the eighth page of The Weekly Times, and explains how any subscriber to The Weekly Times may secure any one of nearly 400 choice books for a very small sum. The books are fine enough for any library and have been selected with great care.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Secretary Herbert says the Miantonomoh will go nofurth-Norfolk at present. He refrains from any intimation that she will join the New-York in Rio Harbor. Indeed there appears to be some question whether the Miantonomoh, with her coal supply of 300 tons, could reach Rio with any certainty.

Lawson N. Fuller, whose championship of elevated transit to the upper part of the city and whose criticisms of delay have made him objectionable to the Rapid Transit Commissioners, has undertaken to point out to them, since they will not hear him speak, the only practical way to accomplish anything, in the following open letter, addressed to the Commissioners:

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- West Chicago was the most active stock on the list to-day. Opening at 145, it declined to 144 1/2, recovered to 145 1/8, and closed steady at those figures. Some 2,600 shares changed hands, Alley L was next in activity, selling between 39 3/4 and 40. The movement in the stock, however, was entirely speculative, with hardly a thing doing for immediate delivery.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Major Julius Rhodes, who is enlisting men for Peixoto's army at Elmira, has an agent in this city enrolling recruits. The agent is Harry Tatchell, formerly a Sergeant in the British Army. He says he has enlisted several men who are willing to fight for the Brazilian Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The sub-com- mittee of the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House, to whom, was com- mitted the question of repealing the State bank tax, divided on-the matter, Mr. Cox of Tennessee submitting, a report embodying unconditional repeal, and Mr. Warner of New-York and Mr. Hall of Minnesota reporting in favor of conditional repeal.

The annual shoot for the Riker Trophy took place in the Twelfth Regiment Armory on Wednesday evening. Teams of five men from each company competed, each man having five shots at 200 yards and five shots at 500 yards. The trophy was won by Company E, with a total score of 215.

Henry Clausen, Jr., one of the most prominent brewers of this city, died at 5 o'clock yesterday morning at Dr. Lange's private sanitarium, where he was undergoing an operation for trouble of the liver.

"As soon as the appropriations for 1894 are available I shall call the heads of the various city departments together to arrange a systematic plan whereby public work may be undertaken with all possible speed for the purpose of providing employment for as many men as possible who are now out of work.

"God bless them all!" muttered an old woman coming from the Avenue A Mission, just above Fifteenth Street, yesterday afternoon. She was one of the members of the Mothers' Helping Hand Society connected with St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Sixteenth Street, who had just finished their annual Christmas dinner at the mission.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- The market to-day was very uncertain, nearly all stocks recording declines. The traction, stocks were especially weak. There was no support in Philadelphia Traction. Metropolitan was dull and weak, probably on the announcement in the morning papers of a larger issue of mortgage bonds by the Broadway and Seventh Avenue Road.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- There are many complaints in the State, War, and Navy Building of the sanitary condition of that edifice, although the building is the latest of the public buildings here.
John Y. McKane treated, the serious charges made against him yesterday in The New-York Times by the taxpayers of Gravesend as if they were in the nature of jokes.
BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- The following letter was received at the Executive Chamber this morning from Henry Watterson of Louisville:

The property and franchise of the NewYork, and Northern Railroad was exposed for sale in Yonkers at noon yesterday, by Edward Clark, referee in the foreclosure proceedings of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company. That company recently foreclosed a second mortgage for $3,200,000. The sale occurred in the waiting room of the railroad on Getty Square.

Many Christmas tree celebrations for the children of the Sunday schools in the different parishes were held yesterday, the selection of Holy Innocents' Day being found convenient as well as appropriate, The spectacles in which so many thousands of little persons had joyous participation were peculiarly charming, and in some cases unique in beauty.

The astonishing disclosures made in The New-York Times yesterday concerning the manner in which John Y. McKane has depleted the treasury of the town of Gravesend caused a crowd of reporters to be sent down to the Town Clerk's office, Gravesend, yesterday. They all had in their hands the story from The New-York Times, and they sought John L. Voorhees, Town Clerk, for the purpose of ascertaining whether the charges made therein were true.

-- Henry T. Bronson has been appointed receiver, in supplementary proceedings, for Neil Macdonald, railroad contractor at 6 Wall Street, in the suit of Amos F. Eno. Mr. Maedonald was a partner in the firm of William V. McCracken CO., railroad contractors at 40 Wall Street, for which Mr. McCracken, the liquidating partner, made an assignment on Tuesday.

It was a happy thought of Mr. Irving, as "Olivia" could not be put forward for a long run in his present engagement, to reserve that charming play till nearly the close of his visit. It was acted at Abbey's Theatre last evening, and will be repeated there to-morrow night, when Mr. Irving, Miss Terry, and their associates will say farewell.

If we are to believe the assertions of the high-tariff press, the manufacturers of the ordinary bottles and vials, made of flint or lime glass, are among those who see ruin staring them in the face whenever they look at the Wilson bill, and are now compelled by the prospect of tariff revision to close their factories or reduce the wages of their employes.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 28. -- The latest development in the New-York and NewEngland receivership affair is the issuance of an order toy Judge William K. Townsend here to-day summoning the Sheriff of Hartford County to appear in this city tomorrow afternoon and show cause why he should not be held in contempt.

E.W. Ward, one of the receivers for the Hoffman House toy virtue of an appointment in New-Jersey, called yesterday on E. S. Stokes, receiver for the Hoffman House by virtue of an appointment by the courts of New-York. Their meeting was friendly and unique.

-- The British steamer Cornhill, 1,313 tons, bound for Malta, was sunk off Gibraltar yesterday. She was in collision with the British steamer Douglas Hill bound from Noples for Newport, England. The Douglas Hill was also badly damaged. Everybody on the Cornhill was saved.

The popularity of Gounod's "Faust" and the public admiration for the manner in which it is performed by the present company, under the management of Messrs. Abbey Grau, were shown again, yesterday, when a large audience attended a special matinee. It was evidently a wise movement on the part of the managers to take advantage of the musical dullness of the week.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28.--The indictment for bigamy, which had been returned against Samuel Belasco, in Essex County, was found April 10, 1891. The court officers were never able to locate him, and the capias for his arrest was pigeonholed, months ago. His arrest in New-York City on another charge brings the matter once more before the courts here.

The final session of the American Jewish Historical Society's annual meeting was called to order at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the Lecture Hall of the Columbia College Library, and the reading of papers relative to the early settlement of the Jews in this country was continued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Mrs. Richard Wainwright gave a tea this afternoon to introduce her daughter to society. The residence, on New-Hampshire Avenue, was thronged with friends, many of whom had sent in advance of their coming bouquets to the young debutante, who stood beside her mother, in a gown of white muslin and lace, and carried a large cluster of La France roses.

The spirit of charity directed by Mrs. A.B.Fish, assisted by the King's Daughters of the Church of Zion and St. Timothy, gave pleasure and practical aid to about fifty poor families in Adelphi Hall, at Fiftysecond Street and Broadway, yesterday afternoon. For several years past Mrs. Fish, who is prominently identified with charitable work, has organized a Christmas tree entertainment for the benefit of such deserving poor families as may come to her notice.

Charles Stewart Smith, Treasurer of the Finance Committee of the Emergency Fund to Give Relief by Work, appointed at the meeting at the Charities Building on Dec. 21, reports that $6,153.04 was received, up to Dec. 27, from the following contriibutors:

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- State Controller-elect Roberts arrived here this morning from Buffalo and will familiarize himself with the affairs of the Controller's office before the present incumbent shall retire on Jan. 1. He took the oath of office before the Secretary of State to-day. Col. Morgan, who will be Mr. Roberts's Deputy, is also in town.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 28. -- A hot flight is going on over the organization of the Ohio House of Representatives, which will be brought to a conclusion Saturday afternoon, in the Republican caucus: There are three candidates for Speaker -- Charles P. Griffin of Lucas County, Alexander Boxwell of Warren County, and Joseph T. Haskell of Lorain County.

-- Aaron P. Mitchell, one of the best-known and wealthiest men in Essex County, N.J., died at his home in Grove Street, East Orange, Wednesday. He was born in East Orange in 1829, and came of old colonial ancestry. He was graduated from Hamilton College, New-York, in 1850, and embarked in the dairy business in East Orange, where he was successful, and by judicious real estate speculations amassed an ample fortune.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- State Agricultural Commissioner Schraub to-day notified all the deputies and agents of his department to keep a sharp lookout for violators of the cider-vingar law, which the General Term of the Fourth Departhment has declared to be constitutional.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 28. -- Mr. Andrew Carnegie telegraphed from New-York to-night that the proposition embodied in his letter addressed to Robert Pitcairn, a member of the local relief committee, means that he will duplicate the money already subscribed to the fund for the relief of the unemployed, as well as duplicate all that may be subscribed within the time specified in his letter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The present distribution of United States war ships in foreign waters, it is stated, marks an intention on the part of this Government to obtain the extension of American trade and commerce in countries which would naturally have large commercial interests with the United States.

Justice Barrett had a busy time of it yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer with the election fraud cases. Thirty-one men, of whom fourteen had previously obtained bail, filed before the bar to plead to charges of violation of the election laws.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Murray-Mosher. PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Miss Mary E. Mosher, daughter of Mrs. Isaac W. Rushmore of West Seventh Street, was married to-day to William D. Murray, President of the Young Men's Christian Association here and a lawyer in New-York. The ceremony took place in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, the Rev. Dr. Richards officiating.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- An Illinois veteran has made an unusual proposition to Congressman Cummings. He acknowledges that his suggestion is a strange one, "to come from a crippled ex-soldier," but he believes there will be a hearty echo to his proposition among all patriotic pensioners. The ex-soldier says in his letter:

The papers in the receivership suit brought by Thomas C. Platt and others against the New-York and New-England Railroad were filed with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court in this city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The work of the House Committee on Appropriations is well advanced. Chairman Sayers said to-day that if there should be any delay in the consideration of the tariff, the Appropriations Committee Stood ready, at a day's notice, to provide material for the attention of the House.

From Bradstreet's, Dec. 30. What will doubtless be known as the "panic year 1893" has brought with it, as was to be expected, the largest number of business failures ever recorded in the United States since the records of the same have been kept, the total as reported to Bradstreet's amounting to 15,560, in which are included only commercial, industrial, and financial business failures in which estimated actual assets are smaller than reported liabilities.

From The Buffalo Courier, Dec. 21. About 650 species of mushrooms are growing in New-York State to-day, and of these only 75 are edible. In consequence, the eaters of home mushrooms axe in constant danger of being poisoned.

More money is still the cry of those working for the relief of the unemployed. The Woman's Conference of the Society for Ethical Culture has increased the number of women to whom it gives work from the forty who began on Tuesday to sixty. Of these only half are employed aft the room, 18 Delancey Street, and there is room there for as many more, without other outlay by the conference than the additional wages.

-- George Wells Cheney, one of the family of the Cheneys, the famous silk manufacturers of South Manchester, Conn., died there at 1 o'clock yesterday of catarrhal pneumonia. He attended the marriage of his son, G. Herbert Cheney, at Brooklyn, N.Y., Dec. 20, and caught a cold which resulted in his death. Mr. Cheney, who was seventy years old, was the son of Wells Cheney, one of the original Cheney Brothers.

RIO JANEIRO, Dec. 29 -- The representative in this city of the United Press has learned from an unimpeachable authority that Admiral Saldanha da Gama, who is in command of the insurgent fleet in the Bay of Rio Janeiro, in the absence of Admiral de Mello, when, asked on what constitutional grounds the insurrection had been started, replied:
Local Weather Forecaster E.B. Dunn has just issued a report on the weather in New-York during 1893. He says:

There is talk not only about a legislative investigation of the administration of municipal affairs in this city, but about a similar inquiry into the City Governments of Brooklyn, Buffalo, Albany, and Troy. There are also suggestions of an overhauling of the past doings and present condition of several departments of the State Government at Albany.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- By the sailing this afternoon from Liverpool for this port of the steamship Southwark the International Navigation Company has a fine addition to its fleet of transatlantic steamers. The Southwark is a new boat, and her present trip is her maiden voyage. She is a steel steamer of 8,000 tons carrying capacity, and has accommodations for 1,000 saloon and steerage passengers.

The Kings County Grand Jury appeared in the County Court of Sessions yesterday and presented a number of indictments, among them being two charging John J. Vail, ex-cashier of the defunct Commercial Bank, with forgery in the third degree.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- A hearing was had this afternoon before the Chairman of the Western Passenger Association of charges made by the Santa Fe against the Rock Island in connection with the sale of California tickets, on which it was alleged excessive commissions had been paid. The case had previously been before, the local association, which convicted the accused and imposed a fine of $125.

Capt. Dundas of the British steamship Woolwich, which reached Quarantine late Thursday night, gave to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday a detailed account of a voyage which came perilously near ending in disaster. Hurricanes formed the principal feature of the trip, and one of these, which was encountered when the vessel was five days out from Middleborough, the Captain says was among the most violent he ever experienced.

From The Medical Record. For somewhat over twelve months the readers of medical literature have been confronted in small caps with the conundrum: "Do the sick ever sneeze?" We do not know why this inquiry has become so popular; no prize has been attached to its proper answer; in fact, comments and replies are not even solicited.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Two large petards were exploded this evening just outside the barracks in Catania, Sicily. Little damage was done to property and none at all to persons. It is supposed that the explosion, was the work of malcontents.

B.S. Klee, dealer in woolens at 597 Broadway, is a Democrat who voted for President Cleveland. He believes in tariff reform, and is still as ardent an admirer as ever of the President. He was in an indignant frame of mind yesterday afternoon when he told to a reporter for The New-York Times a story of a Republican method of working against the Wilson bill.

Ex-Judge Granville P. Hawes died early yesterday morning in his home, 9 West Forty-sixth Street. He had been confined to the house by a cold but one day. Intestinal troubles developed, and the end came suddenly soon after 10 o'clock in the morning, when, he was found unconscious. Death was caused by angina pectoris.

American railway securities were again weak in the London market. Rumors that the dividend on Louisville and Nashville would, toe passed seriously affected that stock, and the selling movement of yesterday was continued. Atohison and St. Paul also declined sharply. Lake Shore advanced 1 per cent, and was the only strong feature.
Edward Corcoran, alias Edward Clark, a hack driver, of 86 Greene Street, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for examination on a charge of highway robbery.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Millionaire George H. Baboock's will was admitted to probate to-day. Property to the amount of $2,000,000 is disposed of. It gives to the Plainfield Public Library $10,000 and three, brick residences, to be used in establishing a fund for the Babcock Scientific Library, to be included in the former.

President Jeffery of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, will be in New-York to attend a meeting of the Board of Directors on next Tuesday. His visit to this city has given rise to reports that the managers of the road are obliged to straighten out some financial difficulties. George Coppell, Chairman of the Board of Directors, disposed of that report very decidedly yesterday.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 29 -- Mrs. Jonas Carlson was put through the rest of her cross-examination in the Coughlin trial to-day, and made the same impression as her husband. She gave the same unsatisfactory answers as to why she knew it was the 4th of May, the 20th of March and April, and other occasions.

From The Boston Globe. "When I was first in Washington," said the Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale, "I had a letter from a lady here inclosing $100 to use in keeping a Washington family. It was the first considerable trust that I had had reposed in me. I hunted the family up and found it consisted of a lady, the widow of a soldier, and her boy, a bright lad, who was named 'Thad.'

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Complaint of the shooting of sailors of the American schooner Henry Crosby, by San Domingo soldiers has not reached the State Department, and it is learned that the cable message telling Secretary Gresham of the likelihood of a revolution on that island, which caused the Navy Department to send the Kearsarge there, contained no mention of the occurrence.

Real estate men were much, interested yesterday in the decision of the Clearing House Association to buy the Ottinger Brothers' property at 77,79, and 81 Cedar Street, the details of which are given elsewhere.

Barring accidents, Shock, the small, ungainly Austrian rider, will win first honors in the six-day bicycle race. He has a commanding lead over Waller, the big German, and Martin, the American champion, is hopelessly in the rear, a hundred miles behind the leader.

Everybody is anxious to secure something really first-rate in the way of pictures that are faithful reproductions of the splendid architectural and artistic conceptions of the great exposition. There are a great many pictures of World's Fair views extant, but not many of them will stand very close inspection.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 29 -- The result of a meeting held yesterday afternoon to protest against the free-ore clause of the Wilson Tariff bill was that resolutions were adopted urging the member of Congress from this district both to support and to oppose the free-ore clause.
