To the Editor of The New-York Times: Referring to the editorial, "Collars and Cuffs," appearing in your issue of Saturday last, we recognize that the writer thereof has been misinformed regarding the facts of the case, and consequently writes under a misapprehension in supposing:

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The principal business transacted in wheat to-day was in the line of "evening-up" trades, as regards the closing days both of the year and of the month. Shorts were the principal local buyers. New-York furnished a number of orders on that side of the market too. The bulk of them seemed to be in the hands of Boyden Co. and of H.V. Lester Co.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A dispatch dated at Pernambuco on Dec. 22, and forwarded via Cape Vincent, says:
Mayor-elect Schieren of Brooklyn has named two more Cabinet officers. It is understood that he will complete his Cabinet to-day.

In The Century Magazine for January -- which is an excellent number with which to enter upon the new year -- is printed a valuable paper by ex-Senator Henry L. Dawes of Massachusetts in regard to the culmination of the feud between Conkling and Blaine during the Administration of President Garfield.
"I look for an extended debate on the Tariff bill in the Senate," said Senator J.L., Mitchell of Wisconsin to a reporter for The New-York Times at the Astor House yesterday.
From The Washington Post. During Capt. White's travels in Cochin China the then Viceroy gave him a magnificent tigress 5 feet long and 3 feet high.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 29 -- The story of an unfortunate marriage came out in the Superior Court to-day before Judge Robinson. Mme, Varney, a fashionable dressmaker of this city, petitioned for the annulment of her marriage with Dennis D. Durham.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- William F. Sheehan's latest attempt at sneak legislation was defeated by the Board of Supervisors to-day. Last Wednesday he was instrumental in the passage of a resolution designating some two hundred miles of roads as county charges, to be constructed and maintained at the expense of Erie County, the city, however, bearing 82 per cent, of the cost.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 29 -- Mrs. Lease has written a letter to the Governor in relation to her removal from office. She alleges that she has not had even so much as is accorded criminals -- the right of self-defense. She says she was an employe of the State, and not a personal hireling of the Governor. She signs herself "President of the Board of State Trustees and President of the Board of Charitable Institutions."

The District Attorney has decided not to present the charges against the National Cordage Company and James M. Waterbury to the Grand Jury. Mr. Nicoll gave out this statement regarding the case yesterday:

In the last years of Louis XV. it was abundantly evident to those who were watching events that a crisis was impending. It was only a question of time when a great change would be wrought in the Government of the country. The nation was in suspense and nobody knew exactly what would happen.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Raymond Blathwayt, who has passed two years in the United States studying the condition of the Catholic Church there, has written a letter to The Chronicle on Cardinal Gibbons's attitude toward the labor question. The letter is intended to refute a recent article in The Chronicle which reflected upon the Cardinal's sympathy with the efforts of the working people to better themselves.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Dec. 29 -- P.M. There was further contraction in the stock market to-day, the dwindling of business being due largely to the indispositon of the average trader to undertake new engagements at the close of the year. Prices were, as a rule, strong, owing to a general movement to cover outstanding short contracts.
The Extraordinary Grand Jury will make its report to Justice Cullen this morning. It will then be discharged for the term.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Ever since the mysterious disappearance of Thomas J. Smith, the rollicking clubman of this city, cases have cropped out in court bearing upon him. To-day J.M. Swift, executor of the will of J.H. Swift, father of the absent man, brought an action for the construction of Thomas's father's will.

These three volumes supplement material published within the last few years relative to the great Prussian strategist. In the "Moltke Correspondence," the "life and Character," and the "Letters to His Mother and Brothers," (1892,) we saw the peculiar diligence of the man, and how his career as a soldier possessed above all else an "infinite capacity of taking pains."

BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- The Beobachter, the principal Democratic newspaper in Stuttgart, published this morning a remarkable anti-Prussian leader, in the course of which it said: "As true Democrats and Wurtembergers we must be particularists, inasmuch as the Government of Wurtemberg is more of a constitutional Government than Prussia's.

There is a report that Lieut. Gov. WILLIAM F. SHEEHAN proposes to be a candidate for re-election next Fall for the purpose of securing a "vindication." It is to be hoped that the Democratic organization of the State will be in such shape before the next convention meets that it will be impossible to load down the ticket by any such nomination.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A dispatch from Rio Janeiro, dated to-day, says: "The Ministers of foreign powers have refused Admiral da Gama's request that the insurgents be recognized as belligerents.

In the literature of the civil war few biographies have made more peculiar claims to interest than the biography of that Southern leader who was the founder of a college, Bishop of Louisiana, and a General in command -- Leonidas Polk. In two volumes of moderate size, his son. Dr. William Polk of New-York, has narrated the story of his too short life, and Longmans, Green Co. have published it.

Yesterday was the fourth day of the second annual intercollegiate chess tournament, which was played at the Harvard School, 578 Fifth Avenue There was again a large number of spectators present. It was Yale's great day. for both her men came out victorious. The men were pitted against each other in the following order: Spalding (H.) vs. Hymes (CL,) Hewins (H.) vs. Libaire (C.,) Roberts (P.) vs. Ross (Y.,) Swing (P.) vs. Skinner (Y.)

The Democratic-Republican electors of the City and County of New-York are hereby notified that on Saturday, Dec. 30, 1893. between the hours of 8 and 9 P.M., primary elections will be held at the places and under the conditions hereinafter mentioned in the several Assembly Districts, and they are hereby invited to participate therein.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer has failed to find indictments against the Inspector and the Captain of Police who were charged with, neglect of duty in connection with the suppression of disorderly houses because the evidence presented was "not sufficiently clear."

The Extraordinary Grand Jury decided yesterday that sufficient evidence had not been presented to warrant the indictment of Inspector Alexander S. Williams and Capt. Schmittberger of the "Tenderloin" Precinct, and the formal complaints against those police officials, drawn by District Attorney Nicoll, were dismissed on that ground.

From The Boston Journal, Dec. 28. Gen. John L. Swift, Deputy Collector of the clearance department at the Custom House, Is lying dangerously ill at his home, 23 Circuit Street, Roxbury. His physicians state that he will probably never appear at his desk again. He may die at any time, although it is possible that he will live a month or two.

From Electricity, Dec 27. The question of fire risks from electrical sources is one that is constantly being agitated by different boards of fire underwriters throughout the country, and the prominence which has been attached to the subject has given rise to an exaggerated opinion on the danger of electric wires in the minds of the public.

The New Municipal Building Commission met in the Mayor's office yesterday and received the report of the advisory committee of architects who have been examining the 134 plans submitted to the commission. The commission is made up of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, County Clerk Purroy, Register Levy, and Surrogate Frank T. Fitzgerald.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 29 -- The movement for the relief of the unemployed of Pittsburg was given, a new impetus at the meeting of the Citizens' Relief Committee to-day, when Robert Pitcairn, Chairman of the Finance Committee, presented the letter of Andrew Carnegie, printed yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Sheriff Preston and Receiver Sherwood of the Philadelphia, Reading and New-England Railroad will not face the contempt proceeding's before Judge Townsend in New-Haven this afternoon. Arrangements have been made by Arthur Perkins, representing the receivership, and Charles E. Cross, representing Mr. Sherwood, to have the hearing postponed until Monday nest.

From Dun's Review, Dec. 30. Starting with the largest trade ever known, mills crowded with work, and all business stimulated by high hopes, the year 1893 has proved, in sudden shrinkage of trade, in commercial disasters and depression of industries, the worst for fifty years. Whether the final results of the panic of 1837 were relatively more severe the scanty records of that time do not clearly show.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Times's correspondent at Rio Janeiro sends the following dispatch, dated Dec. 22, via Montevideo:

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 29 -- The report of the receivers of the Continental Life Insurance Company, which will be filed with the Superior Court here Saturday, shows that they have on hand $35,553 in cash. The annual dividend from the Utica Cement Company stock was $15,000. There are 15,000 shares of this stock, held in the interest of the policy holders.

The position of Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT in State and city politics is peculiar. It is always unique, but at present it is unprecedented even in his own career. As to State politics, there is no doubt that Mr. PLATT entertained last Summer the same view that was generally entertained by well-informed persons that this was the Democrats' year for carrying New-York.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29 -- All conceivable phases of mystery are being applied to the murder of Miss Elizabeth Petty. None has the semblance of a genuine clue so much as the fact that a tall, broad-shouldered, and suspicious-looking man was seen leaving the recluse's house, on Commerce Street, at 2:35 o'clock Tuesday morning.

The audience at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening, though not so large as some which have been present this season, was conspicuous for the number of gray heads. It was evident that the announcement of "Verdi's "Rigoletto," one of the battle pieces of the old operatic repertoire, had called out a goodly number of veteran operagoevs, moved doubtless by a desire to find out whether Mme.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 -- The Grand Jury has about concluded its investigation into the giving of fraudulent mortgages to the Old Men and Widows' Homes, by which the treasuries of these institutions have been swindled out of thousands of dollars. It is said that six persons have been indicted, among whom are some of the most prominent in the city.

City Hall Park bird hunters had a new game yesterday. The sparrows had a rest, and the supply of quail on toast in the Jim Fisk restaurant on Park Row ran short in consequence. So did the potted squab which goes as a free lunch with a schooner of beer at "the Printers' Rest," on that same thoroughfare.

At the meeting of produce commission merchants at the New-York Mercantile Exchange yesterday it was charged that the manufacturers of oleomargarine and imitations of dairy cheese are using money freely to prevent the enforcement of Federal and State laws concerning the manufacture and sale of imitations of dairy products.
Hugh O. Pentecost was yesterday appointed an assistant in the District Attorney's office at a salary of $7,500. He is to succeed H.B.B. Stapler, resigned.

During the present week plans and specifications were entered in the Building Department for the construction of seventeen new buildings, involving a total estimated cost of $155,000, and likewise for alterations to be made to twenty-two various structures, at an expense of $40,000.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- In the United States Circuit Court at 10 o'clock this forenoon, before Judge Colt, arguments were resumed on the application for the appointment of temporary receivers for the New-York and New-England Railroad Company in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The different interests were represented by W.C. Loring and A.A. Strout of Boston, C.E. Perkins of Hartford and Mr. F.H. Platt, of Boardman Platt, of New-York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Army officers who are in command of posts have complained of the methods of the Inspector General of the army. The latter, in the course of his examinations into all that pertains to the service, is privileged to exact of commanding officers such information as he believes valuable to his office.

The horse and carriage men feel much more confident as the 1st of January approaches that they will about come out even, which is much more than many people interested in other branches of business will be able to do. The sales of carriages, harness, and horses for the last mix weeks have been remarkably good, with every prospect of a very much better trade in the Spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- If there is any sort of good investment demand for local Stocks about the middle of next week, a fair advance over present prices is likely to be recorded. A good indication of that to-day was in Lehigh Valley. This stock has been hammered constantly, with a view of breaking it, but short stock is absorbed by the investor, who takes it off the Street.

LENOX, Mass., Dec. 29 -- The guests to the number of about 130 who are to attend the marriage of Miss Alice Greenleaf and Mr. William Adams at Trinity Church on New Year's Day, at noon, have been arriving ever since Tuesday of this week. A delegation of about forty came up yesterday with Mrs. A.P. Stokes and her family.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Unless the law shall interfere, Patrick Eugene Joseph Prendergast, the murderer of Carter Henry Harrison, will die on the gallows. Twelve representative citizens of Cook County this afternoon adjudged him responsible for his cowardly deed on the night of Oct. 28, and the death watch to-night sits outside his cell in the county jail.

The Clearing House Association, held a special meeting yesterday afternoon to consider the action of its committee appointed to purchase a site for a new building, the business of the association having outgrown the capacity of the building at the north-west corner of Nassau and Pine Streets.

The final action of the Clearing House Association with reference to a new home, fitted to its present and future needs, is one on which not the members of the association, only, but the community, must be congratulated. The site selected on Cedar Street is in the very heart of the district where the great interests with which the Clearing House is concerned are largely concentrated.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Mr. Gladstone is eighty-four years old to-day. He is in excellent health. He arose this morning at an early hour, looking strong and well. The scene at his official residence in Downing Street throughout the morning was unusually animated. The hourly mails were extraordinarily heavy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- There are very few members of the Legislature here yet, though enough are on hand to indicate that there is a very strong and growing sentiment against the methods of Thomas C. Platt. All the legislators arriving are Republicans, and they seem to be uneasy under the yoke that Platt is insisting that they shall wear.

MOSCOW, Idaho, Dec. 29 -- George Colgate, the ill-fated cook of the Carlin hunting party, who was left on the banks of the north fork of the Middle Fork of the Clear-water River, where it was supposed he had perished, is alive and probably still at the place where he was deserted by the others comprising the hunting party.

"David Lewis, Business Manager of 'The Dark Secret,'" the blonde-haired young man who has been swindling leading jewelers and merchants out of goods with worthless checks, representing himself as a theatrical manager, and directing that the goods be left to be called for at the offices of various city theatres, was arrested yesterday by one of Inspector McLaughlin's men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Postmaster General Bissell has given his last order for the printing of the Columbian postage stamps, known in the department as the "Big Columbiads." The order was for 165,000,000, and it completed the 2,000,000,000 contracted for by Mr. Wanamaker. The following circular has been sent to Postmasters in this connection:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 29 -- Miss Madeline Pollard and her brother are still in this city, and it is likely that their visit will be extended a few days. She is here, it is said, to secure evidence in her suit against Congressman Breckinridge, and it is evident that she is meeting with much difficulty in obtaining the desired information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Mrs. David Smith gave a tea Thursday afternoon to introduce her daughter, Miss Helen Smith, at their residence on Connecticut Avenue. The house was decorated with palms, and the mantels were filled with the bouquets received by the debutante. Mrs. Smith received in a grown of ivory satin brocade trimmed with point lace and seed pearls.

WATERTOWN, Mass., Dec. 29 -- William Lyman Akin, A.M., who died to-day at his home here of chronic Bright's disease, was known for many years in New-York as a teacher of exceptional ability. He was born in Rotterdam, N.Y., Oct. 1, 1820. He attended the district school and the Lyceum in Schenectady, and in 1846 he entered the sophomore class at Union College.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- The Clearing House rate was unchanged this morning at 1 per cent. New-York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. There was no change in the outside market. Money is in abundant supply where the collateral and credit of the borrowers are satisfactory. Call money is freely offered, at 2 per cent, and time money at 3 1/2@4.

Of all the assertions made by the promoters and defenders of McKinleyism there is none more absurd than the assertion that the tariff duties are paid by foreigners. It is only in the last few years that the advocates of high and higher duties have tried to teach this senseless doctrine in the hope of misleading thoughtless partisans.

An investigation yesterday of the prices paid by the City of Brooklyn for property used for the extension of the structure toward the Brooklyn City Hall brought to light two facts of decided interest.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant will take possession of the St. Nicholas Bank as its receiver to-day, when Bank Superintendent Preston and Bank Examiner Judson will submit to him a complete statement of the bank's affairs. To-day's proceedings will be entirely formal, for the receiver has been at the bank most of the time for two days, and has informed himself in regard to everything of which he will now become officially aware.
KENSICO, Dec. 29 -- After two years' steady work of drilling a tunnel through 2,600 feet of solid rock, the opening was finished last night.

C.P. Huntington authorized the statement yesterday that the lease of the Central Pacific Railroad to the Southern Pacific, which was made in 1885, had been revised by the Southern Pacific Directors. The practical effect of this revision is that the Southern Pacific ceases to guarantee the dividends on the Central Pacific stock.

About eighty members of the New-York Athletic Club, forming the opposition to the regular ticket that has been nominated for election, met in a room in Music Hail, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue last night. Mr. Frederick M. Hanaling called the meeting to order shortly after 8 o'clock, and those present were engaged in club politics until nearly 11 o'clock.

Major Charles B. Throckmorton of 204 West Eighty-second Street was appointed Assistant Superintendent of the Street-Cleaning Department yesterday by Commissioner Andrews. His salary will be $2,500 a year, and he will have special charge of the reorganization of the stables. He succeeds John T. Birmingham, Who has been a District Superintendent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

From The Boston Traveler, Dec. 21. A novel bet was paid yesterday, and of all the miserable creatures I ever saw the chap who was paying it was about as much to be pitied as any one could be. He was a Thomas N. Hart man at the last election, and bet his friend that the Republican would be chosen Mayor.

Envy, hatred, and malice are not novelties, and nothing else than these goes to the constitution of an Anarchist.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 30 -- Judge Guernsey to-day committed Albert Van Wagnen, an American lawyer, who for many years resided in London, to the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane. Thirty years ago, when Judge Barnard was first elected to the Supreme Court bench, Van Wagnen was associated with him in the practice of law in this city.

The race question has come up again, this time in a San Francisco training school. An application being made for the admission of a Chinese girl, the nurses raised strenuous objections, and, in order to prevent a small revolution, the Directors were obliged to decide against taking her in.

What this means, none of the Shakespearean critics or commentators tell us, and, as far as I can find out, none of them profess to be able to do so.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 30 -- Detective Joseph Batnarello of Brooklyn, N.Y., to-night arrested William H. Grim at the City Young Men's Christian Association here. Grim is wanted in Brooklyn on an indictment by the Grand Jury for bigamy. It is said that he has five wives living -- No. 1 in Hartford, Conn.; No. 2 in Dubuque, Iowa; No. 3 in Quincy, Ill.; No. 4 in Fulton County, Penn., and No. 5 in Brooklyn.

There have been a number of sensational stories circulated recently about Col. David E. Austen of the Thirteenth Regiment compelling his Captains to resign. The reports are denied by both Col. Austen and by the Captains themselves. Capt. W.W. Hanold of Company G was one of the officers mentioned, and he is very indignant about the story of his resignation.

From The Georgetown (Ohio) News-Democrat, Dec. 28. A couple of years ago, in conversation with Gen. S.F. Carey, in reference to the newspapers of the United States, he, without equivocation, pronounced The NewYor Times, everything considered, the best newspaper printed in America.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30 -- An interesting paper, recorded in the Coun'ty Clerk's office to-day, reads as follows:

The students of Columbia won both their games against the Yale men in the fifth round of the intercollegiate chess tournament yesterday, and are now almost certain to again win the championship for the season of 1893-4. There were some good games played yesterday, and a large crowd of interested spectators was present at the Harvard School, 578 Fifth Avenue, where the games are being played.

That all the feeling engendered by the civil war has not yet died out is evidenced in the existence of a woman's club in St. Louis which bears the title of the "Post-Bellum Club." At a recent meeting a discussion was had upon "Percy Gregg's History of the American Civil War."
The ring members of the Brooklyn Democratic "machine" are endeavoring to save from the wreck the Board of Supervisors, in order that John Y. McKane may be elected Chairman pro tem.

The case of William Sinclair Crewe of 25 West Forty-second Street, who was arraigned on a charge of grand larceny in the Yorkville Police Court Sunday last, came up again yesterday in that court, before Justice Grady.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury of the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, convened by the authority of Gov. Flower to investigate the election frauds in Gravesend and Brooklyn, finished its labors, as far as Gravesend was concerned, yesterday, and presented a great bundle of indictments to Justice Cullen.

People in Brooklyn have established a new place to lionize in that city. They no longer take visitors, as they used to, up to Prospect Park proudly to exhibit its broad acres, its dense and thrifty woodlands, its silver lakes. They have found a more remarkable and more interesting place.

The gymnasium of the New-York Athletic Club was packed last night, floor and galleries, with members and their guests, who came to witness the third professional boxing tournament provided this season by the club's management.

WEST POINT, Dec. 30 -- Permission was yesterday granted to the baseball team to arrange its schedule for 1894, and leave to draw upon the five-hundred-dollar fund already subscribed to cover any expense that is incurred. The team has organized, with Cadet Gilmore Captain and Cadet Pence manager. The players for 1894 will be as follows:

This volume is not a formal biography, nor is it a book consisting mainly of Mrs. Botta's own letters and reminiscences. The pages in it which were written by her are the least conspicuous. They come not at the beginning, but at the end. They fill not much more than one-third of the volume's total of 400 pages, and of this third the larger part is filled with selections from her published prose and verse.
DOVER, N.J., Dec. 30 -- An accident occurred to-day at the Richard Mine, at Port Oram, about four miles from this city, in which two men were killed and four badly injured.

Leoncavallo, the gifted composer of "Pagliacci," is a genuine Wagnerite. He has seen interviewed by the musical editor of The Berlin Courier with great success. The visitor was shown into a room decorated with Japanese fans, weapons, lanterns, carpets and hangings, bamboo chairs and couches, and vases full of chrysanthemums, and amid a crowd of slit-eyed deities and masks there was visible a large poster of Canio in his white dress beating his big drum.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- R.A. Wade, senior counsel for the defense, was so indignant over the verdict in the Prendergast case that he hardly had words to express his feelings. He said:

The close of the year brought less business than frolic at the Stock and Produce Exchanges. At the Stock Exchange about twenty footballs appeared on the floor just before the last gong sounded. Everybody with energy of foot joined in the games thus improvised, and Chairman Mitchell had no auditors for a notice which it was his duty to proclaim before the day ended.
The announcement of the appointment of Hugh Owen Pentecost as Assistant District Attorney, at a salary of $7,500, has caused universal surprise in political circles.
Wheat advanced 1/2 @ 5/8 c on local covering and firmer cables, with a dull trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Next Friday will be a field day in the House of Representatives on Hawaiian matters in all probability. It is the present understanding that the majority and minority reports of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the Hawaiian situation will be taken up on that day for discussion and action.

John Wood Dodge, a veteran artist, died in Pomona, Tenn., on Dec. 17, agred eighty-seven years. He was born in New-York City in 1806, his parents and grandparents all having been natives of this State. There is now standing, in good repair, near Poughkeepsie, the family house of his ancestors, one of the oldest in the country.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- A decade ago, next to Boston the City of Albany possessed more houses with historical reminiscences attached to them than any other city in the United States, Philadelphia included. The irresistible hand of civilization, however, has chopped, many of them into kindling wood, and the steady growth of corporate power has led to the removal of many others.

Ernest Lambert of Plainfield, N.J., assistant editor of The Forum, died yesterday at Southern Pines, N.C., where he had gone early in the Winter with the hope of recovery from phthisis. Mr. Lambert was born in the Island of Jersey, in the English Channel, in October, 1863, of French and English parentage.

The closing week of a year is rarely marked by large transactions in realty, and the past few days have been no exception to the general rule. There have been a few sales of business property and residences, as the columns of The New-York Times have slown from day to day. But general trading has been moagre.

The Provisional Committee of One Hundred, to preside over the Kings County Democratic reorganization, held its initial meeting at the Clarendon Hotel, in Brooklyn, last night. In the absence of George Foster Peabody, the President, J. Warren. Greene called the meeting to order.

Mr. "ABE" HUMMEL has found it to the advantage of a client of his to maintain that the well-known Ives pool law is unconstitutional. His contention is that a horse race is a lottery, and that the Legislature has no power to legalize lotteries. His client betted and lost $1,150 in French and auction "pools" at Saratoga, and was reluctant to pay.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The opening of the Manchester Ship Canal Monday will not be the ceremonial affair that it was to have been. It was originally planned to have a procession of big merchantmen from distant parts making the finish of their long voyages at Manchester on New Year's Day.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- A swindler who came to town several weeks ago departed the other day with $1,700, easily taken from the unsuspecting client of a Brooklyn lawyer.

When the steamer Pilgrim of the Fall River Line arrived at her pier yesterday morning, Stateroom No. 155 was unlocked and the passenger who had occupied it was missing. Several pieces of wearing apparel, some handkerchiefs, and a gold chain and silver watch were found in the room, and a card found in the vest indicated that the occupant had been A.H. Howland, a civil engineer of 95 Milk Street, Boston.

Perhaps our civil war had on neither side a more interesting and picturesque figure than Bishop Leonidas Polk, who throughout the greater part of the war was one of the Confederate military leaders, and who, when killed in 1864, was a Lieutenant General in the Confederate service. The career of Gen. Polk has found a worthy memorial in this biography by his son, Dr. William M. Polk of this city.

The report on 134 plans for the new municipal edifice in City Hall Park made by Messrs. LE BRUN, WARE, and KENDALL is only what was expected. They have sifted the plans to six, and report that not one of the six meets the demand for a structure which shall be in external beauty worthy of New-York and at the same time fit for the various purposes to which such a building must be put.
NOVGOROD, Dec. 30 -- During a charity carnival that was being held on the Volga River, the ice broke and a large number of people fell into the river.

Holiday week was rounded out musically Hast night with the performance of "The Messiah" at the Music Hall. Since the Oratorio Society began to render Christmas tribute at the shrine of Handel it has drawn to itself for this service a following ever increasing in numbers and of a churchly turn. Last night's audience was of the kind to frown upon the levities of life, but it knew "The Messiah" by heart.

Richard Bruner, thirty years old, from Trenton, N.J., an alleged agent of Dr. Parkhurst's society, was arrested last night under peculiar circumstances and locked up in the Fifth Street Police Station. Lizzie Brown is his accuser. When taken to the station house with Bruner she said: "I was walking along Third Avenue to my home when I was accosted by this man Bruner.

The usually peaceful and somewhat sleepy atmosphere which prevails at the Republican Club is disturbed just now. There is a row on hand. It has been in progress for a week or two, and has been growing worse steadily.

A familiar human example will make this general muddliness and uncertainty of nature realizable to every one. If we see a negro in the streets of London we immediately recognize the broad difference that marks him off from the common mass of white men by whom he is surrounded. But that, of course, is only because we take an individual instance.

The time from ten to fifteen years of age, writes Kate Upson Clark in a paper on the above subject, is of all the periods of life the most lacking in reverence. The problem of how to live with this young person, often three or four strong in a single family, is an absorbing problem in the minds of parents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The attitude of the Populists in the Senate on the Tariff bill is giving the tariff reformers concern. The Democrats have a majority of 5 in the Senate, there being 45 Democrats, 37 Republicans, and 3 independents or Populists, Peffer, Kyle, and Allen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The thoughts of society generally are pretty well monopolized with plans for the new year receptions. Invitations from the White House to be present and "stand behind the line" ait the new year reception are eagerly coveted, regardless of what Administration may be in power.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- With the closing of the year several of the open seasons for game close, Woodcock, grouse or partridge, quail, and squirrels cannot be taken after to-morrow. Neither can muskallonge be caught. The squirrel season will remain closed until September; that of woodcock and partridge to Aug. 15: that of quail to Nov. 1, and that of muskallonge to May 30.

PARIS, Sunday, Dec. 3 -- One of my friends, who has business connections in the rubber district of Para, recently received communication of the immediate arrival of a young Indian, a lad, sent here by his father -- mistaken man -- to "ornament his mind," (sic.) A few days later came the youth Don Triste Rocca, or Sad Rock, as the translation reads.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- The reports of the seizure by natives of the German Government House at the Cameroons. West Africa, have been confirmed by dispatches received to-day, among them being an official dispatch from the Governor of the Cameroons.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

The New-Year's matinee and evening performance of "The Councillor's Wife" will close the run of that pleasing comedy at the Empire Theatre, and Tuesday evening Charles Frohman will present "Sowing the Wind," a play by Sidney Grundy, which is now in the fourth month of its run at the Comedy Theatre, in London.

Mrs. John Drew's acting in a condensed version of Holcroft's comedy, "The Road to Ruin," was the most important new thing of last week. Mrs. Drew's acting is not new, of course, and Holcroft's comedy is older than she is by about twenty-six years. "The Road to Ruin" was written in 1792; Louisa Lane was born in 1818, and has been an actress since her tenth year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- This Having been Christmas Week, and business having taken a general rest, the sportive newspaper elves that considered it a duty to make it merry for their readers have had a great many things quite their own way. The Wilson bill has been beaten off-hand, viva voce, there being not enough members in town to have a constitutional roll call.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 30 -- Early in February ex-President Harrison will leave here for California, where he will give a series of lectures on international law at Leland Stanford University, and politicians are discussing the significance of the trip.

NEW -- ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- The men who fought on either side in the civil war find it hard to realize that a generation has gone and another one come since the first gun was fired on Sumter; that two-fifths of the native-born voters were unborn when Major Anderson evacuated the fort and the long struggle between North and South began.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- It is said the Republicans are taking steps to contest the election in the First Ward of this city and unseat John Sheehan, Democratic Alderman-elect, in favor of the Republican candidate, John White.

Theodore W. Myers, who for the last six years has been Controller of the city, closed his connection with the Finance Department at noon yesterday, and his successor, Ashbel P. Fitch, will take that office at noon to-morrow. As the noon hour approached, City Auditor George W. Lyon and many of the employes of the Finance Department entered the office and presented the Controller with a magnificent gold watch, beautifully inscribed.

Caesar Borgia was bold, ambitious, crafty, able, handsome, and remarkable for his physical strength. But he was as false and, cruel as his father. He early formed large schemes for the extension of his domains, and his plans he might have carried out had he not been arrested at a critical moment by the death of the Pope and his own illness.

The positively last appearance of Mayor Boody as a speechmaker in the Brooklyn City Hall took place about noon yesterday. At that hour he took leave of his Cabinet, very much after the manner in which a retiring tragedian parts with the members of his supporting company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- One of the biggest electric searchlights in the world is to be mounted at Sandy Hook. Gen. Flagier, the army Chief of Ordnance will purchase a monster light for experimental purposes. The apparatus desired, including the light proper, the dynamo, the steam engine and boiler, will cost between $6,000 and $10,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- The Emperor, as is his custom, will reassemble about himself on New Year's Day the leading Ministers and Generals. Some of the newspapers, knowing that the custom will be observed Monday, pretend that they have knowledge that important political utterances will then be made by his Majesty.

Mr. Isidor Straus will succeed Ashbel P. Fitch as the representative in Congress from the Fifteenth District. Mr. Fitch was elected to the House of Representatives from this district a year ago by a majority so large as to make it certain that any Democratic candidate nominated as his successor will be chosen by the voters of the district.

GREENLAWN, L.I., Dec. 30 -- Centreport is agitated over the disappearance of Abby Malone, the seventeen-year-old adopted daughter of Capt. Patrick Malone. Miss Malone was one of the prettiest girls in the place, and had many admirers. She left home a week ago. All efforts to learn her whereabouts have failed.

Some clever writer once said that there were only three ways to end a novel -- first, the two get married; second, one of them marries some one else; and, third, one of them dies. To these three terminations this writer has said that Mr. Howells has added another, by which no one does anything.

Vast and populous as China is, the experience of the present century shows that she is weak for aggressive purposes. She has not the hold on territory adjacent to her borders which she could claim a hundred years ago. European nations are pressing on her, both on the south and on the north.

Nothing that has occurred in the collegiate world of chess in many years has excited such an interest among the players, and so stimulated their greatest skill in this most scientific of all games, as the costly trophy offered by a number of graduates of Yale, Harvard, Princeton, and Columbia for an annual chess tournament between the students of the four colleges.

Even Horace would have been content with the home of dear old "Ik Marvel," who wrote "Reveries of a Bachelor" so long ago that it seems hardly possible that he could now be living in good health and in full possession of his mental vigor. He became famous before he was thirty. That is the reason.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 30 -- A daring gang of burglars made its appearance here last night. The burglars live in the fashionable village of Hempstead. Two of the gang are known. Their capture is only a matter of time, unless their relatives succeed in keeping the hands of suburban justice tied up.
SING SING, Dec. 30 -- One of the traditional "oldest inhabitants" of this old town recently told a reporter for The New-York Times the following story of by-gone days:

The House of Commons has some 670 members, and it has seats for little more than half the number. Even if we take into account the members' galleries, which run along two sides of the chamber, there still is not nearly room enough for all the men who are entitled to take their places in the House of Commons. What are the members to do who have not got seats?

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The police of this city to-day found themselves confronted with the most mysterious and brutal tragedy it has ever been their lot to puzzle over. The victim was a young woman of irreproachable character and independent means, who followed the profession of a music teacher.

The inventive genius of woman is not of recent recognition. For centuries her skill in devices of one sort and another has been known and accepted. In the home, generations of husbands and sons have relied upon "mother" to tide them over all its emergencies, and few mothers have been unequal to the task.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst held a long consultation yesterday with Lawyer Moss, Mr. Kenneson, and other members of the Executive Committee of the Society for the Prevention of Crime. Afterward he prepared a statement in which he said that something more complete would appear later.

In an important thoroughfare in the West End, London, is the only dairy in and about the city where asses' milk can be procured. This fluid, as is well known, is a valuable remedy in certain complaints, but only the rich can indulge in it very freely, for it costs 75 cents a pint!
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 30 -- The Sligo Iron Mills, on the south side, will resume operations, double turn, on Tuesday, Eight hundred men will be employed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Holiday weather has accompanied the midwinter holidays in Washington. Visitors who have never been here before in the season, and who have been enjoying all the sights with the encouragment of the most beautiful weather, are going away with the best impressions possible of the charm of Washington as a Winter city.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The novelties among the bills prepared by the managers of the down-town theatres for New Year's week will be limited to one, which will be found at the Grand Opera House. The play will be "L'Enfant Prodigue." At the Schiller Theatre Mr. Felix Morris will make a change in bill, presenting at the New Year's matinee three favorably-known short plays -- "The Game of Cards," "The Vagabond," and "Moses."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 3O -- Pugilistic circles are still worried over the attitude of Gov. Mitchell His telegram to county officers here, charging or in ilmating collusion, has provoked great comment and the officials have replied in a very peppery manner. The Governor is expected hers soon, and those who favor the contest will exert every possible pressure to have him keep quiet.

Mr. Cooper describes the Hon. Richard Francis Milner Escott as "a phenomenally wicked person." When he wrote letters to his sire, who was Lord Stratton, and asked for money to pay his gambling debts, his way of addressing his respectable father was, "Dear F." The Hon. Richard had four children, and he did his best to ruin them.
"This is my last night. I'm tired of it. I was brought up to better things than this."
Watch night will be held generally in the Brooklyn churches this evening. Large gatherings are expected at the final religious services of the year.

The Tammany primary elections in all the Assembly Districts of this city were held last night. They were formal and peaceful affairs. Between 12,000 and 15,000 men were elected to form the General Committee for 1894. The voting strength of this committee, however, is 3,528.

The temporary and permanent relief associations all over the city are doing a vast amount of work in relieving the distressed, feeding the hungry, lodging the homeless, and supplying clothing to those in need of it.

The Fire Department estimates that the losses by fire for the year 1893 were $5,630,937, the insurance on the buildings and other property burned or damaged being $80,447,194. The average loss at the fires for the year was $1,362.42. The records give the following statistics as to the number of fires:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Grand Jury this afternoon returned an indictment against George H. Engeman, President of the Ivy City Jockey Club, charging him with violating the gaming laws of the District of Columbia. A bill was also returned against George B. Marvin and three others for book-making. Mr. Engeman is now in New-York, but his friends look for his appearance in Washington the first of the week.

During the last twelve months a vast amount of work was done by the Surrogate's office. The summary for 1893 shows that 1,640 wills were offered for probate and 1,566 admitted. The number of wills contested was 80. There were 3,427 special motions heard and disposed of, and 2,648 opinions written.

Every year a jovial band of gentlemen and ladies, all true devotees of sport, go to Maine to enjoy the fishing, shooting, and other delights afforded by the State dear to the heart of the hunter and the angler.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The behavior of the war ship Resolution during the recent gale she encountered in the Bay of Biscay continues to excite considerable comment among naval experts.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The Hon. Levi P. Morton, ex-Vice President of the United States, has been confined to his room since he underwent recently a surgical operation. Mr. Morton said this afternoon that the toe joint that has caused the trouble is nowmuch better. The trougle was at first supposed to be an attack of gout, but was really an abscess caused by a misfitting boot.

Every sale at auction scheduled, for the present week will be in pursuance of legal proceedings. Several of them have been adjourned from previous dates. All will be held at 111 Broadway. Details are subjoined:

The formal presentation to the City of New-York of the bronze bust of Gen. Win- field Scott Hancock, which has been erected in Hancock Park, at the intersection of Manhattan and St. Nicholas Avenues, was made yesterday afternoon in the Governor's Room of the City Hall.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 30 -- Prof. William Libby, Jr., of Princeton University delivered a lecture at Yale last night on "The Hawaiian Islands." He confined his remarks to a general description of the country and its people. To-day, however, he talked freely relative to the present political situation there.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music held a large and well-pleased audience last night when some of the principal artists of Messrs. Abbey Grau's opera company appeared in Gounod's "Faust." More than ordinary interest was aroused by the performance from the fact that M. Plancon made his first appearance in this country in the part of Mephistopheles.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Gustave Klahre, the young tinsmith who worked in his father's shop at 88 Clark Street in 1889, testified at the Coughlin trial to-day that on May 6 of that year a man came into the shop with a big tin box. He identified Martin Burke at the first trial as the man. Burke wanted the lid of the box soldered air-tight.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The body of a man who had committed suicide was found to-day in a lodging house in Oldford Road, East London. The man had shot himself with a revolver in the temple. When the police saw the body they were at once struck by its resemblance to the descriptions of the mysterious "Scott," for whom they have been looking for months in connection with the alleged murder of Lieut. Hambrough.

Nothing ever became JOHN Y. McKANE so much as his eleven indictments. They fit him perfectly and are a natural and appropriate adornment for a person of his walk and conversation. Indeed, McKANE not under indictment is a startling solecism. There has been something manifestly wanting in his make-up, a lack that the December Grand Jury has generously and conscientiously supplied.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 30 -- When "Blue -- eyed Billy" Sheehan of Buffalo sanctioned and approved of a legislative act last Winter, creating a General Improvement Commission in this city, with authority to expend $1,500,000 in street improvements, he made a mental note of the fat sum of money to be spent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Representative Lockwood of this district will introduce in Congress soon a new immigration bill, drawn up under the auspices of the Central Labor Union, and designed to remedy the defects in the present law and to restore the stream of immigration to the normal volume it had before the competition between ocean steamships enabled the pauper and criminal element to be dumped upon our shores by the hundreds of thousands.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Mrs. Mackay's reply to the assertion made by Prince Colonna, that his wife, stepdaughter of Mr. Mackay, the American millionaire, drew and spent the entire amount of money Mr. Mackay sent to her, is that Prince Colonna forced his wife to draw checks in favor of servants, who cashed them and turned the money thus obtained over to the Prince.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- The last business day of the year and a full band of music made the volume of business small. Transactions were difficult and unsatisfactory. The traders who have been short of New-England and Atchison put out new lines, but, as they covered up somewhat before the close, prices stiffened.

The year 1893 began in doubt and ended in disaster. It is not true, as stated in some quarters, that 1893 began with "all business stimulated by high hopes." Its opening found the financial community in a state of serious concern over the currency situation. The gravest fears were expressed that disaster impended from that source.
That work on the building of the new drive, commonly known as the speedway, has not yet been commenced has been the cause of impatient remarks by thousands of local owners of fast horses.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- The charter of the Louisiana State Lottery Company, obtained in the Constitutional Convention of 1869, to last for twenty-five years, expired by limitation, and the last drawing took place at 4 o'clock to-day. There were nearly a thousand policy shops scattered over New-Orleans, and each one of these transacted its last business to-day.

When Oscar Wilde wrote his play, "A Woman of No Importance," he expected Charles Coghlan to play the part of Lord Illingworth, and he built his leading character, so to speak, about that actor. It was a great disappointment to the author when he found that Mr. Coghlan was not to be in the cast, and he promptly expressed his regrets by cable.

Justice Voorhis, who administers justice to lawbreakers in the Essex Market Police Court, had an argument yesterday with Lawyer Mark Atler as to the Old Testament. Mr. Atler was present as counsel for John Burns and John Morris, charged with having robbed Edward Collins of Brooklyn, in Forsyth Street, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The Montclair Athletic Club has been disbanded. The cozy little white clubhouse on Valley Road is locked up tight, the athletic grounds and toboggan slides are deserted, and there is hard feeling among those who were the club's members. The cause of the whole trouble is liquor. The club'a demise, however, is a rather unusual temperance object lesson, being a result, not of intemperance, but of prohibition.
A burglar, who gave his name as George Ellis of 103 Prince Street, was caught by George Degenhardt, Jr., plundering his father's saloon, 349 West Fifty-ninth Street, about 2:30 yesterday morning.

MADISON, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Grace Church was reopened to-day, after being closed more than four months while undergoing alterations. This edifice occupies one of the most attractive and beautiful sites in the town and is within a hundred yards of the station. The building is about 30 by 100 feet, and is built entirely of stone.

PEEKSKILL, Dec. 31 -- Coffin S. Brown, who was a prominent citizen and Democratic politician of this city for many years, and who died suddenly several years ago, was considered eccentric, as was also his wife. The fine Brown farm, where the couple lived, was bought last year by Dr. E.D. M. Lyon.
The Gansevoort Carriage Company, Tenth Avenue and Thirteenth Street, is offering a large number of carriages and traps at surprisingly low prices, when the quality of the goods la considered.

We have repeatedly urged our readers to give to charity at this time all that they can. We have to urge them with equal emphasis to give through responsible agents, except in cases where they can satisfy themselves that the need is real and that the needy are unable to get work or unable to do work.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 31 -- The Dutch tank steamer La Flandre, Capt. Schmick, seventeen days from Antwerp for New-York, in ballast, arrived here this morning. Her port bow was crushed in and all her compartments were flooded with water.

Mr. SPRINGER, Chairman of the Committee of Banking and Currency of the House of Representatives, has published a synopsis of his banking bill which he will lay before his committee this week. Chairman SPRINGER is opposed to the unconditional repeal of the tax on the circulation of State banks, in which he is supported by the general sentiment of the business men of the country.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Some of us ministers who regularly read the religious papers are somewhat more than amused at the way in which they are discussing the Hawaiian question. A few months ago they were claiming that not since the early conquest of the Roman Empire by Christianity had there been another to anywhere equal it, save the victory of Christianity over the cannibals of the Sandwich Islands.

Martin M. Becker, who lives in St. Louis and is said to be one of the Superintendents of the Wabash Railroad system, made an attempt Saturday to take his two little children from his wife, who, for a week, has been living with her aunt, Mrs. Rose of 264 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street.

STAPLETON, S.I., Dec. 31 -- The "machine" candidates who have been declared elected and will take their seats to-morrow are: Stephen D. Stephens, County Judge and Surrogate, 608 plurality; John J. Kenney, County Clerk, 156 plurality; Hubbard R. Yetman, School Commissioner, 8 plurality.
To the Editor of Hardware: I notice In your issue of Dec. 25 protests against the Wilson Tariff bill from hardware merchants in Pittsburg and Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- There has been more or less discussion of the statehood question in the holiday recess, and the prospect is that when Congress shall reconvene the friends of statehood from the four remaining Territories will begin an active campaign with an eye to their admission to the Union.

In a collision between a Brooklyn fire engine and a trolley car yesterday afternoon the engineer was run over and killed, several other firsmen were injured, the trolley car was thrown off the rails and badly injured, and the engine itself was nearly wrecked.

The following tables show monthly and aggregate sales of grain, flour, and pro- visions at the Produce Exchange for 1893. Comparisons are also given for a series of years. Average prices for 1893 are not yet accurately computed, but it is known that they are the lowest on record, running approximately 20 cents per bushel for grain below the average of the last ten years.

In his address before the Society for Ethical Culture in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning, Dr. Stanton Coit, speaking on the subject, "Abraham Lincoln's Method: a Lesson for Social Reformers," touched briefly on the wage question and the sufferings among the poor of New-York.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31 -- The Maryland Legislature will convene on Wednesday. The session probably will be one of the liveliest in the history of the State. The leading issue is the question of a new assessment, with the usual antagonism between the city and the country, between the farmer and the money man.

The measure which has been reported in the House for continuing the task of seaboard defense strikes a happy mean between the liberal appropriation which, would be justified in ordinary times and that mistaken frugality that withholds funds absolutely needed. The fortifications acts of the Fifty-first Congress carried respectively $4,232,935 and $3,774,803.
M. Coquelin and Mme. Jane Hading, who will appear in "Thermidor" at Abbey's Theatre to-night, came to this city yesterday from Boston.

"Deacon" William Richardson, ex-President of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company, in Brooklyn, died at 3 o'clock yesterday morning at his home, 125 South Oxford Street, that city, of a complication of ailments.

In the table of receipts and payments at the Sub-Treasury for 1893, compared with 1892, the only item requiring explanation is that of pensions. Pension payments decreased at this point in 1893 only because much money heretofore disbursed here was paid out elsewhere, to save expressage from New-York to distant parts of the country.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 31 -- The police of this city have reason to believe that three members of the desperate gang of masked housebreakers that have been operating successfully in this city and Newtown for several months are locked up in the Second Precinct Police Station on Fourth Street, this city.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 31 -- Yale's new trophy room has Just been finished, and during the present holiday vacation workmen have been busy in removing thither the relics of Yale's victories by land and sea since the beginning of intercollegiate athletics years ago. Previous to this time the trophies have been scattered, but they are now collected in the greatest aggregation of athletic relics in the world.
"Adams Mitchell, 5 Perry Street, decorators and upholsterers. Shades, draperies, parlor furniture, and carpets. Lace curtains done up equal to new."
To the Editor of The New-york Times: I have read with much satisfaction your excellent articles opposing the objectionable and inquisitorial Internal revenue tax upon personal incomes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Two prominent shipbuilders have appealed to Secretary Herbert from the recommendations of the naval boards which conducted the final trial trips of the Machias and the Columbia. Messrs. Cramp Song, the builders of the Columbia, and the Bath Iron Works, where the Machias was constructed, have represented to the Navy Department that the boards imposed hardships on the firms, and Secretary Herbert has recognized the contention.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, in his sermon yesterday morning, made vague allusions to a possible movement on the part of the police to assist in bringing about a new stare of affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- There is serious trouble ahead in regard to the title to recently-acquired Indian lands, an empire themselves in extent. The development of the difficulty has been gradual, but the gravity of the matter is now fully appreciated, and it is possible that the question may come up for action immediately on the reassembling of Congress.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The National Skating Association proposes to hold its championship races here on Jan. 25, and, if the Shrewsbury River freezes over before that date, much sport may be looked for at this place. The North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club will have charge of the affair, as they have made a bid for the races, and their proposition was accepted.

The National Free Art League, having its headquarters at 145 West Fifty-fifth Street, has issued the following letter to the press in support of the clause for free art in the Wilson bill to reform the tariff:

Macmillan Co. will publish a biography of Joseph Jefferson, by William Winter, who is now engaged in writing it. They will bring it out in a style uniform with Mr. Winter's biography of Edwin Booth, which is already entering upon its third edition.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The usual crowd gathered outside St. Paul's Cathedral between 11 and 12 o'clock to welcome the new year. Most of the crowd were well dressed and were bent on uproarious jollity. They gulped down whisky and shouted music-hall choruses, drowning the voices of the few who tried to sing hymns or make religious addresses.

Only the signature of Judge McAdam of the Superior Court is now necessary to grant to Mrs. Annie Odell Allen a decree of divorce from her husband, Harry Allen, a grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. Ex-Judge Henry E. Howland, the referee appointed to hear testimony in the case, has filed his report recommending that the divorce be granted.

Philip Auserhe, 355 East Eighty-eighth Street, has discovered a new, quick, cheap, and sure method of reaching the height of Bacchic pleasure. He tried it Saturday night. It worked like a charm, and he appeared before Judge Welde, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The Government's first encounter with the Conservative-Clerical coalition will take place on the issue of the extraordinary marine credits. The official theory is that the Chancellor has assured the passage of the military and naval extra credits and of the Russian commercial treaty, which is all he wants from the Reichstag.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Monday night will be a night of caucuses. The Republican Senators will meet in the Senate Chamber, the Democratic Senators in the room of Lieut. Gov. Sheehan. The Republican members of the Assembly will gather in the Assembly Chamber, the Democratic members in the Assembly parlor.

The revival of Bonapartism in France is one of the moat striking of current phenomena. About the extent of it there can be no doubt. Literature and the stage and journalism are very largely given up to it The only question about it is whether it has any "political significance," and the better opinion seems to be that it has not.

Nathanicl Wheeler. Nathaniel Wheeler, President of the Wheeler Wilson Manufacturing Company, died at his home in Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday morning. He had been suffering from a disease of the stomach for three months, and his condition had been hopeless for several weeks.

Mrs. Mary Northrop, nee McDonald, once Principal at Castleton, Isle of Man, of the Royal School for Officers' Daughters, and of late years a confirmed dipsomaniac, who was as nomadic in her habits as an Arab, died yesterday morning on "The Terrace" under Beekman Hill under circumstances which the police consider peculiar enough for thorough investigation.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: The Society of Decorative Art received four medals for its work at the Columbian Exposition, also the following testimony from The Staats-Zeitung:

The Knights of Labor have suffered another loss in this city by the withdrawal of a large number of painters from the order. Progressive Painters' Unipn, No. 6, had about 300 members, and on Friday evening about 180 of them met in Odd Fellows' Hall, at 98 Forsyth Street, and decided to leave the Knights of Labor and to return their charter as a local assembly to the General Executive Board.

Eleven indictments, seven for felonies, which are State prison offenses, and four for misdemeanors, almost upset the big Chief of the Coney Island Police. For the first time in years, McKane is worried.

In the address made by him on entering upon the duties of his office. Mayor Hopkins set forth his policy regarding three important points. It is the sincere desire of all good citizens, regardless of their political preferences, that he will carry out his intentions.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 31 -- The Legislature will meet Jan. 8, and the Republican caucus for United States Senator will be held soon after in the same week. There will be a hard fight for the Senatorship. The candidates are almost evenly matched, with their order of strength about like this: John H. Gear, A.B. Cummins, W.P. Hepburn, George D. Perkins, John Y. Stone, John F. Lacey, and L.S. Coffin.

This octavo volume of about 350 pages has to do principally with a description of a colony situated in the outskirts of Bielefeld, a manufacturing town of Westphalia, Germany. According to this description, which is very full in many directions, and so straightforward on its main lines as to appear trustworthy, the enterprise is a very remarkable one, having a much larger scope and better results than the ordinary charitable undertaking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- W.T. Harris, the United States Commissioner of Education, to-day made public the report of the Committee of Ten on Secondary School Studies, appointed at the meeting of the National Educational Association, held in July, 1892, at Saratoga, N.Y.

The Red Star Lane steamship Rhynland, which readied this port early yesterday morning from Antwerp, four days overdue, brought a story of storm and havoc at sea such as the big liners rarely have to tell. When the steamship was docked in Jersey City ambulances were watting, and they took three injured sea-men to Christ Hospital.

Yesterday's Times, over which for the three hundred and sixty-fifth and last time appeared the figures "1893," made an admirable termination for the newspaper year. Its twenty pages were, as always, most diversely interesting, and every one of them showed at least one of the new features of progress which have of late marked this journal.

Owing to circumstances of various kinds, the year of grace 1894 will be ushered into existence under what may be called conditions of the utmost parsimony. Hitherto each Annus Domini has arrived in a carriage and four, so to speak, and been received with a feu de joie fired out of an indefinite and innumerable number of guns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The contest for the position of United States Marshal of Kansas continues to attract attention here, where the principal contestants are novv encamped. The candidates, ex-Marshal W. C. Jones of Iola and Dr. Neely of Leavenworth, have been here ever since the resignation of Marshal R.L. Walker was received at the White House.

CHICHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The well-known bear hunters Nate Hill, Fred Simon, Dubois Brush, and John Moon started a day or two ago, with two dogs, to hunt rabbits. Their destination was Spruce Mountain, only a few miles from Chichester. After they got into the woods, one of the dogs commenced barking.

Excellent work is being done in the Educational Department of the Young Men's Institute, at 222 Bowery. An exhibit was recently made of the free-hand, mechanical, and architectural drawings, and the examination papers and specimens of work in penmanship, bookkeeping, shorthand, and typewriting. English grammar, electricity, steam engineering, and carriage drafting.

PARIS, Idaho, Jan. 1 -- The fourth trial of the now celebrated Hillmon case in the Federal court, at Topeka, Kan., next February, and the presence in this city of Detective John Sawhan have close connection. The promise is made that at last the true inwardness or a conspiracy to defeat justice and at the same time defraud the New-York Life Insurance Company and the Connecticut Mutual will be brought to light.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 1 -- The textile workers and workmen employed in the industrial establishments of this city claim they were tricked into attending a Republican protection mass meeting Saturday evening. They are indignant over the matter.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 1 -- A law suit between the New-York and New-England and the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroads, growing out of the latter road's taking off the 6:25 train from this city to New-York, is probable. This train has heretofore been consolidated with one on the New-York and New-England Road.

Henry Anthon, who died early Sunday morning from heart disease, at his home, 13 West Thirty-fifth Street, was the son or the late Rev. Dr. Henry Anthon, rector of St. Mark's Church, and nephew of the late Prof. Charles Anthon, the author of many widely-known Latin and Greek text books. Mr. Anthon's death was very sudden, being preceded by an illness of only an hour.

When the stanch Guion liner Virginian arrived at her dock at the foot of West Twenty-ninth Street yesterday morning she showed evidences of having encountered severe weather, as was told in The New-York Times of Monday. The bridge was badly wrenched, and the iron stanchions were twisted in all sorts of fantastic shapes.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 1 -- Two men were fairly cooked alive in a terrible boiler explosion that occurred at 10 o'clock this morning in the roundhouse of the Cincinnati Southern Railway. Charles Beckert, a boilermaker, was engaged in repairing an engine which came in last night with a leak in the steam flues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The British Ambassador and Lady Pauncefote gave a small dance, followed by a cotillion, tonight, in honor of the debut of their daughter, Miss Lillian Pauncefote. The drawing rooms were decorated with palms. Lady Pauncefote received in a gown of black satin, with trimmings of pink satin.

The Young Men's Christian Association grave its customary New Year's Day reception to young men yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the association. Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. During the afternoon there were recitations and music in the reading room and parlors.

-- Several members of the old Voorhis Democracy in the Ninth Assembly District went into the Tammany Hall organization in that district at the primary election Saturday night. The list was headed by Col. Edward Glion, one or the City Assessors, and included Dr. Alonzo Blauvelt, Patrick J. Leavy, Denis Markey, W.S. Finn, Henry Buthter, Charles W. Walters, S.B. Crapper, and Cornelius Van Keuren.

Ashbel P. Fitch took charge of the Controller's office at noon yesterday, and Theodore W. Myers, who has been Controller for the last six years, retired from official life. Controller Myers reached the office at 10 o'clock and wound up his affairs. Mr. Fitch arrived just about noon, and Postmaster Charles W. Dayton, Isidor Straus, who will succeed Mr. Fitch in Congress; Edward P. Steers, and John C. Delavergne came in with him.

RICHMOID, Va., Jan. 1 -- Charles T. O'Ferrall was inaugurated Governor of Virginia to-day, with more pomp and display, perhaps, than have characterized any previous occasion of this sort New Year's Day is a legal holiday, and public buildings, banks, railroad offices, and many business houses were practically closed, so that the people of the city had an opportunity to some out and witness the ceremony.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 1 -- Capt. Picking of the cruiser Charleston, who is in command of the American naval squadron here, has issued an order to the commanders of the vessels of the fleet, instructing them to cut off the shore leave hitherto given to the seamen, marines, and others of the crews.

Society goes out of town for New Years in these days. That is to say, it is supposed to flee from the metropolis. As a matter of fact, all of it doesn't, but by the aid of one of those polite little fictions which act as the lubricants of life, it is supposed to be in parts remote.

The third performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The cast has been changed at each successive performance for the better, and that of last night was the best of all. It seems to be an important part of the policy of the present managers of the house to endeavor to attract the public by strong combinations of singers.

The question of timing sprinters and cyclists has been discussed at great length by the sporting authorities of England and America, and there appears to be a difference of opinion regarding the best watch to use. In amateur circles in both countries the fifth-second stop and fly-back is universally used, but among professionals the old-fashioned side-movement watch that records yards, and not fractional parts of seconds, has the call.

When the Extraordinary Grand Jury lately sitting in Brooklyn, which is to be credited with having heaped his eleven blushing indictments thick upon John Y. McKane, adjourned without day, there was one important question it had to leave unsolved. The question was, Who was Policeman No. 11, who took part in the McKane riots at Gravesend?

-- Last night at Koster Bial's, new features of the programme were the reappearance in America of Letta and Foden, hand balancers and tumblers; first appearance in this country of the Zenatta Troupe, Japanese jugglers; the performance of Jessican on the wire, O'Brien and Redding in a comic sketch, and the Crescendos, electrical clowns, who have made a great hit.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times moat reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 -- A very peculiar condition exists here as to the proposed international "slugging" match between Corbett and Mitchell, which has been now set down to take place between the hours of 11 A.M. and 6 P.M. an the 25th inst. If ever a community was humbugged the good citizens of this city have been by the promoters of the fight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Chilean Government has notified Secretary of State Gresham that it cannot accept the proposition of the United States for an extension of the existence of the United States and Chilean Claims Commission, now in session in this city. State Department officials refuse to discuss the matter, but it is known that they are somewhat disappointed at the failure to secure the desired extension.

Policeman Martin Milmarr of the Twentieth Precinct, Brooklyn, celebrated the death of the old year, Sunday, by getting drunk. He notified everybody on his beat that he intended to honor them with a New Year's visit. When suspended from duty for his misbehavior, he tried to murder a schoolboy.
MANCHESTER, Jan. 1 -- The Manchester Ship Canal was opened to traffic to-day, and the city thereby becomes a port of entry. The banks of the canal were lined by 750,000 spectators.

On a field completely covered with snow the Thistle Football Club of Paterson gave a splendid exhibition of association football against the Americus Athletic Association team yesterday afternoon at Hoboken. The players at times found it difficult to keep their feet, and "spills" were numerous, but no accident occurred of a serious nature.

A fire in the tall apartment house known is Earlscourt, at 136 and 138 Madison Avenue, on the northwest corner of Thirty-first Street, yesterday afternoon, caused by the explosion of an ammonia tank in the cellar, created a great deal of excitement among the tenants, but there were no casualties.

Joseph Jefferson, as President of The Players, passed the loving cup for the first time in the celebration of "Founder's Day" on New Year's Eve. He also on this occasion made his first speech as President, and spoke in loving terms of his predecessor, Edwin Booth. In speaking of the founder of The Players, Mr. Jefferson said:

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- In the new play of the Gymnase Theatre, the "Duchesse de Montelimar," M. Albin Valabregue, the author, endeavors to give a new tune to the old-fashioned Moliere air of the gentleman bourgeois. Mme. Bonnardel suddenly inherits a fortune of several millions of francs, and the family leave their provincial home and come to Paris to set into society.

Mr. EDWIN H. FITLER of Philadelphia, a manufacturer of binding twine, made some doleful and rather surprising remarks in the last week of the old year, which are reported by the Philadelphia Press under an impressive series of sympathetic headlines, one of which asserts that be " Sees Ruin Ahead."

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Annie Wise, an Anarchist arrested outside of St. Paul's Cathedral last night, was arraigned in the Mansion House Police Court to-day to answer to a charge of rioting. The prisoner said that she was only doing her duty in attempting to call public attention to the misery of the unemployed.

The small boys of Brooklyn thought yesterday that Buffalo Bill and his show had come to town to pay them a New Year's call when four large omnibuses, loaded with the roughest and toughest lot of wild Westerners ever seen in the peaceful City of Churches were driven up Fulton Street from the ferry.
Dr. Francis Minot Weld, a distinguished Burgeon and physician, died on Sunday at Jamaica Plain, Mass. He was formerly a resident of New-York.

New Year's was a cold day in ring circles in Brooklyn. This fact did not escape the earnest attention of the members of the Police Department, who have been taking careful observations of the temperature ever since Charles A. Schieren was elected Mayor on Nov. 7.

LENOX, Mass., Jan. 1 -- The marriage of Alice Greenleaf, the second daughter of Dr. R.C. Greenleaf, to William Adams of New-York took place at Trinity Church, in Lenox, at 12:30 to-day. It was the first New Year's wedding that has ever taken place in Lenox among the society people. The church was completely filled with guests from New-York, Boston, and other cities.
Some of the New-Year's "spreads" at the leading hotels yesterday were like a cook's dream of the Midway Plaisance.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 1 -- Alfred E. Burr of this city completed fifty-five years of journalistic life to-day. He is the oldest newspaper man, by actual years of service, in New-England, and is still a daily occupant of the responsible editor's desk in the office of The Hartford Times. Mr. Burr became the editor of the paper, which has distinctly borne the impress of his character and genius for half a century, Jan. 1, 1839.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- 2:15 A.M. -- At 1:15 this morning an explosion of gas caused a fire in the Globe Theatre on Washington Street, between Essex Street and Hayward Place. The fire started near the scene room, and spread rapidly through the building.

There was a genuinely warm welcome in Abbey's Theatre last night for the accomplished French comedian. Constant Coquelin, a welcome participated in largely by his own compatriots, resident in New-York, though the audience included large numbers of native citizens, who remembered vividly the keen enjoyment they received from Coquelin's acting when he was here in the Winter of 1888-9.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The Yonkers Lawn Tennis Club opened its new house to-night with a reception and dance, which was attended by over 400 people. The club is composed of about 250 men and women of social standing in Yonkers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The social functions of New Year's Day were performed in the usual manner by Gov. and Mrs. Flower. The Governor's well-known liberality in providing entertainment attracted quite a number to the Executive Mansion between 3 and 5 o'clock. While the reception at the Capitol was larger than usual, that at the mansion was not as largely attended as usual.

At the lecture room of the Methodist Episcopal Church in East Seventeenth Street, where the Rev. Isaac Naylor has been conducting evangelistic services recently, several hundred men and one woman were served with hearty breakfasts at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The woman, the wife of one of the men, was in need of immediate assistance.

New-York may possibly be spared the disgrace of having an avowed Anarchist, a man who has openly commented upon the laws of the land, an unbeliever in Christianity, a preacher of various harum-scarum ideas, in the important place of an Assistant Public Prosecutor.
