Through the co-operation of Columbia College and Cooper Union a practical course of lectures is to be given this Winter in the large hall of Cooper Union to the electrical workers of New-York. The need of such a course of public lectures at a nominal cost has been seriously felt for several years.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $2,877,375. The banks now hold $80,815,150 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the average show an increase in loans ot $1,319,900, an increase in specie or $1,795,700, an increase in legal tenders of $2,979,200, an increase in deposits of $7,590,100, and a decrease in circulation of $2,877,375.

William H. Grimm, the missionary attached to Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, whose matrimonial troubles were exposed two months ago, is a prisoner in Raymond Street Jail. He is held on a charge of bigamy. He arrived in Brooklyn yesterday from Fort Wayne, Ind., in the custody of Detective Bagnarello, of District Attorney Ridgway's staff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Old as the custom is, familiar as has become every incident of it to the men and women who have lived in Washington through many Administrations, the New Year ceremony at the White House has asserted its hold once again upon the people of the national capiial.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Gov. Flower will issue a proclamation to-morrow modifying the proclamation of last week with reference to the special election far members of Congress to be hold in New-York City. The date for the election will be changed from Jan. 23 to Jan. 30, pursuant to requests from both parties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Vice President and Mrs. Stevenson received at the Normandle from 2 until 5 o'clock. The parlors on the first floor were taxed to their utmost capacity to accommodate the callers, the majority of whom went there directly from the White House. The rooms in which the reception was held were emptied of their usual furniture, as space was the most desirable requisite of the occasion.

A suave, well-informed man, who posed as the Rev. N.C. Cantwell, a converted Roman Catholic priest, in search, of light, truth, peace of heart, and incidentally also of free board and pocket money, has been imposing upon-several clergymen in this city. He even went so far as trying to persuade Archbishop Corrigran that he had repented and wanted to return to the fold of the Church he had left.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Gen. F.M. Aguirre of Honduras is among the arrivals here from Central America. The General says that, while war between Honduras and Nicaragua is imminent, diplomats from different Central American Governments are now making a patch-up between the two republics.

It is the fortune, good or ill, or, perhaps, good and ill, of plays like "The Rivals" to serve as reminders of great things greatly done by great actors in the past, rather than as objects of consideration, in themselves and material upon which actors of the present day can exercise their powers of conception and expression.
Three thousands persons, irrespective of party, wished Mayor Charles A. Schieren a happy New Year in the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The opinion of Senator Morgan on the questions arising in the Bering Sea arbitration, which were filed with the Secretary of the tribunal at Paris last Saturday, were not so voluminous as those of his associate arbitrator, Justice Harlan, although, there were more of them.
Columbia won the intercollegiate chess chamionship yesterday, with a total of 8 1/2 games won. Harvard stands second, with 7; Yale third, with 5, and Princeton last, with 3 1/2.

One of the bills which Thomas C. Platt has caused to be prepared for submission to the Legislature seeks to provide for a nonpartisan Police Board in this city. This bill is now said to be in the hands of Senator O'Connor, and it is complete except for the clause which has to do with the question as to who shall do the appointing.

Entries for three important stakes announced by the Coney Island Jockey Club will close to-day. These are for the Futurity Stakes for 1896, to which the club will add, as last year, $17,500; the Double Event and the Great Trial Stakes, both for two-year-olds, to be run at the June meeting this year. The former is a guaranteed stakes of $10,000, and the latter one of $20,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -- The mystery surrounding the case of Miss May Barrowcliff remains as impenetrable as ever. The police still hold to the theory that Miss Barrowcliff was assaulted by a man whom she knew and with whom she went voluntarily across the lot where she was found, but they have made no visible headway in solving the mystery.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Patrick Eugene Joseph Prendergast was on his dignity again to-day. When his breakfast was served he was asked if he wanted coffee to drink. "No," he snarled. Two hours later the condemned assassin demanded that Clerk Ben Price be sent for. When Mr. Price appeared Prendergast complained that he had not received his coffee.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- George Youngs, son of H.W. Youngs, was shot in the breast last night by some one of a party of revelers who were out celebrating the advent of the new year.
There was no racing at Guttenberg yesterday. It was the first time this so-called sport was omitted there since 1888.

Alexander Melville, thirty-two years old, of 284 Third Avenue, while on his way home at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, encountered a stranger at Twenty-third Street and First Avenue, and quarreled with him about some trivial matter. The stranger drew a pocket knife and stabbed Melville twice in the calf of the leg and once in the abdomen.

There was a general taking possession of office yesterday by those elected last November, and it produced considerable change of political complexion. At Albany Republicans took charge of the executive departments for the first time since 1883, except that the candidacy of MAYNARD for Secretary of State in that year led to the continuance of CARR in that office for two years more.

"Africa's" Explorer Married. -- John A. Coleman, the explorer of "Africa," who begins at the Star Theater where Stanley left off, received a wife for a New Year's gift, and very few of his friends discovered it until yesterday. On Sunday evening, with a few whom he had taken into his confidence, he went over to Brooklyn and was there quietly married to Miss Laura Millard, formerly the prima donna of the "Africa" company.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 1 -- The Globe National Bank to-day passed its dividend, the result of the defalcation by Teller Bennett. A messenger boy has been found who, on Wednesday last, the day before the flight, was summoned by Bennett to a well-known resort and given $20 to purchase a mileage book on the Consolidated Railroad.

One of the latest rumors in football circles is one from Princeton to the effect that the leaders of the sport at old Nassau are agitating the question of organizing a league to be composed of Harvard, Yale, University of Pennsylvania and Princeton. As yet nothing definitet has been done, but it is understood that Princeton will make the initiative move at the first opportunity.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 1 -- The trio of alleged masked burglars arrested last night by Detectives White and Welsh were arraigned in the police court this morning. Justice Duffy was on the bench, and at the request of the detectives he remanded the prisoners until Friday, in order to give them more time to obtain evidence against the men.

Thus gracefully did Col. Thomas Wentworth Higginson in an autographic note express his gratitude to the Cantabrigia Club of Cambridge, Mass., for orchids presented to him on his seventieth birthday: "Let me not thank the Cantabrigia Club verbally alone for the magnificent cyprepediams which led only to the inconvenience that they inspire in my visitors an inextinguishable envy and uncharitableness.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- Nathan Matthews, Jr., was to-day inaugurated Mayor for the fourth time. Chief Justice Field of the Supreme Court administering the oath of office, who, in turn, swore in the members of the city council. The Aldermen elected Alpheus Sanford Chairman of the board and Christopher F. O'Brien was chosen President of the Common Council.

Doubtless the caucus action at Albany last night will determine the organization of the two houses of the Legislature to-day, and the action of the Republican caucuses was a mere ratification of the decrees of " Boss" PLATT. This shows that PLATT controls a majority of the majority, but it does not prove that he can control the majority of the whole Legislature.

The brightness of the New Year penetrated even into the Egyptian gloom of the City Prison. At present the Tombs Is giving unasked-for board and lodging to 413 prisoners, 375 of whom, axe men, 73 are women, and 38 are boys. It is a matter of congratulation that there are no girls.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Three hundred and fourteen years ago the English navigator Sir Francis Drake made a landing from his ship, the Golden Hinde, at what has since been known as Drake's Bay, and Francis Flitcher, a Presbyter of the Church of England and Chaplain of the Golden Hinde, preached the first sermon in the English tongue on the Pacific coast.

The new financial plan under which the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad is to be reorganized will be issued in circular form to-day. It bears the signature of all of the Directors and is addressed to the holders of the second consolidated mortgage bonds, the funded coupon bonds of 1885, the income bonds, and the preferred and common stock.

Throughout the year, but particularly at this season, when the city is dependent upon the tropics for its fruit supply, almost every steamer entering this port brings a number of many-footed stowaways. The steamers which bring the most of these stowaways are those that come from the West Indies and Central America, loaded with bananas, and a naturalist will always be rewarded by a visit to any of the piers where these vessels unload.

There is one subject that may very well engage the attention of the Constitutional Convention about which nothing has heretofore been said, and that is the propriety of a change in the mode of choosing what are called the State officers. The present method of choosing them probably results from the adoption of a false and vicious analogy concerning their functions.

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 30 -- The week in the local stock market has been one almost devoid of transactions, only a few shares having changed hands at private sale. Providence Gas has sold at 80, ex dividend, and some few shares of Commercial National Bank at 45@46 1/2. The bid price for Old National Bank has advanced 4 points upon the declaration of the regular semi-annual dividend of 3 per cent., payable Jan. 1.

The arrest of MITCHELL and CORBETT in Florida was evidently a very friendly affair intended to head off the other MITCHELL, who happens to be Governor of the State, from interfering with the prize fight that has been arranged to come off at Jacksonville on the 25th inst.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 7/8 @1 1/2 per cent., the average being about 1 per cent.

Panic-stricken by a fire which started from candles on a Christmas tree in apartments on the fourth floor of the five-story flat house 548 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street last night, a mother jumped from a front window to the street with her four-months-old baby in her arms.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 1 -- A hearing was held here this afternoon before Judge William Townsend of the United States District Court, to show why Sheriff Preston of Hartford County should not be held in contempt for attaching rolling stock belonging to the New-England Railroad alter a receiver for that road had been appointed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- There is a dead-lock in the Common Council in this city. It was revealed to-day, when an attempt was made to organize the board, which stands eight Democrats to six Republicans. George Briggs, a Democrat, voted with the Republicans, which made the vote on organization stand 7 and 7.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- There was paid from the Treasury of the State of New-York in 1892 about $2,250,000 for charity. This amount was distributed among asylums for the deaf and dumb, the blind, and the insane and feeble-minded; the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, and the reformatory institutions for juvenile delinquents.

Charity turned, hostess yesterday and kept open house for the hungry. Her tables were abundantly supplied. No grand lady ever had so many or such appreciative guests, for thousands in this city to whom the new year must otherwise have opened cheerlessly had their hearts warmed through their stomachs.
The body of Mrs. Mary Northrop, found in the sand of the Terrace, under Beekman Hill, Sunday morning, will not be consigned to the oblivion of Potter's Field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- In so far as the judgment of the Ways and Means Committee can affect the question of taxation of individual incomes, it has been expressed, and in favor of the tax. That was the decision in the meeting held late this afternoon. Net incomes of $4,000 or over, whether of corporations or individuals, are to be subject to a tax of 2 per cent.

-- Sergrt. James G. Cooper, Jr., was tried at Police Headquarters for shooting Frederick Dallin, a boy, with bird shot in Veria Avenue, Woodlawn, on Hallowe'en and for arresting Dallin'a comrade. Robert Paul and not taking him to the police station. The Grand Jury would not indict Sergt. Cooper for the more serious offense.

Peter L. Bretz, livery stable keeper, of 518 West Forty-eighth Street, has a claim of several hundred dollars against the Standard Gaslight Company for the loss of a team of horses which yesterday morning plunged into an unilghted and unguarded trench for a main of the company at Forty-third Street and Broadway.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 2 -- At the annual election of Directors of the Terre Haute and Indianapolis Railway yesterday the following were elected: W.R. McKeen, John G. Williams, D.W. Minshall, and H. Hulman of this cits; James N. McCrea, John E. Davidson, and J.T. Brooks of Pittsburg.

An Oyer and Terminer Grand Jury was impaneled in Brooklyn yesterday to continue the work of investigating election frauds, begun by the Extraordinary Grand Jury drawn in December. The latter body would have been continued in existence had there not been a doubt as to the legality of such a proceeding.

John A.P. Fisk closed a career of forty-seven years as a restaurant keeper down town by posting a notice yesterday on the door at 76 Broad Street that he had made a general assignment to George A. Minasian. The causes were declining business and large expenses. For the property which the restaurant occupied at 76 Broad Street and 10 and 12 Marketfield Place he paid $14,500 a year.
THE AGRICULTURAL DEPARTMENT contains The Growth of Trees, by Henry Stewart; Tuberculosis in Cows, Farm Experiences, and Answers to Correspondents, with other valuable and interesting matter.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Gov. Roswell P. Flower to-day transmitted his annual message to the Legislature, as follows:

The Municipal Art Society is a young bird, but its wings are sufficiently grown to try a flight in a direction novel enough to New-York. The new building for the Criminal Courts on Centre Street near the Tombs is chosen for the first attempt to bring decorative art in painting to bear on the adornment of halls to which the public have access.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- Money between banks to-day was nominally 1 per cent.; in reality, it was difficult to give away. Street call rates were 1 1/2 @ 3 per cent. Time money was easy at 3 1/2 @ 4 per cent, on prime collaterals.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 2 -- In the Criminal Court of Record this morning the attorneys for Corbett and Mitchell appeared and, confidently expecting that Judge Phillips would decide the case against them, had their clients in the Circuit Court, where arrangements had been made for a hearing by Judge Call to-morrow, on a motion that a writ of habeas corpus be issued and the men released.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The Right Rev. Francis McNierney, Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany, died at 8:30 o'clock to-night at the episcopal residence in this city from typhoid pneumonia.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 2 -- Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor opened the January term of the Queens County Supreme Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer here to-day. The courtroom was crowded with lawyers, jurors, witnesses, and spectators, all anxious to get a look at the new Justice.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The opening day of the session was grasped by the Democratic leaders to demonstrate their realization of the signs of the times. In the Assembly, besides attempting to introduce the eight-hundred-and-fifty-thousand-dollar Capitol appropriation bill, Leader Sulzer (Dem., New-York,) made an effort to bring before the House a ballot-reform bill which provides for a blanket ballot.

Col. Edward Hincken, the oldest and best-known shipping broker down town, is lying unconscious at the house of a relative up town, and his physicians hold out no hope that he will recover. He had a stroke of paralysis Sunday, which seems to have involved nearly all of his functions. He never suffered from anything of the kind before.

OSWEGO, Jan. 2 -- It was announced this evening that Miss Pauline Babcock, daughter of Bronson Babcock, had been married to Allen Stuart McGie, a private in the United States Ninth Infantry, stationed at Fort Ontario. The marriage was a secret one.

Gov. FLOWER appears to unusual advantage in his annual message to the Legislature. The document itself is a businesslike review of the more important interests of the State, and its suggestions are for the most part judicious. There is scarcely a trace of the spirit of partisanship in its treatment of public questions or of party purpose in the recommendation of legislative measures.

SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The moquette mills of the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, at Yonkers, will resume work to-morrow. These works have been shut down for six months and employ 4,000 men, women, and children, and pay out wages aggregating about $100,000 a month, the loss of which has been severely felt by the operatives and merchants of the city.

Under foreclosure of a mechanic's lien, Messrs. Smyth Ryan sold at auction in the Trinity Building yesterday a four-story stone-front dwelling and lot for $3, subject, however, to prior incumbrances of about $30,000. The property is at 164 West Seventy-eighth Street, and the dimensions are 20 by 102.2. Mary M. Kellard was the defendant.
Francis T. Walton, or "Plunger" Walton, as he is often called, who is proprietor of the Grand Hotel, at Broadway and Thirty-first Street, made an assignment yesterday to his son, Charles L. Walton.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- The peasants in a village in the Province of Trapani seized a Tax Collector this morning and arraigned him before a mock tribunal. They convicted him of oppression, and ordered that he be shot, the community applauding. The sentence was executed. Troops have been sent to the village.

Although we referred, in our remarks about Mr. FITLER and the duty on binding twine, to the admission in Mr. THOMAS B. REED'S minority report on the Wilson bill that the present duty on binding twine is only 6 per cent., we now find that we overlooked in that amusing document something which we should have placed by the side of Mr. FITLER'S startling prediction.
Orlando B. Potter fell dead shortly before 9 o'clock last night in front of the Buckingham Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Jan. 2 -- P.M. No story of impending disaster seemed too improbable for consumption in Wall Street to-day. Rumors of disaster to banks, trust companies, and individual firms were discussed with such an air of apparent belief in their truth that the only wonder is that there was a market for securities at any price.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 2 -- The electric power station of the Inter-State and Attleborough. North Attleborough and Wrentham Electric Street Railway Companies, situated at Farmers, on the Wrentham branch of the Consolidated Railroad, was destroyed by fire, with its contents, machinery, dynamos, , at 4 o'clock this morning.

Frederick W. Dietzel, formerly a steward in the Hotel Hungaria and the Elks' Club, wants to recover $28,818, which he says he lost in a poolroom kept by Michael and James Murray, at Fourteenth Street and Fourth Avenue. The case was on trial yesterday before Judge Glegerich, in the Court of Common Pleas.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The representative of the United Press to-day had an interview with Baron de Courcel, who was President of the Tribunal of Arbitration appointed to settle the dispute between Great Britain and the United States regarding Bering Sea. Baron de Courcel said that Justice Harlan and Senator Morgan, the American arbitrators, were the only members of the tribunal who had filed opinions.

Worthington C. Smith of St. Albans, Vt., ex-member of Congress and a former Trustee and Manager of the Vermont Central and Vermont and Canada Railroads, died yesterday of paralysis. He was born in St. Albans in 1823, and was a brother of the late ex-Gov. J. Gregory Smith. He was graduated in 1846 from the University of Vermont, of which institution he was for many years a Trustee.

-- Social Register for To-day. -- Among the social functions for to-day are the following: Mrs. James Dwight Foot of 269 Lexington Avenue; at home informally 4 o'clock until 7. Mrs. John H. Linsley of 6 West Fiftieth Street; at home informally, Mrs. George S. Bowdoin of 39 Park Avenue; a dance for Miss Edith Bowdoin. Mrs. Ranney and Mrs. Richard Henry Reed of the Buckingham.

-- Ebenezer Sandford, one of the oldest and richest citizens of Hudson County, N.J., died at his home in Kearney Monday, after an illness of one week, from pneumonia. He was eighty-two years old and was a direct descendant of Capt. William Sandford, who purchased all the land which now includes Harrison. Kearney and part of Bergen County over 200 years ago from the Indians.

Mr. Charles Frohman put forward at the Empire Theatre last night, in a most tasteful manner, a play in four acts, called "Sowing the Wind," written by Mr. Sydney Grundy of London and produced there by Mr. Comyns Carr at the Comedy Theatre three months or more ago, with so much success that it is still current.

The Trustees of the Louis Down-Town Sabbath and Daily School have accepted the proffer of an amateur entertainment. This will consist of an original sketch by Charles Davis Levin, entitled, "Marie," and Gilbert's comedy, "On Bail," and will be given at the Berkeley Lyceum, Forty-fourth Street, near Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the Footlight Club, this evening and to-morrow evening.

Henry Vizitelly, whose death at Farnham, England, was announced in these columns yesterday, was in the regard of many young English artists a martyr; of many others, a great culprit; of the greater number of conservative persons, a good man who had committed a grave error, but had deserved indulgence.

The gentleman whom the Republican majority of the Senate has selected to preside for the next two years over their deliberations -- by the grace of Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan -- has the honor of having his name attached to more reform political measures than any other man ever elected to the Legislature of this State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Mrs. John D. Langhorne gave a tea this afternoon at her home, on Eighteenth Street, to introduce her daughter to society. Mrs. Langhorne received in a gown of dark heliotrope velvet and brocade. Miss Langhorne's gown was of white moire antique, with ruffles of chiffon on the corsage.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Oscar Craig, President of the State Board of Charities, died at 9 o'clock this evening at his home on South Washington Street, this city. He was born at Medina, Orleans County, on Nov. 15, 1836, of Scottish parentage. Mr. Craig at an early age entered Union College, from which he was graduated with high honors in the Spring of 1856, with the degree of A.B.

To all the mothers, grandmothers, maiden aunts, and women individually and collectively was given some good advice at the meeting of Sorosis yesterday, and if it is put at the head of the new leaf turned on Monday this new year may prove a millennium for the children.

There appeared in The Evening Post of last night a letter in which was treated at some length the tendency of several charitable institutions and experiments to pauperize the poor. The letter claimed that laborers of all classes, especially domestic servants and those who do farm work, were encouraged to abandon their situations and flock to New-York in order to profit by the largesse of its public Government and of rich private citizens.

-- John Drew in New-York. -- It is not yet definitely settled at what theatre John Drew will play his engagement in this city. Charles Frohman's contract calls for Palmer's Theatre, and it is possible that this house may be made available yet. "Prince Karn" is to go to the Casino Jan. 29 instead of the Garden, as originally planned, and this leaves the latter house open to Mr. Drew.

ELIZABETH, Jan. 2 -- Judge Van Syckel, to the surprise of the big crowd of lawyers and others present to-day at the opening of the Union County court, strongly charged the Grand Jury in reference to the scandal of granting a license of the Linden Park Blood Horse Association by the Township Committee of Linden.

There was begun before Justice Patterson yesterday, in the Supreme Court, a suit for insurance money which will be of surpassing interest, as its details unfold, to every policy holder and insurance man in the country.
Applications for the erection of the following new buildings were received yesterday by Superintendent Brady of the Building Department:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- Isaac L. Rice of New-York gained an important point to-day in his suit for the removal of the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company. Judge Butler, in the United States Circuit Court, referred the main charges to George L. Crawford, the Special Master in, litigations arising under the receivership, to take testimony.

ATLANTIC, HIGHLANDS, Jan. 2 -- Great interest is taken in the Monmouth County League bowling championship. On New Year's Day 300 men gathered at the Commercial Hotel alleys to witness a match between the teams of Asbury Park and Atlantic Highlands, lewis Foster was the umpire and Wilbur A. Campbell, Secretary or the home team, the scorer.

The Executive Committee of the Holland Trust Company, at 33 Nassau Street, decided yesterday to recommend to the Trustees at Friday's meeting that the company liquidate its affairs and retire from business. Such a course at present will give the stockholders par for their holdings, and leave something over for division among them.

Philip Ferris, a mild-mannered youth, careful and elegant in attire, polished, even elegant in manner, has been sleeping for three nights in the West Sixty-eighth Street Station, because his perfectly gentlemanly appearance is only the mask of a criminal propensity.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 2 -- The friends of Miss May Barrowcliff to-day had their hearts gladdened by the positive assurance that, in the absence of any new complications or a relapse, she would recover. She will not probably be able to tell her story fully, completely, and in intelligent form for several days, however; possibly not until the end of the week.
DAYTON, Iowa, Jan. 2 -- Two hundred miners came here last night from the little town of Frazier and took possession of a hall in which a dance was in progress.

Hugh O. Pentecost will not be an assistant to Col. John R. Fellows, the new District Attorney. This fact was authoritatively established yesterday afternoon. Col. Fellows takes to himself the credit of retracing steps, even at the eleventh hour. He declares there was no politics in the appointment in the first place, and, above all, Richard Croker had nothing to do with it.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- There is a legend among some Board of Trade operators that the first market day of the year is more auspicious for the short seller than for the buyer. Just why it should be so considered it is difficult to determine. At all events, there was considerable selling of wheat at the opening to-day. Many of the orders came from New-York, and, as a result, the start was weak.

VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- Cracow (Poland) newspapers contain accounts of a recent abortive attempt to poison the Czar. According to these reports, on the one hundred and twenty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Imperial Order of St. George, a grand dinner was given to all those who had been awarded the decoration.

For the benefit of the New-York Kindergarten Association William Hamilton Gibson will deliver in the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre a course of three lectures for children. His subject will be the "Mysteries of the Flowers," and the lectures will be delivered at 3 P.M., Jan. 6, Jan. 10, and Jan. 18.
Money on call loaned at 1 @ 1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The one hundred and seventeenth session of the Legislature of the State of New-York opened to-day with the Republicans in control of both houses and the Democrats in control of the Executive branch. The representation of the two parties in the Legislature is: Senate -- Republicans 19, Democrats 13. Assembly -- Republicans 74, Democrats 54.

The three coal yards established in different parts of the city, where fuel is supplied to the poor at actual cost, sold fully 100 tons yesterday. From early morning until the yards closed, at 5:30 o'clock in the afternoon, hundreds went to the yards and came away bearing in sacks upon their shoulders or else carrying in pails, boxes, and small wagons, sufficient coal for at least one day.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 2 -- A large crowd of unemployed men and women at an early hour this morning filled the streets in front of the Bethel, where they had for some time received their supplies of provisions from day to day. When Superintendent Raymond made his appearance he said:

The proceedings of the Kings County Board of Supervisors yesterday threw a good deal of light on the condition of mind of the old machine Democrats there. We do not pretend to know the exact provisions of law governing the cases of the three Supervisors whose right to their seats is in dispute.

Statistics recently published by the Mark Lane Express (Dec. 11) point to one of the causes of the continuing depression prices in the American wheat market. These statistics show the quantity of wheat (and flour in terms of wheat) exported in eleven months of the calendar year 1893 from the countries which produce more than they consume, and are as follows, three ciphers having been cut off at the end of each number:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The policy of the Administration to concentrate United States war ships in the harbor of Rio de Janeiro is being rapidly carried out. Telegrams received at the Navy Department report the arrival of the New-York at Santa Lucia yesterday and of the San Francisco at Pernambuco on Sunday.

The first meeting of the new Board of Supervisors of Kings County, which was held at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, was the liveliest session of that body ever held. From beginning to end pandemonium reigned. More than once it threatened to break up in a free fight.
Two steamships from ports in Brazil arrived here yesterday, bringing news of the revolution in that country.

A ripple of interest has been aroused over the meeting of the Republican State Committee, which will be held at the Fifth Av-_ enue Hotel to-morrow at 10 o'clock. It is for the purpose of reorganizing the committee, and the interest lies in the selection of a Chairman.

Frederick Seagrist was nominated for Congress last night by the Republicans of the Fifteenth District, to succeed Ashbel P. Fitch in the Fifteenth, and Lemuel E. Quigg was nominated in the Fourteenth District, to succeed Col. John R. Fellows. Under the last proclamation issued by Gov. Flower, the date of the special election to fill the vacancies in these districts was changed from Jan. 23 to Jan. 30.
One man and a child lost their lives in a fire last night in the five-story building at Pearl Street and Coenties Slip.
"The world regards Lord Illingworth as a very bad man."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The cheap lodging house on Swan Street, between Main and Washington, kept by Lizzie Hackett, was destroyed by fire at 3 o'clock this morning. Of the score or more of lodgers, two perished and all of the others were more or less seriously burned and injured.

VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- Count von Arnim, son of Count Harry von Arnim, who was driven from the German diplomatic service by Prince Bismarck, and was prosecuted for misconduct in office after the Franco-Prussian war, threatens to challenge the "Old Chancellor" to fight a duel.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- The Globe Theatre, the burning of which was announced in a dispatch to The New-York Times this morning, is a total wreck, nothing being saved from the conflagration. The fire, it is believed, was caused by a defective electric wire igniting the woodwork in the men's coatroom in the front of the theatre, under the balcony stairs.

The present political situation in the State of New-York is full of peril for the City of New-York. The combination of a Republican Legislature not over scrupulous and a Democratic Governor not over wise is what constitutes this peril. To the ingenuous and inexperienced friends of good local government this combination seems alluring.

Unless the Republican politicians who were at State Headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night are much mistaken, the State Committee will simply reelect its present officers at its meeting to-day. It was said to be foreoruained that William Brookfield will be Chairman; Charles W. Haokett, Chairman of the Executive Committee, and John S. Kenyon, Secretary.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Charles Mitchell signed the amended articles of agreement to-day, under pressure from the officials of the Duval Athletic Club.

An entertainment is to be given on Saturday evening, Jan. 27, at the Berkeley Lyceum, in aid of the Lawrence Athletic Club. This club is an organization connected with the Church of the Holy Communion. The Rev. Henry Mottet, D.D., the rector of the church, is President, the Rev. W.W. Moir Vice President, the Rev. Charles H. Eaton Treasurer, and C.W. Ogden, Jr., Secretary.

Another telephone central office was opened yesterday in the new building of the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company, at 95 Broad Street. By this addition to the company's plant the section bounded by Broadway, Wall Street, the Battery, and the East River will be served, and the Cortlandt Street station, overcrowded with the wires of 5,000 subscribers, will be greatly relieved.

The Hanover flat house at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-second Street was badly dam- aged by fire early last evening. The fire, which started from candles on a Christ- mas tree in a room on the second floor, spread so rapidly that the tenants were driven out before they could save their belongings.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- Controller Roberts and Attorney General Hancock were in consultation to-day with regard to the civil service laws and the Democratic employes in the departments which now have Republican heads who are protected by the civil service laws. An investigation will be made in order to ascertain whether or not these employes regularly passed the civil service examinations and whether their appointments have been regularly certified to by the Controller.

Miss Phoebe Cantor, sister of Senator Jacob A. Cantor, was married last night to Lossie Minzie of Newark, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cantor, at 137 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street. The Rev. Dr. Harris of Temple Israel officiated.

The Organization Committee of the proposed newjockey club held a two-hour session at the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon and heard a report from the sub-committee that had a conference with the members of the Board of Control on Tuesday afternoon. The meeting was a secret one, as it was only to hear the report of progress of the sub-committee.

BAHIA, Brazil, Jan. 3 -- The Brazilian cruiser Nictheroy, Capt. Baker, formerly El Cid, is still coaling at Pernambuco. The taking on of fuel is not, however, all that detains her. There is trouble about paying the members of her crew, the particulars of which are not known here.
BAHIA, Brazil, Jan. 3 -- The United States revenue steamer Grant, en route from New-York to Puget Sound, arrived here today with her machinery disabled.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The wheat market responded to the effect of good exports to-day. At the start there was an inclination to sell, influenced by a decline of 1/2d at Liverpool. This decline, however, was but a reflection of our own weakness of yesterday, and was not influential enough to prevent the subsequent reaction.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Jan. 3 -- P.M. There was a complete change in the disposition of the speculative element in Wall Street to-day. It had slept over the ghost stories which had proved so effective in frightening holders out of their securities on Tuesday, and had regained a certain amount of confidence over night.

Upon the call of Mayor Gilroy the heads of the various city departments met in the Mayor's inner office yesterday to devise a plan of furnishing city work to the unemployed. The meeting was private. It continued in session more than an hour and a half. The Mayor expressed himself as well satisfied with the progress that had been made.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 --The Board of Directors of the Massachusetts Yacht Club met in special meeting last evening and appointed a committee to secure new quarters. The club's rooms were destroyed by the fire that burned the Globe Theatre. This committee's task, will be made easy by the fact that desirable quarters were tendered during yesterday. Thus arrangements are completed, and the lack of a Winter house will be of short duration.

We notice that some of our Republican friends are opposing to the arguments for "home rule" for New-York the experience of the city at the time when the Metropolitan District was formed and the police force, Health Department, and Fire Department were organized under what was known as the Metropolitan system.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Mayor Wanser to-day decided that the charges of malfeasance, extravagance, and neglect of duty, preferred against the Street and Water Commissioners by a committee of citizens three weeks ago was sustained by the evidence, and, as a consequence, he ordered their removal.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Jan. 3 -- A meeting of ladies prominent in society and charitable work on Staten Island was held at New-Brighton Village Hall this afternoon and effected a permanent organization under the title, "Woman's Club of Richmond County." Twenty-six were present and signed the club roll and paid an initiation fee of $5.

How readily the heart of New-York society beats responsive to the call of charity was shown last night at Madison Square Garden. Viewed simply as a social function, the Charity Ball of 1894 was notably successful. Taken as an expression of that divine sentiment which, on the best of authority, is said to be the greatest of moral graces, it was still more satisfactory.

The Countess Fanny Zampini Salazar gave her farewell lecture to an American audience at the house of Mrs. Henry Draper, 271 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The laboratory formerly used by Dr. Draper and now frequently opened for parlor lectures was comfortably filled with an interested and enthusiastic audience.

An endeavor to frame a general freightrate agreement, such as can be put in force at all important Western points on eastbound traffic, was begun yesterday by the freight officers of all the important railroads operating in Trunk Line and Central Traffic territory, besides many other roads east of the Mississippi River and north of Newport News.

The committee appointed at a public meeting in the United Charities Building on Dec. 21 to take steps toward relieving the present distress of the poor in this city, of which Seth Low is the Chairman, has appointed the following sub-committees:

At the meeting of the Tammany Organization of the Eighteenth Assembly District, held in Washington Hall, 781 Eighth Aveue, last evening, ex-Assemblyman Thomas J. McManus was elected Leader Plunkitt's business" associate. This completely upsets the "deal" between Mr. Croker and ex-Police Justice Henry Murray for the election of ex-Congressman John Quinn, and may unsettle Judge Murray in the Seventeenth District.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Mrs. Eveleyne Farrell, who says she owns considerable property in Brooklyn, is in jail here, on a charge of not paying a board bill of $284.75 contracted at the Lakota Hotel. Mrs. Farrell claims that she is the victim of conspirators who desire to get possession of her property. She says the conspiracy began two years ago, when she married James Scott at Kenosha, Wis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- An undue preponderance of Boutelle in the House to-day prevented Representative Wilson from making the motion contemplated by him to take up the Revenue bill for consideration.

Detective Casey was addressed at Thirtieth Street and Sixth Avenue Tuesday night by a well-dressed stranger, who began to talk about the weather. Soon, however, he said: "How would you like to play a little bank?" Casey said he would, but supposed all gambling places in the "Tenderloin" Precinct were closed.

-- Commissioner John A. Shields, as Clerk of the United States Circuit Court, has submitted to the Judges the report of the work in the department during the year 1893. The report says: "There were 267 actions commenced in the common-law branch of the United States Circuit Court during 1893, and 573 were tried and disposed of.
The North American Review for January contains a paper on "Income Tax," by William L. Wilson, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, from which the following is an extract:

-- Operatic Changes. -- Some changes have been made in the programme of the Metropolitan Opera House. "Semiramide" will be revived for next Saturday's matinee, instead of "Lucia dl Lammermoor," Mme. Melba appearing for the first time as Semiramide. On Monday night Wagner's "Meisterslnger" will be presented for the first time this season, and Masoagni's "L' Amico Fritz" will be sung for the first time in the new house next Wednesday night, with Mmes. Calve.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 3 -- John Shafer, a tugboat fireman of Wilkesbarre, Penn., and Henrietta Brown, a prepossessing young woman, twenty-three years old, of 140 Houston Street, New-York, were arraigned before Justice O'Donnell this morning, charged with stealing $465 from Julia Ryan, a chambermaid at Rich's Hotel, 3 Exchange Place.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A new scheme to make money at the expense of the Government has been unearthed here. Three arrests were made to-day of people who have been mutilating old coins and fixing them up so that they would pass current again. Over $42,000 in gold coin was mutilated. The discovery was made by the officers of the Union Trust Company, a bank at which the people secured the coin.

George Thatcher purchased of Rich Harris yesterday their interest in the musical comedy "Africa," now running at the Star Theatre, and became the sole proprietor and manager of the enterprise. The terms of the sale have not been made public, but are said to have been satisfactory to Rich Harris.

The marriage of Miss Hattie St. Clair Fairchild, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Fairchild, to William Burnet Ogden, Jr., took place at 7:30 last evening at the home of the bridegroom's parents, 173 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street. The bride wore a gown of white satin, with high-cut corsage, full sleeves, and train, trimmed with duchesse lace and pearl trimmings.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Charles A. Orr has returned home from Albany, the scene of his unsuccessful canvass for the Assembly Clerkship. He is outspoken in his denunciation of the methods employed by Platt and the Republican State Committee to bring about the election of Col. Dunn.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 3 -- This Winter there has come another excitement for which Annapolis is indebted to Naw-York. Over the large estates of Southern Maryland there is real fox hunting, with real faxes and no aniseseed. Heretofore the hunting has been done with native dogs and native horses, and has simply been good hard riding, without spectacular equipments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Naval officers are a good deal exercised over the evident intention of the Navy Department to carry out the provisions of a paragraph of the naval regulations prohibiting correspondence with the public press without special permission. The department exacts of officers an application for the privilege of writing for the newspapers and magazines.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- At the trial of Daniel Coughlin to-day the witnesses of Importance were Miss Sarah McNerney, Alfred Ketner, and Thomas Jones. Charles Carlson's cross-examination was finished. A question put by Juror Larsen brought out the reason why young Carlson was accompanied in his pleasure trip by a detective before the first trial.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Jan. 3 -- Deputy Sheriff Louis Walters of Queens County this afternoon took possession of the elegant Summer residence of Edward I. Woolsey, the Astoria millionaire and clubman, to satisfy a judgment of $1,200, obtained by the Delamater Iron Company of New-York against Woolsey on Friday last.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 3 -- The reconvened Republican Convention of Aug. 19 last to nominate a candidate for Congressman at Large to fill the unexpired term of the late Gen. William Lilly was called to order at 12:15 o'clock this afternoon in the Opera House by Permanent Chairman Horace B. Packer.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 3 -- There was a disastrous fire in this city this evening, which caused a loss of over $500,000. At 5:50 o'clock flames broke from the top story of the Quale elevator, on Water and Madison Streets and on the river front. The firemen were slow in getting the alarm, and when they arrived at the scene the flames had possession of the top story of the great elevator.
Col. Floyd Clarkson, Past Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic for the State of New-York, died suddenly at his home, 48 East Sixty-sixth Street, Tuesday afternoon, of heart failure.
BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- Our market on local stocks was dull and colorless. There was little or no gossip on the Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senhor Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister, was this evening questioned by a United Press reporter in relation to the published dispatches of today concerning the situation of affairs in Brazil. Replying to the statements of Capt. Richards of the British steamer Basuto, as to Peixoto's undisciplined army and the brutalities of his troops, Minister Mendonca said:

The confession of SALVADOR FRENCH, who threw the bombs that exploded in the Liceo Theatre at Barcelona on Nov. 7 and killed twenty-five persons, is a very instructive document. It is not a confession so much as a boast, but all the more it reveals the nature of the man who made it and his motive for murdering a number of persons who had done him no harm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The officers of the Marine Corps are greatly depressed over the gloomy prospect of promotion in that branch of the public service. They have discovered that there will be but one compulsory retirement for age in the Marine Corps for the next eight years.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Thirty-one Republican Assemblymen-elect held a long conference here this afternoon, but accom- plished little. The conference was called by Max Salinger, a member from Hudson County, presumably in the interest of John I. Holt, the candidate for Speaker, and to shut off a conference called to take place in Newark to-night in the interest of Assemblyman Joseph Cross of Union County, who is his opponent.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Warden Blore of the Union County Jail has been watching o'nights for evidences of an alleged spook, which is said to roam at the midnight hour through the portion of the jail where the prisoners sleep.

The very heart of the "Tenderloin" quivered with excitement last night, the like of which has not been felt for years. It was due to an encounter between "Jere" Dunn, gambler, man-killer, and perfumed vagrant, who glories in his record as a "bad man," and James F. Caldwell, who also glories in a "record."
Money on sail loaned at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Count von Arnim has transferred from Vienna to Berlin his attack on Prince Bismarck, on account of Hans Blum's recent accusation that Count Harry von Arnim prostituted, his official duty at the Paris Embassy to bourse speculation. Blum made the accusation in his "Germany in the Times of Bismarck," published, to a certain extent, under the old Chancellor's patronage.

The Park Commissioners discussed the proposed Harlem River Speedway for two hours in secret session yesterday, and one result obtained was regarded as a victory for those who have all along maintained that the views of the landscape architect should be considered in some measure. But the concession is only so far as the second section of the speedway is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- According to the utterances of the Republicans in the House and the Senate, the principal object for which the country elected Democrats in 1892 was to vindicate Harrison and Stevens and make permanent the McKinley tariff. They opened their campaign for those persons and things when the Congress reassembled, and they resumed operations to-day having the same objects in view.

Eight indictments, charging officers of the Madison Square Bank with "participation in fraudulent insolvency" were dismissed by Justice Barrett in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, after lengthy argument upon the demurrer interposed by the defendants' lawyers. The ground on which the indictments were dismissed was that they did not specify the loans and discounts said to have been made with criminal negligence.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3 -- Hard times have forced Harvard to retrench. Notice has been given to two professors and four instructors that their services will not be required after the close of the current academic year. They are Prof. Bennett H. Nash, Professor of Italian and Spanish; Prof. C.J. White, Professor of Mathematics; Oliver W. Huntington, instructor in chemistry; G. Bendelari, instructor in history; T.W. Harris, instructor in elocution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Almost without exception the newspapers found the White House reception on New Year's Day an enjoyable one, made agreeable by the President and Mrs. Cleveland in their cordial reception of an unusually large throng of callers, who occupied much more than the usual time in reaching and passing the reception party.

An elaborate statement has been issued by the receivers of the Richmond and Danville Railroad system covering the operations of the several roads in that system up to the first of this month. The Messrs Huidekoper and Foster were receivers from June 17, 1892, to July 31, 1893, and since the last-named date Samuel Spencer has acted with the other two, the number of receivers having been increased to three.

Bank Superintendent Charles M. Preston completed his statement yesterday of the affairs of the St. Nicholas Bank. The statement is a transcript from the bank's books. It makes only an apparent showing of the bank's condition, however, and might have been issued by President Graves as the statement of a solvent institution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Mrs. Cleveland gave a luncheon to-day in honor of her guest, Mrs. John E. Russell of Massachusetts. Those asked to meet her were Mrs. Gresham, Mrs. Carlisle, Mrs. Lamont, Mrs. Olney, Mrs. Bissell, Mrs. Hoke Smith, Miss Herbert, Miss Morton, and Mrs. Stevenson. The decorations of the table were entirely in green.

Some peculiar facts developed yesterday in the remarkable suit of Austin against the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association. At the close of Tuesday's hearing before Justice Patterson, in the Supreme Court, it seemed certain that the company had entered on a wholly useless and unjustifiable defense against the life-insurance claim put in by Joseph Elliott Austin as the executor of his brother, John C. Austin.

The formal transfer of the Sutherland restaurant building to Mr. William Ziegler was made yesterday. Its sale was announced some months ago in the columns of The New-York Times. The property is at 64 Liberty Street. amd ,easires 25 by 81.8 by 22.5 by 82. It was bought by Mr. Sutherland on April 21, 1866, for $55,000, and was sold for nearly $150,000.

The bridge was being cleared of snow yesterday. The snow fell on Saturday last. A good deal of it had obligingly melted away. Some of it was stubborn, however, obstinately refusing to go away of itself, and persisting in remaining to create trouble and annoyance for the bridge management.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- State Engineer Schenck, in his annual report to the Legislature, reviews the work of the department last year. Speaking of canals, he makes some recommendations for repairs and then proceeds to a discussion of ways and means of making the canals more valuable to the State.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The condition of Miss May Barrowcliff, the victim of last Friday night's mysterious assault, is to-day much improved physically, though mentally she is about the same. Her wound was dressed at noon by Dr. Varick, and this afternoon several tests were made. Her temperature was normal and there was no fever.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- The situation in Sicily is regarded with increasing alarm by the Government. Gen. Mocenni, War Minister, has called under arms another section of the class of 1869. This section is 6,000 strong. The troops now in Sicily number 40,000. Two hundred, reserve officers also are reported to have been called out for service.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- "Well, I wonder what is the matter with the Capitol Appropriation bill," was the remark that Gov. Flower made as he was about to leave the Executive Chamber at 5:30 o'clock this evening. "It seems to me that it ought to have reached me before this. It was passed more than twenty-four hours ago.

-- Six cases were decided against the Texas and Pacific Railway Company yesterday in the Supreme Court of the United States at Washington. They were all damage suits, in which judgments for various amounts had been ren- dered against the company in the courts below, as follows: Henry Saunders, $2,500; Henry Horn, $4,990; T.R. Johnson, $15,000; E.S. Overheiser, $7,500; Tyler M. Griffin et al., $4,605; Adolph Valk, $8,000.

Policeman James Sharkey of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station created great excitement and uproar at the corner of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Fifteenth Street while returning from the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning. He was under the influence of liquor at the time, and was accompanied by Policeman Whalen, who had his head bandaged in consequence of injuries he received from three men he arrested the night previous.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- A new set of rules has gone into effect with the new year to govern all Harvard athletics. These rules are practically the same as those adopted by Capt. Waters of Harvard and Capt. Mackey of the University of Pennsylvania for the football game. There are three rules that are important and interesting to outsiders.

Efforts will be made during the present session of the Legislature to amend the election laws of this State in three important particulars. No citizen who sincerely desires to have elections absolutely honest and fair can consistently object to any one of the proposed amendments, and yet there is danger that Democrats and Republicans in the Legislature will not agree about their adoption.

The publication in an evening newspaper of a story alleged to have been vouched for by a "police official high in authority in the department" to the effect that in the reorganization of the Board of Police, Police Commissioner-District Leader-Martin, who has been President of the board for two years, was to be "turned down" and Commissioner McClave chosen President in his place, caused a ripple of excitement at Police Headquarters yesterday.

The conference committee of various organizations appointed at the invitation of the City Club to formulate a new ballot law had a session last night at the City Club, which lasted until 12:30 o'clock. It was hoped that the bill might be perfected. Discussion was started, however, on various propositions, not going to the substance of the bill, but contributing to delay.

The Hoffman House is to be sold under foreclosure. Yesterday Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court signed a decree ordering its sale to satisfy a mortgage held by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, as trustee for the bondholders. The full amount now due the bondholders is $437,750.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 3 -- Contrary to all announcements and expectations, a lottery drawing was held Monday and sixty-five policy shops were in operation at their old stands. The new lottery company is called the New-Orleans Premium Company, and is a syndicate of policy-shop men, local politicians, and a few capitalists, all of whom were more or less connected with the Louisiana Lottery Company.

Russell Sage has undertaken the role of peacemaker in the now discordant NewYork and New-England family. He believes that a serious mistake was made in the manner of putting the road in the hands of receivers, and he thinks that great damage will result to the property unless harmony is speedily restored.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- There was nothing in the bearing of the Senate when it assembled to-day which betokened anxiety, and the people in the gallery, who had gone there with the idea that something exciting would mark the reassembling of the august body, had their trouble for their pains.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- William C. Sanford of this city, well known in New-York, is insane, and is thought to be suffering from paresis. He was taken from here this afternoon in a special car drawn by Superintendent Harrington's private engine, the Mohawk, and it is rumored that his destination was a retreat near New-York.

Along with the proposition to be submitted next Tuesday to the stockholders of the Southern National Bank to reduce the capital from $1,000,000 to $500,000, and to apply the $500,000 of capital thus lopped off to surplus, there is a prospect of an appeal to the stockholders in a Directors' quarrel over the retention of William W. Flannagan as President.

DUNDEE, Jan. 3 -- Mr. George W. Savage, the American Consul at this place, died this morning after a lingering illness. For two months he had been incapacitated by age and increasing feebleness from performing the duties of his office, but it was only recently that he developed alarming symptoms.

FLUSHING, L.I., Jan. 3 -- George F. Butler, the Long Island Express agent here, delivered, a bicycle to a strange young man a few days ago and accepted in payment a certified check on the Globe National Bank of Boston for $85, that being the amount due, the machine being sent C.O.D. The check was forwarded to the shippers, W.E. Sanborn Co. of 145 Columbus Avenue, Boston.

Mrs. S.B. Powell, better known as "Shirley Dare," the editor of The Housewife, was charged with larceny in the Tombs Police Court yesterday by her son, Andrew J. Powell, the owner of the magazine. She was given a private hearing, and when it was over Mr. Powell said the case had been dropped.

The marriage of Miss Alethea Carmer Mesier to the Rev. George Wharton McMullin took place yesterday at noon at Calvary Church, the Rev. Henry Y. Satterlee officiating, assisted by the Rev. J. Nevett Steele of Trinity and the Rev. John Hardenbrook Townsend of Ascension Church, Atlantic City.

Adolph L. Sanger, President of the Board of Education, died suddenly at his home, 50 East Sixty-third Street, yesterday morning, of pneumonia. Ten days ago he contracted a severe cold, but was at his law office, 115 Broadway, attending to business until Friday afternoon, when he became seriously ill.

John Y. McKane and his Gravesend henchmen won a little battle yesterday, and they were exultant, but on Monday next the victory of yesterday may result in a great defeat. The Sheepshead Bay Sunday school Superintendent had been notified to appear before Justice Bartlett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, to plead to the eleven indictments found against him by the Extracrdinary Grand Jury.

How to furnish work for 80,000 wage earners or food for 240,000 persons, when the present facilities show but 20,000 meals in sight, was discussed by a number of men and women engaged in practical charity work, at the rooms of the Provisional Com- mittee for feeding the hungry, at the Imperial Hotel, yesterday afternoon.

The Governor remarks that "an endeavor has been made to carry out the full spirit and letter of the civil service law during the year, and with good results." We regret to say that this statement, very general as it is, is hardly borne out by the facts that have come to the knowledge of the public.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The Essex County branch of the Daughters of the American Revolution celebrated the anniversary of the battles of Princeton and Trenton this afternoon, with a luncheon given at the Essex County Country Club in West Orange.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 3 -- The American Wool and Cotton Reporter will to-morrow publish the following letter from Chairman Wilson of the Ways and Means Committee:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 3 -- The General Improvement Commission of this city that awarded a contract to District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan of New-York to build a sewer here for $92,764 had a surprise in store to-day for the contractors who put in bids for the Hoyt Avenue sewer.

Some of the youths who are not included in "Father Bill" Curtis's "blacklisted" Four Hundred will take part in the amateur boxing tournament to be held in the Lenox Lyceum this evening and Saturday night under the auspices of the Clinton Athletic Club. The preliminary bouts will take place to-night. The entries are appended:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Two young men, Edward Corbally and John Dunn, who were arrested on suspicon of having murdered Miss Elizabeth Petty, after a searching investigation this morning were released. Corbally is only eighteen years of age. He answers the description of the man whom little Eddie Miller claims he saw last Tuesday morning coming out of Miss Petty's gate.

There has been nothing in the recent history of the United States Senate more scandalous and inexcusable than the prolonged failure to act upon the appointment to fill a vacancy on the bench of the Supreme Court, at a time when it is causing serious embarrassment to the court and the postponement of all cases involving constitutional questions.

A young man who the police believe may prove to be the assailant of Miss May Barrowcliff, who was so brutally attacked in Jersey City last week, is locked up in the Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, awaiting an investigation.

One of the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee is Mr. JULIUS C. BURROWS of Michigan, and when it became known that copper was transferred to the free list in the Wilson bill he raised his vioice in lamentation and prediction of dire calamity. The proposed change, he declared, would "make the successful operation of the [copper mining] industry impoassible."

--President Samuel Sloan of the Lackawanna Railroad denies that a new traffic agreement has been made between that company and the Lehigh Valley. It was reported that an arrangement had been entered into for an interchange of freight and passenger traffic for Buffalo and Western points.

Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, who died at her home in Jamaica Plain, near Boston, Wednesday morning, came of the good old Massachusetts family of Peabody, known in the walks of theology and learning, and was herself distinguished as the founder of the kindergarten system in this country. She was born in Billerica, Mass., May 16, 1804, the daughter of Nathaniel Peabody, a physician.
At a meeting of the heads of the city departments at the City Hall on Wednesday the following resolution was adopted.

Some of those frequenters of the "Tenderloin" who take a judicial rather than sentimental view of current events in that section expressed regret yesterday at the outcome of the quarrel between "Jere" Dunn and "Starter" Caldwell of the previous evening. In their opinion, the incident had been lacking in an important essential, for they regarded an encounter between two such men in which neither had been seriously hurt as an opportunity wasted.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The latest diversion in the famous Cronin murder case and trial of Dan Coughlin is the alleged discovery of the trunk strap which "J.B. Simonds" bought, with the cottage furniture, from Revelle's establishment and had removed to the Clark Street flat. The strap, which appears on the scene to-day after being in hiding, as alleged, for four and a half years, corresponds exactly with the salesman's description, of the genuine article.

William Brookfield was chosen Chairman of the Republican State Committee at its meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, and, notwithstanding numerous statements from him within recent years that he did not want the place, on this particular occasion he was glad to get it. For Mr. Brookfield had a change of heart regarding the matter at about the time the Legislature organized this year, and since then has emphatically recanted from his previous professions.
Harry Kennedy, the song writer and ventriloquist, died at midnight Wednesday at his home, 288 State Street, Brooklyn. His death was caused by Bright's disease, which developed on Sunday from a cold.

"Shirley Dare," Mrs. Susan D. Power, until lately editor of The Housewife, sent a message last night to her son, Andrew F. Power, the publisher of that magazine, inviting him to call to see her to-day at the Broadway Central Hotel, where she is stayting.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- At the Clearing House this morning balances between banks were offered at 1 per cent., and were practically unlendable. On the Street call money ranged from 2 @ 3 per cent., and 3 1/2 @4 per cent. for time money. New-York funds sold at par and 5c premium.

The defense in the trial of Austin against the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association will begin to-day, and an interesting session may be expected. The defense will endeavor to prove that John C. Austin, on whose life the fifteen-thousand-dollar policies in suit were issued, is still in the land of the living.

-- A dispatch was received at Berlin yesterday from Warsaw saying that the infantry barracks in Smolensk 250 miles southwest of Mocsow, were set on fire by an incendiary, and that some of the soldiers who were compelled to jump from windows were injured. The report was not credited in Berlin.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 4 -- While the Emperor was proceeding to his Winter palace to-day bandits attacked the procession.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- The unusual spectacle of 200 clergymen, robed in cassock, surplice, and beretta, moving along in solemn procession, following a coffin, is not often seen on the street in our American cities, but a great number of Albanians witnessed this sight this afternoon, just after the bell in the tower of Brownstone Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception pealed out the hour of four.

Samuel Tilton, sixty-nine years old, a Boston merchant of forty years' standing, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon on a charge of disorderly conduct in Central Park by Park Policeman Higgins, who recently made an arrest on a similar charge, which has been much criticised.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- State Department officials, when asked in regard to an alleged dispatch from Montevideo asserting that negotiations were in progress between President Peixoto and Mr. Thompson, United States Minister to Brazil, for a settlement of the Brazilian trouble by the intervention of the American fleet, said the story was too silly for serious consideration.

At the annual meeting of the Coffee Exchange yesterday President Henry Hentz reported that options for 5,880,250 bags of coffee had been sold in 1893 at the Exchange, against 6,926,000 in 1892. The highest price was in October, touching 17.75 cents a pound for that month. April brought the lowest price, when September options sold at 12.75 cents a pound.

Marshall Bronson Blake died yesterday morning at his home, 116 West Seventy-eighth Street. He was seventy-nine years old. While at breakfast New Year's morning, Mr. Blake was stricken with apoplexy and was thereafter conscious only at intervals. His was, until 1885, an active life in business and politics, although in the latter field he had but one office, that of Collector of Internal Revenue, under the original law.

The Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs has arranged a pool tournament to be played between the clubs in the association. The first game will be played to-day. Following is the schedule of games:

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- For the first time in Three years the several branches of the State Government of Massachusetts are under Republican control. The Legislature met yesterday and organized. The Executive branch made its how to-day in the person of his Excellency, Frederick. T. Greenhalge, who was inaugurated just before noon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- There had been a number of stories afloat in the last month as to the President's alleged intentions concerning New-York State appointments, but he had filled so few New-York offices that the rumor-mongers had grown somewhat fatigued. He caused not a little surprise this morning by sending to the Senate eighteen nominations of Democratic Postmasters in New-York State.

Maynard, Merrill Co., publishers, of 47 East Tenth Street, began a novel suit under the copyright law in the United States Circuit Court yesterday. On July 23, 1891, they allege that Alonzo Reed copyrighted a work on the early study of the English language and made over to Effingham, Maynard Co. the sole right to publish and sell it.

The Boston Association of the Alumni of Dartmouth College will have its annual reunion and banquet at the Tremont House in that city, on Wednesday evening, Jan. 10. The association expects to have as its guests the new President of the college, Dr. William J. Tucker, Treasurer C.P. Chase, and several members of the Faculty; Edward Sanborn of this city, son of Prof. Sanborn; Charles Prouty of Vermont, and others.

A Widowers' Association has been formed at Dresden. No man can join unless his wife is dead, and should he marry again, he becomes merely an honorary member. One of the principal objects of the association is to help new members -- that is to say, newly-made widowers -- by looking after their wives' funerals and putting out his children, if he has any, to nurse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The House Democrats have not yet had vacation enough. Owing to the absence of about 100 Democrats, according to the roll call, the Republicans again managed to consume a day and to waste it. Mr. Wilson was prevented from calling up the Tariff bill, and the dominant party was once more subjected to the sneers and gibes of the minority.

-- Sardou as a Plagiarist. -- Whenever Sardou produces a new play charges of plagiarism are preferred against him. Many of these have been sufficiently proved. "Le Crocodile" was unquestionably taken from the same source as Tom Taylor's "Overland Route." The subject and situations of "Fedora" were previouslyused in a novel and play by Belot.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- By a typographical error a dispatch to The New-York Times from this city, printed in to-day's issue, stated that "there was no confidence that the Senate would oppose the income tax clause in the Tariff bill." The word oppose should have read "approve," and to-day it looks as if the doubt about approval might be asserted for the House.
ROME, Jan. 4 -- The Secolo, a Radical organ of Milan which opposes the triple alliance and advocates an alliance with France, to-day publishes an article that causes considerable comment.

Russell Sage's amiable endeavor to restore harmony between the clashing factions of the New-York and New-England Railroad bore fruit yesterday. At a meeting of the Directors a long preamble and resolutions were adopted, favoring a permanent receivership for the road, and asking for the appointment of Thomas C. Platt as sole receiver.
The Board of Education met yesterday afternoon to take action on the death of its President, Adolph L. Sanger. Ex-President of the board, John L.N. Hunt, presided.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- There is no doubt that a feeling of terror is running throughout the various State departments and bureaus where clerks have been employed without passing the civil service examination. While all the State departments were in the control of the Democrats rules were relaxed and men were employed who could not pass the examination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Commissioner of Pensions has decided, in view of the passage of the act of Dec. 21, 1893, declaring pensions a vested right, that he no longer has the right to withhold the pension of Judge Long of Michigan, and has accordingly ordered that the suspension of his pension be removed.

Most interest by those gathered in the auction room at 111 Broadway yesterday centred in a sale which did not take place. It was that of the residence of the defaulter Francis H. Weeks. The building is a handsome four-story brownstone highstoop dwelling at 11 East Twenty-fourth Street, north side, just adjoining the mansion which was the residence of the late Catherine Lorillard Wolfe.

-- The continuation of the suit brought in the Court of Common Pleas by Mrs. Genevieve Allen against her husband, Frank Allen, for a separation, on the ground of cruelty, was rendered interesting yesterday for the spectators by the frequent and lively quarrels between the opposing counsel. W.H. Townley, for Mrs. Allen, and the aged Col. O.H. Dawson, for the defendant.

BUFFALO, Jan. 4 -- William F. Sheehan is on his political uppers in Buffalo, so to speak. He has nothing left now but the Police Department, and he is in a fair way to lose that, and the Board of Councilman. The Board of Aldermen is Republican by more than two-thirds majority. but the Democrats have six out of the nine members of the Board of Councilmen.

The Chamber of Commerce, at its monthly meeting yesterday, indorsed the recommendation of Secretary Carlisle to Congress in favor of an issue of short-term bonds, demanded a better law than the present one to prevent dumping in the harbor, and upon the petitions of various members received notice of a special meeting, to be held next Thursday, for the consideration of the proposed income tax.

The conference committee of the various organizations taking part in the movement for the amendment of the election laws of this State, with a view to the adoption of the blanket ballot, has prepared a voluminous bill making many changes in the provisions and in the wording of the present law.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst last evening gave out for publication the statement which he promised, last week, the committee of the Society for the Prevention of Crime would have ready regarding the cases of Police Inspector Williams and Capt. Schmittberger, whom the recent Extraordinary Grand Jury refused to indict on charges presented by the society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Secretary of War to-day transmitted to Congress a special report made by the Chief of Engineers in regard to the constant violation of the act of Congress to prevent obstructive and injurious deposits within the harbor and adjacent waters of New-York City by dumping or otherwise.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Undaunted by the plan to make the next New-Jersey Senate a tie by debarring Senator-elect Bradley of Asbury Park from being sworn in the sub-committee of the Republican County Committee, which is assisting the Essex legislators to frame good bills, met this afternoon and made preparations for introducing repealers.

The fifteen Republican Aldermen met at Republican headquarters, on Lawrence Street, Brooklyn, last night, to decide upon a candidate for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen, and also a candidate for City Clerk.

Effective steps were taken at the Hoffman House yesterday toward the organization of a jockey club which shall have supreme control of racing on all the tracks in this vicinity, superseding the Board of Control as a governing power.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 4 -- Hostilities were begun anew in the Lewelling-Lease Imbroglio this morning, the Governor having persisted in Mrs. Lease's removal, regardless of the statute which states plainly that he had not the power to turn her out of office. All efforts toward effecting a compromise have been discontinued.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 4 -- Transportation Agent J. B. Bray of the State Penitentiary arrived to-day from Green County. Ark., having in custody Charles Roberts White, whom he consigned to the penitentiary to serve a life sentence for murdering his wife. Roberts was sentenced to be hanged, but the Governor commuted his sentence to life imprisonment.
"Is society doing its share toward reliev-- ing the prevailing distress?" Ward McAllister was asked yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times.

George W. Ihrig, the retired produce merchant, of 278 South Third Street, Williamsburg, whose eccentric methods of distributing charity to the poor and entertainments for boys of his neighborhood have created so much remark, will probably start in a day or two for California. His sons have decided that a change of scene and climate may have a beneficial effect upon his nerves and perhaps restore him to his normal mental condition.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 4 -- O. Kanouse, proprietor of the Hotel Republic of this place, a few days ago sent to the managers of the Children's Home and the Mountainside Hospital the receipts of New Year's Day at his hotel, each institution receiving one-half the money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The first state dinner of the season was given to-night by President and Mrs. Cleveland in honor of the Cabinet. The decorations in the East Room, where the President and Mrs. Cleveland received their guests, were very elaborate. The mantels were banked with ferns, and below, on the floor, was a massing of foliage plants and small palms.

"The statements made by Mr. Oliver Sumner Teall Wednesday evening at the meeting of the Provisional Committee for Aid of the Hungry are sensational, and apt to be harmful to the great work of charity which is being done in the City of New-York," said General Secretary Knowlton of the Charity Organization Society to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday.
