WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Senate remained in open session but a short time today, and then the doors were closed and a number of minor appointments were considered. Several Postmasters were confirmed. The question of the confirmation of R.E. Preston as Director of the Mint, was again taken up, but no decision was reached.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The annual report of the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, Worthington C. Ford, which has just been issued, comprises in 157 printed quarto pages statistics of the foreign commerce of the United States for the year ended June 30, 1893. Discussing the causes of the movement of gold, the report says:
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- The British steamship Chilian, Capt. Fetters, arrived here to-day from Pernambuco. The Chilian left the Brazilian port on Dec. 16.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- From the time they opened their "Business Exchange," about the 1st of October, 1893, until a few days ago, when they found it convenient to seek new fields of activity, Charles H. Carlton and Charles G. Atkins fairly reveled in wealth. They were over ears in money. Greenbacks and silver certificates and bank notes distended their pockets.

The Times has for many years ranked as one of the most reliable newspapers in this country, both in its news departments and in its editorial utterances. It has long been recognized as the uncompromising foe of frauds of every description, especially the political fraud, and of the latter, whether of its own or any other party, it has been forward to tear off his mask and expose him to the world.

-- Bockins -- Hamlin Wedding. -- Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. George Hamlin of 121 West Seventy-first Street for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence Bell Hamlin, to Edward Graham Bockius. The ceremony will take place on Jan. 17, at the Hotel New-Netharland.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The new State Treasurer, Addison Colvin of Glens Falls, is already affording the politicians of the State and the citizens of Albany endless amusement by his vagaries and verdancy. Mr. Colvin is now thirty-four years of age and has been almost everything, from a newspaper writer and Chief Engineer of the Fire Department of Glens Falls to State Treasurer.

An official statement was issued yesterday by J.W. Reinhart, J.J. McCook, and J.C. Wilson, the receivers of the Atcnison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, in reply to certain criticisms printed in London newspapers of recant date. The receivers say:

A plot of ground, 330 feet on Flatbush Avenue, 300 feet on Nostrand Avenue, and 170 feet on Avenue G, Flatbush, has been sold by the Germania Real Estate and Improvement Company of Flatbush to John Betts of Brooklyn, for $9,250. Other lots near-by have been sold at about $350 per lot.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 4 -- Republicans Whose chief interest is the selection of a United States Senator are sharpening knives to-day. The candidates outside the powerful cabal known as the Gear combine are now confident that Gear has made a combination with Henry Stone for Speaker and various other officers to be selected by the Legislature next week, including State Printer and the Wardens of two penitentiaries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- An extraordinary investigation is in progress in the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. Upon the motion of a Democrat, Senator Morgan of Alabama, the committee is pursuing an inquiry, having for its object, apparently, the ascertainment of whether the Democratic Administration has proceeded in the Hawaiian matter in such a way as to deserve the censure of its own party.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 4 -- William Mason, tenor in the choir of Christ Episcopal Church, will not play the leading male part in a church operetta because it has been discovered that he works in Henry V. Aillien's stable in Glen Ridge.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 4 -- E.O. Hopkins, Vice President, and James H. Wilson, Secretary and Treasurer of the Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis Railroad, were to-day appointer receivers for that road.

BABYLON DEPOT, L.I., Jan. 4 -- Frederick R. Satterlee of New-York City, who for over a year has been living in BabyIon, was shot at to-day, while riding past the Deer Park Avenue entrance to the residence of Austin Corbin, by some one who, it is believed, was secreted in the woods which extend close to the road.

The Executive Committee of the Merchants' General Committee to aid the Industrial Christian Alliance in its work in keeping up the people's restaurant system met again yesterday in the office of Vermilye Co., at 16 Nassau Street. A letter was read from Archbishop Corrigan to C.S. Foote, the Secretary of the committee, as follows:

The will of Henry Clausen, Jr., the brewer, was filed for probate yesterday. It was executed March 10, 1892. Henry W. Schmidt and Peter V. Stocky, the testator's brothers-in-law, are appointed executors and trustees to receive the entire estate in trust. Mr. Clausen's widow, Mary Clausen, has $300,000 set aside for her own benefit.
John Dettwiller, a retired shoe merchant, residing at 183 Clifton Place, Brooklyn, was arraigned before Police Justice Walsh in the Adams Street Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of begging.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Navy Department experts have been discussing the plans for a new torpedo cruiser, for which bids were asked several years ago without success. Now that the market prices are lower and business duller than it was, the Secretary hopes to secure proposals. The alterations necessary to make the cruiser a strictly modern vessel may bring the additional expense above the appropriation.

NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 4 -- Business men in this city to the number of twenty-five or thirty, have received circulars from greengoods men within the last few days. The letters are all postmarked New-York, and contain confidential typewritten letters, signed "Secrecy," and newspaper clippings headed "A Counterfeiter Goes Free."
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

A scrap of paper contains the will of Frederiek A. Lovecraft, business manager of Palmer's Theatre and Assistant Secretary of the Coney Island Jockey Club, who committed suicide Oct. 26 last, in his room, at 45 West Thirtieth Street. The will reads:

Matron Boyle of the Immigration Bureau had a strange visitor yesterday in the person of John McCartin, who had just come from Chicago in search of a wife. He asked Matron Boyle to help him get one, and after obtaining her promise to do what she could for him he went away. Later he dropped into the Ship News Office and asked the reporters if they could help him in his quest.

A most wholesome judgment, our Paris correspondent says, has been given by the Second Chamber of the Civil Tribunal there in a case brought for damages by a seamstress against a fellow-tenant. The latter bought a slow-combustion stove and set it up in a room contiguous to the one the seamstress occupied.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Many deaths have been caused here by the extremely cold weather. A number of old and poor persons nave been frozen to death in their miserable lodgings. Others, despairing of finding other relief from their sufferings, have killed themselves. Several destitute persons have been picked up lifeless in the streets.

The original lucky dog was a hapless animal compared to the Democratic Party in its occasional periods of buoyant fortune. Several times within the recollection of younger voters, good luck has plucked it by the hair out of the whelming waters. At the close of the war nobody expected the organization to survive, at least not under its old name and old leaders and with its old principles.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- P.M. Continued covering of short contracts was the feature of to-day's stock market. The advance which naturally accompanied the movement led to a feeling of hopefulness, which was strengthened by the cheerful tone of an interview with President Miller of the St. Paul Company, in which he expressed the opinion that business generally has reached its lowest ebb, and that conditions are favorable to improvement.

The examination into the sanity of Mrs. Catherine Fitzgerald, sister of Inspector McLaughlin, who is charged with killing Mrs. Carrie Pearsall, was resumed yesterday afternoon in the office of Charles A. Jackson, Chairman of the commission appointed to make the examination, at 16 Exchange Place.

It behooves all men who hitherto have not shown a proper regard for the cause of woman suffrage to focus their wits upon it speedily, for the flat has gone forth that they, not the women, must put their shoulders to the wheel and carry to victory in the Constitutional Convention the cause of the woman suffragists.

At the elections of 1892 the Democratic Party received the votes of a great number of citizens who had not before acted with it, and many, perhaps the majority of whom, had been in the habit of acting in opposition to it. In part this was a practical protest against the profligacy and extravagance to which the Republican Party, under the influence of the beneficiaries of the tariff, had been given over.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The feature of the market to-day was Alley L, which was the result of anticipation as to what action would be taken at to-day's meeting of the Directors. Many had faith in the ability of that portion of the stockholders opposed to the present management to oust the incumbents of the offices, while others were firmly convinced that the attempt would be unsuccessful.

Mayor Schieren has decided that the Board of Education shall be a non-partisan body, and with that idea in view he has determined to purge the board of its political workers. He will not be able to accomplish much in this direction until July, when he will have fifteen appointments to make.

The Architectural League met Wednesday night in the Vanderbilt Gallery, at the Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, to discuss the question of freeing works of the fine arts from customs duties. The present duty is 15 per cent. ad valorem, and the Tariff bill recently reported by the Committee on Ways and Means to the House of Representatives frees works of art in painting and sculpture from all duty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Miss Herbert gave a luncheon to-day in honor of Mrs. Cleveland, at which the decorations were In scarlet and green. On a silver centrepiece a silver flagon was filled with American Beauty roses. At either end of the table were open rings of maidenshair ferns.

At auction in the Triuity Building Salesroom yesterday Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly sold, under foreclosure, for $13,000, to Theodore M. Barnes, as executor, the plaintiff in the action, the five-story brick tenement 515 East Seventieth Street, north side, 273 feet east of Avenue A, 25 by 100.5.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 5. Henry Collins, son-in-law of Edward Ridley, the late New-York dry goods merchant, who is accused of stealing an old buggy from Mrs. Hayward Prince, formerly of South Bay, L.I., but now of Undercliffe, N.J., will have a hearing to-morrow before Justice Seaman at Hempstead.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Monday morning the Mohawk Valley Cotton Mills, in this city, will resume operations after having been closed three weeks for repairs. Three hundred and fifty persons will be given employment. The mill has been equipped with new machinery. A new addition now being fitted with machinery will be ready March 1.

NEW-YORK. Friday, Jan. 5 -- P.M. Business was much less active to-day and prices were irregular. The opening was fairly firm, with the exception of Sugar, which was depressed. London orders were quite numerous in the early trading, and did much to sustain prices.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Will you kindly give a place to the following in connection with the efforts of our association to relieve the worthy poor of New-York City in a judicious manner in the present emergency? The outlook for January and February is discouraging, and the association anxiously awaits further contributions to its special fund.

There is always a good deal of curiosity among those interested in the welfare of the hospitals and charitable institutions of Brooklyn to learn in what proportion the excise moneys are distributed. The distribution of these funds is made annually.

The evolution of republican feeling in Brazil, with the birth of institutions which Minister Mendonca says must be defended at all hazards, is the subject of the following article in the current number of The North American Review by Brazil's distinguished representative in this country:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The caucus of Democrats to-night uncovered the weakness of the Democratic opposition to the Wilson bill, making it evident to all who attended that there could be no hope of success for the less than a dozen men who have done the rallying for the opposition and given the Republicans a momentary feeling that the measure might be greatly changed or wholly beaten.

David Leary, a son of Jeremiah Leary of 1,160 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, and connected by marriage with Police Superintendent Campbell, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself in the cellar of his house. Mr. Leary was thirty-three years old. He had no regular occupation. He lived with his parents and brothers in a handsome brownstone mansion, with ample grounds around it.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 5. -- Knights of Labor were considerably exercised to-day over the news that ex-General Master Workman Powderly and ex-General Worthy Foreman Hugh Cavanaugh were under indictment before the General Executive Board and in a fair way to be expelled from the order.

William H. Grimm, the Brooklyn bigamist who, it is alleged, has four wives will be sentenced to-day by Judge Moore in the Kings County Court of Sessions. Grimm pleaded guilty Tuesday and threw himself on the mercy of the court.
W. H. Tilford, President of the Board of Directors of the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad, has issued a circular to the stockholders of that company, in which he says:

COLUMBUS, Miss., Jan. 5. -- A cowardly attack was made at an early hour this morning upon C. C. Brown, night train dispatcher at the office of the Georgia Pacific Railroad. While Mr. Brown was on duty, five men In disguise quietly entered his office, and with drawn pistols made him march to a thicket of trees about a quarter of a mile from the depot, where they made him lie upon his face.

POUGHKEEPSLE, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- A trip along the Upper Hudson shows that the ferries, including Rhinebeck, Tivoli, and Catskill, nave good tracks, and the ferryboats are running regularly. The propriets of an Upper Hudson icehouse said:

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- A dispatch from the Isle of Wight, where the Queen is at present sojourning, says that the mercury registers 10 above zero, Fahrenheit, which is the lowest point it has reached in 100 years. The River Yar, which flows into the Solent, is frozen over to within a few yards of the Solent.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Thomas Mack, twenty-six years old, who boarded at 257 Passaic Avenue, was found to be suffering from smallpox last night. The police of the Third Precinct have in their custody two men who lived in the house. They were arrested last night on a charge of stealing chickens.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 5. -- Mrs. Mary Bushnell, widow of the noted theologian, Horace Bushnell, is gradually failing at her home in this city. She may die any day. She is eighty-seven years of age. She has resided in Hartford continuously since her marriage, having come here from NewHaven sixty years ago.

In relation to the cablegram from London of yesterday announcing that Frank S. Bacon, the amateur champion of England, had issued a challenge to run T.P. Conneff, the American champion. Mr. Conneff makes the following statement:

It is all because Avandra Outten, a furniture dealer of 31 Carmine Street, cannot defend his 200 pounds avoirdupois from the cruelty of his 120-pound wife, Mary, that he has brought suit for separation in the Superior Count before Judge Dugro. Although she is such a little thing, and he is so big, Avandra avers that she has treated him most shamefully.

The unseasonable mildness of the weather thus far hits of coarse operated to mitigate the distress of those who are out of employment. Fuel has not been as necessary as food, and those who have shelter without the means of warmth have not thus far experienced any very acute suffering by reason of this privation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Without verification of the Auckland dispatch concerning events in Honolulu, the State Department will not believe that to-day's information is correct. All the news from Hawai since the arrival at that port of Minister Willis has strengthened the opinion held from the first by the Administration of his wisdom and discretion.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- The publicity given to the alleged deficit in the Chicago City Treasury has brought about a very wholesome discussion of the entire subject in this city, and has resulted in Mayor Hopkins appointing as City Controller W. F. Ackerman, late Auditor of the World's Columbian Exposition, and formerly connected for many years with the Illinois Central Railroad Company.
Copyright, 1894, by The United Press. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5. -- The revenue cutter Corwin, which was due last Saturday, arrived at the entrance of the harbor about 11 o'clock this morning.

Mayor Schieren is annoyed at the stories published to the effect that he is interfering with the men whom he has selected for heads of the Brooklyn city departments regarding appointments. He has heretofore denied these stories. Yesterday he said:

In order that no poor person may be without food and coal, Nathan Straus, who has established stations where these necessities may be secured at cost or less, has announced a reduction in prices which will be a practical bit of charity to the 6,000 or more who are daily supplied at these stations.

Superintendent Byrnes submitted to the Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday afternoon his report on the investigation of the charges made by the Rev. Dr. C. H. Parkhurst against Capt. Edward Slevin of the Fourth Precinct. The report completely exonerates Capt. Slevin, and declares that Dr. Parkhurst's allegation that disorderly houses were allowed to exist in the Fourth Precinct was not found to be borne out by facts.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Justice of the Peace William Levy of Passaic was to-day convicted in Hudson County of perjury, committed in a suit before Chancellor McGill. Levy sued George P. Rust, who is counsel for Passaic and a reputable lawyer, for the recovery of some title deeds to property worth $20,000.

Under the title "A Champion of the Cross," the Rev. Charles F. Sweet has written a biography of the Rev. Dr. John Henry Hopkins, and James Pott Co. have brought it out in a single volume. Dr. Hoopkins's brother began the work, but was unable to complete it, and the task then fell to (Mr. Sweet, who modestly tells us he has done the best he could under the circumstances.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The news received at Liverpool concerning the slaughter of British troops in the interior of Sierra Leone by French soldiers has been confirmed by the advices of the Foreign and War Offices. The officers killed were Capt. Lendy, Lieut. C. Wroughton, Lieut. Liston, and a Sergeant. The twenty-six privates who were shot were all negroes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Another day has been lost through, the absence or neglect to vote of Democratic members of the House. On one of the several roll calls to-day the Democrats numbered 165, and it was apparent at that time that there were enough silent Democrats present to make up the 177 required for a quorum.
The hearts of 500 of New-York's "Little Mothers" were made happy yesterday afternoon with candy, cake, cream, dolls, and a good entertainment.

The riots in Sicily seem mainly to indicate that the pressure upon the Italian people has reached the breaking point. That the revolt against a condition that has everywhere become intolerable should have broken out in Sicily rather than in any other part of the kingdom is due, of course, to special cause and to be explained by a reference to local conditions.

The potent magnet to attract the public in the current season of grand opera at the Metropolitan Opera House is undoubtedly Bizet's noble music-drama, "Carmen." Some persons have fallen into the error of attributing the great success of the work this Winter to the admirable impersonation of the title role of Mme. Calve.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 28.-- All revolutionary talk has been superseded here by the sensational discovery that Gabriel and Manuel F. Lugo, two of the best-known young men in Caracas, and their uncle, Francisco Lugo, are the perpetrators of a great robbery, committed more than a month ago, and that they are assassins as well.

Leonard R. Welles, who is to succeed Henry I. Hayden as Police Commissioner of Brooklyn Feb. 1, is not going to assume the office without having a knowledge of the duties he will be called upon to perform.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5. -- The Duval Athletic Club ran against another snag to-day in the person of Sheriff Broward of this county. The club has been claiming all along that despite Gov. Mitchell's opposition the fight would occur in Jacksonville, because the officials of the city and county would not interfere as long as the courts had not passed on the Florida law in regard to prize fights.

The sub-committee of the Assembly Committee on Elections, which hopes to unseat several Democrats, met yesterday morning in Part III. of the Court of Common Pleas. The committee is composed of two Republicans, Assemblymen Terry of Saratoga and Vacheron of Queens County, and one Democrat, Assemblyman McNamee of Ulster County.
The Democratic politicians of Brooklyn were interested yesterday in the news from Washington to the effect that Joseph C. Hendrix intended to leave Congress.

The Tammany Hall General Committee of the Thirteenth Assembly District met last evening in the rooms of the Pequod Club, of which District Leader-Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan is President, and organized for 1894. The following officers were elected:

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Two important reforms are expected from this Legislature. One is the abolishing of the infamous and corrupt institution known as the engrossing room in each house; the other is the adoption of closure in the Senate. The New-York Times exclusively announced six weeks ago that the Senate would find a way to stop obstructive debate.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Inspector General Thomas H. McGrath is of opinion that the dress coat of the National Guardsmen of New-York should be single breasted, with seven or nine buttons. He advances this idea in his annual report to the Governor, which is part of the Adjutant General's report.

The general freight officers of the railroads east of the Mississippi River completed their task of formulating a new east-bound freight agreement yesterday. They adopted a plan which they hope will result in the permanent maintenance of rates from the Western cities to the Atlantic seaboard. This plan will apply uniformly to all of the Western gateways to the east-bound traffic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The probability of an early confirmation of the nomination of Mr. Hornblower to be a Justice of the Supreme Court was discussed briefly In that court to-day. Mr. William Gobel, representing the State of Kentucky, in two cases, moved the court to postpone the hearing from next Monday until a full bench should be present.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- The D. Lothrop Company, book publishers, has made an assignment to Louis D. Grandeis, who estimates the firm's liabilities at $250,000. The assets consist of outstanding bills, plates, and copyrights of 3,000 books, and machinery valued at $6,000. In May, 1893, their assets, as returned to the State House, amounted to $460,101, but their real value is very uncertain at present.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 5 -- John Y. McKane, the indicted "boss" of Coney Island, was the defendant in a suit before a referee in this city to-day, and in spite of the efforts of his attorney, was compelled to answer questions regarding his connection with the Gravesend affair.
Dun's Review will say to-morrow:

Oliver Sumner Teall, Chairman of the Provisional Committee for the Aid of the Hungry, with headquarters at the Hotel Imperial, yesterday sent the following letter to Superintendent Hebberd of the Charity Organization Society: Robert W. Hebberd. Superintendent Charity Organization Society:

Judge BUTLER'S reference of the petition of Mr. ISAAC L. RICE for the removal of the receivers of the Reading Company to a Master to take evidence on the charges made therein marks an important step in the movement which has in view the operation of the property for the benefit of its security holders.

John C. Austin, life size, in hunting costume, was flashed on the jury yesterday in the celebrated insurance suit before Justice Patterson, to the Supreme Court. It wasn't Mr. Austin in the flesh. It was only a black and white copy of the photograph marked for identification on Wednesday by the defense, but the effect was almost as startling as if the original of the picture had come into court in person.

Mrs. Catherine M. Fitzgerald, who shot and killed Mrs. Carrie Pearsall on Oct. 2, 1893, was taken yesterday afternoon to the office of Charles A. Jackson at 16 Exchange Place. Mr. Jackson is Chairman of the commission appointed to inquire into her sanity. All the Commissioners were presant, and Judge Martine also listened to the proceedings.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- When Gov. Flower had finished his day's work and was about to leave the Executive Chamber, Chief Examiner Carmody of the Civil Service Commission entered with several pages of typewritten matter. The pages contained the names of clerks in several departments of the Government who had not passed a civil service examination. Gov. Flower had asked for these names.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 5. -- The United States District Court at New-Orleans, for the first time since the days immediately following the war of the rebellion, had to resolve itself to-day into a court of prize and sit upon a case involving the forfeiture of a vessel.

Mayor Schieren, with the assistance of seven plucky Aldermen who believed they were elected in the interests of good government, has won another hard battle. His candidate for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen will be elected Monday.

Capt. Belden of he Welsh bark Atlantic, which arrived here from Pernambuco yesterday morning, says that when he was in the harbor of Pernambuco, where the Atlantic lay for nine weeks, the Government soldiers, of whom there were many in the town, took every opportunity to exhibit their cruelty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Thomas H. Carter of Montana registered at the Arlington to-night. He will remain in the city until after the meeting of the Republican National Executive Committee, which is to be held Jan. 11. Mr. Carter said in response to numerous inquiries concerning the Harrison and McKinley Presidential booms which are reported to be under headway that he had not encountered them anywhere on his journey eastward.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 5. -- The case of William Ryan against John Drennan, Jr. and James De Witt has been concluded. Ryan brought suit for $10,000 damages for the loss of a hand, which was shot off. The shooting occurred at Ryan's house on the night of Jan. 17, 1891.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 5. -- E. C. Chick, who wants $100,000 from George Gould, is still here, and says he will stay a month, if necessary, to complete his arrangements with Mr. Gould. He may be arrested as a vagrant to-morrow. He says he has seen the inside of nine lunatic asylums, and that he is seldom detained more than a week. He shows this certificate:
BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The Vossische Zeitung says to-day in a leader on Hawaii and the United States:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The attention of the Controller of the Currency has been called to an article in a New-York paper, asserting that the United States was "discrediting its bonds," and purporting to give an account of a ruling made by Controller Eckels reversing former rulings of that office, and discrediting the 2 per cent. bonds as a basis of national bank circulation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- The State Commissioners of Fisheries met here to-day and adopted their annual report, which will be submitted to the State Legislature on Tuesday next. The report says that last year the commissioners expected, and, in fact, planned, to hatch at least 100,000,000 of fry, and, as it was, they succeeded in distributing over 80,000,000 of the best varieties of fishes in the waters of the State.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. ROME, Jan. 5. -- Dispatches received from Palermo late this evening say that the proclamation of the state of siege in Sicily has made a good impression upon the people, and has been especially reassuring to the law-abiding citizens, who had become alarmed by the apparent impotence of the local authorities.

Prof. Smith's discussion of questions of the day proceeds from the independent standpoint of a zealous philosopher. Prejudice may warp his views, particularly in his treatment of matters that pertain chiefly to England, but he is unhampered by those personal considerations which weigh with politicians and statesmen.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- A special dispatch to the United Press from Lisbon says that in a fight that occurred at Rio Negro, in the State of Santa Catharina, Brazil, between the Government forces and the insurgents, the former were victorious. The insurgents lost forty killed and nineteen prisoners.

Ex-District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll made the following statement yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times in reference to Dr. Parkhurst's charges that he had used his influence with the Extraordinary Grand Jury to shield Capt. Schmittberger, Inspector Williams, and other officials against whom the Society for the Prevention of Crime had obtained evidence:

Fire did $25,000 damage yesterday afternoon to the exhibits from India which were at the World's Fair, and which have since been kept in the stores at the Knickerbocker Apartment House, 247 and 249 Fifth Avenue. The damage to the building was $1,000.

Under the direction of Mr. Charles J. Bell, who thus proved himself an uncommonly skillful theatrical director, an English translation of Ibsen's awful "Ghosts" was acted in the Berkeley Lyceum yesterday afternoon. Before the play Mr. Bell, who took no part in the performance, spoke a few words in behalf of the Ibsen cult.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- The election for Alley "L" Directors leaves practically the old Directorate in control, only one opposing candidate having been chosen. As predicted yesterday, no matter which side would win, the disappointed candidates and their friends would sell their holdings. This occurred to-day.

The Excise Board yesterday afternoon continued its investigation of complaints for violation of the excise laws. Carl W. Frieling, 109 Bowery, was complained of for allowing women and tramps to frequent his place. Frieling was for five years Financial Secretary of the Retail Grocers' Association.

Orlando B. Potter was buried in Greenwood Cemetery, in the family plot, yesterday afternoon. The funeral ceremonies were held at Grace Church, Broadway and Ninth Street, of which the deceased was a member. These services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Huntington, the rector, and his assistant, the Rev. George H. Bottome.

Out of respect to the memory of Adolph L. Sanger, President of the Board of Education, who was buried yesterday, the public schools were closed. The burial was at Salem Fields, Cypress Hills Cemetery. A large number of mourners accompanied the body to its final resting place.
PALERMO, Jan. 5. -- Thirty persons were killed and fifty were wounded in a riot that took place to-day at Marineo, a town eleven miles southeast of here.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 5. -- The police and hospital authorities became suddenly reticent to-day in regard to Miss May Barrowcliff's condition. All they would say was that Miss Barrowcliff was better, mentally and physically, but her memory was not improved.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Superintendent Hannan of the State Department of Public Works has completed his annual report to the Legislature. It shows that the expense of operating the canals last year and making the ordinary repairs was $726,086, the lowest annual expense since 1886. Mr. Hannan gives considerable space to discussion of the recent trial of electric propulsion on the Erie Canal.

MADRID, Jan. 5. -- At the opening to-day of the new Municipal Council at Malaga the members became involved in disputes that ended in scenes of violence. Several of the Councilors engaged in fisticuffs, and a free fight appeared to be imminent. A general row was averted only by the hasty adjournment of the Council.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The final services in memory of the late Bishop McNierney, unitll his death the head of the Albany Diocese, were held to-day in the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception. Despite a heavy rainstorm, thousands of people thronged into the church, and for hours those who were unable to gain entrance stood about in the rain.

The evidence brought out during the trial of the Rev. GEORGE FREDERICK BURGOYNE HOWARD, and the conviction of that picturesque scoundrel on twenty-two counts of the indictment, ought to open the eyes of thousands of American citizens who have been led to believe that they are heirs to enormous estates in England and that they can establish their rights to enjoy the same.

The foreign exchange market was very quiet. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.85 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.83 3/4 @$4.84 for sixty-day bills, $4.85 3/4 for demand, $4.86 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.82 1/2 @$4.83 for commercial.

Mr. Joseph Pennell has revenged himself for his early years of repression in Philadelphia by making more stir in the world than any American artist save Whistler. This native of the Quaker City is of a belligerent turn of mind; he will not be "put upon," and acts as if he were a British grumbler by birth rather than adoption.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- An interesting list has been completed in the Naval Hydrographic Office of collisions which have occurred in the North Atlantic in the past seven years. All those that have occurred within bays, harbors, or other tributary waters to the Atlantic have been omitted from this list. The list is divided into four parts according to the damage sustained.

It has for a century been a custom of American printers to celebrate the anniversary of the birthday of Benjamin Franklin, who began his career on Jan. 17, 1706, and ended it on April 17, 1790. This year the celebration in this city by the Typothetae will take the shape of a dinner at the Brunswick.

Mayor Schieren is pleased that Jackson Wallace is to be the President of the Board of Aldermen. They are old friends, and Mr. Schieren is positive that Mr. Wallace will be a first-class presiding officer. He is also of the opinion that Joseph Benjamin, who is to be City Clerk, is a fair man.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S. I., Jan. 6. -- Rumors have been circulated for some time to the effect that County Treasurer Matthew S. Tully had disappeared, and that $11,000, which should be to the credit of the County Loan Fund, on deposit with the People's Trust Company of Brooklyn, was not there. These rumors were published in a sensational New-York newspaper this morning.

Spirits of turpentine dull; firm; 29 1/2@3 1/2c. Refins quiet; steady; common to good strained, $1.25@$1.27 1/2 WILM1NGTON. Jan. 6 -- Resin quiet; strained, 95c; good strained, $1. Spirits of turpentine firm at 27 1/2c. Tar quiet at 90c. Crude turpentine quiet; hard, $1; soft, $1.60; virgin. $1.60.

NASSAU, N.P., Dec. 26. -- Christmas is over, and everybody who has any nerves is positively glad of it; for Christmas in Nassau is about as noisy a holiday as one can well imagine. The subjects of her Majesty the Queen are as loyal to old Santa Claus as they are to Victoria, and the entire colored population of this island has been on the rampage for the past week.

SING SING, Jan. 6. -- The present open Winter up through this region has set a good many of the older portion of the population recounting stories of the Winters they have known on the Hudson. The river, thus far, has only had a thin coat of ice on it here, but up where there is less salt in the water there has been skating.

H. Sielcken, a large coffee importer at 77 Broad Street, who by his business is brought to an intimate knowledge of the results, particularly the commercial effects, of the Brazilian troubles, speaking to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, said:
The Twelfth Night Club celebrated its annual feast with all the rites and ceremonies of ye olden times.

WEST POINT, Jan. 6. -- The cadet hospital here is one of the finest on any military post in the country. Built in 1883 at a cost of $125,000, and completely equipped with every apparatus known to medical science, it stands pre-eminently at the head of all similar institutions in the world.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner William S. Andrews was made defendant in a suit brought in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday by Lawyer Theodore Von Bremsen, as attorney for Leila Grace Toplanyi, to recover $1,500 which it is alleged he has unlawfully retained from the pension money he, as agent, collected for the plaintiff's father.

" Our Country Cousins," by Paul M. Potter, to be produced at the Lyceum Theatre to-morrow night, is a play of more or less fashionable society in Newport, or, rather, deals with the affairs of a New-York husband and wife and their relations resident for the Summer at that resort.

The ideal biographer should, in the first place, write of some one who is thoroughly sympathetic to him. Excessive admiration, though a fault, is a fault on the right side. As Arbuthnot observes in the recipe for an epic poem, the fire is apt to cool down wonderfully when it is spread on paper. Readers will make deductions enough in any case; and nothing can compensate for a want of enthusiasm about your subject.

PARIS, Monday, Dec. 18 -- There is one quarter of Paris in high glee to-day. The inhabitants of the Place Boieldieu would be quite willing to pay for extravagant illuminations -- they might understand a bomb. at last the long-talked-of, much-expected spade is going to break the ground for the building of the Opera Comique.

PEEKSKILL, Jan. 6. -- A fire this morning in the bakery of Paul Wessells Son, on South Street, caused $20,000 damage to that and adjoining property, and the loss of the lives of Charles Curry, thirty years old, and Henry Penzhorn, forty-five years old, both married, who were bakers, at work in the shop in the basement.

It is half a century since Dr. Parsons put forth the first part of his translation of Dante, when he issued anonymously the first ten cantos of the "Inferno." The translation was prefaced by a poem in seven stanzas entitled, "On a Bust of Dante," which is probably much better known to lovers of the great Italian's work than the name of its author.

On nearly all sides there is evidence of a gradually-diminishing mortality among the causes of the London death rates, and nothing is more certain than the fact that this satisfactory state of things is the direct outcome of the beneficent, practical, and expedient health laws by which the public health is controlled.

A whale came to town yesterday, R. W. Willoughby, a gripman on the Harlem cable road, was the only man who had a good look at It, but he saw it with the eyes of a New-Bedford sailor, and saw it so well that various other persons more than half believed they saw it, too.

Mr. Beard gives the result of many years of experience, and without laying down, any absolute laws, believes that such suggestions as he offers would help the student in the representation of motion in art. It is evident, he says, "that things should be represented as they seem to be rather than as we may know them to be."

We venture to suggest to the enterprising and hustling gentlemen who are urging Congress to raise the Territory of Oklahoma to the rank of a sovereign State that their list of arguments is incomplete. They have taxed their imaginations and exhausted the resources of an extensive vocabulary in the enumeration and description of the wonderful advantages, natural and acquired, of this newly-settled region, but they have overlooked the provisions of the Oklahoma divorce laws.

The Common Council Chamber in the Brooklyn. City Hall was filled yesterday with politicians and lawyers who are interested in the cases being investigated by the Assembly Sub-Committee on Privileges and Elections. The committee consists of Assemblymen Keck of Fulton and Hamilton Counties, Wesley Gould of Delaware, and J. C. Harrigan of Westchester.

Thomas Arthur, thirty-three years old, of 318 East Forty-fourth Street, was committed in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday to await the result of injuries he inflicted upon his wife. Arthur is a plasterer, but has been out of work for some time. On Tuesday, while intoxicated, he knocked his wife down, who is about to become a mother, and kicked her in the side and stomach until she became unconscious.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 6. -- The Executive Committee and the General Manager of the Consolidated Traction Company have rearranged the list of permanent officers of the company. The officers of the Jersey City and Bergen County Railway Companies and the New-Jersey Traction Company are now combined in one organization.

LONDON. Jan. 6 -- Further details have been received from Free Town, the capital of Sierra Leone, of the killing of British troops by the French. According to the latest information at hand, the British were encamped in the Connoh district, near Warina. Their camp was within the British sphere.

It cannot be disputed that the interesting feature of the third concert of the Symphony Society, at Music Hall, last night, was Henri Marteau's performance of Dr. Dvorak's violin concerto. The performance was quite as interesting as it would have been had the programme shown a strict regard for veracity.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6 -- Reports received this week from different parts of the Chesapeake Bay say that oysters are unprecedentedly scarce, and that fewer boats are at work than in any season during the last fifteen years. Many of the rocks which formerly yielded abundantly are barren, and in Tangier Sound, where there are usually thousands of vessels, only 300 were at work this week.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- The subject of United States Senator Dolph's address at the annual meeting of the New-York State Bar Association, in the Assembly Chamber Jan. 16, is announced as " Law Reform."

William Diamond, a dissipated car driver, thirty years old, while in a desperate mood owing to drink and jealousy, yesterday attempted to murder his reputed wife and then put an end to his own life by shooting himself twice with a revolver. The woman in the case is Jennie Dubois, who is twenty-six years old.

That the bicycle is fast becoming popular and useful is an undisputed fact. In country towns and large cities where good roads can be found the silent steed, as it is called, may be seen going noiselessly over the ground at a pace that would soon tire the fastest trotter. For some reason or another in years past there was a prejudice against the bicycle.

The Duc de Roquelaure was a man or great ugliness and much humor. One day he met in the street a most unlovely-looking Auvergnat, who had some petition or memorial to present at Versailles. He immediately introduced him to Louis XIV., remarking that he was under a special obligation to him.

Conditions affecting real estate in this city have not been materially changed by anything which has happened during the week just ended. Sales have been few and hardly any of special note have been reported. But dickering and bargaining continue with a great deal of energy, too often futile.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 6. -- " You're a liar, and you know it," was the startling exclamation which fell from the lips of Representative Amos J. Cummings of New-York at the Capitol to-day.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 6. -- The John Morris Company, 118 and 120 Monroe Street, is going out of business. It is reputed to be the largest firm of its kind in existence. It is notable in that it has combined under one management branches of business which are usually conducted as independent enterprises.

During its old colonial days of commercial prosperity there was no one in Aberdeen more respected as a man of substance than bold Bart Mynderse. Then, as now, people said things about their neighbors; but then, as now, they whispered when doing so, and never more cautiously than when speaking of him.

The first of a course of three lectures for children on the " Mysteries of the Flowers," for the benefit of the New-York Kindergarten Association, was given yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre. The lecturer, William Hamilton Gibson, who has made botany a lifelong study, was aided in his talk, by colored illustrations and mechanical charts invented by himself.

James Samuel McClelland,the fourteenyear-old son of William McClelland, a livery stable keeper at 236 West Thirtieth Street, was killed in the Central Park yesterday morning by a horse he was riding rearing and falling backward upon him. The lad, with three companions of about his own age, went out riding.

Horses, and even sheep, occasionally suffer from a form of sore throat resembling diphtheria, and Dr. Turner, in a report made to the Local Government Board in 1887, records his surprise at discovering the number of diphtheria victims in country districts, whose occupation had been the management of animals.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 6 -- It is reported that eight Lieutenants of the United States Army are now in South Carolina to look out for arms and munitions of war which are to be shipped to South America.

The Parisian police raid upon the Anarchists seems to have been very well managed. The individual Anarchist may be hard to get, but the flourishing continuance of an Anarchist organization is a reproach to the police of any country in which it occurs. The raid of the Paris police will greatly discourage the French Anarchists.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- Dr. Miquel, Prussian Minister of Finance, has issued invitations for an official dinner that will be held on Tuesday night next. Chancellor von Caprivi and all the imperial and Prussian Ministers will attend. The concord between the Ministers appears on the surface to be so complete that it might not be thought that the real underground conflict continues.

Our esteemed contemporary the Courrier des Etats-Unis promulgates a merry jest that comes to it from the Pacific coast of South America. There is in Chile a town called Callipuli which is largely populated by foreigners, and especially by Frenchmen and Germans. The German colonists had not long ago what the correspondent of the Courrier calls the "bizarre idea" of celebrating the anniversary of Sedan, and they assembled at a banquet for that purpose.

John Y. McKane, Chief of Police of Coney Island and Pooh Bah of Gravesend, became a messenger yesterday and carried a letter from George W. Roderick's office to District Attorney James W. Ridgway. Chief McKane was smiling, and his diamond flashed, but he did not look as tidy as usual.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- The Globe Iron Company has decided to build a freight steamer and keep its workmen employed. It will be one of the largest on the lakes. Unless a buyer is found, the boat will be put into commission by her builders as soon as completed. Contracts for three large steel tugs are about to be closed.

PLAINFIELD, N. J, Jan. 6 -- The second Assembly ball was danced at the Casino Monday night. It proved to be one of the most brilliant social affairs Plainfield society has known for many years. The regular Assembly set was out in full force, clad in gorgeous raiment and bent on having a good time.

Force of circumstances has driven an Englishwoman -- one Mrs. Coleman -- to adopt the unusual occupation of pavement artist as a means to earn a living for herself and her sick husband. She is probably the first gentlewoman to attempt this calling, which is one of the common street sights of London, though comparatively unknown here.

Mr. Kahichi Sano of Tokio has nearly 600 porcelains, bronzes, lacquers, carvings, ceremonial costumes, and other Japanese objects in the collection at the American Art Galleries. Most of them, if not every one, were shown at the World's Fair. They will be sold on the afternoons of to-morrow, Tuesday, and Wednesday, the auction beginning at,3 P. M.

From The Philadelphia Press. The users of tobacco have found a comforter and defender in Dr. James W. Keiser of Reading. He read a paper before the Medical Society of that city in which he combated the general position that tobacco is injurious. He asserted that in moderate doses it calms restlessness, stimulates the intellectual faculties, causes a feeling of repose, increases the flow of saliva, and has a slightly laxative effect.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6 -- The news received here that the two Scotch Crofter settlements at Killarney and Saltooats, in the Province of Manitoba, are utterly ruined is the first announcement of the failure of the pet lmmigration scheme of the English Colonization Board and of Sir Charles Tupper.

An eminent authority estimates the money loss to the people of this country, in one Tray and another during the past year, due to ignorance of the elementary principles underlying public policy in matters of currency and taxation, at not less than $1,000,000,000. Incidental to this loss are much hardship and suffering, and the estimate takes no account of what is yet to be undergone before a normal condition of things is re-established.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Nearly every working day in the year, at about 2 o'clock in the afternoon, a queer procession may be seen threading its way through certain dark corridors of the United States Treasury Building. Visitors invariably halt when they see this procession approaching, and gaze at it until it disappears.

The demands upon the resources of the numerous charitable organizations are becoming greater every day. Some of the associations which exist for the relief of the needy and deserving poor are finding that there is greater scope for their work than their means will permit. In a few cases it has been found necessary to appeal to the public for assistance.

Charitable and church work is nowadays as much a part of the daily life of a society woman as are those gay functions with which, she is popularly identified. There are, of course, many exceptions to this rule, but on the whole the time that a typical New-York woman of the exclusive sets devotes to aiding the needy is considerably in excess of that which she gives to her personal pleasures.

HARTFORD, Conn,. Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court in this State will become Democratic for the first time in thirty years on Sunday, Jan. 14. Since the beginning of the civil war the Republicans have controlled the court without interruption. For a brief period Origer S. Seymour, a noted Democrat from Litchfield County, was Chief Justice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- For the fourth time since the close of the holiday recess the spectacle has been presented to the country of a Democratic House sitting powerless to transact public business.

In civilized society of the Middle Ages convulsions and trance led either to the stake or to canonization, while since 1710, or so, they have been medically treated, and would not even qualify a man for knighthood, still less increase his wealth and political power. Thus the abnormal phenomena, if any, have been neglected.
Wheat gained 1/2 @5/8 c through local covering and following the West, but business was slow.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 6. -- Charleston alleys, for narrowness and length, will bear comparison with any in the country, and in quaintness will yield probably only to Boston or Annapolis. Travelers say that they are reproductions of alleys in old cities like Chester, England, and in towns of Normandy.

Copyrighted, 1894, by the United Press. ROME, Jan 6. -- A search of Deputy de Felice's house in Rome has resulted in the seizure of several letters addressed to him from Paris by Signor Ciprlani, the Socialist exile.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 6. -- The Legislature will meet next May. The two most prominent candidates for United States Senator are Don Caffery of St. Mary and N.C. Blanchard of Caddo. Congressman Boatner is also regarded as a possible candidate, but under existing circumstances the chances for a dark horse are not promising.

The original engagement of Rose Coghlan at the Fifth Avenue Theatre was to have closed next Saturday night, but an extension of two weeks has been secured from Manager Miner, and as Miss Coghlan has received many requests to appear in some of her best-known characters, she will devote the last two weeks to a series of productions calculated to show the capacity of the strong company which she has brought together.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- Suddenly, and if not from a clear sky, at least from an unexpected quarter of the horizon, a lightning flash has startled Europe. There has been some strange sort of night encounter between English and French, forces in the bush up the Niger Valley in that vague Hinterland between Sierra Leone and Senegambia.

The overdue rally in the market started about the middle of the week, and had made good progress by the close yesterday. Advances were quite rapid in those stocks which had the largest short interest in them. Bull pools had been made in St. Paul and Western Union, and a fivepoint rise in both was scored without much apparent difficulty.

ORANGE, Jan. 6. -- There is a scheme on foot among Orange business men to consolidate Orange, East Orange, West Orange, and South Orange into one city. The promoters of the scheme urge that such a consolidation would be advantageous to all the municipalities, and that public works would be much facilitated.

In this era of truce on the waters, when the natives of the world meet only for competitive reviews, why should that virile adjunct of the sea power of Great Britain, who fires his salutes and throws his Greek fire "At the Sign of the Ship" in Longmans Magazine, stir up non-combatants by attempting to use "Americanisms?" Mr. Andrew Lang is justly admired for his good English.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- Judges Thayer, Arnold, and Wilson, sitting in the Common Pleas Court, to-day refused to grant the application of Shareholders H.P. Goldschmidt Co. and Thomas Barrett of NewYork for an injunction to postpone the annual election of the Philadelphia and Reading Company from Jan. 8 until Feb. 12, "or such other time as the court may deem proper."

Mrs. Richards modestly describes her little book as a collection of "Flummery a la Louis Quatorze," and warns historical students that they will not find matter of moment in it. "Old stories retold, familiar figures summoned once more from the shades to make their bows and play their parts" -- that is her offering.

This story naturally divides itself into two parts -- one having to do with religious belief, the other being worldly and treating of men and women. Of the two, that devoted to theology is by far the more striking. The author possesses not alone originality in his method, of thinking as to the means whereby we can attain grace, but brings into the discussion a fund of theological knowledge.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 6. -- The Albany Theatre, a structure five stories high and covering an area of half a block, was completely destroyed by fire at noon to-day. Save three walls and a mass of debris, nothing remains of the structure. The firemen could do little but devote their efforts to saving surrounding property, and were successful in confining the flames to the theatre building.

There is not much use in indulging in surmises as to the contents of the official dispatches from Honolulu brought by the Corwin, and the "impressions" reported from Washington seem to be based upon surmises. There will soon be definite information upon which something more than impressions may be based.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The report of ex-State Treasurer Danforth for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 last, which will be submitted to the Legislature next week, reveals some interesting and instructive facts.

The question whether variolin could in safety be substituted for vaccination as a preventive of smallpox, which has been engaging the attention of the advocates of the homeopathic and allopathic systems of treatment in Brooklyn during the past eight years, was yesterday decided in favor of the latter by Health Commissioner Griffin.

Frederic H. Hatch, C. Amory Stevens, and Wilbur F. Herbert, Jr., have addressed to the stockholders of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company a protest against the plan of the Reorganization Committee as already reported. The Reorganization Committee sent out notice a few days ago that assents to the plan had been received from the owners of more than 60,000 shares, constituting a majority of the stock, and that the plan would accordingly be carried out.

Man at a very remote period learned to be imitative, conservative, and gregarious. Hence habits and customs. For an act often repeated becomes a habit, and a habit widely imitated becomes a custom. Thus habits and customs form the larger part of the history of mankind. Could we accurately know them, then the ingrained ideas and feelings of the people of the past would be palpably presented to us.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- While the afternoon newspapers report that there was much excitement to-day at the State Department over the news received from Honolulu by the Corwin, the excitement was all in the newspapers.

A brilliant procession moved down the stairs to the small ballroom at Sherry's, where a luncheon was prepared, yesterday afternoon, at which the Daughters of the American Revolution proposed to celebrate the anniversary of George Washington's wedding day. The giving of this luncheon by the Daughters showed in a graceful way the womanly side of their natures as contrasted with the spirit of patriotism exhibited by them at the celebration of Revolutionary battle anniversaries.

who among the military of this country has not heard of " the maimed hero of Groveton," Brig. Gen. James McLeer of Brooklyn? Few of the heroes of the civil war are better known than the commanding officer of the Second Brigade of our New-York State National Guard. He is at home among his old comrades, and they, the humblest of them, are his dearest friends.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- W. Bowen Moore, a pension attorney of this city, was arrested, with his son, at noon to-day on the charge of defrauding the United States Government through the Pension Department. Dispatches from Washington about a month ago stated that Moore's frauds aggregated about $150,000.
Justice William J. Gaynor of the Supreme Court presided yesterday for the first time on the bench in Brooklyn, and promptly disposed of the business before the court.

From The LewIston (Me.) Journal. The Rev. Charles T. Ogden, the Episcopal State Missionary, was years ago when younger and rather less wise than at present, the keeper of what amounted to a lodging house for tramps. Mr. Ogden was settled at Bellow's Falls at that time, and there were many tramps on the road.

One of the most popular wheels with bicycle riders is the Credenda. It is made by A. G. Spalding Brother, whose New-York office is at 243 Broadway. The Credenda has been on the market for three years and is becoming more and more popular all the time. It is made in three patterns -- the "Pacer," the " Consort," and the "Diamond" -- each being conctructed throughout of steel tubings and forgings.

The eyesight of George Du Maurier, Punch's most famous artist, is falling rapidly -- so one of his friends, who has just arrived from England, reports. For some time Du Maurier has been obliged to do his sketches almost in life-size on a wall, from which they are reduced by photography, and it is feared that he will soon be compelled to abandon his crayon altogether.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee will hold its annual meeting to-morrow night at the Thomas Jefferson Hall, and the old war horses of the " machine " will retire from the offices of President and Secretary.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Art critics are much concerned over the future of Palmer's masterpiece, " The Angel at the Sepulchre," which is one of the finest pieces of monumental art in Northern New-York. It is on the burial plot of Gen. Robert Lenox Banks, in the Albany Rural Cemetery, and is of ALBANY, Jan. 6 The Angel of the Sepulehre, Albany. large proportions, being 7 feet in hight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The most outspoken army officer who submits reports to the War Department is Inspector General Breckinridge, who bears the relation of general critic to the service, and exercises the privilege without reserve. He has made a report to the Secretary of War on the operations of his department for the year 1893.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- There are to be two tests of rapid-fire guns at Sandy Hook during February or March, one being of twelve-centimeter guns -- three foreign weapons and one American gun of that calibre. The conditions will be identical, the object being to have a competitive trial, and upon the results will be based the selection of a gun of this calibre for the army.

Oliver Sumner Teall, Chairman of the Hungry Committee at the Hotel Imperial, , announced Friday that he had sent a letter to the Superintendent of the Charity Organization Society, Robert W. Hebberd. Mr. Hebberd had received no letter from Mr. Teall up to a late hour yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- The Traction stocks did not respond to the advance in New-York stocks, probably because there is no short interest in them. Philadelphia was 90 told and was offered at 91. Metropolitan was still for sale, and although some organized support was developed it was not strong at any time to-day.

Aside from its psychological side, this biography contains material of singular interest. The acquaintances made by Mr. Brisbane in his early life, especially in Prance, Germany, and England, and the quick perceptive qualities of the man allowed him to paint many portraits of past celebrities which are striking.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Retired army officers will stand no chance hereafter of being detailed for college duty. Secretary Lamont to-day relieved from duty as Professors of Military Science and Tactics eleven army officers who are on the retired list. The cause of the order is found in a provision of the act of Congress approved last November, which reads:

The Maori women are a potent factor in island life and must not be forgotten. Liquid dark eyes, soft voices, affectionate and merry dispositions, light-brown skins of ivory smoothness, and gracefulness in every movement, are their most striking characteristics. Seldom are they to be seen in a passion, and not a single "cuss word" for man or woman is to be found in the vocabulary of this charming people.

The giving away of Miss Frances Willard's health last year in England brought her, in the relation of patient, into an acquaintance with the lately-deceased physician, Sir Andrew Clark. She has recorded in an English print some of her impressions received of this distinguished practitioner and big-hearted man, whose death has deeply moved a wide circle of friends, eminent and lowly.

Here is an astounding story of banking in Brooklyn. It is a story which will be read with amazement even by those financiers who are familiar with the operations which resulted in the wrecking of the Marine Bank, the Sixth National Bank, and the Madison Square Bank of this city.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 6. -- The Winter colony of cottagers on Wednesday evening drove to Bryer's Farm, in Middletown, where they had a delightful dance. The affair was given by Miss Edith Norman, and her mother, Mrs. George H. Norman, received. The cotillion, for which there were dainty favors, was led by William R. Hunter, dancing with Mrs. William H. Mayer.

Among the counterfeiters of comparatively modern times the German, Becker, stands pre-eminent. With incredible skill he engraved dies for upward of 300 types of coins, principally Roman, and as most of these were struck in gold -- a metal that does not change in appearance with time -- he realized large sums from unwary collectors.

-- With a record of 170 nights in Boston and 118 in New-York, together with the original company, complete stage settings, , Hoyt's " A Temperance Town " seems to be well equipped to give satisfaction to the frequenters of Col. Slnn's Park Theatre, where it will be presented for the first time for the approval of Brooklyn, theatregoers to-morrow night.

It is not by any manner of means stretching the facts to declare that Mayor Schiertn's first week in office has been made miserable by the politicians. They have descended upon him as the Assyrians did -- like the wolf on the fold. It has been, for the last three days, a regular Balaklava charge of war horses.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 6. -- A sensational suicide occurred this morning on Carondolet, near Josephine Street, in the heart of the most fashionable residence portion of the city. George Winchester, a man of middle age, of fine family and good position, being a Government sugar weigher, shot himself in the right temple because his wife refused to meet his overtures for a reconciliation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- To-day's was the most active session held on the local Stock Exchange in a month. While the calls of yesterday and the day before were turbulent, the commotion was confined to two securities. To-day, however, the heavy transactions were spread over the entire list. The elevated and surface stocks were especially agitated.

The twenty-first anniversary of the establishment of the Church Mission to Deaf Mutes will be celebrated to-night in the Protestant Episcopal Church of Zion and St. Timothy, in Fifty-seventh Street, near Ninth Avenue. The society was incorporated in 1872, being an outgrowth of St. Ann's Church, founded in 1852, the first church in Christendom to undertake systematic pastoral care of and work among deaf mutes, through the labors of the Rev. Dr. Thomas Gallaudet.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Jan. 6 -- Lambert W. Jackson was captured to-day in the pine woods back of Asbury Park after a search lasting three days. He was sent to jail to await trial upon a charge of having tried to burn to death Mrs. Mary E. Connett and her two small children.

Regarding the methods made use of to determine authorship, specialists are naturally reticent. Some of them have admitted, however, the nature of the leading principles which guide them. The philosophy of the matter rests mainly on the fact that it is very rare for any two persons to write hands similar enough to deceive a careful observer, unless one is imitating the other.

NEWPORT, R. I., Jan. 6 -- The inaugural address of Mayor Daniel B. Fearing, who took office Monday, was of great interest to New-Yorkers who own residences and grounds here. In fact, it has caused a sensation because of its recommendations for the betterment of the cottage colony.

One of Keen's boon companions was a low comedian of the Adelphi, named John Reeve. He was a clever imitator of wellknown characters, including Kean. He was, however, more prudent in money matters. When he received his salary on Saturday night he would leave the greater part of it at home, and then sally forth for a lark.

GREENPORT, L. I., Jan. 6 -- A sensation was created here yesterday. The wife of Dr. C. H. Wilson was seen rushing down. Main Street, screaming for help. She said her brother. Dr. William P. Manaton, had gone crazy and was trying to kill her.

Funeral services were held yesterday afternoon over the body of Col. Floyd Clarkson, Past Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic of the State of New-York, at the Collegiate Church, Forty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue. The church was filled with the personal friends of Col. Clarkson and delegations from the Grand Army of the Republic and the various societies to which he belonged.

The Yeni Jami is one of the beautiful mosques of Stamboul, frequented at all hours by a motley crowd of worshippers. Leave behind you the glare, the hurry, and the rush of the thronged street, thrust your feet into the wide slippers at the door, and enter the beautiful building at the hour of prayer.

The delegates to the Kings County Republican Committee held a conference in Criterion Hall, Fulton and Grand Avenues, Brooklyn, last evening. There were seventy delegates present. The conference was held in order that there might be no factional fight at the annual meeting of the committee Tuesday night.
Women's organizations are becoming so numerous and popular that " I saw you at the club the other day " is a remark frequently to be heard among women as they meet in the shops and on the streets.

Dr. Chauncey M. Depew had a word to say yesterday about the make-up of the Assembly committees. He said it to George R. Malby, the Speaker, who was at the Windsor Hotel, but concealed from all visitors except Thomas C. Platt, Dr. Depew, James R. Belden, and possibly one or two others who are directing him how to revise the work which he will submit to the Assembly this week.
BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- Money between banks was offered very freely at 1 per cent. Call loans on the Street were reported at a lower figure than yesterday.

From The London Daily News. Mr. Joseph Standeven, a Yorkshire cattle dealer, appears, from his own evidence given in the Coroner's Court at Blackstone Edge, to be a person of playful habits which lead him to jest with young women on the subject of marriage. Like Praed's heroine, he has " smiled on many just for fun," but unlike that person, he has not always conveyed the impression that there was " nothing in it."

From The London Telegraph. Since it was decided in a case recently referred to in these columns that the French law of 1800 against the wearing of unauthorized disguises applies to women dressing as men, and not to men dressing as women, the authorities appear to have determined to put into fresh vigor such powers as they do possess under it.

It appears that the custom of paying an author by an agreed percentage on the sale of each volume is almost universal in France. Books are sold in editions of 1,000, and publishers find it to their interest to advertise that a book has passed into as many editions as possible, as the more successful the public suppose the book to be, the more it is bought.

EASTON. Md., Jan. 6 -- A contested election case, which has been going on since before Christmas, drew the usual crowd to-day. As it progresses the fun of what was at first laughed at as a great joke oozes out, and the serious consequences begin to loom up rather ominously.

A newspaper feud of long standing culminated yesterday at Flatbush, L,. I., in a battle royal between two local editors, Henry C. Furphy of The Supervisor and Victor L. Bedingfield of The Flatbush Press.

It must be admitted that the pterodactyls were somewhat dragonlike, especially the larger species; for, though most were of moderate size, not exceeding that of a crow or a flying fox and some even no larger than sparrows, yet the largest attained a spread of wing of more than four fathoms.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S. I., Jan. 6 -- The perjury case of District Attorney Fitzgerald against Lester A. Scofield and David J. Jones was concluded before Justice Acker to-day. The case has been pending since October. The complaint grew out of charges made by Scofield and Jones against Fitzgerald, George Van Name, and Edward Lawson, alleging that they had received and counted illegal votes and double ballots at a primary in the village of Port Richmond.

-- Mr. Richard Burmeister, the eminent pianist and composer, whose recent appearances with the Damrosch Symphony Orchestra stamped him as an artist of the first rank, has been engaged to give two piano recitals, on the evenings of Tuesday, Jan. 16, and Friday. Jan. 19, at Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, under the management of Leon Margulles's concert bureau.

RONDOUT, N. Y., Jan. 6. -- An explosion which shook the country for miles around, destroyed thousands of dollars' worth of property, and instantly killed four men, occurred at the works of the Laflin Rand Powder Company in Rifton at 8 o'clock this morning.

It is, indeed, inconceivable that he should have attacked a British force when and where he did knowing it to be British.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., Jan. 6 --" Auldwood," the magnifieent Summer residence which Joseph C. Hoagland of New-York and Brooklyn is constructing three miles from this place, will be completed and ready for occupancy about the 1st of June next.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 6. -- Police zeal in this city has reached its zenith. One faction of local "Hawkshaws," anxious to secure the conviction of the men they consider guilty of committing the now famous masked burglaries, has distanced all detective competitors in the race for evidence.

The first "Saturday Night" of the Lotos Club in 1894 was of a type worthy the occasion. The club quarters at 558 Fifth Avenue were pretty well filled last evening with members and guests, and the evening, taken as a whole, was of a characteristically jolly nature.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which the correspondents desire to be used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 6. -- Mrs. Frank B. Clark, President of the Minnesota Woman's World's Fair Board, a familiar figure at all the gatherings of the National Board in Chicago last Summer, and a woman prominent in all movements for the advancement of woman, has mysteriously disappeared according to a story which appeared in this week's issue of the leading Catholic paper of the North-west.

PARIS, Jan. 6. -- At the Ministerial Council held at the palace of the Elysee to-day a dispatch was read from the Governor of Senegal confirming the reports of an engagement between French and British forces near Warina. The Governor said the French commander thought the British were enemies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The actors and actresses who are now playing engagements at the Chicago theatres lent substantial aid to their less fortunate. fellows Thursday. As a result of the annual benefit matinee given for the Actors' Fund of America at the Columbia, Manager William J. Davis of the theatre has in round numbers $1,600, which he will turn over to Frank Sanger, the Treasurer of the fund, for the relief of the needy.

The fashionable season for small persons accords with that of their elders, and, though the holiday week is popularly supposed to be sacred to children, the rest of the Winter witnesses a good deal of little folks gayety. The dancing school receptions -- most of them take place early in the year -- and children's parties are not considered incompatible with the Lenten fasts.

Mr. Greenwood writes with perfect sincerity and with scarcely a trace of irony, let alone cynicism. His lexicon is divided into short, unnumbered chapters, and each is a little essay in which the author's rich fund of general knowledge and of special information on this subject is illustrated, not without humor, but with sympathy and an evident sense of the real importance of his task.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 6 -- To-day the rivals of John. Henry Gear for Senator from Iowa have devoted to bracing up their own columns and resisting the onslaught of the Gear campaign of bluff. The result has been a strengthening of each man's candidacy and somewhat of a weakening of the Gear columns.

There are, of course, a large number of people who will say that the physical danger of football outweighs all possible advantages. This is an objection to our preamble which must be disposed of before proceeding further. The question is one of degree. There is an amount of danger to life and limb which would outweigh the advantages of football or anything else except patriotism or martyrdom.

An industry which may have a great future in the United States has been started in New-York. It is that of tapestries, to rival those of the Gobelins and Beauvais looms, which have been, and are being, woven at a small private establishment on the banks of the classic Bronx in Westchester.

NEWPORT, R. I., Jan. 6 -- Upon the return of yachtsmen next season Newport Harbor will be found greatly improved, both as to its entrance and for anchorage purposes. The extensive dredging about the southeast end of Goat Island is about completed, and, under the direction of United States engineers, a spit is now being placed in position to mark the limit of safe anchorage.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 6. -- Notwithstanding repeated raids of the police the lottery shops are still in operation in every part of the city. Twenty-five to thirty arrests have been made daily since the day the new concern began its operations, but as each policy shopkeeper is arrested, an agent of the company appears to give bonds for the prisoner, and he resumes his place in his lottery den.

A well-dressed and fine-looking man was taken yesterday morning to the Tombs Police Court. He had been brought from Police Headquarters, where he had spent the night, and was accompanied by Detectives Evanhoe and Vallely and by Deputy Sheriff Cornish of Oswego, N.Y., who had a warrant for his arrest, issued by the Recorder of Oswego.

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date in 1892. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

With the blessing of this Holinesa the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople and Pope of New Rome, Neophytus VIII., transmitted through his accredited representative, a new congregation of the orthodox Greek Church was born in this city yesterday.

Copyright, 1894, by The United Press. BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The differences between Chancellor von Caprivi and Finance Minister Miquel have been settled provisionally. At least, the rupture has been postponed through Miquel's waiting policy. The Chancellor's quarrel with Count Botho zu Eulenburg, Prussian Premier, grows keener.
The following additional contributions to the general fund of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association collection are reported by Charles Lanier, the Treasurer, 17 Nassau Street:

The effect of President HARRISON'S retaliatory proclamations and duties upon our trade with Venezuela, Colombia, and Haiti is to be seen in the decline of imports rather than in the condition of our export trade with those countries. For example, the value of our imports from Venezuela fell from $10,325,338 in 1892 to only $3.625,118 in 1893.

Two hopeful residents of Reading, Penn., JOSIAH L.
