KOLBACH and AUGUSTUS ALBRIGHT, are going to Germany next week in pursuit of the Spang estate, which holds a modest place in the list of such properties, being a paltry matter of only $20.000,000. For two generations, we are told by the Philadelphia Press, the American "heirs" of this estate have been trying to establish their claims and get hold of the money.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The local security market showed an improving tendency, but the investment demand was not of sufficient magnitude to create an advance in prices. Quotations show few changes of importance. There was very little news to affect values.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 7. -- Dispatches-dated at Rio de Janeiro on Jan. 4 say that Admiral da Gama is still making a hard fight. He expected at that time that Admiral Mello would be back at Rio by Jan. 5 with the Insurgents' cruisers Republica and Aquidaban. Mello was then supposed to be in the south.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $2,981,500. The banks now hold $83,796,650 more than the legal requirements. The charges in the average show an increase in loans of $1,200,700, an increase in specie of $4,757,000, an increase in legal tenders of $1,246,200, an increase in deposits of $12,086,800, and a decrease in circulation of $67,500.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Dec. 18. -- The United States Revenue steamer Grant, en route from New-York to Puget Sound, sailed from this port to-day for the coast of Brazil. The destination is either Pernambuco or Bahia, and is dependent upon the condition of the coal supply in the vessel when Pernambuco shall be reached.

John Y. McKane, Justice Richard V. B. Newton, Justice Kenneth F. Sutherland, and the Gravesend Election Inspectors will this morning be called upon to plead to the indictments found against them by the Extraordinary Grand Jury ten days ago.

There were symptoms of unusual police activity in the down-town districts between midnight of Saturday and early this morning. This unwanted display of official energy was directed toward the saloon keepers, and they were inclined to attribute it to some new or impending movement on the part of the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst and his forces.

WASATCH, Utah, Jan. 7. -- The Wintah and Uncompahgre Indian reservations, which Delegate Rawlins is endeavoring to have opened for settlement this Winter, comprise some of the richest agricultural and mineral lands in the Territory. There are about 5,000,000 acres, probably one-fourth of which is available for agricultural and grazing purposes, and 250,000 acres for agricultural purposes alone.

The annual meeting of the patrons and members of Mount Sinai Hospital was held yesterday in the dispensary building, at 149 East Sixty-seventh Street. The Directors in their annual report said that the generous contributions to the hospital funds, even during the financial depression, had enabled the officers to maintain the work up to, and even beyond, the standard.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. ROME, Jan. 7. -- Palermo has been filled with rumors since yesterday morning that an attempt would be made to mob the prison and release Deputy de Felice, the Socialist leader. Last night, therefore, the guard at the prison was increased, but there has been no sign of an approaching attack on the building.

Sunday among the poor of New-York differs little from any other day in their hard struggle to keep life and hope in existence until the crisis of poverty shall be past. The east side yesterday was a picture, the far west side a scene of life and activity.

BOSTON, Jan. 7. -- In response to a call issued by Capt Wheelright of Harvard, 160 candidates for the Mott Haven team appeared before Instructor Lathrop. The latter said that even at this early date it is plain that there is to be an intensely-exciting struggle for the cup this year. There has been a great increase in the interest in track athletics at Yale during the past few years.

A middle-aged man, with a dark mustache and Van Dyke beard, is creating a sensation in South Brooklyn by accosting pretty girls and kissing them without the formality of an introduction. The man is a stranger in the locality. He first made his appearance Thursday afternoon at Robert Graves's wall-paper factory.
Supervisor at Large Thomas Fitchie remained at home yesterday, resting and preparing for the battle that is to be waged at the meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors this afternoon.

"Heredity; Its Influence on Character," was Dr. Stanton Colt's subject when he addressed the Society for Ethical Culture in Music Hall yesterday morning. He had a large audience, which applauded his address at its conclusion.

Mr. ELIHU THOMSON has written an interesting article entitled "Electricity in 1876 and in 1893," being, as the title implies, a comparative study of the electrical exhibits at Philadelphia and at Chicago. Indeed, there is no comparison. It seems that the whole application of electricity to human uses, excepting only in telegraphic communication and in the plating of metals, has been developed since the Centennial.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 7. -- Great excitement prevails in Belem Prison over the escape of Father Castanada, a priest implicated in the late uprising in the State of Guerrero, and one of the most important prisoners held by the authorities. While the guards were not looking he succeeded in making his escape and has not been seen since, although telegrams have been sent in every direction and scores of officers are scouring the country.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1@1 1/2 per cent., the average being about 1 per cent.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 7. -- There is much discussion here as to the possibility of John J. Ingalls entering the Senatorial contest for the seat now occupied by John Martin, of fusion fame. It is true that the last public declaration made by Ingalls was that he would bide his time, and he intimated that the time would be when a successor to Peffer was to be selected.

Those Republicans who think it worth while to make a show of trying to elect Lemuel E.Quigg and Frederick Seagrist to Congress as successors to Ashbel P. Fitch and John R. Fellows have arranged for some campaign speaking by spellbinders of national reputation.

ELGIN, Ill., Jan. 7. -- Clark Burr, one of the wealthiest and most prominent farmers in this county, shot and instantly killed his seventeen-year-old son, Charles Burr, this morning. The two were engaged in a quarrel, and young Burr attempted to draw a revolver. The father seized a shotgun and fired the contents into the boy's head, killing him instantly.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The Foreign Office is giving much attention to the uprising in Sicily in view of its probable effect on the European situation. It is known that the Emperor has conferred with Chancellor von Caprivi and Freiherr von Marschall-Bieberstein on the subject of France's responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- About all that the foreign war ships in Rio Harbor find to do just now is to protect the merchant vessels of their respective Governments from the intermittent firing of the Government forts and the insurgent ships. Important commercial interests are being constantly exposed to injury, much to the anxiety of the masters of vessels.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 7. -- Peter De Grief, a retired and rich hotel keeper of Greenport, died here yesterday. His body had hardly been laid out by Undertaker Ruland when an undertaker from Greenport appeared and demanded of Albert Jones possession of the body, by authority of Mrs. Cook of Greenport, with whom De Grief boarded previous to his visit to Patchogue.

An exhaustive report of the operations of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies for the year ending Nov. 30, 1893, has been issued by the receivers and the President and Board of Managers of the two companies. It is shown that a large decrease in railroad gross receipts was caused by the prostration of business in the last half of the year.

Luther D. Wishard, who is one of the Secretaries of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association, spoke yesterday afternoon at Association Hall on "The Young Men of the World." Mr. Wishard returned recently from the Orient, where he spent four years conferring with missionaries and studying the educational institutions of various lands with the view of ascertaining the advisabiliay of further extending the foreign field of the work of the association.
The following letter was made public yesterday:
The astounding disclosures in The NewYork Times yesterday regarding the ruined Commercial Bank of Brooklyn caused profound Amazement in every circle.

The Boston correspondent of The Book Buyer writes: "The brief autobiography of Francis Parkman, which has been so long in the keeping of the Massachusetts Historical Society without its nature being known, proves to be most charming. There was in Mr. Parkman a sweetness, a manliness, a nobility, which make any personal utterance of his doubly attractive, and the only regret is that the document is not more extensive.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 7. -- A movement has been started here for the erection of a statue to the memory of Nathan Hale, who was captured on the shore of Huntington Bay by the British. Those having the matter in charge have planned to raise by subscription sufficient money to place a bronze statue in front of the memorial building erected to the memory of soldiers and sailors killed in the civil war.

"The Jesuit Conspiracy Against Our Public Schools" is the title of a series of sermons, the first of which was preached yesterday by the Rev. Madison C. Peters, in the Bloomingdale Church, Boulevard and Sixty-eighth Street. He said:

W. O. Atwater, Professor of Chemistry in the Wesleyan University, lectured last evening before the Science Sermons Society, in the chapel of the Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, on "The Food Supply in its Relation to the Present Condition and Future Development of Society."
In the course of some comments upon the present condition of business and industry in this country and the causes of the prevailing depression, the Toronto Globe says:
MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 7. -- The United Press correspondent in Rio de Janeiro has sent this dispatch under the date of Jan. 2:

Major S.T. Dickinson has sold to A. J. Weich of Hartford, Conn., the whole of his stable of fast trotting horses, with one exception. This constitutes the largest private sale of trotting stock ever consummated in this city. The eight mares sold cost the Major $47,500, but the price that "Andy" Welch gave for them is not stated.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- When the Legislature shall meet on Tuesday night, the committees in both houses will be announced. The names of the Chairmen of the leading Senate committees were printed in The New-York Times a week ago. No change has yet been made in the list.

From the wilds of Arkansas there has come to town the weird story of one Anita Vernon, a beauteous and forlorn damsel found half starved, footsore, and exhausted on the Ozark Mountains by two gentlemen of Texas -- to wit, Manuel Nobez of Dallas and "Piney" Netters of El Paso.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L. I., Jan. 7. -- District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan did not start work on his contract in this city during the first week in January. That was the time set for the commencement of operations by the General Improvement Commission that awarded the job to the District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor.
The Brooklyn "machine" leaders will meet to-night in the Thomas Jefferson Building, on Court Square. The Kings County Democratic General Committee is to be organized for the year 1894.

The first Sunday Times of 1894 was a remarkably good paper. In its twenty-four pages was news from all over the world, remarkably diversified as to character, and much of it as important as it was interesting.

The bicycle exhibition will open in Madison Square Garden this morning. It will be the greatest exhibition of bicycles and accessories that has ever been held in this or any other country. All the big bicycle manufacturers of this country and many of the most important ones from England will have exhibits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Everbody who has read the amazing story of J. Hale Sypher's performance in the Committee on Naval Affairs of the House, when Sypher accused members of the committee of having been appointed to allow speed premiums to contractors in violation of law, have wondered that Sypher escaped being, kicked out of the committee room.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 7. -- The Mississippi Valley passenger train that arrived here at 8:05 this morning was boarded by robbers at the crossing of the Vicksburg and Meridian Railroad, just south of Vicksburg, at 1:05 A. M. The train was stopping at the crossing, waiting for a Vicksburg and Meridian train to pass.

An alert and ingenious imagination, good taste, and more intimate acquaintance with the sea and with naval affairs than the most exacting may expect are revealed in this little book on Paul Jones. This hero has not been one of our familiar deities. He left in Paris a record which American chronicles do not match.

SALTLAKE CITY, Utah, Jan. 6. -- In the minds of the people at large the name Utah is associated with Mormonism, pure and simple. People who know nothing of its wonderful resources have, or believe they have, perfect knowledge of that remarkable mail who led his poverty-stricken followers to the Great Basin, then a desert, and caused it to bloom as a paradise.
Alderman William H. Murphy, who represented the Twelfth Assembly District in the Board of Aldermen, died yesterday morning at Lakewood, N. J., after a short illness.
PARIS, Jan. 7. -- Senatorial elections were held to-day in 189 districts. The returns up to midnight show the election of 78 Republicans, 9 Radicals, 2 "Rallied," and 5 Conservatives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- During the last three or four days, while the Democrats have been trying to get the Wilson Tariff bill before the House, there has been at all times a quorum of Democrats in the city, and there should have been no delay in ordering consideration of the Wilson bill and in shelving the question of privilege of Capt. Boutelie.

A Maronite priest, who has come all the way from Mount Lebanon, Syria, and who reads and speaks the Chaldaic language, is soon to commence missionary work among the Arabic-speaking Catholics of the United States. He has been, given permission by Archbishop Corrigan to officiate as a priest in this diocese, and he has also been recommended to other Archbishops and Bishops throughout the country.

Capt. Hugh Coleman, until a few weeks ago commander of Company E, Sixty-ninth Regiment, intends to have Adjt. Gen. Porter tell him whether or not Major Duffy has any right to order him out of the room of his disbanded company when he goes there for the purpose, he says, of attending to the business of turning over State property to the battalion.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7. -- The large plant of J. J. Dobson at the Falls of Schuylkill will start up to-morrow, giving employment to 1,800 hands. This notice was posted yesterday:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan.7. -- Col.E.A. Walton, a well-known oil man, dropped dead here to-day while walking on the street with two friends. He had been living in Buffalo for a year. He was the inventor of a process for diluting oil which was said to cheapen it without injuring its quality.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 7. -- Beyond the meagre fact that Miss May Barrowcliff had passed a comfortable night and was visibly improved this morning, the authorities at the City Hospital would give no information concerning the patient's condition. Reporters who called were told that no further information could be given out.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 7. -- The Iowa Legislature will meet to-morrow. There has been little pretense at keeping Sunday by the Republican politicians, who are plotting and scheming to control the organization of the two houses. The scenes of yesterday were repeated to-day, except that the women candidates kept away from the hotels and other places where the preliminary contests were being fought out.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 7. -- The Iowa Legislature will meet to-morrow. There has been little pretense at keeping Sunday by the Republican politicians, who are plotting and scheming to control the organization of the two houses. The scenes of yesterday were repeated to-day, except that the women candidates kept away from the hotels and other places where the preliminary contests were being fought out.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7. -- The true financial status of Harvard College was shown the other day when the announcement was made that two professors and four instructors were to be dropped at the close of this academic year. Outside of Cambridge it has usually been believed that Harvard is the possessor of fabulous wealth, and that the Faculty, from the President down, are drawing magnificent salaries and living in state.

C. William Noyes of the Royal London Yacht Club is in Philadelphia. He is going back to England this week, after a four months' visit to this country. The Philadelphia Inquirer says Mr. Noyes is hopeful of there being a good yachting season this year.

Mayor Schieren will have the hearty cooperation of the Senators and Assemblymen from Brooklyn in his reform work. The Legislature this year will work in the interests of the people. All the bills to be presented will first be submitted to Mr. Schieren. He will be aided in this work by James Taylor, who will be appointed Chairman of the Committee on Cities by Speaker Malby.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 7 . -- The various athletic teams for sports which prevail in the Spring at the Naval Academy have selected their management and started into regular draining and practice.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 6. -- The local stock market presents the characteristic dullness of the first week of the new year. Few transactions on the street, and still fewer on the local exchange, with slightly lower quotations, both as regards bids and offers, will cover the situation.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Jan. 7. -- There is excitement here over the election of the President and Directors of the national bank which takes place to-morrow. The contest is between the rival tickets representing the difference between a conservative and, as some of the citizens intimate, a far too progressive governing body.

JEFFERSON'S declaration, in defining the limit of safety beyond which we should not go in annexing outlying islands, that "nothing should ever be accepted that would require a navy to defend it," may, in these later times, be amended by adding "and all entanglements in island countries having no cable connection should be diligently avoided."

It is now pretty well settled that the Democratic majority will stand by the cause of tariff reform, and that the incometax proposition will not be saddled on the Tariff bill, but will be submitted separately, with no doubt as to its fate. On both decisions, if they shall be carried out as now seems certain, the party and the country are to be congratulated.

Mrs. Henry Ady believes that the letters of Charles II to his sister, which she here reproduces in their original text for the first time, "give us a better idea of this monarch's character than we had before." "We see him," she says, "it is true, with all his faults and weaknesses, his incurable levity and cynical unconcern, his indolence and easy good nature.

At a dinner given by the Manufacturers Exchange of Denver on Dec. 20 speeches were made which prove conclusively that in spite of the direful forebodings of some of her citizens that Colorado would go to the "demnition bow-wows" as a result of the repeal of the silver-purchasing clause of the Sherman law, the State is by no means discouraged, but, on the contrary, is fast recovering from the general financial depression.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 8. -- The Duval Athletic Club this afternoon announced that it proposed to bring about the prize fight between Corbett and Mlttchell, despite the opposition of the Governor and the opinion of Attorney General Lamar that the fight would be a violation of the laws of Florida. The club people say they hare the law on their side and that Gov. Mitchell is acting in a tyrannical and extra-judicial manner.
Mayor Gilroy received this communication yesterday from R.H. Macy Co.:
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 8. -- Julius Burrow, an insurance broker of 12 Waverley Place, New-York, committed suicide at his home here this morning by shooting himself in the right temple with a revolver.

The mountaineers by whose testimony the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association intends to prove that John C. Austin is alive, made their debut yesterday in the witness stand before Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court, where the suit to recover $15,000 insurance on the life of Mr. Austin is on trial.

The members of the "reform" movement in the New-York Athletic Club, who have nominated Mr. W. S. Schuyler for President in opposition to Mr. Bartow S. Weeks, issued a criticism of the Treasurer's report yesterday. A comparative analysis was made showing the difference in the receipts and expenditures between the years 1892 and 1893. The income last year was $10,8615.24 more than, the previous year, and the expenditure $50,761.13 more.

The funeral services of James Austin Underhill were held yesterday afternoon at his late residence, Brick Church, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Anthony Schuyler of Grace Church, Orange, officiated, with the impressive ceremonies of the Protestant Episcopal Church for the burial of the dead.

John Y. McKane and his Coney Island henchmen, indicted by the Extraordinary Grand Jury, did not plead to the indictments in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. The case was adjourned until this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- When the House met again, at 8 P.M., there were only twenty members present, but there was a large crowd in the gentlemen's gallery. The House promptly went into Committee of the Whole on the Tariff bill -- Mr. Richardson (Dem., Tenn.,) in the chair.

All those who are interested in the decent and orderly transaction of Congressional business must resent Mr. Boutelle of Maine. At present such persons include everybody who is engaged in business in the United States, for it is agreed that, the sooner Congress disposes of the new Tariff bill the sooner will business revive.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- The Oswego Board of Trade, at a meeting held to-day, unanimously adopted resolutions favorable to the Wilson bill and specially commending the clause regulating the duty on barley and barley malt.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- The peristyle, with the Music Hall and Casino at either end, was the most imposing object seen by the World's Fair visitor as he approached Jackson Park from Lake Michigan.

A few days ago Mr. Andrew Carnegie made provision for a continuance of work in the factories of the Carnegie Steel Company, offered to duplicate all contributions for the benefit of the unemployed in Pittsburg to the amount of $250,000, and sailed for Europe in pursuit of health.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Supreme Court of the United States, Monday. Jan. 8 -- Present: The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Field. Mr. Justice Har an. Mr. Justice Gray. Mr. Justice Brewer, Mr. Justice Brown, Mr. Justice Shiras, and Mr. Justice Jackson.

-- Falsehoods, -- Same droll llar prints in a San Francisco newspaper a statement that, Irving played only four weeks in New-York to "poor business," and that Bessie Bellwood is "drawing to "big business," while the presence of the Bellwood woman has been scarcely noticed. Archer, the "crank" critic of The London World, informs raders of that paper that American "dramatic critics" preferred " The Silver Shell "to "The Second Mrs. Tanqueray."

When the registration figures for Gravesend were announced by John Y. McKane last Fall. The New-York Times was the first newspaper to call attention to their startling significance and to point out the enormous frauds on the ballot which they foreshadowed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The cruiser NewYort, now on her way to Rio Janeiro, was formally and finally accepted by the Secretary of the Navy to-day, and becomes the sole property of the Government. Treasury warrants for the balance of the amount due on her have been mailed to her contractors.

Upon the application of the required number of citizens Judge Wallace of the United States Circuit Court yesterday signed an order authorizing John I. Davenport to appoint Inspectors of Election for the special elections of Jan. 30, when two Congressmen to succeed Messrs. Fellows and Fitch in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Districts are to be chosen.

The opening or the present week shows an increase of activity by real estate brokers and agents. A number of sales were made yesterday which the persons concerned in are not yet ready to announce, and the indications are favorable to further business. There are also intimations of a beginning of voluntary auction offerings.
The following announcement was made yesterday at the Department of Taxes and Assessments:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- It is understood here to-night that the request for the restrictions which have been placed upon the Corwin's crew came from Minister Willis and was turned over to Secretary Carlisle for enforcement.

ROME, Jan. 8. -- According to dispatches received from Sicily to-day affairs are quiet on that island. Gen. Morra di Lavriano, the military commander of the island, which is in a state of siege, has issued an order forbidding the company controlling the cable connecting the island with the mainland to accept any cipher messages or messages written in secret languages.

When the sub-committee of the Assembly Committee on Elections met yesterday morning in Part III. of the Court of Common Pleas to continue its investigator of the contested cases by which the Republicans hope to unseat six Democratic Assemblymen, the frivolous character of the charges on which the defeated Republican candidates base their claims became apparent.

American railway securities were strong in the London market. Saturday's upward movement in the New-York market had caused prices to open considerably higher, and on liberal covering of shorts the advance continued until near the close, when a fractional reduction occurred. St. Paul continued the leader, closely followed by Lake Shore.
Whitelaw Reid gave a dinner at his residence. 451 Madison Avenue, last night, at which a number of prominent Republicans were present.

There was more excitement about the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday afternoon than has been known since the building was erected, fifty years ago. Politicians blocked up the corridors, filled the committee rooms and crowded into the Council Chamber, all anxious to witness the organization of the new Board of Aldermen.
"The landlords of New-York are doing splendidly in this great crisis of poverty," said Superintendent Hebberd of the Charity Organization Society to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday.
The second of this season's trio of balls by the Patriarchs took place last night at Delmonico's. The function was larger than its predecessors, and equally successful.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 8. -- With creditable unanimity the Democrats of the House to-day asserted their right to control the business of that body, swept aside the pestilent Boutelle, and took up the Tariff bill under a rule that will bring it to a vote on Monday, Jan. 29.
Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 8. -- Everything is quiet to-day in this capital.

After the third act of "Our Country Cousins," the new play by Mr. Paul M. Potter, which had its first presentation at the Lyceum Theatre last evening, the audience applauded until the curtain had three times revealed the row of bowing comedians, and then, as the demonstrative expressions of approval still continued, Mr. Frohman himself appeared.
Money on call loaned at 1 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 8. -- Notwithstanding the number of men eager for almost any kind of work in Waltham, there is one job that workmen are fighting shy of; in fact, one man says: "I would not undertake it again if they would give me the whole Walker estate."

The place of business in this city at 69 Mercer Street of the George C. Treadwell Company, whose fur manufacturing head-quarters are at Albany, N.Y., was seized by the Sheriff yesterday on several attachments, which were obtained on the ground that the company is a New-Jersey corporation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- The visible supply statement was the most important feature to the wheat market to-day. When it was expected to show from 500,000 bushels to 750,000 bushels decrease early in the day prices advanced, but when the official returns were all posted and the difference from last week was but 275,000 bushels less prices declined.

The South Brooklyn Railroad and Terminal Company presented yesterday to the Common Council of Brooklyn an application for permission to extend its railroad eastward through the Twenty-sixth Ward of that city.
VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 8. -- The steamer Warrimoo, which arrived here to-night, brings advices from Honolulu under date of Jan. 1.

Although, according to Superintendent Hebberd of the Charity Organization Society, Mr. Oliver Sumner Teall is "not to be treated seriously," there are others, among them Austin Corbin, who seem to have the utmost confidence in his plan, of handing out food without asking questions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- Ten shares of Metropolitan Traction sold to-day at 96 7/8 Philadelphia Traction was quoted at 89 1/2 @90, and Baltimore was dull around 16 1/2@17. People's sold at 28. While there are very few orders to buy any of the tractions there are quite as few orders to sell, and the market is so dull at times that it is almost impossible to make quotations either way.
The New-York Presbytery adopted measures at its meeting in the chapel of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon for the further relief of the poor people of the city.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 8. -- The Oyster Dredgers' Protective Association is at work on its first case -- the problem of liberating a German who is said by former associates to be held in captivity. The German Society of Maryland has helped, or tried, to obtain justice for hundreds of ill-used and unfortunate dredgers, and the protective association is an outgrowth thereof.

The defense of the provision in the "conference committee's" draft of a new ballot law which permits the "independent illiterate voter" to have assistance in marking his ballot, as stated in the letter of Mr. Gustav H. Schwab printed in our columns yesterday, is that something of the kind is necessary to avoid an obstacle to the exercise of the right of suffrage which might be judicially construed as invalidating the law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The extent to which partisans will go who are inspired by malice and a cheap desire to manufacture political capital for their party is well illustrated in the conduct of Mr. Hoar and Mr. Chandler in connection with the Hawaiian affair.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- The annual statement of through-rate shipments of flour, grain, and provisions east-bound from Chicago, as prepared by the Central Traffic Association, shows that the total shipments for 1893 amounted to 1,041,367 tons, against 1,334,887 tons for 1892. The total shipments were made up of 282,229 tons of flour, 1,237,222 tons of grain, and 421,916 tons of provisions.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 8. -- Police Superintendent Smith this evening denied with much indignation a sensational report, to the effect that Miss May Barrowcliff had told the police that she was waylaid in Sip Avenue by two tramps, who carried her to a vacant house, where she was detained until 2 or 3 o'clock the next morning, and then removed to the vacant lot, where she was left for dead.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Jan. 8 -- P. M. The law of gravitation was at work in to-day's stock market upon the securities that were favorites in last week's upward movement. Holders of stocks in which the quotations showed good profits seemed disposed to yield to the temptation to transfer to their pockets the accounts that looked well on paper, content to make fresh start at another time.

The case of the New-York and Northern Railway minority stockholders against the New-York Central Railroad Company and others came up on demurrer yesterday before Justice Ingraham in the Supreme Court. Special Term. Simon Sterne appeared for the minority stockholders, and Thomas Thatcher for the New-York Central.

Herman Roeber on Dec. 26 applied at the Leonard Street Police Station for lodging. Just as he approached the desk in the station house the Sergeant was reading an order from Superintendent Byrnes directing the police to arrest all persons who might be found carrying weapons.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 8. -- As soon in the Spring as the ground shall be in condition, the Sigma Phi Society, which recently lost by fire its stately and costly society house, will replace the building with another -- not a new structure, but a building which has a history.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Pelous, Goddess of Fire, waved her torch over the White City tonight, and in a few hours the most beautiful architectural creation of modern times was totally destroyed, and the largest and most imposing of any age was a blackened and smoking ruin.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- Balances between banks this morning loaned at 1 per cent., with New-York funds at par to 10c premium. Money on the Street has not changed since Saturday, call loans ranging from 1 1/2@3 per cent. The best commercial paper only is in demand at 3 1/2@4 1/2 per cent.

The special committee of the State Board of Charities which has been investigating the charges of cruelty against Superintendent Brockway of the Elmira Reformatory listened to testimony on behalf of Mr. Brockway at a session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

The declaration of the court that all the race-track legislation of last Winter is unconstitutional was a complete "knock-out blow" for the owners of the race tracks in New-Jersey who have paid out large sums of money, first to secure the placing of the laws on the statute books and then for the licenses that have been granted under them.

Isidor Straus was nominated for Congress in the Fifteenth Congressional District to succeed Ashbel P. Fitch, and Col, William L. Brown was nominated in the Fourteenth Congressional District to succeed Col. John R. Fellows by Tammany Hall last night.
Applications for the construction of the following new buildings were received by Superintendent Brady of the Building Department yesterday:

Mr. H. Grattan Donnelly's latest play comes pretty near being fine old melodrama of the blood-curdling sort. If you are not too hardened a playgoer to have thrills it will give you a fine assortment of those agreeable sensations. There are "Ha's!" in it and "Halts!" there are "Foileds" and "Furys."

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- The annual report of Charles M. Preston, State Superintendent of Banks, relative to State banks of deposit and discount for the year ended Sept. 30 last is an interesting document to peruse at this time.

Ex-Congressman Frederick Hoisted Teese, one of the best-known lawyers of Newark, died suddenly at the Hoffman House, this city, Sunday night from pneumonia. At 7 o'clock Mr. Teese arrived in New-York from St. Louis, where he had been on business for the Mutual Life. Insurance Company of this city.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 8. -- Justice Lippincott of the Supreme Court has filed his opinion in the case brought against the City of Elizabeth and the New-Jersey Jockey Club, to test the soundness of the race-track laws passed last Winter, and he decides that they are unconstitutional. Justices Depue and Abbett concur in the opinion, and it will not be necessary for the Legislature to take the trouble to repeal the acts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- An unfavorable report upon the nomination of William B. Hornblower of New-York to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States was decided upon to-day by the Senate Judiciary Committee. It was understood before the committee met that the nomination would be acted upon and there was general interest in the result.

Four policemen, commanded by Sergt. White of the Central Office squad, were in attendance at the meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors yesterday afternoon, but, although the meeting was a lively one, the policemen were not called upon to act in an official capacity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Dr. S.F. Neely of Leavenworth, Kan, was in the Senate Press Gallery with a friend this afternoon when his name was presented to the Senate for confirmation as United States Marshal for the District of Kansas. The doctor had expected to hear this news sooner or later and he exhibited no surprise.

If a plan of relief of the poor, suggested by W. d'H. Washington of 145 Broadway and favored by many men prominent in business circles, can be put into successful operation, about $13,000 per day can be raised, in addition to the great sums already contributed to the various charity organizations.
PARIS, Jan. 9. -- La Liberte to-day pubishes a dispatch under a Rio Janeiro date stating that President Peixoto has resigned. The statement contained in the dispatch is not credited here.

Lawyer David Sternlicht of 118 Rivington Street is to-day nursing a face and shoulders sore from the lashes of a horsewhip, wielded by the plump and pretty, as well as vigorous, hand of Miss Rosa Beinglass of 179 Forsyth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Frank Ives to-night defeated George Slosson in the second game of the six-day billiard tournament. He defeated Slosson by 600 to 169, which was worse for Slosson than the game on Monday night, when Sohaefer defeated him by 600 to 208. To-night Ives ran 487 with the anchor nurse.

John Y. McKane, the "boss" of Gravesend, having been grievously beset by reporters both before and since his multifold indictment by the Extraordinary Grand Jury in Brooklyn for his misconduct on election day, yesterday executed a flank movement on one of his reportorial enemies, James H. Fish, the official Reporter of the Extraordinary Grand Jury.

The Lamport and Holt Line steamship Hersched, which arrived from Brazil yeserday, brought a budget of news concerning Mello and his revolt. Two invalid American naval men -- Charles Sullivan, a marine, and Charles Muehlich, a seaman, both from the United States cruiser Newark -- were on board.

William H. Davis, a negro, who is known to the police as " Black Strap," and who is a professional burglar and thief, was arrested Monday night by Detective Sergeant O'Brien on suspicion of having been concerned in the murder of William G. Kaiser, a wealthy baker of Camden, N. J., Dec. 5. The negro was found at 195 Bleecker Street.

Many of the marble blocks in the Washington Arch, which faces Fifth Avenue, are cracked. How deep these cracks are and what caused them the inexperienced observer cannot determine, but they are there, and any one can see them who takes pains to look.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- A court stenographer spoke this afternoon at the trial of Daniel Coughlin for the most important dead witness. Patrick Dinan. His story of the white horse which figured in the Cronin murder and the conversations with the detective forms one of the most binding links in the chain of circumstantial evidence upon which the State proposes to rest its case.

Mayor Gilroy in his annual message to the Common Council presents a methodical review of the affairs of the municipal administration and makes some important suggestions. While the net debt of the city has increased by something over $2,000,000, its distance from the constitutional limit is greater than a year ago, and the amount of bonds issued on account of permanent improvements was fully five times as great as the increase in the debt.

Bartow S. Weeks, Assistant District Attorney, was last night elected President of the New-York Athletic Club by a vote of nearly two to one. The other members of the regular ticket against whom the reform movement was directed were also elected, but by smaller majorities.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L. I., Jan. 9. -- Mrs. Mary Lynch, a widow living at 41 Ninth Street, this city, is a prisoner in St. John's Hospital on suspicion that she caused the death of her new-born child last Friday morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Investigation of the charges against Sheriff Beck of Erie County was begun this morning. Henry W. Bentley, who was chosen by the Governor to hear the charges and report his findings, occupied the Judge's bench. Attorney General Hancock examined the witnesses for the prosecution, and John Cuneen and Willlam E. Delaney acted as counsel for the Sheriff.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. William Cole sold to Elizabeth J. and Margaret A. Culbert, plaintiffs, for $9,960, the four-story brick flat, 850 Lafayette Avenue, south side, 275 feet east of Sumner Avenue, 20 by 100. The adjoining similar building, 852 Lafayette Avenue, he sold to Francis R. Culbert, plaintiff, for $9,930.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin of the Treasury Department, who has charge of customs matters, speaking to-day of the destruction by fire of the exhibits of the World's Fair buildings, said:

Frank Adams, alias James O'Neill, alias James Henry, whose soubriquet is " Jacky," an escaped convict, was arrested in this city yesterday. June 19, 1891, he was sentenced to State prison by Judge Cowing for two years and a half for stealing a watch on a Houston Street car. He was sent to Sing Sing Prison.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- Judge Butler, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day made a formal order upon George L. Crawford, Special Master in the Reading Railroad receivership, directing him to hear testimony in the suit of Isaac L. Rice for the removal of the Reading receivers and for the investigation of other matters pertaining to the management of the company.

So far as the latest news from Hawaii is of an official character it goes to show the absurdity of the sensational reports which are so industriously set afloat every time Honolulu is heard from and so eagerly caught up by those who are anxious to see their own Government "put in a hole."
The principal holders of the bonds of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe and the St. Louis and San Francisco Roads have formed committees as follows:

The foreign exchange market was firm but quiet. The posted rates for sterling were $4.85 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84 1/4, @$4.84 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/2 for demand, $4.86 3/4 for cable transfers, and $4.83@ $4.83 1/2 for commercial.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Owing to the many false reports circulated in regard to Miss May Barrowcliff's condition and a charge that she was not receiving proper attention, her friends being refused permission to see her, Dr. Varick, Chief of Staff of the City Hospital, this evening made an official statement for publication.
"The world was sad, the garden was wild, and man the hermit sigh'd -- till woman smiled."
The Philadelphia Record of the 7th inst. published the following:

Coquelin plays Don Annibal as though he had "made up" "between the yellow covers of a novel written in 1830, and stepped from them directly upon the stage to serve as a living illustration for "Capitaine Fracasse" or "Cinq-Mars."

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 9. -- Minister Williss, in his conference with the provisional Government of Hawaii, read this agreement of Lilluokalani, which he had secured from her as a condition to his efforts to restore her to the throne:

The annual election and meeting of the Bar Association was held last evening at 7 West Twenty-ninth Street. After the routine business James C. Carter submitted resolutions deploring strongly the fact that the Judiciary Committee of the Senate had made a report adverse to the confirmation of the nomination of William B. Hornblower as Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

Steamship Nictheroy, off Pernambuco, Brazil, Dec. 23. -- The Admiral paid a visit to the Nictheroy yesterday and made terms with officers and men for continued service. All hands are satisfied. The Brazilian Government has acted with patience and liberality toward the people on the Nictheroy. Most of the demands made upon it have been allowed.

The New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company, at 52 Wall Street, one of the oldest institutions of its kind in the city, and numbering among its officers some of the most widely-known business men, was charged yesterday with gross mismanagement of a trust fund of more than $80,000, and with having misrepresented the way in which the funds were invested.

An application was received by the Aldermen yesterday from the Police Board for permission to contract for all supplies and work necessary for the special Congressional election in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Districts without advertising for bids. The application was laid over for one week under the rules.

A very pretty entertainment was given in the Empire Theatre yesterday afternoon by the pupils of the Empire Theatre Dramatic School, of which Nelson Wheatcroft is the founder and director. It was the first public exhibition given by the school, which has only been in existence since last Fall, and was designed to show the progress that had been made during this short period.

The increasing amounts of money offered on mortgage loans at 4 1/2 Per cent, is one of the encouraging features of the real estate market just now. But the property on which such loans are to be had must be of the best class. The present week, however, shows more money available in this way than has been the case for many months past.

BUFFALO, Jan. 9. -- William H. Curtiss, well known here, and until a few years ago a well-to-do real estate dealer of this city, shot his wife and eldest daughter, Fannie, at their home, 141 Park Street, this afternoon. The daughter will die.

Manager Sanger of the Madison Square Garden Company is highly pleased with the success of the cycle show. All the afternoon the building was comfortably filled with young ladies and boys, and in the evening its capacity was taxed The show is a very good, one, and the spectators found all their time occupied in studying the different styles of machines and the novelties introduced for the first time.
"I have come around for my money. Is it ail ready? If not, please put it up as soon as you can."

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The Times seems so far to have been the only newspaper to discover and point out the extreme danger underlying what is known as the "independent illiterate" provision in the proposed ballot reform act. The article entitled, "Worse than the Paster," which appears in to-day's issue, is a very strong and logical argument against the adoption of this provision.

The stockholders of the Southern National Bank carried out yesterday the programme outlined last week by voting to reduce the capital stock from $1,000,000 to $500,000. The $500,000 taken from capital will be transferred to surplus, increasing surplus to $615,000, and reducing taxes by $15,000 per year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- There was an absence of talk in the Senate wing of the Capitol to-day on the subject of Hawaii, which was gratifying to those who prefer to be furnished with all the facts relating to the matter before entering upon a discussion of the case.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- But very little business was done in either house beyond the announcement of the committees and appointments by the Speaker and Clerk. In the Senate, Senator Lexow of Rockland introduced the long-expected bill abolishing the Police Board in New-York and re-establishing a board on the non-partisan basis.

The alumni of the University of the City of New-York had their annual dinner at the Brunswick Hotel last night, and several hundred persons were present. The occasion was of especial interest because of a statement made by Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken, which unfolded to some extent a new system of study in some branches of the university's work.
LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The Lisbon correspondent of the United Press forwards the following mail advices, brought from Brazil by the steamship Clyde:

Whenever a dramatic situation of the French repertory disappears for a day, everybody says that Sardou must have taken it, and straightway Sardou is searched. The old experience of Geoffrey of Monmouth, Robert Wace, and Layamon then repeats itself. The situations that Sardou had taken are taken from him, but they are identified everywhere as Sardou's.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Representative Wilson concluded to-day his opening speech on the Tariff bill, a speech that is admitted by members on both sides of the House to be one of the best that has ever been heard in the chamber on the tariff reform side.

There is no doubt that the resources of the existing charitable organizations are overtaxed, and this not merely in respect to money, but in respect to the increase in the work of investigation. But it is also true that a system of indiscriminate almsgiving threatens very extensive mischief.

A well-informed contributor to the columns of The United States Investor, under date of Jan. 3, makes some interesting statements concerning the condition and prospects of the Great Northern Railway, while correcting some errors and omissions in a recent tabulated statement comparing the traffic density of that company with other transcontinental lines.

District Attorney Fellows announced yesterday as successor to Assistant District Attorney Henry B.B. Stapler, Deputy Assistant District Attorney John D. Lindsay. Mr. Lindsay will have charge of appeal cases, and will receive a salary of $7,500 a year, in place of his former salary of $6,000. Col. Fellows first named Hugh O. Pentecost to succeed Mr. Stapler, but the outcry against the nomination caused him to withdraw it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- For upward of two hours this afternoon the Senate Finance Committee held an informal but decidedly interesting meeting, in which an attempt was made to devise ways and means for helping the Treasury. Secretary Carlisle was present for at least an hour, and, with the members of the committee, discussed the condition of the national finances.

Orlando B. Potter died without having made a will. Application was made in the Surrogate's office yesterday for the granting of letters of administration to his son, Frederick Potter, who lives in Ossining, Westchester County. Mrs. Mary Kate Linsly Potter, his mother, renounced her right to serve as administratrix in favor of her son, and the letters were granted.

In the eleventh annual report of the Board of Railroad Commissioners of this State, which was sent to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, the general railroad situation is described as extraordinary. New problems are now confronting the railroad managers, and, in common with vast numbers of business institutions and associations, many of the companies are struggling for existence.

Although the day was cold and cheerless, 400 sportsmen went to Marion. N. J., yesterday to witness the live-bird match between members of the Kings County and New-Jersey Run clubs. There was plenty of sport for the visitors and for the shooters, too, for a wily Jersey City youth opened an "under-and-over-seven" game in the barroom behind the shooters' box, and did a lively business under the very nose of a Jersey City policeman.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 9 -- John Newton, a student at Bethel College, Russellville, Ky., committed suicide last night. He used morphine. The following " advance account " of the suicide, written by himself, was discovered on the table in his room: " Jack Newton of Cadiz, K.y., who has been attending school here for the last six months, was found dead this afternoon in Dr. Harrel's office, with a dagger in his heart.

We advise the Democratic voters and leaders of the districts in which Mr. Straus and Col. Brown are running for Congress to stop making comfortable deductions from the majorities of 1892 and go to work as if they had districts to win against odds instead of districts to hold merely.

Considerable speculation was made about the telegraphic statement some weeks ago that Mr. de Cernea of this city had purchased Clara D., 2:14 3/4. tor $1,600. Mr. de Cernea is one of the best-known men in New-York City in the matter of Handling the trotring stock, and everybody was on the lookout to see who had paid this large price for a road horse.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- The Peristyle, Music Hall, and Casino were totally destroyed by last night's fire. The Manufactures Building was only slightly damaged. The fire was mainly confined to that portion of the roof where the promenade was. The French exhibit suffered most. A fair estimate of their loss is $4,500.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Senate spent some time in executive session to-day, and the impression got abroad that it had the Hornblower case under consideration. This was incorrect. The understanding reached yesterday was that Mr. Hornblower's fate should be decided on Thursday. Inquiry among Senators to-day has failed to develop a sentiment in favor of overriding the decision of the Judiciary Committee.

An unusual number of criminals were arraigned yesterday morning in the Yorkville Police Court by detectives from the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station. The detectives brought into court thirteen prisoners charged with burglary and robbery.

John C. Austin was a most reckless swindler, according to the stories of the Adirondack witnesses examined yesterday in the suit to recover $15,000 from the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association on Mr. Austin's life.

American railway securities were weaker in the London market. The declines, however, did not exceed a fraction, except in Northern Pacific preferred, which fell off 1 1/3 per cent. There was no bad news to affect prices, and the reaction was mainly due to the taking of profits from the recent advance.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Money between banks was offered and loaned at 1 per cent. On the Street call money was 2 per cent., with time money nominally at 3 1/2@4 per cent. Mercantile paper was dull, except for the very best.

Gentlamen interested in athletics on the Pacific coast are desirous of Joining forces with the Amateur Athletic Union, and with that purpose in view H. E. Judge, Chairman of the Multnomah Amateur Athletic Club of Portland, Oregur, made application to form a new association in the far West. In his letter to Secretary Sullivan, he says:

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- The plot to prevent legislation in the interest of the people was carried out this afternoon, attended by the most exciting circumstances ever witnessed in the New-Jersey State House.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 9 -- The managers of the Duval Athletic Club have set a snare for its enemy. Gov. Mitchell, into which they hope JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 9 he mill fall and thereby give them an opportunity to test the Florida law in relation to prize fights.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- An unexpected and sensational turn was given to wheat by the figures issued by the Government yesterday. As far as the report treated of the yield of 1893, very little attention was paid to it, but the acreage given as sown in Winter wheat for 1894 was rather startling, and induced very free buying. One million five hundred and fifty thousand acres less is given as the area for this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Secretary of State and Mrs. Gresham gave a dinner party to-night in honor of the President and Mrs. Cleveland. The dinner was served in the parlors of the H Street annex to the Arlington Hotel. The decorations were in red. The mantels were banked with scarlet blossoms and the tablecloth was strewn with scarlet poinsetta leaves.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- The bears were masters of the situation pending the morning call, but in the afternoon they were on the run. Alley L. opened at 33, and fell steadily until it reached 29 3/4, making only temporary recoveries as it went down. In the afternoon it closed 1/4 better. Lake Street acted in sympathy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The President yesterday sent to the Senate the following nominations:

Mrs. Catharine Palot, a respectable Frenchwoman, who has been a widow for several years, went to Police Headquarters yesterday in search of tidings of her sisterin-law, from whom she had not heard since 1836. Mrs. Palot lives at 226 East Fortyfirst Street, with her two children, whom she supports by doing fine embroidery.

The entries for stakes of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, which closed on the 2d Inst., obtained very flattering support. The names of the horses entered for the Brooklyn Handicap of $25,000, one mile and a quarter, are appended:

A most interesting half hour was devoted yesterday at the home of Richard Watson Gilder to a talk about the Kindergarten Association, in aid of which the second lecture by William Hamilton Gibson, telling of the "Mysteries of the Flowers," is to be given to-day. With the charm of fairy tales these accounts of the ways of nature were described as captivating the intellect and making it half-unconsciously the recipient of absolute scientific knowledge.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 9. -- The Rev. Father Patrick Corrigan, pastor of St. Mary's Church Lady of Grace, died at the rectory, at 8:45 o'clock this evening, from bronchial pneumonia.

UTICA, Jan. 10. -- A great deal of indignation was caused here to-day by certain action of the Board of Supervisors. An investigation into county affairs, made three years ago, disclosed such a state of affairs that suits were brought against several excounty officials to recover money which, it was alleged, they had illegally secured from the county by overcharges.

The amended order entered in Philadelphia by Judge Butler in the suit brought by Mr. Rice against the Reading receivers, together with the court's interpretation of its decision, removes all doubt about a thorough investigation of the receivers' conduct being made. The course of the receivers from their appointment will now be fully ventilated, not only for the benefit of the security holders, but in the public interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Senator and Mrs. Call gave a dinner party to-night in honor of the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Carlisle. The other guests were Minister and Mme. Romero, Miss Mildred Lee, Representative and Mrs. Draper, Senator and Mrs. Charles Gibson, Mr. Sturgis, and Prince Cantacuzene.

commission house of W. F. Beck Co., of this city, which delt chiefly in salmon and in dried and cannedfruits has failed for $300,000. W.F. Beck, in an interview, said: "Our houses in New-York and chicago have also assigned.We have fortytwo agencies throughout the country, and these will all be affected.

ROME, Jan. 10. -- Anarchists made demonstrations at the railway stations in Mantua, Pisa, Modena, and several other cities today, while the troops which had been ordered to Sicily were taking the trains. The Anarchists cheered for Sicily and Anarchy, but when charged by the police they dispersed hurriedly.

Company F's junior team covered itself with glory last evening by scoring 629 points and taking second place in the competition for the Abeel Trophy on the Seventh Regiment's range. This is the highest score ever made by a junior team in this competition. The scores and standing of the various teams follow:

A decision in the long-contested " oyster " cases was made by Justice Gildersleeve, in the Superior Court, yesterday. It was a victory for Timothy Shea. Frank Flandreau, to whom he had assigned his claim against Philp Elsworth for wharfage, received a verdict for $1,288, subject to the opinion of the General Term on the questions of law involved.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 10. -- The reconvened Democratic State Convention of Sept. 19 last was called to order in the Opera House at 12:20 o'clock this afternoon by ex-Congressman E.P. Gillespie of Mercer County, the permanent Chairman. At the beginning of the convention it was manifest that James Denton Hancock of Franklin, Venango County, would be the nominee.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your article of Sunday last, entitled " What Take Teall Seriously? " giving the opinion of Mr. Hebberd, Superintendent of the Charity Organization Society, regarding Mr. Teall'a work for hungry humanity, incites me to openly voice the question that some of us have long been asking among ourselves, " What is the work of the Charity Organization Society in our town? "

The transfer of the Old Epiphany House property, in Stanton Street is in contemplation. This church institution is to be made over to the Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, thereby being placed under the Bishop's direct control. The system of philanthropic work established in this building has received its character largely from the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, represented by Mr. Wills.

BARCELONA, Jan. 10. -- Santiago Salvador, who was arrested at Saragossa and who confessed that he was the author of the bomb explosion in the Lyceum Theatre in this city, was further examined to-day. He denied that Saldani, the Italian Anarchist, also under arrest, took any part in the Anarchist plots.
Charles H. Knox was elected President of the Board of Education at its meeting yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The Republican programme already decided calls for the unseating of one Senator, John McCarty, in the Sixth Kings, and of two Democratic members of the Assembly, Graham of the Sixteenth Kings and McGuire of Richmond County. It has been decided to accept as final the judgment of the Supreme Court of Kings County, and to throw out the whole of the Gravesend votes.

Editors of Republican papers from many parts of the State were in this city yesterday as thick as blackberries. They came in response to a call from John A. Sleicher to organize an association, for social and political purposes.

Terence C. O'Reilly, a lawyer, who had an office at 155 East Fifty-seventh Street and lived at 8 Beekman Place, died yesterday morning at the home of his father-inlaw, Felix A. Mulgrew of 21 Beekman Place, from injuries received on Monday afternon by being knocked down by a United States mail wagon near the entrance of the Brooklyn Bridge.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10. -- The movement to get the Legislature to give a part of the public school funds to the parochial schools of the Catholic Church having been abandoned by order of Cardinal Gibbons, there remains general interest in the policy of the Catholic Church toward the public schools of the State.

The Executive Committee of the Business Men's General Committee to aid the Industrial Christian Alliance in its people's restaurant system received a letter yesterday from Archbishop Corrigan, who had promised his aid. The letter read as follows:

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Jan. 10 -- Five masked men stopped the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railway's fast train, the " Ell," about 6:40 this evening, four miles east of this city, and robbed the express and mail cars. The men placed torpedoes on the track and swung a red lantern to stop the train, and as it slowed up three of them climbed into the engine cab.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The Buffalo and the Brooklyn Republicans have declared war, and the trouble predicted in these columns ten days ago has been started. A more disgusted and disgruntied lot of statesmen has seldom been seen around Albany than the representatives of the second and third largest cities in the State.

William C. Whitney has retired from the Directory of the Western National Bank, of which he was one of the incorporators and original Directors when the bank was organized, in 1885, with ex-Secretary Daniel Manning as President. J.M. Ceballos has been elected a Director in Mr. Whitney's place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Representative Tom L. Johnson made a speech in the House to-day on the Tariff bill that created a profound sensation. It was business itself, and the energetic and vivacious talker imparted to the House so much of his vigor and spirit that when he closed the body was in a tingle of excitement.

The loan market continues to be a significant feature in real estate transactions. Nearly every office yesterday had money to loan at 4 1/2 per cent, as was predicted by The New-York Times would be the case. The largest of the loans at this rate called to notice yesterday was by the New-York Cotton Exchange, for $300,000.
LONDON, Jan. 10. -- A news agency in this city has the following dispatch, from Venice:

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- The star night of the great triangular billiard tournament brought out an immense throng of spectators. Central Music Hall was filled to overflowing. Ladies in brilliant toilets and resplendent with glistening Jewels occupied the boxes, and pre-empted the choice localities of the amphitheatre.

Edward Burke, fourteen, years old, of 444 West Thirty-first Street, was charged in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday with stabbing Frank Casey, fifteen years old, of 529 West Forty-fourth Street, in the right side, and inflicting wounds which it is feared will prove fatal. He was remanded until to-day, in order to give the wounded boy an opportunity to identify him.

Inspector McLaughlin has in custody Niels Madsen Nielsen, a Dane, twenty-four years old, who confessess that on Jan. 4, at Hurley, S.D., he brained his employer, Christian Peter, with an axe and stole $700.

A large number of politicians and public men attended the funeral of Alderman William H. Murphy of the Twelfth Assembly District yesterday afternoon. There were thousands of others present, humble citizens of the " gashouse" district, of which Charles Murphy, a brother of the Alderman, is the Tammany Hall leader.

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- The trial of Auguste Vaillant, the Anarchist who threw the bomb in the Chamber of Deputies on Dec. 9 last, opened before President Judge Caze and a jury in the Assize Court to-day and ended with his conviction and sentence to death. Policemen, in couples and threes, were stationed every ten yards around the immense block occupied by the Palace of Justice, in which the court sits.
Applications for alterations to the following buildings were approved yesterday by Superintendent Brady of the Building Department:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 10. -- St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, in the Astoria section of this city, was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The parish records and the silver service were saved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day received from Attorney General Olney an opinion in which, he holds that the Chinese Exclusion act and prior acts regarding the Chinese permit Chinese laborers coming from or going to China to countries other than the United States to pass in transit to the country of destination through the United States.
The following letter has been sent by Mr. Michael D. Harter, Congressman from the Fourteenth Ohio District, to Mr. David A. Wells:

The conference of the Secretary of the Treasury with the Finance Committee of the Senate is a hopeful sign, so far as it goes, that Congress is to be moved to act in a situation that is to the last degree discreditable and embarrassing, and that at any moment may become full of peril.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- In the convention of the State Federation of Labor to-day resolutions were adopted in favor of making Labor Day a national holiday, indorsing the local option tax bill, urging amendments to the mechanics' lien law, demanding the labeling of prison-made goods put on the market to sell.
John Girardot, clam man, Coney Island, was the star at yesterday's hearing in the trial of Austin against the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association.

Mascagni's " L. Amico Fritz " was brought forward at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. If the performance served no other purpose, it served to correct some false impressions which have been gaining ground. One of these was that Mme. Calve's personal triumph had been so great that people were flocking to the Opera House simply to hear her.

VICTORIA, B. C., Jan. 10. -- The British bark Trafalgar, from New-York, arrived at Melbourne Dec. 17 in command of a boy. At Batavia three of the crew deserted, and the second officer obtained his discharge, having incurred the III will of the crew. Capt. Edgar died with Java fever. Chief Officer Richard Roberts took command and sailed with a crew of twenty-three.

The bill which was introduced in the Senate Tuesday night by Senator Lexow, providing for a reorganization of the Police Board in this city, was yesterday characterized as one of Thomas C. Platt's little pieces of proposed legislation.

Edward Lauterbach appeared before the Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday with an assurance from Frederick Uhlmann, Adolf Ladenburg, Jacob Ruppert, John Schaefer, Simon E. Bernheimer, and their associates interested in the East River Bridge, the Brooklyn elevated railroad system, and the proposed cross-town elevated road in this city, that they would bid for the franchise of the independent elevated system, as laid out by the Commissioners.

ALBANY, Jan, 10. -- Mr. Thomas C. Platt's first attempt to dictate legislation has become manifest. It has appeared in Albany in such a shape as to justify the suspicion, long time prevalent, that a satisfactory arrangement on the offensive defensive plan has been entered into between Mr. Platt and Tammany Hall, in return for past favors on both sides.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The conference committees of the Knights of Labor Congress and State Federation of Labor Convention met this afternoon with a committee representing ninety organizations from New-York City to consider the question of legislation in behalf of the unemployed. It was stated that there were 150,000 men out of work in New-York alone.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Senate Committee on Finance spent two hours again this afternoon considering the condition of the Treasury.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 10 -- Miss Elizabeth M. Swan, daughter of Edward H. Swan, was married to-day to Capt. Horatia McKay, commander of the Cunard steamer Lucania. The ceremony took place at the home of the bride's parents, on the Sound shore, at Cove Neck. About fifty friends and relatives of the couple were present.

The old shallow, double tenement house 50 East Houston street, which is part of the estate of Jacob Weeks, was on fire at 4:30 yesterday morning, and seven families, in which were twenty-seven persons, were in peril because the fire went from the cellar to the stairs shaft, which was so near the windows passed by the fire escapes that the latter were useless.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the American Sugar Refining Company in Jersey City yesterday disclosed that some of the large holders of the stock have been disposing of their holdings, or are willing to have the public believe so. They mustered at the meeting 273,510 shares of stock belonging to themselves or held by proxy.

We publish this morning a very interesting letter from Representative Harter of Ohio to Mr. David A. Wells, in which he defines, with his accustomed clearness and energy, the line which he believes his party ought to follow. We commend it to the careful study of his fellow-members of the majority.

There was a particularly large gathering at the rooms of the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon, for a talk upon " Organization for Women " by Mrs. " Jennie June " Croly, one of the Vice Presidents of the league, had been announced.

There wag further discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Park Board on the proposed Harlem River speedway. Commissioner Dana continued his opposition to the plan which provides for only an inner sidewalk instead of an outside one as well.

Frank Bolles. Frank Bolles, Secretary of Harvard University, died in Boston yesterday of pneumonia. He came of a distinguished NewEngland family. His father, John A. Bolles, was once Secretary of State of Massachusetts, then a Brigadier General of the war, while his mother was the sister of the late John A. Dix, Senator, Governor, Minister to France, and Major General.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 10 -- The extra session of the Ninth General Assembly of Colorado organized at noon to-day with the same officers as at the regular session. A joint session was promptly called, and Gov. Waite occupied two hours in reading his message, outlining his reasons for some of the propositions made in his call.

A story was current at Police Headquarters yesterday that the Rev. Henry Pereira Mendes, rabbi of the Congregation Shearith Israel, who was shot in the abdomen on March 5, 1892, at his home, 6 West Ninth Street, by a Moorish Jew, Joseph Mizrachee, was threatened a week ago by a mendicant who boasted that he was "one of Mizrachee's fellows," and that detectives' had been assigned to catch the man.
It is said that Edward Melvin will resign from the Brooklyn Club.

Five Delconte brothers, Calabrians, are in America, and yesterday two were working at Sing Sing and three were in NewYork. Of the latter, Luigi and Gaetano lodged at 20 Mulberry Street, and Andrea at 37 Mulberry Street.

The brief report from Philadelphia Tuesday, in reference to the settlement of the order referring the issues in the suit of Isaac L. Kice against the receivers of the Reading Railroad to Special Master Crawford for the hearing of evidence failed to bring out many important points which should be fully understood.

The Notification Committee appointed on Monday night by the Democratic Convention in the Fifteenth Congressional District waited upon Isidor Straus last night at his home, Boulevard and West One Hundred and Fifth Street, to inform him of his nomination for Congress to succeed Ashbel P. Fitch.

RED BANK, N. J., Jan. 10 -- Mrs. Ann Fowler, for many years a resident of Keyport, was found dead in her house to-day. By the side of her chair, on the floor, lay two dead cats. About her neck was a rope, not pulled tight. On the table was a raw chicken, partly cut up.

The second lecture in the course of three by William Hamilton Gibson on " Mysteries of the Flowers " was delivered yesterday afternoon in the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre. The lectures are for the benefit of the New-York Kindergarten Association.

The most awkward street in New-York for a fire, because of its narrowness and winding, is Doyers Street, whose bend is the centre of Chinatown, and a third-alarm blaze in it yesterday afternoon electrified, the Celestials and made the firemen profane.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 10. -- Attorney General Cunningham to-day filed an injunction suit, entitled State of Louisiana against The Premium Club and others. The defendants are the persons who have been conducting daily lottery drawings since Jan. 1 in violation of State and city laws.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- For a brief interval to-day party lines were drawn in the Senate and there was a vigorous interchange of party talk, which was relished by the occupants of the galleries, who had been deprived of entertainment of this kind for some time.

The Bowdoin College Alumni Asociation of New-York had its twenty-fourth annual dinner at the Hoffman House last night. President Hyde was one of the guests, and, in his speech, he made a statement showing the generally prosperous condition of the college. The value of the college buildings, he said, had increased from $144,000 in 1884 to $450,000 to 1893.

Chin Tung of 155 Stanton Street told a strange story in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday of persecution by fellowcountrymen. As a result of his statements. Goh Fon of 38 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street and Ah Loy of 24 Mott Street, both laundrymen, were held for examination on a charge of conspiracy, until Way Mun, another alleged conspirator, can be arrested.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 10 -- The hearing on a permanent receivership for the New-York and New-England Railroad, which was scheduled to take place here to-day before Judge W. K. Townsend, was postponed till Friday, Jan. 12, owing to the absence of the attorneys in New-York City.

Thomas C. Platt as a receiver with a view of permanency does not suit many of the holders of New-York and New-England railroad securities. Politics and railroads, it was pointed out in court yesterday, do not form a desirable mixture.

Fred Taral, who is just now at the top of the list of American jockeys, has gone to Florida with his family for the Winter. Taral is making Jacksonville his headquarters for the present. He is now under a two-years' contract to ride for J.R. F.P. Keene.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The first lot of heavy armor falling to meet the requirements was fired upon yesterday at the Naval Ordnance Proving Grounds. It came from the Carnegie Works. The plate tested represented 500 tons of nickel-steel armor, the last group of armor for the navy to be shipped without being treated by the Harvey process.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres says: "It is reported that the Aquidaban has re-entered Rio Bay, and that the insurgents have captured Mocangue and Engenho Islands. The general belief at Rio Janeiro is that serious events are impending. It is expected that the forces of Admiral Mello will land at Nictheroy and thence conduct their attack upon the city President Peixoto is preparing to resist them."

The first game of the home bottle-billiard tournament will be played at the Hanover Clubhouse, Brooklyn, to-morrow evening. The success that attended the recent bottle-pool tournament has furnished food for anticipation in the inauguration of the coming event.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The long-expected amendment to the Senate rules for closure came in this morning with the rules themselves which Senator Saxton, the President pro tem, submitted. It provides that when a resolution or a motion has been under consideration six hours it shall be in order for any Senator to move that the debate shall be closed, and the President shall recognize the Senator who wishes to make such motion.

There are so many new members in the Senate and Assembly this year, and so many of them got there unexpectedly, that it is difficult to judge of the makeup of the committees, except as to the few more important ones, and as to those members who have become known through past service.

Interest in the cycle show in Madison Square Garden is increasing every day. In spite of the unpleasant state of the weather last night, the big building was crowded with lady and gentleman lovers of the wheel, and they walked arm in arm from booth to booth scrutinizing closely every style machine on exhibition.
Charles Smith, forty years old., who said he lived at 274 Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, started to ride from, this city to Brooklyn yesterday afternoon on the railroad cable of the Brooklyn Bridge.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 10. -- The suit of Armenia Chadwick against Albert F. Chadwick for divorce on the ground of cruelty was begun before Vice Chancellor Green this morning. Mr. Chadwick is Principal of a public school, and Mrs. Chadwick, before marriage, was a typewriter in NewYork.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:
