Everybody must sympathize with the efforts of everybody else to raise the tone of politics, and especially of local politics. For this reason everybody of a normal moral constitution and respectable social standing must be interested in the efforts of the Union League Club to raise the tone of Republican local politics.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 11 -- The rectory of the Church of St. Mary. Our Lady of Grace, in which the body of Father Corrigan lay in state during the day. was crowded by mourners, anxious to testify their respect for the dead priest. This evening the body was removed to the church, which was thronged until late in the night.

Judging from the reports of those mariners who yesterday brought their ships into harbor, the Atlantic has been displaying something' more than its usual bad temper. Moat of the Ships arriving had marks of its violence to show, and the voyages of all the arrivals were unduly protracted, by gales and hurricanes.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- The annual reports of trust companies for the year 1893 are being received at the office of the State Superintendent in Banking. The statements thus far made show that, despite the times, seven or eight companies which were the first to report were able to pay dividends. Abstracts of the first reports received are as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- The names of the men Mr. Platt has selected to act as the Republican Commissioners if his non-partisan Police Board bill shall become a law leaked out to-day. His candidates are said to be:

Louis Windmuller in the Independent, Jan. 1. Men of Independent means who know how to manage their affairs need not insure their lives. They may save the expense of the administration of their money through others by investing for themselves to better advantage. Insurance is chiefly valuable:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Mr. Turpie made his promised speech in the Senate to-day on the resolution he recently introduced declaring it to be the policy of the United States that there should not be any foreign intervention in the affairs of Hawali. He took the position that the provisional Government of Hawail; having been recognized by the United States and other Governments.

The birthday of Alexander Hamilton was celebrated last evening by the Hamilton Club of Brooklyn, which gave its annual dinner in the clubhouse, on Remsen Street. It was more than usually interesting, as the special guests were Mayor Schieren and the men appointed by him as the heads of the various municipal departments.

Since Richard Croker suggested to the Committee on Organization of Tammany Jail that it was the duty of the organizaion to work just as hard in every election district of the city to relieve the suffering of the unemployed as it would work in a political campaign, and harder if necessary, he vast machinery of the organization has been moving swiftly in the direction of relleving distress in every way possible.
The "Bowery" at Coney Island is almost as populous in midwinter as the Bowery in New-York, according to John Y. McKane's polling lists.

When John Y. McKane took his seat in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning the big diamond in his shirt front sparkled and he smiled at his friends, evidently sanguine that his counsel, George W. Roderick, was about to quash all the indictments against him and his Coney Island henchmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- There was a sensation at the Capitol this morning, when it was learned that the Senate Committee on Commerce had ordered an unfavorable report on the nomination of J. Scott Harrison of Kansas City, the brother of ex-President Harrison, to be Surveyor of Customs at Kansas City.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The marriage of Miss Elsie Burrows, the youngest daughter of Ogden Hoffman Burrows of Newport, and Capt. John Shiffner, eldest son of the Rev. Sir George Coxton Shiffner, Bart, took place this afternoon at St. Patrick's Church at Hove, a suburb of Brighton. The church was artistically decorated with tall palms and white flowering plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Secretary Lamont has decided to remind officers that they must be careful about accepting " favors " from subordinates, either individuals or organizations. There has been a good deal of this sort of thing in recent years, and it has lost whatever significance it once possessed, some of the officers believe.

In noting the recommendations of Gov. Flower as to amendments of the civil service law, we expressed the opinion that the statutes as they stand would be found sufficient, if fairly interpreted and firmly enforced, to prevent illegal appointments. By illegal appointments we meant those made without compliance with the conditions as to examination and competition prescribed by the civil service rules in accordance with the law.

-- The Peoria (Ill.) Water Company has been placed in the hands of a receiver, Cornelius E. Gold of New-York City has been named for the position in the sum of $100,000 and has entered upon his duties. There will be no radical changes in the management of the company. The city holds a first mortgage on the plant to the amount of $295,000.

Copyright. 1894, by the United Press. PALERMO, Jan. 11. -- A telegram from King Humbert has been published here. His Majesty's dispatch is in answer to an address sent him by Gen. Morra di Lavriano, military commander of Sicily, on the occasion of the anniversary of the death of King Victor Emmanuel, Jan. 9, and has produced an excellent impression.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- The first official statement by the State Civil Service Commission regarding violations of the State civil service laws has been issued. It is dated Albany, Jan. 11, 1894, and is addressed to the Governor. It is as follows:

ASHEVHiLLE, N. C., Jan. 11. -- Lawrence Pulliam, cashier of the National Bank of Asheville, left here on Dec. 30 with $6,200 for Eastern banks, saying he could save express charges by carrying the money, as he was going as far as Philadelphia for the purpose of having an operation performed.

The sub-committee of the Assembly Committee on Privileges and Elections continued its investigation yesterday in Part 111. of the Court of Common Pleas into the alleged, election frauds in several Assembly districts at the last election. The three members of the committee were present -- Chairman. Terry of Saratoga, Assemblyman Vacheron of Queens County, and Assemblyman.
Sergt. W.B. Murphy of the Boston Park Police, in his report, has this to say about the use of cycles for park police.
The Chamber of Commerce denounced the proposed income tax at a special meeting yesterday afternoon. There was a large attendance. The declaration of the meet ing was as follows:

The evidence that " Boss " Platt intends to run the Legislature this Winter and to use it in carrying out political " deals " is much more conspicuous than the evidence that he will be able to accomplish his purposes. He has been fairly successful in controlling the organization of the two houses and the make-up of the more important of the committees.

-- A. Oakey Hall and Artemus H. Holmes, representing W. E. D. Stokes and William R. Martin, were in the Court of General Sessions yesterday to oppose a motion setting a day for the trial of their clients upon the charge of criminally libeling Edward S. Stokes of the Hoffman House. They argued that the criminal, proceedings should not be begun until the civil suits bearing upon practically the same matters were settled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Much valuable time is likely to be squandered in the general debate on the Tariff bill. A few general speeches at the opening, and then a week of five-minute debate of amendments would have given all the necessary opportunity for argument, and the bill might have been disposed of by such a programme at least a week earlier than it will be under the arrangement made.

Ex-Senator Thomas Clark died at his home in North Stonington, Conn., yesterday. He was sixty-three years old, and was one of the best-known men in that section of the State, having been active in the Republican Party many years, and honored by his townspeople with rapid political advancement.

Police Justice Tighe of Brooklyn is a past master of the art of self-defense. He is courageous when he has only Vikings and Gowanusians to deal with. Yesterday, however, he showed that he was no match for a big, able-bodied Amazon with a red-hot poker.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 11 -- The Hat Manufacturers' Association to-day sent a letter to Mayor Andrews saying that they were about to resume the manufacture of hats, and they wanted to invoke the aid of law to protect them in their endeavor to start up their factories and run them as they chose.

Edward M. Field returned to this city last night after an absence of nearly two years. He came from the State Asylum for Insane at Buffalo, and was in the custody of Deputy Sheriff Joseph J. Burke, who called there for him at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning, with Justice Van Brunt's order for his transfer to Ludlow Street Jail.

LANCASTER, Perm., Jan. 11. -- Judge Livingston this morning delivered an opinion dismissing the exceptions to and confirming absolutely the report of the auditors in the estate of the late Thaddeus Stevens, the " Old Commoner."

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- The case of Princess Colonna against her husband, which is an action for a judicial separation, was called in court to-day, and was again postponed for a week. Counsel for the Princess demanded in Chambers that the Judge authorize her to remove the children to Mentone, on the ground that their health demanded the change.
During the past four days Constant Coquelin has displayed his marvelous art in three distinct and widely different domains of comedy.

As a rule, during the Winter months in this section, light harness horsemen decide all their trotting races round the stove, but the open weather of the present season has resulted in two exceptions to this, and, curiously enough, both of these events have caused so much "kicking" that the law has been appealed to to unravel the tangle.

Very few of the members of the American Hackney Horse Society were present yesterday afternoon at the annual general meeting of that organization, which was held at the offices of the society, 51 East Forty-fourth Street. The members of this association are very widely scattered, many of them residing in the Western States and in Canada.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- The Cities' Committee to-day reported favorably Senator Owens's bill authorizing the erection of a new high school in his district in Brooklyn at a cost of $250,000. Senator Owens asked that the measure be passed at once.

The annual meeting of the Union League Club yesterday was graced by a collection of paintings by local artists, lent for a few days only. They are good, indifferent, and poor, the good being in sufficient numbers to leaven the mass, but the poor quite numerous enough to prove that no great care and skill have been used to accomplish the difficult feat of bringing together fourscore masterpieces.

Mrs. Emily A. Livingston Has begun suit in the Supreme Court against her brother, Charles E. Green, for an accounting of the administration of a threemlllion-dollar trust left by an uncle, John C. Green. Mrs. Livingston, who lives at 113 East Seventeenth Street, also desires an accounting from her brother as the surviving executor of their father, Henry W. Green. Mrs.Livingston's son by a former marriage, William B. Blackwell, Joins his mother in the suit

Russell Sage expressed himself frankly and earnestly yesterday in favor of reorganizing the New-York and New-England Railroad without resort to foreclosure proceedings. He thought that new money could be found to put the property on its feet, and he was not in favor of allowing it to fall into the hands of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Company.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- Count Posadowsky, Secretary of the Treasury, introduced the Tobacco bill in the House to-day. He spoke for nearly two hours in behalf of the measure. The members were not willing to sit and listen to his prosy speech, and before he had talked long the Mouse was nearly empty.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- The conference of representatives of the Knights of Labor Congress, the State Federation of Labor Convention, and a delegation representing New-York City's movement in behalf of the unemployed, which has been planning for legislation designed to secure work for the needy, concluded its session and reported to the labor conventions here to-day.

The wife of Michael Manderer, a polisher, of 1,358 Vanderbilt Avenue was committed to the Tombs for disorderly conduct last week and allowed to take with her her daughter, Catharine, live months old. While Mrs. Manderer was exercising in one of the corridors, a scrubbing brush was dropped from an upper tier and the child was struck on the head.

Secretary Sullivan has been notified that to Thomas J. Vegellus, the well-known distance runner of Jersey City, was tendered a benefit last Saturday evening in Jersey City by the Scottish-American and Aroma Athletic Clubs. This, of course, makes Vesellus, a professional, and in the future his entry will be rejected by amateur organizations

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Bureau of Military Information is to be overhauled by Secretary Lamont. The character of the information which is being gathered by this branch of the War Department is not just what is deemed valuable. It is proposed, too, that the data gathered by the bureau shall not all be treasured with secrecy.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- Just before adjournment of the Senate to-day Mr. Cantor raised a little breeze by introducing a resolution which he said had been prepared by the trades unions, reciting that there were now 100,000 unemployed in New-York City to whom the construction of Corlear's Hook Park, Mulberry Bend Park, the annexed district parks, and the street improvements and the building of school houses and municipal lodging houses would give work, and adding:

At a meeting of the Directors of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad in this city yesterday a resolution was adopted that no dividend be paid on the capital stock at the present time. Such a policy was declared to be " for the best interest of the company."

In his annual report to the stockholders of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, President E. P. Wilbur emphatically contradicts a statement made in the Reading receivers' recent report that " the actual result of the operation under the lease (Lehigh Valley) during the year 1892, was at a loss of $1,412,419.60." President Wilbur says:

During the Summer season, when the bicycle racer is winning medals, diamonds, pins, pianos, machines, furniture, and other prizes, while the "scorcher," a term applied to fast road riders, is making life miserable for the slow pedalers, and when the beginner is bruised from head to foot, the result of various tumbles, the manufacturers are at war.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- Notwithstanding Vaillant's assertion yesterday that he would not sign the appeal from his sentence, he to-day announced that he would sign it. The appeal will ask the Supreme Court to quash the verdict and to grant a new trial. Valiant says that if the appeal should be rejected he would not appeal to President Carnot for a pardon.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 11. -- Major Frank H. Harcourt, inspector of the rifle sharpshooters of the State militia, on the brigade staff, has begun an investigation into the recruiting here for. President Peixoto's forces in Brazil.

Copyright,1894, by The United Press. RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11. -- The two Government columns, under the command of Gens. Hipolito and Sampayo -- the former marching from Libramento and the latter from Cerro Chato -- which were ordered to proceed to the relief of Bage, in Rio Grande do Sul, should arrive to-day at their destination.

Lawyer A.H. Hummel gave a surprise yesterday to Paul Puller of the law firm of Coudert Brothers, and incidentally to Justice Lawrence, before whom, in Supreme Court Chambers, he was arguing against Mr. Fuller's application for counsel fees and alimony for Alice L. Hopkinson, pending her suit for absolute divorce against George W. Hopkinson, a jeweler at 202 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The first card reception of the year given at the Executive Mansion to-night in honor of the Diplomatic Corps was made the event of the season by resident society.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L. I., Jan. 11. -- The war between the two Republican factions in this city was carried into the Supreme Court to-day. Theron Burden and others applied for and secured an order to show cause why the County Central. Committee should not be permanently restrained from seating City General Committee delegates elected at the primaries held several weeks ago.
"My brooch was worth only about $10, and I don't mind its loss so much as the manner in which those dirty brutes choked and slapped and tried to kiss me," says Miss Lizzie Stewart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The air of mystery which the members of the Executive Committee of the National Republican Committee wore when they assembled at the Arlington last night for an informal talk was intensified to-day when the committee met to decide whether there should be a permanent headquarters of the Republican Party, and, if so, where it should be established.
From The Indianapolis Journal. The young husband was somewhat surprised when his wife came into the office. She opened the Conversation at once.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Jan. 11 -- P. M. Great duliness and declining prices marked to-day's stock market. The opening was weak. Sugar touched 80 3/4 in the early trading and then strengthened to 82 1/4, that price being made early in the morning. After that the stock sagged and closed at 81 3/8, a net loss of 1/3.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- It was expected in view of the differences which arose some time ago between the State Commissioners in Lunacy and the Boards of Trustees of State hospitals that the report of the Trustees would contain severe criticisms on the commission. The only reference to the work of the commission is made in the report of the Binghamton Asylum Trustees.

Some of the depositors in the defunct St. Nicholas Bank have begun proceedings against Receiver Hugh J. Grant, and their case will come up before Judge Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, on Wednesday next. Their complaint is that a sum over $100,000 in aggregate was received and accepted from them after the bank had closed.

An interesting suit to determine the ownership of a life insurance policy was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Cullen, sitting in Special Term. It is the case of the Jewelers' League of New-York against Mrs. Ellen B. De Forest and Mrs. Anna B. De Forest, mother and wife, respectively, of Charles S. De Forest.

Henry C. Payne, one of the receivers of the Northern Pacific, and ex-Senator John C. Spooner of counsel to the receivers, are in this city. The work of preparing an answer to the complaint in the suit brought by the Board of Directors for the removal of the receivers is under way, and will be completed as soon as possible.

The Union League Club has at last decided to take an active part in the fight for good city government, irrespective of party lines. It will follow the example of the City Reform Club and the Good Government Clubs, to unite with all sincere citizens' movements to attain that end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11, -- Just before the Senate went into executive session this afternoon, Mr. Chandler laid before that body the minority report of the Committee on Privileges and Elections on the bill to repeal the Federal elections law. It is a type-written document of about seventyfive pages, and begins with a reference to the attempt in 1890 to pass the so-called Force bill, citing the provisions of that proposed law.

The first of the two assemblies of 1894, popularly known as the "Matriarchs," took place at Sherry's last evening. These functions are in point of smartness and excluslveness counterparts of the dances given by the Patriarcha. The distinction between the two functions is of quantity rather than of quality.

The proposition of Edward Lauterbach, on behalf of a syndicate of capitalists, to build a new elevated railroad in this city on the Bushe plan, and the fact that the syndicate was composed of men of undoubted financial ability, caused much interest yesterday among residents both of this city and of Brooklyn, who are now subjected to all sorts of physical discomforts under the existing systems.

The third concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra was given at Music Hall last evening. The programme consisted of the following numbers: Symphony No. 1 in C minor, Brahms; recitative and aria, " Abscheulicher," from " Fidelio," Beethoven; overture " Euryanthe," Weber; recitative and aria, " Celul dont la parole," from " Herodiade," Massenet, and overture, " 1812," Tschaikowsky.

Angelo Vicci, swarthy, but pinched of face and clod in garments which were but he merest apology for protection against he grip-breeding weather of yesterday, walked timidly down the few steps that lead to the People's Restaurant, at 170 Bleecker Street, and, with trembling hand, pushed open the door.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S. I., Jan. 11. -- Misi Cornelia Belle Sloan, daughter of the Rev. Arthur Sloan, and Thomas Landon Fowler of Richmond Hill., L. I., were married this evening at the Randal Memorial Church, Sailors' Snug Harbor, of which the bride's father is rector. Fifteen hundred invitations had been issued, and the imposing white marble edifice was crowded with guests from New-York, Long Island, and Staten Island.
The color question is agitating the Southern wheelmen. The assembly will be held in Louisville next month, and the riders will make a strong effort to have the line drawn.

Robert Bleakie of Hyde Park, Mass., one of the principal woolen men in the country, whose letters, , in favor of tariff reform form some of the principal features of the literature of that subject, was, by a mistake, made to appear in the reports as a speaker at the annual meeting of the Wool Manufacturers' Association, held Wednesday at the Metropolitan Hotel.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the erection of the following new buildings were filed:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- There has been a postponement of the Hornblower case by the Senate until next Monday. Some of the friends of Mr. Hornblower profess to believe that the delay they have managed to secure is indicative of final success, but his opponents appear to be as sanguine as ever that the report of the Judiciary Committee will be sustained when the Senate takes up the case in earnest.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 11. -- The numerous defiances and manifectos of the Duval Athletic Club have determined the Governor of Florida to stop the Corbett-Mitchell fight at all hazards. The club has thrown down the gauntlet and he has eccepted the challenge.

"Woe to him who calls them off or seduces them from their duty!" said John Sabine Smith, President of the Republican Club, when speaking of the legislative committees which he would like to see overhaul the affairs of this city this Winter. Some who heard the remark asked seriously if Mr. Smith intended thus to hurl "woe" at Thomas C. Platt's head.

Three witnesses swore with positiveness yesterday in the austin insurance case to having seen John C. Austin alive at the Lamarehe country seat in New-Jersey after July 4, 1891, the date of his alleged drowing at Manhattan Beach. One witness swore positively, also, that at least one of the Lamarches, as well as Joseph E. Austin, knew all about: it and had sheltered Austin.

An experiment in ocean transportation that will be regarded with much interest is the newly-established line of the White Star Steamship Company running from Liverpool to New-Zealand. According to H. Maitland Kersey, the New-York agent of the White Star line, who has just returned from England, the ships of that service will circumnavigate the globe.
The Fenton Company yesterday closed a large contract with the Tracy-Wells Company of Columbus, Ohio. The latter will have exclusive control of that State for the Fenton wheel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Daniel Coughlin will soon know the strength of the evidence upon which the jury is expected by the State to judge him guilty of complicity in the murder of Dr. Cronin. The plan of prosecution was to close next Saturday, but new witnesses have made themselves known and prolonged the trial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Civil Service Commission has completed the schedule of examinations that will be held in the first six months of this year to fill positions in the Railway Mail and Indian Services. The chronological order of the route is as follows:

TO the Editor of The New-York Times: I find that remarks made by me in the State Senate Chamber yesterday have been misrepresented by some of the morning papers as constituting an adverse criticism upon President Cleveland. I desire to say that the language actually used by me could not by any possiblity be fairly so construed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12 -- B. Bruanschweig, an Anarchist, told a German reporter to-day that the last time the unemployed in New-York City marched through the streets they were prepared to resist any efforts the police might make to stop the parade.

The affairs of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn continue to engross a large amount of attention. Director James Lock of the Commercial Bank yesterday made public the deliberations of a secret meeting of the Directors, held in 1889, at the office of Bergen Dykman.

The schedules of William V. McCracken Co., railroad contractors, at 40 Wall Street, in the assignment made on Dec. 26 by William V. McCracken, the liquidating partner, were filed yesterday. They show direct liabilities of $1,166,409, contingent liabilities of $264,421, nominal assets of $4,604,850, and actual assets of $754,193.

The New-York Tribune publishes a letter from a correspondent who warmly commends its attack upon Mr. Andrew Carnegie, and says: " The duty on steel rails does not trouble him -- be it high or low -- because he can produce steel rails so cheaply that he can defy foreign competition, and the freight alone would be sufficient protection should prices advance here and prices on the other side decline.
HISTORICAL PHILOSOPHY IN FRANCE AND FRENCH BELGIUM AND SWITZERLAND. By Robert Flint. Svo. New-York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $4.

A woman who was known to her neighbors as Mrs. Frances Griffiths, and whose husband is said to be a traveling man, at present absent from the city, was found dead yesterday afternoon in her apartments, on the fourth floor of the tenement house 253 East Tenth Street. She had committed suicide by inhaling illuminating gas through a rubber tube.

Only one sale at auction of real estate was had in Brooklyn yesterday. This was by Mr. T. A. Kerrigan, who sold to Andrew P. Alvord, the plaintiff, for $5,000, the two-story and basement brick dwelling 703 Macon Street, north side, 58 feet west of Ralph Avenue, 18 by 100.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The Argus to-morrow will print the following: "Mr. John B. Riley, who was removed from the position of Civil Service Examiner by Gov. Flower, has made public a letter, in which he brings very serious charges in reference to the sale, redemption, and cancellation of tax sales of the State's holdings of lands in the Adirondack forests. Mr. Riley says, among other things:

The name of the Rev. Sylvester Malone, the venerable pastor of Sts. Peter and Paul Church, in Williamsburg, has been mentioned in connection with the vacancy in the State Board of Regents, caused by the death of Bishop McNierney of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany. The Brooklyn Assemblymen are reported to be in favor of Father Malone's appointment.

Tammany began its campaign for 1894 last night. Its new General Committee met in the Fourteenth Street Wigwam, organized for business, and outlined the policy which it proposes to pursue. In the resolutions adopted it declares against the income tax, demands prompt action, on the tariff by Congress, and praises Gov. Flower and the Tammany administration in this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Mrs. Cleveland has as her guest Miss May Huddleston, her young cousin, who will be remembered in Washington as a child during the first Cleveland Administration. Miss Huddleston will remain at the White House for the season, and will assist Mrs. Cleveland in receiving at her reception to-morrow afternoon.

The sub-committee of the, Assembly Committee on Privileges and Elections had another surprise yesterday. At the afternoon session, at which the case of Mr. Page, the defeated Republican candidate in the Twenty-second District, who claimed the seat of Michael F. Tobin, was set down for a hearing, counsel for Mr. Page requested permission to withdraw the contest on the ground that the facts did not justify the charges made in the protest.

John Y. McKane, Chief of the Gravesend police, Richard V. B. Newton, and Kenneth F. Sutherland, Justices of the Peace, and the eighteen Election Inspectors of the town of Gravesend, indicted by the Extraordinary Grand Jury on the charges of misconduct as registry omcers and oppression, will be tried Monday, Jan. 22.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The adjournment of the Senate until Monday may not prevent the transmission of the Hawaii correspondence to Congress to-morrow, although the probability is that it will not be sent until both houses are in session. It is hinted that the President will send the papers to the House to-morrow, because the House called for them independently of the Senate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- French Consul Bruwaert is now in Washington to learn the attitude of the Government toward paying the claims of the exhibitors. The exhibitors propose to be paid for their losses, and unless an amicable agreement is reachel the courts will be called upon to decide the matter.

PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 12. -- The roof of the new Holland Church, in course of construction on. Gray Street, was blown off by the wind to-day. The storm also overturned a number of barns and uprooted many trees in the suburbs of the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- No news was received at the Brazilian Legation to-day from the war in Brazil, and, as usual in the absence of cablegrams, Minister Mendonca was inclined to make use of the old war phrase: "There is no change in the situation."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 12. -- The funeral of Father Corrigan took place to-day from the Church of St. Mary, Our Lady of Grace, of which he was for many years pastor. The hour set was 9:30, but the church doors were thrown open at a o'clock. Half an hour later the edifice was crowded.

Forty-three miles an hour was the velocity attained by the wind about 6:30 o'clock last evening, and out at Sandy Hook it was blowing still greater guns, fifty miles an hour. However, it was blowing from the fight direction, the northwest, and brought dry, clear, and cold weather, and dispelled the damp, uncomfortable feeling that prevailed on Thursday night.

A. A. H. Boissevain's return from Europe a day or two ago has given a fresh impetus to the rumors about the Union Pacific reorganization. It is generally believed that Mr. Boissevain, who is a member of the Reorganization Committee, discussed the essential points of a plan with the foreign security holders.

Every day the crowd increases at the bicycle show in Madison Square Garden. In the early afternoon hours yesterday the building was comfortably filled with ladies and misses, but in the evening standing room was at a premium. It was "Liberty" night, and the manufacturers of that machine bought and distributed 2,000 admission tickets among the riders of NewYork and Brooklyn.

In making the appropriation for the execution of the law providing for the State care of the insane last Winter the Legislature provided that the medical Superintendent of each of the State hospitals for the insane should make a detailed estimate of expenses every month and submit it to the Commission in Lunacy.

By the adoption or the supplementary resolution, offered by the President of the Chamber of Commerce, the Union League Club saved itself from the charge of indefiniteness and of " paltering in a double sense," in dealing with the question of municipal reform at its annual meeting on Thursday night.

The suit brought by William R. Lapham, formerly Chief Clerk of the Stationery and Printing Division of the Interior Department, against ex-Secretary John W. Noble, head of the same department under President Harrison, was on trial yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Lacombe and a jury.

William H. Hildreth of the firm of Abe Stein Co., 97 Gold Street, which failed on Dec. 1, 1893, with liabilities amounting to about $1,000,000, was arrested yesterday upon a bench warrant issued by Recorder Smyth of the Court of General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The income tax and the other internal revenue features of the Tariff bill will be reported as a separate measure. This conclusion was reached at the meeting of the committee this morning by a vote of 6 to 5. Those who voted in the affirmative were Messrs. Wilson, (Dem., West Va.,) Breckinridge, (Dem., Ark.,) Stevens, (Dem., Mass.,) Cockran, (Dem., N. Y.,) Montgomery, (Dem., Ky.,) and Bynum, (Dem., Ind.)

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Dr. William Everett of Massachusetts interested the House to-day with a tariff speech, delivered with all the originality of expression and earnestness with which he addressses himself to any Question regarded by him as calling for remarks.
The Seventh Assembly District of Brooklyn will hereafter be known as the " Blind Man's District."

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- The last game but one of the billiard tournament was witnessed by a meagre audience. As on last evening, many visiting New-Yorkers were present, out of compliment to George Slosson, whose turn it was again to meet the young Napoleon of the billiard world. After winning the bank, the "Student" led off with a miss, while Ives picked up 19, and went out on a cross-table shot.

The great distress that prevails among the unemployed on the east side is made painfully apparent in the District Courts, where unprecedentedly large numbers of applications have been made for dispossess warrants, to dispossess families whose bread winners have been, out of work for months and have spent all their savings.
The New-York Wheelmen will hold a "stag" at their clubhouse, 331 Lenox Avenue, next Saturday evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- This was " cleaning up " day in the Senate, and the executive calendar was relieved of the burden of many Presidential nominations, some of which had been pending for months. The much-discussed case of Isaac J. Wootterr of Laurel, Del., who was nominated last Summer to be Indian Agent in Nevada, was the first one taken up in executive session.

A new volume is ready of the "Dictionary of National Biography," (Macmlllan,) of which Sidney Lee alone. In succession to Leslie Stephen, is now editor. It is the thirty-seventh of the imposing series, and carries us down to Millyng. Like all the volumes, it is one that impresses us with the enormous resources which men in England, have to call upon in the preparation of such a work.

It is impossible to take a very serious view of Roeth, the person who was yesterday sentenced to two years' imprisonment for promiscuously shooting a pistol in Delmonico's. It is true enough that imprisonment for two years is a serious ordeal to the person who is condemned to undergo it.

The General Term of the Supreme Court gave a decision yesterday refusing to confirm the report of the commission appointed to take testimony as to the right of the East River Bridge Company to construct an elevated railroad in connection with its proposed two bridges across the East River.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Although the Hornblower case will not be decided until next Monday, it is the leading topic of conversation at the Capital and in the hotel lobbies.

Dr. George H. Holt, a physician, living at 1,370 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, during a fit of delirium, caused by liquor, cut his throat yesterday with a razor. He was taken to St. John's Hospital, where he was reported last evening as in a fair way for recovery.
A suit in which the names of two very well known citizens of Brooklyn figure prominently is on the calendar of Part III. of the Supreme Court in New-York City awaiting trial.

James M. Varnum, Everett Herrick, and Cornelius C. Cuyler were appointed by Justice Patterson, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, to Inquire into the sanity of Arthur Beckwith, said to be suffering from homicidal mania. He is said to believe himself pursued by assassins, and often refuses food because, he says, it has been poisoned.

ROME, Jan. 12. -- The Deputies of the Extreme Left presented to-day to the President of the chamber a protest against the arrest in Palermo of the Socialist Deputy Gluseppe de Felice, at the same time reserving the right to interpellate the Government as to the arrest upon the reopening of Parliament.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 12. -- By the giving way of a temporary wooden bridge across Newtown Creek, connecting Bradley Avenue, Laurel Hill, with Meeker Avenue, Brooklyn, at least seventyfive men were thrown into the icy waters of the creek a few minutes after 6 o'clock this evening.

The deplorable effect of McKinleyism upon the mind of a gentleman whose natural impulses are good is shown by Congressman Dingley's assertions in the House on Thursday concerning tin plate. According to the press report, Mr. Dingley said:

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 12. -- There was no excitement at the State House to-day. There was a crowd of curious men, on hand to enjoy whatever excitement might develop, however. The Governor was not there, and the clerks in the Executive Department say he will not be until Monday night.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Street Opening and Improvement various improvements in the annexed district were discussed. Commissioner Haffen of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards asked that the New-York Central Railroad Company be required to bridge its tracks at One Hundred and Fifty-third and One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Streets.

Notice was posted at the Coffee Exchange yesterday calling for a special meeting of members next Wednesday to consider plans for a new building on property owned by the Exchange on Beaver and Pearl Streets, adjoining the Cotton Exchange. The plans, drawn by R. W. Gibson, the architect, were on view, having been accepted by the Site Committee and approved by the Board of Managers.
The Murphy brothers are fixtures at the show. Waller, the professional, says that he can ride 450 miles on a Remington machine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The Administration is evidently determined that the Congress shall find a way for supplying the expected deficiency of revenue to which the Secretary of the Treasury has repeatedly called the attention of the Committee of Finance of the Senate.

No confirmation of the report that President Peixoto had been asked to resign could be had in this city yesterday. At the office of C.R. Flint Co., a firm which is in communication with its Brazilian agents, it was said that no information confirming the rumor had been received.

There seems to be no end to the crossswearing in the Austin insurance case, before Justice Patterson, in the Supreme Court. With the utmost serenity, one witness will swear positively to one state of things, to be followed a short time afterward by another witness who will swear Just as firmly in the other direction.

There is no charity more happily directed to relieve Buffering than the work of the Orthopaedic Dispensary and Hospital, which is at 126 and 128 East Fifty-ninth Street. Any one who will take the trouble to drop in there between 1:30 P. M. and 3 P. M. of any week day can see what are the nature and value of the aid given to the crippled children of the poor.

The great Abeel match was finally brought to a successful conclusion on the Seventh's range last evening, and resulted in a victory for Company C's team, which was one of the last companies to shoot. They put up the fine total of 637 points, and, incidentally, broke their own and Company H's record of 322 points at 500 yards by making a total of 333 points at that distance.

The city banks whose officers promised Secretary Carlisle to protect the Treasury reserve by supplying from their own vaults such gold as might be required for export are seriously considering the advisability of withdrawing from that agreement. Congressional coquetry with the financial situation is responsible for the attitude toward which the banks are leaning.

The name of Moliere at the programme's head served last night to fill every seat in Abbey's Theatre, and then for three hours Coquelin's genius kept the audience fascinated, now thrilling them with an agony of horror and repulsion, and now exciting laughter as irresistible and sincerely simple as that which marks the games of children.

The author of this volume in the wellknown series devoted to women of the French Court, is not the eulogist of the Sardanapalus of France. But M. de SaintAmand has a way of saying a kind word, when he can, of even the roost infamous of men and women. It is difficult to discover in Louis XV. any superior qualities.

The plan for the improvement and preservation of the Riverside Park water front was adopted at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Street Opening and Improvement. The plan gives the Dock Board 1,100 feet for dock purposes at the root of West Seventy-ninth Street and 825 feet at the foot of West Ninety-sixth Street.

Final steps which will lead to the creation of the proposed jockey club were taken last evening at a meeting between the representatives of the Coney Island Jockey Club and the Organization Committee of the proposed new club.

A suit to test the liability of bank stockholders to depositors is about to be brought in the Supreme Court by Jacob Hirshfield against the stockholders of the Madison Square Bank. It will be the first suit of the kind growing out of the failure of the bank, but others are in preparation, and it is not unlikely that other depositors may join in this action.
Property Clerk Powell of Brooklyn has another mystery, which the Brooklyn and New-York police are trying to solve for him. It is a small japanned box, filled with jewelry.

Robert Bleakie, the tariff-reform wool manufacturer of Hyde Park, Mass., whose views in relation to the wool schedule were outlined in The New-York Times yesterday, has indicated a course of tariff treatment for wool which, he thinks, will overcome the criticism that the revision proposed in the Wilson bill is too radical to be immediately operative with the best effect.

Perhaps the most interesting patient that has ever been treated in the Gouverneur Hospital, from a surgical point of view, is little Isaac Goerstein, who is lying, encased in a plaster jacket, in the children's ward there, with a dislocated neck. The fact that the child is alive is in itself remarkable, but, what is still more remarkable, House Surgeon Jamal says, is that he will probably recover.

Constable Andrew S. Jamison of the town of Gravesend win on Monday plead to four indictments, each charging him with perjury. He was indicted on the same charge by the December Extraordinary Grand Jury, but his counsel, Foster L. Backus, demurred to the indictments on the ground that they were faulty, and Justice Bartlett sustained the demurrer.

From The London Globe. In a recent paper read to the Isis Society of Dresden, Herr A.B. Meyer shows that according to Pliny, Sophocles, and other ancient authors amber was formerly brought from Eastern India by Phoenician traders along with the peacock feathers, tin, jewels, and spices from Ophir.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Jan. 13 -- P.M. The volume of to-day's transactions at the Stock Exchange, 60,386 shares, tells its own dull story. Dealers for the short account fear to sell stocks, because properties with any value whatever cannot be depressed below the present level, and signs of returning general prosperity are not to be ignored, even by the foolhardy.

A week ago the market closed with a display of strength which seemed to justify the expectation of a further advance of two or three points. By Tuesday, however, the activity and the strength also had gone; trading fell off; quotations lapsed, and since then the market has been quite irregular, some stocks up and others down.

Assistant District Attorney Vernon M. Davis began an investigation yesterday into a report that certain false statements had been made in the reports of the suspended St. Nicholas Bank. When asked about the matter, Mr. Davis said:

Owing to the common use nowadays of the clinical thermometer, most persons are aware that the normal temperature of the human body is about 98.6 Fahrenheit. It is however, subject to important daily fluctuations, which have to be considered in estimating any decided alterations. It is sufficient here to notice that the human temperature falls to its lowest about 1 or 2 o'clock A.M., while the maximum daily temperature occurs some time in the afternoon.

ORANGE, Jan. 13. -- There was a pleasant entertainment at the Country Club last night, about 100 young people being present at the third in a series of subscription dances being given at the clubhouse. Among those seen in the ballroom were Mr. and Mrs. John Rafferty, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Colby, Mrs. Brewer, the Misses Burke, Miss Edith Freeman, Miss Mabel Kingman, Miss Julia Adams, Graham Brewer, Harold Lee, and Robert Kilbourne.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Treasury Department will begin business Monday, Jan. 15, with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Secretary Carlisle was engaged a large part of the day in preparing a statement for the Finance Committee of the Senate to guide them in reaching a conclusion as to what they should do to improve the finances.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 13. -- All Charleston knows the elegant residence of the late William Bull Pringle, on King Street, near Lamboll, where the fair Widow Brewton, during the British occupancy of the city, by the sharpness of her wit and brilliancy of repartee kept Lord Rawdon, Col. Balfour, and the elegant Major Barry in constant dread, and where fair women made piteous appeals to the British commanders for the life of Hayne.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. W.P. Burden were here this week to look after their new cottage on Harrison Avenue. The building is so well along that the Burdens could occupy it late next Summer if they so desired. The Chickering cottage, which they have rented for another Summer, however, is most comfortable, and they will undoubtedly object to moving in the middle of a season.
Thomas C. Platt got a bad political black eye last night.

From The London Telegraph. This afternoon the ladles composing the group of champions of woman's rights called "La Solidarite des Femmes" met in conclave in the Town Hall of the Saint Sulpice District for the purpose of protesting against some of the ideas put forth by Dr. Cesare Lombroso in his last book, "La Donna Delinquente."

It is the exceptional boy who is fond of dancing school; yet it is the boy, not the girl, who especially needs its teachings. Grace, self-possession, and a knowledge of what to do with one's hands and feet, all these come naturally far oftener to the average girl than to the average boy; but it is the boy who, not having them, has to be prodded to so where he may acquire them.

Wedding rings were used both by the Greeks and Romans, but then only at the ceremony of betrothal and not that of marriage. The Anglo-Saxon bridegroom at the betrothal gave a wed, or pledge, and a ring was placed on the maiden's right hand, where it remained until marriage, and was then transferred to the left.
A protest of citizens follows, with these headlines:

Of all the places in the city where relief is being offered to those in need, there is none that will better repay a visit than the rooms at 18 Delancey Street, where, from 8 o'clock to 10:30, five nights in the week, the Relief Bureau of the Young Men's Union of the Society for Ethical Culture distributes clothing to the needy.

The third concert of the Philharmonic Society, which was given last night at Music Hall, was one of those agreeable entertainments which please the hearer, but do not provide him with much food for thought. There were only three numbers on the programme, and these were well known to all music lovers.

The last of the series of three lectures on "The Mysteries of the Flowers," given by William Hamilton Gibson for the benefit of the New-York Kindergarten Association, was delivered yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre. The lectures throughout have been well attended, but the number of children present yesterday was much larger than at either of the previous lectures.

In "The Story of Parthia" (Putnam's) Prof. George Rawlinson has done his best to bring together all that is known in regard to that land. What were the exact dimensions of Parthia we hardly know. That it was fairly rich in soil and productive can be fairly established. Ethnographically, the question.

The constitutional amendment campaign of the woman suffragists of New-York State was begun in earnest this last week by a mass meeting at Rochester Monday night under the direction of Mrs. Jean Brooks Greenleaf, President of the New-York State Woman Suffrage Association, and Miss Susan B. Anthony, President of the National American Woman Suffrage Association.
Inclosed, in connection with this dispatch, is a report of the meeting of the citizens, headed as follows:

There was an important conference at Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon to arrange for the campaign in the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Congressional Districts, where successors are to be elected on Jan. 30 to Ashbel P. Fitch and Col. John R. Fellows.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Juror Lane's right hand and forearm were swathed in surgical bandages when he appeared in Judge Tuthill's court this morning at the continuation of the Coughlin trial. He cut his thumb accidentally and the wound has not healed properly, giving rise to fears of blood poisoning and a gap in the jury box.

The Conference Committee, consisting of Gustav H. Schwab, L.L. Delafield, Mortimer C. Addoms, Frederick Adams, and John Fennel, selected and appointed from various organizations at the invitaiton of the City Club, met last night in the clubhouse, at 677 Fifth Avenue, to consider changes submitted by the sub-committee to the new ballot law, which was formulated by the conference at the City Club on the night of Wednesday, Jan. 3.

During the week ending at noon yesterday there were reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics of the Health Department 929 deaths, 1,103 births, and 336 marriages. The deaths were 51 more than during the preceding week, but were 103 less than the average for the corresponding week during the last five years.

The Trustees of the Adelphi Academy, Brooklyn, have purchased a lot 267 by 420 feet, at Classon Avenue and Prospect Place. They intend to erect a handsome new building for the academy. The purchase price of the ground was $50,000.
The funeral of Dr. Samuel A. Brown, the Fulton Street druggist, who died of pneumonia on Monday, was held in Scottish Rite Hall Friday night.

From The Springfield (Mass.) Republican. Some years ago John Malloy, whose achievements as a railroad builder in South America have made him well known among men engaged in that industry, and many others, deposited in our City Library a number of books which he secured in Lima, the capital of Peru, and in other places in that country.

Although the New-York Life is a worldwide company, it closed its books for 1893 on Dec. 30, and publishes its annual report, covering the receipt and disbursement of millions of dollars, to-day. The statement of the company shows its assets and surplus as advertised are exactly the same as they will appear in the annual report of the Insurance Department.
PALERMO, Jan. 13. -- A decree has been posted in all the towns of Sicily prohibiting the importation of firearms. The people are also forbidden to have firearms in their possession.

-- Judgment by default for $17,813.845 against the Richmond and West Point Terminal Railway and Warehouse Company was entered in the County Clerk's office yesterday in favor of Charles H. Coster, Anthony J. Thomas, and George Sherman. The gentlemen named compose the sub-committee having in charge the details of the Richmond Terminal reorganization plan, and the judgment is a step in furtherance of that plan.

Ibsen's plays are not for the amateurs. Indeed, the chance performance by professionals is not altogether the way to bring the works of the philosophic playwright before the public in a way to turn the dramatic tide in the direction of the serious in our entertainment. From the managerial point of view Ibsen's dramas have no value.

IPSWICH, Mass., Jan. 13. -- Flames were discovered soon after 1 o'clock this morning in the photograph rooms of George Dexter, in the upper portion of the Jewett Block, on Central Street. The wind was blowing a gale, and the temperature registered nearly at zero. The flames spread rapidly, and help was summoned from Salem, Beverly, Newburyport, Danvers, and Lynn.
Zimmerman said yesterday that he would ride faster than ever this year.
I. One lovely Spring afternoon a calm-faced lady, whose hair was deeply streaked with gray, came out upon the porch of a New-England, homestead, and stood there, looking both, worried and sad.

George W. Orton, the Canadian runner who is now taking a course of study at the University of Pennsylvania, thinks that he and not Conneff should meet Bacon, the English champion. Conneff holds the record for a mile, but as Orton won both the American and the Canadian championships, last year, he thinks that he might have first chance at the Englishman.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- The market for local stocks was stagnant this morning. The only activity was shown in Bay State Gas, which advanced from a close of 6 7/8 yesteray to 8 1/2. The first mortgage 5 per cent. onds sold up 1 1/4, to 80, and the second 5s 1/2, to 59. Bidding from insiders was said o cause the advance.

Prof. Seeley a number of years ago wrote a series of papers on Goethe, which he has carefully revised and enlarged, and now brines together in this volume. Not alone does Goethe occupy the first place in modern literature, but he is in no small measure the creator of it. What, then, Mr. Seeley is desirous of accomplishing is to present some sort of "a companion or key" to Goethe.

Department of Foreign Affairs, Honolulu, Dec. 23, 1893. Sir: Your Excellency's communication of Dec. 19, announcing the conclusion which the President of the United States of America has finally arrived at respecting the application of this Government for a treaty of political union with that country, and referring also to the domestic affairs of these islands, has had the consideration of the Government.

-- Military circles for the past week have been destitute of sensations. The Sixty-ninth Regiment affair and the reduction of the Eighth have become "chestnuts" in the line of gossip, and every one seems Inclined to let them alone. Every other orgranization has settled down to the hard work of the drill season, and the men are attending strictly to work.

The Special Express on the Upper Midland Railroad, which was hourly eliminating fifty miles of distance between the metropolis and Aberdeen, doubtless bore just as many interesting subjects to those who believe that the "Proper study of mankind is man," as it did passengers: unfortunately, however, for the general cause of ethical science, the scope of this veracious tale can only deal with three of them.

At the February meeting of the New-York Yacht Club members of that organization will have an opportunity to vote on the first application ever made by a woman for admission to the club. The applicant is the widow of Thomas M. Carnegie of Pittsburg.

One of the most interesting exhibits in the museum at Ghizeh is the jewelry of Queen Abotpou of the seventeenth dynasty (say about B.C. 1750) taken from her Majesty's person when her mummy case was opened by Mariette Bey. Among the most beautiful objects in this very ancient collection is a gold chain or necklet, with a scarab pendent as its central ornament.

John L. Stoddard, the lecturer, who was accompanied by photographers in his trip through Japan, China, and India, was struck by the difference in the people among whom he traveled on the Question of being photographed. He found the Japanese ideally polite and always willing to pose.

From The London Daily News. In the Assize Court of the Seine the trial took place of Moore or More, the poet-cabman, who attempted to shoot M. Lockroy last August for not answering a note asking him to make an appointment. This touchy Parnassian is fifty-seven, has a thick, dark beard that covers his cheek bones, a gray mustache, and has the vivacity of an Italian of humble condition.

The Queen of Denmark, in her seventy-sixth year, is one of the finest harpists in the world. A thoroughly-accomplished musician, she assists in trios of which the other two parts are taken by professionals of high standing.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Unless the House of Lords disregards the compact made in the House of Commons and adopts an independent course on the Parish Councils bill, Parliament and the country will see the measure completed about the middle of February, and then will-enter upon a period of comparative repose.

HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- F. Sidney Bouchier, who fled from Poughkeepsie this morning, leaving an unpaid hotel bill of $40, and who, while there, attempted to raise money by fraudulent draft, was arrested here to-night. His wife was with him. He registered as S.F. Sims.

The premium list for the Eighteenth Annual Dog Show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which is to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 20 to 23, has been issued. Prizes are offered for the well-known breeds of dogs, and, in addition to the money prizes given by the club, several cups and medals are offered.

James Furman, a negro convict in the Kings County Penitentiary, who has gained notoriety by several daring escapes from custody, was caught in an attempt to cut his way from his cell Friday afternoon. He was confined in Cell 10, which is an the lower tier, or what is known as the dark tier, where the long-term prisoners are confined.
The indefatigable workers of the cause of woman suffrage have opened their constitutional-amendment campaign with an effort to make their cause fashionable.

Publishing houses in different parts of the country report an extraordinary run on reproductions of scenes of the World's Columbian Exposition. Since the holiday trade in pictorial goods has abated, this demand has been exceptionally large, although before the holidays it was not by any means small in its Character.

Under date Nov. 19, 1893, Mr. Willis transmits an explanation and apology of Mr. Charles Creighton for putting Mr. Blount's name on a cane presented to Claus Spreckels. The next dispatch from Mr. Willis is as follows:

According to Mollien, Napoleon was so devoted to his son that it roused the jealousy of Marie Louise. The Austrian Government was afraid that some attempt would be made to rescue the boy from its clutches. All the French part of the house-hold were dismissed, (some of them had cried out "Vive l'Empereur" on hearing of his arrival at Cannes.)

Among families who can afford it, the question of sending girls abroad for the study of music and the modern languages, with the cultivation gained from travel, constantly recurs. Many do go, and return with French and German phrases on their congaes, and with their musical acquirements greatly enlarged.
With regard to the seasons for celebrating marriage the Church was formerly very strict. The parish register for St. Mary's Beverly, contains the following entry under date Nov. 25, 1641.

LAKE WOOD, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The dull days of this week brought only rain here, leaving no trace of the snow which covered the surrounding country. The hotels have affored plenty of amusement for their guests. The enjoyable morning concerts have done much to while away the dreary days at the Lakewood Hotel and at the Laurel-in-the Pines.

Dr. Strahan holds to the theory that a large percentage of those who kill themselves are degenerate persons, the victims of suicidal temperaments, and that if, in the propagation of the human race, better care were taken, we should hear of fewer suicides. The remarkable prevalence of suicide in England last Summer and the public discussion of the cause of it furnished him with his motive.

The committee of conference of the several organizations engaged in the movement to secure the blanket ballot in this State has revised its draft of a bill to be submitted to the Legislature, and has introduced some very important changes. The most important is the adoption of the party column arrangement for the names of candidates on the ballot, instead of what is known as the Massachusetts plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Some interesting reports of the military departments at colleges in New-York where army officers are stationed as Professors of Military Science have been received at the War Department. The colleges were inspected by Col. R.P. Hughes, Inspector General, and Capt. H.J. Nowlan, Seventh Cavalry, both on duty at Governors Island.

After several postponements on account of the illness of the prima donna, Rossini's remarkably florid opera, "Semiramide," was brought forward Friday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was Mme. Melba's first appearance in the trying part of the bravura queen, and considerable curiosity was excited by the event.

The life which the Queen leads is this: She gets up soon after 8 o'clock, breakfasts in her own room, and is employed the whole morning in transacting business; she reads all the dispatches, and has every matter of interest and importance in every department laid before her. At 11 or 12 Melbourne comes to her, and stays an, hour, more or less, according to the business he may have to transact.

The form of an agreement for the permanent restoration of rates on east and west bound passenger traffic was completed by the joint committee of General Passenger Agents yesterday. It is similar in its general character to the new freight-rate agreement formulated a few days ago, and both agreements require the approval of the managers of the roads interested before becoming operative.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- The last programme offered by the Theatre Libre cannot count among its best. "Inquietude," by MM. Jules Perrin and Couturier, was a disappointment, coming from the authors of "Fenetres"; and the musical farce of "Romeo et Juliette" was only mild fun, admirably staged and pantomimed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The register at the Shoreham bore the name to-day of Mayor Gilroy, Corporation Counsel William H. Clark, and Dock Commissioner Andrew J. White of New-York. The gentlemen arrived on an early train, and have since combined business with pleasure in a way satisfactory to all.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Carter Harrison sent Constable Haskins of Judge Bradawell's court to Mr. Ruben's office, on Randolph Street, last evening, where the plaster cast of the late Mayor Harrison's features was, with a writ of replevin. The papers said that the property belonged to Mr. Harrison and was valued at $200.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13. -- Lorin A. Thurston, Hawaiian Minister to the United States, stated to a United Press reporter who boarded the steamer Australia that the situation in the islands at present is one of perfect quiet. The uncertainty and public disquietude prevailing for weeks after the arrival of Minister Willis has been replaced by public confidence, and both sides now wait patiently for the decision of the American Congress.

HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 13. -- The contempt case against the State Board of Canvassers which originated in the Dutchess -- Cohimbia Senatorial case of Deane vs. Osborne, now bearing the title of "The people ex rel. John I. Platt vs. Frank Rice et al.," was up at the Special Term of the Circuit Court, before Judge Edwards, to-day, it having been sent back to him by the General Term for review.

Societies or artists and architects in New-York, Boston, Milwaukee, Detroit, and other cities have spoken out so plainly in favor of the clause of the pending Tariff bill which frees paintings and sculptures from duty that it is no longer possible for any one to allege that the artists demand protection.

From The Sheffield Telegraph. There were present the husband -- an ironworker, resident at Masborough -- the wife, who, it is alleged, had transferred her affections to a Kilnhurst miner; the miner himself, the wife's parents, and two friends. The wife was prepossessing in appearance, and was of about the same age as her husband and her suitor -- twenty-six or twenty-eight years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The reception given by Mrs. Cleveland this afternoon from 3:30 until 5:30 o'clock engaged the attention of society to the exclusion of everything else. It is safe to assume that every one invited was present, for the thousand invitations issued brought an attendance of 1,200, notwithstanding that cards of admission were required.

The newspapers of this city have organized a news service for the collection and distribution of all local news. The organisation thus effected will be known as The United Press Local News. Its news will be furnished for publication in the NewYork City newspapers that are identified with the United Press, and to the United Press itself for general distribution throughout the country.

Dr. G.Q. Colton, at the request of the Rev. Mr. Collyer, will give an illustrated lecture on the magnetic telegraph at the Church of the Messiah, on Tuesday evening, and the entertainment will conclude with an exhibition of a circular railroad, on which will be driven around the track the first engine ever worked by electricity.

The existing enceinte of Toulon surrounds a large tract of land, much of which has been reclaimed from the sea, and which lies to the north of the bay known as the Petite Rade. Within this enceinte are, to the eastward, the town, and to the westward the various parts of the dockyard bearing the names of Vauban.

Sala in The London Telegraph. From my very earliest childhood we spent at least six months of the year at Brighton, and I retain the pleasantest of remembrances of the stage coaches in which I traveled to and from town between 1833 and 1839. My mother's favorite coach was the Age, a model vehicle, splendidly horsed, which used to start from Castle Square, Brighton.
Mayor Schieren had a very quiet day at the City Hall yesterday, and as it was a half holiday he left the Mayor's office at noon.

Bentzon and Paul Bourget, compared notes of their American impressions recently, and a symbolist poet who heard them wrote the following sketch on his book of agenda, the covers of which are in mouse-colored sealskin, with silver corners:

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- The final game of the triangular billiard tournament this evening attracted one of the largest crowds of the week to Central Music Hall. The members of the fair sex were out in force and manifested as much interest in the contest as their escorts. The game was between Schaefer and Ives.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 13. -- William Dugdale, Postmaster at Noroton Heights, a small station on the Consolidated Railroad, a few miles west of here, was the victim of an imposter last Thursday. In addition to acting as Postmaster, Dugdale also conducts a grocery store. On that evening a well-dressed stranger entered the place.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Marshaled by Senator Murphy's henchmen, the Troy Republicans, to all appearances, "rounded up" the entire population of "Collardom" recently, and secured, at a monster mass meeting, "a popular protest in the interests of 10,000 collar girls" against the passage of the Wilson bill.

The other day a certain circuit of the United Methodist Free Church assembled, and passed the following resolution: "That this meeting deeply deplores the many terrible deaths resulting from the game of football, and urges upon her Majesty's Government the great importance of so amending the law as to make it a capital offense for one man to kick his fellow to death on the football field."

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The element of the Democratic Party that defeated the party last November is making its last raly in its attempt to obstruct the State Government. It is evident that the scheme now working confusion was concocted by a few Democrats.
