State Commissioner of Agriculture Schrauh addressed a meeting of the New-York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on the vexed subject of oleomargarine.
The following additional contributions to the general fund of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association are reported by Charles Lanier, Treasurer, 17 Nassau Street:

A certificate was filed with the Secretary of State in Albany yesterday to the effect that the New-York and Northern Railroad Company had been Reorganized under the title of the New-York and Putnam Railroad. The fact is set forth in the papers that the reorganized road is the property of the NewYork Central, which assumes the responsibility of paying the outstanding New-York and Northern bond.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 13. -- E.L. Gates, a wealthy citizen of this place, is searching for Miss Minnie L. Porter of Norfolk, Conn., who called on him last Sunday morning while his family was in bed and at once suddenly disappeared. Miss Porter, who is a friend of the Gates family, had been confined in the Norfolk Asylum for the Insane for some time, although she protested that she was of sound mind.
Edward M. Gibbs, Treasurer of the NewYork Life Insurance Company, 346 and 348 Broadway, sent the following telegram yesterday to Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle:

One of the most prominent workers in the cause of woman suffrage for the last five years has been Mrs. Carrie Lane Chapman Catt, an eloquent and logical speaker, with executive power and a gift for organization that has made her a valuable partisan.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Yesterday was one of the most disagreeable days that the Riverside Gun Club ever experienced, the cold weather and keen northwest winds testing the hands of the hardiest marskmen. The wind also blew with gale force and made the blue-rock targets fly in every direction. There was a smaller attendance than usual, and it was decided not to hold the medal shoot.

"Tom" Eck, the veteran bicycle rider, who is known from Maine to California in connection with the wheel, is perhaps, the foremost trainer of bicycle riders in the country. He had charge of John Johnson of record-breaking fame all last season, and to Eck's advice and clever handling the young rider attributes much of his success. On the question of training, in a long letter to The American Wheelman, Eck says:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The dedicatory services of the new St. James Methodist Episcopal Church in this city will begin to-day and continue through the week. Many well-known people will be present.
Confidential. No. 14. Legation of the United States, Honolulu, W.I., Dec. 18. 1893. The Hon. W.Q. Gresham, Secretary of State:

The Assembly sub-committee investigating the contested election cases in Brooklyn resumed its labors in the City Hall yesterday. A number of witnesses testified regarding the cases of alleged "blindness" and other frauds perpetrated at the polls in the Seventh Assembly District.

Daniel Williamson, a negro, nineteen years old, of 533 West Forty-second Street, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for trial on charges of swindling west side merchants. His plan, it is alleged, was to visit grocers, butchers, or druggists and order $3 worth of goods sent to some house in the neighborhood, with the undrestanding that the change for $10 should be sent with the goods.

SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- It is not generally known to the world at large that Emperor Napoleon III. of France was once behind the bars in Sing Sing Prison. In the Spring of 1887 Prince Louis Napoleon, afterward Napoleon III., Emperor of France, made a visit to Washington Irving at Sunnyside, a little north of Irvington-on-the-Hudson, accompanied by a young French Count, and escorted by Mr. Anthony Constant of Hastings.
Official notice from Nebraska reached the office of the Union Pacific receivers, in Wall Street, yesterday, that the United States court there had authorized the payment of the following coupons:

-- When the Cercle Francaise de l'Harmonlo mask ball takes place on Feb. 5, the dancing floor of Madison Square Garden will be separated by a drop curtain reaching to the roof, dividing the building into two parts. On the westerly side of this partition will be a row of new private boxes, and the entire space on the other side will be used for a cafe.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13. -- The follewing Honolulu advices arrived here this morning by the steamer City of Peking:

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- Deputy Boeckel, AntiSemite, spoke in the Reichstag to-day against all the new taxes proposed by the Government. He advocated rather taxes on racing, hunting, and lotteries. Men not serving in the army, he said, might be taxed for their freedom from the onerous duties of the service.

When Geoffrey of Monmouth wrote his history of the Britons, he wrote it like a classical epic, but with the inspiration of French chivalry and legend. Thus Caxton had little difficulty in making acceptable Sir Thomas Malory's translation of the Arthurian legends as they had been written in France.
John W. Frothingham, one of the prominent citizens of Brooklyn, died at his home, 110 'Remsen, Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, of pneumonia, after an illness of four days.

In the matter of party and dancing school dresses for little girls, there is such a variety of fabrics to choose from that one is puzzled to know which to select. Equally suitable are the dainty China silks, delicate crepes, and crepons, or some of the exquisite organdies and challies already to be found on the counters of the shops.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The representative of the United Press to-day visited the Mother Superior of the Convent of La Dame de la Providence, at Colombes, a suburb of Paris, to learn if any new facts had developed in the case of Edward Webster, the young American student whose family live in New-York, and who mysteriously disappeared on New Year's Eve.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- All the Episcopal churches in the Albany Diocese will hold special services on Feb. 2 to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the ordination of the Right Rev. William Croswell Doane as the first Episcopal Bishop of Albany. In December, 1868, Dr. Doane was appointed to the Bishopric, and in the February following was ordained and assumed his charge.

Brig. Gen. Fitzgerald was asked last week his opinion concerning the recommendation of Inspector General Breckinridge to the Secretary of War that closer relations be established between the regular army and the National Guard, and that appropriations by the General Government for the National Guard be increased.

Hoyt McKee announce that they have succeeded in renewing their lease of the Madison Square Theatre for a term of nine years, beginning the 1st of October. From that time the theatre will be leased directly from the owners, Amos R, Eno and Phillips Phoenix. Until that time the present arrangements with Mr. Palmer will be continued.

From The London Telegraph. Letters have been received at Rome describing in detail some atrocious acts of barbarity perpetrated at the Abyssinian Court. Some time ago a conspiracy was discovered against the life of the Negus Menelik. Several well-known members of the Court were implicated in the plot, but in view of the influence they possessed the Emperor considered it advisable to pardon them.

From The London Telegraph. The Pope this morning celebrated mass in St. Peter's, in presence of a congregation computed at 15,000 persons, consisting for the greater part of members of deputations from the various Catholic societies of Rome. The pontifical mass, which commenced at 9:30 and lasted half an hour, was said at the altar in the north transept.

Another Englishwoman has been here and taken notes to go home and write us up. In an exhaustive study of "Society in the United States," one Harrie E. Mills, who we conclude is a woman, and we suspect is not an American, says in The Queen:

It is a peculiar fact that animal trainers and men associated with wild beasts in captivity gradually grow by force of their association to resemble their savage pupils in bodily and facial characteristics. Proof of this statement may be found by the curious at Hagenbeck's arena. Many people have noticed it, and it has attracted a great deal of attention.
The Republicans of Brooklyn are now fighting over the Chairmanship of the Executive Committee. Charles M. Newins of the Twenty-third Ward and J.M. Fuller of the Seventh Ward are the two candidates.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 13. -- This city has experienced a political earthquake of greater severity than that of November last, when all the calculations of its most astute "ring" politicians were so disastrously overthrown.

Wherever Democrats of any sort or kind of political enthusiasm met on Monday in this great Democratic community -- a city which long ago outgrew its present unbecoming nickname of a "town" -- there was sure to be a toast drunk or a sentiment expressed in honor of the glorious memory of Andrew Jackson.

A distinctly better feeling has prevailed among real estate men during the past week. Inquiries have become more frequent than for months past and quite a number of sales are on the verge of being concluded. Such private sales as have been reported have shown prices to be quite well upheld and have demonstrated that there is a market for good property.

A boy, seventeen years old, who said his name was Henry Brown, of 435 East Thirtyninth Street, New-York, was arrested in the hallway of 780 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. Patrolman Hogan saw what he thought was a fight in the hallway. He found Purdy A. Anser of 628 St. Mark's Place grappling with the boy.
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- SS Queen Adelaide, (Br.,) Capt. Ritson, from New-York Dec. 17 for Shanghai, arr. Port Said yesterday.

The strain of a year's wear, with exposure to wet, sun, and wind, upon the Innumerable fibres and hooklets brings the feather into a somewhat dilapidated condition. It then, by a natural process, falls from its attachment, and a new and perfect one grows in its place.
This war of giants will have Russia and France on the one side, Germany, Austria, and Italy on the other.

The bicycle show is over, and the dealers will start for their homes to-day satisfied with the result of the exhibition. In every respect it surpassed all other affairs of a similar character. The orders received during the week were larger than those given at previous shows, and the manufacturers and dealers have every reason to believe that the coming season will be a large and prosperous one.

One of the most striking departures in women's clubs up to the present time is the recent organization of the Civitas Club of Brooklyn. Its members represent the very flower of the young society life of the city, and come from the families representing the greatest culture and wealth. It is a girls' club, but a few young matrons are included.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 13. -- District Leader-Police Commissioner-Contractor John C. Sheehan of New-York -will have to commence work on his contract to build a mile of brick sewer in this city for $92,764 before many days more elapse. The General Improvement Commission has decided that operations must be started next Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan, 13. -- The romance of reality is exemplified in the public and private career of Jay Cooke, who now resides in the outskirts of this city, in the peaceful enjoyment of health, wealth, a good conscience, and troops of friends. To make and lose and then regain a fortune is one of the things that fall to the lot of few men in this world.

The annual election of officers of the Republican Club will be held at the clubhouse, 450 Fifth Avenue, to-morrow night. The trouble which broke out when the Nominating Committee of Nine posted its ticket has been growing, and since the second ticket was posted has developed into the hot- test fight which has been known in the club for many years.

The quality and extent of this year's art exhibition at the Union League Club, Brooklyn, were highly appreciated by art lovers. It ended last evening. Three thousand women and men viewed the exquisite works of art.

Monday was the last day of the exhibition of the Architectural League inclusive of that made by the Sculpture Society. Every year there is improvement in some respects, but not by any means in every respect. This year the sculpture was more interesting, but the important matter of the catalogue had been neglected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The week just ended has been a very gay one in society. To-night the gossips find a source of talk in the fact that at the tea given at the White House this afternoon comparatively few of the leading society people were present. Whatever may be the reason, the list of guests was pruned of many names that figure generally in the lead of gay doings at the national capital.

Five hundred men, women, and boys skating on the old Steamer Fond in Flatbush cheered lustily yesterday when Richard Botts, a thirteen-year-old boy, was rescued from drowning. More dead than alive, and well-nigh frozen, he was pulled out of the water by Joseph Walsh and Albert Clayton of Flatbush and Henry Cutler of the lower Fulton Street office of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

The Kneisel Quartet of Boston produced in the Chamber Music Room at Music Hall Friday evening two new compositions by Dr. Dvorak. They were a quartet in F major. Opus 96, and a string quintet in E flat, Opus 97. The former has been performed once in Boston, but the latter was heard for the first time last night.

-- Five plans for the Library Museum at Milwaukee were selected from the large number of competing designs by Prof. Ware of Columbia College. Of these five, two by Milwaukee architects received the votes of the fifteen members of the Board of Trustees. That by Ferry and Clas received nine votes; that by H.C. Koch Co., six. Messrs.

From The London Daily News. Mr. Justice Kennedy has decided against the Chilean Government in the action brought by it to recover the silver bars -- some u130,000 in value -- pledged by the late President Balmaceda to the London and River Plate Bank. Under a law of March, 1887, the silver was deposited in the Chilean Treasury in order to guarantee certain issues of paper money.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The intimation made in the Reichstag by Herr Aloys Fritzen, a Centrist leader, that the Centre Party would not support the Government's proposals to place higher taxes on tobacco and wines, was supposed to seal the fate of Finance Minister Miquel's financial projects.

At the War Office Mr. Smith's Private Secretary observed that his chief, on leaving office for the country, used to pack a dispatch box with papers and take it with him, and suggested that he would save himself trouble by leaving them to be packed in the usual official "pouch" and forwarded by post.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The mild and open Winter has made the bear-hunting season unusually long this season, for few, if any, bears have yet sought their lairs to sleep until Candlemas Day, when they are all supposed, to come out to look for their shadows.
Minister Willis transmits Mr. Dale's reply, accompanied by the following letter, announcing that he will take no further steps:

Let us see what his actual receipts were. In addition to his proper salary of u200, he had what was called a bye salary of u75.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- For two or three days at the beginning of the week the English press gave its biggest type and most impressive headlines to news, conjecture, and comment on that strange and still mysterious fatality out in the unmapped wilds of Africa. Now it has sunk to little type and the most obscure corner of the papers.
There is trouble in Chinatown, and the cause if it all is the Chinese "Mayor." Chin Chok Wong, who came here from Portland, Ore., a year or so ago.

It was said yesterday in Brooklyn that the new revelations concerning the management of the defunct Commercial Bank, which were brought out in connection with the arrest on Saturday of President Seth L. Keeney, Vice President Elbert Snedeker, and Director Robinson on charges of misdemeanor, would result in a further investigation of the causes of the failure of the bank by the Kings County Grand Jury.

Chairman C. Simis of the Teachers' Committee of the Brooklyn Board of Education is the originator of a practical and highly-successful plan of aiding the needy and distressed through the medium of the pupils in the public schools.

GREENPORT, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- News of the wreck of the schooner Meteor off Orient Point, and the perilous adventure of her crew, was received here late last night. The Meteor is a large two-masted schooner owned by Daniel Crowley of New-London, Conn. She was commanded by Capt. P. O'Keef.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The candor of Secretary Kellogg of the Charity Organization Society, in replying through The Times to the questions put by "Justice" concerning the society and its work, certainly leaves nothing further to be asked. But could there be a more emphatic confirmation of the opinion that the society has outlived its name and its usefulness as a separate existence than Mr. Kellogg's own words give?
The Oswego Times publishes the following under the head "Oswego Starch Factory":
LONDON, Jan. 14. -- Dispatches which left Uganda on Aug. 4 arrived here this evening. They report fighting between Protestant and Mohammedan natives at Toro.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- The result of last night's billiard game between Sohaefer and Ives, which the former won by a single point, is to tie the two for first place. It is not likely that the tie will be played off, but that the men will divide the stake of $1,500 and 80 per cent, of the net receipts of the week. The other 20 per cent, go to George Slosson.

Henry Wolfert, the Republican candidate for Senator who was defeated by John McCarty, claims McCarty was elected by illegal votes, and he is contesting the election. A portion of the Senatorial district includes the town of Gravesend.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14. -- The report of the graduate Treasurer upon the baseball receipts and expenditures of 1892-3 appeared a few days ago. According to the statement, the total receipts of the association, including $1,899.60 balance from the previous year, amounted to $23,823.76. Of this, $19,586 was gate money. The total expenditures were $18.477.20.

The public yesterday got another object lesson of bridge mismanagement. Although there was a fall of snow on Saturday night and early yesterday morning, it had not been removed at nightfall. Twenty hours after the snow fell it was lying in piles on the New-York approach to the bridge, and walking was especially disagreeable from Park Row to the New-York tower.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 14. -- A Glasgow yachting correspondent writes: "There is considerable uneasiness as to the British yachting season of 1894. With the Valkyrie on the American side of the Atlantic and no chance of the Calluna being launched and fitted out, the first-class racing will be confined to the Britannia and Iverna.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Jan. 14. -- Six crews were set at work this morning dredging Newtown Creek to recover the bodies of the men who were drowned Friday evening, when the flimsy footbridge connecting Bradley Avenue, Laurel Hill, with Meeker Avenue, Brooklyn, collapsed.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 14. -- A large three-masted schooner was discovered at daybreak this morning in the breakers on the outer bar, opposite Amagansett, by a surfman of Mecox Life-Saving Station. The surfman notified his station, and the crew went down to the wreck.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan 14. -- The University Museum is now the possessor of two magnificent specimens of the rata or sycamore of NewZealand, the gift of Prof. Thomas Kirk of Wellington, New-Zealand. The logs are each 4 and 4 1/2 feet in diameter, and are among the best specimens ever sent to this country.

Mr. Platt's bi-partisan Police Commission bill, introduced in the Senate and Assembly last week, links one virtue with the possibility of a thousand crimes. It removes from office the present Commissioners, and that would be a great blessing. Mr. MacLean will pardon us for saying that we should be willing to see him, a good officer, summarily retired to private life if at the same time we could be rid of his less worthy associates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The majority members of the Commitee on Ways and Means, with the exception of Mr. Cockran, were in session several hours to-day considering proposed amendments to the Wilson bill to be offered by the committee. A number of unimportant changes were agreed upon, and two or three of relative importance.

There are several matters of interest before the United States Senate, a body in which a majority of the members actually sitting are Democrats. One is the condition of the Treasury, with the policy formulated by the Secretary for its prompt and easy relief. Another is the Hawaiian affair, as to which the Administration has taken an honorable and courageous course, which has advanced the country in the respect of the civilized world.

RUSSELL, Kan., Jan. 14. -- At 1 o'clock this morning there was a terrible exhibition of prairie justice here, and three men met death at the hands of Judge Lynch. No such outbreak of the old-time swift frontier justice has been witnessed in Kansas for years. The mob was one of the quietest and most determined that ever came together.

The project of the New-York and NewJersey Bridge Company for a bridge across the Hudson River is meeting with opposition from sources perhaps not well informed or having interests opposed to those of the public. All great enterprises meet such opposition. The laying out of Central Park and the building of the Brooklyn Bridge were thus opposed.

Policeman Thomas Gorman of the Second Precinct, Brooklyn, who distinguished himself a few days ago by raiding a policy shop in the guise of a tramp, made a mistake on Saturday evening while on patrol duty by arresting an innocent man as a suspicious character.

The Rev. R.S. MacArthur, D.D., spoke in the Twenty-fifth Street Free Baptist Church yesterday afternoon on the question, "Shall Public Moneys Be Given to Sectarian Schools?" He said the American people had been misled by the supposed liberality of Archbishop Ireland and the supposed patriotism of Mgr. Satolli, and that Archbishop Corrigan's advocacy of everything Roman was preferable to the smooth utterances of Ireland and Satolli.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 13. -- The week In the local stock market was almost without notable feature. Some few shares of Providence Gas stock have changed hands at 79, and Narragansett Electric Lighting Company at from 75 to 76. The whole list is somewhat lower in the bid prices, but the asking prices show but little decline.

There was a large list of entries in the Third Class match on the Seventh Regiment's range on Saturday evening, and some good scores were made. Private E.S. Coy of Company D won first prize, with a score of 64. The conditions of the contest were seven shots standing and seven prone at the two-hundred and the five-hundred-yard ranges.
The funeral of the late Robert Livinston Cutting, Sr., will be held at Grace Church at 11 o'clock Wednesday. It was announced yesterday that there would be no pall bearers.

Representatives from twenty-six Kings County and four Queens County Grand Army of the Republic posts met in the City Hall, Brooklyn, Saturday evening and unanimously declared Joseph W. Kay their choice for Department Commander. February 20 they will go in a body to Rochester, where Mr. Kay's name will be presented.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 14. -- The Republican caucus to nominate a United States Senator will be held Monday night. The majority of the members and prominent politicians believe that the contest will be protracted long beyond to-morrow night, but there are some, among them E.P. Heiser, who is managing Congressman Perkins's candidacy, who think that four or five ballots will settle the fight.

Arvid Torngren about three years ago left his comfortable home in Finland, after a quarrel with his father, who objected to his wild and extravagant ways. He came to this country -- to him, as to many others, the land of promise. For a while he prospered, but his habits, still retained, cost him several positions, and finally all trace of him was lost.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The two Military Academy cadets who are suspended until next August will not be paid during the term of suspension, as recommended by the Judge Advocate General of the Army. Cadets C.H. Conrad and Louis H. Bash were sentenced to dismissal, and the sentence was commuted by the President to suspension.

ROME, Jan. 14. -- Socialists met in Leghorn last evening to debate recent events in Sicily. They protested against the sending of troops to the island, called the dead Sicilian rioters martyrs, and appealed to Italian workingmen to declare on Monday a general strike as a demonstration of their brotherhood with Sicilian workingmen.
Columbia College opened last week after the Christmas holidays, with two main ideas absorbing the minds of the students, the coming midyear examinations, which begin Jan. 29, and the new gymnasium.
A complimentary dinner was given to ex-Mayor David A. Boody at the Montauk Club, Brooklyn, Saturday evening. Republicans and Democrats alike honored the ex-Mayor.

From The Philadelphia Inquirer, Jan. 13. The enjoyable reception that has been an annual feature of the First Unitarian Church for more than half a century was last night tendered to the pastor emeritus. Dr. W.H. Furness, and the pastor, the Rev. Joseph May, D.D. It was the sixtyninth anniversary of Dr. Furness's connection with the church, and the eighteenth anniversary of Dr. May's pastorate.

Herman Arno Zeidlitz, member of a wealthy family living in Schelleberg, Germany, died alone in his little room at 377 East Tenth Street, some time between midnight Friday and 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

JAMAICA, L.I., Jan. 14. -- There was a lively fight between two rival lovers in front of the Union Church in Hyde Park a few nights ago. The principals were John Radketsy of that village, who is said to have been jealous of attentions paid to a girl by Peter Klein, assistant station agent in Floral Park.

There is a movement on foot in Brooklyn to establish a new home for newsboys, with schools attached, to be known as the Newsboys' College. In this institution street urchins are to be provided with comfortable homes, and at the same time receive a fair education. The project has received the indorsement of many prominent and charitably-inclined citizens in Brooklyn.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 14. -- In response to the call issued by Capt. Johnson of the Yale crew, the candidates for the 'Varsity boat were assembled yesterday afternoon for the first day's practice of the season of 1894. Seventeen aspirants for aquatic honors reported for duty and were put through an afternoon's rugged work.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 14. -- Miss May Barrowcliff was greatly improved to-day. She was able to talk at some length with her nurses.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- If this Legislature, which will convene to-morrow night and begin the actual work of the session, is sincerely desirous of making a reputation for itself as a reform and economical body it can safely follow the lead of Senator Joseph Mullin in an effort to reduce the working force of many of the bureaus and departments of the State.

The funeral or Policeman William Adams, who was known to actors, clubmen, and men-about-town who frequent Upper Broadway, was held yesterday afternoon at 710 Eighth Avenue. The services were attended by a large number of policemen and former friends of the deceased. Adams was a policeman attached to the West Thirtieth Street Station.

John D. Townsend has issued a statement addressed "To the people of New-York," in which he criticises the Department of Public Works, declares that "since the advent of the present Tammany ring all honest competition for asphalt paving work has been cut off," quotes prices to sustain the charge that the city has been made to pay too much, and gives figures to show how much it should have paid for asphalt paving.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- The work of selecting the men to compose the freshman crew has already begun. Some sixty candidates have presented themselves to Mr. Courtney, and new men are dally coming in. Commodore Brown has not yet made any formal call to the members of the freshman class to appear for training, but will doubtless do so if the near future.

Some of those statements which John E. Milholland, leader of the anti-machine Republicans, was about to make when he began his protest against the "deal," at the meeting of the Republican County Committee Saturday night, were made in typewritten form yesterday. It will be remembered that the Sergeant at Arms of the committee ejected Mr. Milholland Saturday night before he could express himself.

Copyright, 1894, by The United Press. BERLIN, Jan. 14. -- The fate of the Chancellor turns on the result of the rupture in the Clerical Party over the Tobacco Tax bill. A plenary meeting of the Clerical Deputies on Wednesday showed that the majority would follow Dr. Fritzen in opposing every new tax proposed by the Government, excepting the one on Boerse operations.

Mrs. Henry Ward Beecher was suddenly stricken with heart disease in Plymouth Church a few minutes before the close of the services yesterday morning, and a good deal of excitement prevailed for a while among the congregation.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- George (McAneny, Jr., Secretary of the New-York Civil Service Reform League, as a result of his examination, for violations in the State departments of the civil service laws, of the records in the office of the State Civil Service Commission, last week, has made public the following:

NEW-YORK, Monday, Jan. 15 -- A.M. With the daily contraction of business to the point of dullness, the downward course of last week's market was only natural. No news of a distinctly unfavorable character appeared, except that the railroads failed to reflect the improvement in general business indicated by Dun's and Bradstreet's commercial reports.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 13. -- The best demand this week has been for Natural Gas shares. Philadelphia Gas stock, sold at 21 5/8@22 1/4, and lost the fractions on the failure to find oil in the last well drilled in Ohio township. The closing bids are Westinghouse Air Brake 126, Duquesne Traction 21, Citizens' 58 1/2 ex dividend, Birmingham 14 3/3, Philadelphia Gas 21 7/8, and Bridge-water 40.

Patrolman John Kenny of the Eleventh Precinct and Patrolman K.J. Larkin and Roundsman Michael Downs of the Twelfth Precinct were arraigned before Justice Taintor in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning, charged with the deliberate and systematic extortion of money from east-side peddlers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Treasury Department people are having a controversy with the Southern Pacific Railroad over the transportation of baggage for the army, and the settlement is of interest to army officers everywhere. Some time ago a troop of cavalry made a short trip in California and carried nearly 200,000 pounds of freight, such as camp utensils and live stock.

The new schedule of studies proposed by the committee of the Faculty for use on removal of the university to University Heights, and in a general manner explained by the Chancellor, Henry Mitchell MacCracken, at the alumni dinner last Tuesday evening, has been the fruit of long and arduous duty, and suggests many changes in the old methods.

It is interesting to be assured in a Washington dispatch that the dispute over the confirmation of Mr. Hornblower is regarded as "a test of strength between the Administration and the New-York organization." How many "tests" must there be to satisfy "the organization"?
A very successful entertainment was given last evening at the Harlem Opera House by the Stuyvesant Democratic Club in aid of the poor people of Harlem.

A meeting of taxpayers owning property in the vicinity of Washington Heights, which was held Dec. 8 in Library Hall, Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred, and Fifty-fifth Street, to protest against the failure of the Rapid-Transit Commission to furnish rapid-transit facilities to the residents of the Annexed District, has recently given rise to much discussion among the property owners of the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- A report of the Executive Committee of Awards of the World's Fair, to accompany President Palmer's report of the Columbian Commission to President Cleveland, has been made public. This Executive Committee consists of Commissioners John Boyd Thacher of New-York, A.T. Britton of the District of Columbia, A.B. Andrews of North Carolina, A.J. Sewell of New-Jersey, and B.B. Smalley of Vermont.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 14. -- Three prisoners escaped from the Hudson County Jail this afternoon. The fugitives are Frank Miller and George Morrell, burglars, and a pickpocket named Henry. Talbot.

Although all the auction sales of real estate set down for to-day are in legal proceedings, one will be held at the Real Estate Exchange salesroom in Liberty Street. The others are to take place at 111 Broadway. A detailed list is subjoined:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In The Outlook of Nov. 18 I showed that certain pugilists, driven from Minnesota, Indiana, and New-York, might do to go to Louisiana, for that State has no statute against the prize ring. It was announced Nov. 5 that the Olympic Club of New-Orleans offered the winner in the international Corbett-Mitchell fight $20,000 for a glove contest to be held Dec. 18.

Mayor Schieren has been considering the trolley question since he entered upon his duties as Chief Magistrate of Brooklyn. He enjoys unusual advantages for observing the work of the trolley cars, as nearly all the lines in the western district run past the City Hall.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14. -- The indications are that there will be a large and curious crowd at the State House to-morrow night, attracted by the announcement that the Governor will present the opinion furnished to him by the Attorney General. Both Senates will get it.

Mr. H.M. Mills of Bridgeport, Conn., has a new yacht, which was designed and built by the Coulter McKengie Machine Company of Bridgeport. The yacht is 60 feet long, 12 feet beam, 5 feet deep. It draws 20 inches forward and 3 feet 4 inches aft. The engine, a very fine one, is a fore-and-aft compound, designed to furnish 75 horse power.

George McAneny, Jr., Secretary of the New-York State Civil Service Reform League, has issued a statement relative to the results of an examination made by him a few days ago in the office of the Civil Service Commission at Albany.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 14. -- The arrangements for the three days' carnival of ice sports, which are to be held here this month under the auspices of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club, are about completed. The first entry received for the national championship skating events is that of J.C. Hemment of New-York, who will also skate in the two-mile handicap race, which is open to all amateurs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The regular troops did very little marching last year. Less than 60,000 miles were covered by the soldiers. Most of this distance was made by the cavalry regiments the total in that branch being 43,000 miles. The infantry marched about one-fourth of that distance, and the artillery batteries, which never have very much marching to do, traveled only 900 miles.

The members of the Organization Committee of the new Jockey club who are also horse owners, held another meeting at the Hoffman House Saturday afternoon to receive the answer from Gottfried Walbaum, President of the Saratoga Racing Association, as to whether he would consent to have racing at the Saratoga race track under the management of a Board of Stewards representing the new turf club.

A few Republicans in this city have made an attempt to transfer the fight against the Wilson Tariff bill from the Capitol at Washington to an upper room in a twostory brick business block on Broadway, near Fifty-eighth Street.

Nothing has been done in the name or the United States in recent times, certainly not since the days before the war, so discreditable and humiliating as the intervention by which the Government of Hawaii was overthrown, just one year ago, in pursuance of a scheme of forcible annexation.

Andrea Santana, twenty-nine years old, employed as a keeper of silverware in the Clarendon Hotel, on Eighteenth Street, this city, was shot at 11 o'clock last night and probably fatally wounded, by Domingo Figara, twenty-two years old. The shooting occurred a few moments after Santana was married in the boarding house 81 Main Street, Brooklyn.
PARIS, Jan. 15. -- In an article on the United States Embassy, The Figaro today says:
Among the improvements it is proposed shall be brought about in the government of New-York City, that affecting a reorganization and rearrangement of the Police Board is not the least important.
It looked very much yesterday as If all the six plans recommended by the Advisory Committee of Architects to the new Municipal Building Commission would be rejected.

Fiss Doerr have just received several carloads of general purpose and railroad horses at their Blue Front Mart on East Twenty-fourth Street, as well as some carriages and knee-actors, and two lots of heavy draught horses. Their bi-weekly sales are well patronized, and the bidding is brisk, as each animal is sold with the ample guarantee of this firm.

Dr. McLeod, who has already been President of the association for three terms, stood as the representative of the older and more coservative members, while Dr. Valentine admitted that he was the candidate of the younger men in the association.

George M. Pinney, Jr., of 44 Pine Street, representing the Gorham Manufacturing Company, W. J. Sloane, and the Phoenix Furniture Company, yesterday obtained from Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court a temporary injunction restraining Gen. Ferdinand P. Earle from transferring, removing, or making other disposition, or placing any incumbrance on the personal property in, and the lease of the Hotel Normandie, at Broadway and Thirty-eighth Street, of which Gen. Earle is proprietor.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 15. -- Col. Frank A. Burr, who was widely known as a newspaper correspondent, died at his home today in this city from a complication of diseases, after a long illness. Col. Burr was born in Michigan fifty years ago. When three years of age he was stolen by the Chippewa Indians.

With the beginning of the new year freight rates, which had become greatly demoralized, were restored to a standard basis by an agreement between the Presidents of the Eastern and Western trunk line railroads. Since then the general freight and passenger officers of about fifty important railroads have formulated elaborate agreements designed to maintain uniform schedules of rates permanently.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Mr. Thomas C. Platt is in a whirlpool of political trouble nowadays. To-day he sent two emissaries to Albany for the purpose of preparing and managing a caucus of Republicans to be held on a number of important measures now pending, particularly on the Thornton and Lexow non-partisan Police Board bills.

Frederick Linde was elected yesterday by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen as Supervisor of the Eighth Ward, to succeed George Kehoe, whose term, the Republicans claim, expired Dec. 31. The courts will now be called upon to settle the question of the legality of Mr. Linde's election.

Andrew Armstrong, a policeman, bad a warrant some weeks ago for Ephraim Robinson, a colored man who worked for George Brown, a truckman. Ephraim's wife was prosecuting him for abandonment. The policeman found both Brown and Robinson sitting on a truck at Sixty-third Street and Ninth Avenue.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 15. -- Nine persons were killed and thirty-seven badly injured in a rear-end collision between Delaware, Lackawanna and Western express trains, on the Hackensack Meadows, at 8:20 this morning.
John Y. McKane did not show the Senate Sub-Committee on Elections yesterday how the voters from the Coney Island "Bowery" were run through the hopper in Gravesend on election day.

HAMMEL'S STATION, L.I., Jan. 15. -- Joseph Scintr, a shoemaker, was stabbed to death here this evening by August Ruppel, a tailor. The two men lived together in a small store, facing the Boulevard. They were each fifty years old. Ruppel is said to have a family in California, and Scintr's family lives in Far Rockaway.

Copyright, 1894, by the United Press. ROME, Jan. 15. -- The appeal issued by the Socialists of Leghorn to the workingmen asking them to inaugurate to-day a general strike as a protest against the policy of repression being pursued by the Government in Sicily met with no response except from the men employed in some of the shipyards.

ALL NEXT WEEK. -- The young, beautiful, popular Singing Evangelist. Miss SARAH WRAY. from London, England, at St. Bartholomew's Rescue Hall, (seats 1,000.) 42d St. and 3d Av., assisted by the powerful Revivalist, Mr. MURRAY, and Evangelist POTTER of Moody's Training School; also orchestral organ, large chorus; come early to this famous nightly resort; hundreds turned away last night. Col. HADLEY, Superintendent; Prof Hayden, Organist.

Albert C. Swabacker, who claims to be a son of ex-United States Senator Swabacker, was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday charged with perjury and robbery. Mrs. Josephine Raudolph of 3 East Broadway, accused the young man of stealing jewelry and diamonds worth $1,500. He also stole, it is alleged, $100 worth of jewelry from Mrs. Claus of 234 West Twentyseventh Street, who had befriended him.

The death of Mother Immaculata of the Ursuline Order has Just been publicly announced. She died at the Ursuline Convent, at Bedford Park, Saturday afternoon at 5:30 o'clock, after an illness of nearly a year.

The sad and sudden death of Robert L. Cutting, Sr., while traveling in a Broadway cable car, has naturally caused a shock to the entire community. The prominence, the standing, and the wealth of the gentleman were known to all, and his untimely death is greatly to be regretted.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 15. -- The gloomy outlook for sugar and an urgent telegram from the Louisiana representation were the causes of an influential delegation of sugar planters leaving for Washington to-night. They were John Dymond, James P. Kock, James A. Ware, W.B. Krumbhaar, H.C. Warmouth, S.A. Knapp, and Emile Rost, all large planters and leaders in the democratic counsels, save Gov. Warmouth, who is a Republican.

We regret to remark that a correspondent of ours has been moved to suggest that the single Police Commissioner that all disinterested people are agreed should be substituted for the present bipartisan hydra should be appointed by the Judges of the criminal courts. This is a most unfortunate suggestion, in the line of the experiments of charter tinkering in which inconsiderate reformers are so prone to indulge.
